description: Did you hear the one about the Writers Guild calling Jay Lenos monologues a strike violation even though hes writing the jokes himself? Not funny. Read more

title: The Wire, Season Five
description: Editors at the Baltimore Sun discuss a news story.

title: Live From Des Moines, Its Caucus Night
description: Goodnight Iowa!  As we shut down for the evening, were contemplating the magnitude of Mr. Obamas win here as well as the challenges for the Clinton campaign. Mr. Edwards is somewhere in the middle. Hes got bragging rights over Mrs. Clinton, even though he beat her by only .28 percent and its not clear how much he can build on his showing here. Mrs. Clinton has just five days to prove she is electable; if Mr. Obama beats her in New Hampshire, he will almost certainly win South Carolina. And that makes the Feb. 5 states all the more challenging for her.

title: Congrats to the Iowa victors
description: Ive made my doubts clear; but for tonight, I simply offer best wishes and hopes for a brighter future.

title: Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s Closing Pitch
description: Joseph R. Biden speaks to voters on Jan. 1. (NBC Video)

title: Purple States: Economic Realities
description: In New Hampshire, Bert asks the candidates about government spending and their plans for the economy.

title: A Villa by Any Other Name
description: A villa suggests something slightly regal, a palace in the country. Rich people escape to villas, estates of grand gardens, wide terraces and, perhaps, a vineyard or two.

title: A Feel-Good Story Goes Sour
description: One of the most pleasant experiences I had this college football season was traveling to Bushnell, Fla., in September to profile the touching family story of South Florida linebacker Ben Moffitt.

title: Voters Turn Out in Iowa
description: Competitive campaigns and compelling candidates in both parties sparked record turnouts.

title: Chaos in Kenya
description: Chaos and ethnic fighting has ignited in Kenya, destabilizing the country, just one week after Kenyans went to the polls to elect their president.

title: Moving On to New Ground and Issues
description: DERRY, N.H.  As the race for the White House moves from the frigid plains of Iowa to the snow-capped mountains of New Hampshire, there will be a realignment of the contest, and the focus will shift from social and religious issues to taxes and national security.

title: The QB Most Likely to Succeed?
description: The N.F.L. playoffs feature three quarterbacks likely to rank among the all-time greats: Brett Favre, Tom Brady and Peyton Manning. Which of the younger quarterbacks in the postseason -- David Garrard, Eli Manning, Philip Rivers, Ben Roethlisberger, Tony Romo, Vince Young -- would you most like to have lead your team for the next 10 years, and why?

title: One Republican Caucus Is Found to Be an Uncomplicated Affair
description: CLIVE, Iowa  After the months of speeches, millions spent on advertisements and seemingly zillions of debates, the culminating event of the Iowa caucus campaign in the city of Clive, Precinct 4, is an orderly, uncomplicated affair.

title: Tumultuous Mind, Spread Across Canvas
description: By any standard, the Italian painter Antonio Mancini lived through tumultuous times. He was born in 1852 and died in 1930. In the intervening years Europe experienced the unification of Italy and of Germany, World War I and the rise of communism and fascism.

title: Manhattan: Former Teacher Charged
description: A former high school teacher was arrested Thursday after school investigators said he had made sexual and harassing comments to several 14-year-old students, including asking one girl out on a date and promising another a good grade if she would hook him up with someone pretty. The teacher, Richard Dulberg, 32, who resigned in September, was charged with endangering the welfare of a child, according to Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the city schools. Mr. Dulberg was removed from his position at the School for the Physical City, on East 25th Street, last spring after the investigation began. According to the investigators report, released Thursday, Mr. Dulberg denied the allegations. Attempts to reach him at home and through his lawyer were unsuccessful.

title: Clemens Says Injections Were Not Steroids
description: In a 60 Minutes interview that will be shown on CBS on Sunday night, the former Yankees pitcher Roger Clemens admits that he received injections from his former personal trainer, Brian McNamee. But he says that the injections were of the painkiller lidocaine and vitamin B12  not steroids or human growth hormone, as McNamee alleged in the Mitchell report released last month.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $4,316,116

title: Flooding and High Winds Hit Northern California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A fierce Pacific storm howled into Northern California on Friday, bringing a treacherous mix of flooding, hurricane-force winds, and blizzard conditions for millions of residents.

title: Economy and Geopolitics Decide Where Oil Goes Next
description: NOW that the price of crude oil has crossed the $100-a-barrel threshold, and then retreated slightly, what direction will it take now?

title: Big Sky Resort
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Bush Ponders Move to Bolster Economy
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush said Thursday that he was considering whether to propose a stimulus package to shore up the economy, the clearest indication yet of a growing concern inside the White House over rising oil prices, the subprime mortgage crisis and the possibility of recession.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Miraculous Recovery for Man Who Fell 47 Floors
description: Alcides Moreno plunged 47 stories that morning last month, clinging to his 3-foot-wide window washers platform as it shot down the dark glass face of an Upper East Side apartment building. His brother Edgar, who had been working with him on the platform, was killed.

title: Defendant in Westchester Killing Admitted Affair, Court Papers Say
description: The Chappaqua lawyer accused of murdering his wife on the side of a Westchester road on Nov. 18, 2006, admitted he had sent flowers just before the shooting to his longtime mistress, according to court documents released on Friday.

title: New Fitness Instruction: Sing the Body Eclectic
description: How to Look Good Naked, a new series on Lifetime, bears a title provocative not for its suggestion of sex but rather for its intimation of futility. To a great many people older than 26, How to Look Good Naked sounds an awful lot like How to Build a Global Brand Just Like Steve Jobs, Before the Next Rose Bowl.

title: Rising Above the Ways of a Tough Neighborhood
description: Margaret Brooks has raised eight children in her apartment at the Louis H. Pink Houses, but the rooms were empty as she recently sat in her wheelchair by the window, staring across the barren courtyard of the project in Brooklyn.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Sean Penn to Lead Cannes Jury

title: Brooklyn Bouncer Gets 50 Years to Life for 2 Murders
description: A Brooklyn strip club bouncer and martial arts enthusiast who had said he was framed by police assassins was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison on Thursday for the murders of two men in 2005.

title: New York Water Taxi From Lower Manhattan to Haverstraw, N.Y.
description: Thurs., Jan. 3, 5.30 p.m. Water Taxi From Pier 11

title: Many Clients of Astor Lawyer Left Him Bequests in Their Wills
description: Elisabeth von Knapitsch may not have known Brooke Astor, and Ms. von Knapitschs fortune  $15 million  was certainly modest compared with Mrs. Astors legendary wealth.

title: Top Editor Ousted at San Jose Paper
description: The editor of The San Jose Mercury News was replaced Thursday in a top-level shake-up at the newspaper. The publisher of the California newspaper, Jeff Kiel, said that the executive editor, Carole Leigh Hutton, would step down immediately and would be succeeded by David J. Butler.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Connecticut Continues Its Turnaround
description: NEWARK  With a young group coming off a poor season, all Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun can really ask of his team is that it keeps moving in the right direction. With the Big East season now under way, it does not seem like that is going to be a problem.

title: An Inquiry Seen as Payback in a Rivalry
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Departments criminal inquiry into the destruction of the Central Intelligence Agency interrogation tapes will be carried out largely by agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which has been sharply at odds with the C.I.A. over the agencys interrogation practices.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Minnesota: Boy Dead in Snowbank
description: A 2-year-old New Ulm boy died after crawling out of bed next to his sleeping mother and wandering outside on a frigid night, the authorities and the woman said. The woman, Dara Lenz, found the body of her son, Lucas Boldt, in a snowbank about 10 to 20 feet from her home and called the police, who tried to revive him. The temperature was minus 9 degrees. Ms. Lenz, 26, said she and Lucas went to sleep in her bed at 9:30 p.m. Tuesday, but when she woke up in the morning, he was no longer next to her. He was not in his room, and she raced outside and found him in the snow. It was unclear if the doors had been locked. The police do not suspect foul play, Cmdr. Myron Weiland said.

title: Kansas Surprises Virginia Tech
description: MIAMI  Instead of their usual blue, the Kansas Jayhawks wore red shirts for the Orange Bowl. And that was not their only surprise during a 24-21 victory over Virginia Tech in what was, finally, a tense and interesting game in this seasons Bowl Championship Series.

title: Charm Citys Cops and Robbers, Schoolboys and Stevedores
description: SEASON 1 Were introduced to the theme and the character that will thread through the series: drugs, and the smart, disillusioned, drunk Baltimore homicide detective Jimmy McNulty (Dominic West). McNultys anger when a member of the Barksdale drug gang is acquitted of murder charges spurs the creation of what will become the Major Crimes Unit and the introduction of other central law-enforcement characters: Lt. Cedric Daniels (Lance Reddick) and the unit members Kima Greggs (Sonja Sohn), Ellis Carver (Seth Gilliam), Prez Pryzbylewski (Jim True-Frost) and the eccentric Lester Freamon (Clarke Peters). These are the good guys, who, along with McNultys partner, Bunk Moreland (Wendell Pierce), and the prosecutor Rhonda Pearlman (Deirdre Lovejoy) do daily battle with crime and with their own bosses at police headquarters and City Hall.

title: Evolution Book Sees No Science-Religion Gap
description: In 1984 and again in 1999, the National Academy of Sciences, the nations most eminent scientific organization, produced books on the evidence supporting the theory of evolution and arguing against the introduction of creationism or other religious alternatives in public school science classes.

title: The System Worked? A Defender Begs to Differ
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.

title: Michael Goldberg, 83, Abstract Expressionist, Is Dead
description: Michael Goldberg, an abstract painter of the New York School whose vibrant works are in major museums and private collections, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about the University of Southern Californias 49-17 victory over Illinois in the Rose Bowl reversed, in some editions, the surnames of two U.S.C. players involved in a scoring play. They are Garrett Green and Desmond Reed.

title: Steroids Spotlight for a Veteran Bulldog
description: Mike Wallace has been the central figure at 60 Minutes since its inception in 1968, CBSs embodiment of the unyielding interrogator. Now hes 89, working on two stories a year, not 10 or 20 as in the past, in his role as correspondent emeritus.

title: Nature Abhors a Vacuum, and Politics Abhors Clear Statements
description: Could it be that the one person able to get Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to talk absolutely straight about his political plans is Ryan Seacrest? It doesnt seem likely, but who knows? In a year when the country may elect its first female, black, Mormon, Arkansas preacher or thrice-married Roman Catholic president, anything is possible.

title: Under Spagnuolo, Giants Give Grudgingly
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  After the Giants beat the Bills in Buffalo 11 days ago, cornerback R. W. McQuarters went looking for Steve Spagnuolo, the Giants defensive coordinator. At first, McQuarters could not find him on the field or in the locker room.

title: Stage Doors and Rail Stops
description: THE Gettysburg train station, which dates from 1859, is next to the Majestic Theater, and there is a worn path between them. Trains, theaters and traveling shows once went hand in hand.

title: Bucs Lift Non-Floridian Ticket Ban
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Ticketmaster acquiesced to the demands of the New York attorney general on Thursday that fans outside Florida be allowed to buy tickets for Sundays wild-card game against the Giants.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: More Than a Coach
description: It's not unusual for high school coaches to play big roles in their players' lives. But Jack O'Brien, the basketball coach at Charlestown High School in Boston, takes it to another level. In "The Assist: Hoops, Hope, and the Game of Their Lives" (Public Affairs, $26), Neil Swidey, a staff writer for the Boston Globe Magazine, uses practically unfettered access to detail the ups and downs of O'Brien's powerhouse program and the coach's fierce dedication to the players.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Arapahoe Basin Grows Wider and a Bit Less Wilder
description: TALL, dark and scary isnt an easy reputation to live down.

title: Delay in Shuttle Launching
description: The next effort to launch the space shuttle Atlantis could come as early as Jan. 24, but will probably slip into February as engineers test and repair a suspect fuel sensor connector, a NASA official said. The official, John Shannon, deputy space shuttle program manager, said experts at NASAs Marshall Space Flight Center in Alabama were to test the electrical connector, taken from the Atlantiss external fuel tank, next week to confirm that it was the source of the problem. Meanwhile, Mr. Shannon said in a telephone news conference from the Johnson Space Center in Houston, technicians at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida will start modifying the shuttles tank. NASA postponed two efforts in December to fly the Atlantis and its cargo to the International Space Station and had hoped to try again on Jan. 10.

title: Drugs Offer No Benefit in Curbing Aggression, Study Finds
description: The drugs most widely used to manage aggressive outbursts in intellectually disabled people are no more effective than dummy pills for most patients and may be less so, researchers are reporting.

title: Bittersweet Work of Wrapping Wire
description: CLARK JOHNSON, who plays a crusading newspaper editor in the fifth and last season of The Wire, beginning Sunday night on HBO, likes telling autobiographical stories.

title: Delgado Prepares to Hit; Minaya Is Going to Israel
description: Mets first baseman Carlos Delgado said his rehabilitation from a fractured left hand was on schedule and that he expected to be at full strength when he reports to spring training in six weeks. As Delgado prepared to begin the next phase of his recovery, hitting off a tee, General Manager Omar Minaya was getting ready to depart for an eight-day good-will tour of Israel.

title: Reports Show Signs of Continued Weakness in the Economy
description: Reports on factory orders and the labor market released Thursday portrayed an economy that is skirting recession as attention shifts to government figures on employment to be released Friday.

title: U.S. Curtailing Bids to Expand Medicaid Rolls
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration is imposing restrictions on the ability of states to expand eligibility for Medicaid, in an effort to prevent them from offering coverage to families of modest incomes who, the administration argues, may have access to private health insurance.

title: Two Dreams (One Big, One Tiny) Come True
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Once a week before drifting off to sleep, David Garrard, the Jaguars even-keeled quarterback, uncorks his giddiness. Hell turn to his wife, Mary, in bed and whisper: Can you believe the kind of season were having? Can you believe the kind of season Im having? This is what it is like to wake up every morning to a cotton-candy dream that feels as if it is being spun fresh every Sunday.

title: A Firefighter Is Killed in a Brooklyn Blaze
description: A fire lieutenant died Thursday evening fighting a smoky and blinding fire that enveloped a high-rise apartment building in Brooklyn at the site of the former Ebbets Field, city officials said.

title: Race Upended, Candidates Sprint Toward Tuesday Vote
description: NASHUA, N.H.  A smaller field of presidential candidates arrived in New Hampshire Friday facing a dramatically upended campaign after two one-time insurgents  Senator Barack Obama, an Illinois Democrat, and Mike Huckabee, the Arkansas Republican  won the Iowa caucuses Thursday night.

title: Idaho: Furor Over Funeral Home
description: Several older residents of Coeur dAlene are protesting plans for a funeral home across the street from a center for the elderly, saying it would be a little too close for comfort. About 100 people have signed a petition calling on the City Council to deny a special-use permit for Aspen Funeral Home LLC, the center manager, Vickie Harrison, said. They plan to present the petition Feb. 5, she said. The citys planning commission approved a special-use permit in December, but a neighbor appealed the decision. Ms. Hansen said the building had been chosen because it suited the businesss needs. Doy Seng, 81, had a practical view of the proposed funeral home. Were old here; were all ready to go, Ms. Seng said. I think it will be handy.

title: Gerald Astor, 81, Writer on Americans in Combat, Dies
description: Gerald Astor, an author and journalist who drew on the remembrances of combat veterans in his books recounting epic battles of World War II, died Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 81.

title: What Did Pitcher Know and When Didnt He Know It?
description: Roger Clemens keeps inching closer to Barry Bonds territory. By acknowledging that he took injections from his highly personal trainer, Clemens has lost some of the control he likes to impose on every aspect of his life and image.

title: Bloomberg Will Limit Parking Perk
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, taking aim at one of the most treasured perks of city employees, announced Thursday that he would reduce by 20 percent the number of parking permits issued to city employees.

title: Blige Tops Last Week, but Groban Takes the Year
description: In the final week of 2007, Mary J. Bliges Growing Pains (Geffen) took the top spot on the Billboard chart from Josh Grobans Nol (Reprise), which had five straight weeks at No. 1 and was the best-selling record of the year. Growing Pains, in its second week out, sold 205,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan reported, and Alicia Keyss As I Am (J) sold 193,000, climbing one spot to No. 2. Nol sold 178,000 last week; released in October, it has sold 3.7 million copies. With no major albums released last week, Chris Browns Exclusive (Jive) jumped five spots to No. 5, and Colbie Caillat rose seven to No. 10 with Coco. Keyshia Coles Just Like You (Geffen) climbed 15 spots to No. 16, and Robert Plant and Alison Krausss Raising Sand (Rounder), popular on critics year-end lists, rose five to No. 18.

title: Milwaukee Arts in Transition
description: Edo de Waart has been appointed the next music director of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra as the unanimous choice of a 10-member search committee composed of an equal number of musicians and board members. This season and next he will serve as music director designate, and beginning with the 2009-10 season, when he will conduct a minimum of 12 weeks, he will assume responsibility for the artistic thrust of the ensemble. He succeeds Andreas Delfs, who will have the title of conductor laureate in the 2009-10 season. Mr. de Waart is the chief conductor and artistic director of the Hong Kong Philharmonic and chief conductor of the Santa Fe Opera. ... Daniel T. Keegan has been named to succeed David Gordon as director of the Milwaukee Art Museum. Since 2000 Mr. Keegan has been the executive director of the San Jose Museum of Art in California.

title: Knicks Stuck in a Loop of Defeat and Despair
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  As the television cameras panned the Knicks bench in search of vital signs late Wednesday night, one stubbornly optimistic face stood out in a sea of dour expressions. Malik Rose, on the fringe of the rotation but still vital for all of the right reasons, was urging aggression over passivity, belief over doubt, as he addressed his bedraggled teammates.

title: For Happy Warrior of Political Coverage, Another Joyous Night
description: If Tim Russert of NBC News is the New Hampshire primary of political pundits  crucial, serious and august  then his colleague Chris Matthews, intense, voluble and unavoidable, is the Iowa caucuses. And it takes one to cover one, as Mr. Matthews demonstrated with his coverage Thursday night on MSNBC.

title: In War and Peace, in Silver and Gold
description: Tibetan Buddhism, represented by the peace-loving Dalai Lama, is not normally seen as a religion that advocates violence. Earlier generations of followers, however, defended the road to enlightenment with armed horsemen.

title: Brooklyn Infant Is Killed by Familys Dog
description: An 8-month-old Brooklyn boy was mauled to death by his familys Doberman pinscher on Thursday as the boy played on the floor of his apartment, the police said.

title: For Some Kenyan Villagers, the Action Is in Des Moines
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The postelection mayhem consuming Nairobi and other parts of Kenya has not struck Nyangoma-Kogelo, the western village of tin shacks where some residents also kept an eye on the results of another vote, the Iowa caucuses.

title: Tata Pulls Ford Units Into Its Orbit
description: LONDON  When Ratan Tata visited the home of the designer Ralph Lauren last autumn, the two auto enthusiasts spent much of their time in the garage, admiring Mr. Laurens extensive car collection, including the Batmobile-esque 1955 Jaguar XKD.

title: Bhuttos Deadly Legacy
description: New Delhi

title: New Years With the Horses
description: To the Editor:

title: Shiite Praises Anti-Insurgent Militias
description: BAGHDAD  The leader of Iraqs most influential Shiite party offered surprisingly conciliatory remarks on Thursday about the former insurgents and other Sunnis who have banded together into militias to work with American forces, stating that the groups had helped improve security and should be continued.

title: Initial Reaction
description: Is it just my long-time Giants loyalty speaking, or is anyone else wondering how the nickname "L.T." was so easily transferred to LaDainian Tomlinson? Is it as simple as a decree from "SportsCenter" or should the standard be higher -- say, like transforming the very way the game is played? That's what the original L.T., Lawrence Taylor, did when he was terrorizing quarterbacks in the 1980s and early 1990s. Tomlinson's superb talent is unquestioned, and he seems sure to eventually join Taylor in the Hall of Fame. But he doesn't have two Super Bowl rings, hasn't willed his team to greatness, and most importantly hasn't fundamentally altered strategy on the other side of the line of scrimmage. Let's reserve that nickname for its rightful owner.

title: Judge Denies Bail to Men Accused of Plot Against Fort Dix
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  A federal judge on Thursday denied bail to the five men accused of plotting to attack the Fort Dix military base, saying they would have ample access to evidence to prepare their defense while incarcerated.

title: Let It Start Now
description: The candidates have spent a year and tens of millions of dollars in Iowa, and Thursday night the first actual voters offered their first assessments. Some candidates and their strategists were hoping the caucuses and the New Hampshire primary next week would settle the race, weeding out the contenders for the two major parties presidential nominations. Watching the campaign in cold, snowy and mostly empty Iowa, we were hoping for something else  that this years Iowa-New Hampshire rush to judgment will be the last.

title: Iowa Results Lead Dodd and Biden to Quit Race
description: Two Democratic senators from the Northeast  Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware  became the first casualties of the Iowa caucuses on Thursday night. After both failed to get a single percentage point, they issued statements saying they would drop out of the race.

title: Law Summons Viewers
description: The 18th season of NBCs Law & Order proved the show can still be a ratings force as its two-hour debut attracted Wednesday nights largest audience, 13.4 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. NBC won the night over all in total viewers, leading the 8 oclock hour preceding Law & Order with its game show Deal or No Deal (12.2 million). Among adults 18 to 49, however, NBC ranked third, trailing just behind ABC and more distantly behind Fox, which led over all in that age group with its Fiesta Bowl college football coverage. ABC got a boost from season premieres of Wife Swap at 8 (8.5 million) and Supernanny at 9 (8.9 million), followed by a second episode of Supernanny at 10 (9.1 million). CBS finished fourth over all with repeats after the second-season start for Power of 10 at 8 (6.7 million).

title: Cameron Is Fired by Dolphins
description: Bill Parcells cleaned the Miami Dolphins house Thursday morning, firing the first-year head coach Cam Cameron and 16 of his assistants, leaving only two members from the coaching staff that led the Dolphins to a 1-15 season.

title: Boy and Girl Meet Beasts, Armadillo to Zany Zebra
description: The phrase based on the book by may have never been stretched so far.

title: Teaching the Arts in City Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Gone So Long We Forgot to Miss You
description: If it weren't so ridiculous, you'd almost have to admire the quixotic, archaic, almost misanthropic way that college football organizes its postseason, which, after all, is theoretically the most exciting portion of its schedule. Essentially, college football builds up an avalanche of momentum, then pauses and says, "Hey, everybody, let's take a month off!"

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,893 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: West Virginia Pulls Another Shocker and Hires Stewart
description: The West Virginia coaching search had every element of a melodrama. There was meddling from the states governor, big-money boosters bickering with the administration and volumes of vitriol directed at the departed football coach and his family. And just when it appeared that the search could be starting over, West Virginia added one more twist  a surprise ending.

title: Lush Movement to Break Winters Spell
description: Snowflakes fell in New York on Wednesday, but none onstage at Lincoln Center. New York City Ballet had closed its annual season of George Balanchines Nutcracker with a particularly bright performance on Sunday. On Wednesday it opened its eight-week winter repertory season with an account of Balanchines Jewels. The Nutcracker is narrative; Jewels has its place in history as the first abstract full-evening ballet (as it was billed when new in 1967). Both ballets serve as ideal introductions to what dance theater has to offer; and both are classics that repay innumerable rewatchings.

title: United Arab Emirates: Link to U.S. Dollar Kept
description: The United Arab Emirates will keep a 30-year link between its currency, the dirham, and the United States dollar, after completing a review of its currency regime, said the central bank governor, Sultan bin Nasser al-Suwaidi, left. In 12 months I can say to you that the U.A.E. will maintain the peg, Mr. Suwaidi said. We have come to the conclusion that the inflation problem does not lie with the peg against the U.S. dollar. The dirham is fixed to the dollar at 3.6725. We were studying the causes of inflation, and we came to the conclusion that the causes are not in the dirham/U.S. dollar peg, therefore we need not do anything on that front, Mr. Suwaidi said.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Spain: Inflation Rate Is Highest in 10 Years
description: Led by higher food and energy costs, inflation in Spain accelerated to the fastest rate in more than a decade in December even after economic growth slowed. The inflation rate rose to 4.3 percent, the highest since the European-standard index was introduced in 1997, the Labor Ministry said. Prices jumped even with unemployment rising for a third month, as a softening real estate market led to a 13 percent increase in benefit claims by construction workers, a separate report showed.

title: Mexico: Presidents Cousin Briefly Abducted
description: A cousin of President Felipe Caldern was abducted at gunpoint, beaten and held for four hours on Wednesday in Morelia, in Michoacn State, newspapers reported. It was unclear if the kidnapping of Alfonso Reyes, who owns a foreign-exchange business, was connected to Mr. Calderns offensive against organized crime.

title: In Grace Notes, Linear Riffs on Reality
description: A Drawing is the correct title for my work, the artist Stuart Davis wrote in a 1954 notebook. He meant the correct title for all his work, including the high-color, post-Cubist, proto-Pop paintings that have made him a revered presence in the American modernist pantheon.

title: Buckeyes Look to Correct Past Mistakes
description: NEW ORLEANS  Of all the enduring lessons and endless perceptions that came out of Floridas blowout victory against Ohio State in the national title game last season, Ohio State offensive tackle Kirk Barton might have summed it up most succinctly.

title: Theater Listings
description: ONEILL FESTIVAL AT 10 When Eugene ONeill was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1936 (he is the only American playwright who has been so honored), his speech, delivered in absentia because of health problems, acknowledged a debt to August Strindberg, whom ONeill called that greatest genius of all modern dramatists. Many playwrights today would say the same about ONeill, who wrote with grim candor about his own family and, somehow, a bit about everyone elses at the same time.

title: How to Assess Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Newcomers Jolt Parties Status Quo
description: DES MOINES  The Democratic and Republican establishments and their presidential candidates, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former Gov. Mitt Romney, were brought low in Iowa on Thursday night, shaken seriously by two national newcomers who won decisively on messages of insurgency and change.

title: Embracing the Cold in a Genteel Place
description: DAVID BARRELL and his wife, Brenda, have nothing against palm trees, white sand beaches and balmy days. But when the time came seven years ago to put a down payment on a vacation getaway, they chose Magog, Quebec  a ski resort 135 miles north of their year-round home in Quechee, Vt.

title: Life, Love and the Pleasures of Literature in Barsetshire
description: The weather has been cold, the snow deep, the long, dark evenings perfect for holing up with a book. In the past few weeks, Ive read nine of Angela Thirkells Barsetshire novels. I expect to keep going right through all 29 of them, and when Im done I may start over again. This is a confession of sorts. When I first came upon Thirkell, nearly 30 years ago, she seemed like a diverting minor writer. Minor now seems too slight a word to me for the purveyor of such major pleasures.

title: Dealing With the Dragon
description: On both Wednesday and Thursday, the price of oil briefly hit $100 a barrel. The new record made headlines, as well it should have. But what does it mean, aside from the obvious point that the economy is under extra pressure?

title: Lacey Township: Environmental Approval for Nuclear Plant
description: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station received approval from New Jersey environmental officials on Thursday for the plants continued operation. The approval was the last major hurdle before the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission votes on whether to extend the plants license for 20 years. The State Department of Environmental Protection approved the plants coastal land use plans for the next 20 years. The owner, the AmerGen Energy Company, agreed to restore some nearby wetlands and oyster beds and to maintain a recreation area near the nuclear plant. The commission could vote on the extension as soon as Jan. 22.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Al Jazeera No Longer Nips at Saudis
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  When a Saudi court sentenced a young woman to 200 lashes in November after she pressed charges against seven men who had raped her, the case provoked outrage and headlines around the world, including in the Middle East.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Dec. 25 about the information storage capacity of individual neurons referred imprecisely to the process by which brain cells communicate with one another. Although a cell does fire a chemical burst across a space called the synapse to stimulate the hairlike spines on the receiving cell, the part of the cell that sends the burst is called an axonal ending, not a spine.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article in some editions on Monday about running back Thomas Joness solid performance in the Jets 13-10 overtime victory against Kansas City misspelled the surname of the Chiefs player who stopped Jones on a fourth-down play in the third quarter. He is Tamba Hali, not Ali.

title: New Face and a Call for Change Shake Up the Democratic Field
description: DES MOINES   They rolled the dice.

title: Bronx: Lehman Principal Leaving
description: The veteran principal of Herbert H. Lehman High School has agreed to step down at the end of the school year, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said on Thursday, after investigators found that two of his assistant football coaches had for years been paid overtime wages for time spent at home. The principal, Robert Leder, said he had agreed to retire after 29 years in his post only after Education Department officials said he would otherwise be removed from the school midyear, pending a further inquiry into the payments. According to a report by the special investigation commissioner for the schools, Mr. Leder said that he had approved the off-campus overtime payments, explaining that the assistant coaches were always working. But in a telephone interview, Mr. Leder said the report had mischaracterized his statements. He said he had been unaware of the improper payments until the investigation started. June Pinto, president of Lehmans Parent Association, said her group would continue to press Mr. Leders case with various elected officials. Hes an excellent principal, she said. Were hoping that somebody will be able to help us keep him.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Sports of The Times column on Sunday about the writers travels in covering sports in 2007 misidentified the team that defeated the Mets on the final day of baseballs regular season. It was Florida, not Washington.

title: Tata Pulls Ford Units Into Its Orbit
description: LONDON  When Ratan Tata visited the home of the designer Ralph Lauren last autumn, the two auto enthusiasts spent much of the time in the garage, admiring Mr. Laurens car collection, including the Batmobile-esque 1955 Jaguar XKD.

title:
Kenyan Riot Police Turn 
Back Rallying Protesters
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Nairobi degenerated into violence again on Thursday, as riot police officers used tear gas, batons and water cannons to push back thousands of opposition supporters who poured into the streets to answer a call for a million-person rally that had been banned by the government.

title: Bert Bolin, 82, Is Dead; Led U.N. Climate Panel
description: Bert Bolin, a pioneering climatologist and the first chairman of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which shared the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize with former Vice President Al Gore for their warnings about global warming, died Sunday in Stockholm. He was 82.

title: Newark: Some Progress at Medical School
description: New Jerseys state medical school has improved its accounting and billing practices in the two years it has been under federal supervision, but still lacks the ability to investigate fraud allegations aggressively, according to a monitors final report, released Thursday. The school, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, has been under supervision since 2005, after revelations that school officials had been overbilling Medicare by tens of millions of dollars, giving hundreds of millions of no-bid contracts to politically connected vendors and offering jobs based on patronage. The monitor, Herbert Stern, said in his report that those practices have stopped and that the school can now conduct its business honestly and legally, but urged the university to correct problems in its office of compliance and ethics. Anna Farneski, a university spokeswoman, said it was developing more robust internal monitoring procedures.

title: Jury Sides With Hospital and Doctor in 02 Suicide
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Six years after a chronically suicidal woman hanged herself in her hospital room, a Superior Court jury here ruled Thursday that the psychiatric hospital and a doctor who treated her were not responsible for her death.

title: The Power of Immigration to Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: After Iowa, Challenges Lie Ahead for Obama
description: DES MOINES  As he accepted his victory in the Iowa caucuses Thursday night, Senator Barack Obama presented his presidential candidacy as a vessel to wipe away partisan divisions, transcend the boundaries of race and build a coalition for change that stretches through red states and blue states.

title: Panels Inquiry on Spitzer Aide May Go On
description: ALBANY  The State Commission on Public Integrity can continue, for now, to gather evidence related to Gov. Eliot Spitzers former communications director, Darren Dopp, while a separate criminal investigation proceeds, a state judge ruled on Thursday.

title: Obama Takes Iowa in a Big Turnout as Clinton Falters; Huckabee Victor
description: DES MOINES  Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, a first-term Democratic senator trying to become the nations first African-American president, rolled to victory in the Iowa caucuses on Thursday night, lifted by a record turnout of voters who embraced his promise of change.

title: New Faces Make Most of a Moment in the Sun
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  Most years, the golfers on the leader board at the $5.5 million Mercedes-Benz Championship, the PGA Tours annual opening event for winners only, do not require an introduction. This year  with a dozen first-time winners in the field of 31 and the worlds Nos. 1 and 2 players taking a pass  is an exception.

title: Albany: Birds Killed by Virus
description: A virus killed hundreds of crows across the state in the last week, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation. Officials said concentrations of dead crows were spotted in Orange, Dutchess, Albany, Jefferson, Montgomery and Steuben Counties. Ward Stone, a state wildlife pathologist, said the strain of avian reovirus attacks the birds intestinal system and is spread through fecal matter. Winter facilitates the spread, with crows gathering in large roosts. The strain is not likely to be contracted by humans, he said.

title: Letterman Kvetches, Leno Gets By
description: The writers strike has upset the natural order of television, and that topsy-turviness was not set right with the return of late-night talk shows this week.

title: Binghamton: I.B.M. Sued Over Dumping
description: Lawyers representing nearly 1,000 upstate residents filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court here on Thursday charging I.B.M. with dumping industrial solvents that have contaminated hundreds of homes and businesses over several decades in and around the Broome County village of Endicott. I.B.M. manufactured a range of products, including typewriters and computers, in Endicott from 1924 until 2002. The company discharged millions of gallons of trichlorethylene and other solvents that, over time, formed an underground plume of hazardous chemicals. In 1979, it was discovered that vapors from the chemicals were seeping into homes in Endicott and the neighboring town of Union. Michael Maloney, a company spokesman, said I.B.M. began to address the problem in late 2002, and so far has installed vapor remediation systems in more than 440 properties. The lawsuit claims that residents face higher rates of kidney cancer and other diseases while also suffering losses in the value of their properties.

title: Open Your Door and Youre on the Lift
description: SKI in with an offer; ski out with a bargain?

title: Lottery Numbers
Sean Penn to Lead Cannes Jury
description: Sean Penn, winner of an Academy Award as an actor and recipient of praise as a director, was named on Thursday the president of the jury of the 61st Cannes Film Festival, Reuters reported. The appointment of Mr. Penn, who is also known for blunt criticism of President Bush and the United States-led invasion of Iraq, injects an element of politics into the festival. In 2004 it awarded its top prize, the Palme dOr, to Fahrenheit 9/11, Michael Moores critique of Bush administration policies. Mr. Penn won the 2004 best-actor Oscar for his portrayal of an ex-convict tortured by his daughters murder in Mystic River. He is the director of Into the Wild, which led the field with four Screen Actors Guild Award nominations when the guild announced them last month. The Cannes festival will run from May 14 to 25.

title: Padilla Sues Ex-Government Lawyer
description: Jose Padilla, the American citizen who was held in military detention for more than three years as an enemy combatant, filed a lawsuit Friday against a former Justice Department lawyer who helped provide the legal justifications for what the suit says was Mr. Padillas unconstitutional confinement and gross physical and psychological abuse.

title: Saudi Arabias Promised Reforms
description: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia did the right thing when he pardoned the Qatif girl. The perfect injustice of the case, in which a young woman was gang raped and then sentenced to 200 lashes for being alone in a car with a man to whom she was not married, left him no choice. Now another ugly face of Saudi justice has been revealed, one that cannot be explained by religion, ancient tradition or culture. The detention last month of an outspoken blogger, Fouad al-Farhan  only confirmed by the Interior Ministry this week  is an act of thoroughly modern despotism and one the king should immediately overrule.

title: Merck Makes Deal to Develop Schizophrenia Drug
description: Merck & Company agreed on Thursday to pay a Swiss company, Addex Pharmaceuticals, as much as $702 million to help develop a new schizophrenia drug.

title: Eager South Koreans Tour a Semi-Open City in the North
description: KAESONG, North Korea  Under the gaze of a bronze statue of Kim Il-sung standing atop a hill, a convoy of 11 buses packed with South Koreans wound its way through this quiet city center in North Korea, which was opened up to daily tours early in December and is now suddenly host to hundreds of mostly South Korean tourists seven days a week.

title: Art in Review
description: ALBERTO BURRI

title: CBS Takes a Tighter Hold of CSTV
description: CBS Sports took a firmer grip on CSTV, the college sports media company it acquired in late 2005, by announcing Thursday that it was taking over day-to-day control of it from the last of its three founders, Brian Bedol, who will soon leave CBS.

title: Broadway Actor Pleads Guilty to Backstage Sex Act With Girl, 15, in 2001
description: A Broadway actor admitted on Thursday that in 2001 he seduced a 15-year-old girl who visited him backstage, and agreed as part of a plea bargain to reveal that admission to anybody he works for in film, television or theater for up to the next three years.

title: Israeli Forces Kill 9 in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli forces operating in Gaza killed at least nine Palestinians on Thursday and blew up the houses of some known militant commanders, as the Palestinians fired a Katyusha rocket from Gaza that landed in northern Ashkelon, a city of 120,000 people.

title: PATH Riders May Get Slight Break on Fare Rise
description: Bridge and tunnel commuters will see expected increases in fares, while those taking PATH trains may get a little bit of a break after the Port Authority votes on proposals on Friday, according to an agency official.

title: Railroad Pays Fines
description: The CSX Corporation, the third-largest American railroad by sales, paid $349,265 in fines for violating federal rail-safety violations, government railroad regulators said. The Federal Railroad Administration investigated safety on CSXs rail network, which spans the eastern half of the United States, after a series of accidents. CSX is based in Jacksonville, Fla. The Union Pacific Corporation and the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation are the two largest American railroads by sales.

title: The Tragic Sublime and Concrete Rubble
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.  To its proud owners it was a great work of art. To the Historic District Commission of Fairfield, Conn., it was a broken down concrete wall and it had to go. The courts sided with the commission, so the 82-foot-long, 42-ton concrete sculpture by the internationally celebrated German artist Anselm Kiefer no longer occupies the lawn in front of Andrew and Christine Halls 19th-century Greek Revival mansion, where it had resided from August 2003 until late this summer. Now on extended loan to the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art here, it is the centerpiece of an exhibition that includes six gigantic Kiefer paintings, also owned by the Halls.

title: Few Viewers for Infancy of Fox Business
description: How many people are watching the new Fox Business Network?

title: Even Trucks Hit the Wall in an Erratic 2007
description: DETROIT  They may be built like a rock, be able to haul boulders and hail from deep in the heart of Texas. But pickup tricks cannot stand up to tough economic times.

title: One Tough Dame Tells Heartfelt Tales
description: Take away the sets, the costumes, the props, the special effects: It all comes down to storytelling. The ground-level reality of show-business magic is the ability to spin a spellbinding yarn anytime, anywhere. Elaine Stritch has it at her fingertips.

title: At Huckabee Central, Cheers for Evangelical Base
description: DES MOINES  Just as the Republican caucuses began on Thursday at 6:30 p.m., a small group of women and children joined hands in the middle of the ballroom at Mike Huckabees headquarters here and began to pray for his election.

title: Weak Job Growth Numbers Prompt Stock Selloff
description: The unemployment rate surged to 5 percent in December as the nation added only 18,000 jobs, the smallest monthly increase in four years, the Labor Department reported on Friday. Investors responded by sending the stock market down sharply.

title: The Auction Block Is the Next Stop for a Well-Traveled Lady
description: In 1994 a young antiques dealer living in Gothenburg, Sweden, bought a dusty, life-size carved-wood sculpture of a woman from a local farmer. The farmer told him that it had once been used as a scarecrow but that it had scared people as well as birds, so one of his ancestors had stuck it in a barn, where it had remained, undisturbed, for a century.

title: Back at the Zoo, With Sadness for All Casualties
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The giraffes were aloof, the penguins were show-offs and the rhinoceros refused to wake up. But among the human visitors on Thursday at the San Francisco Zoo  as it reopened a little over a week after a tiger escaped and mauled three visitors, killing one  a lingering and conflicted sadness seemed to be a common emotion.

title: Parent of Dating Sites Looks for a Match
description: Wanted: Single dot-com Yenta seeks ambitious Mr. Big with deep pockets for a long-term relationship.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Cases column in Science Times on Tuesday, about a doctors decision to apologize to a patient for a medical error, misstated the number of states that have enacted legislation encouraging such apologies. It is 29, not 17.

title: After Iowans Vote, Others Step in to Comment
description: Mike Huckabees win was Mitt Romneys loss; Barack Obamas decisive victory was the official end of Hillary Rodham Clintons inevitable march, and Fred D. Thompsons (narrow) third-place finish could save him from the crowded mausoleum of dead campaigns past for which he was supposedly destined.

title: The Two Earthquakes
description: Ottumwa, Iowa

title: With Few Options, Colorado Considers All-Mail Vote
description: DENVER  Colorados crash course in how to hold an election has begun.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Findings column in Science Times on Tuesday, about the way severe weather is tied to predictions of global warming, gave an outdated academic affiliation for Timur Kuran. He is a professor of economics and political science at Duke University; he is no longer a professor of economics and law at the University of Southern California.

title: Early Warriors in the Fight for Racial Equality
description: In the three decades that followed World War I, black Southerners and their allies relentlessly battled Jim Crow, Glenda Elizabeth Gilmore writes at the outset of this rich but sprawling book. Ms. Gilmore, a professor of history at Yale, wants her collective biography of activist black and white Southerners from that era to illuminate how resistance to the Souths elaborate system of racial segregation, often nicknamed Jim Crow after a 19th-century minstrel song, long predated the onset of traditionally celebrated civil-rights initiatives in 1954-55.

title: School Commendations Come With a Critique
description: It was supposed to be a day to celebrate the citys best schools. The schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, trekked to Public School 46 in Bayside, Queens, to announce that the schools that had received the highest marks on the citys new school report card were to receive a windfall of extra money.

title: Another Record Year for Orders at Boeing
description: Boeing said late Thursday that it had received orders for 1,413 commercial jets last year, setting a third consecutive annual record driven by demand from Asian and Middle Eastern airlines.

title: Frightful Weather? Pack Your Tent.
description: Yes, it is colder, windier. But the air is crisper, the views clearer, the animal tracks easier to see, Dave Caldwell writes in The Times tomorrow. So, it is the perfect time to go camping, right? Read about five ideal spots in the Northeast for the hardy lover of snow and cold.

title: Free in Parents Murders, and Weighing Future in Law
description: In the first few days after winning his freedom, Martin H. Tankleff  who was sent to prison 17 years ago for two murders he insists he never committed  relished the things that were little more than routine to him half a lifetime ago.

title: Where Others Saw a Big Old Barn, They Saw a Home
description: DEREK AND MICHELLE SANDERS had been hunting for a vacation place for several months when they heard about a property in Roxbury, N.Y., three hours north of Manhattan, and drove out on a wintry day in 2002 to have a look. Rounding a scenic ridge, they caught sight of it  a rambling old Dutch-style barn nestled in the valley below.

title: Camping Under a Mantle of Snow
description: THE great outdoors beckons, even in the dead of winter.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article in some editions on Monday about running back Thomas Joness solid performance in the Jets 13-10 overtime victory against Kansas City misspelled the surname of the Chiefs player who stopped Jones on a fourth-down play in the third quarter. He is Tamba Hali, not Ali. (Go to Article)

title: High School Coach Earns Army Award
description: For 30 years, Roger Barta has been a football coach in tiny Smith Center, Kan.  one good enough to win seven high school championships. On Thursday, his success was recognized far beyond the plains when the U.S. Army All-American Bowl Selection Committee named him the national coach of the year.

title: Pennsylvania Road Show
description: THE ghost light stood guard over the empty stage of the Fulton Opera House in Lancaster, Pa. The harsh light from its bare bulb spilled out over the red velvet seats of the dimly lighted auditorium and here and there caught ornate details on columns, plaster moldings and the faces of the cherubs on the box seats to either side of the stage.

title: State Street Corp. Is Sued Over Pension Fund Losses
description: The State Street Corporation, which manages $2 trillion for pension funds and other institutions, ousted a senior executive on Thursday and said it would set aside $618 million to cover legal claims stemming from investments tied to mortgage securities.

title: Finalists Named for Hugo Boss Prize
description: FINALISTS NAMED

title: Ex-Goldman Associate Sentenced to More Than 4 Years for Inside Trades
description: A former Goldman Sachs associate who was accused of masterminding one of the broadest insider-trading conspiracies in years was sentenced on Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

title: Law & Order, London-Style?
description: Britain could soon hear the sound, familiar to Law & Order fans, of dun-dun. NBC Universal is close to signing a pact with a British production company to create a version of the long-running New York drama that would be set in London. Kudos Film and Television intends to produce the series for the British network ITV. Stephen Garrett, a managing director of Kudos, said he was in advanced talks to license the rights to the series. Variations of Law & Order are already produced in Russia and France, but the British show would be the first foreign English-language version of the NBC original. If a deal is signed, Kudos will start production in the summer, Mr. Garrett said.

title: Musharraf Says Bhutto Took Excessive Risks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Pervez Musharraf on Thursday rejected any suggestion that he or any members of the Pakistani military or intelligence agencies played a role in the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, and said it was probably carried out by the same extremists responsible for a number of suicide bombings in recent months.

title: Change at Westport Playhouse
description: Joanne Woodward and Anne Keefe have returned as co-artistic directors of the Westport Country Playhouse in Connecticut. An announcement said they would be interim leaders, succeeding Tazewell Thompson, whose departure after two years was attributed to artistic and professional differences by Elisabeth Morten, the president of the Playhouse board. The announcement said that as a result of the change, the 2008 roster of productions would be altered.

title: Payroll Is at Heart of Santana Debate
description: Perhaps the most significant story in a busy Yankees off-season has been the emergence of Hank Steinbrenner at the top of the teams hierarchy. Steinbrenner, the senior vice president, has been outspoken on potential player moves, but he cannot and has not acted unilaterally.

title: China: Restrictions on Web Video and Audio
description: China will allow only state-run Web sites to broadcast video or radio through the Internet, tightening the governments regulatory grip over the media content offered there. Starting Jan. 31, Internet broadcasting license applicants must be government-run entities, Chinas State Administration of Radio, Film and Television said Dec. 29 in a statement posted on its Web site. Operators will be banned from offering content that promotes sex, violence, gambling or religious cults or divulges state secrets, it said. Internet video and audio providers must be resolute in the service of the socialist ideal and of the people, and regard the interest of overall society as the top priority, according to a statement from the agency, which will supervise Web video and radio services.

title: Bomb Blast Kills 5 in Kurdish Area in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  A bomb exploded near a shopping mall in the largely Kurdish city of Diyarbakir in southeastern Turkey on Thursday, killing five people and wounding more than 60, in the largest attack on a Turkish city in months, the authorities said.

title: One Filmmakers Vivid Tales of Fathers and Other Strangers
Books to Browse or to Savor
description: READING is part of getting away for many people, whether its packing a couple of paperbacks for a Caribbean vacation or browsing the bookshelf on a rainy Saturday at a friends country house. Indeed, built-in bookshelves and rooms called libraries are common amenities in vacation-home properties.

title: 15th Dallas County Inmate Since 01 Is Freed by DNA
description: HOUSTON  After nearly 27 years in prison for a rape he did not commit, Charles Chatman walked free on Thursday, the 15th wrongfully convicted prisoner in Dallas County to be exonerated by DNA testing since 2001.

title: Manhattan: Man Sentenced for Fatal Crash
description: A man who said he mistook a bike path for the West Side Highway and fatally struck a cyclist while driving drunk in 2006 was sentenced Thursday in State Supreme Court to 3  to 10  years in prison. The man, Eugenio Cidron, 28, of Queens, pleaded guilty in November to second-degree manslaughter, admitting he hit the cyclist, Eric Ng, 22. Officials said Mr. Cidrons blood alcohol level was twice the legal limit.

title: Strikers Complain as Leno Dominates Late-Night
description: Jay Leno made a triumphant return to late-night television Wednesday night, easily dominating the ratings competition over his chief rival, David Letterman, and delivering a traditional full-length monologue  even though he was performing without his team of 19 writers.

title: Manhattan: Nominee for City Clerk
description: City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn on Thursday nominated Hector L. Diaz, the longtime Bronx County clerk and a former assemblyman, to fill the open position of city clerk. The $175,000-a-year post was vacated in July, when Victor Robles stepped down. Mr. Diazs appointment requires the approval of the full Council. Mr. Diaz, 63, was the choice of Jose Rivera, chairman of the Bronx Democratic Party, whose support was critical to Ms. Quinns winning the speakers office in 2006 and will also be important if she makes an expected bid for mayor in 2009. Ms. Quinns office would not comment on the political implications of the nomination, but said Mr. Diaz was well qualified. If his appointment is approved, he said, he plans to begin his tenure with financial and performance audits of the office, which in addition to certifying city laws and maintaining records, performs civil marriages and enforces lobbying laws. The clerk serves a five-year term.

title: Ohio to Offer Paper Ballots in March
description: CINCINNATI  All 57 counties in Ohio that still use the touch-screen voting machines that were found to be unreliable in a statewide study must provide paper ballots to any voters who request them for the presidential primary in March.

title: Obamas Kin Glued to the Radio in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The post-election mayhem consuming Nairobi and other parts of Kenya has not struck Nyangoma-Kogelo, the western village of tin shacks where many residents were instead fixated on the results of another vote on Thursday: the Iowa caucuses.

title: Panels Approve New Jersey School Financing Plan
description: TRENTON  Despite mounting criticism from the mayors of the states largest cities, Gov. Jon S. Corzines proposal to revamp New Jerseys formula for financing schools cleared two important legislative hurdles on Thursday.

title: As Buyouts Falter, New Tactics Aim to Lock in Deals
description: Happy New Year? Not for Wall Street deal makers.

title: Illinois: Former Officer Is Sentenced
description: Three former Chicago police officers were sentenced to decades in federal prison for using their guns, uniforms and badges to steal cocaine and marijuana from drug dealers and resell it. You and your merry band essentially raped and plundered entire neighborhoods, Judge Ronald A. Guzman of Federal District Court said in sentencing one of the former officers, Broderick Jones, the admitted leader of the ring, to 25 years. The stiffest sentence went to another former officer, Eural Black, the only one of the three who did not plead guilty and was convicted at trial. Judge Guzman sentenced Mr. Black to 40 years. A third former officer, Darek Haynes, was sentenced to 19 years.

title: Long Wait for N.F.L., Short Wait for Success
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It was cold. It was 3 a.m. Hauling 50-pound water jugs into Manhattan office buildings along Fifth Avenue and throughout Times Square, Greg White recalled how sacking quarterbacks was much easier work.

title: Germany Posts Month 21 of Declining Jobless Rate
description: FRANKFURT  Of all the measures of Germanys economic revival over the last two years, none may be more telling than this: there are 711,000 fewer people out of work in this country than in 2006, and 1.5 million fewer than in 2005, when unemployment reached a peak of more than 5 million.

title: As Expected, Ford Falls From 2nd Place in U.S. Sales
description: DETROIT  Ford Motor had been in second place in the American car market since the Great Depression. But it lost its grip last year.

title: Now You See Those Securities, Now You Dont
description: What better time of year is there than New Years Eve to release some bad news?

title: In Cookies and Coaxing, the Will of the Democrats Comes to Life
description: NEVADA, Iowa  By midafternoon, Kathy Johnson was nervous. In a few hours, she would be chairwoman of Nevada 2, one of 1,781 Democratic caucuses in Iowa, and one of five in this town of 6,000 people, a 40-minute drive north of Des Moines.

title: Movies
description: MOVIES

title: Intel Leaves Group Backing Education PCs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel said Thursday that it had chosen to withdraw from the One Laptop Per Child educational computer organization, which it joined in July after years of public squabbling between Intels chairman, Craig R. Barrett, and the groups founder, Nicholas P. Negroponte.

title: Drugs Offer No Benefit in Curbing Aggression, Study Finds
description: The drugs most widely used to manage aggressive outbursts in intellectually disabled people are no more effective than placebos for most patients and may be less so, researchers report.

title: Guild Complains About Lenos Monologue
description: Jay Leno delivered a traditional full-length monologue without the help of his team of 19 writers on Wednesday night.

title: Advertisers Thankful For Return Of Late-Night TV
description: As noted by TV Decoder on Thursday, the late-night shows enjoyed an overall viewership bump Wednesday. But the strong ratings belie the sagging advertising market for late-night television. Before the strike began the late-night shows had shed approximately 10 percent of their viewers. Two months of forced repeats exacerbated the declines.

title: John McCain
description: John McCain responds to the results of the Iowa caucus. (NBC Video)

title: John Edwards
description: John Edwards comments on the results from the Iowa caucuses.(NBC Video)

title: Chaos in Kenya
description: Chaos and ethnic fighting has ignited in Kenya, destabilizing the country, just one week after Kenyans went to the polls to elect their president.

title: After Iowa: Locker Room Chatter
description: Instant analysis of the Iowa caucuses (thats the political event that was going on while the Kansas Jayhawks won the Orange Bowl) from around the Web:

title: The Women Vote
description: DES MOINES  We just caught up with some numbers that youll want to see. Turns out Barack Obama did better among women than Hillary Rodham Clinton did.

title: Mitt Romney
description: Mitt Romney comments on the results from the Iowa caucuses. (NBC  Video)

title: CBS Takes a Tighter Hold of CSTV
description: CBS Sports took a firmer grip on CSTV, the college sports media company it acquired in late 2005, by announcing Thursday that it was taking over day-to-day control of it from the last of its three founders, Brian Bedol, who will soon leave CBS, Richard Sandomir reports in Fridays New York Times.

title: Moffitt Update: I Love Him, but He Doesnt Know How to Spell.
description: Heres the next chapter of the Ben and Shauna Moffitt saga. Brett McMurphy of the Tampa Tribune digs deeper into the academic fraud aspect of the story in this article.

title: Shanghai pedicure, with sharpened blades
description: Samuel So. Courtesy of the Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong.

title: Caucus: Media Spotlight Shifts To Obama And Huckabee
description: Television anchors and analysts swiftly anointed the Democratic candidate Barack Obama and the Republican candidate Mike Huckabee the frontrunners of their respective parties on Thursday.

title: Caucus: TV Crews Move To New Hampshire
description: A number of television personalities and producers wont get much sleep Friday morning. Correspondents are following presidential candidates to New Hampshire overnight, and several of them will be in position for Friday newscasts.

title: Lets Face It
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Caucus: Inside CNNs Control Room, Balancing Projections With Patience
description: CNNs fifth-floor newsroom was gift-wrapped in shades of red and blue for the Iowa caucus Thursday evening, as the network deployed the latest electronic toys for the first votes of the 2008 presidential elections.

title: The Iowa Caucuses: Looking Ahead
description: The Times's John Harwood analyzes Thursday night's Iowa caucuses and what lies beyond.

title: Where Do We Live?
description: Photos and reviews of plays written by Christopher Shinn.

title: Minimalism
description: Three exhibitions in New York pivot around one of modern art's most enduringly popular styles.

title: What We Learned in Iowa
description: Sorry not to have posted something here yesterday. We had some technical glitches here in Iowa. I know that some of you probably forgot to eat dinner and missed all the victory speeches because you were obsessively hitting your refresh buttons all night long, and for that I apologize.

title: Inside a Caucus
description: The inner workings of a single caucus, that of the second precinct in Nevada, Iowa.
