description: From a Times Op-Ed parody of in-flight instructions, from the vantage point of a single seat:

title: Tata Pulls Ford Units Into Its Ever-Expanding Orbit
description: As Tata Motors begins detailed talks with Ford Motor about buying the Jaguar and Land Rover brands, The New York Times takes a look at Ratan Tata, for whom the takeover will cap 16 years of transforming one of the worlds most diverse and unusual conglomerates, the Tata Group.

title: Why is Shell Warning Europe About Climate Targets?
description: When leading industrialists warn that plans for cutting greenhouse gases may be too ambitious, its hard to know whether they are giving an honest assessment or protecting their interests. That seems doubly true when the person making the comments is a leading representative of the fossil fuel industry like Jeroen Van der Veer, the chief executive of oil giant Shell.

title: N2N to Close After Losing Only Customer, Report Says
description: One year after signing a $30 million first round of venture financing, n2N Commerce is in the process of shuttering its business.

title: Burkle and Ovitz to Square Off Over Investment Deal
description: In the latest twisted tale of Los Angeles dealmaking, lawyers for billionaire and former grocery store magnate Ronald W. Burkle and onetime Hollywood superstar agent Michael S. Ovitz are set to square off in court in February.

title: National City Should Put Itself on the Block, Analyst Says
description: National City Corp., Ohios largest bank, had a rough start to the New Year.

title: Buyout Executive Anticpates More Energy Deals
description: With the price of oil expected to hover near $100 a barrel or move higher still this year, investors should expect more deals to be made in the energy sector, a leading private-equity executive specializing in the oil and gas industry said Thursday.

title: China Invests in 3 Australian Banks, Report Says
description: A subsidiary of the body overseeing Chinas massive $1.4 trillion reserve stockpile has purchased stakes in three leading Australian banks, according to a report.

title: Start-Up Revives San Francisco Wi-Fi Plan
description: A Silicon Valley start-up is said to be promising to blanket San Francisco with free wireless Internet service, reviving a crusade that crumbled last year after two much larger companies, EarthLink and Google, scrapped their plans to build a high-speed network for Web surfing.

title: Britains Chancellor Plans New Rescue Rules for Banks
description: Britains chancellor of the Exchequer is planning to push through sweeping new powers to intervene if banks fail, in an effort to prevent a future Northern Rock-style crisis.

title: Buffetts New Bond Insurer to Plant Flag in Rhode Island
description: Warren E. Buffetts new bond insurer is looking to expand to Rhode Island after hearing that the states treasurer wanted it to apply for a license to operate in the state, according to a spokeswoman for the billionaire investor.

title: MidOcean Names New Chairman
description: MidOcean Partners said Thursday that Mark A. Angelson, the former chief executive of printing giant R.R. Donnelley, would join the private equity firm as its new chairman. He will also take responsibility for the Executive Board at MidOcean, which was founded by Ted Virtue, a former executive from Deutsche Bank. MidOcean was spun out from Deutsche Bank in 2003.

title: As State Street Faces Suit Over Losses, Will Others Follow?
description: Have the floodgates on a new wave of securities fraud lawsuits been opened?

title: American Industrial Coughs Up $100 Million for Brooks
description: American Industrial Partners purchased the Brooks Instrument division of Emerson Electric for about $100 million, Emerson said Thursday.

title: Is the Weather Channel Asking Too Much?
description: Is the Weather Channel over-shooting with its $5 billion price-tag?

title: V.C.s Inject Tempo With $8.1 Million
description: Combination drug developer Tempo Pharmaceuticals raised $8.1 million in a Series B round of venture capital, bringing total funding in a little more than a year to $22 million.

title: Weather Alarmism as a Noble Strategy
description: Amidst the denunciations of my column and post on weather alarmism, there was a calm question from one critic, Annie Jia:

title: New Tactics Aim to Lock in Buyouts
description: Happy New Year? Not for Wall Street deal makers.

title: For Bear Stearns Funds, a Fatal Margin Call?
description: Merrill Lynchs margin call on assets loaned to Bear Stearns may have been the catalyst for the decline in the value of collateralized debt obligations, according to a Bloomberg News report.

title: Bupa Makes First U.S. Healthcare Deal
description: Bupa, the private health insurer based in the United Kingdom, has agreed to pay $640 million for Health Dialog, its first acquisition of a healthcare company in the United States.

title: Lazards Blank Check Grows to $800 Million
description: Investment bank Lazard has filed for an $800 million initial public offering for its blank check company Sapphire Industrial, in what would be the second-largest offering of its kind to date.

title: N.H. Staffs Prep for the Crush
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  In the latest installment of Campus Voices, a few of the students from Harvards Institute of Politics braved the single-digit temperatures today while on their break to visit the candidates campaign headquarters, where preparations were under way for the big push here  finally!  toward next Tuesday. The students academic project has produced both text and video dispatches throughout the fall and winter as they spent a lot of time in New Hampshire following the primary process and the candidates.

title: Citadel Said to Consider I.P.O. This Year
description: For hedge fund magnate Kenneth C. Griffin, 2007 was the best year ever. His Citadel Investment Group emerged as one of Wall Streets top opportunists, picking up the pieces of fallen peers on the cheap. With such deft moves, Citadel rang in 30 percent-plus gains last year, compared with with the industry average of 12 percent.

title: Regulators Said to Examine Mortgage Securities Sales
description: Federal regulators, concerned brokerages may have sold clients money-losing securities tied to subprime mortgages, are seeking information about how the investments were marketed, Bloomberg News reported citing an unnamed source.

title: Liz Claiborne Said to Be Near a Sale of Ellen Tracy
description: Liz Claiborne, the womens clothing giant, is in the process of selling some of its brands and may make an announcement as soon as Friday, Fortunes Suzanne Kapner reported.

title: But Was It Collusion?
description: An interesting item from MSNBC on whether Titans Coach Jeff Fisher and Colts Coach Tony Dungy had an under-the-table understanding at the end of Sunday nights game. Here are some excerpts:

title: Carlyle Hunts for Infrastructure Deals
description: Carlyle Group is looking for ways to spend its new $1.5 billion infrastructure fund, and a Carlyle executive told The Washington Post it would consider backing the controversial Dulles Rail project, which does not take funds from private sources.

title: Parent of Dating Sites Looks for a Match
description: Wanted: Single dot-com Yenta seeks ambitious Mr. Big with deep pockets for a long-term relationship.

title: Dakar Rally cancellation
description: Hard to believe, but the A.S.O., the organizers of the Dakar rally, formerly known as the Paris-Dakar, decided to cancel the race after threats of terrorism in Mauritania led them to conclude it just wasnt worth it.

title: Prom Night
description: For the moment, Dave Poland at The Hot Button and others are saying that the writers strike may shut down a television show called The Golden Globes. But even if the show doesnt go on, the parties will. Why, just last night one gatekeeper for an annual shindig told the Bagger that he couldnt come unless pledged to cough up coverage.

title: Spending Quality Time Inside P.T.s Noggin
description: The Reeler had a spare 699 minutes on his hands and decided to watch every Paul Thomas Anderson-directed movie in existence. And, oh, he live-blogged along the way.

title: Oh, Canada
description: Both Spoutblog and EWs Pop Watch are crushing on Michael Ceras knobby knees.

title: Turkey Shoot
description: The Vulture, which knows a thing about large, ungainly avians that have trouble taking wing, has done a bit of databasing in search of the worst movie of the year.

title: Brooklyn Blaze Kills a Fire Lieutenant
description: A fire lieutenant, Lt. John H. Martinson, 40, died on Thursday evening after a full-scale assault on a smoky and blinding fire that enveloped a 25-story apartment building at 1700 Bedford Avenue in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, at the site of the former Ebbets Field. At least four other firefighters and four residents of the apartment building were injured, with the injuries were not considered life-threatening.

title: For the Moment | Back in the New York Groove
description: This weeks guest bloggers are Loden Dager, a mens wear collective based in New York City that launched in the Fall of 2006 and this week won the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award for new talent. Its members, pictured, are: Melissa Vail, Matthew Sandager, Oliver Helden, Paul Marlow, and Alex Galan. Today the gang is back at work on their upcoming Paris and New York shows. (Read previous blog entries written by Loden Dager and a profile of Alex Galan here.)

title: The Index Kings
description: One of the most evocative short essays Ive read in a while is Enid Stubins My Life in the Indexing Trade, available at moreintelligentlife.com. It pokes around in a part of book production most readers dont often think about  the worker bees who often compile the indexes in biographies and other nonfiction books.

title: FINAL at the WJC: Sweden 2-1 Russia, OT
description: To follow the play-by-play commentary of the World Junior Championship semifinal match, LIVE, as it happens at the CEZ Arena in Pardubice, Czech Republic, click more and then refresh like crazy. Jeff Z. Klein describes the action.

title:
Dining with Gavin and Bella:
Rosa Mexicano
description: Having sampled the mediocre food thats the price of kid-friendly theatrics at Mars 2112, the Jekyll and Hyde Club and Max Brenner, Id come to the sad conclusion that fun for children and decent grub for grown-ups wasnt a combination to be found in Manhattan.

title: The Early Word: Next Up, New Hampshire
description: OK, thats enough celebrating. Iowa caucus kings Mike Huckabee and Barack Obama, thanks to this years condensed primary schedule, have to translate their momentum quickly into a New Hampshire victory before their primary on Tuesday. And candidates who didnt get the results they wanted have limited time to convince Granite Staters that they dont have to follow Iowas cue.

title: A Bottle Bill for the Climate
description: The exploration of ways to create a sellable approach to the daunting task of establishing a firm ceiling on greenhouse-gas emissions is important enough that Im adding another post on this for the weekend.

title: Allah by Any Other Name
description: Heres a headline to get the little gray cells puzzling: The Malaysian government has reminded  that is, ordered  a Catholic newspaper published in the country not to use the word Allah.

title: Should Microsoft Put Plaxo in Its Address Book?
description: Microsoft made a big splash with its $240 million deal to buy a sliver of Facebook. Now, some industry observers think the software giant should consider another social-networking deal. This time, the focus is on Plaxo, an early entrant into the social-networking field that was overtaken by rivals and is looking to fetch as much as $100 million in a potential sale of the company.

title: N.H. Forecast: The Granite State Welcomes You!
description: Countdown: 4 days until the primary.

title: The Carpetbagger
description: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) visits Arnie Sawyer Studios, an advertising firm that specializes in Academy Award print campaigns.

title: Did Employment Grow In 2007?
description: The December jobs report provides more evidence of a sluggish economy. Employers have not resorted to large-scale layoffs, but they seem to be quite unwilling to hire.

title: The Odds of Becoming President
description: How much did the Iowa results change the odds in the 2008 campaign?

title: An Apple TV With a Blu-ray Player?
description: Rumors are flying fast and furious over what Steve Jobs will pull out of his blue-jean pocket a week from Tuesday at his annual speech at the Macworld Expo in San Francisco. These include a movie rental service for iTunes, a super small notebook computer perhaps with a solid-state hard drive, a notebook docking station, and new features for the iPhone. Shaw Wu, an analyst with American Technology Research, suggested that Apple will start shipping some computers with Blu-ray high-definition DVD drives.

title: Bloomberg Parses the Iowa Results
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg continued to stay mum this morning on his own political aspirations, but continued to assert that the leading candidates for president had failed to be specific enough in their proposed solutions for the nations problems. Mr. Bloomberg spoke about a University of Oklahoma conference he plans to attend this weekend, at which participants expect to call for the candidates to renounce what the mayor called partisan bickering.

title: The Clintons Arrive and Face Big Challenges
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband Bill emerged here on Granite State soil Friday morning for a pep rally, as her campaign  and her ever-popular husband prepared to redouble their efforts after her loss in Iowa.

title: On the Road Again
description: A smaller field of candidates arrived in New Hampshire facing an upended campaign after the Iowa caucuses.

title: Caucus: Reviewing The Coverage
description: Alessandra Stanley reviews the Iowa caucus coverage and finds lots to like on MSNBC, where Chris Matthews co-anchored with Keith Olbermann:

title: Fred Thompsons Caucus Speech
description: The following is a transcript of Fred D. Thompsons remarks to supporters after the Iowa caucuses, based on audio provided by the campaign.

title: The Mouse That Roared (on Cable)
description: The Disney Channel bested USA to become the top-rated cable network of 2007, according to yearend data released on Thursday by Nielsen.

title: Injuries Dash Hopes of Some African Stars
description: Some of Africas brightest stars will miss or are likely to miss the African Cup of Nations later this month in Ghana. Egypt midfielder Mohamad Barakat was ruled out today due to a knee injury. The Egyptian sports site Fil Balad said Barakat, who helped Egypt lift a record 5th African Cup two years ago, was considered a replacement for winger Mohsen Hindawi, also injured. Barakat, who plays for Al Ahly in Cairo, will have surgery in Germany.

title: Video: For Your Consideration
Friday Kickoff: Kansas Gets Its Signature Victory
description: Kansas entered the Orange Bowl against Virginia Tech as the least-respected 11-1 college football team in recent memory, writes Joe Posnanski of the Kansas City Star. The Jayhawks left with a signature victory that silenced their many critics.

title: Romney Pivots, Aims at McCain Again
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  Just hours after his plane touched down here, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney congratulated Mike Huckabee on his win in the Iowa caucuses, saying he did a real nice job. But he quickly added: Things are different here in New Hampshire.

title: Outside the Box: Hasbros Cranium Deal
description: Is Hasbro changing its game plan?

title: A Richardson-Obama Deal? Some Caucus-Goers Thought So
description: DES MOINES  There were many factors contributing to Barack Obamas decisive victory in Iowa Thursday night - his efforts to reach out to first-time caucus voters, record turnout, and a willingness by voters to take a chance on a candidate who seemed improbable not long ago - but was an agreement with the Bill Richardson campaign one of them?

title: A Scene From "The Wire"
description: Clark Johnson plays a newspaper editor on HBO's "The Wire."

title: College Admissions: A Little Guidance
description: Families today agonize over a bewildering array of deadlines and policies. How does early decision differ from early action, or single-choice early action? Does an honors course carry the same weight as A.P.? Whats the best tack for an essay?

title: Hey, Mr. D.J., Spin Me That Vinyl Obsession
description: As someone who has lugged a couple of hundred beat-up vinyl records to and from more apartments than I care to count over the years, throwing out my back out once in the process, I was excited and a little apprehensive about interviewing James Dier for The City section this week.

title: There Are More Black People in the Beatles Than in Iowa
description: Aired Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: The Iowa caucus went on today. Whoever wins gets to be president of Iowa, I guess. I dont know.

title: It Used to Take a Village, Now It Takes Synergy
description: The Village Voice and the Los Angeles Week, both of which are owned by Village Voice Media, polled film critics  those still with jobs after the company, which has bought many city weeklies, dumped the local film writers in favor of syndicated ones  and found out that serious film types are still basking in the brilliance of There Will Be Blood.

title: Howard Dean, You Are Missed
description: This time around, Iowa doesnt seem to have produced its Howard Dean moment, so well just have to live with the original

title: Alarming Weather and Global Warming
description: Our provocative science columnist John Tierney endured a hailstorm of responses for a column and blog post this week on the tendency of some climate campaigners to focus on extreme weather as a selling point for cutting greenhouse gases. Today hes posted an explanation and defense of his view, echoing a lot of what Ive been writing over the past several years.

title: Caucusing: Isnt That What Got Bill Clinton Impeached?
description: Aired Thursday night on CBS: The Writers Guild strike does continue. Let me simplify this for you. Heres what the writers want. Tell me if you dont think this is fair. They want a share of internet revenues and four more years of President Bush.

title: Come Down Off That Limb, Son
description: Kris Tapley, who you could call an veteran Oscar ninny if he wasnt so young and ungrizzled, has gone out on a limb and brought his saw with him, picking Into the Wild for best picture. As Mr. Tapley and others, including Pete Hammond, have pointed out, it is an hellaciously confusing year, with no movie making a clear break out of the pack.

title: Fox Experiments With Monday Nights
description: Fox is moving two of its midseason dramas, New Amsterdam and Canterburys Law, to higher profile time slots. But because the writers strike has led to a shortage of new episodes, the shows will be shown in sequence  one will start after the other ends  instead of at different times on the same night between February and May.

title: FINAL at the WJC: Canada 4, USA 1
description: To review the play-by-play commentary of the World Junior Championship semifinal match at the CEZ Arena in Pardubice, Czech Republic, click more. Lew Serviss described the action.

description:
A scene from MTV's virtual Lower East Side.
Director, producer and writer: Annie Ok
Assistant director: Derek Lerner
Song: "Sonic" by Modrocket

title: The Farmers Daughter Was Home
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: As you know, tonight was the big night in Iowa. Its easy to remember because this is the only big night in Iowa.

title: McCain Swings Back at Romney
description: HOLLIS, N.H.  With the full glare of the national media spotlight now focused squarely on New Hampshire, Senator John McCain wasted little time responding to the latest line of assault from his chief rival here, Mitt Romney.

title: Kenya Isnt Rwanda
Q. & A.: Time To Panic About Unemployment?
description: The headline numbers on the monthly jobs report this morning were pretty scary. The unemployment rate took its biggest jump up in 12 years, to 5 percent, and only 18,000 nonfarm jobs were created in December, in an economy that needs more than 100,000 a month just to keep up with natural population growth. Take government workers out of the picture, and the economy actually lost 13,000 private-sector jobs.

title: Bloomberg Weighs In
description: Will Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg enter the already tumultuous field of presidential candidates by mounting a third-party bid for the White House? The billionaire mayor  who appeared on David Lettermans show on Thursday  continued to stay mum this morning on his own political aspirations. But in a morning radio call-in program, Mr. Bloomberg continued to assert that the leading candidates for president had failed to be specific enough in their proposed solutions for the nations problems. He also discussed a University of Oklahoma conference he plans to attend this weekend, at which participants expect to call for the candidates to renounce what the mayor called partisan bickering.

title: Ratings: Huckabee, Obama andTrump?
description: With the Iowa caucus returns on cable and Orange Bowl college football coverage on Fox, NBCs Celebrity Apprentice still managed to earn Thursday nights top ratings among adults 18 to 49.

title: If Sony BMG Drops D.R.M. for Music, D.R.M. Is Gone
description: Steve Jobs and Jeff Bezos may be rivals in the music sales business, but between them they have forced the music industry to abandon digital rights managementthe software that limits how you copy songs you buy and download.

title: Challenges Ahead for Obama
description: In his Web column today, Jeff Zeleny writes that an inspection of the results in Iowas 99 counties also underscores some of the challenges that lie ahead for Senator Barack Obama as the presidential campaign continues beyond the early-voting states. Go to column

title: Boats for Sale (Catfish Wrestlers Not Included)
description: Among the cast of characters at this years New York National Boat Show: two Oklahoma men who wrestle catfish by grabbing them in their mouths (one had the broken fingers to prove it), Miss Geico (a transvestite version of the insurance company gecko wearing a bikini and a fake eyelashes), two men who created a dolphin-shaped submersible boat named Sweet Virgin Angel (We call it Angel for short, one said), and a boating staff that spent hours simulating fishing with the Nintendo Wii.Boaters can fall either into the stodgy or whimsical lots  and both were evident at the boat show, which started last Saturday and runs through Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Giuliani Seeks a Better Finish in N.H.
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Rudolph W. Giuliani never expected to win the Iowa caucuses. But he returns here Friday afternoon as Iowas sixth-place finisher, much lower than expected, having won fewer than half the votes cast for Representative Ron Paul of Texas.

title: Bear Stearns Said to Face More Scrutiny Over Funds

title: When you Cant Find a London Cab
description: Although Londons iconic black taxis are sometimes in short supply, visitors should steer clear of unlicensed minicabs that cruise the streets looking for business. They are illegal and dangerous. Their drivers are not licensed by Transport for London (TFL) and often drive unsafe, uninsured vehicles. They are unlikely to know their way around the city and probably will overcharge for any journey.

title: Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island Crumbles
description: The hauntingly abandoned, Gothically forbidding Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island  perhaps New York Citys most romantic ruin  turned far less romantic and even more ruined last month when part of its crumbling gray stone facade fell to the ground.The collapse, which seems to have been a matter of gravity picking up where negligence left off, came as the publicly owned landmark hospital was closer than ever to being stabilized and preserved as part of the new Southpoint Park planned on the island.

title: Got Tree? Make Mulch
description: On Saturday and Sunday, New Yorkers will be allowed take their old Christmas trees to 85 parks around the five boroughs for the 12th annual MulchFest  at which tree limbs, branches and trunks are ground into wood chips and turned into vegetation-friendly mulch.Last year, about 12,000 trees were recycled through MulchFest, out of more than 160,000 trees recycled citywide. It turns out that mulch is an important argument in the perennial debate on whether real Christmas trees or the artificial, synthetic versions are better.

title: Late-Night Hosts (Heart) Huckabee
description: The Republican presidential candidate Mike Huckabee has a lot on his plate, starting with building on his caucus win in Iowa and trying to raise some money to help him stay competitive through an intense primary season. But somehow, despite his busy schedule, he is making time for the late-night talk show circuit.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: An Interface of Ones Own
description: Microsoft Word. Light of my mind, fire of my frustration. My sin, my soul. Mi-cro-soft-word. The mouth contorts with anti-poetry. My. Crow. Soft. Word.

title: Clinton Camp Looks to Feb. 5
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator Hillary Clintons campaign is trying to forestall the notion that after her loss last night in Iowa, a loss in New Hampshire could end her quest for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Open Caucus: Post-Iowa Post-Mortem
description: Some members of our voters roundtable decided to weigh in about the Iowa results, and began looking ahead. As always, we invite you to take part in the conversation in the comments section below.

title: Huckabee Is Hit for Raising Taxes
description: One group decidedly unhappy with Mike Huckabees win in the Iowa caucuses is the Club for Growth, an anti-tax organization that has spent $550,000 in an effort to derail his candidacy.

title: Did Warner Brothers Just Kill HD DVD?
description: In addition to Apple, Warner Brothers is now going to throw its weight behind the Blu-ray format for high-definition disks. Warner has been the only major studio to publish its movies in both Blu-ray and HD DVD formats. Today, the studio announced that from now on, it would only issue movies in Blu-ray.

title: It Sure Doesnt Look Like The Onion
description: Updated, 7:21 p.m. | Transit officials have complained about the free newspapers that often litter the floors of subway stations and cars.

title: The Future of College Football
description: NEW ORLEANS  With the generally uninspiring set of bowl games so far, the issue of the future of footballs postseason format has emerged as the hot topic of the off-season. The 11 conference commissioners will convene in Miami in late April for meetings that could well change the course of college football.
The number of people watching Fox Business News.

title: Look Out Below
description: When I grew up, in the 60s, leisure air travel was still relatively expensive and exceptional for people  like us back then  of modest means. So I was 13 when I took my first flight. By way of contrast, our now-22-month-old is a frequent flier. She took her first flight at six months, to France no less! Nowadays, flying is so cheap and routine that its those who dont fly frequently who are exceptional.

title: Gee. A Bizarre Britney Incident. Imagine That.
description: Sigh. Another Friday, another Spears meltdown story all over the tube and the tabs. So duty calls: blog we must.

title: Guild Says Actors Will Not Cross Picket Lines For Golden Globes
description: Following a private meeting with high-profile Golden Globe nominees, the president of the Screen Actors Guild reiterated on Friday that members would not cross picket lines to appear on the awards show later this month.

But somehow, despite his busy schedule, he is making time for the late-night talk show circuit.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 4
description: Here is a slide show of 10 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the last run of New York Water Taxi service on the East River until May, ringing in 2008 in Times Square and the transformation of the High Line elevated railway.

Matthew Yglesias of The Atlantic, left, and Jonathan Chait of The New Republic debate whether Iowa set the stage for a Giuliani comeback.

title: Giuliani: English Only (Sometimes)
description: NASHUA, N.H.  It was just about 25 hours ago that Rudolph W. Giuliani addressed a group of Cuban-American supporters in Hialeah, Fla. His warm-up speakers addressed the crowd in Spanish. His wife, Judith, greeted the crowd in Spanish. And his campaign launched a new radio ad in Spanish, and passed out Spanish-language campaign fliers about his 12 Compromisos con el Pueblo Americano.

title: At the Iowa Caucuses: Battle of the Brands in a High School Library
description: Des Moines

title: Red-Carpet Crawl
description: Ive just returned from the living room with a copy of Happy Times, the photo collection of gods and goddesses by Jerome Zerbe and Brendan Gill. I wanted to see, or to imagine, what the Golden Globes will look like without television cameras, scripted gags and, perhaps, the red-carpet parade of dresses. In other words, if the Globes are to go on as a closed event, without a telecast (which could well be the only alternative at this stage), will the atmosphere resemble the days when Hollywood seemed spectacularly intimate, its gods and goddesses even more remote and unearthly?

title: A Respite From Violence
description: Despite continuing political tension between Kenya's president and  opposition leaders, life was edging back to normal in many parts.

title: Globes a No-Fly Zone for SAG Members
description: Alan Rosenberg made it official: SAG members will not walk past pickets even to get their hands on a Golden Globe.

title: A Respite From Violence
description: Despite continuing political tension between Kenya's president and  opposition leaders, life was edging back to normal in many parts.

title: Will He? Wont He? Should He?
description: The Titans said that Vince Young took part in practice Friday but would be a game-time decision for Sundays game against the Chargers. Coach Jeff Fisher said he did not want Young to go full speed on his injured quadriceps.

title: Vows: Caroline and Karl
description: Karl was a prosecutor chasing terrorists; Caroline was a law school graduate who watched his trials. They found a perfect match online. Case closed.

title: Probabilities in finance
description: Joe Stiglitz, today at the American Economic Association Meetings, talking about financial crises: Once-in-a-hundred-years events occur every 10 years. Hes thinking of the stock market crash of 1987, the Long Term Capital Management crisis of 1998, and the current subprime-plus crisis  all of which involved changes in asset prices that were supposed to be vanishingly unlikely.

title: Panama Extends Tax Break
description: Good news for buyers in Panama. The government has extended a 20-year exemption on property taxes for new homes. Under the law, even if you buy an existing home built in recent years, the exemption is transferable.

title: Clinton at N.H. Democratic Party Dinner
description: MILFORD, N.H.  This is the new battleground, where Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama will fight anew. She comes humbled, but emboldened and ready as her new signs say, for change and to lead. He comes triumphant.

title: Making a McCain Town Hall Meeting
description: John McCain gets another try at New Hampshire, where he won in 2000 by 18 percentage points.

title: Oh-ba-ma Fires It Up
description: MILFORD, N.H.  Spontaneous combustion! Were here at the New Hampshire Democratic Partys big dinner and out of the masses of 3,000 people, who have been listening politely to Dennis Kucinich, Hillary Clinton and Bill Richardson, comes a huge surge of people toward the stage for the next speaker  Barack Obama.

title: Leno Faces Writers Guild Action Over Monologues
description: The restrictions that the striking Writers Guild of America has placed on late-night television hosts to keep them from writing material for their shows continued to have no impact on the leading late-night star, Jay Leno, who planned once again to write and perform a comedy monologue for NBCs Tonight Show Friday night.

title: A Campaign Retools to Seek Second Clinton Comeback
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have been in career-threatening scrapes before, but never quite like the one they face in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, when nothing less than their would-be dynasty will be on the line.

title: Firehouse Dispute Raises Racial Tension in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS  An African-American firefighters complaint that he found a stuffed monkey hanging by its neck in his firehouse last month has become a stark reminder of this citys troubled racial legacy.

title: Anti-Abortion Bill Imperils Italys Governing Coalition
description: ROME (Bloomberg News)  The Vatican is backing an Italian opposition proposal to make it harder to end pregnancies, threatening to open new divisions in Prime Minister Romano Prodis coalition.

title: Ferocious Storm Punishes Northern California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A fierce Pacific storm howled into Northern California on Friday, bringing a treacherous mix of hurricane-force winds, torrential rains for millions of residents and blizzard conditions for many others.

title: Taking a Veteran Approach to the Job of a Young Lifetime
description: Brad Stevens walked off the court earlier this season after a victory at Evansville looking as if he had just stepped from the back room at the dry cleaners. His suit had hardly a wrinkle, and not a strand of his neatly trimmed brown hair appeared out of place.

title: If Giants Feel the Pressure, They Sure Dont Show It
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As Coach Tom Coughlin slid into the scrum of reporters gathered for his postpractice remarks Friday, he saw a reporter who had needed medical attention during the workout because of dizziness.

title: Fruitcake Might Be a Better Gift
description: WITH the holiday season now behind us, the nation is awash in gift cards. The Tower Group, a research firm, estimates that gift card sales totaled $97 billion in 2007, well above sales of $83 billion in 2006.

title: The Obama Phenomenon
description: Manchester, N.H.

title: Job Cuts at Sun-Times
description: The Chicago Sun-Times, the flagship newspaper of the Sun-Times Media Group, has proposed cutting 35 union newsroom positions, or about 19 percent of the papers nonmanagement news jobs. The union has two weeks to make a counterproposal and plans to ask Sun-Times management to offer a buyout package, said Misha Davenport, a features writer and co-chairwoman of the Chicago Newspaper Guild. Sun-Times Media, formerly Hollinger International, is under pressure from shareholders to sell the company after revenue fell 10 percent to $279 million last year through Sept. 30.

title: Aetna and Colonoscopies
description: To the Editor:

title: 2nd-Place Edwards Rallies for Next Vote
description: NASHUA, N.H.  In his last days on the campaign trail in Iowa, John Edwards closed his stump speech with a cry that often brought audiences to their feet, clapping and cheering.
