description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the motivations of the C.I.A. in taping some interrogations and then destroying the tapes misidentified the position held by John A. Rizzo at the intelligence agency. He serves as the acting general counsel; he was never confirmed by the Senate as general counsel. (The White House withdrew his nomination because of mounting opposition from Democrats over Mr. Rizzos role in the harsh interrogation of C.I.A. detainees.) (Go to Article)

title: Heads Up, Ms. Bradshaw, New Foursomes in Town
description: This may not be such a good time for the rich and powerful.

title: The Smithsonian, Again
description: W. Richard West Jr., the founding director of the Smithsonian Institutions National Museum of the American Indian, spent $48,500 in museum funds to commission a portrait of himself, The Washington Post reported. The painting, by Burton Silverman, a New York artist whose portraits have appeared on the cover of Time and in The New Yorker, hangs in the patrons lounge of the museum. Mr. West, 64, whose last day on the Smithsonian payroll was Monday, also spent more than $250,000 over four years on travel and hotels, the Smithsonian has confirmed. Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California and chairwoman of the Rules Committee, have asked for independent investigations of the expenses. The Smithsonian said it did not comment on former employees. Similar questions about personal spending by the Smithsonians secretary, Lawrence M. Small, led to his resignation last March.

title: Juvenile Detention Trap
description: One way to lessen the chance that troubled young people grow up to be full-fledged criminals is to send them to community-based counseling and probation programs instead of to detention centers where they are often traumatized and inducted into a life of crime. The community-based programs are less expensive than detention and more effective when it comes to cutting recidivism. But states and localities are often hampered by policies that provide perverse financial incentives for sending young people to the lockup.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the motivations of the C.I.A. in taping some interrogations and then destroying the tapes misidentified the position held by John A. Rizzo at the intelligence agency. He serves as the acting general counsel; he was never confirmed by the Senate as general counsel. (The White House withdrew his nomination because of mounting opposition from Democrats over Mr. Rizzos role in the harsh interrogation of C.I.A. detainees.)

title: Proposal to Better Unite City Leaves Dresden Divided
description: DRESDEN, Germany  The battle to prevent construction of a proposed bridge in this historic city has embroiled everything from a tiny endangered bat, to the countrys reigning literary lion, Gnter Grass, to activists who are staging a round-the-clock occupation of a centuries-old beech tree.

title: North Korea Says Earlier Disclosure Was Enough
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Friday that it had already explained enough about its nuclear programs to meet a deadline for declaring its nuclear activities, saying the information was in a nuclear declaration it prepared in November and gave to the United States.

title: Daring to Believe, Blacks Savor Obama Victory
description: For Sadou Brown in a Los Angeles suburb, the decisive victory of Senator Barack Obama in Iowa was a moment to show his 14-year-old son what is possible.

title: Baftas Short List of Films
description: The British Academy of Film and Television Arts has announced its nominees for the best foreign film of 2007, the BBC reported. They are: Lust, Caution, La Vie en Rose, The Lives of Others,  The Kite Runner and The Diving Bell and the Butterfly. The Bafta ceremony will be held on Feb. 10 at the Royal Opera House in London.

title: Nets Beat the Bobcats and Get Back to .500
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets are hot, relatively speaking.

title: Injured Window Washer Has Operation on Spine
description: A window washer who has made a surprising recovery from a 47-story fall underwent another operation on Friday, and the surgeon said that everything went smoothly.

title: This Round, Accusations of Spying and Thievery
description: Yuan Cao spent a weekend in late September 2006 in front of a computer at Institutional Credit Partners, a private investment bank where he had worked for five weeks. That Sunday, he moved computer files onto two flash drives  standard backups, he would later maintain  signed off, and left the office. Two days later, he quit by e-mail message.

title: To Friends and Family, a Fallen Firefighter Was Johnny Nice Guy
description: Beneath the freshly hung black- and-purple bunting on Engine Company 249s firehouse in Brooklyn on Friday morning, the firefighters commanding officer summed up the departments latest loss in six words.

title: Huckabee Moves to New Hampshire, With Tweaks to His Message
description: HENNIKER, N.H.  Fresh from his victory in the Iowa caucuses, Mike Huckabee has to be considered a serious contender for the Republican presidential nomination. But that has not sobered up his distinctive Bible Belt-meets-Borscht Belt act on the stump.

title: The Company With the Biggest Little Black Book
description: EVERY phone call, fax and personal computer connection in North America depends on the services of a little-known company called NeuStar, based in Sterling, Va. The company manages a directory of 500 million telephone numbers in the United States and Canada, says Jeffrey E. Ganek, its chairman and chief executive. The company, a spinoff from Lockheed Martin, had an estimated $430 million in sales in 2007.

title: James Costigan, Writer of Prestige TV, Is Dead
description: James Costigan, an Emmy-winning writer for television who worked with some of the leading actors of the postwar years, among them Katharine Hepburn, Laurence Olivier, Joanne Woodward and Paul Newman, died on Dec. 19 at his home on Bainbridge Island, Wash. He was believed to have been in his late 70s or early 80s.

title: The (Possible) Perils of Being Thirsty While Being Green
description: I HAVE the usual New Years resolutions  exercise more, lose weight, be a nicer person. I also hope to find out if I am inadvertently poisoning my children.

title: Warner Backs Blu-ray, Tilting DVD Battle
description: LOS ANGELES  The high-definition DVD war is all but over.

title: China Censors a Film, Then Bans It Entirely
description: China has pulled Li Yus Lost in Beijing, a movie whose sexually explicit scenes were already censored, from theaters and banned its producer from the film business for two years, The Associated Press reported. The ruling against Lost in Beijing accused the filmmakers of publishing unapproved pornographic scenes from the movie on the Internet and on DVDs, the official China News Service Web site reported. The films producer, Fang Li, said he believed that Chinese officials faced political pressure to act amid the rapid spread of uncensored versions of Lost in Beijing and another sexually explicit film, Ang Lees Lust, Caution, on the Internet and in pirated DVDs.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 8 of Arts & Leisure this weekend about Jock Sotos transition to teaching dance after a career as principal dancer with the New York City Ballet misstates the given name of his father. He is Jose Soto, not Joseph.

title: McCain May Benefit From Huckabees Jolt to G.O.P.
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mike Huckabees defeat of Mitt Romney in the Iowa caucuses jolted a Republican Party establishment already distressed about the state of its presidential field.

title: Rehabilitating Libya
description: We are all for forgiveness and second acts, but Libyas sordid human rights record and continuing police state tactics should not be forgotten. Businesses  and their government backers  rushing to procure contracts with the oil-rich state would prefer to ignore whats happening on the ground in Libya. President Bush and other democratic leaders cannot, and must keep pressing Tripoli for change.

title: Noontime Web Video Revitalizes Lunch at Desk
description: In cubicles across the country, lunchtime has become the new prime time, as workers click aside their spreadsheets to watch videos on YouTube, news highlights on CNN.com or other Web offerings.

title: Congress Calls on Clemens and 4 Others to Testify
description: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens and his former personal trainer Brian McNamee have been asked to testify under oath before a Congressional committee Jan. 16 in what promises to be a compelling showdown.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Friday about the pressure facing Ohio State as it prepares to play for the college football national championship after losing in last years title game misstated the teams 2006 and 2007 regular-season records. They were 12-0 and 11-1  not 11-0 and 10-1.

title: A Single Mother of 5Wants to Become Somebody
description: Since the age of 14, and for most of her adulthood, Cynthia Lora has lived in other peoples homes.

title: The Appetite for Securities Turns Less Hearty
description: TO some on Wall Street, the last half of 2007 may have had the feel of a buyers strike. Financial products that had experienced rapidly growing demand suddenly became all but unsalable.

title: In Race for Gossip, TV Shows Turn to Blogs
description: Are Joel and Nicole splitting up? Will Britney get her babies back? OmiGOD!

title: It Takes a Family (to Break a Glass Ceiling)
description: Washington

title: Padilla Sues Former U.S. Lawyer Over Detention
description: Jose Padilla, the American citizen who was held in military detention for more than three years as an enemy combatant, filed a lawsuit Friday against a former Justice Department lawyer who helped provide the legal justifications for what the suit says was Mr. Padillas unconstitutional confinement and gross physical and psychological abuse.

title: Flyer Accused of Biting Hand in the Devils Shutout Victory
description: NEWARK, Jan. 4  The middle finger on Devils center Travis Zajacs left hand had been stitched and was wrapped with tape late Friday. Such an injury among hockey players is common, but the cause of this one was highly unusual.

title: Centennial Celebration for a Conductor
description: Salzburg, Austria, which was the host for Mozarts 250th-birthday celebrations in 2006, will commemorate the 100th birthday of another famous native son, the conductor Herbert von Karajan, above. The festivities will begin with a concert by the Berlin Philharmonic on Saturday at the Grosses Festspielhaus hall in Salzburg, Agence France-Presse reported. The orchestra, which von Karajan conducted from 1955 until his death in 1989, will also play in Berlin, Paris and Tokyo, and there will be a Karajan Festival in Lucerne, Switzerland, among other festivities in 2008. The birthday itself, on April 5, will be honored with a ceremony in the Mozart House museum in Salzburg. Von Karajan joined the Nazi Party in 1935, a move that greatly helped his career until he fled Germany for Milan in 1944. He was the favorite conductor of Hermann Goering, Hitlers second in command. After the war the Allies banned him from conducting. The ban was lifted in 1947.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Dec. 10 about the ways New York has changed in the 20 years since the publication of the Tom Wolfe novel Bonfire of the Vanities, which depicted a city in decline, referred imprecisely to the Tawana Brawley case, an example of the racial tension of the times. Although a special prosecutor had been appointed to lead the investigation of claims that Ms. Brawley, a black teenager, had been sexually assaulted by white men, the prosecution did not later collapse because there was in fact no prosecution of any suspect. (A grand jury investigation concluded that there was no evidence that Ms. Brawley had been sexually assaulted.)

title: Paring Down Parking Permits, and Raising a Fuss
description: When the city announced plans to crack down on the abuse of parking permits issued to city employees, Christopher Stephens felt a shiver of furious recognition.

title: Death Is on the Line; Can You Hear It Now?
description: Early in One Missed Call a snooty cat is yanked into a fish pond by a disembodied arm, unexpectedly following her owner to a watery grave. The moment is wickedly humorous and suggests a movie thats unwilling to take itself too seriously. If only.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Dec. 28 about Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister of Pakistan, misstated the location of her detention at the time her father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the former president and prime minister, was hanged by the military authorities in April 1979. It was a deserted police training camp at Sihala, Pakistan, a few miles from the Rawalpindi District Jail where her father was hanged; she was not under house arrest.

title: Drawing a New Map for Journalism in the Mideast
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates

title: N.F.L. Offenses Undergo a Thaw in Thinking
description: PITTSBURGH  A video of the Jacksonville Jaguars December victory here has played on a loop at the Steelers headquarters this week, a continuous reminder of the teams only home loss this season. The result was startling enough. But one look at the snow, the chopped-up field and the 147-yard pounding by Jaguars running back Fred Taylor underscores the world-turned-upside-down subtext to these playoffs: the geographic rules of football do not apply.

title: In Obamas Victory, Clues to the Challenges Ahead
description: DES MOINES  As he accepted his victory in the Iowa caucuses Thursday night, Senator Barack Obama presented his presidential candidacy as a vessel to wipe away partisan divisions, transcend the boundaries of race and build a coalition for change that stretches through red states and blue states.

title: Unexceptional Events Set Off Fatal Blaze
description: A series of minor, seemingly unrelated events  a stove left on to warm an apartment, a boy waving a toy wrapper over the flames, and a self-closing door that got stuck on a rug  helped create the blinding maze of black smoke and oven-hot heat that claimed the life of a veteran fire lieutenant in Brooklyn on Thursday night, officials said Friday.

title: Recruiting Intensifies for Cant-Miss Prospect
description: SAN ANTONIO  The call log on Terrelle Pryors cellphone doubles as a list of coaches from college footballs blue-blood programs.

title: Fears on Inflation and Jobs Give 2008 a Stumbling Start
description: Fears that a recession is imminent  or perhaps has already begun  rocked the major stock markets this week as anxiety-addled investors staggered through the first days of 2008.

title: Glenn W. Ferguson, Former Ambassador to Kenya, Dies at 78
description: Glenn W. Ferguson, a former ambassador to Kenya, the president or chancellor of three universities and, for a brief time in the 1980s, the president of Lincoln Center, died at his home in Santa Fe, N.M., on Dec. 20. Mr. Ferguson, who held other influential positions during his career, including head of Radio Free Europe, was 78.

title: Lawyer Is Suspended as Conduct Is Criticized
description: A Brooklyn lawyer has been suspended from practicing as a state panel investigates her handling of the estate of John L. Phillips Jr.  the so-called kung fu judge and the owner of the Slave Theater in Bedford-Stuyvesant  while she was acting as his legal guardian.

title: Hedging Their Way to Billions
description: REMEMBER the colossal salaries of hedge fund managers  when they needed to earn at least $240 million just to be included among the 25 wealthiest in 2006? Well, those numbers may now look puny, especially at the top of the range.

title: Three Guitars and Plenty of Blues
description: Hubert Sumlin, now 76, is used to playing concerts like Howlin for Hubert, at the Jazz Standard through this weekend. He was the guitarist who played the silvery leads on Howlin Wolfs great Chicago blues records of the 1950s and 60s. On Thursday every tune was from Howlin Wolfs songbook, and Wolfs name scarcely needed to be mentioned. Its a Hubert Sumlin gig now.

title: Liam OGallagher, 90, a Beat Avant-Gardist and Teacher, Dies
description: Liam OGallagher, an avant-garde sound artist, painter and teacher whose San Francisco studio became an early gathering place for Beat writers and poets in the 1950s, died Dec. 4 at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: New H.I.V. Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Dec. 23 about a newly declassified plan by J. Edgar Hoover, when he was director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to suspend the writ of habeas corpus and imprison Americans suspected of disloyalty misstated the process by which the Internal Security Act of 1950, also known as the McCarran Act, became law. President Truman vetoed the measure as unconstitutional, but Congress voted overwhelmingly to override his veto and the measure then became law; Truman did not sign the bill.

title: Nudged by Bush, Israel Talks of Removing Illegal Outposts
description: JERUSALEM  Pressed by President Bush to keep promises to destroy illegal settler outposts, Israeli leaders said Friday that they hoped to take action after his visit to the region next week.

title: City Ballets Greatest-Hit Makers Get Help From Some Old Masters
description: Does any other ballet company in the world come even close to New York City Ballet for the sheer quantity of repertory it presents? The first four weeks of its winter season introduce eight full programs, three of them starting this coming week. Balletgoers in most other cities of the world, wildly grateful if their local companies can open more than four programs in a single month, have long been justly envious.

title: At Full Strength, Dorsey Is Ready for His Next Step
description: NEW ORLEANS  As the final weeks flipped off the college football calendar, Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey slipped out of the spotlight.

title: Intel Quits Effort to Get Computers to Children
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A frail partnership between Intel and the One Laptop Per Child educational computing group was undone last month in part by an Intel saleswoman: She tried to persuade a Peruvian official to drop the countrys commitment to buy a quarter-million of the organizations laptops in favor of Intel PCs.

title: Supporter of Democrats Is Sentenced in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Norman Hsu, the shamed political powerbroker and Democratic donor, was sentenced Friday to a three-year prison term by a California judge in connection with a 1992 plea in a fraud case in which investors lost millions of dollars in an elaborate Ponzi scheme.

title: Donors Bring Big Telescope a Step Closer
description: A project to build a digital camera of cosmic dimensions on a mountaintop in Chile has received a $30 million boost from a pair of software moguls and philanthropists.

title: Romney Embraces Theme Used to Beat Him
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Having barely slept after landing at 3 a.m. on Friday, weary advisers for Mitt Romney gathered a few hours later in a conference room in the Courtyard Marriott in Portsmouth to regroup after the resounding defeat Mike Huckabee handed them in Iowa.

title: How Long Will Profits Slump?
description: THE housing slump and credit squeeze have affected the broader economy and are finally having an impact where it matters most to stock owners: the bottom line. After increasing at double-digit rates for most of the last five years, corporate profits are about to decline for the second straight quarter, if analysts are correct.

title: Man Charged in Wifes Death Acknowledged Having Affairs
description: The Chappaqua lawyer accused of murdering his wife on the side of a darkened Westchester road admitted he sent flowers to his longtime mistress on her birthday in November 2006  the day of the shooting  according to the details of an indictment made public on Friday.

title: Bequeathing, With Strings Attached
description: ONCE only for the superrich, dynasty trusts now provide a way for the rest of us to leave money to loved ones, preserve wealth for future generations and even control how an inheritance is used once donors die.

title: Bearing Up
description: Juneau, Alaska

title: Japan Prisons Begin Adapting to Elderly
description: TOKYO  Japan will build wards exclusively for elderly inmates at three prisons to deal with the steep rise in the prison population 60 and older, the Justice Ministry announced Friday.

title: A Tribute Followed by Precision and Fire
description: Had it gone exactly as planned, the New York Philharmonics concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night would have seemed a flashy, almost carefree welcome to the new year. Along with what turned out to be a winning performance of the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto by a promising young violinist, Viviane Hagner, the program included a Mozart concerto played by the orchestras principal hornist, Philip Myers, as well as Mendelssohns nimble Midsummer Nights Dream Overture and Elgars mammoth Enigma Variations.

title: Knicks Stay Close, but Spurs Show How to Win
description: SAN ANTONIO  The difference between the defending N.B.A. champions and the team that qualifies as their polar opposite seemed remarkably small at times Friday night. But the true gap between the San Antonio Spurs and the Knicks showed up in the final seconds of a tight game that ended the way one would expect.

title: What Would Hillary Rodham Do?
description: Des Moines

title: First G.O.P. Delegate Goes to Romney
description: CASPER, Wyo.  Mitt Romney won the first delegate elected to the Republican National Convention Saturday when Albany County chose Tammy Johnson as its representative to the convention in Minneapolis-St. Paul next September. She defeated a Fred Thompson supporter and an uncommitted candidate at the county convention in Laramie. Eleven more delegates were to be elected throughout the day in other counties.

title: Lottery Numbers
Interior Secretary Rejects Catskill Casino Plans
description: The federal government rejected plans for two casinos in the Catskill Mountains on Friday, saying that the reservations of the two tribes that submitted the plans were too far from where the casinos would be built.

title: In Global Battle on AIDS, Bush Creates Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  Dr. Jean W. Pape did not know what to expect in early January 2003, when he slipped away from his work treating AIDS patients in Haiti and flew to Washington for a secret meeting with President Bush.

title: Put Buyers First? What a Concept
description: My Christmas story  the one Ive been telling and retelling these last 10 days  began on Friday, Dec. 21.

title: Music Business Dealings
description: Radiohead has signed with iTunes to allow its latest album to be downloaded from the online music store, Agence France-Presse reported. The band was one of the few major acts not to have its songs on the service. In October Radiohead left the EMI record company after its contract expired. The band made its new album, In Rainbows, above, available on its Web site, radiohead.com, asking fans to pay whatever they thought it was worth. Radiohead has not said how many times the album was downloaded or the average price paid. ... The concert producer Live Nation said it had reached a two-year deal with the Jonas Brothers band, under which that New Jersey group would play more than 140 concerts around the world, starting in Tucson on Jan. 31, Reuters reported. In October Live Nation lured Madonna from Warner Brothers with a multi-album touring and merchandising partnership.

title: Arrest in Shooting of Queens Boy Who Answered Door
description: The authorities arrested a suspect in the attack on an 11-year-old boy who was shot after he answered the front door of his home in Queens on Sunday, the district attorneys office said Friday.

title: Tracking and Adoring Lions in the Desert
description: Its hard to say which is the more arresting sight in The Desert Lions: the lions themselves, sleek and playful and deadly against the astounding backdrop of the Namib Desert, or Flip Stander, the man whos there to save them. Tip-toeing, storklike, across the rocky desert in his bare feet or bending down to sniff the paws of a tranquilized lioness  a sweet, musky smell, he sighs  Dr. Stander, Cambridge educated, fiercely dedicated and a little loony, is the real star of this episode of the PBS series Nature.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Dec. 27 about the sentencing of six French aid workers who were convicted in Chad of trying to kidnap 103 children in a campaign to aid Sudanese orphans misstated the outcome of negotiations by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France during a trip to Chad in early November. He negotiated the release of three French journalists and four Spanish flight attendants, but did not secure the release of the aid workers.

title: Redskins Rally (Around Gibbs) to Salvage Season
description: ASHBURN, Va.  Joe Gibbs was wondering how in the world he had ever won three Super Bowl titles and earned a place in the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and he wanted his Washington Redskins to know it. He had just called back-to-back timeouts to ice Buffalo kicker Rian Lindell, not knowing it would warrant a 15-yard penalty for unsportsmanlike conduct.

title: Time-Traveling Musical
description: Tommy Tune, right, will direct Turn of the Century, a new musical comedy written by Rick Elice and Marshall Brickman, the writers of Jersey Boys, at the Goodman Theater in Chicago, The Associated Press reported. The basic premise involves a young songwriter-piano player and his girl singer who find themselves through mysterious, supernatural, Twilight Zone-ish activities thrown back to the turn of the century, the 20th century, said Robert Falls, artistic director of the Goodman. The score will consist of standards by Irving Berlin, Rodgers and Hart, George Gershwin, Rodgers and Hammerstein and others, Mr. Tune said. The show is scheduled to open in September or October. The Goodmans 2008-9 season will also feature Brian Dennehy in a revival of Eugene ONeills Desire Under the Elms.

title: Judge Imposes Stricter Rules on Navy to Protect Marine Life
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge has ordered the Navy to adopt stringent new safeguards intended to improve protection of whales and dolphins during its sonar training exercises off Southern California.

title: The Political Road Ahead
description: It is dangerous to draw too many conclusions from the Iowa caucuses  a telegenic display of activism by a tiny slice of Americans.

title: Scoring One for the Defense and Snagging a Teams Title
description: The Flight A Swiss Teams on Dec. 28 at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Midtown Manhattan was won by Carl Berenbaum of Elkins Park, Pa.; Julian Heicklen of Teaneck, N.J.; Brett Kunin of West Orange, N.J.; and Dennis Thompson of Lake Hiawatha, N.J.

title: Expanding Into Wind Energy
description: Scottish and Southern Energy, a British utility, agreed to buy the Irish wind farm operator Airtricity for 1.83 billion euros ($2.7 billion) in cash to add to its production of renewable energy. In the deal, Scottish and Southern said it would also take over 375 million euros of debt. The European Union has called for 20 percent of all energy, including transport fuels and heating, to come from renewable sources by 2020. Airtricity, Irelands largest wind farm operator, has been expanding operations in Britain and last year won approval to install turbines off the coast of England. Scottish and Southern, based in Perth, Scotland, said the deal would probably be completed in the first quarter.

title: On TV, Celebrities Trump Politics
description: NBCs Celebrity Apprentice won Thursday nights ratings among adults 18 to 49. Nielsen estimated that the premiere of the latest edition of the reality show, with celebrities including the boxer Lennox Lewis, below, had 11 million viewers in the 9 oclock hour, an improvement of almost 2 million over last seasons debut. NBC tied Fox for No. 1 over all, leading at 8 with Deal or No Deal (13.3 million) but trailing at 10 with ER (9.6 million). CBS ranked third, despite drawing the largest audience of the night with a repeat of CSI at 9 (13.5 million). ABC was a distant fourth.

title: Hasselbeck Quietly Proves He Is One of Elite
description: KIRKLAND, Wash.  At the Seahawks holiday party last month, teammates dragged Matt Hasselbeck onto the dance floor. A crowd gathered around.

title: Sentence for Jones Could Be Longer
description: Despite a plea to the judge for a light sentence, the former Olympic track star Marion Jones may be facing more prison time than she expected for lying about her steroid use and involvement in a check-fraud scheme.

title: Top Runners Are Caught in Kenyas Rising Violence
description: Lornah Kiplagats afternoon run is out of the question. Even though her training center in Iten, Kenya, is only a mile from her house, the short trip is more daunting than any race.

title: Embracing His Moment, Obama Preaches Hope in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H.  Senator Barack Obama hops up to the stage in that hip-mod gray suit of his, clapping along with the audience on Friday, clapping for himself, clapping for this moment. He gazes at 1,200 people in overcoats and woolen hats and snow boots and asks for a show of hands.

title: Britney Spears in Hospital After Standoff
description: LOS ANGELES  Britney Spears was strapped to a gurney late Thursday night after a three-hour standoff involving her two toddler sons, Kevin Federline, a court-appointed child monitor, police officers, paramedics and a locked bathroom door. She was rolled out of her home in the hills near Mulholland Drive as photographers swarmed and helicopters hovered, and taken to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center for her own welfare, as one police spokeswoman put it.

title: Opposition Seeks New Vote as Violence Ebbs in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  If the price of cabbage is any indicator, things here in Kenyas capital may be edging back to normal.

title: Hunting a Tribe of Minimalists on the Streets of the Upper East Side
description: Unlike the sleek white boxes of Chelsea, the town house galleries of the Upper East Side tend to be small, old and charmingly idiosyncratic. Wooden floors creak, antique moldings and multiple doorways eat up wall space, and ghosts of residents past lurk in the shadows.

title: Justices to Decide if Rape of a Child Merits Death
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether the Constitution allows the death penalty for the rape of a child.

title: On Postcards and Even in Rice, Portraits of a Beloved Saint
description: If youre searching for a reason to visit the too often overlooked Hispanic Society of America in Upper Manhattan, a striking installation of the artist Francis Alss collection of St. Fabiola portraits will do just fine. The exhibition is the work of the Dia Art Foundation and is the first of three exhibitions that it is organizing with the Hispanic Society. Dia has been without a New York City exhibition space since 2004, when it closed its building in Chelsea after the draining effort of creating Dia:Beacon, the vast upstate outpost that it opened in 2003. It is currently searching for a new foothold in the city.

title: In Chinese Factories, Lost Fingers and Low Pay
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Nearly a decade after some of the most powerful companies in the world  often under considerable criticism and consumer pressure  began an effort to eliminate sweatshop labor conditions in Asia, worker abuse is still commonplace in many of the Chinese factories that supply Western companies, according to labor rights groups.

title: A Film Comic Who Portrayed Lifes Drama With His Feet
description: This years Dance on Camera Festival documents modern dance in Montreal, looks at choreography in pop music videos and uses film to extend the boundaries of human movement  all lively but not that unusual for the festival, now 36. But there is one oddity: The Choreographic Moves of Jacques Tati, which focuses on that great French comic actor and director and his first feature, Jour de Fte.

title: Footnotes
description: Dennis OHare and Michael Cerveris will star in Red Bull Theaters Revelation Readings presentation of Brechts Edward II on Monday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater in Manhattan. Information: (212) 279-4200. ... The soprano Dsella Lrusdttir will make her New York recital debut on Feb. 20 at Merkin Concert Hall. Information: (212) 501-3330 or kaufman-center.org.

title: DNA Suggests That Boy in Chvez Rescue Effort Was Long Gone From Jungle Rebels
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A DNA analysis released on Friday indicated that a 3-year-old boy born in the Colombian jungle to a woman kidnapped by Marxist guerrillas may have been living near his relatives, without their knowledge, in a foster home in Bogot, Colombia.

title: For Now, Musharraf Has Muzzled Legal Critics in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Not so long ago, Muneer A. Malik was often photographed sitting on the roof of a Mitsubishi Pajero, fists raised, showered with rose petals and thronged by supporters as he accompanied the embattled Supreme Court chief justice on protest cavalcades that became the starkest symbol of opposition to President Pervez Musharrafs rule.

title: Its Time for Roger Clemens to Face the Legal Posse
description: The posse appears to be gaining ground on Roger Clemens.

title: Saturday Vote Tests Georgian Leader
description: TBILISI, Georgia  The pro-Western president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, was leading in the polls ahead of an election on Saturday that he hoped would restore his mandate to govern after he ordered a police crackdown on protesters and declared a state of emergency here in November.

title: Health Benefits and Retirees
description: A new federal regulation allows employers to reduce or eliminate health benefits for retirees when they turn 65 and become eligible for Medicare. Although that will cause distress for some, it is a welcome step that could help slow the deterioration of employment-based health insurance. It seems likely that the new rule will help far more people than it hurts.

title: Like Knicks, Randolph Cannot Shake Troubles
description: SAN ANTONIO  Zach Randolph was suspended Friday, an indignity that might not even rank among his top 10 in his short Knicks career.

title: Unemployment Sounds Warning About Economy
description: The unemployment rate surged to 5 percent in December as the economy added a meager 18,000 jobs, the smallest monthly increase in four years, the Labor Department reported on Friday.

title: Booker Is Losing 2 Top Officials, 18 Months Into His Newark Administration
description: NEWARK  There are two notable details that distinguish the otherwise unremarkable office occupied by Bo Kemp, the citys business administrator, who announced his resignation on Friday.

title: Alabama Banks Loan Losses
description: Regions Financial, Alabamas biggest bank, will quadruple its reserve for loan losses, to $360 million, for the fourth quarter because of slowing real estate markets in Florida and Georgia. Regions moved $900 million of its $7.5 billion in loans to residential builders into a special asset pool because of slumping demand for housing, particularly in Miami and Atlanta. The Birmingham, Ala., bank raised its provision for loan losses from $90 million as of Sept. 30, to $360 million, and said it expected losses to increase throughout 2008.

title: A Roosevelt Island Ruin Sinks Further Into Decay
description: The hauntingly abandoned, Gothically forbidding Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island  perhaps New York Citys most romantic ruin  turned far less romantic and even more ruined last month when part of its crumbling gray stone facade fell to the ground.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Dec. 19 about the record producer Joel Dorn, using information provided by a spokesman for a record company with which he was affiliated, referred incorrectly to a survivor, Faye Rosen. She was Mr. Dorns wife, not his companion. The obituary also misstated the relationship of the recording executive Nesuhi Ertegun, whom Mr. Dorn wrote to as a young man, to Atlantic Records in its early days. Mr. Ertegun joined Atlantic after it was founded by his brother, Ahmet Ertegun, and Herb Abramson. He did not found it with his brother.

title: Japan: Prisons to Adapt to Older Inmates
description: Japan will build wards exclusively for older inmates at three prisons to deal with the rise in the prison population 60 and older, the Justice Ministry announced. The wards will include the kind of ramps, handrails and other fixtures found in Onomichi Prison, in western Japan, now the countrys only prison with a ward for older inmates. The number of older people convicted of mostly nonviolent crimes, like shoplifting, has risen sharply because of a breakdown in family ties and a weakening of the social safety net. From 2000 to 2006, while the total population of Japanese 60 and older increased by 17 percent, prisoners in that age group swelled by 87 percent.

title: More Confusion for Frockmakers
description: So it appears that none of the nominees or presenters for the Golden Globes will have to worry about what to wear on Jan. 13. Alan Rosenberg, the president of the Screen Actors Guild, said members would not cross the picket line to attend the awards event, at the Beverly Hilton. There had been some thought, or hope, that the ceremony would go on, without being televised, and we could at least see the peacock display and the nominees could have their moment. But of course that would mean a tremendous loss of revenue. Anyway, it looks like Wanda McDaniel of Armani was on the money when she characterized the appointments she has scheduled with actresses for this weekend as faux fittings. Fashion houses and stylists are going through the motions. But what choice do they have? Come tomorrow or Monday, it could be a different story. The SAG statement, on the face of it, was pretty blunt. The next move seems to belong to NBC. Meanwhile, designers are facing deadlines of their own: the Paris couture starts in two weeks, and the N.Y. shows on Feb. 1.

title: Respond to Todays Column: What Would Hillary Rodham Do?
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Jan. 5 column.

title: Daily Show And Colbert Report Seek Agreement With Guild
description: The Daily Show With Jon Stewart and The Colbert Report with Stephen Colbert have been seeking to make their own deal with the Writers Guild for an agreement similar to the one Worldwide Pants was able to reach, Bill Carter reports in Saturdays Times.

title: The View of the Giants From Florida
description: Lets take a look at what they are saying about the Giants down south as the first-round playoff game against the Buccaneers nears. It has been a turnaround season for Tampa Bay, and Chris Harry of The Orlando Sentinel examines what went right and what went wrong, saying that the signing of quarterback Jeff Garcia was only part of a collective excavation project. In a slideshow preview of the game, The Tampa Tribune says the Giants are the Buccaneers toughest challenge since playing the Colts in Week 5. The Buccaneers defense is facing a tall task in stopping Plaxico Burress, according to The Tribune. The St. Petersburg Times says the tall order for Tampa is running back Brandon Jacobs. Similarly, the Buccaneers Web site puts the focus on the battle in the trenches.

title: Mounting Decay at Smallpox Hospital
description: As a plan to stabilize the ruins of the Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island progresses, so does the decay of the landmark building.

title: The Republican Debate in New Hampshire
description: Following is the transcript of the Republican presidential debate at St. Anselm College in Manchester, N.H., as transcribed by Federal News Service.

title: The Democratic Debate in New Hampshire
description: The following is the transcript of the Democratic presidential debate at St. Anselm College in Manchester, N.H., as transcribed by Federal News Service.

title: Jihad and Jew-Hatred
description: The Muslim Brotherhood and Palestine

title: The Science of Toga Parties
description: Field work can be hell. But thanks to the dogged researchers who attended 66 college parties in Southern California, now at last it can revealed:

title: WJC Bronze Final: Russia 4, U.S.A. 2.
description: Review the play-by-play commentary of the World Junior Championship bronze medal match, as it happened at the CEZ Arena in Pardubice, Czech Republic. Mark Pargas described the action.

title: Rudy Rides!
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  He took a ride  after all.

title: N.H. Forecast: Debate Day
description: Countdown: 3 days until the primary!

title: The Early Word: Sequels, Classics and Indie Hits
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tries to shoot The Comeback Kid: The Sequel, her chief rival in New Hampshire is trying to make sure his debut feature actually makes it to the big screen. The Timess Michael Powell is on the trail with Senator Barack Obama:

title: Clinton Greets Foxs OReilly
description: PENACOOK, N.H.  In a shift from her failed campaign strategy in Iowa, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton dispensed with her stump speech at her first campaign event here Saturday morning and threw open the floor for questions.

title: Romney Rolls Out Change Message, Too
description: DERRY, N.H.Mitt Romney appeared energized before several hundred people at a gymnasium this morning, campaigning with a transformed stump speech centered on change.

title: Clinton Defends Vote on Iran Resolution
description: PENACOOK, N.H.  At a campaign Q & A session with hundreds of voters here Saturday morning, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton moved forcefully to correct the record about her vote in September on Irans Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps  and asserted that her enemies were spreading misinformation about that vote.

title: Photos: N.H. Crowds
description: Related: Clinton Greets Foxs OReilly

title: The Spouse Is Out and About
description: Bow, N.H.  Speaking at a small rally at a high school here on Saturday morning, former president Bill Clinton was trying to make the point that his wife, Senator Hillary Clinton, could work with Republicans.

title: Ratings: Cable Networks Get Their Iowa Boost
description: The cable news channels treated the Iowa caucus like a full-fledged presidential election, and viewers noticed. Thursdays special reports garnered nearly six million viewers, two million more than the 2004 caucus coverage did, according to Nielsen Media Research.

title: WJC Gold Final: Canada 3, Sweden 2, OT
description: The play-by-play commentary of the World Junior Championship gold medal match, as it happened at the CEZ Arena in Pardubice, Czech Republic. Mark Pargas described the action live from the bunker in New York.

title: ABC Prepares for Saturdays Back-to-Back New Hampshire Debates
description: ABCs pair of presidential debates, scheduled to take place Saturday evening in Manchester, N.H., are special for several reasons.

title: Saturday Kickoff: Aloha for Jones?
description: June Jones is reportedly meeting with officials from S.M.U. today and is expected to be offered the Mustangs coaching job, according to Stephen Tsai of the Honolulu Advertiser.

title: McCain on Tour in New Hampshire
description: John McCain has hosted numerous town hall meetings in the state in the past year, and seems to revel in letting people take a crack at him.

title: If Its Saturday, It Must Be New Hampshire
description: DERRY, N.H.Mitt Romney, no doubt weary from the sprint to the finish in Iowa and now New Hampshire, seemed to momentarily forget where he was towards the end of his speech here this morning, appearing to confuse his New Hampshire audience with Iowans.

title: Etheridge Misses Kucinich
description: Melissa Etheridge gave us a call today, just to, ya know, chat about politics.

title: A Different Story for Deal Making
description: Deal making wont be dead in 2008. But it wont look like it has over the past two years. As DealBook peers into its crystal ball for the upcoming year, its clear that the narrative has changed from 2006 and 2007.

title: OReilly Involved in Shoving Match at Obama Event
description: UPDATED

title: Is Huckabees Tax Plan Fair?
description: In his Web column today, Tom Redburn writes that the FairTax, the plan championed by Mike Huckabee to replace federal income and payroll taxes with a national sales tax, is considered anything but fair by most tax experts. Go to column

title: Tracking Poll Shows Tight N.H. Contests
description: The latest results of the 7 News/Suffolk University tracking poll indicates close races in both primaries in New Hampshire, with many voters open to changing their mind before Tuesday.

title: ABC Prepares for Saturdays Back-to-Back New Hampshire Debates
description: ABCs pair of presidential debates, scheduled to take place Saturday evening in Manchester, N.H., are special for several reasons.

title: No, They Really Werent Netrooting for Him
description: What does Barack Obamas victory in Iowa mean for the prominent activist bloggers in the Democratic Party who call themselves the netroots  many of whom have spent the past year either dismissing Obamas candidacy (MyDDs Jerome Armstrong scoffed at Obamas fake self-proclaimed movement' in June) or being actively hostile to it (a common enough sentiment that it led the DailyKos poster with the puckish sobriquet Mark Warner Is God to write a sarcastic post titled, Barack Obama will eat your children)?

title: Talking Policy at the Bagelry
description: DURHAM  After a somewhat rollicking morning, it was Hillary Rodham Clinton the Policy Wonk who showed up at a bagel shop here this afternoon (90 minutes late).

title: New Hampshire Voters Weigh Their Options
description: Candidates from both parties crisscrossed New Hampshire looking for votes.

title: Leno, Kimmel Finally Find Guests: Each Other
description: In an unusual act of unity emerging from the screenwriters strike, two of televisions late-night hosts, Jay Leno of NBC and Jimmy Kimmel of ABC, will appear on each others shows on Thursday, Bill Carter reports.

title: Manchester Debate Scene
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  We snaked our way to St. Anselm College through awesome, crawling traffic  yet another sign of the intensity of interest in the campaigns at this point  to reach the site of tonights back-to-back debates.

title: Strike News: Everybody Wants A Waiver
description: More than one week after it was signed by both parties, the Writers Guild of America on Friday released a summary of the agreement with Worldwide Pants that allowed the company to resume production of The Late Show with David Letterman.

title: Photos: The Day in New Hampshire
description: More Photos

title: New Hampshire G.O.P. Backs Out of Fox Forum
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Ron Paul raised nearly $20 million in the last quarter, likely more than any of his rivals. He garnered 10 percent of the Republican vote in the  Iowa Caucuses, surpassing Rudolph W. Giuliani. And hes in New Hampshire this weekend on the airwaves and the campaign trail before the Jan. 8 primary.

title: Obama and Clinton Are Neck-and-Neck in New Polls
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are neck-and-neck according to two polls of New Hampshire voters. John McCain appears to be pulling ahead of Mitt Romney in New Hampshire, with a 6-point advantage in both surveys, which were released this evening and based on interviews conducted after the Iowa caucuses.

title: Next Up: The Top Prospects Game
description: Now that the World Juniors are done, the next stop for scouts is the C.H.L. Top Prospects Game on Jan. 23 in Edmonton. The Top Prospects game will feature 40 of the best Canadian junior players who are eligible for this years draft. Unlike most All-Star events, this is rugged junior hockey with lots of hitting and the occasional scrap (Canadian for fight).

title: Edwards Supporters Pre-Debate Rally
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Volunteers for the Edwards campaign were gathered on Elm Street for a pre-debate rally, awaiting the arrival of Mr. Edwards, who was scheduled to stop by and greet them on his way to the debate.

title: Bits and Pieces
description: NEW ORLEANS  Here are a few highlights from media day for the B.C.S. title game.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Jan. 6
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mike Huckabee won the most delegates in the Iowa caucuses, a feat that appears to have earned him the most appearances on the Sunday talk shows. Mr. Huckabee appears on CNNs Late Edition, ABCs This Week, and Fox News Sunday. His relatively high number of television bookings aligns with his overall campaign emphasis on media appearances over extensive campaign travel. (Its cheaper too.)Tied for second place on the shows at least are Mr. Huckabees two top rivals, Mitt Romney and Senator John McCain. Mr. Romney shares Mr. Huckabees face time with Chris Wallace on Fox and George Stephanopoulos on ABC. Mr. McCain gets Tim Russert of NBCs Meet the Press and Bob Schieffer of CBSs Face the Nation all to himself.

title: Live Blogging the Republican Debate
description: 8:53 p.m. | Wrapup This is really the first time that weve heard the Republican candidates talk about the possibility of running against Mr. Obama. It was the highlight of this debate  but hold on! ABC is trotting out all the Democrats to shake hands with all the Republicans before they leave the stage. A giant and hilarious photo op is taking place, with multiple side photo ops!

title: Checkpoint: Giuliani on Clinton Troop Reductions
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani slightly overstated a figure about reductions in troop numbers under former President Bill Clinton during the tonights Republican presidential debate in Manchester, N.H.

title: Two Parties; Odd Embraces
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  One of the more fascinating scenes of Saturdays presidential debates occurred during the brief period between the two scrums, when the Republican candidates were leaving the stage and the Democrats were coming on. For a few curious moments, members of the rival castes joined in a series of public exchanges, some no doubt awkward, some perhaps heartfelt.

title: Live Blogging the Democratic Debate
description: 11:13 p.m. | Wrapup These debates gave New Hampshire its own chance to evaluate the candidates in the new post-Iowa dynamic.

title: Colonial Woes
description: Shares of Inmobiliaria Colonial, the second largest property company in Spain, plunged 40 percent last week and the board ousted chairman Luis Portillo, amid growing concerns about the companys health.

title: Purple States: Building America
description: Bert and Tamara voice concerns about issues such as government tax policies and rising health care costs.

title: A Cold Blanket for a January Game
description: Before Giants fans book their hotels and airline tickets for the second round of the playoffs, here are some figures to chew on before their team plays the Buccaneers on Sunday:

title: New Hampshire and Those Labor Ads
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  As weve been driving around New Hampshire this week, we cant help but hear the radio ads playing repeatedly. Weve heard Ron Paul ads, John McCain ads and then ads that just stopped us  those for Hillary Rodham Clinton and against Senator Barack Obama.

title: Lauren Varga and Andrew Finkelman
description: Lauren Marie Varga and Andrew David Finkelman were married on Saturday at Arlington Street Church in Boston. The Rev. George G. Whitehouse, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Nikoa Evans, Garrett Lee Hendricks
description: Nikoa Subrina Evans and Garrett Lee Hendricks were married on Saturday on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. The Rev. Sandra Robinson, an African Methodist Episcopal Zion minister, officiated at Frenchmans Reef and Morning Star Marriott Beach Resort.

title: Before Act I
description: An intriguing restaurant scene continues to develop in Fort Greene, home of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and other cultural destinations. Two of the places in this list, 67 Burger and the Smoke Joint, have opened in the past 15 months.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Page 8 of Arts & Leisure this weekend about Jock Sotos transition to teaching dance after a career as principal dancer with the New York City Ballet misstates the given name of his father. He is Jose Soto, not Joseph.

title: The Blank Space in Our Family Album
description: EVERY once in a while I am clunked on the head by one of the many baby books weve shoved into the upper corner of our future childs closet. Given the shortage of space in our 700-square-foot apartment, I probably should have given them away by now.

title: Jacobs Is a Bull of a Runner and a Teddy Bear of a Father
description: It was the ball-in-the-belly stunt that first showed that Brandon Jacobs was not who he seemed. Kim Jacobs was pregnant last season, and when her husband scored a touchdown, he celebrated by sticking the football under his jersey.

title: Kenyan City Is Gripped by Violence
description: KISUMU, Kenya  Oginga Odinga Street, the main thoroughfare in town, is a testament to rage.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
description: It was mid-July, 10 days into a heat wave so unrelenting that it had penetrated the thick stone walls of my parents Umbrian farmhouse, and there was no relief to be found, indoors or out. There was also a big fresh Mediterranean fish waiting in the fridge  its name, in Italian, is ombrina. But not one of us felt like eating, let alone going anywhere near a stove. By the time the sun finally set that night, it was nearly 9:30; we jumped into the pool, cooled off and suddenly realized we were famished. Improvising with what was at hand, my mother, a superb cook, braised the ombrina in a quick sauce of tomatoes, garlic and saffron, and then, reaching for the nearest bottle, splashed some grappa into the pan  and so a favorite family recipe was born.

title: From Across the Ocean and Across the Street, All Weigh In on the Meaning of Iowa
description: Gary Younge writing in The Guardian of London about Senator Barack Obamas victory in Iowa.

title: Bowl Games Provide Respite in a Garden of Tedium
description: I came up with a newfound appreciation of the college bowl system the other night. Its pretty easy to be dismissive of these dozens of bowl games flopping across the blank screens of our minds at years end, particularly when you compare them with the orderly playoff system of the N.F.L., commencing this weekend.

title: Sushi, Style and More in a Choice Location
description: LOCATION, location, location. Is it as important in the success of a restaurant as it is in real estate? A look at the Woodbury Village Shopping Center suggests it might well be an ingredient.

title: An Interface of Ones Own
description: Microsoft Word. Light of my mind, fire of my frustration. My sin, my soul. Mi-cro-soft-word. The mouth contorts with anti-poetry. My. Crow. Soft. Word.

title: New Day in the Americas
description: SO PAULO, Brazil

title: The Economy Looks a Lot Like Pizza
description: HIGHER commodity prices. Weak consumer spending. And heavy borrowing.

title: The Ivies, Then
description: To the Editor:

title: Framing the Past in the Light of the Present
description: Of all of Ted Kawalerskis photographs of the Hudson River, the one that most resonates with me is of Bannerman Castle in the winter. In the foreground, a Metro-North or Amtrak train rumbles by the waters edge. The picture reminds me of traveling this train route to and from museums in the Hudson River Valley on my art-reviewing rounds.

title: Beneath the Grime, the Glories of Ancient Greece
description: IN the early 1970s, a pair of Staten Island art professors named Pat Passlof and Arthur Levine came across a dozen bas-relief friezes depicting trotting horses and caped cavalrymen that hung on the walls in the library of a St. George school building destined for the wrecking ball.

title: Filming Robbins in the City He Loved
description: ARIEL SCHULMAN is making a film about sex, violence, racism and teenage angst. But the film is also a ballet, which to some sounds much more intimidating.

title: Last Stop Before Adulthood
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y.

title: He Moves. He Moves On. Catch Up.
description: THE usual image of a ballet stars retirement is one of triumphant culmination: rapturous fans, showers of confetti, grand bouquets, embraces from the departing dancers colleagues and loved ones.

title: Correction: The Binocular Brigade
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the National Audubon Societys annual bird count in the region misidentified a bird shown sitting in a holly tree. The photograph showed a house sparrow, not an American tree sparrow.

title: Condo Confections Hit a Snag
description: ASBURY PARK and Vernon are two communities offering up cautionary real estate tales to start the year: a grand development project in each has taken a sharp turn for the worse. In Vernon, work has ceased prematurely on a ski-resort village, and in Asbury it has screeched to a halt at the Esperanza, a condominium complex front and center in the effort to revive the beachfront.

title: Television | The Week Ahead
description: Television

title: For a Franchise, Success Is in the Hiring
description: SUPER BOWL SUNDAY is weeks away, but Dave Melton, a Dominos Pizza franchisee in Manhattan, is already gearing up.

title: An Ever-Evolving Site on Madison Avenue
description: A MODEST but elegantly detailed two-story Georgian-style building between 64th and 65th Streets is just the kind of oddity that makes Madison Avenue fun.

title: Fight Against Youth Cancer Enters the Recording Studio
description: HOUSTON  Madison Keel, a gap-toothed 7-year-old with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, perched atop a doctors examination table here at Texas Childrens Cancer Center, struggling.

title: A Place for Greek That Sets Itself Apart
description: ARE you here for the restaurant? asked the man in front of Santorini, a new Greek restaurant in Sleepy Hollow, as we worried over our poorly defined parking spot. Ill keep an eye on the car for you.

title: The Siren Call of the River to a Commuter on the Shore
description: ARI HOFFNUNG, a rosy-cheeked 34-year-old bundled in a dark overcoat over his business suit, boarded the 7:50 a.m. ferry from Yonkers as a rising sun bathed the Palisades in golden light. Seagulls squawked overhead, and whitecaps licked the edge of the yellow, high-speed catamaran as it glided smoothly down the Hudson River.

title: Letters: The Huckabee Factor
description: Zev Chafets (Dec. 16) reports that Mike Huckabee spoke with bitterness about my lack of endorsement of his candidacy. For the record, as a matter of policy during my 19-plus years of service at the Southern Baptists Ethics and Religious Liberty Commission, I have not endorsed  and will not endorse  candidates for political office. I have defended various candidates when they have been, in my opinion, attacked unfairly. In recent weeks I have defended Huckabee, Mitt Romney and Fred Thompson, among others. Defending against criticism is not endorsement.

title: Building Suspense Along the Trail of an Invisible Man
description: YOU dont ride with the devil in Zodiac, that rare American movie that doesnt turn murder into kicks. With cool intelligence, David Finchers masterly opus tracks the years-long efforts by several detectives and newspapermen, including Robert Graysmith (who wrote the book on which the movie is based), to find the killer  the self-anointed Zodiac  who committed a string of murders in Northern California starting in the late 1960s and perhaps continuing into the early 1970s. For these men the search is not only about seeking knowledge but also seeking justice. It is consciousness and conscience both.

title: Storm Covers Wide Swath of West Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Residents across the West Coast struggled Saturday to dig out and dry out after a thumping storm system, even as more snow and rain bore down on towns from the Puget Sound to the California border with Mexico.

title: Paperback Row
description: FINAL EXAM: A Surgeons Reflections on Mortality, by Pauline W. Chen. (Vintage, $13.95.) To doctors, who are in the business of saving lives, death represents failure. I learned from many of my teachers and colleagues to suspend or suppress any shared human feelings for my dying patients, Chen, a liver surgeon, writes. These lessons in denial and depersonalization began as early as my first encounter with death in the gross anatomy dissection lab. In these thoughtful, moving essays on the relationship between medical practice and the emotional events surrounding death, Chen draws on her 15 years of clinical experience to inform a discussion of the failings of medical education (and possible remedies) and to share stories about dying patients and their families.

title: Letters: The Ethicist
description: The Ethicist (Dec. 23) informs a high-school teacher that the 25-plus letters of recommendation he or she writes each year for students is part of the job. Is it?

title: Janice Mahon, Jeffrey DuFour
description: Janice K. Mahon and Jeffrey D. DuFour were married on Thursday morning at the South Brunswick Municipal Center in South Brunswick, N.J. Mayor Frank Gambatese of South Brunswick officiated. Next Saturday, Judge William D. Cohen of the Vermont Superior Court will lead a marriage celebration at Tre Piani, a restaurant in Princeton, N.J.

title: Voting for a Smile
description: CONCORD, N.H.

title: A Turning Point for Transit
description: YOU dont need Nostradamus to know that traveling to work, visiting Manhattan to catch a play or heading to the shopping mall is going to get more expensive in 2008.

title: Voice From the Past Becomes an Obsession
description: CECILIA BARTOLI just may have found the role of a lifetime: the diva Maria Malibran, who was born in 1808 and died in 1836.

title: Letters: Desperately Seeking a Kidney
description: Thank you for Sally Satels article (Dec. 16). When my income was higher, I used to donate a substantial portion of it to charity. For the last few years, I have been working in restaurants, and I cant afford to give away much of my money. But I am 26 years old and healthy, and her article showed me a way I can give something valuable, without having to give money. I am planning to start the process with MatchingDonors.com.

title: Could It Be the Year of the Rising Dollar?
description: THE dollars sharp drop over the last two years has been a huge boon for Americans who bought foreign stocks.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $4,469,777

title: The Right Side of the Tracks
description: KINGS Cross, a traffic-congested, unlovely neighborhood in north London anchored by the train station of the same name, hasnt been much of a tourist spot in recent years  just a place to get out of as quickly as possible if you are arriving by rail from cities like Cambridge and Edinburgh, often bypassing prostitutes and drug dealers on your way to the taxi stand.

title: Curator? No, the Deli Man.
description: CROTON-ON-HUDSON

title: Joining Forces to Stem Flooding
description: DARIEN

title: On Double Secret Probation
description: ONE of the oddest features of American university life is the stubborn persistence of Greeks on campus. Not the classical Greeks, but the only occasionally toga-clad brothers and sisters of fraternities and sororities, with their rushing and pledging, their hazing, their bonding, their ritual chugging and barfing.

title: The Anticipated, the Indie and the Overlooked
description: Alan Jackson

title: Classical | The Week Ahead
description: Classical

title: With His Mothers Death, a Giant Learns a Lesson About Love
description: It was just another Saturday night, and David Tyree was in a meeting with his teammates at a Marriott in Teaneck, N.J. The Giants were playing the Redskins the next day, Dec. 16. Someone pulled Tyree from the room.

title: Correction: A Life Dedicated to Helping Others Learn
description: A profile last Sunday about Andrew L. Morzello, a White Plains teacher inducted into the Westchester Senior Hall of Fame, misstated the name of the county department headed by Mae Carpenter. It is the Department of Senior Programs and Services, not the Department of Social Services.

title: Singapore Supersizes the Ferris Wheel
description: When it opens in March, the Singapore Flyer will become the worlds tallest observation wheel, usurping the current bragging rights of the Star of Nanchang in China.

title: Theater | The Week Ahead
description: Theater

title: Note to Readers
description: Readers are invited to submit letters to cityletters@nytimes .com. Each letter should include the authors name, address and phone number, though only the authors name and neighborhood will be published.

title: Inside the List
description: THE FALL OF 2001: Islam was not much on Americas mind on Sunday, Sept. 9, 2001  two days before 9/11. The No. 1 book on The Timess nonfiction list that week was Stephen E. Ambroses Wild Blue: The Men and Boys Who Flew the B-24s Over Germany, followed at No. 2 by David McCulloughs John Adams. (The book at the top of the fiction list was Valhalla Rising, by Clive Cussler.) Within a few weeks, though, the picture began to shift. Among the books that received special attention and began to appear on the hardcover nonfiction list that fall  all of them written before 9/11  were: Islam, by Karen Armstrong, first published in 2000; Germs, a book about biological weapons by the New York Times reporters Judith Miller, Stephen Engelberg and William Broad; Twin Towers: The Life of New York Citys World Trade Center, by Angus Kress Gillespie; The Lost Son: A Life in Pursuit of Justice, a memoir by Bernard Kerik; and Final Days, a critical book about the Clinton White House by Barbara Olson, who died aboard a hijacked jetliner on Sept. 11. After these books, the deluge.

title: Mermaids Past and Present Keep Things Real
description: ARIPEKA, Fla.

title: Expensive Boo-Boo
description: When my husband developed a leg infection, his physician prescribed the wrong antibiotic. The insurance company, recognizing the mistake, refused to cover the prescriptions $573 cost. But I had already filled it, and my husband had taken a dose. I think our doctor should reimburse us. (The correct treatment for this common infection was immediately prescribed by two other doctors.) My husband demurs. You?  NAME WITHHELD, LOS ANGELES

title: The Pragmatic Caliphs
description: Many Westerners think the world would be safer if it were less Muslim, more Western. And in the Middle East and beyond, many Muslims are horrified by our arrogance; a tiny minority respond with violence. Yet the so-called clash of civilizations, as Zachary Karabells important new book demonstrates, draws strength from a profoundly partial reading of history. Peace Be Upon You is a polemic in the service of peace  readable, accessible and, maybe, indispensable.

title: They Didnt Stop Thinking About Tomorrow
description: AFTER so many years of fear and loathing, we had almost forgotten what its like to feel good about our country. On Thursday night, that long-dormant emotion came rushing back, like an old dream that pops out of the deepest recesses of memory, suddenly as clear as light. They said this day would never come, said Barack Obama, and yet here, right before us, was indisputable evidence that it had.

title: Home-Style Colombian
description: Breaking bread is easy at Arepas Paisas, a luncheonette in Morristown that serves Colombian and Mexican food. The hard part is deciding between a tortilla and an arepa, a flatbread thats shaped like a pancake.

title: Abused Muslim Women in U.S. Gain Advocates
description: CHICAGO  After enduring seven years of beatings from her husband, a young Yemeni-American woman recently fled to a local shelter, only to find that the heavy black head scarf she wore as an observant Muslim provoked disapproval.

title: Events on Long Island
description: FILM

title: Beyond the Burka
description: The veiled, oppressed Muslim woman has become overexposed. American book clubs consume her memoirs. Novels about her, as long as they are bleak, appear in the windows of our bookstores. Intellectuals argue over how she should be described and who can save her.

title: Cosmetic Imperatives
description: Some beauty products simply get the job done, while others become obsessions. Here are some of winters top-selling, most coveted items.

title: A Movie Star for All Eras, Even the Present
description: SUCH a deep streak of nostalgia runs through George Clooneys career that he seems to be working his way through every decade of the 20th century.

title: Her Objects of Desire
description: WHEN I was 20 and married and I desired a life in the fast lane of Los Angeles, I used to collect objects. After these phases and others passed me by, I gave away the wedding gifts, the plastic couch in honor of veganism, a mattress, linens, two bar stools, one directors chair, my sisters handmade shelves, the hanging things on the walls and the electronic devices of the 80s. Not that much, and yet all was offered to my secretary, a new arrival to Los Angeles. She brought her tall male friend along to take whatever they wanted. What they didnt take, Goodwill did.

title: Man Killed by the Police After a Chase
description: The police shot and killed a Queens man during a struggle early Saturday after he ran from officers seeking to question him and pointed a loaded pistol at one of them, the authorities said.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Long Pole in the Tent
description: The most difficult aspect of developing a weapons program, said President Bush, trying to counter the C.I.A.s N.I.E.-jerk relaxation response to Irans nuclear ambitions, or as some would say, the long pole in the tent, is enriching uranium.

title: Private Cash Sets Agenda for Urban Infrastructure
description: NEW HAVEN  Conceived as a freeway, the Route 34 Connector still promises to whisk motorists across New Haven as they exit Interstate 95. But in less than a mile, the three broad lanes abruptly end, forcing traffic onto side roads that skirt the unbuilt right-of-way  a wasteland of elongated asphalt parking lots and scrub grass.

title: New and Improved Stations Top List of Rail Projects to Benefit Riders
description: JAMES PETERS has been taking the New Jersey Transit train from Trenton for more than a decade, so long that he remembers when it used to be just a Roy Rogers with a train station.

title: Racing Toward the Sun
description: PUT aside for the moment the matter of wretched excess. Nobody needs 480 horsepower or a top speed just south of 200 miles an hour, unless he plans to overtake a jetliner before liftoff. And nobody has to spend $136,000 for an invigorating sports car experience.

title: Long on Beer, Short on Pretense
description: Los Angeles
