description: COMEDY

title: Events in Westchester
description: Film

title: Who Will You Be This Summer?
description: IT will surprise nobody that the most competitive wave of high school graduates is now the most competitive wave of college students. The generation that made admissions a contact sport bring the same sharp elbows to how they spend their summers. Or, put in a form that parents would understand: Internship is to first job as community service is to college.

title: Frustrated Sellers, Take Note
description: ON Jan. 27, Fereydoun and Dolores Fanis five-bedroom three-bath Stony Point colonial is scheduled to be sold at auction. This is not because the house is in foreclosure, but because the Fanis have been waiting 18 months for a buyer to come along, have already moved elsewhere and are tired of paying for two homes.

title: As All-American as the Matzo Ball
description: IN 1654, when the Portuguese seized Recife, Brazil, from the Dutch, many Jews fled; 23 of them ended up in New Amsterdam, now New York City.

title: Scratch Bloombergs Surface, Find a Democrat
description: Hundreds of miles from the hustings of New Hampshire lurks a possible presidential candidate who supports gay marriage, abortion rights and stricter regulation of handguns. Who doesnt mind taxing the rich on their income or big companies on their carbon emissions. Who says that deporting illegal immigrants would destroy the nations economy. And who is not necessarily averse to adding more bureaucrats to the government payroll.

title: Humor Sliced and Diced
description: TRACY MORGAN wore a New York Yankees ball cap and a BerdMan sweatshirt, but more important was what he was not wearing, made clear when the waitress at Benihana approached for his drink order.

title: Quiz Answers
Dont Urbanize the National Park Service
description: To the Editor:

title: A City Reveling in Contrasts
description: BIG is to small, as day is to night, as rich is to poor, as New York is to ... ? New York, of course.

title: And Out of the Corner of My Eye...
description: I HAVE preached to my 17-year-old son that a persons true character is revealed by his actions when he thinks theres no chance of being rewarded for them or little danger of getting caught. I myself have failed this litmus test.

title: Against Hoyas, Rutgers Cant Outscore Its Football Team
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Georgetown does not simply defeat its opponents, it smothers them. The Hoyas win with a stifling defense and just enough offense, which was, once again, a successful formula Saturday against Rutgers as Georgetown picked up an easy victory in its Big East opener.

title: A Doyenne of All-in-One Living
description: WHEN Barbara Kling tells you that she turned down the opportunity to buy her spacious three-bedroom, two-bath apartment at 100 West 57th Street when the building went co-op in 1977, your first reaction is to feel sorry for her. After all, she missed her chance to buy at a low insider price that would have allowed her to make a killing today. (She said a similar apartment recently sold for $1.5 million.)

title: Next-Gen Taliban
description: One day last month, I climbed onto a crowded rooftop in Quetta, near Pakistans border with Afghanistan, and wedged myself among men wearing thick turbans and rangy beards until I could find a seat. We converged on the rooftop that afternoon to attend the opening ceremony for Jamiat Ulema-e-Islams campaign office in this dusty city in the southwestern province of Baluchistan. Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam, better known by its abbreviation, J.U.I., is a hard-line Islamist party, widely considered a political front for numerous jihadi organizations, including the Taliban. In the last parliamentary elections here, in 2002, the J.U.I. formed a national coalition with five other Islamist parties and led a campaign that was pro-Taliban, anti-American and spiked with promises to implement Shariah, or Islamic law. The alliance, known as the Muttahida Majlis-e-Amal, or M.M.A., won more than 10 percent of the popular vote nationwide  the highest share ever for an Islamist bloc in Pakistan. The alliance formed governments in two of the countrys four provinces, including Baluchistan.

title: Picketing Feet Could Scuff Red Carpets
description: AN Oscar, as anyone who buys a movie ticket can tell you, has strong symbolic value. Beyond its shape  next to a Coke bottle, it is one of the most recognizable artifacts of Western civilization  Oscars public profile means that the telecast sometimes serves as a platform for agendas that have nothing to do with movies. But the Oscars have never been held hostage quite like this.

title: Salad Days
description: Traditionally, Epiphany, or Jan. 6th, is the day that homes are stripped of Christmas greenery. In my house, I drag out the tree and bring in fresh greens  in the form of salads. After the holidays, a pretty head of lettuce can make all those sugar cookies fade like a bad dream.

title: Letters: The Clinton Referendum
description: As a lifelong liberal baby boomer, I will say that there is little in Clintonism that conforms to my ideology (Matt Bai, Dec. 23). But what I realized in 1992, as I moved from despising Bill Clinton to actively working on his election campaign, was that he was fundamentally asking me to grow up. He was saying that despite whatever my (or his) utopian dreams for America might be, and no matter how eloquently even the most articulate liberals might convey the short- vs. long-term cost-benefit analysis, the vast majority of Americans were unwilling to go there. The added fact that many liberal candidates were inarticulate in selling this message, while refusing to embrace Clintonesque phrases like People who work hard and play by the rules or End welfare as we know it, is one reason Ive spent most of my life with a Republican in the White House. While these expressions dont conform to my personal ideology (talking about welfare reform is outrageous without a discussion of corporate welfare), their use was an attempt by Clinton to bring back into the Democratic Party what had been lost to Reagan Democrats.

title: Lottery Numbers
Correction: A City of Churches Emerges as a Culinary Hub
description: The Next Stop column on Dec. 23 about Adelaide, South Australias capital and a culinary hub, misidentified its coastal location. It is on the Gulf St. Vincent on the Indian Ocean coast; it is not along the Pacific coast.

title: Cakes and Ale? No, Port
description: Fonseca Bin No. 27 port evokes a Chesterfield wing chair, fireplace and W. Somerset Maugham novel.

title: Settling In After an 8-Mile Move
description: IN an early review of Mama Tucci, theres a photo of the restaurant a few months after its opening in 2004: a narrow storefront on Main Street in Madison, with closely spaced tables, hanging plants and a blackboard with a scrawled list of specials.

title: A Coen Brother Scales Down to the Stage
description: ETHAN COEN tries very hard to ration his conversation. But he has two different laughs.

title: Church and State
description: To the Editor:

title: Randolph Returns; Losing Never Left
description: HOUSTON  The question was a little convoluted and complex, but the premise was clear enough: how could the Knicks play so well against the San Antonio Spurs on Friday, add a highly productive Zach Randolph on Saturday and yet be soundly beaten by a lesser Houston Rockets team?

title: Mission of Mercy, Ocean of Guilt
description: AT 2 p.m. on a Friday afternoon, I am racing through a Toys R Us, searching for Winnie the Pooh gift wrap. Not the Disney version, with Pooh in the tacky T-shirt, but the original Shepard illustrations, where Pooh is naked, but so British you dont notice.

title: Knicks Seem Small Next to Yao and Rockets
description: HOUSTON  Yao Ming towered over Eddy Curry, lorded over Zach Randolph and generally stood in the way of the Knicks latest attempt at progress.

title: We Agreed to Agree, and Forgot to Notice
description: AS Martin Bunzl was getting on a plane in 1966, something happened that would stick in his head for the next four decades. A man taking his seat looked around and announced, loudly enough for all to hear: Oh, geez, not a Negro stewardess.

title: Can Burts Bees Turn Clorox Green?
description: IN the summer of 1984, Burt Shavitz, a beekeeper in Maine, picked up Roxanne Quimby, a 33-year-old single mother down on her luck, as she hitchhiked to the post office in Dexter, Me. More than a dozen years Ms. Quimbys senior, the guy locals called the bee-man sold honey in pickle jars from the back of his pickup truck. To Ms. Quimby, he seemed to be living an idyllic life in the wilderness (including making his home inside a small turkey coop).

title: In Newark, Remembering the Dead
description: Aljira, a feisty alternative art space in Newark, often shows artwork that has a razor-sharp social and political edge. Its latest exhibition, Rest in Peace, by Helen M. Stummer, is probably the most stark and arresting yet.

title: For Those Who Remember the Neediest, Helping Others Is Its Own Reward
description: Since Nov. 4, The New York Times has been printing daily profiles looking into the lives of New Yorkers who have overcome hardships with help from one of the seven agencies supported by The Neediest Cases Fund.

title: If You Go . . .
description: WHEN Mary Hardy of Larchmont, N.Y., began visiting prospective colleges last year with her son, she had no idea how many campuses they would cover or how much it would cost. It wasnt until their fourth campus, and a stay at an expensive Boston hotel, that she realized, Wow, this is really going to add up.

title: Oh, My Poor Arthritic Ski Club
description: Waitsfield, Vt.

title: Aesthetic Heft, Sized for a Snow Globe
description: FOR uncounted centuries artists have tried to fit realitys scale into smaller confines: framed canvases, chiseled statues, portraits on ivory. Walter Martin and Paloma Muoz have climbed into their own distinct niche: known collaboratively as Martin & Muoz, they sculpture and arrange miniature, three-dimensional scenes of alienation, dread and dark humor and set them inside snow globes.

title: Minus Housing, U.S. Job Cuts Look Tame
description: When it came to job cuts last year, a kind of economic firewall seemed to protect most industries from the ravages of the housing crisis.

title: Notre Dame Recruits Shine in All-Star Game
description: SAN ANTONIO  Before the start of this season, Notre Dame fans expected their inexperienced Fighting Irish to play in a bowl game.

title: Family Van With More
description: WHILE the Stout Scarab suggests the origins of the minivan, the Nissan Forum could be its future. A concept vehicle that will be displayed at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit this month, the Forum represents an effort to escape the dull bread-loaf design of minivans.

title: Must a Co-op Owner Install New Pipes?
description: Q Im a shareholder in a co-op. I would like to spruce up the bathroom by retiling it and replacing the old vanity and sink. I have been told by the managing agent, however, that this work will require replacing all pipes under the floor and in the walls to the point where they connect to the plumbing risers. This will be a substantial additional cost.

title: Arabic Lessons
description: One dark afternoon last winter, after too many hours spent studying Arabic verbs, I found myself staring uncomprehendingly at a video on my computer screen. An Arab man was holding forth tediously, his words half drowned by the rain outside. At first all I could make out was the usual farrago of angry consonants and strangled vowels. No progress there. Then, at last, the letters lighted up at the back of my brain.

title: Can Foundations Take the Long View Again?
description: AS business leaders like Ted Turner, Bill Gates and George Soros have moved vast swaths of their private wealth into the philanthropic sector, market expertise has migrated there, too. As a result, foundation directors, trustees and advisers from corporate America have taken a stance that the return on charitable dollars should be tangible and measurable, and should drive capital flow in much the same way that earnings figures do in commerce.

title: In an Unlikely Part of the Country, a Tiny Huckabee Movement Is Born
description: This is how Bill Garcia became what he calls a Huckabeezer.

title: Chopra Makes Grand Entrances, On and Off Course
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  When Daniel Chopra strode into the lobby of the Ritz-Carlton Kapalua on Friday night, well-coiffed heads turned and well-heeled patrons watched. Clad in a form-fitting shirt hanging out of snug Euro designer jeans, Chopra glided across the woven rugs and dark hardwood floors of the reception area toward the Alaloa Lounge to greet some friends, all the while smiling at strangers.

title: 1977 Exam Opened Escape Route Into Chinas Elite
description: BEIJING  In the autumn of 1977, as relative calm returned to China after the decade-long chaos of the Cultural Revolution, An Ping was laboring in the countryside where she had been sent, like millions of other young people from the cities, to learn from the peasants.

title: Record-Setting Rice Leads Rutgers Over Ball State
description: TORONTO  He had been making Ball State tacklers miss all day during a record-setting performance. And in the news conference after Rutgerss 52-30 victory Saturday over the Cardinals at the International Bowl, Ray Rice, the Scarlet Knights sensational running back, was just as elusive concerning his future.

title: Killing in Nicaragua Makes Spectacle of the Courts
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Somebody raped and strangled Doris Jimnez in her tiny clothing boutique 14 months ago. Ever since, Nicaraguas justice system has found itself on trial.

title: 911 Has a Long Memory
description: RIVERHEAD

title: Correction
description: An essay on Dec. 16 about J. M. Coetzee misspelled the given name of the cultural critic who once referred to him as the Greta Garbo of South African literature. He is Shaun de Waal, not Sean. The essay also referred incorrectly to the student with whom the protagonist of Coetzees novel Disgrace was involved in a sexual harassment scandal. The novel doesnt specify her race; she is never described as colored. The religion to which T. S. Eliot, whom Coetzee discussed in a 1991 essay, became a convert was also misstated. It was Anglicanism, not Catholicism.

title: To Walk a Landscape Is to Know It
description: COMES over one an absolute necessity to move. And what is more, to move in some particular direction. A double necessity then: to get on the move, and to know whither. The unforgettable opening of D. H. Lawrences Sea and Sardinia, a work written in six weeks flat. Why cant one sit still? he asks.

title: Anyone Can Make Maps
description: AS popular as global positioning satellite devices have become  they were the fastest selling electronic item last Christmas  consumers still largely use them to get from Point A to Point B.

title: Israeli Army Operation in Nablus Is Suspended
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Army wound up a large-scale, three-day operation in the northern West Bank city of Nablus on Saturday evening, an army spokesman said.

title: Canada Wins 4th Junior Title in a Row
description: Matt Halischuk gave Canada its fourth consecutive world junior title Saturday night, scoring 3 minutes 36 seconds into overtime for a 3-2 victory over Sweden in Pardubice, Czech Republic. In the third-place game, Russia beat the United States, 4-2.

title: Lincolns Cottage to Open to Public
description: For a quarter of his presidency, Abraham Lincoln did not live in the White House, but rather in a hilltop cottage three miles north in Washington. It was there that he worked on key war and emancipation strategies, and mourned the death of his son Willie. He last visited the cottage  if you can call a 34-room Gothic Revival, above, a cottage  the day before his assassination.

title: Paris: BlackBlock
description: Bring me back a present, the Significant Other says every time I leave for the Paris fashion shows, when what he really means is, Why arent you bringing me?

title: Intimate Apparel
description: When my mom took me shopping for my first bra, I was terrified that a classmate might see me. I kept my head low as she guided me through the dense jungle of satin straps and cups, and I nearly died of humiliation when she asked where the training bras were located.

title: Biggest Loser: Looking to Food
description: To the Editor:

title: A Retreat for Nature Lovers
description: Clinton, Conn.

title: What This Gadget Can Do Is Up to You
description: HACKERS, welcome! Here are detailed circuit diagrams of our products  modify them as you wish.

title: Exit Polling Suggests Election Victory for Georgias Pro-Western President
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Georgias pro-Western president seemed close on Saturday to winning an early election called after he declared a state of emergency this fall to deal with protesters.

title: Going for Growth, Even in a Slowdown
description: IN times of economic uncertainty, you would think that investors would flock to traditionally defensive stocks, like shares of stable utility companies or value-oriented dividend-payers.

title: The Clash
description: It would have been unlike Samuel P. Huntington to say I told you so after 9/11. He is too austere and serious a man, with a legendary career as arguably the most influential and original political scientist of the last half century  always swimming against the current of prevailing opinion.

title: No Country for Old Hatreds
description: Nairobi, Kenya

title: Comic Relief via Shortwave
description: THE great joke of our era is that this is called the information age, said the actor and humorist Harry Shearer. In other words, if information is free, you get what you pay for. Since childhood, Mr. Shearer has tried to get the genuine article, even if that has meant spending a little time and effort to do so.

title: Online System Will Let Riders Report Lost Items
description: AFTER John Guastella of Dix Hills dashed from a Long Island Rail Road train recently to avoid missing his stop, he could not find the eyeglasses that had been in his lap.

title: Army Lets a Felon Join Up, but N.Y.P.D. Will Not
description: NAWA, Afghanistan  On the day after he completed a one-year sentence at the Rikers Island jail, Osvaldo Hernandez walked into an Army recruiting office in Elmhurst, Queens. He was a felon with a plan to change his life.

title: A Swashbuckling Violinist, Fresh From the 1700s
description: Dobbs Ferry

title: Ive Been in That Club, Just Not in Real Life
description: IT began as a typical night on the Lower East Side. A few weeks ago a crowd of young urbanites gathered in the bowels of Cake Shop, the pastry cafe cum music club on Ludlow Street, to see a performance by an indie-rock band, the Virgins. A couple of minutes into the show the subterranean space was already packed to capacity and smelling of stale beer, so I left.

title: Iowa Victories Scramble the Money Game, Too
description: Victories by Senator Barack Obama and Mike Huckabee in Iowa have not only upset political calculations, they have also upset the money game and spurred a growing flood of donations for these candidates while making fund-raising trickier for the rest.

title: Right Hand Man
description: As a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and former speechwriter for President Bush, youre surprisingly critical of him in your new book, claiming he has appointed consistently mediocre people to important jobs and made a shambles of the Iraq war. Do you see the book as a mea culpa? No. Mea culpa is a kind of hand-wringing, breast-beating, woe-is-me attitude that I dont share. What I am saying is that there is exhaustion, intellectual exhaustion on the part of Republicans and conservatives.

title: Not Too Famous to Mind Her Mum
description: LONDON

title: Emily Ryan, Michael Escott
description: Emily Clare Ryan, the daughter of Carol L. Ryan and E. Peter Ryan of West New York, N.J., was married on Saturday to Michael James Escott, a son of the late Mimi Escott and the late Michael Escott, who lived in New York. The Rev. Stephen Katsouros performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: What Is It About Mormonism?
description: Our post-denominational age should be the perfect time for a Mormon to become president, or at least the Republican nominee. Mormons share nearly all the conservative commitments so beloved of the evangelicals who wield disproportionate influence in primary elections. Mormons also embody, in their efficient organizational style, the managerial competence that the partys pro-business wing considers attractive. For the last half-century, Mormons have been so committed to the Republican Party that the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints once felt the need to clarify that Republican affiliation is not an actual condition of church membership.

title: Aliza Pressman, Craig Chosiad
description: Aliza Michal Pressman, a daughter of Beverly Pressman and Rabbi Daniel Pressman of San Jose, Calif., is to be married on Sunday to Craig Isaac Chosiad, the son of Barbara and Jonathan Chosiad of Stoughton, Mass. The brides father will officiate at the Decathlon Club in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Commanding Attention in or Out of Costume
description: ITS sometimes hard to remember that the British actress Keira Knightley is only 22. Not that she looks or acts old, exactly. She still has the same gangly teenage frame that earned her the label sexiest tomboy beanpole. Not in the least shy about undressing, however, she has lately appeared nearly naked on the cover of Interview and, accompanied by a strategically placed bowler, in an ad for Chanel.

title: A Sense of Duty Takes Shape During Dinnertime Discussions
description: Starting when she was 9, Claire Gaudianis father impressed upon her the importance of being informed. At dinner they would discuss current events.

title: Many Without Power Amid California Storm
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Residents all across the West Coast struggled on Saturday to dig and dry out from a thumping winter storm system, even as more snow and drenching rain bore down on soaked towns from Puget Sound to San Diego.

title: When the Grooves of a Lifetime Start to Feel Like a Rut
description: IT started out innocently enough for James Dier. He was about 18, and growing up in Long Beach, Calif., he had attended record fairs and gone home with something rare from Madness or the Specials. This was bigger: an ad in the newspaper from a retired judge who was selling his son-in-laws entire collection  300 old records for $100.

title: Finding a Home on Long Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Film | The Week Ahead
description: Film

title: From Closet to Condo
description: DURING his first two years out of law school, Akinyemi Akiwowo was satisfied rooming with two friends in a Hoboken, N.J., rental.

title: The Lost Garden
description: The Umayyad dynasty of Spain, which dominated the Iberian Peninsula for almost 300 years, remained, for all its high cultural sophistication and sheer military might, an empire rooted in nostalgia. Like its founder, Abd al-Rahman I, who composed poignant lyrics evoking the palm groves of his youth in the summer palace of Rusafa, in distant Syria, its poets and chroniclers looked yearningly eastward. They lived in Granada or Seville among feuding Berber tribesmen and conquered Visigoths, but when they wrote their pens flew home to the lost gardens of their origins. When Abd al-Rahman I was proclaimed amir, or ruler, of the dynasty on May 15, 756, he was not quite 25 years old, but he had already had long training in the backward glance. He, and the dynasty he created, were fortuitous survivors of a long succession of hairbreadth escapes.

title: A Breed Apart
description: The art world has long been aware of the singular beauty and intensity of outsider art, also known as art brut  work by self-taught artists, or those with mental disabilities. These are artists working outside the mainstream, historically having little or no contact with art galleries and museums.

title: One Generation Got Old, One Generation Got Soul
description: SIXTEEN students sat around a table in the Manhattan cafeteria of the New School discussing where commas should go. They were rewriting, for the third time, a mission statement for their chapter of Students for a Democratic Society, the activist group that had been dormant for nearly 40 years. They wanted the document to be collectively produced, but after more than three weeks of communal drafting, no one seemed particularly content with the results.

title: Does the Road to Princeton Run Through Elizabeth?
description: Elizabeth High School anchors an aging industrial city, about 20 miles southwest of midtown Manhattan, that has become the first stop for many immigrant families in search of a better life. With more than 5,000 students, its one of the largest public high schools in New Jersey. Only a quarter of them attend four-year colleges, with the rest dispersing to two-year colleges, the military  Elizabeth is popular with recruiters  or the lower ranks of the work force.

title: Cartoon Villains
description: Is there such a thing as Islamophobia? To show there is, Peter Gottschalk and Gabriel Greenberg cite a talk show host for CNN Headline News telling Keith Ellison, the first Muslim American congressman: I have been nervous about this interview with you, because what I feel like saying is, Sir, prove to me that you are not working with our enemies. Presumably, the host believed that his viewers shared this anxiety  and popular culture seems to bear that out, according to Gottschalk and Greenberg. Many members of the media, they write, characterize Muslims as Muslims to the exclusion of any other aspect of their identity.

title: Public to Weigh In on Leaf Blower Ban
description: A PROPOSED ban on using gas-powered leaf blowers in Yonkers in the summer is scheduled for a public debate Tuesday, after which the City Council is likely to make it official  for a second time.

title: Dance | The Week Ahead
description: Dance

title: Palms and Sand, but No Boutique Hotels (Yet)
description: AS founder of the stately but weathered South Florida burg of Hollywood, Joseph Wesley Young called his dream city a place designed to welcome everyone from the opulent at the top of the industrial and social ladder to the most humble of working people.

title: Scores Fall, but Weir Holds His Ground
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  The rain stopped, the winds calmed and the golfers in the $5.5 million Mercedes-Benz Championship reacted accordingly. Permitted to lift, clean and place their golf balls for the first time all week, they unleashed a full-on assault on the defenseless Plantation Course at Kapalua on Saturday, lowering the field stroke average by one full shot and raising the bar for anyone who hopes to claim the $1.1 million first-place check Sunday.

title: Freedom at Gunpoint
description: In early 1798 the Directory, the oligarchy that was ruling revolutionary France, ordered its top general, Napoleon Bonaparte, to plan the invasion of England. Instead, Napoleon organized and carried out the invasion of Egypt, which became the first modern incursion by the West into the Middle East.

title: Slips, Falls and Potholes
description: Slips, Falls and Potholes

title: Top 10 Films: Give Us a List, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Miles Is Thriving by Making Quick Decisions That Work Out
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  On Dec. 24 every year, Louisiana State Coach Les Miles clears out a few afternoon hours to do all of his Christmas shopping. He even bought his wifes engagement ring on Dec. 24 years ago.

title: Borges and the Foreseeable Future
description: THE Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges might seem an unlikely candidate for Man Who Discovered the Internet. A fusty sort who from the 1930s through the 1950s spent much of his time as a chief librarian, Borges (1899-1986) valued printed books as artifacts and not just for the words they contained. He frequently set his stories in a pretechnological past and was easily enthralled by the authority of ancient texts.

title: Editors Choice
description: DIARY OF A BAD YEAR, by J. M. Coetzee. (Viking, $24.95.) Coetzees new novel follows the late career of one Seor C, who, like Coetzee himself, is a South African writer transplanted to Australia and the author of a novel titled Waiting for the Barbarians.

title: 36 Hours in Melbourne, Australia
description: ITS hard not to feel some sympathy for Melbourne. Often overlooked by travelers as they sprint their way through Australias Big Three tourist attractions  the dazzling metropolis of Sydney, the startlingly beautiful Great Barrier Reef and the historic Aboriginal site of Uluru  this laid-back city is a place that takes some time to appreciate. But Melbourne slowly grows on you as you stroll around the immaculately preserved Victorian-era downtown or along the revitalized Yarra waterfront, or linger over a cup of flat white in one of trendy cafes on Chapel Street (where the very mention of the name Starbucks is greeted with horror). And in January, at least, it has something that Sydney and those other places dont: the Australian Open. This is a country that loves its tennis, and for two weeks, this city feels like a nonstop party, one in which the chances that a local hero may finally take the title are debated each night in the pubs and where even a doubles match played on an outside court and featuring unranked players from the former Eastern Bloc will draw a capacity crowd. Who needs the Opera House?

title: Jaguars Beat Steelers at Their Own Game
description: PITTSBURGH  A sense of foreboding hung over Pittsburgh last week, with a city and a fan base used to Steelers success confronting their uh-oh scenario. The Steelers were division winners, but ticket-holders could not give them away, few fans volunteering to bear witness to what might happen when the Jacksonville Jaguars returned.

title: As Strike Persists, Late-Night Hosts to Be Guests
description: In an unusual act of unity emerging from the screenwriters strike, two of televisions late-night hosts, Jay Leno of NBC and Jimmy Kimmel of ABC, will appear on each others shows on Thursday.

title: The Matzo Show on Rivington Street
description: ALL day long, people ask Leonides Negron if he is Jewish.

title: The Wheel Keeps on Rolling
description: The N.H.L. is rife with parity this season, but the Detroit Red Wings refuse to play along.

title: The Dead and the Naked: Conclusion: The Cruel Little Boy With Golden Curls
description: Last week: Professor McPherson explained to Detective Oakwood and Miss Skattergoods that Dick Treekape stole Lee Stones novel after the young mans death.

title: Six Decades at the Center of Attention, and Counting
description: WHEN the vast baby-boom generation exploded into adolescence in the 1960s, marketers exulted. Advertising consultants, always eager to coin a phrase, began happily explaining to corporations the difference between teenyboppers and counterculture consumers. Over the next 40 years, as Aquarius aged and the billable hours accumulated, marketers explained that such market segmentation techniques were the key to untold riches.

title: Caught in the Ayatollahs Web
description: How many men and women have been brutalized in Evin, Tehrans notorious political prison? Built by the shah, the prison became a ghoulish instrument of the ayatollah after the Iranian revolution in 1979. Although Evin remains the repressive arm of the state, we rarely hear about its victims. (One notable exception is the Iranian-born Canadian photojournalist Zahra Kazemi, who made headlines after she died under interrogation there in 2003.)

title: Watchful Eyes on Peaceful Streets
description: SHORTLY after 9 on a recent Friday night, Lou Kirchgessner drove his brand-new Acura sedan over a railroad crossing, passing into a desolate industrial area of Glendale, Queens. As the car crawled past the corrugated metal exterior of a Stop and Stor self-storage business, Mr. Kirchgessner noticed what would be the nights first flutter of excitement.

title: Words and Art
Fortunes Sisters
description: THERE is an ancient Chinese myth that people who are destined to meet are connected from birth by invisible red thread. For three Brooklyn mothers who were strangers until a few years ago, the legend has a deeply personal resonance. In early 2004, when they traveled in the same group to adopt year-old girls in China, Martha Laserson, Molly Parker-Myers and Lauren Uram made a discovery that would thread their families together for life.

title: Many Unhappy Returns
description: Returned Goods

title: Stirred, Not Shaken
description: Seattle

title: Blind Faiths
description: Several authors have published books on radical Islams threat to the West since that shocking morning in September six years ago. With The Suicide of Reason, Lee Harris joins their ranks. But he distinguishes himself by going further than most of his counterparts: he considers the very worst possibility  the destruction of the West by radical Islam. There is a sense of urgency in his writing, a desire to shake awake the leaders of the West, to confront them with their failure to understand that they are engaged in a war with an adversary who fights by the law of the jungle.

title: To Ski the Lights: Fantastic
description: ON four nights of the year, when the moon is full and if the sky is clear, the ski resort of Zermatt in Switzerland offers the rare opportunity to journey to the 10,180-foot-high top of the Rothorn ski area, enjoy a traditional fondue dinner, and then ski down, with only the glow of the moon and stars to guide the skiers.

title: 60 Years Removed From War, but Some Hardships Remain
description: Robert Ivker, 43, read an article in December 2006 about Svetlana Ismailov, a caseworker dedicated to helping Holocaust survivors and World War II refugees apply for reparations from Germany.

title: U.S. Considers New Covert Push Within Pakistan
description: This article is by Steven Lee Myers, David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt.

title: Stage-Door Johnnies, With an Agenda
description: FOR generations, when a Broadway show has ended, another time-honored drama has begun at the stage door, where crowds collect to get autographs from the stars. Behind the barricades, please! guards urge dozens of times a night in an effort to impose a little order on the scene. We have to keep the sidewalks clear for pedestrian traffic.

title: Religious Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Free-Market Sophistry
description: To the Editor: In your Practical Traveler column "Does Low Cost Mean High Risk?" (Dec. 23) the author quotes the safety expert David Learmount as saying low-cost operations have been safer in the United States because the Federal Aviation Administration heightened its safety oversight ... .

title: California Rules
description: California has now sued the Bush administration over its refusal to allow the state to set its own rules controlling greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks. The states legal arguments are sound and so is its policy, especially when one considers the White Houses seven-year failure to seriously confront the problem of global warming.

title: Heirs to a Headache
description: IN New York City real estate, death is the ultimate leveler, evicting the residents of 16-room duplexes as well as those in fifth-floor walk-ups. It doesnt matter whom you know.

title: Charlotte Warren, Vincent Spadafora
description: Charlotte Mary Warren and Vincent Gregory Spadafora were married on Saturday at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields in Manhattan. The Rev. Caroline Stacey, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: No Happy Ending in Dickensian Baltimore
description: ANOTHER swath of society  this time the fourth estate  has fallen into the ecosystem of The Wire, bringing with it another set of not-so-great expectations.

title: Web Site Brings Vox Populi to College Football Polling
description: The final college football polls will be released Tuesday. One will be posted at fanspoll.com, a Web site where fans, not sportswriters or coaches, choose their national champion.

title: Letters: Cookies and Birdseed
description: Judy Maloneys Lives column (Dec. 23) was touching and funny, but it was a real downer for those of us who are in our 80s. Next Christmas, please try to run something more cheerful. Yes, I hope to be reading The Times then, after carefully checking that Im out of my robe, dinner is in the oven and the presents are wrapped. Thanks for the to-do list.

title: Priscilla Fraser, Marcello Cipriano
description: Priscilla MacMillan Lovat Fraser, a daughter of Linda Lovat Fraser and Arthur William Lovat Fraser of New York, was married on Saturday to Marcello Cipriano, the son of Nuala Hallinan of New York and William Cipriano of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Ann Benton Fraser, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. James Church in New York.

title: That Campaign Button Can Sting You at Work
description: Q. As the presidential elections heat up, many of your co-workers are openly advocating certain candidates. Are these displays of affiliation appropriate in the office?

title: Job Requirement
description: SCHOOL-supported stints in the workplace have become as familiar a part of the undergraduate world as bleary-eyed cramming for finals. While on most campuses such spells are optional, more than 125 institutions require a dip into the workforce for certain majors, and at least a dozen mandate it for every full-time undergraduate.

title: Vans and Skechers, Squaring Off in Court
description: It is fairly common for apparel makers to borrow ideas from one another, but when it comes to those checkerboard slip-ons, Vans Inc. feels very protective. Vans, a longtime purveyor to surfers and skateboarders, contends that a new offering by Skechers U.S.A. bears far too close a resemblance to its own checked pattern.

title: A Stylish Cavern, Straddling a Border
description: IMAGINE a narrow, high-ceilinged cavern illuminated by chandeliers, reminiscent of the cave where Anthony Hopkins mentors a young Antonio Banderas in The Mask of Zorro. Now imagine it smaller; add a few tables and a dark wood bar, and youve got Bistro Basque in Milford.

title: A New Tower for the Las Vegas Skyline
description: Watch out, Bellagio: Las Vegass newest luxury resort, the Palazzo Las Vegas is opening this month.

title: In Dispute With a Landlord Over a Deposit
description: Q On Nov. 19, my landlord told me that he was raising the rent $100 and that the increase would take effect with the new lease. Our lease was up on Nov. 30, giving us only 11 days to respond. We decided we didnt want to pay the higher rent, so within 24 hours of being notified of the increase, we let our landlord know that we would not be renewing.

title: Video Art Thinks Big: Thats Showbiz
description: WERE in a house of many tight, messy rooms. In the suburbs? Cyberspace? Hard to say. Anyway, its night. A door bangs open. A girl, who is also a boy, dashes in, talking, talking. Other people are already there, in gaudy attire, dire wigs and makeup like paint on de Koonings.

title: The College Info Fest
description: ABOUT a year ago, a federal commission called on colleges to share more relevant information about themselves, particularly about how well they prepare graduates for the real world. At the same time, the anti-rankings movement, working to undercut the influence of U.S. News & World Report rankings on college selection, has gathered steam.

title: Street Smarts in Bangkok
description: SURROUNDED by groups of civil servants greedily slurping bowls of soup at Chote Chitr, a tiny, family-run restaurant in the older part of Bangkok, our table soon overflows like a Thai Thanksgiving. The yam makhua, a salad of grilled long eggplants topped with tiny dried shrimps, combines the tang of fresh shallots with expert charring. Prepared by the hand of a skilled griller, the vegetables retain a smoky crunch on the outside, but a first bite pierces the crackling char and reveals a juicy eggplant so sweet it resembles a ripe peach, full of lime juice and fish sauce that has soaked into the flesh.

title: Red, White, Blue and Green
description: This book is many things. It is, first, a personal chronicle of Imam Hassan Qazwinis own trajectory from Karbala, Iraq, where he was born in 1964, to exile in Kuwait and Iran, to Dearborn, Mich., where he currently heads the Islamic Center of America. Second, it is an argument for Qazwinis variety of Shia Islam, rooted in Iraq and Iran and adapted for America. Finally, it is a political statement  in fact, two of them  a plea for Muslim Americans to immerse themselves in the life of the United States while simultaneously deepening their identification as Muslims, and also for a particular outcome in Iraq, where Qazwinis father, a leading ayatollah, is imam of the mosque of Imam Hussein in Karbala.

title: Facing New Mileage Rules, Porsche Preps a Hybrid S.U.V.
description: IT is hard to imagine a less likely candidate for the hybrid treatment: the Porsche Cayenne, a 5,000-pound S.U.V. that ranks among the fastest, most powerful trucks ever built.

title: Keishann Lee and Clyde Haynes Jr.
description: Keishann Celena Lee, a daughter of Vernetta M. Lee and the Rev. Lynroy L. Lee of Jamaica, Queens, was married on Friday to Clyde Burnett Haynes Jr., the son of Gwendolyn Smith-Allen and Mr. Haynes Sr., both of Chicago. Adam Burt, a senior associate pastor with Morning Star New York, an interdenominational ministry based in Manhattan, officiated at All Souls Church in Manhattan.

title: A Mystery Tour More Menacing Than Magical
description: ONE of the most surreal moments in Across the Universe, Julie Taymors passionate 60s fantasia set to the songs of the Beatles, is a three-and-a-half-minute sequence at an Army induction center in New York City. Here is where Max Carrigan (Joe Anderson), a spirited hippie rebel from an upper-middle-class family, reluctantly reports for his physical examination after receiving his draft notice. Because he was told that if he swallowed cotton balls they would show up on an X-ray as spots on his lungs, he quickly ingests one as he enters the building.

title: Putting the Quantity in Unknown Quantity
description: Mark down these names and check in the next few years to see how many appear in major league box scores:

title: Arden Myrin and Dan Martin
description: DAN MARTIN realized he was deeply in love when his girlfriend, Arden Myrin, began dancing wildly to piped-in music in the frozen food aisle of a Hollywood supermarket.

title: Law and Order
description: Seventy-two percent of students see campus safety as very important in selecting a college, says a survey being released this month by the Art and Science Group. How safe is any one campus? With so many ways to consider and report crime, statistics are inconclusive. But by federal law, colleges and universities must distribute them annually. Crime rates can be compared at www.ope.ed.gov/security/Search.asp. The graphic, at left, contains recently posted figures from the nations largest urban campuses with residence halls.

title: If You Need a Past, Hes the Guy to Build It
description: THE production designer Jack Fisk has made a specialty of bringing lost worlds to life. In a more literal sense than cinematographers, production designers are responsible for the look of a film  they create its physical reality  and Mr. Fisks projects tend to be more physically demanding and more rooted in reality than most.

title: A Conservatory Stresses the Music and Eliminates the Bills
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Where Once Brooklyn Triumphed, a Tragic Scene
description: It has been 50 years since the Brooklyn Dodgers played their last game at Ebbets Field on Sept. 24, 1957. For residents of the Ebbets Field Apartments  the high-rise housing complex erected at the site of the ballpark in Crown Heights  50 years can seem like ancient history.

title: Nearby Haven for Ancient Ways
description: ON the sun-drenched mornings in Playn Chico, Panama, the graveyard is the liveliest place in town. Playn Chicos inhabitants, the Kuna Indians, still hold to their ancient beliefs that each person has a good and a bad spirit, and that after death the good spirit needs help to get to heaven. So every morning, the Kuna women march up the slippery jungle slope to the hilltop graveyard to keep their deceased relatives company and provide a little celestial boost.

title: Art | The Week Ahead
description: Art

title: Giants vs. Buccaneers
description: Eli Manning vERSUS Jeff Garcia

title: In Game of Swings, Last One Tilts to Seahawks
description: SEATTLE  They met near the Seahawks logo at midfield. Tim Ruskell, the general manager and architect of the revamped defense, extended a hand. Matt Hasselbeck, the quarterback and offensive engineer, shook it.

title: Loose Lips Win Elections
description: Washington

title: Officials Say Iraqi Soldier Killed 2 U.S. Soldiers
description: BAGHDAD  Two American soldiers killed last month during an operation in the northern city of Mosul appear to have been deliberately shot to death by an Iraqi soldier on patrol with them, senior Iraqi officers said on Saturday.

title: Television, From Many Sides
description: MOST of the kids in my neighborhood were going to be doctors or lawyers, so I enrolled in pre-med at the State University of New York at Binghamton. But when it was time to take the Medical College Admission Test, I walked into the test center and walked right back out. I really had no interest in being a doctor.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: At Debate, Two Rivals Go After Defiant Clinton
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  It was as if they sensed vulnerability.

title: Testing Investors Faith in State Street
description: FORCED over the last five months to face icky truths about the credit crisis, investors seem to believe we are near the end of a disturbing interlude. How else to explain the 8.2 percent rally last Thursday in shares of the State Street Corporation after it said it would seek fresh capital and add $618 million in reserves to cover lawsuits over subprime mortgage investments it made for some clients?

title: Caroline Werner and Karl Metzner
description: Caroline Lisa Werner and Karl Metzner were married on Saturday evening at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Kelly Fuhrman, Benjamin Taylor
description: Kelly Colleen Fuhrman and Benjamin Andrew Taylor were married on Saturday evening at Plymouth Congregational Church in Miami. The Rev. Moira McGuinn, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: Huckabees Tax Plan Appeals, but Is It Fair?
description: Long before Mike Huckabee, the former Republican governor of Arkansas, began campaigning for president, advocates for replacing the entire federal tax system with a national sales tax were campaigning to convert him to their cause.

title: Playing the Angles as a Fare Increase Looms
description: FOR four decades, many pennywise subway riders have hatched a common scheme when confronted by a fare increase. Maybe, goes the thinking, it will pay to hoard. The tradition began in 1966, when the subway fare rose to 20 cents from 15, the first increase since the token was introduced in 1953. In the days preceding the rise, frugal riders bought pocketfuls of tokens, delaying the increase for themselves.

title: Words and Art; Biggest Loser;  Long-Form Music; Top 10 Films
description: WORDS AND ART

title: Kinkri Devi Is Dead at 82; Fought Illegal Mining in India
description: Kinkri Devi, an illiterate and impoverished woman who had waged a long and at least partly successful fight against illegal mining and quarrying in the mountainous northern Indian state of Himachal Pradesh, died last Sunday in Chandigarh, India. She was 82.

title: Democrats in Sync, Mostly
description: DEMOCRATS might be forgiven for wearing shades, so bright are their days just now.

title: Lights, Camera, Traffic Ticket
description: IS being forewarned really the same as being forearmed? In the case of radar detectors, law enforcement has often argued that such devices encourage drivers to speed; if drivers believe that they wont be caught, it will embolden them to speed even more frequently. But is the same argument true when it comes to recent technology that warns drivers about the presence of so-called red-light cameras?

title: Reading the Koran
description: For Muslims the Koran stands as the Text of reference, the source and the essence of the message transmitted to humanity by the creator. It is the last of a lengthy series of revelations addressed to humans down through history. It is the Word of God  but it is not God. The Koran makes known, reveals and guides: it is a light that responds to the quest for meaning. The Koran is remembrance of all previous messages, those of Noah and Abraham, of Moses and Jesus. Like them, it reminds and instructs our consciousness: life has meaning, facts are signs.

title: Galleries and High-Line Views
description: IF a Manhattan neighborhood ever had a history of being on the far side of the tracks, it would have been the western part of Chelsea at the turn of the last century.

title: He Came, and He Saw, but Did He Moderate?
description: The first debates after the Iowa caucuses were a crucible for the candidates, but they were also a test of the Gibson Doctrine. ABCs anchor, Charles Gibson, began the evening with a policy statement: The less of a moderator, the better.

title: Soldiers of Allah
description: Before the Iraq invasion, a young imam offered some chilling advice to Muslims at the University of Toronto: if they could not fight the jihad against America with their souls or their sons, they should fight with their money. The Muslim Students Association told campus authorities that the imam did not represent the true spirit of Islam. With that, the case was closed.

title: Correction: When an Auld Acquaintance Was Brand-New
description: An article last Sunday about the first ball dropped in Times Square on New Years Eve, in 1907, referred incompletely to the origins of the tradition. It was begun by Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The New York Times, as part of an annual promotional celebration outside the Times Building, which had been the newspapers home for three years. The first ball was dropped from a structure atop the building.

title: Art That Walks a Fine Line Between Reality and Illusion
description: In The Republic, Plato uses an allegory of prisoners chained in a cave watching shadows on a wall to suggest that the things we believe are real are often only an illusion, a kind of puppet show of real life. To experience true reality we must escape from the cave of ignorance and into the clear light of day.

title: Celebrating the Bowerys Proud History, From Weegee to CBGB
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Fighter Retains Title
description: Paulie Malignaggi successfully defended his International Boxing Federation junior-welterweight title Saturday night, unanimously outpointing Canadas Herman Ngoudjo in Atlantic City. Malignaggi (24-1), of Brooklyn, and Ngoudjo (16-2), a native of Cameroon, treated a capacity crowd at Ballys ballroom to an exciting fight, with the outcome in doubt until Malignaggi took control in the later rounds.

title: Ghosts That Haunt Pakistan
description: CAMBRIDGE, England

title: Tribute to an Uncle Strengthens a Family Bond
description: Stanley Rosenfeld was an Army sergeant stationed in the Pacific during World War II. He returned to New York thankful to be in one piece, he said.

title: A Visionarys Minivan Arrived Decades Too Soon
description: THE 2008 Chrysler Town & Country minivan offers a removable table and second row seats that turn 180 degrees to face the rear, a feature that Chrysler calls Swivel n Go. But in 1936, William Bushnell Stout had already demonstrated such amenities in his eccentric Stout Scarab, an ancestor of the minivan.

title: A Starring Role in a Family Series
description: BERKELEY, Calif.

title: Railroad Plans Improvements
description: WITH its ridership expected to go up by 2.4 percent to nearly 82 million people in 2008, and the number of trains projected to increase by 1 percent, or 2,214, to almost 205,000, the Metro-North Railroad has a list of improvements that it plans to start or complete this year.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 8 of Arts & Leisure this weekend about Jock Sotos transition to teaching dance after a career as principal dancer with the New York City Ballet misstates the given name of his father. He is Jose Soto, not Joseph. (Go to Article)

title: Just in Case
description: The day before the coldest day last week  when the temperature started out at 4 below and rose to 5 above  I knocked the mailbox off its post with the tractor blade. The mail doesnt come unless the approach to the mailbox is carefully plowed. So after every storm I sculpture a drive-through lane, because I dont see the point of a day without mail. By then the Internet had been out for a couple of days because the satellite dish on the peak of the roof had filled with wet snow. And I crushed a hens egg I had thoughtlessly stuffed in the pocket of my hand-me-down chore coat.

title: Gabrielle Lansner, Dean Taucher
description: Gabrielle Elizabeth Lansner was married on Friday to Dean Taucher. Elaine Affronti, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated at San Francisco City Hall.

title: Raines Could Slide Safely Into the Hall on First Try
description: Even if Tim Raines had not been among the greatest base runners in baseball history, he would still be comfortably qualified for the Hall of Fame, which will announce its new members on Tuesday. Raines was regularly among the league leaders in on-base percentage. He also posted excellent slugging percentages for a leadoff man in the low-scoring 1980s and contributed above-average defense. If he had been merely an average base runner, his long and distinguished career would still have been roughly as valuable as those of his contemporaries Dave Winfield and Paul Molitor, who are in the Hall of Fame.

title: Runaround on Air Safety
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has grudgingly released data from a four-year survey of pilots about the safety of American aviation. The information was released the day before New Years, with no interpretation of the findings and in a format that is very difficult for outsiders to analyze. If the agency intended to show contempt for the flying public, it succeeded.

title: The Most Social Guy Who Ever Wanted to Ditch Society
description: SLAB CITY is a paradoxical  and maybe quintessentially American  place. Situated in the scrubby desert hinterlands of Southern California, this sprawling encampment is a community of mavericks, a makeshift society of misfits, anarchists and stubborn individualists. For Chris McCandless, Slab City is a way station on a long, meandering journey he hopes will ultimately take him to Alaska. But when Chris shows up there at a trailer belonging to Rainey and Jan, a pair of wanderers who had picked him up hitchhiking a few months before, his arrival is also a homecoming.

title: Nell Shanahan, Adam Schwartz
description: Helena Thorsen Shanahan, a daughter of Kristi V. Shanahan and Edward J. Shanahan, both of Wallingford, Conn., was married on Monday evening to Adam Harris Schwartz, the son of Sally Schwartz of Manhattan and the late Joseph W. Schwartz. Rabbi Jon R. Haddon officiated at the Seymour St. John Chapel of Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, with the Rev. John P. Duffell, a Roman Catholic priest, participating.

title: The Early Days
description: Few events in history have had so swift, profound and far-reaching an impact as the arrival of Islam. Within a mere 15 years of the Prophet Muhammads death, in A.D. 632, his desert followers had conquered all the centers of ancient Near Eastern civilization. They had erased a great and enduring regional power, Persia; reduced its brilliant rival, Byzantium, to a rump state; and carved from their territories an empire as vast as that of Rome at its height. Within 100 years, Muslim armies were harrying the frontiers of Tang dynasty China in the east, while 5,000 miles to the west, they had charged across Spain to clash with the Merovingian princes of what is now France.

title: Crucial Year for Corzine
description: TRENTON

title: Economic Policy for Tough Times
description: As one economic pillar after another began to buckle in 2007  lending, home sales and house prices, factory orders, holiday shopping  economists kept saying that recession was avoidable as long as employment held up. A job means a paycheck, a paycheck means spending, and spending means hope for the economy.

title: Caren Raine, Joel Camche
description: Caren Joy Raine and Joel Truex Camche were married on Saturday at the Harvard Club in Manhattan. Bentley Kassal, a retired justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, officiated.

title: To the Highest Bidder
description: Used to be, the way to land an internship at a hoity-toity magazine was through tenacity, talent or family connections. Now, in the name of giving, you can bid your offspring into a spot at a national publication.

title: Morozevich, on a Roll Again, Dominates at Russian Superfinal
description: Alexander Morozevich of Russia is almost certainly the most dangerous player in the world.

title: How to Approach an Estate Sale
description: EVEN when heirs and executors move in harmony, estate sales can lumber along at an achingly slow pace.

title: V.I.P.
description: THE guidance department of Mamaroneck High School, a public school of 1,454 in affluent Westchester County, gets an airy suite on the top floor of what looks like a glass-and-steel Adirondack lodge. The walls are covered with glossy posters of colleges and universities, from the Gothic grandeur of Harvard and Duke to the leafy campuses of Indiana Bloomington, St. Lawrence and Wheaton. A popular tradition is for seniors to autograph the posters of the places they plan to attend. Some of the posters bear half a dozen signatures, scribbled in thick black marker.

title: 3 Kings Transform a Church
description: Plainfield

title: Up Front
description: Islam, one of mankinds great religions, numbers 1.3 billion adherents around the world, with major communities not only in Cairo, Baghdad, Istanbul, Jakarta and Tehran, but also in London, Paris, Berlin, New York and Washington. Yet most Americans know very little about Muslims, which often means they know very little about their own neighbors. Even public officials with responsibility for our national security  powerful congressmen, top F.B.I. agents  betray an ignorance of the most basic facts about Islam, like the difference between Sunnis and Shiites.

title: More Than a Bachelor, Less Than a Master
description: WITH a B.A. in studio art from the University of New Hampshire, Erik Evensen worked as a graphic designer for a few years before deciding to pursue painting as a career. He applied to the masters program at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, in Boston. He was rejected.

title: Presbyterian Scares North Carolina State
description: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP)  Presbyterian College, the first-year N.C.A.A. Division I team playing 25 of its 30 games on the road, gave a scare to North Carolina State on Saturday.

title: Candidates Mount Frenzied Final Push in N.H.
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  A day after back-to-back debates before the voters of New Hampshire, the Republican and Democratic presidential candidates set off Sunday on breakneck campaigning to make their final arguments in person, with the leading contenders seeking to carry their momentum into the primary on Tuesday.

title: Eat Your Heart Out, Homer
description: In the summer of 2002, as Pentagon strategists were planning the invasion of Iraq, a short distance away, on the National Mall in Washington, the Smithsonians Arthur M. Sackler Gallery was showing one of the most interesting exhibitions of Islamic art seen in the United States for years. The show illustrated a story largely set in the Iraqi cities that would shortly become the targets of the Pentagons munitions.

title: Victory for Venus Williams
description: Venus Williams beat Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 6-3, to win the JB Group Classic exhibition Saturday in Hong Kong, a warm-up event for the Australian Open. Serving at 4-5 in the first set, Sharapova sent a backhand into the net after a long rally, then missed another backhand to allow Williams to take a one-set lead. Sharapova was erratic in the second set. She trailed, 3-2, then double-faulted and missed a forehand to give Williams a crucial break.

title: Tales of New Life, Aging Life, Hard Life
description: JUNO

title: Datebook
Letters: Galpagos Restrictions
description: To the Editor: Your article "Sailing Toward Paradise" (Dec. 23) does sailors and the Galpagos a disservice. While mentioning that private boats are restricted to two anchorages, it fails to point out that they are forbidden from sailing or motoring around the islands without a permit, held only by local operators who also carry a licensed guide. And that would prohibit their stated activities of cavort[ing] with baby sea lions and snorkel[ing] with hammerhead sharks and sea turtles from their sailboat.

title: Seeds of Hate
description: One day in Damascus not long ago, I visited the understocked gift shop of the Sheraton Hotel, looking for something to read. There wasnt much: pre-owned Grishams, a hagiography of Hafez al-Assad, an early Bill OReilly (go figure) and a paperback copy of The International Jew, published in 2000 in Beirut. The International Jew is a collection of columns exposing the putative role of Jews in such fields as international finance, world governance and bootlegging. Wherever the seat of power may be, thither they swarm obsequiously, the book states. These columns, which are based on the Protocols of the Elders of Zion  they are a plagiary of a forgery, in other words  were first published in Henry Fords Dearborn Independent more than 80 years ago.

title: Turns Out Summers Not Far Off
description: THE Hamptons may have a glut of homes sitting on the low end of its housing market  that is, under $10 million  but the picture is completely different when it comes to rentals for next summer.

title: Miami Beach:   The Anglers Boutique Resort
description: THE BASICS

title: Correction: Sailing Toward Paradise
description: An article on Dec. 23 about the Galpagos Islands misstated the rate for a multiday cruise and tour offered by Lindblad Expeditions. Prices for a trip to the Galpagos alone, double occupancy, start at $4,320; they do not start at $7,580, which is the rate for the Galpagos cruise and a week in Peru.

title: Can You Count on Voting Machines?
description: Jane Platten gestured, bleary-eyed, into the secure room filled with voting machines. It was 3 a.m. on Nov. 7, and she had been working for 22 hours straight. I guess weve seen how technology can affect an election, she said. The electronic voting machines in Cleveland were causing trouble again.

title: A Thrill-Seeking Promoter Who Has Just About Everything Going On
description: On a recent night in Times Square, with the temperature dipping to the low 30s, the red neon lights of the Hawaiian Tropic Zone restaurant never looked so inviting.

title: Scuffle Occurs as TV Pundit Tries for the Attention of Obama
description: NASHUA, N.H.  After a rally for Senator Barack Obama here Saturday, a brief tussle ensued between Bill OReilly, the Fox News host, and a campaign aide for Mr. Obama, and it created enough of a stir for the Secret Service to become involved.

title: The Falling-Down Professions
description: YOU cant say law firms arent trying.

title: A Defensive Strategy for REIT Investors
description: AS concerns mount about the credit crisis and its effects on the economy, money managers have been urging investors to use a more defensive tack when choosing real estate investment trusts. For many investors, however, that may take some getting used to.

title: Pop | The Week Ahead
description: Pop

title: Real Virtues of Doormen
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolyn Kalos and Brian Byrd
description: Carolyn Kalos and Brian I. Byrd were married on Saturday evening at Bridgewaters, an event space in New York.

title: Mortgage Insurance: More Tax Breaks
description: THE Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 will have wide-ranging effects, not just the changes that apply to co-op corporations, discussed last week in Your Home.

title: Classic Revival
description: JUST about every historic campus has an Old Main, usually a musty warren of registrars and deans offices. Once they were the epicenter of campus life. Vassars Main housed dorms, classrooms, the dining hall, the chapel, the art gallery and the infirmary. Its wide corridors could be used for exercise in wet weather. The colleges president and lady principal lived in the central pavilion, the better to keep an eye on students.

title: Disarming Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: In This Race, Independents Are the Prize
description: NASHUA, N.H.  The race for president, steeped in appeals to each partys base for nearly a year, is for the next few days largely in the hands of voters who identify themselves as neither Republican nor Democrat.

title: AIDS Patients Face Downside of Living Longer
description: CHICAGO  John Holloway received a diagnosis of AIDS nearly two decades ago, when the disease was a speedy death sentence and treatment a distant dream.

title: Independence Daze
description: At some point early in this new year, President Bush and major European Union leaders are likely to recognize the independence of Kosovo over the furious objections of Serbia and its traditional protector, Russia. Such a decision may have unintended consequences. If Kosovo successfully achieves statehood, Republika Srpska, the Serb entity in Bosnia, will be tempted to follow suit in reprisal, slicing Bosnia almost in half. Meanwhile, Belgium has been gripped by talk about repeating Czechoslovakias 1993 velvet divorce, with Flemings and Walloons possibly splitting and forming their own little states. What about the claims for the independence of Kurdistan from Iraq or Chechnya from Russia or Transdniestria from Moldova? Referring to two regions of Georgia, President Vladimir Putin of Russia remarked, If someone believes that Kosovo should be granted full independence as a state, then why should we deny it to the Abkhaz and the South Ossetians? Its not a bad question  and its sure to bedevil Bushs successor in the White House.

title: West Coast Snow Prompts Emergency
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Snow continued to pile up in the Sierra Nevada on Sunday, where at least five feet had fallen from a storm that contributed to flooding in Fernley, Nev., killing at least three people and leaving thousands without power.

title: Uncomfortable Scrutiny for Two Friends Pitching Partnership
description: Roger Clemens and Andy Pettitte are thick-bodied starting pitchers who for years shared a trainer, an agent and a clubhouse. Clemens is an avid golfer, a father of four and a proud Texan, and so is Pettitte. Clemens was named in the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, and so was Pettitte.

title: McCain Mixes It Up on a Town-Hall Tour of New Hampshire
description: DERRY, N.H.  Senator John McCain was resting his chin on the microphone as a man with a full white beard in the corner of the opera house in Derry laid into him for his continuing support for the war in Iraq.

title: A Year in Iraq
description: MANY Americans and Iraqis feel that 2007 was the year the war in Iraq turned around: the surge strategy has pacified large sections of the country; previously hostile factions like those of the cleric Moktada al-Sadr and the sheiks in Anbar Province have dropped their opposition or even sided with American and government forces; and the number of insurgent attacks has dropped steadily. Still, numbers dont lie: for those in uniform, 2007 was the deadliest year since the invasion.

title: Reader Questions
description: Out-of-Control Debt

title: When Living at All Is the Best Revenge
description: IM going to get a cigarette, the actress Natasha Lyonne said by way of greeting. Do you want to go on the roof?

title: Lucky Charm
description: Lucky Charm

title: How to Survive the Lecture Course
description: The Reality

title: Two, Three, Many Columbias
description: ON a bitter night in November, I watched two protests face off on Columbia Universitys central quad. At the sundial, about 100 supporters of a five-student hunger strike, then in its ninth day, gathered close, screening their votives from the cold wind. They were demanding more money for ethnic studies, a more multicultural curriculum and a more neighborly plan for expanding north into Harlem from the Morningside Heights campus.

title: A Cozy, Comfortable Pub
description: As the summer home of Yales music and art schools, Norfolk is a popular warm-weather destination. In winter, when snow drifts blanket the ground and the rural, woodsy community lives up to its nickname, the Ice Box of Connecticut (owing to its high elevation), the comfortable, cozy Speckled Hen Pub offers another reason to stop by.

title: Seyna Bruskin, Thomas Zaslavsky
description: Seyna Jo Bruskin and Thomas Zaslavsky were married on Saturday at the Ren Pujol Restaurant in Manhattan. Marilyn Graman, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: The New Year Begins With a Thud
description: Wall Street got off to a miserable start of the year, with all three major indexes dropping by sizable margins.

title: Keeping It Real
description: What is Magna Carta worth? Exactly $21,321,000. We know because thats what it fetched in a fair public auction at Sothebys in New York just before Christmas. Twenty-one million is, by far, the most ever paid for a page of text, and therein lies a paradox: Information is now cheaper than ever and also more expensive.

title: El Al-American Pact to Add Service to Israel
description: Last month, El Al (www.elal.co.il), the national airline of Israel, and American Airlines (www.aa.com), the worlds largest airline, applied to their respective Departments of Transportation for authorization to begin a code-sharing agreement on Feb. 1. The agreement would give El Al and American Airlines passengers more options for flights between the United States and Israel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Second Opinion on Clemens

title: Downtown Moved Away
description: Hartford

title: Youll Remember Mamas
description: Sweet Mamas Good Kitchen is as retro and charming as the pint-size model of a red 57 Chevy that sits on its shingled roof. Inside the white clapboard house on the corner of Alsace Place and Route 25A in Northport, yellow-checkered tablecloths, wainscoting and vinyl-and-chrome chairs recreate the cheery look of a small-town 1950s luncheonette. Ketchup bottles and maple syrup dispensers sit on every table.

title: Harry Macklowes $6.4 Billion Bill
description: IN August 2003, Harry B. Macklowe raced from lender to lender to round up a record-breaking $1.4 billion to buy the General Motors Building, the 50-story commercial skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan that is one of New Yorks trophy properties.

title: Romney Wins Most Wyoming Delegates
description: CASPER, Wyo.  Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts who is locked in an intense primary battle in New Hampshire, captured the majority of Wyomings delegates to the Republican National Convention as the states Republicans met at county conventions.

title: Mary Beth Pitta, Jonathan Adelson
description: Mary Elizabeth Pitta and Jonathan Scott Adelson are to be married Sunday at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y. Ralph T. Gazzillo, a supervising judge of the Superior Criminal Court in Suffolk County, will officiate.

title: Branded at Garden: Bulls Are in Town
description: The Professional Bull Riders Inc. is celebrating its 15th season this weekend with competition in Madison Square Garden. Were not rodeo because were so different, the P.B.R. chief executive Randy Bernard told Reuters. Were closer to a cross between a Rolling Stones concert and a Nascar race. Above, J. B. Mauney prepared for his ride. At left, the bulls entered the Garden. Below, from left, a ramp leading to the pens; Tyler Pankewitz fell after riding Bad Action for eight seconds; and the riders Zack Brown, front, and Cole Taylor, on table, in the trainers room.

title: Sharp Clashes in Hectic Days Before Primary
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  The presidential candidates rushed into a final weekend of compressed and often harsh campaigning here Saturday, as they presented new themes to New Hampshire voters and tried to keep pace with a schedule that left little room for error before the primary on Tuesday.

title: The Deluge Before the Dollar
description: IN A Nation of Counterfeiters (Harvard University Press, $29.95), Stephen Mihm takes us back to the screwball days between the American Revolution and the Civil War, when the dollar did not exist.

title: Plan for Sewage Plant Splits Neighborhood
description: Locust Valley

title: Stop the World (and Avoid Reality)
description: IN the early 1960s, a Broadway musical called Stop the World, I Want to Get Off was all the rage. But you hear the sentiment of that title a lot these days.

title: Which Editing Is a Cut Above?
description: EVERY year, when the members of the editing branch of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences sit down to watch movies and choose the five nominees for film editing, they try very hard not to look at what theyre supposed to be looking at.

title: Commuting by Road, but Not by Car
description: FOR eight years, Brenda J. Murtha, a pension consultant with Aetna, drove 50 miles round-trip from her home in Colchester, Conn., to her job in downtown Hartford. But when Aetna recently announced that employees would be charged to park, she decided to try CT Transits Marlborough-Colchester Express bus.

title: A Hand That Links Germans and Turks
description: HAMBURG, Germany

title: Exploiting Sound, Exploring Silence
description: FOR all the raves and awards that have so far greeted Joel and Ethan Coens No Country for Old Men, there is one term of praise that does not apply: It is not a popcorn movie. Which is to say, it is especially ill-suited to the crunching of snacks or the crinkling of wrappers or any of the usual forms of movie-theater noise pollution. There is virtually no music on the soundtrack of this tense, methodical thriller. Long passages are entirely wordless. In some of the most gripping sequences what you hear mostly is a suffocating silence.

title: Destruction of More Than C.I.A. Tapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Strike Now, While the Deals Are Hot
description: YOU returned the crystal candy bowl from your mother-in-law, put the sweater from Aunt Ethel on eBay and now, as the cold, grim winter sets in and with no more festivities to distract you from the bleakness, you need a vacation somewhere hot and sunny.

title: In a Spirited Republican Forum, Romney Finds Himself a Frequent Target
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  It was five against one, or maybe one against five: Mitt Romney skirmished with each of his Republican rivals on Saturday night during a fiery debate here that was marked with repeated attacks that sometimes dripped with scorn.

title: Just for Men Just Right for Former Stars
description: It was (and is) cheesy, hokey, goofy, silly and evidently effective. It was a cri de coeur to men that their moribund love lives could be resuscitated with brush-in facial hair gel. It was the Just for Men advertisement with Keith Hernandez and Walt Frazier as barside analysts of Miss Hotties brush-off of poor Mr. Graybeard.

title: In the Shadow of Kenya's Violence
description: While much of Kenya is trying to get back to normal after violence that claimed more than 300 lives, Kisumu, Kenya's third-largest city, is still quivering with anger.

title: The Rematch Bowl

title: A Booster Shot for Medical School

Columbia University is credited with offering the first one, in 1955, for college graduates who lacked the science courses and board scores to apply to medical school. Today, more than 90 programs help potential doctors improve their chances. The certificate programs have proliferated as med schools have become more open to older applicants and more focused on increasing the number of admissions from underrepresented minorities.

title: The Adventures of Amir Hamza
description: The florid news writers, the sweet-lipped historians, revivers of old tales and renewers of past legends, relate that there ruled at Ctesiphon in Persia (image of Heaven!) Emperor Qubad Kamran, who cherished his subjects and was a succor to the impecunious in their distress. He was unsurpassed in dispensing justice, and so rigorous in this exercise that the best justice appeared an injustice compared to his decree. Prosperity and affluence thrived in his dominions while wrong and inequity slumbered in death, and, rara avis-like, mendicants and the destitute were extinct in his lands. The wealthy were at a loss to find an object for their charity. The weak and the powerful were equals, and the hawk and the sparrow roosted in the same nest. The young and the old sought one another's pleasure, neither ever deeming himself the sole benefactor. The portals of houses remained open day and night like the eyes of the vigil, for if someone stole even the color of henna from the palm, he was ground in the mill of justice. The thief therefore did not even dream of thieving, and if perchance a wayfarer should come upon someone's property on the road, he took it upon himself to restore it to its owner. Compared with Qubad Kamran's fearlessness, might, and valor, Rustam was the same as a hag most decrepit and cowardly.

title: The Unseen Merger Boom: SPACs
description: The rampant predictions of a 2008 decline in mergers and acquisitions are missing one coming takeover boom: acquisitions by special purpose acquisition companies or SPACs. SPACS are companies organized to purchase one or more operating businesses. The equity funds to acquire these businesses come from their initial public offering. Think private equity for the masses.

I figured the team was good for one year without Michael Schumacher and Ross Brawn, but surely not two, and not with a revolutionary design.
