A friend of Jones told Stephen Tsai of the Honolulu Advertiser that Jones resigned Saturday, citing a lack of commitment and loyalty on the part of athletic department officials. The move would seem to clear the way for Jones to accept a job offer from S.M.U.

title: Live From Tampa: a Fake Pirate Ship and Some Bad News for the Giants
description: The most interesting things about Raymond James Stadium is not its proximity to the Yankees spring-time home, Legends Field (across the street), or the league-high number of strip clubs within a square mile (about seven, but whos counting)? No, where the stadium feels like no other is in the north end zone, where a pirate ship has been beached on the concourse overlooking the stands. The pirates, fortunately, appear to have abandoned ship, and are nowhere to be found. In their place is a bunch of people taking turns climbing aboard and taking photos.

Equally important to good picture quality is the screens contrast ratio, its ability to display a wide range of tones, from dark blacks to white whites.

The finding counters a decade-old assumption that libraries serve as a bridge for people who want to use the Internet, but have only dial-up connections, or no access at all.

description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Alberto Alonso, a Cuban-born dancer, ballet master and choreographer, died last Monday at his home here. He was 90.

description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  Brandt Snedeker does things fast. Talk? Machine-gun bursts of words. Play golf? Not in the Mark Calcavecchia or John Daly category, but it is best not to glance away when it is his turn to hit. Achieve? The 2007 PGA Tour rookie of the year, he shot 61 in his opening round as a PGA Tour player, and his first career win came last year at 26 in the Wyndham Championship in Greensboro, N.C.

title: Times and CNBC to Share Material on Web Sites
description: CNBC and The New York Times have agreed to share material on their Web sites, uniting the main competitive targets of the News Corporations new ventures, the Fox Business Network and The Wall Street Journal.

description: With the stock plummeting and rivals on the attack, Starbucks is bringing back its top barista to turn the company around.

title: For migr Fans, Soothing Words and Spirited Rhythms From Home
description: Women squealed as the headliner took the stage at S.O.B.s late on Friday night, elegant in a dark suit with a yellow necktie. He started an anthemic ballad, and within moments, the audience was joyfully singing along and waving its arms overhead. The pop star onstage was Gossaye Tesfaye, a 32-year-old songwriter from Ethiopia, and he was singing love songs in the Amharic language. The crowd that filled the dance floor at 1 a.m. must have made up a considerable fraction of the 2,500 Ethiopians that the last census counted as living in New York City.

title: Investors Said to Seek a Takeover of CNet
description: CNet Networks, one of the original online media companies, would typically write about all the gossip and speculation at the Consumer Electronics Show this week in Las Vegas. Now, however, the company is likely to be the one talked about.

title: In Response to M.T.A.s Say Something Ads, a Glimpse of Modern Fears
description: After 9/11, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority coined the slogan, If you see something, say something, and put it on posters encouraging subway and bus riders to call a police counterterrorism hot line if they encountered anything suspicious. Then, last July, the authority trumpeted results on new posters and in television ads: Last year, 1,944 New Yorkers saw something and said something.

title: Mickey Mouse Paintings Are Recovered
description: Two valuable Walt Disney Company watercolors depicting Mickey Mouse as the sorcerers apprentice in the 1940 film Fantasia have been recovered 17 years after they vanished from a collection on loan to what was then the International Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye, N.Y., The Associated Press reported. The paintings were brought to the attention of the police on Oct. 30 by an antiques dealer in New Smyrna Beach, Fla., who bought them from someone who had acquired them in a sale of unwanted items from a storage facility in Florida. The police said the dealer researched the watercolors history and realized they were stolen. Rye Brook Police Chief Gregory Austin said they were valued at $60,000 to $80,000 at the time of the theft. It was not immediately clear what would become of them. The museum moved to Boca Raton, Fla., in 1996 and eventually closed.

title: After New Hampshire, a Rapidly Changing Race
description: The people paying closest attention to the 2008 presidential race have no idea what will happen next. So far, the contest keeps defying precedents.

title: France Is Trying Free Museum Admission
description: France is proceeding with an experiment in free admission at 18 national museums in an effort to entice more French to visit them, Reuters reported. Until June 30, some of the museums, including the Louvre in Paris, will offer free admission to their permanent collections while others will offer it to visitors under 26 one night a week. Normally the entrance fees range from $9 to $12. French museums are ready for more visitors, and we hope to draw in a new public, especially young people, said Christine Andr, a spokeswoman for the Culture Ministrys museum arm. Its a question of money for some people. Foreign tourists, who make up three-quarters of the visitors between the ages of 18 and 25, will also benefit from the experiment. Ms. Andr said, If the French start seeing long lines in front of the museums, theyll start to tell themselves: Hey, foreigners are taking advantage of this. Wed be morons not to.  Museum attendance in Britain has risen 50 percent since free admission was introduced there in 2001.

title: After Slow First Half, Chargers Show They Can Win in Postseason
description: SAN DIEGO  For a dozen seasons, the fans of the San Diego Chargers waited patiently for their drought to end. The reigns came for others. In Boston, the Red Sox won the World Series; so did the Chicago White Sox.

title: Filling Big Hiking Boots at an Early Age
description: A year and a half ago, Bindi Irwin was an 8-year-old growing up in the Australian outback, home-schooled so she could travel with her father, Steve Irwin, to film popular nature shows like The Crocodile Hunter. She sometimes appeared on camera, happily petting the occasional wallaby.

title: Justices Hear Arguments in Lethal Injection Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday heard starkly different descriptions of Kentuckys method of putting people to death, with a lawyer for a condemned prisoner asserting there is an unacceptable risk of agony and a lawyer for the state saying nothing could be further from the truth.

description: To the Editor:

description: SAN FRANCISCO  There may not be a Yahoo phone in the works, but the struggling Internet company is betting that a new mobile-phone strategy will help it better compete with the likes of Google, Microsoft and others for a share of the growing cellphone advertising business.

title: Spitzer Wants to Endow States Public Colleges
description: In his annual address to the Legislature on Wednesday, Gov. Eliot Spitzer will propose establishing an endowment for the states higher education system and adding 2,000 faculty members, according to a person with knowledge of the speech.

description: GOMA, Congo (Agence France-Presse)  Talks to secure peace in conflict-torn eastern Congo opened Sunday amid warnings by the Roman Catholic Church against a Balkanization of the vast African country.

title: Jamaican Music Is Missing
description: An extensive collection of vinyl records and discs of 1970s music, including original recordings by the reggae greats Bob Marley and Peter Tosh, has vanished from the archive of the former Jamaica Broadcasting Corporation, The Associated Press reported. Olivia Grange, Jamaicas information minister, said the possible theft of the music was a blow to the history of the island.

title: Issue May Really Be How Far Players Will Go to Gain an Advantage
description: When Roger Clemens explained on 60 Minutes on Sunday night that he received injections of a painkiller and a vitamin, he illustrated how pervasive various pharmaceuticals, supplements and protein potions have become in professional baseball, in which competition is its own narcotic.

title: A Tax Scare at the Garden, Among Other Worries
description: These are not halcyon days for Madison Square Garden. The Knicks are rapidly affirming their place as the most uninspired team in basketball. Their coach, Isiah Thomas, is greeted nightly by a chorus of boos.

description: SEATTLE  Quarterback Matt Hasselbeck wore designer jeans, a sweater and a smirk as he stood on a podium and started his postgame news conference.

title: Lacking a Permanent Home, He Must Lean on Nice People
description: Despite a right knee stiffened with arthritis, James Zemans actors bearing makes him appear taller than his six feet three inches. His taste in poetry runs to the classics: Emily Dickinson and William Blake.

title: Clinton Talks About Strains of Campaign
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  In perhaps her most public display of emotion of the presidential campaign, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons eyes welled with tears, and her voice cracked dramatically on Monday, as she talked about holding up under the rigors of the race and her belief that she is the best candidate for the Democratic nomination.

title: Record Victory for Finnish Ski Jumper
description: Janne Ahonen of Finland became the first ski jumper to win the prestigious Four Hills tournament for a fifth time.Ahonen, 30, won the final stop in rainy conditions in Bischofshofen, Austria, with jumps of 126 and 136 meters, earning him 251.6 points in the World Cup event.His main competitor, Thomas Morgenstern of Austria, finished third with 242.7 points. Ahonen also won the Four Hills tournament in 1999, 2003 and 2005. In 2006, he shared the victory with Jakub Janda of the Czech Republic.

title: Sri Lankans Kill 36 Rebels as Monitors Begin Pullout
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, (Agence France-Presse)  Heavy fighting raged Sunday in northern Sri Lanka, where Tamil Tiger rebels said they lost one of their leaders, as Norwegian-led monitors began pulling out before the formal end of a tattered truce.

title: Poughkeepsie: Assemblyman Hospitalized
description: State Assemblyman Thomas Kirwan, right, was scheduled to have a pacemaker installed Monday following an emergency visit last week to the hospital for a heart ailment. Mr. Kirwan, 74, a Republican from Newburgh, is scheduled for surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. We were told, absolutely, not to be concerned, his wife, Verna, said, The Poughkeepsie Journal reported Sunday. They decided to get this done so he can get his life back on track.

title: That Gilbert and Sullivan Maiden With Mission and Erudition
description: For more than 30 years the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players have won loyal audiences by providing musically ingratiating, broadly comic and very tame productions of this timeless repertory. You will not see high-concept stagings here  no Pirates of Penzance set in Guantnamo Bay. And thats the way patrons of this tradition-bound company like things.

title: Bhutto Book Release Advanced
description: HarperCollins will publish Reconciliation: Islam, Democracy and the West, by Benazir Bhutto on Feb. 12, six days before Pakistans postponed parliamentary elections are to take place. HarperCollins advanced publication from April 8 after Ms. Bhutto, the two-time former prime minister of Pakistan, was assassinated at a rally on Dec. 27. In the book, completed just days before she was killed, Ms. Bhutto, who collaborated with her friend Mark Siegel, a Washington lobbyist, argues that Islam should be reconciled with democratic principles. The book opens with a chronicle of her return to Pakistan in October after eight years of exile and the assassination attempt upon her return. Her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, now co-chairman of the Pakistan Peoples Party, has written an afterword with her three children. No one could have know that these would be Benazir Bhuttos final words, and somehow that makes them carry even more weight, especially at a time like this, said Tim Duggan, who edited the book. This book is her legacy. HarperCollins has also bought paperback rights to Daughter of the East, Ms. Bhuttos autobiography, originally published in Britain in 1988. It will be reissued in the United States in the spring under the title Daughter of Destiny.

title: A Murder Trial, 16 Tenacious Years Later
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y.  On an average Sunday in October 1991, the last average day they would have, David and Ann Scoville called their daughter, Patty, to see how she was settling into her new life in Stowe, Vt.

title: Manhattan: Fire Response Times Improve
description: The Fire Departments average response time decreased in 2007 for the second consecutive year, even as the number of calls increased slightly, the fire commissioner announced Sunday. The citywide average response time for all incidents was 4 minutes 49 seconds in 2007, a decrease from 4 minutes 54 seconds in 2006, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said. In 2005, the average response time was 5 minutes and 9 seconds, he said. The citys firefighters responded to 490,767 calls in 2007, a slight increase from 484,954 in 2006, Mr. Scoppetta said. For nonmedical emergencies, firefighters responded to 209,943 calls, the most in the departments history, he said.

title: Chopra Wins Mercedes in a Four-Hole Playoff
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  With night closing in on the Plantation Course at Kapalua on Sunday, the man with hair white enough to pierce the darkness put an end to sudden death. Daniel Chopra, dressed in white from head to toe, won the Mercedes-Benz Championship on the fourth hole of a playoff with Steve Stricker.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,897 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

description: Roger Clemens did not muster up a gift cocker spaniel named Checkers, the way Richard M. Nixon did in 1952, and he did not wag his finger at the nation the way President Bill Clinton did in 1998. All he could do was muscle up a fading fastball of what appeared to be false outrage Sunday night for 60 Minutes.

title: Iowa Caucus Results Put Pressure on Black Leaders for Endorsements
description: Before the Iowa caucus returns were in on Thursday, the phones started ringing in the home of Fletcher N. Smith Jr., a black state legislator from Greenville, S.C. Like other black leaders, Mr. Smith finds himself being courted so assiduously by the campaigns of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama that he said he had thought, Gosh, maybe I should run for president.

title: Poland Signals Doubts About Planned U.S. Missile-Defense Bases on Its Territory
description: BERLIN  Signaling a tougher position in negotiations with the United States on a European antiballistic-missile shield system, Polands foreign minister says his countrys new government is not prepared to accept American plans to deploy missile-defense bases in Poland until all costs and risks are considered.

title: Ligety and Miller Fail in Slalom
description: Mario Matt of Austria won the mens World Cup slalom Sunday, and Ted Ligety and Bode Miller of the United States failed to finish.Matt, a slalom specialist, finished with a total time of 1 minute 48.45 seconds at the Kuonisbaergli course in Adelboden, Switzerland, a tenth of a second ahead of his teammate Benjamin Raich.Ligety had tied for third in the first run in soft snow conditions. He straddled a gate and went out in the second run. Miller made an error at one of the first gates, then lost his footing a second time and failed to finish the first run.Jimmy Cochran was the only American to finish. He came in eighth, 1.27 seconds behind the leader.

title: Manhattan: Unlimited-Ride Cards for Path
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plans to introduce unlimited-ride cards of varying time periods on PATH trains later this winter. The cards are similar to ones now sold by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for use on buses and subways. One-day cards will cost $6, 7-day cards will cost $18 and 30-day cards will cost $54. The introduction of the unlimited-ride cards was part of the Port Authoritys decision last Friday to raise the one-way fare to $1.75, from $1.50. The price for 10-, 20- and 40-ride fare cards will increase to $1.30 per PATH ride, from $1.20. The new unlimited-ride cards will be introduced in early March, the same time the higher fares will take effect. PATH, for Port Authority Trans-Hudson, is a railroad that connects New York and New Jersey under the Hudson River.

title: Publishing Thats All About Me
description: Last Wednesday, I boarded an airplane, one of the last gated communities for major media. Up there  for the most part  there is no e-mail, no YouTube, no cellphone. Just me, my 11-year-old daughter in the bulkhead seat next to me and a stack of newspapers and magazines.

title: Saying Will You for Prizes, on the Web
description: ENGAGING the consumer is a popular phrase in marketing, particularly as the public shifts its attention from television to interactive media like the Internet. This Valentines Day, engaging consumers  or getting consumers engaged  is precisely what the online floral retailer 1-800-Flowers.com aims to do.

title: Keeping Guns Out of the Parks
description: Forty-seven United States senators recently wrote to the secretary of the interior, Dirk Kempthorne, asking him to lift the ban on carrying ready-to-fire weapons in national parks and wildlife refuges. Under current law, guns carried into or through a national park or refuge must be unloaded, taken apart, or cased in a way that will prevent their ready use. According to the senators letter, this rule infringes on gun owners rights and is confusing, burdensome and unnecessary.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: CBS Early Show Tries a Revised Format, Again
description: Morning viewers have seen this show before.

title: Economists Say Movie Violence Might Temper the Real Thing
description: NEW ORLEANS  Are movies like Hannibal and the remake of Halloween, which serve up murder and mutilation as routine fare, actually making the nation safer?

title: Bloomberg and Others Begin Talks on a Nonpartisan Path
description: NORMAN, Okla.  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and a dozen current and former elected officials from both parties arrived in this college town Sunday evening with little fanfare but grand ambitions.

title: Bomber Kills 4 on Iraqi Army Day
description: BAGHDAD  As jubilant Iraqi soldiers celebrated Army Day by dancing and chanting anti-insurgent slogans inside a downtown office building here on Sunday, a suicide bomber attempted to shove his way through the gate.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Bacardi & Company, Miami, chose the Santa Monica, Calif., office of 180, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle the creative duties for its Bombay Sapphire gin, which had been handled by Sugartown Creative, New York. Spending was estimated at $10 million.

title: Voter ID Laws Are Set to Face a Crucial Test
description: INDIANAPOLIS  In April 2006, a federal judge upheld Indianas law on voter identification, the strictest in the nation, saying there was no evidence that it would prevent any voter from having his ballot counted.

title: Queens: Man Fatally Shot
description: An 18-year-old man was found with a fatal gunshot wound to his head in Bayswater late Saturday night, the police said. The man was identified as Neville Ward of Hassock Street. Police officers responding to a report of a shooting found Mr. Ward behind a building near his home shortly before 11:30 p.m., the police said. He was pronounced dead 30 minutes later at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. There were no arrests Sunday. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Israel Says It Will Toughen Response to Longer-Range Fire
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli security officials said Sunday that a rocket with a longer range than usual fired by Palestinian militants from Gaza into the coastal city of Ashkelon on Thursday had been made in Iran. It was the first such rocket to land in Israel, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said Israel would intensify its response to the firing of such longer-range rockets.

title: As Primary Day Looms, Republican Rivals Go After One Another
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  After being pounded by his rivals at the Republican debate on Saturday, Mitt Romney struck back with a vengeance on Sunday by aggressively going after his main rivals, Senator John McCain of Arizona and Mike Huckabee, accusing them of breaking with Republican orthodoxy on taxes.

title: Retracing His Steps, McCain Is Feeling Rejuvenated
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator John McCains presidential campaign wheeled out a confetti gun on Saturday in Peterborough to boom a festive end to his 100th town-hall-style meeting. It was the same place he began his New Hampshire primary campaign of 2000.

title: Grief for a Fallen Fire Officer and Class Act
description: At the entrance to the Staten Island funeral home, the mourners lined up four rows deep, among them many who had known Lt. John H. Martinson all his life, and at least one man who had never laid eyes on him.

title: A Careful Game Plan, and a Bold Step
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: Bush Acknowledges Mixed Signals on Economy
description: CHICAGO  Dampening the administrations customary upbeat tone on the economy, President Bush acknowledged Monday that the economic signs were increasingly mixed, but he also suggested he would oppose Democratic initiatives to increase spending to head off a recession.

title: Decades-Long High School Streak Ends
description: The Brandon (Fla.) High School wrestling teams national record of 459 consecutive dual victories dating to 1973 has ended. South Dade High School topped Brandon, 32-28, on Saturday night in the finals of the Jim Graves Beat the Streak Tournament at Brandon High. Brandons streak began after Jim Graves, for whom the tournament is named, took over as the Eagles wrestling coach. Graves coached the team for nine years. The streak included 66 individual state champions and 18 team titles.

title: Going Beyond Crafty Defense Into the World of Underruffs
description: The winners of the Board-a-Match teams that ended Dec. 30 at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Midtown Manhattan were David Gurvich and Michael Lipkin of New York; Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J.; and Michael Prahin of Irvington, N.Y. They finished less than one point ahead of Melody Bi of Woodbury, Minn.; Steven Beck and Fred Chang of New York; and Michael Camp of Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Lottery Numbers
Short Passes Lead to Long Day for Bucs Defense
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Buccaneers claimed to know the answers even before Eli Manning and the Giants offense provided the test Sunday in their National Football Conference wild-card playoff game.

title: Readers Comments
description: I appreciate Alina Tugends article on plastic bottles even though it was inconclusive about the dangers of drinking from them. There are other dangers she didnt mention and they include to the environment. The attached Sierra Club report indicates that most single use bottles end up in landfills, in parkways, etc. to the tune of 10 billion a year!

title: Bronx: Fatal Stabbing After Party
description: Two men were stabbed, one fatally, after attending a house party in Crotona Park East early Sunday, the police said. The stabbings occurred shortly after 2:10 a.m. at an address on Southern Boulevard, the police said. Officers responding to a call of an assault found Frank Banks, 26, of East Harlem, with a stab wound to his chest and a second victim, whose name was not released, less seriously injured, according to the police. They were taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where Mr. Banks died. No arrests were announced Sunday.

title: After Iowa, Campaigns Cast Even Wider Net Online
description: MANCHESTER, N.H. -- While we have been racing to the candidates speeches in New Hampshire and counting the crowds on the ground, theres been a surge in online interest in both Senator Barack Obama and Mike Huckabee, the winners of the Iowa caucuses. Tech President has quantified it here.

title: Foiling U.S. Plan, Prison Expands in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  As the Bush administration struggles for a way to close the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, a similar effort to scale down a larger and more secretive American detention center in Afghanistan has been beset by political, legal and security problems, officials say.

title: A Paper Trail for Voting Machines
description: Los Angeles

title: Xerox Hopes Its New Logo Doesnt Say Copier
description: Still think copier when you hear the name Xerox?

title: Letters From Contributors to The Neediest Cases Fund
description: My brothers, sister and I were born in New York City, as were my mother (in the Bronx) and father (in Brooklyn). None of us currently live in New York City, but I proudly consider myself a New Yorker. My grandfather passed through Ellis Island, as did many of my relatives of his generation. New York City treated them well. In their memory I would like to help others who live in New York City and are in need.

title: Whose Century Is It Anyway?
description: The general election for president is still a ways off, but the New Hampshire primary campaign is providing a preview of the ultimate contest. So far, its not looking so good for the Republicans.

title: On Ground, Jaguars Can Keep Game Up in the Air
description: The Jacksonville Jaguars had lost an 18-point lead, ceding control and emotion to the Pittsburgh Steelers, and watching their chance for a franchise-altering victory evaporate.

title: As Electronics Show Grows, Some Scale Back
description: LAS VEGAS  People attending the Consumer Electronics Show, starting here on Monday, will encounter a crowded and noisy stage where technology companies from around the world unveil their latest wares.

title: Stadium Goes Up, but Bronx Still Seeks Benefits
description: Several years ago, as the Yankees negotiated to build a new stadium in the South Bronx, the neighborhood faced the realities of a massive construction project in its midst: parks would be closed and moved, traffic would be horrendous, life would be, for a while, a hassle.

title: In New Hampshire, Bill Clinton Finds Less Spark
description: DURHAM, N.H.  Is this what it would have been like had Elvis been reduced to playing Reno?

title: Yale to Increase Endowment Spending
description: Yale University, facing pressure from Congress and even some of its own donors to use more of its robust investment gains, announced on Monday that it would increase by nearly 40 percent the amount of money the university spends next year from its endowment.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
A Reliever From the Old School Awaits His Hall of Fame Day
description: The Yankees new relief pitcher lost three of his first four games, and people, including catcher Thurman Munson, were wondering what was going on. That pitcher, Rich Gossage, thereafter to be known primarily as Goose, gave up game-losing hits to Richie Zisk (home run) and Don Money (double), then made errors on successive sacrifice bunts.

title: In Trenton, Farewells Are Effusive, if Not All Fond
description: TRENTON  Call it the long goodbye.

title: Police Suspect Drag Racing Played Role in 3 Deaths
description: NORTH BERGEN, N.J.  Three people were killed and a fourth was seriously injured in a two-vehicle collision on Sunday afternoon on a New Jersey road with a reputation as a place for drag racing, the police said.

title: Clemens Calls Drug Accusations Totally False
description: Roger Clemens said his former personal trainers accusation that he had used steroids and human growth hormone was totally false, in a 60 Minutes broadcast Sunday. The interview set up a showdown next week before a Congressional committee that has summoned them to testify under oath.

title: 8 Die as Bus Tumbles Off Utah Road
description: Eight people were killed and 20 others were injured on Sunday when a chartered bus ran off a rain-slick road in far southeastern Utah on a weekend when fierce winter weather caused troubles across a wide swath of the West.

title: A Big Blue Breakthrough for Manning
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Most of the red-clad fans had turned their backs and gone, but a pocket of blue boiled in the northwest corner of the stadium, near the abandoned fake pirate ship on the concourse. The scoreboard overhead showed that the Giants had beaten the Buccaneers, 24-14.

title: Georgias President Narrowly Wins Vote
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Georgias pro-Western president narrowly won re-election over the weekend, according to official results released Sunday, but the main opposition candidate contested the outcome.

title: From Hype to Fear
description: The unemployment report on Friday was brutally bad. Unemployment rose in December, while job creation was minimal  and its highly likely, for technical reasons, that the job number will be revised down, showing an actual decline in employment.

title: Googles Lunchtime Betting Game
description: IT probably doesnt come as a huge surprise to learn that while employees in many companies sit in the cafeteria gossiping about work, or the boss, or the competition, at Google they are doing something else.

title: Long Island Rail Road from Long Beach to Penn Station
description: Monday, Jan. 7  7.39 a.m. Train

title: Mobile Backups at Quarterback Find Themselves in a Pivotal Role
description: NEW ORLEANS  The two starting quarterbacks in the Bowl Championship Series title game Monday night are more caretakers than playmakers.

title: If Your Hard Drive Could Testify ...
description: A couple of years ago, Michael T. Arnold landed at the Los Angeles International Airport after a 20-hour flight from the Philippines. He had his laptop with him, and a customs officer took a look at what was on his hard drive. Clicking on folders called Kodak pictures and Kodak memories, the officer found child pornography.

title: Queens: Two Killed in Collision
description: Two men were killed early Sunday when their Ford Thunderbird slid into the path of a public bus on Hillside Avenue in Jamaica, the police said. The accident occurred approximately 4:15 a.m., when the car, traveling east, slid sideways into the bus path at 168th Place, the police said. The cars driver, Christopher Boyd, 23, and his passenger, Eric Richmond, 25, both of Queens Village, were pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. The bus was carrying seven passengers from Hempstead to Queens, said Aaron Donovan, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The bus driver and one passenger were treated for minor injuries at Mary Immaculate Hospital and released, he said. The bus driver was not charged or issued a citation, the police said.

title: Energy Costs a Top Concern for New Hampshire Voters
description: HILLSBOROUGH, N.H.  People here treasure their rugged surroundings and relative isolation in the hills of southwestern New Hampshire. They welcome winter, and consider their distance from urban sprawl a clear advantage.

title: Treasure Still Jingling at the Box Office
description: The Disney film National Treasure: Book of Secrets maintained its grip on the No. 1 spot at North American box offices for a third consecutive weekend, while the small film Juno powered past the $50 million mark. National Treasure hauled in an estimated $20.2 million to bring its three-week total to $171 million, according to the box-office tracking company Media by Numbers. The creepy One Missed Call (Warner Brothers), starring Shannyn Sossamon, took in $13.5 million in its debut for fifth place. Between these finishers were the holdovers I Am Legend (Warner Brothers), rising to second from third last week with $16.3 million; Juno (Fox Searchlight), moving to third from fifth with $16.2 million (and a total take of $52 million in its fifth week in release); and Alvin and the Chipmunks (Fox), dropping to fourth from second on a gross of $16 million. The cumulative total for I Am Legend reached $228 million, and for Alvin $176.7 million. In terms of income per screen, the leader was There Will Be Blood (Paramount Vantage), with an average of $26,215 from 51 screens, compared to $8,429 for Juno from 1,925 screens and $5,376 from 3,762 screens for National Treasure.

title: Wiki Citizens Taking on a New Area: Searching
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Jimmy Wales co-founded Wikipedia in 2001 and called the site, which carried only a few articles then, a free encyclopedia, not many people took him seriously.

title: Deadly Bombing Mars Iraqi Celebration
description: BAGHDAD  As jubilant Iraqi soldiers celebrated Army Day by dancing and chanting anti-insurgent slogans inside a downtown office building here on Sunday, a suicide bomber tried to shove his way through the gate.

title: Accuracy Takes a Hit in Debates
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mitt Romney denied describing Senator John McCains immigration proposal as amnesty in an advertisement. John Edwards claimed he had never taken a dime from a Washington lobbyist in my entire time in public life. Rudolph W. Giuliani said the Islamic terrorist threat has nothing to do with our foreign policy.

title: Maazels Back in Mets Pit, and It Took Just 45 Years
description: Right conductor, wrong podium? Not at all.

title: A Literal Page Turner of a Mystery
description: For the librarians, says the dedication page of Geraldine Brookss new novel, People of the Book. Thats an understatement. What librarian could resist a novel that has the word book in its title, is centered on an intrepid book conservator, exults in book-preservation exotica (I know the flesh and fabrics of pages, the bright earths and lethal toxins of ancient pigments) and has a plot about a rare book with a long, fraught and serpentine history?

title: Songs From an Unrecorded Minstrel
description: This is a new song, Natalie Merchant announced onstage at the Hiro Ballroom on Friday night, at her first full New York City concert in four years. Try to absorb it here, now, cause I dont know when Ill make a record.

title: New Glosses on Ill-Fated Young Lovers
description: Golden lads and girls all must/ As chimney sweepers, come to dust. These lines from Cymbeline came to mind with the final tableau of Peter Martinss ballet of Romeo and Juliet for New York City Ballet. In this version, which returned to the repertory on Saturday afternoon after its premiere season in May, the star-crossed lovers end their lives in thoroughly nonballet style. Juliets head is across Romeos chest, but her knees are bent; he is lying at an unpicturesque and probably uncomfortable angle.

title: Romney Decides Second Beats Last
description: NASHUA, N.H.  With T-minus 36 hours and counting until the New Hampshire primary, Mitt Romney has had a marvelous revelation: He finished second in Iowa, which really means he almost won, which really means he is almost a front-runner here.

title: Rush of Water Leaves a Nevada Town in Anguish
description: FERNLEY, Nev.  With each squishy step she took Sunday morning on her saturated living room carpet, Becki Morales spotted more trouble. The floodwaters that rushed in after a levee broke on an irrigation canal early Saturday had largely receded in her one-story rental, but they left a sty of stained furniture, soaked power strips and damaged computer parts.

title: Film Critics Honor There Will Be Blood
description: The National Society of Film Critics named There Will Be Blood, directed by Paul Thomas Anderson and starring Daniel Day-Lewis, right, as a greedy oil speculator, as the best picture of 2007. Mr. Anderson was chosen as best director and Mr. Day-Lewis best actor. The Romanian director Cristian Mungius 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days, the Cannes prizewinner about two student friends who are ruthlessly exploited when one seeks an illegal abortion, was designated best foreign-language film. Honors for best actress went to Julie Christie for her portrayal of a woman afflicted with Alzheimers disease in Away From Her. Casey Affleck was named best supporting actor for his performance as the gunslinger Robert Ford in The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford and Cate Blanchett was named best supporting actress for her portrayal of Bob Dylan in Im Not There. No End in Sight, Charles Fergusons examination of the quagmire in Iraq, was designated best nonfiction film. The votes were cast on Saturday by 41 of the 61 members of the National Society of Film Critics at a meeting at Sardis Restaurant.

title: Observe Early and Often
description: Washington

title: Cruel and Far Too Usual Punishment
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments on Monday in a case about whether Kentuckys use of a cocktail of injected poisons to carry out the death penalty is unconstitutional. We believe that the death penalty, no matter how it is administered, is unconstitutional and wrong. If a state does execute anyone, it must do so in a way that is humane and does not impose needless suffering. Kentuckys method does not meet that standard.

title: Straddling Cultures, Irreverently, in Life and Art
description: BEIT SAFAFA, Israel  Being an Arab Israeli has always been a complex affair, at times almost a contradiction in terms. For Sayed Kashua, 32, an Israeli-born Arab journalist and author, it just got more complicated.

title: Not So Fast, Clinton Says About Obama Momentum
description: DERRY, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday sought to slow the momentum of Senator Barack Obama heading into the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday by pointedly challenging his voting record and the assertion that he is the only candidate who would bring about change.

title: Ill-Met by Moonlight With Pain to Spare
description: In Between Blood & Bone, an excerpt from Diane Arvanites-Noya and Tommy Nebletts Apokalypsis performed by its choreographers, the two alternately grapple with and curl around each other. Are they seeking advantage or escape? Something quietly terrible is unfolding between these worn-down individuals who seem to have known each other, in a particular way, long enough to have fought to a standstill.

title: In Musharrafs Shadow, a New Hope for Pakistan Rises
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Over the last several months, a little-known, enigmatic Pakistani general has quietly raised hopes among American officials that he could emerge as a new force for stability in Pakistan, according to current and former government officials. But it remains too early to determine whether he can play a decisive role in the country.

title: Some Brand-Name Bloggers Say Stress of Posting Is a Hazard to Their Health
description: Om Maliks blog, GigaOm, regularly breaks news about the technology industry. Last week, the journalist turned blogger broke a big story about himself. Mr. Malik, 41, blogged that he had suffered a heart attack on Dec. 28.

title: Jones Torn as Hawaii Makes Third Offer
description: The agent for Hawaii Coach June Jones said late Sunday night that his client was torn between taking the head-coaching job at Southern Methodist and a third offer from the University of Hawaii.

title: Brutishness Begets Brutishness on the Road
description: It may seem an odd thing to say about a film in which a baseball bat as an instrument of assault and rape is a recurring theme, but what makes A Bloody Aria a darkly delightful surprise is its restraint.

title: Paper Bags Get Pretty Chatty Nowadays
description: Dance may be in for a dire time, judging by the Fresh Tracks program on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop. Precious vacuity ruled in this latest installment of an august showcase devoted to choreography by emerging artists, suggesting that these Gen Y artists may not have the tools to make their ideas come to life.

title: Kenya Kikuyus, Long Dominant, Are Now Routed
description: NAKURU, Kenya  Kenyas privileged tribe is on the run.

title: Dig We Must for a Better St. Louis
description: In recent weeks, viewers of TV networks like TCM were treated to numerous showings of a favorite holiday film, Meet Me in St. Louis. Now comes a campaign that acknowledges it is going to be awfully hard for a long time to meet anyone in St. Louis.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the cover of the Business Day section on Saturday referred incorrectly to the status of the nonprofit organization One Laptop Per Child. The organization, which seeks to put low-cost computers into the hands of the worlds poorest children, continues to operate; there has been no demise of One Laptop Per Child. (An article inside that the headline referred to reported that the chip maker Intel had withdrawn its support from the organization.) (Go to Article)

title: Britney Spears Leaves Hospital
description: The troubled pop star Britney Spears was released on Saturday from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. She had been taken there by paramedics on Thursday night, when the police were summoned to her home after a dispute with her ex-husband, Kevin Federline, about their sons, Sean Preston, 2 and Jayden, 1. On Friday a court commissioner suspended the right of Ms. Spears, 26, to visit the children and awarded sole physical and legal custody to Mr. Federline before scheduling another hearing for Jan. 14. Previously Mr. Federline had temporary custody, and Ms. Spears had court-monitored visitation rights. After seeing Ms. Spears in the hospital, Phil McGraw, the television psychologist, said, My meeting with Britney and some family members this morning in her room at Cedars leaves me convinced more than ever that she is in dire need of both medical and psychological intervention.

title: President Mike Huckabee?
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Pro-Western President Re-elected in Georgia
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Georgias pro-Western president narrowly won re-election over the weekend, according to official results released Sunday, but the main opposition candidate contested the outcome.

title: A Tired Nadal Is Overwhelmed in India
description: Rafael Nadal, fatigued from a nearly four-hour match the previous day, was routed by fourth-seeded Mikhail Youzhny, 6-0, 6-1, Sunday in the final of the Chennai Open in India.The 19th-ranked Youzhny clinched the fourth title of his career. The second-ranked Nadal held his service only once.The 57-minute match turned out to be a letdown for Nadal, who needed 3 hours 54 minutes to overcome his fellow Spaniard Carlos Moy in what was the longest three-set match on the ATP Tour in 15 years.Rafa was not Rafa, Youzhny said. I did not win today, it was Rafa who lost. I did not expect it to be so easy.

title: Discovering Irishness, Recovering Niceness
description: David Morse, the only American in the otherwise all-Irish cast of The Seafarer, Conor McPhersons dark and glinting boozefest of a play now on Broadway after an acclaimed run in London, had a choice of roles. When his agent sent him the script, Mr. Morse said, two parts were open: Sharky, an endearing loser who, as his brother says, has made a pigs mickey out of everything, and the sleek and mysterious Mr. Lockhart (now played by Ciaran Hinds, most familiar to many Americans as Caesar in the HBO mini-series Rome).

title: G.M. to Show a Vehicle That Drives by Itself
description: LAS VEGAS  Within a decade, General Motors thinks it will have the ultimate solution to the growing problem of distracted drivers: a car that can do the driving itself.

title: Conspiracy and Democracy in Pakistan
description: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan has bowed, somewhat, to domestic pressure and called in Scotland Yard to help figure out who killed Benazir Bhutto. A credible investigation is urgently needed and Mr. Musharraf  who has no credibility of his own  needs all the help he can get.

title: In Blog, a Military Man Writes About His Own Death
description: Andrew Olmsted, a United States Army major who wrote an online blog for The Rocky Mountain News, prepared for the possibility of his death by writing a 3,000-word piece.

title: The Weeks Economic Reports
description: ECONOMIC INDICATORS It is a light week for economic data, headlined by the trade deficit figures for November (Friday). Other reports will include consumer credit for November (Tuesday) and wholesale trade inventories for November (Thursday).

title: In Strike, Separate Deals Draw Ire of Big Producers
description: LOS ANGELES  A deal between United Artists and the Writers Guild of America West to let the production company sidestep the screenwriters strike may have opened the door to a full-blown brawl, as other producers demanded to know why writers have granted some companies a special agreement but not others.

title: The Times, Are They A-Changing?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Trend-Spotting in N.F.L. Playoffs, Day 2
description: A look at some of the storylines to come out of wild-card weekend:1. Rivers vs. Manning.  Philip Rivers will be matched against Peyton Manning in the next round, but on Sunday, as he has been most of his career, he was on a parallel course with Eli Manning. The Titans stopped LaDainian Tomlinson and forced Rivers to beat them, and he did, earning his first playoff victory.

title: Need a Will? Leave It to Me!
description: More of your late-night comedy (send yours via the comment link below):

title: Wiki Citizens Taking on a New Area: Searching
description: Jimmy Wales, the co-founder of Wikipedia, expects his new Internet search engine, Wikia Search, to follow a trajectory similar to that of his free encyclopedia, which since its launch in 2001 has grown into an important, if not always reliable, digital reference for millions of Internet users.

title: Air China Raises Bid in Battle for China Eastern
description: Air Chinas parent vowed on Sunday to pay at least 32 percent more for a coveted slice of China Eastern than a rival suitor, Singapore Airlines agreed to, raising the ante in their contest for China Eastern, Chinas No. 3 carrier.

title: Former TXU Lawyer Gets $5 Million to Stay On
description: Energy Future Holdingss private equity buyers, led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and TPG, are coughing up bout $5 million to keep the companys general counsel, David Poole, on board for the time being.

title: Rock Band  One Mans Journey
description: A video game nut learns the post-holiday blues, but not how to play them:

title: Deeya Energy Fires Up $15 Million Round
description: Deeya Energy, which makes large flow batteries to provide backup power to industrial plants, raised $15 million in a second round of financing, according to Venture Wire.

title: Lone Star Chairman to Testify in South Korean Suit
description: The chairman of Lone Star Funds plans to testify next week at the trial of the buyout groups South Korean chief for alleged stock price manipulation, a spokesman told The Associated Press.

title: Toronto-Dominion and Commerce Settle Takeover Lawsuits
description: The Toronto-Dominion Bank and Commerce Bancorp, which is being bought by its Canadian rival, have entered into a settlement agreement to put to rest a number of lawsuits that had been filed on behalf of Commerces shareholders.

title: Hedge Funds With Northern Rock Stakes Fight Takeover
description: Hedge funds SRM Global and RAB Capital on Monday detailed their case for blocking takeover offers for Northern Rock, the troubled British bank that precipitated Britains worst banking crisis in more than a century.

title: Time is Crucial for Chinas Wealth Fund
description: The China Investment Corporation may still be operating out of makeshift offices, but with its $5 billion investment in Morgan Stanley the contours of the infant sovereign wealth funds strategy are becoming clearer.

title: When Melanie Met Cristina
description: It takes two to tango but you to amuse. Tell us whats going on down Argentine way in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Bashing Cerberuss Chrysler Deal
description: It was only five months ago that Cerberus Capital Management bought 80 percent of Chrysler from Germanys Daimler but already the vultures are circling, Fortune notes.

title: Harry Macklowes $6.4 Billion Bill
description: In August 2003, Harry B. Macklowe raced from lender to lender to round up a record-breaking $1.4 billion to buy the General Motors Building, the 50-story commercial skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan that is one of New Yorks trophy properties.

title: Finish Line Said to Explore Options to Genesco Deal
description: If Finish Line is forced to complete its ill-fated takeover of rival shoe seller Genesco, the combined company may have to shed assets or sell out to a private-equity shop, The New York Post reported.

title: Foreign Buyers Ramp Up U.S. Deal Making
description: Foreign investors ramped up purchases of United States companies in the fourth quarter to the fastest pace in at least a decade, a reflection of the falling value of the dollar, Bloomberg News reported.

title: For the Moment |  Business as Usual
description: Last weeks guest bloggers were Loden Dager, a mens wear collective based in New York City that launched in the Fall of 2006 and recently won the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award for new talent. Its members, pictured, are: Melissa Vail, Matthew Sandager, Oliver Helden, Paul Marlow, and Alex Galan. Judging from their final dispatch, which could not be posted on Saturday because of technical difficulties, its as if they never left. (Read previous blog entries written by Loden Dager and a profile of Alex Galan here.)

title: Pension Funds Balk at Buyout Fund Increases
description: Is a confrontation between buyout shops and pension funds, their largest and most loyal investor base, in the offing?

title: Coal for Some Goldman Employees?
description: With all the hype recently about Goldman Sachs being the only major investment bank to avoid being stung in last years subprime mortgage fiasco and the record profits it rung up last year, bonus time was expected to be a time of good cheer for Goldman employees.

title: Hedging Their Way to Billions
description: Remember the colossal salaries of hedge fund managers  when they needed to earn at least $240 million just to be included among the 25 wealthiest in 2006? Well, those numbers may now look puny, especially at the top of the range.

title: The Appetite for Securities Turns Less Hearty
description: To some on Wall Street, the last half of 2007 may have had the feel of a buyers strike. Financial products that had experienced rapidly growing demand suddenly became all but unsalable.

title: FairPoint and Verizon Edge Closer to Clinching Deal
description: FairPoint Communicationss amended $2.7 billion merger with Verizon Communicationss local phone operations in the New England states won general approval from Maine regulators, the company said Friday.

title: Resource Pacific Rejects $840 Million Xstrata Bid
description: An Australian coal mining company, Resource Pacific Holdings, on Friday rejected its second offer in a month, saying a 960 million Australian dollar ($840 million) bid from Switzerlands Xstrata  was too low and failed to reflect potential synergies.

title: Monster to Acquire Affinity Labs for $61 Million
description: After roughly nine months on the job, Sal Iannuzzi, the chief executive of Monster Worldwide, the online employment company, is continuing his efforts to revive the company.

title: Heritage-Crystal Details I.P.O. Terms
description: Heritage-Crystal Clean, which provides parts cleaning and container waste services, expects to sell 1.7 million shares priced between $10.50 and $12.50 each in its initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Friday.

title: A Silver Lining Behind Imperiums Aborted I.P.O.?
description: The announcement last week by Imperium Renewables, a biodiesel producer, that it had withdrawn its plan to go public, amounted to an admission that Imperium was overly ambitious in gauging investor demand for alternative energy stocks, The Deal.coms Tech Confidential blog argued.

title: Schwarzman Said to Offer Olive Branch to Banks
description: Stephen Schwarzman has been forced to eat a rare slice of humble pie on Wall Street. Schwarzman, chief executive of the Blackstone Group, went hat in hand to JPMorgan Chase and Lehman Brothers in an effort to mend fences after the banks pulled the plug on his $1.8 billion deal to acquire PHH, The New York Post reported.

title: An Intellectual Bent for New Start-Up
description: Peter Hopkins, a civic-minded and idealistic 2004 Harvard graduate, is hoping that his new Web site, Big Think, will do for intellectuals what YouTube, the popular video-sharing site, did for bulldogs on skateboards.

title: Carrefour Abandons Bidding for Turkeys Migros
description: Carrefour, the French supermarket group, said on Monday it had pulled out of the auction of Migros Turk, the biggest supermarket group in Turkey, leaving the field clear for four private equity groups and Agrokor of Croatia, The Financial Times reported.

title: Credit Suisse Shares Fall Amid Write-Down Fears
description: Shares in Credit Suisse fell by around 3 percent on Monday after a Swiss newspaper reported the bank faced writedowns in its commercial mortgage and leveraged-finance business, Reuters said.

title: JPMorgan Plans Asia Hiring Spree
description: JPMorgan Chase plans to add at least 700 staff to its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Hong Kong over the next three years and lease up to 11 floors in a new office block to accommodate the growth, Reuters reported.

title: Clinton's New Hampshire Strategy
description: A look at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's strategy shift  in her first three days in New Hampshire after finishing third in Iowa.

title: Has Measuring Risk Changed Forever?
description: For years, three big agencies assigned risk ratings to thousands of securities, helping investors figure out which were likely to be safe investments and which were more speculative.

title: Investors Seek a Takeover of CNet
description: CNet Networks, one of the original online media companies, would typically write about all the gossip and speculation at the Consumer Electronics Show this week in Las Vegas. Now, however, the company is likely to be the one talked about.

title: Colony Capital Hires Ex-Amgen C.F.O. as Principal
description: Colony Capital, a private equity firm focused on real estate, said on Monday that it had hired Richard D. Nanula as a principal with a senior role in the firm.

title: A Different Kind of Support
description: The Bagger saw Amy Ryan, the presumptive favorite in the best supporting category, pick up another laurel from the New York Film Critics Circle for her role in Ben Afflecks Gone Baby Gone. The betting is that she is a near lock for a Golden Guy, with Cate Blanchett providing the only competition for her eerie inhabitation of Dylan in Im Not there. But at the Film Experience blog, the word is, not so fast. What about Marisa Tomei in Before the Devil Knows Youre Dead?

title: The Smart Money On New Hampshire
description: They havent voted yet in New Hampshire, but my unnamed sources tell me theres not much question who will win: Barack Obama and John McCain.

title: LCD or Plasma? Words From the Master
description: Paik Woo is generally regarded as one of the fathers of digital TV. Along with several colleagues, in the early 1990s, Dr. Paik figured out how to compress a digital signal, making it sufficiently small to be able to be transmitted over the air.

title: Eyeing the Future at C.E.S., Part 1
description: As Matt Richtel and I report in Mondays paper, attendees of this years Consumer Electronics Show, which has just kicked off in Las Vegas, should not expect to see the Big Consumer Hit of 2008. The show has become too crowded, loud and obsessed with technical features and standards to produce the simple devices that consumers love, like the iPod, Wii or the Flip Video camcorder.

title: But You Know, Apple Is Really Just One of Us
description: Quantity-wise, C.E.S. has nothing to apologize for. At last count, it has something just shy of a gazillion gadgets and companies.

title: Letting the Air Out of the Globes, Slowly
description: So, the Globes are on/off/live/private/televised and shuttered. The Bagger is getting on a plane no matter what at the end of the week, but he has no idea what he will be doing after he lands. There had been word that NBC would stand down and that the awards would go off untelevised, but we wont know with any certainty until later today, according to Variety.

title: High School With Money
description: What happens when a pregnant teen turns into a monster? Watch and learn, write the folks at rottentomatoes.com:

title: Clinton's New Hampshire Strategy
description: A look at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's strategy shift  in her first three days in New Hampshire after finishing third in Iowa.

title: How Riders Responded to M.T.A.s Say Something Ads
description: In July, to trumpet the results of a campaign to urge people to call a police counterterrorism hot line to report suspicious activity, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority proclaimed on posters and in television ads, Last year, 1,944 New Yorkers saw something and said something. William Neuman, who covers transit for The Times, asks what, exactly, did those 1,944 New Yorkers see, and what did they say?

title: Way Too Early for Shaking Hands
description: NASHUA, N.H.It must have seemed like a good idea at the time to Mitt Romneys New Hampshire staff: get the Gov out early to greet employees coming in to work at BAE Systems here.

title: The Early Word: Whos the Real Change Candidate?
description: The weary, hoarse-voiced presidential candidates have just Monday and part of Tuesday to stop the surges of John McCain, who is leading the polls among Republicans, and his Democratic counterpart Barack Obama, in New Hampshire. Or if they happen to be Mr. McCain or Mr. Obama, there are two days left to fend off their rivals and not make a momentum-killing gaffe.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: New York Hugs Its Own
description: The Bagger made a rare trip in through the tunnel on a Sunday for an evening of awards and vittles at the New York Film Critics Circle. The event itself is always a peach, in part because New York shows up to honor its own and some temporary adopted citizens, like Sarah Polley and Daniel Day-Lewis.

title: Whats Happened to Ronaldinho?
description: He was one of the most dazzling soccer players to samba across the field in a generation. His step-overs, deft flicks, stunning free kicks and uncanny knack for making the ball bend to his will inspired thousands  nay, more than 100,000  YouTube montage tributes.

title: The Tussle Over CNet
description: The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin appears on CNBC to discuss takeover talk about CNET, an online media company.

title: Hall of Fame & Shame: TVs Car Ads, 2007
description: Spoilsports at the Insurance Fraud Bureau of Massachusetts and the Washington-based Coalition Against Insurance Fraud wagged accusatory fingers at Toyota last week for one of the funnier television advertising campaigns of 2007. The ads, pumping the manufacturers end-of-year clearance sale, depicted car owners so desperate to buy new Toyotas that they were resorting to nefarious activities to get rid of their existing cars - including rolling boulders onto them, leaving them on railroad tracks and chopping down trees that fell on them.

title: YouTube Video Draws Australian Condemnation
description: There are YouTube videos that may be described as un-tasteworthy in the extreme, and then there are those that draw the attention of world leaders for precisely that reason. Today, Foreign Minister Stephen Smith of Australia issued an (audio statement) condemning a video that accuses his country of racism, according to Agence France-Presse:

title: N.H. Forecast: Primary Eve
description: Countdown: 1 day until the primary!

title: Sallie Mae Appoints New Chairman, C.F.O.
description: Sallie Mae on Monday appointed a longtime banking executive as its new chairman, replacing Albert L. Lord at that position as the beleaguered student lending giant continues to struggle with tighter credit markets and the wreckage from its failed buyout. Mr. Lord will remain chief executive.

title: Obama Cautions Voters About His Lead Position
description: CLAREMONT, N.H.  It wasnt so long ago when Senator Barack Obama was reminding his audiences not to believe the polls. Today, he isnt disagreeing with the trends polls are showing in the New Hampshire primary  his lead is widening, they say  but he is urging his supporters not to grow comfortable.

title: Kristols Persuasion
description: In general, The Opinionator isnt much inclined toward navel gazing, but sometimes the press (or in this case, the pundit) is the story. William Kristol made his debut on the Op-Ed Page of The Times this morning with musings on the Huckabee phenomenon:

title: Contributor: Mark J. Penn
description: Mark J. Penn was the chief adviser to Bill Clinton in the 1996 presidential election and to Hillary Rodham Clinton in her Senate and presidential races. He is the author of Microtrends: The Small Forces Behind Tomorrows Big Changes.

title: Another jobs picture  Europe vs. US (updated)
description: While Im on the employment thing, I thought it might be worth looking at an international comparison.

title: Who Gets Free Drug Samples?
description: For years, the drug industry has claimed that poor people benefit from the billions of dollars worth of free drugs that are distributed to doctors every year.

title: Romneys 2-Minute Closing Message on the Air
description: Mitt Romney has purchased two minutes of television time tonight on networks in Manchester and Boston for his closing message to New Hampshire voters that centers around his retooled campaign theme focused on change.

title: Championship Week Around the World
description: Its the start of a very special week in the NHL and around the hockey world. Thanks to a series of lucky schedule quirks, the top two clubs will square off in the NHL and in two of the top European leagues. In addition, six of last years best will meet in the four-day-long European Champions Cup in St. Petersburg to decide top dog on the continent.

title: Does the MetroCard Need a Makeover?
description: More so than any credit card, library card or health insurance card, the MetroCard is the one piece of plastic that most unites New Yorkers. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority distributes 180 million of them  thats not a typo  every year. The MetroCard is a fixture of anyones pocket, wallet or purse, a mainstay for any commuter, and  ever since the last tokens were phased out in 2003  the only one way to (legally) ride a subway in New York City. And yet, few people spend much time looking at or thinking about the humble, homely MetroCard.

title: PHH and Blackstone, Together Again?
description: PHH filed a settlement agreement on Monday that it had signed on Friday with Blackstone in connection with Blackstones payment of a $50 million dollar reverse termination fee and the termination of their merger agreement.

title: Huckabee Attacks Romneys Record
description: Mason, N.H.  A day before the New Hampshire primary, former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas embarked on his first full day of campaign appearances here since his victory in the Iowa caucus, stepping up his attacks on an unnamed opponent who sounds very much like former Gov. Mitt Romney.

title: Contributor: Stuart M. Butler
description: Stuart M. Butler is the vice president for domestic policy at the Heritage Foundation, a research foundation, and an adjunct professor in public policy at Georgetown University. In addition to testifying before Congress on health care issues, he writes frequently about health affairs.

title: Contributor: Ezekiel Emanuel
description: Ezekiel Emanuel, an oncologist, is the chairman of the department of bioethics at the Clinical Center of the National Institutes of Health. The co-director of Stanford Universitys FRESH-Thinking Project, which is exploring ways to improve health care, he is also the author of Health Care, Guaranteed: A Simple, Secure Solution for America. In 2004, Mr. Emanuel contributed money to Barack Obamas campaign for the United States Senate, and his brother Rahm Emanuel is President-elect Obamas chief of staff.

title: Maher Returns to HBO Without Writers
description: HBOs Real Time With Bill Maher will return with new episodes Friday without both writers and two of its most popular features, Mahers opening monologue and the closing segment New Rules,' according to The Hollywood Reporter (via Reuters).

title: Contributor: Lawrence C. Levy
description: Lawrence C. Levy, a former political columnist and senior editorial writer for Newsday, is the executive director of the National Center for Suburban Studies at Hofstra University in New York.

title: U.S. Military Reports Skirmish With Iran
description: Updated with official confirmation and reactions from Iran and several bloggers.

title: Taking Stock of SPACs
description: No doubt about it: The number and size of special-purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs, is surging. But SPAC stocks? Thats a different story.

title: Eyeing the Future at C.E.S., Part 2
description: Following up on my last post: what if you didnt have to strap on a pair of geeky goggles to watch video on your iPod, cell phone or video game console, but could project the devices image on a nearby wall or surface? Thats the premise of Microvision, a company from Redmond, Wash., and its pocket-sized, laser-powered Pico Projector.

title: For the Moment |  Adam Kimmel
description: This weeks guest blogger is the New York-based mens wear designer Adam Kimmel. Known for his heady brand of cerebral machismo  Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock are recurring inspirations  Kimmel, 28, will be filing from Florence, Italy, where he is the featured designer at the mens-wear trade show Pitti Immagine Uomo.

title: A New You: Gina Kolata on Fitness
description: How much exercise do you really need? What does science tell us about what it takes to lose weight and to keep the pounds off? Reporter Gina Kolata covers health and medicine for The Times and writes Personal Best, a biweekly column on fitness. This week, as readers begin the hard business of keeping New Years resolutions, Ms. Kolata is answering questions and hosting a discussion on fitness and weight loss. You may post your comments and questions below. Please remember that she cannot answer all questions, and she cannot respond to solicitations for medical advice. [Eds. note: We are no longer accepting questions and comments.]

title: After the Hunt
description: My friend Neil shot a deer. This was not surprising, considering that Neil is one surfboard-riding, juji gatame slapping-on, muzzleloader-wielding kind of guy. So when he brought home the venison yours truly and a small but hungry crew were rested, ready and salivating.

title: The Best Player in the NHL Today?
description: Sidney Crosby is the face of the NHL, the man in all the leagues ads, the player picked to draw interest to showcase events like the Ice Bowl last week and quite probably the Victoria Cup in September. Hes a great player  but is he really the best in hockey?

title: The Problem With CNet: No One Wants to Buy It
description: Andrew Ross Sorkin reports in this mornings New York Times that an investor group has amassed a stake in CNet Networks and wants to put pressure on its management by electing new board members.

title: A Chilling Idea at C.E.S.
description: Lets put our skepticism away for a moment. There are in fact some big ideas at the 2008 C.E.S.  speaking literally, at the very least.

title: L.S.U. Cruises to B.C.S.Title
Contributor: Scott M. Delman
description: Scott M. Delman is the managing partner of a private equity firm and has served on the board of various academic and public policy organizations. He has contributed to and raised money for John McCains 2000 and 2008 presidential bids.

title: Contributor: Eric Wasserstrom
description: Eric Wasserstrom is a managing director at a New York-based hedge fund and previously was an equity analyst for a global investment bank focusing on consumer lending. Prior to working on Wall Street, he did bank regulation for the Federal Reserve. He is also a security fellow at the Truman National Security Project, a national security leadership institute.

title: Monday on the Trail
description: The weary, hoarse-voiced presidential candidates raced around New Hampshire on the last full day of campaigning before Tuesdays primary.

title: A Fan in the French Quarter
description: NEW ORLEANS  I landed here at 10 a.m. Saturday. I sat in front of a nun on the airplane. Maybe that is a sign to behave in the French Quarter.

title: Sallie Mae's Management
description: CNBC's David Faber discusses Sallie Mae's  appointment of a new chairman.

title: The Torch of Womens Lib
description: For centuries women have been told not to smoke. Today, its with good reason  smoking is killing women in record numbers.

title: Contributor: Joanna R. Shelton
description: Joanna R. Shelton is a senior fellow at the Montana World Affairs Council and a research professor in economics at the University of Montana. Previously, she was the deputy secretary general of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. She has also been the deputy assistant secretary of State for trade policy and programs, a professional staff member on the House Ways and Means subcommittee on trade and an economist at the Treasury Department and at the Trade Representatives Office. She has contributed money to Barack Obamas presidential campaign.

title: Big Wheel Keep On Turnin
description: The Red Wings did it again Sunday, beating their Original Six nemesis, the Blackhawks, in Chicago, 4-1. That makes win No. 32.

title: C.E.S.: Bill Gates Keynote
description: Bill Gates headlines the C.E.S. festivities last night, reports CNBC's Jim Goldman.

title: Motorola Still Not Getting the Icahn Lift
description: Carl Icahn has said that his corporate agitations have created $50 billion in shareholder value over the last few years. But so far, Motorola isnt feeling the Icahn Effect.

title: Contributor: Sandra Tsing Loh
description: Sandra Tsing Loh, a writer and a performer, is the author most recently of Mother on Fire, a comic memoir of her struggle to find a school in Los Angeles for her child to attend. She has been a regular commentator on NPRs Morning Edition and Ira Glass This American Life. American Public Medias Marketplace broadcasts her monthly segment, The Loh Down. She is also a contributing editor for The Atlantic.

title: A Candidate Spurned
description: For the last year or so, no one professed to love Iowa and the nominating process more than Hillary Rodham Clinton. She told Iowans how much she appreciated their state. She admired the serious way in which they examined all the candidates. She thought they were just the kind of people to help choose the Democratic nominee. So it was noticeable that, by the time the Clinton campaign touched down here in New Hampshire last week, she and her spurned aides had begun dissing Iowa and its role in the process.

title: Monday Kickoff: Championship Monday Arrives
description: Well, the day has finally come. After all of the unbelievable upsets, the triple-overtime games, the 15-lateral, last-second plays, the final day of the college football season has arrived. Be sure to check out The Quad tonight for live game-tracking of the B.C.S. title game. Until then, here are some articles for your reading pleasure.

title: Sandras Sources | Veya
description: T Magazines Senior Editor Sandra Ballentine opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.

title: Larkin, Atop the High Heap
description: Who is the greatest British writer since 1945?

title: Dexter Will Air on CBS
description: The Showtime series Dexter will be shown on a different network, CBS, starting on Sunday, Feb. 17 at 10 p.m., CBS announced today.

title: CIBC Ousts Two Executives Amid Write-Downs
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, the countrys worst-performing bank stock last year, ousted its top investment banker and chief risk officer after announcing debt writedowns of as much as $3 billion, more than any other Canadian lender, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Picketers Will Greet Colbert and Stewart
description: Comedy Centrals pair of news satires will resume production today after a two-month strike-induced hiatus. Small picket lines of Writers Guild of America members will be stationed outside the studios of both The Daily Show and The Colbert Report as Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert return to their respective broadcasts.

title: Lewis Hamiltons birthday present
description: Lewis Hamilton turned 23 years old today, and as a way for him to forget that he is entering 2008 not only no longer as a rookie but far from being a young man in F1 terms (these days  ask Sebastian Vettel), the McLaren Mercedes team gave him a birthday present in the form of the 2008 car.

title: Romney Finds Stability in Change Message
description: STRATHAM, N.H.  Mitt Romney has seemed distinctly more comfortable in New Hampshire after rolling out a revamped stump speech focused on bringing change to Washington.

title: High-Definition Movies, Without the Format War
description: As the major studios continue to battle over Blu-ray and HD DVD, the competing standards for high-definition DVDs, its always worth considering whether both camps are ultimately doomed  leapfrogged by straight-to-the-home digital downloads of high definition movies.

title: Open Caucus: N.H. Debate Reviews
description: The Timess virtual round table of voters talked about the recent debates in New Hampshire.

title: CBS Poll Reflects Iowa Influence
description: Few Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire say last weeks results were important in determining their choices, but polls show the shape of the contest has changed since the Iowa caucuses.

title: Theres Still Time to Register to Vote in New York
description: Would-be new voters in New York who are head-over-heels for Huckabee or committed to Clinton had better hurry. The deadline is looming for new registrants who want to vote in New Yorks Feb. 5 presidential primaries. The state Board of Elections says that all new registrations must be mailed to county boards with a postmark of Friday or earlier. People who choose to register in person also must do so by Friday.

title: Where Have You Gone, John McCain?
description: Has John McCains window closed as quickly as it opened? Joe Klein at Swampland thinks so:

title: Internet to the TV? Me Too!
description: For all the product announcements and new technologies at the Consumer Electronics Show, there is a monster level of me-tooism. Every exhibitor is trying to out do the other on the topic du jour. This year, as in years past, the topic is: piping Internet content onto your TV.

title: The White House and the Wall Street Factor
description: Are the early results in the presidential races showing an anti-Wall Street tinge?

title: Clinton Tears Up; Talks About Campaign Strains
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  In perhaps her most public display of emotion in the presidential campaign, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons eyes welled with tears, and her voice cracked dramatically, as she talked about holding up under the rigors of the race and her belief that she is the best candidate for the Democratic nomination.

title: Contributor: Michael A. Cohen
description: Michael A. Cohen is a senior research fellow at the New America Foundation and the author of Live From the Campaign Trail: The Greatest Presidential Campaign Speeches of the 20th Century and How They Shaped Modern America. He has served as a speechwriter for Senator Chris Dodd and former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Bill Richardson, and has volunteered for a number of Democratic presidential campaigns.

title: A Word of the Year for Our Times
description: Until the various word authorities agree to hold a decisive event like the Oscars, someones going to have to keep track of all of these words-of-the-year. Thus, today we bring the latest champion, and possibly the most convincing: subprime.

title: Terrelle Pryor Picks Ohio State to Win
description: Terrelle Pryor has yet to make his college choice, but hes picking Ohio State tonight.

title: The Times and CNBC.com Team Up
description: Larry Ingrassia, business editor of The Times, and Allen Wastler, managing editor of CNBC.com, discuss the partnership between the two news organizations.

title: Microsoft's New Hardware
description: A look at Microsoft's presence at the Consumer Electronics Show, with Robbie Bach, president of Microsoft's entertainment devices division, and CNBC's Jim Goldman.

title: Tax Clash on the Trail
description: CONCORD, N.H.  Emotions ran high on the last day before the primary. At a campaign stop here, Mike Huckabee was mobbed by supporters of the libertarian candidate Ron Paul, who shouted Tax Hike Mike! Tax Hike Mike.

title: No More New Things From Microsoft
description: In an era when the vanguard of technology is creating smart devices for entertainment and communications, Bill Gates, the outgoing chairman of Microsoft, had little that was interesting or innovative to show off in his last annual keynote at CES in Las Vegas on Sunday.

title: Contributor: Andrew Kohut
description: Andrew Kohut is the president of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press. He is a former president of the Gallup Organization and a founder of Princeton Survey Research Associates. The co-author of four books, he is a frequent commentator on polls for National Public Radio, PBS and other news media outlets.

title: Contributor: Matthew Continetti
description: Matthew Continetti is the associate editor of The Weekly Standard and author of The K Street Gang: The Rise and Fall of the Republican Machine. He edits The Standards campaign blog and appears regularly as a political analyst on National Public Radio and MSNBC.
