His articles and reviews have appeared in, among other publications, The Times, The Financial Times and The Washington Post.

title: Contributor: Ron Klain
description: Ron Klain was a member of Bill Clintons 1992 campaign policy and debate preparation staff; was the chief of staff for Vice President Al Gore during the 1996 election; ran Mr. Gores war room in 2000; and led debate preparation for Senator John Kerrys 2004 presidential bid.

title: The Heir to the Crocodile Hunter
description: In the late 1990s, as Steve Irwins star rose, so did the popularity of his United States television partner, Discovery Communications Animal Planet channel. More than one year after Mr. Irwin died, his daughter Bindi could conceivably advance Discovery Kids Channel in a similar way.

title: Contributor: Dan Schnur
description: Dan Schnur is the director of the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California. The national communications director for John McCains presidential bid in 2000, Mr. Schnur has worked on four presidential and three gubernatorial campaigns.

title: A Little Late
description: I got the Wiley Business Spring Catalog in the mail today and found a pitch for a new book to be published in March: Subprime Mortgage Credit Derivatives. It is written by an expert author team of UBS practitioners and needs to be read because of the recent growth in subprime lendng.

title: Contributor: The Topical Satire Initiative
description: The Topical Satire Initiative is Rachel Axler, Kevin Bleyer, Rich Blomquist, Steve Bodow, Tim Carvell, Scott Jacobson, Rob Kutner, Josh Lieb and Sam Means, who, when gainfully employed, write funny stuff for The Daily Show With Jon Stewart.

title: Contributor: The McLaughin Group
description: The McLaughin Group is Michael Brumm, Rob Dubbin, Glenn Eichler, Peter Grosz, Peter Gwinn, Barry Julien, Jay Katsir and Frank Lesser, who, when gainfully employed, write funny stuff for The Colbert Report.

title: Wyoming Winter Weighs Down Moondance Diner
description: The cherished Moondance Diner, transplanted to its new home in La Barge, Wyo., went through a trying experience last week that would have been impossible so far this year in New York City. Yes, while in New York, it dodged a wrecking a ball. Yes, a serendipitous online dating moment put it in the loving care of a Wyoming couple. And yes, it survived a perilous 2,100-mile trek cross-country behind a semi to a town with a population of 600 people. But on Thursday, the 75-year-old, yet-to-be-renovated diner simply crumpled under the accumulated weight of snow on its roof.Its pretty much in a heap, said Candy Kjar, the La Barge town clerk, who saw the building as she was driving in and out of town.

title: Shadowing New Yorks Commuters, Week 2
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, with additional details and reader comments here on City Room [Read Week 1]. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: TV Technology Showcased At C.E.S.
description: Recapping some of the TV technology announcements at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas:

title: Contributor: Francis Wilkinson
description: Francis Wilkinson is executive editor of The Week and theweekmagazine.com. He is a former communications consultant for corporations and Democratic campaigns.

title: Contributor: Bill Emmott
description: Bill Emmott, the editor-in-chief of The Economist from 1993 until 2006, is the author of the forthcoming Rivals: How the Power Struggle Between China, India and Japan Will Shape Our Next Decade.

title: The High Low | L.L. Beans Kingfield Sweater
description: You dont need a degree from Central St. Martins to know that good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant affordable gets. In this column, Ts fashion team roll up their Balenciaga sleeves to rummage for the cheap and the chic.

title: Microsoft Shows Off Interactive TV Features
description: Microsoft is demonstrating its vision of interactive television at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week, displaying next-generation scenarios that include interactive boxing matches on Showtime and straw polls during election coverage on CNN.

title: Electronics Makers Look for the Next Display
description: For the last several years, the biggest story in the biggest market in consumer electronicstelevisionshas been the war between plasma and liquid-crystal displays. In the market now, L.C.D.s have clearly won. Even Matsushita,, the biggest backer of plasma technology, is investing in a big new L.C.D. plant.

title: Contributor: Douglas MacKinnon
description: Douglas MacKinnon was a press secretary to former Senator Bob Dole. He was also a writer for Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush and a special assistant for policy and communications in the Defense Department. He has worked on three presidential campaigns and is the author, most recently, of The Apocalypse Directive, a novel.

title: World Club Top 10: Championship Week Edition
description: With the Red Wings and Senators gearing up for their only meeting of the regular season, to take place Saturday at 7 p.m. in Ottawa, we take a glance at the World Top 10. Also, No. 8 Slavia Prague will play No. 9 Ceske Budejovice in the Czech Extraliga, and in the European Champions Cup in St. Petersburg, No. 3 Slovan Bratislava and No. 6 Karpat Oulu will vie in their respective groups toward a potential meeting in the tournament final on Sunday.

title: Team USA to Team Bridgeport
description: Kyle Okposo, the future power forward for the Islanders, will start his professional career as a Bridgeport Sound Tiger in the American Hockey League. He could suit up Friday in Binghamton against the farm team of the Ottawa Senators.

title: Contributor: Steven Heller
description: Steven Heller is the co-chairman of the MFA Design program at the School of Visual Arts. He writes the Visuals column in the New York Times Book Review. He is the author of the forthcoming Iron Fists: Branding the Totalitarian State.

title: Contributor: Bruce Fuller
description: Bruce Fuller, a professor of education and public policy at the University of California at Berkeley, is the author most recently of Standardized Childhood: The Political and Cultural Struggle Over Early Education.

title: Contributor: Lance T. Izumi
description: Lance T. Izumi, a senior fellow in California studies and the senior director of education studies at the Pacific Research Institute for Public Policy, is the co-author of the book Not as Good as You Think: Why the Middle Class Needs School Choice. He was appointed to the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges in 2004 by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, and he is the boards president. Prior to going into the think-tank world, Mr. Izumi served as chief speechwriter and director of writing and research for Gov. George Deukmejian of California and was a speechwriter for United States Attorney General Edwin Meese III during the Reagan administration.

title: Bumpy Ride on McCain Press Bus
description: WARNER, N.H.  If there is a word that could define the McCain campaign operation as the candidate clawed his way back into contention in the Republican primary contest, scrappy would not be a bad one.

title: Final Thoughts From Les Miles
description: NEW ORLEANS  Theres no more talking, at least to the news media. In less than eight hours, No. 1 Ohio State (11-1) and No. 2 Louisiana State (11-2) will take the field of the Superdome for the Bowl Championship Series title game.

title: Best of C.E.S.
description: David Pogue spotlights his favorite tech gadgets from the Consumer Electronics Show.

title: Final Thoughts From Jim Tressel
description: NEW ORLEANS  Here are five things that Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel said in his final pregame news conference Sunday:

title: Basically, Its a Landslide
description: Almost two months after The Lede noted major political promises made in three countries wracked with instability in a single day, we have a resolution to report.

title: Gadgets, Germs and the Juice
description: Everyone at the Consumer Electronics Show is on the juice.

title: A Buckeyes Bash
description: NEW ORLEANS  A strong showing of Ohio State fans gathered Saturday when around 16,000 alumni and fans attended the Buckeye Bash at the Ernest N. Morial Convention Center.

title: CBS Surrounds the Britney Spears Saga
description: Three CBS brands  Dr. Phil, Entertainment Tonight and The Early Show  collaborated to promote Dr. Phil McGraws hospital visit with Britney Spears.

title: Bloomberg Drops No Hints in Oklahoma
description: More than a dozen former and current elected officials met in Norman, Okla., today for what organizers called a bipartisan forum, convened by David L. Boren, the president of the University of Oklahoma and a former Democratic senator, and Sam Nunn, with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as the guest of honor. The goal? Spark national discussion on issues like global warming, the federal deficit and the decline in Americas prestige abroad.

title: A Rapidly Changing Race
description: The simplicity and careful planning of Iowa and New Hampshire are about to give way to a complex, high-velocity game of "Survivor."

title: Dont Be Cruel, Justice Scalia
description: The Supreme Court is getting a well-earned reputation for cruelty.

title: Paulson Discusses Housing Woes
description: Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson says there is no single or simple solution to the housing crisis. CNBC's Mary Thompson has the latest on Paulson's speech.

title: Obamas Thinking About Tomorrow
description: NEW LONDON, N.H.  As Senator Barack Obama stopped by Jacks, a village coffee shop here, he ordered hot tea with lemon to nurse his ailing throat. It was the only moment of the day, so far, that reporters were close enough to ask him any questions.

title: The iPod Economy and C.E.S.
description: Matt Richtel compared being at the Consumer Electronics Show to a return to the tripped out days of the 1960s. My experience, the several times I ventured onto the convention floor in Las Vegas, was somewhat less pleasant: It felt like I was a ball trapped inside a pachinko machine in Tokyos Ginza district.

title: Contributor: Gary David Goldberg
description: Gary David Goldberg is the founder of UBU Productions, which produced nine television series, including Family Ties and Brooklyn Bridge. He is the author of Sit, Ubu, Sit: How I Went From Brooklyn to Hollywood With the Same Woman, the Same Dog and a Lot Less Hair.

title: I Guess Shes Not Crazy After All
description: More of your late night jokes (use the comment link below):

title: Q&A: Manchester Uniteds Mikael Silvestre
description: In a posting late last week, Manchester United defender Mikael Silvestre spoke about his decision to decline a transfer to Newcastle United because of Joey Barton, and also about the prospects of Silvestre one day playing in the United States.

title: Jones Accepts S.M.U. Job
description: Hawaii Coach June Jones accepted the head coaching job at Southern Methodist University today. He signed a five-year deal that will pay him about $2 million per season. The job makes him the highest-paid college football coach outside the six major conferences and also shows how serious S.M.U. is about reviving a football program decimated by receiving the so-called death penalty from the N.C.A.A. in 1987.

title: Sonys Chief Says It Wont Be Late Again
description: There arent many who can admit a mistake like Howard Stringer. Hes charming and easygoing; his relatively close-cropped hair manages to look a little floppy. Hes the big friendly dog who protects you and sometimes tears up newspaper all over the house and then he nestles up to you and you cant help but feel that you didnt want to read the sports section after all.

title: Finding a Faucet
description: Next time I build a custom house (right after hell freezes over), heres one thing I will do differently: Make sure the builder has provided a reasonable allowance for plumbing fixtures.

title: In Pursuit of the Pomegranate
description: Waiting for freshly squeezed pomegranate juice at Meyvemix, a new juice bar between the Galatasaray High School and the British Consulate in Beyoglu. A generous serving costs 3 YTL.

title: Intel C.E.O. on '08 Challenges
description: Paul Otellini, Intel CEO, discusses the challenges his company will face in 2008, with CNBC's Jim Goldman.

title: Missed Connections, Lost Dogs and More
description: What were reading elsewhere

title: Contributor: Jacob S. Hacker
description: Jacob S. Hacker, professor of political science at Yale and a fellow at the New America Foundation, is the author of The Great Risk Shift: The New Economic Insecurity and the Decline of the American Dream. He is also the author of Health Care for America, a proposal for universal health care released by the Economic Policy Institute.

title: Steep City Deficits Predicted in 2009 and Beyond
description: In what is probably its most alarming forecast in recent memory, the citys Independent Budget Office today projected a $3.1 billion budget deficit in the 2009 fiscal year, rising to $4.6 billion in 2010 and $6.3 billion in 2011  largely as as result of the weakening in the housing market and higher labor costs. The office warned that the the citys fiscal picture could become even darker if Wall Streets economic woes worsen or if the housing market, which in Manhattan has remained strong, further declines. The conclusions in the five-page report suggest that whoever succeeds Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be saddled with fiscal problems as serious as the ones Mr. Bloomberg inherited when he took office in 2002 as the city was still reeling from 9/11.

title: Outside Groups Spend in N.H.
description: The last-minute blitz of campaigning by the candidates in New Hampshire is also being matched by a last-minute blitz of independent expenditures  outside groups putting up their own money to advocate for, or against, different Presidential hopefuls.Filings over the last few days at the Federal Election Commission show that Hillary Rodham Clinton is a big recipient of support from two of her strongest outside backers  the American Federation of Teachers and the Emilys List political action committee.

title: Taser Toting, Without Missing a Beat
description: If the world were divided into neat groups  say, between users of Tasers and MP3 players  perhaps TASER International would have no reason to unveil their latest invention. But its not, and they do.

title: Strong Ratings for American Gladiators
description: NBCs remake of American Gladiators muscled its way to a strong start in the ratings on Sunday. The amateur athletic tournament based on the early 1990s series with a cult following delivered the highest ratings among adults aged 18 to 49 of any new show this season on any network, matching NBCs debut of Heroes in September 2006, according to Nielsens estimates.

title: Ask About the Immigrant Experience on the Lower East Side
description: From Jan. 7 to 14, Steve Long, the vice president of collections and education at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, took questions from City Room readers on the history of immigration and tenement life on Manhattans Lower East Side.

title: Hillary Clintons Mixed Emotions
description: She aches, just like a woman  and you can watch it here.

title: For a Moment, They Stopped to Look
description: New Yorkers rarely stop.

title: Yahoos Quest to Open Up
description: For months, Yahoo chief executive Jerry Yang has been talking about swinging open the doors to the Yahoo portal. A key goal, he has said again and again, is to turn Yahoo into a set of platforms for third-party publishers and developers.

title: Comfort Food To Count on, in London
description: Restaurants are abundant here in London, ranging from reasonably priced chains to eclectic ethnic treats to Michelin starred establishments. But when looking for a place guaranteed to offer a good all round experience, the choice becomes more limited. One eaterie that can be said to fulfill most requirements is The Wolseley, in Picadilly, which is modeled on the grand European tradition of caf-restaurant. Located in a building that originally housed a showroom for Wolseley Motors, it is open from 7 am  midnight serving breakfast, lunch, tea and dinner as well as offering an all day menu.The Wolseley

title: Who Are More Human: PC Users or Couch Potatoes?
description: Matters turned philosophical here at the Consumer Electronics Show in a discussion with Toshihiro Sakamoto, president and senior managing director of Panasonic AVC Networks. Mr. Sakamoto is charming, twinkle-eyed and at least a grade classier than the sell-at-all-costs, run-of-the mill American chief executive. (And, as my friend Alex Pham of The Los Angeles Times put it, he sure is handsome.)

title: Contributor: Rachel Kleinfeld
description: Rachel Kleinfeld is the executive director of the Truman National Security Project, a national security leadership institute. She has consulted on homeland security, bioterrorism, defense and rule of law issues for several private and nonprofit organizations.

title: Pennington? Or Clemens?
description: Reporters met with Jets General Manager Mike Tannenbaum on Monday, and he said he expected quarterback Chad Pennington to be back next season, even with a cap number of $7.8 million. Tannenbaum also said he expected Pennington to compete with Kellen Clemens for the starting quarterback job.

title: Contributor: Thomas M. Donnelly
description: Thomas M. Donnelly is the resident fellow in foreign and defense policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute. A former journalist who has worked at Army Times and Defense News, he was a professional staff member at the United States House of Representatives Committee on National Security (now the Committee on Armed Services) from 1995 to 1999.

title: Cable May Open Up Just a Bit
description: One tantalizing tidbit from C.E.S. was the revival of a technology from the cable industry that is meant to let any television or other device hook into cable systems without a set-top box. CableLabs, the industry technology consortium, has been talking about this technology, called OpenCable, for years. Today, it was renamed Tru2Way. Several manufacturers, including Panasonic, said they would deploy sets using the technology.

title: The Animated Life: Trigger Happy
description: Jeff Scher's latest animation is a ballet in black and white. Part of Sightlines, an Op-Ed visual series.

title: Contributor: Bill Barich
description: Bill Barichs books include Laughing in the Hills, Carson Valley, A Fine Place to Daydream and A Pint of Plain about the traditional Irish pub, to be published next March.

title: Bloggingheads: Sex 'Slaves'
description:
Will Wilkinson, left, of the Cato Institute and Kerry Howley of Reason Magazine on whether the international sex trade is enslavement or liberation.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Plenty of Seats Available
description: NEW ORLEANS  Less than four hours before Mondays national championship game upper-level tickets were selling for $650 apiece and lower-level seats were fetching $1,000 to $1,500 each, the ticket broker Curry Hayes said.

title: On the Road With John McCain
description: Senator John McCain, Republican candidate for president, campaigned from Nashua to Hanover a day before the New Hampshire primary.

title: Blogtalk: Emotion and the Campaign Trail
description: At a routine campaign stop in Portsmouth, N.H., Hillary Rodham Clinton got a bit teary after she was asked by a voter how she deals with the pressures of campaigning. There was no all-out crying, just a little misting of the eyes and a noticeable crack in Mrs. Clintons voice. But just the little bit of unexpected emotion from the New York senator was enough to spark debate between bloggers on both sides of the political divide.

title: Were Looking Live
description: NEW ORLEANS  Both Louisiana State and Ohio State are warming up right now and the fans here are getting worked into a fever pitch with a bevy of chants. Heres my pregame analysis, which is always dangerous 47 minutes before the game because the prospect of looking foolish is in real time.

title: Iron My Shirt
description: SALEM, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was about to deliver a line that has become a centerpiece of her campaign since her loss in Iowa.

title: Boosting New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  The Sugar Bowl and Mondays Bowl Championship Series title game had an estimated combined economic impact of more than $500 million for New Orleans, according to Lea Sinclair, the director of communications for the New Orleans Tourism Marketing Corporation.

title: Morning Briefing on the B.C.S.
description: NEW ORLEANS  When measuring developments in terms of changes in the B.C.S., its difficult to get a handle on what qualifies as significant progress. At the Football Writers Association of America Breakfast on Monday morning, both the outgoing B.C.S. coordinator Mike Slive and the new B.C.S. coordinator John Swofford spoke openly about discussing a Plus One model for the future of college football.

title: Home Field for L.S.U.?
description: NEW ORLEANS  Were minutes before kickoff, and one of the much-discussed issues heading into this game was whether or not L.S.U. would have a home-field advantage because Baton Rouge is located just 80 miles down I-10. I boldly predicted that that advantage would be negligible, as U.S.C. didnt appear to have much of a home-field advantage in terms of crowd when they played in the Rose Bowl two years ago.

title: Dorseys Knee Could Affect Draft Status
description: NEW ORLEANS  While the senior Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey is seemingly the front-runner to be the first overall pick in Aprils N.F.L. draft, his stock could be impacted by a right knee injury that he sustained earlier this season.

title: Rock Star Treatment
description: BEDFORD, N.H.  Did it just begin here?

title: Clintons Civil Rights Lesson
description: DOVER, N.H.  As they barnstorm through New Hampshire, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband are often introduced by supporters who once backed another candidate but converted to her cause.

title: Champions, Again and Again
A Blizzard of Ads in New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  If you live in the Boston/Manchester media market and you think youve been bombarded with political ads this year, youre right.

title: Rangers Say Straka Has a Concussion: What a Concept
description: The Rangers are more than a bit woozy from an 0-2-1 trip to Western Canada, but they have enough sense about them to fess up that forward Martin Straka suffered a concussion in Saturday nights shootout loss to Edmonton.

title: Trigger Happy
description: Trigger Happy was made with hundreds of objects found on the streets and sidewalks of New York.

title: And here it comes
description: When the economy was (sorta, kinda) strong, it showed that tax cuts work, and so we needed to make the Bush tax cuts permanent. Now the economy is falling off a cliff  although according to the White House, nobody is predicting a recession (I seem to know an awful lot of nobodies)  and you know what that means: wed better make the Bush tax cuts permanent.

title: Hollywood Hideaway
description: The Costa Brava retreat built by 30s film star Madeleine Carroll is for sale, priced at 10 million.

title: Making Tradeoffs to Ease Pain
description: What would you give up to live pain free?

title: Philly Anchorwoman Fired After NY Arrest
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: Writer-Less Colbert: Where Are My Words?
description: In Tuesdays New York Times, Bill Carter and Jacques Steinberg summarize Jon Stewart and Stephen Colberts returns to television:

title: The Strike Scene at Colbert and Daily Show
description: Fifteen strikers picketed outside The Daily Show studio in the Clinton neighborhood of Manhattan amid unseasonably warm weather Monday. Twenty strikers circled two blocks north outside the studios of The Colbert Report as both Comedy Central shows resumed taping for the first time in two months.

title: After Iowa, Campaigns Cast Even Wider Net Online
description: In her Web column, Katharine Q. Seelye notes that since Barack Obama proved that young people do vote after all, most of the candidates have been cranking up their presence online, especially through YouTube.Go to Column

title: On The Road With Hillary
description: Hillary Clinton swings through New Hampshire on the eve of the nation's first primary.

title: New Hampshire Voices
description: The price of oil is critically important in New Hampshire, and many residents are disappointed in how the presidential candidates are approaching it.

title: Nascar Changes, and Johnson Remains
description: On the first day of the first test session of the 2008 Nascar preseason, Jimmie Johnson was confronted with the question that will follow him every day for the next 11 months.

title: Bridgeport: Ex-Police Detective Sentenced
description: A former New Haven police detective convicted in a Police Department drug scandal was sentenced on Monday in Federal District Court to 90 days in jail. The former detective, Jose Silva, 36, pleaded guilty to depriving an individual of his constitutional rights in October. Federal prosecutors said Mr. Silva knew that another detective, Justen Kasperzyk, had moved suspected narcotics from the basement to the back bedroom of a first-floor apartment in New Haven, resulting in an unlawful arrest in November 2006. Mr. Kasperzyk pleaded guilty to one count of civil rights conspiracy, a felony, and one count of theft of government property, a misdemeanor. He is scheduled to be sentenced March 27.

title: Let the Season of B.C.S. Discussion Begin
description: NEW ORLEANS  Mike Slive officially ended his two-year tenure as Bowl Championship Series coordinator Monday, but not before passing along another catchphrase, something he is famous for.

title: No Strangers to the Cold, Voters Now Feel the Heat
description: HILLSBOROUGH, N.H.  People here treasure their rugged surroundings and relative isolation in the hills of southwestern New Hampshire. They welcome winter, and consider their distance from urban sprawl a clear advantage.

title: Fever May Ease Effects of Autism Disorders
description: Parents of young people with autistic disorders often say they notice that symptoms calm down when the children have a fever. A new study confirms that this may be the case.

title: An Author Sues the Seinfelds, for a Cookbook and for Barbs
description: Missy Chase Lapine, the author of The Sneaky Chef, a cookbook whose recipes camouflage pured vegetables and fruits in comfort food for children, sued Jessica and Jerry Seinfeld on Monday, charging copyright infringement and defamation.

title: New DVDs
description: CARY GRANT

title: Four Wheels for the Masses: The $2,500 Car
description: MUMBAI, India  What does it take to build the worlds cheapest car?

title: U.S. Describes Confrontation With Iranian Boats
description: WASHINGTON  Five armed Iranian speedboats approached three United States Navy warships in international waters in the strategic Strait of Hormuz on Sunday, then maneuvered aggressively as radio threats were issued that the American ships would be blown up, military officials said Monday.

title: Founder of a Nonprofit Is Punished by Its Board for Engaging in an Internet Ruse
description: A founder of GiveWell, a new nonprofit research organization that seeks to assess the effectiveness of charities, has been demoted after admitting that he promoted the organization on a Web site by posing as a prospective charitable donor seeking information.

title: Lender Tells Judge It Recreated Letters
description: The Countrywide Financial Corporation fabricated documents related to the bankruptcy case of a Pennsylvania homeowner, court records show, raising new questions about the business practices of the giant mortgage lender at the center of the subprime mess.

title: F.B.I. Data Show Drop in Crime
description: Crime dipped slightly for the first half of 2007, the F.B.I. reported, signaling a stop to a two-year increase in violence nationwide. Violent crime, including murders, rapes and robberies, dropped by 1.8 percent from January to June last year, according to the preliminary data from the bureau. Property crimes also decreased, including a 7.4 percent drop in car thefts and a 10 percent drop in arsons. But in small cities and rural areas, violent crime appears to be rising, if only slightly, the data show.

title: Despite Weak Economy, Business Travel Demand Was Up in 2008
description: BUSINESS TRAVEL DEMAND UP IN 2008 Any weakening in the economy apparently has not yet affected most business travelers plans this year. According to Access America, an insurance and travelers assistance company, 26 percent of business travelers surveyed said they expected to be on the road more this year than last, and 61 percent said they expected to travel about the same amount. Among other findings in the survey of 1,000 travelers: Nearly 78 percent cited high gasoline prices as one frustration of travel, 55 percent named poor airline service, and 41 percent cited airport security and passport and border procedures. By far the least frustrating part of travel was booking the trip. Only 16 percent said they found making travel arrangements frustrating.

title: Bush Admits Economy Faces Challenges
description: CHICAGO  President Bush, in a marked shift from his usual upbeat economic assessments, conceded here on Monday that the nation faces economic challenges due to rising oil prices, the home mortgage crisis and a weakening job market.

title: Brunswick: Brunos Wife Dies
description: Barbara Bruno, the wife of the State Senate Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, has died after a long battle with Alzheimers disease. She was 77. The senators office announced the death Monday evening. Barbara and Joseph Bruno were married for 57 years, and had four children and seven grandchildren.

title: Preserving a Fundamental Sense: Balance
description: From the Well archives

title: Yale Plans to Increase Spending From Its Endowment
description: Facing pressure from Congress and some donors to use more of its multibillion-dollar investment gains, Yale University announced Monday that it would increase the amount of money it spent from its endowment next year by nearly 40 percent.

title: Two Hopefuls Share Little but Youth Appeal
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  It has the feel and look of a transformative moment, this tidal wave of young voters buoying the disparate campaigns of Senators Barack Obama and John McCain.

title: Anne Frank Musical to Open in Madrid
description: A musical based on The Diary of a Young Girl by Anne Frank is to open next month at the Calderon Theater in Madrid. Its star will be Isabella Castillo, 13, whose mother fled with her from Cuba to Belize, where they lived in hiding before immigrating to Miami, The Guardian of London reported. The newspaper said the production, developed by Rafael Alvero, has been given the support of the Anne Frank Foundation, which holds the rights to the diary. It is adapted from the account written while Anne and her family hid from the Nazis in Amsterdam during World War II. Jan Erik Dubbelman, who heads the international department of the foundation, said: This production respects the message of tolerance, within the tragedy, that we want to keep alive. Being in Spanish, it can also help to take the message of Anne Frank to Latin America.

title: Canada: Appeal in Serial Killer Case
description: Prosecutors in British Columbia asked an appeals court to set aside six second-degree murder convictions against Robert Pickton, and order a new trial on 26 charges of first-degree murder. Relatives and friends of many of the victims were disappointed that Mr. Pickton, a pig farmer arrested in 2002, was found guilty by a jury last month only of second-degree murder, which does not require proof of premeditation. The prosecutors said the judge made errors, including his decision to split the case and put Mr. Pickton on trial on 6 counts of first-degree murder last year, with a trial on the remaining 20 counts to be held this year. Even if the government appeal is successful and Mr. Pickton is convicted on all 26 counts of first-degree murder, it will not change his sentence of life in prison without the chance of parole for 25 years. The remains of the victims, mostly prostitutes, were found buried on his farm in a Vancouver suburb.

title: 2 Canadian Bank Executives Ousted After Subprime Losses
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce fired two executives Monday at its CIBC World Markets unit as it grapples with a $9.8 billion exposure to subprime debt, the largest among banks in Canada.

title: Detectives in Bell Case Want Trial Out of City
description: Lawyers for three police detectives charged in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man in Queens in 2006 filed a motion yesterday requesting that the trial, scheduled to begin next month, be moved out of New York City, saying publicity has incurably poisoned the pool of prospective jurors.

title: Older Men (and Women) Trying Not to Be Angry
description: Norman, Okla.

title: A Long Wait to Win a Title Ends for Senior
description: NEW ORLEANS  As a redshirt freshman four years ago, Louisiana State quarterback Matt Flynn stood on the sideline here in the Superdome and watched his team win a national championship.

title: Justices Chilly to Bid to Alter Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON  With conservative justices questioning their motives and liberal justices questioning their evidence, opponents of the American manner of capital punishment made little headway Monday in their effort to persuade the Supreme Court that the Constitution requires states to change the way they carry out executions by lethal injection.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills Key Sunni Leader
description: BAGHDAD  Militants assassinated two key leaders of American-backed neighborhood militias in northern Baghdad over the past two days, highlighting the militants strategy of eliminating militia commanders who have embraced partnerships with American forces but who themselves remain vulnerable to attack.

title: Madison Square Gardens Godfather, Without the Respect
description: The Godfather movies were not merely yarns about mobsters and blood baths. At heart, they were about dynasty, wealth and power. They were about big business in America.

title: Texas: Environmental Advocates Sue Shell Oil
description: Environmental groups sued the Shell Oil Company and several of its affiliates, claiming that the oil giant has for years released pollutants from its suburban Houston refinery that are well above state and federal limits. In the federal lawsuit, the Sierra Club and Environment Texas claim that the excess air pollutants, including the toxic chemicals benzene and 1,3-butadiene, are a violation of the federal Clean Air Act.

title: Good Boss, Bad Boss. Which Are You?
description: Maybe it is not them.

title: Parents and Visiting Hours (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: With Focus on the Strike, Stewart Returns
description: The glimmer of emotion that Hillary Rodham Clinton displayed in New Hampshire was startling because it was so out-of-character  almost as disconcerting as Jon Stewart returning to The Daily Show on Monday and not making fun of it.

title: A Good Example for Fighting Tobacco
description: The vast majority of all smokers had their first cigarette before the age of 18. Thats why the key to reducing overall tobacco use is to prevent it in the young. The task is daunting. Almost a quarter of high school students nationwide currently smoke. Theres ample reason for hope when one looks at New York City. Smoking among public high school students there dropped from 17.6 percent in 2001 to 8.5 percent in 2007  a rate that is far below the national average.

title: Even in Exile, a Mobster Never Forsook His Code
description: TUCSON  When the time came to remember the man inside the bronze and gold coffin at the foot of the altar, the Brooklyn-born mans three sons did not try to hide what had made their father famous.

title: Strikebound, the Globes Scale Back Awards
description: LOS ANGELES  Are the Golden Globes, the annual movie and television awards given out by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, really news?

title: Stocks Tumble on New Signs of Economic Woes
description: Stocks tumbled Tuesday afternoon after the chief executive of the nations largest phone company, AT&T, suggested a weaker economy was forcing consumers to scale back spending.

title: Political Rivals Take Field Trip; One Takes Shot
description: CHICAGO  What happens when President Bush and Representative Rahm Emanuel of Illinois, the fast-talking, hard-charging leader of the House Democratic Caucus, take a field trip to the Windy City?

title: Comedy Central Hosts Return to TV
description: The late-night stars of the Comedy Central cable network, Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert, returned to their programs for the first time in nine weeks Monday night, ready to sling their satirical stones at a new target: the continuing strike by the Writers Guild of America, which is forcing the stars to find creative ways to perform without their writers.

title: Knicks Need Richardson to Recover From Slump
description: CHICAGO  When all else has failed the Knicks in recent years (which is often), they have at least been able to depend on Quentin Richardsons jump shot, his defense and his conscience. In this season of across-the-board misery, it would seem that only his conscience has survived.

title: Clemenss Lawyer Plays Tape of McNamee Call
description: HOUSTON  Roger Clemens unleashed a furious attack Monday on his former trainer Brian McNamee with a news conference featuring a tape of a recorded phone call and a lawsuit accusing McNamee of lying about injecting him with performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Microsoft Forges Ties to Studios
description: Microsoft announced partnerships on Monday with Walt Disney, NBC Universal and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to bolster online video sales and step up competition with the iTunes operation of Apple Inc.

title: The Claim: Antibiotics Will Beat a Sinus Infection
description: THE FACTS

title: Israeli Troops Kill 3 Armed Palestinians
description: Israeli soldiers shot dead three armed Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, including a woman, an army spokeswoman said. The armed woman, 23, identified by Islamic Jihad as one of its members, and a man approached the border fence near the Erez Crossing in northern Gaza at noon, the spokeswoman said, and opened fire on soldiers nearby before being shot. In a village near the West Bank city of Jenin, soldiers fired at armed men who approached a checkpoint, the army spokeswoman said, killing one. Palestinian officials identified the dead man as a member of Islamic Jihad.

title: Newly Found Planet Orbits Young Star Amid Dust and Gas
description: By itself, the discovery of another extrasolar planet, this time by astronomers in Germany, is no big deal. Its just another in what is now a long line of planets found orbiting stars other than the Sun.

title: Back to Folsom
description: On Sunday, 40 years to the day after Johnny Cash performed at Folsom Prison in Northern California, his longtime drummer Fluke Holland will lead a celebratory concert there. The Columbia recording Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison, released in the summer of 1968, appeared on the country music charts for 90 weeks and on Billboards Top 200 for 122 weeks. Sundays performance will feature several members of Cashs original band, and, according to an announcement, A special guest vocalist will be introduced at the show. Although no inmates present at the 1968 concert will attend the new one, one former guard, now 80, will be there, as well as several guests who were present at the time, said the shows producer, Jonathan Holiff, son of Saul Holiff, the Canadian entrepreneur who managed Cash from 1960 to 1973. The 40th Anniversary of Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison  concert will be filmed and streamed worldwide over the Internet at iClips.net.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on the Iowa caucuses on Saturday gave an incorrect history of the caucuses. One winner of contested caucuses did win the White House: George W. Bush in 2000.

title: McCain and Obama
description: Salem, N.H.

title: Tornadoes Kill 3; More Storms Expected
description: A tornado roared through parts of central Arkansas on Tuesday, killing one person, injuring others, and damaging homes and vehicles and knocking down trees. The latest death brings to three the number of people killed in the last two days in storms set off by unseasonably warm winter air.

title: A Politically Dangerous Liaison for Frances President
description: PARIS  It is called the Carla effect, and it helps explain President Nicolas Sarkozys sudden decline in popularity.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Dec. 31 about the elevation of Benazir Bhuttos 19-year-old son, Bilawal, to succeed her as chairman of the Pakistan Peoples Party three days after her assassination misstated the name of the college he attends at Oxford University, Ms. Bhuttos alma mater. It is Christ Church, not Christ Church College. (Go to Article)

title: High-Level Shake-Up at Cond Nast
description: Cond Nast Publications announced a management shake-up on Monday, including the departure of Mitchell B. Fox, one of the companys highest-ranking executives and a former publisher of Details and Vanity Fair.

title: Krispy Kremes Chief Executive Quits Amid Turnaround
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP)  The chief executive of Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, Daryl G. Brewster, has resigned amid a sputtering turnaround.

title: One by One, Narratives Reflecting Lifes Mosaic
description: All the stories in this lively collection are portraits, mainly of human beings, though a monster with an identity crisis, a giant in search of love and a puppy in need of a home put in appearances as well. While the stories vary widely in quality  a few are dazzling, many are simply well crafted, a handful are embarrassingly slight or contrived  they come together to provide a kind of lesson in fiction writing.

title: Manhattan: Holocaust Case Settled
description: A federal judge on Monday approved a settlement among Holocaust victims, their heirs and an Italian insurer. Saying the settlement was fair, reasonable and adequate, Judge George B. Daniels of Federal District Court ended more than a decade of litigation over the claim that the insurer, Assicurazioni Generali, refused to honor the victims policies. The lawsuit was among nearly two dozen that were thrown out in 2004. The cases were eventually settled, with Generali agreeing to pay $175 million to survivors and their relatives through the International Commission on Holocaust Era Insurance Claims and other channels.

title: Settlement on Use of Central Parks Great Lawn
description: After three years of contentious litigation, the New York City Parks Department agreed Tuesday to back away from a controversial regulation to limit public events on the Great Lawn, in the heart of Central Park, to 50,000 people. The decision to rescind the rule  put in place, the city said, to protect the lawn and used in an early form to deny permits to antiwar demonstrators  was hailed by its critics as a victory for the First Amendment and for the public use of public land.

title: When Superconductivity Became Clear (to Some)
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.  Superconductivity, the flow of electricity without resistance, was once as confounding to physicists as it is to everyone else.

title: A Chairman Is Appointed to Rebuild Sallie Mae
description: Sallie Mae, the beleaguered student lending giant, on Monday appointed a longtime banking executive as chairman as the company struggles with tighter credit markets and fallout from a failed buyout.

title: In Greenland, Ice and Instability
description: The ancient frozen dome cloaking Greenland is so vast that pilots have crashed into what they thought was a cloud bank spanning the horizon. Flying over it, you can scarcely imagine that this ice could erode fast enough to dangerously raise sea levels any time soon.

title: Pennington Is Expected to Stay and Compete
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.,  When General Manager Mike Tannenbaum met with Chad Pennington to discuss the Jets most pressing issue of the off-season, their conversation centered, oddly enough, on bull riding at Madison Square Garden.

title: Florida: Boy, 12, Accused in Cousins Death
description: Prosecutors are reviewing whether a 12-year-old boy should be charged as an adult after the police accused him of fatally beating his toddler cousin Friday afternoon with a baseball bat for interrupting a cartoon show. The boy, whose name was not released, was being held in juvenile custody in the death of his cousin, 17-month-old Shaloh Joseph, who the police said enraged the suspect by crying.

title: Mastic Beach: Body Found in Missing Mans Cesspool
description: Nineteen months after a Mastic Beach man was reported missing by his relatives, Suffolk County police detectives have found a body in a cesspool behind his house, the police said on Monday. The man, Nicolo Caietta, 59, was reported missing on May 30, 2006, and several months later, the investigation of his disappearance was transferred to the homicide squad, the police said, without elaborating why. On Saturday, the police excavated the cesspool behind Mr. Caiettas home at 275 Forest Road West, and found the body. The body had not been identified Monday evening, and an autopsy has been scheduled, the police said.

title: Excerpts From Sarkozys News Conference
description: Following is an excerpt from a news conference by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, as translated by The New York Times, who responded to questions from Roselyne Febvre, a French television reporter, about his relationship with the pop singer Carla Bruni:

title: What to Ask About Exercise
description: A new diagnosis can be a frightening experience, and ever-changing research can complicate already difficult treatment decisions. Here are some questions you might ask your doctor if exercise has been recommended as part of your treatment plan.

title: An Art Donor Opts to Hold On to His Collection
description: LOS ANGELES  Eli Broad, the billionaire financier and philanthropist whose private collection of some 2,000 works of Modern and contemporary art is one of the most sought-after by museums nationwide, has decided to retain permanent control of his works in an independent foundation that makes loans to museums rather than give any of the art away.

title: Canadian Emissions Market Recommended
description: A Canadian government panel recommended Monday that prices be set for greenhouse gas emissions and that taxes, caps and emissions trading plans be quickly established.

title: Frenchman Isnt Ready Yet to Play in U.S.
description: Mikael Silvestre said he liked the United States because everything is big. But apparently the soccer is not yet big enough to entice him to consider relocating across the Atlantic for anything more than a vacation.

title: South Korea: Warehouse Fire Kills 40
description: Fire tore through a refrigeration warehouse under construction in Ichon, south of Seoul, killing 40 workers. A local fire official said all the dead were found in the basement. More than 500 firefighters fought the blaze. The cause was undetermined, although the workers were injecting urethane foam into basement walls at the time. Among the dead were 13 ethnic Koreans from China, the Yonhap news agency reported. China has a sizable ethnic Korean minority and in recent years some have migrated to South Korea to seek employment. Like other foreign migrants, they often end up doing difficult and low-paying work.

title: Musings as We Await New Hampshire
description: To the Editor:

title: Aging: Mental Health Overlooked in Care of Elderly Patients
description: Depression and other mental illnesses are common among the elderly, and when they get treatment, it usually comes from their primary care doctors. But a new study suggests that those doctors may devote too little time to talking about those ailments.

title: Kenyan Leader and Opponent to Meet
description: ELDORET, Kenya  For the first time since Kenya exploded into election-related violence that has killed more than 400 people, the president and the top opposition leader have agreed to meet, both sides said Monday.

title: Now on the Governors Desk
description: Among the measures approved by the Senate and Assembly:

title: Arkansas Proves Its Worth as a Political Testing Ground
description: BEARDEN, Ark.  Long before his diet began, Mike Huckabee would campaign in this hamlet, population 1,000, eyeing the succulent pies at the snug Bear City Diner. Patrons there have also chuckled firsthand at Bill Clintons glibness.

title: Obamas Surge Deflates Forum and Talk of a Bloomberg Run
description: NORMAN, Okla.  He arrived here for what seemed like it could be a big moment. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, eyeing a third-party presidential bid, joined Republican and Democratic elders at a forum to denounce the extreme partisanship of Washington and plot how to influence the campaign.

title: Illinois: Agency to Investigate Control Tower Conditions
description: The United States Transportation Department will investigate the work conditions of Chicago-area air traffic controllers amid an increasing frequency of errors, the agency said. The departments Office of the Inspector General announced the audit in response to a request last month by Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois. That request came after the General Accountability Office released a study showing that OHare International Airport had the second-highest number of near-collisions on runways from 2001 to 2006.

title: Setting May Be More Significant Than the Actual Game
description: New Orleans

title: Sony BMG Will Sell Music Without Copyright Protection
description: Sony BMG Music Entertainment, the record company, said on Monday that it would begin selling digital albums without copyright protection, making it the last record company to do so.

title: Bronx Family Receives Help, From Early Education to Furniture
description: Sonia Gayle and her husband, Kubblla Waliyaya, want their teenage sons and their granddaughter to have one thing on their minds: getting an education.

title: Rome Enjoys Two Gatherings of Masterworks, by Canova and Bernini
description: ROME  Nearly four years in the making, Venus Victorious, Canovas seminude, life-size statue of Napoleons sister Paolina Borghese Bonaparte, was ready to be unveiled in that sculptors studio in Rome in July 1808.

title: Jones Leaves Hawaii to Be Coach at S.M.U.
description: NEW ORLEANS  Less than a week after Hawaiis appearance in the Sugar Bowl, which was a high point in the states sporting history, Coach June Jones accepted the coaching job at Southern Methodist.

title: Ending One Airport Runaround
description: When travelers think about air travel these days, many conjure up images of overcrowded skies. And while that may not be easily fixed, there is another problem plaguing many airports  traffic on the ground. And for that, there is hope.

title: No Golden Globes Show, Just a News Conference
description: LOS ANGELES  Are the Golden Globes, the annual movie and television awards given out by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, really news?

title: Homeless, With a New Loss: Identity
description: There is always plenty to worry about when you are homeless. The most pressing concerns have to do with health and finances, of course. But occasionally there are other worries  deeper, odder, more unexpected. Some are even existential. A while ago, I met a man in a shelter clinic who described the worry that preoccupied him.

title: Selected Studies: Exercise
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: New Jersey Revamps State Aid to Schools
description: TRENTON  After a tense three-hour stalemate, legislators handed Gov. Jon S. Corzine a dramatic political victory on Monday night when they approved his $7.8 billion plan to revamp New Jerseys formula of financing the states public schools.

title: Bush Assails Iran for Naval Confrontation
description: WASHINGTON  Just hours before President Bush began his trip to the Middle East, he sharply criticized Iran on Tuesday for fomenting a dangerous situation in an incident over the weekend in the Strait of Hormuz in the Persian Gulf.

title: Xerox Hopes Its New Logo Doesnt Say Copier
description: STILL think copier when you hear the name Xerox?

title: Parasitic Butterflies Keep Options Open With Different Hosts
description: The larvae of the Alcon blue butterfly, Maculinea alcon, are sly little parasites, tricking ants into raising them. They smell just like the ants own brood  their surface chemicals are very similar. So the ants take the butterfly larvae to their nest, where they feed them, neglecting their own.

title: Microsoft Bids for Norwegian Search Engine Firm
description: Microsoft bid $1.2 billion on Tuesday for a Norwegian search software company in an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products. But it is also making the move with an eye toward Google, according to industry analysts.

title: Garden City: Long Island Rail Road Hails Performance
description: The Long Island Rail Road said Monday that 2007 was its best year for on-time performance since it began keeping records. The railroad president, Helena Williams, said 94.07 percent of its trains were on time last year, the best since record-keeping began in 1979. The previous record came in 2002, when it hit 94.04 percent.

title: Ancient Yucatn Soils Point to Maya Market, and Market Economy
description: Scientists using improved methods of analyzing the chemistry of ancient soils have detected where a large marketplace stood 1,500 years ago in a Maya city on the Yucatn Peninsula of Mexico.

title: A Safety-Net Hospital Falls Into Financial Crisis
description: ATLANTA  Pamela Vaughn is a Grady baby.

title: Handling of Interrogation Recordings Leads to a Defense Request in Padilla Case
description: MIAMI  Citing disclosures that the federal government had concealed, and in some cases destroyed, videotaped interrogations of Al Qaeda operatives, a defense lawyer in the case of Jose Padilla, the Brooklyn-born convert to Islam who was convicted as a terrorism conspirator, asked a federal judge on Monday to disclose any recordings that might bear on Mr. Padillas recruitment into the terrorist organization.

title: Genzyme Wins Cholesterol Drug Deal
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Genzyme has agreed to pay at least $325 million to win the hotly contested rights to a potentially powerful cholesterol-lowering drug being developed by Isis Pharmaceuticals.

title: Striding Past the Cynics
description: Derry, N.H.

title: Does Exercise Really Keep Us Healthy?
description: Exercise has long been touted as the panacea for everything that ails you. For better health, simply walk for 20 or 30 minutes a day, boosters say  and you dont even have to do it all at once. Count a few minutes here and a few there, and just add them up. Or wear a pedometer and keep track of your steps. However you manage it, you will lose weight, get your blood pressure under control and reduce your risk of osteoporosis.

title: Clinton Goes Face to Face With the Public as Obama Plays Not to Lose
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has become the open and accessible candidate  sharing beers with reporters, taking endless questions from voters at campaign events and showing rare glimpses of emotion.

title: Snow Falling on Voters
description: Wilmot, N.H.

title: Navigating Life With Humor and Bewilderment
description: I think the wind created me, says Nicky Gottlieb, the subject of Todays Man, a documentary that has its television premiere on Tuesday night on most PBS stations. Mr. Gottlieb, who in the film offers his theory of how the world was formed, has Aspergers syndrome, a form of autism, and his sister, Lizzie Gottlieb, spent six years committing his life to film. She depicts a highly intelligent man addicted to television, socially inappropriate, self-aware about his condition and negotiating the world with both humor and bewilderment.

title: New Bond Girl
description: The name is Arterton, Gemma Arterton, and before the next James Bond film reaches its conclusion shell probably be shaken and stirred. Ms. Arterton, 21, has been cast as the Bond girl opposite Daniel Craig in the production with the working title Bond 22 now being filmed in London, Reuters reported. Ms. Arterton, above, will play a character named Fields, a representative for the films producer said, adding Its a nice-sized role. No further details were disclosed. Citing reports, the BBC said the film picks up where Casino Royale left off and is loosely based on Risico, a short story by Ian Fleming that pits Bond against a drug ring flooding Britain with heroin.

title: Acting on Mitchell Report
description: Major League Baseball eliminated a 24-hour notice of drug testing and imposed background checks on clubhouse personnel, adopting recommendations in the Mitchell report on drugs in the sport. A statement from Commissioner Bud Selig also said clubhouse personnel would be subject to random drug tests and teams would be required to log all packages sent to major league clubhouses. Personal trainers were banned from locker rooms.

title: Clinton Stuns Obama; McCain Wins
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York rode a wave of female support to victory over Senator Barack Obama in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday night. In the Republican primary, meanwhile, Senator John McCain of Arizona revived his presidential bid with a Lazarus-like win.

title: Nature Overrun
description: Nearly 40 years ago, President Richard Nixon issued an executive order calling for a national strategy to protect wildlife by restricting off-road vehicles to carefully designated trails. President Jimmy Carter later gave the interior secretary the authority to ban such vehicles from sensitive lands. Unfortunately, except for a brief and encouraging crackdown during the Clinton administration, nobody has paid much attention to these directives since.

title: Florida: Delay in Retrial of Six in Terror Plot
description: A judge in Miami delayed the start of jury selection in the retrial of six men accused of plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago, citing an emergency involving the family of a defense lawyer. Ana M. Jhones, the lawyer for the defendant accused of being the ringleader, requested the delay, and Judge Joan Lenard of Federal District Court scheduled a hearing Wednesday to decide whether jury selection would begin this week or next. The first trial ended last month in a hung jury for the six men and in an acquittal for another.

title: Caution, Not Panic, Seen After Drug Warnings
description: A new study may help quiet fears that the suicide warning labels on antidepressants are scaring countless patients away from medications that could help relieve their suffering.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A film review in Weekend on Dec. 21 about Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street referred imprecisely to the story on which the film is based. It was originally serialized in Britain in the 1840s, and was the basis of a play written by Christopher Bond and of Hugh Wheelers book for the stage musical. While Stephen Sondheim wrote the music and lyrics for the musical, from which the film was adapted, the story is not his.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Starbucks Replaces Chief With Chairman
description: With the stock plummeting and competitors on the attack, Starbucks Coffee said Monday that it was bringing back its top barista to help turn the company around.

title: Lottery Numbers
To Gephyrophobiacs, Bridges Are a Terror
description: The Verrazano-Narrows bridge has been called a study in grace.

title: Rolling? Were More Like the Flying Stones
description: TWO years is a long time to be on tour. We started the Rolling Stones A Bigger Bang tour in August 2005 at Fenway Park in Boston, and ended in August 2007 in London at the 02 arena. We traveled the globe, playing North America, South America, Europe, Japan, New Zealand, China and Australia. We even did full-stage rehearsals at a hangar at Pearson International Airport in Toronto.

title: Holocaust Insurance Case Inches Closer to Settlement
description: A federal judge on Monday cleared the way for a long-running dispute over unpaid life insurance claims for Holocaust victims to move a step closer to a settlement. But opponents said they would keep trying to block the settlement, which, they argued, would benefit only a small number of those with potential claims.

title: Scrutiny for Imports
description: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission is expanding inspections of imports after the recalls of toys, toothpaste and pet-food ingredients from China, Nancy A. Nord, acting chairwoman of the agency, said Monday.

title: Nonverbal Actions Add to Clemenss Story
description: From his parched, pursed lips to the jut of his shoulders, Roger Clemens was holding something back, three body-language analysts who watched him over the past two days said Monday.

title: Ballet Star to Retire
description: Damian Woetzel, a principal dancer at the New York City Ballet, said Monday he would retire at seasons end, making official what he had predicted a year ago. Mr. Woetzels final performance will be on June 18 after 23 years with the company. He earned a masters degree in public administration from Harvard University last year and is artistic director of the summer Vail International Dance Festival. Mr. Woetzel said it was fitting to leave as the company commemorates the 10th anniversary of the death of Jerome Robbins by featuring his choreography. His presence was the reason I joined the company, Mr. Woetzel said. He said he will focus his energy beyond the limited space of performing in areas where I hope to make an impact in the second part of my life.

title: Jump-Start on Slow Trek to Treatment for a Disease
description: Last month, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation donated $19 million to the Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative to further one of its goals: finding a new drug for African sleeping sickness.

title: Expectations for Giants Arent Bigger in Texas
description: In the days before the Giants final regular-season game against the undefeated New England Patriots, Coach Tom Coughlin kept his team loose by constantly reminding his players that they had nothing to lose and everything to gain.

title: More Acidic Ocean Hurts Reef Algae as Well as Corals
description: The gradual acidification of the oceans, a result of rising levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, is thought to be bad for coral reefs. The absorption of CO2 by seawater leads to lower saturation levels of carbonate ions, which reduces calcification, the process by which corals make their hard skeletons.

title: Italy: Army Called in to Clear Naples Trash
description: The government sent troops to Naples to start clearing festering piles of rubbish from the streets, many blocking entry to the citys schools, which reopened Monday after the Christmas break. Mountains of trash, too much for garbage collectors to cope with, built up after municipal dumps overflowed Dec. 21. Residents of Naples have taken to burning their own refuse, creating blazes that in some cases have had to be put out by firefighters. The citys effort to move the garbage to a previously closed dump brought a revolt by residents, who blocked garbage trucks access to the area. Naples has faced periodic trash emergencies for the past 14 years.

title: Women Are Never Front-Runners
description: THE woman in question became a lawyer after some years as a community organizer, married a corporate lawyer and is the mother of two little girls, ages 9 and 6. Herself the daughter of a white American mother and a black African father  in this race-conscious country, she is considered black  she served as a state legislator for eight years, and became an inspirational voice for national unity.

title: To Raise Armyworms and Corn Borers, Study Insect Husbandry
description: STARKVILLE, Miss.  The fall armyworm, scourge of young pretassel corn, grows up to be a nondescript brown moth about the length of a long fingers knuckle. Frank M. Daviss trainees are growing about 30,000 of them in the moth house at the United States Department of Agricultures laboratory at Mississippi State University.

title: Hong Kong Power Regulations Based in Part on Emissions
description: HONG KONG  The two electric power companies here have agreed to a new regulatory system that sets their annual rate of return, based in part on how much pollution they emit, a carrot-and-stick approach that could some day be a model for mainland Chinas giant power industries.

title: E.P.A. Seeks New Life for Old Cellphones
description: The way the Environmental Protection Agency sees it, one discarded cellphone is like one vote: on its own, it cannot do much harm or good, but the cumulative effect can pack a wallop.

title: Comcast Plans to Offer a Huge Menu of Films
description: Comcast, the nations largest cable television company, will outline an ambitious plan Tuesday to set up two new paradigms for how people will watch movies and television shows in their homes or on the road.

title: Is Prefab Fab? MoMA Plans a Show
description: To many people the term prefab housing calls to mind trailer parks. Yet lately prefabricated houses  built off site and then delivered largely complete  have become fashionable at architecture schools and among an upscale segment of the housing market. They pose a considerable design challenge.

title: Questioning an Advisers Advice
description: Come on, you can say it. Im a professional entrencher of management.

title: Raw and Edited: The Two Versions of Clemens
description: The moment Roger Clemens cut off his news conference Monday by walking off (still, in high dudgeon, remembering to take his bottle of water), I said to myself, Now thats television!

title: Pros and Cons of Giving Adult Drugs to Children
description: The attention-deficit generation has been supplanted by the bipolar generation, we learn in Tuesday nights Frontline on PBS. And overmedication of children is not the only concern these days. Parents may now be turning their youngsters into guinea pigs.

title: Strong Debut for Gladiators
description: NBCs remake of American Gladiators muscled to a strong start on Sunday. The amateur athletic tournament, based on the early 1990s series, delivered the highest ratings among adults 18 to 49 of any new show this season on any network, matching the debut of Heroes in September 2006, Nielsen estimated. In total viewers, however, American Gladiators was less impressive, drawing an average of 12 million from 9 to 11 p.m. ABCs Cashmere Mafia, by comparison, which made its debut on Sunday at 10 p.m., attracted 10.7 million viewers but markedly lower ratings in the 18-to-49 set. Cashmere Mafia also benefited from a plum time slot following ABCs Desperate Housewives (19.8 million), the only show to outpace American Gladiators on the night among adults 18 to 49. ABC, NBC and CBS finished in a virtual tie for first in that demographic over all on Sunday. CBS, buoyed by an overrun of its afternoon football coverage during the 7 p.m. hour that was followed by one of the highest rated editions of 60 Minutes in recent years (19 million), won the race in total viewers.

title: Little Support for McGwire Among Hall Voters
description: Mark McGwire, the player who did not want to talk about the past, will learn how his achievements are viewed in the present when the voting for the Hall of Fame is announced Tuesday. Unless hundreds of writers experienced stunning reversals in the past year regarding their feelings about McGwire, he is not expected to be voted into the Hall.

title: Respects Paid to Dying Suharto
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  It was the place to be seen over the weekend, the hospital bedside of Indonesias former strongman, Suharto, who was driven from office 10 years ago and is now hovering near death as his heart and kidneys weaken.

title: Fraud Trial Focuses on Insurance Giants
description: HARTFORD  The reputations of two business titans  Warren E. Buffett and Maurice R. Greenberg  came under attack on Monday as the latest corporate corruption trial got under way in federal district court here.

title: Court Revives Lawsuit Against No Child Left Behind Law
description: A federal appeals court on Monday revived a legal challenge to the federal No Child Left Behind education law, saying that school districts have been justified in complaining that the law required them to pay for testing and other programs without providing sufficient federal money.

title: Recording Reveals Frayed Remains of a Friendship
description: In a bizarre news conference in which reporters in Houston and fans on television listened in suspense to a crackling 17-minute telephone call between Roger Clemens and his accusatory former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, no eureka moment emerged from the dissonance.

title: Niacin to the Rescue
description: Q. I am taking niacin for high cholesterol. How does it work?

title: Progress on Guns
description: It took too many years and too many deaths to persuade Congress to act, but President Bush is expected to sign into law today a measure that will make it harder for people with a history of dangerous mental illness to purchase firearms. That is good news, but there is more work to be done.

title: P. K. Sethi, Inventor of the Low-Tech Limb, Is Dead at 80
description: Dr. P. K. Sethi, who invented the affordable prosthesis called the Jaipur foot, which has helped millions of amputees in developing countries to lead normal lives, died Sunday in Jaipur, India. He was 80.

title: Tiny Specks of Misery, Both Vile and Useful
description: I spent New Years Eve with friends and family. A couple of days later, my pathologically healthy mother called to say shed gotten very sick after the party, like nothing shed experienced before. She thought it had been a stomach bug. Hey, its just like in The Devil Wears Prada, I said lightly, the perfect way to jump-start your new diet!

title: A Presidents Defender Keeps His Distance
description: TEHRAN  A rift is emerging between President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Irans supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, suggesting that the president no longer enjoys the ayatollahs full backing, as he did in the years after his election in 2005.

title: Health Spending Exceeded Record $2 Trillion in 2006
description: WASHINGTON  National health spending soared above $2 trillion for the first time in 2006 and has nearly doubled in the last decade, amounting to an average of $7,000 a person, the government reported on Monday.

title: Morocco: Western Sahara Talks Resuming
description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, appealed for substantive results from deadlocked talks brokered by the United Nations between Morocco and the pro-independence Polisario Front over the future of the resource-rich Western Sahara annexed by Morocco in 1975 after the colonial power Spain withdrew. A closed-door round of negotiations, the third in seven months, begin on Tuesday in Manhasset, N.Y., amid fear that failure to settle the dispute in the region, already victimized by violence linked to Al Qaeda, could lead to the resumption of a guerrilla war that lasted until 1991, when the United Nations sent peacekeepers.

title: Alabama: Two Men Charged in Church Fires
description: Two men who the authorities said dabbled in satanism have been arrested in connection with a rash of arson and vandalism at rural churches in east Alabama. Satanic graffiti was scrawled at or near some of the churches. The two men, Geoffrey Parquette and James Clark, both 21, pleaded not guilty. Fires were set at three churches over four days beginning last Tuesday, and one of the buildings was destroyed.

title: Gilbert Harrison, 92, Ex-Editor, Dies
description: Gilbert A. Harrison, a former publisher of The New Republic, the political and cultural opinion journal that for nearly a century has adhered for the most part to a liberal bent, died Thursday in Phoenix. He was 92 and lived in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Record Price Seen for Francis Bacon Painting
description: A triptych by Francis Bacon, appearing at auction for the first time, is expected to set a record for a British or Irish work when it leads Christies Post War & Contemporary Art Evening Sale in London on Feb. 6. Held by a private collection, Triptych 1974-77, above, is the last in a series painted by Bacon (1909-1992) in response to the suicide of his lover, George Dyer, in their room in Paris. Bacons Study From Innocent X (1962) sold in May for a record $52.6 million.

title: Sharpton in Escape Case, but Prosecutor Is Upset
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.  A three-week odyssey appeared to be reaching an end on Monday for one of two men who escaped from a New Jersey county jail here last month, a day after the Rev. Al Sharpton said he had received a request to broker a surrender.

title: The Debate Over How and How Long
description: WASHINGTON  If President Bush becomes convinced the economy is indeed headed toward a recession, he is likely to respond much as he did on entering office in 2001 with the economy on the verge of a downturn: lower tax rates for people at all income levels and provide tax breaks for businesses.

title: No. 3 Train From Times Square to New Lots Ave.
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Spitzer May Ask to Cap Property Tax Increases in Annual Speech to Legislature
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer may propose a ceiling on annual property tax increases, an idea he has rejected before and one that has often met resistance among fellow Democrats.

title: More Caveats Than Clarity in Batteries-in-Baggage Rule
description: LAST week, I spent most of an afternoon trying to get a cogent explanation of a confusing news release issued late on the Friday before New Years by a mouthful of an agency called the United States Department of Transportation Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

title: Bear Stearns Announces New Leadership
description: Bear Stearns announced Tuesday that James E. Cayne, its embattled chief executive, would step down after the deepest losses in the firms history.

title: Detectives Lawyers in Sean Bell Trial Push for Change of Venue
description: Lawyers for the three police detectives charged in the shooting that killed Sean Bell argued in a motion filed on Monday that publicity surrounding the case has incurably poisoned the pool of prospective jurors for the trial next month and asked that the proceedings be moved out of New York City.

title: Albany: First Grants From Stem Cell Program
description: The state has awarded the first grants from its $600 million stem cell research program, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced on Monday. The $14.5 million in grants were awarded to 25 medical institutions to support stem cell research and training, the governor said. The one-year grants will provide $6.1 million for research, $7.4 million for equipment purchases and $1 million for training, state officials said.

title: Mozilla Names New Chief, but Reaffirms Open-Source Commitment
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Mozilla, the developer of the open-source browser Firefox, will announce on Tuesday that John Lilly, the companys chief operating officer, will succeed Mitchell Baker as chief executive.

title: For Cancer Patients, Empathy Goes a Long Way
description: Four years ago, my sister found out she had two types of cancer at the same time. It was like being hit by lightning  twice.

title: Manhattan: Police Officer Faces Federal Charges
description: A city police officer who was arrested last month on charges of raping a 14-year-old girl was charged in federal court on Monday with bringing her and a second teenage girl across state lines to engage in illegal sex, officials said. The officer, Trent Young, 39, had been a martial arts instructor to both victims and, on separate occasions in 2006 and 2007, took them from his hometown, Middletown, N.Y., to his martial arts school in New Jersey, according to a statement by the United States attorneys office in Manhattan. Officer Young was arrested on Dec. 27 by the Middletown police. The second girl came forward on Jan. 3, according to a federal compliant. Officer Young was held without bail on Monday, officials said. Officer Youngs lawyer, Gary Greenwald, said, His defense is it never happened.

title: Charter Bus Crash Kills 9 in Utah as Rain, Snow and Avalanches Batter Region
description: DENVER  A powerful Pacific storm system that slammed into the western half of the country last week wreaked havoc throughout the weekend and Monday, causing fatal traffic accidents, power failures and deep avalanches across the region.

title: Turner Goes From a Tight Spot to Letting Loose
description: SAN DIEGO  The clock was winding down, signaling the end to 12 seasons of futility. As the final seconds of the Chargers 17-6 victory against the Tennessee Titans ticked off Sunday, Chargers Coach Norv Turner stopped strategizing how to replace Antonio Gates or thwart Vince Young and succumbed to the moment.

title: Regimens: Whites More Often Given Opioid Drugs, Study Finds
description: Opioid medications, the powerful painkillers that experts say have been underused by doctors because of their stigma, are increasingly being given in emergency rooms  but white patients are more likely to get them than minorities, a new study finds.

title: Skipping the Grand Canyon for a Town Hall Meeting
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Jim McCloskey has seen the Grand Canyon, Niagara Falls and Yellowstone National Park. Hes been to Ireland, London and Spain. But on Saturday, instead of Londonderry, Northern Ireland, Mr. McCloskey, an accountant in Philadelphia, found himself in Londonderry, N.H., holding his iPhone above the crowd and trying to snap a picture of former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas at a campaign event with the actor Chuck Norris.

title: The Power of Everyday Activity
