description: Steven Blair, an exercise scientist, has been researching the health benefits of physical activity for more than 25 years, first at the Cooper Institute in Dallas and currently at the University of South Carolinas Arnold School of Public Health. He is a former president of the American College of Sports Medicine.

title: In Professors Model, Diversity = Productivity
description: In the long-running debate on affirmative action, Scott E. Page, a professor of complex systems, political science and economics at the University of Michigan, is a fresh voice.

title: Baltimore Is Suing Bank Over Foreclosure Crisis
description: Baltimores mayor and City Council are suing Wells Fargo Bank, contending that its lending practices discriminated against black borrowers and led to a wave of foreclosures that has reduced city tax revenues and increased its costs.

title: Bears Cayne to Quit as Chief Executive
description: James E. Cayne, the embattled chief executive of Bear Stearns, will step down after the deepest losses in the firms history, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.

description: As he watched Roger Clemenss interview on 60 Minutes on Sunday with a reporter from SI.com, Brian McNamee guessed that Clemens could beat a lie-detector test.

title: Woman Dies After Car Plunges Into Suffolk Waters
description: One woman died and another was in critical condition after their car went over the edge of a parking lot and landed upside down in the waters of an inlet on the Great South Bay in Bay Shore, N.Y., on Monday afternoon, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Deal for Maker of College Texts
description: Macmillan Publishers has agreed to buy Hayden-McNeil Publishing, a publisher of custom textbooks, for an undisclosed sum. The deal is expected to be announced on Tuesday.

title: The Netherlands: Not Reaching New Heights
description: The Dutch, thought to be the worlds tallest people, appear to have stopped growing, the Central Bureau for Statistics reported. It said growth rates for men and women had increased scarcely or not at all since 2001. The average Dutch man is 5 feet 11 inches tall. The average woman is 5-foot-6.

title: A Daring Bandit Steals Valuables, and Peace of Mind
description: By all appearances, the burglary could not have happened on a more sedate and established corner of Staten Island than this one on Melhorn Road.

title: Ford to Expand in India, Planning a Small Car and an Engine Plant
description: Ford Motor plans to more than double its investment in India to produce a small car for the fast-growing local market and to build an engine manufacturing plant there.

title: Corzine Proposes Huge Financial Move for N.J.
description: TRENTON  Gov. Jon S. Corzine on Tuesday proposed the biggest financial gambit in New Jerseys history, arguing that almost quadrupling highway tolls over the next 15 years could help generate about $38 billion to help the state pay off half of its debt and pay for transportation improvements.

title: In Final Push for Votes, Pledges From Both Sides to Change Washington
description: LEBANON, N.H.  Republican and Democratic presidential candidates alike called Monday for a sharp break with the way the Bush administration and Congress have been running the country, as the final hours of campaigning before the New Hampshire primary became a rush to capture the excitement surrounding Senator Barack Obama.

title: On Eve of Primary, Clinton Campaign Shows Stress
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  Key campaign officials may be replaced. She may start calling herself the underdog. Donors would receive pleas that it is do-or-die time. And her political strategy could begin mirroring that of Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican rival, by focusing on populous states like California and New York whose primaries are Feb. 5.

title: Pain Relief for Some, With an Odd Tradeoff
description: For people with chronic pain, relief comes with a tradeoff. Bed rest means missing out on life. Drugs take the edge off, but they also dull the senses and the mind.

title: Still a Sideshow, Giuliani Bets on Survival Strategy
description: DERRY, N.H.  As Rudolph W. Giuliani trudged along the slushy sidewalks of Nashua on a gray Monday morning, he kept getting the kinds of questions that no candidate wanted to hear on the eve of an important election.

title: Suzy Welch Sells Book
description: Suzy Welch, a former editor of the Harvard Business Review and the wife of John F. Welch Jr., the former chief executive of General Electric, has agreed to sell the rights to her book 10-10-10 to Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster. A person involved in the negotiations said that Scribner paid Ms. Welch a price in the seven figures for world and audio rights to the book. Based on an article Ms. Welch wrote for O, the Oprah Magazine, in 2006, the book offers strategies for making decisions in which people think about what the consequences of a decision will be in 10 minutes, 10 months and 10 years. Robert Barnett, a Washington lawyer, negotiated the deal on behalf of Ms. Welch. Nan Graham, editor in chief of Scribner, will edit the book with Samantha Martin. Ms. Welch, who wrote the best-selling Winning with Mr. Welch, said she originally thought there wasnt a book beyond the article. But, she said, I began to encounter this hunger for people who were using it to play out its nuances. She said the book would include examples from her own life as well as others she has observed using the 10-10-10 process. Susan Moldow, publisher of Scribner, said that although Ms. Welchs article might seem sufficient for those who wanted to know about the strategy, Ms. Moldow believed the book would sell well. The Scarsdale Diet fit on a Xerox-ed sheet that you could fit on the front of a refrigerator, Ms. Moldow said. And it sold millions and millions of copies. Its often true that when something strikes an immediate Aha!, you really want to have time to meditate on it and try to get to know more about it.

title: Concertgoers, Please Clap, Talk or Shout at Any Time
description: Concertgoers like you and me have become part police officer, part public offender. We prosecute the shuffled foot or rattled program, the errant whisper or misplaced cough. We tense at the end of a movement, fearful that one of the unwashed will begin to clap, bringing shame on us all. How serious we look, and how absurd we are.

title: Risks: Lax Catheter Policies Seen at Many Hospitals
description: One of the best ways to get an infection in the hospital is to have a urinary catheter installed (dont everyone rush out at once). Almost half of all infections acquired at hospitals are in the urinary tract, and most are linked to catheters.

title: White Plains: Federal Oversight for Polls
description: A panel of three federal judges has approved the extension of a consent agreement through which Westchester County provided bilingual assistance at the polls for Spanish-speaking voters, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, announced on Monday. The agreement, between federal prosecutors and the county, was signed in 2005 and set to expire last summer, but federal prosecutors asked to extend the agreement to December of this year. In a Jan. 3 opinion, the judges found that the county had made progress in complying with the agreement, but that the extension was still justified, the prosecutors said.

title: Consumer Electronics Show | Chic Squad?
description: As the official blog of T: The New York Times Style Magazine, The Moment works hard to come off like one of the cool kids. Yesterday we blew our cover when we arrived in Las Vegas for the Consumer Electronics Show (C.E.S.), arguably the preeminent geek convention of the year. Our mission over the next few days will be to indulge our obsession with sexy electronics, browsing millions of doodads in search of good design. More on that later  you see, we arent kidding about millions. The show sprawls for miles inside the mother of all convention centers. The crush of business men, cheesecake spokesmodels and high-tech signage has us thinking were in Tokyo, not Nevada. Its an infamously brutal ordeal, and yesterday we saw people passed out on the floor by days end. According to our buddies at Bits, the Timess technology blog, theres a big microbe scare at C.E.S. this year: Everybodys wiping down with Purell, and one company is even handing out sanitary gloves for germ-free handshakes. Lest wed forget our surroundings, upon registration all journalists were issued blue and silver backpacks complete with external mesh pockets for water bottles, a waist belt, reflective coating (safety first) and a handy internal organizer that looks awfully pocket-protector like. Rather than wearing it, The Moment opted for the ghetto-chic boom-box shopping bag (above) we snagged at the Lasonic booth. But when the paper started to give, we saw the error of our ways, donned the backpack and accepted the inevitable. Today, were jumping in again, but this time were bring the new leopard-print Taser to clear the way.

Four years ago, I passed the afternoon playing pool with a couple of other journalists. This time, I might just stop by the mall.

title: Now Booking | Guadeloupe
description: (Daniel Barillot/Masterfile)When I learned that an outpost of Barbuto  a stylish restaurant around the corner from my West Village apartment  had opened on the French Caribbean island of Guadeloupe, I scratched my head. What was the chef Jonathan Waxman, known for his seasonal take on traditional Italian dishes, doing on an island that not only has no Italian connection but is also pretty well overlooked by Americans? Turns out the explanation is a fairly simple: when one of Barbutos partners, Phil Scotti, was visiting Guadeloupe, he happened to meet Valerie Robein, a well respected local restaurateur who was looking to open a new place, and hatched the idea to back her in a Caribbean-inflected version of Barbuto, with Robein helming the stove and Waxman developing the menu. While Barbuto Guadeloupes lasagna with conch or roast chicken with curry arent reason enough to make a trip, the restaurants opening got me thinking again about an island that is said to combine the typical Caribbean assets of sun and sand with what is, lets face it, a real rarity in the region: a vibrant food scene, and one that intriguingly blends both Creole and European influences. Guadeloupe is one of the few major islands I havent been to, but friends who have tell me the foods unusually good, from excellent morning pastries in the cafs to fresh grilled fish on the beach to more ambitious fare in the restaurants of Deshaies, the cute town where Barbuto is based. Whats more, although French tourists in high season do pack the coastal resorts of Grand-Terre, Guadeloupes eastern half, over on Basse-Terre you can supposedly still get some peace and quiet on the beach in January and February. Even in deepest darkest winter Im always discouraging my better half from planning Caribbean getaways, in large part because a week without great eating is not my idea of a vacation, but in 2008 I think Im voting for Guadeloupe. (For an overview of the island, and some hotel and restaurant advice, go here. Been to Guadeloupe? Let me know how you liked it here

title: Wallace Should Hang
description: This week, I want to look at a figure in the history of biology: Alfred Russel Wallace. January 8th was his birthday. And 2008 is the 150th anniversary of one of the most important events in the history of biology. In 1858, Wallace wrote to Charles Darwin from the Moluccan Islands, in what is now Indonesia, where he was collecting birds, beetles, butterflies and anything else he could catch. The letter contained a manuscript in which Wallace outlined the idea of evolution by natural selection.

title: Britain: Bhuttos Son Critical of U.S.
description: Bilawal Bhutto Zardari, the 19-year-old son of Benazir Bhutto, Pakistans assassinated opposition leader, said at a news conference in London that the United States would have to stop supporting dictators in Pakistan for Islamic extremism to be defeated there. Returning to Britain from Pakistan two weeks after his mothers death to resume his first-year studies at Oxford, he gave a battery of feisty answers to reporters who questioned the Pakistan Peoples Partys decision to pick him as his mothers successor as party chairman. To a reporter who suggested he had been appointed to the post like a piece of family furniture, he said he had not sought it, but added, It was recognized at this moment in crisis the party needed a close association with my mother through the bloodline. Asked if he feared for his life, he replied: How many Bhuttos can you kill? From every house a Bhutto will come. Noting that the party had selected his father, Asif Ali Zardari, as the partys co-chairman until he finishes his university degree, he said he would step gradually and carefully into politics. He renewed the familys demands for a United Nations inquiry into his mothers death and spoke out against American support for the generals who have ruled Pakistan for more than half its 60-year existence. The problem is that dictatorships breed extremism, and once the U.S. stops supporting dictators, we can successfully tackle extremists, he said.

title: Appeal Dropped in New Forest Rules
description: The Bush administration has dropped its appeal of a 2007 court decision that overturned new management rules for 191 million acres of national forests. Opponents to the rules had argued that they weakened protection for wildlife and the environment to the benefit of the timber industry. The Justice Department notified the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit this week that it was withdrawing its appeal, saying the other parties, including the timber industry, would do likewise. Last March, a federal district court in California found that the United States Forest Service had bypassed required environmental reviews and provisions under the Endangered Species Act in its overhaul of the management rules, including changes in logging limits, for its national forests.

title: An Affiliate Sues Habitat for Humanity Over a Pact
description: In an extraordinary act of rebellion, the oldest affiliate of Habitat for Humanity International has filed suit to protest a new agreement that the nonprofit housing organization is imposing on its 1,600 local chapters.

title: Young and Broke in the City, but Staying Afloat
description: As hosts of a small gathering the other night to watch a college football game, Brian Markey and his roommate, Owen Cahillane, hustled to get their place ready, which took a startling amount of time, considering that it has only 250 square feet of space. They live on a houseboat in the Bronx, on a finger of water that is formally known as Westchester Creek. It is close to the elbow of the Hutchinson River Parkway and the Cross Bronx Expressway, in a pocket of the city that is in no immediate danger of becoming the new Williamsburg.

title: McCains Victory Scrambles Field
description: MANCHESTER, N.H. After Senator John McCains victory here on Tuesday, the Republican field is more scrambled than ever, with the battleground now shifting to a series of states where each of the leading candidates believes he holds certain advantages.

title: Demolition to Resume at Deutsche Bank Site
description: After nearly five months of inactivity, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation is close to restarting the demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building, where work halted in August after two firefighters died fighting a blaze in the contaminated tower.

title: Recipe: Edamame With Nori Salt
description: Adapted from Evan Rich

title: Let the Horse Race Begin: The Search for a Successor
description: The last time the Metropolitan Museum of Art found itself looking for a director, the institution and the museum world around it were vastly different places.

title: Citigroup Combining Mortgage Operations Into One Unit
description: Citigroup, badly bruised by the sharp downturn in the housing market, is bringing its mortgage-related activities under one roof.

title: Germany: Manufacturing Orders Surge Again
description: Manufacturing orders in Germany unexpectedly surged for a second month in November as domestic companies increased spending on goods such as factory machinery. Orders, adjusted for seasonal swings and inflation, gained 3.4 percent from October, when they rose 4 percent, the Economics and Technology Ministry said. Domestic orders rose 4.2 percent from October and export sales increased 2.8 percent. Orders from the euro area gained 6.8 percent, the report showed. Capital goods orders rose 3.6 percent and sales of intermediate goods advanced 4.3 percent, while demand for consumer goods slid 1.1 percent.

title: Suharto Suffers More Setbacks
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Doctors struggled Tuesday to stabilize the condition of former President Suharto after a setback that they said included new signs of internal bleeding, heart problems and a buildup of fluid in his lungs.

title: From an Iranian Cook, the Taste of Memory
description: FAROKH MEHDIAN, a maker of custom home furnishings, like draperies and tablecloths, has a divided life. In 1999, she moved from Brooklyn first to Alexandria, and then to McLean, Va., to live near her sister, niece and nephew.

title: Microsoft Bids for Search Software Firm
description: Microsoft bid $1.2 billion on Tuesday for a Norwegian search software company, in what analysts said was mainly an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products, but was also being done with an eye toward fending off Google.

title: Nevada: A Shift at Yucca Mountain
description: The Energy Department is cutting operations at the desert site where the government plans to build a national nuclear waste repository and the chief contractor is laying off many of its staff members, officials said, as planners shift from exploring and evaluating the site to preparing a license application. Officials with the main contractor, Bechtel SAIC Company, said all but about 15 caretaking employees would be laid off at the Yucca Mountain repository, about 90 miles northwest of Las Vegas. Edward F. Sproat, the Energy Department official in charge of the project, has vowed to submit a license application to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission by June 30. Mr. Sproat has projected 2017 as the earliest the site could open, with a price tag now topping $77 billion.

title: Storms Strike Midwest, Killing at Least 6
description: Record-breaking temperatures in the midsection of the country gave way to rare January tornadoes and flooding on Monday and Tuesday. The storms killed at least six people, including two young children, and shattered houses and submerged roads.

title: U.S. Attack in Iraq Is No Surprise to Many Insurgents
description: ESAIWID, Iraq  With extraordinary secrecy, and even an information blackout aimed at most of their Iraqi Army comrades, American troops began a major offensive on Tuesday to drive Sunni insurgents from strongholds in Diyala Province. But many insurgents still managed to flee the first villages the Americans went into, showing just how difficult it is to trap the elusive militants.

title: Taxpayer Advocate Urges Apology Payments
description: Taxpayers who endure excessive expense or drain on their time when the Internal Revenue Service mishandles a case should receive apology payments of up to $1,000 each, the National Taxpayer Advocate told Congress on Wednesday.

title: China: Free Plastic Shopping Bags to Be Banned
description: China will ban retailers from giving free plastic shopping bags to consumers starting in June to curb waste and reduce pollution. Chinas cabinet, the State Council, calling the excessive use of plastic bags a serious waste of resources, also said it would ban production of ultra-thin plastic bags measuring less than 0.025 millimeter thick. Retailers will be able to sell plastic bags, but will have to clearly display the price and may not include the cost in the price of merchandise, the State Council said.

title: Idol Winner Goes Solo
description: Taylor Hicks, below, the 2006 winner of American Idol, has followed Ruben Studdard, the 2003 winner, out the door of J Records, The Associated Press reported. Taylor is going to record on his own for the next album, said Liz Morentin, a public relations representative for J, a label within Sony-BMG. Mr. Studdard left his contract with the label late last year but remains under contract with 19 Entertainment, a company managed by Simon Fuller, creator of Idol. Mr. Studdards last album, The Return, sold only 236,000 copies. Mr. Hickss self-titled album, released in December 2006, reached No. 2 on the Billboard chart and sold 699,000 copies, failing to reach the million mark achieved by the debuts of previous Idol winners, Nielsen SounScan reported.

title: Citing Persecution, Spanish Abortion Clinics Go on Strike
description: MADRID  Private clinics in Spain, which perform most of the countrys abortions, began a five-day strike on Tuesday to protest what they said was persecution by anti-abortion campaigners and government inspectors, who have swept clinics in recent weeks to crack down on illegal terminations.

title: Recipe: Fresh Herb Khoresh
description: Adapted from Farokh Mehdian

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Saturday about the prospect of Roger Clemens testifying under oath before a Congressional committee misidentified the Texas town where he lives with his family. It is Piney Point Village on the west side of Houston  not Katy, a suburb farther to the west where he once lived. (The error has appeared in numerous articles and Sports of The Times columns in recent years.)

title: Women Backed Clinton, Exit Polls Show
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Democratic women rallied around Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the New Hampshire primary Tuesday, according to statewide exit polls, confounding expectations and providing her margin of victory over Senator Barack Obama.

title: Recipe: Persian Rice
description: Adapted from Farokh Mehdian

title: Van Crashes Into Restaurant, Killing Queens Woman, 67
description: A woman eating lunch at an Arbys in Queens was killed on Tuesday when a van crashed through the front of the restaurant, the police said.

title: Lessons in a Laptop
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Many Innocents Abroad
description: Antananarivo, Madagascar

title: Extrication Time at Bear Stearns
description: As a top investment banker at Bear Stearns, Alan D. Schwartz deftly outmaneuvered the likes of Carl C. Icahn and won plaudits for his pragmatic ways.

title: McCain and Bushs Heirs
description: John McCain has never pretended that economics was his big issue, and he has never seemed too tied to any one view. Elected to Congress in 1982 as a war hero, he focused on military issues early in his career, all the while providing a reliable vote for tax cuts.

title: Are We in Danger of Consuming Ourselves Away?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lentil Soup to Make You Stop, Taste and Savor
description: FOR years it seemed that everyone I knew had a special lentil soup recipe, one that sustained them and kept them warm all winter long. I had flirted with countless incarnations, and most tasted reasonably good. They were brawny, solid and predictable. I liked them in varying degrees, but never quite enough to take home to my soup pot. Until recently, when I fell head over heels. Could this be the one?

title: Retail Sales Fell in November, to Lowest in 10 Years
description: European retail sales fell the most in at least 10 years in November as rising food and energy costs sapped consumer confidence. Retail sales declined 1.4 percent in November from a year ago, the biggest drop since at least 1997, the European Unions statistics office in Luxembourg said. From the previous month, sales fell 0.5 percent, the third decline in four months. Higher gasoline and food costs are eroding purchasing power in the euro area and restraining spending even as unemployment falls to a record low.

title: A Show of Emotion That Reverberated Beyond the Campaign
description: It was not that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton teared up. It was all the times she did not.

title: Denmark: Cargo Carrier to Lay Off Up to 12%
description: A. P. Moeller-Maersk, the worlds largest ocean cargo carrier, will cut as many as 3,000 jobs in the container division after the unit posted a loss in 2006 for the first time in at least three years. The division, Maersk Line, will reduce its 25,000-member work force by 2,000 to 3,000 people, or as much as 12 percent, the company said. Maersk Line, which owns more than 500 vessels that carry 1.7 million containers, posted a $568 million loss in 2006, its first since Maersk began breaking out division figures in 2003. Moeller-Maersk is based in Copenhagen.

title: Clinton Escapes to Fight Another Day
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Hillary Rodham Clinton is back.

title: Maazel at the Met, Brnnhilde in a Bind
description: As soon as Lorin Maazel appeared in the pit at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night to conduct the seasons first performance of Wagners Walkre, he received a sustained ovation from the audience. At 77, after an inexplicable 45-year absence, Mr. Maazel has finally returned to the Met. Facing high expectations, he delivered, conducting a lucidly textured, rhythmically incisive and strongly conceived account of this touchstone opera and winning what looked to be very respectful applause from the orchestra musicians when he took a solo curtain call at the end of the five-hour evening.

title: Debate Was Key to Win, Clinton Says
description: A day after the New Hampshire primary recast the presidential race, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Wednesday that the candidates debate on Saturday was a turning point in her surprising victory over Senator Barack Obama, while Mr. Obama sought to remain upbeat and traveled to New York on a fund-raising mission.

title: Habitat for Humanity Sued by Affiliate
description: In an extraordinary act of rebellion, the oldest affiliate of Habitat for Humanity International has filed suit to protest a new agreement that the nonprofit housing organization is imposing on its 1,600 local chapters.

title: Redskins Gibbs Retires After a Trying Season
description: Hours after the Washington Redskins arrived home Sunday morning following their playoff loss to the Seattle Seahawks, Coach Joe Gibbs was back on a plane, this time for a crucial visit with his family in North Carolina.

title: Food Allergies Stir a Mother to Action
description: Lafayette, Colo.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Tuesday about a musical based on Anne Franks diary, scheduled to open in Madrid next month, misstated the history of such musicals. There is at least one other, Yours, Anne, which was produced Off Broadway in 1985. The one in Madrid will not be the first.

title: Making Way in America: Jewish Identities and Personal Allegiances
description: Jewish journeys into American society receive an earnest, lively PBS treatment that often seems as all-encompassing as the six million citizens who share this heritage. Their ancestors may have come from different homelands, but their ethnic commonality is considered essential to the dozens who testify in this six-hour sprawl of history. Still, in these testimonials, many assert there are competing elements in their self-definitions.

title: Corpse Wheeled to Check-Cashing Store Leads to 2 Arrests
description: Even for the once-notorious Hells Kitchen neighborhood, it may have been a first: Two men were arrested on Tuesday after pushing a corpse, seated in an office chair, along the sidewalk to a check-cashing store to cash the dead mans Social Security check, the police said.

title: Thailand: Ex-Premiers Wife Arrested
description: Pojaman Shinawatra, the wife of the ousted prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, returned to Thailand to fight corruption charges. She was met by the police after her flight arrived from Hong Kong, arrested, quickly released on bail, and ordered not to leave the country. Analysts said her return  the couple have been living mostly in London and Hong Kong since a military coup in 2006  signaled confidence that the political situation, still unsettled after a victory by Mr. Thaksins allies in elections last month, would turn in their favor once a new government has been formed. Noppadol Pattama, a lawyer for the family, said Monday that Mr. Thaksin planned to return by mid-April. He is charged in the same cases as his wife, charges brought by the generals who carried out the coup.

title: Gossage Elected to Hall in His Ninth Attempt
description: With an explosive fastball that unnerved hitters, a motion that was an intertwining of long arms and long legs and a Fu Manchu mustache that was his perpetual Halloween mask, Rich Gossage was an intimidator. Gossage, a dependable bouncer on the mound who was known as Goose, pushed his way to baseballs highest honor Tuesday when he was elected into the Hall of Fame.

title: Ernestine Stodelle, 95, Modern Dancer, Dies
description: Ernestine Stodelle, a pioneering modern dancer who performed with Doris Humphrey and Jos Limn and also wrote about dance, died on Saturday in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 95.

title: Oneida: Broken Track Is Blamed in Explosion
description: An undetected break in a section of rail jarred a CSX train from its tracks last year just outside Oneida, triggering an explosion of four liquid propane tankers, a federal report said on Tuesday. The explosion on March 12 forced the evacuation of 200 residents and temporarily shut down the New York State Thruway, according to the Federal Railroad Administrations report. There were no injuries. The administration said that the crew had been operating the 80-car train in compliance with federal standards and that the track had been inspected and tested regularly. Inspectors determined that the rail was broken before the train passed over it.

title: Amazon Consolidates in Growing Area of Seattle
description: Amazon.com, the worlds largest online retailer, will soon finally have one place to call home.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Jan. 1 about a federal judges rulings on prosecution evidence in the wiretapping case against the Hollywood private eye Anthony Pellicano was published in error. The rulings were issued on Dec. 21 and were reported in The Times on Dec. 25; they were not issued on Dec. 29. (Go to Article)

title: Rise Seen in Trafficking of Enhanced Ecstasy
description: Methamphetamine-laced Ecstasy is flowing across the Canadian border into the United States, according to a warning last week from the federal government to public health and local law enforcement officials.

title: Demolition Crews Go to Work on a Winter Wonderland
description: The candy canes were the first to go.

title: Antiwar Groups Claim Victory in Settlement Over Great Lawn
description: After three years of litigation, the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation agreed on Tuesday to back away from the main part of a controversial regulation limiting public events on the Great Lawn, in the heart of Central Park, to 50,000 people.

title: Job Cuts at McGraw-Hill Will Eliminate 3% of Staff
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies said Tuesday that it was cutting 611 jobs, or 3 percent of its staff, and taking an after-tax charge of $27.3 million, or 8 cents a share, in the fourth quarter.

title: There Amid the Madness, Dark Humor Lies in Wait
description: Depending on how you look at it, Three Lost Chords is a single work in three loosely related acts, or three short, single-character operas yoked together. The source material is far-flung, with Kafka and Poe as the outer acts, and a slighter story by Muriel Spark between them. But these monodramas have something in common, apart from music by Lance Horne and librettos by Mark Campbell. Each of their protagonists is dead, insane or (somehow) both. And ghoulish though the stories are, Mr. Horne, Mr. Campbell and David Schweizer, who directs the production at the Zipper Factory Theater, have found a current of dark humor within each.

title: Fordham Seniors Honored
description: Fordham punter Benjamin Dato and linebacker Earl Hudnell, both seniors, were named Football Championship Subdivision All-Americans by the Sports Network. Dato was named to the first team and Hudnell was an honorable mention.

title: Tributes and Grief at a Funeral for a Firefighter
description: By the time thousands of mourners gathered on Tuesday to say farewell to Lt. John H. Martinson, his fellow firefighters had already spent five days telling the world about his bravery, his willingness to run first into the flames and stay there until everyone had escaped, which is part of what led to his death last week at a smoky Brooklyn blaze.

title: SEC Is Confirmed as King of Conferences
description: NEW ORLEANS  Louisiana State Coach Les Miles interrupted his postgame news conference late Monday night for an impromptu celebration.

title: Doctors Try to Stabilize Suharto
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Doctors struggled Tuesday to stabilize the condition of former President Suharto after a setback that they said included new signs of internal bleeding, heart problems and a buildup of fluid in his lungs.

title: Despite Early Results, News Outlets Let Caution Rule on Calling Winner
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly after 10:30 Tuesday night, John King, the chief national correspondent for CNN, was telling viewers how the network would have already declared Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton the winner of the New Hampshire primary under normal circumstances, and how these were anything but.

title: Wireless Start-Up Fails to Get Financing
description: Frontline Wireless, which wanted to build an innovative cellular network for both private use and local public safety agencies, has collapsed because it could not raise enough money to bid in the government auctions of wireless spectrum that start later this month.

title: As the Ice Melts, Can the Polar Bears Survive?
description: To the Editor:

title: A One-Night Shift in the Late-Night Wars
description: For the first time since televisions late-night shows returned to the air last week, David Letterman was able to nose out Jay Leno in the ratings. It was just for one show, Monday night, and Mr. Lettermans lead was not sizable, but Mr. Leno had won the first three nights. Their competition resumed last Wednesday, when most of the late-night hosts came back after supporting the writers strike for two months. Mr. Leno is working without his writing staff, which is still on strike against his Tonight Show on NBC, while Mr. Letterman, above, was able to return with writers to his CBS show because of a separate deal his production company made with the Writers Guild of America. Mr. Letterman has also been able to book the normal roster of movie-star guests; on Monday night he had Tom Hanks, while Mr. Leno had the upstart Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul. In the overnight ratings, measuring the countrys 65 largest cities, Mr. Letterman had a 4 rating on Monday to Mr. Lenos 3.8. (Each point is worth 787,659 households.) But in their shows first half-hour, when Mr. Leno is performing a monologue over the opposition of the writers guild, he still beat Mr. Letterman, with a 4.5 rating to a 4.3. CBSs thin victory margin continued on the 12:35 a.m. shows, where Craig Ferguson enjoyed a rare ratings victory over NBCs Conan OBrien, with a 1.9 rating to a 1.8 for Mr. OBrien.

title: The Legacy of a Pragmatic Custodian of Human Civilization
description: Either you become more autocratic or you relax, Philippe de Montebello said some years ago, drumming his fingers on his desk. He had been asked to reflect on what was then a quarter-century as director of the Metropolitan Museum. Im much less imperious now. I know pretty much what Im doing.

title: Can Hillary Cry Her Way Back to the White House?
description: DERRY, N.H.

title: Him, Her and Him by the Seashore, Balancing Levity and Suffering
description: About 10 minutes into Woman on the Beach, a bittersweet accounting of the geography of desire from the South Korean director Hong Sang-soo, two men and a woman stand staring into the sea. This seemingly casual triangle is a classic formal and sexual configuration for Mr. Hong, whose elegant, restrained films chart the mysteries of the heart and the follies of the head with intelligence and shock waves of feeling. Yet true to form, Mr. Hong draws this triangle with hard, sharp lines, which you grasp when one man tells the other that he admires him because its hard for a married man to openly bring along his girlfriend, as he has.

title: Group of Women to Buy Storm
description: A group of Seattle women, led by the former deputy mayor Anne Levinson, will buy the Seattle Storm of the W.N.B.A. from the SuperSonics owner, Clay Bennett, for $10 million. The purchase option for the franchise was completed in the last few days, ensuring the Storm would remain in Seattle, while Bennett continues his push to move the SuperSonics to his hometown of Oklahoma City. The group, calling itself Force 10 Hoops, has until the end of February to close the sale and would need approval from the W.N.B.A. Board of Governors.

title: Riding Horses Helps in Hurdling Obstacles for Rookie Jockey
description: CICERO, Ill.  For the first time in a long time, Sylvia Harris has a roof over her head, money in her pocket and relative peace of mind. She has found this place, this good place, by riding horses.

title: Stocks Dive on Reports of New Ills
description: Shares tumbled late Tuesday after the head of AT&T suggested that consumers might be cutting back and Countrywide Financial denied that it was tumbling into bankruptcy.

title: TV Station Fires Anchor
description: Alycia Lane has been dismissed by KYW-TV, the CBS-owned station in Philadelphia, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lane, 35, was arrested in Manhattan on Dec. 16 and arraigned on a felony charge of assaulting a police officer. The police said she punched an officer in the face, and a police complaint said she used a sexual slur. Ms. Lane has denied the charges. She had been off the air since the incident and had been scheduled to return on Monday. But in a statement that day, the station said she has been released from her contract effective immediately. Ms. Lane was previously the subject of reports that she had e-mailed images of herself in a bikini to a married ESPN sports anchor. Michael Colleran, the president and general manager of KYW-TV, said, After assessing the overall impact of a series of incidents resulting from judgments she has made, we have concluded that it would be impossible for Alycia to continue to report the news as she herself has become the focus of so many news stories. In a statement, Paul Rosen, Ms. Lanes lawyer, declared the termination to be contrary to the terms of her contract.

title: South Florida Officer Killed, Becoming 4th in Six Months
description: MIAMI  An off-duty Miami police detective was shot and killed early Tuesday morning, and the authorities speculated that he may have stumbled on a drug transaction in progress.

title: Maldives: Quick, a Merit Badge
description: A 15-year-old Boy Scout foiled an assassination attempt on President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, grabbing a mans knife as he leapt from a crowd and lunged at the leader, a government spokesman said. The president was unhurt, although the knife ripped his shirt. No motive was given. The boy, in his scout uniform for the event on the northern island of Hoarafushi, suffered a hand injury.

title: Hes Staying in Campaign, Edwards Tells Supporters
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Reminding voters that less than one week ago he took second in the Iowa caucuses, John Edwards said Tuesday night that he would continue his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, despite his distant third-place showing in the New Hampshire primary.

title: Recipe: Wok-Seared Spicy Calamari Salad
description: Adapted from TenPenh, Washington

title: A Regulator Not Stymied by Red Tape
description: Shortly before Thanksgiving, Eric R. Dinallo, the insurance regulator for New York State, did something unusual. He called Warren E. Buffetts right-hand man on insurance, Ajit Jain, and suggested that he start a new company to insure municipal bonds in New York.

title: U.N. Official Warns of Darfur Failure
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations top peacekeeping official told the Security Council on Wednesday that obstructionism by the Sudanese government, the unwillingness of other countries to supply needed transportation equipment and continuing outbreaks of violence threatened to doom the mission of the freshly deployed peacekeeping force in Darfur.

title: Texas: Child Abandonment Charges Filed
description: A woman accused of leaving her children with little food and no money while she traveled to Nigeria to marry a man she met on the Internet has been charged with child endangerment and child abandonment. The authorities have issued an arrest warrant for the woman, Shanell Monique Mosley, 33, but her relatives have not heard from her, a Child Protective Services spokeswoman said. Harris County sheriffs deputies conducting a welfare check last week at the home in Cypress, outside Houston, found six children ages 1 to 9 being cared for by their 15-year-old sister. A neighbors 3-year-old boy and 4-year-old girl were also in the house. Ms. Mosleys six children and the neighbors two children have been placed in foster homes, and a custody hearing is scheduled for Jan. 16.

title: A Dangerous Game in the Strait
description: Iran played a reckless and foolish game in the Strait of Hormuz this week that  except for American restraint  could have spun lethally out of control.

title: Calendar
description: Distilled Apples

title: Recipe: Clementine Clafoutis
description: Time: About 1 hour

title: Universities Need to Retake Control
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Lackluster Dance
description: Dance War, a spinoff of ABCs popular series Dancing With the Stars, attracted only modest interest in the ratings on Monday, drawing 11 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Among adults 18 to 49, the reality competition between the choreographers Bruno Tonioli and Carrie Ann Inaba earned about half the ratings of the most recent premiere of Dancing With the Stars in September. The dancers also fell well short of NBCs American Gladiators during the 8 p.m. hour. That new reality show, despite drawing just 10.9 million total viewers, would have led the night among the 18-to-49 set but for Foxs football coverage, the Bowl Championship Series, which averaged more than 20 million viewers total. NBC ranked second for the night behind Fox, earning solid numbers from Deal or No Deal at 9 (10.7 million) and the premiere of the fourth season of Medium at 10 (9.6 million). ABCs October Road drew a disappointing five million viewers at 10.

title: A Taste for Brews That Go to Extremes
description: AS a life philosophy, it may not lead to wealth, happiness or old age, but for many American brewers today the motto printed on the bottle of Moylander Double I.P.A., from Moylans, a West Coast brewer, is a guiding principle:

title: Rutgers Rice Will Enter N.F.L. Draft
description: Ray Rices most productive game in a Rutgers uniform will apparently also be his last.

title: Global Ad Agency Moving to Far West of Manhattan
description: Ogilvy & Mather, the international advertising and public relations agency, said Tuesday that it would move its headquarters to 636 11th Avenue, at 47th Street, becoming one of the first corporate tenants to embrace that stretch of the Far West Side of Manhattan.

title: F.T.C. Asks if Carbon-Offset Money Is Well Spent
description: Corporations and shoppers in the United States spent more than $54 million last year on carbon offset credits toward tree planting, wind farms, solar plants and other projects to balance the emissions created by, say, using a laptop computer or flying on a jet.

title: Lottery Numbers
Bonds New Woman
description: Oh, that James Bond. Sometimes its just about impossible to keep up with him and his women. A day after announcing that the British actress Gemma Arterton will be the new Bond girl, Reuters revised its call, reporting that 007s sidekick will be the Ukrainian actress Olga Kurylenko. The news agency, citing a source close to the film, said that although Ms. Arterton has a role in the forthcoming film, it is not as extensive as that of Ms. Kurylenko, above, a former model seen recently in Hitman.

title: Dissent Inside Habitat for Humanity
description: In an extraordinary act of rebellion, the oldest affiliate of Habitat for Humanity International has filed suit to protest a new agreement that the nonprofit housing organization is imposing on its 1,600 local chapters.

title: Pairings
description: EXTREME beer? Extreme food!

title: Color Her Protest Pink (and Floral)
description: It all started with the pink shoes. As a girl in Iran in the 1980s, Zarah Ghahramani gravitated toward bright colors and lots of jewelry. She particularly loved a pair of pink slip-ons with flowers on the toes. Unfortunately, with the war against Iraq in full swing, and black the prescribed color for clothing, pink constituted a political affront. At 6, Ms. Ghahramani was already headed for trouble.

title: Trying to Be Heard Above the Din, and Be Trusted
description: IN bank advertising, what matters is getting noticed at a time when the airwaves are cluttered, customers are nervous and marketing budgets are being slashed. JPMorgan Chase has that in mind with a sleek new brand campaign aimed at unifying its consumer advertising, streamlining its message and stretching the dollars it spends.

title: A Losing Streak Had to End, but It Isnt the Rangers One
description: The Rangers hit a point in Tuesday nights game against Tampa Bay when they finally became disgusted with themselves. They had lost three straight games and several players to injuries, and they were trying to rally from a three-goal deficit against the worst team in the Eastern Conference.

title: Retooled Campaign and Loyal Voters Add Up
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  The Clintons rarely make the same mistake twice.

title: Two Drifting Life Rafts on a Sea of Circumstance
description: Theres not a single wrong note in Liberty Kid, Ilya Chaikens poignant drama about marginal lives strained to breaking by the aftermath of Sept. 11.

title: Knicks Win With Marbury Back in Body and Spirit
description: CHICAGO  Stephon Marbury has been back on the Knicks active roster for a week, and back in the lineup for several days. It was not until late Tuesday night, however, that he truly seemed back in his realm  physically, emotionally and competitively.

title: Italy: Prodi Intervenes in Naples Trash Crisis
description: Prime Minister Romano Prodi announced emergency measures to deal with Naples mounting garbage crisis, including three new incinerators, a special garbage czar, and an attempt to get other regions to volunteer to take the trash. The northern Valle dAosta offered to help, reports said.

title: Clinton Is Victor, Turning Back Obama; McCain Also Triumphs
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York rode a wave of female support to a surprise victory over Senator Barack Obama in the New Hampshire Democratic primary on Tuesday night. In the Republican primary, Senator John McCain of Arizona revived his presidential bid with a Lazarus-like victory.

title: Fed Panel Was Divided Over Outlook for Economy
description: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones/AP)  Reflecting a highly uncertain and divided outlook on monetary policy, regional Federal Reserve banks supported three options for the discount rate last month, according to minutes of the December meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, released Tuesday.

title: What You Get for ... $5 Million
description: Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Recipe: Halibut With Nori Jam
description: Adapted from David Myers

title: University of Georgia President Calls for Playoffs
description: In a move that drew laughter for its feasibility and scorn for its timing, Michael F. Adams, the president of the University of Georgia, said he would use his position as the chair of the N.C.A.A.s executive committee to push for an eight-team playoff.

title: Metro-North Hudson Line From Grand Central to Croton-Harmon
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: If This Happens in Vegas, It Can Sure Stay in Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  Parking was plentiful right by the door, there was no one to wrestle with for use of the slot machines, and Paris Hilton would not have been caught dead anywhere near this joint.

title: Spitzer Strikes a Conciliatory Tone
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer kicked off his second year with warm words for his friends and foes alike, offering a strikingly less combative tone in his State of the State address Wednesday.

title: Clementines in a Blanket
description: IT was one of those why didnt I think of that? moments. I took one glance at a menu in a Paris bistro, and presto! Suddenly I wanted to make a clafoutis with clementines, too.

title: A Serbian Directors Eye Remains Fixed on Uncomfortable Truths
description: He has been a Yugoslav and a Serb and worked under dictators as philosophically opposed as Tito and Milosevic. He has made films about old people (These Earthly Days Go Rolling By), young love (Beach Guard in Wintertime) and a Serbia racked by frustrations and irrational violence (Cabaret Balkan). So it makes perfect sense that the place where Goran Paskaljevic really likes to work right now is Ireland.

title: Footnotes
description: The Directors Guild of America has announced its nominees for directorial achievement in feature film: Paul Thomas Anderson for There Will Be Blood, Joel and Ethan Coen for No Country for Old Men, Tony Gilroy for Michael Clayton, Sean Penn for Into the Wild and Julian Schnabel for The Diving Bell and the Butterfly. The winner will be announced on Jan. 26. ... The Oscar-winning actress Nicole Kidman and her husband, the country singer Keith Urban, are expecting a baby, Reuters reported. The birth is expected in mid-2008.

title: Easing a Grandmothers Burden
description: It has been seven years since Brenda Hopkins started the treatments that do what her kidneys no longer can. She goes to the Brooklyn Kidney Center for dialysis treatment every Monday, Tuesday and Thursday, and sometimes on Saturday if she has excessive swelling in her ankles.

title: Recipe: Pork Chops With Apple Nori Pure, Yams and Edamame
description: Adapted from Evan Rich

title: 7 Feet 7 and 360 Pounds, With Bigger Feet Than Shaqs
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C.  The University of North Carolina-Asheville mens basketball team has perhaps the most effective inbounds play in the country: the Bulldogs point guard lofts the ball high toward the basket, and center Kenny George either tips it in or dunks it, without leaving his feet, as his opponents leap in vain.

title: How the Polls Were Off
description: Pre-primary tracking polls conducted by some of the nations most reputable polling organizations like Gallup and CNN, raised expectations in the Obama campaign, lowered them in the Clinton campaign and had the media reporting that Barack Obama was such a strong candidate after his victory in Iowa that he was virtually unstoppable. But last night Hillary Rodham Clinton proved wrong what had by then become the conventional wisdom and won the New Hampshire Democratic primary, shifting the klieg lights onto those pre-primary tracking polls.

title: Kenya Crisis Worsens as Opposition Cools to Talks
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The political mood darkened again in Kenya on Tuesday, with opposition leaders cooling to the idea of negotiations with the government after the president unilaterally made major cabinet appointments, a move that set off riots across the country almost immediately.

title: Georgia: Inmates Sue Corrections Officers
description: A group of prisoners filed a class-action lawsuit contending that corrections officers have systematically beaten restrained inmates in prisons throughout the state, leaving two dead and dozens of others injured. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Valdosta, names 25 guards and other corrections officials as culprits in routine beatings and torture of inmates. It also claims that they subsequently covered up the abuses by inflicting even more beatings on prisoners who filed complaints. Most of the incidents reportedly took place from 2003 to 2005.

title: Realtors Index Shows Dip for Existing-Home Sales
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Pending home sales dipped in November, a trade group for real estate agents said on Tuesday, but the association expects sales to pick up in the second half of 2008.

title: Director Speaks Out on Broad Collection
description: Michael Govan, the director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, said late Monday that he believed Eli Broads decision to keep his art collection in a private foundation that makes loans to museums is a positive development because it means none of the artworks will be sold, an act that would limit access to them by the Los Angeles museum and others. The museum will open the $56 million Broad Contemporary Art Museum next month, and it has long been speculated that Mr. Broad would donate his collection at least in part to the museum. But Mr. Broad said he had recently decided to keep his collection in his foundation because no museum, the Los Angeles one included, could commit to exhibiting a significant portion of it permanently. Asked if he viewed Mr. Broads decision as demonstrating a lack of confidence in him or the museum, Mr. Govan said: Quite the reverse. Since Day 1 hes privately and publicly given me a lot of support. Mr. Govan said that from the public perspective, I dont think most people care when they walk in the door whether the museum owns the works or not, as long as they dont lose them to private sales. And, he added, hes got 2,000 works, so there is plenty to go around.

title: Olsons Wife Files Challenge
description: The wife of Arizona Coach Lute Olson filed a court challenge to his attempt to divorce her. The petition said Christine Olson denies the marriage is irretrievably broken and remains committed to preserving the marital relationship. The petition was filed in Pima County Superior Court in Arizona last Friday and seeks marital counseling. Olson, a 73-year-old Hall of Fame coach, filed for divorce Dec. 6, the same day he announced his leave of absence would be extended for the rest of this season. He began his leave for unspecified personal reasons Nov. 4, shortly before he was to have opened his 25th season at Arizona.Christine Jack Olson, 50, is a prominent business executive and a member of the Republican National Committee from Pennsylvania. She married Olson in 2003 and is Olsons second wife. His wife of 47 years, Bobbie, died of ovarian cancer in 2001.

title: Hearing Right Waived
description: The New Mexico State freshman Herb Pope waived his right to a preliminary hearing on a drunken driving charge filed by police officers who said they found Pope passed out in a running car on a western Pennsylvania highway. The decision to waive Tuesdays hearing means Pope will be scheduled to stand trial in Allegheny County Common Pleas Court. Officers found Pope, 19, unresponsive in the drivers seat with the engine running in the Pittsburgh suburb of Moon Township on Dec. 28. Pope, a heralded recruit, had been academically ineligible at New Mexico State until a New Mexico judge ordered an end to the N.C.A.A. ban based on an alternative-education program he took in high school.

title: Nori Steps Away From the Sushi
description: ITS hard to imagine that nori was once the ugly duckling of the sushi bar. About 30 years ago, sushi chefs devised the inside-out roll (whose outer layer is rice rather than nori) to placate diners willing to try raw seafood but not dried seaweed.

title: The Foods Ready, but the Dcor Is Evolving
description: I FIRST caught word about Seymour Burton in the days after the tryptophan-induced haze of Thanksgiving had worn off, through an e-mail message from a friend that included that dangerous verbal pairing best and burger.

title: California Pension Fund Expected to Take Big Stake in Silver Lake, at $275 Million
description: Silver Lake, the largest technology-focused private equity firm, has reached a deal to sell a 9.9 percent stake to the California Public Employees Retirement System for about $275 million, according to people briefed on the deal.

title: A Place So Crowded, Nobody Goes There Anymore
description: When Robert L. Sammons walks home from work each day through Times Square, he frequently encounters a crush of tourists shuffling to Broadway shows like The Lion King or restaurants like Planet Hollywood.

title: When Talk Show Hosts Worked Without a Net
description: Wednesday nights episode of the PBS mini-series Pioneers of Television, devoted to the roots of the late-night talk show, has one sequence that could be particularly helpful, or perhaps just frustrating, for current hosts who are without the services of their writing staffs.

title: New Investigation in Texas E-Mail Case
description: HOUSTON  Already forced to drop his re-election bid over e-mail love notes sent from work to his executive secretary, District Attorney Charles A. Rosenthal Jr. of Harris County faced new questions Tuesday with the disclosure of hundreds of other office e-mail messages containing racy jokes, racial slurs and political campaign materials.

title: Fighting Inflation, China Freezes Energy Prices
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao responded Wednesday to growing public anxiety about inflation by announcing that China would freeze energy prices in the near term, even as international crude oil futures have continued to surge.

title: A Cathedral Resists the Label Property of Russia
description: NICE, France  On a February morning in 2006, a group of experts in Russian art approached the onion-domed Russian church here and demanded to be admitted to take an inventory of the building and its contents  icons, liturgical vestments, incense burners, everything.

title: Unite, Not Divide, Really This Time
description: The New Hampshire primary has done Americans a service by leaving both parties nominating contests open and giving a truly broad range of voters a chance to participate in these vitally important choices. The coming contests will be colored in large part by how the contenders and their backers answer a basic question: Just how far are they willing to go to win?

title: California Pension Fund Takes Big Stake in Silver Lake, at $275 Million
description: Silver Lake, the largest technology-focused private equity firm, announced a deal on Wednesday to sell a 9.9 percent stake to the California Public Employees Retirement System.

title: Stewart (Angsty) and Colbert (Not) Return, Gazing at Navels and News
description: The glimmer of emotion that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton displayed in New Hampshire was startling because it was so out of character  almost as disconcerting as Jon Stewart returning to The Daily Show on Monday and not making fun of her.

title: Bush Signs Gun Measure
description: President Bush signed legislation intended to prevent the severely mentally ill from buying guns, in a rare bipartisan agreement with the Democratic-led Congress after the shooting massacre last April at Virginia Tech. The bill authorizes up to $1.3 billion in grant money for states to improve their ability to track and report individuals who should not qualify to buy a gun legally, including those involuntarily confined by a mental institution. Much of the money, to be spent over five years, would be used to increase state feeds to a national system used to run background checks on gun purchases. The Virginia Tech gunman, Seung-Hui Cho, was able to pass a background check and buy two guns even though a Virginia court had deemed him a mental defective.

title: Bid for China Eastern Airline Stake Rebuffed
description: HONG KONG  Singapore Airlines was rebuffed Tuesday in an effort to take a stake in China Eastern Airlines in a move that could remake the shape of Chinas aviation industry with the possible emergence of one dominant Chinese carrier.

title: The Secret of the Humble Chickens
description: IVE had the roasted chicken at Barbuto when snow was blowing against the restaurants glass walls, and Ive had it when summer sun streamed through. Ive had it before 6:30 p.m., when the restaurant was just stirring, and after 10:30, when it was at full tilt.

title: Apple Agrees to Cut iTunes Prices in Britain
description: LONDON  Apple said Wednesday that it had agreed to cut the prices on its iTunes digital music store in Britain to align them with those in Continental Europe, settling an antitrust case brought by European regulators.

title: Queens: Man Admits Fatally Stabbing Friend
description: A homeless man who had been taken in by a Queens family pleaded guilty on Tuesday to charges that he fatally stabbed a family member during a botched burglary attempt, the prosecutors said. The man, Emmanuel Polanco, 22, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to manslaughter in the stabbing of David Higgins, 19, on Oct. 30, 2006, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Polanco previously stayed at Mr. Higginss home in Hillcrest, and later attacked Mr. Higgins when he came home and found Mr. Polanco burglarizing the residence, the prosecutors said. Mr. Polanco was also charged with beating Mr. Higginss mother with a bat when she arrived a short time later. He faces 30 years in prison when he is sentenced next month, the prosecutors said.

title: Surfers Defy Giant Waves Awakened by Storm
description: DANA POINT, Calif.  One of the strongest storms recorded in the northern Pacific Ocean pummeled the West Coast last weekend, leading to widespread flooding and state and federal disaster declarations. The storm also left behind some of the most remarkable waves ever surfed.

title: Rell Urges Strengthening Connecticut Justice System
description: HARTFORD  In the aftermath of last summers grisly home invasion in which a mother and her daughters were killed, Gov. M. Jodi Rell on Tuesday proposed a package of measures intended to bolster Connecticuts criminal justice system.

title: Bush Castigates Iran, Calling Naval Confrontation Provocative Act
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush chastised Iran on Tuesday for committing a provocative act by confronting United States Navy warships in the Persian Gulf over the weekend. The Pentagon released video showing Iranian speedboats maneuvering around the American convoy.

title: McCains Victory Muddles G.O.P. Field as It Looks to Michigan
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  After Senator John McCains victory here on Tuesday, the Republican field is more scrambled than ever, with the battleground now shifting to a series of states where each of the leading candidates believes he holds certain advantages.

title: Corzine Proposes Steep Rise in Tolls
description: TRENTON  Gov. Jon S. Corzine proposed the biggest financial maneuver in New Jerseys history on Tuesday, arguing that drastically increasing highway tolls over the next 15 years could generate as much as $38 billion to help the state pay off half its debt and finance transportation improvements.

title: City Names New Principal for English-Arabic School
description: On Tuesday, the New York City Education Department named an educator who has a working knowledge of Arabic as principal of the Khalil Gibran International Academy, the embattled Brooklyn school whose founding principal resigned under pressure after being quoted as defending the word intifada as a T-shirt slogan.

title: Central Islip: Man Charged With Killing Landlord
description: A body found in a backyard cesspool in Mastic Beach has been identified as that of a man who has been missing for nearly 19 months, and a former tenant was charged on Tuesday with murder in the death, a Suffolk County police detective said. The tenant, Jaime Rosario, 38, a nursery worker from Center Moriches, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree murder and was ordered held without bail at his arraignment in Suffolk Countys First District Court. Mr. Rosario had been renting a room for $100 a week from the victim, Nicolo Caietta, 59, in his Mastic Beach home, Detective Sgt. Edward Fandrey said. He said Mr. Rosario was accused of beating Mr. Caietta to death with a baseball bat in May 2006, dumping his body in the cesspool and stealing $800 that Mr. Caietta had withdrawn from the bank to buy a counterfeit drivers license. The body was found on Saturday when officers excavated the cesspool behind Mr. Caiettas house, at 275 Forest Road West.

title: Afghan Civilians Were Killed Needlessly, Ex-Marine Testifies
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C.  A former member of an elite Marine combat unit that operated last year in eastern Afghanistan testified Tuesday that his comrades appeared to have needlessly killed civilians after their convoy was attacked by a suicide car bomb.

title: Executive Leaving Barclays Capital
description: LONDON  Barclays Capital, which reported a write-down of 1.3 billion ($2.6 billion) in credit securities two months ago, said on Tuesday that its co-president, Grant Kvalheim, had resigned and would leave at the end of the first quarter.

title: India Debates Protocol for French Pair
description: NEW DELHI  Should a motorcade be allocated to Carla Bruni, the girlfriend and possible fiance of the French president? That is one of the protocol issues perplexing Indian officials as they prepare to welcome Nicolas Sarkozy for the nations Republic Day celebrations this month.

title: 3 Americans Arrested in Gang Battle With Mexican Police
description: MEXICO CITY  Three Americans were part of a well-armed gang that waged a gun battle with soldiers and police officers in Rio Bravo on Monday, the Mexican authorities said.

title: Ways to Improve the Way We Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Golden Globes Sponsors Withdraw
description: Some prominent advertisers have pulled their sponsorships for NBCs strike-subdued Golden Globes coverage and others were weighing their options, media buyers said Tuesday. The decisions came a day after the traditional format for the awards program was scrapped in the face of anticipated picket lines.

title: Trenton: Ex-Boxing Commissioner Sues the State
description: New Jerseys former boxing commissioner is suing the states attorney general, Anne Milgram, claiming that she ousted him for exposing errors by a subordinate. The former commissioner, Larry Hazzard Sr., filed a whistle-blower protection lawsuit against Ms. Milgram and others in Federal District Court on Friday. Mr. Hazzard, a former boxer and referee, was commissioner of the State Athletic Control Board from 1986 until he was fired in November. The board oversees boxing in Atlantic City, one of a handful of cities where big prizefights are often fought. A spokesman for the attorney general declined to comment on Tuesday.

title: From a Big Boost for Obama to a Sharp Blow
description: NASHUA, N.H.  On the eve of the New Hampshire primary, Senator Barack Obama delivered a message to supporters: Do not take this race for granted. I know we had a nice boost over the last couple of days, but elections are a funny business.

title: Lawyers Learn How to Be Businesslike
description: When Gabriel R. Munson graduated from law school in 2003, his goal was to have his own practice someday, modeling himself after Atticus Finch, the small-town lawyer in Harper Lees classic To Kill a Mockingbird.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Thursday about Salvatore (Bill) Bonanno, a member of the Bonanno crime family, and an article on Tuesday about his funeral in Tucson, referred incorrectly to his role in the publication of Honor Thy Father, a 1971 account of the Bonanno family by Gay Talese. Although Mr. Bonanno was extensively interviewed by Mr. Talese, he did not collaborate with him on the writing.

title: Deal Reached to Buy Some Verizon Lines
description: FairPoint Communications reached an agreement on Tuesday with the Vermont Public Service Department that would allow it to buy Verizon Communications phone lines in the state.

title: Bronx: Man Shot by Police Officer
description: A city police officer shot and wounded a man during an attempt to stop the mans car on Tuesday morning, the police said. The officer fired three times as he and his partner struggled with the driver, who continued driving, the police said. Both officers, who were working as part of a plainclothes unit, saw the car being driven erratically, stopped it and approached on foot, the police said. The driver sped away and the officers followed in their car, the police said. At West Kingsbridge Road and Aqueduct Avenue about 11:33 a.m., the officers again approached the suspects car on foot, and the struggle ensued, the police said. Both officers, who were not identified, were slightly injured, the police said. The suspect, who was not identified, suffered a gunshot wound to his leg and was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, the officials said.

title: Attack-Agent Detectors May Require City Permit
description: Individuals and companies have increasingly expressed interest in buying detectors to warn them of a biological, chemical or radioactive attack. But at a public hearing on Tuesday, a City Council committee considered a proposal that would require New Yorkers to get a permit from the Police Department to buy or use such detectors.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated Senator Edward M. Kennedys position on the presidential race. He has not endorsed Mrs. Clinton or any candidate.

title: Newark: Computer Administrator Sentenced
description: A former computer administrator at Medco Health Solutions was sentenced on Tuesday in Federal District Court to 30 months in prison for tampering with the companys computer systems. The administrator, Yung-Hsun Lin of Montville, pleaded guilty in September to one count of transmitting computer code with the intent of causing damage in excess of $5,000. The prosecutors said Mr. Lin was angry at the possibility of losing his job. The tampering, aimed at a database used by pharmacists to track potential drug interactions, failed to work because of a programming error.

title: A New Agency for Roads, or Version 2 of the Turnpike Authority?
description: TRENTON  For all the complex leaps of financial logic needed to grasp Gov. Jon S. Corzines plan to leverage New Jerseys toll roads, several crucial components remain unchanged.

title: Sarkozy Says Press Is Free to Ignore His Personal Life
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy refused to use the M word.

title: We Still Need the Big Guns
description: Washington

title: Escapee Caught Just Six Blocks From the Jail
description: Law enforcement officers arrested an escaped prisoner Tuesday night, finding him in an apartment just six blocks from the Elizabeth, N.J., jail from which he and another inmate broke out more than three weeks ago, the police said.

title: The Court and Voter IDs
description: From the early indications, Americans are feeling enthusiastic about their constitutionally guaranteed right to vote. The Supreme Court should encourage, not frustrate, that enthusiasm when it hears a challenge today to a harsh voter identification law adopted by Indiana. The law aims to be an anti-fraud measure, but its main impact will be to disenfranchise large numbers of registered voters. The court should not let it stand.

title: A Parade! A Circus! A Carnival! Or, the New Hampshire Primary
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  To fully appreciate the pure political carnival that is New Hampshire on Primary Day, there is no better place to absorb it than on Elm Street, the main thoroughfare that runs through the heart of downtown Manchester, the states biggest city.

title: Naked and Free
description: The pay-what-you-choose initiative begun by the British art-rock band Radiohead has crossed over to the realm of classical music. The British violinist Tasmin Little plans to offer her next recording, The Naked Violin, free as a digital download in an effort to popularize such music, Reuters reported. Just the fact that people can listen to it on a computer means that hopefully they wont feel a need to have an education or be from a particular background or a certain sector of society, she said. The album, featuring three pieces for unaccompanied violin and a commentary from Ms. Little, will be available on Monday from tasminlittle.net.

title: Schwarzenegger Acts on Californias Big Deficits
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facing chronic budget problems as well as a short-term deficit bigger than many states annual revenues, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Tuesday proposed amending the California Constitution to give governors new budgetary powers, including the ability to cut spending in the middle of a fiscal year.

title: Humbler Spitzer Likely to Focus on Economic Growth and Higher Education
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to strike a more conciliatory note with the Legislature in his annual address to lawmakers on Wednesday  the first political step of the embattled governors second year in office.

title: 3 Killed in Florida Highway Pileup
description: Three people were killed and dozens injured early Wednesday in a major pileup on Interstate 4 in north central Florida, as fog and smoke from brush fires combined to make it almost impossible for motorists to see.

title: American Motherhood and the Question of Home Birth
description: The Business of Being Born is a passionate ground-level examination of home childbirth, anchored in a scene in which its executive producer, Ricki Lake, the actress and former talk-show host, gives birth to her second child in a bathtub. That graphic scene, and several other unblinking sequences of home birth attended by a midwife, are intended to erase any stigma from the situation. Practiced widely in Europe and Japan, home birth has largely disappeared in the United States, the documentary states, because of an image as a primitive, unsanitary ritual.

title: From Same Dugout to the Same Row Before Congress
description: Roger Clemenss plan to testify before a Congressional committee next week portends a scene made for the rolling television cameras: a longtime friend and former teammate, Andy Pettitte, being asked questions regarding Clemenss possible use of steroids with Clemens sitting beside him.

title: Director (and Voice) of Metropolitan Museum to Retire
description: Philippe de Montebello, who has led the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 30 years and has virtually become synonymous with its monumental profile, announced Tuesday that he planned to retire at the end of the year.

title: Britain: Prison for Would-Be Jihad Fighter
description: Sohail Qureshi, a London dental technician who was arrested at Heathrow Airport in 2006 boarding a flight to Pakistan, was sentenced to four and a half years in prison in the first conviction under a new law against planning terrorism. The prosecutor said Mr. Qureshi, originally from Pakistan, planned a two- to three-week operation either in Pakistan or Afghanistan, possibly against Western troops. He was carrying nearly $18,000, a telescopic night sight and a computer hard drive loaded with militant Islamic tracts, the court was told. Prosecutors said that he had trained with jihadist groups in Pakistan linked to Al Qaeda and that his skills included encrypting e-mail messages. The court was also told of e-mail exchanges he had with Samina Malik, known as the lyrical terrorist, who received a suspended sentence in November for keeping a library of terrorist material. Ms. Malik, a clerk at a Heathrow newsstand who wrote poetry limning her passion for Islamic militancy, received an e-mail message from Mr. Qureshi asking about security arrangements at Heathrow. According to the prosecution, she replied, The airport security is as tight as ever.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $5,553,470

title: Former Premiers Wife Arrested on Return to Thailand
description: BANGKOK  The wife of the ousted Thai prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, returned from exile Tuesday to face charges of corruption and an uncertain future for her family and its political allies.

title: Pettitte Plays a Pivotal Role for Clemens
description: On the day that Rich Gossage deservedly gained entry to the Hall of Fame, I thought it would be appropriate to create the Hall of Infamy. Charter members: Pete Rose, Barry Bonds, Roger Clemens and Mark McGwire.

title: Canada: Rocket Builder Makes Acquisition
description: Alliant Techsystems, a maker of weapons and space systems, said it had agreed to buy a unit of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates for 1.33 billion Canadian dollars ($1.34 billion) to build complete satellite systems. Alliant agreed to buy MacDonalds information systems and geospatial information services group in its biggest acquisition ever and its first outside the United States, said Alliants chief executive, Daniel Murphy. The purchase will be complete by the end of March and will add to Alliants profit starting in the 2010 fiscal year. Alliant, based in Edina, Minn., will be able to build and operate full satellite systems as sales slow in its main business, supplying bullets to the United States Army. MacDonald is based in Richmond, British Columbia.

title: Primaries: Brokaws Novel Idea For The Media
description: Just after 11 p.m., the MSNBC anchor Keith Olbermann drew comparisons between the medias pre-primary predictions and the infamously wrong 1948 headline Dewey Defeats Truman in the Chicago Daily Tribune.

title: Primaries: Startled By Clintons Surge, TV Pundits Recast The Democratic Race
description: The television networks were quick to declare John McCain the winner of the Republican primary in New Hampshire Tuesday night, but hesitant to project a first place winner in the Democratic race. Hillary Rodham Clintons surge of support was deemed a surprise by media commentators who largely expected another win by Barack Obama.

title: Travel Basics: Frankfurt
description: AIRPORTS: If you are like most of the people coming to Frankfurt, you are well on your way to going as well, which is to say you are changing flights at the mammoth Frankfurt International Airport. Most people at Frankfurt airport are transit passengers, but if you are not, then fear not: transportation into town is as good as anywhere in the world.

title: Travel Basics: Madrid
