description: AIRPORTS: Barajas International Airport has won deserved renown for its vast, wavy-roofed Terminal 4, designed by award-winning architects Richard Rodgers and Antonio Lamela. Inaugurated in February 2006, the airy, luminous terminal is an impressive introduction to Madrid  though confusing signs, long walks from gates and problems with the luggage sorting system have become familiar gripes among Madrileos. If you fly to Spain on Iberia airlines, you will probably have the good fortune to come to T4. Far less prepossessing are Terminals 1 to 3, which share many of the inadequacies that have become emblems of international air travel: dim lighting, grim cafs and endless construction. But they are functional, check-in and security lines are manageable and access to taxi ranks and the subway system is simple.

title: John McCain's New Hampshire Speech
description: John McCain comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

title: John Edwards's New Hampshire Speech
description: John Edwards comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

title: Victories and Defeats
description: At the end of the night, the candidates savored their wins or licked their wounds.

title: Hillary Rodham Clinton's N.H. Speech
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

title: Mike Huckabee's New Hampshire Speech
description: Mike Huckabee comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

title: Barack Obama's New Hampshire Speech
description: Barack Obama comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

title: The Unpredictability Factor
description: The Times's John Harwood analyzes how Hillary Rodham Clinton's victory in New Hampshire has changed the presidential race.

title: Flameout on Figueroa
description: NASHVILLE PREDATORS 7LOS ANGELES KINGS 0

title: Locking up a Star
description: The Dallas Stars wisely got Mike Ribeiros signature on a five year, $25 million deal lest he get to unrestricted free agency in July. Ribeiro, who turns 28 next month, has become the heart of the Dallas offense since he was obtained from Montreal at the start of last season for a song (Janne Niinimaa, who is now playing in Switzerland).

title: Sights and Sounds From Primary Day
description: The day in New Hampshire began with candidates making their final push and ended with victories by Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain.

title: Welcome to the New Nuclear Era
description: The nuclear industry went through decades of stagnation after devastating accidents in the 1970s and 80s. But nowadays the industry has a handy sales pitch: It can claim to be a technology that emits nearly nothing in terms of greenhouse gases.

title: Making the Switch (or Not)
description: Readers share their experiences with compact fluorescent bulbs.

title: Sawing Wood
description: An ad for the home improvement catalog that gets things done:

title: Body Check
description: From the metro report in Tuesdays Times:

title: Co-President of Barclays Capital Resigns
description: Barclays Capital, which reported a write-down of 1.3 billion pounds ($2.6 billion) in credit securities two months ago, said on Tuesday that its co-president, Grant Kvalheim, had resigned and would leave at the end of the first quarter.

title: FairPoint Closer to Winning Approval for Verizon Deal
description: FairPoint Communications reached an agreement on Tuesday with the Vermont Public Service Department that would allow it to buy Verizon Communications phone lines in the state.

title: Countrywide Denies Rumors of Bankruptcy
description: Shares of Countrywide Financial, the nations largest mortgage lender, plunged 28.4 percent Tuesday after it denied rumors that it was planning to file for bankruptcy protection.

title: With Fast Search Deal, Microsoft Aims at Google
description: Microsofts $1.2 billion bid on Tuesday for a Norwegian search software company, was seen mainly as an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products, but was also being done, analysts said, with an eye toward fending off Google.

title: In New Ads, JPMorgan Tries to Be Heard Above the Din
description: In bank advertising, what matters is getting noticed at a time when the airwaves are cluttered, customers are nervous and marketing budgets are being slashed. JPMorgan Chase has that in mind with a sleek new brand campaign aimed at unifying its consumer advertising, streamlining its message and stretching the dollars it spends.

title: Wireless Start-Up Fails to Get Financing
description: Frontline Wireless, which wanted to build an innovative cellular network for both private use and local public safety agencies, has collapsed because it reportedly could not raise enough money to bid in the government auctions of wireless spectrum that start later this month.

title: PubMatic Nabs $7 Million
description: PubMatic, an advertising optimization software company, said Tuesday it had received $7 million in venture financing.

title: CalPERS to Take Stake in Silver Lake
description: Silver Lake, the largest technology-focused private equity firm, has reached a deal to sell a 9.9 percent stake to the California Public Employees Retirement System for about $275 million, The New York Times reported. The transaction, which values Silver Lake at about $2.75 billion, is expected to be announced Wednesday.

title: Cisco Systems Connects With SoonR
description: The networking giant Cisco Systems led a $9.5 funding round of a two-year-old application hosting firm, SoonR.

title: Diller to Keep His Hand In After IAC Split
description: Barry Diller, the media mogul who runs the Internet conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp, told investors Tuesday that after the company spins off four divisions, he will stay involved in the management of the restructured IAC, Expedia and Ticketmaster.

title: Credit Suisses DLJ Takes a Bite of Den-Mat
description: DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, the private equity arm of the Credit Suisse Group, said Tuesday that it has purchased a majority stake in Den-Mat Holdings, a maker of cosmetic dental products such as Lumineers, from Den-Mats founder.

title: Analysts Eye Murdochs Next German Move
description: By acquiring a stake in the German pay-television broadcaster Premiere, Rupert Murdoch has cemented the companys status as a takeover candidate in a saga that hinges on the next auction of Bundesliga soccer rights.

title: Alliant Makes $1.3 Billon Acquisition in Canada
description: Alliant Techsystems, a maker of weapons and space systems, said it had agreed to buy a unit of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates for 1.33 billion Canadian dollars ($1.34 billion) to build complete satellite systems.

title: Wave of Grim News Expected to Crash on Wall Street
description: Sometimes when it rains, it pours on Wall Street. And next week, forecasters are calling for a flood.

title: Hedge Fund Loses Suit Against Telos
description: You win some and you lose some. Thats the case with a series of lawsuits filed by an activist hedge fund manager, Costa Brava Partnerships, against a defense networking and information technology contractor, Telos, and Goodman & Company, the companys independent auditor.

title: Pioneer Aims to Tap $136 Million in Blank-Check I.P.O.
description: Pioneer Southwest Energy Partners, a limited partnership formed to acquire oil and gas properties, said Tuesday it plans to raise $136 million in an initial public offering of 7.5 million common units, according to an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Liz Claiborne to Sell 2 Brands to Perry Ellis
description: Liz Claiborne said Tuesday it had decided to sell two of its brands to Perry Ellis International and close another as part of a strategic review.

title: Hong Kong May Limit Cornerstone Investors
description: In Hong Kong, preferential access to initial public offerings is a lucrative privilege. But as Forbes.com reports, that cash machine may get shut off now that Hong Kong regulators are considering a ban on the practice of doling out pre-I.P.O. shares to so-called cornerstone investors.

title: Moelis Hires Partner for Buyout Unit
description: The advisory firm founded by the former UBS banker Ken Moelis last July has added a partner to its private equity division taking its headcount to 45 in six months.

title: A Regulator Who Cut Through Red Tape for Buffett
description: In the last days of December, as the financial strength ratings of the old bond insurance companies were under pressure and the insurers were being forced to put up additional capital, Warren E. Buffett announced the start of his new municipal bond insurer, the Berkshire Hathaway Assurance Corporation.

title: More Hedge Funds Means More Activists, Report Finds
description: Thanks mainly to a rise in the number of hedge funds players in the field, activist investors in the United States increasingly bared their teeth last year.

title: Will Lewis Regret Hunting Bear?
description: Is Joseph C. Lewis beginning to regret his big bet on Bear Stearns?

title: Number-Crunching the 2008 Election
description: Well, I guess I picked the wrong day to tout the Intrade futures market.

title: Extrication Time at Bear Stearns
description: When he was a top investment banker at Bear Stearns, Alan D. Schwartz deftly outmaneuvered the likes of Carl C. Icahn and won plaudits for his pragmatic ways.

title: Lichtenstein Launches Proxy Battle With Rowan
description: In a surprise move, Warren G. Lichtensteins Steel Partners said it would nominate three candidates to the board of the Rowan Companies, an oilfield services company, to unlock more value.

title: Merrill Likely to Stay in Lower Manhattan, Report Says
description: Merrill Lynch has put off plans to build a headquarters in Midtown Manhattan and is likely to renew its lease in Lower Manhattans World Financial Center, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing undisclosed sources. But a lease renewal hasnt been signed, and the deal could still fall through, the Journal added.

title: Nobody knows anything
description: But to be more specific, the prediction markets  which you see, again and again, touted as having some mystical power to aggregate information, know no more than the conventional wisdom. Heres the Intrade price for Clinton wins the Democratic nomination over the past month:

title: High School With Money 2.0
description: Defamer tracks Ben Silverman, the co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, nominating himself as the Prom King in an interview with Ryan Seacrest. Sadly, it feels like the nerdiest, ugliest, meanest kids in the high school are trying to cancel the prom, said Mr. Silverman, whose network holds the rights to broadcast the Golden Globes. But NBC wants to try to keep that prom alive.

title: Almasi Wins Reggio Emilia
Oxygen Shortage
description: The Risky Biz blog noted that dressmakers wont be the only ones who take a hit from the deflation of the Globes. American Gangster, The Great Debaters and Sweeney Todd all could use a Globe-induced boost, but it will be hard to make an impression amid the tick-tock of an hour-long press conference.

title: Everyone Knows Its Indy
description: One strategy to make the Oscars more palatable to the Writers Guild would be to minimize the presence of the major studios. Sort of silly really, but then the Bagger noticed that indies and specialty divisions dominated the Directors Guild awards. Paramount Vantage has a lot of irons blazing away, with a piece of three of the five: There Will Be Blood, No Country (with Miramax) and Into the Wild.

title: A Wave of Information
description: The technology featured in the blockbuster movie Minority Report is coming to a Hilton hotel near you.

title: God and Mammon
description: Its like contemplating my own mortality. I know its something I have to face, but not today.  An industry executive contemplating the ankling of the Oscars in Variety.

title: Too Much TV for Cisco
description: Televisions have gotten big. Very, very big. Perhaps too big to be practical. Over a lunch of veggie wraps and chicken sandwiches, Michael Kisch, director of consumer marketing for Cisco, told the tale of The TV That Was Too Big.

title: What to Expect in the State of the State
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to strike a more conciliatory note with the Legislature in his annual address to lawmakers today  the first political step of the embattled governors second year in office. But lawmakers on both sides of the aisle remain wary and in many cases openly critical of the governor, and some fellow Democrats are troubled by reports he may propose imposing a ceiling on property-tax increases.

title: The Early Word: Its a Wide-Open Race
description: Change is out, and comeback has taken its place as the hot political buzzword, at least as far as New Hampshire voters would have you know.

title: MBIA Cuts Dividend to Preserve Rating
description: MBIA, the worlds largest bond insurer, slashed its common stock dividend 62 percent on Wednesday as part of a plan to strengthen capital and preserve the triple-A credit ratings it depends on to operate normally.

title: Food Stuff
description: A Creamy Tuscan Ricotta, Made Fresh in Brooklyn

title: They Were Misinformed
description: Well, it was a shocking defeat for this group, and today theyre going to have to take a long hard look at what went wrong. No, I dont mean Team Obama  that crowd can move ahead  I mean the pollsters who were so certain that the Clinton campaign was D.O.A.

title: Pirate Watcher Adds Up Attacks for 2007
description: In the previous three years, the struggle against piracy on the high seas seemed to be turning a corner  from 445 attacks in 2003 to 239 in 2006, according to statistics from the International Maritime Bureau, an agency founded in 1981 to combat sea crime.

title: A magical French clinic for ailing dolls and bears
description: Henri Launay is the doctor to the dolls, a self-taught surgeon of French porcelain poupes. For the last 43 years, Launay has presided over a refuge of sorts in northeast Paris for battered celluloid babies with cracked heads and ancient teddy bears in desperate need of snout transplants.

title: Here a Cluck, There a Cluck
description: Just as I was finishing this weeks review of Barbuto, which throws a spotlight on its roasted chicken, a news release came my way.

title: E*Trade Rises on Modest Sales Loss
description: In announcing a modest sales loss, E*Trade Financial managed to reap about a 10 percent gain in its battered stock in trading Wednesday morning.

title: For McCain, Quiet Before the Big Stage
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Senator John McCain stood silently, hands in his pockets, staring at the television as the first television station called the election last night. The only indication of what he thought about this latest chapter in his adventurous life was a wide grin.

title: School Popularity Affects Girls Weights
description: Girls who think they arent popular are at higher risk for weight gain, according to a new study.

title: John McCain, Wall Street Underdog
description: If Mac is truly back  as many supporters of John McCain were chanting Tuesday night  will more of Wall Street open its wallet to this Republican presidential contender? A few big names in high finance have supported his campaign, including John Thain, the new chief executive of Merrill Lynch, but they are a relatively lonely crowd.

title: A Landmarks Fight on Madison Avenue
description: Not as swiftly as Paul Revere, but with no less determination, Francine Ravitz made her way along Madison Avenue on Tuesday, sounding the alarm from East 65th Street, where she and her husband live, all the way to 64th Street.At one stop, Mrs. Ravitz pulled an envelope from a bag hanging on her walker. She presented it to Karen McAdoo, the manager of the Morgane Le Fay womens clothing store in the two-story building at Nos. 746-48. Inside was a Dear Neighbor letter from her husband, Robert J. Ravitz, a principal in the David J. Greene and Company investment company.

title: Clintons Strategy Echoes Bush in 2000
description: Hillary Clinton stands behind no Democratic presidential candidate in her scorn for George W. Bush  but that isnt stopping her from implementing Mr. Bushs 2000 primary strategy. In one notable consequence of the front-loaded 2008 political calendar, she implemented it before the New Hampshire primary, not after.

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Nicholas Christopher
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: A One-Night Shift in the Late-Night Wars
description: For the first time since televisions late-night shows returned to the air last week, David Letterman was able to nose out Jay Leno in the ratings, Bill Carter reports in Wednesdays New York Times. It was just for one show, Monday night, and Mr. Lettermans lead was not sizable, but Mr. Leno had won the first three nights.

title: An Advance Look at Spitzers Speech
description: Updated, 2:41 p.m. | Judging from excerpts released this morning, Gov. Eliot Spitzers second State of the State address this afternoon will strike a conciliatory tone and focus heavily on meat-and-potato issues like schools, property taxes and health insurance as he seeks to regain his political footing, turn attention away from the multiple and potentially crippling ethics investigations he still faces, and build the foundation for his second year in office.Such a speech would not be so different from Mr. Spitzers first such address a year ago, despite the decline in the governors fortunes since then. Mr. Spitzers first state of the state address mixed broad reform proposals unpopular with Albany lawmakers (campaign finance reform and non-partisan redistricting) with a large platter of proposals that offered something for everyone, whether more education spending for Democrats or workers compensation reform for Republicans.

title: Congress to Investigate Denials by Clemens
description: The House committee looking into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball has postponed a hearing next week that was to feature Roger Clemens and his accuser so that the panel can begin its own investigation into Clemenss adamant denial that he used such drugs.

title: Editors Note | The High Low
description: Only readers of The Moment could have a heated discussion about a cotton sweater. While we love action in our comments section, the editors have some comments of their own regarding Mondays post, The High Low | L.L. Beans Kingfield Sweater, which was the initial installment of a feature on chic, affordable goods. First of all, we goofed and published an incorrect image  the author, our fashion associate Melissa Ventosa Martin, liked the sweater in ivory, not the deep red color we showed. The correct color is shown here. [UPDATE: The sweater has sliver buttons, not a zippered neck; photo corrected.] Secondly, a couple of readers commented that they saw the L.L. Bean sweater and immediately thought: blatant product placement advertising. We dont do that. The Times has a policy that keeps advertising separate from editorial content. There is not, however, a Times policy on stylishness  though there should be  so readers should feel free to blow the whistle when theyve spotted a fashion violation. Those, however, will be hard to come by.

title: Terrelle Pryor Still Open to Buckeyes
description: Despite Ohio States loss to Louisiana State in the Bowl Championship Series title game, the highly regarded quarterback Terrelle Pryor said it did not affect his interest in the Buckeyes.

title: Primary Predictions Popped
description: The political prediction markets just went through their version of the dot-com bubble.

title: Voting in Violence
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Wednesday Kickoff: A Question of Priorities
description: Many applauded the stance taken by the Georgia president, Michael F. Adams, who publicly supported the idea of a playoff in college football. Jason Whitlock of the Kansas City Star was not among them. He says that university administrators need to focus on investing in college athletes, rather than concentrating on an insignificant sports issue.

title: Whats Your Pick for the Best and Weirdest of C.E.S.?
description: Hey, Bits reader. Have you been trudging through the halls of the Las Vegas Convention Center? Or have you been obsessively following the gadget blogs all week? Give us your top pick from the Consumer Electronics Show for any of these three categories:

title: A New Orleans After-Party
description: NEW ORLEANS  Fans clad in yellow and gold celebrated until the wee hours in the French Quarter after the B.C.S title game.

title: Poll: Some Would Draft Bloomberg, for Governor
description: Hows this for uncertainty? A majority of New York City voters  52 percent  think Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would make a good president, and a nearly equal proportion believe it is likely that he will run, but only 16 percent would actually like him to do so, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released today.But perhaps because of dissatisfaction with Gov. Eliot Spitzer, whose poll numbers have plummeted, New York City voters would be far more enthusiastic if Mr. Bloomberg were to run for governor in 2010.

title: The Vanishing Numeric Keypad
description: And now, another note from the Pogue mailbag:

title: 2008: The Year of the Big Airline Merger?
description: It is one of the oldest stories on Wall Street: the idea that big mergers will sweep across the United States airline industry, reshaping a business that is notoriously prone to sharp downturns. And so far, it has largely been a piece of fiction.

title: Update: Talk Off | Skinny Jeans
description: Earlier this week, in The Moments Talk Off column, fashion associates Bifen Xu and Melissa Ventosa Martin debated the virtues of skinny jeans. A record number of readers voted by leaving comments  first Iowa, then New Hampshire, and now Talk Off! Heres the skinny: Bifen, who argued the affirmative position, won the Talk Off with approximately 62 percent of the votes. Note: Political analysts will question the fairness of a fashion contest that had Kate Moss squaring off against MC Hammer.

title: Consumer Electronics Show | The Vanishing Point
description: Sometimes the best gadgets are those that wont spoil the decor (Ken Hayden/Getty Images)

title: NBC Will Show Dateline Before Globes
description: NBC has confirmed that a two-hour edition of Dateline NBC will be shown before the Golden Globes press conference on Sunday.

title: Will the Oscars Go On?
description: Following Mondays announcement of a scaled-back Golden Globes, all eyes in Hollywood and on Madison Avenue have turned to the fate of the Academy Awards, currently scheduled to be shown Feb. 24 on ABC.

title: The Backstory | Ara Starck
description: (Jean-Baptiste Mondino)

title: Leaders Ride Quick Draws to Victory at Hastings. Is This a Problem?
description: The 83rd edition of the Hastings International Chess Congress in England, which may well be the oldest annual tournament (with a break for World War II for obvious reasons), ended Sunday, Jan. 6, in a three-way tie for first. The winners were Valeriy Neverov of the Ukraine, Vadim Malakhatko of Belgium and Nidjat Mamedov of Azerbaijan. The results, as well as a history of the tournament, are on its Web site.

title: How Bad Does He Want It?
description: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: John McCain is leading in New Hampshire. McCain really, really wants to be president. As a matter of fact, its No. 2 on his bucket list.

title: He Just Has No Plans
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: I love how the government keeps telling us how the weather affects gasoline prices. For example, when the weather was rainy and cold, well, it takes more fuel to heat our homes. So of course the price of oil goes up. Then when its sunny out, well, we take more vacations. We drive around. The price of oil goes up. In fact, the only time weather makes the price go down, I believe, is when it snows in hell.

title: Obama Receives Union Endorsements
description: After suffering a setback in New Hampshire, Senator Barack Obama received some welcome news today from two powerful labor unions in Nevada.

title: Ever Wish You Werent So Tall?
description: In The New York Times today, Anna Katherine Clemmons wrote a story on Kenny George, the tallest college basketball player in the United States. As the headline says, hes 7 Feet 7 and 360 Pounds, With Bigger Feet Than Shaqs.

title: Council Votes to Require Stores to Recycle Plastic Bags
description: Putting New York City within the forefront of a growing movement to curb plastic bag use, the City Council overwhelmingly passed a sweeping measure today that would require stores to collect, transport and recycle the plastic bags they issue to customers.

title: The Road from Climate Science to Climate Activism
description: Richard C. J. Somerville, a climatologist at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography near San Diego, is one of a growing array of scientists who have chosen to move beyond studying heat transfer and cloud physics and take on the role of activist: prodding society to move aggressively to cut greenhouse gases.

title: A PB&J for the Planet?
description: Can peanut butter save the world and boost your health?

title: Oh, Mama: Tobias Saga Goes Supernatural
description: The bizarre drama surrounding the death of Seth Tobias just got another offbeat character. Allow us to introduce Madam Simbi MArue, a woman identified by The New York Daily News as a voodoo priestess. She apparently also goes by the name Mama.

title: Behind the Scenes of Mad Men
description: Seven years ago, the executive producer of The Sopranos passed a script to development executives at HBO.

title: (Really) Tiny House for Sale
description: A 300-square-foot (28-square-meter) detached bungalow billed as Torontos smallest house is for sale. Squeezed between two larger buildings, the intimate

title: A Sincere Plea to Coors Light
description: Coors Light sponsors an amateur ad contest, with the victors snagging a trip to the Super Bowl.

title: An Unusual Spark for the CNet Fight
description: The most recognizable player taking on CNet Networks is easily the activist hedge fund Jana Partners. But according to PEHubs Dan Primack, the original agitator in the brewing proxy fight was, of all things, a venture capital firm.

title: Its Politics  Expecting Verse?
description: From a reader of The Caucus blog:

title: Mmmm, Cowabunga!
description: Tonights episode of Pioneers of Television on PBS, reviewed in todays Times, harks back to late-night trailblazers like Steve Allen and Jack Parr  and, of course, Johnny Carson, here with Jack Benny circa 1955:

title: A Frozen Plea to Coors Light
description: Coors Light sponsors an amateur ad contest, with the victors snagging a trip to the Super Bowl.

title: New Yorks City Council Bags Plastic Bags
description: Heres a frightening statistic: its estimated that Americans use 84 billion plastic bags a year.

title: An Animated Plea to Coors Light
description: Coors Light sponsors an amateur ad contest, with the victors snagging a trip to the Super Bowl.

title: A Sexy Plea to Coors Light
description: Coors Light sponsors an amateur ad contest, with the victors snagging a trip to the Super Bowl.

title: A Desperate Plea to Coors Light
description: Coors Light sponsors an amateur ad contest, with the victors snagging a trip to the Super Bowl.

title: Campus Voices: Primary Wrap
description: One advantage our student reporters from Harvards Institute of Politics had over some seasoned journalists covering the New Hampshire primary was that these students had been pounding the pavement up there weekend after weekend since September.

title: Consumer Electronics Show | A Case for Funky-Fresh Wires
description: In a previous post from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, we mentioned the aesthetic advantages of wireless technology. Now were wondering if seeing wires might be a good thing. Its an idea that runs completely against the trends of technology and home design  and thats exactly why we were intrigued by the tiny booth of Shenzhen Kechenda Technology. This obscure Chinese company was showing a collection of HDMI cables (commonly used with high-fidelity TVs and DVDs) that have the same graphic impact as a pair of sneakers from A Bathing Ape. Our favorites were a glittery emerald and yellow HDMI, a glossy purple one that looks like a jump rope from the Eighties and a wonderfully baroque silver cord with flashy gold plugs. Hook these babies into your home theater and itll be business in the front, party in the back.

title: Bear Stearns Said to Close Third Hedge Fund
description: Months after closing two hedge funds that helped precipitate the credit crunch, Bear Stearns is closing a third fund, Bloomberg News reported Wednesday.

title: Bear's New CEO Speaks
description: Alan Schwartz, Bear Stearns's new chief executive, talks with CNBC's David Faber.

title: And in Other News
description: Vaguely recalling that New Hampshire is not the center of the universe, the Opinionator decided to check up on what else happened yesterday, and the answer was, a lot: The president (remember him?) flew to Israel; the Pentagon released a bizarre tape of Iranian speedboats supposedly threatening Navy warships and the Supreme Court heard arguments in a voter-ID case that may have far broader implications for our democracy than any partisan primary.

title: HD DVD is Dealt a Blow
description: Whoa and hallelujah.

title: A health care system to die for
description: Rudy Giuliani warned us about what would happen if a Democrat wins:

title: Bear's New CEO Speaks
description: Alan Schwartz, Bear Stearns's new chief executive, talks with CNBC's David Faber.

title: Dawn of the Pundits
description: I watched Saturday nights Democratic debate in the filing center on site, along with two of my editors, Gerry and Megan. When Hillary Rodham Clintons temper flared, Gerry and I practically recoiled in our seats. Another male journalist sent me an e-mail saying, She just lost. But Megan saw something completely different, and even before the candidates could ask another question, she admonished us for being sexist. Why can a man flash some anger, she wanted to know, but not a woman? What was so distasteful about a woman showing a little fight?

title: A 60,000-Vote Differential
description: Some observers, including David Brooks , have looked at the New Hampshire primary results and concluded that roughly equal numbers of votes were recorded in the Republican and Democratic primaries. But I see a huge difference in the numbers  differences of historical significance, in fact.

title: The Man Who Turned Against the C.I.A.
description: What kind of C.I.A. agent was Philip Agee? With the news today of his death, there have been variations on a theme. Reuters headlined him as a whistle-blower while The Associated Press preferred renegade, and Redstate, a right-wing blog, was the most unsparing: A Traitor Dies In Exile.

title: Employing the Masses
description: Ive been reading a lot about an impending recession, but its hard to imagine its reality when I hear about the number of people working on our dream home. It seems like half the population of Anna Maria is working on it right now.

title: For The Moment | Florence Night Owl
description: This weeks guest blogger is the New York-based mens wear designer Adam Kimmel. Known for his heady brand of cerebral machismo  Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock are recurring inspirations  Kimmel, 28, will be filing from Florence, Italy, where he is the featured designer at the mens-wear trade show Pitti Immagine Uomo. In todays post, Kimmel writes about the final preparations for his dinner at the Istituto darte on Thursday.

title: CNBC Video: Bears New C.E.O. Speaks
Huckabees Bobsled Lessons
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C.  Every candidate has a crop of funny stories, but with all due respect, as they love to say in election campaigns, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabees are probably funnier. He does voices. He makes noises with a microphone that any Comedy Central stand-up act might respect.

title: The Peoples Choice: Tune Out the Awards
description: The two-month-old writers strike took a significant toll on the Peoples Choice Awards on Tuesday, as the taped, scaled-down version on CBS lost nearly half its audience compared with a year ago. The show attracted 6 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates, down from the 11.3 million people who watched the shows live broadcast on the same night last year.

title: Clintons New Hampshire Win Pays Off for Some
description: Hillary Rodham Clintons big win in New Hampshire has already made some investors happy  those who have bought futures contracts in Mrs. Clinton in the Iowa Electronics Trading market.

title: How the Polls Were Off
description: In her Web column today, Janet Elder writes about pre-primary tracking polls that showed Barack Obama leading in the New Hampshire primary.

title: What Makes Wah-High So Special
description: What were reading elsewhere

title: Hillary Rodham Clinton on 'Today'
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton talks about her victory in New Hampshire. (NBC Video)

title: A Call to Action From Newarks Mayor
description: His intensity matched the soaring oratory and suddenly found voices of the presidential campaign season, but the Democratic mayor of Newark, Cory A. Booker, was thundering about local crime earlier today, and trying to convince 72 police department recruits  some looking dazed, and all the men with their heads shaved  that they were most important people in the world. The stage was small, and there was no blinding glare of television lights. A photographer got too close to Mr. Booker, who told him to back off.

title: "Extreme Hybrid" 3D Animation
description: This video provided by AFS Trinity Power illustrates the operation of its ultracapacitors in a hybrid vehicle.

title: Bomb Scare Derails Giuliani Event
description: MELBOURNE, Fl.  Rudolph W. Giuliani bypassed Michigan on Wednesday to return to his must-win state, Florida. There, his effort to shift the focus of his campaign from security to tax policy was dealt a slight setback when a bomb threat forced him to relocate a speech on tax cuts from a corporate headquarters to a secure airplane hangar.

title: Columbia Says It Knows of No Visit to Iran
description: Officials at Columbia University were taken aback on Tuesday when the Mehr News Agency, a government-sponsored news outlet in Iran, reported online that a delegation of professors and deans planned to travel to Tehran to apologize for the behavior of Columbias president, Lee C. Bollinger, during the visit to New York by Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, last September.

title: Gossage on Steroids: I Probably Would Have Done It
description: Timing is everything, not that Rich Gossage needs a lesson in that. The pitcher nicknamed the Goose made a living unleashing unusually fast pitches with unusual accuracy, which happens only by letting go at just the right moment.

title: The Real Winner in New Hampshire
description: If youre going to troll for poll data at Real Clear Politics any time soon, take time to check out a piece by John Ellis making a plausible case that the real winner in New Hampshire was Mike Huckabee.

title: None
Answers About Immigration on the Lower East Side
description: Following is the first set of answers from Steve Long, the vice president of collections and education at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, who is taking questions from City Room readers this week on the history of immigration and tenement life on Manhattans Lower East Side. Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment link below.

title: C.E.S. Picks: Wireless Video Networks and G.P.S. for Dogs
description: Earlier, I asked Bits readers for your picks of the best and weirdest from the Consumer Electronics Show. Ive turned the tables and asked the same question of our reporters who braved the cab lines in Vegas. So far Ive heard back from Brad Stone and Eric Taub. Their answers are below.

title: Museum on Wall Street Celebrates Dollar Signs
description: Updated, 8 p.m. | Robert Vinci pointed at a spindly tree chart that laid out an evolutionary ancestry. It was not dissimilar, he said, to the hierarchical diagrams, known as cladograms, of dinosaur families that he used to work with at the American Museum of Natural History.Only this one laid out the elaborate ancestry of the Bank of America, stretching back to names now relegated to history, including Massachusetts Bank (founded 1784), the Providence Bank (founded in 1791), and, more recently, Fleet, and BayBank.

title: Fear and Anger in Kenya
description: Kenya's recent election has untapped decades of resentment,  displacing thousands of people and claiming around 500 lives.

title: Next Stop: Workers Paradise
description: LAS VEGAS  Forget about the cholesterol-counting mob heirs to Bugsy Siegel or shy casino kings like Steve Wynn and their $5,000-a-night rooms. The real power in Vegas is centered in a schlub of a building next to razor-wire-enclosed repo lots in the shadow of the glitzy Strip.

title: A Hormone Is a Hormone, F.D.A. Says
description: Menopause hormones mixed by pharmacists arent any safer than commercially prepared hormones from drug companies, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: In Harlem, a Tough Choice Between Clinton and Obama
description: The race for the Democratic presidential nomination, as it moves to Nevada and South Carolina, remains as unsettled as ever. Senator Barack Obama visited New Jersey and New York on Wednesday for a rally and a fund-raising event, while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton gave interviews from her home in Chappaqua, N.Y., in Westchester County. We took the occasion of their visits here to ask several self-identified Democrats in Harlem which candidate they supported and whether the results on Tuesday in New Hampshire had affected their decisions.

title: In Harlem, a Tough Choice Between Clinton and Obama
description: The race for the Democratic presidential nomination, as it moves to Nevada and South Carolina, remains as unsettled as ever. Senator Barack Obama visited New Jersey and New York on Wednesday for a rally and a fund-raising event, while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton gave interviews from her home in Chappaqua, in Westchester County, N.Y. City Rooms Sarah Kramer and Alexis Mainland asked several self-identified Democrats in Harlem which candidate they supported and whether Tuesdays results in New Hampshire have affected their decision.

title: John McCain With Brian Williams
description: John McCain speaks to NBC's Brian Williams after his victory in the New Hampshire Republican primary.

title: Bloggingheads: Barack vs. Hillary
description:
Joshua Cohen of Stanford University, left, debates Glenn Loury of Brown on whether Barack Obama or Hillary Clinton would be more effective in the White House.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Fantasy Football Wild-Card Weekend
description: So there were a few surprises in the wild-card games, many of which hurt playoff fantasy teams nationwide. But if youre struggling after Week 1, dont fret . . . you likely have studs like Brady, Romo, Favre, Peyton, Moss, Welker, Wayne, Addai, Grant, Jennings, T.O. and Witten waiting in the wings to right your ship. Unless on a gut feeling you drafted all Titans (including Ben Hartsock).

title: Richardson to End Presidential Bid
description: Updated

title: CBS News And Writers Reach Agreement
description: CBS News and a union representing 500 of its employees announced Wednesday that they had reached an agreement on a new contract, ending a two-and-a-half-year dispute that contributed to the cancellation of a presidential primary debate last month.

title: Fear and Anger in Kenya
description: Kenya's recent election has untapped decades of resentment,  displacing thousands of people and claiming around 500 lives.

title: Barack Obama With Brian Williams
description: Barack Obama speaks to NBC's Brian Williams.

title: Faulty E.P.A. Climate Math on California Car Plan
description: My colleague covering the nations environment, Felicity Barringer, sent this note from California, where it seems some clarity is emerging in arguments over who gets to limit greenhouse gases from vehicles  the states or the United States.

title: The Slap Shot Half-Season Awards
description: The wonderful New York expression not for nothin' is used as a blanket indemnification for whatever grossly offensive statement may follow. Not for nothin, but youre dumber than the Thornton-to-San Jose trade. (O.K., as long as its not for nothin. If it were for something, youd be open to the Steve Downie treatment.)

title: Burt Cuts His Price
description: Will the horrors of the slumping U.S. market never end? The latest tale of suffering: actor Burt Reynolds, best known for the epic Smokey and the Bandit movies, is having trouble selling his Florida home.

title: Big Sam Is Out At Newcastle
description: MANCHESTER, England  It began last Sept. 20 when Jose Mourinho left Chelsea, a team he led to back-to-back titles in the English Premier League. On through Sammy Lee (Bolton), Martin Jol (Tottenham), Chris Hutchings (Wigan), Steve Bruce (Birmingham), Billy Davies (Derby County) and Lawrie Sanchez (Fulham).

title: Respond to Todays Column: Hillarys Free Pass
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Jan. 10 column.

title: Woman With Bodies to Face Murder Charges
description: WASHINGTON  The woman found in her home on Wednesday with the decomposing bodies of four children, believed to be her daughters, will face murder charges, authorities said Thursday.

title: The Approval of Seals
description: A BODY can take only so much modernism. Crisp head-to-toe newness is all well and good, but it needs some kind of counterweight  preferably, of course, in precious metal. Perhaps this is why signet rings, traditionally worn as a paterfamilias hand-me-down, are enjoying a revival. Cleverly referencing and romancing the past without becoming overwrought about it (see: goths), the new crop of restrained signet rings manages to whiff of the Knights Templar while conveying the continental lan of, say, Simon Templar. Having one subtly flashing on your finger is the perfect way to broadcast your affirmation of a bright modern future while reminding everyone of your ancestral ties to the past.

title: Portland, Ore., Acts to Protect Cyclists
description: Ghost bikes, riderless and painted white, were placed at two busy intersections in Portland, Ore., last October, makeshift memorials to two bicyclists killed when they were hit by trucks in accidents that month.

title: Shipmates Under the Influence of Gilbert and Sullivan
description: Since the company was founded in 1974, the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players have made a point of building their seasons around an alternation of the three most frequently heard Savoyard operettas  The Pirates of Penzance, The Mikado and H.M.S. Pinafore  and the lesser-known works that make up the rest of the canon.

title: In Corpse Episode, Echoes of a Grittier Time
description: You would see them around Hells Kitchen, the men neighbors knew as Jimmy and Fox. They were relics of the past in the once-notorious neighborhood, and now they lived on its edges.

title: Energizing Moves That Slice and Dice
description: Revelations is modern dances unquestionable greatest hit, anchoring countless performances by Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and inspiring applause before it even starts. But many troupes have their enduring crowd pleasers, signature works that reveal core artistic values. There is Esplanade, Paul Taylors joyously unforced celebration of everyday virtuosity, or Batty Moves, Jawole Willa Jo Zollars ode to the female derrire. These days the much diminished Martha Graham Dance Company settles, tellingly, for a remnant: Sketches, from the 1936 antiwar rallying cry Chronicle.

title: Yao Proves a Handful for a Handful of Knicks
description: Order was restored to the Knicks universe Wednesday night, thanks to Yao Ming.

title: Flights of Fancy: Artist as Medicine Man
description: Over the course of three decades, until his death at 78 in 1986, Emery Blagdon built what he thought of as a great healing machine in an unheated shed on his farm in the Nebraska Sandhills, near North Platte.

title: CBS News and Writers End Dispute After 2 Years
description: CBS News and a union representing 500 of its employees announced Wednesday that they had reached an agreement on a new contract, ending a two-and-a-half-year dispute that contributed to the cancellation of a presidential primary debate last month.

title: Forecast for Spring: More Yankees Drama
description: Andy Pettittes 13-year-old son, Joshua, is recovering from a broken arm and a head injury sustained in a four-wheeler accident after Christmas. Pettittes father, Tom, was in the hospital Wednesday with heart trouble.

title: Opening Government
description: A presidential advisory board released a report Wednesday with recommendations to reform the way the government declassifies documents.

title: Art Stolen From So Paulo Museum Is Retrieved
description: State police in Brazil have recovered two paintings, above, including a Picasso valued at $50 million, that were stolen last month in a predawn break-in at the So Paulo Museum of Art, Reuters reported. The museums president, Julio Neves, said Picassos Portrait of Suzanne Bloch and the Brazilian artist Candido Portinaris Coffee Worker, valued at $5 million, were in perfect condition when found at a house on the citys outskirts. The police arrested one suspect, Francisco Laerton Lopes de Lima, on Dec. 27, and his capture led them to Robson de Jesus Jordao, who was arrested on Tuesday. Police Chief Mauricio Freire said the two men had long criminal records, including participation in previous robbery attempts at the museum. Mr. Neves said both paintings would be on view in their previous locations when the museum opens on Friday.

title: Consultant Questions Beijings Claim of Cleaner Air
description: BEIJING  A new study has cast doubts about whether air quality has truly improved in Beijing and has concluded that irregularities in the citys system of measuring air pollution have enabled the city to meet environmental targets linked to the coming Olympic Games.

title: Theyre Playing My Song. Time to Work Out.
description: FITNESS magazines and Web sites love to ask readers about their favorite workout music while presenting their playlists or suggestions from celebrities. Self.com features the  80s cardio playlist, which includes the short-shorts video classic Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go by Wham! On Fitnessmagazine.com, the singer Rihanna reveals her favorite workout songs  immodestly recommending four of her own for when you have to pick up the pace on the treadmill.

title: Further Adventures in Americas Favorite Pastime, Addictionology
description: Addicts come in many guises, but the most pernicious are substance-abuse abusers  those reckless, incorrigible souls who cannot stop bingeing on the weaknesses of the rich and semi-famous.

title: Executive to Leave Warner Bros.
description: LOS ANGELES  Dawn Taubin, the head of domestic marketing at Warner Brothers for six years, has been ousted in a management shake-up that the movie studio did little to conceal.

title: Are We Ready for a Woman President? More Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama Swipes at Clinton, but Takes Aim at Bush
description: JERSEY CITY  Senator Barack Obama, showing strain in the wake of his surprise defeat in New Hampshire, hewed closely to his standard script of hope and change before a largely enthusiastic audience here on Wednesday, keeping his aim squarely on the administration of President Bush.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Antiques Benefit

title: Two Drives Team Up to Save a Networks Data. (If They Run Into Trouble, Theyll Let You Know.)
description: A new storage device guards against the day when your PC drive takes a dive. The ReadyNAS Duo, announced this week at the Consumer Electronics Show, is made by Netgear and will go on sale in March. Unlike simple single-drive storage connected to one computer with a cable, it is part of the home or office network, so it can be reached by all of the networks PCs or media players.

title: Weak December Sales for Retailers
description: The nations big retail chains, a closely watched barometer of economic health, reported dreary December sales on Thursday, which may stoke fears of a recessionary downtown.

title: Clintons Message, and Moment, Won the Day
description: At first, the moment seemed like a disaster: The televised images of the teary-eyed exchange Hillary Rodham Clinton had with a New Hampshire voter about the rigors of the campaign caused her advisers to express fears that it would badly undercut her message of strength and experience.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about President Bushs criticism of Iran for confronting American warships over the weekend misstated the conclusion of a recent National Intelligence Estimate on Iran, which Mr. Bush also discussed. The intelligence estimate, issued in December, concluded that in 2003 Iran halted its program to develop a nuclear weapon; it did not say that Iran had abandoned its efforts to enrich uranium.

title: Footnotes
description: The playwriting debut of the filmmaker Ethan Coen sold out before its first preview on Wednesday night Off Broadway at the Atlantic Theater Companys Stage 2. Featuring F. Murray Abraham, Jonathan Cake, Mark Linn-Baker and Mary McCann, the three short plays, under the title Almost an Evening, open officially on Jan. 22 for a run through Feb. 10. ... Kate Winslet will replace Nicole Kidman opposite Ralph Fiennes in The Reader, Variety reported. Ms. Kidman, citing her pregnancy, dropped out on Monday. The film, directed by Stephen Daldry  (The Hours, Billy Elliot), is based on a Bernhard Schlink novel about a German teenager who falls in love with a woman who once worked in Auschwitz.

title: Colombia: Plan for New Hostage Mission
description: President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela said Colombian guerrillas had provided him with the location of two captives, Clara Rojas, a former aspirant to Colombias vice presidency, and Consuelo Gonzlez, a former Colombian lawmaker. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, had agreed last month to release the hostages, but an operation led by Mr. Chvez fell apart after the rebels were found not to have the 3-year-old son of Ms. Rojas, who was instead living in foster care in Bogot. Colombias government gave its approval to the new operation. Mr. Chvez said rescue helicopters could depart as soon as early Thursday.

title: Best Beats
description: "Studies have shown that listening to music during exercise can improve results, both in terms of being a motivator (people exercise longer and more vigorously to music) and as a distraction from negatives like fatigue," Steven Kurutz writes in The Times today. "But are certain songs more effective than others?"

title: Planning a Life With Room for Debate
description: NEAR the start of the film The Great Debaters, the young man who would grow up to be the civil rights leader James Farmer Jr. comes home with the news that he has been chosen for his schools debate team. His father sternly warns him that something as frivolous as debate must not get in the way of homework and grades. Never take your eye off the ball, he said. But one suspects that it was those debates, more than those grades, that led Mr. Farmer to found the Congress of Racial Equality and help change the world.

title: A Better Life Here, Yes, but Not Without Worries
description: Raymond Acevedo and his sister, Katiria, share a bedroom in their familys apartment near Yankee Stadium, in the Bronx. It is tight quarters for two teenagers with different interests. Katirias side is decorated in pink and with Hello Kitty paraphernalia. Raymonds features sports equipment and posters of girls in bikinis.

title: Democrats Rush to Build Up Campaigns in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS  Scores of college students fanned out in neighborhoods across this city Wednesday, phone banks buzzed with newly minted volunteers and endorsements were proffered as the Democratic presidential candidates ratcheted up the volume in this once-quiet caucus state.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. My kitchen tile is scuffed and worn in high-traffic areas. Can I fix it without replacing the whole floor?

title: A Pocket Cam Zooms in for the Games Highlights
description: Canons latest entry-level video camera, the ZR950, does not skimp on specs. But it also does not carry a lot of doodads or protrusions like a TV-station rig. Instead it is smooth-edged for popping out of a pocket to capture the moment when Junior suddenly comes in goal range  even from the high school version of nosebleed seats.

title: Folsom Prison Officials Pull Plug on Concert
description: Officials have canceled a concert scheduled for Folsom Prison on Sunday, 40 years to the day after the famous Johnny Cash performance there, The Associated Press reported. Late Monday, citing problems with filming rights and media access, as well as concerns about security, officials at the prison in Northern California called off the 40th Anniversary of Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison performance that was to have featured some members of Cashs original band and been streamed worldwide on the Internet. Jonathan Holiff, the producer of the planned show, said the cancellation was a broken promise by the officials. I was in tears when I found out, he said.

title: Ex-Senator Wants to Pay Lawyers With Election Funds
description: Former State Senator Wayne R. Bryant of New Jersey, who is facing criminal corruption charges, is hoping to tap a new source to help pay mounting legal bills: his campaign account.

title: Tony Blair Expected to Join JPMorgan
description: The former prime minister of Britain, Tony Blair, will join the banking giant JPMorgan Chase & Company as a part-time adviser, a person with knowledge of the decision said Wednesday night.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Aide Wont Testify on Tapes Without Immunity
description: WASHINGTON  A lawyer for Jose A. Rodriguez Jr., the former Central Intelligence Agency official who in 2005 ordered the destruction of videotapes of harsh interrogations of prisoners at a secret site overseas, has told Congress that Mr. Rodriguez will not testify about the tapes without a grant of immunity, a person familiar with the discussions said Wednesday.

title: Richardson Drops Out of Democratic Race
description: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico is pulling out of the presidential race, after coming in fourth in both the New Hampshire primary and the Iowa caucuses.

title: The Smile Boutique in the Dentists Office
description: DR. PIA LIEB, a cosmetic dentist, held an unusual food tasting last month in a Chelsea loft. Plenty of red wine and gobs of delectable nibbles were on hand, including beet and goat cheese salad and raspberry mini-tarts. Dr. Liebs aim wasnt to delight guests but to discolor their teeth.

title: The Kaufman Center: Something New for Both Ear and Eye
description: On schedule and on budget, the Kaufman Center, home to the popular Merkin Concert Hall, opened its doors on Tuesday night with a gala reception and concert after an eight-month, $17 million renovation. On Monday night anyone passing the center, on 67th Street just west of Broadway, might have wondered how on earth the place was going to be ready to go in 24 hours.

title: Paul MacLean, 94, Neuroscientist Who Devised Triune Brain Theory, Dies
description: Dr. Paul D. MacLean, a neuroscientist and psychiatrist who developed the intriguing theory of the triune brain to explain its evolution and to try to reconcile rational human behavior with its more primal and violent side, died on Dec. 26 in Potomac, Md. He was 94.

title: Deleted but Not Erased: Photos Reborn
description: THANKS to digital cameras, memories are easier than ever to gather. But as Amy Sevigny learned, they can be more fragile as well.

title: Candy Magnate Loses Bid to Bar Drilling on Ranch
description: HELENA, Mont.  A state judge has ruled that an energy company has the right to explore and drill for natural gas on a sprawling cattle ranch owned by the billionaire candy magnate Forrest E. Mars Jr., despite his opposition.

title: An Upstart in Films With Many Fast Moves
description: LOS ANGELES  At the Cannes Film Festival last May, the movie producer Avi Lerner knew he had an alluring property on his hands: Robert De Niro and Al Pacino, who have shared the screen only once before, in 1995s Heat, were starring in a gritty New York police drama called Righteous Kill.

title: Queens: Teenagers Admit Fatal Beating
description: Two Queens teenagers pleaded guilty to manslaughter on Wednesday, admitting that they choked and fatally beat John Canora, 55, in his Howard Beach home in October 2006, prosecutors said. At the time of their arrest, the teenagers, Billyray Staton, 18, of Beach 27th Street in Far Rockaway, and Alex Brown, 18, of Liberty Avenue in Jamaica, told the police that Mr. Canora had hired them to do maintenance work on his home and had offended them by making sexual advances. They said they choked him, beat him with an aluminum baseball bat and a fire extinguisher, and hid his body in the basement.

title: Governor Doesnt Seek Tuition Rise for Colleges
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers State of the State message was filled with benefits for New Yorks public universities, including 2,000 new full-time faculty members and the creation of an endowment of at least $4 billion.

title: Any Other Bright Ideas?
description: WHEN Lloyd Levine, a California assemblyman, proposed last year that his state become the first in the country to ban energy-wasting incandescent light bulbs, his position was met with outrage.

title: Air Travelers Woes Likely to Worsen This Year
description: The miserably full flights of 2007 might seem like a good reason for airlines to roll out a few more planes and ease the crowding.

title: Florida: Arrest in Killing of Detective
description: The Miami police have a man in custody who they believe inadvertently killed an off-duty police officer while firing an assault rifle at a couple in an apparent jealous rampage, a police spokesman said. The man, Ricardo Ajuste, 21, was charged with two counts of attempted murder for allegedly opening fire on a car parked near the vehicle of the officer, Detective James Walker. Detective Walker was found dead Tuesday in his unmarked police cruiser in an alley in North Miami Beach. Mr. Ajuste has not been charged with the killing but is a prime suspect, the police said.

title: A Breezy Exchange Between Old Friends (Jazz and Poetry)
description: This is not an exercise in nostalgia, or giggling at the 50s, the poet Robert Pinsky said on taking the stage at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night. Along with his colleague Charles Simic, the current poet laureate of the United States, Mr. Pinsky was taking part in a program billed as Words and Music. And his disclaimer doubled as a pledge. We hope the evening will not be about goatees and berets, Mr. Pinsky said, but about art.

title: Fixated on TVs, and Whats on Them
description: The Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week was an unabashed display of high-technology gadgetry. Televisions, enormously wide and remarkably thin, were front and center, and overhead, and in the faces of all the visitors to the expansive show, which ends Thursday. Some advertised other new products, but most were there just to display images that were slightly crisper than those seen years before.

title: Michigan Next, G.O.P. Rivals Turn to the Economy
description: PONTIAC, Mich.  Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney sped to Michigan on Wednesday and turned their focus to the slowing economy as they headed toward the next showdown in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Edmund Hillary, First on Everest, Dies at 88
description: Sir Edmund Hillary, the lanky New Zealand mountaineer and explorer who with Tenzing Norgay, his Sherpa guide, won worldwide acclaim in 1953 by becoming the first to scale the 29,035-foot summit of Mount Everest, the worlds tallest peak, has died, New Zealand Prime Minister Helen Clark announced Friday in Wellington.

title: The Bride Made Me Buy This
description: IN the new romantic comedy 27 Dresses, Jane, a perennial bridesmaid, smiles a shade too brightly in response to a remark repeated in scene after scene. Eyeing her invariably frothy bridesmaids dress, a well-meaning friend chirps, Well, you can always wear it again.

title: Britain Moves to Build New Nuclear Plants
description: PARIS  The British government on Thursday approved plans to refresh the countrys fleet of nuclear reactors, signaling new enthusiasm for the technology and giving a lift to the industry.

title: Edwardss 3 Little Words: The Long Haul
description: CLEMSON, S.C.  Diving into the South Carolina primary, John Edwards has a plan to keep himself positioned to capture the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Met Forms Search Committee for Director
description: Wasting no time, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has formed a committee to begin an international search for a replacement for Philippe de Montebello, who announced on Tuesday that he would retire after 30 years as the museums director.

title: Blog Takes Failed Marriage Into Fight Over Free Speech
description: BOSTON  Normally, Garrido v. Krasnansky, a divorce case playing out in Vermont family court, would be of little interest to anyone but the couple involved. But the court has ordered the husband to stop posting blog items about his wife and their crumbled marriage, possibly turning an ordinary divorce into a much broader battle over free speech on the Internet.

title: Ken Nelson, Record Producer Behind Bakersfield Sound, Dies at 96
description: Ken Nelson, the record producer behind the twangy Bakersfield Sound made popular by Buck Owens and Merle Haggard, died on Sunday at his home in Somis, Calif. He was 96.

title: Bank of America in Talks to Buy Countrywide
description: The Countrywide Financial Corporation, the troubled lender that came to symbolize many of the excesses of the subprime mortgage crisis, is reportedly negotiating a sale to Bank of America, a move that would rescue Countrywide from an uncertain future.

title: Suspects Arraigned in Dead-Mans-Check Case
description: A sister of Virgilio Cintron, the 66-year old man whose corpse was wheeled up to a check-cashing store by two of his friends on Tuesday, was working at the store when the two men tried to redeem her brothers check, according to the criminal complaint.

title: Philip Agee, 72, Is Dead; Exposed Other C.I.A. Officers
description: Philip Agee, the former Central Intelligence Agency officer who turned against the agency and spent years exposing undercover American spies overseas, died Monday in Havana. He was 72.

title: Blame for 1993 Attack at Center Is Still at Issue
description: One of the most painful parts has been the wait, a lawyer for victims of the 1993 bombing at the World Trade Center told an appeals court on Wednesday.

title: Kerry Endorses Obama as Campaign Goes Nationwide
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John Kerry embraced the presidential candidacy of Senator Barack Obama here on Thursday, saying Mr. Obama had the greatest potential to lead a transformation, not just a transition.

title: The First Primary: Its Clintons Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: 	Anarchy Rules: The Dishes Stay Dirty
description: An article last Thursday about communal or punk houses misstated the university affiliation of Joel Olson, a former resident of one such house. Mr. Olson is an assistant professor of political science at Northern Arizona University, not Arizona State University.

title: Fighting in Congo Rekindles Ethnic Hatreds
description: MUSHAKE, Congo  Andre Simwerayi looked on with satisfaction as the army blasted rockets over a verdant hillside, pummeling what officers said were the positions of forces loyal to a renegade Congolese Tutsi general.

title: Besting the Tiger Slam
description: Tiger Woods said on his Web site last week that winning all four professional majors in a single year, a feat never accomplished, is "easily within reason." Do you expect him to win the Grand Slam this year? If not, who or what will stop him?

title: Remaking the Condo With Light and Air
description: WHEN Bob Harper began his search for a new home in West Hollywood, Calif., last summer, what he thought he wanted was a house. But he quickly changed his mind after his real estate agent took him to see a two-story condominium in Habitat 825, a 19-unit building at 825 North Kings Road that was nearing completion.

title: The G Train From Smith-9th Streets to Long Island City
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Tunes for Every Tribe
description: Though most gym-goers turn on their iPods and tune out everyone else, many health clubs still pump music throughout the gym, tailoring the playlist to their clientele.

title: Giants Using Power to Start, and Finesse to Finish
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Dressing side by side in the Giants locker room, Brandon Jacobs and Ahmad Bradshaw make an unlikely pair: Jacobs at 6 feet 4 inches and 264 pounds, and Bradshaw at 5-9 and 198.

title: Study Says DNA Flaw May Raise Autism Risk
description: A rare genetic flaw that occurs spontaneously near or during conception may sharply increase the risk that a child will develop autism, researchers reported Wednesday.

title: Congress to Investigate Denials by Clemens
description: The House committee looking into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball has postponed a hearing next week that was to feature Roger Clemens and his accuser so that the panel can begin its own investigation into Clemenss adamant denial that he used such drugs.

title: Alicia Keys Climbs Chart
description: In a slow week for the Billboard chart, Alicia Keys reached No. 2 with 112,000 sales of As I Am (J); Mary J. Blige moved 89,000 of Growing Pains (Geffen) to reach No. 3; Now Thats What I Call Music! Vol. 26 is at No. 4 with 54,000; and the 18-year-old country singer Taylor Swift rose three spots to No. 5, though sales of her self-titled album, on the Big Machine label, dropped 39 percent last week to 47,000, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Radiohead reached No. 1 with the conventional release of In Rainbows, through the ATO label, on CD and other formats. The indie-rock Juno soundtrack (Rhino), popular online, opened at No. 8 with 38,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about President Bushs criticism of Iran for confronting American warships over the weekend misstated the conclusion of a recent National Intelligence Estimate on Iran, which Mr. Bush also discussed. The intelligence estimate, issued in December, concluded that in 2003 Iran halted its program to develop a nuclear weapon; it did not say that Iran had abandoned its efforts to enrich uranium. (Go to Article)

title: In Address, Spitzer Sets New Tone, for Unity
description: ALBANY  The man who swept into the Statehouse a year ago, determined to overhaul Albany, instead tried to embrace it on Wednesday, as Gov. Eliot Spitzer called lawmakers his friends, asked for prayers for the family of his political nemesis, and shelved, for the time being, talk of dramatic reform.

title: More Than a Steak Dinner
description: A Texas judge was so delighted last week to free a wrongly convicted inmate  after 27 years in prison  that the judge bought him a steak dinner and taught him how to use a cellphone to spread the news. The fact that this happened in Texas, famous for its draconian criminal punishments, was heartening. Most heartening of all was that Dallas County, where it occurred, is turning into a model for the rest of the nation in preserving potentially exonerating evidence in capital cases.

title: China to Freeze Energy Prices in an Effort to Quell Worries About Inflation
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao responded Wednesday to growing public anxiety about inflation by announcing that China would freeze energy prices in the near term, even as international crude oil futures have continued to surge.

title: W.H.O. Says Iraq Civilian Death Toll Higher Than Cited
description: The World Health Organization on Wednesday waded into the controversial subject of Iraqi civilian deaths, publishing a study that estimated that the number of deaths from the start of the war through June 2006 was at least twice as high as the oft-cited Iraq Body Count.

title: Hollywood Investigator to Be His Own Lawyer
description: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that Anthony Pellicano, the Hollywood private investigator facing trial on wiretapping and conspiracy charges, can represent himself at trial next month. Judge Dale S. Fischer of United States District Court said she was bound by Supreme Court case law to let Mr. Pellicano do so, but urged him to reconsider. The ruling raises the prospect that Mr. Pellicano, who often grabbed the limelight in his career as an investigator to the stars, would again take center stage at his trial, set to begin Feb. 27. By acting as his own lawyer he will cross-examine prosecution witnesses like Anita Busch, the former journalist who the authorities say was wiretapped by Mr. Pellicano and was threatened in a scheme he orchestrated, as well as other cooperating witnesses who prosecutors say hired Mr. Pellicano to wiretap their adversaries.

title: 2nd Finish in Fifth Fails to Dim Pauls Hopes
description: CONCORD, N.H.  In a state that many people considered his best opportunity to match his strong fund-raising with enough votes to shake up the Republican race, Representative Ron Paul came up short on Tuesday.

title: Fed Chief Signals Further Rate Cut
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, sent a strong signal on Thursday that the central bank will lower interest rates again this month as it tries to stave off a recession.

title: Cash, Check, or Euro?
description: The plummeting United States dollar is not something most sports fans think about -- that stuff is for economists and politicians. But next week in New York, American sports executives will have to deal with a consequence of the greenback's weakness, as National Hockey League executives meet with European hockey officials to hammer out a new agreement governing international player transfers.

title: Hillarys Free Pass
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.

title: Study Finds Possible Targets for AIDS Drugs
description: Using a new type of genetic screen, researchers at Harvard Medical School have identified 273 proteins that the AIDS virus needs to survive in human cells, opening up new potential targets for drugs.

title: In the Catskills, Wondering if Casinos Time Has Passed
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.

title: Niceness Campaign in Albany Gets Nowhere as G.O.P. Pouts
description: ALBANY  Few second dates have been so awkward.

title: Steppingstone Squeeze on the Path to a Victory
description: In a Flight A/X Swiss Teams, your team is either A (you have players with lots of master points) or X (your team is not weighed down with points). But although a team is X rated, if you will excuse the expression, it does not mean that its members cannot play.

title: Tom Cruise and His Bully Pulpit
description: If Andrew Mortons Tom Cruise: An Unauthorized Biography is published peacefully next Tuesday, one of its basic assertions will be undermined. That is because if Mr. Morton is right about the litigious fervor of either Mr. Cruise, who is the books ostensible subject, or the Church of Scientology, which is its real one, the publication will be met with dirty tricks, messianic anger and relentless harassment. If Mr. Morton is wrong about that, there will be fewer fireworks. After all, among this biographys revelations is the fact that Tom Cruise was a cute kid.

title: Must Flatter, Work Nights and Last Forever
description: Here is a brief guide to the types of light bulbs discussed in the accompanying article.

title: Second Escapee From N.J. Jail Arrested in Mexico
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.  The second of two inmates who escaped from the Union County jail here last month was captured in Mexico City on Wednesday, ending a nearly four-week search that began with a nighttime jail break and ended with two arrests in two countries within 24 hours.

title: MySpace Is Said to Draw Subpoena in Hoax Case
description: LOS ANGELES  A federal grand jury here issued subpoenas to MySpace and others last week in connection with the suicide of a 13-year-old Missouri girl after she received cruel messages from people posing as a teenage boy on the site, The Los Angeles Times reported Wednesday.

title: At 0-17, N.J.I.T. Has Hit Bottom, and Things Arent Looking Up
description: NEWARK  When the New Jersey Institute of Technology mens basketball team lost its season opener to Manhattan, 70-28, the players and coaching staff might have figured that at least things could not become worse. Some two months later, they are finding out that they were wrong.

title: Nevada Savors Its Place as Maker of Momentum
description: LAS VEGAS  Scores of college students fanned out in neighborhoods across this city Wednesday, phone banks buzzed with newly minted volunteers and endorsements were proffered as the Democratic presidential candidates ratcheted up the volume in this once-quiet caucus state.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Europes Next Rate Move May Be an Increase
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank suggested Thursday that its next interest rate move was most likely to be an increase, despite signs that European economies are slowing.

title: At Jewish Cemetery, Vandals Strike on Large Scale
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Celia Tracy lay on the ground beside the toppled tombstone, stretching her arm underneath the large slab of marble. As if reading Braille, she rubbed her fingers along the engraved surface, now hidden, searching in vain for any indication that here was the grave of her in-laws.

title: Where Skis Meet Skates
description: THE cross-country ski has come a long way from the days of wooden slats and bamboo poles. In the last 10 to 15 years, the equipment has undergone drastic changes, resulting in skis that are lighter, faster and stronger.

title: 9 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Sunni Strongholds
description: ARAB HAMADAH, Iraq  In one of the deadliest stretches for American troops in months, militants killed nine soldiers in the volatile Sunni Arab heartlands north of Baghdad on Tuesday and Wednesday as the military began its third offensive in a year to dislodge Sunni guerrillas from sanctuaries deep within the lush farmlands and palm groves of Diyala Province.

title: A Microscope for the Lab, Minus the Squinting
description: Mad scientists of an earlier era were content with using a microtome and glass slides to examine odd cell structures through a dusty lens. Modern mad scientists know that theres something a bit clearer available: the Celestron LCD Digital Microscope.

title: Cowboys Wont Say If Owens Will Play
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  While the off-field adventures of Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo have attracted attention, Terrell Owenss health is a far more critical component of Sundays game.

title: Digital Tools Help Users Save Energy, Study Finds
description: Giving people the means to closely monitor and adjust their electricity use lowers their monthly bills and could significantly reduce the need to build new power plants, according to a yearlong government study.

title: Albany: Lawsuit Over Ski Resort
description: Residents and community groups in the Catskills filed a lawsuit on Wednesday in State Supreme Court charging the state with a conflict of interest in the way it is handling its review of a proposed resort near the state-owned Belleayre Ski Center in Ulster County. The Catskill Heritage Alliance, the Pine Hill Water District Coalition and individuals who live near the planned development assert that the State Department of Environmental Conservation is a partner in the project at the same time that it is deciding whether to grant final approval. In September, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced an agreement to move forward with the long-delayed project to build hotels, housing units and a golf course alongside the Belleayre center in Highmount, near two reservoirs that supply water to New York City. The developer, Dean Gitter, agreed to scale back the project and sell 1,200 acres to the state, which in turn agreed to expand the number of ski runs and lifts at Belleayre.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: The Elusive Perennial

title: Fans in a Video Playoff for Super Bowl Tickets
description: DONT tell the children who watched Miracle on 34th Street on TV last month, but there is no Santa Claus  at least, not in a contest being sponsored by Coors.

title: Ashcroft Deal Brings Scrutiny in Justice Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  When the top federal prosecutor in New Jersey needed to find an outside lawyer to monitor a large corporation willing to settle criminal charges out of court last fall, he turned to former Attorney General John Ashcroft, his onetime boss. With no public notice and no bidding, the company awarded Mr. Ashcroft an 18-month contract worth $28 million to $52 million.

title: Conditions in Cascades Raise Avalanche Danger
description: SEATTLE  The big snows that pummeled the Cascade Range recently have transformed the mountains into an alluring fresh-powder playground for winter sports. But they have also helped make this one of the deadliest avalanche seasons on record in Washington.

title: Study Sees Complex Ties Between Plants and Animals
description: A few years ago, Todd Palmer, an ecologist at the University of Florida, was walking past a fenced-off research site in Kenya when he noticed something curious: instead of thriving, acacia trees protected from leaf-eating elephants and giraffes were withering and dying.

title: Ditching the Suit, the Vest Struts Its Stuff
description: WOMEN may have plenty to smirk about these days as men turn into the very clotheshorses they once sneered at. Even so, men still have a healthy distrust for an impractical trend.

title: Womens Support for Clinton Rises in Wake of Perceived Sexism
description: If the race wasnt about gender already, it certainly is now.

title: Panama: Noriega Loses Another Round
description: Judge Paul C.
