Huck of United States District Court in Miami denied a request by lawyers for the former Panamanian strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega to block his extradition to France to face money laundering charges. The lawyers said France had offered insufficient guarantees that Mr. Noriega would be repatriated to Panama after his legal process was completed in Europe. But the judge said France had made assurances that he would be accorded all the rights of a prisoner of war, including repatriation to Panama, even though it did not intend to designate him as one. The judge also rejected an argument that Mr. Noriegas status as a prisoner of war in the United States prohibited his extradition. The lawyers said they would appeal. Mr. Noriega, who in September completed a 15-year prison term in Miami, will remain in American custody until he exhausts all his appeals.

title: Philippe de Montebello
description: For 30 years, Philippe de Montebello has been the edifice within the edifice of the Metropolitan Museum of Art  as iconic, in his own way, as the museums Fifth Avenue facade. He has announced that he will retire at the end of the year, but it is almost easier to think of him as an antiquity  and I mean this only sculpturally  being restored to the country of his origin. He must have come to us from private life, and to private life he will return, though it is hard to imagine him or the Met without each other as a backdrop.

title: Not Just the Fed
description: The American economy is weakening fast, and some prominent economists are saying a recession is already here. The Federal Reserve, with its prodigious lending capacity and power to cut interest rates, could yet save the day. But with prices, and fears of inflation, also rising, the Fed has less room to maneuver.

title: Lawmaker Tied to Abramoff to Retire
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John Doolittle of California, once a rising star in the Republican Party but more recently under investigation in a scandal involving the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff, announced his retirement from Congress on Thursday, declaring that it was time for a new chapter in his life.

title: Retailers Limit Purchases of Designer Handbags
description: FOR products that are truly in demand, like Wii game consoles, tickets to the Super Bowl or cans of corn Niblets on double-coupon day, it may seem reasonable to limit the number a customer can buy at one time.

title: Ice Maker in Talks With Hedge Fund on New Buyout Terms
description: PHILADELPHIA (Reuters)  Reddy Ice Holdings, a producer of packaged ice, said Wednesday that it was in talks to revise a $1.1 billion deal to be bought by a hedge fund, GSO Capital Partners.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A film review in Weekend on Dec. 21 about National Treasure: Book of Secrets referred imprecisely to a scene in the film North by Northwest that takes place at Mount Rushmore, as does a scene in National Treasure: Book of Secrets. While Eva Marie Saint dangles near George Washingtons face in North by Northwest, she is not shown dangling from his nose.

title: Down and Out and Running Numbers in the Rougher Precincts of Manila
description: Much like mans best friend, the rough-hewn Filipino movie The Bet Collector chases its protagonist from step to step, misery to misery, all but nipping at her heels. Though you never see her sell anything, Amy (Gina Pareo) operates a tiny store out of the front of her ramshackle Manila house with her husband and tries to make ends meet by illegally running numbers. Its a living (if barely), though there are moments in this aggressive, predictably sympathetic excursion into miserablism when it seems a lot more like dying.

title: Genetic Flaw May Explain Some Cases of Autism
description: A rare genetic flaw that occurs spontaneously during development may sharply increase the risk that a child will develop autism, researchers reported Wednesday.

title: Iran Accuses U.S. of Faking Persian Gulf Video
description: TEHRAN  Irans Revolutionary Guard accused the United States on Wednesday of fabricating a video showing Iranian speedboats confronting United States Navy warships in the Persian Gulf over the weekend, according to a report carried by the semiofficial Fars news agency and state-run television.

title: Tip of the Week: Managing Your Passwords
description: Tired of having to click that Forgot Password? link when trying to log into a secure Web site? Consider using a password-management program to organize and store all the passwords you pick up on your Internet travels. With most programs, you need to remember only one password to unlock the softwares encrypted database and reveal all your others. Free options include Password Safe (passwordsafe.sourceforge.net) and Password Corral (www.cygnusproductions.com). SplashID has $20 password software for PCs and smartphones at www.splashdata.com, and several other programs are rated at password-management-software-review.toptenreviews.com.

title: Korean Fire Ends Migrants Hard Journey Home
description: ICHEON, South Korea  When 31-year-old Sohn Dong-hak and six relatives, all ethnic Koreans from China, began migrating to South Korea several years ago, they were retracing the route of their forebears, who had left their native land a century ago for China to escape poverty and Japanese colonial rule.

title: A Fierce Corzine Opponent Turns Ally
description: TEANECK, N.J.  Gov. Jon S. Corzine on Wednesday turned to the Republican he defeated in a bitter race for the United States Senate in 2000 to help with what may be his toughest campaign yet: persuading taxpayers and legislators to accept costly increases on New Jerseys toll roads to pay off billions in debt and maintain its bridges and highways.

title: Admirable Spirit, but Rules Are Rules
description: In August 1945, a former Army pilot with an artificial leg pitched five and a third innings for Washington against Boston. This would turn out to be Bert Shepards only major league game, and it remains one of the heartwarming moments in baseball history.

title: For Bernanke, a Question of Toughness
description: Is the Federal Reserves chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, too nice for the job?

title: Artemis and Stag at Met Museum
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is the new (if temporary) home of Artemis and the Stag, below, the 2,000-year-old classical bronze sculpture that sold last year for a record $28.6 million at a Sothebys auction in New York. The sculpture, sold by the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo to an unidentified private collector for the highest price ever paid for a sculpture or antiquity at auction, will be on view for six months in the Leon Levy and Shelby White Court (the central atrium in the new Greek and Roman Galleries).

title: Manhattan: Republican Ex-Official Sentenced
description: A former chairman of the Manhattan Republican Committee was sentenced on Wednesday in State Supreme Court to five years probation for violations of tax and state ethics laws, prosecutors said. The former chairman, James A. Ortenzio, pleaded guilty in November to tax evasion and violating disclosure laws for public officials. Mr. Ortenzio, who also served as chairman of the Hudson River Park Trust, failed to disclose about $180,000 in income in 2004 and 2005, prosecutors said. As part of the plea deal, Mr. Ortenzio agreed to pay back taxes and penalties.

title: 3 Groups Lend Names to Suit Asking Release of Database
description: Three groups, including The New York Times, have filed papers in support of a lawsuit seeking to have the police make public a database of officers recordings on more than 850,000 stops of civilians between January 2006 and September of last year.

title: London Art Show to Proceed
description: The Royal Academy of Arts in London announced on Wednesday that it had received official approval from Russia for the loan of its art for the exhibition French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925 From Moscow and St. Petersburg. The show is scheduled to run from Jan. 26 through April 18. Russia had cast the show in doubt while seeking assurances that none of the 120 paintings would be seized to satisfy possible claims that they had been confiscated by the state after the 1917 revolution.

title: Bank of England Resists Calls for a Rate Cut
description: LONDON  The Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate unchanged Thursday, resisting calls this week from politicians and businesses that it cut borrowing costs among fears of slowing economic growth in Britain.

title: Keeping the Housing Slump at Bay
description: THE housing slump has exacted its toll on everyone from banks and Wall Street firms to builders and mortgage brokers. But there are the exceptions, the entrepreneurs who either have long experience in real estate or have carved out a special niche. So far, they have been able to ride out the worst.

title: Same Old Electronics Show, With Some Intriguing New Ideas
description: One million exhibitors. Sixty million attendees. Four trillion booths spread across an area the size of Rhode Island.

title: Study Suggests That Amputee Holds an Unfair Advantage
description: The Olympic aspirations of Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee sprinter from South Africa, may end soon. Track and fields world governing body is expected to announce that he is ineligible to race against able-bodied athletes because his state-of-the-art prosthetics give him an unfair advantage.

title: City Council Passes Bill for Recycling of Plastic Bags
description: The stash under the sink grows inexorably: bags from Duane Reade and DAgostino, bags from Home Depot and the health food store. Wadded up, stuffed one inside the other, they explode out of the cabinet as you wonder how youll ever get around to using all of them.

title: On Gossages Plaque, a Yankee Cap
description: Rich Gossage will wear a Yankees cap when he enters the Baseball Hall of Fame. The announcement was made at a news conference in New York on Wednesday, one day after Gossage was the only player elected by the Baseball Writers Association of America in the 2008 class.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,901 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday and Tuesday:

title: Gov. Spitzer Tries Nice
description: After six rocky months feuding with Republicans, Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York on Wednesday laid out ambitious goals for his second year in office  all in a new and welcome diplomatic style. The centerpiece is a plan to upgrade the states uneven public university system with a $4 billion state endowment and a $3 billion innovation fund to encourage academic work that also helps the economy statewide. A public university system truly worthy of New York is certainly long overdue.

title: A Simpler Digital S.L.R. Camera That Borrows Features From Its High-End Big Brother
description: When Sony entered the digital single-lens reflex camera business in 2006, it did not reinvent the category. Its first offering, the A100, was essentially a well-received refinement of the technology it acquired after Konica-Minolta abandoned the photography business. The A200, which will be available next month, takes things a step further.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Weekend Explorer column on Dec. 14, about the Upper East Side, misstated the history of the name of the Yorkville area. Historians believe it was named for the Duke of York (later King James II), as were New York City and State. It was not named for Sgt. Alvin C. York, the World War I hero. (York Avenue was named for him.) The column also misidentified the borough in which Woody Allen, a longtime Upper East Side resident, was born. It was the Bronx  not Brooklyn, the borough in which he grew up.

title: Justices Question Validity of Voter I.D. Case
description: WASHINGTON  There are many ways to lose a Supreme Court case, and by the end of an argument before the court on Wednesday, the Democrats who are challenging Indianas voter-identification law appeared poised to lose theirs in a potentially sweeping way, with implications for many future election cases.

title: Snow Day
description: Burning calories in the snow doesn't always have to burn a hole in your wallet. This Saturday, Jan. 12, is Winter Trails Day, when rookies can try out cross-country skiing and snowshoeing for free at nearly 100 cross-country centers, parks and recreation areas in 24 states.

title: 4 Say Marines Took Fire in Attack by Afghans
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C.  Marines from an elite combat unit who American military commanders said killed 19 Afghan civilians last year after a suicide bomb attack withstood hostile gunfire immediately after the explosion, witnesses testified on Wednesday.

title: Targets Chief Plans to Retire
description: MINNEAPOLIS (AP)  In a long-expected move, the Target Corporation, the discount retailer, said on Wednesday that its chief executive, Robert J. Ulrich, will retire May 1 and will be succeeded by the companys president, Gregg W. Steinhafel.

title: Getting It Wrong
description: Washington

title: Great Lawn Just Got Better, Park Visitors Agree
description: One day after the city rescinded a regulation that had limited the size of the crowds allowed on the Great Lawn in Central Park, there were no blankets, no tents, no fans with picnic baskets  and no picnic baskets, either. And no Paul Simon, no giant stages and no giant video monitors, as there were when Mr. Simon appeared there in 1991.

title: Spain Says 2 Confessed to 2006 Airport Bombing
description: MADRID  Two men accused of being members of a militant Basque separatist group who were arrested last weekend have confessed to carrying out the December 2006 bomb attack on Madrids airport that killed two people and shattered peace talks with the militant group, the government said Wednesday.

title: Finding Missing Gmail Messages
description: Q. I use Gmail and have turned on the POP3 function to download messages to my computer. I sometimes check mail on the Web version of Gmail, but I notice that messages I download dont show up in my online in-box. Is there a way to keep all the mail on the Web, too?

title: Taxpayer Advocate Urges Apology Payments
description: Taxpayers who endure excessive expense or drain on their time when the Internal Revenue Service mishandles a case should receive apology payments of up to $1,000 each, the national taxpayer advocate told Congress on Wednesday.

title: 2005 Use of Gas by Blackwater Leaves Questions
description: WASHINGTON  The helicopter was hovering over a Baghdad checkpoint into the Green Zone, one typically crowded with cars, Iraqi civilians and United States military personnel.

title: Radiohead Finds Sales, Even After Downloads
description: LOS ANGELES  In a twist for the music industrys digital revolution, In Rainbows, the new Radiohead album that attracted wide attention when it was made available three months ago as a digital download for whatever price fans chose to pay, ranked as the top-selling album in the country this week after the CD version hit record shops and other retailers.

title: From Palestinians, Harsh View of Bush
description: JERICHO, West Bank  President Bush will not be coming to this oasis city of beige hills, lush green plantations and ancient ruins on his visit to the Palestinian Authority on Thursday. Given the apparent antipathy of the local population, it is probably just as well.

title: Lottery Numbers
Is Ethanol for Everybody?
description: CAMPOS, Brazil

title: In Patriots Season to Remember, a Teammate Is Not Forgotten
description: In one of their last telephone conversations, Marquise Hill confided in his mother, Sherry. Back in his native Louisiana for a weeklong visit before the New England Patriots June minicamp, Hill, a 24-year-old reserve defensive lineman, said: Momma, guess what. I feel like were going to be unstoppable.

title: New Penalties Set as Bush Calls Iran a Threat to Peace
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush charged Wednesday that Iran remained a threat to world peace as the Treasury Department imposed strict economic penalties on a top Iranian military commander, a Syrian-based television station and three militants in the region accused of helping the insurgency in Iraq.

title: Durant Plays, but Seattle Is No Match for the Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets funk did not last long. One night after a 115-99 loss at Charlotte threatened to halt their momentum, the Nets rebounded with a 99-88 victory against the Seattle SuperSonics at the Izod Center. It was their sixth victory in their last seven games.

title: You Can Go Home Again, but Why?
description: TOKYO

title: Judges Tell San Francisco It Can Begin Health Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal panel of judges granted San Francisco the right on Wednesday to put in place a key part of its universal health care program as legal arguments about the first-in-the-nation plan continue.

title: Justices Indicate They May Uphold Voter ID Rules
description: WASHINGTON  There are many ways to lose a Supreme Court case, and by the end of an argument that was before the court on Wednesday, the Democrats who were challenging Indianas voter-identification law appeared poised to lose theirs in a potentially sweeping way, with implications for many future election cases.

title: Strike Nips Awards Show
description: The two-month-old writers strike took a significant toll on the Peoples Choice Awards on Tuesday as the taped, scaled-down version of the awards show on CBS lost nearly half its audience compared with a year ago, attracting just 6 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., Nielsen reported. A year ago, the shows live broadcast averaged 11.3 million. For the night, CBS ranked third overall, trailing second-place Fox with its all-repeat lineup. NBC finished first, leading every hour of the night among adults 18 to 49 with a two-hour episode of The Biggest Loser (10.2 million), followed by Law & Order: Special Victims Unit at 10 (15.2 million). CW delivered its best Tuesday ratings since March thanks to One Tree Hill, which averaged 3.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 in its fifth-season debut. ABC trailed CW in last place among adults 18 to 49.

title: U.N. Official Warns of Darfur Failure
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations top peacekeeping official told the Security Council on Wednesday that obstructionism by the Sudanese government, the failure of other countries to supply needed transportation equipment, and continued violence threatened to doom the mission of the freshly deployed peacekeeping force in Darfur.

title: Delta Chief to Seek Merger Talks
description: The chief executive of Delta Air Lines plans to ask the companys board for permission to enter into formal merger talks with both Northwest Airlines and United Airlines, a person close to Delta said on Thursday.

title: Now That Romo Has Rested, Critics Ask if Hes Ready
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants Coach Tom Coughlin was asked to describe the blooming and well-documented relationship involving one of the quarterbacks in Sundays playoff game with the Cowboys.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Intel Gets New York Subpoena in Antitrust Inquiry
description: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York issued a wide-ranging subpoena to the Intel Corporation on Thursday as part of an investigation into whether the company violated federal or state antitrust laws in the way it priced and sold microprocessors.

title: 4 Children Flung From Bridge, Police Say
description: Search and rescue crews scanned coastal waters off Alabama on Wednesday for the bodies of four young children believed to have been tossed off a bridge by their father after a domestic dispute.

title: Military Leaders Seek 3,000 More Troops for Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  Senior military officers will soon propose deploying about 3,000 additional American troops to Afghanistan, where the NATO-led security and stabilization effort is short of combat forces and trainers, Pentagon officials said Wednesday.

title: VoIP Backups for Power Failures
description: Q. Is it true that you lose VoIP phone service if theres a power failure? What can you do if it happens and you dont have a mobile phone to fall back on?

title: Analyzing the New Hampshire Surprise
description: The morning after Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton claimed victory in the New Hampshire Democratic primary, many pollsters and news organizations plunged themselves into a post-mortem centered on a single question: How could they have not seen it coming?

title: Richardson Said to Be Dropping Out
description: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico is pulling out of the presidential race, after coming in fourth in both the New Hampshire primary and the Iowa caucuses, according to people with knowledge of his decision.

title: Oo-rah! A Squad of Actors Takes Lanford Wilson to the Marines
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif.  Adam Driver, former Marine lance corporal, First Battalion, First Marine Regiment, Weapons Company, 81st Platoon, remembers two shows he saw while stationed here on this sprawling base north of San Diego. There was a skateboarder who performed tricks. And a performance by the San Diego Chargers cheerleaders.

title: Manhattan: Rathers CBS Suit Proceeds
description: A state judge ordered on Wednesday that parties to a lawsuit filed by Dan Rather against CBS, Viacom and executives of the companies prepare to share evidence. Mr. Rather filed the suit in September, saying that CBS violated his contract by giving him insufficient air time as a correspondent after forcing him to step down as anchor of CBS Evening News. The suit also asserted that CBS conducted a flawed inquiry into a controversial report by Mr. Rather about President Bushs National Guard service that the network concluded was based on documents that could not be authenticated. CBS said Mr. Rathers accusations were without merit and asked in November that the lawsuit be dismissed. Justice Ira Gammerman of State Supreme Court said on Wednesday that the parties should share evidence while he considered parts of the motion, and ordered lawyers to reconvene in two weeks.

title: Apple to Cut the Prices of iTunes in Britain
description: LONDON  Apple said on Wednesday that it had agreed to cut the prices on its iTunes digital music store in Britain to align them with those on the Continent, settling an antitrust case brought by European regulators.

title: Toy Makers Mount Drive to Salvage Chinas Safety Reputation
description: HONG KONG  Jay Horowitz, owner of American Classic Toy, started putting a prominent notice last October on all his products, most of them made in China, stating that they contained no lead-based paint.

title: Bush Begins Peace Effort Bonded With Olmert
description: JERUSALEM  They share an enthusiasm for sports, fitness and the occasional cigar. They are both unpopular leaders, scarred by terrorism and zealous in their warnings about the threat of Islamic extremism. And yet they profess grand ambitions to accomplish what other leaders have failed to do for decades: make peace between the Israelis and Palestinians.

title: No New Trial for Former Chief of Brocade
description: SAN FRANCISCO (Bloomberg News)  The former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, Gregory L. Reyes, who was convicted in August of stock-options manipulation, is not entitled to a new trial, a federal judge ruled Wednesday, rejecting arguments that new evidence had emerged.

title: A 70s-Style Brawl in Russia
description: Were filing this under Championship Week because Ak Bars Kazan are techinically a championship team, having won the Continental Cup last weekend in Riga. But look what happened upon their return to the Russian Superliga on Tuesday night  they started a full-fledged 70s-vintage, bench-clearing brawl with Traktor Chelyabinsk, which you can see in its entirety on the Telekanal web site here, or, if you prefer, below:

title: College Matchup of the Week
description: Wisconsins Kyle Turris (Phoenix Coyotes) and Denvers Rhett Rakhshani (Islanders) and Tyler Ruegsegger (Maple Leafs) are going to get sick of seeing one another. Last week they faced off wearing the jerseys of Canada and the United States, when Turriss Canadian squad drubbed Rakhshani, Ruegsegger and their fellow Americans in a 4-1, semifinal win at the World Junior Championship in the Czech Republic.

title: Fight in the Stands!
description: While the players were brawling in Kazan, in St. Petersburg the fans were doing the brawling. This was the scene Tuesday at the SKA St. Petersburg-Spartak Moscow match at the Ice Palace:

title: The World According to Bob Clarke
description: Bob Clarke, the Flyers senior VP, went on TSNs Off the Record, where he told the host Michael Landsberg that Steve Downies hit on Dean McAmmond wasnt so bad and that Jason Blake deserved to be sucker punched for saying Downie deserved a lifetime ban for the McAmmond hit.

title: Dress Codes | Ditching the Suit, The Vest Struts Its Stuff
description: The vest has divorced itself from the three-piece suit.

title: Masks at James Cohan Gallery
description: Images from the group show.

title: The Green Reaper
description: From Reuters:

title: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Cross-Country Skis
description: Drew Gelinas, nordic skier, tests cross-country skis.

title: Your Daily Commute?
description: Image found here.

title: Tom Cruise, the Early Years
description: The new Tom Cruise bio by Andrew Morton may face legal action, but not for spreading gay rumors about his schoolboy years. From our review of the book:

title: Whos Next for the Deal Dead Pool?
description: Reddy Ice on Wednesday announced that it was in price renegotiations with respect to its pending $1.1 billion purchase by GSO Capital Partners. The announcement comes as the February 3, 2008, termination date for the transaction fast approaches. GSO must decide prior to that date whether to commit to the transaction if it can obtain financing, or terminate on that date and pay a $21 million termination fee. In the latter event, GSO may claim a material adverse change to Reddy Ice under the terms of the merger agreement in order to escape even paying the $21 million reverse termination fee.

title: Launching cars on the Internet  and beyond
description: A couple of hours ago the Toyota Formula One team launched its presentation of the 2008 racing car live on the Internet. At 7 PM Indian Standard Time this evening the Force India team will launch its car live on the net, presenting its new car and drivers (with the surprise announcement of Giancarlo Fisichella signing on as the second driver already being scooped by Vijay Mallya in todays Gazzetta dello Sport newspaper in Italy). BMW Sauber also just announced today that its car launch will be done with live streaming on the BMW Sauber teams Internet site next Monday at noon. They will also put up a film of the launch later on, at 2:30 in the afternoon on Monday.

title: Tony Blair to Join JPMorgan as Adviser
description: The former prime minister of Britain, Tony Blair, will join the banking giant JPMorgan Chase as a part-time adviser, the bank said.

title: F.C.C. Backs $2.7 Billion Verizon Sale in 3 States
description: Federal communications regulators on Wednesday cleared the way for Verizon Communications to sell its phone lines in three New England states for $2.7 billion to FairPoint Communications.

title: No New Trial for Former Chief of Brocade
description: The former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, Gregory L. Reyes, who was convicted in August of stock-options manipulation, is not entitled to a new trial, a federal judge ruled Wednesday, rejecting arguments that new evidence had emerged.

title: Greenberg Shifts Tone About A.I.G. Moves
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, said on Wednesday that a group he represents did not intend to solicit proxies from A.I.G. shareholders, buy more A.I.G. shares or start a tender offer for the company.

title: Bayhill Therapeutics Aims to Raise $86.3 Million in I.P.O.
description: Bayhill Therapeutics said Wednesday it plans an initial public offering of its common stock, but the biopharmaceutical company did not disclose any terms in its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Merrill Fires 8 London Bankers, Report Says
description: In what may be John Thains latest housekeeping effort since taking the helm at Merrill Lynch, the worlds biggest brokerage reportedly fired at least eight bankers in London from a group that sold asset-backed debt and invested the firms money.

title: Among V.C.s, Talk of a Green Bubble Arises
description: Egged on by $100-a-barrel oil and consumers going green, venture capitalists plan to pour ever more cash into environmentally friendly technology this year, prompting talk of a bubble reminiscent of the dot-com era.

title: Affiliated Computer Signs Deal for Britains Syan
description: Affiliated Computer Services said Wednesday that it had purchased Syan Holdings Limited, an information technology outsourcing firm based in England, for about $60 million.

title: Aruba Picks Up AirWave
description: Aruba Networks, the wireless-networking company, announced on Wednesday that it would buy a multi-vendor network management company, AirWave Wireless, for $37 million in cash and stock.

title: NYSE Said to Be in Deal Talks With Amex

title: BofAs Tough Countrywide Choice
description: As it watches its $2 billion investment in Countrywide Financial erode, the Bank of America faces a tough choice, says Fortune: It can buy Countrywide outright, pour even more money into the once high-flying mortgage lender, or simply bide its time and hope for the best.

title: Remembering the Old, Gritty Hells Kitchen
description: After his roommate, Virgilio Cintron, died, James OHare, 65, and another friend, David Daloia, 65, dressed Mr. Cintrons corpse, carried him down a flight of stairs and heaved his body into a computer chair with wheels. Outside, they rolled him over the uneven sidewalk, pulling the chair toward Pay-O-Matic, a check-cashing shop on Ninth Avenue, seeking to cash Mr. Cintrons Social Security check. A crowd gathered, a police detective eating his lunch called the authorities and soon the men were arrested.

I put up a post and Dot Earth readers responded in droves with comments about their good, bad, and ugly experiences. There is a strong sense that these bulbs are a transitional technology, but that lighting will be less and less of a drain on the grid after a century of incandescent convenience.

title: News Corp. Says It Isnt Bidding for Monster

title: Scent Notes | Mandorlo di Sicilia by Acqua di Parma
description: There are perfumes built in the classic French fashion, with shiny exteriors of gold and titanium. Wearing them is like wearing a brilliant Cartier ring inlaid with diamonds. You wear these fragrances to show them off. (The French value: the brilliance and ego of the artist.) There are American perfumes that smell like a handsome, showered baseball player, sporty, young and relaxed, and you wear these to assume that identity, as you might wear a polo shirt with a country club logo. (The American genius: self-invention.) Then there are perfumes in the Italian style  often lemon/bergamot citrus scents  that serve as luxury ID badges, and one wears these as one would a beautifully-made Italian dress shirt, to say, Admire my level of comfort and elegance. (The Italian obsession: status and the identification of ones social group.)

title: Tata Motors Unveils $2,500 Car
description: Ratan Tata, chairman of Tata Motors, displaying the Nano in New Delhi on Thursday. (Photo by Money Sharma/European Pressphoto Association)  Video  Tata Motors today took the covers off the world's cheapest car -- the Nano.  Over the past year, Tata has been building hype for a car that would cost a mere 100,000 rupees (roughly $2,500) and bring automotive transportation to the mainstream Indian population. It has been nicknamed the "People's Car." Over the course of the New Delhi Auto Expo, which began this week, anticipation had grown to fever pitch.  With the theme from "2001: A Space Odyssey" playing, Ratan Tata, chairman of Tata Motors drove the small white bubble car onto Tata's show stage, where it joined two others.  The Tata Nano could sell for around $2,500. (Photo by Raveendran/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images)  "They are not concept cars, they are not prototypes," Mr. Tata announced when he got out of the car. "They are the production cars that will roll out of the Singur plant later this year."  The four-door Nano is a little over 10 feet long and nearly 5 feet wide. It is powered by a 623cc two-cylinder engine at the back of the car. With 33 horsepower, the Nano is capable of 65 miles an hour. Its four small wheels are at the absolute corners of the car to improve handling. There is a small trunk, big enough for a duffel bag.   "Today, we indeed have a Peoples Car, which is affordable and yet built to meet safety requirements and emission norms, to be fuel efficient and low on emissions," Mr. Tata added. "We are happy to present the Peoples Car to India and we hope it brings the joy, pride and utility of owning a car to many families who need personal mobility.  The base price for the Nano will be 120,000 rupees, including road tax and delivery. Higher level models will cost more and come with air-conditioning. Sun visors and radios are extra.  The nearest priced competitor is the Maruti 800, which costs roughly twice as much as the Nano. In comparing the Nano to the Maruti 800, Mr. Tata said, "It is 8 percent smaller -- bumper to bumper -- and has 21 percent larger seating capacity than Maruti 800."  The Hindustan Times reports reactions from a couple of Tata's competitors, Maruti and Hyundai:   Jagdish Khattar, a former head of Maruti 800 manufacturer Maruti Udyog Ltd., says it's too early to say whether the Nano will overtake the original.  "It's a good product but it's still too early to say whether it will overtake the 800 because it caters to a totally new market segment," he said while watching a live telecast of Tata's press conference after unveiling of the Nano.  But clearly, at least one other manufacturer was worried.  An official of Hyundai Motors, which unveiled an LPG version of its Santro Thursday, was more circumspect.  "We definitely see it as impacting our sales," he said in halting English, preferring to maintain anonymity.    Anand Mahindra, managing director for Mahindra & Mahindra, Tata Motors' primary competitor, said before the unveiling, "I think it's a moment of history and I'm delighted an Indian company is leading the way."  The Nano will go on sale in India later this year with an initial production run of 250,000 a year. Tata says it will offer the Nano in other emerging markets in Latin America, Southeast Asia and Africa within four years.  Related:    Slide Show: Highlights From the New Delhi Auto Expo  With Cars in Reach, Indians Must Learn to Drive (January 11, 2008)  Four Wheels for the Masses: The $2,500 Car (January 8, 2008)  In India, More Cars, Going Faster (December 7, 2007)  In India, a $2,500 Pace Car (October 12, 2007)  Indias $2,500 Car (June 22, 2007)

description: Belichicks career is a tricky thing to weigh, especially to those of us who admire the old econ majors application of reason to football, but who despair at his fetish for brutal efficiency in a game that has no shortage of brutality, Tommy Craggs writes in this weeks Play newsletter. It is a dehumanizing way to run a team in our most dehumanizing sport. Alas, in the modern N.F.L., it is also the most effective.

These studios have commitments to release some discs this year in HD DVD, but both have ended their exclusive commitment to that format, which is backed by a group led by Toshiba.

title: See Rudy Run  Or Not
description: The story in New Hampshire this week was, of course, all about the stunning revivals of Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain. Buried a little further down the scoreboard, though, was another sign of just how fluid and unpredictable presidential politics can be. After winning just 5 percent of the vote in Iowa, Rudolph W. Giuliani managed a fourth place finish in New Hampshire, barely edging out Ron Paul (who had edged him out in the caucuses). To put this another way, the hero of September 11, the man they call Americas Mayor, is now battling to put some distance between himself and the former standard-bearer of the Libertarian Party, who would abolish most of the federal government.

title: Same Time, Next Year
description: The world wont come to an end because the Golden Globes are kaput. In any case, Steven Spielberg neednt worry, the Baguette says. He had been voted this years Cecil B. DeMille Award for lifetime achievement, but the Hollywood Foreign Press Association has postponed conferring the honor till next years show. By then, presumably, labor and management will have settled their differences, so Mr. Spielberg will be able to receive his award with all the usual hoopla.

title: New Yorkers, You May Be Excused: A Pay Toilet Opens
description: Few toilets  if any  have ever received the level of government and media fanfare that greeted the new public pay potty that opened today in Madison Square Park. First, the full force of New York Citys newspapers, television and radio were there to tape, record and take notes on the first flushes. Second, the toilet is the product of an on-and-off decades efforts (detailed below) by city officials to, uh, serve the needs of New Yorkers.So it was understandable that the city officials reveled in the toilet paper roll-cutting ceremony (which, fittingly, they did with their hands) on Madison Avenue, between 23rd and 24th Streets. But they couldnt resist the temptation of scatological humor: No. 1! (Janette Sadik-Khan, transportation commissioner), in loo of (Adrian Benepe, parks commissioner), doesnt block pedestrian movement (Daniel L. Doctoroff, outgoing deputy mayor for economic development).

Thanks to AwardsDaily for both of the points.

title: Huckabees Michigan Ad
description: There may be no better place than Michigan (uh, other than the entire Rust Belt), where the line former Gov. Mike Huckabee has perfected about knowing the guy you work with, rather than the guy who laid you off, will resonate. Its all part of his portrayal as the candidate who represents the common man, the worker-bee (pardon yet another variation on his name), and so not reflective of the corporate executive like his rival, Mitt Romney.

title: For The Moment | NY Artists Alight in Florence
description: This weeks guest blogger is the New York-based mens wear designer Adam Kimmel. Known for his heady brand of cerebral machismo  Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock are recurring inspirations  Kimmel, 28, is filing from Florence, Italy, where he is the featured designer at the mens-wear trade show Pitti Immagine Uomo. In this post, Kimmel writes about the arrival in Florence of a group of downtown artists hes invited to be the models for his dinner at the Istituto darte on Thursday evening.

title: On the Road Toward One Billion Cars
description: Hold on to your steering wheel. India  where roads are already in near-constant gridlock  took a big step toward mainstreaming car culture, and sending the world on a path to surpass 1 billion cars by 2020, with the unveiling of the $2,500 Nano. The vest-pocket four-seater has an engine barely bigger than those powering some American lawn mowers.

title: The Noise from Brazil | Fashion Rio
description: If you think the mania surrounding a Marc Jacbos show is the ultimate in fashion insanity, then try getting into Colcci, Brazils popular high street label and the hottest ticket in town at Fashion Rio, which is underway this week in Rio de Janeiro. On Tuesday night the scene outside the Centro Cultural da Ao was sheer chaos, as a conga line of gawkers, guests and gorgeous girls and boys tried to gain access. The show started more than an hour late and when Brazils perpetual top model, Gisele Bundchen, took to the rotating circular catwalk, the crowd went as wild as any soccer mob at Maracan stadium. As an outsider, it was confusing why such banal clothes (imagine a Dsquared and Cavalli collaborative capsule collection for H&M) could inspire such a frenzied reaction.

title: Lo-Fi
description: The Bagger, oh the shame of it, is a big fan of twee-core, that musically challenged warbling and strumming whose only value is its ability to produce ersatz emotion between the ears of the listener. Is it any wonder that he fell for  SLIGHT SPOILER ALERT  the stoop-sitting cover of the Moldy Peaches tune Anyone Else But You, sung by Michael Cera and Ellen Page in Juno?

title: Mayor Bloomberg and the Cheez-Its
description: Updated, 10:25 p.m. | The mayors snacks are suddenly a topic of discussion.

title: Blogtalk: The Obama-Kerry Alliance
description: Boy, that John Kerry is one unpopular guy.

title: Team USA: There Goes the Love
description: When U.S. Coach John Hynes first faced his team for the World Junior Championship at camp in Ann Arbor, Mich., last month he stressed togetherness. He told the team to stretch as a group, eat as a group and dress as a group.

title: Update: $124 Million for Ovechkin
description: The Washington Capitals majority owner and chief blogger, Ted Leonsis, put his money where his keyboard is, signing his electrifying young star, Alex Ovechkin, to a 13-year contract extension. The Associated Press reported that the deal is worth $124 million, the richest in NHL history.

title: Ranking Banks for a Different Kind of Green
description: Has the green movement finally begun to take hold of the bottom-line-driven banking industry?

title: Bill Richardson, Seeing Good in Everyone
description: In his years as a diplomatic negotiator, Bill Richardson learned to never offend anyone and to look for something positive in each individual. So as Mr. Richardson, New Mexicos governor, ended his presidential bid Thursday, before about 300 well-wishers at the Statehouse in Santa Fe, he had a nice word for the candidates in the Democratic field. Yes, even for former Senator Mike Gravel of Alaska, who is still in the race.

title: NPR Cancels Republican Debate
description: Last week, candidates were complaining about their not being included in some debates. This week, low attendance is forcing National Public Radio to cancel its forum with the Republican candidates in Columbia, S.C.

title: The Carpetbagger
description: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) attends the New York Film Critics Circle Awards with Sarah Polley, director of the lauded "Away From Her."

title: Live Blogging the G.O.P. Debate
description: 10:58 | Wrapping It Up This debate was a bit of a hard slog, mostly a repetition of talking points with a few sharp elbows thrown in.

title: McCain on Iraq
description: John McCain answers a question from an anti-war voter at the Opera House in Derry, N.H.

title: Video: The New York Film Critics Circle Awards
Remembering Sir Edmund Hillary
description: Sir Edmund Hillary, who won worldwide acclaim in 1953 by becoming the first to scale the summit of Mount Everest, has died.

title: Emotion Without Thought in New Hampshire
description: On the morning after the New Hampshire primary, CNNs John Roberts interviewed Marianne Pernold Young, the woman whose coffee shop question  How do you do it? How do you keep upbeat and so wonderful?  is largely credited with setting into motion Hillary Clintons surprise victory on Tuesday.

title: Experiencing New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  It would be easy for fans to visit this city for a big game and completely miss the bigger picture.

title: Have $2.7 Million? Buy The Last Super Bowl Ad
description: Fox Broadcasting has sold all but one of the 63 30-second commercials that it plans to run during the Super Bowl on Feb. 3, Stuart Elliott reports in Fridays New York Times. The average cost of each 30 seconds of commercial time is estimated at $2.7 million, compared with $2.6 million for spots in Super Bowl XLI in February 2007.

title: Spain Buyers Heading Inland
description: Buyers in Spain are looking inland for genuine Spanish settings and better deals, according to the latest trends report from Kyero.com, the property site. Country homes accounted for 27 percent of the searches on the site, compared to only seven percent for apartments.

title: A Ploy for Uncommitted in Michigan
description: Rarely do people work so hard to drum up votes for no one in particular.

title: Best of the Romo Headlines (So Far)
description: Announcing the first round of eliminations. We received more than 100 submissions, but some had to be deleted for taste.

title: Jessica Isnt the Only Distraction: Futures of Favre and Dungy Make News
description: The second-round playoff games are set to begin Saturday, but a few big-name participants in this weekends games spent a lot of time Thursday talking about next season instead. In an article in The Sun Herald of Biloxi, Miss., Brett Favre sure sounded as if he planned to play another season. For the first time in three years, I havent thought this could be my last game, he said. I would like to continue longer. And he has the endorsement of his daughters: Breleigh then spoke up and said, Dad, dont retire. And Brittany said, Dad, I think you need to play one more year.

title: Q & A With John Branch
description: New York Times reporter John Branch makes his living asking the tough questions. Thats how he is able to write about the big issues in the National Football League such as Tony Romos playoff preparation regimen and the Giants re-inherited, always-welcome underdog status heading in to Sundays N.F.C. playoff game in Dallas.

title: Manhattan: Labor Leaders Trial Delayed
description: The federal trial of Brian M. McLaughlin, the former president of the New York City Central Labor Council, was pushed back on Thursday and is now scheduled to begin on March 10. Mr. McLaughlin, left, who is accused of illegally obtaining $2.2 million through embezzlement, fraud and bribes, was to have gone on trial in Federal District Court at the end of the month, but in court on Thursday, Judge Richard J. Sullivan said scheduling conflicts required a delay. Mr. McLaughlin, who is free on $250,000 bail, has been charged with stealing from his own organization, the State Assembly and a Little League team in Queens.

title: Newark: Gang Sweep Nets 23 Arrests
description: About two dozen people suspected of being gang members were removed from Newark streets in a two-day sweep by F.B.I. agents and local law officers, the authorities said Thursday. Those arrested are believed to be members of a violent Bloods subset called 793 Bloods, and face weapons and drug-trafficking charges, the F.B.I. said. The gang controlled the sale of heroin and cocaine in part of the South Ward, officials said. The 23 people arrested this week are in addition to 16 arrested in the past two years as part of the same investigation, the F.B.I. said. Three others remain at large.

title: Many Palestinians Offer a Bleak Opinion of Bush
description: JERICHO, West Bank  President Bush did not come to this oasis city of beige hills, lush green plantations and ancient ruins on his visit to the Palestinian Authority on Thursday. Given the apparent antipathy of the local population, it is probably just as well.

title: Vincent Gruppuso, 67, Seller of Pudding Snacks, Dies
description: Vincent Gruppuso, the founder of Kozy Shack Enterprises, a company in Hicksville, Long Island, that sells millions of four-ounce cups of pudding, particularly rice pudding, at supermarkets in the United States, Canada, Mexico and Europe, died Dec. 29 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 67.

title: Out West, Where the Ladies Are Consumptive and the Men Confused
description: Comanche Moon, a six-hour mini-series beginning Sunday on CBS, is based on Larry McMurtrys novel of the same title, and begins as it ends, with the camera retreating from the image of a distraught child. Both the first boy and the second have lost their mothers to the ravages of the 19th-century Texas frontier.

title: Leader of Microsofts Office Business Is Retiring
description: Jeffrey S. Raikes, a 26-year veteran of Microsoft and leader of the companys lucrative Office business, plans to retire later this year. The company announced on Thursday that it was reaching outside its ranks for his successor, Stephen Elop, 44, the former chief operating officer of Juniper Networks.

title: Iran Shows Its Own Video of Vessels Encounter in Gulf
description: WASHINGTON  Iran released its own video Thursday of the encounter on Sunday between Iranian patrol boats and American naval vessels in the Strait of Hormuz in an effort to show that no confrontation occurred.

title: Ciao to a Met Prize Returning to Italy
description: In the coda to a long tug of war, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is bidding goodbye to the Euphronios krater, a 2,500-year-old vessel that has been a showpiece of its collection for more than three decades. Sunday is the last viewing day.

title: If Nice Guys Finish Last...
description: Put me squarely in the minority, among the people who do not view Bill Belichick as the walking manifestation of evil or the Nixon White House or whatever those barking dogs are telling ESPN.com's Gregg Easterbrook to write these days. I care little about the New England coach's cinematography, less about his habit of running up points until the scoreboards say "tilt," and least of all about his churlishness with the same media scolds who reckon a postgame handshake a glimpse into a man's soul. He may not be the National Football League's warmest presence, but he is a very good coach of what may be the very best football team ever concocted, and once upon a time that would have been enough.

title: 7 Indicted After Agent Gets Inside Cocaine Ring and the Ships It Used
description: To infiltrate the cocaine ring, the man had to make his way into the bowels of a cargo ship docked off Staten Island and retrieve a newspaper and a hat that had been hidden there at a stopover in Panama.

title: North Korea: U.S. Suggests a New Nuclear Deadline
description: Christopher R. Hill, the State Departments point man on North Korea, urged it to give a full accounting of its nuclear weapons programs before Lee Myung-bak, the new president of South Korea, who is inclined to offer the North more sticks and fewer carrots, takes office on Feb. 25. North Korea missed a year-end deadline for declaring its nuclear activities. After meeting with Mr. Lee in Seoul, Mr. Hill said while there had been bumps in the road, it would be very desirable if the process were finished by Mr. Lees swearing-in. Unlike the departing president, Roh Moo-hyun, Mr. Lee intends to make aid and economic exchanges conditional on nuclear compliance.

title: The Game for Santana Is Stretching On
description: The most popular baseball game of the winter seems to be endless. If it were being played in July, it would be in extra innings, and the innings would be whizzing by with no end in sight.

title: Top Prospect Suspended for Fighting
description: Lance Stephenson, a point guard from Coney Island who is considered a top national prospect in the class of 2009, was suspended from school for five days and will miss three games for his role in a fight with a teammate earlier this week.

title: A Physician Caught Trying to Heal Himself
description: Corpses had always made me queasy, Sandeep Jauhar writes in Intern, the brutally frank chronicle of his medical apprenticeship. Dead bodies lead a long list of aversions. When giving a rectal examination to one patient, he turns aside and vomits. Unpleasant odors and icky tactile sensations disturb him.

title: Annan to Help in Kenya, Group Says
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  With no sign of a breakthrough in the Kenyan political crisis, it appears that a high-profile mediator may be flying in to help: Kofi Annan.

title: Buddy LeRoux, 77, Boston Sports Fixture, Is Dead
description: Edward LeRoux, a former trainer for the Boston Red Sox who rose to become a controversial part owner of the team while amassing a fortune in real estate, died Monday in Wolfeboro, N.H. He was 77 and lived nearby in Tuftonboro.

title: Joness Soaring Career Now a Cautionary Tale
description: Once, Marion Jones ran through the streets for a commercial, her girl-next-door smile and spectacular talent sprinting across television screens throughout America. She would become the most glamorous Olympian in 2000, winning five medals, including three golds, and a rare track and field star who was a household name.

title: A Hard Look at the Life of Benazir Bhutto
description: To the Editor:

title: Want to Buy Some Tap? Theyre Happy to Sell It
description: All good performers reveal themselves, but there is something about tap, which lacks the strict exoskeleton of, say, ballet, that demands that more aggressively. Like another of Americas great democratic art forms, jazz, tap celebrates the individual, and it is through the ineffable qualities let slip during solos  and not, usually, through technique  that tap dancers win or lose viewers hearts.

title: Administration Is Rebuffed in a Ruling on Deportation
description: A federal judge in Pennsylvania on Thursday blocked the governments efforts to deport a Coptic Christian who said he would be tortured if he were returned to Egypt. The ruling was a rebuff to the Bush administrations practice of relying on confidential assurances to send people to countries that have been known to practice torture.

title: Energys Forms: Snazzy, Sly and Sexy
description: Reviewers tend to shrug off the work of David Parsons. Yet the rest of the audience does not seem to have qualms about settling for undemanding entertainment, to judge by the response when Parsons Dance presented a new program on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. It doesnt hurt that the entertainment is delivered by a company of individualistic performers who dont all look like dancers but move with the same slyly sizzling energy. Tommy Scrivens appeared to be having the time of his life in the jazzy closing piece, Shining Star, after carrying out demanding lead roles in the two preceding dances.

title: A Step Toward a Free Great Lawn
description: In the decade since it spruced up Central Parks Great Lawn with private money, New York City has put in place fussy and undemocratic rules barring the lawns use for political demonstrations. These free speech restrictions were especially offensive in 2004 when the Republican National Convention came to town and major antiwar rallies were blocked, supposedly to protect the lawn. Now, to avoid a court battle, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has agreed to take another look at his selective keep-off-the-grass policy.

title: Schwarzeneggers Budget Includes 10% Cuts
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Faced with billions of dollars in deficits, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger announced a stark state budget on Thursday, including 10 percent cuts in most departments, early release for thousands of inmates and the closing of dozens of state parks.

title: Bosnia: Police Take Passports of Karadzic Family
description: At the request of the international war crimes court in The Hague, the Bosnian Serb police seized the passports of the wife, son, daughter and son-in-law of Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader during the countrys 1992-95 war and one of the most wanted men in the world. His family is suspected of helping him evade capture, along with a network of supporters.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: New Rushdie Novel Due
description: A new novel by Salman Rushdie, will be published on June 3 by Random House. Titled The Enchantress of Florence, it is set in Renaissance Florence and the court of the Mughal Empire as it tells of a woman attempting to command her own destiny in a mans world, a Random House announcement said. In March, Random House Trade Paperbacks will repackage and republish Mr. Rushdies works The Satanic Verses, Shame and The Jaguar Smile.

title: Fishing Boats, Surfboards and Not a High-Rise in Sight
description: PUERTO ESCONDIDO, a tiny fishing village turned surfers hub on the Pacific coast of Mexico, certainly has the hallmarks of a tropical paradise: wide beaches, hidden coves and rocky cliffs that soar above crystalline waters.

title: Whiteface Mountain
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Infection Control
description: To the Editor:

title: United Antidoping Program Is Formed
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  Several of the biggest, most powerful sports organizations in the United States announced Thursday the formation of a joint antidoping research program, financed with at least $10 million, to find more effective, but less expensive methods to detect and deter the use of performance-enhancing drugs in sports.

title: Chinese Director Arrested
description: The maverick Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yuan was arrested after he was found taking drugs in his Beijing home, Reuters reported, citing accounts on Thursday in official news media. Mr. Zhang, with four friends, was taking a variety of drugs when the police burst into his apartment, the Xinhua news agency reported, crediting a Beijing television account. A urine sample tested positive for ketamine and crystal meth, the report said. Mr. Zhang, named by Time magazine in 1994 as one of 100 young world leaders for the 21st century, is one of Chinas Sixth Generation filmmakers, whose works have addressed alienation, nihilism and homosexuality. Although he has won acclaim and awards, some of his films have been banned in China.

title: 4 Youths Arrested in Vandalism at Jewish Cemetery in New Jersey
description: The police have arrested four teenagers who they said toppled nearly 500 tombstones at a Jewish cemetery in New Brunswick, N.J., on two separate nights of mischief.

title: In Writers Strike, Signs of Internal Discontent Over Tactics
description: LOS ANGELES  When Hollywoods studios walked away from the bargaining table last month, striking screenwriters came out swinging. They filed a legal complaint, boycotted an awards show and picketed late-night television programs.

title: Weinstein in Deal With Writers
description: LOS ANGELES  The Weinstein Company, one of Hollywoods biggest independent film companies, is expected to formally announce an agreement with striking writers as early as Thursday, according to Harvey Weinstein, the companys co-founder.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the filmmaker Goran Paskaljevic, who is the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, misstated the effect of the 9/11 terror attacks on the scheduled showing of his film How Harry Became a Tree at the Toronto International Film Festival in September 2001. Although Mr. Paskaljevic remained in Paris after the attacks and did not travel to Toronto, the film was in fact shown at the festival.

title: U.S. and Germany Plan to Recognize Kosovo
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia  The United States and Germany have agreed to recognize Kosovo after it declares independence and to urge the rest of Europe to follow suit, say senior European Union diplomats close to negotiations over Kosovos future.

title: Good Deal for NBC
description: NBC won a slim victory over second-place CBS in the ratings on Wednesday, largely because of its game-show programming at 8. Nielsen estimated that NBCs Deal or No Deal attracted more than double the audience for CBSs Power of 10, with 13.3 million viewers compared with 6.1 million. CBS led the 9 and 10 oclock time slots, however, with Criminal Minds (14.6 million) and CSI: NY (11.6 million), which outperformed NBCs Law & Order: Criminal Intent (9.6 million) and Law & Order (11 million), respectively. ABC ranked third for the night in total viewers, delivering decent results from Wife Swap at 8 (7.8 million) and Supernanny at 9 (8.9 million) but struggling at 10 with Cashmere Mafia (6.2 million). Among adults 18 to 49, ABC tied CBS for second place, just behind NBC. Fox, with repeats, was fourth over all.

title: Exit Another Idol Star
description: Add the name Katharine McPhee, to the growing list of American Idol contestants cast adrift from Sony-BMG labels. Ms. McPhee, the runner-up to Taylor Hicks in 2006 on the fifth season of Idol, has left RCA after a single album, Billboard reported. Last year her self-titled debut sold only 366,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Mr. Hicks and Ruben Studdard, the 2003 American Idol winner, recently parted ways with J Records, another Sony-BMG label.

title: Personal History, Captured in Plastic
description: Flip through your Jansons History of Art and there they are: sex, death and religion, arts old standbys, its holy trinity, on almost every page. Visit Keith Edmier 1991-2007, and youll find them still: alive, and weird, and living  or something like it  two hours north of New York City, at Bard College.

title: Herbert Keppler, 82, Dies; Covered Photo Gadgetry With Folksy Style
description: Herbert Keppler, a publisher and columnist at leading photographic magazines who advised amateur photographers on everything from lenses and shutter speeds to camera bags and tripods and who helped pioneer independent testing of camera equipment, died last Friday in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Mr. Keppler, who lived in that village, was 82.

title: Carefully Sorting Legal Chaos Out, With Duke Case as Unlikely Guide
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  After a night of heavy drinking just before Christmas break, three linemen on the North Carolina football team called 911 from an off-campus apartment. They were drunk, half-naked and bound at the wrists and ankles.

title: Credit Suisse Pursuing a Partnership in the Chinese Market
description: SHANGHAI  Amid signs that China may be opening its securities market to more foreign investment banks, Credit Suisse announced Thursday that it was seeking to form a joint venture with a Chinese brokerage firm, Founder Securities.

title: Delta Executives Consider Merger Talks
description: Executives of Delta Air Lines, facing increasingly grim economic conditions, plan to ask the carriers directors on Friday for permission to engage in merger discussions with United Airlines and Northwest Airlines, a step that could push the industrys much-talked-about need to consolidate closer to reality.

title: Teachers Union Is Leery of Effort to Limit Taxes
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzers plan to contain the rising property taxes that support New Yorks schools could mean a confrontation with the states largest teachers union, whose president said on Thursday he was wary of a new commission leading the effort.

title: Stern Looks on Bright Side of the League
description: Fans who are not worried about the Knicks are scarce in Manhattan, but N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern is one of those rare birds.

title: California Seeks Thermostat Control
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The conceit in the 1960s show The Outer Limits was that outside forces had taken control of your television set.

title: Defensive Leaks Lead to 5th Loss in a Row
description: When the Rangers latest dispiriting performance was over, littered with mistakes by some of their most accomplished players, the players sat quietly at their lockers absorbing the reality of a 6-2 loss to the Flyers on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: First-Year Giants Are Hazed but Helping
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The feet of the Giants rookie Steve Smith have been green for days, discolored by a dye discreetly placed in his socks. A dress shirt in his locker hung stripped of its sleeves. Across the locker room, Plaxico Burress explained.

title: Clinton to Seek Package to Lift Confidence in Economy
description: WASHINGTON  Adjusting her campaign to address increased fears of a recession, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Thursday that she would call for quick enactment of a $70 billion emergency spending package and for a possible $40 billion tax rebate later if economic conditions worsen.

title: Sony Joins Other Labels on Amazon MP3 Store
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sony BMG, the music company, announced Thursday that it would become the fourth and final major label to begin selling digital music on Amazon.com, offering its entire catalog in the MP3 format by the end of the month.

title: Archdiocese Is Target of Sickout at 10 Schools
description: This is an anxious time for the students of Cathedral High School. Midterms are next week; the SATs are the week after that.

title: Tide to Make Its Super Bowl Debut
description: THEY say time and tide wait for no man, but Tide has waited a long time to be advertised on the Super Bowl. Soon, Tide, the biggest detergent brand in America  sold by the biggest advertiser in America  will appear for the first time on the biggest day for advertising in America.

title: Metro-North Harlem Line From Fordham to Chappaqua
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: For Values-Based Produce, a Heroic Seafaring Quest
description: You dont have to go far into the press material for The Pirates Who Dont Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie before you hit the phrase faith-and-values-based property. It is used to describe this and earlier offerings from the VeggieTales franchise, but the faith component of this rather ordinary film for children doesnt make itself readily apparent.

title: Waking Up an Idle Hearth
description: NOTHING makes a winter getaway more inviting than that warm glow crackling in the fireplace. Since cave man times, we like to build a fire and poke around in it, said Ashley Eldridge, director of education for the Chimney Safety Institute of America.

title: Tiffanys Downturn Jolts Luxury Retailing
description: Not even luxury products are immune.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about the controversy over a plan by a Roman Catholic archbishop in Italy to exhume and place on display the body of Padre Pio, the popular Italian saint, misstated the number of years that elapsed between his death in 1968 and his canonization in 2002. It was almost 34 years, not four.

title: When an Apology Is Not Enough
description: It is one thing for network audio to capture Tiger Woods curse a bad shot, but another for a network announcer to say, as the Golf Channels Kelly Tilghman did last Friday, that one way for young golfers to stop Woods is to lynch him in a back alley.

title: In Lifes Web, Aiding Trees Can Kill Them
description: A few years ago, Todd Palmer, an ecologist at the University of Florida, was walking past a fenced-off research site in Kenya when he noticed something curious: instead of thriving, acacia trees that were protected from leaf-eating elephants and giraffes were withering and dying.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: One Dead After Attack on Transit Worker
description: A New York City Transit worker walking home after a late shift, three muggers armed with a curved knife and a bystander who somehow got caught in the middle: they all converged on a dark and rainy street in Upper Manhattan late Thursday in a blood-soaked frenzy that left the bystander stabbed to death and two others  including the transit worker  hospitalized.

title: New Yorks Overlooked Ski Resorts
description: DO you know which state has the most ski areas?

title: A Season for Big Works (and Two Grand Finales) at the Philharmonic
description: Eras, short and long, will end at the New York Philharmonic next season.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Thomas Sentenced to a Seat on the Bench
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The N.B.A. has decided not to fine or suspend Knicks Coach Isiah Thomas after he was ejected in the fourth quarter of the Knicks loss to the Houston Rockets on Wednesday night.

title: Patriots Get Back to the Basics: Stopping the Run
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The old Giants film is brought out sometimes, providing a turn-back-the-clock tutorial for the New England Patriots linebackers. Who better than Lawrence Taylor and Harry Carson  Hall of Fame players from Coach Bill Belichicks past  to emphasize a technique or provide a snapshot of a play. Or even to refresh Belichicks memory of how he coached them.

title: Indians Hit the Road Amid Elephants
description: NEW DELHI  A few weeks ago, the traditional Indian joint family household of Vineet Sharma, a fertilizer industry consultant, achieved a long deferred dream. Having ferried themselves on scooters all these years, the Sharmas bought a brand-new, silver-gray hatchback known as the Tata Indica.

title: Giant Write-Down Is Seen for Merrill
description: Merrill Lynch is expected to suffer $15 billion in losses stemming from soured mortgage investments, almost double its original estimate, prompting the firm to raise additional capital from an outside investor.

title: Manhattan: Sentence in Tour Managers Slaying
description: The companion of a man who was a former tour manager for the musicians Billy Joel and Paul Simon was sentenced Thursday in State Supreme Court to 23 years in prison for stabbing the man to death 26 months ago during a fight in their apartment. The companion, Kathleen Connors, 39, was sentenced on her guilty plea to a reduced charge of first-degree manslaughter in the slaying of the former manager, Daniel L. Harrison, 57, on Nov. 20, 2005. The police said when Ms. Connors was arrested that she and Mr. Harrison had argued violently in their Manhattan apartment, near Gracie Mansion, before the stabbing.

title: Two Old Friends Arraigned in Dead-Mans-Check Case
description: Two men who the police say wheeled the corpse of their friend up to a cash-checking shop in Hells Kitchen on Tuesday to try to cash his Social Security check face charges that include failing to bury the body soon enough, according to a criminal complaint.

title: Hot Prospect for Oils Big League
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  While some of the worlds largest oil producers, including Mexico and Iran, are struggling to remain exporters, Brazil is moving in the opposite direction. A huge underwater oil field discovered late last year has the potential to transform South Americas largest country into a sizable exporter and win it a seat at the table of the worlds oil cartel.

title: Pockets to Grandfathers: Times Lovely Face
description: Heres an apt attraction for the start of the new year: The Art of Time at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a wonderful presentation of about 90 European timepieces from the museums permanent collection. They range from pocket watches to grandfather clocks and date from the 16th to the 18th century. They include traditional mantel clocks in wooden, peaked-roofed houses and extravagantly fanciful forms like a revolving globe engraved with star charts and figures of the zodiac held up on the wingtips of a flying horse, all beautifully fashioned in silver, from 1579.

title: Rival to Georgias President Is Charged With Terrorism
description: MOSCOW  Prosecutors in Georgia on Thursday charged Badri Patarkatsishvili, a bitter rival of President Mikheil Saakashvili and a losing presidential candidate in the election last Saturday, with terrorism and conspiring to overthrow the government.

title: Europe and U.S. Diverge on Rate Prospects
description: FRANKFURT  Can Europes economy stay on track even if the United States goes off the rails?

title: Judge Queries Plan to Give Private Schools Priority on Randalls Island
description: A Manhattan judge on Thursday sharply questioned the citys decision to turn over primary use of the athletic fields on Randalls Island to a group of 20 private schools in Manhattan. The judge asked whether the city had failed to submit its plans to environmental reviews and to hold enough public hearings.

title: Newly Elected South Korean Leader Faces Inquiry
description: SEOUL  South Koreas Constitutional Court on Thursday authorized an independent prosecutor to investigate whether President-elect Lee Myung-bak engaged in financial misdeeds years before his landslide victory in elections on Dec. 19.

title: Democrats See Enthusiasm Gap in Their Favor
description: It used to be the credibility gap that afflicted politicians. Now Republicans and Democrats are peering over the edge of the enthusiasm gap.

title: Forget Pundits, Giuliani Says
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani began running the following television commercial on Thursday in Florida, where he is competing most heavily, urging voters not to discount him based on news media coverage of his losses in Iowa and New Hampshire:

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Middle-Class Capitalists
description: In 1974, a group of economists and journalists got together in a bar and launched supply-side economics. It was a superb political and economic package. It addressed a big problem: stagflation. It had a clear policy focus: marginal tax rates. It celebrated a certain sort of personality: the risk-taking entrepreneur. It made it clear that the new, growth-oriented Republican Party would be different from the old, green-eyeshade one.

title: Bush Outlines Mideast Peace Plan
description: JERUSALEM  President Bush outlined Thursday in the clearest terms so far the shape of a two-state peace treaty he is hoping to broker between Israel and the Palestinians by the end of his term.

title: Edmund Hillary, First on Everest, Dies at 88
description: Sir Edmund Hillary, the lanky New Zealand mountaineer and explorer who with Tenzing Norgay, his Sherpa guide, won worldwide acclaim in 1953 by becoming the first to scale the 29,035-foot summit of Mount Everest, the worlds tallest peak, died Friday in Auckland, New Zealand. He was 88.

title: Calls Grow for Bloomberg to Make Up His Mind
description: Nearly every day a tiny new development trickles out from the stealth presidential campaign of Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire mayor of New York.

title: Incident at Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Federal Trade Commissions hearings on green marketing misspelled the surname of the general manager of Gaiam, a yoga equipment company that offers carbon offsets to its customers. He is Chris Fisher, not Fischer. The article also misidentified the organization that U-Haul works with to provide carbon offsets. It is the Conservation Fund, not Carbonfund.org.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the coming Republican Party caucus in Michigan misstated the title of Craig DeRoche, shown speaking with Mitt Romney on board a plane. He is the minority leader of the Michigan House of Representatives; he is not the speaker.

title: Chrysler and Nissan in Production Deal
description: DETROIT  Chrysler and Nissan of Japan took the first step toward a possible broader alliance on Friday, reaching agreement for Nissan to supply Chrysler with a small car to be sold in South America.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Well column in Science Times on Jan. 1, about excessive clutter and compulsive hoarders, omitted the names of two authors of a book on the subject. Besides David F. Tolin, the book Buried in Treasures was written by Randy O. Frost and Gail Steketee.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A music review on Wednesday about Three Lost Chords, at the Zipper Factory Theater, misstated the surname of the composer at one point. As noted elsewhere in the review, he is Lance Horne, not Holmes. The review also referred incorrectly to the song in the section The Girl I Left Behind Me. It was written by Mr. Horne; it was not the British song of the same name. And schedule information gave an incorrect telephone number for the Zipper Factory Theater. It is (212) 352-3101.

title: Democracy by Other Means
description: Laikipia, Kenya

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Nice Journal article on Wednesday, about a struggle between the Russian government and local Russian Orthodox leaders over the Cathedral of St. Nicholas in Nice, France, described incorrectly the visit of Patriarch Aleksei II of Moscow to Notre Dame, the Roman Catholic cathedral of Paris. The Russian prelate went to Notre Dame to venerate the cathedrals celebrated relic, the Crown of Thorns. He did not celebrate Mass there. (Go to Article)

title: Bank Agrees to Buy Troubled Loan Giant for $4 Billion
description: Bank of America announced Friday that it had agreed to pay about $4 billion in stock to acquire Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: Poland and Czech Republic Team Up in Missile Defense Talks With U.S.
description: BERLIN  The governments of Poland and the Czech Republic agreed Thursday to coordinate their negotiations with the United States over its request to place elements of an antiballistic missile shield in those countries.

title: Inmates Are Recaptured, but Skirmish Over the Case Goes On
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.  The manhunt ended, the shouting match did not and the questions kept coming.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Bombs Iraqi Insurgent Hideouts
description: BAGHDAD  American bombers and fighter aircraft dropped 40,000 pounds of bombs on suspected militant hide-outs, storehouses and defensive positions in the southern outskirts of Baghdad on Thursday, the United States military said.

title: Wal-Marts Holiday Strategy Proved a Timely One
description: Twelve months ago, long before fears of a recession loomed, senior executives at Wal-Mart Stores hatched a plan to disrupt the marketplace during the 2007 holiday season, said Eduardo Castro-Wright, the chief executive of the companys United States division.

title: Literary Laurels
description: Five winners of Costa Book Awards, formerly the Whitbread Book Awards, have been chosen from 553 entries to compete for the 2007 Costa Book of the Year Award. They are the Costa Novel Award winner, Day, by A. L. Kennedy; the Costa First Novel Award winner, What Was Lost, by Catherine OFlynn; the Costa Biography Award winner, Young Stalin, by Simon Sebag Montefiore; the Costa Poetry Award winner, Tilt, by Jean Sprackland; and the Costa Childrens Book Award winner, The Bower Bird, by Ann Kelley. The winner, who receives about $49,000, will be announced in London on Jan. 22. ... Three books will compete for the $20,000 Story Prize, given for the years best short fiction, The Associated Press reported. They are Jim Shepards Like Youd Understand, Anyway, Vincent Lams Bloodletting & Miraculous Cures and Tessa Hadleys Sunstroke and Other Stories. The winner will be announced on Feb. 27.

title: Cuomo Subpoenas Intel Over Antitrust Accusations
