description: ALBANY  The New York State attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, issued a wide-ranging subpoena to the Intel Corporation on Thursday as part of an investigation into whether the company violated federal or state antitrust laws in the way that it priced and sold microprocessors.

title: Fish Out of Water in the Deep Blue Sea
description: Loved the shoes. Loathed the show.

title: Where TV Once Turned for Its Tables
description: Cheeseburger, cheeseburger  that was our diner stuff, Lloyd Kabram said. He was referring, as you may have guessed, to the John Belushi routine on Saturday Night Live.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Britain: Lethal Bird Flu at Famed Swan Reserve
description: The deadly H5N1 strain of avian flu has reached one of Englands most famous swan breeding grounds, the Abbotsbury Swannery on the Dorset coast. Tests on three dead mute swans confirmed the virus, spread by wild birds. The manager said he was working to determine how many swans might be affected.

title: Help With One Months Rent Mends a Familys Safety Net
description: Lilia and Rolando Solis, both 39, immigrated to New York City from Mexico 11 years ago, searching for a better way to provide for their family. Its hard, but we think that we have to do it, so we have a better life, a better future, for the kids, Mr. Solis said.

title: Stocks Drop Sharply Amid Subprime Woes
description: In many ways, the markets seem to be stuck in a loop.

title: As Military Seeks Site, a Move to Protect Rolling Acres
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.  A few months ago, when Wesleyan University announced that it would create 10 scholarships to encourage military veterans to study here, school officials and students talked of welcoming them with open arms.

title: NYSE Urges China to Be Flexible on Where Companies Raise Capital
description: PARIS  NYSE Euronext, the merged trans-Atlantic stock exchange, is lobbying the Chinese government to raise standards of corporate governance and loosen rules on where companies can raise capital as part of an effort to win business from rival markets in cities like London and Hong Kong.

title: Mend Your Foolish Ways, Would-Be Church Bandits
description: Ice Cubes recent movie roles, in the Barbershop and Are We There Yet? franchises, have emphasized his cuddly, family-man side. In First Sunday, which is not a new installment in the earlier Friday series, he departs a bit from the upright-citizen persona, playing a man driven to crime by desperate circumstances.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Wholesale Inventories Rise, Suggesting Output May Fall
description: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  Inventories at wholesalers rose more than forecast in November and sales increased, reflecting rising prices for oil and farm products, the government reported on Thursday.

title: When the Family Ski Trip Is What Brings You All Together
description: KATE cant ski tomorrow.

title: Colombian Rebels Free 2 Hostages
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombian guerrillas freed two politically prominent hostages on Thursday, handing them over to emissaries of President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela in a breakthrough in mediation efforts with Latin Americas largest rebel group.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Dec. 11 about the effort to develop a malaria vaccine using live, weakened parasites grown in mosquitoes referred imprecisely to the financing of a rival vaccine invented by Dr. Pierre Druilhe, a malaria expert at the Pasteur Institute in France. Dr. Druilhe and the Gates Foundation broke off discussions over a grant for vaccine development; his project was not rejected by the foundation.

title: South Korea: Court Rules for Inquiry of President-Elect
description: The Constitutional Court cleared the way for a special prosecutor to start an investigation into allegations of links by President-elect Lee Myung-bak to a 2001 stock manipulation scheme. The inquiry is to be finished before his swearing-in on Feb. 25.

title: Cuomo Remark in an Interview Takes Clarifying
description: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos staff spent much of Thursday explaining Mr. Cuomos use of shuck and jive, a term with racial overtones, during a radio interview on Wednesday about the presidential race.

title: Viceroy Anguilla and the Orchard at the Carneros Inn
description: Viceroy Anguilla

title: British Arts Cuts Inspire Protests
description: The outcry from London theater professionals has been growing in response to proposals by Arts Council England, the government arts-development agency, to cut or eliminate financing for nearly 200 arts organizations. At a meeting on Wednesday at the Young Vic theater in London that was attended by hundreds of actors, including Kevin Spacey and Ian McKellen, members of the British actors union lashed out at the Arts Council, passing a no confidence motion against the agency, the BBC reported. Tom Stoppard, Salman Rushdie and Harold Pinter were among dozens signing a letter of protest on behalf of the Bush Theater, which is facing a proposed cut of about $353,000, nearly 40 percent of its government funds. Josie Rourke, the artistic director of the Bush, said that the proposed cuts appeared to be based on inaccurate data. At the meeting on Wednesday the arts councils chief executive, Peter Hewitt, responded by saying that 80 new organizations would get money and three-quarters of the groups now receiving funds would receive an increase under the proposals.

title: Blackstone to Buy Hedge Fund to Strengthen Credit Operations
description: The Blackstone Group said Thursday that it had agreed to buy GSO Capital Partners, a $10 billion hedge fund, for as much as $930 million in cash and stock as it seeks to build its credit operations amid tough market conditions.

title: Of a Birthday and a Baby, on the Very Edge of Mime
description: On Wednesday Performance Space 122 opened its Coil festival. This is promoted as featuring some of the best up-and-coming artists in New Yorks underground performance scene, but it also includes Cest Duckie, an annual sensation in London for several consecutive Christmas seasons.

title: Art in Review
description: THE HAND-DRAWN

title: Americana Dealer Cleans House
description: If its January, its Americana time in New York. The viewings of American antiques, folk art, ceramics and paintings begin on Saturday at Sothebys and Christies before next weeks auctions. And this season the most talked-about sale is probably the personal collection of the veteran dealer Marguerite Riordan of Stonington, Conn.

title: American Express Warns About Earnings
description: American Express forecast first-quarter earnings below analysts estimates on Thursday and adopted a cautious view for 2008 because of a slowing economy.

title: Cast in Stone
description: Fiona Shaw is indisputably the queen of the mountain in Deborah Warners blazing production of Samuel Becketts Happy Days, an import from the National Theater in London that opened this week at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Notice that I say mountain, not molehill.

title: Face Time: Masks, Animal to Video
description: The mask is one of the most basic and recognizable of all forms, and for good reason. One way early humans made sense of the universe was to personify its forces, and the most visible form of personification was the face. Masks have long been central to religious rituals, serving as tools of transformation and bridges to the spirit world. They have figured in ceremonies intended to ensure fertility and raise the dead, make crops grow and rain fall, kill enemies, ward off evil and cure sickness. They have been used by soldiers and celebrators of Lent, astronauts and action heroes, hockey players and fencers, firefighters and welders.

title: A New Clinton, Going Door to Door in Nevada, Asks for Help
description: LAS VEGAS  The all-new, listening and accessible Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took her message door to door on Thursday night in a heavily Hispanic working-class neighborhood near downtown Las Vegas. She knocked on doors with campaign workers, urging voters to caucus for her in the coming Democratic contest.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the mens college basketball East roundup on Dec. 16 about Niagaras upset victory at St. Johns misstated the year that Niagara last beat St. Johns. It was 2004  not 1963, which was the last time Niagara won at Carnesecca Arena (formerly Alumni Hall).

title: California: Supervisor Resigns
description: Ed Jew resigned from the San Francisco Board of Supervisors as part of a legal settlement with the city for lying about living in the district he represents. Mr. Jew, 47, was accused of living in the city of Burlingame when elected in 2006 to represent the outlying Sunset District in San Francisco, a violation of election rules. He still faces two criminal cases for state election code violations and a federal bribery and extortion case in connection with what the authorities say was a scam to obtain city permits for several business owners, in exchange for $84,000. Already on suspension from the Board of Supervisors, Mr. Jews resignation ends two local battles over misconduct with San Francisco authorities.

title: Symphony President in Cincinnati to Retire
description: Steven Monder, the president of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, will retire in June after 37 years, the orchestra announced. Mr. Monder, 62, joined as a production manager in 1971 and has held the orchestras top executive position  with varying titles  since 1976. During his tenure the Cincinnati Pops was created, the Riverbend Music Center was opened on the banks of the Ohio River, and since 1979 the orchestra has released more than 100 recordings on the Telarc label, with worldwide sales of nearly 10 million.

title: Manhattan: Former Immigration Official Sentenced
description: A former supervisor with the federal Citizenship and Immigration Services office in New York was sentenced in Federal District Court on Thursday to 42 months in prison for taking bribes in exchange for granting citizenship to ineligible applicants, prosecutors said. The defendant, Jimmie Ortega, 59, of Lindenhurst, N.Y., admitted that from 2004 to 2006, he used his position as an adjudications officer to obtain citizenship for at least 20 immigrants in exchange for payments of $1,500 to $4,000, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Ortega, who retired in April 2006, pleaded guilty last July to conspiracy and soliciting bribes, prosecutors said.

title: Take the Kids, and Dont Feel Guilty
description: Over the last few years, in the course of many parent conferences and elementary-school curriculum nights, Ive become familiar with the concept of the just-right book. This, my childrens teachers patiently explain, is a book that is perfectly suited to a childs reading ability: neither too easy, in which case he or she will grow bored, nor too difficult, which risks frustration and confusion.

title: Charles M. Taylor, 78, Atlanta Real Estate Developer, Is Dead
description: Charles M. Taylor, one of the major real estate developers of Buckhead, an affluent northern section of Atlanta, where high-rise office towers, condominium buildings and boutique malls dot a landscape of mansions tucked into forests, died Saturday at his home in Buckhead. He was 78.

title: Alabama: Father Now Denies Tossing Children
description: A man accused of tossing his four young children off a coastal bridge denies killing them and says the police harassed him into making a false confession, his lawyer said. The authorities say the man, Lam Luong, 37, of Irvington, confessed to killing the children, ranging in age from a few months to 3 years, a day after reporting them missing and claiming a woman had taken them. But Mr. Luongs appointed lawyer, Joe Kulakowski, said his client told him he had falsely confessed under pressure after being questioned Monday night and the entire day Tuesday. Search crews have found no sign of the children.

title: Knoblauch Ends Silence About Report From Mitchell
description: HOUSTON  In his first public comments since the Mitchell report was released last month, the former Yankee Chuck Knoblauch said on Thursday that he was not angry about being named in the report, although he did not explicitly admit that he had used human growth hormone, as the report asserts.

title: The Will (if Not Triumph) of the Frau
description: The life of Leni Riefenstahl, the filmmaker who made movies for Hitler, has been examined and critiqued aplenty, but rarely so entertainingly as in Amazons and Their Men, a brash play by Jordan Harrison receiving a lively production by Clubbed Thumb at the Ohio Theater.

title: Vermont: Proposal to Lease Lottery
description: Gov. Jim Douglas proposed leasing the state lottery to a private company to raise more than $50 million for schools and for property tax reduction. The governor, a Republican who took office in 2003, unveiled the plan in his State of the State address after broaching the idea last month with the lottery commission. Other states including California and Florida are considering selling or leasing such public assets amid a slowdown in tax revenue. A private company would pay the state $23 million a year to operate the lottery under a 40-year lease, on top of a $56 million upfront payment, according to Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., which Mr. Douglas hired to analyze the plan.

title: Poor December at Retailers; Most Report Drops in Sales
description: The weakest holiday shopping season in five years ended dismally for most retailers, whose sales tumbled despite deep discounts and extended store hours, stoking fears that the economy is tipping into a recession.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: A Gruesome Find, and a Mother Is Accused of Murders
description: WASHINGTON  United States marshals made a gruesome discovery on Wednesday when they went to evict Banita M. Jacks from her home  the decomposed bodies of Ms. Jackss four daughters.

title: Jurors in a Cape Cod Murder Case Testify About Racial Remarks
description: BARNSTABLE, Mass.  More than a year after it convicted a black trash hauler of a shocking murder on Cape Cod, a jury returned to court here Thursday for an extraordinary hearing on whether racism influenced its verdict.

title: Civil Rights Tone Prompts Talk of an Endorsement
description: WASHINGTON  Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina, the highest-ranking African-American in Congress, said he was rethinking his neutral stance in his states presidential primary out of disappointment at comments by Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton that he saw as diminishing the historic role of civil rights activists.

title: Study Finds Possible Targets for H.I.V. Drugs
description: Using a new type of genetic screen, researchers at Harvard Medical School have identified 273 proteins that the AIDS virus needs to survive in human cells, opening up new potential targets for drugs.

title: Theater Listings
description: UNDER THE RADAR If you wander into Veselka restaurant anytime between noon and midnight these days, you may not realize that the folks sitting at one table are both actors and audience members for an unusual two-person production, courtesy of Rotozaza, a London theater company. The show, Etiquette, which opened in London almost a year ago, has visited several countries since and was presented at the Theater Communications Group conference at the Guthrie Theater last June (with Sunder Ganglani and Anne Erbe, below).

title: Horses Spared in U.S. Face Death Across the Border
description: SHIPSHEWANA, Ind.  At the weekly horse auction here, No. 274, a handsome chestnut-colored draft horse, looked at the surrounding men while being led into a small ring. Two of the men looked back, calculating how much meat the animals carcass would yield, and started bidding accordingly.

title: Baseball and Union Discuss the Mitchell Reports Recommendations
description: Representatives for Major League Baseball and the players union met this week to discuss the recommendations in the Mitchell report that require the consent of both sides.

title: Bank Agrees to Buy Troubled Loan Giant for $4 Billion
description: Bank of America announced Friday that it has agreed to pay about $4 billion in stock to acquire Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: Weinstein Company Makes a Deal With Guild Writers
description: LOS ANGELES  The Weinstein Company, one of Hollywoods biggest independent film companies, has completed a separate agreement with striking writers, according to Harvey Weinstein, the companys co-founder.

title: Marines Body Reportedly Found
description: The mystery of a missing pregnant marine may turn out to be a homicide. Lance Cpl. Maria Lauterbach, who disappeared from Camp Lejeune on December 14, is believed to be dead, said Sheriff Ed Brown, of the North Carolina county where the military facility is located.

title: Manhattan: Man Is Fatally Shot Outside Club
description: A 32-year-old Queens man was fatally shot early Thursday outside a West Side nightclub, the police said. The man, Brione Schneider, was shot once in the back about 3:45 a.m. after a dispute with another man that began inside the club, Stereo, and spilled into the street, the police said. He was taken to St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan and pronounced dead about 4:40 a.m., the police said. Detectives are investigating reports that the dispute was over a woman and say they believe that the assailant, who was still being sought Thursday, left the club first and may have retrieved a 9-millimeter gun from a car, the police said. Brad Zeifman, a spokesman for the club, on West 29th Street, said in a statement that the club was not aware of any prior altercation inside. The police said they brought nuisance abatement proceedings against the club last year because of drug activity, assaults and under-age drinking.

title: Gift for Miami Arts
description: The $461 million performing arts center in Miami, entering its second year and struggling financially, has received a $30 million infusion. As a result of the gift, announced on Thursday, the complex will be renamed in honor of the donor, Adrienne Arsht, a lawyer, business executive and philanthropist. Previously known as the Carnival Center for the Performing Arts, it will be named the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts of Miami-Dade County. The center is to receive the money over the next three years. Of the total, $13 million will be received immediately. Of that amount, $4 million will be allocated to programming; $7 million will be applied to a bank loan; and $2 million will be refunded to the Carnival Corporation, which relinquished its naming rights. It had a 10-year, $10 million agreement with the center.

title: New Yorkers Pay More to Keep Their Homes Warm
description: New York residents are being hit with an unusual combination this week: unseasonably warm weather and maddeningly large heating bills.

title: U.S. Nuclear Envoy Puts Gentle Pressure on North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The United States urged North Korea on Thursday to rethink its position and give a complete and correct accounting of its nuclear weapons programs before a new conservative South Korean president takes office in late February, perhaps with more sticks than carrots for the North.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column in some copies on Tuesday about the discovery of a body in a cesspool behind the home of a Long Island man missing for 19 months misspelled the given name of the man. He was Nicolo Caietta, not Nicholas.

title: Homeland Security on the Hustings
description: Voters in the 2008 elections need to hear in detail how the presidential candidates intend to wrestle the sprawling homeland security apparatus into sync with the true state of the terrorist threat. That critical connection has become befogged in years of hyperbolic alarms, official ineptitude, enormous spending and political sleight of hand.

title: Endorsing Obama, Kerry Calls Him Leader of Wisdom, Instinct and Vision
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John Kerry embraced the presidential candidacy of Senator Barack Obama on Thursday, praising him as the only Democrat in the race who can inspire a movement to dislodge Washington partisanship and create a new image around the world.

title: Europes Next Rate Move May Be an Increase
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Thursday but signaled that it could raise it pre-emptively if generous wage deals threatened to ignite inflation.

title: The Primary, Upon Further Dissection
description: To the Editor:

title: A Youthful Awakening to Mother Natures Laws in a Turkish Village
description: Livestock far outnumber humans in Times and Winds, Reha Erdems transporting vision of life in a mountain village in northwest Turkey as seen through the eyes of three children on the verge of adolescence. Make no mistake: The movie, for all its majestic shots of the rocky landscape and of the moon skittering behind clouds, is not a lump-in-your-throat portrait of the noble poor living in harmony with the elements.

title: Congressman in Inquiry on Lobbying Will Retire
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John T. Doolittle, a California Republican who has suggested he is almost certain to face criminal charges in a Congressional lobbying scandal, announced Thursday that he would retire from the House next year.

title: Pushing Back as Columbia Moves to Spread Out
description: NICHOLAS SPRAYREGEN, the Upper Manhattan property owner who has dueled to a standoff with an acquisition-minded Columbia University in the real estate version of a whoever has the most toys, wins competition, knows better than to ask for a sympathy vote.

title: Northern Rock Sells Some Assets
description: LONDON  Northern Rock, one of Britains biggest casualties of the credit crisis, sold part of its mortgage portfolio on Friday to JPMorgan Chase as it seeks to repay about 25 billion, or $49 billion, in emergency financing.

title: Tina Brown to Write Book on the Clintons
description: Tina Brown, the former editor of Vanity Fair, The New Yorker and Talk magazine, has signed with Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group to write a portrait of the Clinton era, to be titled The Clinton Chronicles, in an echo of The Diana Chronicles, her best-selling book about Diana, Princess of Wales. The new book, scheduled for publication in 2010, will cover the lives of Bill and Hillary Clinton and also reflect on the social and political contexts of their rises to power. I really felt that the Clinton story is such a sort of thrilling roller coaster of a story that also enabled me to write about the media and social culture of the era in which theyve dominated the stage, Ms. Brown said in an interview. The media has played a large part in that, with the rise of the Drudge moment and the blogosphere, and thats the sort of material that speaks to me.

title: Bank May Buy Troubled Giant in Home Loans
description: Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis, is close to being acquired by Bank of America for slightly more than $4 billion in stock, people briefed on the transaction said Thursday.

title: Spate of Executions and Amputations in Iran
description: TEHRAN  Using strict enforcement of Islamic law, the judicial authorities in a restive region of southern Iran amputated the right hands and left feet of five convicted robbers this week, part of what the government said was an effort to deter other troublemakers.

title: Banks Plead They Cant Follow Rules
description: When you are shoveling money, keeping track of the paperwork is an awful burden.

title: Bomb Kills at Least 23 in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber approached a crowd of police officers outside a courthouse in Lahore on Thursday and set off a powerful explosion, killing at least 23 people and wounding 58, police officials said.

title: For Many a Follower, Sacred Ground in Colorado
description: TRUST an unknown future with a known God, urges the sign in front of the Sangre de Cristo Christian Church on the outskirts of Crestone, Colo., which is close to a four-hour drive south of Denver off Highway 17. The town might seem to be in the middle of nowhere, but if youre seeking a taste of the divine, youve probably come to the right place.

title: Britain Shows New Enthusiasm for Nuclear Power Plants
description: PARIS  The British government on Thursday approved plans to refresh the countrys fleet of nuclear reactors, signaling new enthusiasm for the technology and giving a lift to the industry.

title: Apples Customer Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Trenton: New Jersey Chemical Rules Stand
description: The federal government will not override New Jerseys chemical security laws, which are tougher than the national standard, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg announced Thursday. A measure, promoted by Senator Lautenberg and recently signed by President Bush, insulates all states from federal pre-emption, and allows them to pass laws protecting their residents from an attack on chemical facilities within their borders. The co-chairmen of the Sept. 11 Commission, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean and former Representative Lee H. Hamilton, joined the National Governors Association and the National Conference of State Legislatures in supporting the measure.

title: An Arizona Road Trip on the Edge of America
description: AS you enter the Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument in southern Arizona, its not the parks namesake plant, thick with a cluster of many branches, that inspires gasps of awe, but thousands of saguaro, the iconic tall cactus of countless Western films. Upright and lanky, with whimsically outstretched arms, one after another the saguaros wave you in.

title: Off-Road Vehicles
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Observatory column in Science Times on Tuesday, about research on ocean acidification, referred incorrectly to the experiments. They were intended to determine whether lower ocean pH, not higher pH, affected a certain type of algae. (On the pH scale, which runs from 0 to 14, the lower the number the greater the acidity.)

title: Campaign Turns to Economic Concerns
description: WASHINGTON  With the economy trumping all other issues, at least for the moment, Democrats and Republicans were trying on Friday to generate momentum for a variety of moves that they said were designed to keep the country from sinking into recession.

title: Whats on the Art Box? Spins, Satire and Camp
description: You are the product of TV, declares Television Delivers People, Richard Serras six-minute 1973 video screed of scrolling text set to elevator music. If Mr. Serra were to recreate the piece today, he might call it People Deliver Television.

title: No Immunity Deal
description: We suppose we shouldnt be surprised. Yet another player in the Bush administrations break-all-the-rules war against terrorism is trying to evade accountability.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: The Comeback Continent
description: Today Id like to talk about a much-derided contender making a surprising comeback, a comeback that calls into question much of the conventional wisdom of American politics. No, Im not talking about a politician. Im talking about an economy  specifically, the European economy, which many Americans assume is tired and spent but has lately been showing surprising vitality.

title: Owens Practices but Is a Game-Time Decision
description: IRVING, Tex.  The secrecy surrounding the status of Dallas Cowboys receiver Terrell Owens diminished slightly Thursday, enough to reveal indications that he will play Sunday in the teams playoff game against the Giants.

title: Burned by Investing in Troubled Times
description: Bank of America had hoped for a tidy profit when it bought a $2 billion stake in Countrywide Financial and tried to stanch the mortgage lenders bleeding.

title: Lawmakers Ask Justice Dept. for Information on Monitors
description: WASHINGTON  The chairmen of the House and Senate Judiciary Committees joined in asking the Justice Department on Thursday for details of contracts that the department directed to former Attorney General John Ashcroft and other outside lawyers who are monitoring companies in out-of-court settlements of criminal allegations.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Nice Journal article on Wednesday, about a struggle between the Russian government and local Russian Orthodox leaders over the Cathedral of St. Nicholas in Nice, France, described incorrectly the visit of Patriarch Aleksei II of Moscow to Notre Dame, the Roman Catholic cathedral of Paris. The Russian prelate went to Notre Dame to venerate the cathedrals celebrated relic, the Crown of Thorns. He did not celebrate Mass there.

title: Rikers Island: Jail Death Investigated
description: City health officials are investigating the death of a 17-year-old arrested on sexual misconduct charges who apparently committed suicide while jailed at Rikers Island. Jessica Scaperotti, a Health Department spokeswoman, told El Diario/La Prensa on Wednesday that the city would undertake a thorough investigation of the death of the teenager, David Mercado of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Mr. Mercado, who was arrested on Dec. 17, was placed in a dormitory with 50 other prisoners even though a state judge in Queens flagged the youth as a suicide risk, the newspaper reported. Correction officials said Rikers Island medical staff did not deem it necessary to place Mr. Mercado under observation. Mr. Mercados lawyers said he hanged himself with a sheet less than 24 hours after arriving.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $5,836,670

title: A Trail to Your Door
description: Ive been Nordic skiing seriously since 1974, and Ive been coaching for five years. Right now Im the head coach for the Minnetonka Nordic Ski Team at Minnetonka High School. Ive been coaching the senior class since they were freshmen, and its fantastic. Its definitely cool to follow through with one group over four years like this.

title: Fed Chief Signals Further Rate Cut
description: Presenting a bleak picture of a deteriorating national economy, Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, strongly suggested on Thursday that the Fed would cut interest rates soon, perhaps by a large amount.

title: Exchanges in Latest Debate Highlight a New Dynamic in the Republican Field
description: Fred D. Thompson tried to salvage his faltering presidential campaign at a debate Thursday night with a barrage of sharp attacks on the liberal policies of Mike Huckabee, the fellow Southerner whom he clearly sees as a rival in the South Carolina primary.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Greetings, Earthlings. Your New Restroom Is Ready.
description: When New York Citys open-armed embrace of tourists finally extends beyond the boundaries of Earth to creatures from outer space, these visitors will find themselves right at home in Madison Square Parks sleek, shiny new public toilet.

title: Celebrating Barristers in Temple!?
description: London is full of hidden secrets, one of which is Temple, an area steeped in history. Here, you can find the hall where Shakespeare premiered Twelfth Night in 1602 (Middle Temple Hall), as well as Temple Church (built by the Knights Templar in 1185) which is featured in Dan Browns The Da Vinci Code. It was used as the location in the film.Hall From Garden  credit  reproduced by kind permission of the Masters of the Bench of the Honourable Society of the Middle Temple

title: Bidding on Loose Horses
description: An auction for doomed horses in Shipshewana, Ind.

title: Williams team deal with Baugur Group
description: According to a very good source, the Williams team last night sold one third interest of the team to the Baugur Group, an Icelandic investment company that specializes in retail, media and finances. Among other properties, Baugur owns a supermarket chain in Iceland, a retail chain in Denmark, and in the UK the Hamleys toy store and the House of Fraser department store.

title: N.H.L. Halfway Standings
description: On Thursday night the last two N.H.L. teams reached the regular seasons halfway point (for the record, Philadelphia and St. Louis, and they both won), enabling us to bring you the leagues halfway standings.

title: 'Intern'
description: I had been an intern less than an hour, and already I was running late. The sloping footpath leading up to the hospital was paved with gray cobblestones. My feet ached as my oversize leather sandals slipped on the rounded irregular rocks. The hospital was an old building browned by the passage of two centuries, with spidery cracks in its faade. Founded in 1771, New York Hospital is the second-oldest hospital in the United States, a mecca for doctors and patients from all over the world. I had been in the building once before, six months ago, for a residency interview. I spun through a revolving brass door, nearly running into the burly security guard reading the New York Post. He looked up from the tabloid just long enough to point me in the direction of the elevator.

title: Afghanistan's Police Force
description: Afghanistan's police force, lightly equipped, marginally trained and undermined by corruption, struggles to police a country that lacks the rule of law.

title: World Biggest Demolition Derby?
description: India, home of the worlds cheapest car  and millions of buyers whove never been behind the wheel, like the Sharma family:

title: No, Let ME Chop That Onion
description: Highlights from your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Credit Suisse Pursues a Partnership in China
description: Amid signs that China may be opening its securities market to more foreign investment banks, Credit Suisse announced Thursday that it was seeking to form a joint venture with a Chinese brokerage firm, Founder Securities.

title: NYSE Urges China for More Listing Flexibility
description: NYSE Euronext, the merged trans-Atlantic stock exchange, is lobbying the Chinese government to raise standards of corporate governance and loosen rules on where companies can raise capital as part of an effort to win business from rival markets in cities like London and Hong Kong.

title: Would a Monster Move Make Sense for Murdoch?
description: Despite News Corporations denial of rumors that it was in talks to buy online recruiting giant Monster Worldwide for $4.8 billion, Breakingviews thinks such a deal could make sense for Rupert Murdochs media company.

title: Brazils Telemar Talks Up a Deal for Brasil Telecom
description: Telemar Participacoes , the owner of Brazils largest fixed-line phone carrier, said its in talks to take over Brasil Telecom Participacoes to gain control of almost two-thirds of the countrys land lines, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Brian Regan on Emergency Care
description: This Comedy Central regular has noticed some overlooked problems of going to the emergency room, like the lack of valet parking

title: F.C.C. Said to Approve Clear Channel Deal
description: Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital Partners appear to have jumped one significant regulatory hurdle for their deal to buy Clear Channel Communications, but investors still seem jittery about whether or not the deal will actually close.

title: After 16 Years, Southeast Bank May Rise from the Dead
description: A New York investment bank plans to inject $1.5 billion into Southeast Banking, a company thats been in bankruptcy for more than 16 years but still has $800 million worth of unused net operating loss carry-forwards, which apply past losses to future profits.

title: Young Broadcasting to Shop San Francisco Station
description: Young Broadcasting of New York said Thursday that it had retained Moelis & Company, the advisory firm founded by the former UBS banker Ken Moelis, to shop San Franciscos KRON-TV, which it acquired in 2000 for $823 million.

title: Fund to Oppose Macrovision-Gemstar Deal
description: Macrovision investors showed their displeasure with the companys pending $2.4 billion bid for television-listings provider Gemstar-TV Guide International by stampeding for the exits soon after the deal was announced in December.

title: Chinas Tencent Leads $11 Million Round for Outspark
description: Venture capital flowing from Silicon Valley to China is old news. Whats new are the investment dollars trickling back from Chinas fast-growing economy.

title: In Macau, a $1 Billion Casino I.P.O. With More Expected
description: A $1 billion initial public offering planned by the tycoon Stanley Hos Macau flagship company is giving investors a rare chance to bet on a casino boom that has been financed mostly by loans, but more raising of capital on public markets is in the cards.

title: Bears Said to Eye Stake in China Asset Management
description: Bear Stearns is in talks to buy around 10 percent of Chinas biggest fund house, China Asset Management, to tap the countrys red-hot mutual fund market, Reuters reported.

title: Canopy Nabs $15 Million in First Round
description: Canopy Financial announced a $15 million first institutional round of capital from Granite Global Ventures on Thursday.

title: Ze-gen Raises $2.5 Million from Pinnacle
description: Ze-gen, a company that has a process for converting municipal waste into electricity, has raised $2.5 million to fund construction of its first full-scale plant.

title: G.E. Executive to Join Private Equity Firm
description: The vice chairman and chief executive of the $28 billion General Electrics GE Industrial unit, Lloyd G. Trotter, will step down next month to join a small New York buyout firm called GenNx360 Capital Partners, BusinessWeek reported.

title: Buffett Raises Burlington Stake
description: Warren Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway bought 29,600 more shares of Burlington Northern Santa Fe stock, giving Berkshire ownership of 17.4 percent of the nations second-largest railroad.

title: Synergy Closes $143 Million Debut Fund
description: Synergy Life Science Partners on Thursday announced that it had wrapped up its debut fund with $143 million in committed capital, making it one of a dwindling number of firms to raise a first-time investment vehicle.

title: 2 CBOT Traders Charged With Fraud
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission on Thursday charged two traders with defrauding investors by as much as $2.1 million in a carefully timed deal at the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Hedge Funds Said to Put Pressure on Canadas Nexen
description: Hedge fund managers are stepping up their campaign to break up or sell the Canadian energy giant Nexen, whose stock has gone sideways over the past year, The Globe and Mail reported.

title: Burned by Investing in Troubled Times
description: Bank of America had hoped for a tidy profit when it bought a $2 billion stake in Countrywide Financial and tried to stanch the mortgage lenders bleeding.

title: Giant Write-Down Is Seen for Merrill
description: Merrill Lynch is expected to suffer $15 billion in losses stemming from soured mortgage investments, almost double its original estimate, prompting the firm to raise additional capital from an outside investor.

title: London Bay Wraps $130 Million for Selling Source
description: London Bay Capital, a mid-market private equity firm, said it had completed its $130 million acquisition of Selling Source, an online marketer of specialty finance services.

title: Predicting the Hot Tech I.P.Os of 2008
description: Just because the U.S. economy might be looking at a recession, doesnt mean a few good tech initial public offerings cant light up the market, says Fortune.

title: BofA to Buy Countrywide for $4 Billion
description: Bank of America said early Friday it would buy Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis, in an all-stock deal valued at $4 billion.

title: Buyout Bust Cuts Into Fees to Banks, Report Finds
description: The decline in leveraged buyouts is slashing fees for investment banks, including Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan Chase, by about 50 percent, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Northern Rock to Sell Portfolio to JPMorgan
description: Britains troubled Northern Rock has sold a 2.2 billion pound ($4.3 billion) portfolio of mortgages to JPMorgan Chase, a first step to help the troubled lender repay loans from the Bank of England, Reuters reported.

title: UBS Seeks to Raise Billions from Foreign Investors
description: UBS began its campaign to win support for plans to raise $17.6 billion in new capital following the consequences of the United States subprime crisis, but warned shareholders 2008 was likely to be another generally difficult year, The Financial Times reported.

title: Standard Chartered Signs Deal for South Korea Bank
description: Standard Chartered signed an agreement on Friday to buy a mutual savings bank from South Koreas government restructuring agency for a reported 150 billion won ($160.3 million).

title: Tatas Nano and Global Warming
description: The worlds cheapest car, launched this week by Indias Tata Motors, seems to herald a mobility revolution for people in the developing world. Millions of consumers each year could leap virtually overnight from the indignity of two-wheeled motor scooters to the relative luxury of four wheels and a roof.

title: Kellwoods Throwback Playbook
description: In fending off a potentially hostile bid from Sun Capital Partners, Kellwood, the apparel maker, is using a tactic straight from the great takeover battles of the 1980s.

title: Worries about the Fed (a wonkish post)
description: The signs point increasingly to an imminent, or perhaps already begun, recession. Ben Bernanke has in effect pledged to do whatever is necessary. But does the Fed have what it takes?

title: Hype-notized
description: New Yorker film critic David Denby has turned into the thinking mans Pete Travers, the master of breathless reviews at Rolling Stone. Mr. Denby not only suggested that Paul Thomas Anderson fumbled the end of a There Will be Blood on purpose, he took the froth on the latte by declaring that The Diving Bell and the Butterfly feels like nothing less than the rebirth of cinema. Vulture called that the blurbiest blurb ever blurbed.

title: Is J.P. Morgan in Deal Mode?
description: Is J.P. Morgan Chase going to do a deal?

title: Do as We Do, Not Just as We Say
description: The Writers Guild of America, showing good manners and an ear for the moment, announced that they will not hold their awards show on Feb. 9. The thought of holding their own fete while shutting down others seemed a little too, too, the Bagger guesses. It puts all the more attention on the Screen Actors Guild awards, which will be held on Jan. 27. So far, only SAGs awards show is expected to go off as planned, and with the consent and participation of the A-List.

title: Managing Up
description: Tom Hanks was his usual polite self in addressing the whole Oscars-in-peril scenario, but his meaning was clear:

title: The Early Word: Its the Economy
description: Some campaigns have been shuttling between Nevada, Michigan and South Carolina, highlighting different issues depending on their constituencies.

title: Stalag 17
description: The Bagger is wheeling up for a weekend of fun and frolic in LA, keynoted by this bit of news in Variety.

title: Time for the Mayor to Make Up His Mind?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs flirtation with the idea of running for president has stretched on and on, with his enthusiastic approval despite his public denials. But even before actually entering the contest, Mr. Bloomberg may have already risked losing peoples patience, Diane Cardwell and Ray Rivera write in a front-page article, noting signs of an emerging backlash. Editorial pages from The Wall Street Journal to The New York Post, The Village Voice and The New Yorker have taken him to task. Members of the administration have been rolling their eyes and referring to Kevin Sheekey, Mr. Bloombergs political architect, as the deputy mayor for presidential politics.

title: Now It Gets Really Ugly
description: How petty can it get in the throw-down between Big Media and the writers? Really, really petty. A rep from one of the publicity firms told the Bagger that ABC sent out an email to all publicists for ABC-affiliated stars who were nominated for the SAG awards on Jan. 27. The rep said the email suggested the stars would have to foot the bill for hairstyling and makeup because the ABC didnt want to pay for what it expects will be a studio-bashing event.

title: CNBC Stirs JPMorgan-WaMu Talk
description: Charlie Gasparino of CNBC discusses talk of a link-up between JPMorgan and Washington Mutual.

title: Kucinich: Recount Redux
description: Democrat Dennis Kucinich, who won less than 2 percent of the vote in the New Hampshire primary, said Thursday he wants a recount to ensure that all ballots in his partys contest were counted, reports the Associated Press:

title: Moving Billions of People on a Still-Green Planet?
description: Jesse Ausubel, who studies, well, everything at Rockefeller Universitys Program for the Human Environment, has long been exploring patterns of development and their broader consequences. Hes a quirky, sometimes prickly, thinker who, for example, sees a fossil fuel, methane, as a keystone  and greatly neglected  resource serving as a bridge to a climate-friendly energy future.

title: Milan Looks to Teen to Save Its Season
description: One of the great Serie A rivalries will be renewed on Sunday when Napoli visits the San Siro to take on the struggling AC Milan. It was 18 years ago that Napoli, led by the irrepressible Diego Maradona and aided by Daniel Fonseca and a young Gianfranco Zola, edged Milan for the scudetto. It was the azzuris last title before Maradonas tragi-comic, drug-fueled downfall and before Napoli suffered financial disaster.

title: BofAs Countrywide Deal: Bargain or Bad Move?
description: Bank of America announced Friday that it would buy Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender, for $4 billion in stock, confirming reports that circulated the night before. But one thing remained up for debate: who was getting the better end of the deal.

title: The Craig Ferguson of the Presidential Race
description: Aired Thursday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson: It is a great day for America, but not such a great day for Bill Richardson. He dropped out of the presidential race today. I think I speak for all of us in America when I say, Who the hell is Bill Richardson? Hes the Craig Ferguson of the presidential race.

title: Weve Got the Beat
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Signs of Discontent Over Strike Tactics
description: When Hollywoods studios walked away from the bargaining table last month, striking screenwriters came out swinging, Michael Cieply writes in Fridays New York Times. But the militant tactics may be creating fissures within the guild.

title: Whoever Wins, Death to Israel
description: Stephen Colbert surveys headlines from around the globe:

title: ECC: Sparta Reaches the Final; Slovan Beats MoDo
description: Sprata Prague beat HC Davos of Switzerland, 6-4, Friday at the European Club Championship in St. Petersburg. It was the second straight win for the Czech team, propelling them to the tournament final on Sunday.

title: Yahoos Core Value Is Falling
description: The market is taking stock of still more rumors that Microsoft is trying to buy Yahoo. (This would be a great deal, if it werent for management, strategic and cultural differences that would probably sink any combination.

title: A Toilet That Uses 14 Gallons? Oh Gosh!
description: Some City Room readers were understandably perplexed by the 14 gallons of water consumed by each use of the spiffy new pay toilet at Madison Square Park. So we will break it down for you, according to what Cemusa, the Spanish advertising conglomerate that runs the toilets, told us:

title: Stray Questions for: Buzz Bissinger
description: Buzz Bissingers books include Friday Night Lights and A Prayer for the City.

title: Didnt That Used To Be Called Murder?
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Hey, some good news today from the Middle East. Its still there.

title: For The Moment | Show Time for Adam Kimmel
description: This weeks guest blogger is the New York-based mens wear designer Adam Kimmel. Known for his heady brand of cerebral machismo  Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock are recurring inspirations  Kimmel, 28, is filing from Florence, Italy, where he is the featured designer at the mens-wear trade show Pitti Immagine Uomo. In this post, Kimmels friend and V magazine editor Christopher Bollen reports on the event weve all been waiting for: Kimmels artist-fueled fashion show, which happened last night.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, Jan. 11:

title: Strike: Moguls Say Strike? What Strike?
description: Media executives continue to sound nonchalant about the effects of the ongoing writers strike.

title: Before Countrywide Deal, Lots of Bullish Bets
description: With all the speculation this week about a potential bankruptcy filing for Countrywide Financial, it would have taken a brave soul to buy call options on Countrywides stock. But there were a lot of brave souls on Thursday, when, even before the reports that the troubled lender was in talks to be acquired by Bank of America, trading in these options went through the roof.

title: Medical Googlers, Part Two
description: Its time for a second opinion about medical Googlers.

title: Democrats See Enthusiasm Gap in Their Favor
description: In his column today, Carl Hulse writes about signs in the last two weeks of an imbalance of public excitement that favors Democrats. It used to be the credibility gap that afflicted politicians. Now Republicans and Democrats are peering over the edge of the enthusiasm gap.

title: Manual of Style
description: A new subgenre! Videos about how to pick up girls!

title: Sovereign Funds: Rich, But Are They Ready?
description: Sovereign wealth funds  huge government-backed investment firms that control about $3 trillion  are on a roll these days, investing huge chunks of money at a time when their capital is sorely needed. Funds based in the Middle East and Asia recently purchased stakes in Bear Stearns, the Carlyle Group and Advanced Micro Devices, just to name a few deals. Sometimes the deals seem to materialize in a matter of days.

title: A Guide to Hunting Bear Stearns
description: With Bear Stearnss prompting new takeover rumors, how well can the investment bank resist?

title: Snow in Baghdad
description: A cell-phone camera video by Ahmad Fadam, an Iraqi employee of The New York Times.

title: The ACE Award Nominees
description: The ACE Awards, in which American film editors honor their own, were announced today. The awards take place Feb. 17 at the Beverly Hilton Hotel and because it is a private, un-televized function, a spokesperson said the awards show do not interfere with the WGA strike and will go on as scheduled.

title: Mayor Deflects Talk of Higher Property Taxes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg deflected speculation this morning that the city could be headed for higher property taxes in the face of a weakening economy. I dont know that theyre going to go up, the mayor said on his weekly call-in radio program on WABC-AM (770). The first thing were going to do for the city is try to reduce spending.

title: SEIU Urges Action Against Countrywide Deal
description: Bank of Americas deal to acquire Countrywide Financial has garnered both praise and brickbats from the financial community and the press. But it is also drawing fire from an unusual quarter: a major labor union.

title: Of All Things in Baghdad, Snow
description: Heres a development we can all overinterpret to a fare-thee-well if were of a mind: It snowed in Baghdad this morning, for the first time in living memory.

title: Leno and Kimmel Commiserate
description: E! Online calls it the cross of the couches: the NBC comedian Jay Leno and the ABC funnyman Jimmy Kimmel visited each others shows on Thursday and commiserated about the ongoing writers strike.

title: The Backstory | Meet the Locals
description: Polaroids of the amateur models appearing in Sundays Times Magazine. (Tyler Healy)

title: Eat Food. Not Too Much.
description: It was a canny move, on the part of Penguin Press, to publish Michael Pollans new book, In Defense of Food: An Eaters Manifesto, right after the holidays.

title: Giuliani Aides Go Without Paychecks
description: Corrected Some top members of Rudolph W. Giulianis top staff are foregoing their paychecks this month, a few weeks before the Florida primary.

title: A Candidate Not a Cause
description: A final word about this Democratic primary in New Hampshire, and then Ill move on.

title: Artists Studios in the Fotan Industrial Area
description: Hong Kongs downtown galleries (which you can read about here) have become increasingly commercial and expensive, largely because of the boom in contemporary Chinese art prices overseas. On a recent tour, a friend and I saw works by local artists in small upstairs galleries retailing for a quarter-million or half-million Hong Kong dollars, or tens of thousands of U.S. dollars.

title: When Fitness Means Life or Death
description: Are you fit enough to save your own life?

title: Mock the Vote
description: Markos Moulitsas is feeling devious today:

title: New York Connections to The Wire
description: Maybe because the show never seems to win any of the awards it deserves, but fans of HBOs The Wire can tend to take on a certain evangelical fervor.

title: The G.O.P.s Unanswered Question
description: Thursday nights Republican debate in South Carolina in the wake of John McCains comeback victory in New Hampshire and Mike Huckabees surprising win in Iowa emphasized what a difference one week can make in the nomination process. And in terms of who will get the nod, it raises more questions than answers.

title: Surprise! Instant Jury Duty for Shoppers
description: Finding enough qualified jurors to keep the justice system running has been a nagging problem in American courthouses for decades. Legislatures and court administrators have tried all kinds of angles to attack the problem, from eliminating exemptions (so more people are called) to making jury duty more convenient (so fewer people skip out) to streamlining voire dire and lopping years off the time before a juror can be called again (to make the most use of the people who do show up).

title: Can Detroit Be Relevant?
description: This week, Rick Wagoner, chief executive of General Motors, was at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas talking about driverless cars and the Cadillac Provoq, a concept vehicle powered by a fuel cell.

title: Clinton Backers Pow-Wow in L.A. and D.C.
description: Updated About 100 donors and top supporters are gathering with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tonight in Los Angeles, and a similar number are huddling tonight and this weekend with former President Clinton and campaign officials in Washington, D.C., to discuss the ongoing Democratic nomination fight against Barack Obama.

title: The Week in Comments: A Hare-Brained Idea
description: Monday, Jan. 7

title: D.L.C. Leaders Cut Edwards Out
description: As would be expected, the two gentlemen from the Democratic Leadership Council on a conference call today told reporters theyre very confident in their partys chances of reclaiming the White House, theyre happy that substantive issues are being discussed

title: Democrats, McCain and the Iraq War
description: It didnt take long this week for the Democrats to take aim at Senator John McCain as he emerged the frontrunner from his win in New Hampshire.

title: Help Desk | Mens Dress Shoes for Cold Weather
description: Paraboots Guitry boot.

title: One Analyst Boosts Warner, But Another Barks
description: Shares of Warner Music Group got a big lift on Friday thanks to an upbeat report from Merrill Lynch. But the tune coming from Rich Greenfield, an outspoken analyst at Pali Research, was quite different: He blasted the record label Friday for what he considered to be wasteful spending on an under-the-radar deal.

title: Friday Kickoff: Is There Anybody Alive Out There?
description: Loyal Quad readers will know that we like to drop the occasional Bruce Springsteen lyric in our headlines. And that Radio Nowhere chorus could be heard at B.C.S. headquarters in the aftermath of yet another low rating. (Oh, wait, the B.C.S. doesnt have headquarters. Sorry.) Jeffrey Flanagan of the Kansas City Star has the latest batch of ratings bad news. (Warning, theres a scarily large head shot when you open the link.)

title: Strike: Original Episodes Running Awfully Thin
description: This week, more than any other, television viewers are feeling the effects of the two-month-old writers strike, as six of the most popular and buzz-worthy series on broadcast television showed their last original episodes.

title: Posh Ads Appear | Victoria Beckham for Marc Jacobs
description: Earlier this week we wrote a tribute to Miz Poshs momentary style lapse. Today all is forgiven. Were seeing leaked photos from her far-out Spring ad campaign shot by Juergen Teller for Marc Jacobs. The ads should be appearing in the latest batch of fashion magazines like W, Vogue and Interview. The images shown here we scored on Canal Street.

title: Podcast: A Rare Pivotal Primary in New York
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: New Models for the Detroit Auto Show
description: Automakers will present lots of new models at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

title: Sinai for the Sinuses!
description: After her stunning comeback in the New Hampshire primaries, Hillary is now crowing, Whos your momma, Obama!  Warren Hughes

title: Over the Line at C.E.S.
description: The TV-B-Gone is an infrared clicker that lets you anonymously turn off TV sets in public places, like bars or restaurants.

title: Now Hanging | Katy Grannans Photography
Energy Conservation Begins at Home
description: COMMERCE CITY, Los Angeles  For Hillary Rodham Clinton, energy conservation apparently starts at home, as in Chappaqua, or so she told a labor audience today as she was laying out an economic program that called for, among other things, a crash winterization program to help homeowners save some money on heating costs.

title: Romneys Ground Zero
description: LANSING, Mich.  Mitt Romney, in what may prove an unfortunate choice of words, has taken to referring to Michigan as ground zero for his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Manchester City Closing In on Iraqi International
description: MANCHESTER, England  Nashat Akram Abid Ali is close to becoming the first Iraqi to play in the top flight of English soccer.

title: Milberg Questions Arise for New City Bar Leader
description: The woman chosen to be the next leader of the New York City Bar Association has a stellar record as a trial lawyer, a federal prosecutor, and a history of pro-bono good works, to boot.

title: Up Next: The Moviegoer
description: The Reading Room returns from its holiday hiatus next week with a discussion of The Moviegoer, the 1962 National Book Award winner by Walker Percy. Weve put together a great panel: Julia Reed, a journalist and author of a forthcoming memoir about New Orleans; Jonathan Galassi, the publisher of Farrar, Straus & Giroux; and Dean Baquet, the Washington bureau chief for The New York Times. Ill be moderating the discussion, and will kick things off next Friday with an introductory post. Well begin in earnest on the week of the 21st.

title: The Odd Couple
description: Jack Klugman and Tony Randall in "Big Mouth," which originally aired Sept. 22, 1972.

title: Kill A TV Bore: Watch The Wire
description: Some of the reviews of the fifth and final season of HBOs inner-city Baltimore drama The Wire practically pleaded with viewers to watch.

title: Kerrey Backs Clinton, Likes Obama More
description: Former Nebraska Senator Bob Kerrey was candid about his endorsement of Hillary Clinton, despite what he admitted was an affinity for Barack Obamas less doctrinaire politics. This was at a breakfast with some fellow-transplanted Cornhuskers (two of us, to be precise).

title: Edwardss Run-of-the-Mill Ad
description: Everyone knows John Edwardss dad, Wallace, fed his family on a modest millworkers salary. The Democratic candidate brings it up in nearly every speech he delivers.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: Ancestral Allure
description: The dewy and innocent milkmaid at the center of Thomas Hardys tragic novel Tess of the dUrbervilles is destroyed not by rape or heartbreak; what does her in is genealogy. The problems start on the books first page, when a troublemaking parson calls Tesss bumpkin father Sir John.

title: Arizona Governor Backs Obama
description: LAS VEGAS  Another day, another endorsement.

title: Huntsman-Hexion: A Deal Agreement to Applaud
description: Its a bit weird to outsiders, but a well-drafted merger agreement is something treasured by any deal lawyer. They will read through and collect these agreements over the years, pointing out the good and bad provisions to younger deal lawyers in training and referring to them in deal negotiations.

title: Upcoming Auction Highlights
description: A selection of cars to be auctioned soon that may offer an indication of the strength of collector-car prices.

title: Paragraph Four, Page 114
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: God and Small Things
description: There may not be a lot of agreement among the worlds religions on exactly what constitutes humans playing God, but you never hear a preacher or rabbi suggesting such behavior is wise or laudable. So you would think they might have a lot to say about nanotechnology. After all, nanotech involves rearranging not just DNA and the other building blocks of life  already a source of controversy in biotechnology  but the very atoms and molecules that make up all matter. If that is not messing around in Gods closet, what is?

title: Pick a Color, Any Color
description: Several readers have asked whether we know what color we will be painting the exterior of the house. Ive been spending most of my spare time this week contemplating the answer.

title: Will Stock Payments Add to Merrills Woes?
description: Merrill Lynchs move to accelerate vesting on previously awarded stock-based pay to employees could add to the huge fourth-quarter loss already expected by analysts, Reuters reported Friday.

title: The Next Sir Edmund Hillarys: Riders on the Storm
description: Yes, Sir Edmund Hillary is dead. But before you start muttering into your Darjeeling about how they dont make chaps like him anymore, men with pluck and courage and the daft compulsion to test the limits of human achievement at the extreme edges of the Earth, consider these odd words: Cortes Bank and Billabong.

title: Kids, Get Your Jessica Simpson Mask Here
description: Now, were not sure just what use this will be for most Giants fans, presumably watching the Cowboys-Giants game thousands of miles from Texas, but that is not the point. An enterprising man contacted us to tell us that he has created Jessica Simpson masks for fans of recent Cowboys opponents, and has devised a New York-themed one for this week.

title: How Mozilo Should Spend His Exit Package
description: Speculation is already buzzing that Countrywide Financials chief executive, Angelo R. Mozilo, wont stick around Bank of America after it completes its purchase of the mortgage lender later this spring..

title: Maybe exports wont save us
description: Ive pointed out that rising exports, thanks to the weak dollar, were what allowed the US to avoid slipping into recession up through 3rd quarter 2007. But Brad Setser points out that real exports have stalled over the last few months (this is monthly non-petroleum exports in 2000 dollars, seasonally adjusted):

title: Clinton Found Her Voice, Now Seeks Youth
description: No doubt women came out strong for Hillary Rodham Clinton in New Hampshire, but the youth demographic still rallied behind Barack Obama. A new video segment on her Web site reaches out to those younger voters.

title: Strike News: Throwing the Globes Wide Open
description: The Golden Globes press conference will not be a NBC News exclusive, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association announced Friday.

title: Too Big or Just Right?
description: Interesting article by Corie Brown in The Los Angeles Times this week on Adam Tolmach of the Ojai Vineyard. According to the article Tolmach has had a conversion experience and has decided to dial back the strength and ripeness of his pinot noirs, chardonnays and syrahs. The article quotes Tolmach as saying that while his wines received high scores from critics, they were not, after all, the style of wines he likes best.

title: Candidates Push for a N.H. Recount
description: Corrected

title: Old Trees of New York, Reborn
description: It takes certain qualities  patience, resilience, even stoicism, perhaps  to survive in New York City. That explains the selection criteria that were used to select specimens for an unusual program that will produce genetic reproductions of some of the oldest and sturdiest trees in the five boroughs.Some of the trees go as far back as the creation of Central Park in the 19th century; others are believed be even older. Thats particularly remarkable given that urban trees typically dont survive longer than 50 years in parks and less than decade on city streets.

title: UrbanEye: Julian Schnabel
description: "Navigation Drawings," a new exhibition by artist and filmmaker Julian Schnabel opens at the Sperone Westwater gallery.  Melena Ryzik reports.

title: NBC No Longer Taking Hostages at the Globes
description: NBC has returned custody of the Golden Globes to the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and that means there will be lots of coverage, no pickets and maybe even a few stars. The Bagger is grateful that his betters barked him onto an airplane and he is now in position to cover the unfolding story. See you over the weekend.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 11
description: Here is a slide show of 11 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the funeral of a firefighter on Staten Island, the dismantling of this seasons Christmas decorations in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, and the worlds largest spectator squash tournament.

title: Group Singalongs Flourish
description: Ben Ratliff finds a band of energetic singers in East  Lansing, Michigan.

title: The Readers Speak
description: Im afraid Ive been a little remiss in answering readers lately, but I did want to address just a few comments before we all break for the weekend.

title: Bloggingheads: The Politics of Juno
description:
Film critics Chris Orr of The New Republic Online, left, and Ross Douthat of National Review discuss whether recent movies are sending pro-life messages.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Vows | Scenes From a Love Marriage
description: The wedding of Sabeen Ali and Hashim Mian in Coral Gables, Fla., offered a colorful mix of ancient Pakistani and Muslim religious traditions and contemporary customs.

title: Bill Clinton Tries to Tamp Down Fairy-Tale Remark About Obama
description: The Clinton campaign moved Friday to try to quell a potentially damaging backlash over recent comments by Bill and Hillary Clinton that have drawn criticism from African-Americans just as the presidential primary campaign reached Southern states with significant blocs of black voters.

title: Taco Day on the Trail
description: EAST LOS ANGELES  Sometimes its not easy being a candidate for president  particularly if you want to do something like have lunch. Hillary Rodham Clinton found that out Friday afternoon at a lunch (O.K., a photo opportunity) at King Taco, a well-known if tiny taco spot in East Los Angeles, a Mexican-American enclave here.

title: Vows: Lindsay & Lee
description: After Lindsay Stieber and Lee Milstein attended the same bar review course, they didn't let distance keep them apart.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III catches air (and snow) on Whiteface Mountain in his first foray in snowboarding.

title: Obama Plays Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  What happens in Vegas should not stay in Vegas.

title: A Paradise for Surfers
description: Sandy Huffaker for The New York Times

title: On the Trail
description: Friday was another busy day on the campaign trail for the Democratic and Republican candidates.

title: Whats With the East All-Star Goalies?
description: Well be the first to agree that the NHL All-Star Game is completely meaningless and a good excuse to take a short holiday from hockey. But its still astonishing just how wrongheaded some of the selections can be.

title: Irene Reid, Singer, Bandleader and Actress, Dies at 77
description: Irene Reid, a singer who toured and recorded with Count Basies band and appeared on Broadway in The Wiz, died last Saturday in the Bronx. She was 77.

title: China: Horse Racing to Return
description: The government has approved regular horse racing at the Orient Lucky City racecourse in Wuhan, the main city in Hubei Province, starting in September, and is considering allowing legal gambling on the races next year on a trial basis, the official Xinhua news agency reported. Gambling, popular in pre-Communist China, has been illegal since the Communists came to power in 1949 and deemed it a major vice, along with opium.

title: After Finding the Right Fit, Moss Is Proving Critics Wrong
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Dennis Green spent a lot of time last spring with a telephone jammed against his ear, defending a player he thought he understood. Caller after caller wondered how the player, who had once flippantly said he played when he wanted to, could possibly fit in with the most businesslike of football franchises.

title: Bush, Leaving Israel, Keeps Up Push for Peace Treaty
description: JERUSALEM  As he left for Kuwait, President Bush promised on Friday to return in May for Israels 60th anniversary, a visit that could serve as additional pressure on both Israelis and Palestinians to negotiate a peace treaty by the end of his term.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about the American detention center at the Bagram military base in Afghanistan omitted a reporting credit. Kirk Semple, Carlotta Gall and Abdul Waheed Wafa contributed from Kabul.

title: 3 Convicted Who Led Charity Tied to Militants
description: Three leaders of a defunct Islamic charity were convicted Friday of defrauding the federal government by winning tax-exempt status for their organization while concealing the fact that it supported militant fighters in Afghanistan and elsewhere.

title: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Seeking to Block Atlantic Yards
description: A state judge on Friday dismissed a lawsuit filed by a coalition of community groups against the Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn, dealing a major setback to opponents of the $4 billion development plan.

title: Many Mulligans Later, City Is to Start Anew, and Alone, on Bronx Golf Course
description: It was supposed to be a world-class golf course, designed by Jack Nicklaus, and best of all, it would cost the city next to nothing. Developers would pay for it all and recoup the cost of the city-owned course from greens fees.

title: U.S. and Europe Ponder Divergent Rate Policies
description: FRANKFURT  Can Europes economy stay on track even if the United States goes off the rails?

title: A Romance Novelist Is Accused of Copying
description: Who says romance novel fans care only about ripped bodices and manly men?

title: A Political Forums Message: Were One Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: A Clergyman of the Streets Leaves His Historic Pulpit
description: LEIPZIG, Germany

title: Not So Itsy Bitsy
description: A giant sculpture of a spider by Louise Bourgeois, similar to one, below,  that has been luring the crowds to Tate Modern on Londons South Bank, has been donated to the gallery, the BBC reported. Vicente Todoli, the museums director, called the gift of the almost 30-foot-tall work, titled Maman, a historic moment. The steel and bronze sculpture was given to the Tate by Ms. Bourgeois and an anonymous benefactor. It is the largest of a series of spiders made by Ms. Bourgeois, now 96. The artist, who lives in New York, has described the piece as an ode to my mother, my best friend. She added: Like spiders, my mother was very clever. Spiders are friendly presences that eat mosquitoes.

title: Top Giuliani Aides Forgo Salaries to Help Big Push
description: Rudolph W. Giulianis senior campaign aides have given up their paychecks for the month to help save dwindling campaign funds as Mr. Giuliani heads into the crucial primary races where he has staked his candidacy.

title: U.N. Nuclear Official Urges Iran to Clarify Outstanding Issues
description: TEHRAN  Mohamed ElBaradei, the chief of the International Atomic Energy Agency, on Friday urged Iran to move more quickly to clarify questions about its nuclear activities, the Iranian news agency ISNA reported.

title: Cardiac Arrests in the Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Waves Mean No Small Preparation for Surfers
description: HALF MOON BAY, Calif.  The image of the quintessential American surfer  a bronzed slacker in board shorts  may be firmly entrenched. But that surfer dude bears little resemblance to the athletes known as big-wave surfers, a small community composed of men and women who often become amateur oceanographers and experts in wave dynamics in order to ride waves that can be more than 50 feet high.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about the Knicks 101-92 loss to the Houston Rockets misidentified the referee who ejected Coach Isiah Thomas after there was incidental contact between them. It was Eric Lewis  not Dan Crawford, another official working the game. Because of an editing error, an article on Friday repeated the error. And a picture caption in some editions with the article on Friday, using information from the European Pressphoto Agency, misidentified the referee shown with Mr. Thomas. It was Mr. Lewis, not Mr. Crawford. (Go to Article)

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $6,363,022

title: Citing Drop in Inmate Population, Spitzer Plans to Close Four Prisons Upstate
description: The Spitzer administration announced on Friday a plan to close a medium-security prison and three minimum-security camps upstate, citing the declining crime and prison population across the state. Officials said the move would save taxpayers upward of $70 million in the next few years.

title: Getting Help to Enable Herself to Help Others
description: The littlest things you do in peoples lives that, you dont know, it changes their whole life, Iman Thomas said.

title: A Day of Confusion at Golden Globes
description: The fight over the Golden Globes on Sunday night has left the once glamorous awards show in a confusing state: a news conference announcing the winners will still be broadcast on NBC, but not exclusively; the striking writers will not picket the event as threatened but it is unclear how many nominees or other celebrities will show up.

title: Running and Fighting, All to Save Her Son
description: The writers strike brings with it, of course, the significant potential to lower our viewing standards now that televisions midseason is under way. How amenable will most people be to rendering honest judgments on anything new and being shown and not the 923rd season of a reality venture in which people trade wives, or nannies, or plastic surgeries, or wallpaper or ferrets?

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about the Knicks 101-92 loss to the Houston Rockets misidentified the referee who ejected Coach Isiah Thomas after there was incidental contact between them. It was Eric Lewis  not Dan Crawford, another official working the game. Because of an editing error, an article on Friday repeated the error. And a picture caption in some editions with the article on Friday, using information from the European Pressphoto Agency, misidentified the referee shown with Mr. Thomas. It was Mr. Lewis, not Mr. Crawford.

title: Of Hope and Politics
description: Were about to find out how resilient Barack Obama is.

title: Ringo Returns
description: Ringo Starr, above, returned to his hometown of Liverpool, England, on Friday to help kick off the citys year as a European Capital of Culture, The Associated Press reported. The ex-Beatle joined Dave Stewart of Eurythmics in headlining an outdoor concert that included about 600 local musicians. On Saturday Mr. Starr is to appear in Liverpool, the Musical, a tribute to the citys musical heritage, which features the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra and local rock groups. Each year two cities in the European Union are designated culture capitals.

title: Food From Cloned Animals Seems Safe, a Panel Finds
description: Meat and milk from cloned animals seem to pose no special health risks, said a draft report released Friday by the European Food Safety Agency. It was a first step toward the eventual sale of such products within the European Union.

title: Christopher Bowman, Skating Champion, Is Dead at 40
description: Christopher Bowman, a two-time United States figure skating champion acclaimed as a stylish, crowd-pleasing performer despite a long struggle with drug abuse, was found dead Thursday in North Hills, Calif., near Los Angeles. He was 40.

title: A Resilient Indonesia Moves Beyond Suharto
description: JAKARTA  As Indonesias former strongman, Suharto, lay on his sickbed this week, the country that rejected him 10 years ago was in the early stages of a democratic election campaign.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Friday about Thursdays Republican presidential debate in Myrtle Beach, S.C., referred incompletely to the sponsors of the debate. In addition to the South Carolina Republican Party, Fox News Channel sponsored the debate.

title: Teach to the Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleopatras Demise Told in Dramatic Harmonies
description: Berlioz described his cantata La Mort de Cloptre as somber, broad, sinister and lugubrious: a great voice breathing a menacing lament in the mysterious stillness of the night. The Prix de Rome jury, however, to which he submitted it in 1829, thought the bold harmonies and adventurous orchestral sonorities weird.
