title: A Quartet Crosses Its Boundaries
description: These days young musicians are devoting a lot of thought and energy to redefining themselves, not only in terms of what and where they perform but in purely structural matters as well. The Lark Quartet offered a glimpse of its own ambitious reconfiguration plan on Thursday evening when it presented itself, and friends, as the Lark Chamber Artists in an expansive concert at the newly renovated (and acoustically brightened) Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Giants-Cowboys Game Is on the Lines
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants face the favored Cowboys on Sunday in the National Football Conference divisional playoffs, the outcome may depend on how the Giants aggressive defensive line performs against the Cowboys big and gifted offensive line.

title: Oil Is Blamed for Widening Trade Deficit
description: Record oil prices widened the United States trade deficit in November as the cost of imported petroleum outpaced a modest rise in exports.

title: Jurors Testimony in Cape Cod Murder Ends
description: BARNSTABLE, Mass.  Rare juror testimony on whether racial bias tainted a high-profile murder conviction ended here on Friday, leaving the judge alone with the thorny task of deciding whether a new trial is warranted.

title: Blinded and Broken by Ambition
description: White Plains

title: Old or New? Once Each With Feeling
description: It wasnt supposed to be a competition, but everyone knew it was. At the Morgan Library & Museum on Thursday, two inanimate objects battled for first place. In one corner stood a Conrad Graff fortepiano from the first part of the 19th century, in the other a seven-foot Steinway grand.

title: 3 Buddies Home From Iraq Are Charged With Murdering a 4th
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  After surviving intense combat in Iraq, Specialist Kevin Shields was killed on what he had thought was friendly soil. His bloody, bullet-riddled body was found by a newspaper deliverer, sprawled on a downtown sidewalk here on Dec. 1.

title: That Daunting Commute
description: To the Editor:

title: For Islanders, an Early Look at a Top Prospect
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  On the first day of his professional hockey career, Kyle Okposo got a ride to the Bridgeport Sound Tigers practice with Jeff Tambellini, his new housemate and linemate. Tambellini steered clear of hockey talk.

title: Directors and Producers to Begin Talks
description: LOS ANGELES  The Directors Guild of America and Hollywoods production companies said Friday afternoon that they plan to start formal contract negotiations on Saturday, promising a significant break in the entertainment industrys troubled labor situations.

title: Packers Harris Is at the Front of a Defensive Turnaround
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Four years after making one of the most memorable plays in Green Bay Packers playoff history, cornerback Al Harris stepped to the lectern at a news conference this week and flatly announced he would not entertain questions about it.

title: Curing What Ails Starbucks
description: To: Howard Schultz

title: Fighting to Lose
description: Nyack, N.Y.

title: Lottery Numbers
CSI Gives CBS a Lift
description: With new episodes of ABCs Greys Anatomy and CBSs CSI at 9 p.m. on Thursday, both networks surged to the top of the nights ratings. CSI attracted the largest audience, 18.1 million, Nielsen estimated. But Greys Anatomy (17.6 million) led among viewers ages 18 to 49, putting ABC on top in that demographic. CBSs "Without a Trace" won at 10 p.m. in total viewers (13.8 million), while ER on NBC (9.1 million) ranked first in the hour among the 18-to-49 group. For the night, NBC ranked third in that age group, with The Celebrity Apprentice at 9 (8.1 million), My Name is Earl (7.7 million) and 30 Rock (6 million).

title: Variation on a Partner Signal Becomes Lost in Transmission
description: The basic suit-preference signal was invented by Hy Lavinthal in 1934. Suppose the contract is four spades. You lead a singleton club. Partner, bless his or her boots, wins with the club ace and gives you a club ruff. If only you could get partner back on lead, you could get a second ruff and defeat the contract. But do you shift to a spade, heart or diamond?

title: South Africa: Police Chief to Be Charged
description: Prosecutors said they would charge Jackie Selebi, the national police commissioner and president of Interpol who has been accused of having links to organized crime syndicates, with corruption. A date for the court hearing has yet to be determined, they said.

title: Taiwan Prepares for First of 2 Major 2008 Elections
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Voters went to the polls here on Saturday in the first of two closely spaced elections that will shape this self-governing islands strategy for dealing with mainland China, its rival.

title: W. F. Ganong, 83, Expert in Brains Control of Body, Dies
description: William F. Ganong, a former chairman of one of the leading physiology departments at an American university and one of the first scientists to trace how the brain controls important internal functions of the body, died Dec. 23 at his home in Albany, Calif. He was 83.

title: Court Allows Scientists to Work at NASA Until Trial Over Background Checks
description: A group of scientists working at NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory won a round in federal court on Friday in their challenge to a Bush administration requirement that they submit to extensive background checks or face losing their jobs.

title: Syria Rebuilds on Site Destroyed by Israeli Bombs
description: The puzzling site in Syria that Israeli jets bombed in September grew more curious on Friday with the release of a satellite photograph showing new construction there that resembles the sites former main building.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Tuesday about Rabbi Shmuel Berenbaum, leader of the Mir Yeshiva in Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to its policy on music, song and dance, and referred imprecisely to the Torah, the sole subject of the yeshivas curriculum. As defined by Orthodox Jews, the Torah can include the Old Testament, commentaries upon it and the oral tradition known as the Talmud  not just the first five books of the Bible. And the yeshiva does in fact permit music, song and dance; they are not shunned.

title: Knicks Starters Play Poorly, Then Not at All
description: Fifteen seconds into the Knicks game against the Toronto Raptors on Friday, Chris Bosh sank a smooth 15-foot jumper from the baseline. The deficit felt narrow at the time, only 2-0, but it turned out to be wider than an ocean. For the rest of the evening, the Knicks played from behind.

title: Judge Sentences Jones to 6 Months in Prison
description: WHITE PLAINS  The former track star Marion Joness tearful courtroom plea to avoid jail was denied Friday by a federal judge who said her sentence should serve as a deterrent for others who may lie to federal agents, and Jones was sentenced to six months in prison for pleading guilty to two counts of perjury.

title: Some Debt Trends Are Good. This Isnt One of Them.
description: AMERICAN credit card debt is growing at the fastest rate in years, a fact that may signal coming trouble for the banks that issue them.

title: Suitcase of Cash Tangles U.S. and 2 Latin Nations in Intrigue
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  One day last August, an airport policewoman in Buenos Aires noticed something peculiar as she was monitoring a baggage scanner: the appearance of six perfect, dense rectangles inside a suitcase.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary Friday about Sir Edmund Hillary, who with Tenzing Norgay became the first to scale Mount Everest, misidentified the route they took to the summit. It is the South Col, not the South Tor. In comparing the feat to one by Charles A. Lindbergh, the obituary misstated Lindberghs accomplishment. Though he was the first to make a solo nonstop trans-Atlantic flight, in 1927, he was not the first aviator to make the nonstop crossing; John W. Alcock and Arthur W. Brown did so together in 1919, from Newfoundland to Ireland. In addition, the precedents for Sir Edmunds reaching the South Pole in 1957-58 were referred to incorrectly. Robert Falcon Scott reached the pole in 1912, and the United States built a base there in 1956; Sir Edmund was not the first to reach the pole since Roald Amundsen in 1911.

title: North Korea: Russia Regrets Slow Talks
description: Russia regrets the slowed state of progress in talks on North Koreas nuclear program but will fulfill its commitment under the six-nation agreement to provide North Korea with fuel oil this month so as not to slow diplomatic efforts further, a senior Russian diplomat said, according to Russian news reports. The announcement came as Christopher R. Hill, the chief United States envoy for North Korea, visited Moscow to discuss diplomatic approaches to North Koreas nuclear program. North Korea did not meet a year-end deadline to disclose its nuclear activities. Mr. Hill again urged North Korea to make a complete declaration and said another meeting of the two Koreas, the United States, China, Japan and Russia could be held soon.

title: In an Ancient Culture, a Team Takes Root
description: ACOMA PUEBLO, N.M.  To the north, the Sky City casino draws truckers off Interstate 40 with its billboard advertisements promising loose slots and low limits.

title: Directors and Producers to Hold Talks
Robbery of Transit Worker Turns Into Knife Fight, Killing One
description: A New York City Transit worker walking home after a late shift, three suspected muggers armed with a curved knife and a bystander whose role was unclear converged on a rainy street in Upper Manhattan late Thursday in a blood-soaked encounter that left the bystander stabbed to death and two others  including the transit worker  hospitalized.

title: France: Sarkozys Ex Loses Bid to Bar Book
description: A Paris court rejected an attempt by President Nicolas Sarkozys ex-wife Ccilia, left, to block publication of a book that quotes her making critical comments about him. It ruled that a ban would be totally disproportionate, all the more so because the book is already on sale. The book, Ccilia, by Anna Bitton, appeared in bookstores Thursday and was ranked as the top seller on Amazons French site on Friday. The judge also noted that Ms. Sarkozy had discussed her relationship with her ex-husband in two interviews after her divorce, suggesting she was not seeking to keep her private life secret.

title: The Change We Want
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about reaction from people in Central Park to a settlement in which New York City agreed to temporarily ease crowd-size rules for the Great Lawn misidentified the area of the park where Garth Brooks, the country singer, held a concert in 1997. It was the North Meadow, not the Great Lawn.

title: Escalating Losses Force Citigroup to Seek More Foreign Investment
description: Citigroup is turning to cash-rich foreign investors for a second time as it confronts mounting losses on mortgage-related investments.

title: Chase Buys Some of Lenders Assets
description: LONDON  Northern Rock, one of Europes biggest casualties of the credit crisis, sold some of its mortgage portfolio to JPMorgan Chase on Friday as part of its plan to repay about 25 billion ($49 billion) in emergency funding.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Jan. 2 about construction of a park on the site of the High Line elevated tracks in Lower Manhattan misidentified the employer of Gerard Zimmermann, a chief inspector, who said the elevation of the project was not a problem for workers. He works for the LiRo Group, a construction consulting firm, not Kiska Construction, the general contractor.

title: U.S. Issues National ID Standards, Setting Stage for a Showdown
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government issued national standards on Friday that states would have to meet in order for drivers licenses they issue to qualify as identification at airports and federal buildings, setting the stage for a confrontation with states that have voted not to cooperate.

title: Toll Increases in New Jersey Would Be Steep, and the Debate Will Be Fierce
description: Driving the family car on the New Jersey Turnpike from the Lincoln Tunnel to the Delaware Memorial Bridge  just about the length of the highway  could rise to $48 from $5.85. For truck drivers, navigating that same stretch of highway would soar to $186 from the current $23.

title: Mother Accused of Endangerment Is Now Charged With Killing Baby
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J. (AP)  A Piscataway woman recently accused of child endangerment for leaving her 9-month-old daughter alone in a car was charged with murder on Friday after she drowned the girl at the family home, law enforcement officials said.

title: A Mountaineer Who Defined the Notion of Heroic Explorer
description: I was just an enthusiastic mountaineer of modest abilities, Sir Edmund Hillary said on the 50th anniversary of his pioneering climb of Mount Everest, an average bloke. Even at the moment of his greatest triumph, he claimed no more. After his descent in 1953, he wrote to his mother, Well, I may not have produced much joy or happiness in the world but at least Ive helped make the Hillary name a bit more famous.

title: Yonkers and the Leaf Blowers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sir Edmund Hillary
description: I am one of those people who can close their eyes and see Hillary and Norgay on the summit of Everest. I was born the year before that climb, and while I was growing up, Sir Edmund Hillary was the last word in simple, bold heroism. I quietly set him apart in my mind, knowing that I would probably never test my own limits of physical and mental endurance, as he did. What makes the news of his death Friday at age 88 so moving, was his modesty, the sense of a civilian heroism held in reserve apart from that one great moment. He made the word beekeeper  his and his fathers vocation  sound like an honorific.

title: Boris Lurie, Leader of a Confrontational Art Movement, Dies at 83
description: Boris Lurie, a Russian-born artist who survived the Holocaust and then depicted its horrors while leading a confrontational movement called No! Art, died Monday in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Florida: Safety Board Faults Cruise Line
description: A boiler explosion that killed eight crew members on a passenger ship was probably caused by Norwegian Cruise Lines improper operation, maintenance and inspection of the steam chamber, federal investigators have said. Part of the boiler on the S.S. Norway had extensive fatigue cracking and deteriorated materials that caused it to rupture under steam pressure in May 2003, the National Transportation Safety Board said in a report adopted last October. The Norway, the lines only steam-powered ship, was docked in Miami when the boiler exploded. Seventeen workers were injured, but none of the 2,135 passengers were hurt.

title: True and Untrue Confessions
description: What did Martin Tankleff look and sound like when he confessed in 1988 to bludgeoning and slashing his parents to death? Did he seem like a killer or a confused 17-year-old being pressured into admitting something that he did not do? Well never know. There is no video or audio recording, just an incomplete narrative, handwritten by detectives, which Mr. Tankleff signed, quickly repudiated, and spent nearly two decades trying to undo.

title: The Battle of the Mitts
description: Ever since Barack Obama won big in Iowa, Mitt Romney has been running as a change candidate. It is a little strange to see a guy whose party has been in power for years standing in front of a big blue Washington is Broken sign, but I think we have already determined that Romney is nothing if not really, really adaptable.

title: On a Board, Shredding and Stomping, but Mostly Falling
description: I COMMITTED to my executive pursuit of snowboarding by deliberately falling down on my butt. It was minus 17 degrees on the slopes of Whiteface Mountain outside Lake Placid, N.Y. My 56-year-old body was wrapped in long johns, a fur-lined jacket and wind pants. With my black rental helmet, amber goggles and black felt face mask, I fancied myself a winterized Power Ranger. I was determined to drop in, air it out and stomp a ride  just as soon as I learned what all of that meant.

title: Picking Pockets? Nah, Surfing Shoulders
description: The stop at Grand Central barely amounted to a pause. On the evening of Nov. 29, at the end of a long, wearing day, a man on his way home to Connecticut decided to get a beer for the trip. Almost without breaking stride, he dashed up to a wall of cash machines, took out $40, bought his beer and caught his train.

title: Alongside the History of the Nation, the Story of Jewish Immigrants
description: PHILADELPHIA  Alongside some of the most historic landmarks in the United States, a building is rising that will tell the story of the national immigration experience through the life of the Jewish people.

title: Awards Season, and the Swag Goes to ... Few
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The Hollywood writers strike has claimed many casualties in the past few weeks, including this Sundays Golden Globes award ceremony, an important precursor to the Oscars. And now it threatens another beloved Tinseltown institution: the swag bag.

title: What Is Lurking in a Laptop?
description: To the Editor:

title: Colorado: Woman Missing After Avalanche
description: Rescue crews were searching for a woman reportedly swept away by an avalanche in southern Colorado, and searchers continued to hunt for two New Mexico snowboarders who have been missing in southwestern Colorado since last weekend. The authorities said a man reported his sister missing after they were hit by an avalanche Thursday near the 14,345-foot Blanca Peak. Ground crews were searching, but a helicopter was forced back because of high wind, said Carol Orton, a spokeswoman for the Alamosa County sheriff.

title: With Economy Slowing, All Speeches Are Turning to It
description: WARREN, Mich.  Presidential hopefuls of both parties pivoted sharply to the economy on Friday, proposing new federal spending plans, help for homeowners facing foreclosures and tax cuts and making promises to preserve and create new jobs.

title: Searching for Happiness? Beware of Commercials
description: The surface of a production by the French-Austrian performance group Superamas is so shiny and so deeply comical that its pretty wrapping almost  but not quite  masks the seriousness of its core. As part of the Under the Radar Festival, the collective returned to the Kitchen on Thursday with the final installment of a trilogy, BIG, 3rd episode (happy/end), a purposeful exploration of the most lauded of Oprah-approved emotions: happiness.

title: Teachers Sue to Block Hotel Workers Union Vote in Nevada Caucus
description: LAS VEGAS  Nevadas state teachers union and six Las Vegas area residents filed a lawsuit late Friday that could make it harder for many members of the states huge hotel workers union to vote in the hotly contested Jan. 19 Democratic caucus in Nevada.

title: The Burger and Latte Combo
description: McDONALDS assault on Starbuckss coffee hegemony is not a bet-the-franchise move, but it is a wrongheaded strategy that is bound to lose, according to Chris Dannen, writing on Fast Companys blog this week (blog.fastcompany.com).

title: Disney Reports Chiefs Compensation
description: LOS ANGELES (AP)  Robert A. Iger, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, received a compensation package in the 2007 fiscal year valued by the company at $27.7 million, according to an analysis of documents filed Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Debt Relief Made Harder for Homeowners
description: Bankruptcy filings began climbing last year, as the housing crisis and rising consumer debt began to take their toll.

title: Iraq Passes Bill Easing Limits on Former Baathists
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi Parliament passed a bill Saturday to allow some former officials from Saddam Husseins party to apply for government positions, in the first of the political benchmark measures to pass after months of American pressure for progress.

title: A Long-Dry California River Gets, and Gives, New Life
description: INDEPENDENCE, Calif.  What Los Angeles took a century ago  a 62-mile stretch of river here in the parched Owens Valley  it is now giving back.

title: Bush and Congress Seen Pushing for Stimulus Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration and Congressional leaders, increasingly concerned about a possible recession, are moving closer to agreeing that an economic stimulus package is needed soon, Washington officials said Friday.

title: Old Worries Bring Big Decline
description: In many ways, the markets seem to be stuck in a loop.

title: Dismay at Plan to Shut 2 Newark Hospitals
description: NEWARK  The demise of a community hospital is always painful, but residents here awoke Friday to the depressing news that two of the citys most beloved hospitals will close in the spring.

title: Real Estate, Cheap and Scary
description: HERES one way of dealing with home prices that remain stubbornly high despite the recent downturn: Buy your second home first.

title: Demand More From Libya
description: To the Editor:

title: Probation in Case of Stolen Cruise Photos
description: A man who tried to extort $1.3 million from Tom Cruise in exchange for stolen photographs of his wedding to Katie Holmes was sentenced to two years probation, The Associated Press reported. Marc Lewis Gittleman was also fined $3,000 after pleading guilty on Sept. 21 to interstate transportation of stolen property. Mr. Gittleman, a computer technician, obtained thousands of photos from a damaged hard drive that was brought to his workplace by a photographer. He then contacted David Hans Schmidt, 47, who was known for peddling nude pictures and sex tapes of celebrities, and sent Mr. Cruise an e-mail message demanding $1.3 million to keep the pictures private. The authorities set up a sting operation to catch the two men. Mr. Schmidt pleaded guilty to transmitting threatening communications with intent to extort and hanged himself in September.

title: Bush Promises to Return to Israel
description: JERUSALEM  As he left on Friday for Kuwait, President Bush promised to return in May for Israels 60th anniversary, a visit that could serve as additional pressure on both Israelis and Palestinians to negotiate a peace treaty by the end of his term.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Picture captions with an article on Tuesday about the aftermath of a disputed presidential election in Kenya misspelled the name of the presidents ethnic group, whose members were targets of much of the violence by opposition supporters. They are the Kikuyus, not the Kiyukus.

title: A 16-Year-Old, Two Families and One Hard Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: New Role in Pakistan: Lessons for Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Breaking the Habit of Disposable Diapers
description: TERESON DUPUY thinks reusable diapers are having their back-to-the-future moment.

title: Bush Prepared to Slow Reduction of Forces in Iraq
description: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait  President Bush said Saturday that he was prepared to slow or even halt further reductions of forces in Iraq, emphasizing that any decision depended on security and the stability of the Iraqi government.

title: Policies on Juvenile Detention
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nature of Reasons: Two Philosophers Feud Over a Book Review
description: Over the ages, philosophy has offered valuable guidance on profound questions of truth, beauty and existence, yet still unresolved is the conundrum of how to respond to a bad book review.

title: Museum Attendance Drops in Sweden
description: Visits to Swedens national museums dropped nearly 20 percent last year after they ended their free admissions policy, Agence France-Presse reported. The culture ministry said that Swedens 19 national museums, 16 of them in Stockholm, recorded some 6.5 million visits in 2007, down from around 8.0 million a year earlier. The decline came after Swedens government pushed through new admission fees to the museums starting on Jan. 1, 2007, two years after the previous government had removed the fees.

title: A Combative Thompson Sways Voters
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  John and Ann Berenberk dutifully watched the umpteenth Republican presidential debate on television on Thursday night and had an epiphany. It was about the candidate they had previously referred to as the tall, silent one. Fred D. Thompson.

title: Magic and Mayhem From a Video Game
description: Like actors in an amateur stage play, the large, mostly all-star  or has-been star  cast of In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale look, rather dazedly, to be playing dress-up.

title: Bank of Americas Chief Makes Big Bet
description: Kenneth D. Lewis has gambled on bold acquisitions to build Bank of America into the nations largest bank.

title: Louisiana: Supremacists to Rally in Jena
description: A white supremacist group will be allowed to hold a rally in Jena on Martin Luther Kings Birthday without posting a $10,000 bond after a federal judge questioned the constitutionality of the requirement in pretrial conferences, officials said. The Nationalist Movement, based in Learned, Miss., wants to protest a march held last September to support the Jena Six, a group of black teenagers charged in the beating of a white schoolmate on Dec. 4, 2006. Towns are permitted to have ordinances for groups wanting to protest or march, said Walter E. Dorroh Jr., the town counsel. But if the law requires a bond, he said, it must have a provision to set that aside for indigent groups or have an appeals process. Jenas ordinance did not, he said.

title: Footnote
description: Aidan Quinn completes the cast of the new history play by Richard Nelson, Conversations in Tusculum, at the Public Theater. Mr. Quinn is to play Brutus alongside Brian Dennehy as Cicero, Joe Grifasi as Syrus, Gloria Reuben as Porcia, David Strathairn as Cassius and Maria Tucci as Servilia. Previews begin Feb. 19.

title: British Peer Cites Twins Who Married Unwittingly
description: LONDON  A brother and sister who were parted at birth and adopted by different families married without knowing of their biological relationship, and then won an annulment, a leading anti-abortion campaigner, David Alton, said in the House of Lords on Friday.

title: Director of Music at Trinity Steps Down
description: Owen Burdick, the organist and music director at Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan, who significantly improved its musical offerings and became a major fixture on the early-music scene, abruptly left his job on Monday after 17 years.

title: Ailing District to Get Grant for Schools
description: Legislative leaders announced on Friday that they had reached an agreement for an $8 million bailout of the financially troubled, 2,800-student Roosevelt school system in Nassau County after earlier efforts stalled last fall.

title: Clintons Move to Tamp Down Criticism From Blacks About Recent Comments
description: WASHINGTON  The Clinton campaign moved Friday to try to quell a potentially damaging reaction to recent comments by Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton that have drawn criticism from African-Americans just as the presidential primary campaign reached Southern states with significant numbers of black voters.

title: Nevada: O.J. Simpson Jailed
description: O. J. Simpson was taken into custody in Florida and will be brought before a judge in Las Vegas on accusations that he violated terms of his bail in an armed robbery case. District Attorney David Roger of Clark County, Nev., said that in a voice-mail message, Mr. Simpson told his bail bondsman to contact a co-defendant, Clarence Stewart, and express frustration about testimony given at the hearing where Mr. Simpson, Mr. Stewart and Charles Ehrlich were ordered to stand trial. Mr. Simpson had been instructed by a justice of the peace not to have contact with anyone involved in the case  not even by carrier pigeon.

title: For McNamee and Clemens, a New Dispute
description: Brian McNamee told federal authorities last summer that Roger Clemens developed an abscess on his buttocks about the same time that McNamee said he was giving him steroid injections during the 1998 season, according to a lawyer with knowledge of details of the case.

title: Lack of Supervision Noted in Deaths of Home-Schooled
description: Ten states and the District of Columbia, where Banita M. Jacks was charged on Thursday with four counts of first-degree murder in the deaths of her four daughters, have no regulations regarding home schooling, not even the requirement that families notify the authorities that they are educating their children at home.

title: Resurrecting an Urban Earth Mother
description: Synesthesia, the sensory phenomenon in which musical sounds can be perceived as specific colors and objects, was a condition experienced by the phenomenally gifted singer-songwriter Laura Nyro, who died 10 years ago. So states the sometime Broadway singer Judy Kuhn in Serious Playground: The Songs of Laura Nyro (a nightclub spinoff from her 2001 Off Broadway show, Elis Comin), playing Thursday evenings at Iridium through Jan. 31. (Ms. Kuhn also has an album with the same title.)

title: Munch Thieves Draw Longer Sentences
description: The Norwegian Supreme Court on Friday increased the sentences of two men convicted of stealing two masterworks by Edvard Munch, The Scream and Madonna, right, and ordered a new trial for a third convicted man, The Associated Press reported. The paintings were stolen in August 2004 in a daylight raid on the Munch Museum in Oslo. They were recovered by police nearly two years later, and are undergoing repairs for scrapes, punctures, loose paint and moisture damage. Last month the three men appealed their 2006 sentences. In answer, Norways highest court unanimously ruled that the prison terms for two of the men, Petter Tharaldsen and Stian Skjold, were not long enough, considering the irreplaceable national cultural value of the paintings. The court increased Mr. Tharaldsens sentence by one year, to 10  years, and Mr. Skjolds sentence by six months, to six years. The court did reject the conviction of a third man, Bjoern Hoen, saying that testimony in his trial may have been tainted, and sent his case back for a new trial.

title: Keep Up the Fight on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Rituals and Symptoms in a Triple Bill of Movement
description: Is this true? Do we believe this? These questions  constantly asked by actors about their own performances and those of their colleagues  should apply across the board in the arts. During the new triple bill presented by Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet on Thursday night, they came to mind again, but because I could not believe in, or find truth in, more than two-thirds of what was before me.

title: On Texting, a Question of Access or Invasion
description: NASHVILLE  Like many 17-year-olds, Jrue Holiday does not answer his cellphone.

title: Should Voter ID Be Required?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleveland Sues 21 Lenders Over Subprime Mortgages
description: CLEVELAND  Cleveland is suing 21 of the nations largest banks and financial institutions, accusing them of knowingly plunging the city into a financial crisis by flooding the local housing market with subprime mortgage loans to people who could never repay.

title: Indian Point Nuclear Waste Moved to New, Dry Home
description: Nuclear waste may not have found a permanent resting place, but 32 bundles of spent fuel rods from the Indian Point 2 plant in Westchester County have found a home suitable for at least the next few decades  a steel and concrete cask surrounded by razor wire, floodlights and surveillance cameras about 300 feet from the reactor building.

title: Nets Fade in Fourth as Celtics Take Over
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Suddenly, and for no apparent reason, the Nets began handling the basketball Friday as if it weighed 22 pounds instead of 22 ounces. Open shots hit the rim, and passes skipped off their hands and to the Boston Celtics.

title: A Tale of Teaching in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Stirs Concern Kazakh Oil Deal May Be Scuttled
description: MOSCOW  Shares in the Italian oil company Eni dipped on Friday after a Russian news agency reported that the government of Kazakhstan was preparing to cancel a contract with a consortium led by Eni that is developing the Kashagan field, one of the worlds largest oil projects.

title: Anxiety for Luxury Brands as Tiffany Reports Slowdown
description: Not even luxury retailers are immune.

title: Inquiry Focuses on Withholding of Data on Loans
description: An investigation into the mortgage crisis by New York State prosecutors is now focusing on whether Wall Street banks withheld crucial information about the risks posed by investments linked to subprime loans.

title: Nepal: Crucial Election Set for April
description: An election to choose an assembly that will rewrite the Constitution and guide Nepal to a new political system after the downfall of the monarchy will be held April 10, the government said. The election has been postponed three times since June.

title: Obama Giving Clinton a Race in Her Backyard
description: With Senator Barack Obama vowing to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on her home turf, the Democratic presidential primary in New York on Feb. 5 is shaping up as the states most competitive since 1992, when Bill Clinton took up a rivals mantra of change to all but cinch the nomination.

title: Justices to Hear Case Testing Rule on Witness
description: WASHINGTON  A defendants right to cross-examine the prosecutions witnesses is among the most valuable of constitutional rights in the courtroom, one to which the Supreme Court has paid increasing attention in the last few years. A landmark decision in 2004 held that unless the witness is available for cross-examination, the state cannot ordinarily introduce any incriminating statements the witness made before disappearing.

title: United We Fall
description: Austin, Tex.

title: At a Child-Murder Trial, Raising Questions All Parents Face
description: The prosecutor posed a series of questions about the challenges of raising children, the necessity of discipline, the ubiquity of corporal punishment, and the matter of how hard is too hard.

title: Still Waiting to Seize the Moment
description: Visiting the Middle East this week, President Bush sounded an unaccustomed note of diplomatic urgency. He insisted that Israel and the Palestinians will conclude a peace agreement before he leaves office in early 2009, and he tried to rhetorically prod the process along.

title: Gas Terminal Gets Nearer to Approval
description: HARTFORD (AP)  A liquefied natural gas terminal proposed for Long Island Sound moved a step closer to approval on Friday with a finding by the staff of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that it would have no major environmental impact on the region.

title: Publicly Financed Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Price on Flights of Fantasy
description: MY husband and I struggle to stay in sync financially  which is being polite about it.

title: Body Double Onstage
description: Miley Cyrus uses a body double. A YouTube video shows the 15-year-old entertainer as Hannah Montana dancing onstage during the popular Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus Best of Both Worlds tour. She goes offstage through a trapdoor, but another girl, identically dressed and with blond hair, appears and briefly stands in as Hannah. Ms. Cyruss public relations firm denied that anything underhanded was at work. The switch, it said, is used in only one song to help speed the stars transition from Hannah to Miley.

title: Iran Encounter Grimly Echoes 02 War Game
description: WASHINGTON  There is a reason American military officers express grim concern over the tactics used by Iranian sailors last weekend: a classified, $250 million war game in which small, agile speedboats swarmed a naval convoy to inflict devastating damage on more powerful warships.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens
description: Record oil prices widened the United States trade deficit in November as the cost of imported petroleum outpaced a modest rise in exports.

title: Baseball Adds Department to Investigate Drug Use
description: Major League Baseball has set up a department of investigations to look into allegations of illegal drug use by players and other threats to the integrity of the game, Commissioner Bud Selig announced Friday.

title: State to Audit No-Bid Award of Citys School Contracts
description: The state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, is opening an audit of the City Education Departments increasing practice of awarding contracts without competitive bidding. In the past five years such contracts have totaled $315 million.

title: An Actor Whose Approach to Singing Lets the Words Take Center Stage
description: As a devotee of Stephen Sondheims musicals and a big Johnny Depp fan, I was surprised, intrigued and very dubious when I first heard that Mr. Depp would play the title role in Tim Burtons film of Sweeney Todd.

title: Kenyan Opposition Calls for New Rallies and Sanctions
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyas opposition leaders on Friday called for three days of nationwide protests next week and urged foreign governments to impose sanctions over the countrys flawed elections last month.

title: Pass Coverage: The Long and the Short of It
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It seemed a complicated question, but R. W. McQuarters had a one-word answer. If so many N.F.L. wide receivers are tall, he was asked, why are so many cornerbacks not even six feet?

title: Comics and Other Reading Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Blackhawks Potential Gives the Fans a Reason to Cheer
description: CHICAGO  As fans stood for the national anthem before a game last weekend, clapping and cheering while the singer belted out the last words, they filled the United Center with noise, something that had been sorely missing during years of dismal Blackhawks games. It was excited, hopeful, vibrant, this-game-is-going-to-be-fun noise.

title: Hadrians Head to Visit Hadrians Wall
description: Two hundred years after it was pulled from the silt of the River Thames, a bronze head of the Emperor Hadrian, below, ruler of the Roman Empire from 117 to 138, will leave the British Museum for the first time, bound for sites along the 73-mile wall he ordered constructed in Northern England to mark the Roman frontier, the BBC reported. The head, once part of a statue thought to have been displayed in London in 122 to commemorate Hadrians visit, is to be exhibited at Tullie House in Carlisle next month and at the Segedunum Roman Fort, Baths and Museum in Wallsend in April, before returning for the exhibition Hadrian: Empire and Conflict on July 24.

title: The Gawker Job Interview
description: The following is an instant-message exchange between Nick Denton, the owner of Gawker Media, and Richard Morgan, who was eventually hired as a reporter at Mr. Dentons flagship Gawker.com, but who quit earlier this month, after his first full day on the job. This exchange, in which Mr. Denton discusses much of his philosophy behind Gawker, occurred on Dec. 19, 2007. Mr. Morgan provided the transcript.

title: Hong Kong-Macao Hydrofoils Collide in Fog
description: Two high-speed hydrofoils ferrying passengers between the Chinese territories of Hong Kong and Macao collided in heavy fog off Macao, seriously injuring 19 people, the Macao government said. Hours earlier, another high-speed ferry traveling from Hong Kong to Macao with more than 370 passengers hit a small fishing boat. No one was injured.

title: Shifting Through the Company Catalog
description: Four choreographers were represented in the program presented by New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. Still, the folks in the companys marketing office seem to have run out of steam when they named it Four by Four, unless a new subscription series for off-road enthusiasts has crept into the roster. The selection of ballets was odd and rather pallid, though each of the four choreographers has played a major role in the development and maintenance of City Ballet. But standout performing saved the day.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday about Oscar Pistorius, who runs world-class times on artificial lower legs, referred imprecisely to Lou Brissie, a World War II veteran who nearly lost a lower leg in combat and went on to pitch in baseballs 1949 All-Star Game. He was a left-hander, not a righty.

title: Pakistan Warns U.S. on Attacking Al Qaeda on Its Own
description: WASHINGTON  President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan warned in an interview published Friday that any unilateral attacks by the United States against Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters in his countrys tribal areas would be treated as an invasion.

title: Japan Approves Bill on Afghan War
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government on Friday pushed through a special law authorizing its navy to resume a refueling mission in the Indian Ocean as part of the American-led military effort in Afghanistan.

title: Stake Is Bought in IAC/InterActiveCorp
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, the entertainment and Internet retailing company controlled by the billionaire John C. Malone, purchased 14 million shares of IAC/InterActiveCorp, the company controlled by Barry Diller, for $339.5 million.

title: Marion Jones Sentenced to Six Months in Prison
description: WHITE PLAINS  Marion Jones, the track and field star who pleaded guilty in October to lying to federal agents about her use of performance-enhancing drugs and her connection to a check-fraud case, was sentenced to six months in prison at the United States District Court here on Friday.

title: Chrysler and Nissan in Production Deal
description: DETROIT  Chrysler and Nissan of Japan took the first step toward a possible broader alliance on Friday, reaching agreement for Nissan to supply Chrysler with a small car to be sold in South America.

title: Hailed, From Everest to Park Avenue
description: In March 1954, 10 months after his triumphant ascent of Mount Everest, the newly knighted Sir Edmund Hillary embarked upon a victory tour of the United States.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report from The Associated Press in the N.B.A. roundup in some editions on Friday about Detroits victory against San Antonio misidentified the Pistons player who had 23 points and 15 rebounds. He is Rasheed Wallace  not Ben Wallace, a former Detroit player who is now with Chicago.

title: Agency Acts to Cut Delay in Gaining Citizenship
description: Federal officials said Friday that they had agreed on an emergency plan to hire back about 700 retired government employees in an effort to pare an immense backlog in applications for citizenship by legal immigrants.

title: Refugees in the Cold
description: Thousands of elderly and disabled refugees who have found safety in the United States in recent years may soon find out just how cold and equivocal Americas welcome can be. These vulnerable newcomers are subject to a federal law that cuts off their disability benefits if they do not become citizens within seven years.

title: Respond to Todays Column: The Battle of the Mitts
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Jan. 12 column.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III catches air (and snow) on Whiteface Mountain in his first foray in snowboarding.

title: You Stink. I Love You.
description: From The Economist, on a dating site inspired by research into mens smelly T-shirts:

title: Tonight on the Blog: Detroit at Ottawa, LIVE
description: Tonight at 7 p.m. Eastern time on the Times hockey blog, well be bringing you our live play-by-play commentary of the Senators-Red Wings game, right as it unfolds at Scotiabank Place in Kanata, Ont. Its the first and only regular-season meeting of the two best teams in the National Hockey League  the Sens, who are running away with the Eastern Conference, and the Wings, who have already run away with the West. Its the big game of the season, and well have it for you, LIVE, with Lew Serviss describing the action.

title: Whale Hunters Hunted
description: Anti-whaling campaigners caught up with Japans whaling fleet on Friday in what has become an annual cat and mouse game across the vast stretch of Pacific waters off Antarctica. The crew of Greenpeaces whaler-hunting Esperanza, a 237-foot ship, has been blogging and posting fresh photos. The Web site also has three webcams through which visitors can monitor the hunt for the hunters.

title: Citing Impact of Strike, Studios Begin Canceling Deals With Writers, Producers
description: ABC Studios on Friday became the first TV studio to terminate production deals as a result of the Hollywood writers strike, The Hollywood Reporter (via Reuters) reports. Close to 30 writing and nonwriting producers who dont have active projects have been axed.

title: Directors Will Begin Talks With Studios
description: The Directors Guild of America and Hollywoods production companies said Friday that they planned to start formal contract negotiations on Saturday, promising a major break in the entertainment industrys labor troubles, Michael Cieply reports.

title: The Early Word: Countrywide
description: Now that the focal points of Iowa and New Hampshire are behind us, the race is becoming increasingly disparate geographically. Of course, while thats standard for presidential elections, the early states failure to knock out any of the major candidates adds a whole new dimension of blurriness to the race.

title: Saturday Kickoff: Goodbye to McFadden?
description: In a move that can hardly be qualified as surprising, Darren McFadden looks like hes headed to the N.F.L. ESPN.com is reporting that McFaddens father sent the appropriate paperwork to the N.F.L. this week, clearing the way for McFadden to skip his senior season at Arkansas and enter the draft.

title: Rewind | The Pitti Mens Shows
description: T Magazines mens fashion director Bruce Pask filed this report on the mens-wear trade show Pitti Immagine Uomo, just concluded in Florence, Italy.

title: Romney Highlights Michigan Roots
description: Mitt Romney, a Michigan native who emigrated to Massachusetts after high school, played up his local roots in several appearances here on Saturday.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, Jan. 12:

title: A Vegan Cannibal?
description: From NBC Channel 5 in Texas:

title: Endorsements Can Look Good or Bad
description: Quite a lot of endorsements have been in the news lately, most notably for Senator Barack Obama, who has been racking up big names since his win in Iowa. With endorsements often come credibility, access to donors and e-mail lists and, in the case of unions, boots on the ground. But sometimes, endorsements can be more trouble than theyre worth.

title: Manglish as a Second Language
description: As the packages found here attest, globalization continues to take its toll on English. We can probably guess what the producer meant by janitavy towel (below), but can anyone explain the square of milk (above)?

title: ECC: Magnitka  by Shootout  Make It to the Final!
description: Metallurg Magnitogorsk earned a place in the European Club Championship final by beating a stubborn Slovan Bratislava in a penalty shootout today in St. Petersburg. The game ended in a 1-1 draw, so it went to penalties, where Magnitka defenceman Aleksei Kaigodorov scored twice to win the game for the Siberians.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Jan. 13
description: The primary battles are playing out on the Sunday news shows.

title: And the Rangers Answer Is  Malik?
description: Trying to jar his team out of its current doldrums, Rangers Coach Tom Renney decided to juggle his defensive pairings for tonights game against Montreal at Madison Square Garden.

title: FINAL: Senators 3, Red Wings 2
description: Tonight we bring you live commentary of the match between the league-leading Detroit Red Wings and the Easts best team, the Ottawa Senators. Lew Serviss is at the keyboard.

title: Forget Silver; Huckabee Gets the Gold
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee often jokes about how desperately his campaign needs money, but a story he told supporters at a rally here Saturday night may illustrate just how desperate that need really is.

title: As Snow Falls, Packers Advance
description: The Green Bay Packers won their first postseason victory in four years.

title: On the Trail
description: Presidential candidates campaigned in Michigan, Florida, Nevada and South Carolina on Saturday.

title: Giving In to Pressure, Washington State Is Perfect No More
description: LOS ANGELES  The Washington State mens basketball team should have felt at ease Saturday in Pauley Pavilion, where it has won one game in its history. In fact, Washington State ought to have felt as if it were playing its identical twin, going up against a U.C.L.A. team that relies, as the Cougars do, on a physical and aggressive defense, a selfless offense and a general stout-heartedness.

title: Editors Choice
description: AMERICAN CRESCENT: A Muslim Cleric on the Power of His Faith, the Struggle Against Prejudice, and the Future of Islam and America, by Hassan Qazwini. (Random House, $26.95.) Qazwini wants Muslim Americans to immerse themselves in the life of this country.

title: Almost Famous, but Still Working a Grocery Shift
description: THESE are strange times for Chad L. Coleman, an actor and a resident of Brooklyn, whose name you probably do not recognize. But if you are one of the fervent few who have watched the HBO series The Wire over its past two seasons, his face will be familiar. Mr. Coleman, who plays a parolee trying to leave crime behind and start a boxing gym, knows that very well by now, from people jumping out of cars to greet him, stopping him on the subway or just grinning across a crowded coffee shop.

title: A Terror Threat in the Courts
description: Newark

title: Coaches Wanted in the Game of Life
description: NOTHING quite fit Shawn Driscolls schedule, or her passion, until she became a life coach. Her job is to help people set and achieve goals in their careers and their personal lives.

title: Lindsay Stieber, Lee Milstein
description: Lindsay Rebecca Stieber, the daughter of Denise R. Stieber and Michael H. Stieber of North Caldwell, N.J., was married on Saturday evening to Lee Charles Milstein, the son of Marjorie D. Milstein and Eddy L. Milstein of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Howard Goldsmith officiated at Capitale, an event space in New York; his wife, Rabbi Jennifer Goldsmith, also participated in the ceremony.

title: Emerging Markets, in Emerging Currencies
description: AS emerging-market bonds have racked up strong gains and become more expensive in recent years, fund managers seeking new opportunities have often turned to such debt that is denominated in local currencies.

title: Over Rome and Above New Zealand
description: With Valentines Day drawing near, there are two offers that will sweep lovers off their feet  or at least off the ground. The Hassler Roma (www.hotelhasslerroma.com), atop the Spanish Steps, has a skyline package that includes a helicopter tour of the city and three nights in a suite. Valid through Feb. 28, it starts at 6,570 euros, or $9,855 at $1.50 to the euro. For those looking for a more remote outing, the Otahuna Lodge (www.otahuna.co.nz), near Christchurch in New Zealand, is offering a Romance Among the Vines package that includes a helicopter trip across the Banks Peninsula and the Canterbury High Country to the Waipara Valley wine district for a wine tour and lunch. The package, which starts at 4,700 New Zealand dollars, or $3,560 at 1.32 New Zealand dollars to the U.S. dollar, also includes two nights in a suite and two tasting dinners with wine pairings.

title: Remaking Paramount by the Seat of His Pants
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Never Grow Up
description: For 21st-century kids growing up surrounded by video games, iPods and YouTube, the idea of playing cats cradle with a piece of string or snatching quarters off ones elbow may seem as quaint as the corncob dolls in Little House in the Big Woods. In fact, one worries that all these old skills will be swatted aside by the Nintendo Wiis wireless controller. But now The Encyclopedia of Immaturity is here to preserve that knowledge  and to document a few hundred more goofy tips, tricks and gross-out moves of its own.

title: Ellis Wins Comeback Award
description: Greg Ellis made a major impact for the Dallas Cowboys at outside linebacker and Saturday was named as The Associated Presss N.F.L. Comeback Player of the Year. Ellis went from a nonfactor in Dallas to a Pro Bowl player in his new position after spending most of his career as a defensive end. He had 12  sacks, forming a dynamic pass-rushing force with the All-Pro linebacker DeMarcus Ware.

title: For Magnet School, Protests and Hurdles
description: GREENWICH

title: The Wire: What About the Women?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Contemporary Twist on Traditional French
description: FACED with todays dining trends toward grazing, fusion cuisine (particularly Asian), and the use of local and organic foods in a lighter style of cooking, most traditional French restaurants have been forced to beat em, join em or simply close up shop. Jacques Loupiac, owner of La Panetire in Rye, has decided to join em, gingerly, and his new direction is clear.

title: Bush Urges Arab Allies to Confront Iran
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  President Bush urged wary Persian Gulf allies on Sunday to rally against Iran before it is too late, even as the International Atomic Energy Agency announced that the country had agreed to answer outstanding questions about its nuclear programs within four weeks.

title: Boxing Day
description: He had a thing for blue. Also clay pipes and Victorian postcards, ticket stubs, bits of tulle, starfish and old clock parts. He was drawn to automats and secondhand-book stalls, corresponded with ballerinas, filmed pigeons, liked pie.

title: Under My Skin
description: How do you write a book about someone about whom next to nothing is known? For most writers, the answer would be move on to the next subject. But Bill Hayes has an unusual set of skills. The author of previous books on insomnia and blood, he is part science writer, part memoirist, part culture explainer. The Anatomist, his appealing new book about the man behind Grays Anatomy, combines his search for the remaining traces of Henry Gray with a memoir of his own experience as a dissection student and a scalpels-eye tour of the body.

title: Ancestral Allure
description: The dewy and innocent milkmaid at the center of Thomas Hardys tragic novel Tess of the dUrbervilles is destroyed not by rape or heartbreak; what does her in is genealogy. The problems start on the books first page, when a troublemaking parson calls Tesss bumpkin father Sir John.

title: Animal Spirits
description: In his 2005 film, Grizzly Man, Werner Herzog reconstructed the final years of Timothy Treadwell, an animal advocate who went into the Alaskan backcountry to live among the bears he loved, and  in an unanticipated form of bonding  was eventually devoured by one of his subjects. Herzog was fundamentally dismissive of Treadwells project, finding no kinship, no understanding, no mercy ... only the overwhelming indifference of nature. He believed Treadwells death was pointless. Those of us who have ever loved a pet may feel otherwise. Animals  wild or domestic  are sentient creatures and have much to teach us about our own emotional lives.

title: The Afterlife of Cellphones
description: 1. Cellphones in Hell

title: McCain and Romney Tangle Over Job Losses in Michigan
description: WARREN, Mich.  Senator John McCain and former Governor Mitt Romney battled Saturday over how to rejuvenate Michigans rusting economy as the two remained in a tight race in the final 72 hours heading into the states Republican primary.

title: Unfinished Debate on Iraq
description: Iraq will be a central challenge  perhaps the central challenge  for whoever succeeds President Bush and has to repair the profound damage he has wrought with a war that should never have been fought and has been managed so ineptly. The candidates must talk more to the American people about when troops will be withdrawn and how it will be done, as well as how they will manage relations with Iraq and the region.

title: Correction: Traveling the Globe on a Single Ticket
description: The Practical Traveler column on Dec. 30, about booking around-the-world airline tickets, rendered incorrectly the name of a city in New Zealand. It is Christchurch, not Christ Church. In addition, it included a quotation that contained a statement that is factually incorrect. A travel agent is quoted as stating that it is preferable to travel westward, with the rotation of the earth. In fact, the earth rotates west to east.

title: North Island Coast of Small Wineries and Big Pleasures
description: VISITORS to New Zealand usually plot a trip to the South Island to taste notable wines or glimpse iconic scenery. Yet an hour north of Auckland, on the North Island, you can find an alternative wine destination, on the Matakana Wine Coast, where boutique vineyards and cafes offer specialty wines and sophisticated sustenance at the end of a drive alongside dramatic bays and through sheep-dappled hills.

title: Closely Watched Trains
description: SOMEWHERE under the corner of Avenue of the Americas and 14th Street, at 2:42 p.m. on a Tuesday, the subway platform was quiet. The L train to Brooklyn had pulled away at 2:40  four minutes later than it was supposed to, according to one of the light-up signs that for more than a year have been hanging above the platform to inform riders of approaching trains  and another was due in one minute.

title: Coaches in Texas Welcome Clemens
description: WACO, Tex.  In the fight of his life, Roger Clemens has been called a cheat and has been summoned to defend himself under oath before a Congressional committee. But some people in Texas still love him.

title: Real Director of Fake Fights
description: RICK SORDELET causes an awful lot of fights to break out. But for the most part no one gets hurt.

title: A Law Office Thats Young at Heart
description: THE former offices of Kriss & Feuerstein, a real estate law firm, were a safe mix of traditional furniture in a modern shell.

title: A Defenseman Brings Offense to the Capitals
description: After starting the season poorly enough to get their coach fired, the Washington Capitals have found their legs.

title: Infinite Jest
description: Right from its perplexing title and mysterious 16th-century epigraph  These demanders for glimmer be for the most part women; for glimmer, in their language, is fire  Nicola Barkers latest novel, Darkmans, is difficult to grasp. The narrative has barely begun before youre plunged into a detailed (and somewhat bewildering) exploration of the history of Ashford, in Kent, and the impact of the Channel Tunnel on the region. Yet once youre in the grip of this broad, funny, deeply strange book  once you and Darkmans are grappling with each other  neither you nor the novel is likely to let go.

title: Clinton Accuses Obama Camp of Distorting Her Words
description: RENO, Nev.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Saturday accused Senator Barack Obamas campaign of distorting her remarks to suggest that she had cast aspersions on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: D.M.V.: No GETOSAMA Vanity Plate
description: Smithtown

title: Researchers Create New Rat Heart in Lab
description: Medicines dream of growing new human hearts and other organs to repair or replace damaged ones received a significant boost on Sunday when University of Minnesota researchers reported success in creating a beating rat heart in a laboratory.

title: Evaluating, by the Book
description: Two annually updated portable wine books by influential British critics help focus consumers attention on Long Island wines. Both in hardcover, popular and easy to find, they are Hugh Johnsons Pocket Wine Book 2008 and Oz Clarkes Pocket Wine Guide 2008.

title: Consumer Man
description: Im one of those people who yell at store clerks. Not just any store clerks, but the ones who are rude, incompetent or indifferent. In other words, all store clerks. Im the guy who always has to speak to the manager. In my head, Im Consumer Man: a superhero fighting on behalf of oppressed consumers the world over. In my wifes head, Im crazy.

title: Loathe Thy Neighbor
description: For all the acts of cruelty committed between its covers, Sara Paretskys BLEEDING KANSAS (Putnam, $25.95) might as well have been a crime novel requiring the services of her series sleuth, V. I. Warshawski. Set in the rural Kaw River Valley, where the author grew up, and sparked by a feud between two families that pioneered this farm region during the 1850s, the multigenerational narrative bristles with the kind of prickly social issues that give substance to Paretskys detective stories. But the pointed absence of her Chicago private eye may indicate that some of the social conflicts currently polarizing the American heartland cant be resolved in the fair-and-square manner of genre tradition.

title: Why Reading Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Abbazia and Gregory Rowland
description: Amy Elizabeth Abbazia, a daughter of Catherine Schmitt of Huntington, N.Y., and Patrick Abbazia of Brooklyn was married on Saturday to Gregory Samuel Rowland, the son of Joncie Rowland and Hugh Rowland Jr., both of Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hoke, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Manhattan.

title: In Texas, Weighing Life With a Border Fence
description: GRANJENO, Tex.  Rafael Garza, a former mayor of this small border city, stood steps from the back door of his simple brick house and chopped the air with a hand. This is where the actual fence would be, he said.

title: Rebirth Along the River
description: THE Fishtown district of Philadelphia was known as a tight-knit Irish Catholic enclave  and a place to score drugs. Set along the Delaware River in the northeastern part of the city, the area was the former home of a Stetson hat factory and a Schmidts beer plant, before its brick warehouses and shad markets were abandoned.

title: Where to Eat? A New Restaurant Genre Offers Manhattan More Choices
Who Helps Whom in the Peace Corps?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Recovered Addict Struggles to Keep His Home
description: Around Gabriel Crumitys neck, a few inches to the left of the scar from chemotherapy treatments, hangs a gold medallion the size of a quarter with a triangle punched out of the middle.

title: Cuomo Set to Look Into 1988 Long Island Murders
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer appointed Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo on Saturday as a special prosecutor to investigate the 1988 murders of a Long Island couple whose son, Martin H. Tankleff, was recently released from prison after doubts arose over his conviction in their deaths.

title: The Rebel Director, Sincere and Hopeful
description: SOME would say Carl Forsman is too well adjusted to be cutting edge. Hes polite and soft-spoken, and he had a happy childhood in Chatham, N.J., where his mother was a high school teacher and his father was a Methodist minister. Recently, over a healthy breakfast, Mr. Forsman even described his worldview as humanistic, saying he believes compassion and generosity are a normal, natural part of existence.

title: Who Needs Country Radio? Not Tom T. Hall
description: Franklin, Tenn.

title: A Million Miles vs. a Few More Smiles
description: JAMES T. KANE, a corporate consultant on customer loyalty, has a news flash for his airline.

title: A Main Street With Real Staying Power
description: WHILE new neighborhoods strive to produce a sense of community, usually by creating a Main Street-like district in a dense residential center, real old-fashioned Main Streets are dying off across New Jersey, particularly in areas not supported by good transportation networks or well-heeled shoppers.

title: The Crying Game, and the Political Herd
description: ONE of the CNN regulars working the New Hampshire primary last Tuesday, Jeffrey Toobin, turned up his palms during the broadcast and vented his and many viewers impatience with his co-hosts analysis of Hillary Clintons surprising lead.

title: French Cabinet Position Not Enough? Then Try Mayor.
description: PARIS  The justice minister wants to be a mayor. So does the finance minister. And the culture minister. And the government spokesman.

title: Easy Slogans, Twinkly Funk and One Busy String
description: Jeffrey Lewis

title: The Bone Diaries
description: Near the beginning of Frances Itanis latest novel, Remembering the Bones, Georgie Danforth Whitley, a Canadian widow, is bound for London to meet Queen Elizabeth. The two share a birthday, and Georgie is one of 99 commoners invited to a celebratory luncheon. But despite careful planning, she will not make it to the palace. En route to the local airport, her car slips through a pair of guard posts and flips down a hillside, throwing her into the brush and leaving no trace of her accident visible from the road above. Helpless and alone, she staves off thirst by sucking on the silver buttons of her cardigan. Panic is staved off by revisiting 80 years worth of memories in which she has been daughter and granddaughter, sister and niece, mother, wife and widow.

title: Emily Haverstick, Tyler Umbdenstock
description: Emily Whalen Haverstick, a daughter of Jessica W. Haverstick and Samuel A. Haverstick II of Short Hills, N.J., was married on Saturday to Tyler Johnson Umbdenstock, the son of Linda J. Umbdenstock and Robert P. Umbdenstock of Lebanon, N.J. The Rev. Ronald W. Johnson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Caneel Bay, a resort in St. John, V.I.

title: Baby-Sitter Confidential
description: WHEN I was 17, I moved from the North Shore of Staten Island, where I had grown up, to Morningside Heights, where I was a student at Barnard College. To earn spending money, I worked on and off for the college baby-sitting service. I preferred working weekend nights, because the hours were longer. There were plenty of clients, and I never ended up going to the same house twice. This was 1968, and the pay was $1.50 an hour.

title: The Chicken Soup Chronicles
description: THE other day I felt a cold coming on. So I decided to have chicken soup to ward off the cold. Nonetheless I got the cold. This happens all the time: you think youre getting a cold; you have chicken soup; you get the cold anyway. So: is it possible that chicken soup gives you a cold?

title: Still Perfect, and Passing Game Almost Is
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Throughout their season of superlatives, the New England Patriots have rarely met an opponent that could keep pace with their offense, which made a mockery of the N.F.L. record book. The Jacksonville Jaguars, whose grind-it-out running game belies the geographic rules of football, seemed an unlikely candidate to match Tom Brady and the pinball numbers he and the Patriots put up.

title: Man Who Fought Attackers Was Rejected 3 Times by Police Dept.
description: A transit worker who stabbed a man to death while fending off a group of attackers on a Harlem street Thursday night killed a man in self-defense in 1994, and was rejected three times in the 1990s for a job on the police force, the police said Saturday.

title: Fire Erupts at Hideout of Escapee
description: ELIZABETH, N.J. (AP)  The authorities are investigating a fire that broke out early Saturday at the house where an escaped inmate from the Union County Jail was found on Tuesday.

title: The Soul of Suburbia, Captured on Film
description: Gazing out the 10th-floor window of the Joan and Donald E. Axinn Library at Hofstra University in Hempstead is quite something. On a clear day, you can see the Jones Beach Water Tower to the south, the skyscrapers of Manhattan to the west. Closer at hand, there is a striking, if more prosaic, panorama of houses  a birds-eye view of suburbia.

title: Interpreting a Blueprint for Birds
description: JAMES PROSEK is a visual artist, an author and a filmmaker. He is a musician and an environmental advocate. He is a lifelong resident of Easton and a fly fisherman who has traveled the world in search of trout.

title: Proof
description: A physicist, a biologist and a mathematician walk into a bar. Bartender says, Any of you believe in God? Which of the three is most likely to say yes? Answer: the mathematician. Mathematicians believe in God at a rate two and a half times that of biologists, a survey of members of the National Academy of Sciences a decade ago revealed. Admittedly, this rate is not very high in absolute terms. Only 14.6 percent of the mathematicians embraced the God hypothesis (versus 5.5 percent of the biologists).

title: Two Views of Innovation, Colliding in Washington
description: AS the Senate prepares to tinker with the nations patent laws this spring, its worth recalling the law of unintended consequences.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Film

title: A Co-op Board Member No Longer Lives There
description: Q A shareholder who was a board member in my co-op sold her apartment. After she moved out, she ran for the board again and was re-elected. Is it legal for a nonshareholder to be voted in as a co-op board member in New York?

title: Events in Westchester
description: Film

title: Protecting Our Lands
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Says He Could Halt Withdrawal, if Security Dictates
description: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait  A year after he ordered a large increase in American troops in Iraq, President Bush said Saturday that he was prepared to slow or even halt further reductions of forces there, emphasizing that any decision depended on security and the stability of the Iraqi government.

title: Between Rock and the River, the Going Is Slow, and Costly
description: At the eastern portion of ground zero, hundreds of workers contend with a nasty subterranean nest: steel and concrete, a defunct railroad, forgotten foundations, landfill, quartz deposits and glacial remnants in a vast pit that the Hudson River ceaselessly tries to inundate with icy, brackish water.

title: Last Years Role Model
description: Madison, Wis.

title: Footprints of Holocaust in a Battle for Lost Art
description: ARMONK, N.Y.

title: Uncertainties in the Shadow of Unrest
description: THE violence that erupted in Kenya after a disputed presidential election on Dec. 27 raised questions for those planning a trip to one of Africas most popular safari destinations. Is it safe? Can I postpone? If I cancel can I get my money back? Am I covered under travel insurance?

title: Oppo Man
description: What led you to write your new book, Confessions of a Political Hitman, which chronicles your rather unsavory career as a Republican Party operative who was hired in hundreds of political campaigns to dig for dirt on Democratic candidates? I wouldnt use the word unsavory. The voter has the right to know the history of any candidate in order to make the most educated vote.

title: The House of Myth
description: Americans have long delighted in movies like Its a Wonderful Life, Heaven Can Wait (both the 1943 and 1978 versions) and Bruce Almighty  divine comedies, to borrow the marketing shtick of the day, in which a benevolent male Judeo-Christian God and sometimes his demonic counterpart are represented by stock imagery like billowing clouds, bolts of lightning, bumbling plainclothes angels and horned creatures thumping pitchforks. The humor may be irreverent, but its always delivered with a basic attitude of respect.

title: In Swirling Snow, Packers Leave Mark
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Not quite three minutes into his first N.F.L. playoff game, Green Bay Packers tailback Ryan Grant looked up into the snowflakes as if searching for an explanation. Grant had lost his second fumble of the game, on only the third time he touched the ball. The Seattle Seahawks had converted the first turnover into a touchdown, and would soon score off the second to grab a 14-point lead.

title: Aptitude for Destruction
description: The most heartbreaking place Ive ever visited is the vast, spare, tree-lined cemetery where half a million people who died in the Nazi siege of Leningrad from 1941 to 1944, most of them civilians, are buried in gently rising, grass-covered mass graves  long, rectangular and symmetrically arrayed, each plot holding thousands of dead. From loudspeakers, tragic music swells over the grounds, where a statue of the Motherland watches over all. In pavilions near the entrance, by an eternal flame, notes and photographs of the victims are collected in glass cases.

title: Letters: Buffon and Jefferson
description: To the Editor: Richard Conniffs article "Forgotten, Yes. But Happy Birthday Anyway" (Dec. 30) on the Comte de Buffon failed to mention Buffons comical quarrel with Thomas Jefferson.

title: Take Me as I Am, Whoever I Am
description: AS a bipolar woman, I have lived much of my life in a constant state of becoming someone else. The precise term for my disorder is ultraradian rapid cycler, which means that without medication I am at the mercy of my own spectacular mood swings: up for days (charming, talkative, effusive, funny and productive, but never sleeping and ultimately hard to be around), then down, and essentially immobile, for weeks at a time.

title: Austrian Wins Giant Slalom
description: Elisabeth Grgl of Austria won a World Cup giant slalom in Maribor, Slovenia, for the first victory of her career. Grgl, who led after the first leg, finished in a two-run combined time of 2:38.49. Manuela Moelgg of Italy took second, 0.49 behind, and Denise Karbon of Italy finished third.

title: Colts Record of Success Is Failing to Stir a Buzz
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Are the Colts really sneaking up on the N.F.L. consciousness as they begin their postseason quest to repeat as Super Bowl champions? Perhaps this is partly true as they play host to the San Diego Chargers on Sunday in an American Football Conference divisional playoff game.

title: News Boxes: All for One, or One for All?
description: TOURISTS seeking the tidiest spot to grab a newspaper might consider the large box on the northeast corner of 34th Street and Fifth Avenue. The box, a multirack version that holds several publications, is well tended by the 34th Street Partnership; one recent afternoon, a maintenance worker was busily removing stickers and scrubbing away at the graffiti on the little windows.

title: Afghan Police Struggle to Work a Beat in a War
description: NAWA, Afghanistan  Many of the problems frustrating Afghanistans efforts to secure its dangerous eastern and southern provinces were evident in the bizarre tour of duty of Shair Mohammad, a police officer who spent 18 months in an isolated swath of steppe.

title: Lawsuit Over Precincts in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS  In what has become a proxy battle between the presidential campaigns of Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, the large hotel workers union in Nevada on Saturday attacked a lawsuit by another major union that would make it more difficult for hotel workers to vote in this states hotly contested Democratic caucuses.

title: Unions Pouring Resources Into Nevada Caucus Fight
description: With Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama eager to win the Democratic caucuses in Nevada next Saturday, labor unions backing Mr. Obama are in a surprisingly intense, expensive fight with those supporting Mrs. Clinton.

title: Paperback Row
description: RALPH ELLISON: A Biography, by Arnold Rampersad. (Vintage, $17.95.) With Invisible Man, published in 1952, and the essays collected in Shadow and Act (1964), Ralph Ellison established himself as a gifted novelist and analyst of black American culture. But as he struggled with a second novel he withdrew from the black community, growing ever more protective of his position as the ranking black novelist of the day and as the only black person in whatever room he happened to be standing in, Brent Staples wrote in the Book Review. Rampersad, a professor of English at Stanford, Staples continued, is uniquely qualified to examine the Ellison case. The first biography of Ellison, originally published in 2002, is also newly available in paperback. Lawrence Jacksons RALPH ELLISON: Emergence of Genius (University of Georgia, $22.95) focuses on Ellisons early years and ends as he wins the National Book Award in 1953.

title: Creating the Right Vibe in Harlem
description: WE tell people were a rock n roll band from Harlem, and they look at us like thats an oxymoron, said Mark Hermann of his group, Citizens of Contrary Knowledge. But the people around here will tell you, its all been going on for so long  blues and jazz and rock n roll.

title: Opposition Wins Taiwan Parliamentary Election
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The opposition Kuomintang party won a landslide victory in parliamentary elections in Taiwan on Saturday. President Chen Shui-bian, who has antagonized China with his efforts to forge a national identity for the self-governing island, resigned as chairman of the governing Democratic Progressive Party to take responsibility for the loss.

title: Larry, Curly, Moe and the Economy
description: NOW for a few short notes on the economy  and you can digest them along with your FiberCon and your English muffins.

title: Under His Hat
description: Nicolaus Copernicus stands in sharp contrast to the later giants of the scientific revolution. For Kepler, Galileo or Newton, biographers can draw on copious correspondence. Kepler complains to his former teacher that his son never writes home from college. Galileo protests that he cant have his house arrest suspended to visit his doctor in Florence. Newton accuses John Locke of trying to entangle him with women.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $6,363,022

title: First Wives World Is Their Oyster, Pearls Included
description: THEIR ring fingers were empty.

title: Correction: Ghosts That Haunt Pakistan
description: An article last Sunday about Pakistans history of difficulty in sustaining democracy misstated the crime for which the former prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was hanged in 1979. Mr. Bhutto was found guilty of conspiring to murder a minor political opponent, not of murdering him. (The opponent survived an assassination attempt, in which his father died.) The article also misstated the opponents home region. It was the Punjab, not Baluchistan.

title: Tara Walpert and Michael Levy
