description: Tara Ellen Walpert and Michael Alexander Levy were married Saturday evening at the State Room, an events space in Boston. Rabbi Elaine Zecher officiated.

title: Man Accused in Killing of Wife and Children
description: MASON, Ohio (AP)  The police charged a man Saturday with murdering his wife and their four children, who were pulled from their burning home the night before.

title: Drunken Driving Charge for Clinton Aide
description: Sidney Blumenthal, an unpaid senior adviser to Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign, was arrested the day before the New Hampshire primary in Nashua, N.H., on a charge of drunken driving, according to the police.

title: Letters: The Good Old Days
description: To the Editor: In response to the Practical Traveler column on Dec. 30, "Traveling the Globe on a Single Ticket," about airline alliances for round-the-world travel, I heave a sigh of nostalgia for the good old days of far simpler international air travel decades ago, before the advent of computerized reservations and e-mail.

title: Latvians Say Foe Got Signals From Her Tube of Lip Balm
description: Has it come to this, that a player who has a remarkably good result in a tournament is immediately suspected of cheating?

title: The Train in Spain Keeps Moving Faster
description: Trains are getting faster in Spain. AVE (Alta Velocidad Espaola, or Spanish High Speed) is working to decrease the travel time between Madrid and Barcelona from four hours to three by spring (and ultimately to two and a half hours, once the latest version of the European Train Control System has been installed). In December, travel times were shortened between Madrid and Segovia (from two hours to 30 minutes) and Madrid and Mlaga (from four hours to two and a half). It is the goal of the Spanish government to upgrade 4,350 miles of track to high-speed quality by 2010, making all major cities reachable by train from Madrid within four hours, and from Barcelona within six and a half hours (www.renfe.es; for English, click inside the box found at the lower left on the site).

title: Racing to Capture Vanishing Languages
description: JEREMY NEWBERGER, a documentary filmmaker, was camped on the banks of Lake Titicaca in Bolivia with two scientists studying the worlds vanishing languages. They were trying to meet a medicine man who is one of about 100 people who still speak Kallawaya, when one of the scientists, Gregory D. S. Anderson, became ill.

title: For Duck Farms, Dealing With New Limits
description: MORICHES

title: A War of the States Over Dredging Rules
description: IN October, Connecticut officials told the Post Road Boat Yard in Westchester that the marina had until Nov. 1 to produce the necessary New York permits before they would sign off on plans to place material from dredging in Long Island Sound.

title: Standoff at Nassaus Last Trailer Park
description: SYOSSET

title: Has Gawker Jumped the Snark?
description: THE ideal Gawker item, Nick Denton, the owner of Gawker Media, wrote in an instant message last month to a prospective hire, is something triggered by a quote at a party, or an incident, or a story somewhere else and serves to expose hypocrisy, or turn conventional wisdom on its head.

title: Congestion and Other Terminal Illnesses
description: AS I sat on the tarmac for an hour waiting to deplane at Leonardo da Vinci Airport outside Rome after a short-haul flight earlier this year, the pilot got on the public address system to apologize to me and my fellow passengers. Sorry, he said, everybody knows this is one of Europes worst airports.

title: Obsessed With Her Novels
description: To the Editor:

title: Is the Apartment Rent Stabilized, or Not?
description: Q When I signed the lease on my West Village rental three years ago, I was told it was not stabilized, and the rent-stabilization language was crossed out of the lease. The rent at that time was $1,695.

title: Family Recipes for German Favorites
description: GERMAN restaurants are a dying breed on Long Island. It was therefore a cause for celebration when the Village Lanterne opened in Lindenhurst in late October. The Village Lanterne has the same ownership as the Black Forest Bakery, just a few doors away. Tom Lorch, who took over the bakery five years ago from his father, Herb, uses the recipes of his mother, Ursula, at his restaurant.

title: Notable Thai, on the Outskirts of Town
description: WITH Thai Tida, the jumping new restaurant in Lambertville, theres good news and bad news. The good news is the solid food, the service, the crowd  the whole experience.

title: A Building Boom to Welcome the Winter Games
description: AS the sawdust flies in anticipation of the 2010 Winter Olympics, new hotels  and many other things as well  are rising around Vancouver.

title: Dancing Permitted
description: MY father was a strong influence in my life in terms of my values and performance, but he didnt believe that a woman should go to college.

title: Scotch Purists Beware
description: THE first time I visited the restaurant Shortys.32, acting on a tip about a new single-malt Scotch cocktail, the bartender turned me down. No such drink on the menu, he claimed.

title: There Is a God
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Swells, Tall Waves, Wipeouts and a Perfect Ride
description: HALF MOON BAY, Calif.  Big blue waves heaved under a bright blue sky for the sixth Mavericks Surf Contest at Pillar Point in Half Moon Bay on Saturday. After all the tall wave faces were carved and wipeouts endured, Greg Long, 24, gripped the coveted first-place check for one of the worlds premier big-wave surfing competitions.

title: Eating in Cuban
description: On Oct. 30, 1961, an 8-year-old boy named Eduardo Machado and his 5-year-old brother boarded a Pan Am plane in Havana and flew to Miami. They were part of Operation Peter Pan, a program run by the United States government, Cuban exiles and elements of the Catholic Church that transported about 14,000 children from Cuba to the United States. The flight was brief, but it took Machados home away from him, embittered him toward his parents and changed his life forever.

title: A Murderous Talent
description: Serial killers are localists. They murder within their chosen patch  a red-light district, a city quarter  and tend not to travel beyond it. Changing location means recoding the method; learning a new vernacular of murder. It also increases the risk of detection: an out-of-towner is more likely to be remembered from a crime scene.

title: Another Win for Grange
description: Jean-Baptiste Grange of France won a World Cup slalom Saturday in Wengen, Switzerland, capturing his second victory in two days. He easily held off Jens Byggmark of Sweden, finishing with a combined time of 1 minute 34.81 seconds. Grange won Fridays super-combi for the second World Cup victory of his career.

title: When a Mountaintop Might as Well Have Been the Moon
description: EDMUND HILLARY, short of breath in the freezing wind, took a few more whacks of the ice ax and surmounted the top of the world, Mount Everest, as high as anyone can aspire and still be rooted on terra firma. At the time, May 29, 1953, it was a magnificent achievement of human daring and endurance culminating an era of crossing oceans, penetrating continental interiors and reaching the ends of the earth.

title: Shira Tydings and Lee Bressler
description: Shira Elizabeth Tydings, a daughter of Dorothy A. Tydings and Dr. Lawrence H. Tydings of Laurel Hollow, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Lee Alexander Bressler, a son of Jane C. Bressler of New York and the late Martin J. Bressler. Rabbi Neil Kurshan officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

title: Correction: That Campaign Button Can Sting You at Work
description: The Career Couch column last Sunday, about presidential politics in the office, referred incorrectly to comments by Daniel I. Prywes, a partner in the Washington offices of the law firm Bryan Cave. When Mr. Prywes said that soliciting participation in political events might be permissible, he was referring to both employers and employees, not just employees. In addition, he said that employers who coerce employees to make political contributions would be violating federal election laws; he was not referring to employees who solicit contributions.

title: Dr. Jonathan Shay on Returning Veterans and Combat Trauma
description: Dr. Jonathan Shay is a psychiatrist who specializes in treating the psychic wounds of war. He is also the author of two books, "Achilles in Vietnam: Combat Trauma and the Undoing of Character" and "Odysseus in America: Combat Trauma and the Trials of Homecoming," which examine the experiences of combat veterans through the lens of classical texts.

title: Michigan Voters Wary of Revitalization Talk
description: STANDISH, Mich.  This quiet town, tucked between the thumb and the rest of the fingers in Michigans mitten, feels worlds away from the struggling automobile factories of Flint and Detroit. But economic gloom has made its way here just as it has seeped through so much of this state.

title: Pistons, Long a Team of Veterans, Reload With Youth
description: Change is coming slowly to one of the N.B.A.s steadiest teams.

title: New Coordinator for Browns
description: Mel Tucker, Clevelands defensive backs coach the past three seasons, is the clubs new defensive coordinator. He will replace Todd Grantham, who was fired Friday. Clevelands defense was one of the N.F.L.s poorest in 2007. ESPN.com

title: What Awaits the Met
description: THOUGH expected, the news last week that Philippe de Montebello would retire as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art elicited a range of emotions among museumgoers: pride and sadness at the end of a stellar era, and anxiety about the future.

title: Closing the Power Gap Between a Hybrids Supply and Demand
description: A HYBRID that drives the first miles of each trip on batteries charged from the electricity grid  and burns no gasoline at all until the batteries have been drawn down  is a widely sought antidote to $3 gasoline. But no automaker has yet shown a battery pack for such a vehicle, known as a plug-in hybrid, that would be durable enough for mass production.

title: A Long Haul, and No Place to Park His Rig
description: Ridgefield

title: Sabeen Ali and Hashim Mian
description: AS first-generation Pakistani-Americans, Hashim Mian and Sabeen Ali moved easily between the cultures. Both read the Koran and visited relatives in Karachi and conversed in Urdu at home. They also drank beer, liked to party and fell in love without their parents knowing about it.

title: Mr. Rogerss Neighborhood
description: IN the 1970s, when Jim Rogers was working with George Soros on some little-known hedge funds, he took to riding his motorcycle around the region looking for the perfect place to live, perhaps a house facing the water or a park.

title: Rangers Rebound Against (Who Else?) Montreal
description: Something about the Montreal Canadiens seems to bring out the best in the Rangers.

title: It Finally Came: The Year of the REIT Retreat
description: AFTER rewarding investors with rich returns for the last seven years, real estate mutual funds reversed course in 2007, ending the year with sizable declines, as the sector succumbed to the turmoil in the credit markets.

title: Above the Sofa, Sour Notes
description: MICHAEL LEVITON, 27, is a ukulele player. His girlfriend, Leah Hayes, 26, plays a three-stringed guitar called a thunderstick. They met in 2003 during an open-mike night at the Sidewalk Cafe on Avenue A in the East Village.

title: Australian Open Evens the Playing Surfaces
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Blue has taken over the seasons first Grand Slam tournament: from the signs, to the uniforms of the ball boys and girls, to above (and below) all, the playing surface.

title: Cruel Jokes, and No One Is Laughing
description: WHAT do banks call it when a troubled borrower abandons her home, sending them the keys?

description: NATHANIEL LAGEMANN had just clinched a tournament victory at a chess club in Santa Monica, Calif., when the artist Diana Thater found him discussing the match with his final opponent.

title: So We Thought. But Then Again . . .
description: HARRY S TRUMAN once said he wanted to talk to a one-armed economist, so that the guy could never make a statement and then say: on the other hand. Yet economic knowledge continues to progress in unexpected ways. Here are a few of the things we learned in the last 12 months:

title: Lonesome Blues on the Rikers Bus
description: ON a recent Sunday morning, a 20-year-old woman named Christina Cruz walked up to a near-toothless, gray-haired man sitting on a portable bench on East 149th Street near the Grand Concourse. She held out a $10 bill.

title: Correction: Review of The Long Embrace: Raymond Chandler and the Woman He Loved
description: A review on Dec. 30 about The Long Embrace: Raymond Chandler and the Woman He Loved, by Judith Freeman, misstated the type of fibrosis that killed Chandlers wife, Cecilia. It was pulmonary, not cystic.

title: American Finishes Second
description: Ronny Ackermann of Germany won his third Nordic combined World Cup event of the season ahead of Bill Demong of the United States in Val di Fiemme, Italy. Ackermann completed the two jumps and cross-country race in a combined time of 41:52.2. Demong finished 34.1 seconds behind.

title: On the Lookout for Out-of-District Students
description: AT 8 oclock one morning, Juanita Ludwig and Vincent Constantino, employees of Clifton Public Schools, are knocking on the door at a house to check a tip. Someone had said a Clifton elementary school student did not really live there and was sneaking in from another district.

title: Easy-Bake Oven Alternative
description: A visit to Cookie Party, an 1,100-square-foot emporium that opened the day before Thanksgiving in a nondescript shopping center in East Hanover, leaves a few distinct impressions.

title: 3 Names Put Tech Above the Fray
description: IT was a very good year for technology mutual funds, which returned more than 17 percent, on average, according to the research firm Morningstar. But a few tech funds seemed to be operating on a far faster track in 2007, lapping the field while racing to gains of 30 percent or more.

title: Uneasy Mix: Suburbs and Gun Ranges
description: FAIRFIELD, N.J.

title: Road Show to Sell Toll Raises
description: TRENTON

title: No Quick Fix to Downturn
description: As leaders in Washington turn their attention to efforts to avert a looming downturn, many economists suggest that it may already be too late to change the course of the economy over the first half of the year, if not longer.

title: Say What You Will
description: Throughout his long career as an author and a reporter and columnist for The New York Times, Anthony Lewis has been one of the most inspiring advocates of a heroic view of the American judiciary. Each year I read aloud to my criminal procedure students the final paragraphs of Gideons Trumpet, Lewiss definitive account of the 1963 Supreme Court case that recognized a constitutional right to court-appointed counsel. They never fail to bring a lump to the throat  at least to mine. In his new book, Freedom for the Thought That We Hate, Lewis offers a similarly heroic account of how courageous judges in the 20th century created the modern First Amendment by prohibiting the government from banning offensive speech, except to prevent a threat of serious and imminent harm. Many of the great advances in the quality  the decency  of American society were initiated by judges, he writes. The truth is that bold judicial decisions have made the country what it is.

title: Far From Home, but Almost There
description: At 6 feet 9 inches and 260 pounds, with a soft touch around the basket and from the perimeter, Samardo Samuels stands out on a basketball court.

title: 36 Hours in Hollywood
description: HOLLYWOOD is one of those rare places that live up to their stereotypes, right down to the sign. But with minimal effort, it can offer a whole lot more. The pedestrian-friendly district represents both Los Angeles past, with icons like the Capitol Records building, and the citys future  multi-ethnic, vertical, dense. A recent renaissance means there are now million-dollar condos, trendy restaurants, celebrity watering holes and a world-class movie theater. But there are still tattoo parlors, sex shops and homelessness. Tying it all together is the Hollywood Walk of Fame, where it is hard not to be at least momentarily tickled (hello, Mister Rogers) or merely confused (who the heck was he?). It remains a place that only Los Angeles could produce.

title: Lottery Numbers
Great Adaptations
description: Mass-market adaptations make Great Books go bad. Or so conventional wisdom would have it. But every so often, plundering and pillaging a canonical text for the sake of entertainment gives it the kiss of life. Take Beowulf and Paradise Lost. The unpalatable truth is that both originals are now virtually unreadable. Beowulf is written in Old English, an inflected Germanic tongue that looks a lot less like our language than one would hope. As for Miltons epic, its in normal English, but its blank verse is so densely learned, so syntactically complicated and philosophically obscure, that its almost never read outside college courses. Even Samuel Johnson, writing 100 years after Milton, said: Paradise Lost is one of the books which the reader admires and lays down, and forgets to take up again. None ever wished it longer than it is.

title: Hows the Family? Fascinating
description: BERLIN

title: Dawning of a New Day to Get Organized
description: WILTON, Conn.

title: Three Approaches, and Each Paid Off
description: WHEN the stock market climbs, as it did in much of 2007, mutual fund managers can ride it upward, like hawks clustered in a rising column of warm air. But when it slides, as it did late in the year, smart picks  and a dollop of luck  matter more. Free rides become fewer.

description: MOBY is singing a sweet song to his co-op board at 300 Central Park West.

title: What to Ask When It's Over
description: The questions that arise after a divorce can be every bit as tough as those that precede the decision to part. The following were drawn from conversations among the women who attended the First Wives World meeting on Jan. 2, and from postings on the groups Web site:

title: Voices From Past Are Echoing Today
description: They were two of the distinctive American voices, born 97 miles apart as the catbird flies. Red Barber and Mel Allen spoke the language of baseball in Southern cadences to Northern ears. In this year of debates and primaries and elections, their regional accents may still be relevant as Americans sort out exactly who we are.

title: Paris: Afaria
description: In Paris, gastronauts are accustomed to trekking to the untouristed fringes of the city in search of good, affordable cooking. For over a decade, La Rgalade has lured diners to a bland stretch of the 14th Arrondissement for its enriching 32-euro dinner menu. In the hills of the 20th lies Le Baratin, an organic wine bar where three courses and a glass of unfiltered red will set you back about 20 euros, while the 14-euro lunch menu at Le Chteaubriand draws modern-cooking cultists to the edge of the Bastille.

description: Pity the Professionals

description: Directing the Grants

description: Yorktown

description: To the Editor:

title: A Prodigy, Sure, but Theres Plenty of Normal Teenager, Too
description: MADISON

title: Iraq Eases Curb for Former Officials of Husseins Party
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi Parliament passed a bill on Saturday that would allow some former officials from Saddam Husseins party to fill government positions but would impose a strict ban on others. The legislation is the first of the major so-called political benchmark measures to pass after months of American pressure for progress.

title: Correction: Stocks in the News
description: The Stocks in the News on the DataBank page last Sunday contained incorrect labels for the stocks estimated price-to-earnings ratios. They were for 2008, not 2007.

title: A Renters Right to a Pet in a Condo Building
description: Q I just moved into a large condominium building, renting the apartment directly from its owner. Upon moving in, I was informed that renters are prohibited from having dogs, while owners are not. Upon further inquiry, I discovered that the buildings condo board was considering instituting a monthly $250 fee for renters who want to have dogs.

title: Borges and the Web: An Additional Precursor
description: To the Editor:

title: For Him, the Devil Is in the Rhymes
description: THE Irish playwright Mark ORowe cuts to the chase. Best known for writing Howie the Rookie, a darkly comic blood-and-guts crime story told with racing momentum that made its debut at the Bush Theater in London in 1999 and came to New York two years later, he writes brutal plays that are so packed with energy and verve that they can leave an audience dizzy.

title: Ways to Whittle Your Energy Bill
description: WITH home heating fuel prices near $3 per gallon, it may be time to take serious energy-saving action in your home or apartment.

title: Whats Next for New York City Real Estate?
description: LOOKING back, 2007 was supposed to be the year that the Manhattan residential real estate market slowed down and began to look a bit more like the slumping national market.

title: Levy Seeks More Funds to Fix Storm Damage
description: AS the Suffolk County government begins receiving its $12 million share of a $20 million federal aid package for repairs to publicly owned coastal areas damaged by rain, wind, waves and erosion from last Aprils northeaster, the county executive, Steve Levy, is asking for more.

title: Letters: The Lives They Lived
description: Of all the great tributes in your annual Lives issue (Dec. 30), I was most touched by The Guardians, by Dexter Filkins. Perhaps because I, like Omar Mora, am a native of Ecuador and because, as a young immigrant with only a green card, I, too, decided to serve my adopted country by enlisting in the United States military in 1958, a service that continued through the war in Vietnam. But here is where the similarities end. Although a volunteer for duty, I did not see combat, and I now enjoy the fruits of my service and of being a naturalized U.S. citizen. Omar not only heroically served in combat but also made the ultimate sacrifice for his new country. As a result, tragically, he never got to enjoy the benefits I did. Gracias compatriota!

title: Amy Minella, Reeves Ambrecht
description: Amy Finch Minella and Reeves Dunning Ambrecht were married Saturday evening on Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. William Welles Eddy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Pauls Church.

title: Inside the List
description: THE CELLAR MASTER: Sometimes a book can sell tens of thousands of copies, year after year, and not make a dent in one of The Timess best-seller lists. Such a book is the annual issuing of Kevin Zralys Windows on the World Complete Wine Course. According to Zraly, these volumes have sold some 2.5 million copies since the first edition appeared in 1985. Zraly became the cellar master at Windows on the World the year the restaurant opened in 1976. He was 25 at the time. The books grew out of the wine courses hes taught ever since. Windows on the World is a hard place for me to talk about, Zraly said recently. I was there for 25 years, from the day it opened until Sept. 11, 2001. He would have been in 1 World Trade Center on the day it fell, he said, had he not stayed home because of his oldest sons birthday. After 9/11, I had no desire to do anything, or to teach anymore, he said. But many people wanted me to carry on the legacy. Really, the only things now left of Windows on the World are the wine courses and my books.

title: Heather Whitaker, Richard Maloy Jr.
description: Heather Ann Whitaker, the daughter of Barbara A. Whitaker and Frank M. Whitaker of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married on Saturday to Richard Alan Maloy Jr., the son of Ann M. Maloy and Mr. Maloy Sr. of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. The Rev. James P. Kvetko, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the National Hotel in Miami Beach.

title: Of the Migrating Of
description: I could of avoided this subject because its not too big of a deal, but to observe these mistakes a couple times a day  and to see one as the headline of a full-page ad accepted by at least two major newspapers  makes me want to fall off of my chair.

title: Correction: The Eye on the Prize

description: A steady stream of men, their ruddy faces and colorful clothing splashed with mud, marched into the Jockeys Room at Aqueduct Raceway on Wednesday. Louis Olah, his hands dripping with soapy water, was there to greet them.

title: Having a Little Work Done (at the Mall)
description: ANDREW RUDNICK snickered when he first saw a medical spa offering Botox and laser hair-removal services on a visit to a Las Vegas mall in 2002. He laughed at the thought of someone  anyone  shopping for the latest fashions, grabbing a bite to eat and then, oh yeah, strolling in for a quick shot of Botox to zap out a nasty wrinkle.

description: Ted Nordhaus and Michael Shellenbergers 2004 essay The Death of Environmentalism sparked passionate debate and earned them a reputation as the bad boys of the environmental movement. Judging from their new book, Break Through, which expands their argument in favor of a new approach to the urgent problem of global warming while continuing to go after former allies with gusto, its a status they clearly relish.

description: When we moved to Westchester from the city a few years back, one of the things I missed most poignantly was Manhattans abundance of low-priced Indian restaurants. There are some great places to get Indian food in the county, but the cost isnt exactly on par with the East Village.

title: A Note to the Unconverted
description: THE huge wave of condominium development that has washed over Manhattan in the last few years may be beginning to wane, but this does not mean renters fearing that their lives will be disrupted by a condo conversion should let their guard down.

title: Fill in Your Dance Card on the Queen Mary 2
description: If youre single and find yourself inspired by Dancing With the Stars to pick up some new moves on vacation, you might want to check out the new dance cruise for solo travelers aboard the Queen Mary 2. Organized by Singles Travel International (www.singlestravelintl.com), the trans-Atlantic cruise to Paris, departing from Brooklyn on July 8, includes daily dance lessons (salsa, cha-cha, merengue) and nightly dance soirees set to a full orchestra in the ballroom. The seven-day cruise, which starts at $1,699, double occupancy, and includes all meals, will also give participants the chance to explore the ships amenities, like the Canyon Ranch spa, the Veuve Clicquot Champagne Bar and the planetarium. For those wanting to dance in warmer climes, there will be a Nov. 21 dance cruise departing from Brooklyn and ending in Fort Lauderdale with stops in St. Kitts, Grenada and Bonaire.

title: Correction: Datebook
description: The Datebook column on Dec. 30, about the Santa Barbara International Film Festival, misstated the name of the hotel that is offering a festival package. It is the Four Seasons Resort the Biltmore Santa Barbara, not Santa Monica.

title: Stand by Your Man
description: What might it feel like to be married to a charming and handsome man, highly accomplished, in many ways admirable, who propelled himself from modest beginnings to the highest reaches of our government, who professes undying love for you and appears to feel it, but who cant stop himself from repeatedly cheating on you in the most public and humiliating ways? What might it be like to stay married to this man, to spend years of your life campaigning for him, covering for him, while at the same time living apart, leading a separate life and discovering new and personally gratifying pleasures and ambitions? What would it be like to reunite with him, on your own terms, with your own power base, to love him more fully, perhaps even to trust him  only to have your faith finally, fatally shattered?

But one aspect of the neighborhood has changed drastically: these fine restaurants have all opened in the past 18 months.

description: THE BASICS Nobody has put a bigger bet on Macao, the only place in China with legalized gambling, than the Las Vegas Sands Corporation, which has just opened the 3,000-suite Venetian as the cornerstone of a 20,000-room complex of 14 interconnected hotels. Built to handle Macaos 55 percent annual growth in gambling, the Venetians casino is three times the size of the largest casino in Las Vegas.

title: Comedy Central, by Way of the Torah
description: AS usual, Mendy Pellin wore the traditional black coat and hat of a Hasid and sat on a high stool facing the camera. He read quickly through a page of notes, shook his head vigorously in the way of preparation, and signaled his readiness with a nod to his cameraman, Dovi Trappler. As the camera rolled, Mr. Pellins voice dropped to the confident baritone of an overeager news anchor.

title: The Highest Fashion: A Royal Accessory
description: The new year started smashingly for Glenda Bailey, editor in chief of Harpers Bazaar: she was one of 235 citizens of Britain and its commonwealth countries named to the Order of the British Empire as part of Queen Elizabeths New Year Honours List.

title: Searching for Sharapova, and Finding a Dichotomy
description: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif.  The story revolved around an airport, which figures, because Maria Sharapova lives out of a suitcase, crisscrossing the globe to play tennis. As she told it, the man walking to the car on the tarmac in Miami looked really familiar.

title: Admissions Anxiety, With a Twist
description: IF you are friend or kin to one of Connecticuts 47,018 public and private high school seniors, pause a moment to take this humane little quiz. If, over the next two and a half months, you encounter this young person, how might you greet him or her?

title: Correction: The Deluge Before the Dollar
description: The Off the Shelf column last Sunday, a review of A Nation of Counterfeiters, a book about the history of American counterfeiting, referred incorrectly to a practice in Britain, where counterfeiting was once considered a treasonable act. It was punishable by death without benefit of clergy, meaning the special protections once granted to clergy members and certain others to be tried in separate church courts and to avoid some types of punishment; it did not have to do with access to clergy for absolution rites.

title: Clinton and Obama Spar Over Remark About Dr. King
description: Escalating their fight for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama engaged in a war of words on Sunday over Mrs. Clintons recent remark about the role that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. played in securing civil rights laws in the 1960s.

description: PLANTSVILLE

title: In the Farm Bill, a Creature From the Black Lagoon?
description: IT may not surprise you to learn that much of the pork and chicken and beef and milk that you buy at the grocery store comes from huge, industrial-size operations that bear little resemblance to the quaint family farms that adorn many food packages.

title: A Collectors New Plan
description: This is an exciting time for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. It has nearly completed a major new addition called the Broad Contemporary Art Museum. But times are not quite as exciting as the museum had hoped. Eli Broad, the financier and collector for whom that new addition is named, has announced that he will not be giving away his art after all. Instead, his foundation will keep permanent control of his collection, making loans to museums in much the way museums lend works to one another.

title: Datebook
All the Foods of the Mideast at Its Stable Center
description: ON a warm evening last fall, a handful of old men shuffled into Al Quds, a big, overly lit restaurant on a bustling stretch of King Hussein Street in downtown Amman. Platters of syrupy pastries, crispy phyllo shells and fried dough were artfully stacked in the windows. But the men were there for the house specialty: mansaf.

title: A Not-So-Simple Plan
description: I am, lets face it, not the best eater. I dont like foods touching, I insist that meat, fish and even fowl be perilously rare, and I know how to say sauce on the side in five languages. When I was a kid, my diet consisted of American cheese slices that I would not eat unless they had been cut into pretty shapes. On my birthday, I was allowed to skip dinner.

title: Calm as Ever, Brady Wins With Postseason Poise
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  From the leagues most valuable player to a litany of both personal and team records, Tom Brady has not been shortchanged on awards during this transcendent Patriots season.

title: N.C.A.A. Ban on Text-Messaging as Recruiting Tool Will Remain
description: NASHVILLE  Members of N.C.A.A. Division I upheld a ban on text-messaging to high school students Saturday at their annual convention, defeating a movement by college coaches who had argued that the new technology was vital to connecting with teenage prospects.

title: The Howl That Haunts West 66th Street
description: IT was a Tuesday afternoon on far West 66th Street and the subject, as usual, was noise. Lloyd Lederkramer, a beatific-looking 56-year-old with hip black eyeglasses, stood on the balcony of his building at 303 West 66th Street, on West End Avenue, and gazed at the building across the street.

title: Daunted by Data? See Prospectus Lite
description: BUYERS of mutual funds may soon get an easy-to-understand description of potential investments without having to confront that formidable outpouring of legal verbiage known as the prospectus.

title: McFaddens Father Denies Report
description: The father of the Arkansas star running back Darren McFadden denied a report that he has sent paperwork to the N.F.L. so his son can enter the upcoming draft. ESPN.com, citing unidentified sources, reported that the father, Graylon McFadden, provided the relevant paperwork early this week.I hate to be saying anything because all these false stories and everything are floating around, Graylon McFadden told The Associated Press on Saturday. But no, I didnt  and thats all Ive got to say.

title: The Right Hires
description: To afford to start a new business, I must use low-cost foreign manufacturers, some of whom likely maintain unsafe working conditions. It is difficult to be certain from here. In the relevant country, many workers doing the tasks Ill require receive low wages and face serious health problems including chronic colds , fever , stomach disorders, chest pains and tuberculosis. Is it wrong to start my business in this way?  NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: Ameristar to Open Hotel in Missouri
description: St. Charles, Mo., has come a long way since the Lewis and Clark expedition. For one thing, its no longer necessary to rough it along the banks of the Missouri River. Ameristar (www.ameristar.com), a Las Vegas-based gambling and entertainment company, is set to open the hotel at its complex in St. Charles soon. The 400-room luxury hotel, with a 7,000-square-foot spa, will be the first all-suite property for the company, whose casino, conference rooms, nightclub and restaurants have already opened in St. Charles. Highlights of the Ameristar Casino Resort Spa include an indoor/outdoor pool and sunken living rooms in each suite and floor-to-ceiling window views of the river or the city. Nightly rates start at $169.

title: Two Giants Try to Learn to Share Asia
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India will arrive in Beijing on Sunday for a three-day visit to China, with each country eager to increase bilateral trade, promote mutual friendship and offer reassurances that Asia is big enough to accommodate the ambitions of both rising powers.

title: Glad to Dance and Eager to Talk About It
description: WHOEVER first said, The road to hell is paved with good intentions might have been inspired by the purgatory of a panel discussion on the creative process. Laborious, awkward and vapid, such talks rarely offer even a glimpse into what makes artists tick. Discussions of dance, a nonverbal form, can be distinctively painful.

title: Tough Guys for Tough Times
description: YOU dont need to follow Mike Huckabee, or even politics, to appreciate that Chuck Norris is everywhere these days.

title: U.S. Presses Kenyan President and Opposition Leaders to Meet
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The American government on Saturday took its toughest position yet on Kenyas disputed elections, calling on Kenyas president and opposition leaders to meet immediately and saying that the election had been so flawed that it was impossible to know who had won.

title: Fathers and Sons
description: To be neoconservative is to bear almost daily witness to the resurrection of Adolf Hitler. Truly Hitlerian, the Washington Post columnist Charles Krauthammer pronounced Saddam Husseins saber-rattling before Iraq invaded Kuwait. Three days after the 9/11 attacks, Paul Wolfowitz, then deputy defense secretary, opined that Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda followers misread our system as one thats weak, that cant take casualties. ... Hitler made that mistake. Norman Podhoretz, the former editor of Commentary, said of the Iranian president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad last spring, Like Hitler, he is a revolutionary whose objective is to overturn the going international system. In the same month, the defense analyst Richard Perle mused on whether it had been a correct reading of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to believe that business could be done with him that would produce a result? I dont think so. These are the difficult decisions. Diplomacy with Hitler. Chamberlain went to Munich, presumably on the theory that you talk to your enemies and not to your friends, and what did it produce?

title: Lost Children, Lost Truths
description: BUENOS AIRES

title: A Passage to India
description: STANDING at the beginning of the buffet line at Jackson Diner in Queens, Krishnendu Ray took a plate from the heated stack of dishes, plopped on spoonfuls of several offerings and headed to table No. 22. There, a waiter tucked the bill into a wire stand and set down a pink plastic jug of water.

title: Defensive Line Gives Thanks for Praise, Then Takes Aim
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants face the favored Dallas Cowboys on Sunday in a National Football Conference divisional playoff game, the outcome may depend on how the Giants aggressive defensive line performs against the Cowboys big and gifted offensive line.

title: From 10 Hours a Week, $10 Million a Year
description: MARKUS FRIND, a 29-year-old Web entrepreneur, has not read the best seller The 4-Hour Workweek  in fact, he had not heard of it when asked last week  but his face could go on the books cover. He developed software for his online dating site, Plenty of Fish, that operates almost completely on autopilot, leaving Mr. Frind plenty of free time. On average, he puts in about a 10-hour workweek.

title: Colts vs. Chargers
description: Is there any team more overlooked in these N.F.L. playoffs than the Colts? All they did was win the Super Bowl last season and repeat as American Football Conference South champions with a 13-3 record. It is worth noting that the A.F.C. South produced three playoff teams, each of which won at least 10 games. That has to be good training for the playoffs.

title: Christine Julian and Garrett Moritz
description: Christine Camille Julian, a daughter of Mary and Francis Julian of Wilmington, Del., was married there on Saturday to Garrett Barak Moritz, a son of Patricia and Elan Moritz of Lynn Haven, Fla. The Very Rev. Daniel W. Gerres performed the ceremony at St. Anns Roman Catholic Church.

title: From Israel, 2,188 Varieties
description: Rising interest in Israels wines, both kosher and nonkosher, makes the 2008 Rogovs Guide to Israeli Wines ($19.95, Toby Press) invaluable.

title: A Militia of One (Well Regulated)
description: THE Supreme Court is poised to decide whether the Second Amendment guarantees an individual right to keep and bear arms or only a collective right tied to service in a state militia. While the arguments in the case will draw on history, policy and empirical data, the discussion must at least start with the text of the amendment.

title: Havent We Heard This Voice Before?
description: SHE had me at Well, that hurts my feelings.

title: A Fed Signal Cant Dispel the Gloom
description: It was another dismal week for the stock market, despite a short-lived rally on Thursday after Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, signaled that the Fed is ready to cut interest rates further.

title: The Family Ski Challenge
description: ON our first morning at Copper Mountain Resort, I watched as my 8-year-old son cut his first tracks through the powder on Vein Glory, a beginner slope below the High Point chair. I live for this! he shouted back to me as he bombed down the hill in a pizza stance, rarely bothering to turn.

title: The Corn Pudding Mob
description: Lets talk about how a washed-up rocker from New Jersey can get play on country radio but we cant, said Shooter Jennings as he stood in the buffet line at Hill Country, a barbecue restaurant in Chelsea, on a recent Thursday night. Jon Bon Jovis crossover single Who Says You Cant Go Home? was playing as Mr. Jennings, 28, the country-rock musician, waited expectantly for what he calls his favorite shoepeg corn pudding and string bean casserole this side of Texas.

title: Track Work Disrupts Service on No. 7 Train in Queens
description: The No. 7 train is to Roosevelt Avenue in Queens what the A train is to Harlem: the rhythm of the place. On Saturday, the beat was off as thousands of subway riders in some of the most diverse neighborhoods in the city endured life on Roosevelt Avenue, at least temporarily, without the train that some call the Immigrant Express.

title: Cowboys vs. Giants
description: Cowboys pass offense

title: In Spain, a Monumental Silence
description: MADRID

title: Condos With Deco in the Details
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Will Foreign Stocks Start to Disappoint?
description: FOREIGN stock markets have been an ideal refuge from troubles at home: decelerating economic and earnings growth, subprime mortgages, a subpar housing market and a tumbling dollar. But after years of strong outperformance abroad, some fund managers are bringing their investors money home.

title: Marienbad Returns, Unsettling as Ever
description: WHEN Alain Resnaiss gorgeous puzzle box of a movie, Last Year at Marienbad, reopens at Film Forum for two weeks on Friday, New York cinephiles may find themselves as mystified and delighted as their counterparts were when the film first reached Manhattan in 1962. Marienbad either does or does not tell the story of what may or may not be a love triangle that does or does not end violently, though the movie could also be presenting shards of a dream, a memory or a fantasy. What transpires among the three nameless principal characters is, the filmmakers have always maintained, up to you to figure out.

title: Correction: Caren Raine, Joel Camche
description: Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Caren Raine and Joel Camche misstated the date of their ceremony. It was Saturday, Jan. 5, not Jan. 4.

title: Thrown by Housings Shaky Foundation
description: THE fourth quarter of 2007 ended much as the third quarter did, with investors having reason to be hopeful and maybe more reason to be nervous. Both periods featured steep and sudden declines in the prices of stocks and all but the highest-quality bonds as it became clear that the broader economy and financial system were not immune to worsening conditions in the housing market.

title: Prosecutor Who Unraveled Corruption in Boston Turns to C.I.A. Tape Case
description: WASHINGTON  In 1999, John H. Durham, a federal prosecutor based in Connecticut, was assigned to wade into a seemingly impenetrable and corrupt network in Boston involving police officers, federal agents and organized crime figures.

title: Up Front
description: In the early 1990s, Jeffrey Rosen served as a law clerk to Abner Mikva, then the chief judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Rosen described Mikva in an e-mail message as a great champion of the First Amendment. Anthony Lewiss first book in 17 years, Freedom for the Thought That We Hate, which Rosen reviews on the cover, also champions the First Amendment. In his own book The Most Democratic Branch, Rosen argues that the Supreme Court is most successful when it reflects a national consensus on constitutional values. I share Lewiss admiration for the First Amendment cases, he said, but disagree that most of them were bold judicial decisions. By the time the court got serious about protecting free speech in the 1960s, a majority of the country was willing to go along.

title: Vanishing Act
description: What if the United States were at war during a presidential election  and none of the candidates wanted to talk about it? Iraq has become the great disappearing issue of the early primary season, and if nothing fundamental changes on the ground there  a probable result of current policy  the war may disappear even more completely in the new year.

title: The Two Paths to Wealth: Earn More, Spend Less
description: REDUCED to the absolute essence, there are only two ways to become richer than you are: you need more money coming in, or you must reduce the amount going out.

title: A Pig and a Priss in Their Prime (Time)
description: SELDOM, if ever, has a single comedic property gone through so many incarnations as The Odd Couple. It began life in 1965 as Neil Simons Broadway hit about the domestic discord between two divorced yet utterly dissimilar roommates, the finicky neat freak Felix Unger and the sloppy, beer-swilling Oscar Madison. It became a film (1968) and a television series (1970-75). It then morphed into a Saturday morning cartoon (1975-77), followed by a short-lived black television version (1982-83) and a more successful, virtually all-female Broadway rendering (1985-86) before reverting to basics with the 2005 revival on Broadway.

title: Will Nardelli Be Chryslers Mr. Fix-It?
description: DETROIT

title: A Power Trip With Green Detours
description: HEAR the noise, feel the thunder, experience the lightning! Detroit is firing up the pyrotechnics as it prepares to play host to the 2008 North American International Auto Show. Perhaps all the hoopla will make it easier for the industry to forget, just for a while, the stark new realities of the showroom, where car buyers seem to be falling out of love with the kinds of vehicles that made Detroit the capital of the automobile world.

title: Is Eloquence Overrated?
description: IN the end, said Theodore C. Sorensen, the celebrated speechwriter for President John F. Kennedy, what made a great speech in 1940 or 1961 is not much different from what makes a great speech in 2008.

title: Connecting to Roots With Dances From India
description: PARSIPPANY

title: Jack Brod, Early Tenant of Skyscraper, Dies at 98
description: Jack Brod, a businessman who over nearly eight decades gradually worked his way from the 7th floor of the Empire State Building to the 76th, where he reigned as the skyscrapers last original tenant, died last Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 1: Glass Houses

title: Parent Trap
description: With all the ambitious novels for young adults and fat fantasy trilogies, its easy to forget the abiding category of childrens domestic fiction  stories for 9-to-12-year-olds about school, friends and family. Beverly Cleary provided the postwar model with her books about Beezus, Ramona and Henry Huggins; Judy Blume and Norma Klein brought a little edge to the genre in the 1970s; and Ann M. Martin sold millions of books with the Baby-Sitters Club series in the 1980s.

title: Clemens Faces Dangers of Spin in Steroid Case
description: Roger Clemens has not stumped in New Hampshire, has not yukked with Stephen Colbert, and most certainly has not welled up in a coffee shop. Yet he is running perhaps Americas most provocative campaign.

title: Rushing and Posturing in Danbury
description: Congresss failure to pass meaningful immigration reform last year dispersed the debate to dozens of municipalities nationwide. On Monday night, the City Council in Danbury, Conn., will consider a question being asked in too many cities and towns: whether local police should become enforcers of federal immigration law.

title: Duel of the Titans
description: Duel of the Titans

title: In Paris, Selling a Duplex
description: PARIS

title: Teacher Talks Turn Contentious Over Letter
description: THE tone of negotiations between teachers in Mamaroneck, who have been working without a contract since the old one expired June 30, and the school district went from cooperative to contentious last week after the district sent a letter to the community suggesting that the union was to blame for the slow pace of negotiations. Teachers said the letter was misleading.

title: Lilah Schechner and Marcus Nicolaidis
description: Lilah Schechner, the daughter of Danice Bordett and Bill Schechner of Berkeley, Calif., was married on Saturday to Marcus J. Nicolaidis, a son of Lynn L. Licata of Sylvania, Ohio, and Nick Nicolaidis of Dallas. Matthew J. DEmic, an acting justice of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, officiated at the Bowery Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Facing Rumors About Future, Thomas Remains Defiant
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Defensiveness and denials filled the air Saturday afternoon, which made it pretty much like any other day recently at the Knicks trouble-filled training center. Nothing changes here except the Knicks winning percentage and their mood, which are plummeting in tandem.

title: Their Satanic Majesties
description: With its motifs of homosexuality, Satan worship, drug addiction, promiscuity, nihilism and general decadence, Zachary Lazars superb second novel, Sway, reads like your parents nightmare idea of what would happen to you if you fell under the spell of rock n roll.

title: Forecast in Arizona: Cooling Prices at Some Elevations
description: TO the casual collector, the giant car auctions around Phoenix in January have the confused and frenzied air of a commodities exchange as participants bid on Mustangs, Cobras and Ferraris, with the occasional bus and amphibious car thrown in.

title: Huckabee Splits Young Evangelicals and Old Guard
description: WASHINGTON  Much of the national leadership of the Christian conservative movement has turned a cold shoulder to the Republican presidential campaign of Mike Huckabee, wary of his populist approach to economic issues and his criticism of the Bush administrations foreign policy. But that has only fired up Brett and Alex Harris.

title: Turn Down the Burner, Fire Up the Sound
description: WHAT is it about men and stereo equipment? This fabled connection may be a clich on par with mens reluctance to ask for directions. But clichs do not exist in a vacuum  and sound cannot travel through one anyway.

title: A Remodeling Gift to Remind Tarrytown of a Churchs History
description: Tarrytown

title: No Lack of Curiosity, or Civility, at Corzines First Forum on Toll Proposal
description: LIVINGSTON, N.J.  One person blurted out that Gov. Jon S. Corzine should raise the gas tax. Another yelled that New Jerseys biggest yoke was its overabundance of elected officials.

title: A Surreal Moment in the Age of Digital
description: UNABLE to sleep the other night, I got up and wandered around the house. Everywhere I looked I saw little green lights  on the TV, the smoke detectors, the downstairs computer  and digital display screens.

title: The Moral Instinct
description: Which of the following people would you say is the most admirable:  Mother Teresa, Bill Gates or Norman Borlaug? And which do you think is the least admirable? For most people, its an easy question. Mother Teresa, famous for ministering to the poor in Calcutta, has been beatified by the Vatican, awarded the Nobel Peace Prize and ranked in an American poll as the most admired person of the 20th century. Bill Gates, infamous for giving us the Microsoft dancing paper clip and the blue screen of death, has been decapitated in effigy in I Hate Gates Web sites and hit with a pie in the face. As for Norman Borlaug . . . who the heck is Norman Borlaug?

title: Quiet on the Home Front
description: A TOP-FLOOR apartment was what Michelle Panzer and Paul Campbell wanted most. They craved the quiet that came with having no inconsiderate neighbors tromping above them.

title: Lives of Poverty, Untouched by Chinas Boom
description: YANGMIAO, China  When she gets sick, Li Enlan, 78, picks herbs from the woods that grow nearby instead of buying modern medicines. That is not a result of some philosophical choice, though. She has never seen a doctor and, like many residents of this area, lives in a meager barter economy, seldom coming into contact with cash.

title: New Listings With Your Decaf?
description: SOUTH NORWALK

title: A Bookworms Holiday
description: EVERYONE knows libraries are not just about books anymore, but no one knows it better that the women at the main information booth of the New York Public Library at 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Refusing to Let the Mob Hijack What It Means to Be Italian
description: DONT get her wrong: Rosanne De Luca Braun loves The Godfather. Ditto, The Sopranos. But she has devoted much of the last seven years to exploring why certain Italian-American stereotypes  especially the gun-toting, cannoli-loving mobster  loom so large on screen, and in the national psyche.

title: Correction: The Girl Beneath the Gilding
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 9 about Audrey Munson, who was the model or inspiration for more than 15 statues in New York City, misidentified a city near her final home, in the town of Mexico, N.Y., and her grave, in New Haven, N.Y. Both Mexico and New Haven are near the city of Oswego, on Lake Ontario  not near Lake Oswego, which is a city on Oswego Lake in Oregon. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Jan. 5.

title: Man Is Charged in Babys Death
description: The father of a 3-week-old baby was charged with murder on Saturday, nearly two weeks after the child died at a Staten Island hospital.

title: Correction: The Huckabee Factor
description: An article on Dec. 16 about Mike Huckabee misstated his academic credentials. He majored in religion at Ouachita Baptist University in Arkadelphia, Ark., not speech and communications. Speech was his minor.

title: Clinton Campaign Builds Post-Feb. 5 War Chest
description: The Clinton presidential campaign is moving this weekend to create an organizational hierarchy for its donors to accelerate fund-raising to pay for increasingly expensive advertising, travel, and voter-outreach efforts, with an ambitious goal of raising more than $10 million by the end of January, according to several of the donors and a campaign official.

title: Trend-Spotting in the N.F.L. Playoffs, Part 3
description: So unlike last Saturday with its wild fourth quarters, Saturdays playoff games started strong and then got out of hand late. What else do you see out there?

All they did was win the Super Bowl last season and repeat as American Football Conference South champions with a 13-3 record. It is worth noting that the A.F.C. South produced three playoff teams, each of which won at least 10 games. That has to be good training for the playoffs.

description: Introduced on Sunday: 2009 Ford F-150 pickup.

Dodge Seeks Bull Market

description: Images of statues and monuments to Francisco Franco, Spain's former general.

title: An Interview With Jacqueline Wilson
description: Jacqueline Wilson, 62, has sold more than 20 million books in the United Kingdom, and earlier this month was made a Dame of the British Empire. Yet while shes a household name in England, her books for children and young adults have never caught on in the same way with American readers. Her new publisher, Roaring Brook Press, is trying to change that with Candyfloss, a novel with a classic Jacqueline Wilson heroine: Floss is loyal and resourceful, and determined to stand by her hard-luck Dad when her mother takes off for a more glamorous life in Australia. Wilson answered a few questions about her work by email. The Editors

description: Introduced on Sunday: Saab 9-4X BioPower Concept.

title: Entering Hades
description: On July 11, 1991, a solar eclipse occurred in the sky over Los Angeles. At 10:12 a.m., the moon began to move in front of the sun, and by 11:28 it covered 69 percent of it. That morning, a couple of men and their children drove up to Corral Canyon Road in Malibu, northwest of the city, to watch the event.

title: Irreligion
description: Are there any logical reasons to believe in God? Billions of people over thousands of years have entertained this question, and the issue is certainly not without relevance in our world today. The chasms separating literal believers, temperate believers, and outright nonbelievers are deep. There are many who seem to be impressed with the argument that God exists simply because He says He does in a much extolled tome that He allegedly inspired. Many others subscribe with varying degrees of conviction to more sophisticated arguments for God, while atheists and agnostics find none of the arguments persuasive.

description: Introduced on Sunday: Mercedes-Benz Vision GLK Freeside.

description: Introduced on Sunday: Audi R8 V-12 TDI Diesel Concept

description: Introduced on Sunday: 2009 Kia Borrego

title: Under the G.M. Big Top
description: DETROIT  We live in a hypersophisticated marketing world. Just last week I saw - glimpsed might be the better word - an episode of The Hills on MTV, that reality show about those kids who live in the Hollywood Hills. This special episode was called Living the Life of the Hills and there were layers of graphics calling out each product and its price. Arnette sunglasses: $105. Polo shirt $75. BMW: $47,000.

title: Im Telling You, Its Like the Hollywood Writers Strike
description: Aired Friday night on CBS: President George W. Bush is in the Middle East. Hes over there right now because his approval rating is higher.

title: The Early Word: The Evangelical Vote
description: Its Sunday, and were returning to a theme thats permeated the 2008 presidential race: religion and politics. The focus this morning is on Republican presidential candidate and former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee.

title: Odysseus in America: Combat Trauma and the Trials of Homecoming
description: CHAPTER 3Pirate Raid: Staying in Combat ModeJust as some thieves are not bad soldiers, some soldiers turn out to be pretty good robbers, so nearly are these two ways of life related.Sir Thomas More, Utopia, published in 1516But will warriors lay down, together with the iron in which they are covered, their spirit nourished . . . by familiarity with danger? Will they don, together with civilian dress, that veneration for the laws and respect for protective forms . . . ? To them the unarmed class appears vulgar and ignoble, laws are superfluous subtleties, the forms of social life just so many insupportable delays.Benjamin Constant, Swiss, 17671830But all was not right with the spirit of the men who came back. Something was wrong. They put on civilian clothes again, looked to their mothers and wives very much like the young men who had gone. . . . But they had not come back the same men. Something had altered in them. They were subject to queer moods, queer tempers, fits of profound depression alternating with a restless desire for pleasure. Many of them were easily moved to passion when they lost control of themselves. Many were bitter in their speech, violent in opinion, frightening. For some time while they drew their unemployment pensions, they did not make any effort to get work for the future. . . . Young soldiers who had been very skilled with machine-guns, trench-mortars, hand-grenades, found that they were classed with the ranks of unskilled labor in civil life.Philip Gibbs, British, 1920

title: The Ultimate Passat, or the Phaeton Revisited?
description: Introduced on Sunday: Volkswagen Passat CC

title: Worst Airports in Europe? Cast your vote!
description: As a frequent (and frequently frustrated) flyer in Europe, over the past two months I undertook a completely unscientific survey of my fellow air travelers, asking them to nominate the worst airports and to explain their choices. I wrote about it in the International Herald Tribune and the New York Times. You can read about it here.

title: What Does That Do for Your Self-Esteem?
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: You know, I was reading a story in the paper today about a man who actually trains the suicide bombers in the Middle East. And he says he does not accept every person who volunteers. Well, what does that do for your self-esteem?

title: Shades of Grey
description: Paramount, through is specialty division, Paramount Vantage, is in the thick of this years Oscar hunt with There Will Be Blood and No Country for Old Men, among others. The Baggers colleague Michael Cieply spends some space and time talking with Brad Grey, the head of the studio, about how planning is a bit overrated and why his gut told him making Cloverfield, the new J.J. Abrams movie that is the biggest hand-held pic ever, would be a great way to start the new year. The Hot Blog, incidentally, takes a decidedly less sunny view of Cloverfield.

title: In the Beginning, Hyundai Did Not Make Luxury Cars
description: Introduced on Sunday: 2009 Hyundai Genesis sedan

title: Chevy and Mazda Win North American Awards
description: DETROIT  On Sunday morning, the Chevrolet Malibu and Mazda CX-9 were named 2008 Car and Truck of the Year in a brief ceremony at the Detroit auto show. Tony Swan, senior editor of Car and Driver, made the announcement in front of a large crowd that spilled into the nearby Changfeng Motors display.

title: Kitchen Magician
description: The Four Seasons is serving as a de-facto watering hole for Globe orphans, including the Bagger, who sat down with Brad Bird, the writer-director of Ratatouille. The rat caper/cuisine movie picked up an AFI citation last Friday, as one of the best films of the year, never mind the animation asterisk.

title: Missouri Senator Endorses Obama
description: LAS VEGAS  Since losing the New Hampshire primary last week, Senator Barack Obama has won a string of endorsements. The latest one came Sunday, with Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri announcing her support for Mr. Obamas presidential candidacy.

title: Turns Out We Do Need Your Stinking Badges
description: The show, or at least a simulacrum of it, will go on, and so of course there must be badges and security to match.The Bagger stopped at the Beverly Hilton for his credential photo where he met Jerry Mark, the head of EventCredentials LLC.

title: Sunday Kickoff: Neuheisels Long Road
description: Just how far has Rick Neuheisel traveled to become U.C.L.A.s new head coach? Well, as Kurt Streeter of the Los Angeles Times writes, Neuheisel began resurrecting his coaching career by volunteering as an assistant for a high school team.

title: Swag Soldiers On
description: A lot of things have been missing this weekend because of the stripped-down Globes, with its decimated roster of festivities. The Bagger wonders where those 300 vacant-eyed party girls, who were everywhere in L.A. last year at this time, are right now. Are they parking cars somewhere, getting their nails done, or thinking about going back to school and getting their MBAs?

title: Predix Later Today
description: Taking a stab at what the Hollywood Foreign Press Association will celebrate  show or no show - is a little like predicting who your batty rich aunt is going to leave all the loot to. Dreams are crushed and heartbreak ensues. It is a small, idiosyncratic bunch which has been known to be susceptible to the blandishments of stardom.

title: Milan lan: Group Hug
description: Ferres new look.

title: Clawing Our Way to the Top, With Scions Help
description: DETROIT  It wasnt MTV that pimped the Scion xD into a Coney Island claw machine, it was Scions favorite customizer Troy Sumitomo, president of the Five Axis design company. Part of the back hatch rises to become television screens watching us journalists guide the claw over a plush toy Scion (model anonymous) and push the plunger to drop it and squeeze.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, Jan. 13:

title: Dead Batteries Only, Please!
description: DETROIT  This may be the year of the hybrid at the Detroit auto show, but all the display cars with any lights and displays are purely plug-in: No high-voltage batteries are allowed to carry a charge on the show floor or in displays, said Majid Taghikhani, a hybrid expert at Johnson Controls.

title: CSI Gives CBS a Lift
description: With new episodes of ABCs Greys Anatomy and CBSs CSI at 9 p.m. on Thursday, both networks surged to the top of the nights ratings heap. CBS averaged more total viewers as CSI attracted the larger audience of the two hit shows: 18.1 million viewers compared to 17.6 million, according to Nielsens estimates. Greys Anatomy, however, trounced all competition for the night among adults 18 to 49, making ABC No. 1 in that demographic despite a weak showing at 10 p.m. for Big Shots (6.8 million).

title: Let It Snow, Let It Snow
description: DETROIT  General Motors announcement that its Saab brand would introduce a crossover four-cylinder capable of running on E85 ethanol was made with a pair of skiers dressed in white hopping out of the vehicle under a gentle fall of shaved-ice snow. The melting flakes made the stage sticky, but G.M. Chief Executive Rick Wagoner found to his delight that his speech, which he had left on the podium moments before, was protected when he resumed the stage. Theres snow on the podium now; somebody thought of this plastic shield to cover the rest of the script. Good thinking, guys! he said, smiling.

title: From Acoma Pueblo to Texas Stadium
description: Tourists heading to the Acoma Pueblo reservation in New Mexico come over a hill that overlooks a valley that surrounds a 367-foot sandstone mesa rising to the sky. The village rests on top, with its breathtaking views and ancient traditions and houses made from adobe clay.

title: Regarding Tim Thomas
description: Many Islanders fans have written in to object to our assertion that Bostons Tim Thomas is far more deserving of a spot on the East All-Star team than the Isles Rick DiPietro. They say theyve watched DiPietro save the Long Island team all season long, but they dont seem to have seen much of Thomas, who doesnt get a lot of ink as it is. Heres a video resume of Thomass performance last year, featuring some truly amazing stops.

title: Predicting the Globs
description: With not much in the way of events to attend and very little intelligence to go on, the Bagger was reduced to asking random people who they thought the HFPA would pick this year. That included the guy muttering to himself down the breakfast counter at Norms on La Cienega, who turned to the Bagger and asked, Do you think its bad if you are the Archangel? When a question like that comes from someone talking to their waffles, the answer is always tricky.

title: Bulls on Parade
description: Chrysler showcased its new Ram pickup on Sunday with a herd of cattle strolling down Washington Blvd. in Detroit.

title: Chrysler: We Wont Resort to Fleet Sales to Prop Up Sales
description: DETROIT  Chrysler expects to report sales declines every month this year because its dealerships will not be able to sell enough vehicles to compensate for a planned cutback in deliveries to rental companies, a top executive said Sunday at the Detroit Auto Show.

title: BET Founder Slams Obama in South Carolina
description: UpdatedCOLUMBIA, S.C.  Robert L. Johnson, the founder of Black Entertainment Television, who is campaigning today in South Carolina with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, just made a suggestion that raised the specter of Barack Obamas past drug use. He also compared Mr. Obama to Sidney Poitier, the black actor, in Guess Whos Coming to Dinner.

title: Clinton: Pledge to the Flag Every Day
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Senator Hillary Clinton said today that children should recite the pledge of allegiance in school every day.

title: Giuliani Pushes Hard in Florida
description: MIAMI  Florida is Rudy Country, the new signs and stickers say hopefully.

title: Cattle Call Outside Cobo Center
description: Video

title: A World Without Stars
description: Dont look for George Clooney or any of his A-list siblings during the Globes press conference tonight even as the Writers Guild of America has removed the threat of pickets. By the time the word came down on Friday that it was okay for actors to participate, most had made plans that did not include hair and make-up. Said one publicist, Wed all like the Globes to save a little face, but with so little time, there really wasnt much we could do about it.

title: A Twist in the A.F.C. Script
description: Well, well, well. All those anticipating an epic Colts-Patriots rematch in a Super Bowl-esque A.F.C. championship game next week will have to find some film of last years game. The San Diego Chargers, left with Billy Volek and Michael Turner to lead the offense, defeated the Colts, 28-24, a few moments ago.

title: Long Nights Journey Into Night
description: Between the tributes  Sidney Lumet is God!  and the extended spoken word performances of many of the critics  all the was missing was the bongos  the Los Angeles Film Critics Association event on Saturday was a night when movies and the people who make them received big ups  and a little bit of an endurance test. According to David Poland of Movie City News, when Paul Thomas Anderson, the director who was honored for There Will Be Blood, finally got to the podium three hours into the night, he checked his watch and said, If another [charming, but nonetheless redacted profane adjective] film critic criticizes one of my movies for being too long, Im going to remind them of this ceremony.

title: Clinton-Obama War of Words
description: The Timess Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny have just written an article published on our home page about the latest developments in the escalating dispute between Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama about remarks made just before the New Hampshire primary. (Update: Adam Nagourney has more in an article on the front page of Mondays paper.)

title: Milan lan: Prada
description: Prada (Don Ashby)

title: Another War Election
description: Its tempting to claim, based on recent polling data, that the central issue in the 2008 presidential election will be the U.S. economy. In the Iowa Republican Caucus entrance poll, more voters chose the economy as the most important issue (26 percent) than the Iraq war (17 percent). And in the Iowa Democratic Caucus entrance poll, the economy and the Iraq war were tied for most-important-issue status, with each drawing 35 percent support.

title: Poetic Injustice
description: Awards Daily is holding their annual Globes Haiku throwdown. (We Oscar ninnies are an odd, obsessive species.) Take a crack at a poetic summation here.The Bagger is sequestered awaiting his curtain call for the press conference that is now the Globes, but nothing says moody quite like a pre-event haiku:

title: Notable Models From Day One in Detroit
description: A selection of vehicles that were displayed on the first preview day of the North American International Auto Show.

title: McCain Too Busy to Answer Romneys Jabs
description: Senator John McCain drew large crowds in three appearances in Michigan on Sunday, when he rebuffed attempts to be drawn into a tit-for-tat political war of words with Mitt Romney.

title: Banks to Try Chrysler Loan Sale Again
description: From Micheline Maynard, a DealBook colleague:

title: Below-the-Line Protesters
description: Although the Writers Guild of America has said that its members will not be picketing the Golden Globes, a dozen or so below-the-line employees were at the entrance to the Beverly Hilton on Sunday afternoon. A mix of medical personnel, stylists and craft services workers shouted at passing cars and held up signs. Take care of us, we take care of you! yelled Tammy Yazgulian, a set nurse.

title: Obama Questions Nevada Caucus Lawsuit
description: LAS VEGAS  At a rally this afternoon, Senator Barack Obama questioned the timing and legitimacy of a lawsuit that had been filed here seeking to prevent caucuses from being held Saturday in nine casinos on the Las Vegas Strip.

title: GAME OVER: Giants 21, Cowboys 17
description: Postgame: Anyone expect that to happen? Cowboys looked pretty solid in the first half, but they got bit by penalties in the second. Manning finishes 12 of 18 for 163 yards and 2 touchdowns. Brandon Jacobs rushed for 54 yards, Bradshaw for 34. The totals are a little anemic for the Giants offense, but, as I was telling a friend of mine, yards are overrated. Romo does not come through in the end; he was 18 of 35 for 201 yards with a touchdown pass and a pick. Let the debate begin: How well would he have played if hed spent last weekend in Dallas, eating chicken wings at a Hooters? Keep those comments coming. I am turning this thread over to you. How will the Giants fare in Green Bay? Anybody for the Cowboys going to lose his job over this? And are you ready to accept Eli Manning as the Giants quarterback?

title: Press Function
description: The Bagger is in position, up close, stage right, at a table George Clooney probably would have been sitting at if he were coming. The Bagger is always stuck in dreary press rooms at these events, so he is used to it, and the golden motif of the stage for the announcement is actually quite lovely. Carpenters are still hammering stuff together on stage, which gives the room an air of expectation, but its not like there is going to be a sudden starburst of wattage when the programming begins. It will be a nice, dry press conference, which brings the Bagger back to his salad days as a government reporter. Nothing like a couple of crisp announcements to report on deadline to get the old journalistic juices flowing. And speaking of getting juiced, dont forget to make your predictions. Theres still time.

title: In Many Venues, Economy Will Take Center Stage
description: Political wisdom this week runs smack into economic reality. It is not yet clear which force will prove more powerful.

title: The Uses of the Humanities, Part Two
description: In a poem titled Matins, the 17th century Anglican poet George Herbert says to God, If you will teach me thy love to know . . . Then by a sunbeam I will climb to thee. But the dynamics of the proffered bargain  if you do X, Ill do Y  are undercut by the line that proposes it, and especially by the double pun in sunbeam.

title: Remote Reactions
description: Jeremy Piven was on a movie set shooting a film for Paramount Vantage, The Goods: The Don Ready Story, and happened to step into his trailer just about the time that it was announced he won best television actor in a supporting role.

title: The Verdict
description: The results are in. The evening was a downright weird one and contained its share of competitive surprises. Atonement, which had been considered to be losing luster in the awards race, stormed back to life with a win as best motion picture drama. The audience of journalists and press agents gasped a bit when it was announced. Sweeney Todd bested Juno in the best motion picture musical or comedy, also a surprise to some. Cate Blanchett won a best supporting actress for her role, with the HFPA choosing her over Amy Ryan from Gone Baby Gone, who has been the much chattered about favorite. And the directors win for Julian Schnabel for The Diving Bell and the Butterfly came completely out of left field when the only directors being talked about have been Paul Thomas Anderson and the Coen brothers so far this year. A full recap of the evening is already available as well. In case you were wondering, the Bagger got slaughtered in his picks. More details on the debacle later.

title: A Starting Point for Productive Climate Discourse
description: The views expressed here on human-caused climate change run the gamut. Its a hoax. Its a catastrophe. Its a crisis. Its a manageable trend. It can be fixed with a rising tax on carbon. It can be fixed by making people rich. It can be controlled by dumping something in the air or oceans.

title: A Longer Spot Check of Global Warming
description: Roger A. Pielke Jr. has done some further checking of the IPCCs predictions, the subject of the last post. You can see the graphs here. Now hes gone back to 1990 and checked out four different predictions by the U.N.s climate panel. He concludes, among other things:

title: Allison Eckardt Ledes, 53, Editor of Magazine Antiques, Is Dead
description: Allison Eckardt Ledes, who, as editor of The Magazine Antiques, brought a new focus on European, Asian and 20th-century decorative arts to a publication traditionally devoted to Americana, died at her home in Manhattan on Tuesday. She was 53, and was also a resident of Bedford, N.Y.

title: Afghans, Report for Duty
description: Washington

title: Downsized: The Eerie Tale of a Man and His Monster
description: Frankenstein (Mortal Toys), a puppet version of Mary Shelleys novel, turns out to be that happy thing: an inspired melding of material and medium. The creators of Mortal Toys, a production of Here Arts Center and Automata, justifiably call it a miniature spectacle. Contained in a small puppet theater, it evokes the Romantic sublime with unflagging inventiveness: Arctic floes with icy blue light, lands of mist and snow, the delicate flight of a bird over mountains.

title: When West Cannot Wait, Squeeze Goes Unbroken
description: Those who can, do; those who cant, officiate. Then there are those who do both. Andrew Rosenthal is the new president of the Greater New York Bridge Association, but he showed that he can also play well by winning the first two open pair events at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in New York City last month. He captured the Jim Becker Stratified Open Pairs with Bjorn Fallenius, and the Babs Cohen Stratified Open Pairs with Michael Rosenberg.

title: The Democrats Fairy Tale
description: Give me a break. This whole thing is the biggest fairy tale Ive ever seen. Thus spoke Bill Clinton last Monday night, exasperated by Barack Obamas claim that he  unlike Hillary Clinton  had been consistently right (or wrong, depending on your point of view) on the Iraq war.

title: Sears Expects 60% Drop in Profit for Quarter
