description: Sears used to beckon shoppers to come see its softer side. Now, they are starting to see its struggling side.

title: The Early Bird Gets the Bad Grade
description: ITS Monday morning, and youre having trouble waking your teenagers. Youre not alone. Indeed, each morning, few of the countrys 17 million high school students are awake enough to get much out of their first class, particularly if it starts before 8 a.m. Sure, many of them stayed up too late the night before, but not because they wanted to.

title: Drug Has No Benefit in Trial, Makers Say
description: A clinical trial of Zetia, a cholesterol-lowering drug prescribed to about 1 million people a week, failed to show that the drug has any medical benefits, Merck and Schering-Plough said on Monday.

title: Taiwan Election May Ease Tensions With China
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The landslide victory for the opposition Kuomintang in Taiwans parliamentary elections could sharply reduce the political influence of President Chen Shui-bian, who has antagonized China and frustrated the United States with his efforts to forge a strong national identity for Taiwan.

title: When Crime Was Always on Our Minds
description: In the bad old days of street crime, an era most New Yorkers would think of as before 1990, it was a personal quandary and a public obsession: If assaulted, do I run, hand over the money or stand and fight? And should I carry a weapon?

title: Ford and Chrysler Unveil Their Redesigned Pickups
description: DETROIT  Cowboys and live cattle took over downtown on Sunday as Ford Motor and Chrysler heralded new versions of their all-important pickup trucks at the 2008 North American International Auto Show.

title: Ex-Baathists Get a Break. Or Do They?
description: BAGHDAD  A day after the Iraqi Parliament passed legislation billed as the first significant political step forward in Iraq after months of deadlock, there were troubling questions  and troubling silences  about the measures actual effects.

title: PGA Will Move Barclays From Westchester Club
description: The PGA Tour has notified Westchester Country Club that it intends to pull the plug on the remaining five years of a six-year agreement to play host to the Barclays, the opening event of its four-tournament playoffs for the FedEx Cup, the clubs president said Sunday.

title: Fanfare for the Common Kid: Fidgeting but Still Curious
description: Even before the New York Philharmonic played a note of its Young Peoples Concert on Saturday afternoon, Avery Fisher Hall rang with sound. Children plucked strings, banged percussion instruments and stomped blasts of air through organ pipes on the first tier; up on the third level others played notes  or at least made sounds  on a French horn. The lobby was filled with skits, demonstrations and interactive installations.

title: Even a Blowout Victory Ends With Questions
description: Isiah Thomas  still the Knicks coach to the chagrin of many, though for how long, no one knows  was back on the bench Sunday night at Madison Square Garden, presiding over a rare victory and issuing another round of quizzical statements.

title: G.O.P. Voters, in Big Shift, Favor McCain Over His Rivals
description: WASHINGTON  Republican voters have sharply altered their views of the partys presidential candidates following the early contests in Iowa and New Hampshire, with Senator John McCain, once widely written off, now viewed more favorably than any of his major competitors, according to the latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Toyota Will Offer a Plug-In Hybrid by 2010
description: DETROIT  The Toyota Motor Corporation, which leads the worlds automakers in sales of hybrid-electric vehicles, announced Sunday night that it would build its first plug-in hybrid by 2010.

title: Disney Among Firms to Buy Stake in N.B.A.s China Subsidiary
description: The Walt Disney Company and four Chinese investment firms will invest in an 11 percent stake in the National Basketball Associations subsidiary in China, people briefed on the matter said Sunday.

title: Barber Starts and Proves Tough to Stop
description: IRVING, Tex.  When Marion Barber III runs, dreadlocks flap past his shoulders from behind his helmet. His legs churn at a frightening speed, twin jackhammers working in tandem to punish and propel.

title: An Iraqi House Was Rigged to Kill American Soldiers
description: SINSIL, Iraq  The courtyard was a scene of devastation, strewn with medieval mud brick and modern cinder block, shattered alike by the explosion that killed six American soldiers and their Iraqi interpreter.

title: Killing of a Young Hiker Puts North Georgia on Edge
description: ATLANTA  In the days after a young woman was killed after being abducted on a popular North Georgia hiking trail, instructors offering a crash course in personal safety found classes filling up as fast as they were scheduled, and that they had to turn some women away.

title: The Return of Idol, Confident in Season 7
description: LOS ANGELES  Empty seats were common last summer at the American Idols Live concert tour. Two American Idol winners  Taylor Hicks, who took the top prize in the programs fifth season, and Ruben Studdard, who won the second season  recently lost their record contracts. And last season, the sixth, marked the first time that overall viewership of American Idol declined from the previous year.

title: Births
description: Nicole Richie, above left, who starred with Paris Hilton on The Simple Life, gave birth on Friday to Harlow Winter Kate Madden at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. The father is Joel Madden of the rock group Good Charlotte.... The singer Christina Aguilera, above right, gave birth on Saturday to Max Lion Bratman, the RCA Music Group announced. The child is the first for Ms. Aguilera and her husband, Jordan Bratman, a music business executive.

title: Spacecraft Zipping Past Mercury
description: WASHINGTON  The Messenger spacecraft dashed past Mercury today, getting a quick glance at the solar systems innermost planet, which it eventually will orbit for detailed studies.

title: Zagat Family Is Putting Guide Empire on Market
description: A clever and sharp restaurant guide company with telling rankings and a penchant for quote marks from its thousands of in-the-know reviewers is on the block.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: William J. McGuire, 82, Art of Persuasion Pioneer, Dies
description: William J. McGuire, a social psychologist at Yale whose work on the art of persuasion and how to resist it has been applied in political science, advertising and mass communications, died on Dec. 21 at his home in New Haven, Conn. He was 82.

title: Prominent Entertainers Cited in Steroids Inquiry
description: Entertainers including the singer Mary J. Blige and the rapper 50 Cent are among thousands of people whose names are turning up in an investigation into obtaining steroids or human growth hormones, an Albany newspaper reported on Sunday.

title: Clemenss Lawyers Negotiating Deposition
description: When Mark McGwire and four other baseball players testified in front of Congress three years ago, they did so under oath but were not forced to give depositions in advance of their testimony.

title: Woman Released by Guerrillas Returns to Colombia to See Son
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Freed by Colombian guerrillas last week after six years of captivity in jungle camps, Clara Rojas, a former aspirant to the vice presidency of Colombia, boarded a military plane here on Sunday bound for Bogot, where she was reunited with her 3-year-old son.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Adidas Group named NYCA, Encinitas, Calif., as the worldwide agency of record for its Adidas Golf division, a new assignment. NYCA is also the creative agency for the TaylorMade brand of golf equipment, owned by Adidas. Spending was estimated at $5 million.

title: Cartoon Creatures Leave Home and Find ... Home
description: In the halcyon days of our remembered childhoods we played fabulous games of imagination in our neighborhood backyards. Nowadays children dont get out in the yard as much; they watch those games being played on television.

title: West Coast Flair Bounds Into East Coast Sensibilities
description: Benjamin Levy came to New York, where he opened on Friday at the Joyce SoHo trailing awards and admiring reviews, as well as a designation as one of Dance magazines Top 25 Choreographers to Watch in 2004. A great divide may still remain between the dance sensibilities of New York and San Francisco, where LEVYdance is based. The four pieces Mr. Levy presented were certainly professional, as were the dancers, but watching them was dispiriting.

title: Republican Indecision in South Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  To borrow a phrase, Bobbie Brock was for Rudolph W. Giuliani before she was against him.

title: In Defending War Vote, Clintons Contradict Record
description: WASHINGTON  Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have repeatedly invoked the name of Senator Chuck Hagel, a longtime critic of the Iraq war, as they defend Mrs. Clintons 2002 vote to authorize the war.

title: Romney Embraces His Michigan Roots
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich.  Wherever Mitt Romney goes in Michigan, he tells the story of the gift his sons gave him for his 60th birthday last year: a 1962 Rambler.

title: Cry-Baby Finds a Broadway Home
description: Now that The Drowsy Chaperone has finally gone to sleep, Cry-Baby, the musical based on the 1990 movie by John Waters, below, about greasers and squares in 1954 Baltimore, has announced its move into the Marquis Theater on Broadway. The musical, with songs by David Javerbaum (former head writer of The Daily Show) and Adam Schlesinger (from the band Fountains of Wayne) and a book by Mark ODonnell and Thomas Meehan (who wrote the book for Hairspray) is scheduled to begin previews on March 15, with an opening set for April 24. Mark Brokaw is directing, and Rob Ashford is the choreographer. The production also announced that preview tickets would be priced at $54. Get it? 1954? $54? Yeah.

title: With Shows Like These, Forget Reruns
description: Ive got some bad news for striking Hollywood writers: Election 2008 is a breakaway hit.

title: MySpace Agrees to Youth Protections
description: The social networking Web site MySpace and the attorneys general for 49 states announced Monday that they had reached an agreement under which MySpace would make a number of changes aimed at protecting teenagers and children using its site from sexual predators.

title: So, Young Mr. Spinoza, Just What Is Your Thinking About God?
description: In recent years the playwright David Ives has become better known as a theatrical plastic surgeon. Hes the man primarily responsible for nipping and tucking the wayward books of the wheezier Broadway musicals for the City Center Encores! series. And this season he did his level best to spray away the smell of mothballs from a previously unproduced play by Mark Twain, Is He Dead?

title: New Jersey Teams Prove They Can Play the City Game
description: Samardo Samuels, the center for St. Benedicts Prep of Newark, started Sundays Super Six Invitational at Madison Square Garden on the bench, a maroon pullover draped over his immense shoulders.

title: Error by Allies and 2 Clashes Kill 15 in South of Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two NATO soldiers, two Afghan soldiers and 11 Afghan police officers were killed in separate clashes in the volatile southern region of Afghanistan, officials said Sunday.

title: Boone Gives Nets a Lift, Except at the Free-Throw Line
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The adventure begins when the Nets Josh Boone strolls to the free-throw line. With a white headband pulled over his braided hair and the tops of his ears, Boone gazes up at the rim, sadly, as if it were Mount Everest.

title: Blood Drive at Shea Stadium
description: The Mets and the New York City Blood Center are holding a blood drive at Shea Stadium on Monday. All donors will receive a voucher for two tickets for a select game in April. The drive will be held between Gates C and D from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Donors must be at least 17 years old and 110 pounds.

title: Lot of Good 12 Pro Bowl Picks Did for Cowboys
description: Irving, Tex.

title: Music Industry, Souring on Apple, Embraces Amazon Service
description: LOS ANGELES  At the Super Bowl next month, the music industry will be switching teams  from Apple to Amazon.com.

title: Better Transit for Citys Disabled Is Urged
description: The City Council assailed the state of transportation for the disabled in the city, and recommended a system of improvements, in a new report released on Sunday.

title: G.M. Buys Stake in Ethanol Made From Waste
description: General Motors, eager to ensure a supply of fuel for the big fleet of flex-fuel ethanol-capable vehicles it is building, has joined the rush into alternative energy and invested in a company that intends to produce ethanol from crop wastes, wood chips, scrap plastic, rubber and even municipal garbage.

title: Queens: Truck Possibly Hauling Asbestos Overturns
description: A tractor-trailer believed to have been carrying asbestos-contaminated material hit a median divider and overturned on the Clearview Expressway near the Long Island Expressway about 3 p.m. on Sunday, the police said. Cleanup efforts lasted late into the night, and traffic was snarled for hours on both highways. The driver, identified as Artur Gaska, 39, initially fled but returned and was arrested on a charge of leaving the scene of an accident, the police said.

title: Youth and Age Blend Well for Packers in Playoffs
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  So who were the kids here, exactly?

title: Patriots Get a Big Break. Or Do They?
description: New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick was watching just like everyone else Sunday when the game of the year went up in smoke, when the team regarded as the Patriots biggest roadblock to another Super Bowl title was eliminated.

title: Dame Edna Ails
description: Barry Humphries, the Australian comic best known as the flamboyant Dame Edna, below, has been ordered by doctors to rest for six months because of complications from appendix surgery, Reuters reported, citing a spokesman for the Magners Glasgow International Comedy Festival. As a result Mr. Humphries, 73, has canceled a North American tour that was to have started this month. Mr. Humphries underwent surgery late last month for the removal of his appendix and is scheduled for further surgery this week, the spokesman said.

title: Gulf Air Signs $6 Billion Deal for Boeing Jets
description: Gulf Air, Bahrains loss-making national carrier, signed a $6 billion agreement with Boeing for the delivery of 24 Dreamliner aircraft to begin in 2016, a spokesman for the airline, Adnan Malik, said on Sunday.

title: One Big Win, Two Huge Losses for Chargers
description: INDIANAPOLIS To the surprise of many people who follow the N.F.L., the San Diego Chargers, not the Indianapolis Colts, will meet the New England Patriots next Sunday for the American Football Conference championship and the right to play in Super Bowl XLII.

title: Trenton: New State Treasurer Named
description: After five months of searching for a new state treasurer, Gov. Jon S. Corzine has tapped the deputy treasurer, David Rousseau, for the position. Mr. Rousseau, 47, was named on Friday to succeed Bradley I. Abelow, who became the governors chief of staff on Sept. 1. Michellene Davis, who has been serving as the acting treasurer, was named a special senior counsel to the governor.

title: Reward Posted in Hunt for Marine
description: A massive fugitive manhunt was underway on Monday for the Marine corporal who is the principal suspect in the death of a fellow marine who was eight months pregnant when she died.

title: Jazz Showcase Fever Propels a Mini Marathon
description: The Winter Jazzfest, now in its fourth year at the Knitting Factory, is one of the necessary gigs to attend on the New York jazz scene. With nine hours of music and 24 bands from all over the place gathered into one building, its pure cosmopolitan overload.

title: On a Fixed Income, and Facing a Financial Disaster
description: Retirement can mean ending one chapter in life and starting another. Edison Epeck decided after 35 years in banking to put his expertise to use by becoming a volunteer financial adviser after he retired.

title: Lottery Numbers
After Ratings Slip, Animal Planet Turns to Its Wilder Side
description: Animal Planet, long regarded as a gentle wildlife channel, is shedding its cute and cuddly image.

title: Three Seafaring Queens Spend a Day in New York
description: Deborah DAmbrosi can recite with ease the weight of each of the Queens  Elizabeth 2, Mary 2 and Victoria, which are among the worlds most luxurious ocean liners. And she came all the way from her landlocked hometown, Olney, Ill., on Sunday just to see the three girls, as she called them.

title: Bucket List Lives On
description: In its fourth week in release The Bucket List, starring Jack Nicholson, far right, and Morgan Freeman, right, as terminally ill cancer patients determined to live life to the fullest, ascended to the top of the list of the weekends biggest-grossing films. Ranked No. 23 last week at North American box offices, The Bucket List (Warner Brothers) took in an estimated $19.5 million, according to the tracking company Media by Numbers. At the same time National Treasure: Book of Secrets (Disney), the No. 1 film for three consecutive weekends, dropped to fourth, grossing $11.4 million to push its total to $187.2 million after four weeks. Second place for the weekend went to a new release, First Sunday (Sony/Screen Gems), starring Ice Cube as a man driven to crime by desperate circumstances. It earned $19 million and was followed by the small film Juno (Fox Searchlight), with $14 million, bringing its six-week total to $71.2 million. In fifth place Alvin and the Chipmunks (Fox) took in $9.1 million, for a five-week total of $187.7 million. There Will Be Blood (Paramount Vantage), playing on only 129 screens in its third week, averaged $15,039 per screen, compared with $6,712 for The Bucket List on more than 2,900 screens.

title: Mountains and Messiaen in a Music Projects Gift
description: Ensemble ACJWs latest appearance on Friday offered music by Alan Hovhaness and Messiaen at the Paul Recital Hall of the Juilliard School. Carnegie Hall, Juilliard, the Weill Music Institute and the City of New York make up the pool for this teaching and performing project. It is such a handsome gift to the listening public one can only hope that these first-rate young players are learning as much as we are.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Americans Cut Back Sharply on Spending
description: Strong evidence is emerging that consumer spending, a bulwark against recession over the last year even as energy prices surged and the housing market sputtered, has begun to slow sharply at every level of the American economy, from the working class to the wealthy.

title: Romney Battles McCain for Michigan Lead
description: DETROIT  With economic issues at the top of the agenda, the leading Republican presidential candidates set off Monday on a final flurry of campaigning in Michigan ahead of the states primary that could again shake up a remarkably fluid Republican field.

title: Herbert J.C. Kouts, Nuclear Power Safety Expert, Is Dead at 88
description: Herbert J. C. Kouts, a pioneer in nuclear power safety research and an expert in weapons proliferation, died on Jan. 7 at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in East Patchogue, N.Y. He was 88.

title: Bush Urges Unity Against Iran
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  President Bush on Sunday urged wary Persian Gulf allies to rally against Iran before it is too late, even as the International Atomic Energy Agency announced that the country had agreed, yet again, to answer outstanding questions about its nuclear programs within four weeks.

title: Johnny Podres, Series Star, Dies at 75
description: Johnny Podres, who became a celebrated figure in the storied history of the Brooklyn Dodgers in October 1955, when he pitched them to their only World Series championship, died Sunday at a hospital in Glens Falls, N.Y. Podres, who lived nearby in Queensbury, N.Y., was 75.

title: In Many Venues, Economy Will Take Center Stage
description: Political wisdom this week runs smack into economic reality. It is not yet clear which force will prove more powerful.

title: From a Shelter to a Home, but for How Long?
description: This is the year that Jose Guzmans luck is supposed to change. After spending a year and a half in a homeless shelter with his wife and two young daughters, Mr. Guzman is living in a railroad flat at the edge of Bushwick, just across the subway tracks from a cemetery. The city is paying most of the familys $1,170 monthly rent this year, and they are expected to save up a few thousand dollars, which will be matched by the city.

title: A Mother and Son Well Coordinated in Theatrical Flair and Acerbic Humor
description: Robert Leleux is the son of another of those drama-queen mothers: the sort who swoops through life to the accompaniment of jangling charm bracelets, dishing out self-dramatizing wisecracks and using what Mr. Leleux calls the M&M (Moonlight and Magnolia) Act to bag her men. Despite many obstacles, not least of them the danger of sounding like a would-be Augusten Burroughs, he has made her the centerpiece of a frantically giddy coming-of-age story.

title: The Economic Week
description: SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY The economy and bank results will dominate the week.

title: Google Sees Surge in iPhone Traffic
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Of all the iPhones features, none had reviewers gushing more than its Internet browser. It was the first cellphone browser that promised something resembling the experience of surfing the Internet on a PC. Santa helped deliver on that promise.

title: A.P. Says It Wants to Know Everything About Britney Spears
description: The Associated Press is bolstering its entertainment news coverage  and for many readers and viewers, Britney Spears is nothing if not entertaining.

title: When the Hospital Is the Ailing One
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Approved. Is Disease Real?
description: Fibromyalgia is a real disease. Or so says Pfizer in a new television advertising campaign for Lyrica, the first medicine approved to treat the pain condition, whose very existence is questioned by some doctors.

title: Throw in Irreplaceable, Too: Swinging Through Sammy Cahns Songbook
description: When the lyricist Sammy Cahn was asked which came first in his collaborations with this or that composer, the music or the words, he famously snapped, The phone call.

title: Strike Was Unseen Star of the Night
description: Day for night is what filmmakers call the technique for shooting night scenes in daylight. Today for night was the technique NBC used to get through a Golden Globes ceremony that was canceled by the writers strike.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Foreign Sales Help I.B.M. to a Strong Quarter
description: The fallout from the banking industrys woes and a slowing American economy are certainly not hurting I.B.M. yet.

title: Teary-Eyed Owens Backs Quarterback
description: IRVING, Tex.  The softer side of Terrell Owens surfaced Sunday. After the Cowboys season ended in another playoff loss, after his quarterback turned in another playoff disappointment, Owens became downright sentimental.

title: Barreling Through Rossini With a Noises Off Rhythm
description: Every opera company needs its Barber of Seville, and the Metropolitan Opera has one that does quite nicely. The heavy, often murderous gloom that sits over so much of the repertory requires comic fiber in its diet. Unlike Mozarts operas, Rossinis are what they are  no undertones of social upheaval or Parsifal-like mysticism. Face value is full value. Patrons and performers alike are allowed to be silly and glorious at the same time.

title: Trenton: State Backs Electoral College Change
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed legislation on Sunday that approved delivering the states 15 electoral votes to the winner of the national popular vote in the presidential election. Maryland  with 10 electoral votes  is the only state that has enacted the legislation, in the form of a compact. The compact would take effect only if enough states  those with a majority of votes in the Electoral College  agreed to it. Republicans criticized the bill as undermining federal elections.

title: A Political Wish
description: To the Editor:

title: Book Critics Nominate
description: The prolific author Joyce Carol Oates, below, came away with nominations in fiction and nonfiction when the finalists for the annual National Book Critics Circle awards were announced in San Francisco on Saturday. Ms. Oates was nominated in fiction for The Gravediggers Daughter and in the relatively new autobiographical category for The Journal of Joyce Carol Oates. Other nominees in fiction were The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao by Junot Daz, The Shadow Catcher by Marianne Wiggins, In the Country of Men by Hisham Matar and Sacred Games by Vikram Chandra. Ms. Oatess competitors in autobiography are Joshua Clark for Heart Like Water: Surviving Katrina and Life in Its Disaster Zone, Edwidge Danticat for Brother, Im Dying, Sara Paretsky for Writing in an Age of Silence and Anna Politkovskaya for A Russian Diary: A Journalists Final Account of Life, Corruption and Death in Putins Russia. In nonfiction the finalists were Legacy of Ashes: The History of the C.I.A., by Tim Weiner, a reporter for The New York Times; Philip Guras American Transcendentalism; Daniel Walker Howes What Hath God Wrought: The Transformation of America 1815-1848; Harriet Washingtons Medical Apartheid: The Dark History of Medical Experimentation on Black Americans from Colonial Times to the Present; and The World Without Us by Alan Weisman. Winners in these and other categories will be announced on March 6 in New York City.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the effect of the cancellation of the Golden Globes award ceremony on the practice of giving lavish gifts to Hollywood celebrities misinterpreted a comment by the actor Isaiah Washington. When Mr. Washington said, When I commit to something, I stick with it like a bulldog, he was referring to his foundation to help people in Sierra Leone, one of several charities supported by fees paid by companies who want to give away their products. Mr. Washington was not referring to participating in the gift giveaway himself. (Go to Article)

title: Atonement Wins Best Drama at Globes
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Amid the barest hint of star power at a Golden Globes ceremony derailed by striking screenwriters, Atonement captured the award for best drama and Sweeney Todd won for best musical or comedy on Sunday.

title: No. 7 Train From Flushing-Main Street to Times Square
description: 8.25 a.m., Jan. 14, Monday.

title: Footnotes
description: Judy Collins, who received rave reviews leading to a sold-out engagement last winter at the Caf Carlyle in her first New York nightclub appearance in more than 40 years, will return on Jan. 22 for a six-week engagement. She will be followed from March 4 to April 12 by Barbara Cook and from April 15 through May 10 by the Grammy Award-winner Christopher Cross.... On her Mondays off from starring on Broadway in Xanadu, the caustic comedian Jackie Hoffman will bring her retrospective act, Scraping the Bottom: The Most Offensive Songs of Jackie Hoffman, to Joes Pub on Feb. 4, 11 and 25.

title: Family Finds Man Killed in His Home in Brooklyn
description: A 49-year-old man who had helped raise his granddaughter while his daughter served in Iraq was found beaten to death and bound in his apartment in Brooklyn on Sunday, the police said.

title: Fluidity in  G.O.P. Race; Democrats Eye Electability
description: WASHINGTON  Republican voters have sharply altered their views of the partys presidential candidates following the early contests in Iowa and New Hampshire, with Senator John McCain, once widely written off, now viewed more favorably than any of his major competitors, according to the latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: The Candidates Discover the Economy
description: The presidential candidates are only beginning to recognize what many voters have already figured out through painful, personal experience: the economy is in trouble and unlikely to improve without some sensible government response.

title: Responding to Recession
description: Suddenly, the economic consensus seems to be that the implosion of the housing market will indeed push the U.S. economy into a recession, and that its quite possible that were already in one. As a result, over the next few weeks well be hearing a lot about plans for economic stimulus.

title: More Google Queries Get Google Maps
description: The share of Google searches that result in visits to Google Maps has skyrocketed since last year, according to the online traffic-measurement firm Hitwise. Over the week ending Jan. 6, 2007, 0.22 percent of Google searchers went on to Google Maps. During the same week this year, 0.67 percent did. Hitwise calculated the figures by analyzing the behavior of 10 million Internet users.

title: Fitness Center Chain Goes Provocative in New Campaign
description: Editors Note: Look for In Advertising next week on Tues., Jan. 22, rather than Mon., Jan. 21, in honor of the Dr. King holiday.

title: Are Awards Really Awards Without a Red Carpet?
description: It seems somehow fitting that NBC lined up American Gladiators, the overstimulated warfare show that has contestants in tight clothes flogging one another, to follow its telecast of the Golden Globes news conference. If you cant give em sequins, give em spandex.

title: Trenton: School Finance Law Signed
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a law on Sunday that revamps the formula the state uses to subsidize public schools. Under the law, which changes the way the state allocates money to public schools, aid is partly tied to the number of low-income students in each district. Suburban districts with enrollment increases and a large number of low-income students could see annual aid increases as big as 20 percent, while most of the states 31 poor urban districts would receive a 2 percent increase this year and flat state support after that.

title: With Son Nearby, Davenport Seeks Grand Slam Title
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Margaret Court Arena is not center stage at the Australian Open. It is only the third-biggest show court at the tournament and has no retractable roof to keep it safe from the threat of summer sizzle or drizzle.

title: Less Hype, but at Least These Restrooms Are Free
description: Reinventing the chamber pot for the 21st century was no small matter.

title: Europe May Ban Imports of Some Biofuel Crops
description: PARIS  In a sign of shifting attitudes toward biofuels, officials of the European Union are proposing to ban imports of certain fuel crops whose production could do more harm than good in fighting climate change, according to a draft law seen Monday.

title: The Pork King Keeps His Crown
description: The new earmark disclosure rules put into effect by Congress confirm the pre-eminence of Representative John Murtha at procuring eye-popping chunks of pork for contractors he helped put in business in Johnstown, Pa. The Pennsylvania Democrat, a power player on defense appropriations, exudes pride, not embarrassment, for delivering hundreds of millions of dollars in largesse to district beneficiaries. They, in turn, requite with hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign donations.

title: New CDs
description: RINGO STARR

title: Way Up Yonder in Manhattan, Dreaming of Home
description: No one could ever accuse Jazz at Lincoln Center of giving short shrift to the jazz legacy of New Orleans, especially as it pertains to Louis Armstrong. So on a fundamental level Kings of the Crescent City, Friday and Saturday at the Rose Theater, upheld standard practice for the organization. The nearly full house on Friday night confirmed the soundness of this approach.

title: Manhattan: City Reports Record Number of Visitors
description: With a falling dollar encouraging foreign visitors, a record number of travelers came to the city in 2007, spending $28 billion, tourism officials said. With a final count still pending, the citys tourism office said on Sunday that there were an estimated 46 million visitors to the city last year, up 5 percent from 2006. The gain was attributed largely to an increase in foreign visitors, who numbered an estimated 8.5 million, a jump of 17 percent, officials said. The proportion of the citys tourists who were from other countries had dwindled since the Sept. 11 attacks, but last years growth returned the ratio to pre-2001 levels.

title: Just What I Need?
description: The Consumer Electronics Show, held in Las Vegas last week, pitched a sleek and shiny Star Trek future where myriad clever devices would satisfy our every need. Microsofts chairman, Bill Gates, opened the show with a keynote speech touting a second digital decade. More than 2,000 hi-tech exhibitors introduced their brand new wares to about 140,000 attendees.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 9-12 with 1,178 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,061 said they were registered to vote.

title: Addenda: Accounts, People and Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Reality TV Is No Lightweight in the Battle to Outlast Strikers
description: The striking members of the Writers Guild of America may have hoped that television viewers, upset that their favorite dramas and comedies had gone dark, would disdain the chief alternative the broadcast networks had to offer: reality shows.

title: Race and Gender Are Issues in Tense Day for Democrats
description: LAS VEGAS  After staying on the sidelines in the first year of the campaign, race and to a lesser extent gender have burst into the forefront of the Democratic presidential contest, thrusting Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton into the middle of a sharp-edged social and political debate that transcends their candidacies.

title: U.S. Cities Put on the Charm for Foreign Tourists
description: THE weak dollar has made shopping sprees in America a bargain for many international visitors. Still, outside favored destinations like New York, many places in the United States are having a hard time attracting foreign tourists and their euros, pounds and yen.

title: Walter Bowart, Alternative Journalist, Dies at 68
description: Walter Bowart, a founder and the first publisher of The East Village Other, a New York newspaper so countercultural that it made The Village Voice look like a church circular, died on Dec. 18 in Inchelium, Wash. He was 68 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Wesley Snipes to Go on Trial in Tax Case
description: From 1999 to 2004, the actor Wesley Snipes earned $38 million appearing in more than half a dozen movies, including two sequels to his popular vampire thriller Blade.

title: Fire Department Alters Its Inspection Schedule
description: In an effort to focus on larger and more complex construction and demolition projects, the Fire Department has decreased the frequency of inspections for some smaller projects. The move is part of a series of changes made in response to lapses exposed by the death of two firefighters at the former Deutsche Bank building.

title: Big Weddings Bring Afghans Joy, and Debt
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  On the afternoon before his wedding day this fall, Hamid was sitting in an empty teahouse worrying a glass of green tea between his fingers, his brow furrowed in concern.

title: A Depleted Secondary Still Delivers for Giants
description: IRVING, Tex.  Facing down Tony Romo and the high-octane Dallas Cowboys offense with a threadbare secondary is usually not a formula for success. But as the Giants reserve defensive back R. W. McQuarters cradled his end-zone interception, which effectively ended Sundays National Football Conference playoff game, success was all he could feel.

title: Japan and Its Neighbors Scrutinized in Mirrors
description: Why do people attend dance samplers? Presenters want work to present, choreographers want to scout the competition, and critics want to find some trends, or at least some good one-liners. But what does the average dance fan  that mythical beast  hope to gain from such a chancy endeavor? Probably a program in which more than one of five dances succeeds, but that is this critics assessment of the Japan Societys 11th annual Contemporary Dance Showcase.

title: Mail-In Voters Become the Latest Prize
description: LOS ANGELES  The first Tuesday in February, when 22 states hold primaries, may turn out to be the biggest day of the presidential campaign. But for many voters, half or more in some states, the polling place will be the kitchen table, the ballot box will be the mailbox and the choice in many cases will be made weeks before a voting machine lever is pulled.

title: Trying to Fine-Tune Yahoo
description: Jerry Yang began his biggest public presentation since becoming chief executive of Yahoo with something of an apology.

title: Expand the Peace Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: For Broadway Play, Mamet Is a Blogger
description: Before premieres, playwrights sometimes tweak dialogue that actors stumble over in rehearsals, but once the curtain rises they rarely write another word for their characters. But in a promotion for his play November, which will open on Broadway on Thursday, David Mamet will continue to write a blog from the perspective of his leading character, Charles H. P. Smith (played by Nathan Lane), a sitting president about to lose a re-election bid.

title: Oscar Peterson Tribute
description: The pianist Herbie Hancock, the singer Nancy Wilson and the impresario and producer Quincy Jones, as well as Governor General Michalle Jean, Canadas titular head of state, appeared before more than 2,000 fans to pay tribute to the jazz piano virtuoso Oscar Peterson at Simply the Best, a free concert on Saturday at Roy Thomson Hall in Toronto, The Associated Press reported. I dont call many people geniuses, but Oscar Peterson is definitely one, Mr. Jones said. Mr. Peterson died of kidney failure at his home in Mississauga, a Toronto suburb, on Dec. 23. He was 82.

title: H.I.V. Rises Among Young Gay Men
description: AIDS appears to be making an alarming comeback. The Journal of the American Medical Association reports that the incidence of H.I.V. infection among gay men is shooting up, following an encouraging period of decline. The rise of infections among younger gay men, especially black and Hispanic men, is troubling, and the study carries the clear implication that people at high risk of contracting the disease are becoming less cautious.

title: Volek Fills in Exactly the Way a Backup Quarterback Should
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Billy Volek tossed and turned in his hotel bed as Saturday night melted into Sunday morning amid the rain and snow and church bells of central Indiana.

title: Getaways to Coddle New Mothers (or Just Inspire Some)
description: CHATHAM, N.J.  The second-floor suite in the Parrot Mill Inn has all the accouterments of a classic bed-and-breakfast, including stenciled flowers beneath the ceiling, candies wrapped in gold foil, and the scent of spices in the hallway.

title: Giants Make the Leap to Lambeau
description: IRVING, Tex.  In the days before their divisional playoff game with the Cowboys, the Giants were leery of raising the ire of their highly favored opponent and undermining their own quiet, underdog status. But they could not help but point out the perceived discrepancy in talent between the teams. The Cowboys had 12 players named to next months Pro Bowl. The Giants had one.

title: Team Creates Rat Heart Using Cells of Baby Rats
description: Medicines dream of growing new human hearts and other organs to repair or replace damaged ones received a significant boost Sunday when University of Minnesota researchers reported success in creating a beating rat heart in a laboratory.

title: Europe Takes Africas Fish, and Boatloads of Migrants Follow
description: KAYAR, Senegal  Ale Nodye, the son and grandson of fishermen in this northern Senegalese village, said that for the past six years he netted barely enough fish to buy fuel for his boat. So he jumped at the chance for a new beginning. He volunteered to captain a wooden canoe full of 87 Africans to the Canary Islands in the hopes of making their way illegally to Europe.

title: Alternate Worlds Moving on Two Stages, Performing for One Audience
description: BEACON, N.Y.  Because dance occurs in both time and space, it operates upon us as a demonstration of physics. This aspect becomes arresting in the work of two choreographers alone: George Balanchine and Merce Cunningham. Mr. Cunningham has often quoted Einsteins dictum There are no fixed points in space, and since the 1980s some of the ensembles in his work have struck observers as riveting enactments of chaos theory.

title: When Gadget Parts Break or Get Lost
description: THE proliferation of iPods, cellphones and other devices in the hands of smaller children is sure to have profound social significance in the long term, but in the short term it means something else: broken gadgets and lost parts.

title: Pagliacci Becomes Dreamy
description: Canio, the heartbroken clown in I Pagliacci, doesnt just suffer. In the Seattle Operas new version of Ruggero Leoncavallos opera, running through Jan. 26, he also dreams. In an 11-minute sequence inserted after the aria Vesti la giubba, music taken from Leoncavallos Zaz, a Metropolitan Opera hit in the 1920s, is heard as Canio relives his life with his beloved Nedda: He discovers her as an orphaned waif, teaches her to be an acrobat and actress and, finally, is rejected by her. Acrobats play Canio, as well as Nedda at different ages. Speight Jenkins, the general director of the Seattle Opera, found the music he said he felt had the proper sound for the dream; Philip Kelsey, the assistant conductor, orchestrated it for seven winds and strings, as well as piano, to give it a different sound from the usual Pagliacci orchestra, and the director Bernard Uzan, working with Mr. Jenkins, integrated the sequence into the opera, which, in another break with tradition, is not being paired with another work.

title: Amputee Ineligible for Olympic Events
description: LONDON  Track and fields world governing body ruled on Monday that Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee sprinter from South Africa, is not be eligible to compete in Olympic qualifying events. The International Association of Athletics Federations explained in a statement that, after an independent scientific study, it deemed Pistoriuss state-of-the-art carbon fiber prosthetics should be considered as technical aids which give him an advantage over other athletes not using them.

title: Attack Jolts Germany Into Fray on Immigrant Crime
description: WETZLAR, Germany  A brutal war of words has broken out between the two major parties here over violence committed by youths with immigrant backgrounds, and neither side is backing down.

title: Brooklyn: Man Charged in Hit and Run
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested in connection with an Oct. 6 crash that killed one man and injured another near the Belt Parkway, the police said on Sunday. The suspect, Justin Bonilla, 19, of East 34th Street, was charged with manslaughter, the police said. The police said Mr. Bonilla was driving east on the parkway about 4 a.m. when his car veered off the road onto a grassy area and struck two pedestrians. Mr. Bonilla told detectives that his car had been stolen but was charged after a detective identified him in an image from a nearby surveillance camera around the time of the crash, the police said.

title: Whoa! Russian Folk Troupe Stomps In
description: The weather may shift. The voices that enunciate the eternal political pieties may change. But one thing remains certain: The Moiseyev Dance Company will perform a hoedown to Turkey in the Straw on its American tours, as it did on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Center at Brooklyn College. That closing encore was followed by a brief sortie into Hail, Hail, the Gangs All Here, with the audience humming and clapping along.

title: Toyota Will Offer a Plug-In Hybrid Vehicle by 2010
description: The chief executive of the Toyota Motor Corporation said Monday that he is pushing his companys engineers to develop a plug-in hybrid-electric vehicle with a lithium-ion battery before 2010, raising the stakes in a race with General Motors.

title: Golden Globe Winners
description: A look at the winners of the 65th Golden Globe awards.

title: A Sunday on the Trail
description: Presidential candidates attended church services, convened campaign rallies and rode their buses  and even a fire truck.

title: Golden Globes: The TV Winners
description: Series, Drama:Mad Men (AMC)

title: Golden Globes: Strange and Out Of Sync
description: The 65th annual Golden Globes awards are sure to go down as one of the strangest awards shows in the annals of Hollywood, the Associated Press reports. Instead of the usual three hours of star-studded back-slapping that drags on forever, this one flew by in half an hour, with no winners on hand and prizes announced by TV entertainment show hosts.

title: Like, Duh: Coughlin Will Be Back
description: Giants co-owner John Mara, beaming with pride in the visitors locker room at Texas Stadium, would not discuss the possibility of a long-term contract for Coach Tom Coughlin. Pestered, he finally relented by offering a laugh and a somewhat off-color confirmation:

title: That Was the Week That Was
description: Championship Week is over, but its well worth looking back on.

title: Game On!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related article from The Times will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Europe's Smart Car in America
description: Ten years after it appeared in Europe, the Mercedes-designed Smart car will soon go on sale in the United States.

title: Toyota Introduces a Station Wagon (but Wont Call it That).
description: Introduced on Monday: 2009 Toyota Venza.

title: A Truck Too Short
description: Introduced on Sunday: Toyota A-BAT compact pickup concept

title: Pattern and Decoration
description: Pattern and Decoration: An Ideal Vision in American Art, 1975-1985, at the Hudson River Museum, documents the last genuine art movement of the 20th century.

title: The Wright Collection
description: A selection of the more than one million objects of political paraphernalia collected by Jordan M. Wright, a New York lawyer and magazine publisher, since 1968.

title: Tautology TV
description: Programming alert noticed on PBS:

title: The Home of Cover Your Ears Cover Songs
description: The Hollywood writers strike means American Idol faces even less competition in its seventh season starting Tuesday, but not everybodys happy. From a rant on why you shouldnt watch  reason No. 3, song selection:

title: All-Out Nuclear Assault To Prevent Skihad
description: More of your late night comedy (send via the comment link below):

title: A Pig and a Priss in Their Prime (Time)
description: Video

title: Dont Blame Me  I Voted on Hot or Not
description: Dear Old Liberals,Hi, its me, your collective child. Its an election year and once again youre going to make me feel bad for not doing enough. Youre going to tell me about how you protested in the 1960s and how the movement meant something to young people back then. And the thing is we do care, our generation, we really do. Its just that we got a Wii for Christmas and we absolutely have to beat Super Mario Galaxy before we do anything else.

title: Cadillacs Coupe de Thrill
description: Introduced on Monday: Cadillac CTS Coupe concept

title: Missing the Boat?
description: Tell us whats going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: A Tweener for Mitsubishis Lancer Line
description: Introduced on Sunday: 2009 Mitsubishi Lancer Ralliart

title: The Humpback of Abu Dhabi
description: Introduced on Sunday: Maybach Landaulet Study

title: Chrysler Attempting (Kind of) to Go Green
description: Introduced on Monday: Chrysler ecoVoyager concept.

title: Saunas with style against the Berlin winter
description: By most accounts, Berlin has so far experienced a mild winter. But the vicious wind whipping through the capital streets has a way of canceling out the warmer temperatures, and pushes everyone indoors again.

title: Milan lan: Pssst!
description: This week, the fashion circus pitches its tent in Milan, where the mens Fall 2008 shows are taking place. If youre like us, theres probably only so much talk about cashmere 8-yarn tweed in ecru you can take. Thankfully, a lot of the action during fashion week happens off the catwalk. The big scandale of the week has been over Tommy Fazio, the mens fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman, being unceremoniously asked to vacate his front-row seat at Saturday nights Versace show. We spoke to Fazio afterwards who said that he was asked by a clipboard Nazi to make room for one of Beyonces posse. Not surprisingly, Fazio put away the check book and instantly canceled his Versace showroom appointment. Oops.Speaking of Beyonce, the singer and her boo, Jay-Z, walked in and straight out of the GQ party on Saturday when they realized there was no VIP room for themLots of aw-shucks, he so deserves it talk about John Bartletts being given a lifeline by Liz Claiborne, which has signed Bartlett to oversee its mens lineThe buzz late Sunday night had the Spice Girls showing up en masse to todays Roberto Cavalli show. (It would make sense as their concert in London last week may as well have been a Cavalli advertorial, given the number of shout-outs Victoria Beckham gave the designer.) Well let you know later if the rumor pans out to be true. Till then, baci.Read all of The Moments coverage of the Milan mens fashion shows and after-hours shenanigans.

title: Japanese Shipbuilders in Merger Talks
description: Two Japanese shipbuilders, IHI and JFE Holdings are holding merger talks that might result in the emergence of the biggest shipbuilder in Japan and spearhead a realignment of the industry as it looks to compete with powerful South Korean and Chinese rivals.

title: Vodafone Forced to Play Waiting Game in Vodacom Deal
description: Vodafone Group is looking to grow in Africa and other emerging areas, a strategy that has been embraced by the market as revenue declines in Europe.

title: Tesla Fires Executives Amid Shake-Up
description: Tesla Motors has yet to bring a product to market, but the electric-car maker certainly knows how to give off sparks. The closely watched Silicon Valley start-up, which recently became estranged from one of its co-founders, has apparently just sent a large number of its employees packing.

title: Packers Fan vs. Giants Fan
description: Highlights from the reader comments on yesterdays live-blog:A substantive, civil exchange between a Packers fan and a Giants fan sets the stage for Sundays game:

title: Belo Board Approves Spin-Off
description: Belos board of directors on Friday approved details of its spin-off of the companys newspaper group into a separate, publicly traded company, the company said.

title: What Advice Would Dr. Phil Have for Ask.Com?
description: IAC/InterActiveCorp is in the middle of a rather tumultuous reorganization as the company prepares to split into five units later this year. The core company, which keeps Barry Diller as chief executive and the fancy Frank Gehry headquarters next to Chelsea Piers (and Mr. Dillers yacht) , will include Ask.com, Citysearch, Match.com, and a bunch of other advertising driven sites.

title: Terra Firms Reported EMI Moves Rile Artists
description: Following rumors that British financier Guy Hands is looking to sell part of stake in the EMI Group to outside investors, reports surfaced over the weekend that the British music giant is preparing to cut up to 2,000 jobs, or about one-third of its work force, as part of a contentious restructuring plan being prepared by Mr. Handss Terra Firma Capital Partners.

title: Its Week 2 All Over Again. Or Not.
description: No matter what happened Sunday, the championship games in both conferences were going to be rematches of games earlier this season, but the victories by the Chargers and the Giants created a nice bit of symmetry.

title: Goldman to Get New Partner in Alliance Deal
description: The Canadian partner who stepped in last summer to help Goldman Sachs meet foreign ownership requirements in its purchase of Canadas largest film distributor, Alliance Films, has pulled out of the investment, The Globe and Mail reported.

title: Israel Chemicals to Buy Henkel Unit
description: Israel Chemicals said on Sunday that a subsidiary agreed to pay 60 million euros, about $89 million, for the industrial-water-treatment business of Henkel.

title: Pat Robertson Mulls Bid for Landmark Newspaper
description: The religious broadcaster Pat Robertson is considering taking a different kind of pulpit. The founder and chairman of the Christian Broadcasting Network is mulling making an offer for The Virginian Pilot, a daily newspaper he has criticized for its coverage of him and his activities.

title: Disney, Chinese Investors to Buy Stake in N.B.A. China
description: The Walt Disney Company and four Chinese investment firms will invest in an 11 percent stake in the National Basketball Associations subsidiary in China, according to The New York Times.

title: Quebecor to Get Rescue Package
description: Quebecor and Brookfield Asset Management have thrown a controversial lifeline to the struggling printing giant Quebecor World in the form of a proposed 400 million Canadian dollar ($393.6 million) financing package, The Globe and Mail reported.

title: TCW Group Slashes Stake in Circuit City
description: A major shareholder of Circuit City Stores, the nations No. 2 electronics retailer, has sold nearly its entire stake in the company, which reported last week that sales in December had fallen.

title: Endwave Buys Out Wood River Stake
description: On Christmas Eve, Wood River Capital Management finally liquidated its 4.1 million shares of Endwave, a San Jose maker of radio frequency modules used in telelcommunication networks, bringing to a close one of the more bizarre episodes of hedge fund investment in Silicon Valley history.

title: Omeros Files for $115 Milion I.P.O.
description: A Biopharmaceutical company, Omeros, has filed to go public in a maximum $115 million offering.

title: Quad-C Said to Buy Sportswear Firm
description: Quad-C Management is buying the Augusta Sportswear Group from Linsalata Capital Partners in a secondary buyout valued at $405 million to $450 million, The Deal reported.

title: Liberty Takes Bigger Stake in IAC
description: Liberty Media, the entertainment and Internet retailing company controlled by the billionaire John C. Malone, purchased 14 million shares of IAC/InterActiveCorp, the company controlled by Barry Diller, for $339.5 million.

title: Alder Gets $40 Million Injection from V.C.s
description: Alder Biopharmaceuticals raised $40 million in a third round of venture capital to fund clinical trials of its first novel antibody product for treating rheumatoid arthritis and cancer.

title: Cenkos in Deal Talks for Close Brothers
description: Cenkos Securities, a British stock adviser for small and midsize companies, said it is in talks to buy Close Brothers as it seeks to head off competing bidders that may include the Blackstone Group.

title: G.M. Joins Alternative Energy Investment Rush
description: General Motors, eager to ensure a supply of fuel for the big fleet of flex-fuel ethanol-capable vehicles it is building, has joined the rush into alternative energy and invested in a company that intends to produce ethanol from crop wastes, wood chips, scrap plastic, rubber and even municipal garbage.

title: Credit Agricole Sells Suez Stake to Raise Cash
description: Credit Agricole, the French bank, said Monday it is selling its direct 2.1 percent stake in the Franco-Belgian utility Suez, worth an estimated 1.2 billion euros ($1.8 billion).

title: Europe's Smart Car in America
description: Ten years after it appeared in Europe, the Mercedes-designed Smart car will soon go on sale in the United States.

title: Northwest Talks of Merger; Delta Keeps Quiet
description: The chief executive of Northwest Airlines says his carrier could benefit from a merger  if its the right deal.

title: Law Firm Goes Own Way on Compensation
description: In a world of follow-the-leader associate salary scales, a mid-size California law firm is carving its own path, The Recorder reports.

title: Thomson and Reuters Confident on Regulatory Approval
description: Thomson and the Reuters Group said Monday they are confident the Department of Justice and European Commission will approve Thomsons proposed $17.6 billion acquisition of Reuters soon.

title: Peering Inside GlassHouse Technologies
description: GlassHouse Technologies is one of several data-storage companies to seek an initial public offering of late. But GlassHouse is different, according to The 451 Group, because it provides consulting and information technology services rather than storage products. Will the markets buy into the services model?

title: Williams Pipeline to Kick Off I.P.O.s
description: The 2008 initial public offering market kicks off this week with a handful of deals, the strongest of which, analysts say, is that of the natural gas transportation and storage company Williams Pipeline Partners.

title: Kenneth Lewiss Big Countrywide Bet
description: Kenneth D. Lewis has gambled on bold acquisitions to build Bank of America into the nations largest bank.

title: Writers Strike Makes Happy Hunting for Some Start-Ups
description: Few online entertainment ventures today make money. Yet, says The Los Angeles Times, that has not deterred striking Hollywood writers, eager to bypass the studio system, from forming start-ups to distribute their work on the Web.

title: Third Act Surprise
description: Mary Hart, wearing a fire-engine-red dress, brought the press conference to the final award of the evening: Please welcome, the man who has gone through fire for weeks, your own Hollywood Foreign Press Association, Jose Camara.

title: Citigroup May Face $24 Billion Write-Down, Report Says
description: Even as it seeks foreign investment, Citigroup could write down as much as $24 billion as a result of subprime and credit-related losses, CNBC reported Sunday evening. In addition, an estimated 20 thousand layoffs will be part of a comprehensive plan to slash costs and raise capital, the news channel said.

title: Inquiry Focuses on Banks Data on Loans
description: An investigation into the mortgage crisis by New York State prosecutors is focusing on whether Wall Street banks withheld crucial information about the risks posed by investments linked to subprime loans.

title: No Victory Lap
description: Its great of course, Richard Zanuck, who produced Sweeney Todd, the winner of best musical or comedy, said by phone. I dont care about the party, but I do miss the event. Having won for Driving Miss Daisy, I know what its like to be sitting there and have the name of a picture you produced announced from the dais and then take that walk. We all miss that.

title: Sexual Consequences of Female Initiation Rites in Africa
description: Heres another expert with answers for the Lab readers who have been debating female initiation rites in Africa. Lucrezia Catania is a gynecologist and sexologist in Florence, Italy, at the Research Center for Preventing and Curing Complications of FGM/C (Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting). For more than two decades, the center has been treating women who have undergone these procedures, especially those with complications from the type called infibulation.

title: Inside the Bubbles
description: Champagne was uncorked and laughter was heard in the ballroom last night following the event, but it was coming from journalists, not from winners. The reporters may have been sad about trading Keira Knightley for Mary Hart, but they were happy to celebrate an early end to a busy night with free booze.

title: Congress Returns to Face Economic Worries
description: Congress returns this week  at least half of it does  for the start of 2008 and a session that should have distinct differences from 2007.

title: Citis Investment From China May Hit Snag
description: Citigroups attempt to get a $2 billion investment from the China Development Bank may have hit an obstacle in the form of new opposition from within the Chinese government.

title: La Vie en L.A.
description: Marion Cotillard was in L.A. when, plopped down in front of the tube, she find out that the Globes voters had judged her performance in La Vie en Rose irresistible. Definitely there was champagne involved. she said.  Definitely. It was a big surprise.

title: Study Sparks Regulator Scrutiny of Merger Arbitrage
description: With the rise of proprietary trading desks, investment banks sometimes find themselves taking positions in the stocks of companies they are advising in merger talks. At least a few of those instances are probably coincidental, and the firms will certainly argue that they are.

title: Zagat Publisher Seeks Buyer
description: A clever and sharp restaurant guide company with telling rankings and a penchant for quote marks from its thousands of in-the-know reviewers is apparently on the block.

title: Failing Global Geography
description: The Bagger went 8-for-14 last night. The technical term for his performance is, um, butt ugly, but the Bagger has been preoccupied by other matters and didnt make all the calls he should have to his trusted Globe sources.

title: The Early Word: Michigan
description: All of the Republican candidates, save for Fred D. Thompson, will campaign heavily today in Michigan, which holds its primary tomorrow. Mitt Romney is still hinging his campaign on a win there, although John McCain and Mike Huckabee have made it a very tight race.

title: The Ultimate Gas-Saving Machine
description: Introduced on Sunday: BMW X6 ActiveHybrid

title: A Zeo Chance of Going on Sale?
description: Introduced on Monday: Dodge Zeo concept.

title: Cooking Up a Beauty With Some Borrowed Ingredients
description: Introduced on Sunday: Mitsubishi Concept-RA

title: BMW Goes Back to Its Roots
description: Introduced on Sunday: BMW 1-Series convertible

title: Green Dreams in the Jeep Styling Studio
description: Introduced on Monday: Jeep Renegade Concept

title: When Crime Was on Everyones Mind
description: A bloody melee on a Harlem street is flashing New Yorkers back to the era of personal anticrime tactics, like muggers money, self-defense classes and concealed pepper spray. Just before midnight on Thursday, the police said, Maurice Parks, 39, a subway motorman who had just ended his shift, was preyed upon by a group of muggers armed with at least one knife.

title: CNet and the Future of Poison Pills
description: Late Friday evening, CNet announced that its board of directors had adopted a shareholder rights plan, commonly known as a poison pill.

title: A Flexible Flyer from Saturn
description: Introduced on Monday: Saturn Flextreme

title: When Cars Are All Electric, Well Buy and Sell to the Grid
description: DETROIT  Automakers arent the only companies with big ideas.

title: Richard Wagoner on G.M.'s Outlook
description: CNBC interviews Richard Wagoner, chief executive of General Motors, at the Detroit Auto Show about the challenges facing his company.

title: Hybrid Cars Take Detroit Spotlight
description: Phil LeBeau of CNBC shows the new breed of hybrid and plug-in cars and trucks.

title: Badmouthing Barack
description: Robert L. Johnson, the founder of Black Entertainment Television, alluded Sunday to Barack Obamas admission of drug use as a young man in Obamas memoir, Dreams From My Father. Josh Marshall reacts at Talking Points Memo:

title: Ford Explorer America: Same but Different
description: DETROIT  One of the vehicles Ford unveiled on Sunday was the Explorer America concept. If you havent already guessed, it foreshadows the next Explorer.

title: The Right Way to Swaddle
description: Swaddling, the practice of tightly wrapping a baby in a light blanket, is an age-old technique that not only calms babies but makes them portable. The technique is growing in popularity in the United States as a result of a best-selling parenting book that teaches frazzled parents how to soothe crying babies.

title: Answers About Immigration on the Lower East Side, Part 2
description: Following is the second and final set of answers from Steve Long, the vice president of collections and education at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, who took questions from City Room readers from Jan. 7 to 14 on the history of immigration and tenement life on Manhattans Lower East Side. A first set of questions and answers was posted on Jan. 9.

title: A Debate on Bits: Technology as a Weapon Against Piracy
description: This week, Bits will host a debate about copyright issues and technology between Rick Cotton, the general counsel of NBC Universal, and Tim Wu, a professor at Columbia Law School. See the entire debate here.

title: Hybrid Cars Take Detroit Spotlight
description: Phil LeBeau of CNBC shows the new breed of hybrid and plug-in cars and trucks.

title: In Every Other Country
description: In todays Times, Bill Carter reports that some of reality shows are besting their scripted counterparts on broadcast TV:

title: Does the Rover Family Have a Baby on the Way?
description: Introduced on Sunday: Land Rover LRX Design Study

title: Aronian, Carlsen Take Lead at Corus
Business Class for the Ground Bound
description: Introduced on Monday: Lincoln MKT

title: Ferrari in a Bow Tie
description: Introduced on Saturday: 2009 Chevrolet Corvette ZR1

title: A Fuel-Cell Cadillac
description: Introduced on Monday: Cadillac Provoq Hybrid Concept

title: More Power to the People
description: Introduced on Sunday: Audi TTS coupe and roadster

title: A Nonconformist Subaru Veers Toward the Generic
description: Introduced on Monday: 2009 Subaru Forester

title: Citi and the Kitchen Sink Theory
description: At first blush, CNBCs report that Citigroup could announce up to $24 billion in write-downs Tuesday because of credit-related losses sounds like disastrous news. That figure is much higher than what sell-side analysts were expecting, and more than twice the high end of Citis previous estimate in early November, which put the losses at $8 billion to $11 billion.

title: Stunners on Waterboarding and Guantnamo: Less Than Meets the Eye
description: Close Guantnamo, the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff says. Waterboarding is torture, the director of national intelligence admits.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Managing Editor John Geddes
description: John M. Geddes, managing editor of The Times, answered reader questions Jan. 14-18, 2008. Questions may be e-mailed to askthetimes@nytimes.com. To skip to the most recent answer, click here.

title: Who Is G.M.s New Ethanol Partner?
description: DETROIT  On Sunday, Rick Wagoner, chief executive of General Motors, pushed ethanol to the gathered press like it was going out of business.

title: Theyre Still Talking About It
description: Even after posts scroll off the blog front, readers keep talking. Some recent highlights.

title: Eyes on the Prizes
description: The winner of the Randolph Caldecott Medal for most distinguished picture book for children was announced this morning at the American Library Associations annual midwinter meeting: it was The Invention of Hugo Cabret, by Brian Selznick (Scholastic). The equally prestigious Newbery Medal went to Good Masters! Sweet Ladies! Voices From a Medieval Village, by Laura Amy Schlitz (Candlewick).

title: Bains Big Premium for Bright Horizons
description: Leveraged buyout activity may be lean these days, but that isnt stopping Bain Capital from paying a fat premium for its chosen takeover target.

title: Open a New Window: A Tower With a View
description: The only thing standing between the occupants of 375 Pearl Street and some of the most commanding views in Lower Manhattan is three inches of limestone.Though the 32-story telephone company tower is not truly windowless, it might as well be. There are three-foot-wide slits running up and down the structure, some with glass in them. But, like the windows of the World Trade Center, these do little more than offer a tantalizingly small slice of what could have been an extraordinary panorama.

title: Monday Kickoff: Slaton Headed to the N.F.L.
description: Steve Slaton is passing on his senior season at West Virginia to enter the N.F.L. draft. It wasnt an easy decision, but Slatons father told The Philadelphia Daoily News that  surprise  it had a lot to do with Roch Rodriguezs leaving to go to Michigan and taking most of his staff with him.

title: The Mysteries of Surgeons, Revealed
description: What kind of music is played in the operating room? Why dont you ever see surgeons wearing their stethoscopes? These and other pressing questions are answered in an interesting blog post from University of Virginia medical student Mark Hoofnagle, written after his first week on a surgical rotation.

title: Bits Debate: Is Copy Protection Needed or Futile?
description: UPDATED 4:18 PM

title: Equinox "Happily Ever" TV Spot
description: Equinox TV advertisement for the "Happily Ever" campaign.

title: Saab Boasts BioPower for a New Crossover
description: DETROIT  Saab showed its first crossover vehicle on Sunday at the Detroit Auto Show, the 9-4X BioPower. It is still very much a concept vehicle, but theres nothing superfuturistic about it, so its quite likely well be seeing it on the street sometime soon.

title: Felicitations, Cover Girl
description: (Raymond Meier)

title: MySpace to Let Parents Block Their Children From Joining
description: Representatives from MySpace and the attorneys general of 49 states are announcing a new partnership to fight sexual predators and clean up social networks.

title: Giulianis Lead Shrinks in Florida, Poll Shows
description: NAPLES, Fla.  The campaigns signs say Florida is Rudy Country. But despite Rudolph W. Giulianis heavy advertising effort here, and the fact that he has the state almost to himself while his rivals duke it out in colder climes, a poll released Monday shows that his lead in Florida has slipped, and the state is now very much up for grabs.

title: Deconstructing Time Warners Fix-It Guy
description: At a conference in November, Richard Parsons, the outgoing chief executive of Time Warner, was asked what he would do if he were in the shoes of his successor, Jeffrey Bewkes. If I were Jeff, Mr. Parsons replied jokingly, I would shoot myself.

title: For the Moment |  Francesco Vezzoli
description: This weeks guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidals Caligula, starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandellos Right You Are (If You Think You Are), starring  among others  Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his first post of the week, Vezzoli explains his affection for Magnani.

title: Steve Jobs Keynote: Fun and Games
description: On Tuesday, Apple CEO Steve Jobs takes the stage in San Francisco at the 2008 Macworld Expo. Hell show charts of iPod and iPhone success! Hell unveil beautiful new products! Hell wear black turtleneck and jeans!

title: The Skim
description: Times of London

title: A New You: Dr. Richard A. Friedman on Mental Health
description: What are the first steps to take when confronted with a serious mental illness? How do you cope with grief, or everyday stress? Is there a recipe for happiness? This week Dr. Richard A. Friedman, professor of clinical psychiatry at Weill Cornell Medical College and a frequent contributor to Science Times, is answering questions and hosting a discussion on mental health and emotional well-being. You may post your comments and questions below. Please remember that Dr. Friedman cannot answer all questions, and he cannot respond to solicitations for medical advice. [Eds. note: We are no longer accepting comments and questions.]

title: A Bears Questions
description: David A. Rosenberg, a Merrill Lynch economist, is out with a report today that concludes that home prices need to fall another 20 percent or more to get into reasonable territory relative to rental prices.

title: Filipino Monkey and the Naval Confrontation With Iran
description: If that wasnt an Iranian military officer who was threatening American ships in the Strait of Hormuz last week  a claim that the Pentagon is backing away from, conceding that the threat could have come from anyone on shore with a radio  then who was it?

title: Staying Current on Currency: Another Day, Another Euro?
description: With travel to New York City at record levels, and with the the dollar at near-record lows against the pound and the euro, does it make sense for New York City businesses to start accepting foreign currency?A recent article in The Villager, a neighborhood newspaper, caught our eye. It noted that East Village Wines, a liquor store at 138 First Avenue, accepts payments in euros as well as dollars. During a recent visit to the store, City Room noticed a sign that stated the current exchange rate and noted that euros were welcome.

title: The Rise, Fall and Rise of Bruce Wasserstein
description: In 1991, GQ magazine pronounced his high-flying career in finance finished: Its over for Bruce Wasserstein, the magazine declared. Just a few years ago, that might have seemed prescient. But today, that conclusion seems more than a bit premature, as Karl Taro Greenfeld reports in a generally flattering article about the Lazard chief executive that appears in the February issue of Portfolio magazine.

title: Q and A: Lachlan Mackinnon-Patterson
description: To this point the chefs whom Diners Journal has asked to participate in its Q and A have all had their principal restaurants in New York. But with todays post we widen the focus to include chefs rooted in other parts of the country.

title: Edwards Campaign Calls Nevada Race a Dead Heat
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  The Edwards campaign characterized the Nevada race as a three-way dead heat in a conference call with reporters today, pointing to poll numbers and a robust field operation in the state.

title: Ford Rides the Election Coattails
description: DETROIT  With a giant wink of the eye, Ford printed up campaign buttons for its Escape Hybrid, claiming that it is The Candidates Choice.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Jan. 14:

title: Princely Sums for New Sallie Mae Leaders
description: Sallie Mae is paying a pretty penny to get itself out of its latest troubles.

title: How Now, Green Cow?
description: DETROIT  Journalists at this weeks auto show here cannot stop talking about two topics: green vehicles and cows. Cows, of course, referring to the 120 Texas Longhorns that Chrysler paraded through downtown to spice up the introduction of its 2009 Dodge Ram pickup.

title: Bad buzz
description: So far, there are very few hard numbers showing a recession underway. What there is, instead, is buzz  an accumulation of small items like the Baltic Dry Shipping Index, plus the way people are talking.

title: Dont Feed the Pigeons Here. But Over There, O.K.
description: Safe pigeon-feeding zones may be designated around the city as part of the negotiations between animal rights groups and the Brooklyn city councilman who has proposed fining pigeon feeders as much as $1,000 as strategy to control New Yorks pigeon population.Fines, which had been used successfully in Basel, Switzerland, to limit pigeon proliferation, were the most concrete proposal in a pigeon report issued by Councilman Simcha Felders office in November. Other ideas in the report included pigeon birth control and a pigeon czar.

title: The Clintons and History
description: WASHINGTON  Theres an old joke people here in the capital like to tell about Charles E. Schumer, the New York senator, and over the years Im sure its been used to describe other politicians, as well: The most dangerous place to stand in Washington is between Chuck Schumer and a bank of television cameras.

title: Looking Lucky at Harrahs
description: Harrahs Entertainment on Monday announced a scheduled closing date for its long-pending $27.8 billion acquisition by funds affiliated with the Texas Pacific Group and Apollo Management. The date is Jan. 28, more than a year after the initial agreement was announced.

title: Worker Is Killed in Accident at Trump SoHo Tower
description: Updated, 8:46 p.m. | A construction worker plunged to his death, and two others were injured, after a wooden structure on the 42nd floor of the Trump SoHo hotel and condominium tower under construction in Manhattan collapsed, city officials said. The building, which is to rise 46 stories, has been a persistent source of debate, with community groups complaining about its size and proposed use, even before construction began last May.

title: Bush tax cut mythology
description: As the debate turns to economic stimulus, were starting to hear this: Bush realized that the economy needed help, so he asked Congress to enact tax cuts to provide stimulus. And this turned the economy around.

title: Globes Show Delivers Low Ratings For NBC
description: The Hollywood writers strike took the glitz, the glamour and roughly two-thirds of the audience from this years Golden Globe Awards, the Associated Press notes.

title: ber-Brunch Buffet on a Sunday in Frankfurt
description: I have never specifically had a German tell me that The Sunday Brunch Buffet is an institution in Frankfurt. But that may be because it is so obvious, no native of the city would feel the need to comment. Having lived in four German towns now, from very small to the largest one (Berlin was my previous billet) I would say that Frankfurt surpasses them all, measured by the quality of Sunday brunch.

title: Crash Test Outside Cobo
