description: DETROIT  I was standing in front of the Cobo Center just before 4 p.m. on Sunday when I heard a huge crash. I turned and saw a police car go sailing across the street and smash into the wall in front of the new Sheraton hotel, formerly the Pontchartrain. A pedestrian jumped out of the way of the police car and barely escaped being sandwiched between bumper and wall. I was impressed by the huge pile of debris in the middle of the street  and the black Vibe that it appeared had smashed into the back of the police car and sent it flying. The area was soon swarming with policemen; both drivers turned out to be all right.

title: Politics and Soccer: Strange Bedfellows?
description: If money makes the world go-round (certainly, it makes the soccer world go-round), then certainly money also qualifies as the mothers milk of American political campaigns.

title: The Butterfly Effect
description: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, which had a big night at the Globes, woke up to the equivalent of Dennys Grand Slam breakfast by being one of the the Producers Guild of Americas five nominees for best picture. Juno, No Country, There Will Be Blood and Clayton were the other four, while Atonement, which wore the slipper last night, went unshod, as did Sweeney Todd. Variety has the story.

title: Question: Steroid Cloud Over Entertainment, Too?
description: In his report released in December, former Senator George Mitchell said that steroids posed a serious threat to the integrity of the game of baseball. But can the same be said about entertainment?

title: Soft Serve | A News Feed of Light Reading
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Gov. Spitzers New Project: Lowering Property Taxes
description: After a rocky first year that saw his approval ratings nosedive, New York Governor Eliot Spitzer is beginning his second year with a campaign that can be expected to have broad appeal among voters: lowering property taxes.

title: Where the Smart Car Sells
description: DETROIT  Californians are trendy, so it is no surprise that they are expected to buy more two-seat Smart cars this year than any other state. The tiny car, manufactured in France by Daimler AG, is being delivered this week to its first customers in the United States.

title: Terminator Kills the Golden Globes
description: NBCs bare-bones version of the 65th Annual Golden Globes attracted just 5.8 million viewers on Sunday, a small fraction of the 20 million who tuned in to the awards show a year ago, according to Nielsens estimates. A two-hour Dateline that preceded the 9 p.m. announcement show and featured interviews with the nominees did not fare any better, attracting just 4.4 million viewers. Combined, the three-hour broadcast delivered a dismal 1.3 rating in the critical demographic of adults 18 to 49, a far cry from the 6.5 rating the show earned in prime time on a Monday last January.

title: Animal Planet Bares Its Feral Side
description: Last month the film Grizzly Man debuted on Animal Planet, the cable channel owned by Discovery Communications. The 2005 documentary explored the life of a man who spent years with bears in the Alaskan wilderness before being mauled to death.

title: Deep-Fried Controversy
description: No one has wielded the power of humor more effectively on the campaign trail than Mike Huckabee, whose one-liners have softened the edge on his Republican populism and enhanced his image as a likable alternative to his better financed opponents. But a joke at Mr. Huckabees expense has caused a major headache for a young satire show on public radio as it faced the wrath of a religious advocacy group.

title: Spain Nightmare
description: The British press is having a field day with the story of a retired couple in Spain who watched their house bulldozed by the government last week.

title: Notable Models From Day Two in Detroit
description: A selection of vehicles that were displayed on the second preview day of the North American International Auto Show.

title: Karma Commuting, She Comes and Goes, Week 3
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commuting trip for NYTimes.com/realestate, with additional details and reader comments here on City Room [Week 1 | Week 2]. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Lowes Provides a Venza Grabber
description: DETROIT  It may seem like a stretch to say that Lowes, the home improvement store, has anything to do with Toyotas new Venza crossover vehicle.

title: Corvette ZR1
description: General Motors officially revealed its newest high-performance Corvette, with a supercharged 6.2-liter V-8.

title: The Gingerbread Man
description: I hate to sound like one of those Vaudeville comedians whod begin their routine with a funny thing happened to me on the way to the theater  a man walked up to me and said, I havent had a bite to eat for days. So I bit him.  but I have no choice. Bear with me.

title: The Save XP Petition
description: An eyebrow-raising initiative from an old editor friend of mine:

title: Romney Addresses a Car Industry That Has Changed
description: DETROIT  In the days leading up to Tuesdays Republican primary, Mitt Romney has made much of his Michigan upbringing, stressing his experiences as a child of the auto industry. But much has changed since Mr. Romneys father, George Romney, who later became governor, was running the American Motors Corporation in the 1950s.

title: That Was Then, This Is Now
description: Today is Jan. 14. And once upon a time  that would be many, many Democratic fights over the nominating calendar ago  this would have been the day of the Iowa caucuses. Back in Des Moines, our friend and colleague Kay Henderson of Iowa Radio shares a post on her blog of what might have been had it happened today. (Veterans of the John Edwards campaign who had been hoping for bad weather, and instead got flooded by new Obama voters who pushed Mr. Edwards back eight-points behind Mr. Obama, might want to skip Ms. Hendersons post.)

title: More on Giuliani and Florida
description: PUNTA GORDA, Fla.  Brent Seaborn, the chief strategist for the Giuliani campaign, just offered a few observations Monday afternoon on the race in Florida, given the Quinnipiac poll showing Mr. Giulianis lead here evaporating.

title: Clinton Receives Tepid Reception at MLK Event
description: Speaking to black and Hispanic New Yorkers this afternoon, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tried to quell the controversy over race and the Democratic presidential nomination fight by crediting the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King for his march for freedom and justice that had benefited both herself and her rival, Senator Barack Obama.

title: How Much Is That Rat in the Window?
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Airbus Chief Announces U.S. Plant
description: CNBC interviews Thomas Enders, Airbus chief executive, about the company's plans to build an aircraft assembly plant in Alabama.

title: Magellan Opens to New Investors
description: Harry Lange, portfolio manager for Fidelity's Magellan Fund, discusses opening up the fund to new investors for the first time in a decade.

title: More Gladiators On the Way
description: NBC has announced a second season order of American Gladiators, one week after the series was introduced and drew strong ratings.

title: Senator Brunos Wife Is Eulogized
description: Several hundred people  including Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the archbishop of New York, and a whos who of state politicians  turned out today for a memorial service for Barbara Bruno, the wife of the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. Mrs. Bruno died on Jan. 8 after a long battle with Alzheimers disease.Lining the first row: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, Gov. Eliot Spitzer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his companion, Diana L. Taylor; the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, and Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson. Others in attendance includes former United States Senator Alfonse M. DAmato, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli.

title: Of Suzy Menkes, Poetry and Hedge-Fund Hotties
description: The Moment is pleased to welcome the International Herald Tribune to its blogroll. Specifically, wed like to draw your attention to the work of Ms. Suzy Menkes, who is covering the mens shows in Milan for the I.H.T. (Shes a T Magazine columnist too, by the way.) In this video interview with Burberrys Christopher Bailey she begins by saying that Burberrys last collection was all about hedge-fund hotties, whereas the new seasons clothes are autumnal and poetic. As the video brings to light, Bailey sprinkled the runway with leaves and dressed the boys in turkey feathers. Suzys editors, meanwhile, are quite enamored of Posh Spices comments about a billboard showing Becks in his B.V.D.s, in this Suzy video. Whatever works

title: This Papal Visit Will Be Smaller Than the Last One
description: Pope Benedict XVIs visit to New York City will be significantly more modest than the much-celebrated visit his predecessor, Pope John Paul II, made in 1995, as judged by a preliminary itinerary released by the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Blogtalk: An Uncommitted Vote?
description: What do you do if youre a Democrat in Michigan?

title: Facebook Is No Kingmaker
description: Sundays 60 Minutes feature on Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook, hit all the logical bases: privacy, business model, the Beacon miscues and his youth. Only one section struck me as oddly off: the brief section on politics.

title: First-Timers in Vegas
description: Dont wager on the latest Nevada numbers: Markos Moulitsas doesnt buy the new Reno Gazette-Journal poll showing a dead heat in Nevada among the three remaining Democratic candidates for president: How the heck do you poll likely caucus goers in a state that has never had a presidential caucus this early? he writes. He adds:

title: Anything but the E Word
description: Mondays New York Times poll, invokes the word I dread the most in any discussion of primary campaigns: electability.

title: Finally, New Corvette ZR1 Makes Official Debut
description: DETROIT  What can you build for $100,000?

title: Jumbo Jet to Fly (Partly) on Biofuel
description: Car makers are racing to put out new vehicles with ever higher fuel efficiency or  in the case of plug-in hybrids planned for 2010 by GM and Toyota  the prospect of traveling without combustion at all. Such vehicles eventually could (if the grid were powered by nuclear plants, dams, windmills, or solar energy) form the basis for the kind of green mobility I wrote about a few days ago.

title: Friends of the Father
description: Mitt Romney, son of the former car company executive and Republican Gov. George Romney of Michigan, is counting on his fathers outsized reputation to help him turn around his losing streak in the states Republican primary Tuesday. But several of his fathers former associates have come out against him.

title: Function Dysfunction
description: (Editors note: Allison Arieff wrote on design for NYTimes.coms Opinion section in September 2006. She returns now with a monthly column.)

title: Obama Tries to Stop the Silliness
description: RENO, Nev.  As he campaigned in northern Nevada on Monday, Senator Barack Obama said he was concerned that a heated discussion of racial issues in the presidential campaign could divide the Democratic Party.

title: Im Gonna Wash That Brand Right Into My Hair
description: A hair-care brand is hoping to generate some attention through a worldwide campaign that gets under way with a star-filled commercial during Super Bowl XLII on Fox on Feb. 3.

title: Amazon Beat eBay in Holiday Traffic
description: For years, eBay ruled the e-commerce roost. Each holiday season, more visitors spent more time and looked at more pages on eBay.com than on any of its rivals, including Amazon.com. It made sense; eBay is a wide open forum for every kind of seller and item, while Amazon has traditionally pushed a selection of products through its network of physical warehouses.

title: Bloggingheads: Why Not Chris Dodd?
description:
Bloggers Ezra Klein, left, of The American Prospect and Peter Suderman of National Review Online debate the media's role in choosing presidential contenders.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Thought Experiment
description: As a monkey walked in North Carolina its brain activity controlled a robot in Japan. The two treadmills were not connected.(Credits: Duke University and JST)

title: Monday Injury Update: Chargers Edition
description: San Diego quarterback Philip Rivers has a sprained medial collateral ligament in his right knee and is questionable for the A.F.C. championship game Sunday at New England. He injured the knee when he landed awkwardly after throwing a touchdown pass to Darren Sproles late in the third quarter. He was already wearing a brace on his left knee from a Dec. 9 injury. Chargers Coach Norv Turner said Rivers would be limited in practice this week. (You can watch Turners news conference here.)

title: The Fortune Cookie
description: Jennifer 8. Lee of The New York Times tracks down the original fortune cookie.

title: Whos Afraid of Terrorists?
description: How worried are you that you or someone in your family will become a victim of terrorism? Very worried, somewhat worried, not too worried, or not worried at all?

title: Next-Generation Pickups
description: Rising gasoline prices have driven some consumers toward more fuel-efficient vehicles, prompting manufacturers to offer trucks with improved fuel economy.

title: Candidates Cruise the Auto Show
description: Cars took a back seat at the Detroit Auto Show for a few hours Monday, as the three top Republican candidates in Tuesdays Michigan primary stopped by to tour the exhibits.

title: Fiat King Holds Court in Rome
description: Five years after his death, Fiat kingpin Gianni Agnelli is being commemorated in an exhibit here that blurs the boundaries between the myth and the man. The show runs until Jan. 30 at the Vittoriano Museum Complex, an exhibition space underneath the monument dedicated to the Italian king Vittorio Emanuele II that is usually unkindly compared to a wedding cake and/or gigantic white typewriter. History buffs may be interested to know that the monument commemorates Italian unification and includes a museum to the Risorgimento, as the unification movement is known, as well as the Altare della Patria, the altar of the fatherland.

title: CNN Beginning Nightly Election Wrap
description: CNN says it is beginning a nightly prime-time wrap-up of election news, further evidence that the 2008 presidential campaign is a television hit, the Associated Press reports.

title: Sex After Prostate Surgery
description: For men facing prostate cancer, their first worry is about dying. Often, their second worry is whether the treatment will kill their sex life.

title: Kucinich Should Be Allowed to Debate, Judge Rules
description: A Nevada judge has ordered MSNBC to include Representative Dennis Kucinich, a Democratic presidential candidate, in Tuesday nights debate in Nevada, the Associated Press reports.

title: Our Fetid City
description: Naples, Italy

title: Johnny Podres, Series Star, Dies at 75
description: Johnny Podres, who became a celebrated figure in the storied history of the Brooklyn Dodgers in October 1955, when he pitched them to their only World Series championship, died Sunday in Glens Falls, N.Y. Podres, who lived nearby in Queensbury, N.Y., was 75.

title: Crackdown on L.I. Landlords Is Criticized as Harassment of Immigrants
description: WESTHAMPTON, N.Y.  The officers showed up at 6 a.m. at the four connected apartments on Old Country Road.

title: To Sell Higher Tolls, Corzine Talks Bonds
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine wants you to believe that no politician in New Jersey can be trusted to safeguard the states finances, except one: himself.

title: A Loophole Lets a Foot in the Door
description: The bad news reached Neil Ashe, the chief executive of CNet, as he lounged on the beach in Mexico on vacation with his family over the holidays. The companys lawyer called to say that two hedge funds had secretly acquired the equivalent of a 21 percent stake in CNet and planned to mount a proxy contest to take over the board.

title: Insights: Possible Link Between Sleep and Risk for Diabetes
description: What happens when you rouse people hundreds of time a night when they go into deep sleep  besides the possibility that they might get seriously grumpy?

title: Citi to Announce Big Cuts and New Investors
description: Citigroup is expected to announce a series of drastic steps on Tuesday, including the elimination at least 4,000 additional jobs, a steep cut in its stock dividend and another big investment by foreign investors, in a bid to bolster its finances in the face of deepening losses.

title: U.S. Army Chief in Europe to Run NATO Afghan Unit
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. David D. McKiernan is expected to be appointed as the next commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan, American military officials said Monday.

title: A Favorite Meal, Now Offering a Side Order of Environmental Awareness
description: LONDON  The restaurateur Tom Aikens is opening a sustainable fish and chips restaurant this month in Londons trendy South Kensington. Diners at Toms Place will be able to fulfill their consumer desires and be environmentally correct, too, but at a price.

title: Pelosi Begins Discussions on Stimulus to Economy
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker Nancy Pelosi met on Monday with the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, to discuss potential action by Congress, the White House and the central bank to jump-start the economy and try to shorten the slowdown that many economists say has already begun to take hold.

title: Crisis? Maybe Hes a Narcissistic Jerk
description: With the possible exception of the dog ate my homework, there is no handier excuse for human misbehavior than the midlife crisis.

title: The Show Went On, the Fun Went Away
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD  Those of us who have always wondered why award shows have to be so infernally long got our answer on Sunday night at the Golden Globes: they dont, but all meaning is derived in such matters from the script that goes with such ceremonies. The windy speeches, the tears of joy, the fashion miscues, all arrayed over remarkable superbeings in gossamer frocks are what people turn the television on for. Without pomp, there is no circumstance, at least in Hollywood.

title: The Road May Be Rough, but It Yields Material
description: Its a trick well known to television writers in need of a quick script: stitch together some scenes from old shows with just enough new thread to connect them, however loosely.

title: A Passionate, Yet Light Voice for Icy Songs by Schubert
description: Its hard to think of a song cycle as gripping as Winterreise, Schuberts setting of 24 poems by Wilhelm Mller that trace the downward spiral  physical, spiritual and psychological  of a rejected lover who leaves his town in the dark of night and wanders through the snow toward a hoped-for death. Mllers poetry is presented from a mans perspective, and Schuberts cycle is mostly sung by men, although women (generally mezzo-sopranos) have taken it up over the years.

title: Virgin Atlantic Plans a Biofuel Flight
description: PARIS  Virgin Atlantic said Monday that it would conduct a demonstration flight next month of one of its Boeing 747 jets using biofuel  the first airborne test of a renewable fuel by a commercial jet.

title: Sweet Potatolicious, and Other Healthy Recipes for East Harlem
description: East Harlem, home to a cornucopia of fried foods that cover a range ethnic tastes  tostones, chicken fried steak, pork rinds, egg rolls, refried beans, cuchifritos, French fries and onion rings, among others  has a bad reputation when it comes to good nutrition.

title: Quality Is Major Concern of Toyotas Visiting Chief
description: DETROIT  In his first visit to the Detroit auto show since becoming Toyotas president in 2005, Katsuaki Watanabe used this very public forum to convey a passionate plea to his employees on Monday to take personal responsibility for the quality of Toyota cars and trucks.

title: Waiting in Style
description: The airport lounge is no longer just a bunch of sofas in a quiet place.

title: Doctors Where Theyre Needed
description: Few things are more frightening than knowing you live too far away from the nearest doctor. Yet in many rural or poor urban areas there are far too few doctors to serve the community, and the problem is getting worse.

title: Capitalizing on Oils Rise, Kazakhstan Expands Stake in Huge Offshore Project
description: MOSCOW  A consortium of foreign companies has resolved a dispute over Kazakhstans giant Kashagan oil field by agreeing to pay the government a bonus of up to $4.5 billion and to transfer 8.5 percent of the project to the national oil company of Kazakhstan.

title: Rice Makes Unannounced Visit to Baghdad
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice flew to Baghdad on Tuesday, peeling off a trip to the region by President Bush to give momentum to legislative and political reconciliation, the White House said.

title: Olmert Is Cautious as Talks With Palestinians Begin
description: JERUSALEM  Top Israeli and Palestinian negotiators began talks on core issues on Monday, as Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel sought to lower expectations of reaching a final peace agreement within a year.

title: F.D.A. Says Cloned Animals Safe to Eat
description: After years of debate, the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday declared that food from cloned animals and their progeny is safe, removing the last government hurdle before meat and milk derived from copies of prize dairy cows and superior hogs can be sold at grocery stores.

title: Missouri: Mayor Arrested in Internet Sex Sting
description: A pastor who is the mayor of a small town was in jail on charges of soliciting sex over the Internet from a police detective posing as a 13-year-old girl. The mayor, Allen Kauffman of Collins, was arrested Friday on four counts of felony enticement of a child in the latest sting orchestrated by a police detective in Diamond, another southwest Missouri town. Prosecutors said in court filings that Mr. Kauffman, 63, believed he was communicating with a girl from the Joplin area in a Yahoo chat room last November and December. In online messages, Mr. Kauffman reportedly asked the girl for sex and nude pictures, and encouraged her to have sex with a female friend in front of a Webcam so he could watch, the authorities said. Collins, with a population of about 200, is in St. Clair County.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Says Landing Fees Could Be Used to Ease Airport Traffic
description: WASHINGTON  Airports could manipulate landing fees to encourage airlines to fly fewer planes or schedule landings for off-peak times or even less-busy airports, the Transportation Department said Monday.

title: Canadian Bank Hopes Stock Offer Calms Fears
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said on Monday that it would issue 2.75 billion Canadian dollars in stock at substantially discounted prices as part of an effort to ease investor anxiety about its subprime mortgage exposure.

title: Europe Delays Changing Rules on Cheap Goods
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission has shelved plans to change the trade rules that allow it to retaliate against countries that sell goods below their market value. The move illustrates deep divisions in Europe over how to deal with Chinas booming exports.

title: New DVDs
description: PAYDAY

title: No Immunity, No Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  Jose A. Rodriguez Jr., the former Central Intelligence Agency official who ordered the destruction of interrogation videotapes in 2005, will not be required to appear on Wednesday at a closed Congressional hearing on the matter but may be called to testify later, an official briefed on the inquiry said Monday.

title: In Obamas Pursuit of Latinos, Race Plays Role
description: LAS VEGAS  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has eaten beef tacos in East Los Angeles and sat on the living room couch of a working-class family in a largely Hispanic neighborhood here for 30 televised minutes. At a rally of the culinary workers union in the shadows of the Strip here one night, Senator Barack Obama pumped his fist and chanted with the crowd, S, se puede; s, se puede; s, se puede! or, Yes, we can!

title: Magellan Fund, Closed in 97, Will Reopen
description: BOSTON (AP)  For the first time in a decade, new investors will be able to put money into a mutual fund that helped fuel Fidelity Investments rapid growth in the 1980s and 1990s, but has recently lost many retirement-age investors as they withdraw cash.

title: In Big Ways and Small, the Giants Grew Into a Team
description: All around the Giants are signs and symbols of change and progression, from the once-isolated head coach, who was spotted Sunday night triumphantly bearhugging a player, to the acutely boyish quarterback, who stepped to the podium wearing the flattering look of whiskered grunge.

title: To See (and Hear) the World in Five Hours: Unique Sounds Ripe for Import
description: The most striking group at Globalfest 2008  the five-hour, 12-band showcase of world music on Sunday night at Webster Hall  was the one that traveled lightest: Lo Cr de la Plana, from Marseilles, France. It was six male singers, four of whom also played hand drums and tambourine. They sang in a disappearing language, Occitan, and in an old style that once was church music. They performed traditional and traditionalist songs that took pride in what the groups lead singer, Manu Theron, cheerfully called filthy Marseilles.

title: Childrens' Book Awards Break With the Past
description: The John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to childrens literature was awarded on Monday to Good Masters! Sweet Ladies! Voices From a Medieval Village, by Laura Amy Schlitz. The American Library Association announced the prize at its midwinter meeting in Philadelphia. The book, a series of monologues and dialogues about characters in the Middle Ages, is illustrated by Robert Byrd and published by Candlewick Press. Its format is different from the more traditional novels that have characterized past Newbery winners. The winner of the Randolph Caldecott Medal for the most distinguished American picture book for children was The Invention of Hugo Cabret, by Brian Selznick. That book, published by Scholastic Press, is also different from the more traditional short picture books for young children that win the Caldecott medal. Hugo Cabret is a novel told in blocks of text interspersed with 284 pages of black-and-white drawings.

title: Jeepers, Rappers, Whered You Get Those Arms and Torsos?
description: When news surfaced over the weekend that 50 Cent, Wyclef Jean, Timbaland and other rap stars had been implicated in a steroids investigation, some hip-hop fans were shocked, but to many in the industry the accusations seemed inevitable.

title: Clinton and Obama Call for Truce Over Dr. King Dispute
description: Speaking to black and Hispanic New Yorkers, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tried on Monday to quell a controversy over race in the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination by praising the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and describing him as a trailblazer for both herself and her rival, Senator Barack Obama.

title: More Than Games, a Net to Snare Social Networkers
description: FRIENDSHIP means being able to sink each others battleships.

title: The Fourth Wall Is Broken, but the Floor Is Still Available for Use
description: K T Niehoffs new full-length work, Inhabit, starts off a bit like a dining experience at the restaurant chain Johnny Rockets. All you really want is to devour a cheeseburger in peace, but the exhaustingly upbeat wait staff is so keen on entertaining that vegetarianism suddenly starts to look good.

title: MySpace Agrees to Lead Fight to Stop Sex Predators
description: MySpace, the countrys largest social-networking Web site, has agreed with attorneys general of 49 states to take new steps to protect children from sexual predators on its site. It also agreed to lead a nationwide effort to develop technology to verify the ages and identities of Internet users, officials announced Monday.

title: Ban on Rides for Teenagers Is Attacked
description: CHICAGO  An Illinois lawmaker says he plans to try to save an unintended victim of tougher laws intended to reduce teenage drivers accidents.

title: Motion Ties W. Virginia Justice to Coal Executive
description: A justice of the West Virginia Supreme Court and a powerful coal-company executive met in Monte Carlo in the summer of 2006, sharing several meals even as the executives companies were appealing a $50 million jury verdict against them to the court.

title: Olmert and Omar: Talking Baseball
description: Some people go to Israel and see their grandchildren. Omar Minaya went to Israel last week and met with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, President Shimon Peres, the former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the famed Russian refusenik Natan Sharansky, a former member of the Israeli cabinet and parliament.

title: In South Carolina, a Bid for Black Womens Votes
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Juanita Ramsey, a retired administrative assistant, was standing by her front door in her largely black neighborhood here. As she pointed to the homes of her neighbors, she identified them by political preference:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a film review on Saturday about In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale misspelled the given name of one of the actors. As noted in a listing of credits with the review, he is Burt Reynolds, not Bert.

title: Scaling a Minimalist Wall With Bright, Shiny Colors
description: YONKERS  Pattern and Decoration: An Ideal Vision in American Art, 1975-1985, at the Hudson River Museum, documents the last genuine art movement of the 20th century, which was also the first and only art movement of the postmodern era and may well prove to be the last art movement ever.

title: Coaching the Comeback
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  In the therapy gym for the minimally functional, Jodi Levin props a patient between cushions, kneels behind him and then braces him with her arms. She directs his mother to select photos of his brother and his father. At the coaxing of Ms. Levin, an occupational therapist on the brain injury unit of Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation, the mother holds one photo to the left side of the patients head, the other to the right.

title: Mayoral Candidates Vie for 09 Fund-Raising Lead
description: William C. Thompson Jr., the New York City comptroller, has raised the most money so far in the quest for the Democratic nomination for mayor in 2009, but United States Representative Anthony D. Weiner raised the most in the past six months, according to numbers their campaigns provided on Monday.

title: Yale Plans Sharp Increase in Student Aid
description: Yale said Monday that it would sharply increase financial aid for undergraduates, including those from families with annual incomes up to $200,000, in a bid to ease costs for a broad swath of students.

title: For a Musical Polymath, Only the Wardrobe Color Stays the Same
description: I have a strange relationship to variety, the singer-songwriter Stephin Merritt said recently, as he sat at a West Village cafe meticulously tearing a croissant into little bits. He was discussing his wardrobe  absolutely all of his clothing is in a white-to-brown color palette (more on that later)  but also his career. In music, at least, I like variety, Mr. Merritt said.

title: Mentally Ill and Homeless, Worker Fights to Regain Her Life
description: With her understated makeup, pressed pantsuit and soft-spoken manner, it is easy to imagine Allison Brito at her job, behind a jewelry counter at Macys.

title: Video Game Industry Seeks Political Clout
description: Capitalizing on its improved respectability, the video game industry intends to establish a political action committee to donate money to game-friendly politicians and candidates.

title: Candidate Clinton Scrutinized by Women
description: For the last week reporters, pundits, bloggers and political operatives have turned all their forensic powers on Hillary Rodham Clintons so-called crying moment  the moment in a New Hampshire cafe when her eyes welled with tears in response to some innocuous personal questions from an audience member: How do you do it?, How do you keep upbeat and so wonderful? That moment is credited with helping Mrs. Clinton stage a remarkable comeback in the New Hampshire primary, with galvanizing the sympathy of female voters and with revealing the candidates human side.

title: Nets Are Overwhelmed by the Retooled Blazers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Portland traded Zach Randolph, Dan Dickau and Fred Jones to the Knicks last June, it seemed the Trail Blazers had given up a lot while getting little in return. Randolph, the centerpiece of the trade, was coming off a season in which he averaged 23.6 points and 10.1 rebounds. From the Knicks, Portland received the role player Channing Frye and the slumping Steve Francis, who was waived a few weeks later.

title: Campaign Issues May Fade, but Souvenirs Endure
description: Americans routinely used to wear their political hearts on their sleeves  or at least on their lapels. George Washington proudly displayed his own on his chest when he was inaugurated as the nations first president, where Federal Hall now stands in Lower Manhattan.

title: In Europe, Microsoft Again Faces Inquiries
description: BRUSSELS  After the briefest of truces, Europes antitrust regulator resumed its battle with Microsoft on Monday, opening two new investigations into claims that the company has abused its dominant position to squeeze competitors out of the market.

title: 55-Million-Year-Old Trail Yields Identity of Amber Producer
description: A piece of amber can tell a story, of some unfortunate insect trapped by oozing tree resin millions of years ago. But the tale is often incomplete. It might be easy to identify the insect, but determining what kind of tree produced the resin is another matter.

title: U.S. Plans Sale of 900 Missiles to Saudi Arabia
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The Bush administration said it would sell 900 sophisticated satellite-guided missiles to Saudi Arabia as part of a $20 billion arms sale intended to bolster military relations with Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states and counter the rising influence of Iran.

title: U.S. to Speed Deportation of Criminals in Jail
description: Federal authorities expect to identify and deport more than 200,000 immigrants who are convicted criminals serving time in prisons and jails across the country, the countrys top federal immigration enforcement official said Monday.

title: Sightless Parent Fish Dont Produce Just Sightless Hybrids
description: In a deep cave in northeastern Mexico, there is a population of fish, Astyanax mexicanus, that through the course of evolution has lost its sight. In other caves not far away, there are more populations of the same species, also blind.

title: Masback Looks Back on Career
description: Craig Masbacks achievements include a degree from Princeton, a fellowship at Oxford, a senior associate position for a law firm, ownership of a sports marketing company and an analysts job for televised track and field meets. For the last 10 years, he has been the chief executive officer of USA Track and Field, helping the sport regain some of its luster.

title: Film School Meets Assisted Living, With Understanding for All
description: Tammy Signorile, a sharp-witted 95-year-old with a klaxon voice that seldom rests, is one of the stars of the documentary Andrew Jenks, Room 335. Late in the film, in a rare moment of sentiment, she offers a philosophy of life: It doesnt take much to make somebody feel good. Say something nice to them, tell them how nice they are instead of looking for defects, instead of looking for something theyre not doing right.

title: Pulp Fiction Writer Arrested After Collision
description: Roger Avary, who won an Academy Award as the co-writer of Pulp Fiction with Quentin Tarantino, was arrested on suspicion of manslaughter and driving under the influence after a single-car collision that injured his wife and killed a man on Sunday in Ojai, Calif., The Associated Press reported. The dead man was identified as Andreas Zini, 34, believed to be a visitor from Italy. Mr. Avarys wife, Gretchen, 40, was ejected from the car and hospitalized in stable condition. Mr. Avary, 42, who was also a co-writer of Beowulf, was released on $50,000 bail.

title: Malawi Cuts Diplomatic Ties With Taiwan
description: JOHANNESBURG  Malawi cut its diplomatic ties with Taiwan, the government announced on Monday, drawing a bitter response from Taiwanese officials who accused the Chinese government of luring the Malawians into its camp with $6 billion in aid and other inducements.

title: Trenton: Former Commerce Official Sentenced
description: A former top state commerce official was sentenced in State Superior Court on Monday to six and a half years in prison for public corruption. The official, Lesly Devereaux, left, former chief of staff to the Commerce, Economic Growth and Tourism Commission, was convicted in July of official misconduct and pleaded guilty in October to welfare and public records tampering charges. Ms. Devereaux, 49, of Piscataway, admitted creating fake documents to mask her role in steering $11,000 in state contracts to her mother and sister. Her lawyer, Jack Furlong, said she would be eligible for a tightly controlled parole program after six months.

title: Much Hype in Players Treatment, Doctors Say
description: For all the images of athletes running and jumping in 2007, the sight of Kevin Everett merely walking was one of the most newsworthy.

title: Philippines: Decline in Killings
description: The number of extrajudicial killings of activists and journalists in the Philippines dropped sharply in 2007 compared with the previous year, according to an Interior Department study released Sunday. The study said the Philippine National Police listed only 7 such killings last year, compared with 41 in 2006. Human Rights Watch, a New York-based group, welcomed the drop in killings but challenged the government of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo to prosecute the killers. The group has accused the government of carrying out a dirty war against leftists and journalists.

title: In Search of Answers
description: The Iraqi Parliament has finally done something that the Bush administration, and many others, considered essential to political progress in Iraq: it passed a law intended to open government jobs to former members of Saddam Husseins Baath Party. What should have been heralded as an accomplishment, however, may only serve to further reinforce the bumbling nature of President Bushs ill-conceived adventure in Iraq.

title: Politics and Misogyny
description: With Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons win in New Hampshire, gender issues are suddenly in the news. Where has everybody been?

title: Obamas Wife Evokes Dangers of Campaign
description: ATLANTA  When Michelle Obama addressed an audience of African-American political and entertainment heavyweights here on Sunday, she obliquely addressed fears that her husbands presidential run might put him in danger.

title: Aviation Safety Surveys
description: To the Editor:

title: Englewood: Arrests in Park Killing
description: A security guard and his companion have been arrested in the shooting death of the companions estranged husband in a public park, the Bergen County prosecutors office said on Monday. Horrified onlookers fled Mackay Park shortly after 4 p.m. Sunday after the husband, Severino Cepeda, 45, was shot several times. The police arrested the security guard, Livio Antonio Morales, 46, as well as Mr. Cepedas estranged wife, Patricia Pichardo, 38, who prosecutors say has been living with Mr. Morales in Englewood. Mr. Morales, a security guard for the Supreme Oil Company in Englewood, has been charged with murder and weapons offenses. Ms. Pichardo is charged with hindering apprehension and obstructing an investigation. The two were being held on Monday, with bail set at $2 million for Mr. Morales and $50,000 for Ms. Pichardo.

title: Russia: Gazprom Skyscraper Denounced
description: St. Petersburg residents spoke out against the planned construction of a 1,050-foot-tall skyscraper for the headquarters of the state energy company Gazprom at a public hearing. About 600 residents and activists confronted officials who defended proposed changes in city zoning laws to allow for the building to go up. St. Petersburg is no village and its skyline is an object of world admiration, said Tatyana Krasavina, head of a group fighting the project. Present regulations limit the height of buildings to 157 feet.

title: A Stable Life, Despite Persistent Dizziness
description: On the subway, children twirl themselves around the poles in the cars until they are so dizzy Im ready to catch them. The young seem to delight in making the world spin out of control for a few moments, causing them to flop about like drunks.

title: Intels Big Quarter Fails to Meet Wall St. Forecast
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel reported record fourth-quarter revenue on Tuesday, but the chip makers shares dropped sharply after hours as its earnings and its first-quarter projections disappointed analysts.

title: St. Ann's Warehouse Thinks Very Big
description: St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn has announced its 2008 season, and one of the shows is so big that St. Anns has to set up another theater. In June, TR Warszawa, a Polish theater company under the direction of Grzegorz Jarzyna, will stage a huge, multimedia production of Macbeth, for which St. Anns is creating an outdoor performance space out of the pre-Civil War era tobacco warehouse across the street. St. Anns will also be host to the Druid Theatre Company of Galway, Ireland, known in New York for its productions of DruidSynge and The Beauty Queen of Leenane, which will present a new play, The Walworth Farce, by the Irish writer Enda Walsh. It won the Fringe First Award at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in 2007.

title: Europe May Ban Imports of Some Biofuel Crops
description: PARIS  In a sign of growing concern about the impact of supposedly green policies, European Union officials will propose a ban on imports of certain biofuels, according to a draft law to be unveiled next week.

title: So It Looks Cold on Camera? Try Operating One
description: On Jan. 10, 1982, Cris Collinsworth, then a rookie wide receiver, awakened to a report on his hotel clock radio that the temperature outside was 13 degrees below zero and that the howling 35-mile-an-hour wind made it feel like 59 below.

title: Supreme Court Restricts Securities Lawsuits
description: WASHINGTON  Ruling in its most important securities fraud case in years, the Supreme Court on Tuesday placed a towering obstacle in the path of shareholders looking for someone to sue when a stock purchase turns sour.

title: The Identity Trap
description: Correction appended.

title: Treating Sinus Infections (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Reveals Doubt on Drug for Cholesterol
description: A clinical trial of a widely used cholesterol drug has raised questions both about the medicines effectiveness and about the behavior of the pharmaceutical companies that conducted the study, cardiologists said Monday.

title: A Hereditary Perk the Founding Fathers Failed to Anticipate
description: Legacy preferences in college admissions  the nepotistic advantages given to the children of alumni  are indefensible, of course.

title: Standing on Two Feet (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Sales Help I.B.M. to a Strong Quarter
description: A slowing American economy is not hurting I.B.M. yet.

title: Peer Is Expanding Boundaries Outside the Court
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Shahar Peer is in Melbourne competing in the Australian Open but she will soon be in a much more unusual place for an Israeli tennis player: Doha, Qatar.

title: Trenton: Law Extends Voting Machine Deadline
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a law on Sunday that extends until June 3 the states deadline to create a paper trail for its 10,000 electronic voting machines, the governors office said on Monday. The original Jan. 1 deadline, set by the Legislature in 2005 as part of a law requiring all electronic voting machines to produce paper records, was established so the machines could be retrofitted with printers in time for the states Feb. 5 presidential primary. After it became apparent that the deadline could not be met, state officials pushed back the timetable for the printers to June 3, the date of the Congressional primary. Researchers at the New Jersey Institute of Technology are now testing the printers, said David Wald, a spokesman for the state attorney general.

title: Terminator Tops Globes
description: NBCs bare-bones version of the 65th Annual Golden Globes attracted just 5.8 million viewers on Sunday night, a small fraction of the 20 million who tuned in to the awards show a year ago, according to Nielsens estimates. A two-hour Dateline special, featuring interviews with the nominees and preceding the 9 p.m. announcement show fared no better, drawing only 4.4 million. Combined, the three-hour broadcast delivered a dismal 1.3 rating in the critical demographic of adults 18 to 49, a far cry from the 6.5 rating the show earned over prime time on a Monday last January. The big hit on Sunday was Foxs premiere of Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles, which attracted 18.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. and the highest ratings by far of any new series this season. Although Terminator benefited from following a football game on Fox that attracted more than 35 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour, no other scripted series debut on any broadcast network has done better in the 18-to-49 set in three years. The last scripted series debut on a broadcast network to earn higher ratings among adults 18 to 49 was CBSs Numb3rs on Jan. 23, 2005. Fox easily led the nights ratings, followed by CBS and ABC. NBC ranked fourth. Part one of CBSs Comanche Moon drew 15.8 million viewers.

title: Reflections on Influence While Being Serenaded by Works Past and Present
description: All so-called original art is based on what someone else has done already. An apt subtitle for a lot of 20th-century painting is Picasso Looking at Ingres, and how much late-18th-century music could be called Mozart Listening to Bach?

title: Case on Police Searches Pits State Laws Against Federal
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Courts long-running debate over the meaning of federalism took a new turn in a case the justices heard on Monday.

title: Sears Warns of Another Steep Drop in Profit
description: Evidence of an abrupt slowdown in consumer spending mounted Monday as Sears Holdings, the owner of Sears and Kmart, warned that its profit would most likely plunge as much as 57 percent for the three months ending in early February.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $6,563,171

title: Disparities: Rural Residents Less Likely to Get Organ Transplants
description: Add patients living in small towns and rural areas to the list of people who stand a lower chance of getting an organ transplant if they need one.

title: Florida: Charges Dropped, and a New Suspect Is Arrested
description: A man accused of killing a Miami police detective was arrested after prosecutors dropped attempted murder charges against another man. Andrew J. Rolle, 20, was taken into custody at the Miami police station and later taken to the North Miami Beach Police Department, a police spokesman said. Mr. Rolle, left, was named by North Miami Beach officials as the new suspect in the Jan. 8 slaying of James Walker of the Miami Police Department, who was shot with an assault weapon. Mr. Rolle had been arrested Jan. 5 on misdemeanor loitering and prowling charges but was released on $500 bail, jail officials said. Chief Rafael Hernandez of the North Miami police would not divulge details about how Mr. Rolle was identified as the gunman other than to say technology helped.

title: Monkeys Thoughts Propel Robot, a Step That May Help Humans
description: If Idoya could talk, she would have plenty to boast about.

title: Turning Our Attention Back to Iraq ...
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese and U.S. Demand Drives Commodities Surge
description: The price of copper has tripled in five years. Zinc has doubled. Wheat and soybeans rose 70 percent in 2007. Futures prices of crude oil, gold, silver, lead, uranium, cattle, cocoa and corn are all at or near records.

title: British-Russian Tension Escalates
description: MOSCOW  A British cultural organization on Monday defied a Russian government order to close offices in two cities, creating a fresh strain in the already tense relations between Russia and Britain.

title: Marburys Injury an Opportunity for a Timeout
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Stephon Marbury did not practice Monday because of what the team initially described as a sore left ankle. Marbury said he thought the problem was related to bone spurs, which have plagued him throughout his career. He even raised the possibility of having surgery in the near future.

title: Its Drivers vs. Meter Readers, and Guess Who Wins
description: Once you discount crime, poverty, ailing school systems and public corruption, parking is the real scourge of urban life. Or at least that is what the producers of A&Es new reality series, Parking Wars (broadcast on Tuesday nights), seem to believe. This is a show about stationary road rage, the anger that engulfs certain drivers when they are ticketed and towed, circumstances they could easily have avoided if, apparently, they werent such arrogant, entitled jerks.

title: Decision on Football Playoff Is Delayed
description: NASHVILLE  Top university administrators delayed a decision on whether to start a playoff system for major college football at the National Collegiate Athletic Associations annual convention Monday. They agreed to ask college presidents to weigh in on the topic but did not set a timeline for a decision.

title: Living in Fear and Paying a High Cost in Heart Risk
description: Which is more of a threat to your health: Al Qaeda or the Department of Homeland Security?

title: Open a New Window: A Tower With a View
description: The only thing standing between the occupants of 375 Pearl Street and some of the most commanding views in Lower Manhattan is three inches of limestone.

title: And the Nominees Should Be . . .
description: The ideal slate of Oscar candidates, as chosen by the three critics of The New York Times.

title: Yankees Expect to Open Camp Without Santana
description: Phil Hughes has been working out at the Yankees complex in Tampa, Fla., lately, and Johan Santana has been doing the same at the Minnesota Twins facility in Fort Myers. They will most likely be in the same place when spring training starts in four weeks.

title: Heavy Orders for Airbus and Boeing Raise Backlog Questions
description: PARIS  The chief salesman for Airbus, John Leahy, ended one of the busiest years of his career with a quiet evening at home.

title: Member of U.S. Chess Federations Board Is Asked to Resign in Dispute Over an Election
description: A majority on the executive board of the United States Chess Federation plans to formally ask a member to resign amid allegations that he had posted messages under other peoples names to Internet bulletin boards to get elected to the board.

title: Judge and U.S.-Linked Sunni Fighters Are Killed in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Gunmen in two cars assassinated a respected and high-ranking Iraqi appellate court judge and his driver in western Baghdad on Monday morning, Iraqi officials said. Hours later, in Diyala Province, three American-backed Iraqi militiamen died after they entered a building that blew up and collapsed on them, the Iraqi police said.

title: Bush and the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Steps to Lift Roadblock to Clemens Deposition
description: WASHINGTON  The lawyer for Roger Clemens and the staff for the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform had discussions here Monday that made it more likely Clemens would give a sworn deposition and agree to provide a tape of an interview with his accuser without the panels having to resort to subpoenas, a key staff member said.

title: Shake-Up at EMI Clouds Future of Its Artists
description: LONDON  Terra Firma, the private equity firm that recently acquired EMI Group, on Tuesday announced a major restructuring of the music company, saying it would eliminate close to a third of the staff, as it seeks to streamline operations and focus on the discovery of new artists.

title: Justices Wont Hear Appeal on Drugs for Terminally Ill
description: WASHINGTON  A legal battle ended at the Supreme Court on Monday over whether terminally ill patients who have run out of medical options have a constitutional right to try experimental drugs that have not yet received federal approval.

title: Transit Worker Fought Back Before, Wounding a Man
description: The city transit worker at the center of last weeks bloody melee on a Harlem street fought off a gunman who tried to rob him in Queens 14 years ago, a struggle that left the attacker shot and wounded, officials said on Monday.

title: Quiet Star Now Advocates for Union
description: For 12 seasons in Major League Soccer, Eddie Pope represented himself with quiet distinction and class on the soccer field. Now Pope, a defender who retired after the 2007 season, will further the interests of his former compatriots as the director of player relations for the union that represents M.L.S. players.

title: As Talk of Recession Grows, Republicans and Democrats Differ on Response
description: WASHINGTON  For Democratic presidential contenders, the growing risk of a recession is an opportunity for action. For Republican contenders, accustomed to calling for less government intervention, it presents a dilemma.

title: An Island and Its Ice Cap (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Fare Increases, Crowded Planes, and More Delays
description: BIG FARE INCREASES After United Airlines raised domestic fares across the board by $50 a round trip on Friday, most major carriers quickly followed with similar increases on many routes, according to FareCompare.com. The reason was sharply higher fuel costs. Delta Air Lines raised its round-trip fares by $50 immediately after Uniteds move. American Airlines also posted $50 round-trip increases on 55 percent of its route system, though "conspicuously absent" are increases on its routes that overlap with many Southwest Airlines routes, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Then on Monday, Northwest Airlines also joined in the $50 increase on most of its routes. Continental Airlines, which initially raised fares by $50 on some routes on Friday, withdrew the increases Monday morning, but Mr. Seaney said it was unclear whether Continental might reverse course again soon. This was the second broad fare increase in 2008, and the 10th since last Labor Day, Mr. Seaney said, adding: "It seems the legacy airlines, United in particular, are forgoing the nickel-and-dime strategy of increases every few weeks and are going for the whole enchilada at one time."

title: Europes Appetite for Seafood Propels Illegal Trade
description: LONDON  Walking at the Brixton market among the parrotfish, doctorfish and butterfish, Effa Edusie is surrounded by pieces of her childhood in Ghana. Caught the day before far off the coast of West Africa, they have been airfreighted to London for dinner.

title: Cowboys Struggles in December Foretold a Playoff Flop
description: IRVING, Tex.  On the turf at Texas Stadium in late November, the Cowboys dismantled the Green Bay Packers to take control of the National Football Conference.

title: Producer Signs Deal With Writers
description: Media Rights Capital, an independent production company that helped finance the film Babel, signed an agreement that will let striking Hollywood writers work on its projects.

title: On Sex After Prostate Surgery, Confusing Data
description: For men having prostate cancer surgery, one of the biggest fears is that they will be left impotent. Unfortunately, the research that might help address that question is likely only to confuse.

title: The Battle Against Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel to Study Algeria Blasts
description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon is appointing an independent panel to investigate the car bombing of two United Nations buildings in Algiers last month attributed to a group linked to Al Qaeda that killed 17 staff members and at least 30 other people, the organization announced. The panel is also expected to recommend steps to tighten security at United Nations offices worldwide.

title: Recent Entries From Our Blogs
description: Dot Earth

title: Construction Worker Dies in 42-Story Fall in SoHo
description: A construction worker who was pouring concrete at a condominium hotel in SoHo fell 42 floors to his death on Monday when a wooden mold used to set the concrete collapsed, the authorities said.

title: Woman Released by Guerrillas Returns to Colombia to Greet Son
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Freed by Colombian guerrillas last week after six years of captivity in jungle camps, Clara Rojas returned to Colombia on Sunday, where she embraced and played with her 3-year-old son, Emmanuel, who had been taken from her when he was 8 months old.

title: Stocks Plunge on Economic News and Bank Woes
description: Stocks fell sharply on Tuesday after Citigroup announced a $9.8 billion quarterly loss and an economic report showed retail sales fell in December.

title: 1,500 Job Cuts Expected at EMI
description: LONDON  Terra Firma, the private equity firm that recently acquired the music company EMI Group, plans to announce a reorganization Tuesday, including the elimination of close to a third of EMIs staff, according to people briefed on the plans.

title: Some Treasures Found Over Harburgs Rainbow
description: Words make you think a thought. Music makes you feel a feeling. A song makes you feel a thought.

title: Apple Unveils Movie Rentals and Thin Notebook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple on Tuesday introduced a movie rental service and an ultralight Mac notebook that could set a new industry standard for thinness.

title: Nonprofit Punishes a 2nd Founder for Ruse
description: The board of GiveWell, a new nonprofit research organization that seeks to assess the effectiveness of charities, has disciplined the second of its two founders for promoting the organization by posing on the Internet as someone else.

title: Waterfalls for New York Citys Waterfront
description: Four man-made waterfalls, 90 to 120 feet high, will punctuate New Yorks waterfront for three months starting in mid-July. The creation of the Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson, the project is a collaboration between the city and the Public Art Fund, the nonprofit organization that presents art around the city. The waterfalls (above, in a rendering) have been designed to be environmentally friendly and will be in New York Harbor at Pier 35 in Lower Manhattan, at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge and between Piers 4 and 5 in Brooklyn and at Governors Island. Money for the project, estimated to cost about $15 million, comes entirely from private funds, and the Economic Development Corporation estimates that the waterfalls will bring more than $50 million to the citys economy. Throughout history we have always taken water for granted, said Mr. Eliasson in a telephone interview from his Berlin studio. Now people can engage in the physical nature of something as epic as a waterfall.

title: Big Brain Theory: Have Cosmologists Lost Theirs?
description: It could be the weirdest and most embarrassing prediction in the history of cosmology, if not science.

title: Indonesia Watches as an Ailing Suharto Clings to Life
description: SOLO, Indonesia  The tomb is ready, in a mausoleum at the peak of a small mountain here in central Java, surrounded by shimmering green rice terraces, not far from a sacred retreat where former President Suharto had often come to meditate.

title: Bedside Manner (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Star Power
description: Q. The Sun is a big ball of hydrogen, the lightest element. Why doesnt it have a core of heavier elements that sank to the center?

title: Romney Beats McCain in Michigan Vote
description: LANSING, Mich.  Mitt Romney, seizing on his personal ties to a state where his father made his familys political fortune, captured a must-win victory in the Michigan primary on Tuesday, claiming the first major trophy for his ailing campaign and throwing the wide-open Republican field into further disarray.

title: Hoboken: No Indictment of Police Officials
description: Edward J. De Fazio, the Hudson County prosecutor, said on Monday that he would not seek indictments of Hobokens police chief and a lieutenant accused of forcing subordinates to perform work at their homes on police time. The Jersey Journal reported that Mr. De Fazio said there was not enough evidence to indict the chief, Carmen LaBruno, and the lieutenant, Angelo Andriani, who headed a SWAT unit, but there were clearly administrative issues that should be addressed. Lieutenant Andriani was sued in October by five officers who said he coerced four of them to work on his house when they should have been on duty. Lieutenant Andriani has denied the allegations. The SWAT unit was disbanded in November after racy pictures emerged from a trip to the New Orleans area to help Hurricane Katrina victims.

title: Baltimore Finds Subprime Crisis Snags Women
description: BALTIMORE  At Vixxen Hair Salon, the main topic of conversation has always been money. But since last August, Anjanette Booker, the owner, has noticed a new focus. Now its money and foreclosures, Miss Booker said.

title: In California, a Sheriff Quits to Work on Legal Defense
description: LOS ANGELES  Sheriff Michael S. Carona of Orange County resigned Monday to focus on his legal defense against federal charges that he traded his office for hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of cash and lavish gifts.

title: At Open, an Aggressive Stance on Gambling
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  With this tennis season now in full swing on the new, blue courts at the Australian Open, last seasons troubles are still in plain view.

title: Praise and Questions for $400 Million Housing Plan
description: In what he called the biggest housing initiative in a generation, Gov. Eliot Spitzer said in his State of the State address on Wednesday that he would propose a $400 million affordable housing fund to help working-class New Yorkers, the poor and people with special needs.

title: Teammates From Long Island to Montreal
description: When Mike Komisarek and Christopher Higgins come home to Long Island, they revel in their anonymity. They play hockey in the hotbed that is Montreal, where they cannot walk a block without someone asking for an autograph or a picture, where they would not dream of going out poorly dressed.

title: Selling Wine Where the Surfs Up
description: TUSCANY is best known for its cypress trees, Florence, the Leaning Tower of Pisa, and of course, vino. But few people know that Tuscany has a great surfing scene. Many even consider the western coast of Tuscany to be the California of the Mediterranean.

title: Ruling Halts Amputee Sprinters Olympic Bid
description: Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee sprinter from South Africa, will not be eligible to pursue his dream of qualifying for the Olympics, according to a ruling Monday by track and fields world governing body.

title: Six Workers Will Be Fired, Mayor Says
description: At least six child welfare workers will be fired for failing to properly address complaints about a womans care for her four daughters, who were later found dead in their home, Mayor Adrian M. Fenty said. The bodies of the girls, ages 5, 6, 11 and 17, were found Wednesday. Their mother, Banita M. Jacks, is charged with murder. A social worker at the oldest girls school tried twice in April to get city agencies to investigate. The employees being fired work for the Child and Family Services Agency and include a division director. More workers could lose their jobs as an investigation continues, Mr. Fenty said.

title: Mississippi: Election Date Is Thrown Out
description: A judge has rejected the date of a special election set by the governor to replace former Senator Trent Lott. Judge Bobby DeLaughter of Hinds County Circuit Court ruled that Gov. Haley Barbour, a Republican, erred when he set the special election for Nov. 4. State law says that after receiving notice of a Senate vacancy, the governor must schedule an election within 90 days if the vacancy announcement does not fall in the same year as a state or Congressional general election. Mr. Lott retired Dec. 18, after Novembers general election.

title: Militants Escape Control of Pakistan, Officials Say
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans premier military intelligence agency has lost control of some of the networks of Pakistani militants it has nurtured since the 1980s, and is now suffering the violent blowback of that policy, two former senior intelligence officials and other officials close to the agency say.

title: A Supreme Court Reversal: Abandoning the Rights of Voters
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments last week in a hugely important case about voter ID laws. Asking for identification at the polls may sound reasonable, but an Indiana law disenfranchises large numbers of people without drivers licenses, especially poor and minority voters. If the court upholds the law, as appears likely, it will be a sad new chapter in its abandonment of voters, a group whose rights it once defended vigorously.

title: Genetic Study Bolsters Columbus Link to Syphilis
description: Columbus, it seems, made another discovery of something that he was not looking for.

title: A Loan to Finish Homes
description: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones/AP)  The home builder Levitt & Sons received approval on Monday to tap a $3.5 million loan to finish building homes across the Southeast.

title: With 07 Vetoes to Confront, the House Returns to Work
description: WASHINGTON  Congress opens its 2008 session Tuesday by returning to a crucial bill lingering from 2007, a major Pentagon policy measure that was rejected in a surprise move by President Bush late last year.

title: Giants Forged Their Identity With Clutch Victories
description: The chance to go to the Super Bowl in the Arizona desert will rest on the outcome of a game that is expected to be played in single-digit temperatures in Green Bay.

title: Citigroup Loses $9.8 Billion; Will Cut Jobs
description: Citigroup announced a steep cut in its stock dividend and another big investment by foreign investors on Tuesday after taking more write-downs related to subprime securities and posting a $9.83 billion loss for the fourth quarter.

title: Bomb in Pakistan Market Kills 10 and Wounds 45
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A powerful bomb hidden underneath a fruit cart detonated among shoppers at a market in the southern port city of Karachi on Monday evening at rush hour, and officials and local news reports said it killed at least 10 people and wounded at least 45, four of them critically.

title: New Bacteria Strain Is Striking Gay Men
description: A new, highly drug-resistant strain of the flesh-eating MRSA bacteria is being spread among gay men in San Francisco and Boston, researchers reported on Monday.

title: Minister Sees Need for U.S. Help in Iraq Until 2018
description: FORT MONROE, Va.  The Iraqi defense minister said Monday that his nation would not be able to take full responsibility for its internal security until 2012, nor be able on its own to defend Iraqs borders from external threat until at least 2018.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about Maurice Parks, a New York City transit worker who the police believe fatally stabbed a man while fending off a group of attackers in Harlem, and about Flonarza M. Byas, the victim, included incorrect information from a law enforcement official and a state senator about a 1994 attack on Mr. Parks in Queens. Mr. Parks shot his assailant in self-defense but did not kill him. An updated account can be read here. (Go to Article)

title: Quadrangle to Manage Bloomberg Fund
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg disclosed Tuesday that he has chosen the firm of a longtime friend, Steven Rattner, an investment banker who moves among New Yorks power elite, to manage the investments of his billion-dollar fortune.

title: The Claim: Fetal Heart Rate Can Predict the Babys Sex
description: THE FACTS

title: Barenboim Accepts Palestinian Citizenship
description: The Argentine-born Israeli pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim has accepted Palestinian citizenship and an honorary Palestinian passport, Agence France-Presse reported. I hope that my new status will be an example of Israeli-Palestinian coexistence, he said after a concert in the West Bank town of Ramallah on Saturday. Among other posts, including Maestro Scaligero, a sort of principal guest conductor, at La Scala Opera in Milan, Mr. Barenboim is the founding director of the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, based in Seville, Spain, which mingles Israeli (Jewish and Palestinian) and Arab youths.

title: Collecting the Trash: Its Science and Value
description: The city employees who sweep your streets and collect your garbage? You know them as sanitation workers. But think of them also as folk sociologists, Robin Nagle says. Shes serious.

title: South Korea Proposes Meeting With North
description: SEOUL  In a surprise initiative, the conservative president-elect of South Korea, Lee Myung-bak, said Monday that he would meet with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, anytime if a meeting could help persuade Mr. Kim to abandon his nuclear weapons programs.

title: Driving Mr. Romney
description: Belmont, Mass.

title: Michigan at Center Stage in G.O.P. Race
description: DETROIT  With the plight of the ailing automobile industry at the top of the agenda, the leading Republican presidential candidates set off Monday on a final flurry of campaigning before a Michigan primary that could shake up anew a remarkably fluid field.

title: Planes Leaving Gates Collide at San Francisco Airport
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Two planes collided Sunday night at San Francisco International Airport as they were pushed away from adjacent gates, and federal investigators were studying evidence on Monday to try to determine why it happened.

title: Caroline K. Keck, Art Conservator, Dies at 99
description: Caroline K. Keck, a pioneer of art conservation, died on Dec. 17 at her home in Cooperstown, N.Y. She was 99.

title: Mayor Gave Away More Money in 07
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg increased his charitable giving by nearly 25 percent in 2007, donating $205 million to 1,100 organizations, according to his latest filing.

title: In Heart of Islamic World, Bush Puts Forth His Faith
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  President Bushs Christianity is so central to his life that it is not surprising that it would figure prominently in a visit to Israel and the Palestinian territories.

title: Off Yemen, a Storied Stand Is Vulnerable
description: SOCOTRA, Yemen  I feel as though Im walking through a cemetery, said Paul Scholte, an environmental scientist who is the chief officer for the United Nations Development Program on this arid, windswept island, 200 miles off Yemen.

title: Spain Dissolves Parliament and Schedules March 9 Elections
description: MADRID  The Spanish government on Monday dissolved Parliament and called general elections for March 9, officially opening what promises to be a close race between the governing Socialists and the opposition Popular Party.

title: Regulatory Games and the Polar Bear
description: Although Congress and the courts have largely frustrated the Bush administrations efforts to open up Alaska to oil and gas drilling, Vice President Dick Cheney and his industry friends remain determined to lock up as many oil and gas leases as they can before the door hits them on the way out. They are certainly not going to let the struggling polar bear stand in their way.

title: Samsung Chairmans Office Raided in Inquiry
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Special prosecutors investigating the Samsung Group raided the office of its chairman, Lee Kun-hee, and the homes of his aides on Monday, a unusual move in a country both proud and suspicious of family-run conglomerates.

title: House Asks Justice Dept. to Investigate Tejada
description: WASHINGTON  The House Oversight committee has asked the Department of Justice to investigate the possibility that Miguel Tejada, the 31-year-old star shortstop for the Houston Astros, made material false statements in interviews with Congressional investigators, the chairman of the committee said Tuesday at the opening of a hearing on performance enhancing drugs in baseball.

title: For the Laptop Toters, a Roomier Flight to Europe
description: BRITISH AIRWAYS announced its plans last week to join the new boutique premium-class airline game across the Atlantic. But it isnt bringing a lot of money to the table.

title: Former Times Editor in New Post at Magazine
description: Howell Raines, who lost the top newsroom job at The New York Times in 2003 amid public rancor and scandal, will become a media columnist  covering, among others, The Times  at Cond Nast Portfolio, the magazine announced Monday.

title: Bank of America Curbs Investment Banking
description: Bank of America said Tuesday that it was scaling back its investment banking operations, shedding an additional 650 jobs after suffering heavy trading losses from bad mortgage investments.

title: Indias $2,500 Car
description: To the Editor:

title: Working-Class Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Spacecraft Gets a Peek at Mercury
description: WASHINGTON  The Messenger spacecraft dashed past Mercury on Monday, getting a glance at the solar systems innermost planet, which it will eventually orbit for detailed studies.

title: Shell of New Species of Land Snail Coils Its Own Way
description: It looks like the plumbing on a rocket engine, or perhaps an alpenhorn gone wild. But the oddly coiled tube pictured here (at great magnification) is actually the shell of a land snail.

title: Faulty Design Led to Minnesota Bridge Collapse, Inquiry Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Investigators said Monday that the Interstate 35W bridge in Minneapolis, which collapsed into the Mississippi River on Aug. 1, killing 13, came down because of a flaw in its design.

title: Roosevelt Island Tram
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Queens: Body Found at Subway Station
description: A mans body was found beneath a stairway at a subway station in Edgemere on Monday morning, the police said. The body, which appeared to be that of a Hispanic man in his 30s, was found about 8:30 a.m. at the A train station at Beach 44th Street and Rockaway Freeway, the police said. A police spokeswoman said she did not know the circumstances under which the body was discovered. The police said the city medical examiner would determine the cause of death.

title: Hazards: Needing the First Aid They Give to Others
description: Paramedic, heal thyself.

title: Many Voices Chime In on Spains Anthem Lyrics
description: MADRID  After decades of humming along to the national anthem or bellowing ta ta ta from soccer stands, Spaniards finally have the missing ingredient: words.

title: Meditations Conjure Incense, Stained Glass and Devotion
description: The 100th anniversary of the French composer Olivier Messiaens birth doesnt arrive until December, but centenary celebrations have already begun. Numerous prominent performances of this vastly influential avant-gardists orchestral, chamber and instrumental works lie ahead. While it may seem rash to make the claim so soon, a survey of Messiaens organ music performed by Gail Archer is sure to be among the years highlights, to judge by the initial installment on Sunday afternoon.

title: Bjork Accused of Attack
description: The Icelandic pop singer and songwriter Bjork was accused of attacking a news photographer, ripping his sweatshirt in half after he ignored a request not to take any pictures on her arrival on Sunday at Auckland International Airport in New Zealand, The New Zealand Herald reported. Glenn Jeffrey, above, a photographer for the newspaper, said Bjork was accompanied by a man who asked him not to take pictures. I took a couple of pictures and I got about three or four frames of her, Mr. Jeffrey said, and as I turned and walked away, she came up behind me, grabbed the back of my black skivvy and tore it down the back. As she did this, she fell over. She fell to the ground. At no stage did I touch her or speak with her.

title: Blast at Kabul Hotel Kills 6

title: How The New York Times Counts Delegates
description: Updated | April 9, 2008 State political parties choose different means of selecting their delegates  either a primary or a caucus. A primary is completed in one day and is often binding, while a caucus is the first step and is generally a multitiered process that culminates with the selection of delegates. This year, a number of states have been penalized and docked a portion of their delegates because they scheduled their nominating contests too early.

title: '30 Ways of Looking at Hillary'
description: In an episode of "The Simpsons" from a few years ago, Bart gets a glimpse thirty years into the future and sees that his sister Lisa has been elected president. The show doesn't make a lot of fuss over the notion of a woman commander in chief (in fact, in an aside we learn that Lisa is "the first straight woman president.") But it's impossible not to notice that President Simpson looks a lot like Hillary Clinton: her spiky hairdo has been smooshed down into a power-helmet; she wears monochrome pants suits and a string of pearls. She is intelligent and earnest, and she has a problem with authenticity. Bart, who has grown into a middle-aged slacker with a ponytail, ends up playing Bill to Lisa's Hillary; he saves the day by smooth-talking a mob of angry world leaders who have converged on the White House. At one point he says, "I coulda been president, but I'm too real."

title: Thompson and Weiner Ahead in Fund-Raising for Mayoral Race
