description: Via Elizabeth Warren: William F. Buckley discovers the virtues of regulation and calls for government intervention to help fix the mortgage crisis.

title: Theres Something About Sarah (A Huge Marketing Push, For Instance)
description: Fox is already calling Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles this television seasons highest rated new series. The first half of the pilot episode aired on Sunday and drew 18.3 million viewers; part two followed on Monday, with ratings to be announced Tuesday.

title: Open Caucus: A View From Michigan
description: As the primary season unfolds across the country, well be asking our voters in the Open Caucus to weigh in individually from their states.

title: No Nanoparticles Were Killed Making This Post
description: The Soil Association, Britains largest certifier of organic products, issued a press release Tuesday proclaiming itself to be the first organization in the world to ban nanoparticles. On closer inspection, that boiled down to the group saying it would not allow its organic label to be used on any product containing synthetic particles with a mean size of less than 200 nanometers or in which the smallest particles were less than 125 nanometers.

title: Soft Serve | A News Feed of Light Reading
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: NBC Fights to Keep Kucinich Out of Debate
description: Updated | 6:11 p.m. One hour after the Supreme Court hearing was scheduled to conclude and three hours before the debate was expected to begin, the court had yet to announce a decision, leaving it unclear whether Mr. Kucinich would participate in the debate.

title: NBC Fights to Keep Kucinich Out of Debate
description: MSNBC continues to promote tonights Democratic presidential candidate debate, while the cable news networks parent company awaits a ruling from the Nevada Supreme Court that will determine whether the forum may proceed without Dennis Kucinich.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Jan. 15:

title: Why Must the Health Channel Die?
description: The formation of OWN: The Oprah Winfrey Network in 2009 will mean the end of the eight-year-old Discovery Health Channel.

title: Steve Jobs Shows Off Sleek Laptop
description: CNBC interviews Steve Jobs, Apple's C.E.O., on his new laptop, new movie service and what's next for the company.

title: We the Tenants Look Like Cat Haters
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Sandy Speaks on Citis Dividend Cut
description: Citigroups decision to cut its dividend by 41 percent didnt please everyone; ask common stockholders or Richard X. Bove of Punk Ziegel. But one man in particular found the choice hard to swallow: Sanford I. Weill, the architect of the financial supermarket.

title: A Promising Way of Containing Out-of-Control Medical Spending
description: Conventional wisdom holds that health care costs, especially federal spending for Medicare, are driven by aging. Based on that belief, its not illogical to conclude that as the baby boom generation ages, the sheer number of retirees will simply overwhelm the nations ability to pay for all of them.

title: Would-Be Jumper Sues Empire State Building
description: Jeb Corliss, the professional parachute jumper who tried to leap off the Empire State Building on April 27, 2006, released a short video today showing him struggling with plainclothes security guards and police officers on the observation deck.

title: The Week Ahead
description: Alison Smale, of the International Herald Tribune, discusses events in the world this week.

title: The European Challenge to Successful Companies
description: Microsoft, once again, is in the crosshairs of European antitrust regulators, but major American technology companies have to wonder whether this will stop with Microsoft.

title: Goldmans Top Tech/Telecom Banker Retires
description: Matthew LHeureux, who headed technology, media and telecommunications investment banking for Goldman Sachs, has retired, people familiar with the situation told DealBook. Mr. LHeureux, 45, told his colleagues the news in an internal memorandum at the end of last year.

title: Steve Jobs Shows Off Sleek Laptop
description: CNBC interviews Steve Jobs, Apple's C.E.O., on his new laptop, new movie service and what's next for the company.

title: For the Moment | Francesco Vezzoli
description: This weeks guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidals Caligula, starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandellos Right You Are (If You Think You Are), starring  among others  Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his second post of the week he writes about the actress Silvana Mangano. To read all of Francesco Vezzolis prior blog posts, click here.

title: Online Video Reignites Tom Cruise Media Storm
description: The New York Timess review of a recent unauthorized biography was headlined Tom Cruise and His Bully Pulpit, a reference to the actors life as a take-no-prisoners leader of the Church of Scientology.

title: No Return Fire?
description: Or maybe Barack Obama should turn Robert L. Johnson  and by extension, Hillary Clinton  into the Sister Souljah of 2008? Obama needs to turn this around, writes Robert A. George, an editorial writer for The New York Post, at Ragged Thots, his personal blog. George continues:

title: Quadrangle to Manage Bloombergs Wealth
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg disclosed Tuesday that he has chosen the firm headed by his long-time friend, Steven Rattner, a financier who moves among New Yorks power elite, to manage the investments of his billion dollar fortune.

title: The Wonders of Sticky Snow
description: This planets extraordinary climate  equable and potent, dramatic and sublime  produces a remarkable number of magical moments. Id like to share one with you, on video at least. I live up on a range of hills paralleling the Hudson River about 50 miles north of Manhattan, at an elevation about 800 feet above sea level. This is just high enough to turn what is a January rain nearby into sticky fluffy snow. As the first potent noreaster of January rolled up the East Coast Sunday night and Monday, just enough snow fell, of just the perfect light-but-sticky consistency, to cloak a patch of woods near our house with cold cotton.

title: Congress Takes Second Swing at Steroids in Baseball
description: 2:15 | Wrapping Up The hearing ended rather abruptly but rather predictably  with the chairman, Henry A. Waxman, praising the three witnesses (George Mitchell, Bud Selig and Donald Fehr) for their participation and general candor, while also encouraging them to be vigilant in pursuing a stronger anti-drug program in baseball.

title: Just Browsing | Ripped From the Fashion Rags
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: Another Media Exec Leaves Yahoo
description: As Yahoo narrows its focus on a few key priorities, its not surprising to see those whose projects fall outside those areas leave the company. And Yahoos media group, whose once lofty mission to produce original, Hollywood-style content has been scaled back significantly over the past year or so, has seen its share of departures.

title: Barolo Fest
description: Ive got Barolo on the mind. How can I not, as I had the privilege of drinking 15 or 16 (there is some dispute) other-worldly bottles at a dinner this past weekend, along with two Champagnes, a Barbaresco, a barbera and a Taurasi. Ive recounted the essentials of this dinner in my column for Wednesdays newspaper, but mere newsprint cannot contain me.

title: George of the Jungle, Clip 1
description: The Cartoon Network renews the 1960s animated series, where  the main character is warned to "watch out for that tree."

title: George of the Jungle, Clip 2
description: The Cartoon Network renews the 1960s animated series, where  the main character is warned to "watch out for that tree."

title: Here Come the Devils
description: Detroit and Ottawa have dominated the NHL this season, but now a third team are poised to join the ruling junta. Right now New Jersey have a pretty good 20-15 record in regulation and a 6-3 record in overtime and shootouts  but heres the thing: they compiled those marks by playing 26 of their first 44 games on the road.

title: Video Podcasts: The Sleeping Giant on AppleTV
description: While Steve Jobs talked for a long time Tuesday at Macworld Expo about the movie rental feature of iTunes and Apple TV, he spent only a short time demonstrating its capabilities for podcasts. In fact, the ability of Apple TV to view podcasts may in the long run be its most important feature.

title: Detente, But Only for Some
description: On the same day that Gil Cates, the producer of the Academy Awards telecast, said in no uncertain terms that the Oscars will go on regardless of what happens with the writers strike, Patric Verrone of the Writers Guild America West said in equally certain terms that there will be no such thing if the strike is still in progress on Feb. 24.

title: Republican Is New City Elections Director
description: Marcus Cederqvist, the executive director for the New York Republican Party in Manhattan, was selected this afternoon as the new executive director of the New York City Board of Elections. Mr. Cederqvist, 38, replaces John A. Ravitz, who stepped down in October to accept a position as chief executive of the American Red Cross in Westchester County. Mr. Ravitz, too, was a Republican, and a former member of the Assembly. The selection of Mr. Cederqvist was done unanimously by the 10-member Board of Elections, which includes two members from each of the five boroughs, a Democrat and a Republican.

title: McCain Campaign Responds to Attack
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The polls had not even closed in Michigan yet when the McCain campaign worked Tuesday evening to repel an attack here in South Carolina, where a brutally negative campaign derailed Senator John McCains candidacy in 2000.

title: L.S.U.s Quick Study
description: The national championship game was eight days ago, but it is never too late for a good story.

title: The Short List Short a Few Gems
description: The Academys short list for the best foreign-language film has a few eye-popping omissions, including 4 Months, 3 Weeks, and 2 Days, the flat-out the favorite movie of the year for many critics, and Persepolis, an animated coming of age film that was one of the most, remarkable, head-turning films of the year. Tune in to Hollywood Elsewhere and join in the outrage.

title: A Coffin for Rabies
description: On June 26, 2007, a dog walked into Lupiro, a small village in southern Tanzania. It bit eight people and 11 other dogs before anyone managed to kill it. It had rabies or, as the French call it, la rage.

title: Born Ready
description: Born Ready (Basket Trailer)Uploaded by PeteRock

title: Looking Ahead to Michigan and Beyond
description: John Harwood, of The Times and CNBC, analyzes the state of the Republican and Democratic presidential races ahead of Michigan's primary.

title: Blogtalk: Nevada Caucus Crunch
description: As Nevada bloggers get ready for their states caucuses on Saturday, theyre wondering if the Democrats will touch on two hot topics tonight during their MSNBC debate.

title: McCains Michigan Test
description: Its too early, of course, to know who will win todays primary in Michigan. Whats interesting about this one, though, is the extent to which it would seem to test one of the principal ideas underlying John McCains campaignthat Republicans will respond to difficult truths rather than the distant echoes of an old ideology.

title: The Passion of Steve Jobs
description: Even more than when hes performing on stage, Steven P. Jobss passion for personal computing comes through when he talks about the years he spent cajoling his designers to build what he presented today as the worlds thinnest computer.

title: Last Phase for a Legend
description: When it comes to coverage in high profile magazines and winning awards, Pezula is the Godzilla of high end property projects. So it seems worth noting that the last custom home lots recently went on sale in the oft-publicized development, which covers 612 hectares (1,500 acres) adjacent to a nature reserve on the rugged Southern Cape of South Africa.

title: Whole-Grain Pancakes
description: Mark Bittman, a k a the Minimalist, makes nutritious pancakes delicious.

title: NBC Wins Battle Over Debate
description: The Nevada Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that MSNBC is not required to include candidate Dennis Kucinich in its scheduled Democratic presidential debate.

title: Oprah Winfrey Show On OWN? Maybe Eventually
description: Edward Wyatt reports on Oprah Winfreys new network, OWN, which will launch in 2009:

title: The Oscars, The Grammys and The Strike
description: On the same day that Gil Cates, the producer of the Academy Awards telecast, said in no uncertain terms that the Oscars will go on regardless of what happens with the writers strike, Patric Verrone of the Writers Guild of America West said in equally certain terms that there will be no such thing if the strike is still in progress on Feb. 24, David Carr writes on The Carpetbagger blog.

title: Shades of Green
description: Carmakers seeking to prove their environmental street cred, highlight fuel-efficient models at the Detroit Auto Show.

title: Romney and McCain in Michigan
description: Before his victory Tuesday night, Mitt Romney spent the day emphasizing his personal ties to the state; John McCain tried to close the gap.

title: The Week Ahead
description: Alison Smale, of the International Herald Tribune, discusses events in the world this week.

title: A Paris Bus Map for your iPhone
description: This week IHT staffer Mike Cosentino  who also happens to be Globespotters web designer!  bought an iPhone. And being far more tech-savvy than the average journalist, he immediately created a version of the Paris bus map that can be loaded on to the device. Want it for your phone? Hes sharingTo find out more and to get the map for your smart phone click here for Mikes blog.

title: A Momentary Lapse of Protocol?
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Usually, on election nights, protocol dictates that losers get to give their concession speeches, and have their say, before the winners.

title: Republicans Brawl, Democrats Yawn
description: Here are a few things that happened Tuesday night.

title: Paul Beats Giuliani (Again)
description: The bad news for Rudolph W. Giuliani Tuesday night in Michigan was that Representative Ron Paul of Texas appears to have beaten him handily again, just as he did in Iowa.

title: Live Blogging the Democrats in Nevada
description: Wrapup The Democrats pulled themselves back from the brink tonight. Or they can only hope they did.

title: Weather Update: Maybe We Should Talk About the Government
description: Because the forecasts for Green Bay and Foxborough are getting worse. (Actually, if you do want to talk about the government, theres plenty of that going on at the Bats blog.)

title: Packers Trivia (Making the Leap)
description: It wasnt a Packers receiver or a running back who originated the Lambeau Leap; it was a safety, LeRoy Butler, in 1993.

title: New Jersey Toll Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling Quashes Kucinichs Hope of Joining Lineup
description: LAS VEGAS  Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio flew here on Tuesday, hoping to join the leading Democratic presidential candidates at a debate, but his wishes were dashed by the Nevada Supreme Court less than an hour before showtime.

title: 3 Winners, but No Anchor for Republicans
description: Can anyone bring the Republicans together again?

title: Houghton Mifflin Names Publisher of a Unit
description: Becky Saletan, publisher of the trade division of Harcourt, has been named publisher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Adult Trade Books, a combined unit that resulted from Houghton Mifflin Riverdeeps recent $4 billion takeover of Harcourt.

title: Mona Really Was a Lisa
description: The University of Heidelberg in Germany says it has identified the woman in Leonardos Mona Lisa (detail below), The Associated Press reported. She is Lisa del Giocondo, wife of Francesco del Giocondo, a Florentine businessman. In a statement on Monday, the college said its library expert, Armin Schlechter, found the answer in a copy of the works of Cicero, where, in 1503, Agostino Vespucci, a Florentine official and friend of Leonardos, wrote in the margins that the artist was working on a portrait of Lisa del Giocondo. Surprise? For centuries the Mona Lisa has been known in Italian as La Gioconda. Though anecdotal evidence pointed to Giocondo as early as 1550, vague references in 1517, 1525 and 1540 pointed to others.

title: Carbon Offsets
description: To the Editor:

title: Prog-Rock, Punk Fury, Psychedelic Euphoria
description: Tens of thousands of notes hurtled by during the Mars Voltas nearly nonstop two-and-a-half-hour set at Terminal 5 on Monday night. Compared to virtually any other band thats equally popular, the Mars Volta is a progressive-rock whirlwind, constructing maniacally complex music and performing it with a mixture of rigorous virtuosity, psychedelic euphoria and punk intensity.

title: Markets, Greened
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue-Collar Jobs Disappear, Taking Families Way of Life Along
description: JACKSON, Ohio  After 30 years at a factory making truck parts, Jeffrey Evans was earning $14.55 an hour in what he called one of the better-paying jobs in the area.

title: States Advised to Check for a Bridge Design Flaw
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Highway Administration moved quickly Tuesday to tell state authorities to re-examine bridges to make sure they do not have the newly discovered design flaw that doomed the Interstate 35W bridge, which collapsed in Minneapolis last summer.

title: California: Thermostat Plan
description: After an outcry of objections, the California Energy Commission withdrew its proposal to require new buildings in the state to have radio-controlled thermostats that, in a power emergency, could be used to override customers temperature settings. Instead of making the proposal part of new state building requirements, the commissioners will discuss the use of the programmable communicating thermostats when considering how to manage electrical loads  with the understanding that customers would have the right to refuse to allow the state to override their wishes.

title: Mamaroneck: Settlement Over School Building
description: The Village of Mamaroneck has agreed to pay $4.75 million to the Westchester Day School to settle a five-year lawsuit over the schools attempt to erect a new building on its campus, representatives of the school and the village announced on Monday night. Westchester Day, a 60-year-old Orthodox Jewish school, sued after the village denied its application to add a fifth building to its 25-acre campus. The school will also be able to move forward with the project. In October, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit found that the village had shown an arbitrary blindness to the facts when it denied permission for the construction.

title: With Kimchi, a Little Alchemy
description: SOME people collect stamps, others vintage bartender guides or mounted rare butterflies. Im cultivating a prodigious collection of condiments that is slowly taking over the fridge, much to my husbands dismay.

title: Northern Rock Investors Reject Curbs on Asset Sales
description: NEWCASTLE, England  At a special meeting, shareholders in Northern Rock, the ailing British mortgage lender, voted Tuesday against proposals by two hedge funds that would have forced managers to seek shareholder approval for even small asset sales.

title: As Spitzers Popularity Fell, Donors Rallied to His Side
description: ALBANY  Even as Gov. Eliot Spitzers popularity plunged last fall, a star-studded group of donors that included Ivanka Trump, Christie Brinkley and Edward Norton, as well as wealthy developers, poured thousands of dollars into his campaign account, helping the governor to amass nearly $3 million.

title: Decline in New Generic Drugs Draws E.U. Scrutiny
description: BRUSSELS  European Commission antitrust regulators raided some of the continents biggest drug makers on Wednesday as part of a far-reaching inquiry into whether settlements of patent disputes and lawsuits are being used to improperly keep generic products off the market.

title: One Killed and 9 Are Hurt in Blast at Metal Parts Factory
description: CARLSTADT, N.J.  An explosion at a small metal parts factory flung a man 30 feet, killing him and injuring nine others on Tuesday  three critically  according to the authorities here.

title: Lender to Cut 2,400 Employees, Including Sales Staff in India
description: LOS ANGELES (AP)  The mortgage lender IndyMac Bancorp said Tuesday that it would cut its work force by 24 percent, laying off 2,403 employees to cut costs as it tries to weather the worsening housing slump.

title: Visiting American Admiral Confers with Chinese Generals
description: BEIJING  China must be more open about its rapid military buildup and should expand military collaboration with the United States to develop greater trust and thereby prevent misunderstandings and confrontation, the United States commander in the Pacific said Tuesday.

title: With No Time to Waste, Fish Advances Quickly in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  A spectator no more, Mardy Fish is back in Australia and thriving, even on a new surface.

title: Bronx: Body Found in Apartment
description: Officers responding to a complaint of a foul odor found the body of a 39-year-old man on Tuesday morning in a bathtub of an apartment at 529 East 138th Street in Mott Haven, the police said. The victims identity was withheld pending notification of his relatives. The body was fully clothed, and the bathtub was dry, investigators said. The case remains under investigation, the police said, and the medical examiners office would determine the cause of death.

title: Romney in Crucial Victory Over McCain in Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor who ran as a son of Michigan though he left the state nearly 40 years ago, won a commanding victory Tuesday in the Republican primary here with a message aimed at voters deeply anxious about the states ailing economy.

title: Settlement in Bias Suit That Stalled for 37 Years
description: A federal judge has approved a $6.2 million settlement for black and Hispanic sheet metal workers in a 37-year-old lawsuit against a union that critics have called one of the citys most notorious for racial discrimination, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced on Tuesday.

title: An Effort to Stem Losses at Citigroup Produces a Renewed Focus on Risk
description: Ben Bernanke, meet Gary Crittenden. While youre easing credit, he is tightening it.

title: Whole-Grain but Not Heavy
description: WHEN my friend Gary Danko made whole-grain pancakes for me a while ago, I and everyone else in our little brunch party could not get enough of them.

title: Broadway Web Sites: Now for Fans as Well as Fanatics
description: A poll question on the new Web site BroadwaySpace.com plays to the most stereotypical image of Broadway fans: Who is your favorite diva? The choices are (no last names needed) Bernadette, Betty, Idina, Patti.

title: Spears's Visiting Rights Remain Suspended
description: The right of Britney Spears to visit her two little boys remained suspended under a ruling issued at a closed-door hearing by the Superior Court commissioner, Scott Gordon, on Monday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Neither Ms. Spears, 26, nor her former husband Kevin Federline, 29, was required to attend. He did; she came late to the courthouse but never went inside. He retains custody of the boys, Sean Preston, 2, and Jayden James, 1. Another hearing is scheduled for Feb. 19.

title: From One Prairie Home to Another, a Suit
description: ST. PAUL  Perhaps they will be able to share some tuna hotdish and work things out, but right now the spat between Garrison Keillor and a next-door neighbor is proving a good deal harder-edged than The News From Lake Wobegon.

title: Guild Allows Writers to Work on N.A.A.C.P. Awards
description: LOS ANGELES  Patric M. Verrone, president of the Writers Guild of America West, said the unions board voted to approve an interim agreement to let next months N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards proceed with guild writers and without the threat of pickets.

title: The Kite Runner Film Outlawed in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Culture Ministry has quietly banned the importing of The Kite Runner, a film based on the best-selling novel about childhood betrayal, ethnic tension and sexual predation in Afghanistan.

title: Check-Cashing Chain Is Takeover Target
description: Last week, a store in the Pay-O-Matic check-cashing chain was the scene of a macabre event when two men were charged with trying to cash a dead friends check  with his body in tow.

title: Carlyle Said to Be in Talks to Buy Booz Allen Unit
description: Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm, is in talks to sell its government contracting business to the Carlyle Group and several other private equity firms for about $2 billion, people briefed on the discussions said Tuesday.

title: Second Leg of Apples Plans Includes Jumping Back Into Movie Rentals
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs is rebooting Apples digital movie effort and putting the company squarely in the middle of an intensifying industry battle to download movies and Internet content to high-definition televisions.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Saturday about an investigation by the New York attorney general related to subprime loans referred incorrectly to a sign in a photograph of a residential street in Queens. The sign was an advertisement for a company offering refinancing or credit services to those in danger of foreclosure. It was not a foreclosure sign.

title: Norman Morrice, Director of Royal Ballet, Dies at 76
description: Norman Morrice, a former artistic director of the Royal Ballet and Ballet Rambert who shook up traditional British dance sensibilities by championing modern-dance choreographers and mentoring young talent, died last week, the Royal Ballet said in a statement. He was 76.

title: Global Advances Challenge U.S. Dominance in Science
description: The United States remains the world leader in scientific and technological innovation, but its dominance is threatened by economic development elsewhere, particularly in Asia, the National Science Board said Tuesday in its biennial report on science and engineering.

title: Spate of Police Commander Murders in Mexico
description: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico  The Interior Minister stepped down Tuesday in the latest sign that President Felipe Caldern is shaking up his cabinet after a little more than a year in office, officials said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Thursday about the country record producer Ken Nelson erroneously included a band among his recording credits. While he produced Rose Maddoxs solo recordings for Capitol Records, the Maddox Brothers & Rose had disbanded by the time Mr. Nelson was handling the Capitol label.

title: As Diseases Sneaked Up on Woman, the Piles of Clutter Grew
description: She simply shut the door. Maybe that would keep everything inside. The debris. The anxieties. The worn furniture. The sadness. The stacks of yellowing papers. The tangle of once-fine clothes. The jumble of interwoven memories of a life past. If she shut the door, it would all be hidden away, and she wouldnt have to confront It  whatever It was.

title: What to Expect When Youre Free Trading
description: Rochester

title: Manhattan: Parachutist Sues Empire State Building Company
description: A professional parachutist who tried to jump off the Empire State Building in 2006 filed a $30 million lawsuit on Tuesday against the Empire State Building Company. The parachutist, Jeb Corliss, 31, accused the buildings agents of defaming his character, unlawfully imprisoning him on the observation deck by shackling him to a fence when he tried to jump and causing him emotional distress and lost income. His lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, was a counterclaim to a $12 million suit filed against him last year by the company. That suit accuses Mr. Corliss of disrupting business, endangering bystanders and being motivated by money. A spokeswoman for the Empire State Building Company declined to comment on Tuesday.

title: A Strong Intel Disappoints on Outlook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel reported record fourth-quarter revenue on Tuesday, but the chip makers shares dropped sharply after hours as its earnings and its first-quarter projections disappointed an already jittery Wall Street.

title: Pope Cancels Speech After Protest at University
description: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI, in a rare papal acquiescence to protest, has canceled a speech at the prestigious Sapienza University here amid opposition by professors and students who say he is hostile to science.

title: Isaac Mizrahi Leaves Target to Revamp Liz Claiborne
description: Isaac Mizrahi, the cheap-chic designer who helped create the image of Target as a style destination, defected from the retailer on Tuesday to a more ambitious, and lucrative, role of making over the struggling Liz Claiborne label.

title: Knicks Rarity: Two Victories in a Row
description: All this winning at Madison Square Garden is beginning to feel a little monotonous. The Knicks followed their victory two nights earlier by beating the Washington Wizards on Tuesday night, 105-93. For those keeping count, that is two wins in two games.

title: Solving a Riddle Wrapped in a Mystery Inside a Cookie
description: Some 3 billion fortune cookies are made each year, almost all in the United States. But the crisp cookies wrapped around enigmatic sayings have spread around the world. They are served in Chinese restaurants in Britain, Mexico, Italy, France and elsewhere. In India, they taste more like butter cookies. A surprisingly high number of winning tickets in Brazil's national lottery in 2004 were traced to lucky numbers from fortune cookies distributed by a Chinese restaurant chain called Chinatown.

title: Returning to Tour After Long Detour
description: PALM DESERT, Calif.  To reach this sun-soaked valley in the desert for the first Bob Hope Chrysler Classic of his career, Todd Demsey, 35, flew six and a half hours on a red-eye from Honolulu to Phoenix on Sunday night, drove his R.V. 287 miles across I-10 from Phoenix to an R.V. park on Monday, then drove his courtesy car the remaining few miles to the Classic Club on Tuesday.

title: Spies, Blonde and a Guy Go North by Northwest
description: Its all too easy to identify with Richard Hannay as he first appears in The 39 Steps, the absurdly enjoyable, gleefully theatrical riff on Alfred Hitchcocks 1935 film. True, the odds are that youre not as deeply, fatuously handsome as Richard (Charles Edwards), or as square of jaw, clipped of diction or cocked of eyebrow.

title: Belgium: Copyright Violation Is Claimed
description: Belgian newspapers, emboldened by a court victory against Google last year, have started a preliminary copyright action against the European Commission over links on agency Web sites. Two Web sites owned by the commission, the Brussels-based executive for the 27 European Union nations, infringe copyright laws by linking to Belgian newspaper articles free, according to Copiepresse, a copyright group for French- and German-language newspapers. A Brussels court, asked by the group to look at its claim, appointed an expert to study how information is gathered for the E.U. sites. Once the expert has submitted his report, we may decide to file a lawsuit, said Margaret Boribon, the groups secretary general. A Brussels court in February ruled Google had violated Belgian copyright laws by publishing links to the newspapers without permission and ordered the company to remove the links or pay a daily fine of 25,000 euros ($37,000).

title: In New Jersey, School Chief Appointed to Flagging District Quits
description: Michael E. Glascoe, the state-appointed superintendent of the Paterson Public Schools, said on Tuesday that he would step down in July because he did not have the complete trust and support of New Jerseys education commissioner, Lucille E. Davy.

title: Blue-Ribbon Beer
description: To the Editor:

title: Footnotes
description: The pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim has won the Royal Philharmonic Society Gold Medal for outstanding musicianship. Mr. Barenboim will receive the medal at Royal Festival Hall in London on Jan. 28. ... Zaha Hadid Architects of London has been named the winner of the design competition for the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum at Michigan State University in East Lansing. ... From the estate of the hotelier Leona Helmsley, Impressionist and modern art, Old Master Paintings, Russian art, Chinese art and furniture and silver will be auctioned in 15 sales beginning on Thursday at Christies New York in Rockefeller Center. Net proceeds are to benefit the Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust. ... The Lebanese singer Mika, the boy band Take That and the reality television star Leona Lewis led the way with four nominations each when the shortlist for the Brit Awards, Britains version of the Grammys, was announced on Monday.

title: More House Salads, Whether the House Likes It or Not
description: Washington

title: The Other Nano
description: What do a 73 Volkswagen Bug, a navigation system on a new Jaguar and a brand new Nano sedan have in common? Two things: they cost about $2,500 and involve the Indian entrepreneur Ratan Tata.

title: Lottery Numbers
Judge Scolds Simpson but Allows Bail
description: Las Vegas  Five days after being returned to custody for attempting contact with a co-defendant in his armed-robbery case, O.J. Simpson received a tongue-lashing from a judge Wednesday and then a higher bail with stricter rules for his release.

title: Citigroup Loss Raises Anxiety Over Economy
description: Citigroup, the nations largest bank, reported a staggering fourth-quarter loss of $9.83 billion on Tuesday and issued a sobering forecast that the housing market and the broader economy still had not bottomed out.

title: Correction: Calendar
description: Because of an editing error, a calendar listing last Wednesday about a class on American whiskey followed by a dinner with whiskey cocktails at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., misstated the date. It will be held Thursday; it did not take place last Thursday.

title: Short on Fund-Raising, Red Cross Will Cut Jobs
description: Facing a $200 million operating deficit, the American Red Cross is preparing to cut as much as one-third of its headquarters staff, up to 1,000 employees, and pare regional management.

title: Bernanke Is Said to Support Stimulus Measures
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has told members of Congress that he can support tax cuts or spending measures to stimulate the economy, even if they temporarily increase the budget deficit, as long as the measures are quick and temporary.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the challenge facing Barack Obama as he pursues Latino voters in his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination misidentified, in some editions, the former mayor of Los Angeles who defeated Antonio R. Villaraigosa for the post in 2001 and lost to him in a 2005 rematch. He is James Hahn  not Kenneth Hahn, who was his father.

title: In an Eclectic Concert Series, a Meeting of Rock and Classical Composers
description: With all the fuss over Radioheads new In Rainbows album, with its pay-what-you-want downloading policy in the fall, and its CD version topping the charts last week, fans of the band might miss another significant milestone for the group, or at least for one of its players. On Wednesday and Thursday the innovative, genre-mixing Wordless Music series will present the first American performance of Popcorn Superhet Receiver, a 2005 string orchestra work by Jonny Greenwood, Radioheads lead guitarist, on a program with music by John Adams and Gavin Bryars.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of a transcription error, an article on Monday about concern over personal safety in the Atlanta area following the killing of a hiker misspelled, in some editions, the name of the town in Georgia where the hikers dog and some of her clothing were found. It was Cumming, not Cummings. The article also misidentified the place where a suspect in the killing was apprehended. It was DeKalb County, not Cumming.

title: Analyst's Role With YES Shifts away From the Studio
description: David Justice, who was cited in the Mitchell report as having purchased human growth hormone, will no longer be a studio analyst for the YES Network but will contribute columns and participate in chats on the channels Web site.

title: 18 Palestinians Killed in Gaza Clashes
description: JERUSALEM  At least 18 Palestinians, including 13 members of the military wing of Hamas, were killed in Gaza early Tuesday by Israeli Army fire, the highest death toll there in half a year.

title: Recipe: Whole-Grain Pancakes
description: Adapted from Gary Danko

title: The Supreme Court Club
description: Every year, the Supreme Court hears arguments in cases that can change the nation and reshape American rights. Just last week, it heard arguments on a challenge to a harsh Indiana voter ID law, a partisan scheme to disenfranchise poor and minority voters. It was, like many legal showdowns in the court, something Americans would have been interested in observing firsthand. Yet beyond a few hundred visitors, the public was denied that opportunity because members of the court, stubbornly clinging to their clubby ways, refuse to allow their proceedings to be televised.

title: Faith, Freedom and Bling in the Middle East
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

title: Friendlier Tone, but Plenty of Tough Talk
description: WASHINGTON  There were no baseball players in the Congressional committee room Tuesday, but the greatest slugger and pitcher of the era were not far from anyones mind during a four-hour hearing on the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs.

title: A Wine Spree Worth Savoring
description: I WAS sitting at my desk in Paris one day in 1988 when the phone rang. It was Jean-Claude Vrinat, the owner and director of Taillevent, the famed Paris restaurant, who died of cancer last week at the age of 71.

title: Don Cardwell, 72, Pitcher for 1969 Mets, Is Dead
description: Don Cardwell, a right-handed pitcher who helped propel the Mets to their stunning 1969 World Series championship as he neared the end of a long major league career, died Monday in Winston-Salem, N.C. Cardwell, who lived in Clemmons, N.C., was 72.

title: Boeing Delays Dreamliner Again
description: CHICAGO  Boeing announced on Wednesday that it was delaying the first flight and deliveries of the 787 Dreamliner because of continued supply-chain problems.

title: Justice Dept. Cites Obstacles in Blackwater Case
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Department officials have told Congress that they face serious legal difficulties in pursuing criminal prosecutions of Blackwater security guards involved in a September shooting that left at least 17 Iraqis dead.

title: A Campaign With Echoes From 1968
description: Jesse Epps will be in New York on Thursday afternoon to speak about the future, carrying a credential from history.

title: In the Czech Republic, a Green Castle
description: MCELY, Czech Republic

title: War on Allergies
description: To the Editor:

title: Belichick Sells Patriots on Opponents Strengths
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Out in San Diego, at least one player, swimming in the giddiness of the Chargers upset of the Indianapolis Colts, thinks the New England Patriots are more worried about having to play the Chargers in Sundays A.F.C. championship game than the Chargers are concerned about the undefeated Patriots.

title: Pennsylvania: Egyptian Released
description: The government released Sameh Khouzam, an Egyptian citizen, from a Pennsylvania prison after a federal judge ruled last week that the United States could not deport him to Egypt. The Egyptian government said Mr. Khouzam was convicted of murder in absentia. But Mr. Khouzam, a Coptic Christian, has maintained his innocence and has said he was tortured in Egypt because he refused to convert to Islam. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials said the United States had received confidential assurances from Egypt that Mr. Khouzam would not be tortured upon his return. But a federal judge ruled that the government could not rely on secret assurances that could not be independently reviewed to deport Mr. Khouzam. The government was granted a short stay on Mr. Khouzams release, which elapsed Tuesday, and it then sought an emergency stay of his release from the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, which was denied on Monday.

title: Justice Department Asked to Investigate Tejada
description: The House committee holding hearings into baseball and steroids promised an early news nugget, and it delivered: The committee formally asked the Department of Justice to investigate the star shortstop Miguel Tejada on the suspicion that he made false statements to the committee nearly three years ago.

title: Wrangling Over Stimulus Is One-Sided So Far
description: WASHINGTON  The economy needs stimulating  on that much, at least, Congressional Democrats agree. But from there, things get complicated.

title: A Pair of Rebels Are at It Again
description: THERE are rules by which a vigilant diner lives. There are dictums of common sense.

title: Bloomberg Chooses a Friend to Manage His Fortune
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has chosen the firm of a longtime friend, Steven Rattner, a financier who moves among New Yorks power elite, to manage the investments of his multibillion-dollar fortune.

title: That Masked Man Is Always in Goal
description: Buffalo Sabres goaltender Ryan Miller girded for a heavier workload this season, and Lindy Ruff, his coach, has had no choice but to take advantage. Miller played 20 games in a row before Ruff sat him down for a game Thursday in Ottawa.

title: Bill Proposes Database of Offenders to Aid Dating
description: LOS ANGELES  Web sites that promise to give the dirt on prospective dates abound. A guy has a roving eye? Look him up on DontDateHimGirl.com.

title: At Auto Show, Chinese Are Sidelined but Not Ignored
description: DETROIT  The basement of Cobo Center, where newcomers to the Detroit auto show are relegated, is drawing bigger crowds than usual this year.

title: Rice, in Baghdad, Praises New Law
description: BAGHDAD  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made a surprise visit to Iraq on Tuesday to brief Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and other top politicians about President Bushs recent talks with Arab leaders and to praise recent legislative progress.

title: The Truth About Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Charged in Death of a Woman Who Vanished in Florida
description: A 32-year-old man who the police believe had been living in his car was arrested on Tuesday on charges that he murdered a young Brooklyn woman who disappeared last spring while on vacation in Florida, the authorities said.

title: A Classic Series, Retooled and Swingin
description: IN 1967, when the cartoon series George of the Jungle was introduced, cigarette commercials still ran on TV, DVD meant Dick Van Dyke and video was a word in the titles of series like Captain Video and Video Village.

title: A Quick Fix for Electronic Voting
description: When Americans go to the polls in November, many will likely have to cast their ballots on unreliable paperless electronic voting machines. If the election is close, the country could end up with a rerun of 2000s bitterly contentious and mistrusted count. In an effort to avoid another such disaster, Representative Rush Holt, Democrat of New Jersey, plans to introduce a bill this week that would help address the weaknesses in electronic voting. Congress should pass it without delay.

title: Rice Makes Unannounced Visit to Baghdad
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice flew to Baghdad on Tuesday, peeling off during a trip to the region by President Bush to give momentum to legislative and political reconciliation in Iraq, the White House said.

title: High-Tech Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: An Immigrant With a Tough Job and an Easy Smile
description: From the stylish streets of SoHo, where he labored on the rising frame of the newest condo hotel to bear the Trump name, to the modest three-story brick walk-up in Greenpoint where the sounds of his early departure for work served as a virtual alarm clock for his landlady, Yuriy Vanchytskyy was remembered on Tuesday as a reliable, hard-working and cheerful presence.

title: The Meat of the Matter in a Pasta Debate
description: FOR a simple dish, pasta allamatriciana is freighted with controversy.

title: A Tool to Stimulate the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Enhancing Its Hits, Apple Adds Movie Rentals, Ultralight Laptop
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, took several big gambles Tuesday, betting that he could repeat his success in selling digital music by persuading Hollywood to allow Apple to rent digital movies, while at the same time returning to his original Macintosh roots with an elegant  but limited  ultralight computer called the MacBook Air.

title: Deal on Dams on Klamath Advances
description: Bitter opponents over the future of the Klamath River unveiled a formal agreement on Tuesday to pave the way for removal of four aging hydroelectric dams that re-engineered the watershed and sharply decreased fish stocks.

title: A Broadway Producer Is Bringing Back Drama
description: Jeffrey Richardss office, a space crowded with show posters, old marquee signs and two dogs walking around wearing souvenir T-shirts, is downstairs from his apartment and 18 blocks from where he grew up. With the exception of four years away at college, Mr. Richards, a press agent turned Broadway producer, has lived and worked his whole life within shouting distance of the theater district.

title: JPMorgan Joins Banks in Write-Downs
description: JPMorgan Chase said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter net income dropped 34 percent as problems stemming from the housing market downturn widened in both its investment banking and consumer businesses.

title: Interest Fades in the Once-Mighty V-8
description: DETROIT  The V-8 engine, long a symbol of power for American car companies, is sputtering.

title: Chefs New Goal: Looking Dinner in the Eye
description: LAST Friday, in front of 4 million television viewers and a studio audience, the chef Jamie Oliver killed a chicken. Having recently obtained a United Kingdom slaughtermans license, Mr. Oliver staged a gala dinner, in fact a kind of avian snuff film, to awaken British consumers to the high costs of cheap chicken.

title: Female Business Owners Fault New Rules on U.S. Contracts
description: Women who own small businesses  about a third of all small businesses in the United States, in fact  have been pushing for years for a bigger piece of government contracts, which now total $400 billion a year.

title: NBC's Deal Delivers
description: Facing some strong competition in prime time on Monday, NBCs Deal or No Deal and American Gladiators managed to rank No. 1 and No. 2 in the nights ratings. Nielsen estimated that Deal or No Deal delivered the largest audience overall, 15 million viewers at 9 p.m., while American Gladiators at 8 drew a less impressive 10.7 million viewers. Among adults 18 to 49, however, the two shows outpaced all other programming on the night, including Foxs Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles at 9 p.m. That show, which made its premiere on Sunday to 18.4 million viewers, declined in the ratings substantially with its second showing, attracting just 10.1 million while matching the 10 p.m. leader, CBSs CSI: Miami (14.7 million), for the third highest ratings on the night among the 18-to-49 set. Fox ranked second for the night in that demographic but third in total viewers behind both NBC and CBS, which broadcast repeats of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10. ABC was fourth over all, faring better earlier in the night with Dance War from 8 to 9:30 (10.5 million) but struggling later on with Notes From the Underbelly at 9:30 (4.8 million) and October Road at 10 (4.9 million).

title: Many Violations for Employer of Worker Who Died in a Fall
description: A contractor involved in Mondays fatal construction accident in SoHo has a history of safety violations at projects in Manhattan and has been fined tens of thousands of dollars in penalties, according to federal records.

title: Inflation Continues to Edge Up
description: Investors clamoring for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates had two reasons to smile on Wednesday: inflation rose only slightly in December and business activity slowed, according to separate government reports.

title: New Genetic Risks for Prostate Cancer Identified
description: A combination of common and minor variations in five regions of DNA can help predict a mans risk of getting prostate cancer, researchers are reporting today.

title: Investors Show a Deepening Pessimism
description: The stock market fell sharply to its lowest level in nearly a year Tuesday after Citigroup announced a large quarterly loss and an economic report offered more evidence that consumers were cutting back.

title: Britain: Inflation Exceeds Banks Target
description: Inflation in Britain was above the Bank of Englands 2 percent target for a third month in December, adding to the case for fewer interest rate cuts this year. Consumer prices rose 2.1 percent from a year earlier, the same as in November, the Office for National Statistics said.

title: What You Get for... $600,000
description: Newport, R.I.

title: Atlantic City: Embattled Casino to Rehire 150 Employees
description: Acknowledging that it had made major mistakes that drastically hurt its business, the Tropicana Casino and Resort said on Tuesday that it planned to rehire 150 workers and begin a major advertising campaign to improve its reputation. The casino is struggling to recover from a year in which the former owners, the Kentucky-based Columbia Sussex Corporation, eliminated 900 jobs and alienated customers with poor service and housekeeping. Those problems led the states Casino Control Commission to strip Columbia Sussex of its casino license in December, and the state is seeking a buyer for the property, which includes New Jerseys largest hotel, with 2,129 rooms.

title: A Pianist Plays Middleman for Two Composers Who Spoke in Different Voices
description: Listeners could forget about thematic unity at Radu Lupus Carnegie Hall recital on Monday night. A sold-out house heard Schuberts Piano Sonata in D (D. 850) before intermission and Debussys first book of Prludes after it. The Schubert represents the composers strenuous efforts to be big-time in the manner of Beethoven. The Debussy is a series of scenes painted by a master.

title: Baseball Is Challenged on Rise in Stimulant Use
description: WASHINGTON  When George J. Mitchell was appointed to investigate the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball nearly two years ago, amphetamines were not part of his mandate. The substances had been around baseball for decades, were sometimes winked at and were not even banned until the 2006 season, several years after the sport began to address what seemed to be the far larger controversy of steroid use.

title: Clues Offered in Search for Student
description: HOUSTON  A month after a Rice University student vanished with his car after withdrawing $500 from a bank machine, school officials on Tuesday disclosed information suggesting the disappearance might have been planned.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about the filing of murder charges against a Staten Island man in the death of his 3-week-old daughter misidentified the current Staten Island district attorney. He is Daniel M. Donovan Jr.  not William L. Murphy, who was the previous district attorney.

title: Buddy, Can You Spare a Billion?
description: First hard-pressed Wall Street banks turned to rich foreign governments for help. Now, they are seeking aid from the likes of New Jersey and big mutual funds to bolster their weakened finances.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about the filing of murder charges against a Staten Island man in the death of his 3-week-old daughter misidentified the current Staten Island district attorney. He is Daniel M. Donovan Jr.  not William L. Murphy, who was the previous district attorney. (Go to Article)

title: U.N. Chief Calls for Constructive Dialogue Among Cultures
description: MADRID  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon appealed Tuesday for global dialogue to fight terrorism, though he conceded that there was no quick way to eliminate the Islamist terror threat.

title: At African Tournament, Goalkeeper Is One of a Kind
description: His teammates on Senegals national team call him the American.

title: New Jersey Transit from Penn Station to Metropark, N.J.
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: 9 Jewish Leaders Say E-Mail Spread Lies About Obama
description: The leaders of nine Jewish groups released an open letter on Tuesday condemning what they called hateful e-mails that they said spread lies about Senator Barack Obamas religious beliefs and his intentions.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the status of reality television shows affected by the writers strike referred incorrectly to the competition faced by the NBC show Celebrity Apprentice in its debut on Jan. 3. While its ratings that night were the strongest for the series since 2005, it was not until the next week, on Jan. 10, that the show faced stiff competition from original episodes of C.S.I. on CBS and Greys Anatomy on ABC. On Jan. 3, both of those shows were repeats.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $6,607,383

title: Long Robust, Gains in New York City Property Values Start to Flatten Out
description: The robust growth in real estate values in New York, a trend that helped fuel years of record budget surpluses and city spending, has nearly skidded to a halt, city officials said Tuesday, and that shift could bring new pressure on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to raise taxes.

title: Nearly 12 Years Old, Rent Is to Close
description: Nine hundred thirty thousand, one hundred eighty minutes.

title: Unrest, a Love Triangle and Swinging Hips
description: A colorful and confounding head trip, Opera Jawa is guaranteed to test the fortitude of all but the most adventurous viewer.

title: Michigan, Hearing Promise of Revival, Returns the Favor
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich.  At the end of Mitt Romneys victory speech here on Tuesday night, he donned the mantle he had worn for the last week while campaigning to salvage his presidential candidacy  that of native son.

title: A Fine Day for Giants and Barolos
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

title: Out of the Icebox, the N.F.L. Caught Fire
description: It was the day before New Years Eve, and New Yorkers were leaving the city in droves. Not to escape Times Square celebrations, but to watch the N.F.L. championship game.

title: Hyperion Editor Leaving for Internet
description: Will Schwalbe is stepping down as editor in chief of Hyperion Books on Jan. 25 to pursue an unspecified Internet-related project. Mr. Schwalbe, who was at Hyperion for 11 years  seven of them as editor in chief  is also the author, with David Shipley, deputy editorial page editor at The New York Times, of Send: The Essential Guide to Email for Office and Home. Im really just incredibly excited by what is out there in new media, Mr. Schwalbe said. Ive had some thoughts that I want to test and see if I can put them into practice. Mr. Schwalbes shepherded authors included David Halberstam; Chris Anderson, the editor of Wired magazine; and the chef Jamie Oliver.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Queens: One Dead in House Fire
description: One person was killed in a fire at 89-03 91st Avenue in Woodhaven on Tuesday, the police said. The fire, on the second floor of a single-family house, was reported just after 4 p.m., the Fire Department said. Sixty firefighters responded and had the fire under control by 4:36 p.m., the department said. The victim was identified as Stephen Korovich, 51. The police said there was no indication of foul play, and the cause of the fire was under investigation on Tuesday.

title: In Baseball, Fear Bats at the Top of the Order
description: Chicago

title: Recipe: Seared Pork Chops With Kimchi
description: Time: 30 minutes plus 30 minutes to 24 hours refrigeration

title: Worry in Michigan as Forests Change Hands
description: MARQUETTE, Mich.  Last summer, as land and housing values crumbled in much of Michigan, Northern Michigan Land Brokers and a group of investors completed a $7.3 million deal to buy 7,300 acres of forest and undeveloped land  80 parcels in all  along several rivers in the Upper Peninsula.

title: South Korea: L.C.D. Sales Help Samsungs Profit
description: Samsung Electronics, the semiconductor and flat-screen maker, posted a smaller drop in fourth-quarter profit than analysts estimated as liquid-crystal display earnings countered a decline in chip prices. Net income fell 6.6 percent, to 2.21 trillion won ($2.4 billion), from 2.37 trillion won in the period a year earlier, the company said. Profit exceeded analysts estimate of 1.95 trillion won.

title: Driver Abandons Child After Chase
description: When a car chase on Long Island ended in an accident on Tuesday night, the driver tried to flee on foot, leaving a toddler strapped in the back seat, the police said.

title: A Queens High School With 3,600 Students, and Room for Just 1,800
description: From its brass entry doors to its rooftop observatory to the intricate oak paneling of the principals office, Richmond Hill High School in Queens was built to inspire something like awe for public education. The only discordant response during the structures dedication in 1923 was whether, with a capacity for 1,800 students, it was too large.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The TV Sports column on Tuesday, about the impact of frigid weather on the N.F.L. playoffs, misidentified the position that Forrest Gregg played in the so-called Ice Bowl of 1967 in Green Bay. It was offensive tackle  not guard, a position he occasionally played.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Nov. 2 about Col. Aleksandr Feklisov, a Soviet spy, misspelled the surname of the Soviet prime minister for whom Mr. Feklisov handled security for a 1959 visit to the United States. He was Nikita Khrushchev, not Krushchev. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message last week.

title: Indian Leader in China Urges Closer Ties
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India on Tuesday described an ascendant Asia in which India and China had a special opportunity to overcome historic hostilities, promote regional development and collaborate on concerns about energy, water supplies and food.

title: Cholesterol Drug Bombs
description: There have long been suspicions, but it was still very disturbing to learn this week that a heavily promoted cholesterol-lowering drug had flunked a clinical trial of its effectiveness in reducing fatty deposits in arteries. The two companies that reap billions from the drug had been cynically sitting on the results for more than a year.

title: A Library Exhibition Not for the Childrens Room
description: PARIS  The lighting is bordello red, but the librarians insist that their X-rated exhibition is serious.

title: Spring Training and the Syringe Generation
description: Washington

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on May 19 about Karen Hess, a food historian, gave an incorrect account of the career of her husband, John, and misidentified the city in which they met. He was a merchant marine and a journalist, but never a longshoreman. They met in Salt Lake City, where he was working as a reporter, not in San Francisco. The errors were pointed out in an e-mail message from the family last month.

title: Obama and Clinton Seek a Softer Tone
description: LAS VEGAS  A Democratic presidential debate unfolded with an exchange of pleasantries and acts of contrition among rivals on Tuesday as Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama promised to dispel a rancorous feud over race and gender that had threatened to divide the party and alienate voters.

title: F.D.A. Says Food From Cloned Animals Is Safe
description: After years of debate, the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday declared that food from cloned animals and their progeny is safe to eat, clearing the way for milk and meat derived from genetic copies of prized dairy cows, steers and hogs to be sold at the grocery store.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 3 about an announcement by the Suffolk County, N.Y., district attorney that he would not retry Martin Tankleff in the 1988 murders of his parents after his conviction was overturned by a state appellate court misquoted, in some copies, Judge Stephen Braslow of Suffolk County Court, who had refused Mr. Tankleffs appeal, in which he cited new evidence and new witnesses. Judge Braslow called the new witnesses a cavalcade of nefarious scoundrels  not characters. (The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 22 about the voiding of the conviction and on Dec. 28 about Mr. Tankleffs release.) The Jan. 3 article also misstated, in some copies, the length of time Mr. Tankleff was interrogated by the police and the timing of hearings before Judge Braslow. Mr. Tankleff was interrogated for about seven hours, not 18, and the hearings took place in 2004 and 2005, not last year.

title: Albany: Bailout for Long Island School District
description: The State Assembly and Senate passed legislation on Tuesday authorizing an $8 million bailout of the 2,800-student Roosevelt school system in Nassau County. The legislation provides a one-time state grant of $8 million to the district, the only school system ever placed under state control, to settle a debt that had threatened to create a fiscal crisis. The legislation also doubles the amount of an annual state grant to the district for academic improvement, to $12 million from $6 million. The money will allow the district to raise its per-pupil spending. The legislation will now go to Gov. Eliot Spitzer for approval.

title: High School Musical Role Reprisals
description: All the stars will be back again when High School Musical makes the jump from the Disney Channel to the big screen, Reuters reported. Zac Efron, Vanessa Hudgens, Ashley Tisdale, Lucas Grabeel, Corbin Bleu and Monique Coleman, seen in the hit High School Musical (2006) and its sequel, are confirmed to reprise their roles in the movie, High School Musical 3: Senior Year, when Troy (Mr. Efron) and Gabriella (Ms. Hudgens) face separation as they go off to college. Once again, Kenny Ortega will direct. The film is to be released in October.

title: Scorsese's Stones Film to Open Berlin Festival
description: Shine a Light, the Rolling Stones concert documentary by Martin Scorsese, right, will open the 58th Berlin International Film Festival on Feb. 7. Mr. Scorsese and the Stones will be in attendance, Paramount Pictures announced. The film, derived from more than half a million feet of concert footage, captures the band in two concerts at the Beacon Theater in New York, on Oct. 29 and Nov. 1, 2006, when guest performances were delivered by Christina Aguilera, Buddy Guy and Jack White of the White Stripes. The film will be released in North America by Paramount Classics on April 4.

title: Judah Folkman, Researcher, Dies at 74
description: Dr. Judah Folkman, a path-breaking cancer researcher who faced years of skepticism before his ideas led to successful treatments, died Monday in Denver. He was 74.

title: Volkswagen Corruption Trial Includes Seamy Testimony
description: BRAUNSCHWEIG, Germany  Rarely have so many top auto executives been summoned to talk about something other than cars.

title: U.S. Dominance in Science at Risk, Report Says
description: The United States remains the world leader in scientific and technological innovation, but its dominance is threatened by economic development elsewhere, particularly in Asia, the National Science Board said on Tuesday in its biennial report on science and engineering.

title: Justices Back N.Y. Trial Judge System
description: WASHINGTON  Sweeping aside complaints that New York State chooses its trial judges through an antiquated, patronage-tainted system that favors party cronies and gives voters no real say, the United States Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld the states unique system.

title: Bank of America Curbs Investment Banking
description: Bank of America, the banking giant, said on Tuesday that it was scaling back its investment banking operations, shedding an additional 650 jobs after suffering heavy trading losses from bad mortgage investments.

title: New Troubles for Apartment Mogul in South
description: Michael B. Smuck was one of the leading real estate syndicators in New Orleans in the 1980s until his limited partnerships began unraveling, causing large losses and unleashing years of legal battles with unhappy investors.

title: Bomb Targets U.S. Car in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A bomb exploded next to an American Embassy vehicle on Tuesday, killing at least three civilians and wounding many other people, including an American bystander and an embassy employee, Lebanese and American officials said.

title: Bush Prods Saudi Arabia on Oil Prices
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  President Bush on Tuesday urged Saudi Arabia and other members of OPEC to consider the strain the high cost of oil was having on the American economy, addressing an issue that has begun to color the last year of his presidency and dominate the presidential election campaign.

title: In His Own Words
description: Excerpts from remarks to supporters on Tuesday night after winning the Republican primary in Michigan:

title: Novelist Sells Archive
description: The archives of Cormac McCarthy, below, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, have been bought for $2 million by the Southwestern Writers Collection of Texas State University-San Marcos, The Associated Press reported. The university said the archives included correspondence, notes, drafts and proofs of 11 novels by Mr. McCarthy, 74, who won the Pulitzer for his 2006 novel, The Road, and a 1992 National Book Award for All the Pretty Horses.

title: Brad Renfro, Former Child Movie Actor, Dies at 25
description: Brad Renfro, the former child star who played a witness to a mob lawyers suicide in the 1994 legal thriller The Client and a suburban youth tutored in evil by an elderly Nazi war criminal in the 1998 film Apt Pupil, was found dead Tuesday morning in his Los Angeles home. He was 25.

title: More Delays Expected for Boeings Dreamliner
description: CHICAGO  Boeings great success in selling its 787 Dreamliner  it has 817 of the fuel-efficient planes on order, valued at more than $100 billion  is turning to a period of frustration.

title: Romney Seeks New Edge in South Carolina
description: BLUFFTON, S.C.  Fresh from his victory in Michigan, Mitt Romney rolled into South Carolina on Wednesday as he continued to his focus on the economy but also tried to play down expectations of how he would fare in the states Republican primary on Saturday. (The Democratic primary here is a week later.)

title: Airbus Orders Trailed Boeing in 2007
description: TOULOUSE, France  Airbus said on Wednesday that it had secured a record 1,341 orders for new aircraft last year, closely trailing Boeing but surpassing it in terms of deliveries as a surge in demand for air travel drove demand for new planes.

title: Supreme Court Limits Lawsuits by Shareholders
description: WASHINGTON  Ruling in its most important securities fraud case in years, the Supreme Court on Tuesday placed a towering obstacle in the path of shareholders looking for someone to sue when a stock purchase turns sour.

title: Music Festival Coming to Liberty State Park
description: In the latest shift in the competition for music fans this summer, the concert promoters behind the popular Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in California will stage a three-day event in Liberty State Park, according to people briefed on the plans. The new festival, tentatively scheduled for Aug. 8 through Aug. 10, is to be presented by the promoter AEG and its Goldenvoice subsidiary. A competing event, the Vineland Music Festival, held by C3 Presents and Festival Republic, a unit of the concert giant Live Nation, is scheduled from Aug. 8 to Aug. 10 in Vineland, N.J. The band Radiohead and the singer-songwriter Jack Johnson have been mentioned as headliners at the Liberty State Park event, though a lineup has not been announced. Representatives for AEG declined to comment.

title: Coca-Cola Urged to Close an Indian Plant to Save Water
description: NEW DELHI  A leading environmental research group based here has asked Coca-Cola to consider shutting down a bottling plant in the drought-stricken state of Rajasthan, saying that the plant is depleting scarce water supplies.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Saturday about videotaping police interrogations referred incorrectly to a written confession attributed to Martin Tankleff in the murders of his parents in 1988. He never signed it.

title: Scoldings, Regrets and Forced Geniality, but Little Fun
description: The Democrats debate in Las Vegas didnt turn out to be a testy showdown between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama. It was a school intervention for the leaders of the eighth-grade Mean Girls clique.

title: Dining Briefs
description: NEW PLACES

title: Board Tells States to Look for Bridge Design Flaws
description: WASHINGTON  Acting swiftly on the recommendation of accident investigators, the Federal Highway Administration told state authorities to take a new look at bridges to make sure they do not have the kind of design flaw that doomed the I-35W bridge, which collapsed in Minneapolis last summer.

title: Library of Congress Settles Scottish Spat
description: Card-catalog classifications hardly seem the subject of trans-Atlantic imbroglios, but the Library of Congress recently settled one when it agreed to reinstate a past policy of classifying works by Scottish authors under the heading Scottish literature. Early last year the library started classifying about 600 titles by Scottish writers as English literature, with subheadings like Scottish authors or Scottish poets. That offended the National Library of Scotland, which complained, enlisting the support of an American congressman, Mike McIntyre, Democrat of North Carolina. Early this month, the librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, wrote to the National Library of Scotland and the British Library, informing them that the Scots would get their own catalog distinction. As of now the Library of Congress is still classifying the works of Irish and Welsh writers under subcategories of English literature, but a spokesman, Matt Raymond, said the library has yet to receive any complaints.

title: Trenton: Corzine Vetoes Change to Wrongful-Death Law
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine pocket-vetoed a controversial bill on Tuesday that would have expanded the states wrongful-death law and allowed families to sue for pain and suffering. The bill had been supported by trial lawyers and victims advocates, who argued that under current law, families cannot recover damages when the death of a child, disabled person or retiree could have been prevented. The bill had been opposed by business interests, including the pharmaceutical industry, which argued that liability insurance and property taxes would escalate as a result. In a statement, Mr. Corzine said that he had allowed the bill to expire without signing it because of his concern about a significant impact on state and local budgets.

title: Sun Buying Swedish Software Firm for $1 Billion
description: Sun Microsystems, one of the biggest sellers of open-source software in the United States, said Wednesday that it would spend $1 billion to buy MySQL, a Swedish company that is the world leader in open-source database software used by Internet powers like Google, Yahoo, MySpace and YouTube.

title: In Complex Times, Turkey Seeks a Reassuring Face
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Looking dapper in a bow tie and a crisp suit, the founder of the Turkish republic, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, stared fiercely into a dark room. He was made of wax and standing in a museum, but for some visitors last week, he might as well have been alive and breathing.

title: Dusty Cohl, a Toronto Film Festival Founder, Dies at 79
description: Dusty Cohl, a founder of the Toronto International Film Festival, a bellwether for the annual movie awards cycle, died on Friday in Toronto. He was 79 and lived in Toronto.

title: A Revival of 1992s Glum Mood
As Jobs Leave Ohio, Many Are Driven to the Edge
description: JACKSON, Ohio  After 30 years at a factory making truck parts, Jeffrey Evans was earning $14.55 an hour in what he called one of the better-paying jobs in the area.

title: Oracle, Sweetening Terms, Buys BEA
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Oracle Corporation said Wednesday that it would acquire BEA Systems for $8.5 billion, just three months after BEA handily rejected its original unsolicited bid..

title: Bankrupt Art Dealer Asks to Sell House for Millions
description: An art dealer who filed for bankruptcy last year after his gallery was ordered padlocked by a judge is seeking permission to sell his Upper East Side town house, for up to $25 million. The dealer, Lawrence B. Salander, ran the Salander-OReilly Galleries. By the time he filed for bankruptcy in November, complaints were mounting from people who said they had consigned artworks to the gallery but were never paid for them. Some former clients maintained that the gallery had sold their paintings without their permission.

title: 4 Arrests Made in Kabul Hotel Attack
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Police authorities in Afghanistan have arrested four people in the aftermath of the suicide bomb attack on Monday evening at a Kabul luxury hotel and said Tuesday that three Americans and one Frenchwoman might have been among the six dead.

title: Kenyan Opposition Wins a Skirmish
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Judging from the opening session of Parliament on Tuesday, it looks like it is going to be a long political year in Kenya.

title: Iraqi Spending to Rebuild Has Slowed, Report Says
description: Highly promising figures that the administration cited to demonstrate economic progress in Iraq last fall, when Congress was considering whether to continue financing the war, cannot be substantiated by official Iraqi budget records, the Government Accountability Office reported Tuesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Dec. 25 about the choreographer Michael Kidd misstated his given name at birth and his birthplace. He was Milton (not Michael) Greenwald, and he was born in Manhattan, not Brooklyn.

description: On a hot summer day in 1989, Sudhir Venkatesh, a callow sociology student with a ponytail and tie-dyed T-shirt, walked into one of Chicagos toughest housing projects, clipboard in hand, ready to ask residents about their lives. Sample question: How does it feel to be black and poor? Suggested answers: very bad, somewhat bad, neither bad nor good, somewhat good, very good. Actual answers: unprintable.

description: Romney wins: If things keep going this way, John Edwards will win Nevada, Fred Thompson will win South Carolina, Rudy Giuliani will win Florida, and the two parties will have to dig up scores of new candidates to win the remaining states. But despite the murky state of the race on both sides, Portfolios Matt Cooper (whose wife, Mandy Grunwald, works for Hillary Clinton) says the economy is becoming the defining issue of the 2008 campaign. At his Portfolio blog, Cooper notes that Romney dominated the economic vote in Michigan, according to the exit polls. He writes:

That happens to be the day celebrated as Martin Luther Kings Birthday. And this happens to be the first time that the South Carolina city will officially recognize the holiday.

description: Though it has held up better than many of its Wall Street peers in recent months,  J.P. Morgan Chase is feeling the subprime pinch. The bank on Wednesday posted a 21 percent decline in net income from continuing operations for the fourth quarter, driven in part by a $1.3 billion write-down on assets tied to mortgage loans.
