description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Now Hanging | Whats New At The New Museum
description: Clockwise from top left: Kim Jones, Mark Bradford, Christian Holstad, Martha Rosler, John Stezaker. (New Museum)

title: Those Bugs That Want to Suck Your Blood? Theres Help
description: Bedbugs continue to disrupt New Yorkers sleep. Since July, the citys 311 hot line has registered 4,000 complaints about the nocturnal blood-sucking creatures, 1,700 of which resulted in violations issued to building owners across the city.

title: Trying to Profit Off O.J. Fatigue
description: No attempt to exploit buzz surrounding the latest O.J. Simpson trial should be surprising, especially considering the hyper-promotional nature of Las Vegas, the fame of its defendant of the moment and the shameless product placement at the first hearing.

title: Here, There and (NBC) Everywhere
description: Is NBC Universal worried about the flow of advertising revenue at its networks as the writers strike drags on? Executives made like Alfred E. Neuman today with a pair of What, me worry? presentations, which played up ways for marketers to sponsor ads beyond the TV sets that viewers watch  or are watching less  at home.

title: A Liberal Victory for Romney?
description: Ross Douthat, on his blog for The Atlantic, complains that in the context of the Michigan primary, the weakness of the Huckabee/McCain economic message seems to have been that it wasnt, well, liberal enough.

title: Congestion Pricing and Disparities in Commuting
description: Supporters and opponents of congestion pricing converged on the auditorium of Hunter College this afternoon for a citywide public hearing on the interim report of the New York City Traffic Congestion Mitigation Commission, the state panel charged with weighing Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs proposal to charge fees for driving in Manhattan against alternatives, like imposing tolls on the East River bridges.

title: When Will J.P. Morgan Strike a Deal?
description: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

title: A Bikes-Only Parking Lot in Midtown?
description: A few business executives have dreamed up a private-sector solution to the problem of secure bicycle parking in New York: the citys first bikes-only parking lot. They have a space on West 33rd Street. All they need is a corporation willing to pay as much as $200,000 a year to sponsor it.

title: Antimodern
description: After a century of devoted minimalism, a turn toward ostentation.

title: The Bunker Is Listening
description: Rob Brown used to drive me crazy. When he was scoring, he would light up the board and make those geeky Fantasy team owners very happy.

title: 'Baghead' Clip
description: A clip from the "Baghead," directed by the Duplass Brothers. The film is playing at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: 'Birds of America' Clip
description: A clip from Craig Lucas's film "Birds of America," which is playing at the Sundance Film Festival. Courtesy of Plum Pictures.

title: A Brigade of Grannies on Fifth Avenue
description: An activist group, Grandmothers Against the War, held a mock funeral procession this afternoon from the Times Square Armed Forces Recruiting Center to Rockefeller Center to protest the war in Iraq. The group has been holding weekly antiwar vigils for four years. Its founder, Joan Wile, is one of 18 women  all grandmothers  who were arrested in 2005 for trying to enter the recruiting station. They were acquitted of disorderly-conduct charges after a six-day trial. The protest today occurred without incident.

title: Fasten Your Seatbelts, It Could Be a Bumpy Ride
description: LAS VEGAS  Trading in the role of presidential candidate for airline attendant, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just hopped on the public address system of her plane here  which two dozen reporters and photographers are riding in  to announce the maiden voyage of Hill Force One.

title: Leetch Night Festivities
description: The Rangers are starting the ceremony to honor former defenseman Brian Leetch at 6:30 p.m. on January 24, to try to kick their game off close to on time. Fortunately, it is unlikely to be the marathon event that Mark Messiers number retirement was. Leetch is reliably less talkative than Messier.

title: Race Bait
description: SEATTLE  On the West Coast, we are the deepest of blue state America. We have ditched our badges of tribal politics for a post-racial era. We can break the padlocks of prejudice, and why not?

title: Love Letter
Bloggingheads: Soft Power Politics
description:
Bloggers Henry Farrell of Crooked Timber, left, and Daniel Drezner of danieldrezner.com debate about which presidential candidates are helping America's image abroad.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: What Recession? PC Sales Stay Strong
description: The economy may be teetering, but the personal computer business is still nimbly running at full speed, according to the tally of sales in the fourth quarter of 2007 from the International Data Corporation. Worldwide, 77.3 million PCs were sold in the quarter, up 15.5 percent from the fourth quarter of 2006. That represents almost double the growth rate of 2005 to 2006.

title: New London Record
description: Lev Leviev, a 51-year-old Israeli most often called a diamond billionaire, has reportedly paid a record amount for a new home in Britain.

title: Brad Guzans Possible Move to Fulhamerica
description: Kasey Keller, Clint Dempsey, Brian McBride and Carlos Bocanegra already play for Fulham.

title: Inside the Giants: Plaxico Channels Bum Phillips
description: Giants receiver Plaxico Burress has played in two A.F.C. championship games with the Steelers, and is thirsty for his first Super Bowl.

title: The Latest Thompson Ad Blitz
description: If youre a South Carolinian, you wont be able to surf away from a Fred Thompson ad tomorrow between say, 6:25 and 6:30 p.m.

title: In Fla., Giuliani Tackles Insurance
description: GULF BREEZE, Fla.  In his bid to win Florida at the cost of all the earlier primary states, Rudolph W. Giuliani touted his support for a national catastrophic fund to help insurance companies in the wake of a major national disaster. Mr. Giuliani announced the plan at a firehouse in the Panhandle and released a new ad in the state.

title: Obama Talks About the Economy
description: VAN NUYS, Calif.  The truce among Democratic presidential candidates over the divisive topics of race and gender appears to have weathered a full news cycle, one day after the rivals showed their congeniality during a televised debate in Las Vegas.

title: Reporting From Green Bay
description: Some notes and observations from in and around the Green Bay locker room on Wednesday:

title: The Mac Daddy Formula
description: A lot of buzz still surrounds Apple chief Steve Jobs and his keynote address. With David Pogue and CNBC's Melissa Francis.

title: Respond to Todays Column: The Anti-Charm Offensive
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Jan. 17 column.

title: Mine Legislation Passes House
description: The House voted to approve sweeping mine safety legislation aimed at preventing underground accidents like the one that took nine lives last year at Crandall Canyon Mine in Utah. The margin of the vote, 214 to 199, would not be enough to override a threatened veto. The legislation would add safeguards to a practice used at Crandall Canyon that is known as retreat mining, in which the pillars supporting an area of the mine are removed or reduced to extract as much coal as possible. It would also require mine operators to use new coal-dust monitors. And it would give the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration subpoena authority; increase penalties for safety violations; place the agency completely in control of a rescue site; and create an ombudsmans office to handle miners safety complaints. A similar bill is under consideration in the Senate.

title: State Body Orders Lawyer to Talk in Spitzer Inquiry
description: ALBANY  Pressing forward in its investigation of Gov. Eliot Spitzers administration, the states Commission on Public Integrity has subpoenaed a lawyer who represented Darren Dopp, the governors former communications director, according to people involved in the case.

title: Another Slip-Up on the Air, Another Apology
description: It was late in Connecticuts 81-65 win over St. Johns on Jan. 8 when the ESPN analyst Bucky Waters grew euphoric over the nine steals by Jerome Dyson, the Huskies sophomore guard.

title: Parts Didnt Click Together for Boeing Jet
description: CHICAGO  Plug and play  a concept that allows buyers of computers and electronic games to avoid frustrating assembly  is proving difficult for Boeing, which staked its 787 Dreamliner on a far-flung network of suppliers that would send what amounts to snap-on components to a plant for final assembly.

title: Correction: Must Flatter, Work Nights and Last Forever
description: A glossary last Thursday with a story about energy-efficient light bulbs described induction technology incorrectly. In an induction light bulb, an electromagnetic field causes gas in a tube to emit ultraviolet radiation, which stimulates phosphors to produce light. The electromagnetic field does not vibrate, nor does the gas itself release visible light.

title: Arts Council in England Taketh (and Giveth), Leaving Anger in Its Wake
description: LONDON  On Dec. 14 Josie Rourke, the artistic director of the tiny Bush Theater in West London, received an unwelcome Christmas present. It was a letter from the Arts Council England, the government-financed body that doles out subsidies to the arts, announcing plans to cut the Bushs public funding by some 40 percent  to about 300,000 (roughly $588,000) a year, from 480,000 ($942,000).

title: The Popes Canceled Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: After Veto, House Passes a Revised Military Policy Measure
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Wednesday approved a sweeping $696 billion military policy measure after revising a single provision in the 1,300-page bill that had prompted a surprise veto by President Bush.

title: Spitzer Offers Broad Plan to Help Upstate Economy
description: BUFFALO  Gov. Eliot Spitzer offered details on Wednesday of his proposal to infuse $1 billion in state funds into upstate cities, farms and parks as a way of revitalizing the regional economy, rescuing it from what he called an economic storm.

title: Congress on Steroids
description: On Tuesday, Bud Selig and Donald Fehr, baseball's commissioner and union leader, testified before Congress about steroids in baseball. Roger Clemens and his former trainer, Brian McNamee, are scheduled to testify next month. Do you expect anything good to come out of this Capitol Hill drama, or is it just grandstanding?

title: D.E.A. Agents Say Movie Libeled Them
description: Three former agents of the New York office of the Drug Enforcement Administration filed a defamation lawsuit on Wednesday against NBC Universal studios, claiming that the movie American Gangster libeled D.E.A. agents.

title: Social Engagements
description: The stripper Dita Von Teese, above, former wife of the shock rocker Marilyn Manson, will accompany the Austrian socialite Richard Lugner on Jan. 31 to the annual Opera Ball in Vienna, the highlight of the Austrian social calendar, Agence France-Presse reported on Wednesday. Mr. Lugner, 75, who traditionally invites a star or starlet to be his guest, told a news conference that his daughter had begged him to invite Ms. Von Teese, 35, the former Heather Sweet of West Branch, Mich. Conservative members of Vienna society have complained that Mr. Lugners much-publicized invitations lower the tone of the ball. Last year his guest was Paris Hilton. ... This year Ms. Hilton will attend Harvard University. Just for a day. Ms. Hilton, whose new movie, The Hottie & the Nottie, is to be released on Feb. 8, will be in Cambridge, Mass., on Feb. 6 to accept the Hastiest Pudding of the Lampoon Award from Harvard Lampoon.

title: New Coach of Dolphins Also Protg of Parcells
description: The Parcellsification of the Miami Dolphins was completed Wednesday when Tony Sparano, who was a member of Parcellss Dallas Cowboys coaching staff in the 2006 season, was named the coach of the Dolphins.

title: Bypass the Computer When Shifting Old Video to Digital
description: Life often gets simpler if you skip the middleman. You could wrestle with cables and software to turn analog video into digital movies on the computer, but the Pinnacle Video Transfer device lets you skip the whole computer part and record the video directly onto an iPod or Sony PlayStation Portable.

title: Climate Talks Cancellation Splits a Town
description: CHOTEAU, Mont.  School authorities cancellation of a talk that a Nobel laureate climate researcher was to have given to high school students has deeply divided this small farming and ranching town at the base of the east side of the Rocky Mountains.

title: Islanders Beat Devils for 5th Time This Season
description: NEWARK  Patrik Elias had the puck in the slot, and only the goaltender stood between him and a goal. Maybe if the goaltender were anyone but the Islanders Rick DiPietro, Elias would have scored easily. But DiPietro has become the Devils nemesis.

title: As Crawford Takes Over, Knicks Take 3rd Straight
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the dull-gray January days of a dull-gray season, the Knicks have summoned an inexplicably sunny new demeanor, brimming with confidence and a slight hint of swagger. No one can say where it came from or what took so long. There is rarely anything rational to the Knicks rhythms.

title: A Defeat for Judicial Reform
description: By upholding New Yorks machine-dominated system for selecting judges, the Supreme Court has dealt another setback to voters. The court has once again allowed political bosses to rig elections in ways that deny voters a meaningful role. New Yorks political power brokers are no doubt cheering, but they should not be allowed to triumph. Even if New Yorks method of selecting judges is constitutional, it remains unfair and undemocratic. It needs to be replaced.

title: Dispute Deepens for Russia and Britain
description: MOSCOW  A British cultural organization at the center of a dispute between the Kremlin and Britain closed its office in St. Petersburg on Wednesday under pressure from Russias intelligence service, which summoned the organizations entire Russian staff for questioning, Russian and British officials said.

title: For the Junior Airborne Division
description: LONG a sport for adventure seekers, snowboarding has become a family affair, with young enthusiasts shredding the mountain alongside their parents. In the last decade, the number of snowboarders age 7 to 11 has nearly doubled, to 860,000 in 2006 from 476,000 in 1997, according to the National Sporting Goods Association.

title: French Court Finds Oil Company Partly Liable for Spill
description: PARIS  In a ruling that could set a precedent for responsibility in maritime pollution, a French court ruled Wednesday that the oil company Total was partly liable for a vast tanker spill in 1999 that blackened the Brittany coast with fuel oil even though the company did not own the ship.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the On Baseball column on Sunday about the fluid nature of voting for Hall of Fame candidates who remain on the ballot year after year misstated the number of votes that Jim Rice lacked for induction. It was 16, not 42. (A candidate must be named on 75 percent of all ballots to make the Hall of Fame.)

title: China Says Its Seafood Is Safer
description: BEIJING  Chinas Ministry of Agriculture says a recent nationwide crackdown on the use of illegal veterinary drugs has already significantly improved the quality and safety of the countrys seafood production.

title: Though Idol Returns, Some Viewers Don't
description: Foxs American Idol came roaring back to prime-time television on Tuesday, dominating the nights ratings as usual, but in a sign that the series, now in its seventh season, might have reached a plateau this years premiere fell more than 4 million viewers short of last years record-breaking debut. Nielsen estimated that 33.2 million viewers tuned in for the first rounds of auditions from 8 to 10 p.m., compared with 37.4 million a year ago. Among adults 18 to 49, the shows ratings were down by about 13 percent. CBS finished as runner-up for the night with the second most viewers, thanks to NCIS at 8 (15.9 million) followed by Comanche Moon from 9 to 11 (12.5 million). NBC ranked third with a two-hour Biggest Loser at 8 (7.2 million) and Law & Order: Special Victims Unit at 10 (12.1 million). Despite modest audiences, the two shows lifted NBC well ahead of CBS for the night in the 18-to-49 group. Meanwhile, with a mix of reruns and new comedies, followed by Boston Legal at 10 (7.4 million), ABC lagged behind its competitors in fourth place overall.

title: Egypts Problem and Its Challenge: Bread Corrupts
description: CAIRO  Get out! Get back! Get back! I am not selling to you!

title: Antidepressant Studies Unpublished
description: The makers of antidepressants like Prozac and Paxil never published the results of about a third of the drug trials that they conducted to win government approval, misleading doctors and consumers about the drugs true effectiveness, a new analysis has found.

title: Merrill Lynch Posts a $9.8 Billion Loss
description: Merrill Lynch, a firm one-third the size of Citigroup, posted an equally huge fourth-quarter loss of $9.8 billion on Thursday, fueled by write-downs totaling $16.7 billion, more than double the firms 2006 profits.

title: 'Oh, and I Have a Pretty Good Team, Too'
description: Bill Belichick may have the best football team in creation, but that doesn't stop the New England Patriots' coach from reverting to pure reverie about another great team -- the Giants of the 1980s, when Belichick was the defensive coordinator and coached a linebacking corps that was among the best ever. Our colleague Judy Battista, who has covered the Patriots regularly this season, tells us that the old Giants defenses are one of the few subjects that the circumspect Belichick gets animated about. He shows film of them to his players, and talks about them so much that linebacker Mike Vrabel engaged in a give-and-take with Belichick during training camp that prompted the coach to leave a Giants helmet in Vrabel's locker. (Vrabel wore it while warming up).

title: L.I. School Stands Out in Science Contest
description: Ward Melville High School in East Setauket on Long Island led the nation in semifinalists this year in the Intel Science Talent Search, the countrys most prestigious high school science competition.

title: Pakistan Fort Overrun by Militants
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Hundreds of Islamic militants attacked a paramilitary fort in Sararogha, in the restive South Waziristan tribal region in north-west Pakistan on Tuesday, killing 22 soldiers and taking several others hostage in a nearly six-hour battle, government intelligence agency officials and local officials said Wednesday.

title: Shes Dying  Quick, Better Overnight Those $500 Sheets
description: IF you are unlucky enough to receive a diagnosis of cancer, the best to hope for is Movie Cancer, in which you become wiser, more assured and better-looking  and, in the case of the heroine of Amy Redfords new movie, The Guitar, you furnish your newly acquired dream loft with no concern about money.

title: A Tireless Partner for Workouts, Perched on a Wrist
description: Like its forebears, the Garmin Forerunner 405 is a G.P.S.-enabled watch with an abundance of training features to keep runners and bikers motivated.

title: Too Cold to Exercise? Try Another Excuse
description: JULIA HENSLEY, a 41-year-old artist, got a taste of bitter cold a decade ago when she spent a winter living on a glacier near Seward, Alaska. Typical winter temperatures were 10 to 15 degrees below.

title: N Train From 34th Street to Coney Island-Stillwell Avenue
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Moss Denies Injuring a Woman He Knows
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Randy Moss, whose record-setting season with the Patriots seemed to indicate that he had put his troubled past behind him, has been accused by a Florida woman of battery causing serious injury. A temporary restraining was issued against Moss on Monday. No criminal charges have been filed.

title: Clocks of Brooklyn Building Are Ticking, and in Sync
description: The many months of planning, of disassembling and reassembling, of testing and retesting, had wound down to this scene: Alexander Krukis focusing on his BlackBerry, his nervousness and excitement seeming to increase with each passing minute.

title: Teenage Girl Held in Death of Another
description: A dispute between two teenage girls in Newark left an 18-year-old dead of stab wounds and a 15-year-old arrested on murder charges, law enforcement officials said on Wednesday.

title: National Theaters Plans
description: Nicholas Hytner, artistic director of the National Theater in London, announced on Wednesday the theaters 2008 season, which includes a stage turn by Jeremy Irons in Never So Good, a new play by Howard Brenton about the British prime minister Harold Macmillan. Other highlights, some previously announced, include a dance work directed and performed by Juliette Binoche and Akram Khan; a new version of Sophocles Oedipus by Frank McGuiness and starring Ralph Fiennes; and new work by Michael Frayn, Rebecca Lenkiewicz and Tony Harrison. Joan Didions Year of Magical Thinking, which played on Broadway last year, is also a part of the season.

title: Rivers Is Still Talking and Plans to Do More
description: SAN DIEGO  Philip Rivers squinted into the sunlight, a natural reaction for someone who had spent most of his waking hours this week sequestered indoors, receiving treatment for a sprained right knee.

title: Former Congressman Is Indicted Over Ties to Islamic Charity
description: WASHINGTON  A former Republican congressman from Michigan was indicted Wednesday on federal charges of money laundering and obstruction of justice. The charges involve his work as a lobbyist for an Islamic charity accused of illegally funneling about $130,000 to an Afghan warlord labeled a terrorist by the United States government.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How do I choose a coffee table?

title: Staying Private on Facebook
description: Q. How much information from my Facebook profile can random people find out about me with a regular Web search?

title: Two Desperate Teams, Only One Winner
description: The two teams that played at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night were wearing the same uniforms as the Rangers and Sabres teams that battled each other in the Eastern Conference quarterfinals last season, but both looked so different they were hardly recognizable.

title: Alicia Keys is Tops
description: Music sales continue to plunge. This week Alicia Keyss As I Am (J), below, is the top album with 70,000 copies sold, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Thats not a new low for the weekly sales of a No. 1 record  the Dreamgirls soundtrack earned that dubious distinction last January, with 60,000  but its close. Radioheads In Rainbows (ATO), in its second week of CD sales, is No. 2 with 69,000. One of the few success stories on the Billboard chart recently, the Juno soundtrack (Rhino), rose five spots to No. 3 with 68,000 sales. Mary J. Bliges Growing Pains (Geffen) is No. 4 with 64,000, and Taylor Swifts self-titled album on the Big Machine label holds at No. 5 with 35,000. No new albums reached the Top 20.

title: Disease or Not, the Pain Is Very Real
description: To the Editor:

title: A Growing Epidemic, a Gnawing Suspicion
description: The disclosure at the Congressional hearing Tuesday that baseball is awash in a previously unknown epidemic brought two things to mind: Steve Howe and Officer Krupke.

title: Fraud by University Owner Is Found
description: PHOENIX (AP)  The Apollo Group Inc., the company that owns the University of Phoenix, fraudulently misled investors in 2004 about student recruitment policies, a federal jury decided Wednesday. The panel ordered the company to pay shareholders about $280 million.

title: Sarkozy Uses French Clout as His Own Slips
description: PARIS  Under fire at home, his marital status a mystery, President Nicolas Sarkozy is projecting French power in far-flung places and promoting himself as a global intellectual.

title: White House Exempts Navy From Sonar Ban, Angering Environmental Groups
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Bush administration jumped into a long-running legal fray in California on Tuesday, exempting the Navy from a law that environmental groups have used to prevent the use of a type of powerful sonar that is believed to harm whales.

title: Entrepreneurship Takes Off in Ireland
description: DUBLIN  Ireland is now alive with enthusiasm for entrepreneurs, who seemingly rank just below rock stars in popularity.

title: Ex-Time Editor to Help Lead Book Publisher
description: Priscilla Painton, most recently the deputy managing editor of Time Magazine, has been named editor in chief of the adult trade imprint of the publishing company Simon & Schuster.

title: Protests Bring New Violence in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Opposition protests resumed in Kenya on Wednesday, and as many people here feared, violence erupted across the country once again.

title: A Center Called McCain
description: Nobodys been right all the time on Iraq, but Senator John McCain has been less wrong than most. He knew a bungled war when he saw one and pressed early for increased force levels. He backed the injection last year of some 30,000 troops, a surge that has produced results.

title: Bernanke Is Said to Support Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has told lawmakers that he can support tax cuts or spending measures to stimulate the economy, even if they increase the budget deficit, provided the measures are quick and temporary.

title: New Questions on Treating Cholesterol
description: For decades, the theory that lowering cholesterol is always beneficial has been a core principle of cardiology. It has been accepted by doctors and used by drug makers to win quick approval for new medicines to reduce cholesterol.

title: The Anti-Charm Offensive
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Judge May Question C.I.A. Agents About Tapes
description: A federal judge in New York said Thursday that he was disappointed in how investigators from the Central Intelligence Agency had handled videotapes documenting the harsh interrogation of detainees from Al Qaeda, adding that he was considering questioning agency officials who had watched the tapes about why they had made no record of them in their files.

title: Fed Chief Backs Quick Action to Aid Economy
description: WASHINGTON  A recession is probably not on the horizon, despite the drumbeat of grim financial news, but the ailing economy needs quick passage of a stimulus package plus aggressive action by the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress on Thursday.

title: College Legacies Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Louisiana: L.S.U. Chancellor Quits
description: Chancellor Sean OKeefe of Louisiana State University resigned after three years in the position. In his resignation letter, Mr. OKeefe said the chancellor should have the confidence of the university systems president and governing board, reinforcing suggestions that board members and the system president, John Lombardi, wanted to fire Mr. OKeefe. Reports had circulated for nearly two weeks that Mr. OKeefe had been told by Mr. Lombardi to start looking for a new job because of a dissatisfaction by some university officials and by business leaders. No specific complaints against Mr. OKeefe were ever lodged publicly, and business leaders around Louisiana voiced support for him. Before taking the chancellors job, Mr. OKeefe was the administrator for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: A Transformation Is a Bit of a Stretch
description: OVER the holidays I visited my fathers photography portrait studio.

title: In the Math of Mergers, Airlines Fail
description: Airline stocks rallied last week on news that Delta Air Lines was mulling a takeover of either United Airlines or Northwest Airlines, suggesting that many investors think airline mergers are a brilliant idea.

title: European Antitrust Regulators Raid Large Drug Makers
description: Antitrust regulators on Wednesday raided big European drug makers as part of an investigation into whether patents and lawsuit settlements are being manipulated to keep generic products off the market.

title: Newly Released
description: Each book on this months newly released list has a secret at its heart, whether its one held between lovers, friends, or parents and children. For the characters in these novels, what is hidden is liberating, destructive or, most often, both.

title: 61 Arrested in a Sting on Car Fraud
description: A Queens chop shop operated by undercover detectives in a sting operation aimed at exposing car insurance fraud has led to the arrests of 61 suspects, including a city police officer and several other government workers, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

title: Race and Politics
description: After watching the subject of race intrude on the primaries last week, and become even more prominent this week, we were relieved that Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama called a truce Tuesday night.

title: Extracting Survivors Stairway for a Home at the 9/11 Museum
description: With the new World Trade Center rising clamorously around it, the last standing vestige of the old World Trade Center is about to be uprooted.

title: In South Carolina, the Campaign Mud Arrived Before Santa
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  On the bloody political battlefields of South Carolina, where memories of the brutal attacks on Senator John McCain in 2000 are still fresh, there are already signs of nasty and false attacks against other candidates as the presidential campaigns descend on this state.

title: Taking Life Philosophically, One Heartache at a Time
description: Sandy Stewart and Bill Charlap turned the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel into a meditation room on Tuesday evening. As Ms. Stewart, a sphinxlike oracle planted on the clubs tiny platform stage, sang My Ship, accompanied on piano by Mr. Charlap, this Kurt Weill-Ira Gershwin standard with its Freudian imagery of a womans love hoarded like a priceless treasure, assumed a Homeric dimension. Ms. Stewart became Penelope patiently awaiting the return of Odysseus, while Mr. Charlaps gleaming piano hinted at the rubies, jam and spice under guard.

title: U.N. Says Algeria Ignored Security Requests Before Bombing
description: UNITED NATIONS  A senior United Nations official said Wednesday that the Algerian government had ignored repeated requests to close off the streets outside the organizations building in Algiers in the months before a suicide car bombing there last month killed 17 staff members.

title: Bush Lauds Egypt Leader, Avoiding Record on Dissent
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt  President Bush lavished praise on President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt on Wednesday, emphasizing the countrys role in regional security and the Israeli-Palestinian peace process while publicly avoiding mention of the governments actions in jailing or exiling opposition leaders and its severe restrictions on opposition political activities.

title: Clinton Seeks Blend of Policy and Persona
description: RENO, Nev.  There has been Commander in Chief Hillary Rodham Clinton, the steely leader who, voters were assured, would destroy terrorists and be Thatcher-like tough.

title: Bike Parking Lot, With Attendant, Is Planned for Midtown
description: City officials have been trying to create more places where New Yorkers can ride their bikes safely, but finding secure places to park them is an enduring problem.

title: Researchers Find a Bias Toward Upbeat Findings on Antidepressants
description: The makers of antidepressants like Prozac and Paxil never published the results of about a third of the drug trials that they conducted to win government approval, misleading doctors and consumers about the drugs true effectiveness, a new analysis has found.

title: Research Links New Virus to Rare Form of Skin Cancer
description: Scientists have discovered a new virus and strongly linked it with the most aggressive form of skin cancer, they reported in a scientific journal on Thursday.

title: Video Store in a Web-Connected Box Bulks Up Its Storage
description: The Vudu box, introduced last fall as a networked device to deliver high-quality movies to home theater systems, now comes in a supersize version. The new Vudu XL packs a terabyte of storage space under its stylish black hood  enough to store hundreds of digitized movies right on the TV altar.

title: Gizmos, Gadgets and Steve Jobs, Too
description: Its a rock concert! Its a pep rally! Its a news conference!

title: Honoring the Brave and the Rare
description: JERICHO, N.Y.

title: OTB Agency Announces Plan to Halt Operations
description: Seeking to pressure state lawmakers for a larger share of horse racing revenues, New York Citys Off-Track Betting Corporation unveiled a contingency plan yesterday to close its entire operation by summer. The move would mean more than 1,500 layoffs and the shuttering of about 70 betting locations across the five boroughs.

title: Antidoping Officials  Give Baseball Leaders Failing Grade
description: Leaders of two major Olympic antidoping agencies criticized Major League Baseball on Wednesday for what they termed baffling and frustrating responses to recommendations by George J. Mitchell in testimony before a House oversight committee.

title: From Hard Knocks to Crunch Time: Packers Grant Began Career as Giant
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The new assistant football coach reported for work at Queen of Peace High School in North Arlington, N.J., before the 2006 season. Players there knew only the basics in his biography: starred at Don Bosco Prep, played at Notre Dame, spent the 2005 season on the Giants practice squad.

title: A Storybook Life in Red Brick
description: Somerset, Va.

title: $300 to Learn Risk of Prostate Cancer
description: A combination of common and minor variations in five regions of DNA can help predict a mans risk of getting prostate cancer, researchers reported Wednesday.

title: Footnotes
description: Zac Efron, 20, who starred as Troy Bolton in two Disney Channel High School Musical movies, underwent an emergency appendectomy on Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. He was hospitalized a day after the announcement that he would appear in the feature film High School Musical 3: Senior Year. ... The period romance Atonement, starring Keira Knightley and James McAvoy, captured a leading 14 nominations, including best picture, actor, actress and director (Joe Wright), when competitors for the British Academy Film Awards were announced on Wednesday. The prizes will be awarded on Feb. 10.

title: When 3rd Place on the Rich List Just Isnt Enough
description: LAS VEGAS  Sheldon G. Adelson, the casino mogul, has seen his personal net worth plummet by more than $15 billion in recent months as Wall Street investors have grown more bearish about the casino companies that are pushing aggressively into Asia.

title: Sundance Could Be a Sellers Bonanza
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The Sundance Film Festival, which opens Thursday night with In Bruges, the playwright Martin McDonaghs film debut, is one of the oddest ecosystems on earth. The festival of independent film transforms this normally quaint little village, one that offers world-class skiing and a lift smack in the middle of town, into a chilly open-air bazaar where you can hear film executives wearing mukluks and goofy hats shout into their cellphones about deal points and marketing commitments.

title: German Law Seeks to Maintain the States Role in Volkswagen
description: FRANKFURT  Three months after being repudiated by Europes highest court, Germany plans to salvage a central provision of a law that safeguards the role of the state in Volkswagen, the nations largest carmaker.

title: Manhattan: Apollo Theater to Expand
description: The Apollo Theater in Harlem is scheduled to close in January 2010 for a major expansion, which is scheduled to last nine months. After a bruising conflict that began in the late 1990s  in which a lawsuit against the Apollo by the state attorney general was narrowly averted  a new management team was installed in June 2003. The new leadership has successfully completed renovation of the lobby, the seats, the facade and the famous Apollo sign in front. The addition will add 4,000 square feet of usable space by moving offices elsewhere. Officials also plan a Walk of Fame out front. About $51.5 million of the needed $96 million has been raised, and public appeals are planned for the rest.

title: Asian Stocks Fall Sharply
description: TOKYO  Asian shares fell on Wednesday as burgeoning subprime loan problems in the United States and soft economic data provoked international fears that the worlds largest economy may enter a recession and drag down smaller economies with it.

title: U.S. Suggests Embassy Car in Lebanon Was Target
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An American Embassy vehicle was apparently the target of a bombing on Tuesday that killed three civilians and wounded about 20 others just outside Beirut, the State Department said Wednesday.

title: Basking in the Glow of Energy-Saving Lights
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Plunges More Than 300 Points on Grim Outlook
description: The year is not starting off well on Wall Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts last Thursday about Overture Films misstated the amount of its financing and bank loans. It has $325 million in financing, not $225 million, and its bank loans total $225 million, not $125 million. The article also misidentified the writer of Mad Money, an Overture film that is to open on Friday. The screenwriter was Glenn Gers  not Callie Khouri, who directed the film. (Go to Article)

title: For Schubert, a Sad Tale Was the Best for Winter
description: Winterreise, Schuberts 24-song masterpiece of shivery gloom and disappointment, comes to us in a variety of colors. A few days ago Christine Schfer sang it at the Rose Theater as a soprano. Not too many years ago Christa Ludwig sent it our way as a mezzo-soprano. Winterreise came to the postwar record-listening public mainly by way of baritones and basses, not because theirs were the more suitable keys but because most of the best lieder singers at that time happened to have lower voices.

title: Manhattan: Plans in Case of Rail Strike
description: The regions public transit agencies are drawing up contingency plans in case Amtrak workers strike in two weeks, which would force commuters in New Jersey and on Long Island to find other ways to get into Manhattan. Amtrak controls Pennsylvania Station, the Manhattan terminus for New Jersey Transit and Long Island Rail Road trains. Amtrak and unions representing about 7,500 workers have been in talks for eight years; on Jan. 4 a presidential panel recommended that the railroad pay $62 million in back wages. If the sides fail to agree by months end and Congress does not intervene, workers could strike.

title: Head of Canadian Nuclear Regulator Fired
description: OTTAWA  Politicians and academics on Wednesday criticized the late night firing by the Conservative government of the head of Canadas nuclear regulatory agency as a political attack on independent agencies.

title: Albany: Voting Machine Plan Approved
description: A federal judge has approved the State Board of Elections latest plan for bringing New York into compliance with federal voting laws. New York is years behind federal deadlines to comply with the Help America Vote Act, which was enacted after the contested 2000 presidential elections to ensure better vote-counting accuracy and access for the disabled. On Wednesday, Judge Gary L. Sharpe of Federal District Court gave the state permission to follow through on plans to come into compliance. If the state meets the agreed-upon timeline, voting machines accessible to the disabled will be available in every polling place around the state by Novembers elections. The state would then replace all pull-lever machines with high-tech machines by the fall 2009 elections.

title: Brad Renfro, Who Portrayed Witness in The Client, Dies at 25
description: Brad Renfro, the former child star who played a witness to a mob lawyers suicide in the 1994 legal thriller The Client and a suburban youth tutored in evil by an elderly Nazi war criminal in the 1998 film Apt Pupil, was found dead Tuesday morning in his Los Angeles home. He was 25.

title: Spinning Out Into the Pileup on the Information Superhighway
description: In Against the Machine, the swaggeringly abrasive cultural critic Lee Siegel pays a visit to Starbucks. He sits down. He looks around. And he finds himself surrounded by Internet zombies, laptop-addicted creatures who have so grievously lost their capacity for human interaction that social space has been contracted into isolated points of wanting, all locked into separate phases of inwardness. How long until they wake up and smell the coffee?

title: Manhattan: School Trip Under Scrutiny
description: City investigators are examining whether officials at Stuyvesant High School followed proper procedures in the planning and aftermath of a trip to a New Hampshire sporting event that left at least one student with serious injuries. The Associated Press reported that on Saturday, a van carrying members of Stuyvesants girls track team and driven by the teams coach overturned, leaving one student paralyzed. Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the New York City school system, said on Wednesday that Stuyvesants principal, Stanley Teitel, had notified him of the accident that afternoon. Mr. Condon said he was looking at the issue of whether there was school permission for the trip, as well as at the delay in reporting it to us. Mr. Teitel did not return a telephone call seeking comment.

title: Taped Calls Key in Trial of Former General Re Executives
description: Elizabeth Monrad, a former chief financial officer of the General Reinsurance Corporation, has a joyous laugh. But her merriment sounded a bit sinister on secretly taped phone conversations played to a packed courtroom last week in an unusual corporate fraud trial.

title: A Console Plays the Classics, Like Old-School Sonic and Mario
description: The holidays are long gone and the bloom is already fading on that hot new game console. What is a gamer to do? The Gen-X Game Console System, which looks like a cross between a sandwich maker and an old-fashioned answering machine, is here to give new life to the games of decades past.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Architecture by Ban

title: Even at Home, Backers Worry About Giuliani
description: For months, the Republican establishment in New York and New Jersey marched nearly in lock step behind Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former hometown mayor they were confident would become their partys nominee for president.

title: Quarterly Income Slips at JPMorgan, Ending Record Year but Hinting at Concerns
description: JPMorgan Chase said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter net income dropped 34 percent as problems stemming from the housing downturn widened in both its investment banking and consumer businesses.

title: For Squash Fans, an Ideal Final
description: Ramy Ashour, the 20-year-old squash champion, stood amid the throngs in Grand Central Terminal, thousands of miles from his Cairo home, but he looked at ease. He had won the Bear Stearns Tournament of Champions by beating James Willstrop, 11-7, 11-10 (3-1), 11-9.

title: Health Care Is a Big Concern for Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS  Voters in Nevada fret about the economy. Many are disquieted by the war. They worry about taxes, the federal threat of a nuclear waste site in their midst, immigration and gun rights.

title: Mr. Right
description: Washington

title: With This Bridge Device, Songs Can March Directly From One iPod to Another
description: If a friends digital music collection leaves you with playlist envy, instant gratification is one step closer. MiShare lets music connoisseurs swap files between iPods on the fly.

title: U.S. Releases Aid for Heating Costs
description: The federal government released $450 million in emergency funds on Wednesday to help provide relief to low-income homeowners struggling with the rising cost of heating their homes. The money, from contingency funds allocated to the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program, is supposed to help defray utility costs during periods of extreme weather or unusually high oil prices. In New York State, the average price of home heating oil has been above $3.50 a gallon, more than a third higher than it was a year ago. About $82.3 million of the federal money, or about 18 percent, will go to New York State, said Senator Charles E. Schumer. The program is administered by the federal Department of Health and Human Services and, on the state level, by the Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance in Albany. Applications are available on the state offices Web site at otda.state.ny.us/main/heap or through county agencies. In New York City, residents can apply for assistance through the citys Human Resources Administration.

title: A Bond Insurer Ousts Its Chief After Taking a Big Write-Down
description: The Ambac Financial Group , the bond insurer, ousted its chief executive Wednesday, cut the dividend 67 percent and said it planned to raise more than $1 billion to preserve its AAA credit rating after announcing the biggest write-down ever taken by a bond insurer.

title: 2nd Arrest Made in Shooting of Georgia Officers
description: A second man was arrested Thursday and at least one more was being sought in suburban Atlanta in connection with the shooting deaths of two police officers early Wednesday morning.

title: Judge Allows Nevada Caucuses to Proceed
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge in Nevada on Thursday turned down a challenge to the state partys plans to hold caucuses Saturday at nine casinos on the Las Vegas Strip. The state teachers union had filed a lawsuit challenging the fairness of the rules allowing casinos workers to participate in their caucuses, saying it was unfair to other workers in the city.

title: After Losing a Leg, a Caregiver Herself Needs Help
description: The accident that cost Maricile Lauture her right leg almost took her life. I am thankful to be alive, she said, sitting in wheelchair at the Trump Pavilion for Nursing and Rehabilitation in Richmond Hill, Queens.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Q. My two very old and healthy Japanese camellias have outgrown their space, but I dont want to remove them. Can I cut them back severely without killing them if I do it right after they bloom this spring?

title: In Trial, Defense Casts Slain Girl, 7, as a Terror
description: Nixzmary Brown may have been only 7 years old when she died, battered and starved, in her familys Brooklyn apartment two years ago. She may have weighed only 36 pounds  the same as a healthy child half her age.

title: Focus Shifts to South Carolina for Romney and Rivals
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The jumbled Republican presidential race shifted Wednesday to South Carolina, where Mitt Romneys rivals aimed fresh criticism at him in an effort to stymie any momentum gained from his victory in the Michigan primary the day before.

title: Navy Helicopter Crashes in Texas, Killing 3
description: A navy helicopter lost control and exploded in a fiery crash in rural Texas on Wednesday night, killing three crew members and sending a fourth to a hospital with life-threatening injuries, the military said.

title: Feds Survey Provides More Indications of Economic Slippage
description: Government reports released on Wednesday provided additional evidence that the economy was slowing amid credit problems and the housing downturn and raised expectations that the Federal Reserve is likely to cut interest rates when it meets this month.

title: Education Push Yields Little for Indias Poor
Account of C.I.A. Tapes Is Challenged
description: WASHINGTON  The former Central Intelligence Agency official who authorized the destruction in 2005 of videotapes documenting harsh interrogation of detainees from Al Qaeda gave the order despite apparently being directed to preserve the tapes, the senior Republican on the House Intelligence Committee said Wednesday.

title: Mayor Plans Budget Cuts, an Aide Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, squeezed by rising costs and sharply falling revenues, plans to cut spending rather than raise taxes to balance the city budget next year, according to an aide familiar with his thinking.

title: Recalling a Champion Who Still Has Lessons to Share
description: One of the best female players of all time, Marilyn Johnson, died last Oct. 31 in Houston. She was 79. Johnson was born in Vermont, obtained a degree in chemistry at Wellesley College and worked for Shell Oil for 33 years.

title: Putting a Guy in His Place
description: Milan

title: As John Madden Might Say, 'This Is Football'
description: Anyone with a high-definition television and bowl exhaustion found themselves blessed with quite the optic gift on New Year's Day: An outdoor hockey game played in Buffalo as snow fell gently onto the ice. NBC couldn't have planned it better had they pulled a China and tried to manipulate the weather using the famous Beijing Weather Modification Office's cloud-seeding aircraft, artillery and rockets, which fire chemicals into the air. There's something about snow, sports and television.

title: How a Japanese Empress Inspired an American Literary Prince
description: By most standards John Burnham Schwartz enjoyed a charmed start to his writing life. His first novel, Bicycle Days, about a young Yale graduate who goes to live in Japan, grew out of his senior thesis at Harvard and was published on his 24th birthday, to strong reviews and a shower of attention.

title: Italy: Justice Minister Resigns
description: Italys contentious justice minister, Clemente Mastella, resigned amid corruption allegations against him, his wife and roughly 30 other people, including politicians in the southern region of Campania. Italian news reports said the investigation centered on corruption in a local health care system. Mr. Mastella is the head of a small Catholic political party, and his resignation adds another element of instability to the fragile center-left government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi.

title: Rochester: Accord on Toxic Waste Site
description: Bausch & Lomb, DuPont, Eastman Kodak and Xerox are among eight private and public entities that will reimburse New York State nearly $1.6 million for cleaning up their hazardous waste, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, above, said on Wednesday. The state filed a lawsuit in 2005 after having to pay to clean up the Rochester Fire Academy, a hazardous waste site where the six companies, along with the University of Rochester and Monroe County, disposed of hazardous waste between 1954 and 1980. David Cook, a lawyer for the various entities, criticized Mr. Cuomos portrayal of them as polluters. The Rochester Fire Academy was opened in 1954 to train firefighters in handling a range of hazards. During its operation, the companies, university and county sent solvents, petroleum products and other substances to the site for training exercises.

title: McCain Parries a Reprise of 2000 Smear Tactics
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Volunteers making telephone calls for Senator John McCain in South Carolina last weekend noticed something odd: Four people contacted said in remarkably similar language that they opposed Mr. McCain for president because of his 1980 divorce from his first wife, Carol, who raised the couples three children while Mr. McCain was a prisoner of war in Vietnam.

title: Tiptoeing Around the Olive Branch
description: WASHINGTON  It is a testament to the decline in party relations in the House that a simple private meeting Wednesday between Democratic and Republican leaders to discuss an economic stimulus plan was treated as remarkable.

title: Mexico: U.S. Vows Tougher Controls on Guns
description: Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey, in his first official trip outside the United States, announced a crackdown on the illegal flow of firearms from the United States to Mexico. He said that more special agents and investigators would be deployed along the Southwest border and that new tracing technology would be set up in American consulates throughout Mexico in an attempt to quell the drug-related gun violence in Mexico. He referred to Mexicos narcotics dealers as drug terrorists because of a rash of police shootings.

title: The Athlete's Heart
description: The hearts of highly trained, competitive athletes are different from yours and mine. They're bigger, pump slower, and often churn out strange results during routine electrocardiograms (EKG), a test that assesses heart rhythm. These abnormalities have been dismissed for the most part as benign, adaptations to strenuous exercise. But a study published last week in the New England Journal of Medicine questions that wisdom.

title: A Row Over Renovations at the Junior League
description: It was a real estate story that many New Yorkers can identify with. The womens club and charity known as the New York Junior League set out to do renovations  in this case, to its lovely town house in the heart of the Upper East Side  and soon the original plans expanded, along with the expense.

title: March of Dimes Renames a Fund-Raiser
description: The March of Dimes, one of the nations oldest nonprofit groups, is changing the name of Walk America, its biggest fund-raising event, to March for Babies as part of an effort to increase public awareness of its mission.

title: A Suburb Looks Nervously at Its Urban Neighbor
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio  A week after six black teenagers nearly beat her husband to death, Marybeth McDermott looked out her big living room window at the neighborhood she loves, pursed her lips, then looked away.

title: Generation Me vs. You Revisited
description: IN each of the following pairs, respondents are asked to choose the statement with which they agree more:

title: And Now for a Close-Up
description: AS TVs grow ever larger, viewers sit farther and farther back from the screen for the more theatrical experience.

title: Albany: Con Ed Criticized for Explosion
description: State utility regulators said on Wednesday that Consolidated Edison had probably not managed its underground steam system properly before an explosion last summer. After reviewing utility consultant reports on the July 18 accident, in which a pressure buildup ruptured a pipe near Grand Central Terminal, the State Public Service Commission said the company was, or should have been, aware of unsafe conditions, particularly at that location. One woman died of a heart attack while running from the area, and two other people were seriously hurt. The commission told Con Ed that if it did not prove within 10 days that adequate system surveillance and response procedures were in place before the explosion, that the regulators will start an investigation that could ultimately bar the company from passing the repair costs on to consumers.

title: Queens: Man Charged as Fake Doctor
description: A Queens man has been charged with illegally practicing medicine and endangering the life of a patient by injecting a substance that disfigured the mans face. William Ramirez-Concepcion is accused of administering injections in January 2006 to a 46-year-old Manhattan man to correct the sunken appearance of his face, prosecutors said. They said the patient suffered pain, swelling, redness and lumps under his skin, and required operations to correct the condition.

title: Revising a Name, but Not a Familiar Slogan
description: MORE than 35 years after its debut, the slogan for the United Negro College Fund, A Mind Is a Terrible Thing to Waste, remains one of the most recognized in American advertising history.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about a bomb that exploded next to an American Embassy vehicle in Beirut misstated the history of attacks on American interests in Lebanon. The attack was not the first one targeted at Americans since the 1983 truck bombing that killed 241 American service members at the United States Marine barracks in Beirut. There have been other attacks since on American interests and on Americans in Lebanon.

title: Urban Schools Aiming Higher Than Diploma
description: BOSTON  At Excel High School, in South Boston, teachers do not just prepare students academically for the SAT; they take them on practice walks to the building where the SAT will be given so they wont get lost on the day of the test.

title: An Improved Offer by Oracle Captures BEA Systems
description: Oracle has finally won its prize, the rival BEA Systems, after sweetening the offer by 14 percent, just three months after BEA soundly rejected its original bid.

title: U.S. Releases Aid for Heating Costs
description: The federal government released $450 million in emergency funds on Wednesday to help provide relief to low-income homeowners struggling with the rising cost of heating their homes.

title: Good Decision on Tribal Casinos
description: Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne made exactly the right call when he recently denied permission to 11 Indian tribes around the country to acquire more land in order to build casinos.

title: Turmoil at World Bank as Antifraud Chief Quits
description: WASHINGTON  Six months after taking over as president of the World Bank, Robert B. Zoellick faced new turmoil on Wednesday over a campaign against corruption in bank lending, with the resignation of the chief of the banks antifraud unit.

title: Federer and Williams Advance, but Not Davenport
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Roger Federer and Venus Williams won in straight sets Thursday against French players who rely much more on their minds than their muscles, but Federer and Williams left radically different impressions on their way to the third round.

title: Milton Wolff, 92, Dies; Anti-Franco Leader
description: Milton Wolff, the last commander of the American volunteers who fought against Franco in the Spanish Civil War and the longtime commander of the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, died Monday in Berkeley, Calif. He was 92.

title: Music World Braces for a Low-Wattage Grammy Night
description: LOS ANGELES  The Grammy Awards on Feb. 10 were supposed to be a balm to the ailing music industry, a 50th-anniversary celebration of artistry and longevity at a time of mass layoffs and sharply declining sales. Instead the music world began bracing for the latest havoc from the continuing strike by Hollywood writers, as a stalemate with the Writers Guild of America threatened to force record labels and organizers of the Grammy Awards to proceed with a show with severely diminished star wattage.

title: Eliot Prize Is Awarded
description: The English poet Sean OBrien has won the 2007 T. S. Eliot Prize for The Drowned Book, The Guardian of London reported. Established in 1993 to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the Book Poetry Society and to honor the groups founding poet, Eliot, the award goes to the author of the best collection of poetry by an individual to be published in Britain or Ireland. Mr. OBrien, a professor of creative writing at Newcastle University, received a check for 10,000 ($19,600) in ceremonies on Monday night at the Wallace Collection in London. Last years winner was Seamus Heaney.

title: Making iTunes Behave on a Mac
description: Q. Every time I put a blank CD into my Mac, iTunes pops up, even if I just want to burn photos to the disc. How can I burn the pictures?

title: Foxy Brown Wants Out
description: The rapper Foxy Brown, right, citing concerns that damaged hearing could affect her career, appealed to a judge to let her out of prison, Reuters reported. In a four-page handwritten letter to Judge Melissa Jackson of Manhattan Criminal Court, Ms. Brown, 29, whose real name is Inga Marchand, said, I ask you to please take into consideration that my health is in jeopardy. Ms. Brown was sentenced in October 2006 to three years probation for assaulting two nail salon stylists over a $20 manicure, but in September she was sentenced to a year in jail when the judge decided that she had not taken probation seriously. In October, the authorities said, she received 76 days in isolation after a shoving match with another inmate and refusing to take a drug test. In a formal appeal submitted on Tuesday, Ms. Browns lawyer, Laura Dilimetin, said the only doctor who had treated Ms. Browns right ear successfully for profound hearing loss and complications arising from a surgical electronic implant is in California. Ms. Dilimetin said further damage to Ms. Browns hearing will have dire consequences on her ability to maintain her profession and livelihood.

title: Modernist Chicagos Voice of Dissent
description: FOR most of the last century, the official mantra of the Chicago architecture community has been less is more.

title: Accords on U.S. Missile Shield Are Taking Shape, Czech Says
description: BERLIN  The Czech Republic and the United States are within months of signing three framework agreements on the deployment of the Pentagons missile shield, Karel Schwarzenberg, the Czech foreign minister, said Wednesday.

title: Town Told to Turn Over Land for Fence
description: A federal judge ordered the Texas border city of Eagle Pass to turn over 233 acres temporarily to the federal government so it can build a fence to thwart illegal immigration. The judge, Alia Moses Ludlum of Federal District Court, made the ruling on Monday, the same day the Justice Department sued for access to the land. Judge Ludlum ordered the city to surrender the land by Tuesday. Mayor Chad Foster said the ruling seemed a little heavy handed, adding that city attorneys had been working to grant an easement for work on the fence.

title: Applications to Colleges Are Breaking Records
description: Applications to selective colleges and universities are reaching new heights this year, promising another season of high rejection rates and dashed hopes for many more students.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Mimicking Adult Swim Cartoon Series, Designers May Have Gone Too Far
description: Normally one attributes bad video game design to general incompetence, but in the case of the adventure game Harvey Birdman, Attorney at Law, one has to consider the possibility that its gameplay is an effort to replicate the disjointed, purposely dopey style of the animated TV series on which it is based.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Indicted in Islamic Charity Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  A former Republican congressman from Michigan was indicted Wednesday on federal charges of money laundering and obstruction of justice. The allegations involve his work as a lobbyist for an Islamic charity accused of illegally funneling about $130,000 to an Afghan warlord considered a terrorist by the United States government.

title: The Day the Internet Stood Still
description: I NEVER thought Id pay $174.95 a month just for an Internet connection. Im cheap. Instead, I signed up for my cable companys three-way service  Internet, phone and cable TV  for under $200 a month.

title: Giants Tollefson Started as Packers Final Pick
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Dave Tollefson thought back to a still-young football career and the barriers between high school and his current job as a rookie defensive end for the Giants.

title: Tip of the Week: How to Reduce Scrolling
description: If your finger is tired of turning the wheel in the middle of a computer mouse to roll through a page, press down on the scroll-wheel button. Arrows appear and you scroll just by moving the mouse up and down.

title: Dont Tie the Next Presidents Hands
description: President Bush is discussing a new agreement with Baghdad that would govern the deployment of American troops in Iraq. With so many Americans adamant about bringing our forces home as soon as possible, a sentiment we strongly share, Mr. Bush must not be allowed to tie the hands of his successor and ensure the countrys continued involvement in an open-ended war.

title: Housing Starts at 16-Year Low
description: New home construction fell again in December as builders scramble to cut back in the face of rising inventories and fewer orders. The drop-off is likely to hurt businesses that serve the housing industry, which economists do not expect to bottom out until the middle of the year.

title: Major Gift for Museum
description: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art said on Wednesday that a foundation established by the collectors Jane and Marc Nathanson had agreed to donate $10 million to the institution for purchases and exhibitions of contemporary art. Officials at the museum added that a first-floor gallery in its new building, the Broad Contemporary Art Museum, opening on Feb. 16, would be named for the Nathansons, who live in Los Angeles. Mrs. Nathanson is a museum trustee and a psychotherapist, and Mr. Nathanson is a cable television and investment company executive. In what was largely viewed as a setback for the museum, the financier and philanthropist Eli Broad disclosed this month that he did not intend to donate any of his contemporary art to the museum. The museum had seemed a logical recipient because many of Mr. Broads artworks will be displayed there, and he has donated $50 million toward the new building and $10 million toward acquisitions.

title: Sun to Buy Swedish Software Firm for $1 Billion
description: Sun Microsystems, the large American seller of open-source software, said Wednesday that it would spend $1 billion to buy MySQL, a Swedish company that is the world leader in open-source database software used by Internet powers like Google, Yahoo, MySpace and YouTube.

title: Italian Charm for Sale
description: AFTER the clobbering Italian fashion has taken of late  in some accounts for its inability to produce a new generation of hot designers, in others for using underpaid Chinese immigrants to make overpriced handbags  Isabella Rossellini is making a stand for Milan.

title: Under the Radar Festival in Review
description: TERMINUS Public Theater Through Sunday

title: A.M.D. Posts Loss, Writing Down Acquisition
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Advanced Micro Devices reported its fifth consecutive quarterly loss Thursday as it struggled to absorb the huge cost of its purchase of ATI Technologies, a graphics chip maker.

title: Manning Appears to Be Evolving Into the Special One
description: Since Thanksgiving, Eli Manning has thrown four passes that were intercepted against the Vikings (three returned for touchdowns), tossed 35 incomplete passes against the Redskins (the most by any N.F.L. quarterback in 40 years), fumbled five times against the Bills and became the player that the Giants always hoped he would be.

title: Coal Company Hit With E.P.A.s Largest Civil Penalty
description: The nations fourth largest coal producer, Massey Energy Co., was hit Thursday with a $20 million fine, the largest civil penalty ever levied by the federal government for a violation of this type under the Clean Water Act.

title: Blue Collar and 2 Gloves for Rookie on Tour
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  The golfer they call Two Gloves stood next to Yogi Berra on the ninth tee at SilverRock Resort on Wednesday, leaning on his driver and watching John Daly putt for a birdie on the first green about 40 yards away. There was stark contrast and strange symmetry to the scene, played out on a cloudy desert afternoon in the first round of the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: Two Views in the White House on an Economic Fix
description: WASHINGTON  As President Bush weighs a stimulus package to jump-start the sagging economy, a debate has broken out inside the White House over how hard to push Congress to make Mr. Bushs tax cuts permanent  a priority for the president, but one that Democrats say would kill the plan before it is even considered.

title: An Indie Company Counting on a Future Takes 3 Films to Sundance
description: LOS ANGELES  This fall, with the writers strike looming, the producers of a film about Harvey Milk  the barrier-breaking, openly gay San Francisco city supervisor who was assassinated in 1978  raced to lock in deals with stars like Sean Penn. As the budget of Milk, to be directed by Gus Van Sant, ticked upward to around $20 million, its bankroller, Sidney Kimmel Entertainment, withdrew.

title: Bomb Attack by Woman Near Mosque Kills 8 in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A woman carried out a suicide bombing near a Shiite mosque in Diyala Province on Wednesday, killing at least eight people. The attack provoked Shiite militiamen to use mortars against a nearby Sunni village in retaliation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts last Thursday about Overture Films misstated the amount of its financing and bank loans. It has $325 million in financing, not $225 million, and its bank loans total $225 million, not $125 million. The article also misidentified the writer of Mad Money, an Overture film that is to open on Friday. The screenwriter was Glenn Gers  not Callie Khouri, who directed the film.

title: South Koreas Sunshine Policy Dims
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The president-elect on Wednesday proposed eliminating a government agency that has long led efforts to build reconciliation with North Korea, but which he has accused of being too soft on the Communist government there.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $6,607,932

title: Do My Breast Implants Have a Warranty?
description: A NAKED woman, her left arm strategically draped over her nipples, grins beatifically at readers in an advertisement for cosmetic surgery that equates breast implants with a more durable commodity: jewels.

title: Death and Decorating
description: AMY REDFORD, actress, director and youngest child of Robert, is taking the first film she has directed to the Sundance Film Festival this week. It is called The Guitar, and it deals with a self-effacing young woman, drab as a dead leaf in February, who, told she has two months to live, leaves her basement apartment, rents a New York City loft and maxes out her credit cards, furnishing it with opulent and luxurious stuff: one-of-a-kind rugs from Carini Lang; chandeliers that sell for $2,500 a pop; and, finally, the creatively fulfilling guitar of the title. Its kind of a shopaholics version of The Bucket List, with Jonathan Adler designing the Bucket.

title: Canseco Swaps Publishers for His Sequel to Juiced
description: A little more than two months before he expects to have his second book in stores, Jos Canseco is switching publishers for Vindicated, his promised sequel to the incendiary best seller Juiced: Wild Times, Rampant Roids, Smash Hits and How Baseball Got Big.

title: Head of World Bank Fraud Unit Resigns
description: WASHINGTON  Six months after taking over as president of the World Bank, Robert B. Zoellick faced new turmoil on Wednesday over a campaign against corruption in bank lending, with the resignation of the chief of the banks antifraud unit.

title: Hard-Line Legislator Quits Israeli Coalition Over Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Angered over the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, a hawkish and outspoken Israeli legislator withdrew his party from the governing coalition on Wednesday, leaving Prime Minister Ehud Olmert with a significantly slimmer majority in Parliament.

title: Pete Candoli, Jazz Trumpeter, Dies at 84
description: Pete Candoli, a jazz trumpeter who made his mark as a high-note specialist in the big-band era and went on to become one of the busiest studio musicians in Hollywood, died on Friday at his home in Studio City, Calif. He was 84.

title: Justices Uphold New Yorks Judge System
description: WASHINGTON  The challenge to New Yorks method for choosing candidates to run in judicial elections ended in failure at the United States Supreme Court on Wednesday when not a single justice accepted the plaintiffs claim that the system was unconstitutional.

title: Political TV: Fox News On Super Bowl Sunday
description: Political pundits are fond of using sports metaphors during election coverage. And sports events are sometimes treated with the same weight as a presidential election. Why not merge the two?

title: A Love Letter
description: Will Okun, who traveled to Africa with Times columnist Nick Kristof in June, now teaches English and photography in a Chicago school. On Kristof's blog, "On the Ground," Okun explains his love for Chicago high school basketball, and especially legendary coach Dorothy Gaters and her Marshall Commandos.

title: Carlsen and Aronian in Lead at Corus Going Into Round 5
'Close Encounters'
description: This exhibit encompasses Irving Penns work from the 1940s through portraits published in The New Yorker in 2006.

title: New Shows, New Eyes
description: Photos from shows in the 2008 Under the Radar theater festival.

title: A.F.C. Links: San Diegos Side of the Story
description: With all this talk about cold weather (the forecasts for Green Bay and Foxborough are largely unchanged since we last checked, by the way), why dont we warm ourselves up by checking up on San Diego, where the sun is shining and its always 70 degrees.

title: King Rat
description: From the Associated Press:

title: Men's Wear in Milan
description: In Milan, Prada unveils a new man. Hes already housebroken.

title: Buyouts Create Jobs, Industry Study Says
description: A new study funded by the private equity industry says that buyouts have resulted in significant gains in employment over the past several years.

title: Federal-Mogul Names Icahn as Chairman
description: Federal-Mogul, the auto parts supplier that emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy last month, named the billionaire investor and shareholder Carl C. Icahn as nonexecutive chairman on Wednesday.

description: Ireland is now alive with enthusiasm for entrepreneurs, who seemingly rank just below rock stars in popularity.

description: Airline stocks rallied last week on news that Delta Air Lines was mulling a takeover of either United Airlines or Northwest Airlines, suggesting that many investors think airline mergers are a brilliant idea.

title: With Business Objects Deal Done, SAP May Seek a New One
description: At a coming-out party Wednesday for SAPs acquisition of Business Objects, executives left the door open for more big deals.

title: JPMorgans Stock Surges Despite Profit Drop
description: Investors cheered JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday, underscoring how, in these troubled times on Wall Street, a drop in profits can still make a firm look like a champion  mostly because the drop wasnt worse.

title: Suns Deal Nixes MySQLs Hot I.P.O.
description: Sun Microsystems $1 billion deal for MySQL put the kibosh on what was one of the years most anticipated tech offerings.

title: After BEA Deal, Icahn Pats Himself on the Back
description: Carl C. Icahn seemed pleased with himself Tuesday after BEA Systems agreed to a sweetened offer from Oracle.

title: BlackRock Co-Founder Ends Up at Soros
description: Soros Fund Management has appointed a BlackRock co-founder, who left last month to start his own fund, as its new chief investment officer.

title: S.E.C. Says C.B.O.T. Has No Claim on Chicago Options Board
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that former members of the Chicago Board of Trade, which was acquired by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange last year, could not claim a share of the Chicago Board of Options Exchange once it becomes a for-profit company.

title: Thomas H. Lee Offers to Help Refill MoneyGrams Coffers
description: Shares of MoneyGram International traded down sharply for the second successive day after the money transfer company said it was negotiating a capital infusion from a Boston buyout firm.

title: Kellogg Snaps Up United Bakers
description: Kellogg said Thursday it had purchased a Russian biscuit and cereal maker the United Bakers Group, to expand its operations. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Credit Suisse to Expand Private Bank, Report Says
description: The Credit Suisse Group bucked a financial sector trend on Thursday, announcing a worldwide expansion plan for its flagship private banking arm, Reuters reported.

title: The Outlook for Open Source Deal-Making
description: With deals for open-source software companies heating up, The 451 Group asks whether Oracle, IBM, Novell and other acquirers will push the level of open-source mergers and acquisitions to another record in 2008.

title: Has CoBe Walked Off With Pradas Dacks?
description: The Italian luxury retailer Prada Group has sold a Canadian footwear company, Dacks Shoes, to a New York private equity firm, CoBe Capital for undisclosed terms, according to The Deal.com.

title: Bear Stearns Names Head of Securities Unit
description: As Wall Street continues to reshuffle the decks, Bear Stearns has moved its treasurer, Michael Minikes, into anew role as chief executive of Bear Stearns Securities, the unit that handles the investment banks clearing and prime brokerage businesses.

title: Deutsche to Beef Up Commodities Unit
description: Deutsche Bank , Germanys largest bank, plans to increase its commodities staff by 15 percent to 25 percent this year as record prices for oil, gold and soybeans increase the potential for profits.
