description: Is Air-France-KLM  planning to throw some cash Delta Air Lines way?

title: Macklowes Pain Could Be Good News for Blackstone
description: Things arent looking so good for Harry B. Macklowe, the property developer who raced from lender to lender to round up a record-breaking $1.4 billion to buy the General Motors Building.

title: Porsche Displeased by Germanys New Volkswagen Law
description: A speed bump arose Wednesday in Porsches plans to drive off into the sunset with Volkswagen.

title: Is WiMAX Back on Venture Capitalists Wish Lists?
description: Six years into its painfully slow emergence into the telecommunications mainstream, WiMAX, a wireless broadband technology with which venture capitalists have had a fitful relationship, seems to be picking up steam among investors again, according to the Red Herring.

title: Merrill Lost $9.8 Billion in Fourth Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch on Thursday reported a $9.8 billion loss for the fourth quarter, the largest quarterly loss in its 93-year-history, as troubles in the subprime mortgage market took another big bite out of its balance sheet.

title: Readers Weigh In on Year-End Career Exercise
description: Since this blog started a few months ago, few posts have stirred up as much chatter in the comments as the guest post a few weeks ago by the career coach Michael Melcher, offering an exercise intended to help people figure out what to focus on in the coming year. You can read the original post here.

title: When 3rd Place on the Rich List Just Isnt Enough
description: Sheldon G. Adelson, the casino mogul, has seen his personal net worth plummet by more than $15 billion in recent months as Wall Street investors have grown more bearish about the casino companies that are pushing aggressively into Asia.

title: In-Flight Entertainment
description: The Bagger was on the Delta flight from L.A. to Salt Lake City yesterday morning and it was full of industrial strength chatter about Sundance. He heard talk of parties, swag, chef dinners, sponsored concerts, Paris Hilton and fashion houses. Come to think of it, nobody mentioned movies, but maybe he wasnt listening closely enough.

title: Brit Invasion
description: First there was talk of the Brits finding their fizz during awards season at the same time the Americans seemed to be running on empty. Now comes word from the Independent that Sundance is taking on a bit of a mid-Atlantic patina:

title: Buzz Bomb
description: Do you hear that buzzing noise in the background? Thats the sound of the wall of buzz that is about to crest over Park City. IndieWire writes that some movies pick up more crackle than is in their interest, and that it falls to something called buzz managers to make sure that little movies dont get capsized by tsunamis of hype.

title: Nothing Ages Faster Than the Future
description: Sundance may be making big noises about embracing the digital future  its holding a seminar entitled Weboluton in conjunction with the Motion Picture Association  but Wired says the festival folks are just putting futuristic lipstick on a pig, talking the talk, but not walking the walk. As the magazines Sundance blog puts it:

title: The Early Word: McCain Seeks S.C. Redemption
description: Make no mistake, John McCains 2008 South Carolina campaign isnt going to be caught off guard by any smear campaign begun against him.

description: A lot of buzz still surrounds Apple chief Steve Jobs and his keynote address, with David Pogue and CNBC's Melissa Francis.

description: Two intriguing points from Slate blogger Mickey Kaus. The first:

title: Will New Yorks Republicans Be Up for Grabs?
description: Sam Roberts writes in a front-page article today: As Rudolph W. Giuliani has plummeted from first to fourth  or worse  in some national polls, as he finished near the bottom of the pack in the nations earliest primaries, and as his lead evaporated even in Florida, the state on which he has gambled the most time and money, those Republican leaders are verging toward a grim new consensus: If Mr. Giuliani loses in the Florida primary on Jan. 29, they say, he may even have trouble defeating the rivals who are encroaching on his own backyard. (See .)Mayors State of the City Today

title: Merrill Wont Sell Bloomberg, BlackRock Stakes
description: Even before Merrill Lynch announced the worst quarterly loss in its history on Thursday, the firm had already lined up more than $12 billion in fresh capital from outside investors. Depending on whether the securities firm has cleared out all of its subprime-related detritus and how the markets fare, the firm may have to seek yet more financing.

title: An Omnivore Defends Real Food
description: As a health writer, Ive read hundreds of nutrition studies and countless books on diet and eating. And none of these has contained such useful advice as the cover of Michael Pollans latest book, In Defense of Food.

title: National Portrait Gallery Adds Colbert
description: Stephen Colberts mission to insinuate himself into places where he doesnt belong has taken him from the campaign trail to Op-Ed page of The New York Times to, this week, the National Portrait Gallery.

title: Paris Mens Wear | Yves Saint Laurent
description: Its never easy to capture the energy and dynamism of fashion on film, but the Yves Saint Laurent designer Stefano Pilati proved that it can be done. Working in tandem with the up-and-coming actor Simon Woods and Colonel Blimp, a peculiarly named team of video artists from London, Pilati traded the runway for a short video installation Wednesday night that had enough verve and style to keep even the most jaded moviegoers interested. Woods acted out  in one scene, smashing through a glass wall  wearing shiny David-Bowie-in-The-Man-Who-Fell-to-Earth blousons; rich jewel-toned Velvet Goldmine dinner jackets; a woolly lamb overcoat that can go directly from an art opening to the Himalayas; and 70s-inspired suits with cuffed wide-leg trousers. If 50s Americana is more your speed, check out the chunky brothel creepers or the pale yellow sports jacket worn over a baby blue turtleneck. (Trust us, if it worked for Bob Hope, it can work for you.) Pilati neatly tied up the assortment of references with his usual attention to dandyish detail: a silk foulard here, a bit of punkish eye makeup there, and colorfully printed pocket squares just about everywhere.

title: Rarely Seen Ballroom Will Open for Hamill Talk
description: Before there was a downtown, there was the harbor, Pete Hamill declares in Downtown: My Manhattan (Little, Brown & Company, 2004). It is the reason for the citys existence and remains the liquid heart of the city.

title: Cold Play
description: Although it may run contrary to conventional wisdom, exercising in extreme cold causes fewer injuries than exercising in the heat, Gina Kolata writes in The Times today. She writes, "The problem with exercising in the cold, exercise physiologists say, is that people may be hobbled by myths that lead them to overdress or to stop moving, risky things to do."

description: When David Letterman returned to the late-night airwaves with writers two weeks ago, many observers suggested that his scripted advantage could translate to higher ratings for the longtime second-place Late Show.

description: As long-time From the Desk... readers are no doubt aware, I spent the first ten years out of college working on Broadway as an arranger and conductor, killing time while trying to make my way as a composer/lyricist. Those days are long gone now, but from time to time, I still scratch my songwriting itch by writing new words to old melodies.

description: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Scientists have created a living, beating rat heart. Finally, good news for Dick Cheney.

title: He Kept Asking the Prince About His Sister, Paula Abdullah
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Well, congratulations to Mitt Romney. He was the big winner in the Michigan Republican primary. Well, you know his dad used to be governor there, which I think would be inspiration. You know what Im saying? It proves, in America, you dont have to be the wife of a former president to win. Sometimes you can just be the son of a governor.

description: Violence erupts in Kenya as protesters and police clash.

title: Where Is Apples Rental Service for Music?
description: One quick last word on Macworld and what Steve Jobs didnt do. The technology that enables movie rentals also could enable music rentals  or, in other words, a music subscription service like Rhapsody.
The Globes may have come and gone, but some of the more obscure coverage is starting to creep into the public domain.

title: EchoStar-AT&T Deal Still Likely, Analyst Says
description: There are plenty of reasons to be doubtful about recent speculation that AT&T might buy EchoStar, which runs the Dish satellite-television network. For one thing, some believe that, for tax reasons, this months spinoff of EchoStars technology and infrastructure assets puts a two-year kibosh on any EchoStar takeout. Others look to recent sales of EchoStar stock by the companys executives as a bearish signal.

title: Thursday Kickoff: The Rodriguez Saga Continues
description: Rich Rodriguez has taken plenty of hits on the public-relations front recently. Jim Carty of the Ann Arbor News writes that he would help himself if he apologized to West Virginia and paid the $4 million he owes the university.

title: Brook Unbound
description: Defamer deconstructs Juno screenwriter Diablo Codys turn on Oprah and finds a whole bunch of cute.

title: Leahy Endorses Obama
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As he campaigned in California today, Senator Barack Obama collected the long-distance endorsement of a colleague in Washington, adding another senator to the list of those backing his candidacy.

title: The Nostalgic Bill Belichick
description: Bill Belichick may have the best football team in creation, but that doesnt stop the New England Patriots coach from reverting to pure reverie about another great team  the Giants of the 1980s, when Belichick was the defensive coordinator and coached a linebacking corps that was among the best ever.

title: Congress on Steroids
description: On Tuesday, Bud Selig and Donald Fehr, baseballs commissioner and union leader, testified before Congress about steroids in baseball. Roger Clemens and his former trainer, Brian McNamee, are scheduled to testify next month. Do you expect anything good to come out of this Capitol Hill drama, or is it just a bunch of grandstanding?

description: A judge in Ontario today has sentenced the former NHL star Rob Ramage to four years in prison for his role in an automobile accident in December 2003 that claimed the life of Keith Magnuson, another former NHL player.

description: Update: Alliance Data issued a statement this afternoon saying that its deal with Blackstone is on track, on the original terms. The company said that, as a matter of policy, it does not comment on market rumors.

description: Auto enthusiasts over the age of, say, 40 probably remember the muscle car era. They probably remember it fondly, too. It was an era where coupes were king. Chrome was ubiquitous. Colors were loud. And horsepower was still politically correct.

description: SpoutBlog has both the trailer and towel snap for tonights premiere of In Bruges.

title: Googles Earth
description: This is a very quick alert on Googles announcement this morning of $25 million in investments and grants from its moneymaking and philanthropic branches, all aimed at tackling challenges it sees as vital to fostering progress, particularly in the developing world: climate and energy security, education and small business, advancements in technology and information flow to help communities identify and respond to looming threats to health and security (from epidemics to drought).

title: League of Women Voters Looks for a New Home
description: The League of Women Voters of the City of New York, which was founded on June 2, 1919, as an outgrowth of the womens suffrage movement and was the first of what are now 900 state and local leagues across the United States, is about to lose its office on East 33rd Street, its home since 1999, because the building has been sold to a developer and will be torn down to make way for a hotel.

title: Ten That Still Roll
description: Amid the hubbub and hype at Park City, it is pretty easy to forget that Sundance has produced filmed wonders that tilted the rink in permanent ways. Noel Murray and Scott Tobias, over at the A.V. Club, remind everyone that long before Paris and her posse started showing up, Sundance was a dynamo of excellence and innovation.

title: Prosecutors Argue Against Moving Bell Case
description: Prosecutors in Queens are arguing against moving the trial of three detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell, according to in a new court filing [pdf] this morning that challenges the defense teams claims that pretrial publicity has swayed the favor of potential jurors against the detectives. The defense is seeking to move the trial of the officers out of New York City.In the filing, in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, which includes Queens courts, the office of District Attorney Richard A. Brown discounted the results of a public opinion poll conducted by the defense by presenting its own polling statistics that showed that only 35.5 percent of potential jurors report having formed an opinion about this case.

title: Movie Minutes: Taxi to the Dark Side
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Taxi to the Dark Side," a documentary about interrogations in the prisons of Bagram, Abu Ghraib and Guantanamo Bay.

title: Mayor Bloombergs 2008 State of the City Address
description: Following is the prepared text of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs 2008 State of the City address as provided by the mayor's office.

title: World Recession?
description: There is a bubble bursting far from Americas housing market, shown by an index youve probably never heard of.

title: Questions for the Candidates
description: In theory, it should go like this: the more candidates withdraw from the nomination fights in both parties, the cozier and more manageable the debates become, and the better and more illuminating the exchanges. As the debates since New Hampshire have proved, though, the reality doesnt bear this out. The problem is that by this point in a campaign, the candidates have spent so many thousands of hours hammering away at the same points over and over again that theyre practically on autopilot. There are a few sharp comments, a laugh here or there, but mostly the debates devolve into a familiar and unsatisfying contest of wills: moderators try to think up unexpected questions that might force the candidates to speak extemporaneously, while each candidate looks for a way, no matter how tortured, to turn every question into a recital of the same lines we heard in the last 400 debates.

title: Educating India's Poor
description: India is confronting the perils of its failure to educate its citizens, notably the poor.

title: Bloombergs Plan: Tax Cuts, DNA Tests and an End to Social Promotion
description: Updated, 5:10 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his seventh State of the City address this afternoon to make a wide-ranging array of major proposals for his final two years in office, while warning that spending cuts will be needed because the economy appears headed for difficult times.

title: How to Order a Seafood Meal in Sai Kung
description: The Sai Kung Town marina. Photographs by Joyce Hor-Chung Lau

title: CNBC Video: Thain on Merrills Results
description: With Merrill Lynch announcing a $9.8 billion quarterly loss and a bigger write-down tied to subprime mortgages and related instruments, John A. Thain had some explaining to do. Shortly after he spoke with analysts, the firms still-new chief executive spoke with CNBCs Maria Bartiromo on managing risk and how Merrill moves on from here.

title: Purple States: Talking Health Care
description: Purple States citizen reporters Tamara and Elizabeth discuss the high price of health care and how the Republican candidates are addressing the issue.

title: A Feisty Bill Clinton Defends Nevada Lawsuit
description: Updated

title: A New You: Dr. Alan Greene on Parenting and Childrens Health
description: Just how bad are cold medicines for children? What are the early signs of autism? How do you quiet a colicky infant? Dr. Alan Greene is a clinical professor of pediatrics at Stanford University and the founder of parenting Web site drgreene.com. His most recent book, Raising Baby Green, explores environmentally aware approaches to childrens health. You may post your questions below. Please remember that Dr. Greene cannot answer all of them, and he cannot respond to solicitations for personal medical advice. [Eds. note: We are no longer accepting questions.]

title: As John Madden Might Say, This Is Football
description: Anyone with a high-definition television and bowl exhaustion found themselves blessed with quite the optic gift on New Years Day: An outdoor hockey game played in Buffalo as snow fell gently onto the ice. NBC couldnt have planned it better had they pulled a China and tried to manipulate the weather using their famous Beijing Weather Modification Offices cloud-seeding aircraft, artillery and rockets, which fire chemicals into the air. Theres something about snow, sports and television.

title: Diving Into Davos 2008
description: Another year, another high-powered gathering in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Carlyle Adds Telecom and Media Adviser
description: The Carlyle Group, the Washington-based private equity firm, said Thursday that Stephen C. Gray had become a senior adviser to the firms global telecommunications and media group. Mr. Gray is a telecom entrepreneur and former executive at McLeodUSA and MCI.

title: Inside the Giants: Theres Cold and Then There Is Green Bay
description: The Giants better hurry and get to Green Bay, because the temperature forecast for Sunday nights game keeps falling. They are practicing outside at Giants Stadium, where the temperature is 38 degrees. It feels kind of cold. Now, just take that and subtract, oh, about 35 degrees and add a few snow flurries. That is what conditions are expected to be at Lambeau Field.

title: The High Low | The Howling Hex Tote Bag
But he was a great CEO
description: Funny stuff; one member of Congress got confused about the difference between Henry Paulson, who ran Goldman Sachs, and Ben Bernanke, who had the much harder task of running the Princeton Economics Department.

title: When Botanists, Journalists and Google Geeks Collide
description: On Wednesday, a news release circulated with enough attention-getting phrases to tongue-tie a carnival barker:

title: Ratings: Falling Idol, Rising Moon
description: One day after the premiere audience for Foxs American Idol fell 4 million viewers shy of the series 2007 debut, the talent competition slipped even further in the ratings on Wednesday.

title: Snook: Flexible Urban Agility
description: This video provided by Tilmann Schlootz illustrates the concepts at work in his design.

title: Do Retail Investors Matter Anymore?
description: Not as much. The evidence is that companies in the United States no longer automatically turn to the public markets to raise capital, and when they do, the buyers are more often institutional investors rather than Mom and Pop. In this new world, average investors, often termed retail investors, appear to be increasingly less relevant.

title: Fed's Bernanke Speaks to Congress
description: Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke testifies before the House Budget Committee on the state of the economy.

title: How to Rev Up a Slowing Economy
description: As todays 300-plus point drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average suggests, the economy is moving into uncertain times. With growing signs of a recession on the horizon, it seems clear that some sort of fiscal stimulus will be needed.

title: Shanahan Hit May Draw a Fine
description: Buffalo Coach Lindy Ruff railed against Rangers forward Brendan Shanahans cross-check that sent Sabres forward Clarke MacArthur flying into the Rangers goalpost with 9.5 seconds left in the Rangers 2-1 victory Wednesday night, calling for Shanahan to be suspended. The referees did not call a penalty at the time, which was mind-boggling.

title: A Closer Look at the Mayors School Proposals
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his State of the City address to unveil two new education proposals aimed at two groups of students who continue to struggle: eighth graders who are unprepared for high school, and high school students who are unprepared for the working world.The mayor, who has staked his legacy largely on his effort to overhaul the public school system, said that students in the third, fifth and seventh grade rose to the challenge after being faced with new promotion policies based largely on test scores. Mr. Bloomberg said he would now extend that promotion policy to the eighth grade.

title: City Sues Bush Administration Over Heating Standards
description: Updated, 3:16 p.m. | In another sign that local governments are growing impatient with Washingtons timid approach to resolving environmental problems, New York City and three states today joined environmental advocacy groups in suing the Bush administration over new standards for gas-fired furnaces and other home heating appliances. The citys Law Department, along with the states of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York, argue that the new efficiency standards set by the federal Department of Energy last November are far too weak to significantly cut carbon dioxide emissions, or to help lower home heating costs that have hit people in the Northeast especially hard.

title: Thursdays Bunker: Whats Your Ranking?
description: I remember once having a to do list, where I would put in order of importance what needed to get done, keeping in mind what I really wanted to spend my time doing and what I desired to avoid doing. Much like the ratings employed in college sports to determine who is in what football bowl or regional brackets in hockey or basketball tournaments in the United States, I would give a slight edge to the more pleasant things in life.

title: About Merrills Stake in Bloomberg L.P.
description: DealBook reported Thursday morning that John A. Thain, Merrill Lynchs new chief executive, has ruled out a sale of the firms 20 percent stake in Bloomberg L.P. The holding in the financial information giant generated stable cash flow, Mr. Thain asserted by way of explanation.

title: Making predictions is hard
description: especially about the future, and sometimes about the recent past. Will we have a recession? Are we already in one? Nobody knows for sure.

title: My Times Problems
description: Some of our users have informed us that My Times Beta is currently having intermittent trouble with the following:

title: Midwestern Hospitality (Travel Advice)
description: Midwesterners are often viewed as friendlier than your average American.Its good to be skeptical of stereotypes, but some of that generous spirit has come through in the reader comments. A few minutes ago, I cleared one from a reader named Bob Gremley:

title: Reagan and Obama
description: Read Rick Perlstein. Rick is our premier historian of the rise of modern movement conservatism, and knows whereof he speaks.

title: Scent Notes | Versace Eau de Parfum by Versace
description: I saw Donatella Versace on Italian television once when she was asked about her vision. With extravagant gestures, she cried, Lusso, lusso, lusso! (luxury, luxury, luxury), throwing her hands in the air as if seeding a catwalk with bits of cubic zirconia. Versaces perfume licensee, EuroItalia, has faultlessly translated her taste into scent using some of the biggest creative names in the business  Bertrand Duchaufour, Franoise Caron, Francis Kurkdjian, among others; these are some of the best perfumers working and authors in other contexts of very serious olfactory work. Donatella is a master of synthetic luxe, and her perfumes  in particular Bright Crystal and Crystal Noir  are paradigms of the school. Versace Eau de Parfum, however, takes the aesthetic to a new level.

title: Judge Allows Vegas Caucus Sites on the Strip
description: LAS VEGAS A federal judge threw out a lawsuit aimed at shutting down so-called at-large precincts to be set up inside strip casinos for Saturdays Nevada caucuses, insisting that the Nevada Democratic Party has the right to set its rules as it sees fit.

title: Lehman to Cut 1,300 Mortgage Jobs
description: Lehman Brothers on Thursday said it would stop wholesale mortgage lending in the United States because of a continued slump in credit and housing markets, a move that will cut 1,300 jobs and result in a $40 million charge.

title: Giuliani Ad Touts Romneys Praise
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Rudolph W. Giuliani has yet another new ad out in Florida, titled Quotes, featuring the praise of such notable conservatives as Grover Norquist, George Will and  Mitt Romney.

title: Not so fast
description: One assumption in Ben Bernankes testimony today was that if a recession happens, it will be over soon, so stimulus has to come fast or not at all. Its by no means clear that this is right. To be fair, I think its right to caution Congress not to do anything now that wont come in quickly. But both recent history and the nature of our current problem suggest that we may be in for more than a few bad months.

title: The Nevada Stakes for Obama
description: SAN FRANCISCO  So have expectations been raised for Senator Barack Obama in Nevada?

title: Paris Mens Wear | Group Hug
description: It is with nothing but pleasure that The Moment reports on the death of the infantile, ultra-skinny, ankle grazing, Pee-Wee Herman inspired pants. At shows as diverse as Gianfranco Ferr, Yves Saint Laurent and Louis Vuitton, trousers were long (imagine that!) and decidedly full The Anglomania theme that was so prevalent in Florence and Milan continues in Paris: At Yohji Yamamoto, there was enough tartan to outfit a bagpipers convention; Dries van Noten used it more sparingly, on beautiful shirts and slouchy jackets; and what stuffy English gentleman wouldnt want to team his tweedy country blazers with leopard-print bowler hats and tight leather pants, as Jean Paul Gaultier did? Do-it-yourself designer decorator tip of the week: the fake parquet (fauxquet?) runway at Dries Van Noten actually consisted of packing tape strips artfully stuck on the floor At the unheated garage where the ultra-cool Pacific Northwest-inspired Number (N)ine show took place, attendees were offered wool blankets from Portlands hip Ace Hotel to warm up; too bad that security guards snatched them back up as everyone filed out the door. I was prepared to love that show, griped one bedding-deprived editor as he braved the winter drizzle. But now Im hating it. We love it even more.

title: Random Travel Notes: Hong Kong, Bangkok, London
description: I did a bit of schlepping last weekend: Hong Kong-Bangkok-Hong Kong-London. Here are some opinionated travel notes.

title: With The Boys in Paris
description: At this stage of my absence from the blog, I think I should offer only a wildly good story, like I went to Holland to get a pair of custom-made clogs, where I promptly met a man called Fortunato Mannix who promised to give me rubies if I

title: The Boston Bruins: Six Decades of Bad Goaltending
description: All the discussions weve been having about Tim Thomas led us to look back on Boston netminders of years past, and boy, what an undistinguished bunch they are. Not once in all the 42 seasons for which we have NHL save percentage stats has a Bruin led the league in that most important goalkeeping category. That may finally change, as Thomas currently leads the NHL in save percentage, the first Bruin to do so in the 50s, 60s, 70s, 80s, 90s, or 2000s.

title: Crackdown in Kenya
description: The Kenyan police seemed to be ratcheting up pressure against demonstrators and others on Thursday, the second day of renewed opposition protests.

title: Inside the Giants: Strahan Would Rather Be at the Beach
description: Michael Strahan has not decided if he will retire after this season, which could end in three days at Lambeau Field. He will probably wait until mid-spring to decide. But few athletes can turn on the charm and entertain the reporting masses the way Strahan can, and it showed Wednesday afternoon. As they say about comedians, leave them laughing.

title: Charlie Rose Returns To 60 Minutes, This Time On Sundays
description: Charlie Rose, the iconic PBS interviewer, will moonlight as a contributor to the CBS newsmagazine 60 Minutes beginning this season, the network announced Thursday.

title: Time Warner: Download Too Much and You Might Pay $30 a Movie
description: Lets say you buy a new Apple TV because you want to rent high-definition movies. And say you are about to move to Beaumont, Tex. If so, you might wind up paying Time Warner Cable as much as $30 when you download a movie using its high-speed Internet service.

title: In San Diego, Where Its Warmer .
description: Chargers center Nick Hardwick stepped outside the locker room for an interview after practice Wednesday afternoon wearing shorts and no shoes. With the temperature nearing 60 degrees in San Diego, it was a good day to be barefoot and fleece-free.

title: Spitzer to Stay Out of Upstate Race?
description: Continuing his Im-playing-nice offensive, Gov. Eliot Spitzer told an upstate TV station that he will stay out of the hotly contested race to succeed State Senator James W. Wright, a Watertown Republican who recently resigned.The governor had this to say to a Watertown TV station, in reference to Assemblyman Darrel J. Aubertine, a Democrat who is seen as the underdog in the race:

description: Just watch it. Be quiet. Then make your response video.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Summer Palace'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Summer Palace," a film directed by Ye Lou about life before and after the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.

title: Congressmen Push for Paper Ballots
description: Both New Hampshire primary elections are going to be recounted, since Dennis J. Kucinich has put up $27,000 to get the Democratic recount started, and Albert Howard (who was on the New Hampshire Republican ballot) has donated $56,000 to re-tally the Republican vote.

description: Packers receiver Shaun Bodiford spent part of his adolescence homeless. Sometimes, he lived with friends. Other times, he slept on the ground on the streets of Seattles rough-and-tumble Central District, or closer to the home he left in Federal Way.

title: Directors Guild Reaches Deal With Studios
description: After months of informal discussions, Hollywoods movie and television directors tentatively agreed Thursday afternoon to a new contract with production companies, while sending a none-too-subtle message to striking screenwriters: This is not the time to get hung up on new media, Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes report.

title: The G.O.P.s Moral Minority
description: Does Mike Huckabees post-Iowa flameout (so far) demonstrate that the religious right does not dominate the Republican Party?

title: Court Strikes Down Pedicab Licensing Plan
description: In a case that has exposed the division between owners and drivers in the pedicab industry, a state judge in Manhattan has struck down the system the city planned to use to distribute 325 licenses to operate the human-powered vehicles. The city said that it planned to appeal the decision. The legal dispute is another wrinkle in the citys long-standing effort to regulate the pedicab industry for the first time.

title: Phil Hughes Starts a Blog
description: When I covered the Yankees in 2003, a grim daily task was to check David Wells old Web site to see if he ripped anybody. Wells could be hostile to the news media (hes the only athlete who has ever answered my question with a burp), and he used his site to air his unfiltered thoughts.

title: Soft Serve | A News Feed of Light Reading
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Strike: Writers Looking At the Fine Print
description: Updated, 6:59 p.m. | As the industry rushed to interpret the Directors Guild of Americas deal with the studios, the Writers Guild of America said it would carefully evaluate the terms of the agreement:

title: Striking Similarity
description: Joke told Wednesday night by David Letterman, who has settled with striking writers:

title: Week of Family Follies, From bin Laden to Bhutto
description: This week, the descendants of several world figures turned up in the headlines facing challenges of varying levels of seriousness. Heres a quick round-up.

title: For the Moment |  Francesco Vezzoli
description: This weeks guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidals Caligula, starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandellos Right You Are (If You Think You Are), starring  among others  Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his fourth post of the week he writes about the actress Anita Ekberg. To read all of Francesco Vezzolis prior blog posts, click here.

title: Hollywood and the Young Smoker
description: How do we stop young people from taking up smoking?

title: Clinton Kicks Off California TV Campaign
description: Already thinking ahead to Super Tuesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton began showing her first TV ad in California today.

title: Strike: Studios Offer Writers Informal Talks (White Flag Optional)
description: Seven weeks after negotiations stalled, the chief executives of Hollywoods studios are inviting the Writers Guild of America to engage in informal discussions that could lead to a strike-ending deal.

title: For Clinton and Obama, the Burden of Identity
description: The biggest fairy tale in this years Democratic contest may be the hope, expressed with renewed vigor by both Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton at Tuesday nights Democratic debate, that, as the campaign moves forward, they will be viewed as individuals and not as representatives of their gender or race.

title: Laughs and Lyrics With Belichick
description: Occasionally  very, very occasionally  Bill Belichick flashes the sense of humor we are convinced he has buried deep in his hoodie. Today, at the most unlikely moment, we had one of those occasions.

title: Reagan and revenue
description: Ah  commenter Tom says, in response to my post on taxes and revenues:

title: Republicans in Democrats Clothing
description: Nothing is more self-defeating in presidential politics than a candidate trying to be something he or she is not. Sometimes the incongruity is visual  Mike Dukakis photographed riding atop a tank  but more often it concerns a policy stand or a position that seems opportunistic and inauthentic. In such instances, the departure from form may produce some short-term political gain, but in the long run, it leaves voters confused and alienated.

title: IBM: A Separate Reality?
description: We knew the bottom-line numbers, after I.B.M. jumped the gun by three days and announced its surprisingly strong profits and sales figures on Monday. But what was striking in the companys conference call on Thursday afternoon was the unhedged optimism in its outlook for 2008, given the strong whiff of recession fear elsewhere.

title: YouTubes Traffic Continues to Snowball
description: More content begets more viewers, which, in turn, beget more content. Thats the virtuous cycle  the network effect  that has propelled Google-owned YouTube to the No. 1 spot in online video.

title: CBS Outernet Deal: You Can Run From Mary Hart, But You Cant Hide
description: For the second time in 24 hours, a major TV-centric media company is announcing deals to help advertisers reach consumers outside the home.

title: Should Banks Take Back Their Bonuses?
description: With the release of Merrill Lynchs long-awaited fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday, the tallying began. Watchers of Wall Street were quick to count up the bonuses at the five biggest financial firms in the United States, given the disastrous financial results that four of the five reported in the second half of 2007. (The exception was Goldman Sachs.)

title: Lightning Strikes the Avalanche
description: The Colorado Avalanche has been hanging onto the last playoff spot in the West desite the loss of its leading scorer and spiritual leader, Joe Sakic, and its gritty man in the crease, Ryan Smyth.

title: Peshawar Under Siege
description: Situated near the eastern end of the Khyber Pass, Peshawar has long been a gateway to Afghanistan. But in the past year, Pakistan's war with the Taliban and Al Qaeda has spilled right into the Pakistani frontier city, killing policemen and soldiers and scaring its famously tough citizens.

title: A Few Late Words: Wheres Edwards? Flags. Calls.
description: We were going to try to keep this a bit on the short side, but weve got a lot wed like to catch up on from the trail and beyond so  here goes.

title: Hows This for Nastiness? BC vs. BU
description: A couple of great match-ups mark the college hockey landscape this weekend, both with a long history of bad blood. Last weekends preview was of Denver University vs. Wisconsin, but were moving away from the WCHA to avoid situations like this.

title: Tomlinson Practices; Rivers Sits Out Again
description: Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers did not practice Thursday, unless you count throwing a pass along the sideline.

title: Inside the Giants: Will Eli Watch Seinfeld While Wearing Gloves?
description: Phew. If Eli Manning wants to watch Seinfeld on Saturday night, as he usually does before a game, he can. It does not matter that a Green Bay television station is pulling the show out of its usual time slot to show its support of the Packers.

title: Romo Headline Winner
description: Thanks to all who sent their Romo headlines. To review the submissions, click here and here. As it happens, all the top headlines were written before the game.Three Times sports copy editors served as judges, and each was asked to select a top three. Heres how they scored it:

title: Searching for a Packers Refuge in New York
description: If youre a Packers fan in the New York area, you will find few bars Sunday that wont be overrun by Giants fans. Theres the Kettle of Fish in the Village, long a Packer bar, but there must be other places. Any advice for Packer backers?

title: Obama Skewers Critics in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS  At a rally here tonight, Senator Barack Obama mocked his rivals about how they answered a question during the debate on Tuesday evening. (Yes, this is the same debate where the candidates bathed one another in pleasantries and compliments.)

title: 11 Die in Attack on a Shiite Mosque in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  For the second time in two days, a suicide bomber struck outside a Shiite mosque in Diyala Province north of Baghdad on Thursday, as worshipers prepared for one of the most important days in the Shiite calendar. The police and witnesses said at least 11 people were killed.

title: Were All Gonna Die! Grab Your Video Camera!
description: It was only last month that Will Smith started up boogeyman patrol in Manhattan in I Am Legend, and yet here we go again with the end of the world, or at least some of the citys most exclusive ZIP codes. This time, the annihilation comes courtesy of a reptilian creature with a slithering, smashing tail, multiple grabby appendages and an apparently insatiable appetite for destruction. At one point in Cloverfield you get a close, very personal look at that hungry mouth, which agape recalls that of the adult monster designed by H. R. Giger for the first Alien, though without any of the older beasties freakily sexualized menace or resonance.

title: Close to History, Art and Lots of Adobe
description: ONE way to assess condominium real estate values in Santa Fe, N.M., is to strap on a pedometer. Walk outward from the citys geographic, historic and cultural hub, the Plaza, and all else being equal, values decline in direct relation to distance from its center.

title: Americans in the Action as Macao Casinos Soar
description: HONG KONG  A battle for supremacy in Macaos gambling market is shaping up between the casino tycoon Stanley Ho and an American newcomer as the Chinese enclave emerges as the biggest gambling territory in the world.

title: Some New Old Masters at the National Gallery
description: When the National Gallery of Art in Washington opened in 1941, its collection reflected the tastes of its founding benefactors, like Andrew Mellon and P. A. B. Widener. Both men collected Dutch old master paintings but mostly from the latter half of the 17th century. Neither owned work by Salomon van Ruysdael, an earlier landscape painter who now is considered a founding Dutch naturalist.

title: 12 Killed in Suicide Bombing at Shiite Mosque in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Twelve people were killed and 25 others were wounded, three of them seriously, when a suicide bomber detonated explosives on Thursday in a Shiite Muslim mosque in Peshawar in northwestern Pakistan, police and hospital officials said.

title: Legal Immigrants Facing a Longer Wait
description: Because of an unprecedented surge in immigration applications last summer, legal immigrants will have to wait much longer during the next two years to receive visas or naturalization papers, the top official of the federal agency that issues those documents said Thursday.

title: Rock & Pop Listings
description: POP

title: Suddenly Called to Serve: A Dove, a Hawk and a Loon
description: If the abysmal reception so far for films about the war in Iraq is any indication, Day Zero, which imagines a time in the near future when the war has widened, is the last thing movie audiences will want to consume. In this fantasy of the day after tomorrow, coordinated suicide bombings stretch from Ankara to Cairo. An unspecified act of terrorism has wreaked havoc in Los Angeles, and the draft has just been reinstated.

title: One Argument, 12 Million Holes
description: The big fat immigration bill that died last year in Congress was, for all its flaws, an anchor that kept debate tethered firmly to reality. Like it or not, it contained specific remedies for the border and the workplace. It had a plan for clearing backlogs in legal immigration and managing its future flow. Perhaps most critical, it dealt with the 12 million illegal immigrants already here, through a tough path to earned citizenship.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $6,676,015

title: Stones Change Label for New Album
description: Long associated with EMI, the Rolling Stones have signed an exclusive recording agreement to release their next album  the soundtrack for Martin Scorseses documentary concert film Shine a Light  through Universal Music Group, The Associated Press reported. The album is scheduled for March. The announcement prompted speculation that after 16 years the band could part ways with EMI, which has changed ownership and plans to cut as many as 2,000 jobs. Radiohead and Paul McCartney have already left the label. EMI, pointing out that Universal Music is affiliated with Universal Pictures, producers of the film, said its relationship with the Stones would be unaffected.

title: New Jersey Investigating Amgens Marketing of a Psoriasis Drug
description: New Jerseys attorney general has begun investigating whether the biotechnology giant Amgen violated patient confidentiality laws in its effort to sell its drug Enbrel.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about the casino mogul Sheldon G. Adelson misidentified, in some copies, the company controlled by Lawrence J. Ellison, whose wealth was compared with Mr. Adelsons. It is Oracle, not Sun Microsystems.

title: Rockets Hit Israel, Whose Strikes Kill 5 Palestinians
description: SDEROT, Israel  Rockets fired from Gaza slammed into this small Israeli border town in quick succession Thursday evening, and Israeli airstrikes killed at least five Palestinians in Gaza, three of them civilians, on a third day of heightened tension and hostilities between Israel and Palestinian militant groups in the Gaza Strip.

title: Classical & Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Charlie Rose Joins 60 Minutes
description: Charlie Rose, the PBS interviewer, will moonlight as a contributor to the CBS newsmagazine 60 Minutes beginning this season, the network announced Thursday. Mr. Rose is expected to provide several reports each season for the program. He served as a correspondent for the spinoff series 60 Minutes II for six years until it was canceled in 2005. It will be great to have Charlie working with us again, Jeff Fager, the executive producer of 60 Minutes, said in a statement. His considerable talents will make our all-star team even better. Mr. Rose will continue to produce and be the host of his long-running public television series.

title: State Revises Hormone Label for Milk
description: After an outcry from consumers, Pennsylvanias Agriculture Department has backed off its plan to ban milk-container labels stating that the milk comes from cows not treated with bovine growth hormone.

title: Clyde Otis, 83, Executive and Songwriter, Dies
description: Clyde Otis, a songwriter and record producer who was one of the first black executives at a major record company, died on Jan. 8 in Englewood, N.J. He was 83.

title: Europes Social Safety Net, and Americas
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamm Silhouette on League Logo
description: Mia Hamm retired in 2004 as one of the greatest players in womens soccer. Now she is the image of a new league. Hamms silhouette is featured in the logo unveiled Thursday by Womens Professional Soccer, a league that plans to begin play in the spring of 2009 in seven American cities. Hamm is about to strike a ball with her right foot in the navy, red and gold W.P.S. logo. The formation of the league was announced in September, with teams expected in Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles, New Jersey/New York, St. Louis and Washington. The league offices are in San Francisco.

title: Richard Knerr, 82, Craze Creator, Dies
description: Richard Knerr, who gave the company he and a friend started in a garage the altogether appropriate name Wham-O, then marketed products that for two decades virtually defined frivolity in postwar America, from the Hula Hoop to the Frisbee to the SuperBall, died on Monday at his home in Arcadia, Calif. He was 82.

title: Texas Supreme Court Justice Is Embroiled in an Arson Case
description: HOUSTON  A Texas Supreme Court justice and his wife were charged on Thursday in an arson fire that destroyed their suburban Houston home last June, the judges lawyer said.

title: A Brutal Cossack Hero Strides Into Brooklyn
description: Introducing himself to the audience at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night, George Isaakyan, the artistic director of the Tchaikovsky Opera and Ballet Theater of Perm, said the members of his company were happy and proud to be appearing in New York. And nervous, he added.

title: Queens: Suspect Denies Killing Dentist
description: A man arrested in connection with the killing of a 34-year-old orthodontist in Queens was arraigned on murder charges in State Supreme Court on Thursday, prosecutors said. The man, Mikhail Mallayev, 50, an immigrant from Uzbekistan who has a family tie to the victims widow, has been charged with killing the orthodontist, Dr. Daniel Malakov, on Oct. 28 at a Queens playground. Michael Siff, Mr. Mallayevs lawyer, said his client pleaded not guilty. The killing occurred as Dr. Malakovs estranged wife, Dr. Mazoltuv Borukhova, and their daughter, Michelle, 4, looked on, the police said. In a statement on Thursday, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said Mr. Mallayev was acting in concert with another person when he shot Dr. Malakov twice in the chest. But he did not identify the second suspect and did not elaborate.

title: Childrens Events
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Those Days of Doom on the Yangtze
description: A modern master of postmodern discontent, Jia Zhang-ke is among the most strikingly gifted filmmakers working today whom you have probably never heard of. During the past decade he has made some half-dozen documentary-inflected fictions and several documentaries that weigh the human cost of Chinas often brutal, dehumanizing shift from state-controlled communism to state-sanctioned capitalism, a price paid in the blood and sweat of people who have, paradoxically, inspired him to create works of sublime, soulful art.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Manhattan: Lawsuit Over Energy Standards
description: In a sign that local governments are growing impatient with Washingtons approach to solving environmental problems, New York City and three states on Thursday joined environmental advocacy groups in suing the Bush administration over new standards for gas furnaces and other home heating appliances. In a lawsuit filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, the City Law Department, along with the States of New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts, argued that the efficiency standards set in November by the federal Energy Department were far too weak to significantly cut carbon dioxide emissions or to help lower home heating costs, which have hit people in the Northeast especially hard.

title: In Pitches to Doctors, Promise of Big Payday
description: Using e-mail solicitations that promise high pay, US HIFU (pronounced you es HIGH-foo) is trying to build and train a network of American urologists for its offshore prostate cancer treatments. The opportunity before F.D.A. approval is very lucrative, said one message sent by the company.

title: Conservative Approach Pays Off for BlackRock as Profit Grows 90%
description: Dodging the rocky investments that have damaged many Wall Street banks, BlackRock, the giant asset management firm, said on Thursday that fourth-quarter profit jumped 90 percent.

title: Snowmass
description: Updated: December 2008

title: A Leader Looking Out for Future Leaders
description: PRESIDENTIAL material  whos hot, whos not, and whos ready to succeed as a black candidate for president of the United States  is not just a running theme but also a ground-level enterprise in the garment district office of Sandra E. Timmons, the president of A Better Chance. Her mission, which she took on in 2003, is to identify, cultivate, and help educate future Barack Obamas when they are adolescents. On her end, clairvoyance helps. On theirs, brains, talent, and any racial identity except white.

title: Surgery Could Bring an End to Marburys Knicks Career
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Stephon Marbury has decided to have surgery for bone spurs in his left ankle, the Knicks said in a statement Thursday. The operation was expected to take place Tuesday, and Marbury will be out indefinitely, the team said.

title: Gates Seeks Troop Estimates
description: WASHINGTON  When they decided last September to begin a slow withdrawal of troops from Iraq, the White House, Pentagon and senior military officers put off a harder decision about how long those withdrawals should continue.

title: In Tentative Deal, Directors Send Message
description: LOS ANGELES  After months of informal talks, Hollywoods movie and television directors agreed Thursday afternoon to a new contract with production companies. The accord would appear to send a none-too-subtle message to striking screenwriters: This is not the time to get hung up on new media.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Dec. 18 about the escape of two inmates from the Union County Jail in Elizabeth, N.J., included an erroneous age from law enforcement authorities for one of the escapees, Jose Espinosa. He was 19 at the time, not 20; he has since turned 20.

title: Prosecutors Argue Against Moving Bell Case From City
description: Prosecutors in Queens argued Thursday against moving the trial of three detectives charged in the 2006 killing of a man out of New York City.

title: G.E. Profit Rises, Aided by Overseas Sales
description: The General Electric Company said Friday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 4 percent as surging overseas sales more than offset the fallout from domestic woes. The company also reaffirmed its forecast that earnings per share would rise at least 10 percent this year.

title: Everything Old ...
description: Here is a listing of antiques shows taking place in New York this weekend, including those reviewed on this page:

title: Coming Attractions
description: Julie White, who won a Tony Award for her performance in The Little Dog Laughed,  is coming back to New York theater for Manhattan Theater Clubs production of From Up Here, a new play by Liz Flahive to be directed by Leigh Silverman. Previews begin on March 27 for an April 16 opening at New York City Center. ... Shrek the Musical, based on Shrek the Book as well as Shrek the Movie, has announced Shrek the Pre-Broadway Engagement at the 5th Avenue Theater in Seattle. The musical, by David Lindsay-Abaire and Jeanine Tesori, will play there from Aug. 14 to Sept. 21 and is scheduled for Broadway in early November. No theater has been announced, but a musical the size of "Shrek" needs a big theater, sort of like those now occupied by The Color Purple and Legally Blonde. Hmmm.

title: State of the City Could Be a Campaign Speech, Too
description: As the setting for his latest State of the City speech, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg chose a new swimming pool and ice-skating rink complex in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Bloggers Push China to Prosecute Beating Death
description: SHANGHAI  More than 100 people are under investigation and several government officials have been detained or removed from office in central China after a dispute in early January in which a group of city officials beat a bystander to death.

title: Mallett Transfers From Michigan
description: Bobby Petrino landed his first major recruit for Arkansas  Ryan Mallett, the former Michigan quarterback. Mallett has transferred to Arkansas and will have three years of eligibility after sitting out the 2008 season. Mallett, a 6-foot-7 freshman who played in 11 games for the Wolverines, left Michigan after Rich Rodriguez replaced the retiring Lloyd Carr as the coach.

title: Baby Sitter Charged With Murder in Death of Hartford Toddler
description: HARTFORD  A 25-year-old baby sitter who told the police that she tied a toddler in a sleeping bag last week and ran through her apartment with him slung over her shoulder as part of a game was charged with murder on Thursday in Superior Court here.

title: South Pole Building Is Dedicated
description: The National Science Foundation dedicated its third Amundsen-Scott research building at the South Pole on Saturday, the agency said Wednesday. The new building replaces the iconic but increasingly snow-covered geodesic dome that since 1975 covered a kitchen building, sleeping quarters, laboratories and other facilities. The new station, built on pilings, can be raised if necessary to escape drifts. The dome will be dismantled, but will probably be reconstructed somewhere in the United States, Peter West, a spokesman for the agency, said. The base, established in 1957, is named for Roald Amundsen of Norway and Robert F. Scott of Britain, who led the first expeditions to the pole almost a century ago.

title: Renewed Warning on Cold Medicines
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Concerned that many parents continue to give infants over-the-counter cold remedies, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that it strongly recommends that these medicines not be used in children under 2.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Public Lives column in some editions last Friday, about Nicholas Sprayregen, a businessman and Bruce Springsteen fan who is fighting efforts by Columbia University to seize property he owns in Upper Manhattan, referred incorrectly to the shows Mr. Sprayregen attended during Mr. Springsteens 2002-3 Rising tour. He saw six of the multiple-night shows at Giants and Shea Stadiums in 2003; Mr. Springsteen did not give a 10-night stand at Madison Square Garden during that tour.

title: Pennsylvania Acts to Bolster High School Requirements
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  A requirement that students pass a series of state exams before being allowed to graduate from Pennsylvanias public high schools was unanimously approved Thursday by the State Board of Education.

title: Federal Judge Criticizes C.I.A. Handling of Interrogation Tapes
description: A federal judge in New York said Thursday that he was disappointed in how investigators from the Central Intelligence Agency had handled videotapes documenting the harsh interrogation of detainees from Al Qaeda, adding that he was considering questioning agency officials who had watched the tapes about why they had made no record of them in their files.

title: Crash Landing Temporarily Paralyzes Heathrow
description: LONDON  A British Airways passenger jet crash-landed just short of a runway at Londons Heathrow airport on Thursday, plowing on its belly across open grassland before slowing to a halt when it hit the tarmac with parts of its landing gear torn off.

title: Obama and Clinton Trade Attacks in Nevada
description: RENO, Nev.  Senator Barack Obama sharply criticized Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on the eve of the Nevada caucuses, declaring: The American people dont want a president whose plans change with the politics of the moment.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Monday about the simultaneous departure of three luxury ocean liners  the Queen Mary 2, the Queen Elizabeth 2 and the Queen Victoria  from New York Harbor misstated the context of a quotation from Peter Knego, co-editor of a Web site devoted to the history of passenger ships. When Mr. Knego said, They would only meet in the Atlantic and were never in port together, he was referring to the Queen Mary and the Queen Elizabeth  not their successors. (The Queen Mary 2 and the Queen Elizabeth 2 were both in port in New York in 2004.)

title: Filling In as a Parent for 2 Younger Brothers
description: Thomas Leach, 20, does not speak. But his sister, Shedina Leach, says he communicates using expressions that are as clear as words. A bat of his eyelashes means he is trying to persuade her. When he looks down, he is upset. When he smirks, he is happy.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 7 about Big Think, the Web site that has interviews with public intellectuals from a variety of fields misspelled the surname of a politician cited in an example. He is Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, not Spector.

title: McCain Hunts a Second Chance, Wary of the Blade in the Back
description: Aiken, S.C.

title: In Over Their Heads, With Destiny Looming
description: Cassandras Dream, Woody Allens latest excursion to the dark side of human nature, is good enough that you may wonder why he doesnt just stop making comedies once and for all. Perhaps thats heretical, but its the view of someone who has accompanied Mr. Allen on all his recent follies, The Curse of the Jade Scorpion included, and has too often heard her own laughter die gurgling in her throat from a lack of inspiration. Theres nothing remotely funny about Cassandras Dream, save perhaps that immodest title.

title: Hogwarts Founder to Address Harvard
description: J. K. Rowling, who gave the world Harry Potter, will be the principal speaker at the afternoon exercises of Harvard Universitys 357th commencement on June 5. Perhaps no one in our time has done more than J. K. Rowling to inspire young people to experience the excitement and sheer joy of reading, said Drew Gilpin Faust, the universitys president.

title: Corrections: Fishing Boats, Surfboards and Not a High-Rise in Sight
description: Because of an editing error, the Havens column last Friday about Puerto Escondido, Mexico, misspelled the name of a real estate agency there. It is Zicatela Properties, not Zicateca.

title: When Going Gets Tough, a Not-So-Tough Turns to Meth
description: Crime does pay in the movies, at least for a while  the outlaws in Bonnie and Clyde and Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid have delightful rides until the authorities intervene.

title: Cloning Said to Yield Human Embryos
description: Scientists at a small biotechnology company say they have used cloning to create human embryos from the skin cells of two men.

title: For Collectibles, All Roads Lead to New York
description: If art fairs were cameras, their views might range from panoramic wide-angle to sharp-focus close-up. Most land somewhere between, but for the next several days New York will be host to two that define the extremes.

title: Google Offers a Map for Its Philanthropy
description: Google announced a plan on Thursday that begins to fulfill the pledge it made to investors when it went public nearly four years ago to reserve 1 percent of its profit and equity to make the world a better place. The beneficiaries of Googles money range from groups that are fighting disease to those developing a commercial plug-in car.

title: A Little Midday Music and Where to Find It
description: Here is a selection of afternoon concerts in the coming weeks.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about the surprising emergence of running back Ryan Grant of the Green Bay Packers referred incorrectly to his classroom performance at the University of Notre Dame. The university said he was never ineligible to play for academic or other reasons; he did not miss one season because of academic trouble. (Go to Article)

title: Protesters Clash With Police in Kenya and Loot Train
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Law and order seem to be steadily deteriorating in some parts of Kenya, like the Kibera slum here in Nairobi, where on Thursday protesters hijacked and looted a freight train bound for Uganda.

title: Rookies Debut Delights Family and Scares Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Elaine Pope is not a big fan of her sons tattoos.

title: Well, It Looks Like Truth
description: After an autumn of large, expert, risk-free museum retrospectives, the time is right for a brain-pincher of a theme show, which is what Archive Fever: Uses of the Document in Contemporary Art at the International Center of Photography is.

title: Why There Will Never Be a Last Tango
description: The cheering audience seemed eager to linger all night on Wednesday at City Center. But finally the house lights came up. The last encore by Compania Tango X2 was over.

title: Mexican Forces Clash With Drug Cartel Gunmen in Tijuana
description: REYNOSA, Mexico  Drug cartel gunmen and government forces fought a three-hour battle Thursday in Tijuana, the latest in a series of violent clashes in border towns where President Felipe Caldern has deployed the Mexican Army and federal agents to dismantle drug cartels.

title: Ridgeway: Four Killed in House Fire
description: A late-night fire tore through a two-story home in western New York on Wednesday, killing two children, their mother and grandmother, officials said on Thursday. The fire was in the town of Ridgeway, about 35 miles northeast of Buffalo. The victims were April Hausler, 31; her daughter, Dawn, 7; her son, James, 10; and her mother, Anna Monagan, 56, Orleans County sheriffs officials said. The fire did not appear to be suspicious, fire officials said. Ms. Hauslers husband, David, is a truck driver and was on the road when the fire occurred.

title: Defense Secretary, Facing Criticism, Hails NATOs Forces in Afghanistan
description: BERLIN  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday that NATO countries were playing a significant and powerful role in Afghanistan, after some of Washingtons closest European allies assailed him for comments cited in a news report about their counterinsurgency operations in the volatile south.

title: Europes Ethics Panel Says Cloning Harms Animals
description: Just days after being told that milk and meat from cloned livestock were safe for human consumption, Europeans were warned Thursday that cloning causes suffering to the animals.

title: On Deathbed, Suharto Avoids Answering for Crimes
description: SOLO, Indonesia -- Gilang was one of the last victims of former President Suhartos harsh 32-year rule, a young activist who disappeared here on the day the former president was forced from power 10 years ago and whose body was found six days later, shot, stabbed and disemboweled.

title: Mamet, Cornered in the Oval Office
description: You may have been wondering just how all those gagmeisters who make their livings contributing jokes to television talk show monologues and sketch reviews have been occupying their time during the long-lived writers strike. Well, one possibility would be that they have been funneling their one-liners  and not always their best ones  directly to David Mamet.

title: Messenger From Late 50s, Scatting and Swooning Away
description: You have to admire the jazz singer Mark Murphy for his fearless vocal deconstructions of songs in which crooning, scatting, note bending, muttering and bleating create musical equivalents of Abstract Expressionist paintings. But there is a point at which that kind of invention sacrifices a coherent sense of form, when adventurous exploration verges on doodling, and the work never comes together. During Wednesdays opening set of a four-night engagement at Birdland, Mr. Murphy trod perilously back and forth over the line separating expressive invention and foolish self-caricature.

title: Paula Vogel Goes to Yale
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Paula Vogel, director of the playwriting programs at Brown University for 24 years, has been appointed an adjunct professor and the chairwoman of the playwriting department at Yale School of Drama. Shell be part of a much bigger drama department, but thats what appeals to her, she said. Im really proud of the students that Ive had and really proud of the program, Ms. Vogel said of her time at Brown, but I feel like Ive just about done everything I can do. The appointment, which begins July 1, is for five years.

title: A Sad Story, Told by Nixzmarys Things
description: A childs wooden school chair with a length of nylon twine tied to it.

title: Australia: Job Growth Stirs Inflation Concern
description: Australian employment rose for a 14th month in December, adding to the longest hiring boom in almost three decades, which is fanning inflation and may force the central bank to raise borrowing costs next month. The number of people employed climbed by 20,100, after a revised 47,600 gain in November, the Bureau of Statistics said. The jobless rate fell to 4.3 percent from 4.5 percent. Its one more tick in the box for our view that the Reserve Bank will probably have to lift rates as early as February, said John Peters, senior economist at Commonwealth Bank of Australia in Sydney. An ever-tighter labor market runs the risk of wage inflation.

title: Queens: Man Charged With Hate Crime
description: A Queens man has been charged with shouting racial slurs before severely beating a Sikh man in New Hyde Park, prosecutors said on Thursday. The man, David C. Wood, 36, of 263rd Street, was arraigned in Criminal Court on Wednesday evening on charges of second-degree assault as a hate crime and aggravated harassment, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Prosecutors charged that the Sikh man, Chadha Bajeet, 63, had just parked his car on 95th Avenue on Monday when Mr. Wood shouted, Arab, go back to your country! and punched him in the face, breaking his nose and jaw.

title: Israeli Soldiers Man a Fortress of Futility
description: Beaufort may be, strictly speaking, a war movie, but for long stretches it feels more like science fiction. The small band of Israeli soldiers who are its main  virtually its only  characters inhabit a mountain outpost in southern Lebanon that might as well be a space station marooned in a hostile galaxy.

title: Texas Man Held in Pakistani Jail Said to Be Gravely Ill
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani-American doctor who campaigned for the rights of a minority group is gravely ill in a remote Pakistani jail, held without charges under severe conditions for nearly two years, his lawyers and human rights advocates said.

title: Bloomberg Warns of Spending Cuts
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, looking at once to close a multibillion-dollar deficit and burnish his national profile as a fearless innovator, unveiled a mix of tough education and anticrime measures while warmly embracing the virtues of immigration on Thursday at his annual State of the City address.

title: Queens: Eight Injured in Fire Truck Crash
description: Eight people were injured on Thursday in a crash in Laurelton involving a United States Postal Service tractor-trailer, a taxicab and a fire engine responding to an emergency, the Fire Department said. The injured, five firefighters and three civilians, were taken to area hospitals. The Fire Department said the accident, which occurred about 3:15 p.m. at 225th Street and Conduit Avenue, was under investigation. The truck driver, who was not identified, was in critical condition Thursday evening, the police said. The injuries to the firefighters and the other civilians were said not to be life-threatening.

title: Bush Calls for $145 Billion Economic Aid Package
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush called on Friday for about $145 billion worth of tax rebates for American families and incentives for businesses to provide a shot in the arm to keep a fundamentally strong economy healthy and avert a slide into recession.

title: Easy Glider: This Isnt Your Flexible Flyer
description: THE snow was so deep one morning in Vermont last month that Lincoln Gap was barely recognizable as a road. The mountain pass, the gateway to sun-dappled Long Trail hikes in warmer months, was buried beneath white powder.

title: Dont Cry for Me, America
description: Mexico. Brazil. Argentina. Mexico, again. Thailand. Indonesia. Argentina, again.

title: Lowell Wants Flawless H.G.H. Test
description: Mike Lowell, the most valuable player of the World Series, said he was willing to give blood if that is what it takes to be tested for human growth hormone  but only if the test is 100 percent accurate. If its 99 percent accurate, thats going to be seven false positives, Lowell said Thursday before the annual dinner of the Boston chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America. Ninety-three percent is 70 guys. Thats almost three whole rosters. Youre destroying someones reputation. What if one of the false positives is Cal Ripken? Doesnt it put a black mark on his career?

title: A January to Remember as a Dismal Start
description: While the chairman of the Federal Reserve told Congress on Thursday that a recession can be averted, Wall Street sent Washington a different message: its already here.

title: In Offense of Riches, Maroney Is Hidden Gem
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Laurence Maroney sat for most of this week playing dominoes quietly in the middle of a locker room maelstrom, barely watching as the clot of dozens of members of the news media followed his teammates around. Maroney, the N.F.L.s most anonymous starting running back, was overlooked again.

title: Banks Trash Is Treasure for Grabbing
description: In the breezy, amoral heist comedy Mad Money, Fun With Dick and Jane meets 9 to 5 on the way to recession. If this uncomfortably timely movie lacks the political bite of the first and the cozy star chemistry of the second, it sputters to fitful life in the crooked grin of Diane Keaton, whose character, Bridget Cardigan, an upper-middle-class homemaker in suburban Kansas City, Mo., develops an insatiable lust for larceny.

title: Rodriguez and Wright, Together
description: Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees and David Wright of the Mets play the same position, third base, and play in the same city. At the 28th Thurman Munson Awards dinner Feb. 5, they will also take the same stage and receive the same award.

title: Rhode Island: Budget Cuts Proposed
description: Gov. Donald L. Carcieri proposed deep budget cuts to close a $151 million deficit, including forcing state workers to take unpaid days off, removing children of illegal immigrants from state health care rolls and cutting back on welfare spending. The plan by Mr. Carcieri, a Republican, seeks to close a budget gap in the current fiscal year. It now goes to the General Assembly, which Democrats control.

title: Bridesmaid Revisited, Again and Again
description: At the beginning of 27 Dresses, Jane (Katherine Heigl), a serial bridesmaid with an almost pathological devotion to other peoples nuptials, spends a long night shuttling between two weddings. One is in Midtown Manhattan, the other in Brooklyn; one has an upper-crusty, white-bread look, while the other appears to be a Jewish-Hindu intermarriage. But as the director, Anne Fletcher, methodically cuts back and forth between them, she makes the reasonably insightful, moderately funny point that modern American weddings, however they may strain for individuality and specialness, are all pretty much alike.

title: Ex-Hospital Patients File Lawsuit Over the Status of Health Care Services in New Orleans
description: A group of former patients of New Orleanss shuttered public hospital filed a lawsuit on Thursday in a Louisiana state court, saying that medical care for the poor is still woefully inadequate in the city and asking for a return to the level of services the hospital provided before Hurricane Katrina.

title: Bush to Offer Stimulus Plan; Tax Rebates Expected
description: WASHINGTON  The stock market plunged again on Thursday on bad economic news, taking little comfort from reassuring words by the chairman of the Federal Reserve or an emerging consensus about a stimulus plan that many worry could be too late.

title: Collector Returns Art Italy Says Was Looted
description: After 18 months of intense negotiations, the New York philanthropist Shelby White has ceded 10 classical antiquities from her private collection that Italy contends were looted from its soil, the Italian culture minister confirmed this week.

title: Winter Day Out in Atlanta
description: IT is in Midtown that Atlanta feels most like a real city. That is where the sprawl finally ends, where Costco and Outback give way to condos and Outwrite (the gay bookshop). There is a vertical grace to the streetscape, a fundamental yet all too rare appreciation for proportion and design. Home to the arts center, a great urban park and some of Atlantas best restaurants, the district has a vitality that is at once hip and sophisticated.

title: Merrill Posts Huge Loss; Chief Says Firms Capital Is Adequate
description: The outlook darkened for Merrill Lynch on Thursday as news of a huge quarterly loss sent the companys stock plummeting.

title: How Voters Think
description: People in my line of work try to answer certain questions. Why did Hillary surge after misting up in New Hampshire? Why have primary victories produced no momentum for the victors? Why did John McCain win among Republicans who oppose the Iraq war in both New Hampshire and Michigan, but lose among voters who support it?

title: Art Listings
description: A A BRONSONS SCHOOL FOR YOUNG SHAMANS Some group shows, like this one organized by A A Bronson, feel atmospherically of a piece. Mr. Bronson is the surviving member of General Idea, a group of three artists and lovers who were together from 1969 to 1994. Since his partners, Jorge Zontal and Felix Partz, died of AIDS in the 1990s, Mr. Bronson has worked alone, but not really alone. As an artist, mentor of artists, healer and gay role model, he remains, in one way or another, a collaborator. Thats what this rich show is about.

title: California: Smoke-Free Apartments
description: The Calabasas City Council adopted an ordinance regulating smoking in apartments, following the leads of the cities of Temecula and Belmont last year. The Calabasas ordinance requires at least 80 percent of apartment buildings to be permanently designated nonsmoking. It goes into effect Feb. 16, and landlords have until Jan. 1, 2012, to complete the transition. The ordinance allows current tenants who smoke to continue smoking in their units if they request to be grandfathered in.

title: Mayor Bloombergs State of the City
description: National economic indicators may be headed downward, but the annual State of the City speech that New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg delivered Thursday was so upbeat that he proposed another round of tax breaks. The effect was perhaps a little too happy, but the mayor has earned the right to preach at least a little optimism.

title: Southern Blacks Are Split on Clinton vs. Obama
description: ATLANTA  The Peoples Voice African-American Weekly News in tiny Roanoke, Ala., has not endorsed a candidate in the states Democratic presidential primary on Feb. 5  much to the frustration of its publisher, Charlotte A. Clark-Frieson, a Barack Obama supporter.

title: Canadian Manual Has U.S. on Torture List
description: OTTAWA  A training manual for Canadian diplomats lists the United States among countries that potentially torture or abuse prisoners.

title: A Long Way From Radiohead (or Maybe Not So Long)
description: Wordless Music, a series now in its second season, is an experiment in genre mixing that has shown what can be done when you value imagination more than formats and rules. Usually matching rock bands with classical chamber groups, the program has built a following among young listeners on both sides of the street.

title: Effect of Prosthetics Ruling Is Unclear
description: In ruling Monday that the double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius, who runs on two carbon-fiber blades, was ineligible to qualify for the Olympics, track and fields world governing body was hoping to establish a precedent. Instead, the question of whether prosthetic limbs confer an advantage over able-bodied runners remains shrouded in confusion.

title: Bill Clinton, Stumping and Simmering
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton may be the spouse running for office, but it is more Bill Clinton who appears to be feeling the heat.

title: Lottery Numbers
Armstrong to Run in Boston
description: The seven-time Tour de France winner Lance Armstrong plans to run the Boston Marathon in April to raise money for his foundation. Armstrong, 36, qualified for Boston by completing the 2007 New York City Marathon in 2 hours 46 minutes 43 seconds, finishing in 214th place.
