The Boston qualifying time is 3:15 for men ages 35 to 39.In 1996, Armstrong had a diagnosis of testicular cancer that had spread to his lungs and brain. But he recovered to win the Tour from 1999 to 2005.The Lance Armstrong Foundation supports cancer research, prevention and better care for cancer survivors. Armstrong and others running for the foundation raised about $500,000 at last years New York City Marathon.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Friday with an article about Crestone, Colo., as a spiritual center misstated the name of a Catholic monastery there. It is the Nada Hermitage, not Napa Hermitage.

title: Creative Force of VH-1s Reality Shows Leaves, but Not in Reality
description: VH-1, the cable channel which has soared in the ratings because of reality shows like Flavor of Love and I Love New York, is losing its top creative executive but not his creativity.

title: Ohio: Suit Over Voting Plan
description: The American Civil Liberties Union sued the state and its most populous county to block the county from switching to a paper voting system in time for the March 4 presidential primary. The A.C.L.U. claims the system to be put in place in the county, Cuyahoga, violates voters constitutional rights because it does not allow them to correct ballot errors. With more than one million registered voters, Cuyahoga County, which includes Cleveland, plans to send paper ballots filled out by voters to a central location to be scanned and counted. That system does not give voters notice of ballot errors and an opportunity to correct mistakes, the A.C.L.U. says.

title: Frontier Insurgency Spills Into Peshawar
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  For centuries, fighting and lawlessness have been part of the fabric of this frontier city. But in the past year, Pakistans war with Islamic militants has spilled right into its alleys and bazaars, its forts and armories, killing policemen and soldiers and scaring its famously tough citizens.

title: A Mining Town With a Bleak Past Starts to Blossom
description: DOUG GREENWELL and his wife, April, took a ski holiday to Jackson Hole, Wyo., five years ago with the idea of looking for a vacation home. She found it too cold. He found it too expensive.

title: Things They Dont Teach in Any Dental School
description: Teenage horror-movie spoof, John Waters parody, No Nukes protest movie, twisted sex-education film, quasi-feminist fable, outrageous stunt: Mitchell Lichtensteins clever, crude comedy, Teeth, is all these and more.

title: U.S. Fines Mine Owner $20 Million for Pollution
description: WASHINGTON  The nations fourth-largest coal producer, the Massey Energy Company, was hit Thursday with a $20 million fine, the largest civil penalty ever levied by the federal government for a pollution violation of this type under the Clean Water Act.

title: Staten Island Ferry and Staten Island Railway
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Louisiana: FEMA Trailer Refunds
description: Responding to concerns about high levels of formaldehyde in its disaster trailers, the Federal Emergency Management Agency said it would offer refunds to people who bought the units. In the summer of 2006, the government began selling travel and park model trailers through online auctions and to victims of the 2005 hurricanes. Sales were suspended in July 2007 because of formaldehyde fears. FEMA said 10,839 travel trailers and park models were sold at an average price of $6,936, and 864 trailers were sold directly to hurricane victims.

title: No Murphy Marriage
description: Eddie Murphys recent marriage was over before it began. The ceremony he and the film producer Tracey Edmonds took part in on New Years Day on a private island off Bora Bora in French Polynesia was merely symbolic and not legally binding, the couple said in a statement, The Associated Press reported. The statement said that we have decided to remain friends.

title: Planning for Newarks Next Big Step: An Apartment Tower Near the Arts Center
description: NEWARK  An impressive cultural complex in the heart of this down-and-out city? They said it could not be done, but Lawrence P. Goldman, the man behind the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, proved them wrong.

title: Back in His Arms Again: The Home Campaign
description: Sue Millers novels, beginning with her assured debut, The Good Mother (1986), tend to feature soap-opera plots fleshed out with remarkable psychological detail and emotional precision. This is certainly true of her unsatisfying, if professionally executed, new book, The Senators Wife, which revolves around a brilliant, self-made, philandering politician (who seems inspired in part by Bill Clinton, who is frequently mentioned in passing in these pages) and his stoical wife, who like the Hillary Clinton described in Gail Sheehys 1999 tendentious book, Hillarys Choice, is addicted to her husband.

title: Bring on the Lift but Hold the Groomers in Washington
description: THE smothering storm, some 50 inches of snow in four days, wasnt so unusual  not for Washington State. What was rare was the cloudless, not-a-breath-of-wind dawn that arrived on the fifth day, the last of 2007. It was a perfect morning to check out what is possibly this winters most intriguing addition to the ski slopes of the Pacific Northwest.

title: Romney Leaves South Carolina to Focus on Nevada Caucus
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The next big Republican presidential contest is Saturday in South Carolina. So what did Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, the winner of the Michigan primary this week, do on Thursday morning?

title: Secret Service: Detailed Look at 06 Turmoil
description: DENVER  The arrest of a man named Steven Howards in June 2006 after he approached Vice President Dick Cheney at a Colorado ski resort and denounced the war in Iraq might have seemed, at the time, no more than a blip on the vice presidents schedule.

title: Virus Is Linked to a Powerful Skin Cancer
description: Scientists have discovered a previously unknown virus and strongly linked it with the most aggressive form of skin cancer, they reported in a scientific journal on Thursday.

title: Extending Requirement to Advance in School
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday unveiled strict new criteria for promotion to high school that could, if current testing patterns hold, put nearly a quarter of New York Citys eighth graders in danger of spending an extra year in middle school.

title: Tennessee: Ex-Lawmaker Is Sentenced
description: One of five former lawmakers convicted of bribery or extortion in an F.B.I. sting was sentenced to two years probation by a judge who indicated that the defendants heart ailment had kept him out of prison. The former state senator, Ward Crutchfield, 79, pleaded guilty in July to bribery for taking $3,000 from a company called E-Cycle Management, which turned out to be a creation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. His probation includes six months of home detention.

title: A Movement That Brightened Victorian Lives
description: A MOVEMENT

title: Corrections: For Many a Follower, Sacred Ground in Colorado
description: A picture caption last Friday with an article about Crestone, Colo., as a spiritual center misstated the name of a Catholic monastery there. It is the Nada Hermitage, not Napa Hermitage.

title: Sorting Out the New Housing Market
description: The shape of the new American housing market  the post-bubble market  is starting to emerge. It is one that favors the young who never owned a house and the banks that have access to cheap deposits. It may be harshest on the two coasts, where both distress and a newfound lack of mobility may be on the increase.

title: The Senators Wife
description: Meri, June 1993

title: Pacific Islanders Ancestry Emerges in Genetic Study
description: The ancestral relationships of people living in the widely scattered islands of the Pacific Ocean, long a puzzle to anthropologists, may have been solved by a new genetic study, researchers reported Thursday.

title: The Resort as Residence
description: WERE always getting massages, Troy Coughlin said, or my wife is getting her nails done. Were totally pampered by the people at the spa.

title: Art in Review
description: BERTIEN VAN MANEN

title: Bronx: Carwashes to Pay Back Wages
description: The United States Labor Department announced on Thursday that two Bronx carwashes, Tremont Car Wash and Webster Car Wash, and their corporate president had agreed to pay $707,298 in back wages and damages to 237 employees. The departments investigators found that many carwash employees were required to work more than 70 hours a week without being paid the federal minimum wage or time and a half for overtime. The department said the carwashes had also failed to maintain adequate and accurate records. Judge Barbara Jones of Federal District Court in Manhattan said that if the carwashes failed to make the payments, she would appoint a receiver to seize and liquidate their assets to satisfy the order.

title: Resignation Weakens Italys Government
description: ROME  A new element of instability shook Italys government Thursday as the justice minister, resigning over a corruption investigation, withdrew his small party from the already fragile center-left ruling coalition.

title: Winter Day Out in Washington, D.C.
description: FOR a quintessentially D.C. start to a winter day, grab a power breakfast (the fruit platter with salmon is a good morning choice) among the wheelers and dealers at the Old Ebbitt Grill, just steps from the White House. A favorite hangout for Presidents Grant, Cleveland, Harding and Theodore Roosevelt, and now senators and lobbyists, the Grill, built in 1856, makes you feel like a true political insider and gives you a chance to test your C-Span skills by trying to identify fellow patrons.

title: Mayor Hails Citys Immigrants and Innovation
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, looking at once to close a multibillion-dollar deficit and burnish his national profile as an innovator, unveiled a mix of tough education and anticrime measures while embracing the virtues of immigration on Thursday at his annual State of the City address.

title: State Makes Bid to End Costly Tax-Refund Loans
description: New York officials filed civil complaints on Thursday against two tax preparation firms that offer high-interest loans against income-tax refunds, saying the companies had aimed the loans at low-income black and Hispanic families and military families in violation of state antidiscrimination laws.

title: McDonalds Ending Promotion on Jackets of Childrens Report Cards
description: McDonalds has decided to stop sponsoring Happy Meals as rewards for children with good grades and attendance records in elementary schools in Seminole County, Fla.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about inns and hotels in the New York region that cater to new mothers, pregnant women or couples who want to become parents misstated, in some editions, the given name of a man who recently stayed with his wife and their new son at the Parrot Mill Inn in Chatham, N.J. He is Mark Sodano, not Dan.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about the surprising emergence of running back Ryan Grant of the Green Bay Packers referred incorrectly to his classroom performance at the University of Notre Dame. The university said he was never ineligible to play for academic or other reasons; he did not miss one season because of academic trouble.

title: Councilman Is Penalized for Violating Finance Law
description: Five hundred seventy dollars for Spanish food delivery. An additional $770 for campaign jingles. Some $2,000 for a Dominican Day parade float and $1,500 to buy a bus.

title: Footnotes
description: A portrait of Stephen Colbert, below, of The Colbert Report has been hung between the bathrooms in the American Presidents exhibition at the Smithsonian Institutions National Portrait Gallery in Washington, The Associated Press reported. Bethany Bentley, a museum spokeswoman, said the display, scheduled for six weeks, is a joke.

title: Rivers Sits at Practice, but Could Play Sunday
description: SAN DIEGO  Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers did not practice Thursday, unless you count throwing a pass along the sideline.

title: Spare Times Listings
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Giuliani Had Ties to Company Trying to Sell Border Technology
description: On the presidential campaign trail, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani often promotes the installation of electronic monitoring devices at the border to stem illegal immigration, without mentioning that until a few months ago, he was partner in a company trying to market such technology.

title: Prison Makes Way for Future, but Preserves Past
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif.  The dank crypt for the living still wields emotional power, its peeling ocher walls and low vaulted ceilings suffused with chill and darkness.

title: Clemens Hires Top Washington Lawyer
description: Roger Clemens has bolstered his legal team, hiring a powerhouse Washington lawyer, Lanny A. Breuer, who represented former President Bill Clinton during his impeachment hearings as well as numerous corporations that were the subject of Congressional investigations.

title: Winter Day Out in Seattle
description: DRINK coffee. Put on another layer of dry clothes. Repeat. This is the formula to warm inside and out. Then attack a Seattle winter day undaunted, ignoring downpours like the locals, who act as if the epidermis were made of Gore-Tex.

title: Jennings Joins Rangers
description: Jason Jennings, a Dallas native who grew up watching Nolan Ryan pitch for Texas, was introduced as the newest addition to the Rangers rotation. Jennings, a free-agent right-hander, agreed to a one-year deal worth $4 million. Jennings, 29, is coming off an injury-plagued season in Houston, where he was 2-9 with a career-worst 6.45 earned run average. He missed three months with elbow problems.

title: C.I.A. Says Tribal Leader Behind Bhuttos Death
description: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that the assassins who last month killed former Pakistani prime minister Benazir Bhutto were directed by Baitullah Mehsud, a Pakistani militant leader, and that some of them had ties to Al Qaeda.

title: Herald Tribune Publisher Departs
description: PARIS  Michael Golden, the publisher of The International Herald Tribune, said Friday that he was leaving the newspaper and returning to New York to focus on his position as vice chairman of The New York Times Company.

title: South Korea: Bid Is Made for Shipping Service
description: The Kumho-Asiana Group, owner of South Koreas largest builder and second-biggest airline, bid more than 4 trillion won ($4.3 billion) for control of the Korea Express Company to add cargo delivery and warehousing services. The bidding group comprises about 10 companies, not all of which are controlled by Kumho-Asiana, and is the leading bidder, according to a spokesman for the Seoul Central District Court, where Korea Express has been in receivership since 2001. Korea Express, based in Seoul, fell under court control after failing to pay debts inherited from its parent, the Dongah Construction Industrial Company. It runs warehouses and container ports, as well as handling international door-to-door deliveries.

title: Politics Wrapped in a Clothing Ad
description: IT is not often that a clothing advertisement includes the words apartheid and purgatory along with a quote from President Bush, but American Apparel has always been different from other consumer brand companies.

title: Owners Give Selig Ultimate Endorsement
description: Bud Seligs legacy as the commissioner of Major League Baseball will always be complicated. In more than 15 years on the job, he has steered the sport through periods of unprecedented growth and unrelenting controversy.

title: Brazil: Sale of Iron Ore Projects Is Weighed
description: The British mining company Anglo American is in exclusive negotiations to pay $5.5 billion for control of iron ore projects owned by the Brazilian mining concern MMX Minerao e Metlicos, the companies said. Under terms of a complex deal, Anglo American would buy the MMX shares owned by a Brazilian businessman, Eike F. Batista, and secure control of the companys Minas-Rio and Amapa ore mines in Brazil, the companies said. Anglo American said the talks focused on the acquisition of Mr. Batistas 63.6 percent share in what would be a new company broken off from MMX. That company would own MMXs current 51 percent interest in Minas-Rio and 70 percent interest in Amapa. Anglo American would also pay royalties to MMX for the Minas-Rio project beginning in 2025 and beginning in 2023 for Amapa.

title: A Renewed Candidacy for Thompson
description: LAURENS, S.C.  The presidential candidate known as Fred moseys into Whitefords Giant Burger, possessing that La-Z-Boy manner and a fistful of conservative principles.

title: Hamas Police Force Recruits Women in Gaza
description: GAZA CITY  The policemen of Hamas now have company: since the Islamic group took over here last June it has been recruiting policewomen as well.

title: With Big Backlog of Homes, Builders and Buyers Wait
description: New-home construction fell again in December as builders scrambled to cut back in the face of rising inventories and fewer orders. The drop-off is likely to hurt businesses that serve the housing industry, which economists do not expect to bottom out until the middle of the year.

title: Defensive Coordinator Has the Giants Respect
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants started the season losing by 45-35 to the Dallas Cowboys and by 35-13 to the Green Bay Packers, there was dismay in sports bars and on talk radio, but not in the locker room.

title: One Plus One Plus One Equals Infinite Options
description: Wednesday night at the Jazz Gallery, three musicians who have played as a trio only a few times before  the drummer Jeff Ballard, the guitarist Lionel Loueke and the alto saxophonist Miguel Zenn  played as if they were meant to be together, and also demonstrated how wide the knowledge of the well-prepared jazz musician can be today.

title: Directors Reach Accord With Hollywood Studios
description: LOS ANGELES  After months of informal talks, Hollywoods movie and television directors agreed Thursday afternoon to a new contract with production companies. The accord would appear to send a none-too-subtle message to striking screenwriters: This is not the time to get hung up on new media.

title: Snapshots of a Campaign in Flux
description: To the Editor:

title: A Magazine Adds to a Controversy
description: The Golfweek cover, with a noose set against a purplish sky, showed that the comment from the Golf Channels Kelly Tilghman on Jan. 4 that one way for young golfers to stop Tiger Woods is to lynch him in a back alley is not abating.

title: For Leonard, Its All About Fairways, Greens and Rock n Roll
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  A fair wind blew across Justin Leonards left shoulder in the second round of the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic on Thursday, and like any great Texas golfer he knew just what to do with it. Standing on the 15th tee at La Quinta Country Club, a 3-iron in one hand and a share of the tournament lead in the other, Leonard gauged the breezes gusting through the tall palms and pierced them with a textbook shot that stopped 4 feet from the hole, 209 yards away.

title: A Joyful Noise: Midday Music
description: I HAD never seen anyone walk through a church so fast.

title: Acrimony Leads Closure in West Virginia Conflict
description: In the acrimonious aftermath of the Rich Rodriguez era at West Virginia, Bill Stewart, the head coach for about two weeks, is looking for closure, which does not seem to be in reach.

title: Knocked Out
description: Los Angeles

title: Researchers Challenge Water-Flow Model
description: Decades ago, when geologists were developing ideas about how water typically flows across land, many of them studied the streams of the Mid-Atlantic States, concluding that they naturally move in ribbonlike channels cut through silty banks. In the years since, ecologists and conservationists have used this model in efforts to restore streams damaged by urbanization.

title: A Weekend Home Thats Straight Out of a Dream
description: JAMES WOODYARD has no problem starting small.

title: A Car-Fraud Sting With a Long Arm
description: The cars came from all over  upstate New York and Maryland, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The owners brought them to middlemen who would deliver them for a fee to a nondescript garage in Queens. The cars, the owners thought, would be stripped down for parts, and they could then claim the vehicles as stolen and recoup tens of thousands of dollars from insurance companies.

title: Facing Deportation but Clinging to Life in U.S.
description: WAUKEGAN, Ill.  She is a homeowner, a taxpayer, a friendly neighbor and an American citizen. Yet because she is married to an illegal immigrant, these days she feels like a fugitive.

title: West Virginia Chief Justice Steps Away From Case
description: Chief Justice Elliott E. Maynard of the West Virginia Supreme Court disqualified himself on Friday from further participation in a case involving a powerful coal executive after photographs of two men meeting in Monte Carlo in 2006 were filed in court this week.

title: A Season of Achievement, a Week of Distraction
description: Last spring the New England Patriots took a gamble. On draft day, the franchise noted for employing players with character sent a 2007 fourth-round draft choice to Oakland for Randy Moss, a player known for having his share of character issues.

title: Newark: 2 Planes Dangerously Close
description: Federal aviation officials are investigating what they described as an error by an air traffic controller that put two planes landing at Newark Liberty International Airport within 600 feet of each other on Wednesday. The minimum vertical separation allowed for flights landing at the airport is 1,000 feet, according to Federal Aviation Administration officials and air traffic controllers. This was a very difficult and dangerous situation, said Ray Adams, vice president of the air traffic controllers union at the airport. According to Jim Peters, an F.A.A. spokesman, the error occurred when an air traffic controller mistakenly gave one of the planes the frequency for the tower at nearby Teterboro Airport. As a result, the Newark tower was temporarily unable to contact the crew as both planes approached Newark. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Growth of Genetic Tests Concerns Federal Panel
description: WASHINGTON  The science of genetic tests is marching ahead and so are efforts to sell them directly to consumers who are willing to send in a check and a bit of saliva to learn whether they are at risk for a disease.

title: Confederate Flag Takes Center Stage Once Again
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The Republican presidential candidates on Thursday moved to appeal to different types of conservative voters before the South Carolina primary, with Mike Huckabee using colorful language to declare the Confederate flag a states rights issue and Senator John McCain embracing a supply-side tax cut proposal.

title: Britain Suspends Operations of Two Offices in Russia
description: LONDON  A government-financed British cultural organization said Thursday that it had suspended operations in two Russian cities, accusing the Russian security police and tax authorities of harassing members of its local staff by summoning them for interrogation, sometimes late at night in their homes.

title: Edwards Attacks Obama for View of Reagan
description: HENDERSON, Nev.  The legacy of Ronald Reagan was invoked in the Democratic nominating race on Thursday when John Edwards attacked Senator Barack Obama for remarks he made to a Nevada newspaper suggesting praise for Reagan.

title: Taking a Long, Bumpy Ride to Systematic Brutality
description: A year from now, the presidency of George W. Bush will end, but the consequences of Mr. Bushs policies and the arguments about them are likely to be with us for a long time. As next Jan. 20 draws near, there is an evident temptation, among many journalists as well as politicians seeking to replace Mr. Bush, to close the book and move ahead, an impulse that makes the existence of documentaries like Alex Gibneys Taxi to the Dark Side all the more vital. If recent American history is ever going to be discussed with the necessary clarity and ethical rigor, this film will be essential.

title: Its Easier This Year: Serena Williams Cruises to Victory
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It has been a much more tranquil first week at the Australian Open for Serena Williams. A year ago, she was having to slug her way out of early danger as an unseeded outsider who would end up winning the most surprising title of her career.

title: Fewer Idol Viewers
description: One day after the premiere audience for Foxs "American Idol" fell 4 million viewers shy of the series 2007 debut, the talent competition slipped further in the ratings on Wednesday. Still, televisions most popular series continued to crush its competition on the night by tens of millions of viewers, drawing 30.3 million from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen estimated. That tally, however, represented a decline of 3 million from Tuesdays premiere and 6.7 million from the series first Wednesday installment a year ago. In second place, NBC trailed far behind Fox but got a boost from both Deal or No Deal at 8 (11.8 million) and Law & Order at 10 (11.6 million). CBS finished third, struggling at 8 with Power of 10 (4.9 million) but faring better at 9 with the two-hour conclusion of the mini-series Comanche Moon (12.1 million). ABC ranked fourth over all but edged past CBS for third place among adults 18 to 49.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A headline in Business Day on Thursday with an article about research involving two widely used cholesterol-lowering drugs misstated the issue raised by the results. It is whether using drugs to lower cholesterol at all costs is always medically effective, or even safe; there is no question that cholesterol itself can pose dangers.

title: Locating Love Between Silly and Serious
description: When Paul McCartney sang Some people want to fill the world with silly love songs in 1976, he was merely stating the obvious. Nor does the world lack for serious love songs. But writers have also portrayed amorous subjects in countless shades of gray, and it was to some of those works that the New York Festival of Song turned for a concert on Wednesday night in the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at the Juilliard School.

title: Coming From Different Places, Two Americans Advance
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  They are unseeded Americans in the third round of the Australian Open.

title: Despite Doubts, Cancer Therapy Draws Patients
description: PUERTO VALLARTA, Mexico  Some weekends, more than a dozen American men wait at beachfront hotels, anxious for their turns in the treatment room at a small private hospital here.

title: Winter Day Out in Boston
description: BOSTON is a city of ghosts, but on the coldest of days, dont expect them to come to you. Instead, visit Forest Hills Cemetery, a rambling Victorian-era burial ground about four miles from downtown and a splendidly quiet place to roam. Winding paths crisscross its 275 acres, and if you pick up a map by the entrance, you can find the graves of Anne Sexton, E. E. Cummings and Eugene ONeill. Drive slowly along the narrow roads until you find a good place to park and wander. On a recent morning, snow crunched underfoot and fell in soft chunks from the treetops. Bliss.

title: Those Chaotic College Years in Beijing
description: Toward the end of Lou Yes Summer Palace, Yu Hong (Lei Hao) reflects that her college years were the most confused time in her life. A lot of us might feel similarly, but Yu Hong, the beautiful and passionate heroine of this beautiful and passionate film, is something of a special case.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about Coach Bill Belichicks efforts to motivate the New England Patriots for their playoff game against San Diego misstated the Chargers record through the first five games this season. It was 2-3, not 1-4.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Dec. 30 about Nyiga Tenzin Nordon, a Tibetan refugee whose son was badly injured by a hit-and-run driver in Queens and who received help through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misidentified the hotel where Ms. Nordon works as a maid. It is the Hilton Garden Inn in Times Square, on Eighth Avenue at 48th Street  not the Hilton Times Square, on 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

title: Winter Day Out in Chicago
description: WINTER comes and Chicago trudges proudly on as if nothing has changed. On a recent Saturday morning, as the city sat beneath a foot of fresh snow, people strolled in Millennium Park, the citys front yard along Lake Michigan, even as three snowplows scraped circles around them. Still, without violating the citys code of stoicism, one can find the ideal winter day here by alternating all that outdoor grit with a smattering of permitted hideaways.

title: China Says Its Seafood Is Now Safer and Better
description: BEIJING  The Chinese agriculture ministry said a recent crackdown on the use of illegal veterinary drugs had significantly improved the quality and safety of the countrys seafood production.

title: Their House to Yours, via the Trash
description: By 9:15 most mornings, Thomas Germain, a ruddy-faced man in a yellow slicker, is pushing his oversize black wheeled suitcase down 12th Street in the direction of the Strand Bookstore on Broadway. Sometimes, the suitcase is stuffed full of books; sometimes the books fill a box or two or three that he balances carefully on top of it, a mass of swaying literature he rolls all the way from Greenwich Village or SoHo or Stuyvesant Town.

title: The Exalted, Captured but Not Bowed
description: The photographer Irving Penn put Marcel Duchamp in a corner, exposed Colettes forehead and swaddled Rudolf Nureyevs lithe body in layers of winter clothing. His subjects, who included many of the greatest creative talents of the 20th century, emerged from their portrait sessions with their carefully shaped personas profoundly shaken.

title: Chip Maker Is Nearing Profitability Despite Loss
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Advanced Micro Devices inched closer to profitability despite posting a huge loss as it struggled to absorb the huge cost of its acquisition of ATI Technologies, a graphics chip maker.

title: A Reluctant Cornerback Now Likes Green Bay
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  When cornerback Charles Woodson became a free agent after the 2005 season, the Packers called him. When Woodson expressed interest in Jacksonville and Tampa Bay, the Packers called him again. And again. And again.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Never Too Old to Startle the Eye
description: You wont find ebony-veneered cabinets dripping with gilt ormolu at the American Antiques Show. Nor glossy Beaux Arts paintings of scenes from ancient mythology. Americas material culture is homespun and plainspoken. What it lacks in European polish it makes up for in unpretentious directness, inventiveness and sometimes startling idiosyncrasy. That at least is how it appears in this years enthralling roundup of 45 antiques and folk art dealers at the Metropolitan Pavilion.

title: Manning Finds Maturity Loves Company
description: Boomer Esiason instantly remembered when it clicked for him as a quarterback. It was the third game of his second season, in 1985, when he and the Cincinnati Bengals battled Dan Fouts and the visiting San Diego Chargers, but lost 44-41, at Riverfront Stadium.

title: MBIA and Ambac Fall on Ratings Fear
description: Shares of two bond insurers, MBIA Inc. and the Ambac Financial Group, battered by losses from the collapse of the subprime mortgage market, fell sharply Thursday in New York Stock Exchange trading on concern they would lose their AAA credit ratings.

title: Health Care Could Sway Nevadans
description: LAS VEGAS  Voters in Nevada fret about the economy. Many are disquieted by the war. They worry about taxes, the federal threat of a nuclear waste site in their midst, immigration and gun rights.

title: Train Unions in Accord
description: WASHINGTON  Amtrak and nine of its unions have reached a tentative contract agreement, according to industry experts, and plan to announce the settlement on Friday. A strike would have shut down Pennsylvania Station as well as cross-country trains and commuter service in California and the Chicago area.

title: Bobby Fischer, Chess Master, Dies at 64
description: Bobby Fischer, the iconoclastic genius who was one of the greatest chess players the world has ever seen, died on Thursday in a hospital in Reykjavik, Iceland. He was 64.

title: On the Trail
description: The Democratic presidential candidates campaigned in California and Nevada, while the Republicans focused on South Carolina.

title: The Dream Continued
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Rick Nash Goal
description: First, take a look:

title: The Struggle for Palm Oil
description: A steep rise in prices for palm oil has forced many families in Dharavi, a sprawling slum in Mumbai, India, to use less oil or even cut back on food.

title: They Had a Grade A Beef
description: McDonalds to protesters: Fine, have it your way! From todays Times:

title: Anglo American in Talks for $5.5 Billion Brazilian Iron Projects
description: The British mining company Anglo American is in exclusive negotiations to pay $5.5 billion for control of iron ore projects owned by the Brazilian mining concern MMX Minerao e Metlicos, the companies said.

title: South Korean Concern Bids for Korea Express
description: The Kumho-Asiana Group, owner of South Koreas largest builder and second-biggest airline, bid more than 4 trillion won ($4.3 billion) for control of the Korea Express Company to add cargo delivery and warehousing services.

title: Royal Bank of Canada to Change Name of U.S. Unit
description: The Royal Bank of Canada said it plans to drop the Centura name from its United States banking unit in April, and will rename it the RBC Bank.

title: Anagran Hooks Up With V.C.s in $12 Million Round
description: Anagran, a maker of devices that control data flow on computer networks, raised $12 million in a third venture capital round as it begins commercial sales of a new type of router that is positioned as an add-on device to allow for greater network traffic on existing equipment.

title: This Season, Bulked-Up Banks Came Clean
description: This earnings season on Wall Street was like the Mitchell Report for baseball, David Weidner of MarketWatch wrote: We found out who was on the juice.

title: Lazard-Backed SPAC Prices Public Offering
description: Special-purpose acquisition vehicles have become increasingly popular in the last year or so, with well-known deal-makers such as Ronald Perelman and Nelson Peltz sponsoring SPACs of their own. The latest to hit the market is Sapphire Industrials, which is backed by the investment bank Lazard.

title: Investor Calls for Ouster of Comcast Chief
description: Is the performance of Comcasts chief executive, Brian Roberts, a Comcastrophe?

title: London Stock Exchange Opens Beijing Office to Compete With U.S.
description: The London Stock Exchange opened a Beijing office Friday, stepping up its rivalry with United States markets to attract listings by fast-growing Chinese companies expanding abroad.

title: Texas Cable Company Said to Go on the Block
description: A Texas cable provider, Grande Communications Holdings, has tapped Waller Capital to evaluate its strategic opportunities, according to The Deal.com.

title: Independent News in African Advertising Deal
description: Independent News & Media said late Thursday it would pay 86.6 million euros ($127 million) for the 50 percent of Clear Channel Independent, an African advertising firm, that it doesnt already own.

title: Delphi Wins Approval for Bankruptcy Plan
description: The auto parts supplier Delphi said Thursday it had won approval from nearly all of its creditors and cleared away an objection by bondholders for its plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: Bank of New York Mellon Post 68% Decline in Profit
description: Bank of New York Mellon said Thursday that fourth-quarter profit declined 68 percent because of its exposure to assets backed by mortgages and a strong quarter a year ago, when the bank gained $1.4 billion after unloading its retail operations.

title: Private Equity-Owned Somerfield Said to Be for Sale
description: The owners of Somerfield Stores, a British grocery chain, have put the company up for sale and brought in Citigroup to conduct an auction, The Deal reported.

title: A High Price for Countrywide Deals Failure
description: The mortgage lender Countrywide Financial may have to pay Bank of America a fee of $160 million if a deal to buy it falls through, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.

title: Google Offers a Map for Its Philanthropy
description: Google announced a plan on Thursday that begins to fulfill the pledge it made to investors when it went public nearly four years ago to reserve 1 percent of its profit and equity to make the world a better place. The beneficiaries of Googles money range from groups that are fighting disease to those developing a commercial plug-in car.

title: $15 Billion Beer Merger May Be on Tap
description: The worlds next big beer deal could be struck in the next few days, after British brewer Scottish & Newcastle agreed Thursday to sit down with Carlsberg and Heineken, whose approach S&N had resisted for three months,

title: Ex-Amaranth Executive Reappears At Hudson Bay
description: Hudson Bay Capital Management, the hedge fund founded by ex-proprietary trader Sander Gerber, hired Amaranth Advisors former chief operating officer, Charles Winkler, according to a report in HedgeWorld.

title: Targets of M&A Boom May Not Regret Making a Deal
description: The conventional wisdom over the past two decades is that in a merger and acquisition boom, buyers pay too much, leading to value destruction and leaving shareholders to suffer a hangover after bouts of frenetic dealmaking.

title: NYSE Euronext Strikes Deal for American Stock Exchange
description: Announcing a long-rumored deal, NYSE Euronext said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the American Stock Exchange for $260 million in stock to increase its business in options, exchange-traded funds and cash products.

title: Doctors Take On a Notorious E-Mail
description: For years, a message circulating on the Internet has urged women to demand a special blood test as a way to screen themselves for ovarian cancer. Doctors have dismissed the e-mail, saying the recommended test isnt reliable. The original author has even softened her stance, telling women the issue is far more complex than she first thought.

title: Williams Pipeline Raises $304 Million in I.P.O.
description: Williams Pipeline Partners said late Thursday that its initial public offering of 16.25 million common units had priced at $20 per unit, the midpoint of the anticipated price range.

title: China Everbright I.P.O. Expected in the Spring
description: A Chinese financial conglomerate, the China Everbright Group, intends to list its commercial banking arm on the Shanghai A share market and then possibly Hong Kong, state media said on Friday.

title: Willis Group Said to Eye Deal for Marsh & McLennan
description: An insurance broker, Willis Group Holdings, has approached its bigger rival, Marsh & McLennan about a possible takeover of Marsh & McLennan, CNBC reported.

title: Conservative Approach Pays Off for BlackRock
description: Dodging the rocky investments that have damaged many Wall Street banks, BlackRock, the giant asset management firm, said on Thursday that fourth-quarter profit rose 90 percent.

title: Kellwood Shareholder Supports Sun Capital Bid
description: A major shareholder in Kellwood, whose brands include Phat Farm, has come out to support Sun Capital Securities Groups hostile bid for the struggling apparel maker.

title: Borders Puts Pershing Partner on Board
description: Borders Group said it has given a board seat to a partner from Pershing Square Capital Management, an activist hedge-fund firm that is one of the booksellers largest shareholders. The partner, Richard McGuire, is one of five people responsible for managing about $6 billion for Pershing, Borders said in a statement.

title: Wall Streets Next Crisis: Bond Insurers?
description: The growing crisis at Ambac Financial, one of the biggest bond insurers, is raising questions about Wall Streets exposure as counterparties to the bond-insurance industry coming off a period in which the big banks are reeling from more than $100 billion in write-downs of mortgage-related securities, according to Forbes.

title: Multimedia Makeover for F.B.I.s Most Wanted
description: While The Lede is prepared to concede that wanted posters need not be esthetically satisfying to accomplish their purpose, the moral of the Steve Jobs and Apple Computer story is that good design really does make a difference, even in utilitarian things.

title: Merrill May Not Be Out of the Woods Yet
description: The outlook darkened for Merrill Lynch on Thursday as news of a huge quarterly loss sent the companys stock plummeting and analysts expressed concern that the company may be in for more pain in the coming months.

title: How to Read a Private Equity Deal Agreement
description: Reading merger agreements is like putting together a jigsaw puzzle. For those who like their puzzle a bit more complex, private equity merger agreements are the ones with more pieces. And since it is Friday and were all looking for a distraction, what follows is a how to guide for reading private equity agreements for closing risk.

title: UBS to Close U.S. Mortgage-Trading Unit
description: UBS, Europes biggest bank, will close a unit in the United States that makes bets on fixed-income investments as it scales back risk-taking after writing down the value of subprime mortgage investments by $14.7 billion last year, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Thats Really, Like, Weird
description: The Sherman Oaks Galleria shopping center anchors a vital place in the American cultural narrative. Fast Times at Ridgemont High was partly shot there, Frank Zappa memorialized it in song, and it was the indigenous habitat for what became known as the Valley Girl.

title: Just a Couple of Movies, Some Friends, and a Lot of Snow
description: Anne Thompson of Variety points out that there are going to be some folks roaming around Sundance who are not usually thought of as auteurs.

title: The Future is Now
description: Michael Cieply untangles the subtext surrounding the tentative deal announced by the Directors Guild of America, suggesting that the directors decided that right now was no time to get hung up on a digital future that still seems to be around the next bend. It could provide a roadmap for striking writers, or lead to cries that they got thrown under a bus.

title: Bobby Fischer Is Dead at 64
description: Bobby Fischer, the mercurial American champion, has died in Iceland, his adopted home. In his later years, he had become a pariah in the chess world because of his strident anti-Americanism and antisemitism, but even that could not detract from his contributions and impact on the chess board. Although he essentially quit chess after winning the title in 1972 in his epic match with Boris Spassky (coming back only in 1992 for another match with Spassky that drew worldwide interest), he raised interest in chess to unprecedented levels and changed the game profoundly. Garry Kasparov, the former world champion, in the fourth book of his series My Great Predecessors, a volume largely devoted to Fischer, wrote, He abandoned the game at the age of 29, and only really played for just ten years, but he succeeded in achieving more in chess than anyone else!

title: Passing of a Fad Creator
description: Richard Knerr, below, who died on Monday at 82, popularized the Hula Hoop and the Frisbee  and thats not all, as the obit notes:

title: Blackstone and Wellspring to Buy Food Distributor
description: Performance Food Group, a food-distribution company, said early Friday it had agreed to be acquired by the Blackstone Group and Wellspring Capital Management for $34.50 in cash, or about $1.3 billion.

title: Merican Independent Film
description: GeoffreyGilmore, the head of Sundance, introduced In Bruges by saying yes, Sundance celebrates American film and edgy film at that, but that something about the Irish-made movie made it seem right as a program opener. In Bruges is a first-time directing effort by Martin McDonagh, the playwright whose credits include The Lieutenant of Inishmore and The Pillowman. Earlier in the evening, Gilmore mentioned that the program this year includes 58 directorial debuts.

title: In Sundance
description: At the second screening for In Bruges at the Eccles Theater, Dana Williams, the mayor of Park City, had some lifestyle advice for the attendees. No stilettos on Main St., take the bus, and be nice to your waiters and waitresses. The Bagger wonders if Paris Hilton will get the memo.

title: The Early Word: Nevada and S.C. Prime for Primaries
description: The Republican caucus in Nevada, to be held on Saturday, has been overshadowed by far by the Democrats lively race there and the fact that most of the Republican candidates have been consumed with campaigning in South Carolina, where the G.O.P. primary will be held Saturday.

title: Fried Squirrel in a Popcorn Maker
description: Some more of your late night comedy (send via the comment link below):

title: Fridays Links: Dads Go Back to Work, Freelancers Name Their Rates
description: 1. I was pleased to see this story, On-ramping not just for women anymore, by Maggie Jackson in The Boston Globe earlier this week. On-ramping programs that focus on helping women return to work after taking years off for child rearing have been getting a lot of attention, but few people have been writing about the men who go through this same experience. It is a good sign for all of us when something moves from being a womens issue to an everyone issue. And that usually happens once the men start speaking out.

title: Design Awards Undimmed
description: DETROIT  Too bad that it was so dark in the lower level of Cobo Center, where the winners of the Eyes on Design Awards were announced on Tuesday, too bad the people at the adjoining Chinese booths were so noisy, and too bad that the awards chairman, Tom Gale, was absent (for eye surgery, of all things).

title: What the Mayors State of the City Address Means
description: In a front-page article, Diane Cardwell describes and analyzes Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs seventh State of the City address, in which he unveiled a mix of tough education and anticrime measures while embracing the virtues of immigration. One proposal, to collect DNA samples from anyone arrested for a crime in the city, could be tough to sell, especially to state legislators, who took seven years to approve a similar provision for people who had been convicted of felonies and some misdemeanors.

title: Seeking Ways to Help the Worlds Poorest
description: Participants are being sought for the second International Development Design Summit, which will be held next summer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The first such workshop, which I wrote about last year, saw 40 students, engineers, farmers, professors and others from 18 countries hunker down in groups to devise simple, affordable ways to clean water, chill produce, generate electricity, and solve other problems facing the worlds poorest communities.

title: Rideem, Peacock! Nashville Star Moves To NBC
description: The sixth season of USA Networks country music competition series Nashville Star is moving to NBC for a summer run, TV Week reports.

title: Figaro! Figaro! Training the Multitasking Brain
description: Before I reveal the Figaro Factotum regimen for greater personal productivity, let me explain how it came about. Maintaining a blog while doing other things has reminded me of how bad I am at juggling different jobs. Ive tried to excuse this as a consequence of my gender. Ive tried consoling myself with the theories of evolutionary psychologists who say that male hunters on the savanna needed to focus intently on one job  kill or be killed  while women evolved to be better multitaskers because the survival of the species depended on their being able to keep an eye on children while doing other work.

title: The Gospel of Fred
description: Render unto Caesar what is Caesars: Former Bush speechwriter Michael Gerson, in his Washington Post column, says that Fred Thompson lacks moral seriousness for his dismissal of President Bushs global AIDS initiative. Gerson writes:

title: Stray Questions for: Elissa Schappell
description: Elissa Schappell is the author of the novel Use Me and a co-editor of the anthology Money Changes Everything.

title: And the Vizio Goes to
description: It is award season, and it can seem like there are awards for just about everything except best performance by a relatively low-paid football player.

title: Podcast: A Favorite Sons Strategy
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: A View From the S.C. Newsstands
description: COLUMBIA, S.C. - On the newsstands here, in magazines aimed at African-American readers, Barack Obama appears to be the man of the month. He smiles on the cover of the January issue of Jet, Black Enterprise and a South Carolina lifestyle magazine geared to black homeowners, How We Live.

title: Dont Let It End
description: From the Department of Conventional Wisdom: A majority of political consultants apparently thinks that neither the Democrats nor Republicans will be able to pick a nominee by Feb. 5, by which time half the states will have voted.

title: George Returns To Cartoon Jungle
description: The George of the Jungle cartoon returns to television for the first time in 41 years today, with the debut of a Cartoon Network version at 7:30 p.m. Stuart Elliott reports:

title: How Will Wall Street Weather the Storm?
description: The financial carnage isnt over yet. The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, may not use the R word, but more and more analysts and investors are. For Wall Street firms recovering from last years huge losses, that means there may be even fewer sources of new business to give earnings a much-needed boost in 2008.

title: John Thains Golden Hello Loses Some Shine
description: Thursdays 10 percent decline in Merrill Lynchs shares took a toll on the big gift basket of Merrill stock and stock options that Mr. Thain received when he came on board as the securities firms chief executive in December.

title: Podcast: A Favorite Sons Strategy
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: Celeb Reality Mastermind Forms Outside Production Company
description: After a successful run at VH1, Michael Hirschorn is leaving the cable network to form his own production company, which will develop shows initially for that channel and others owned by MTV Networks, including MTV, CMT, and Logo, Bill Carter reports:

title: Romneys S.C. Strategist
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Among South Carolina political strategists, one name stands out: J. Warren Tompkins 3d. His own press release probably has the best description of him, stating that Mr. Tompkins has had an enduring impact on South Carolina politics for nearly two decades.

title: Share Your Thoughts: The Writers Guild Strike
description: The lives of movie and television fans, network executives and, of course, writers, have been turned upside-down during the Writers Guild strike.

title: A Less Stylish Approach to RFID
description: Followers  and opponents  of wireless tracking technology will always have a soft spot for Prada, the Italian fashion design company that ambitiously experimented with attaching RFID tags to clothing and accessories in its showcase Soho store in 2002.

title: Q & A With John Branch: N.F.C. Championship Edition
description: Last week, John Branch answered your questions on all things NYG in the run up to the game against the Cowboys. We know how that turned out.

title: Union Protest Roils Private Equity Conference
description: David Rubenstein was supposed to deliver the keynote speech Friday morning at the Wharton Private Equity Conference, an annual event that draws buyout professionals and academics to discuss the state of the industry. Instead, Mr. Rubenstein, managing director of the Carlyle Group, was hooted off the stage, as The Philadelphia Inquirers Joseph N. DiStefano described it, by protesters from the Service Employees International Union.

title: Talk Off | Starbucks
For the Moment |  Francesco Vezzoli
description: This weeks guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidals Caligula, starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandellos Right You Are (If You Think You Are), starring  among others  Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his fifth post of the week he writes about  and links to  the favorite T.V. moments of his childhood years in Italy. To read all of Francesco Vezzolis prior blog posts, click here.

title: Fans Journal: On My Way to Ghana
description: I will be traveling to Ghana with four friends and fellow soccer fans for the African Cup of Nations where I am expecting the unexpected.

title: The Lid Is Lifted, but the Tune Is Movin Out
description: Gerald Wright, the co-owner, with his wife and in-laws, of Rita Ford Music Boxes in Manhattan, started working there for Mrs. Ford in the 1980s almost by accident. An acquaintance who was working at the store moved away, Mr. Wright needed the money, and the rest was history.

title: Taunting Evidence Intensifies the Tiger Case
description: Was the tiger taunted? The San Francisco polices first answer was found in a court document obtained by The San Francisco Chronicle:

title: Romney Will Appear on Leno Show
description: ELKO, Nev.  Mitt Romney will be flying this afternoon from Reno to Burbank, Calif., for a taping of the The Tonight Show with Jay Leno.

title: Paris Mens Wear  | Louis Vuitton
description: Yesterday was a good day for the Louis Vuitton mens wear designer Paul Helbers, who celebrated both his 39th birthday and his coming out of the designer closet: Marc Jacobs shared his bow with him at the end of the show, officially acknowledging his role. Helbers skillful collection of slick suits, tough bomber jackets and layered nylon blousons was inspired by Alain Delon and Jean Gabins characters as bank robbers in the 1963 film Mlodie en Sous-sol, and was right on trend with the tough edge that is coursing through the season. But what will most likely keep LV cash registers from Tokyo to Dubai ringing nonstop is the new graphite Damier  a slick new black-and-gray version of the well-known Vuitton check pattern  that turned up on hard suitcases, weekender bags, and even motorcycle helmets.Read a profile of Paul Helbers, published in T: The New York Times Style Magazine

title: Rocco Landesman Answers Your Broadway Questions
description: We recently solicited your questions for Broadway producer Rocco Landesman, and threw in a few of our own as well. Reading his answers below, you can see why he is considered not only one of Broadway's best producers, but also one of the most astute. Thanks to Rocco, and to all of you for the questions.  Q: What will Broadway look like in 20 years?   A: This is a live, hand-made industry where the product is created new and live each night, just as it was 50 years ago. As such, in twenty years, it should look much as it does now -- except that Nathan Lane will look notably older.   Q: What factors contribute to the high price of Broadway tickets? Theater rents? Union salaries? Audience expectations of an onstage spectacle? Are these costs increasing? Do rising costs lead to less risk-taking and more middle-of-the-road, lowest-common-denominator fare on Broadway?   A: The issue in our business is that we lack both an economy of scale and mechanization. We can't make a million, or even a thousand copies of the same movie. As I wrote earlier, the product is handmade and repeated live each night. The sets and costumes are custom made. The actors have to be live. It is labor intensive to the Nth degree, and as those costs rise, so do ticket prices. There is really no productivity gain through the technology boom. Actors and stagehands keep getting more money, and the costs of marketing a show seem to keep going up exponentially. Then, of course, the higher the cost, the more risk averse the producer and investors become. So yes, there is inevitably some decline in venturesomeness. Better to stick with the tried and true, or the show with the widest possible audience.   Q: What's the current trend in Broadway attendance? Why do people still go to the theater when it's so much more expensive than other forms of entertainment?   A: Broadway attendance has been trending up. Attendance by New Yorkers has leveled off, but that has been more than made up for by tourists, both American and international. There are many more competing forms of entertainment, but there's really no replacement for a live experience. It is really not replicable through any technology or alternate form of delivery.   Q: Tell us about the economics of hiring a star for a Broadway show versus a non-star. As much as stars draw box office, they also spike the budget and, I assume, limit a potentially long run. Is it worth it?   A: Some shows, especially plays, need a star in order to sell tickets. Of course, from the producers' standpoint, it's best when the show is the star. The Producers ran for more than three years after the departure of Lane and Matthew Broderick.   Q: Where do Broadway audiences come from (geographically)? What's a surprising place that a lot of customers come from?   A: In general terms, the audience for plays is from New York and for musicals, after the first year or so, from outside New York. Which is one reason why musicals usually run much longer than plays.   Q: Assuming that the vast majority of Broadway customers come from out of town, why is there so much Broadway advertising in New York City  on buses, e.g.?   A: Because purchase decisions are often made after the customers arrive. And it would be impossible to advertise in 300 cities.   Q: What's the state of Broadway ticket scalping, and what's your position on it?   A: The problem for years has been that the only people who really score with a hit show have been the scalpers. When we instituted the $400 ticket for The Producers, we started to address this problem. In the new system, the price is printed on the ticket, and the money actually goes to the people responsible for the show -- the investors, the creative team, etc. -- instead of to the ticket brokers. We are in favor of a free market system where the market ultimately sets the price on premium tickets.   Q: You were the first producer to charge $100 for a single ticket, for The Producers. What was the impact and response?   A: It had no effect whatsoever on demand. We could have sold all the tickets we could print.   Q: How true to life is The Producers?   Max Bialystock was based on a real life producer that Mel Brooks knew personally. Current producers are not all crooks -- at least, most of them aren't.   Q: So much of Broadway seems to be derived from movies today (partly thanks to The Producers, which has done it better than anyone before or since). Is this a healthy trend? More broadly, will people still produce original plays and musicals in 5 or 10 years, or will originality be left to off- and off-off-Broadway? What message should playwrights take from this trend?   A: The creators of musicals are always looking for stories. Once upon a time, the stories were found in short stories, novels, plays, and other literary sources. Now, many of the stories are in movies. This is a natural and healthy migration, and the actual process [of creating Broadway shows] hasn't changed.   Q: It seems that in the last few years, there have been a number of shows that exist primarily to showcase the music of one particular artist or band (e.g., Billy Joel, ABBA, Elvis). Is this a trend for the future as well? Should we expect to see "Madonna: The Musical" in the next five to ten years?   A: I truly hope not. But the success of Jersey Boys will probably extend the cycle of so-called jukebox musicals. Usually, if I like the music, I will like the musical, but there has been a wide spectrum of quality in these shows. Compare Good Vibrations with Smokey Joe's Cafe or Jersey Boys.   Q: How well do these so-called jukebox musicals do when measured against traditional musicals?   A: Smokey Joe's Cafe was the longest running review in history. I expect it will be surpassed by Jersey Boys. Generally, these shows are more successful financially because their costs are much lower. The casts are usually smaller and they don't depend on stars or expensive scenery.   Q: If Jujamcyn scores a big advance sale, how do you invest the money?   A: In certificates of deposit.   Q: If you weren't a successful producer and had nothing to do with the entertainment industry, and you had a daughter in high school, would you encourage her to pursue a career on Broadway?   A: I once asked my wife how she would feel if one of our three sons turned out to be gay. She thought for a while, and answered that she didn't think she'd have a problem with it, but she would be upset if one of them decided to become an actor. It is a very tough life, one in which you have little control over your own career.   Q: What benchmarks do you use to judge the success of a show?   A: Critical response and financial reward.   Q: Do you lose more sleep when you first started producing than you do now?   A: Yes. At first, everything was life and death, because that's true at the beginning of a career. My whole career stems from the success of my first show, Big River. After you've had a few hits, everything is not at stake with each show. So I still worry, but I don't lose sleep.  Q: When were you a professional gambler? What kind of gambling did you do?  A: Horse racing. I never bet in casinos.   Q: Do you feel that Broadway is better off after going through a "Disneyfication"?   A: I don't accept the term "Disneyfication." They are producers like everyone else, with their own taste and point of view. The more the merrier.   Q: How do you "break in" as a director or performer? How do you then balance family, children, auditions, rehearsals, etc.?   A: I can't really help on this one. It's very hard, and you have to be incredibly determined -- to be incapable of not doing it. There is no real work/life balancing -- the profession tends to be all-consuming.  Q: How is your relationship with your backstage crew post-strike, and how much do you rely on them?   A: Our stagehands are highly skilled, which is why we never tried to run shows without them during the strike. My relationships -- in many cases, friendships -- with the stagehands I work with was good before the strike, and continues to be good after it. We each did what we felt we had to do.   Q: What is Jerzy Kosinski doing?  A: You'll have to ask God. Or maybe the other guy.   Q: What was the purpose behind the $20 million strike fund that the producers have been accumulating over the last 4 years? Presumably, it was established to keep the shows running during a strike -- which didn't happen.   A: If all of the producers' requests had been granted during the IATSE negotiations, resulting in lowering expenses for the producers, would ticket prices have been reduced? They would have stabilized. That in itself is progress.

title: Looking Forward to Surprises in Africa
description: I didnt want to be a soccer journalist growing up. I wanted to be the next Diego Maradona. But that didnt work out. So here I am, about to head off to Ghana for the 2008 African Cup of Nations where Ill be writing about the tournament. It is the next best thing, as far as Im concerned.

title: Hollywood 411: Like Entertainment Tonight, Only Deeper
description: The TV Guide Network  you know, the one with the omnipresent TV listings  launched its first daily prime time show this week.

title: Friday Kickoff: Talking About Reggie Bush
description: Lloyd Lake, the San Diego business marketer who claims he gave hundreds of thousands of dollars to Reggie Bush during his U.S.C. days, tells USA Today that he is suing Bush because he wants to get his money back and to clear his name.

title: Giuliani Spot Brings NYC to West Palm Beach
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Rudolph W. Giuliani is releasing his third ad in as many days in the Sunshine State, with this spot running specifically in the West Palm Beach market. With a high proportion of Northeastern ex-pats, the area is likely to be a cornerstone of Mr. Giulianis bid for the nomination here, and the spot has plenty of images intended to activate memories (or stereotypes) of New York City.

title: London Most Expensive
description: Central London is the most expensive market in the world for residential apartment buyers, according to a new study by the Global Property Guide, a research firm. In fact, its not even close, with New York, Moscow, Paris and Hong Kong coming across as budget towns, in comparison.

title: Answers About The Jewish Americans
description: Following is a first set of answers from David Grubin, a director, writer and cinematographer working in New York City, who took questions from readers through Jan. 23 on his new three-part documentary, The Jewish Americans, on PBS. A second set of answers was published on Jan. 22. Questions are now closed.

title: Return of the tax families
description: The selling strategy for the first Bush tax cut relied heavily on tax families  photogenic families who would supposedly be the big beneficiaries of the tax break. In fact, they were mainly beneficiaries of the child tax credit and the cutout, the reduction of some peoples rates from 15% to 10%  and they were carefully chosen to give a misleading picture both of how the typical family would fare and who the real main beneficiaries were.

title: Bush Proposes Economic Stimulus Plan
description: President George W. Bush outlines his proposal for a $140 billion economic stimulus plan.

title: Tom Perkins: I Love Bubbles
description: When Tom Perkins isnt blowing the whistle at Hewlett-Packard, sailing in his retro yacht or writing a memoir, he is known as one of Silicon Valleys leading venture capitalists. In that latter capacity, he recently spoke with Spencer Ante, a BusinessWeek editor who also runs the Creative Capital blog, about the current state of venture capital.

title: Would You Want To Vote Sober?
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: At the big Democratic debate the other night, NBC would not allow presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich into the debate because his poll numbers were not high enough. How ironic is that? NBC saying your ratings are too low.

title: Searching for Signs of the Giuliani Campaign
description: Aired Thursday night on CBS: We finally know the name of the woman who posed for the Mona Lisa. Yup. Her name is Lisa del Giocondo. By the way, her identity was leaked by Scooter Libby.

title: Talk About Rebelling Against Your Parents
description: Aired Thursday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: The Presidents daughter, Jenna Bush, has set a date for her wedding. Shes excited about the marriage, especially the part where she gets to change her name.

title: Best stimulus headline
description: From Marketwatch: Bush stimulates the bears.

title: Paris Mens Wear| Group Hug
description: Japanese designers seem to be obsessed with America. The trend started months ago, when Daiki Suzuki of Engineered Garments was tapped to design Woolrich Woolen Mills; he paved the way for Number (N)ines Takahiro Miyashita, who made lumberjack gear look fresh with yesterdays My Own Private Portland show. Today, Junya Watanabe focused on the East Coast with preppy khakis, blazers and varsity jackets that could conceivably make it into a Skull and Bones meeting, while Rei Kawakubo at Comme des Garons set her collection of beautifully weathered clothes stamped with slogans like Demolish the Dominator Culture to the tunes of Ella Fitzgerald Paris club kids are burning over a new dance style called Techtonic. The moves  think sped-up vogueing with a nod to hip-hop  were fully on display last night at the chic lesbian bote Chez Moune, where up-and-coming designer Romain Kremer held a hopping after-show partyWhat is the most fashion-forward item of the week? Could it be Kris Van Assches giant scarf with hand-warming pockets, Comme des Garons plaid kilts that morph into shorts in the back, or Yohji Yamamotos blazers with built-in shawls? Perhaps its the Damier-covered piano that served as a backdrop at Louis Vuitton? Submissions are still being accepted.

title: Fear, Greed and Alliance Data Systems
description: The market is in awe. The gyrations in the stock price of Alliance Data Systems appear to be driven primarily by paranoia and fear of the unknown. As it awaits the closing of its proposed buyout by the Blackstone Group, the company seems to be subject to continuous rumors and hedge fund short selling on a momentum-based, day-trading basis.

title: Ladies, Please Do Not Read This Blog Item
description: Updated, 2:51 p.m. | The Times reported on Thursday about a dispute among board members of the New York Junior League, a womens club and charity, over some missing money, a projected deficit and renovation of the leagues Upper East Side town house. The leagues president has filed a lawsuit and a complaint with the state attorney generals charities bureau. After publication, City Room was provided a copy of the following e-mail message sent out at 10:06 a.m. on Thursday by a member of the leagues board of managers to committee chairwomen:

title: Edwards Appeals for Labor Support
description: LAS VEGAS  Standing in the bed of a white pickup truck parked in a strip mall, John Edwards on Friday asked for support from Nevada union members in Saturdays caucuses.

title: Reacting to Bobby Fischers Death
description: In a small world overcrowded with huge intellects and oddball personalities, he was by all accounts the hugest and the oddest. The chess world is digesting today the news of the death at 64 of Bobby Fischer, the mold-breaking genius who stormed to the world championship and unprecedented fame with his demolition of Boris Spassky in 1972, and then essentially threw it all away, forfeiting his title for failure to defend it and retreating into cranky, rarely broken seclusion.

title: Strike: Who Needs Writers II, Primetime Edition
description: Heres an eye-catching headline: Primetime Ratings Will Increase Thanks to the Strike.

title: Your Results Here
description: And heres yet another way technology is changing the 2008 elections: Digital billboards in South Carolina will be carrying the election returns tomorrow night for the Republican primary as well as the following Saturday for the Democratic primary.

title: Hangover
description: Oooh, I dont like this feeling. I hate it. I cant remember the last time I felt this way.

title: The Mayor and the Philip Roth Quote
description: Updated, 7:12 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg does not often make literary references in his speeches, so we took note when the mayor, at the end of his State of the City address on Thursday, cited a novel.The year ahead is not going to be easy, but as I stand here, Im more optimistic about our future than ever, the mayor said. Theres a great quote in the latest Philip Roth book: I came to New York, the character says, and in only hours, New York did what it does to people  awakened the possibilities. Hope breaks out.

title: Slide Slides Into Some Cash
description: Slide, the maker of applications for social networks, has raised another round of funding  $50 million from the private equity funds at Fidelity and T-Rowe Price, two major Wall Street investment houses. The firms have taken a 9 percent stake in the three-year-old, 64-employee Slide, valuing it at $550 million.

title: N.Y. Panel Calls for Single Financial Regulator
description: A commission assembled to revamp New York States financial regulations recommended on Friday having a single regulator to oversee the securities industry, instead of the current four overseers.

title: Just Browsing | Ripped From the Fashion Rags
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: Explaining the Macintosh Surge
description: At the risk of enraging the Apple bashers, I cant keep my mouth shut any longer: Something is going on with the Macintosh.

title: Coming Sunday

title: Inside the Giants: The N.F.L.s Show About Nothing
description: Friday was the N.F.L.s formal press conference day. We know this because the league sent the Giants a new backdrop to hang behind the lectern in the press room that reads NFC Championship instead of Giants. And the NFL Network has commandeered the corner of the room. As we speak, Solomon Wilcots is on live, and he is shouting as if he is not connected to a microphone. Now, he just apologized to all the reporters in the room.

description: (WireImage)

title: Im Back from Book Leave
description: After five months on book leave, Im back to column-writing. My first column back will be in Sundays paper, and then Ill be writing every Sunday and Thursday. And the book  about women in the developing world  will be out about a year from now.

title: Obamas Closing Argument to Nevada Voters
description: RENO, Nev.  Senator Barack Obama sharply criticized Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on the eve of the Nevada caucuses, declaring: The American people dont want a president whose plans change with the politics of the moment.

title: New S.C. Poll
description: A new Fox News poll in South Carolina shows no bump for Mitt Romney there, after his win in Tuesdays Michigan primary.

title: What Goes Around
description: While I dont especially like the widening effect of either of these looks, from Yohji Yamamoto and Bottega Veneta, they are bluntly similar. As Marko has said in a number of posts, let us praise the Japanese for very often being there firstand without the crucial rhapsody about working-class heroes (as I hum Marianne Faithfulls version.)

title: Co-Lead Defendant in Insider Trading Case is Sentenced
description: A former Goldman Sachs trader who helped lead a $6.7 million insider-trading conspiracy  and then cooperated with the government  was sentenced to time served by a federal district court judge on Friday.

title: The Irresistible Urge to Film New York as Gritty
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The Sundance Film Festival feels like Brooklyn. Wherever you go, you are surrounded by people who say they were here before everyone else was here. And everyone else is still coming, hordes of them, an estimated 50,000 attendees this year, up from 36,000 just two years ago.

title: At Hospital, the Rise and Fall of Latex
description: Products rarely are utterly rejected by the people who invented them, and news releases rarely offer delightful prose. One institution pulled off both in one shot this week, on the subject of latex:

title: South Carolina Ad Wars
description: Over the last three months, John Edwards has flooded South Carolina with television commercials, running far more than either Senators Barack Obama or Hillary Clinton. But in the last two weeks, Mr. Edwards has vastly scaled back his advertising here, and Mr. Obama has ramped his up, according to new figures from Nielsen.

title: Ambac Rating Downgrade Threatens Wider Pain
description: A downgrade of bond insurer Ambac Financial Group is likely to have far-reaching effects, making it more difficult for cities to issue new bonds and forcing further write-downs at financial services companies, analysts said Friday.

title: Why Caucus at All?
description: People who have been close to political campaigns will tell you that the spouse always takes things more personally than the candidate; its just easier to be attacked yourself than it is to watch the person you love get hurt. That probably explains why Bill Clinton, who was as publicly unflappable a candidate as you will ever find in American politics, lost his cool yet again Wednesday (its been happening every six days or so) while lecturing a television reporter on the inherent unfairness of the Nevada caucus system. Of course, Clinton is a persuasive man, but his tirade would have been more convincing had anyone in the Clinton camp complained about Nevadas system before the powerful culinary unions endorsed Barack Obama. And that probably explains why a judge in Nevada ruled Thursday that the caucuses should go on as planned. (Clintons opposition to the plan would also have been more credible, by the way, had Hillary Rodham Clinton herself not noted, after the Iowa caucuses, that a lot of Iowas shift workers hadnt been able to take part. Fair enough, but can you really advocate helping workers caucus in Iowa, where you think they would have voted for you, and then argue against exactly that in Nevada, where you fear they might not?)

title: Whats New at 92 North Shore Drive?
description: We are so excited! Pam Buttoclova, Johns assistant and our official photographer, just e-mailed us a whole bunch of photos documenting progress on our house. Its coming along nicely.

description: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore, who contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog, is in training camp with the United States national team for Saturdays friendly match against Sweden.

title: More Reflections on Bobby Fischer
description: Dylan Loeb McClain, who writes The New York Timess chess blog, Gambit, has been talking to a variety of chess-world figures today about the news that the irascible, inimitable Bobby Fischer, arguably the greatest player in the games history, had died at 64. He has shared some of the choicest fruits of those conversations with The Lede. (Mr. McClains Q&A with Dr. Frank Brady, Mr. Fischers biographer, makes up the bottom half of this earlier post.)
