title: Pete Hamill Downtown, on Downtown
description: Can any New Yorker tell a story quite like Pete Hamill? On Thursday evening, Mr. Hamill, the writer and veteran newspaperman who has edited both The Daily News and The New York Post, kept an audience of more than 500 people enthralled in the Broad Street Ballroom, an architectural gem that is rarely open to the public.

title: The Latest Environmental Victims: The Polar Bear and the Sage Grouse
description: Ed Markey, the tireless Massachusetts Democrat and Speaker Nancy Pelosis brilliant choice to run a Select Committee on Energy Independence and Global Warming, hauled officials from the Interior Department into his committee room last week.

description: Finding new names for vehicle silhouettes was a preoccupation during press previews at the auto show.

description: God forbid if we have to read philosophy in order to read a novel. Walker Percy

title: A Little Something for Everyone
description: WASHINGTON  Bidding to seize control of the accelerating debate over economic stimulus, former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney is proposing a package with something for everyone. In an interview this afternoon for CNBC, Mr. Romney said he will propose: A permanent cut in the lowest income tax bracket to 7.5 percent from 10 percent. The Immediate Retroactive Tax Credit for 2007 applies to employees who earned less than $97,500 in 2007. Make that cut immediately retroactive to 2007 tax liabilities. Permanently eliminate Social Security payroll taxes for workers over 65. Provide 100 percent expensing of new equipment purchased by businesses over two years retroactive to Jan 1 2008. Permanently reduce the corporate tax rate to 20 percent from 35 percent over two years. Permanent eliminate capital gains and dividends taxes on households earning under $200,000 a year, an idea he has previously proposed.

title: Todays Recipe
description: The folksy Mike Huckabee got a lot of laughs when he told MSNBC last week that back in college he and his dorm mates would fry squirrel in popcorn poppers. Clearly this is a case where the Internet might have enhanced the educational experience of yore. For the future Republican presidential candidate could simply have gone to the squirrel recipe page at Backwoods Bound and found all manner of guidance for whipping up chicken-fried squirrel, Daddys squirrel stew, squirrel cacciatore and a

title: I Think I Can, I Think I Can
description: Among the jounalists out here are a few of the Baggers day-job colleagues. David M. Halbfinger is one of them  the Bagger has to get hold of a middle initial of his own somehow  and he just filed the following:

title: Election-Eve Odds
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  As the Straight Talk Express rattled toward a rally here, former Senator Phil Gramm of Texas took a look at his Blackberry.

title: Baghdad Hospital
description: A scene from inside an ambulance, where a mother is being treated for wounds from a bomb.

title: Stray Voltage Still a Problem 4 Years Later
description: On Jan. 16, 2004, Jodie S. Lane, a 30-year-old graduate student walking her dogs, was electrocuted after she stepped on an electrified metal plate in the East Village. Improperly insulated wire beneath the plate had sent 57 volts of electricity running up the side of an underground service box to the plate above.

title: Blogtalk: Details From Nevada and South Carolina
description: With that messy at-large caucus lawsuit behind them, the Nevada blogs have quieted down a little bit ahead of the state caucuses and are turning their attention to wholl be the winners and losers come Saturday night.

title: Merriman Must Battle the Flu Before the Patriots
description: Chargers linebacker Shawne Merriman hopes his defense against Patriots quarterback Tom Brady is better than his bodys defense against the flu. Merriman got sick upon returning from Indianapolis and missed practice earlier in the week.

title: Breaking Bad
description: A scene from AMC's new series, where Bryan Cranston plays a chemistry teacher turned drug dealer.

title: Paris: Not on Easy Street
description: I have several thoughts about recent posts here, notably on Prada and Jil Sander, and some observations about the mens shows we saw today. There is no trace of self-conscious in Junya Watanabes clothes, as there is with so many designers, no gender manipulation that blows up in his face and only makes the rest of us laugh sadly with disappointment. He showed the shrunken blazer, a style he has done before (before Mr. Browne), as if to express the general distaste and contempt that young men have for this formal look. They scorn it, and so does Junya, now showing the coat with ties and shirts that are so glossy and colorful as to perhaps tempt the militant boys into an establishment uniform. A number of the jackets combined classic tweeds with bits of other fabrics, seemingly from a rag bin. OK, he made his point, and didnt sit on it proudly or for too long.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, Jan. 18:

title: Perella Weinbergs Big New Assignment
description: Business got off to a slow start for Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique investment bank founded by Joseph R. Perella, formerly chairman of mergers at Morgan Stanley, and Peter A. Weinberg, a former partner at Goldman Sachs.

title: Councilman Suspects Politics in a Burglary
description: Updated, 6:15 p.m. | Maybe Councilman Hiram Monserrate, Democrat of Queens, has good reason to be sensitive about crime. A former marine and city police officer, Mr. Monserrate became the first Latino elected official from Queens in 2001.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 18
description: Here is a slide show of 12 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the sentencing of the track star Marion Jones, Mayor Michael Bloombergs State of the City address and a Grandmothers Against the War procession on Fifth Avenue.

description: Why is Friday Night Lights such a bust?

Fischers Epochal Match,
Shelby Lymans Star Turn
description: When people say they remember watching the epic 1972 Fischer-Spassky world championship tournament on public television, what they really mean is they remember watching Shelby Lyman.

description: CNBC interviews New York Governor Elliot Spitzer on new financial regulations in the state.

description:
Scholars John McWhorter of the Manhattan Institute, left, and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate Obama's ethnic identity and what it means.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Youre Not Buying Gadgets, You Are Subscribing to Them
description: When I wrote last week, about the apparent victory of Blu-ray discs over HD DVD, there was a deluge of comments from readers. Those that agreed with my take on things, lets say, were a rather small  if well-informed  minority.

title: Rivers Is Doubtful for Sunday, but He Isnt Packing Light
description: After practice Friday afternoon, Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers finished packing for the biggest business trip of his four-year career. Into his black roller bag he tossed a pair of jeans, an extra tie, and a couple of shirts.

description: I cant figure out what it is that keeps me watching the current star search for our next president.

description: Arnie Berman, the chief technology analyst at Cowen, surveyed the consensus expectations on profits at 388 tech companies.

title: Black Support Shifts Toward Obama
description: A new national poll released Friday by CNN suggests Senator Barack Obamas victory in Iowa and other events in recent months have encouraged more black voters to support him.

title: Optimistic Analysts, Part 2
description: Heather Hunt, a Citigroup analyst and longtime fan of MBIA and Ambac, is out with a report today dowgrading the shares to hold, after they have lost most of their value. She says she is throwing in the towel.

title: Off to Davos
description: Ill be in Davos next week, at the World Economic Forum, and will be blogging (and fililng columns) from there.

title: Mind the Gender Gap
description: A lot of attention has been paid to the womens vote in the first two Democratic nominating contests. In the Iowa caucuses, Barack Obama won a narrow victory over Hillary Clinton among female voters. But in New Hampshire women rallied to the former first lady giving her a huge 46 percent to 34 percent margin, which was the deciding factor in her comeback win.

title: Fred Thompson in South Carolina
description: The South Carolina primary may be the make or break moment for Fred Thompson's 2008 presidential campaign.

title: Vows: Emily & Preston
description: Emily and Preston recount their courtship, from a blind date in Newark to an engagement ring in San Francisco.

title: In Green Bay, Even the Footballs Are Frozen
description: No, really. Dead serious. The footballs for Green Bays practices this week were frozen like pizzas in the grocery store.

title: Will Baseball Look to Players to Speak Out Against Steroids?
description: When I was growing up in the 1980s, baseball was embroiled in a cocaine scandal. I was vaguely aware of it; I read the names of the players who were caught, and I perceived drugs to be very bad.

title: Inside the Giants: The End for Strahan?
description: Michael Strahan has been in a great mood recently, having played two strong postseason games (a career playoff-high eight tackles against Tampa Bay, trumped by 10 tackles against Dallas) and sitting within one victory of the Super Bowl.

title: Write Your Own Brett Favre Story
description: Packers quarterback Brett Favre has been compared to everyone from Paul Bunyan to Everyman. The broadcaster John Madden likens Favre to Superman with an S on his chest. ESPNs Chris Berman says that rooting for Favre is like rooting for America. Now you can lionize him, too. Should you need assistance, we offer suggestions below to fill in the blanks.

title: Bits Debate: On the Rights of Readers and Viewers
description: Throughout the debate this week on copyright issues, the question of fair use has come up repeatedly. On Wednesday, the topic for Rick Cotton, the general Counsel of NBC Universal, and Tim Wu, the Columbia law professor, was the legal concept of fair use: how much of a copyrighted work can be included in a review or other sort of work. But in many of the comments we received all week, readers have asked about their own broader sense that when they buy a CD or movie, they purchase rights that include making copies for their personal use.

title: Edwards Leaves Nevada for Oklahoma
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla.  On the eve of the Nevada caucuses, John Edwards has already skipped out of the state on a fly-around tour, looking ahead to states that are holding primary contests on Feb. 5.

title: Gaps in Medical Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Vase Comes Home to a Heros Welcome
description: ROME  As the restless crowd applauded, and flashbulbs popped, the Euphronios krater, at the heart of a three-decade tug of war between the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the Italian government, received a heros welcome here on Friday.

title: From Hospital Into Rehab, Six Weeks After 47-Story Fall
description: Continuing a recovery that has left medical professionals searching for superlatives, the window washer who fell 47 stories six weeks ago was discharged from the hospital Friday.

title: Chargers Rivers Says Hes Ready to Return
description: SAN DIEGO  After practice Friday afternoon, Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers finished packing for the biggest business trip of his four-year career. Into his black roller bag he tossed a pair of jeans, an extra tie and a couple of shirts. In case you have to spend the night Sunday, he explained to one of his teammates, adding, There may be a blizzard.

title: Could Congress Be Waking Up?
description: AMID the clamor of the presidential campaign, its sometimes easy to forget that all 435 House seats and 35 of the Senates seats are up for election this year, too. So how should Congress under its new Democratic leadership be judged?

title: Roddick Loses After Five Sets; Blake Rallies
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Andy Roddick had been here before: deep into a fifth set well past midnight at the Australian Open with the legs getting weary and the mood getting edgy. But this marathon in Rod Laver Arena did not end nearly so happily for Roddick as his coming-of-age epic against Younes el-Aynaoui did in 2003.

title: Director of Antigang Group Sold Illegal Assault Weapons
description: LOS ANGELES  The director of an antigang organization here that sought to reduce gun violence and received $1.5 million from the City of Los Angeles pleaded guilty on Thursday to charges that he sold illegal assault weapons to a federal undercover agent.

title: C.I.A. Sees Qaeda Link in the Death of Bhutto
description: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that the assassins of Benazir Bhutto, the former Pakistani prime minister, were directed by Baitullah Mehsud, a Pakistani militant leader in hiding, and that some of them had ties to Al Qaeda.

title: Four Distinct Dream Worlds, Sharing the Same Language of Classical Ballet
description: Are you a Tombeau freak too? a leading New York dance critic asked me at our first meeting in 1979 at the New York State Theater. We had just been watching Balanchines ballet Le Tombeau de Couperin, which was then less than four years old.

title: Internet Puts a Sugarcoat on Scalping
description: Big games tomorrow. Green Bay against the Giants at Lambeau Field. New England versus San Diego in Foxborough. Winners go to the Super Bowl. Big, big games.

title: Clinton Defeats Obama in Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won the Nevada caucuses on Saturday, capturing strong support from women voters and adding a fresh boost of momentum to her campaign as the Democratic presidential race heads to South Carolina, where she is engaged in a fierce battle with her rival, Senator Barack Obama.

title: When an Innocent Turns Aggressor
description: Janacek based his Diary of One Who Disappeared, a dramatic song cycle, on the familiar scenario of an upstanding young man lured away by a Gypsy temptress. But in the Gotham Chamber Operas provocative production there was nothing innocent about Janicku, the plowman protagonist, who raged around the small stage of the Morgan Library & Museums intimate Gilder Lehrman Hall in a bloodstained shirt, manhandling the Gypsies and chaining them to a wall.

title: 2 Belgian Tourists Killed in Yemen Ambush
description: SANA, Yemen  Gunmen opened fire on a tourist convoy on Friday afternoon in the Hadramawt region in eastern Yemen, killing two Belgian women and two Yemeni drivers, Yemeni officials said.

title: Writers Strike Tests the Mettle of 2 Outsiders
description: LOS ANGELES  Patric M. Verrone, president of the Writers Guild of America West, is a sporadically busy comedy writer with a law degree that has seen him through the rough spots between jobs at shows like The Simpsons and Futurama. David J. Young, his chief lieutenant, is a plumber turned hard-bitten labor organizer, with roots in the rough-and-tumble world of Los Angeles sweatshops.

title: Mr. Blair Sits
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair refused to sit for a formal portrait while in office, but he has now done so for Jonathan Yeo, a well-known portrait painter. His first official portrait was commissioned by the Honourable Society of Lincolns Inn, one of four so-called Inns of Court in London to which barristers of England and Wales belong. The painting will go on exhibition at Lincolns Inn in March, when it will be installed in the Great Hall. Mr. Blair is the 16th prime minister to have been a member of Lincolns Inn, in a line that started with Robert Walpole, generally considered the first prime minister, in 1721. Previous portraits of prime ministers in the Inn include those of William Pitt, Spencer Perceval, Herbert Asquith and Margaret Thatcher.

title: Germany: Another Cub With Fans
description: A female polar bear cub born this month at Nuremberg Zoo and being hand-raised has officially been named Flocke, or Snowflake, by a jury of city and zoo officials, spurring on the baby-bear craze in Germany that began last year in Berlin with the cuddly Knut. The jury received more than 50,000 e-mail messages, letters and postcards from around the world suggesting names, but in the end decided to keep the name zookeepers had given her.

title: Head Scarf Debate Intensifies in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  An angry debate over a ban on the Islamic head scarf, which is strictly forbidden in public buildings in Turkey, spilled into view this week, with the countrys secular elite vehemently opposing any loosening of the restriction.

title: Horses Sent to Slaughter
description: To the Editor:

title: Emergency Room Delays
description: The nations failure to provide health insurance for all Americans seems to be harming even many of those who do have good health coverage. That is one very plausible interpretation of a disturbing increase in waiting times at emergency rooms that are often clogged with uninsured patients seeking routine charity care.

title: Leader of Insider Trading Scheme Free After 2 Years
description: A former Goldman Sachs trader who helped lead a $6.7 million insider-trading conspiracy was sentenced to time served by a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan on Friday.

title: Georgia Frontiere, 80, First Female N.F.L. Owner, Is Dead
description: Georgia Frontiere, the owner of the National Football Leagues Rams for nearly three decades and the first woman to take control of a league franchise, died Friday. She was 80.

title: U.S. Sees Stalling by North Korea on Nuclear Pact
description: WASHINGTON  A debate is under way within the Bush administration over how long it can exercise patience with North Korea without jeopardizing the fulfillment of a nuclear agreement that President Bush has claimed as a foreign policy victory.

title: Russia-Britain Impasse Appears to Reach Pause
description: MOSCOW  Russias Foreign Ministry on Friday expressed satisfaction over the decision of the British government to suspend operations at two cultural centers in Russia, even as the British ambassador said that he hoped the centers would reopen after further negotiations.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about N.F.L. championship games between the Giants and the Green Bay Packers in 1961 and 1962 misidentified the position played by Willie Davis, an All-Pro for the Packers in the 1960s. He was a defensive end, not a defensive tackle.

title: Rockies Settle With Holliday
description: The Colorado Rockies, hoping to lock up Matt Holliday for the long term, settled for a two-year deal with him. Holliday agreed to a two-year, $23 million contract to avoid arbitration. He hit .340 with 137 runs batted in last season, the third player since 1967 to lead the National League in both categories.

title: Ex-N.F.L. Player Pleads Guilty in Balco Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Dana Stubblefield, a former defensive lineman in the N.F.L., pleaded guilty in federal court here Friday to charges that he made false statements to a federal agent about his use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Bush Proposing $145 Billion Plan to Spur Economy
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush called Friday for roughly $145 billion in tax relief for individuals and businesses that he said would provide a shot in the arm for the economy, while Congressional Democrats, in a rare show of Washington bipartisanship, pledged to work with him to enact a plan quickly.

title: Court Rejects Challenge to New Thai Government
description: BANGKOK  Thailands Supreme Court appeared to clear the way for a new government on Friday, dismissing a challenge to the party backed by Thaksin Shinawatra, the ousted prime minister whose return to the country now seems more likely.

title: Footnotes
description: Primary Stages has announced its 2008-9 season, which includes a new play by Tina Howe, Chasing Manet, starring Jane Alexander, and the New York premieres of plays by A. R. Gurney (Buffalo Gal, under the direction of Mark Lamos) and Lee Blessing (A Body of Water, under the direction of Maria Mileaf). Mr. Gurneys play is to kick off the season on July 22. ... Steven Holl Architects of New York and Beijing has been chosen to design an arts complex for Princeton Universitys theater and dance programs, parts of its department of music, its Lewis Center for the Arts and its Society of Fellows in the Creative and Performing Arts. ... Aaron Betsky, an American who directed the Netherlands Architecture Institute of Rotterdam for six years, has been appointed director of the 11th International Architecture Exhibition at the Venice Biennale, to run from Sept. 14 to Nov. 23.

title: Golds Rise: Its Not Just Armageddon
description: THE price of gold has always been a way to keep score of economic, financial and political instability, but the game may be changing. The dollar is weak, inflation is troublesome and the world isnt getting any safer, but it is hard to see how those factors alone drove gold from just over $250 an ounce in 2001 to more than $900.

title: Valentn Agrees to Deal
description: Jos Valentn, a vital member of the Mets 2006 division champion team who missed the majority of last season because of leg injuries, agreed to a minor league deal. Valentn, 38, sustained a season-ending broken leg July 20 in Los Angeles, less than two weeks after he returned from a two-and-a-half-month absence because of a partial tear of the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee.The Mets and Aaron Heilman avoided salary arbitration by agreeing on a one-year deal worth $1.2 million. The team exchanged contract figures with the five remaining arbitration-eligible players  Endy Chvez, Ryan Church, Pedro Feliciano, Oliver Prez and Jorge Sosa  and are still negotiating. Sosa and Prez have requested a 2008 salary that is more than $1 million higher than what the Mets offered. Sosa asked for $2.75 million, and the Mets submitted $1.7 million; Perez asked for $6.5 million, and the Mets offered $4.725 million.

title: In Killing of 7-Year-Old, Defense Cites Fetus in Jar
description: A lawyer for a Brooklyn man charged with killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter drew gasps from jurors on Friday after he submitted photographs of a fetus in a jar in his bid to show that the girls mother was responsible for her death. The mother was driven mad by the miscarriage, the lawyer has said, and held the unruly girl, Nixzmary Brown, responsible, beating her viciously because of it.

title: Clemens to Testify Under Oath
description: Roger Clemens will go to Capitol Hill on Jan. 26 to answer questions from staff members for the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, Clemenss lawyer said Friday, setting the stage for a possible perjury showdown against the personal trainer who says he injected Clemens with performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about plans by the federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency to deport immigrants convicted of crimes misstated how soon the agency would complete some deportations. Although the agency expects to start deportation proceedings this year against more than 200,000 immigrants serving criminal sentences in prisons and jails, the individuals will be removed when they complete their terms  not necessarily in 2008.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about some New Yorkers recollections of the citys more violent past, prompted by a knife fight during a mugging in Harlem, referred imprecisely in some editions to state statutes concerning the possession of knives. Although the state classifies possession of any dangerous knife as a crime provided there is intent to use it, it does not address the length of the blade. (Under city law, it is legal to carry knives with blades shorter than four inches, except for some that are specifically outlawed, including switchblades.)

title: Holiday on Monday: Martin Luther Kings Birthday, Actually Jan. 15, Will Be Observed
description: NEW YORK

title: Scandal Steals Spotlight in Greek Culture Ministry
description: ATHENS  Even as Greece lauds its success in reclaiming ancient classical treasures from museums abroad, a scandal has arisen over its oversight of its archaeological past.

title: Gamez Leads the Hope Classic After Answering the Call
description: PALM DESERT, Calif.  Robert Gamez was packing for Hawaii a few weeks ago when the telephone rang. It was Mike Milthorpe, the tournament director from the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic, calling to offer him a sponsors exemption.

title: Lottery Numbers
Voices Against the Abuse of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats Behind Those Offers to Raise Credit Scores
description: A HOST of companies have cropped up in the last year that offer struggling subprime mortgage holders quick-fix programs aimed at raising their credit scores.

title: For Champions of Haggling, No Price Tag Is Sacred
description: MY husband and I hate haggling. In markets in Istanbul or Jerusalem or Florence, where arguing over price is a high art  and after we have given it our best shot  we always feel we have walked away paying twice as much as the seller expected.

title: Familiar Songs, the Way Youve Never Heard Them
description: Youve probably never heard Heartbreak Hotel performed with the stark, no-frills approach that the British singer Barb Jungr brings to it in her show No Regrets: The Remarkable Barb Jungr at the Metropolitan Room. Stripping it of its hubba-hubba and bump-and-grind beat, with nary a baby to be heard, she forces the song to stand on its own as a surreal, minimalist, blues-flavored lament, whose last word die is hissed.

title: Bodies Yield Evidence of Homicide
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. (AP)  Eight men whose skeletal remains were discovered last year in Fort Myers were the victims of homicide, the police said Friday.

title: Revisiting the Works of a Former Firebrand to See if Theyre Still Warm to the Touch
description: In 1952 Pierre Boulez wrote that any musician who has not felt ... the necessity of the dodecaphonic language is of no use. A year after this youthful, narrow-minded declaration, Mr. Boulez indulged his open-minded interest in the music of foreign cultures by evoking non-European sounds in a chamber work featuring a groundbreaking combination of instruments.

title: Yankees Begin Arbitration
description: The Yankees exchanged salary arbitration figures with three players on Friday and signed another, infielder Wilson Betemit, to a one-year, $1.165 million deal.The biggest difference in figures was with second baseman Robinson Can, who asked for $4.55 million while the Yankees offered $3.2 million. Starter Chien-Ming Wang asked for $4.6 million, $600,000 more than the Yankees offer; and reliever Brian Bruney asked for $845,000 while the Yankees offered $640,000. The Yankees are likely to settle with Bruney before a hearing. They believe their offer to Wang is fair, but a settlement seems possible because the figures are not far apart. Cans case is trickier, since the salary he is seeking would be higher than the $4.5 million earned by Justin Morneau of the Twins last season, after Morneau had won the Most Valuable Player award. The Yankees are unlikely to sign any of the players to long-term contracts, because their general policy is to make one-year deals until players reach free agency.

title: Algeria Angered by U.N. Plans for Bombing Inquiry
description: UNITED NATIONS  Algeria said Friday that it would not cooperate with an independent panel that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon was setting up to investigate the car bombing of United Nations offices in Algiers last month. The Algerians also denied accusations that they had ignored requests to tighten security around the building before the attack.

title: Crawford and Knicks Fail to Keep Streak Alive
description: WASHINGTON  In the post-Marbury era, however long it may last, the Knicks fate will ride most games on Jamal Crawfords stutter-step, his crossover dribble and his streaky jumper. That repertory helped fuel the Knicks longest winning streak of the season this week, but it was not enough to extend that streak to a fourth game Friday.

title: Smarts Are Tops
description: Foxs Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader? delivered its highest ratings in 10 months on Thursday, helping to lift the network to a rare No. 1 finish over all among adults 18 to 49. The quiz show earned 11.5 million viewers, Nielsen estimated, leading the 8 p.m. hour ahead of ABCs Ugly Betty (9.5 million) and repeats on CBS and NBC. In the next hour, Foxs Dont Forget the Lyrics (8.8 million) trailed NBCs Celebrity Apprentice, (9 million) which was the nights top-rated show among the 18-to-49 set. NBC ranked second in that demographic, winning the 10 p.m. time slot with ER, which edged past CBSs Without a Trace despite drawing a much smaller total viewership. Although CBS finished third among adults 18 to 49, the network averaged the most viewers for the night, thanks largely to a rerun of CSI at 9 (14.1 million).

title: Two Charged in Mascot Death
description: A father and son from Paramus, N.J., have been charged with lying to the police about a motor vehicle accident that killed a University of North Carolina student who was the mascot for the universitys basketball team. Authorities said Friday that Gagik Hovsepyan, 52, was covering for his son, Armen, 25, when he told the police last March that he was driving the car that struck the student, Jason Kendall Ray, as he was walking along Route 4 in Fort Lee. Armen Hovsepyan, whose drivers license was suspended at the time of the accident, was actually behind the wheel, authorities say.

title: New York Settles on Far More Modest Expansion of Javits Convention Center
description: Thirteen months and $30 million after the Spitzer administration said it would conduct a 90-day review of longstanding expansion plans for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the state has come up with a new, far less ambitious proposal that major users of the center say is disappointing.

title: Economists Debate the Quickest Cure
description: WASHINGTON  In trying to assemble a bipartisan package to jolt the slumping economy, the White House and Congress have turned to familiar tools that experts say have worked in the past. But there is also a lively debate among economists about which measures will best accomplish the goal.

title: Seeing the Dead
description: Lindsay Lohan, right, will soon be working at a morgue as part of her punishment for misdemeanor drunken driving, The Associated Press reported. Her two four-hour days at the morgue are part of a court-ordered program to show drivers the real-life consequences of drinking and driving. She must also spend two days working in a hospital emergency room. Ms. Lohan was arrested twice last year on drunken driving charges and pleaded guilty in August to misdemeanor drunken driving and cocaine charges. She was sentenced to one day and served 84 minutes as part of a plea deal.

title: Ex-Union Chief Pleads Guilty
description: The former president of the union representing 15,000 New York City school bus drivers pleaded guilty on Friday to extortion and receiving bribes as part of a racketeering conspiracy.

title: Michigan: 911 Operator Convicted
description: A Detroit jury convicted a 911 operator of willful neglect of duty after the authorities said she did not take seriously a boys calls to report that his mother had collapsed. The misdemeanor charge against the operator, Sharon Nichols, is punishable by up to a year in jail. She will be sentenced March 11. Ms. Nichols, 45, testified that she could not hear the boy on the other end of the line. The authorities said the boy, Robert Turner, now 7, called 911 twice on Feb. 20, 2006, to report that his mother had passed out. Robert testified that Ms. Nichols accused him of playing games and hung up on him. The police found Roberts mother, Sherrill Turner, 46, dead three hours after the first call. Charges were dismissed against another operator, Terri Sutton, who took the boys second call.

title: With Reminders of Past, Duquesne Moves Ahead
description: PITTSBURGH  Beneath the bed in his Duquesne University dorm room, Shawn James keeps a red and white, left-foot, size 13 Nike Air Force sneaker. It is not an unusual possession for a college basketball player  except for the bullet hole.

title: Brazilian Museum Declared a Menace
description: More bad news for the So Paulo Museum of Art. The museum, site of the theft last month of paintings valued at more than $50 million, has been threatened by So Paulo state authorities with temporary closing, Agence France-Presse reported. In court proceedings, the authorities contend that the museum has been operating for 40 years without formal permission from the city, the police and the fire service. Mariza Schiavo Tucunduva, a state official in charge of health and safety, said a recent inspection had shown that the fire system was not operating, extinguishers were missing, and exits were not clearly marked. There is an imminent risk to the life and health of museum visitors as well as to the priceless historic and cultural heritage that the institutions collection represents, Ms. Tucunduva said. The museum asserted in a statement that it was the safest in the country.

title: Herald Tribune Publisher Departs
description: PARIS  Michael Golden, the publisher of The International Herald Tribune, said Friday that he was leaving the newspaper and returning to New York to focus on his position as vice chairman of The New York Times Company.

title: Romney Alters His Message, but Questions Remain
description: RENO, Nev.  Mitt Romneys advisers contend he has found his voice with his retooled message focused on changing Washington and confronting the economic jitters gripping the country.

title: New York Panel Rethinks Securities Oversight
description: A commission assembled to revise New York States financial regulations recommended on Friday that the state have one regulator to oversee the securities industry, instead of the current four overseers.

title: Romney Offers an Economic Stimulus Plan
description: Mitt Romney offered an ambitious plan Friday to try to forestall a recession, proposing a $250 billion economic stimulus package with sweeteners for supply-side conservatives, older Americans and corporations.

title: Pipeline Cements Russias Hold on Europes Gas Supply
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  Russia strengthened its grip on Europes energy supplies on Friday as it signed a major gas deal with Bulgaria that analysts said would further undermine the European Unions attempts to diversify its energy sources.

title: India: Bird Flu Spread Alarming
description: Indias third outbreak of avian flu among poultry is the worst it has faced, the World Health Organization said. The chief minister of West Bengal State, which is trying to cull 400,000 birds, called the viruss spread alarming. Uncooperative villagers, angry at being offered only 75 cents a chicken by the government, have been selling off their flocks and throwing dead birds into waterways, increasing the risk. New outbreaks were also reported this week in Iran and Ukraine.

title: What the Surge Doesnt Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Rushdie Visit Leads to Boycott Threat
description: A visit by Salman Rushdie to India has prompted an organization of Islamic clerics to call for a boycott of products from the major conglomerate owned by the family that was his host, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Rushdie, right, a lightning rod for Muslim protests since he was accused of insulting Islam in his 1988 novel The Satanic Verses, arrived in Mumbai last week and left on Tuesday, curtailing his visit by two days when Muslim groups began protesting outside the beachfront house of the Godrej family, whose company, Godrej Industries Ltd., has interests in furniture, machine tools, food processing and chemicals. Maulana Sayyed Atarali, the president of the All India Ulema Association, a national organization of Islamic clerics, said, Until there is an apology, we will boycott all their products.

title: Praying for Christian Unity, When Diversity Has Been the Answer
description: Has the movement for unity among Christians gone into a coma?

title: Equity Firms Acquiring Food Supplier
description: Two equity buyout firms, the Blackstone Group and Wellspring Capital Management, agreed Friday to acquire the Performance Food Group, the food distributor, for $1.2 billion to combine it with a competitor they purchased in September.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A theater review on Thursday about Small Metal Objects, part of the Under the Radar Festival, reversed the identities of two actors and their characters. Gary was played by Sonia Teuben, and Steve was played by Simon Laherty. The review also misidentified the character who had second thoughts. It was Steve, not Gary.

title: Bottom Line on Doing Good
description: ITS alluring and very much in vogue to connect social responsibility with profitability, an article in The Harvard Business Review begins. If you can make a business case for positive social action, everybody wins  employees, shareholders and society at large.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about Still Life misstated the given name of the director of photography. As a listing of credits with the review noted, he is Yu Likwai  not Yu Jianmin.

title: Save the Polar Bear
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer Reveals Secret, Toppling Death Sentence
description: For 10 years, Leslie P. Smith, a Virginia lawyer, reluctantly kept a secret because the authorities on legal ethics told him he had no choice, even though his information could save the life of a man on death row, one whose case had led to a landmark Supreme Court decision.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,915 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Not Funny but Sad
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Freed After 17 Years in Prison Faces New Investigation in Murder
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  A state prosecutor was given 30 days by a Suffolk County judge on Friday to decide how to proceed with a case involving the 1988 murders of a Long Island couple now that the conviction of their son, Martin H. Tankleff, has been overturned.

title: Fighting Before Its Too Late, Jones Jr. Will Face Trinidad
description: As the ever-excitable boxing promoter Don King tells it, he did not arrange the fight between Roy Jones Jr. and Felix Trinidad. Fate, chance and the appetite of the two boxers did.

title: Inquiry Finds Power Failure in London Jumbo Jet Crash
description: LONDON  Both engines on the British Airways jumbo jet that crash-landed just short of a runway at Londons Heathrow Airport on Thursday failed to respond to a demand for more power during the final few moments of the flight, British investigators said Friday.

title: Good Jobs Are Where the Money Is
description: I think of the people running this country as the mad-dashers, a largely confused and inconsistent group lurching ineffectively from one enormous problem to another.

title: UBS, After a Write-Down, Closes Finance Unit in U.S.
description: UBS, Europes biggest bank, said on Friday that it would close an American unit that invested in fixed-income securities as it scales back risk-taking after writing down the value of subprime mortgage investments by $14.7 billion last year.

title: Rodriguez Is Paid Incentives
description: Michigan Coach Rich Rodriguez, who is being sued by West Virginia in an attempt to collect on a $4 million buyout clause in his old contract, received a $287,000 incentive payment from W.V.U. on Friday for goals reached during the 2007 season. Among the incentives was a one-time $150,000 payment for winning the Big East championship and receiving a Bowl Championship Series berth, and $25,000 for finishing in the top 10.

title: G.E. Profit Rises, Aided by Overseas Sales
description: The General Electric Company said Friday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 4 percent as surging overseas sales more than offset the fallout from domestic woes. The company also reaffirmed its forecast that earnings per share would rise at least 10 percent this year.

title: Border Patrol Agent Sentenced for Role in Smuggling Ring
description: SAN DIEGO  A former Border Patrol agent who helped smuggle more than 100 people into the United States and shared internal documents with leaders of the smuggling ring was sentenced Friday to three years in federal prison.

title: Glossary of Terms for Could Congress Be Waking Up?
McCain and Huckabee Avoid Sparring in Final South Carolina Push
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John McCain capped his final full day of campaigning in South Carolina with a big rally in an aircraft carrier museum here on Friday evening, as Mike Huckabee delivered his populist economic message on the trail while highlighting his religious beliefs to draw out the evangelical vote in Saturdays primary here.

title: Giants Recall a Stinging Defeat and See How Theyve Changed
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants faced the Green Bay Packers on Sept. 16 the weather at Giants Stadium was idyllic: sunny and 64 degrees with a refreshing breeze from the northeast. The field conditions were tempestuous: the Giants defense sprung leaks in the fourth quarter and the offense sputtered all day. It amounted to a forgettable 35-13 defeat.

title: A Scout at Heart Leads a Revival in Green Bay
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The rookie scout in the Green Bay personnel department did not attend college all-star games or scouting combines. He parked himself in a chair in an empty office for his first assignment in January 1992.

title: Kenyas Opposition Switches Its Tactics From Street Protests to Business Boycotts
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Protests cooled in Kenya on Friday as opposition leaders, still furious about last months presidential election, announced that they were switching tactics from street demonstrations to boycotts.

title: Behind on the Rent, and Then a Baby Needs Surgery
description: It was Memorial Day 2007. Cheryl Brooks and her family were enjoying a cookout with her youngest childrens father in Upper Manhattan when her 2-month-old, Arianna Williams, started to cry. Then Ariannas heart began to race.

title: From Texas to Iraq, and Center of Blackwater Case
description: DICKENS, Tex.

title: Seeking Tools to Calm a Market
description: Dow 6,000 or Dow 14,000?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 3 about the death, apparently by suicide, of Rudolph Zurick, a corrections officer at the Union County Jail in Elizabeth, N.J., who had been mocked in a note left by two escaping inmates, Jose Espinosa and Otis Blunt, misstated Mr. Blunts age. He is 33, not 32; he was 32 at the time of his escape. (The error was repeated in related articles on Jan. 8 and Jan. 9.)

title: Study Says Drivers Will Use New Jersey Toll Roads Despite Increases
description: Most New Jersey drivers would continue using the states toll roads even if Gov. Jon S. Corzines proposal to raise fees sharply is adopted, according to a traffic study made public on Friday.

title: A Common Foe in Nevada: Confusion
description: LAS VEGAS  As Nevada Democrats began their caucuses on Saturday, the emphasis centered on one question: What, exactly is a caucus?

title: Pakistan, Terrorism and Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Fixing a Budget at the Toll Booth
description: As states and cities look to their roadways to generate badly needed money, the state of New Jersey is offering an approach worth studying. Gov. Jon Corzine wants to shore up his states troubled finances by sharply raising tolls. If he gets his way, the cost of driving most of the turnpike could eventually rise from $5.85 to $48, providing money for both debt reduction and public transportation. The plan has potential pitfalls, but it may well be the best solution to a difficult problem.

title: Phillips in Line at Kentucky
description: Joker Phillips, the Kentucky offensive coordinator, will eventually become the Wildcats coach after Rich Brookss retirement. Brooks, 66, has not set a timetable for his retirement, the university said. He signed a contract extension through 2011 on Friday that will pay him $1.6 million a season. Phillips would become the universitys first black head football coach.

title: Fischer vs. the World: A Chess Giants Endgame
description: There may be only three human activities in which miraculous accomplishment is possible before adulthood: mathematics, music and chess. These are abstract, almost invented realms, closed systems bounded by rules of custom or principle. Here, the child learns, is how elements combine and transform; here are the laws that govern their interactions; and here are the possibilities that emerge as you play with signs, symbols, sounds or pieces. Nothing else need be known or understood  at least at first. A childs gifts in such realms can seem otherworldly, the achievements effortlessly magical. But as Bobby Fischers death on Thursday might remind us, even abstract gifts can exact a terrible price.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about cultural groups in England that face funding cuts from the government-financed Arts Council England included a quotation from Louise Wylie, the councils director of media relations, that misstated the plans of the Bush Theater in West London, which faces a cut. The theater, in fact, does not plan to scale back productions in the next three years.

title: Players Recall Fischer as Inspiring and Difficult
description: Chess players and chess journalists from around the world reacted on Friday to the death of Bobby Fischer with a mixture of sadness, praise and lingering anger about his behavior in his later years.

title: Sprints Customer Erosion Prompts Cutbacks
description: Sprint Nextels announcement on Friday that it is losing customers more rapidly than expected is making investors nervous about a weak economys effect on other wireless companies.

title: Maryland Pulls Away to Win
description: Marah Strickland and Kristi Toliver made consecutive 3-pointers in the second half Friday night to help No. 4 Maryland defeat host Virginia, 74-62, for its 11th consecutive victory.

title: More Kremlin Harassment
description: The British Council is a cultural organization, partially financed by the British government, operating in more than 100 countries around the world. It exhibits films, educates English teachers and, in some countries, sets up student exchange programs  hardly a hotbed of sedition. Nonetheless, the Kremlin has ordered the council to close two of its three offices in Russia.

title: Bond Insurers Distress Rattles Wall Street
description: If it was a terrible week for Wall Street, it was a devastating one for companies that promise to protect investors against bond losses.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A Week in Review article on Jan. 6 about Pakistans history of difficulty in sustaining democracy misidentified the military leader under whom Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who would later become prime minister, served as foreign minister in the 1960s. The leader was Gen. Ayub Khan, not Gen. Yahya Khan. The article also misstated the timing of the disputed parliamentary election that left Mr. Bhutto in a position to emerge from a civil war in 1971 as the first civilian head of government of a truncated Pakistan. The election was held before the war in 1970, not after the war.

title: NYPD Producer Revisits the Police
description: David Milch, the writer and producer best known for his work on NYPD Blue, Hill Street Blues and Deadwood, is working on a new HBO police show, Last of the Ninth, which focuses on the rampant corruption in the New York Police Department in the 1970s, Reuters reported. Mr. Milch wrote the pilot with his fellow NYPD Blue executive producer Bill Clark, a former New York homicide detective. Last of the Ninth stems from Mr. Milchs development deal with HBO, which was extended in August after the network canceled his most recent show, John From Cincinnati, at the end of its first season.

title: No. 3 U.S. Diplomat, Lead Negotiator on Iran, Retires
description: WASHINGTON  R. Nicholas Burns, the countrys third-ranking diplomat and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rices right-hand man, is retiring for personal reasons, the State Department said Friday.

title: When to Start the School Day, So Kids Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Editor's Note

title: Barred Driver Returns to Track, Raising Doubts About Discipline
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Eric Ledford made his return to the Meadowlands on Thursday night, about 21 months after being arrested and charged with race fixing, about 21 months after the New Jersey State Police said it had dealt a crushing blow to illegal activity in the sport of harness racing.

title: Brutality in Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: License, Registration and DNA, Please
description: A brake light on Howard Blums car had burned out, a bit of news he learned when a police officer pulled him over one evening last year as he drove up Park Avenue in Manhattan. Mr. Blum, on his way home to Connecticut, produced his license and registration for the police officer, who returned to his patrol car to check on the documents.

title: SAG Show Is New Star of Awards Telecasts
description: LOS ANGELES  For most of their first 13 years, the Screen Actors Guild Awards played little more than the role of a seat-filler, taking up space between the real shows of the Golden Globes, the Oscars and the Emmys.

title: The Just-So Story of a Justified Ruff-and-Sluff
description: There are a lot of bridge proverbs that we learn, proverbially, at our grandmothers knee. Bridge has survived because we can rarely use the words always and never in those maxims. Take, for example, the axiom Never give declarer a ruff-and-sluff. Most of the time that is good advice, but not always.

title: Armored Vehicle Supply Better After Early Delays
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The Defense Department has now delivered more than 1,500 heavily armored ground transport vehicles to Iraq and Afghanistan in an accelerated program to protect American troops from improvised explosives, senior Pentagon officials said Friday.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $6,881,972

title: Capturing Dream States and Unraveling Knots
description: Nearly 30 years ago, when he was about to celebrate his 70th birthday, I did an interview with Elliott Carter in which we touched on the freighted question of whether a composer can write memorable themes in a difficult modern style. After musing for a moment that certain kinds of art are easier for some listeners than for others, Mr. Carter mentioned that the pianist Ursula Oppens had spoken with him that morning about one of his works she was about to perform.

title: Precision in a Pub-Like Setting
description: FRIMLEY GREEN, England  Evoking an oversized English pub with a cover charge disguised as admission to a sporting event, the lights were dim, the beer flowed freely and the audience was getting rowdy.

title: Can You Hear Me Now?
description: A judge wants more information before she decides whether to let the rapper Foxy Brown, below, get out of jail and go to California for repair of an electronic ear implant, The Associated Press reported. Judge Melissa C. Jackson of Manhattan Criminal Court said she wants proof that deafness looms unless Ms. Brown, 29, goes to a Los Angeles clinic for treatment and repair of a cochlear implant. Ms. Brown revealed her hearing problems during a court appearance in late 2004. Her petition says that her condition is worsening in jail and her hearing faces serious harm unless she has the implant reprogrammed and repaired. Ms. Brown, whose real name is Inga Marchand, was sentenced in September to a year in jail for violating probation. She was put on probation after pleading guilty to misdemeanor assault of two manicurists at a Manhattan nail salon in August 2004.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Tuesday about Barack Obamas pursuit of Latino voters in his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination gave an incorrect date for a speech he gave to supporters in Reno, Nev. It was on Monday, not last weekend.

title: Israel Closes All Gaza Border Crossings, Citing Palestinian Rocket Attacks
description: JERUSALEM  Israel closed all border crossings with the Gaza Strip on Friday, cutting off at least one aid shipment, and bombed the empty Interior Ministry building of the Palestinian Authority, which was already a ruin after a previous Israeli bombing.

title: Inspired by Old Masters, and Each Others Artistry
description: That the musicians of the New York Philharmonic play so well for Riccardo Muti cannot be explained simply by their well-established respect for this eminent conductors skills. Their relationship has that inexplicable chemistry that sometimes just happens, as was clear from the ecstatic performance of Scriabins weirdly fascinating Poem of Ecstasy that ended the orchestras program on Thursday night.

title: Fear and Voting in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the thriving illegal trade in fish to Europe included an incorrect conversion from euros to dollars for the value of the European market for fish. It is worth more than 14 billion euros a year, or about $20.6 billion  not $22 billion.

title: Former N.F.L. Player Pleads Guilty in Steroids Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Dana Stubblefield, a three-time Pro Bowl selection as a defensive lineman in the National Football League, pleaded guilty in federal court Friday afternoon with making false statements to a federal agent about performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Two Escapees Are Remanded to Prison in New Jersey
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.  More than four weeks after making a remarkable escape from their county jail cells in New Jersey, two inmates finally returned to the building they had fled.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about a new DNA test that can help predict the risk of prostate cancer misstated the name of a company formed by researchers at Wake Forest University that plans to market the test this year. It is Proactive Genomics, not ProActive Genetics.

title: Prosecutor Quashes Charges Against Judge
description: HOUSTON  A grand jurys bitter backroom struggle to charge a Texas Supreme Court justice and his wife in the burning of their house burst into the open on Friday after a prosecutor who had opposed the indictments went to court and had them quashed.

title: Belgian Tourists Killed in Yemen Ambush
description: SANAA, Yemen  Gunmen opened fire on a tourist convoy Friday afternoon in the eastern Hadramawt region, killing two Belgian women and two Yemeni drivers, Yemeni officials said.

title: A New, Global Oil Quandary: Costly Fuel Means Costly Calories
description: KUANTAN, Malaysia  Rising prices for cooking oil are forcing residents of Asias largest slum, in Mumbai, India, to ration every drop. Bakeries in the United States are fretting over higher shortening costs. And here in Malaysia, brand-new factories built to convert vegetable oil into diesel sit idle, their owners unable to afford the raw material.

title: Editors Note: Bridgeports New Mayor and His Senate Seat
description: An article in the Connecticut section this weekend describes the decision by Mayor Bill Finch of Bridgeport to retain his seat in the State Senate pending a State Supreme Court ruling on the mayoral election. After the article went to press on Friday, Mr. Finch announced that he would resign the Senate seat.

title: Genetic Bank Raises Issues of Practicality and Privacy
description: Simple cotton swabs would be rubbed inside the mouths of suspects. The collected human cheek cells would then be mined for DNA strands. And those samples would be put together as potential evidence in prosecutions.

title: Canadian Gets Life in Qaeda Bomb Plot
description: A Canadian man who once met personally with top leaders of Al Qaeda in devising a plot to blow up United States embassies in Singapore and the Philippines was sentenced on Friday to life in prison at a court hearing in Manhattan.

title: Russian Boxer's Bout Honors 2 Whose Lives Were Cut Short
description: Roman Karmazin, a world-class professional boxer, has never met the families of Russel Timoshenko, a New York City police officer, and Yevgeniy Marshalik, an auxiliary officer, who died in the line of duty last year.

title: He Violated Probation, but Gets to Keep the Prize
description: A man who was convicted of robbing banks so he could buy scratch-off lottery tickets does not have to worry about keeping the $1 million he won in the Massachusetts lottery.

title: The Immigrant Vote
description: The Nevada caucuses today will be the first test of the mood of immigrant voters since comprehensive immigration reform was killed.

title: Thompson, Lingering in Midpack, Sticks to a Slow and Steady Strategy
description: LAURENS, S.C.  The presidential candidate known as Fred moseys into Whitefords Giant Burger, possessing that La-Z-Boy manner and a fistful of conservative principles.

title: Damaged Landscape Can Still Be Helpful, Researchers Say
description: Researchers who study coastal mangroves, sea-grass beds, coral reefs and sand dunes are reporting that, contrary to widely held views, environmental preservation on the coast does not have to be an all-or-nothing proposition and that landscapes can perform services like storm protection even if they have been somewhat disturbed by development.

title: Spain Arrests 14 in Plotting Attack
description: MADRID  Spain was on high alert for terrorist attacks on Saturday after the police arrested 14 suspects of Pakistani and Indian origin who authorities contend were plotting an attack on Barcelona, officials said.

title: S-q-u-a-b-b-l-e
description: THIRD-PARTY applications are supposedly the secret to Facebooks success.

title: Job Data Passes Threshold Where Recessions Dwell
description: When the number of Americans out of work starts to rise sharply, a recession occurs.

title: Justices Add More Cases on Job Discrimination
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday added two new employment discrimination cases to a docket on which such cases are already well represented.

title: Which Movies Are Right for Kids?
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball Already Knew of Rise in Exemptions
description: As major leaguers ponder their goals for the 2008 season, some hitters wonder how many runs they will drive in, some pitchers wonder how many earned runs they will permit. And some players wonder about securing their therapeutic-use exemption.

title: Former Secretary on Waterboarding
description: The first secretary of homeland security says waterboarding is torture. Theres just no doubt in my mind  under any set of rules, waterboarding is torture, the former secretary, Tom Ridge, said in an interview. Mr. Ridge offered the same opinion earlier in the day to members of the American Bar Association at a conference on national security. Mr. Ridge served as secretary from 2003 to 2005. He said: I believe, unlike others in the administration, that waterboarding was, is and will always be torture. Thats a simple statement. The Central Intelligence Agency has not used waterboarding as an interrogation technique since 2003, and the director of the agency, Michael V. Hayden, prohibited it in 2006, officials said.

title: Sergeant Is Accused of Aiding Drug Ring
description: A New York City police sergeant faces charges that he used a police computer to aid a man federal prosecutors call the leader of a crack-cocaine distribution ring.

title: Courts and Terror Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: McCain Wins South Carolina Primary
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John McCain staved off a spirited challenge by former Gov. Mike Huckabee to win the South Carolina primary on Saturday, exorcising the ghosts of the attack-filled primary here that derailed his presidential hopes eight years ago.

title: Anthony Solomon,  Finance Policy Maker, Is Dead at 88
description: Anthony M. Solomon, a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and an influential behind-the-scenes financial policy maker in three presidential administrations and at the World Bank, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Despite Deadly Clashes in Iraq, Shiite Pilgrims Spared
description: BAGHDAD  Government troops in southern Iraq fought with a millennial religious militia group on Friday in clashes that left more than 40 people dead, but the troops successfully protected millions of pilgrims on the first day of Ashura, the largest religious holiday for Iraqs Shiite majority and one frequently marred by violence.

title: A Leaf Spinning, Darting and Falling in an Electronic Tempest of Light and Video
description: Richard Siegal plunges into a dark and tumultuous world in his new As if Stranger, which opened on Thursday night at the Danspace Project at St. Marks Church. The most acute of dancers, he moves like a leaf in a powerful and contrary wind. Smart and imaginative, he is lost in the roiling void that he has created with pieces of electronic equipment and huge cables and plugs.

title: Between Pulpit and Podium, Huckabee Straddles Fine Line
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C.  Mike Huckabee mentioned his faith only glancingly in his stump speech this week at North Greenville University in Tigerville, S.C. Discussing presidential decisions that will matter after he is long gone, he added: By the way, I have made arrangements for what happens after that, and its all good. Its all good.

title: In Pursuing Terror Cases, Respect Our Freedoms
description: To the Editor:

title: Bobby Fischer, Troubled Genius of Chess, Dies at 64
description: Bobby Fischer, the Chicago-born, Brooklyn-bred genius who became one of the greatest chess players the world has ever seen, died on Thursday in Reykjavik, Iceland. He was 64.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Friday about the Australian Open misstated, in some editions, the score in the fifth set of a match when Vince Spadea saved three match points during his eventual victory against Denis Gremelmayr. It was 5-6, not 4-5.

title: Golfweek Fires Editor Over Noose Cover
description: The parent company of Golfweek magazine on Friday fired the editor who approved this weeks cover image of a noose for an article about the Golf Channel host Kelly Tilghmans use of the word lynch to describe how young players could challenge Tiger Woods.

title: Oil Demand, the Climate and the Energy Ladder
description: Energy demand is expected to grow in coming decades. Jeroen van der Veer, 60, Royal Dutch Shells chief executive, recently offered his views on the energy challenge facing the world and the challenge posed by global warming. He spoke of the need for governments to set limits on carbon emissions. He also lifted the veil on Shells latest long-term energy scenarios, titled Scramble and Blueprints, which he will make public next week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Following are excerpts from the interview:

title: Work Is Afoot to Take the Free Out of Freeway
description: DELAWARE WATER GAP, Pa.  Hundreds of cars and trucks scream past Chris Howsare and Laren Myers in the half-hour they spend examining the hodgepodge of wetlands, historic landmarks and utility lines on the stretch of Interstate 80 that bisects this town on the New Jersey border.

title: Researchers Go Unchecked, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The National Institutes of Health do almost nothing to monitor the financial conflicts of university professors to whom it provides grants, a government report found, and the huge federal research agency does not want to start now.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Saturday about jury selection in the murder trial of Cesar Rodriguez, the stepfather of Nixzmary Brown, a 7-year-old Brooklyn girl who was beaten to death two years ago, misidentified her home address in Bedford-Stuyvesant. It was Greene Avenue, not Green Street.

title: Bracing for the Cold, Giants Punter Puts Emphasis on Receiving
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jeff Feagles is too old to try to play cool. He will wear gloves during the National Football Conference championship game Sunday at Green Bays Lambeau Field because he does not want to let this opportunity slip through his hands.

title: In Nevada, Campaigns Face a Common Foe
description: ELKO, Nev.  On the eve of the Nevada caucuses, the third stop in the battle for the Democratic presidential nomination, the campaigns were doing more Friday than feverishly rallying their supporters. They were also fielding a question: What, exactly, is a caucus?

title: Detainees Lawyers Rebut C.I.A. on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for Majid Khan, a detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, have challenged the Central Intelligence Agencys assertion that videotaping of interrogations stopped in 2002, saying that Mr. Khans interrogations after that time were recorded on videotape.

title: Back to Roots, G.M. and Toyota Trade Places Again
description: DETROIT  At last years auto show here, General Motors and Toyota Motor seemed to be trying to steal each others core customers. G.M. unveiled the Chevrolet Volt, a hybrid-electric concept car, to bolster its green credentials. And Toyota took the wraps off its huge new Tundra, which has a big V-8.

title: A Most Proper Marriage: Jane Austen and PBS
description: Like the current fad for Chinoiserie or fatty meats or big-patterned wallpaper, Masterpiece Theaters presentation of The Complete Jane Austen, a seven-part series in full swing on PBS, feels like something that has already happened. How can it be that televisions great purveyor of baronial imagery  the sweeping shots of mist-covered dells and manor houses, the close-ups of blushed cheeks at the ball  had failed to commit itself fully to the novelist as attached to her property fetish as she was to her moral vision of love? Let it be said that Masterpiece Theater has been remiss. Let it also be said that it has compensated for its lax ways.

title: Justices to Hear Cases on Product Liability
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  The Supreme Courts already substantial investment in defining the boundary between federal regulation and state tort law grew even bigger on Friday. The justices added two new cases to their docket on drug and cigarette labeling requirements.

title: Help for Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: West Virginia Judge Steps Out of Case Involving a Travel Companion
description: Chief Justice Elliott E. Maynard of the West Virginia Supreme Court disqualified himself on Friday from further participation in a case involving a powerful coal executive after photographs of the two men meeting in Monte Carlo in 2006 were filed in court this week.

title: TV Networks Schedule Competition Is Starting to Resemble a Quilting Bee
description: With favorite scripted shows like Desperate Housewives, The Office and CSI now out of fresh episodes, the strike-torn network television season is starting to look like the National Football League around 1987, when replacement players took over the league for three weeks during a walkout by the real players.

The Early Word: 1 Day, 2 States, 3 Contests
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Today is about tie-breaking. With no consistent winner on either side, the G.O.P. primary in South Carolina and the Nevada caucuses could give the victors a chance to claim front-runner status, if not that, at least a hefty chunk of that amorphously important momentum.South Carolina Forecast: Yucky, wintry, with a 100 percent chance of precipitation around the state, maybe even some snow (or, as Columbia, S.C.s The State puts it, SNOW). Turnout is expected to be low, due to both the weather and Republican dissatisfaction with the field.
