title: Best Hockey Commercials
description: What do American hockey fans miss by living in a place where theres no hockey culture? Good TV commercials, for one thing. For those of us doomed to occupy that vast cultural wasteland where backchecking is just an obscure banking practice and the name Rocket Richard draws only a vacant stare, here are some of the best ads, found in places where hockey is part of life.

title: Medallions of Roadkill
description: Some fresh reader comedy (send via the comment link below):

title: My Space, My Ketchup
description: Branding is a constant at Sundance. Everything is brought to you by someone. In the MySpace Celebrity Lounge at the bottom of the chair in Park City, there was a nice place to check e-mail messages and get some vittles. Even though the Bagger is a few rungs belong a celebrity  he doesnt even write about them that much  Lisette, who runs the joint, let him and his camera crew in for a latte and a warm-up. The Bagger was enjoying the high life for the moment, sipping the froth of another galaxy, and then he noticed that both the ketchup and the mustard were branded. My Space Ketchup and My Space Mustard. Rupert Murdoch, chieftain of MySpace owner News Corporation, is clearly at the top of his game, grabbing every opportunity to remind the rest of us that there is not much that he wont eventually own, including the condiments of life. Now, you want fries with that?

title: Cleaning Up
description: Sunshine Cleaning was a tidy, crowd-pleasing hit, with much of main street bubbling about its charms. IndieWire liked it a bunch, calling it an affecting, well-acted drama that casts an even brighter spotlight on rising starlet Amy Adams. At the party afterwards, Harvey Weinstein was out front, chatting about the film  the Bagger did not lean in, so shame on him  and inside Marc Turtletaub was not gloating, but you could tell he knew he had a winner on his hands. Look for the film, which also stars Emily Blunt, to be part of the story of movies that got a nice start at Sundance.

title: The Best Movie Ever
description: Emily Mortimer, the winsome, friendly star of Transsiberian, told the audience at the premiere that the film, the result of an arduous, vodka-infused shoot with Sir Ben Kingsley and Woody Harrelson, was the best set she had ever been on. The Bagger reminded her that she had said the same thing about Lars and the Real Girl, another movie that benefited from her talents. But I really was being sincere this time, she said, managing not to bat her eyes. I love these guys.

title: The All-Star Game: Made for the Outdoors
description: The Hockey News just landed in my mailbox in the desert. Its a big day at my house. I cant wait to see what the latest design is like. (Note to Jason Kay: The current magazine format is just dandy, though I liked the previous ultra-wide edition just as well.)

title: Romney Parses Role of Religion at the Polls
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Maybe God has an opinion.

title: My, Thats Random
description: Random balls of lint in the Baggers notebook: A teeny little dog wearing homemade booties prancing up Main St., who was being follow by an improbably tall woman who was also prancing.

title: At the White Hot Center of Things
description: Last night, the Bagger went to Reaction Lounge on Main St. for the after-party for Transsiberian, the Brad Anderson directed psycho-thriller. There was a bit of a flow problem in the middle of the room at a narrow hallway near the stars  Emily Mortimer and Woody Harrelson. The Bagger wanted to pay his respects, but a large man on a cell phone was using his backside to push the him away, and a seated woman, who was now being stepped on by the Bagger, began pummeling his lower back with fists. He could not move. Just then, a young woman who was also pinned in front of him, managed to get out a business card and slime the Bagger, saying she had a client that shed like him to speak to. If the Bagger had a grenade on him at that instant, he would have pulled the pin.

title: First Contest in the West
description: Democrats vied for the support of crucial union voting blocs in Nevada, and Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mitt Romney emerged as winners.

title: Maliks Downward Spiral
description: The season of Rangers defenseman Marek Malik might have hit a nadir in Saturday afternoons loss to Boston. There were a laundry list of things that went bad for the Rangers in the 4-3 shootout loss but Maliks mistakes were so magnified. If Malik has a lower point, the Rangers surely do not want to see it. He seems certain to be a healthy scratch in todays rematch with Boston and team management has to be mulling a way out.

title: Mitt Romney's Nevada Speech
description: Mitt Romney comments on the results from the Nevada caucuses. (NBC Video)

title: Evangelical Voters
description: Evangelical Christian voters were expected to make up a large share of South Carolina primary voters.

title: Bruins Bergeron May Be Done for the Season
description: The Boston Globe is reporting that the talented Boston Bruins center Patrice Bergeron could be done for the season because of concussion symptoms. Bergeron was rammed into the endboards from behind by Philadelphia Flyers defenseman Randy Jones just 10 games into the season. Jones was suspended two games.

title: Giuliani and the G.O.P.s 11th Commandment
description: THE VILLAGES, Fla.  Rudolph W. Giuliani touts his 12 Commitments on the campaign trail. But he has also committed to following former President Ronald Reagans so-called 11th Commandment: Thou shalt not speak ill of another Republican.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Jan. 20
description: Theres a little something for everyone on this Sundays talk shows.

title: Live From Charleston, the S.C. Primary
description: 10:32 p.m. | Wrapup So, what does Mr. Huckabee do now? Does he turn negative against Mr. McCain, despite what he said in his concession speech? That would be a surprising turn of events, given how effusive Mr. Huckabee has been about Mr. McCain so far.

title: U.S. Is .500 After Winning 500th Game
description: The United States national team played its first international soccer match against Sweden in Stockholm on Aug. 20, 1916. The U.S. won by 3-2.

title: Your Comments on Hillary, Barack, Experience.
description: My Sunday column looks at the accusations that Barack Obama lacks the experience to be a strong president. I argue that the value of traditional Washington experience is overrated as a prerequisite for the presidency: Experience itself is useful, but that includes unorthodox kinds such as growing up in Indonesia. And history suggests that governors often make better presidents than senators, because they gain executive experience. Please post your comments here.

title: A Final Word on the Weather (Maybe)
description: There has been a lot of talk about the weather in the last week, and in several hours we will be able to put the forecasts away and will know just how cold it is in Foxborough and Green Bay.

title: Riverhead Beholds a Mountain
description: EXCEPT for its hilly western North Shore, most of Long Island is as flat as a Midwestern prairie. But if a group of developers and resort designers succeed in building a year-round resort in Riverhead, a new mountain will rise in Suffolk County.

title: Scenes From a Marriage in Baghdad
description: MY wife, Diana, saw the explosion from a Humvee parked a few hundred yards away. Dirt rose over the palm trees, a deep thud shook the ground and Diana told herself I was nowhere near it.

title: The Onward March of the Jumbo Colonials
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn.  PAT MURPHY has been mayor here for almost five years, but she hasnt let it go to her head. Busy as she is, she still finds time to make meals from scratch.

title: Sonali Das and Derek Theisen
description: Sonali Das and Derek Allen Theisen were married on Saturday evening at Capitale, an event space in New York. Brooke Ellison, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the ceremony, officiated.

title: Jessica Adelman, Douglas Sackin
description: Jessica C. Adelman, a daughter of Carol C. Adelman and Kenneth L. Adelman of Arlington, Va., was married on Saturday evening to Douglas M. Sackin, the son of Eileen M. Sackin and Gerald A. Sackin of Denville, N.J. Rabbi Laszlo Berkowits officiated at the Willard hotel in Washington.

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: Young, Female, Energetic and, Now, Dean
description: HEMPSTEAD

title: Chargers Find Renewal Under a Coach Who Shows His Resilience
description: SAN DIEGO  All the voices fanning the flames of discontent in the newspapers, on the radio and at Qualcomm Stadium did not rattle the Chargers first-year coach, Norv Turner. He remained calm as the tongues of ire licked at his heels when his team opened this season with three losses in four games.

title: A Festival to Celebrate a Fabled Wine
description: EVERY year, in the depths of winter, the newest vintage of a little-known wine is unveiled in a weekend of festivities in the Jura mountains of eastern France. The Perce du Vin Jaune  literally, the piercing of the yellow wine  marks the opening of the latest batch of this cult wine, whose minerally taste some compare to sherry. Busloads of wine lovers arrive from all over Europe, with some 50,000 expected at this years event, which will take place Feb. 2 and 3. The atmosphere varies from party-hearty (visitors receive a glass to use for wine-tasting, and a cord from which to conveniently dangle it from their necks) to serious oenophilia.

title: BMW Rethinks the V-8 Engine
description: TUCKED behind a pillar at BMWs Detroit exhibit are the guts of a new gasoline direct-injection twin-turbo V-8 that might have deserved a starring spot in the carmakers display.

title: In Legal Cases, C.I.A. Officers Turn to Insurer
description: WASHINGTON  When Jose A. Rodriguez Jr. came under investigation for ordering the destruction of Central Intelligence Agency interrogation videotapes, one of his first calls was to a small Virginia insurance company that thrives on government trouble.

title: Overseas Investors Buy Aggressively in U.S.
description: Last May, a Saudi Arabian conglomerate bought a Massachusetts plastics maker. In November, a French company established a new factory in Adrian, Mich., adding 189 automotive jobs to an area accustomed to layoffs. In December, a British company bought a New Jersey maker of cough syrup.

title: 36 Hours in Breckenridge, Colo.
description: WHEN carving down Breckenridge, which was one of the first major resorts to embrace snowboarders, it still helps to pack a phrase book for common sayings like, Sick pow, bro! This former mining town, unlike its upscale Colorado neighbors, Vail and Aspen, still exudes a crunchy, laid-back vibe. But Breckenridge also has a new shine. Multimillion-dollar condos now loom over old miners cabins. The year-old BreckConnect Gondola soars over pine forests cleared for luxury homes. And in the historic downtown, wine bars serving marinated olives are taking the place of honky-tonks with beer and Buffalo wings. Still, its your gnarly moves, not your designer outfit, that gets locals stoked.

title: One Teams Discard, Another Teams Ace
description: The San Jose Sharks scored first against the host Phoenix Coyotes last week. The Phoenix goaltender, Ilya Bryzgalov, turned to his net, took a drink, then turned back and went into his crouch. He was ready.

title: Lisa Jane Persky, Andrew Zax
description: Lisa Jane Persky and Andrew David Zax were married Saturday in Beverly Hills, Calif. Chief Justice Ronald M. George of the California Supreme Court officiated at the Beverly Wilshire hotel.

title: Heres My Check; Spend It All at Once
description: THE gift horse could use a good dentist after all. When the American Red Cross said last week that a $200 million deficit would force it to make deep cuts in the headquarters staff, the charitable world detected evidence of one of its most vexing trends: the growing tyranny of donors.

title: Leonard Takes the Lead His Way at the Hope
description: PALM DESERT, Calif.  For much of his professional career, Justin Leonard has been variously described as grim, dogged, ornery or just plain tougher than a 10-cent steak. At various times, during different phases of success and failure, he probably has been all of the above.

description: MATT BLOOD, 34, and Jeff Becherer, 31, live about 100 yards from the Gowanus Canal, at the eastern edge of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn.

title: South Poll
description: The campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination has thus far been marked by a heightened sense of history and optimism  the former because its two leading candidates are pushing up against societal barriers that were once thought unmovable; the latter because Democrats feel as assured of recapturing the presidency as they have at any time since the post-Watergate election of 1976. Now its reality-check time. After early contests in friendlier territories, the nomination fight moves this week into the heart of the Old South, where the inspiring story line of a woman dueling with an African-American will collide, at last, with another side of history. While much of the primary electorate in South Carolina comprises traditional Democrats (black voters, college-town liberals, etc.), the candidates will nonetheless encounter, in a broader way, a less-welcoming political culture in a state that hasnt voted for a Democratic nominee since Jimmy Carter.

title: Packers Robinson Playing for Redemption and a Ring
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Koren Robinson flexed both arms at his locker Friday, then leaned toward his baseball-sized right biceps and planted a quick kiss. The muscle, visual evidence of Robinsons vast athletic talents, also holds a permanent reminder of all the chances that he wasted.

title: Little Cambodia, Growing Still Littler
description: VIBOL SOK SUNGKRIEM, a 31-year-old aspiring filmmaker, had invited a few friends over for dinner, and his apartment just east of the New York Botanical Garden was flooded with camaraderie and the aroma of spicy Southeast Asian food.

title: Hibbert Sets Pace as Georgetown Easily Beats Notre Dame
description: WASHINGTON  On Monday night and well into Tuesday morning, the Georgetown basketball team had plenty of time to think about what it had done wrong.

title: An Iraq Veterans Descent; a Prosecutors Choice

title: Inside the List
description: BEST AND BRIGHTEST I: Thirty-five years ago this week, in January of 1973, the No. 1 nonfiction title was The Best and the Brightest, by David Halberstam, a wide-screen, gossip-packed account of the snaky path to war in Vietnam. The books reviews were essentially positive, with one notable exception: Mary McCarthys scorched-earth put-down in The New York Review of Books. (While reading Halberstams book, McCarthy wrote, she was unable to stay awake for more than a few paragraphs at a go without ferocious application of will power, tea, coffee, drinks of water, propping open of eyelids, pinches, strolls about the room. And thats a friendly passage.) McCarthys 7,000-word review didnt stop the book from selling; it remained on the hardcover list for 36 weeks, and Halberstam sold the paperback rights for $700,000. As John Leonard, then the Book Reviews editor, wrote at the time, the paperback money presumably makes a nice poultice to apply to the wounds of pride.

description: WHAT happens when Japans deeply rooted traditions and its insatiable appetite for new technology collide? The results are on show in a recent wave of hot spring hotels, or onsen ryokans, that merge ancient ideas with concepts from modern design.

title: Blue Skies in a Bottle
description: THE world is a complicated place. So perhaps it is fitting that we should conjure a pointedly optimistic way of thinking just to dispel the voices of certain doom and jaded irony. The first says, It cant be done; the second says, It has been done to death.

title: What Would Obama Say?
description: AT the Radisson Hotel in Nashua, N.H., Jon Favreau sipped Diet Coke and munched on carrot sticks and crackers to pass the time. His boss, Senator Barack Obama, wandered in and out of the room.

title: Johnny Boys Excellent Adventure
description: BY 8 oclock on an evening in early December, the bar at the Hilton Garden Inn in northwestern Staten Island was a scrum of beefy middle-aged men dressed in blazers, fancy dress shirts and loafers. Cheeks glistening in the warmth, they embraced one another noisily, slapping backs, planting kisses on both cheeks and occasionally offering a flurry of mock punches.

title: March of the Jumbo Colonials
description: NEW MILFORD

title: Movies With More Than Munchies
description: When it comes to food, most movie theaters limit their offerings to candy, popcorn and soda. Not the Gilson Caf/Cinema. Gilson doesnt even sell candy, preferring instead to whip up a wide enough array of eats to satisfy most dinnertime appetites.

title: A City That Needs More Places to Sleep
description: NEW hotel developments could add nearly 3,000 rooms to the Manhattan market in 2008, a supply increase that might siphon travelers away from existing properties just as economists are forecasting an economic slowdown, or even a recession.

title: No Quick Knockouts as Races Move to New Terrain
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  With his victory in South Carolina on Saturday, Senator John McCain of Arizona has accomplished what no other Republican presidential candidate has been able to do this year: he has captured two competitive contests. Not incidentally, this one was in the state that effectively sank his campaign in 2000.

title: A Meeting Place Marrying Design and Cuisine
description: PART of the pleasure of eating out is enjoying cuisine in the context in which it is served.

title: Name of Possible Witness Emerges in an Audiotape
description: For the past five years, Jim Murrays job has been to tend to the needs of the New York-area clients of Hendricks Sports Management, a Texas agency that built its name on its representation of Roger Clemens. Murray is far less known than Randy and Alan Hendricks, but his name comes up in two key moments of a 17-minute tape of a Jan. 4 telephone conversation between Clemens and Brian McNamee, his accuser and former trainer.

title: Minnesota Bill Would Ban Limitless Drinking Specials
description: On Thursday nights at the Haze club in the college town of Mankato, Minn., students used to pay $5 for unlimited cups of beer and mixed drinks from 9 p.m. to midnight. A nearby bar, Boomtown, offered similar specials, known as cup nights, on Tuesdays and Fridays, and on Thursdays women drank free.

title: Hi. Buy You a Drink? Save the Planet?
Not a Rhodes Scholar? Oxford Is Still in Reach
description: Live out your Rhodes Scholar fantasy this spring with Insiders Oxford, a new program offered by the Department of Continuing Education at Oxford University, which is based on the popular, multithemed summer program Oxford Experience. From March 30 to April 5, participants will attend morning lectures on the history of Oxford, including its place in literature, music, art and religion, and tour the city of dreaming spires in the afternoon. Meals will be taken in the dining hall, and nights will be spent in Worcester College, which has an 18th-century chapel and hall and extensive gardens.

title: The Abortionist
description: One morning in January 1991, Susan Wicklund arrived at work wearing a heavy coat of makeup and a curly auburn wig pulled over her half-inch-long gray hair. It was a get-up worthy of a double agent, and it succeeded in helping Wicklund slip unnoticed across enemy lines, though not without feeling as if shed stepped into a version of The Twilight Zone. Why do I have to do this? she scrawled in her journal afterward. WHY?

title: Congo Groups Blame Each Other for Killings
description: GOMA, Congo (Agence France-Presse)  Rebels and militias in eastern Congo blamed each other on Saturday for the deaths of as many as 40 civilians in fighting over the past two days.

title: No Room at the Lot and Late at the Gate
description: WITH more travelers taking to the skies, its becoming harder to find a parking spot at the airport.

title: Thumbs Race as Japans Best Sellers Go Cellular
description: TOKYO  Until recently, cellphone novels  composed on phone keypads by young women wielding dexterous thumbs and read by fans on their tiny screens  had been dismissed in Japan as a subgenre unworthy of the country that gave the world its first novel, The Tale of Genji, a millennium ago. Then last month, the year-end best-seller tally showed that cellphone novels, republished in book form, have not only infiltrated the mainstream but have come to dominate it.

title: Letters: Bangkok Street Food
description: To the Editor: The article "Street Smarts in Bangkok" (Jan. 6) about the joys of eating food prepared by street vendors in Bangkok, neglects to mention some street smarts to avoid becoming ill from such foods. The authors only reference to sanitation is Thais are fastidious about cleanliness, important to customers worried about eating alongside a road.

title: The Legal Trail in a Delta Drama
description: OXFORD, MISS.  ON a crisp, sunny morning last week, Mississippis political elite gathered in Jackson for a day of celebration. They began with a gospel prayer breakfast before proceeding to the state Capitol to witness the swearing-in of Haley Barbour for a second term as governor.

title: A Community Tries to Shrink Its Footprint
description: WESTPORT, Conn.

title: Leap Day in the Bahamas: Extra Day, Free Room
description: Does spending Leap Year Day in the Bahamas sound enticing? That is easier to do as a dozen resorts in the Out Islands are honoring the quadrennial event with a free nights stay. Travelers who book at least two nights, one of which is Feb. 29, at one of the participating properties will receive the leap year night in a single or double room free (except for a 12 percent tax and fees).

title: The Education of Ben Bernanke
description: Ben Bernankes first exposure to monetary policy was reading the works of Milton Friedman, the Nobel laureate. That was 30 years ago, when Bernanke was a graduate student at M.I.T., and he has been studying central banking ever since. By the time President Bush nominated him to run the Federal Reserve, at the end of 2005, Bernanke knew more about central banking than any economist alive. On virtually every topic of significance  how to prevent deflationary panics, for instance, or to gauge the effect of Fed moves on stock-market prices  Bernanke wrote one of the seminal papers. He championed ideas for improving communications between the Fed  whose previous chairman, Alan Greenspan, spoke in riddles  and the public, believing that clearer guidance about the Feds aims would help the economy run more smoothly. And having devoted much of his career to studying the causes of the Great Depression, Bernanke was the academic expert on how to prevent financial crises from spinning out of control and threatening the general economy. One line from his Essays on the Great Depression sounds especially prescient today: To the extent that bank panics interfere with normal flows of credit, they may affect the performance of the real economy.

title: New Jersey: Cut Expenses Before Raising Tolls
description: To the Editor:

title: Offering Fresh Weapons Against Test Anxiety
description: WEST BABYLON

title: Looking at the Slope of Things to Come
description: DETROIT

title: Food That Recalls a Childhood
description: At Zuleykas Kitchen in Red Bank, the whereabouts of the chef, Zuleyka Farro, may be obvious, but her cooking isnt. From her stove at this small cafe that opened in 2005, she creates a divergent, but delicious, mix of Caribbean, American and Mediterranean-inspired soups, salads and sandwiches.

title: Odyssey of State Capitols and State Suspicion
description: IN a recent morning interview in a Midtown Manhattan office Ramak Fazel came across as the quintessential world citizen: tall, slim and elegant, his English tinged with an untraceable accent and peppered here and there with an Italian phrase.

title: McCain Victory in South Carolina Caps Comeback
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John McCain staved off a spirited challenge by Mike Huckabee to win the South Carolina primary on Saturday, exorcising the ghosts of the attack-filled primary here that derailed his presidential hopes eight years ago.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: FILM

title: The Bride Got Life
description: It was a murder, one lawyer said, done execution style: On a patch of land near a California road in 1978, Cesario Arauzas arms were crossed over his chest, he was lying on his back and he had been shot in the head, Linda Spalding writes in Who Named the Knife. The body of another victim, Lawrence Hasker, was found around the same time near a highway in Hawaii. He had been shot twice. Once in an ankle. Once in the head, Spalding says. Someone, it must have been, with lousy aim.

title: The Bus to Houston
description: My leaving home actually began by going back there, to Greensboro, N.C., from Mount Holyoke College for the summer of 1966. That was when my mother pretty much went off her rocker.

title: Dr. Jekyll Meets Mr. Hybrid
description: DETROIT

title: Sin City
description: The Madonna-whore complex is seldom as well defined as in The Delivery Man, Joe McGinniss Jr.s brisk, bleak debut novel. Caught in the middle is Chase, a 25-year-old who fled New York University and is festering in his native Las Vegas, a blocked painter turned heel-dragging high school teacher. His girlfriend, Julia, is on the corporate fast track (and in town briefly for a black M.B.A. conference), contemplating bearing his child; Michele, a relic from his past, is, to be brutal, a whore.

title: Sticks n Stones and Allies
description: For the second time in a month, we saw Defense Secretary Robert Gates making headlines  and raising hackles  last week by publicly faulting NATO for what it is doing, and not doing well enough, in Afghanistan.

title: Unintended Consequences
description: The Case of the Red-Cockaded Woodpecker

title: Deena Greenberg, Howard Schacter
description: Deena Joan Greenberg and Howard Andrew Schacter are to be married on Sunday at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Shevack is to officiate.

title: Alpha Poet
description: Louis Zukofsky (1904-78) is the author of an enormous poem called simply A, an 800-plus-page work written over the course of more than 50 years in a mlange of styles and forms, from Poundian free verse to Italian canzoni. A-21  the poem was composed of 24 parts, mirroring the hours of the day  translates an entire play by Plautus. A-24, the final section, is the score of a masque composed by Zukofskys wife, Celia. The most hermetic poem in English, a long intent eccentric unread game, was the critic Hugh Kenners judgment of A, and Kenner liked it.

title: Editors Choice
description: FREEDOM FOR THE THOUGHT THAT WE HATE: A Biography of the First Amendment, by Anthony Lewis. (Basic Books, $25.) Passionately, if discursively, the former New York Times columnist ranges across a variety of free speech controversies.

title: Chinatown Chronicle
description: FOR years, the citys Chinese journalists have documented affairs great and slight in the lives of restaurant workers, souvenir vendors, community leaders, ginseng wholesalers and fake-merchandise dealers. Last weekend at the Lin Sing Association, a century-old social club on Mott Street, these news gatherers were honored with an exhibition of photographs by journalists for the citys Chinese newspapers and other news media outlets. Here are a few of their images.

title: An Old Mentors New Medium
description: O.K., position, ready and. ...

title: Drugs, a Dad and His Midlife Crisis
description: Sherman Oaks. Calif.

title: Jennifer Newman, Peter Bernstein
description: Jennifer Beth Newman, the daughter of Selma Rabin Newman and Jeffrey E. Newman of Miami Beach, was married on Saturday evening to Peter Joshua Bernstein, the son of Vivian Glaser Bernstein and Daniel S. Bernstein of New York. Rabbi Gary A. Glickstein officiated at Westview Country Club in Miami.

title: Correction: Strike Now, While the Deals Are Hot
description: Because of an editing error, the Practical Traveler column on Jan. 6, about affordable getaways in the Caribbean this winter, misstated the name of an inn on Barbados. It is the Peach and Quiet, not the Peace and Quiet.

title: Matzos, Just One Flavor of the Lower East Side
description: To the Editor:

title: From Slavery to Freedom
description: In early 1960, four young black men drove up from the first Southern sit-ins to speak at the Northern university I was attending. So we would know more about what they had encountered, they turned their backs to the audience and lifted their shirts, revealing the scars made by the lighted cigarettes segregationists had put out on their skin at the Woolworths lunch counter. At the time, I didnt understand the historical resonance of this gesture, which reproduced that of former slaves at 19th-century abolitionist meetings, baring their backs to show the gouges of the whip.

title: Giving the People What They Want
description: WHEN Jack W. Batman became the executive producer of the White Plains Performing Arts Center last February, there were no season subscribers. Now there are close to 800, and the theaters 2007-8 season opener, Man of La Mancha, exceeded ticket sale expectations by more than 30 percent, with its final weekend, in mid-December, nearly selling out.

title: Correction
description: A review on Jan. 6 about Islamophobia: Making Muslims the Enemy repeated the books erroneous description of a commentator who interviewed Keith Ellison, the first Muslim American congressman. He is a talk show host for CNN Headline News, not a CNN anchor. (The commentator, Glenn Beck, was not named in either the book or the review.)

title: Shooting Ranges in the Suburbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Ghosts That Haunt Pakistan
description: An article Jan. 6 on Pakistans history of difficulty in sustaining democracy misidentified the military leader under whom Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who would later become prime minister, served as foreign minister in the 1960s. The leader was Gen. Ayub Khan, not Gen. Yahya Khan. The article also referred incorrectly to the timing of the disputed parliamentary election that left Mr. Bhutto in a position to emerge from a civil war in 1971 as the first civilian head of government of a truncated Pakistan. The election was held before the war, in 1970, not after the war.

title: Higher Values, Bigger Tax Bill?
description: CONGRATULATIONS, Manhattan town house owners! Your houses are worth more than ever. And, by the way, the government has noticed.

title: All the Worlds a Page
description: When Hanna Heath, a manuscript conservator, first touches the centuries-old Hebrew codex known as the Sarajevo Haggadah, she feels a strange and powerful sensation, something between brushing a live wire and stroking the back of a newborn babys head. The manuscript is small, the binding soiled and scuffed, but its lavish illuminations  miniature scenes as interpreted in the Midrash, created at a time when most Jews considered figurative art a violation of the commandments  are stunning. Its the spring of 1996 in Sarajevo, and Hanna has been called in to examine the book before its put on display.

title: Its All About Focus
description: THROUGHOUT my life with my parents, growing up in a poor neighborhood in Brooklyn, we rented an apartment and my father had two or three jobs. My mom worked as a clerk at a bank. Money and material belongings were at an absolute minimum. We didnt own a car. Vacations were sparse.

title: Letters: Keeping It Real
description: James Gleick (Jan. 6) writes that an early copy of Magna Carta was sold at auction recently for $21,321,000. If his point was to emphasize the high value placed on artifacts that have historicity compared with the cost of obtaining the ubiquitous information flowing on our computer screens, he may have been unintentionally misleading.

title: Blurring Realitys Edge in Fluid China
description: IN the movies of Jia Zhang-ke, it can often seem that all of modern China is a ready-made film set. Either that or Mr. Jia has an uncanny gift for the metaphorically charged location. His films have taken place within the plastic confines of an Epcot-like Beijing theme park (The World), amid the forlorn public spaces of a declining post-industrial city (Unknown Pleasures) and in an ancient riverside town that is about to disappear underwater (Still Life, which won the top prize at the 2006 Venice International Film Festival and which opened in New York on Friday).

title: Rupa Krishnamurthy and Jeffrey Wong
description: Dr. Rupa Krishnamurthy and Dr. Jeffrey Jason Wong, both ophthalmologists, were married on Saturday at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel in Honolulu. The Rev. Ian H. Farrell performed a Presbyterian ceremony. Earlier in the day, Krishnamacharyulu Samudrala, a Hindu priest, led a traditional Brahmin ceremony at the hotel.

title: On the Waterfront, Sound, Fury and a Lawsuit
description: TIME was, the West 30th Street Heliport was of a piece with the industrial Hudson waterfront: a gritty three-block strip of tarmac that emitted a vacuum-cleaner roar at all hours. But since the creation of Hudson River Park in 1998, Chelsea residents have been complaining about the heliport, which sits within the park next to a jogging path and just north of a promenade.

title: Radical Left, Irans Last Legal Dissidents, Until Now
description: TEHRAN  In early December, a surprising scene unfolded at Tehran University: 500 Marxist students held aloft portraits of Che Guevara to protest President Mahmoud Ahmadinejads policies. Smaller groups of Marxist students held similar protests in several other cities.

title: G.P.S. for My Lost Identity
description: LAST summer, I found out that my identity had been stolen. It was the weekend of a friends wedding, and I was standing outside the Memorial Church at Stanford University for the rehearsal when I called my bank to make sure I could clear an important check.

title: The New Old Boys?
description: BACK in the late 1970s, when I was looking for my first job, there was a lot of talk about the old boys network. Recently, I have been thinking about the new girls network. Let me explain.

title: All Roads Still Lead to Lombardi
description: All you need to know about Green Bay is that Lambeau Field is on Lombardi Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Clean House, Top-Down

title: Buyers, Now Hear This
description: SPRING has already started for residential real estate, at least the way brokers look at it. And spring is coming in, well, not so much like a lion or a lamb as a lumbering bear.

title: From the Depths
description: At the end of Fred Wanders novel about life in the Nazi camps, the narrator lies in the childrens barracks of Buchenwald between a dead man and a pack of starving Jewish boys. It is April 1945; American tanks are at the gate. Delirious from typhus, he is overcome by hope as he watches the boys slice up a potato. Some might say the camp and its bestial conditions had destroyed their human substance, he writes, but I knew right then: everything will start over, nothing has been lost.

title: A Doctors Passion, a Journalists Eye
description: AT Ball State University in Indiana a 30-year-old Iraqi doctor named Omer Salih Mahdi is just starting his second semester of journalism school. But he comes better prepared than most to make the shift from a hospital in Baghdad to the classrooms of Muncie: he has already filmed and directed an International Emmy Award-winning documentary Baghdad Hospital: Inside the Red Zone, to be shown on HBO beginning Jan. 29.

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Melbourne, Australia
description: The 36 Hours column on Jan. 6 about Melbourne, Australia, misstated the price for the Skybus shuttle from Melbourne Airport to the city. A one-way ticket costs 15 Australian dollars, or $13 at 1.16 Australian dollars to the American dollar. It is not 3.30 Australian dollars.

title: Knicks Stop the Heat, So Bring On the Celtics
description: MIAMI  The Knicks beat a recent N.B.A. champion and the worst team in the Eastern Conference on Saturday night. The Miami Heat own each of those identities, so the Knicks can choose what to make of the outcome.

title: Number of Rooms Cant Meet Surging Demand
description: AS if the sagging dollar and soaring oil costs werent enough to dent travel budgets, hotel room rates are expected to surge in the coming year. From New York to Asia, and just about every desirable destination in between, the prices of rooms  especially at hotels and resorts favored by luxury and business travelers  are expected to rise significantly, sometimes in the double digits, analysts say.

title: Is It Paris, or Just Newark After Dark?
description: NEWARK

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 36 of The Times Magazine this weekend, about Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, misspells the surname of the secretary of the Treasury. He is Henry Paulson Jr., not Paulsen.

title: Irans Small Boats Are a Big Problem
description: Silver Spring, Md.

title: Democratic Vistas
description: H. L. Mencken once wrote that democracy is only a dream: it should be put in the same category as Arcadia, Santa Claus and Heaven.

title: Correction: What Is It About Mormonism?
description: An article on Jan. 6 about Mormonism referred imprecisely to the Gospel books of the Bible, mentioned in a comparison of Mormon and evangelical beliefs. Matthew, Mark and Luke are considered synoptic  that is, seen from the same point of view  but John is not.

title: Rock Cantankerousness and Other Moods
description: Cat Power

title: Unscrambling the Alphabet of Fund Fees
description: WHEN stock markets climb, the fees associated with equity ownership are easy to shrug off. But with the stock market ailing in 2008  the Standard & Poors 500-stock index is down 9.75 percent as of Friday  mutual fund investors are right to wonder and worry about the costs they are paying to own their shares.

title: The Story of Night
description: This fall, Elie Wiesels Night was removed from the New York Times best-seller list, where it had spent an impressive 80 weeks after Oprah Winfrey picked it for her book club. The Timess news survey department, which compiles the list, decided the Holocaust memoir wasnt a new best seller but a classic like Animal Farm or To Kill a Mockingbird, which sell hundreds of thousands of copies a year largely through course adoptions. Indeed, since it appeared in 1960, Night has sold an estimated 10 million copies  three million of them since Winfrey chose the book in January 2006 (and traveled with Wiesel to Auschwitz).

title: Intervention, Hailed as a Concept, Is Shunned in Practice
description: UNITED NATIONS  Three years after the United Nations adopted a groundbreaking resolution to help it intervene to stop genocide, even longtime supporters of the rule acknowledge that it has not helped the organization end the violence in Darfur.

title: Rachel Beck and William Owens
description: Rachel Vanessa Beck, a daughter of Deborah B. Beck of New York and the late Bertram M. Beck, was married on Monday to William Matthew Owens, a son of Janet Owens and James Owens of Murrells Inlet, S.C. The Rev. Jerome Blankinship, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Bellagio hotel in Las Vegas.

title: Monster in the Wings
description: LOS ANGELES

title: For Disc Jockeys as Well as Desk Jockeys
description: IF youve always longed to be a disc jockey  or at least to play one on Saturday nights  some new, highly portable D.J. gear could bring that dream much closer.

title: A Walk in the Park, on the Night of the Lovelorn Owl
description: TO find owls, one must become an owl. That is why 20 soggy people were traipsing about the Ramble in Central Park on the evening of Dec. 30 as sleet and rain fell from a darkening sky.

title: Pump-Priming the Economy
description: After months of denial, President Bush seems to be bowing to the need to stimulate the faltering economy. He has also given up, for now, his effort to use the economys deepening woes as an excuse to extend his tax cuts for the wealthy past their 2010 expiration date.

title: Settling Old Scores by Beethoven
description: MANCHESTER, England

title: Fired Up
description: Im fired up! Im ready to go!

title: Michael Keaton Never Expected to Be the Director
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Traditional Trappings for a Modern Mission
description: RIVERSIDE CHURCH, completed in 1930 at 122nd Street and Riverside Drive, embodied modern religious thought but was clad in 13th-century French Gothic. Its massive tower is now ringed by construction scaffolding, as restoration crews go piece by piece, inspecting and repairing the limestone.

title: Adventure Guide to Mexico
description: BEYOND the sunbathers, cervezas and spring break debauchery so conspicuously on display in Cancn and Cozumel, Mexico offers a lesser-known adventure experience  the kind that is found deep in the jungle or near small fishing villages and offshore reefs.

title: Correction: Check In, Check Out: Tschuggen Grand Hotel and Spa
description: Because of an editing error, the Check In/Check Out column on Dec. 30 about the Tschuggen Grand Hotel and Spa in Arosa, Switzerland, misstated the price in dollars that the hotel spent on its new spa last year. It was 35 million Swiss francs, which is about $30 million, not $30,000, at an exchange rate of about 1.15 Swiss francs to the dollar.

title: The Risk of Innovation: Will Anyone Embrace It?
description: THE Prius has become one of the hottest cars in America  an amazing development, because this hybrid-electric car requires some rather large changes in how people behave.

title: Work an Hour, Pay Tax on 2. Is That Fair?
description: MORE than a few commuters from Connecticut and New Jersey have dreamed about skipping the daily slog to their office in New York and working at home.

title: Paperback Row
description: SELECTED POEMS, by Derek Walcott. Edited by Edward Baugh. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15.) Born on St. Lucia in 1930, Walcott was educated in Jamaica and has lived in Trinidad and in the United States, where he still teaches for part of the year at Boston University. Much of his work  which includes 13 books of poetry and seven of plays as well as a volume of essays  reflects his experience with colonial rule and its aftermath. How choose, he asked in an early poem, Between this Africa and the English tongue I love? / Betray them both, or give back what they give? This collection, edited by the Jamaican poet Edward Baugh, represents every stage of Walcotts long career, for which he won a Nobel Prize in 1992. Walcott has captured his islands with a lushness and richness rare in our poetry, our reviewer, William Logan, said. No living poet has written verse more delicately rendered or distinguished.

title: Georgetown Efficiency Thwarts Notre Dame
description: WASHINGTON  Georgetown is an elite team, and Notre Dame could eventually become one.

title: An Earnhardt Revival Would Also Be Nascars
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  A sweeping color change is expected in Nascars top series this season, when the distinctive red hue of the grandstands at each event suddenly turns a deep, dark shade of green. Dale Earnhardt Jr. can have that effect on a crowd.

title: Leaping-Room Only at Lambeau Field
description: Ryan Verrier and Chris Drosner are hoping to catch another Green Bay Packer or two in Sundays National Football Conference championship game against the Giants.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 2: Louise

title: Letters: Hawaiian Cry
description: To the Editor: I first went to Hawaii in February 1968 after sailing for two months on a 36-foot trimaran from Acapulco. I lived on the Big Island periodically from 1969 to 1994. Every time you publish an article like "Not in My Tropical Backyard" (Dec. 30), about a ferry between Honolulu and Maui, and hear about more tourists, more second homes, more hotels, I want to cry.

title: Installment Plan
description: THEA WESTREICH, a prominent art adviser, and Ethan Wagner, her husband and business partner, spend their days immersed in the art world. Even at home, they are surrounded by contemporary art, which is exactly how they like to live. But anyone who is expecting the couples SoHo loft to be a series of sterile, gallerylike spaces is in for a surprise.

title: Red, White and Blue Tag Sale
description: WASHINGTON

title: Bruins Edge Rangers in a Messy Game
description: BOSTON  The Rangers egregious turnovers and bad penalties took a back seat in Coach Tom Renneys mind. He could forgive his team for generating only 28 shots. For that matter, he could ignore almost everything the Rangers did wrong in their 4-3 shootout loss to the Boston Bruins on Saturday afternoon  except the loss itself.

title: Boy, 13, Killed While Driving a Forklift in Queens
description: A 13-year-old boy visiting his fathers workplace was killed Saturday in Queens when a small forklift-style vehicle he was trying to drive flipped over and trapped him, the authorities and company managers said.

title: Living With Ghosts
description: Gloomy poets are rarely very good, and good poets rarely very gloomy. There was Edgar Allan Poe, of course, and Thomas Lovell Beddoes, denizens of that funereal, willow-shadowed decade of the 1840s, a decade half in love with Keats and half in love with easeful death. Thomas Hardy had his black moods, but also his moments of sour levity. For more than 50 years, however, Geoffrey Hill has written a pinch-mouthed, grave-diggers poetry so rich and allusive his books are normally greeted by gouts of praise from critics and the bewilderment of readers who might have been happier with a tract on the mating rituals of the earwig.

title: Classic Event Thrives Without Famous Founder
description: PALM DESERT, Calif.  The old tournament directors sharp eyes gleam when he talks about a time when the names of golf tournaments also had faces. There were 10 of them, including the one he ran that everybody still called the Hope in those days. Even now the litany is familiar.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Film

title: Lottery Numbers
Giants vs. Packers
description: Brett Favre vERSUS Giants secondary

title: A Cutting Tradition
description: When a girl is taken  usually by her mother  to a free circumcision event held each spring in Bandung, Indonesia, she is handed over to a small group of women who, swiftly and yet with apparent affection, cut off a small piece of her genitals. Sponsored by the Assalaam Foundation, an Islamic educational and social-services organization, circumcisions take place in a prayer center or an emptied-out elementary-school classroom where desks are pushed together and covered with sheets and a pillow to serve as makeshift beds. The procedure takes several minutes. There is little blood involved. Afterward, the girls genital area is swabbed with the antiseptic Betadine. She is then helped back into her underwear and returned to a waiting area, where shes given a small, celebratory gift  some fruit or a donated piece of clothing  and offered a cup of milk for refreshment. She has now joined a quiet majority in Indonesia, where, according to a 2003 study by the Population Council, an international research group, 96 percent of families surveyed reported that their daughters had undergone some form of circumcision by the time they reached 14.

title: Stove Ignites Clothing, Killing a Bronx Woman
description: A 78-year-old woman died Saturday after her clothing caught fire as she stood over the stove in her Bronx apartment, the authorities said. Her 98-year-old mother was burned while trying to put out the flames.

title: Jones Knocks Down Trinidad Twice on Way to Victory
description: Roy Jones Jr. had an entourage of rappers with him at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. He had a shiny crown, a menacing grin and some dance moves to boot.

title: A Recessions Impact Is All in the Timing
description: A FEW weeks ago, the big debate on Wall Street was whether or not the economy was headed for a recession. Today, for many investors, the question isnt whether a recession is coming, but when. In fact, some are wondering whether one has already begun.

title: Howls and Wonder: Shakespeare on Love
description: London

title: Fierce Spending in Early Stages Saps Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON  The 2008 presidential race long ago shattered all fund-raising records. But lately even the best-financed campaigns are feeling short on cash.

title: Pas de Deux
description: You expect a French book to be quirky. Theres Georges Perecs Disparition, a 300-page novel without a single e in it (its translated into English as A Void, also e-less). Theres Michel Houellebecqs Elementary Particles, a talky book about a sex addict and his half brother, described in The New York Times as deeply repugnant. And if you havent read those two yet, dont bother: Pierre Bayards How to Talk About Books You Havent Read suggests that the best approach to books might be to ignore them altogether. Surely France has its John Grishams and Danielle Steels, but when a French book shows up in this country, we expect it to be somewhat unusual.

title: Caution: Elephants Brake for Food on Bangkoks Roads
description: BANGKOK  Of all the illegal activities that animate the streets of Bangkok  the vendors who hawk pirated DVDs and fake watches, the brothels that call themselves saunas  one stands out more than others.

title: Study Sees Caffeine Possibly Tied to Miscarriages
description: Too much caffeine during pregnancy may increase the risk of miscarriage, a new study says, and it suggests that pregnant women may want to reduce their intake or cut it out entirely.

title: A Late Bloomer Is Making Connections Through Song
description: SILENCE might seem an unlikely topic for a musician whose life is spent arranging, writing, performing and recording songs. But for Kate McGarry, whose CD The Target reached No. 1 on the JazzWeek chart in September and was named one of the top albums of 2007 by Downbeat, silence is more than the opposite of sound.

title: Public and Private Lives, Intersecting
description: LINDA GREENHOUSE, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Times reporter who has covered the Supreme Court for nearly 30 years, is used to dealing with top-drawer legal authorities. But its not always convenient that she is married to one.

title: Toomer and Strahan Bonding at 100 Yards and at 35,000 Feet
description: There is a perception that the plane ride home after a big road victory, like the one the Giants enjoyed over the Dallas Cowboys last Sunday night, is bacchanal revelry, Mardi Gras at 35,000 feet.

title: Israeli Airstrike in Gaza Kills 2 Hamas Members
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli airstrike killed two members of the Hamas military wing in the northern Gaza Strip early on Saturday, and three Qassam rockets fired by militants from Gaza landed in and around the Israeli border town of Sderot, causing no casualties.

title: Emily Jones, Preston McGowan
description: Emily Joy Jones was married on Sunday evening to Preston LeRoi McGowan. The Rev. Mariah A. Britton, a nondenominational minister, is to officiate at the Rockleigh, a caterer in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: An Unconvincing Shade of Green
description: DETROIT

title: Francis Childs, 68, Dies; Sage of High Corn Yields
description: Francis Childs, a third-generation farmer who studied, schemed and tramped his fields with a spade to become the most productive corn grower ever, died on Jan. 9 in Marshall County, Iowa. He was 68.

title: Carrie Bloom, Gary Ratner
description: Carrie Meredith Bloom, a daughter of Marilyn Bloom and Robert Bloom of East Meadow, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Gary Ross Ratner, the son of Bonnie Ratner and Dr. Martin Ratner of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Albert J. Lowenberg officiated at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Get Out Your Handkerchiefs. Or Maybe Not.
description: IN a city where most people travel by foot, its hard not to notice when someone is having a bad day.

title: Stephanie Patterson, Robert Brown
description: Stephanie Jeannette Patterson and Robert Banks Brown were married on Saturday evening in Naples, Fla. The Rev. Robert W. Bohl, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Ritz-Carlton.

title: Nature Has Protectors Here
description: MAHOPAC, a hamlet just north of the Westchester County border, is richly laced with lakes and streams and densely wooded hillsides. All that beauty is natural, of course, yet it owes its abundance to decades of human planning and effort.

title: Rosanna Giacalone and Tig Krekel
description: Rosanna Lucia Giacalone and Tig Hudson Krekel were married on Saturday evening in New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Church, where he is the rector.

title: Fishing for a Keeper
description: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

title: In Search of Reagan
description: WASHINGTON

title: Recruiting With Real Estate
description: COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY, in a never-ending search for a larger campus, has long had an outpost for faculty housing at 455 Central Park West  53 apartments in an 26-story tower attached to the French Renaissance chateau at West 106th Street.

title: Eve Thompson and Richard Robinson
description: HER family and friends agreed: Eve Thompson, 47, was not the marrying kind.

title: A Main Street With Real Staying Power
description: An entry for a house on the market with the Living In article last Sunday about Newton, N.J., gave an incorrect price and telephone number. The asking price for the five-bedroom Victorian at 5 Maple Avenue is $649,900, not $599,000. The listing agents phone number is (973) 601-1212.

title: Co-ops Reap Unexpected Bonanza
description: FOR years, some New York City co-ops that have retail space in their buildings have been doing the unfathomable. They have rented out their commercial space at bargain rents, and to make sure they werent making too much money on the spaces, they have even occasionally given back thousands of dollars to tenants at the end of the year.

title: Who Needs a 401(k)? Id Rather Have a Castle
description: HUMANITYS need for shelter has always inspired grandiose desires that can become tantamount to lust. The Tenth Commandment even places housing and lust side by side, admonishing, Thou shalt not covet thy neighbors house, thou shalt not covet they neighbors wife.

title: There on Broadway, Friends From Home
description: STEPPENWOLF THEATER COMPANY, the Chicago troupe now in its 32nd season, has staked two claims in the Manhattan theater district in the past two months: August in December and November in January.

title: Tax Rebate or Payment? A Policy Debate Begins
description: WASHINGTON  As President Bush and Congressional Democrats begin negotiations on a package of measures to stimulate the economy, the big fight will be over whether to put extra money in the hands of tens of millions of low-income families who paid little or no income tax last year.

title: Candidates, Behave
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: At the Yippie Museum, Its Parrots and Flannel
description: ASIDE from the oversize photograph of Jerry Rubin sporting a giant Afro and the three-foot-high marijuana leaf painted on the wall, the most noticeable museum-worthy facets of the Yippie Museum and Cafe in Greenwich Village may be the people hanging out there. On a recent Thursday evening, there seemed to be a greater concentration of men and women with long gray hair, flannel shirts and mellow smiles than one was likely to find anywhere else in Manhattan.

title: Schools Face Confusion Over a Vaccine
description: WHEN Heidemarie Ratje of East Patchogue received a letter from the South Country Central School District last June saying that all students turning 11 would be required to get an immunization shot, she thought it did not apply to her daughter.

title: A Passage to India
description: An article last Sunday about an analysis by a New York University food studies professor of seven Indian restaurants in the city inaccurately described the Indian state from where the professor, Krishnendu Ray, emigrated in 1989. The state, Orissa, is a neighbor to the Indian state of West Bengal; it is not part of Bengal, which is a region that comprises West Bengal and Bangladesh. The article also misidentified the cuisine of Saravanaas, a restaurant on Lexington Avenue at 26th Street. Saravanaas serves southern Indian food  not Bengali-Indian.

title: Save a Therm, Get $2 or Even $2.50
description: THE settlement of a rate case involving the Consolidated Edison Company and New York States Public Service Commission could save owners of residential buildings with five or more apartments  including co-ops and condominiums  significant amounts of money if they upgrade their heating systems this year.

title: Drink, Be Merry and Eat if You Must
description: A DECEMBER afternoon, just before Christmas. Inside Harry Cipriani, the restaurant on Fifth Avenue and 60th Street, the tiny tables were crowded together, each offering an expensively arrayed bouquet of people against a backdrop of golden light and polished wood. Suzanne Somers, the actress and purveyor of toning devices, presided over a table of six holidaymakers, the men in bright ties, the womens lips colored outside the lines.

title: 15 People Are Killed Across Iraq on Shiite Religious Holiday
description: BAGHDAD  A rocket attack and several bombings killed at least 15 people in central and northern Iraq on Saturday, Iraqi officials said.

title: This Time, Rate Cuts May Not Be a Panacea
description: THE recent bleak returns on Wall Street have ushered in a period of accord among investment advisers. Many have been prescribing the same bromide to their clients: switch to defensive stocks and cut back on bonds.

title: Theyve Got Those Mekong Blues Again
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Bridgeports New Mayor Holds Tight to Senate Seat, for Now
description: IN Bridgeport, Bill Finch is the mayor, but in two nearby towns, he is also the state senator. While the law allows him to hold both positions, some local officials consider it a conflict of interest and want him to relinquish his legislative seat in Hartford.

title: Portrait in Grief
description: In 2003, the German Remembrance Foundation awarded the historian Gtz Aly the Marion Samuel Prize, which commemorates the one million Jewish children murdered by the Nazis. It was named for a young victim whose name was chosen at random from the lists of the dead, a gesture meant to underscore the tragic anonymity of the Holocausts casualties. In accepting the tribute, Aly set out on a mission to uncover the life of Marion Samuel, to rescue her at least from obscurity.

title: More Interior Gee-Whiz Is on the Way
description: DETROIT

title: Kelli Edwards and Scott Halyard IV
description: Kelli Elisabeth Edwards and Scott Craig Halyard IV were married on Friday at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y. The Rev. James R. Strickland, a Baptist minister, and the bridegrooms maternal grandfather, officiated.

title: Some on Air France Can Use Cellphones
description: Air France is testing in-flight cellphone service aboard an Airbus A-318 that operates in Europe. In the first part of a six-month trial period for the Mobile OnAir system that began last month, passengers can send and receive text and picture messages, and send and receive e-mail messages on mobile devices. After three months, passengers will also be able to make and receive phone calls.

title: Margo Crespin, Joshua Rosenbaum
description: Margo Elizabeth Crespin and Joshua Neil Rosenbaum were married on Saturday evening at the Westwood Country Club in St. Louis. Rabbi Bernard Lipnick officiated.

title: Letters: Can You Count on These Machines?
description: Clive Thompsons article (Jan. 6) on voting technology and election administration was superb. It very much suggests that the Help America Vote Act of 2002 actually might have worked as intended if there had been more election administrators like Ion Sancho and Jane Platten to advise Congress when HAVA was devised. HAVA offered no assistance to inadequately financed election administrators as to what kind of machine to buy. The way out of this impasse may well be the development of professional programs in elections administration at university graduate schools of public policy  M.A. programs that would teach best-practice methods of the sort used by Sancho and Platten, as well as the history of voting technology and election administration, principles of good ballot design and the operation of open-source systems for code development.

title: Letters
description: Of Mortgages and Realities

title: Datebook
description: ABU DHABI

title: Candidates Head for Next Battlegrounds
description: With victories on Saturday for Senator John McCain in South Carolina and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Nevada, candidates for both parties regrouped Sunday to keep up the breakneck pace of campaigning this primary season as they looked toward Florida for the Republicans and South Carolina for the Democrats.

title: Republicans in South Carolina Focus on the Economy and Values
description: Voters in the South Carolina Republican primary on Saturday said they were more concerned about the nations economy than they were about illegal immigration, the war in Iraq or terrorism, according to a poll conducted as people left polling places across the state.

title: Anonymity Breach
description: Our university requires us students to write anonymous evaluations of our professors.

title: Shrinking Pains
description: Kansas City, Mo.

title: Hip-Hops Market: Slow Sales? Poor Product
description: To the Editor:

title: Hiding From the School District Residency Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: The Grapes of Wrath
description: The Food column on Jan. 6, about grappa, misspelled an Italian coffee drink often spiked with it. It is caff corretto, not correcto.

title: Spain Arrests 14 on Suspicion of Plotting Attack on Barcelona
description: MADRID  Spain was on high alert for terrorist attacks on Saturday after the police arrested 14 suspects of Pakistani and Indian origin who authorities contend were plotting an attack on Barcelona, officials said.

title: On Africas Roof, Still Crowned With Snow
description: A THICK veil of snow had settled on Kilimanjaro the morning after my group arrived in Tanzania. Over breakfast, we gazed at the peak filling the sky above the palm trees of our hotel courtyard in Moshi, the town closest to the mountain. It was as Hemingway described it: as wide as all the world, great, high, and unbelievably white in the sun.

title: To Predators, a Target; to Visitors, a Wonder
description: WYCKOFF

title: Caucusing With Flair, Las Vegas Goes to the Polls
description: LAS VEGAS  They came in black-sequined cocktail dresses and neatly pressed, salmon-colored maid uniforms. Men with rumpled hair, just off their bar shifts, wore their sunglasses inside. They stood on opposing sides of ballrooms up and down the Las Vegas Strip, screaming the names of their candidates, blowing ear-piercing whistles and shaking signs in one anothers faces.

title: Pastries of International Pedigree
description: The menu is multicultural at Koryodang, the three-year-old Korean bakery that now occupies the space once held by Mondrian French Bakery and Caf in Great Neck.

title: Plan to Replace Bridge Prompts Lawsuits
description: HIGHLANDS

title: Private Aid Sought for Public Schools
description: YONKERS

title: Timber Thieves Strike at Heart of Lands Held Dear
description: ROYALTON, Vt.  The trees around George and Agnes Spauldings 170-year-old farmhouse here are as good as money in the bank, many being old-growth maples that are valuable not only for the quality of their wood but also for the sweet sap that the couple boils into syrup each spring.

title: Games Hardened by Winter Stay Deeply Etched in Memory
description: Forty years and three weeks ago, the Ice Bowl was chiseled into the consciousness of football nation. On Dec. 31, 1967, with the temperature at minus 13, the host Green Bay Packers beat the Dallas Cowboys at Lambeau Field. Frozen tundra became part of the sporting lexicon, and images of steam rising off the heads of players were burned into the collective memory.

title: Two Americas, Over Hard
description: Chillicothe, Ohio

title: Consent and Advise
description: Condoleezza Rice is a survivor. Of the foreign policy members of the original Bush cabinet, Colin Powell and Donald Rumsfeld are gone. Vice President Dick Cheney is on the defensive. Its Rice, shunted to the sidelines during President Bushs first term, who is now in the ascendant. The signs of her new influence as secretary of state are everywhere.

title: Romney Gains Easy Victory in Nevadas G.O.P. Contest
description: LAS VEGAS  Mitt Romney coasted to victory Saturday in the Nevada Republican caucuses, the first major Western contest of the presidential campaign.

title: No Frissons or Exotica, but Character and Flavor
description: JUDGING by the sheaf of ecstatic early reviews, I figured Id have trouble making a Saturday night reservation when I called Domaine Laurino last September. I didnt know the half of it.

title: Rescued by Newcomers
description: Not so long ago, good restaurants were scarcer in the garment district than in almost any other area of Manhattan. The situation has improved over the past year with these openings.

title: Starting a New Life in Brooklyn
description: ELEANOR ALPER embarked upon a hunt for a new home because her husband was dying.

title: Murder Case Tests Limits on Parents Right to Hit
description: During a break in the Nixzmary Brown murder trial in Brooklyn last week, Jeffrey T. Schwartz, the lawyer for Nixzmarys stepfather, described the predicament he said his client found himself in.

title: Seasonal Blahs? Places to Chill
description: THE holidays are long gone, vacation tans are fading, and February  leap year February at that  is staring us down. If the journey through the New York City year were a road trip, wed have just passed the Careful: Icy Conditions Ahead sign.

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: The Giants Country Boy in Short Sleeves
description: Perhaps an ability to overcome what were once prohibitive odds to make it in professional football, much less to a conference championship game at the Green Bay shrine known as Lambeau Field, has some symbolic connection to the postage-stamp Wisconsin town in which Rich Seubert grew up.

title: Hiltons New Presence in Old Prague
description: The 300-room Hilton Prague Old Town, formerly the Prague Renaissance, opened in November in downtown after a complete refurbishment (420-221-822-100; www.prague-oldtown.hilton.com). The changes added a bar, 15 suites and meeting rooms, and enlarged the ballroom.

title: Skates, Sticks and a Little Support
description: GARDEN CITY

title: Providence, R.I.: risd/works
description: The fuchsia-dyed hair, Flashdance-era leg warmers and Japanese anime T-shirts give Rhode Island School of Design students away in Providence. But across the river from the campus, at risd/works, all that art-school experimentation has grown up and is market ready.

title: They Didnt Use a Shoehorn
description: NEW YORK land is pricey  now about $450 a square foot in prime Manhattan neighborhoods  and so are the steel, lumber and concrete needed to put up something new. In order to turn the kinds of profits that make such costly construction worth their while, developers are masterly at squeezing a lot of building into a little space.

title: Battlegrounds
description: Last year, the Op-Ed page asked five writers to file regular dispatches on the presidential race. Here are their latest reports.

title: French Favorites Meant to Win, Warm and Tempt
description: WHATS the difference between a brasserie and a bistro? Not much, when the places being compared are Brasserie Cassis, which opened in the Plainview Center in November, and its older sibling, Bistro Cassis in Huntington, which opened in 2001. (Bistro Citron in Roslyn, which opened two years later, is also under the same ownership.)

title: The N.F.L. Pulled Something Out of the Air This Season
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  When Amani Toomer caught Eli Mannings short pass, dodged a tackle and sprinted down the Dallas sideline for a 52-yard touchdown last week, the Giants were not only on the path to Sundays National Football Conference championship game. They also represented, in one play, the convergence of schemes, rules and personnel that made this the highest-flying season in N.F.L. history.

title: Breast-Feeding and Allergies
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Bekker, Barry Wintner
description: Karen Bekker and Barry Wintner are to be married on Sunday at the Village Club at Lake Success in Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Lauren Kurland is to officiate, with Rabbi Theodore Tsuruoka taking part.

title: Art in the Age of Franchising
description: Why is Friday Night Lights such a bust?

title: Letters: What Is It About Mormonism?
description: As a sixth-generation Mormon, whose great-great grandfather, John Taylor, was prophet and president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints following Brigham Young, Id say that Noah Feldmans article (Jan. 6) shows a sincere resolve to produce a comprehensive sketch of the faith. I can assure readers, however, that the church leadership wants nothing to do with politics. Most of us consider the term outlier status absurd. I hope that any revelations on the part of our general authorities are seen purely as guidance to sustain the faithful and not as pandering to ill-founded public discourse.

title: In Old-Fashioned Comfort, Head Turner Is a Souffl
description: THE high points of my recent visits to Tosca Caf were the souffls. A house specialty held over from the cafes predecessor, the esteemed and stubbornly French LEurope, souffls float through the dining room in a continuing spectacle, a parade of sugary blimps. Chocolate, raspberry, Grand Marnier, they rise above their ramekins, poufed with egg whites, enriched with yolks. Their golden domes wiggle-wobble, a sign that they are baked to perfection. The waiter slits the crust and spoons a silky sabayon into the crevice before stepping back with an unspoken ta-da! When her souffl arrived on a recent night, one diner let out a whoop that could be heard throughout the restaurant.

title: Rod, Reel and City
description: Rod, Reel and City

title: Opus Jazz: Forgetting a Co-Creator
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Record Falls
description: Chanelle Price of Pennsylvania set a girls national high school record for the 500-meter run of 1 minute 10.30 seconds Saturday in the New Balance Games at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Liliya Shobukhova of Russia won the womens elite mile in 4:31.90 and Alycia Williams took the womens 400 in 53.33 seconds, the fastest times in the world this season.

title: Abandoned Torah, Adopted, Is Revived
description: Hartsdale

title: A Red to Savor With Lasagna
description: Jeff Hock, owner of Winesby.com, says many one-bottle buyers of 2005 Mirabile red return soon for 12-bottle cases.

title: At Some Superfund Sites, Toxic Legacies Linger
description: SAYREVILLE, N.J.

title: Jimmy Breslins Perpetual Deadline
description: JIMMY BRESLIN, in his bare feet and a bricklayers union sweatshirt, sat at home some months ago glumly taking phone calls on the death of Norman Mailer. There were a lot of calls, perhaps there were too many calls; his morning writing had been interrupted. The Times of London had called, as had NPR, The New York Observer and New York magazine, many of them wishing to be told about a distant night, some 40 years ago, at a jazz club in the Village, where Mailer, drunk and stoned on marijuana, had climbed on top of a senators wife. Mr. Breslin, who had been there too that night but wasnt drunk  at least not yet  hung his head and sighed a bit each time the night came up. Surely there were better things to talk about than Mailers ancient antics. He growled, quoted Auden, then sent the poor reporters on their way.

title: New Wave on the Black Sea
description: HAVE YOU SEEN THE ROMANIAN MOVIE? This somewhat improbable question began to circulate around the midpoint of the 2005 Cannes Film Festival. For some reason, the critics, journalists and film-industry hangers-on who gather in Cannes each May to gossip and graze rarely refer to the films they see there by their titles, preferring a shorthand of auteur, genre or country of origin (the Gus Van Sant; the Chinese documentary; that Russian thing). Its a code that everyone is assumed to know, and in this case there was not much room for confusion. How many Romanian movies could there be?

title: Henrys Friends
description: To the Editor:

title: Dramatic Duo Take Reins Again at Westport
description: JOANNE WOODWARD and Anne Keefe look like two former sorority sisters who have kept in touch. Both have white hair now, Ms. Woodwards short and chic with bangs, Ms. Keefes elegant and pulled back. Both dress like affluent country ladies, in pants outfits with good-looking jewelry. Both complain that theyve gained weight. Talking to each other, they laugh easily.

title: Ronald Reagan Is Still Dead
description: CONTEMPLATING the Clinton-Obama racial war, some Republicans were so excited youd have thought Ronald Reagan had risen from the dead to slap around a welfare deadbeat.

title: Up Front
description: Two years ago, Timothy Egan won a National Book Award for The Worst Hard Time, his book about the Dust Bowl. If I said it was better than sex, Id only be half lying, he wrote in an e-mail message. Its a writers fantasy, and it does wonders for bringing an audience to a relatively obscure topic like what it was like to live on dirt floors in the Oklahoma Panhandle 70 years ago. Also, I think you have to give some credit to the town where I grew up  Spokane, Wash. There must be something literary in the river that runs through it. It has produced two National Book Award winners in the last two years (Sherman Alexie, last year), and a third person, Jess Walter, was a finalist for fiction in 2006.

title: The Construction Site Called Saudi Arabia
description: RABIGH, Saudi Arabia  THE alarm bell sounded the end of the lunch break here one November afternoon, and suddenly thousands of workers  on foot, on bicycles and in buses  streamed in, seemingly from out of nowhere, and jolted this huge construction site to life.

title: Free Trade: The Math and the Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Mountains Into Molehills
description: Someday there will be a museum dedicated to all the dirty elements dragged out of the earth to keep us warm and spin our generators. See there, son, a grizzled Gen Xer will say over a barrel of oil, that ancient gunk nearly enslaved us to 12th-century theocrats in the Mideast. And check out those black nuggets  coal, a fossilized time bomb hauled out of the deepest holes in the earth and then belched back into the air as a planet-smothering byproduct. Nearly killed us, the whole lot of it.

title: All in the Family
description: Q: Lets talk about the Democratic presidential caucuses taking place on Feb. 19, in   Hawaii , where   Barack Obama was born. Will you be campaigning for your brother? Yes, of course. I have taken time off from my various teaching jobs in Honolulu and just got back from two months of campaigning. I have a bumper sticker on my car that says: 1-20-09. End of an Error.

title: Hezbollah Taunts Israel With Claims of Soldiers Remains
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollahs leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, on Saturday made his first public appearance here since the 2006 war with Israel, restating his claim that the militant group possessed the remains of several Israeli soldiers left on the battlefields of southern Lebanon.

title: Political Football
description: Shorewood, Wis.

title: Hope Welles, Luke Jernagan
description: Hope Virginia Welles, a seminary student, and the Rev. Louis Rhoda Jernagan III, an Episcopal priest, were married in New York on Friday evening in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd at the General Theological Seminary of the Episcopal Church. Bishop Philip M. Duncan II of the Episcopal Diocese of the Central Gulf Coast in Pensacola, Fla., performed the ceremony, with Bishop George Wayne Smith of the Episcopal Diocese of Missouri taking part.

title: Its Not Like Solomon, but Its Village Justice
description: ARDSLEY

title: Tony Soprano? No, Heres the Real Italy
description: IN New Jersey, to consider oneself Italian is to be in good company. More census respondents in the state  1.6 million, in the latest count  tick off Italian as their heritage than any other single group. But if the home-grown Italian-American Tony Soprano is more familiar to most New Jersey residents than the legendary and thoroughly Italian filmmaker Federico Fellini, not everyone is comfortable with that.

title: Bedbugs: To Tell or Not to Tell?
description: Q My wife and I had bedbugs in our New York City apartment last summer. Needless to say, it was a trying ordeal. Thankfully, though, we have not had any problems for the last six months. Now we are considering selling the apartment. Are we required to tell prospective buyers about the bedbugs?

title: Seeking Fresh Start After Fleeing Abusive Home
description: He would hit her. Then she would deny that it had happened.

title: Heroins Hold on the Young
description: An article last Sunday about heroin use among young people misstated the cost of the drug on the street. Federal officials say it can be as little as $7 for a tenth of a gram, not for 10 grams.

title: Burned but Bullish at Citigroup
description: IF any Wall Street seer should be bearish right now, its Tobias Levkovich, the chief United States equity strategist at Citigroup.

title: Dark Fissures of an Israeli Soldiers Soul
description: Tel Aviv

title: Bump. Grind. Repeat.
description: HIDDEN among the vacant lots and bleak brick warehouses of industrial Williamsburg, a go-go boy shimmied. Clad only in a black jock strap covered by a pair of tiny gray skivvies, knee pads and, yes, a sailor cap, the muscular exotic dancer jiggled his rear end to the Britney Spears song Gimme More, and grinned.

title: Federer Survives a Long Challenge From No. 49 Tipsarevic
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  A supreme crowd pleaser with his elegant, versatile game, Roger Federer gave the fans in Rod Laver Arena quantity as well as quality Saturday. He transformed what looked like a routine third-round match into the Australian Opens latest epic, and gave his would-be victims in the second week a brighter-than-usual glimmer of hope.

title: After Linking New Strain of Staph to Gay Men, University Scrambles to Clarify
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a matter of days, it jumped from a routine press release to a medical controversy.

title: White Irish Need Not Apply
description: Declan is Irish and Declan is black.
