Declan has come from Ireland to study in New York; sick to death of his Dublin professors droning on about Irish writing and its influence on the world he decides, in the penultimate story of Roddy Doyles first collection, to prove that the Harlem Renaissance kick-started Irelands best writing of the 20th century. And, if he couldnt do it, hed cheat; hed make it up. Yeats had died clutching his copy of The New Negro. Beckett never went to the jacks without The Souls of Black Folk under his arm.

title: Some Offstage Help for Apollo Theater
description: Richard D. Parsons, chairman of Time Warner and a Brooklyn native, has been a patron of the Apollo Theater in Harlem since his high school days. The first act he saw there was the Jackson Five.

title: Cassie Marlantes, William Rahm
description: Catherine Alexandra Marlantes, a daughter of Carol W. Marlantes of New York and the late Lorian L. Marlantes, was married Saturday evening to William David Rahm, the son of Susan B. Rahm and David A. Rahm, also of New York. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall performed the ceremony at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: The Dow Toll: Down 507 Points in 5 Days
description: The stock market fell every day last week, despite statements by Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, and by President Bush, aimed in part at reassuring investors.

title: A Helping Hand in Technical Training
description: WHILE working as a summer file clerk in a radiology clinic in 2004, Roberto Cordero took notice of the people producing the X-rays, M.R.I.s and other diagnostic images. He realized the work they were doing appealed to him as a possible career.

title: Computer Is Just Warming Up When Humans Call It a Draw
description: A basic rule calls a game a draw when 50 moves are played with neither a capture nor a pawn move. It is to ensure that a player with an advantage, but not one big enough to win against best play, could not drag a game out hoping for an opponents misstep.

title: The Real Price of Fakes
description: As the economy weakens, consumers hunt for bargains. Sometimes, however, a bargain can be a literal steal, and a dangerous one at that. The World Customs Organization estimates that 7 percent of goods traded in the world are counterfeit  a black market that increasingly includes pharmaceuticals, electronics and other products that must be safe enough to use.

title: A Word From Our Sponsor
description: This is a book whose content somewhat contradicts its title. Mighty Wurlitzer was the metaphor Frank Wisner, the first chief of political warfare for the Central Intelligence Agency, used to describe the C.I.A.s array of front organizations. They were, he said, capable of playing any propaganda tune he desired. But Wisner rather exaggerated what he was able to do, as one learns from this remarkably detailed and researched book by Hugh Wilford, a British scholar now at California State University, Long Beach. For these organizations were not exactly front organizations as the term was understood by the Communist Information Bureau, or Cominform, the model that the young C.I.A. was trying to match.

title: Freuds Family Tree
description: Deep into this lucid history of the rise of psychoanalysis, George Makari cites a tribute an acolyte sent Freud for his 60th birthday in 1916. Beware ... when the great God lets loose a thinker on this planet, he wrote. Then all things are at risk. It is as when a conflagration has broken out in a great city, and no man knows what is safe, or where it will end. Makari doesnt cite Freuds somewhat morose response: Only a funeral oration at the Central Cemetery is normally as beautiful and affectionate.

title: Hillary, Barack, Experience
description: With all the sniping from the Clinton camp about whether Barack Obama has enough experience to make a strong president, consider another presidential candidate who was far more of a novice. He had the gall to run for president even though he had served a single undistinguished term in the House of Representatives, before being hounded back to his district.

title: When One Co-op Owner Alters a Common Area
description: Q What is the recourse for a co-op owner in the following situation: There are only two apartments on each floor of the building. Contrary to the co-ops bylaws, the owner of one of them has replaced the carpeting and fixtures on the landing without the consent of the other owner.

title: Childs Play, From Clicks to Downloads
description: To all those traditional developmental stages in a childs life, like learning to walk, talk and read, we can now add technological milestones like using a mouse, downloading music and surfing the Internet.

title: Modern Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Canada to Rewrite Manual Linking U.S. and Torture
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian minister of foreign affairs, Maxime Bernier, said Saturday that he had ordered officials to rewrite an internal government manual that listed the United States among countries that potentially torture or abuse prisoners.

title: 3 Die in Fire at Brooklyn Apartment
description: Three men died Saturday morning after they were overcome by thick black smoke and flames from a fire in the Brooklyn apartment they shared, the Police and Fire Departments said. Two other men, including one who jumped from a window, were in critical condition.

title: War, Meet the 2008 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON

title: Outside the Box
description: MOST developers aim to sell out their condominiums from the bottom up, starting with the bread-and-butter apartments on the lower floors. Then, when everything is nearly sold out, they market the grand penthouses with those king-of-the-universe views.

title: When Retirement Collides With Reality
description: Q. Retirement is around the corner, and although you are fairly well prepared for it financially, you are starting to wonder what you will do with all that free time. How can you prepare for this new stage of life?

title: Railroad Plans Improvements
description: An article on Jan. 6 about improvements that Metro-North is planning this year misstated the date that a fare increase is scheduled to go into effect. It is March 1, not March 10.

title: No Playwright-Director Tension? Quite a Team
description: PRINCETON

title: For Mothers Who Started Off Older, a Circle of Peers
description: Mill Neck

title: Rebecca Koenig, Jason Berrebi
description: Rebecca Leigh Koenig, a daughter of Phyllis Rothberg Koenig and Neil Koenig of New York is to be married on Sunday evening to Jason Berrebi, the son of Ruth Berrebi and Elie Berrebi of Van Nuys, Calif. Rabbi Sarah H. Reines will officiate at the University Club in New York, with Rabbi Steven Greenberg taking part.

title: San Francisco:  Hotel Kabuki
description: THE BASICS

title: Pakistani Police Uncover Plot to Kill Shiites
description: KARACHI, Pakistan (Reuters)  The Pakistani police said Saturday that they had arrested five militants planning to attack Shiite Muslim processions with cyanide and suicide bombs. The police said the cyanide was going to be used to poison drinks given to people in the processions.

title: Surrounded by Gentiles
description: Think of all the people in the short stories youve read over the past 20 years: so many mildly depressed characters who were sort of like you, trudging morosely through lives that were sort of like yours, coping with existential problems you could sort of identify with. How many of those stories do you remember in detail? How many do you remember at all?

title: Bloomberg Creates a Task Force to Advocate for U.S. Infrastructure Needs
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg attacked Washington politicians on Saturday for what he called short-sighted, politically motivated spending while the nations roads, bridges and airports fall apart.

title: Lisa Cericola, Daniel Browne
description: Lisa Cericola, the daughter of Donna and David Cericola of West Palm Beach, Fla., was married there on Saturday evening to Daniel Browne, the son of Judy and Larry Browne, also of West Palm Beach. Martha Schulman, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism for this wedding, officiated at the Hotel Biba.

title: Extra Noir
description: Writing Crime and Punishment, Dostoyevsky struggled with a major problem: how to narrate from the point of view of a protagonist who is, to put it mildly, frequently impaired. His solution was to adopt the so-called close-third-person perspective, which allows the writer to delve into a characters thoughts, then contrast them with a more omniscient narrative voice. All that was required for Dostoyevsky to slip easily out of his heros mind was to call him Raskolnikov instead of the more myopic I.

title: Where Memories, Not Grocers, Abound
description: Atlantic City

title: For West Coast Boulevardiers
description: LOS ANGELES is a monument to the automobile, but secretly every Angeleno pines for a walkable neighborhood. A scruffy stretch known as Sunset Junction, bordering Silverlake, has become just that  an appealing mix of low-key restaurants and eclectic shops that draw artsy part-timers, including second-unit directors, studio musicians and writers. In other words, creative types with long mornings and limited incomes.

title: No Place to Hide
description: Skeptics about global warming often point to Antarctica to show that Al Gore and others who worry about climate change have exaggerated the dangers greatly. They may concede that the Arctic is melting and even that Greenland is beginning to appear a bit shaky. But look at Antarctica, they will say. Its actually growing colder, and the ice sheet is thickening.

title: Delicate Melodies, in Need of a New Home
description: IF you call Rita Ford Music Boxes on the phone these days, the chances are good that the voice on the other end will belong to Chris Wright, 22, who was born a short time after his father, Gerald, went to work there as a salesman. The elder Mr. Wright, who was playing trumpet in a chamber music quintet, was drawn to the intricate mechanics and delicate melodies of the stores boxes, and he set about learning to repair and restore them as soon as he took the job.

title: Alison Abramson, Matthew Hasson
description: Dr. Alison Joy Abramson and Matthew Adam Hasson were married on Saturday evening at Cipriani 23rd Street, an events space in Manhattan. Rabbi Norton Shargel officiated with Cantor Bernard Dienstag participating.

title: Vote of Women Propels Clinton in Nevada Caucus
description: LAS VEGAS  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won the vote in the Nevada Democratic caucuses on Saturday, giving her a second consecutive victory in what is shaping up as a protracted battle with Senator Barack Obama.

title: White Sox Playing Catch-Up in A.L. Central
description: New York, New York, what a wonderful town! The Bronx is up and the Batterys down. Chicago, Chicago, that toddling town. The Cubs are up and the White Sox are down.

title: Play It Again
description: In the best tradition of the memoir, Perri Knizes Grand Obsession starts as a simple shopping expedition and ends in total existential collapse.

title: Doctors Across New York
description: To the Editor:

title: 1989: Potato, Shiitake and Brie Gratin
description: With Stichelton and Garrotxa now at our fingertips, its hard to remember why we were all once so smitten with Brie. In France you can find handsome specimens of Brie de Meaux, with downy rinds and buttery centers. But here, the cows-milk cheese tends to resemble silicone grouting. Which may explain why in the 1980s we were quick to wrap it in puff pastry and bake it. Everything goes down easier melted and warm, chased by a river of wine.

title: A Showdown for One Side
description: Republican voters went to the polls in South Carolina on Saturday, and John McCain won a crucial victory in an unusually fluid field.

title: Inside a Female-Circumcision Ceremony
description: Photographer Stephanie Sinclair visits a ceremony for young Muslim girls in Bandung, Indonesia.

title: Immersed in Art, Even at Home
description: Thea Westreich and Ethan Wagner don't just work in the art world, they live in it too.

title: Can the Giants Wild Ride Continue?
description: If todays N.F.C. championship game against Green Bay plays out like most of the other contests in the Giants nine-game road winning streak, then be prepared for another thriller.

title: Touchy Feely
description: The Bagger has been guided, manhandled, ushered and led the whole time he has been at Sundance. There is either something in the water spilling out of the Wasatch mountains or in the training of volunteers that leads them to feel the need to lay hands on whomever they are in proximity to. It is sort of creepy and endearing at the same time, but leaves the Bagger longing to get back to NYC, where grabbing a stranger is a social felony. But they are a relentlessly cheery lot, and according to Gregg Goldstein, their special tribal membership does have it privileges. Apparently, a few film executives tried to muscle their way into a volunteer-only screening of Adventures of Power, a comedy starring Ari Gold and Adrian Grenier on Friday night. Goldstein said they were left cooling their heels in Friday nights 1-degree temperature. No doubt, the natural order of things will be restored soon enough and the machers will get what they want when they want it.

title: U2 Can Wear Big Goofy Glasses
description: 50 Cent was not the only must-have ducat. There was a massive crush outside the Eccles Theater at Park High for U2 3D, a movie using the latest in 3D film technology to capture a concert in Buenos Aires. The guy next to the Bagger said that he had heard of offers of $1,000 for a $15 ticket. To a movie. The keening and posturing that went on as people tried to make their way inside brought to mind plenty of painful high school lessons about who the cool kids were. Robert Redford was there. Al Gore was there. U2? All four members were there. They entered to a huge, rock concert roar. There was a mad scramble for seats: Does any one have a single anywhere? The internationally recognized symbol of a saved seat at Sundance  a bulky parka left to warm the seat  lost salience as people fought to plop down somewhere and put on their specially issued 3D glasses.

title: Precious Quarters
description: In a village full of fish-out-of-water fables, the 50 Cent gig at Tao in Park City last night stood out. During Sundance, the toughest ticket draws the most massive crowds, and the hopefuls spilled out onto Main St., blocking traffic while trying to BlackBerry their way past the door. Those who did make it inside underwent further taxonomy: A hierarchy of wrist bands told them where they could and could not go. For the wired but unwashed who made it in to the main mosh, 50s imperative that they put their hands in the air was met with compliance, in part because there was no where else to put them. Servers had to be flanked front and back by burly security guys with winking flashlights to make their way. Smoke from tobacco and other products filled the place while toes were crushed and egos were in conflict. I would not have given that wrist band to you if I had known you were going to be such a jerk about it, shouted one guy to another. Six cameras panned live shots, feeding back to the crowd what they already knew. They were there, they saw the thing, they had juice. Whats up, Park City? 50 Cent shouted. Only you man, only you. (As it turns out, Fiddy might have some skin in the movie game after all.)

title: The Week Ahead: Jan. 20-26
description: Theater

title: The Old Gang Aint What It Used To Be
description: A vignette from a profile of Jimmy Breslin, still kicking at 77. The newsmans home phone is ringing off the hook for his comment on the passing of Norman Mailer:

title: Condoleezza Rice
description: Twice as Good

title: Coal River
description: Something looks very wrong with southern West Virginia.

title: Day
description: Alfred was growing a moustache.

title: Loewys Lincoln: The Fanciest Thing on Wheels
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The first Lincoln Continental, originally designed as Edsel Fords personal vehicle, has often been cited as one of the most beautiful cars in the world. Perhaps no other car can boast of a more prestigious design pedigree. It was originally sketched by Bob Gregorie, Fords chief stylist (reportedly, in an hour, in response to Mr. Fords urgent request for a vacation car).

title: Januarys Poli-Book Best Sellers
description: Its the beginning of a Leap Year, and the beginning, really, of the 2008 election cycle. Much of the best seller list for political books has had staying power into January, perhaps reflecting many of the last-minute shopping items from the final harried days of Christmas.

title: Basketball: Hubert Davis Goes Crazy
description: Awful Announcing is one of the most amusing Web sites out there when it comes to critiquing sports announcers. Their weekly Pammy Awards during the college football season are always good reading and they have a way of tracking down the most bizarre sports television moments (Mike Patrick and Britney Spears, anyone?) and highlighting them. Saturday was no exception.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, Jan. 20:

title: Mike Huckabee in South Carolina
description: Mike Huckabee comments on the results from the South Carolina primary. (NBC Video)

title: Writers Are Ready For Informal Talks
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: John McCain in South Carolina
description: John McCain comments on the results from the South Carolina primary. (NBC Video)

title: A Rare Thursday Win For Fox
description: Foxs Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader? delivered its highest ratings in 10 months on Thursday, lifting the network to a rare No. 1 finish on the night among adults 18 to 49. The quiz show with Jeff Foxworthy as host earned 11.5 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, leading the 8 p.m. time slot ahead of ABCs Ugly Betty (9.5 million) and repeats on CBS and NBC.

title: McCain is Over as the Underdog
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John McCain, who has made a career out of being the maverick underdog, is now teetering into an unfamiliar place: on top, with the establishment, the front-runner.

title: Giuliani in the Golf Cart Communities
description: SUN CITY CENTER, Fla.  Rudolph W. Giuliani is back in his comfort zone, back in his home away from home (much like his audience, many of whom winter in Florida but live up north).

title: At Kings Church, Obama Speaks of Unity
description: ATLANTA  Speaking from the pulpit of Ebenezer Baptist Church, Senator Barack Obama paid tribute here today to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and reprised his call from four decades ago, Unity is the great need of the hour.

title: Reaganomics
description: Since we are, improbably but importantly, discussing Ronald Reagan again, I thought it might be worth posting a few graphs on the Reagan economic record.

title: Live From Green Bay: Lambeaus Warm and Quiet Corner
description: Across the northern prairie, dotting the horizon surrounding Lambeau Field, are smokestacks spouting huge clouds of steam into the otherwise crystal-clear skies. About 90 minutes from gametime, the temperature is 1, and a breeze puts the wind-chill factor down to minus-17. A two-block walk without a hat led to fears that simply touching your ears might cause them to shatter.The current temperature makes us think of this understated yet classic line in Planes, Trains and Automobiles, with John Candy and Steve Martin.

title: One Step Above Karaoke
description: Aired Friday night on CBS: Heres big news for TV viewers, American Idol is coming back. Fantastic show. Its a tremendous, honestly. In terms of entertainment, its just one step above karaoke.

title: In Harlem, a Pastor Endorses Clinton
description: On the eve of Martin Luther King Day, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton snagged an endorsement Sunday from Dr. Calvin O. Butts III, the influential pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem.

title: FINAL: Patriots 21, Chargers 12
description: Thanks for joining me for the A.F.C. championship game. I now hand the reins over to John Woods for the N.F.C. title game. Feel free to continue the conversation in comments, just be nice to each other and keep it clean.

title: Against Independent Voters
description: Were in that season now when we hear the same things being said over and over again, and nothing is said more often by political pundits than this election (it doesnt matter which one) will be decided by independent voters. Accompanying this announcement is the judgment  sometimes implicit, sometimes explicit  that this state of affairs is to be welcomed, even encouraged: its good that the independent voters are making themselves heard and forcing candidates to think outside their partisan boxes. And this judgment itself implies another: independent voters are better, in the sense of being more reflective and less ideological, than voters who identify themselves strongly with one or the other of the two major parties. The assumption is that if we were all independent voters, the political process would be in much better shape.

title: A Seat in the Pew Rather Than a Speech
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  On the last Sunday before the Democratic primary in South Carolina, there is no such thing as separation of church and politics.

title: Find Out What That Tubby Intern Wants
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Amazingly, there is still no front-runner in the Republican race. Still no clear front-runner. You know, the G.O.P. is starting to look like Britney Spears getting out of the limo. Its wide open, ladies and gentlemen. It is wide open now.

title: Bush. Clinton. Bush. Clinton?
description: Americans have lived with either a Bush or a Clinton in the White House since 1989. And that pattern will continue if Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York captures the Democratic nomination and goes on to win the presidency. How do voters feel about that?

title: Two Against One?
description: Bill Clinton said back in 1992 that voters would be getting two for the price of one if they voted for him because his wife, Hillary, was part of the deal.

title: Dont Just Hold the Phone
description: Three of Life Hackers top 10 telephone tricks:

title: The Carpetbagger: Day 3 at Sundance
description: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) confronts his fear of heights to bring you continuing coverage from the 2008 Sundance Film Festival.

title: Huckabee Event Serves Barbecue and a Swipe at McCain
description: NAVASOTA, Texas  Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas came off his Republican primary loss to Senator John McCain in South Carolina and headed here on Sunday, into the arms of supporters and his No. 1 fan, the actor Chuck Norris.

title: GAME OVER: Giants 23, Packers 20
description: Post your wisdom below, and check out the live blogging of the Giants-Packers game, as it happened earlier Sunday. -

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Jan. 21:

title: The Campaign Goes Big Time
description: O.K. The presidential race is beginning to move out of the retail politics mode. No more Q. and A. sessions in picturesque community centers. The Republicans are off to Florida, a very large place you just cant woo one town hall after another  although Rudy Giuliani is certainly giving it the old college try.

title: The Campaign Goes Big Time
description: Okay. The presidential race is beginning to move out of the retail politics mode. No more Q. and A. sessions in picturesque community centers. The Republicans are off to Florida, a very large place you just cant woo one town hall after another  although Rudy Giuliani is certainly giving it the old college try.

title: Lower Aid Increase Planned for Schools in New York City
description: ALBANY  New York City schools are likely to receive $100 million less in operating aid than the city expected in the budget that Gov. Eliot Spitzer will unveil on Tuesday.

title: Power Ballads for Suburbanites
description: Wholesomeness reigned when Rascal Flatts headlined Madison Square Garden on Friday night. The top band in 21st-century country music, with four multimillion-selling albums and a fifth that has sold a million copies since September, Rascal Flatts is fearlessly contented and relentlessly inoffensive.

title: Letter From Penn Berates Paper That Used Him as a Contributor
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A letter to the editor in The San Francisco Chronicle last Monday attacked the increasingly lame-brain paper and said parts of it resembled Mad Magazine. It was signed: SEAN PENN, Former SF Chronicle contributing reporter.

title: Gaza Power Plant Shuts Down Over Dispute
description: JERUSALEM  Israels closing of its border crossings with Gaza remained in effect Sunday, and Gazas only electricity plant shut down because of a shortage of imported fuel needed to run it.

title: Israel Is Set to Promote the Use of Electric Cars
description: JERUSALEM  Israel, tiny and bereft of oil, has decided to embrace the electric car.

title: New York City Braces as Fear on Economy Creeps In
description: By most official measures, the New York metropolitan area appears to be shrugging off the economic troubles that have beset much of the country. With fears of an imminent recession spreading from California to Michigan to Washington, the latest data still show New York recording job gains and rising tax revenue.

title: Tough but Smart on Drugs
description: A dozen troubled men and women from Hempstead, N.Y., got an unusual break this month. They had been caught on tape selling drugs, and as repeat offenders faced serious prison time. But after attending a community meeting, at which they endured the scoldings of neighbors and promised a prosecutor that they would stay out of trouble and take advantage of social services like drug treatment, they walked free.

title: The Women Who Protest Deaths of Man After Man
description: Ariel Dorfmans Widows, having its New York premiere at 59E59 Theaters, is the kind of play that makes you feel bad for being bored.

title: Turkmenistan Lifts Ban on Opera and Circuses
description: Happy days are here again for lovers of opera and circus in Turkmenistan. Reversing a ban imposed in 2001, President Gurbanguli Berdymukhamedov said that the Central Asian nation deserved to have the artistic performances, The Associated Press reported on Sunday. Our flourishing nation should not stand separate from the world, he said at a meeting, the state-run television reported. It absolutely should have a worthy operatic theater and a worthy state circus. The ban was imposed by President-for-Life Saparmurat Niyazov, who declared opera and ballet to be foreign to Turkmen culture and allowed financing for state-sponsored circuses to dry up. He died in 2006 after more than two decades in power. President Berdymukhamedov estimated that the first opera would be performed in six or seven months. It was unclear if his order covered the return of ballet.

title: Frontline Blogger Covers War in Iraq With a Soldiers Eyes
description: Michael Yon was not a journalist, and he wasnt sure what a blogger was. He had been in uniform but not in combat, and he wanted to keep it that way. He went to Iraq thinking he would stay for a month, and maybe find a way to write about the war after he got home.

title: Evolving and Mutating, Dubstep Splits Cells and Gives Life to Dance Floors
description: You could tell this wasnt a normal dance party because the music kept doing something strange: stopping. The record would spin backward, the dancers would cheer, the D.J. would pause, and then the song would start again, from the top. This crowd-teasing technique  the rewind  has long been a major element of reggae concerts and parties. And as a few hundred dancers were reminded on Friday night, it also lives on in the reggae-influenced electronic genre known as dubstep, which has sprouted around London over the last few years.

title: New York Measuring Teachers by Test Scores
description: New York City has embarked on an ambitious experiment, yet to be announced, in which some 2,500 teachers are being measured on how much their students improve on annual standardized tests.

title: Bomber Kills Sunni Allies of the U.S.
description: BAGHDAD  A teenager holding a box of candy strode into a gathering of Sunni Arab tribal members near Falluja and detonated an explosive belt, killing four people and wounding nine, members of the Issawi tribe said Sunday. It was the second major bomb attack to strike American allies in Anbar Province in two days.

title: Doctors Say Suharto Shows Signs of Recovery
description: SOLO, Indonesia  In what they called an amazing recovery, doctors in Jakarta said Sunday that former President Suharto was beginning to move his hands and speak and that they were preparing to begin physical therapy.

title: Betting on a Bright Future for Rear-Projection TVs
description: PLANO, Tex.  Back in the early years of this decade, when plasma high-definition televisions cost $10,000, consumers found that buying a rear-projection TV was a more affordable way to jump into the digital era.

title: What Was Added, and What Was Taken Away
description: There was a lot going on in  ... Not the Same Solo, an intriguing program presented by the Whitney Live program and Jonah Bokaers Chez Bushwick on Friday night at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Three dancers performed solos, which each had adapted from a piece by Deborah Hay called News. All were participating in Ms. Hays Solo Performance Commissioning Project, in which dance artists from around the world work with her on an assigned dance and then spend at least three months adapting it, adding elements like costumes, sound, text, sets and extra performers, with the option of subtracting choreography.

title: The Video Game May Be Free, but to Be a Winner Can Cost Money
description: Ever since John Riccitiello took over last year as chief executive of Electronic Arts, the video game industry bellwether, he has promised to revitalize the company with new games and new ways of reaching consumers. Now, that may be happening.

title: Indie Riffs Wrapped in Reverb
description: Saturday could have been billed as Reverb Night at Terminal 5. All three bands on the bill  Blonde Redhead, the Raveonettes and School of Seven Bells  enveloped their songs in the overtone haze of reverb, the better to conjure grand, mysterious, incantatory recesses in simple structures.

title: Born of Juno: A Hit Soundtrack With an Uneasy Singer at Its Heart
description: Her songs are all over a hit indie soundtrack, and new fans are mobbing her concerts. Most musicians would see this as good news. But for Kimya Dawson, the 35-year-old den mother of the tiny anti-folk scene, all the attention for her music in the film Juno is a little troubling.

title: Court Backs Borat
description: Sacha Baron Cohen, below, creator of the boorish Kazakh journalist Borat Sagdiyev, has emerged victorious from a lawsuit brought by Kathie Martin, an etiquette teacher who unwittingly appeared in the hit movie Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan. Overruling a lower court, the Alabama Supreme Court decided that Alabama could not be the forum for Ms. Martins lawsuit against Mr. Cohen and the companies that produced the film because she had signed an agreement stating that only courts in New York could hear disputes arising from her appearance, The Associated Press reported. South Carolina fraternity members, a Maryland driving instructor, Romanian villagers and a businessman seen fleeing from a hug from Mr. Cohen are among those who have filed suit over the movie, which has grossed more than $200 million.

title: Its Good, and Giants Head to Super Bowl
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Under a full moon, a black sky and a crisp and cruel blanket of cold, the Giants stood on the frozen sideline of Lambeau Field, waiting for a rush of warmth.

title: A Hair-Trigger Double Helps Determine a Contract
description: You are playing in a team-of-four match. Your table finishes much quicker than the one where your teammates are playing. You could get up and move around, or you could chat with your opponents. For a journalist talking is the much better plan, especially if you are playing against someone with a good eye for a deal.

title: Farewell Remarks by Los Angeles Editor
description: Following is the text of an e-mail message sent on Monday by James E. OShea after he was ousted as editor of The Los Angeles Times:

title: In Brooklyn, a Psychic for the Famous, or Rather, for Their Pets
description: Christine Agros career as a pet psychic to the stars started, as so many auspicious events do, with a particularly open chakra. The chakra in question did not belong to her, but to a young woman who happened to pop into one of Ms. Agros yoga classes in upstate New York five years ago, and thanked her at the end of class for freeing up that center of spiritual energy.

title: Cant Tell a Book by Its Cover, or Even Its Title, It Turns Out
description: When Missy Chase Lapine, author of the cookbook The Sneaky Chef that suggests ways to hide fruit and vegetables in dishes for finicky children, was angered by the publication of Deceptively Delicious, a similar book by Jessica Seinfeld (a k a Mrs. Jerry Seinfeld), she had recourse. This month, she sued for copyright infringement and defamation.

title: Los Angeles Editor Ousted After Resisting Job Cuts
description: The top editor of The Los Angeles Times has been forced out for resisting newsroom budget cuts, executives at the paper said Sunday, marking the fourth time in less than three years that the highest-ranking editor or the publisher has left for that reason.

title: Campaign Reporting in Under 140 Taps
description: NASHUA: Just saw Bill Oreily misbehaving at Obama rallly. Shoving Obama staffer.

title: Baryshnikov Arts Center Gets New Director
description: Stanford Makishi has been appointed executive director of the Baryshnikov Arts Center. Mr. Makishi, formerly the director of creative services at Carnegie Hall, succeeds Christina Sterner, who stepped down at the end of 2007 after 20 years. The arts organization built by Mikhail Baryshnikov and Ms. Sterner has brought contemporary works, notably through the White Oak Dance Project, to stages around the world. In 2005 they opened the Baryshnikov Arts Center on West 37th Street.

title: Britain to Aid Northern Rock Sale
description: LONDON  The British Treasury said Monday that it would facilitate a sale of the troubled mortgage lender Northern Rock by converting a pool of the companys assets to bonds for sale to investors.

title: Favres Pass to Driver Provides Early Spark
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Early in the second quarter, after three unsuccessful drives, the Packers offense had matched the temperatures at Lambeau Field. Both were well below freezing.

title: Los Angeles Times Editor Forced Out
description: The top editor of The Los Angeles Times has been forced out for resisting newsroom budget cuts, executives at the paper said Sunday, marking the fourth time in less than three years that the highest-ranking editor or the publisher has left for that reason.

title: None but Soulful Hearts for Schubert and Goethe
description: Schuberts attraction to Goethe approached obsession. He set None but the Lonely Heart six times and returned again and again to the poetry of Wilhelm Meisters Apprenticeship and Faust. Goethe took up much of Saturday nights Schubert recital at Carnegie Hall.

title: Pregnancy Problems Tied to Caffeine
description: Too much caffeine during pregnancy may increase the risk of miscarriage, a new study says, and the authors suggest that pregnant women may want to reduce their intake or cut it out entirely.

title: After Nevada Loss, Edwards Hangs On
description: ATLANTA  It looked like sweet relief for John Edwards that more than 1,700 miles separated him from the Nevada caucuses on Saturday.

title: Radical Love Gets a Holiday
description: IN 1983, Ronald Reagan signed a bill honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a federal holiday. Reagan opposed it, but back then, in the olden times of checks and balances, the vote by 338 representatives and 78 senators establishing the holiday threatened certain veto override.

title: To Drive or Not to Drive: That Was Never the Question
description: Every now and then I meet someone in Manhattan who has never driven a car. Some confess it sheepishly, and some announce it proudly. For some it is just a practical matter of fact, the equivalent of not keeping a horse on West 87th Street or Avenue A. Still, I used to wonder at such people, but more and more I wonder at myself.

title: Undaunted Director at Indian Museum
description: WASHINGTON  It was not exactly a welcome mat that greeted the new museum director. When Kevin Gover left his quiet life teaching American Indian law among the cactuses of Arizona to lead the Smithsonians National Museum of the American Indian here, he arrived during a storm of publicity about spending by his predecessor, W. Richard West Jr.

title: Favre Energizes Packers Offense With One Throw
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Early in the second quarter, after three unsuccessful drives, the Packers offense had matched the temperatures at Lambeau Field. Both were well below freezing.

title: Suharto, From Verge of Death, Is Making a Recovery
description: SOLO, Indonesia  In what they called an amazing recovery, doctors in Jakarta said Sunday that former President Suharto had begun to move his hands and speak and that they were preparing to begin physical therapy.

title: In Harlem, 2 Record Stores Go the Way of the Vinyl
description: On Saturday morning, Bobbys Happy House, a music store in Harlem that opened in 1946, was in a state of chaos.

title: Fischers Roots in City Tangle With His Legacy
description: Before he became notorious for his anti-American and anti-Semitic ravings, and before he became an icon for dominating, and then dismissing, the cloistered world of chess, Robert James Fischer was just Bobby, another young New Yorker on the make.

title: Ailing UConn Womens Team Faces Biggest Test in Tar Heels
description: HARTFORD  Before his teams victory over Cincinnati here Saturday, the University of Connecticut womens basketball coach, Geno Auriemma, entered to what he thought was a standing ovation. He seemed to deserve it. His Huskies were undefeated, ranked first in the country and winning with ease.

title: Thoroughly Unmodern McCain
description: In his victory speech after winning the South Carolina primary Saturday night, John McCain acknowledged the economic challenges we face, and then said: But nothing is inevitable in our country. We are the captains of our fate.

title: Taxi Drivers in London Take a Turn as Pitchmen
description: LONDON  Taxi drivers here have never been shy about sharing their views. George W. Bush? The royals? Cabbies are sure to have an opinion. But what if they start talking about Texas Hold em or a royal flush?

title: On Field and in Stands, Proper Attire Is a Must
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Checklist time. Dante Pasqualucci and his teenage daughter Mia would soon be headed to Lambeau Field for the Packers-Giants National Football Conference championship game, and as they sat in a downtown hotel lobby awaiting their cab, a snugly dressed Pasqualucci made sure he was not the only one prepared for single-digit temperatures and numbing wind chill.

title: Footnotes
description: Nearly 20 Off Broadway shows will offer two tickets for the price of one from Tuesday through Sunday in observance of Live Theater Week, proclaimed by the City Council to celebrate the contribution of live theater to culture in New York. Participants in the promotion, sponsored by the League of Off-Broadway Theaters and Producers, are listed at OffBroadway.org. ... Mariah Carey has set April 1 as the date for the release of her new album, That Chick, Billboard reported. Her last album, The Emancipation of Mimi, was the biggest-selling album of 2005. ... The Peruvian author Mario Vargas Llosa, 71, was rushed to a hospital in Lima on Friday with heart problems, Agence France-Presse reported. He was released on Saturday after undergoing tests and was out of danger, local news media reported. Mr. Vargas Llosas books include Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter, The War of the End of the World and The Feast of the Goat. ... The eighth annual New York Flamenco Festival, running through Feb. 24, will begin on Feb. 8 at Town Hall, with a performance by two of flamencos leading singers, Carmen Linares and Miguel Poveda. The festivals all-star gala, dedicated to the women of flamenco, will be presented on Feb. 15 at New York City Center, where the featured performers will be Merche Esmeralda, Rocio Molina and Beln Maya, with a special appearance by the singer Diana Navarro.

title: The Truth About Ethics Reform
description: Weve long grown used to candidates cherry-picking each others records to score points in a campaign. But the new Congressional ethics law, and the role Senator Barack Obama played in passing it, have been belittled in troubling ways that are worth noting.

title: Republican Field Rides Full Force Into Florida Test
description: POLK CITY, Fla.  The Republican presidential contest entered a new phase on Sunday as the campaigns descended on Florida for the first primary in which all the candidates are participating full force, using as their stage a state famous for divisive election battles.

title: Clean Energy as Stimulus
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Newsman Laments a Dying Craft
description: Somethings burning, said one reporter to another, absently staring out the window at angry, thick black smoke rising over the city of Baltimore.

title: 16 and Pregnant: No Fairy Tale Ending
description: To the Editor:

title: Volcanoes Tied to Thinning of Antarcticas Glaciers
description: Here is another factor that might be contributing to the thinning of some of the Antarcticas glaciers: volcanoes.

title: Where 3 Died in Fire, a Changing Neighborhood
description: The men huddle on street corners in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, like apparitions: No one seems to know their names or anything about them. They speak Spanish in a neighborhood where Italian is still common, even if its presence has waned over the years. They will paint homes, fix roofs, tend to yards or lay bricks if someone is willing to hire them for the day.

title: Place-Kicker Takes Charge and Makes Up for 2 Misses
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Lawrence Tynes did not wait for Giants Coach Tom Coughlin to call for the field-goal team in overtime. He knew roughly where the ball was, inside the 50. He had already missed two critical fourth-quarter attempts, one with four seconds left that would have sent the Giants to the Super Bowl. He wanted another try as badly as anything he ever wanted in his life.

title: Darkness in the Land of Steady Sunshine
description: Stephen Kings Duma Key ventures to an all-but-uninhabited Florida island where the shells groan at high tide, tennis balls appear unexpectedly, foliage grows ominously quickly, and at least one heron flies upside-down. Given this combination of author and setting, its inevitable that something terribly undead will show up before the book is over.

title: Worried About Rivers, Chargers Lose Tomlinson Instead
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  In the days leading up to Sundays American Football Conference title game, the balms and potions that accumulated like junk mail at the San Diego Chargers practice facility were intended mainly for quarterback Philip Rivers, who hardly practiced all week because of a sprained right knee.

title: The Weeks Economic Reports
description: A QUIET WEEK It is a slow week for economic data. The highlight will be the governments report on existing-home sales for December (Thursday).

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about Bill Clintons scolding of a television reporter on Wednesday misstated the location of the reporters station, KGO-TV. It is based in San Francisco, not Oakland.

title: A Finnish Turf Battle Pits Wolf Against Reindeer Herder
description: SUOMUSSALMI, Finland  Close to the tiny Finnish village of Saaravaara, bloody tracks lead through the snow to the frozen carcass of an 8-month-old male reindeer lying on its side, its neck torn, its underbelly ripped open.

title: Gun Wound Leads to Weapons Trove
description: A 37-year old man who was storing weapons, including pipe bombs, crossbows, guns and silencers, in his Brooklyn Heights apartment was also responsible for writing a rash of hateful messages aimed at Jews in his neighborhood last year, the police said.

title: Fuel Shortage Shuts Gaza Power Plant, Leaving City Dark
description: JERUSALEM  Israels closing of its border crossings with Gaza remained in effect Sunday, and Gazas only electricity plant shut down because of a shortage of imported fuel needed to run it.

title: Obama, Reagan and the Internet
description: While the mainstream media has been obsessed with the presidential horse race (guilty!), the Internet has been obsessed with recent comments by Senator Barack Obama about Ronald Reagan and the Republicans.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Public Lives column in some editions on Friday, about Sandra E. Timmons, president of A Better Chance, a national organization that prepares underprivileged students to attend elite preparatory schools, misidentified the preparatory school that President Bush attended. It is Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.  not Phillips Exeter Academy, which is in Exeter, N.H.

title: As Sight Dims, a Battle to Keep His Apartment, and His Place in the Sun
description: The floor is uneven and the stove does not work. Nor does the electricity in the kitchen. Until it was fixed eight months ago, there had been a gaping hole in the ceiling for three years. Julio Angarita, 59, is aware of the flaws in his apartment in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn, but he is still happy to call it home.

title: From MySpace to YourSpace
description: Two years ago, Chris DeWolfe, the co-founder and chief executive of MySpace, was talking about international expansion with Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation bought the social networking site in 2005. According to Mr. DeWolfe, an entrepreneur used to moving at Internet velocity, he suggested that MySpace could expand to four or five countries in the next year.

title: Lottery Numbers
Bruins Make the Most of Their Chances in Beating Rangers
description: By the time forward Brendan Shanahan stepped into the Rangers locker room after Sundays 3-1 loss to Boston at Madison Square Garden, the place was empty and silent. He spoke softly, otherwise his words would have echoed off the empty lockers, equipment hanging forlornly in the wake of another game the Rangers say they gave away.

title: G.O.P. Rivals Open Final Assault in Florida
description: MIAMI  Senator John McCain of Arizona arrived to Latin salsa music on Monday at the Versailles restaurant in Little Havana, downed a cortadito  a shot of espresso with steamed milk  and with the other Republican presidential candidates opened a final assault in Florida before the states presidential primary on Jan. 29.

title: Then, With a Touch of Now, and a Fully Charged Prodigal Son
description: The three ballets in New York City Ballets new Traditions program, which received its first performance on Friday night at the New York State Theater, were created over 50 years: from The Prodigal Son in 1929 through Square Dance (1957, revised in 1976) to The Four Seasons in 1979. But their music, all brightly conducted on Friday by Fayal Karoui, covers a far wider chronological distance.

title: Resurgent Knicks Confront Old Ghosts
description: Doc Rivers had a front-row seat when the Knicks hit rock bottom two months ago. He has recently seen them only on tape, but the contrast is striking.

title: With Brady in Trouble, the Supporting Cast Takes Over
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  All season, the New England Patriots mocked their opponents, the leagues record book and football convention with a blistering passing game.

title: U.S. Worries Deliver a New Jolt Overseas
description: FRANKFURT  The United States economy has demonstrated an enduring power to surprise since late summer. And not for the better.

title: Fires, Falling Buildings and No One to Clean Up
description: The first question you may ask about Life After People, a two-hour documentary being shown on Monday night on the History Channel, is what connection, if any, it has to Alan Weismans popular book The World Without Us, which reached No. 6 on the New York Times nonfiction best-seller list last year.

title: New CDs
description: PATTY LARKIN Watch the Sky  (Vanguard)

title: Celebrating the Circles That Signify Our Lives
description: Concert-stage performances of American Indian dance and music are rare in New York City. But The Drum Is the Thunder, the Flute Is the Wind, presented by the Kevin Locke Native Dance Ensemble at Symphony Space on Saturday night, was often disappointing.

title: A Mans Gunshot Wound Leads to a Weapons Trove
description: Police officers investigating a report of a gunshot wound discovered a cache of weapons that included pipe bombs, numerous types of guns and a crossbow in an apartment in a stately building in Brooklyn Heights on Sunday morning, the police said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about paradoxes that cosmologists face in trying to explain the origin of the universe misspelled the surname of a physicist at the University of California, Berkeley, who commented on the limitations of probability measures. He is Raphael Bousso, not Buosso.

title: Ousted Los Angeles Editor Assails Tribune Co.
description: The top editor of The Los Angeles Times, saying he had been forced out for resisting budget cuts, accused the Tribune Companys management on Monday of using voodoo economics in allocating newsroom resources and forcing him to choose between maintaining foreign bureaus and fully covering the Olympics and the presidential race.

title: For Moss, One Catch and Plenty of Scrutiny
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The New England Patriots march toward N.F.L. immortality continued Sunday, but once again they advanced despite a second consecutive unimpressive performance by the star receiver Randy Moss.

title: HBO Putting Shows Online, at No Additional Charge
description: HBO, cables most popular premium channel, is carefully entering the arena of Internet video.

title: Andy Palacio, Who Saved Garifuna Music, Dies at 47
description: Andy Palacio, a bandleader and songwriter who spearheaded a revival of the Garifuna music of Central America, died Saturday in his native Belize City, Belize. He was 47 and lived in San Ignacio, Belize.

title: A Missing Son, Confused & Unable to Call Home
description: KENNESAW, Ga.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about Bill Clintons scolding of a television reporter on Wednesday misstated the location of the reporters station, KGO-TV. It is based in San Francisco, not Oakland. (Go to Article)

title: Democratic Rivals Remember Dr. King
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The three rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination stood together on the steps of the state capitol here on Monday in a brief display of political unity as they remembered the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: For Clinton, Government as Economic Prod
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that if she became president, the federal government would take a more active role in the economy to address what she called the excesses of the market and of the Bush administration.

title: Ads Use Logos of Washington Post to Skewer It
description: WASHINGTON  Since the beginning of the month, the names of The Washington Posts signature sections have been used in a negative advertising blitz against the paper.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Thursday and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Pentagon Weighs Top Iraq General as NATO Chief
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is considering Gen. David H. Petraeus for the top NATO command later this year, a move that would give the general, the top American commander in Iraq, a high-level post during the next administration but that has raised concerns about the practice of rotating war commanders.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the death of a construction worker in a 42-story fall from the Trump SoHo condominium hotel in Manhattan misstated its location and the location of a gash on the building created by the collapse of wooden molds used to set concrete, the cause of the fatal accident. The building is on the southeast, not northwest, corner of Spring and Varick Streets; the gash is on the southwest  not northwest  corner of the building.

title: Scientists Find Active Volcano in Antarctica
description: Here is another factor that might be contributing to the thinning of some of the Antarcticas glaciers: volcanoes.

title: Superman Stunt Undoes Malaysian Rocker
description: A Malaysian rock singer who stripped off his shirt and bared his chest to reveal a bright red Superman logo has been barred from television concerts for three months by the countrys media authority. The singer, Faizal Tahir, apologized last week for his behavior during the performance on station 8TV. The station declared his stunt shocking and said his actions were unacceptable in the country, which has a Muslim majority. The commission found the artists act was intended without taking into account the sentiments and sensitivities of the viewers and public values, said Muhammad Tahir Muhammad Noor, director of corporate communications for the Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission. Officials said going topless, even for males, is a violation of local broadcasting standards. The commission also banned 8TV from broadcasting any delayed concerts for the period of the ban on Mr. Tahir.

title: Keeping His Mouth Shut, Rivers Lets His Play Do All of the Talking
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Sometimes, Philip Riverss passion looks misplaced, as it did last week when he exchanged barbs with Indianapolis Colts fans on his way to the locker room to have a brace put on his sprained right knee. On Sunday, the New England Patriots and a national television audience saw Riverss passion in all its radiance.

title: See Cookies? Go Watch a Movie
description: It is well known that people often crave certain things after they see them. For example, a nearby dessert cart can prompt a diner to start hungering for a slice of pie.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: On Eve of King Holiday, Race Dominates Campaign
description: ATLANTA  As he stood at the pulpit of Ebenezer Baptist Church here, addressing worshipers at the former congregation of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Senator Barack Obama was doing something Sunday that he has rarely done in his months of campaigning for the presidency.

title: Soap-Operas Are the Hidden Drama of Strike
description: As the writers strike approaches the three-month mark, it has conveyed new cachet, such as it is, on soap operas. Shows like General Hospital and As the World Turns have become virtually the only reliable option for viewers interested in watching rerun-free, serialized drama on broadcast television.

title: Echoes of Dr. King in Finance, Politics and the Daily Grind
description: The leader of one of Americas most venerable civil rights groups kicked off his annual celebration of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in what might have once seemed an unlikely fashion: by ringing the opening bell Friday morning at the Nasdaq stock exchange.

title: Britain Says Northern Rock Is Not Sold Yet
description: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain denied reports on Sunday that he had made a deal with Richard Branson over the sale of Northern Rock during a trip to China and India.

title: Investigation of Study Programs Widens
description: An investigation of college study abroad programs by the New York attorney generals office has expanded to include 15 colleges and universities, among them Harvard, Brown and Columbia, a senior lawyer in the office says.

title: Little Data on Stents Most Common Use
description: From 2003 through 2006, more than one million patients suffering from clogged arteries and veins in their torsos and legs received stents that had undergone scant testing for such uses, said Dr. William H. Maisel, a device safety specialist at Harvard Medical School.

title: Slovenia Chief Is Accused of Censorship
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia  As a young journalist in the late 1980s, Janez Jansa, now prime minister, played a critical role in spurring Slovenias pro-democracy movement after he was sentenced to 18 months in prison for opposing the Communist government and writing articles attacking the former Yugoslav Army.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the Arts, Briefly column on Thursday about a scheduled appearance by Paris Hilton at Harvard on Feb. 6 misstated the reason for her visit. She will be accepting the Hastiest Pudding of the Lampoon Award from Harvard Lampoon. She is not going for the Hasty Pudding Theatricals Woman of the Year Roast, which is on Feb. 7.

title: Poe Toaster Pays Homage
description: In the dead of night, someone came again to the Baltimore cemetery, as happens every Jan. 19. When the figure melted into the darkness, three red roses and a half-filled bottle of cognac were found at the grave site. Once more, tribute had been paid to Edgar Allan Poe, poet and master of horror; born Jan. 19, 1809, in Boston; died Oct. 7, 1849, in Baltimore and buried in the cemetery of Westminster Presbyterian Church. For years  exactly how many is a matter of dispute  a person who has come to be known as the Poe Toaster has made an annual pilgrimage to the site. This year, nearly 150 people gathered outside the cemetery, but Jeff Jerome, above, the curator of the Poe House and Museum, said the toaster was able to avoid being spotted, The Associated Press reported.

title: Suzanne Pleshette, Actress, Dies at 70
description: Suzanne Pleshette, the husky-voiced actress who redefined the television sitcom wife in the 1970s by playing the smart, sardonic Emily Hartley on The Bob Newhart Show, died on Saturday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 70.

title: Stocks Plunge  Worldwide on Fears of a U.S. Recession
description: FRANKFURT  Fears that the United States is in a recession reverberated around the world on Monday, sending stock markets from Bombay to Frankfurt into a tailspin and puncturing the hopes of many investors that Europe and Asia will be able to sidestep an American downturn.

title: Manning and the Giants Can Be Doubted No More
description: Green Bay, Wis.

title: Until All the Fish Are Gone
description: Scientists have been warning for years that overfishing is degrading the health of the oceans and destroying the fish species on which much of humanity depends for jobs and food. Even so, it would be hard to frame the problem more dramatically than two recent articles in The Times detailing the disastrous environmental, economic and human consequences of often illegal industrial fishing.

title: Debunking the Reagan Myth
description: Historical narratives matter. Thats why conservatives are still writing books denouncing F.D.R. and the New Deal; they understand that the way Americans perceive bygone eras, even eras from the seemingly distant past, affects politics today.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about penalties imposed by the New York City Campaign Finance Board on Councilman Miguel Martinez for violating campaign finance laws in the 2001 election gave incorrect figures for the boards earlier determination of violations and penalties. In June, the board listed 17 violations totaling $100,780 in fines, not 11 violations totaling $84,000. (In its final determination, the board fined Mr. Martinez $44,780 for 12 violations.)

title: With Win, Jones Evokes Past and Revives Future
description: Roy Jones Jr. has been in the boxing spotlight for nearly 20 years. But on Saturday night, he might have turned himself into one of the sports most intriguing figures.

title: A Site Follows the Money So Users Can Slice and Dice
description: The more people Shelby W. Bonnie can get arguing over politics, the better.

title: Shares Tumble in Asia and Europe
description: NEW DELHI  Asian and European markets nose-dived on Monday as hope that healthy local economies might escape the force of a United States recession evaporated and fear gripped investors instead.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart in some editions on Dec. 16 with an article about the struggles of New Yorks state university system misstated the relationship between the $1 billion spent on the Tuition Assistance Program and the $3.9 billion that New York spends on higher education each year. The tuition program is part of the total, not separate. This correction was delayed for research.

title: With Power and Putting, Trahan Defeats Leonard
description: PALM DESERT, Calif.  D. J. Trahan overpowered the Classic Club and stunned the overnight leader, Justin Leonard, shooting a final-round 65 that turned a four-stroke deficit into a three-stroke victory Sunday in the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: Getty Images Up for Sale, Could Fetch $1.5 Billion
description: Getty Images, the worlds biggest supplier of pictures and video to media and advertising companies, has put itself on the auction block and could fetch more than $1.5 billion, people briefed on the situation said Sunday.

title: Everests Conqueror, Remembered for His Heart as Well as His Courage
description: The lights were shut off, and suddenly the lanky man with rosy cheeks, the most beloved Western friend of the Sherpas, seemed to come back to life on Sunday.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $6,881,972

title: Low-Key Elections May Affect Castros Role
description: HAVANA  As Cubans went to the polls on Sunday, the ballot boxes, campaign posters and other trappings of democracy that are hauled out every election day were all in place. But there was something else that had not been present for many years  some degree of suspense.

title: At Least 7 Killed in Violence Across Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  At least seven people were killed in Kenya over the weekend in reverberations from last weeks nationwide protests, and police officials have begun investigating the officer seen on television shooting an unarmed demonstrator, police officials said Sunday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about AA Bronsons School for Young Shamans at John Connelly Presents, in Chelsea, omitted part of the surname of Mr. Bronsons current partner. He is Mark Jan Krayenhoff van de Leur, not de Leur.

title: Yes, Belichick Really Is a Genius
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

title: Web Cartoon Bolsters Visits to Newsday
description: The audience for newspapers may be getting older but if the success of Newsdays Web site is any indication, there may be a silver lining in the graying cloud.

title: In Previous Title Game, Giants No Match for Lombardis Packers
description: The Giants and the Packers, two of the N.F.L.s oldest franchises, have played each other 54 times since 1928, but Sundays National Football Conference championship game was only the second of the matchups in Green Bay, Wis., with a title at stake.

title: After Raids, 14 Held in Spain on Suspicion of a Terror Plot
description: MADRID  Intelligence agents on Sunday were sifting through evidence collected during a weekend crackdown on a group of suspected Islamic militants who the police say were plotting an attack on Barcelona.

title: A Venerable Magazine Energizes Its Web Site
description: A year ago, The Atlantics Web site was, to put it gently, weak  in content, staff, traffic and advertising.

title: City Evacuates 11-Story Building in Brooklyn, Citing Safety
description: An estimated 150 people had to relocate when city officials evacuated an 11-story factory building in Brooklyn on Sunday night, citing illegal loft conversions and fire safety violations involving a matzo bakery in the basement.

title: Against Giants, Breaks Dont Go Favres Way
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The ending felt all wrong. In this season, when almost everything went right for the Green Bay Packers and their quarterback, Brett Favre expected victory right up until the very moment that he lost.

title: Cautions in the Air as Sundance Opens
description: PARK CITY, Utah  So much for the sellers market. The Sundance Film Festivals opening weekend, often the setting for rapturous audience reactions and frenzied all-night bidding wars, drew to a close looking more and more like a disappointment, if not an outright dud.

title: Even in Singles, Williams Sisters Are Double Trouble
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  With her doubles partner, Serena Williams, watching from the stands, Venus Williams kept her family undefeated so far at the Australian Open, reaching the quarterfinals with a 6-4, 6-4 victory Monday against Marta Domachowska, a qualifier from Poland.

title: With a Contest in Chaos, Predictions Are Futile
description: People paying close attention to the 2008 presidential race have no idea what will happen next. The contest keeps defying precedents.

title: Monster Gross for Monster Movie
description: Cloverfield, starring Michael Stahl-David and Odette Yustman, both at left, and the monster that mashed Manhattan, obliterated the competition at movie box offices over the weekend, taking in an estimated $41 million to wrest the No. 1 spot from last weeks favorite, The Bucket List. In its debut, Cloverfield, distributed by Paramount, set a record for a January opening and had nearly double the gross of the No. 2 film, another newcomer, 27 Dresses (Fox). That romantic comedy, starring Katherine Heigl, took in $22.4 million, according to the tracking company Media by Numbers. After The Bucket List (Warner Brothers), which attracted $15.1 million in its fifth week, Juno (Fox Searchlight), the little film that became a big hit, accumulated $10.2 million more to bring its seven-week gross to $85.3 million. Fifth place went to National Treasure: Book of Secrets (Disney), which pulled in $8.1 million, bringing its total to $198 million in its fifth week.

title: Suzanne Pleshette, 70, Newhart Actress, Dies
description: Suzanne Pleshette, the husky-voiced actress who redefined the television sitcom wife in the 1970s, playing the smart, sardonic Emily Hartley on The Bob Newhart Show, died Saturday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 70.

title: Brady Is Far From Perfect, but the Patriots Still Are
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The dazzling offense was absent, struggling through misfires and mistakes that threatened to upend the New England Patriots relentless march through the N.F.L. The Patriots had endured suspensions, scandal and the mounting pressure of their own magnificence, but even in their closest calls during an undefeated season, they had never looked quite so lifeless with the ball, and Tom Brady had never seemed quite so befuddled.

title: Songs Bouncy to Melancholy, and Back
description: Many a mezzo-soprano initially draws public attention by donning a mans trousers on the operatic stage. For Kelley OConnor, portraying the Spanish poet and playwright Federico Garca Lorca in Osvaldo Golijovs bracing Ainadamar kick-started what promises to be a major career. Ms. OConnor, a striking young mezzo from California, has sung the role widely, including an engagement at Lincoln Center in 2006. Her smoky sound and riveting stage presence made an indelible impact.

title: In Europe, Apple Faces Hurdles to iTunes Movie Rentals
description: LONDON  After introducing an online film rental business for American consumers last week, the chief executive of Apple, Steven P. Jobs, said he expected that the service would be expanded into international markets later this year.

title: Signs in Kenya That Killings Were Planned
description: KERINGET, Kenya  At first the violence seemed as spontaneous as it was shocking, with machete-wielding mobs hacking people to death and burning women and children alive in a country that was celebrated as one of Africas most stable.

title: Paris: Losing Our Heads
description: On my way to Dior this afternoon to see John Galliano, my driver Bernard Alloux paused in the Place de la Concorde to point out a group of royalists gathered at the site where Louis XVI lost his head. Mr. Alloux said there were quite a few people in France who are royalists and then hastened to add, Pas moi. He gunned the Mercedes toward chez Dior.

title: Video: Continuing Sundance Coverage
description: In another video report from Sundance, the Bagger reaches new heights with Tom Arnold.

title: $2 Million Homes
description: Properties on the market in Washington, D.C., Colorado and Arizona.

title: Paris Mens Wear| Au Revoir from the Fall 2008 shows
description: Two looks from the Raf Simons show

title: Full Pages of the Excerpts and Transcriptions
description: Excerpts from Robert Frost's notebooks, and the corresponding transcriptions from Robert Faggen's book "The Notebooks of Robert Frost."

title: Compressed (MacBook) Air
description: The whole Steve Jobs rigamarole in 60 seconds

title: Fun at Sundance
description: A look at some of the celebrities and events at the 2008 Sundance Film Festival.

title: Youve Got Mail
description: From NewsBiscuit:

title: Short Fusion?
description: Tell us whats going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: A Forfeit Over Refusing to Shake Hands?
description: A game Sunday between Nigel Short of England and Ivan Cheparinov of Bulgaria in the B section of the Corus tournament in the Netherlands ended in a forfeit win for Short after Cheparinov refused to shake Shorts hand at the start of the game. According to a report on Chessbase.com, Short immediately complained to the tournaments referee who consulted the World Chess Federations rules and decided that Cheparinovs conduct merited that he forfeit the game. It was an unprecedented decision, which was appealed and later reversed, although Cheparinov was required to apologize and shake Shorts hand before playing the game on Monday, which Short won.

title: Why Career Change Would Be Bad Reality TV
description: Imagine if career change were the subject of a reality television show. Match up three candidates with a coach. Give them weekly assignments. Tune in every week. And voil. After a season, the contestants would transform before our eyes, and the winner would be the one whose metamorphosis was most complete. There is only one catch. Watching a career transformation could be downright dull. And it would never conclude in the length of a television season.

title: The Giants' Road to the Super Bowl
description: The Giants have won an N.F.L.-record 10 games in a row on the road during their journey to Super Bowl XLII.

title: Third Time for Tynes (the Transcript)
description: I looked for a transcript of Tom Coughlins news conference at Giants.com, and stumbled upon Lawrence Tyness instead. (An excerpt is below.) It describes how Tynes, despite his two earlier misses, influenced Coughlins decision to go for the field goal in overtime. Last year, Coughlin loosed hell and damnation (and Devin Hester) on the Giants season by electing to go for a long field goal in the Bears game.

title: The Early Word: Honoring Kings Birthday
description: The presidential primary race will be in full gear this week in two states, with the Democrats focused on South Carolina and the Republicans in Florida for a long week before that states contest next Tuesday.

title: With a Contest in Chaos, Predictions Are Futile
description: People paying close attention to the 2008 presidential race have no idea what will happen next. The contest keeps defying precedents.

title: Hearing and believing
description: So, Candidate A says things like this:

title: Elsewise
description: The Bagger has been a little too scattered blogging, reporting stories for the newspaper and making videos to keep up with firehouse of movies at Sundance. If you want to see what people are seeing  and what they are saying about it  you might want to log on to FilmThreat. And USA Todays Anthony Breznican has the advantage of youth on the Bagger, so his blog is always coming up with tangy bits, including getting a actual quotation from Robert DeNiro, a very difficult nut to crack, that one.

title: Blood in the Snow
description: The Bagger and quite a few others speculated that the writers market would create a buying frenzy at Sundance. Good logic, nice thesis, but one, as David M. Halbfinger points out, that lacks the prime virtue of being correct.

title: Comparing $100 million fines
description: It will no doubt continue to take a long time to digest the magnitude of the $100 million fine that the FIA asked McLaren Mercedes to pay in last summers Formula One spy scandal. But my wife, Nathalie, last night pointed out an interesting measuring stick: We were talking about the $285 million fine that Total SA, the oil company, along with three other defendants, were asked to pay by a Paris court for the ecological disaster that occurred after the sinking of the Erika tanker in 1999 spread oil along the French coast of Brittany.

title: Stimulus issues
description: The big problem with attempts to provide temporary economic stimulus is how to ensure that the money gets spent. As Milton Friedman pointed out 50 years ago, consumers tend to base their spending on permanent income  the income they expect to have over the long run  rather than their income in any given year. So an $800 check from the Treasury tends, other things equal, to be mostly saved rather than spent.

title: G-Man
description: Paul Giamatti is a low-key guy who just happens to be an adept at the craft of acting. He has played in big movies and small, and he is here at Sundance starring in Pretty Bird, a movie directed by actor Paul Schneider. Mr. Giamatti formed a production company with his wife, Elizabeth and his pal Dan Carey to get the film made.

title: Dropping the Puck
description: Yesterday afternoon, there was a celebrity hockey tournament that featured Luc Robitaille, some other NHL greats, and then some movie folks, including Taylor Kitsch, from Friday Night Lights, who was a demon on ice, and a fairly talented winger named Jason Reitman, better known as the director of Juno. Mr. Reitman said before the came that he was going to make sure the didnt get smushed by Marty McSorley, the legendary NHL enforcer.

title: Fans Journal: Goin Goin Ghana
description: I was greeted in Ghana by the dusty smell of the Harmattan Winds, the punch of tropical humidity and a functional airport decorated lavishly in red, yellow, and green banners with signs greeting soccer fans to their mecca of the moment.

title: Tears of Joy
description: The paradox of choice is manifest at Sundance. Just as the exits from Disneyland are filled with children crying because they missed certain rides, the feeling here is that, no matter where you are, you should be somewhere else.

title: The Democratic Debate in South Carolina
description: The following is a transcript of the Democratic debate in South Carolina as provided by CNN.

title: Barack Obama on Ronald Reagan
description: At an appearance in South Carolina, Barack Obama mocked those who have been questioning recent comments he made about Ronald Reagan.

title: Barack Obama on His Opponents
description: At an appearance in South Carolina, Barack Obama recounted two moments at a recent democratic debate.

title: U.S. Soldiers and Shoppers Hit the Wall
description: Wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have pushed the U.S. armed forces to the limit. Many soldiers have scarcely seen their families in recent years. But a much larger American army, the one that's spent this century shopping, is even more overextended and its pain is now coming home to roost.

title: Sunday Bloody Sundance
description: (AP/Reuters

title: Romneys Spanish Ad
description: Updated | 3:22 p.m.

title: Out and About: Il Nido
description: I could live  and dine out nightly  for more than 100 years, and I still dont think Id come to understand restaurants like Il Nido.

title: Employment and confidence wonkery
description: For wonkish types only: Ive been using the employment-population ratio rather than the unemployment rate as an indicator of labor market conditions; the unemployment rate has been fairly low, roughly late-90s levels, but employment-population has never regained its late-90s peak.

title: For the Moment |  Jeff Klein
description: This weeks guest blogger is Jeff Klein, the hotelier behind The City Club in New York and the Sunset Tower in Los Angeles. In his first post, Klein recalls his early fascination with the hospitality industry. To read all of Jeff Kleins prior blog posts, click here.

title: Making Sense of Arthritis Supplements
description: Arthritis sufferers are routinely targeted by the $20 billion supplement industry, which has introduced more than 800 purported remedies for arthritis in recent years.

title: Binx Bollings Voice
description: Rereading The Moviegoer was a revelation to me, as rereading usually is. Some book has left an imprint, often an indelible one, but it naturally gets fainter and fainter as time goes by, till its more an impression, a shadow on ones consciousness. One of my heroes once wrote that true culture is what remains in a man when hes forgotten everything hes learned. In that sense, The Moviegoer was part of my culture, but in such a generalized way as to be virtually indescribable. I found I really remembered very little of it. And so the reread book is, in fact, a new book, only better than new, because there are neural pathways somewhere that can somehow be reopened

title: Reborn, In Film and In Life
description: Kimberly Rivers, the amazing woman at the heart of Trouble the Waters, a documentary about Katrina that has been a huge hit, took a bit of time out from Sundance to head down to Salt Lake City and give birth gave birth to Skyy Kaylen Rivers Roberts, 7 lb, 1 oz. at 6:15 this morning. New snow on the mountain and new life in our midst. Its a lovely day in Park city.

title: Paris: Investments
