description: In the mood for tradition, a number of designers showed vests at the Paris mens shows. Paul Smith added them to his English checks-and-plaids mix. At Lanvin, they looked slightly more formal, while Ann Demeulemeester evoked country folk heroes with hers.

title: McCain Courts Cuban-Americans in Miami
description: MIAMI  John McCain arrived to Latin salsa music this morning at the Versailles restaurant in Little Havana, downed a cortadito  a shot of espresso with steamed milk  and opened his final push in Florida with an appeal to the powerful Cuban-American community before the states presidential primary next Tuesday.

title: Panic Hits
description: While the United States celebrates one of its non-birthday-birthdays  Martin Luther King Day, although the real birthday was last week  the rest of the world is concluding that the American recession is going to be very bad indeed.

title: Poll Suggests Giulianis Woes at Home
description: The strong advantage that former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani enjoyed in his home state appears to be slipping away, according to the latest WNBC/Marist Poll, while Senator Hillary Clinton is still leading among the Democrats of New York.

title: Global Stock Markets Plunge
description: Markets from Frankfurt to Mumbai went into a tailspin, puncturing the hopes of many investors that Europe and Asia will be able to sidestep an American downturn.

title: Giuliani Shrugs Off Polls
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Rudolph Giuliani paused next to the car bay at the Daytona International Speedway and briefly considered his political prospects, which seem to grow more complicated by the hour. Not only have recent polls showed him in a tight race with John McCain and Mitt Romney in Florida, but now a poll shows him trailing Mr. McCain in his home state of New York.

title: In Dr. Kings Church: Its Time, Its Time
description: ATLANTA  The annual ceremony to honor the late Martin Luther King Jr. here at the Ebenezer Baptist Church, Dr. Kings old congregation, is often a rich blend of prayer and politics. But politics nearly eclipsed prayer this year.

title: Clinton, Edwards and Obama Remember King
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The three rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination stood together on the steps of the state capitol on Monday in a brief display of political unity as they remembered the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Obamas National Ad
description: Barack Obama has begun showing a one-minute national ad on CNN and MSNBC.

title: Reader Responses to Hillary, Barack, Experience.
description: Ive pulled out a number of comments from the hundreds that have been submitted in response to Nicks column on Sunday.

title: The View from the Mountaintop
description: The trip to the mountains of Park City offers writers and directors to gain perspective on a lot of things, including the tentative deal struck by the DGA.

title: The Top Ten Presidents
description: A number of readers chided me for my implicit rankings in Sundays column of which presidents were the greatest. Some argued that I shouldnt have included Woodrow Wilson as a great, while Steve Clemons at The Washington Note believes that I overrate FDR and dont adequately appreciate Nixon or the first President Bush.

title: Greetings from Davos, Switzerland
description: A team of us from The New York Times and The International Herald Tribune will be here at the annual conference of the World Economic Forum, a high-wattage powwow for bigshots of all stripes  think Tony Blair, Bill Gates and Bono  to rub elbows and talk big ideas.

title: How the Other Half Lives
description: When I first read The Moviegoer, I was as intrigued as anyone by Binxs search. But as a New Orleanian who grew up among the working poor of Treme, far from the Cutrer home, what struck me, and what remains after three reads, is the portrait it offers of a certain part of New Orleans that I wanted to understand. For me, reading about the world of the Garden District, the setting for much of the book, was like reading about an exotic country.

title: Professional Driver on a Closed Course: Do Not Attempt
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla  Teetering precariously in local polls, Rudolph W. Giuliani took a lap at a most severe angle on the Daytona International Speedway today.

title: Who Let Mitt Romney Out?
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Mitt Romney has more often been compared to a 1950s television dad than a hip pop-culture savant. This clip, care of Fox News Channels Shushannah Walshe, illustrates why.

title: Who Is Here (And Who Is Not)
description: For some, scoring an invitation to the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum is like getting asked to the prom. For others, it is just another invitation to blow off. (Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. just bailed out at the 11th hour.) This year, the guest list is a heady mix of egos, personalities and leaders. Some have been here before, while others are making their first pilgrimage.

title: Listen Close, Then Go the Other Way
description: The Bagger has been in Park City shoveling copy snow, so he is so far out of the Oscar ninny loop he cant even remember what all the fuss was about in the first place. But you cant win if you dont play, right? Your comments and amendations would be highly regarded.

title: Davos Loses Two of Its Stars to the Campaign Trail
description: With John McCain and Bill Clinton otherwise engaged this year, Davos will be without two of its most reliable draws. While both thrived in this talk shop, there was no mistaking the status gap between a former president and a potential future president.

title: Morning Papers: Weekend Round-up
description: Soap opera drama | Jacques Steinberg reports in Mondays Times: None of the eight daytime soap operas on network television have gone into reruns, and none have plans to do so. But in a genre that thrives on drawn-out cliffhangers, the most sensational mystery in daytime may be how these shows are being written at all, considering that nearly all of their writers are guild members on strike. More

title: Why The Strike May Hurt ABC The Most
description: As previously noted, Fox appears best positioned to weather the writers strike. ABC, on the other hand, may be hurt by it the most. Why? Because it has the biggest scripted hits  and because its audience, heavily female, is most susceptible to being stolen away by American Idol,' Bill Carter reported in Saturdays Times.

title: With Informal Talks Set To Begin, Guild Plans Mass Picket at Paramount
description: Debate roiled within the striking writers guilds over the weekend about whether or not to go with the kind of deal companies just made with the Directors Guild of America, and get back to work. Tuesday looks like a big day.

title: Obama, Reagan and the Web
description: Video

title: Meet Lucas Ossendrijver
description: Lucas Ossendrijver, the 37-year-old Dutch-born Lanvin mens wear designer, has an international resume to rival most diplomats. After graduating from the Fashion Institute Arnhem (ex alumni include Ossendrijvers compatriots Viktor & Rolf), he skipped from Kenzo, to the German-Greek Kostas Murkudis, and then to Dior Homme in the Hedi Slimane years, before being charged in 2006 with translating Alber Elbazs success at Lanvin to the mens market. He hasnt missed a step, as yesterdays Lanvins Fall 2008 show, one of the weeks hottest tickets, proved once again.

title: Bill Clintons Strategic Emotion
description: Remember September 2006? It was a little over a month before Election Day when Bill Clinton gave an interview to Fox News Channels Chris Wallace. The peg for the interview was a summit held by the Clinton Global Initiative, one of the former presidents many philanthropic activities. Wallace asked several questions about the initiative, but four minutes into the interview also brought up criticisms of the Clinton administrations counterterrorism policies that had been aired in Pulitzer-prize winning journalist Lawrence Wrights history of Al Qaeda, The Looming Tower. Whereupon Clinton went  ballistic. His face turned red. His voice rose. He tore into Wallace, accusing the veteran journalist, who over the decades has worked for several mainstream networks and whose credibility seldom has been questioned, of being a right-wing shill. He claimed the neocons who now say he did too little to capture or kill Osama bin Laden had in fact during the 1990s been highly critical of his administrations emphasis on counterterrorism, that they thought I was too obsessed with bin Laden and had no meetings on bin Laden for nine months after I left office.

title: A Return Engagement in a Different Role
description: Almost exactly one year ago, in this space, we observed that Tony Blair, then British prime minister, had celebrated a valedictory moment at Davos  his final appearance at the World Economic Forum as Britains prime minister after almost 10 years in office. In parentheses we added: but probably not his last time at the conference.

title: Live From South Carolina, the Democratic Debate
description: 10:59 p.m. | Wrapup With all this broken china on the floor, its hard to know where to start picking up the pieces. Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Obama showed themselves pretty adept at hurling plates, then reaching into the cabinet and pulling out cups and saucers too.

title: Doomsayers in Fashion This Year
description: The opening panel of the World Economic Forum traditionally gives a macroeconomic weather forecast for the coming 12 months. This year, expect black clouds to gather over Davos when the panel kicks off on Wednesday morning.

title: The Mouse That Roared in Bali
description: Andrew C. Revkin talks with Papua New Guinea's Kevin Conrad about taking a stand at the climate talks in Bali, Indonesia.

title: Bloggingheads: Is McCain on Top?
description:
Spencer Ackerman, left, of The Washington Independent and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate whether John McCain deserves the front-runner status the media has given him.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Cholesterol Study Leads to Confusion
description: This weekend, New York City cardiologist Dr. Nieca Goldberg and her nurse spent their Saturday fielding phone calls from patients. The issue was a recent study of the cholesterol drug Vytorin.

title: Equal Opportunity Insults, in Five Acts
description: This just in from David M. Halbfinger:

title: Zambia: Nationwide Blackouts
description: Zambia was plunged into darkness in what appeared to be the second nationwide power failure in three days. The country relies on hydroelectricity, and national blackouts are rare. The electricity network went down around 7:30 p.m. and was restored about four hours later. There was no immediate explanation. On Saturday, the country lost electricity for eight hours. Neighboring Zimbabwe was also hit by a nationwide blackout over the weekend, and worsening power cuts have caused economic losses and chaos across South Africa.

title: Feeling Misled on Home Price, Buyers Sue Agent
description: CARLSBAD, Calif.  Marty Ummel feels she paid too much for her house. So do millions of other people who bought at the peak of the housing boom.

title: Heath Ledger, Actor, Is Found Dead at 28
description: The actor Heath Ledger was found dead in a Manhattan apartment on Tuesday afternoon, the New York City police said.

title: Mexico Hits Drug Gangs With Full Fury of War
description: RO BRAVO, Mexico  These days, it is easy to form the impression that a war is going on in Mexico. Thousands of elite troops in battle gear stream toward border towns and snake through the streets in jeeps with .50-caliber machine guns mounted on top while fighter jets from the Mexican Navy fly reconnaissance missions overhead.

title: An Opera for a Crowd Unfamiliar With Opera
description: Before a performance at the Dicapo Opera Theater on Saturday afternoon, Michael Capasso, the companys general director, asked how many of the chattering audience members had seen an opera before. About a dozen waved in response. When he polled those who had not, perhaps three times as many hands went up. Among both groups, few appeared to have reached their 10th birthdays. Brightly dressed and mostly attentive, they sat with parents or grandparents.

title: A Pandemic That Wasnt but Might Be
description: Last year, for the first time since avian flu emerged as a global threat, the number of human cases was down from the year before. As the illness receded, the scary headlines  with their warnings of a pandemic that could kill 150 million people  all but vanished.

title: Send-Off for Comic Book
description: MySpace Comic Books, the comics corner of this online social network, and Meltdown Comics, a store in Los Angeles, have teamed up to commemorate the end of Y: The Last Man, the comic book series created by Brian K. Vaughan, above, and Pia Guerra. The event, Y: The Last Party, will be held on Friday, Feb. 8, and will benefit the Comic Book Legal Defense Fund. The organization, founded in 1986, is dedicated to the preservation of First Amendment rights for members of the comic book business. Of late the defense fund has been involved in the case of Gordon Lee, a comic book retailer in Rome, Ga., who has found himself in court over the distribution of obscene material to a minor. The material in question depicted Picasso in the nude. Mr. Vaughan, who is also a writer on ABCs Lost, is a firm believer in the defense fund. Its obviously a completely different situation from the writers strike, but, similarly, its creators taking care of their community, which I always support, he said in a telephone interview. The $100 V.I.P. tickets have sold out, but a limited number of $25 tickets will be available the day of the event. More information:www.myspace.com/cbldf.

title: Failure Isnt Always a Bad Thing
description: Successful entrepreneurs invariably say that they have learned as much from their failures as their successes.

title: For Giants, Redemption Is as Good as It Gets
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  A year ago, when the Giants retained Coach Tom Coughlin despite the seasons disappointing finish, John Mara, the team president and co-owner, heard about it from disgruntled fans. Outside the Giants Stadium offices, it was not a popular decision.

title: Fractured Family Warmed by Its Bright Teenage Star
description: Life of Ryan is a reality television milestone for one good reason: after years of commoners showboating, here comes a showboat who wants to be common. As the MTV seriess second season continues on Tuesday night, the camera crews are tracking the pro skateboarder Ryan Sheckler, someone with real talent rather than yet another manufactured, disposable celebrity.

title: As Alps Warm, a Snow-Deprived Ski Resort Sells for $1
description: ERNEN, Switzerland  Bruno Prior, a British entrepreneur, saw the ad from the Ernen ski-lift company one day as he was sipping coffee and looking through the newspaper in London.

title: University Investigates Whether Governors Daughter Earned Degree
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va.  It started with a phone call from a newspaper reporter in October seeking to verify the academic credentials of Gov. Joe Manchin IIIs daughter Heather Bresch. But in less than three months, the inquiry has mushroomed into a controversy that risks casting a shadow of cronyism over this states flagship university.

title: A Chinese Makeover for Mickey and Minnie
description: What would Walt Disney say? Mickey and Minnie Mouse, left, have gotten a makeover that put him in a bright red Mao suit and her in a cherry-blossom red dress  all in an effort to appeal to Chinese tourists at Hong Kong Disneyland, The Associated Press reported. Mickey and Minnie strutted along a red carpet on Monday to display their new outfits, designed by Vivienne Tam, while nine other models showed off red and black dresses featuring Mickey Mouse patterns. Ive liked Mickey Mouse since I was very little, said Ms. Tam, who was reared in Hong Kong and works in New York. Amid disappointing attendance at Hong Kong Disneyland, which opened in 2005, Ms. Tam was brought in to help attract more tourists from the mainland, which has become the parks biggest market. Bill Ernest, the parks managing director, said, Our mission is to be very connected with the local culture  with mainland China, Hong Kong.

title: Managers Foresee Fewer Airlines and Higher Fares
description: Three-quarters of corporate travel managers said in a recent survey that they expect airline mergers to result in higher fares and more than half expect the quality of service to suffer.

title: Study Says Implants Double Risk of Infection in Breast Reconstruction
description: Breast cancer patients who had reconstructive surgery using implants immediately after mastectomies were twice as likely to acquire infections as women who immediately had breast reconstruction using their own tissue, according to a study published yesterday.

title: Skin as a Battlefield
description: Q. I was recently told I had Stevens-Johnson syndrome. What is happening to cause these burnlike skin lesions?

title: Scrub Soap Opera, Flight Attendants Ask
description: Hot and bothered by a steamy new soap opera about airborne love and lust, Thai Airways flight attendants urged Thailands culture ministry on Monday to nip the show in the bud, The Associated Press reported. After broadcasts of three episodes of the series, The Air Hostess War, the Thai Airways International union protested the story about an affair between a married pilot and a tall, slim flight attendant, featuring sex at stopover cities and love triangles that lead to fighting in the aisles. Viewers were captivated, but Noppadol Thaungthong, a Thai Airways flight attendant leading the unions action, said: This soap opera is insulting and damaging to the reputation of flight attendants. Its all about sex and air hostesses beating each other up in the cabin because of love and jealousy. This kind of thing never happens. We are demanding that the station and the producers immediately stop airing this ugly soap opera. A culture ministry spokesman withheld comment until officials saw the letter of complaint, and the broadcaster, Channel 5, said it had no plans to pull the soap opera but would consider asking the producer to edit scenes found to be offensive.

title: Top Horse of 2007 Is Likely to Return
description: After being named the 2007 Horse of the Year on Monday, Curlin appears on track to take another run at the title. Jess Jackson, Curlins principal owner, said Monday afternoon that he would announce plans to race Curlin in 2008 when he spoke at the Horse of the Year and Eclipse Award ceremonies in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Upside of a Slow Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Allows Some Supplies Into Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, announced Monday night that he was lifting some of the restrictions imposed on Gaza and that on Tuesday morning he would allow delivery of a weeks supply of industrial diesel fuel for the local power station, as well as 50 trucks of food and medical supplies.

title: Iran Leader Backs Parliament in a Dispute With Ahmadinejad
description: TEHRAN  Irans supreme religious leader, in what appeared to be his first public dispute with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, sided with Parliament on Monday in a conflict over energy policy.

title: Rangel Remains in Clintons Camp in Her Battle With Obama
description: Last summer, a Brooklyn lawmaker ran into Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem and they began discussing the presidential race. Mr. Rangel, 77, bluntly told the younger politician that he should get on board with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Deaths of Rare Crocodile in India Stir Alarm
description: NEW DELHI  Three decades after it was brought back from the brink of extinction, the rare Indian crocodile known as the gharial is turning up dead by the dozens on the banks of a river called the Chambal. Forest officials are at a loss to explain why.

title: 4 Officers Arrested in Corruption Inquiry
description: Four New York City police officers are facing criminal charges as part of an ongoing criminal investigation into corruption among officers assigned to a unit of narcotics investigators in Brooklyn, officials said on Monday.

title: Footnote
description: Gary Glitter, the 1970s glam rocker jailed in Vietnam in 2006 for sexually molesting two young girls, has been treated at a prison hospital for intestinal problems and an irregular heartbeat, the BBC reported. Mr. Glitter, 63, whose real name is Paul Francis Gadd, is scheduled to complete his sentence in August.

title: The Psychology of Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Scramble Across Florida as Republicans Square Off
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The Republican presidential candidates began grappling with the complicated electoral landscape of Florida on Monday as they made appeals in Spanish and English and sped from Little Havana in Miami to the racetrack in Daytona Beach.

title: The Body of Her Work: Hearing Questions of Life and Death
description: NEW HAVEN  Anna Deavere Smith covers a big patch of territory in Let Me Down Easy, her populous new solo show at the Long Wharf Theater here. A checklist of topics covered would include the steroid scandal in sports, cancer therapies, African folk healing, the genocide in Rwanda, the tragedy of Katrina and the ailing American health-care system.

title: Ivy-League Letdown
description: LAST month, Harvard reached into its deep pockets  its endowment is $35 billion  and changed the way it calculates student financial aid. The aim, its press release says, is to make Harvard College more affordable for families across the income spectrum. Last week, Yale, whose $22.5 billion endowment is growing even faster than Harvards, followed suit. Yales president, Richard Levin, said he didnt want students to have to choose between Yale and Harvard based on cost.

title: Brazils Vale Confirms Talks to Merge With Xstrata
description: LONDON  Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the worlds largest producer of iron ore, said on Monday that it was in talks with a rival, Xstrata, about a merger.

title: Aviation Industry Offers Ideas to Help Passengers
description: WASHINGTON  Aviation executives are sharing a list of steps they can take to make passengers lives a little easier the next time a blizzard, a hurricane or another event strands planes on the ground.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the mens college basketball roundup in some editions on Friday misstated the home team in Long Island Universitys 85-65 victory over Wagner. It was Long Island.

title: The Battle Against H.I.V.: No Letup
description: To the Editor:

title: Spitzer Proposes New Taxes and Fees
description: ALBANYGov. Eliot Spitzer proposed an array of new taxes and fees, $1 billion in health care cuts and scaled back plans for new education aid and property tax relief in his second executive budget.

title: Reprising a Career
description: This 60-second advertisement for the Democratic presidential campaign of Senator Barack Obama of Illinois began running nationally on cable television on Monday. It is titled, Inspiring.

title: Fed Makes Emergency 0.75% Rate Cut
description: The Federal Reserve, responding to an international stock sell-off and the likelihood of a sharp drop in America on Tuesday morning, cut its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point.

title: Canseco Finds a Publisher for Sequel
description: Less than a week after Jose Canseco lost a publisher for Vindicated, his follow-up book to the controversial 2005 best-seller Juiced: Wild Times, Rampant Roids, Smash Hits and How Baseball Got Big, a new publisher, Simon Spotlight Entertainment, has picked up the book and will publish it in time for opening day.

title: Brazil: Gas Field Discovered
description: The Brazilian state oil company said it had discovered a natural gas reserve off the coast of Rio de Janeiro that could be as big as the recently discovered giant Tupi oil field. The company, Petrleo Brasileiro, said the potential reserves were about three miles below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean, 23 miles west of the Tupi field. The release did not provide figures as to the size of the reserve but said its structure could have dimensions that are similar to Tupis. Late last year, Petrobras announced the discovery of as much as eight billion barrels of light crude oil in the ultra-deep Tupi field.

title: Coachella Picks Headliners
description: Jack Johnson, My Morning Jacket, Kraftwerk and Portishead will be among the headline acts at the Coachella Valley Music & Arts Festival in California, when the events ninth edition takes place in California. Tickets for the festival, from April 25 to 27, will cost $269 as well as fees for all three days; a single days ticket will cost $90, according to the details released by Coachellas organizers, Goldenvoice and AEG. The organizers also said they were planning another three-day event, All Points West, at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, from Aug. 8 to 10. That lineup, not yet announced, is expected to include Radiohead and Mr. Johnson. Paul Tollett, promoter of Goldenvoice, said that unlike Coachella, which takes place on a polo field in the desert about two hours east of Los Angeles, the All Points West will have its own personality, incorporating the areas urban setting and local art scene. Several of this years Coachella headliners will be touring in connection with new releases. Portishead, for example, is expected to release its first album in about a decade internationally in April. Theyve been one of the most requested bands to play Coachella among fans, Mr. Tollett said. Talent is still king.

title: In Vioxx Settlement, Testing a Legal Ideal: A Lawyers Loyalty
description: If you listen to brainy law professors who have been studying big injury cases, you will learn that lawyers no longer owe their clients a duty of loyalty. They say this approvingly, even enthusiastically.

title: L Train From Rockaway Parkway to Eighth Avenue
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 17 at Ceremony Near Capital
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber killed 17 people in Salahuddin Province north of Baghdad on Monday in the latest suicide attack outside the capital.

title: Romney Waxes Lyrical at a Holiday Parade in Florida
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Mitt Romney, whose 1950s manner and celebratory drink of choice call to mind a milkshake man more than a rap singer, gave a shout out Monday that left no doubt that he had spent little time listening to hip-hop.

title: Craig Romney Promotes His Father, en Espaol
description: Mitt Romney on Monday began running the following television commercial, his first in Spanish, in Miami, where Spanish-speaking voters make up a large proportion of the electorate.

title: Patriots Trust in Defense in a String of Close Calls
description: Now for some sobering news to interrupt the Giants revelry: the New England Patriots are ahead of their normal preparation schedule for Super Bowl XLII because the Patriots and the Giants played three weeks ago in a mesmerizing regular-season finale.

title: Cancer Data? Sorry, Cant Have It
description: Not long ago, I asked a respected cancer researcher if he could send me raw data from a trial he had recently published. He refused. Sharing data would make the study team members uncomfortable, he said, as I might use this to cast doubt on their results.

title: Major Printer in Canada Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: OTTAWA  Quebecor World, the second-largest commercial printer in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada and the United States on Monday.

title: Serena Williams Isnt Able to Defend Her Title
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Serena Williams, a surprise winner at the Australian Open last year as an unseeded outsider, was a surprise loser Tuesday against Jelena Jankovic in the quarterfinals. Williamss fine, early form in this tournament dissolved in a sea of unforced errors, halting steps and oddly unconvincing serves.

title: In Matters Big and Small, Crossing Giuliani Had Price
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani likens himself to a boxer who never takes a punch without swinging back. As mayor, he made the vengeful roundhouse an instrument of government, clipping anyone who crossed him.

title: Packers Are Poised to Contend Next Year
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  When their season ended, the Packers shuffled from the field toward a shocked and almost silent locker room.

title: What Money Can Buy: Influence
description: Why isnt Warren Buffett making an investment in Citigroup when Kuwait is? asked Felix G. Rohatyn, the banker who helped save New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s.

title: Here Come the Brides, Really Simply
description: Editors Note: This newsletter is coming to you today because of the Dr. King holiday yesterday. Next week, look for In Advertising on its usual day, Monday.

title: The Subprime Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Issuing a Bold Challenge to the U.S. Over Climate
description: For 15 years, United Nations talks aimed at fixing a faltering 1992 climate treaty have provided little drama. But at the latest session last month on the Indonesian island of Bali, Kevin Conrad, a young man representing one of the worlds least influential nations, Papua New Guinea, gained a worldwide spotlight as he faced down the sole superpower, the United States.

title: Political Animals (Yes, Animals)
description: As the candidates have shown us in the succulent telenovela that is the 2008 presidential race, there are many ways to parry for political power. You can go tough and steely in an orange hunters jacket, or touchy-feely with a Kleenex packet. You can ally yourself with an alpha male like Chuck Norris, befriend an alpha female like Oprah Winfrey or split the difference and campaign with your mother. You can seek the measured endorsement of the town elders or the restless energy of the young, showily handle strange infants or furtively slam your opponents.

title: Musharraf Trip Shadowed by Troubles at Home
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Pervez Musharraf is touring European capitals and plans to attend the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday in a bid to show that he remains in charge of his troubled country, where his popular support has never been at such a low ebb.

title: Italys Government Tottering as Prime Minister Loses Support
description: ROME  Italys staggering government appeared near collapse on Monday after the former justice minister said he would no longer support Prime Minister Romano Prodi, who holds a one-vote majority in Parliaments upper house.

title: The Consequences of Surviving Throat Cancer at 37
description: Cancer of the throat took away Peter Broomfields natural voice. I sound like a robot, he said, pressing the tiny microphone-like instrument, called a Servox, against his neck above the trachea. A listener can slightly imagine how his Caribbean accent sounded before the cancer operation in 1990 that removed his larynx.

title: Cuba: No Surprises, No Losers
description: Officials said that more than 95 percent of registered voters turned out at the polls on Sunday to endorse a slate of parliamentary candidates, including Fidel Castro and his brother Ral. Of the 8.2 million voters, 3.7 percent submitted blank ballots and 1 percent voided their ballots in some way. Election officials called the results a success; critics called it a farce. As in past elections in the one-party state, nobody lost. There were 614 candidates and the same number of seats being chosen in the National Assembly.

title: Venice Opens a Water Bus for Residents, Minus Tourists
description: VENICE  City officials on Monday opened a new water-bus line here with one special feature: no day-trip tourists allowed.

title: Before He Made Kick, Tynes Made a Decision
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants punter Jeff Feagles, who is also the teams holder on field-goal and extra-point attempts, has been around a lot of kickers in his 20 N.F.L. seasons. He knows that in the uncompromising world of pro football, they are ultimately judged by their failures. And, how they respond to them.

title: In Crisis, or Just an Egoist? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
Shopping for Films but Settling for Some Fun
description: PARK CITY, Utah  A half foot of perfect, powdery snow fell here on Monday, carrying a message to the frantic crowd in temporary residence at the Sundance Film Festival: Slow down. Forget the branded parties on Main Street and the accompanying marketplace of film, and just enjoy the crunch of snow underfoot as you make your way to the next screening.

title: Rewards, With Risks, Go Into the Sale of the G.M. Building
description: Harry B. Macklowe is in a hurry to sell all or part of the General Motors Building to raise cash to pay billions of dollars in debts due in less than three weeks.

title: A Fatal Stabbing in Times Square
description: A 20-year-old Newark man was stabbed to death early Monday after a shoving match at a Times Square restaurant spilled out onto the sidewalk and turned into a brawl, the police said.

title: Britain to Aid Northern Rock Sale
description: LONDON  The British Treasury said on Monday that it would facilitate a sale of the troubled mortgage lender Northern Rock by converting a pool of the companys assets into bonds for sale to investors.

title: For Evacuated Buildings Tenants, an Uncertain Future
description: To artists, photographers and writers, it is known as the kibbutz  a pock-marked pasta factory converted into a commune of creative types.

title: In Pakistan, TV Network Loses Bite in Its Return
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  With the notable absence of two hard-hitting political talk shows, Pakistans most popular private television news channel was allowed to resume cable broadcasts within the country on Monday, ending a blackout that had lasted more than two months.

title: A Name Awaiting a Bridge
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is understood to be mulling ways to honor some famous people.

title: In a Sheep Population, Researchers Find a Fitness Gene
description: The Soay sheep of St. Kilda, a group of small Scottish islands, have been living free and unfettered for millennia. While these primitive sheep are still unmanaged, detailed records have been kept on them for the past 20 years. That makes St. Kilda a kind of natural evolutionary experiment, an island-scale Petri dish where sheep, not fruit flies, are the subjects.

title: Dungy to Stay for 2008 at Least, as Caldwell Waits for His Turn
description: Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy, who last year became the first black head coach to win a Super Bowl, will coach at least one more season before retiring, he announced Monday.

title: Anheuser-Busch Pushes the Big Beers for the Super Bowl
description: THE biggest advertiser on the Super Bowl  the most important day on the calendar for advertising as well as football  intends a back-to-basics approach, concentrating on its two top brands in humorous commercials that take a cheery, feel-good tack.

title: Online Reviews of Hotels and Restaurants Flourish
description: Many of the reader-generated reviews of hotels, restaurants, destinations and other travel services on the Web may have started their lives as independent blogs by travel buffs. But they have consolidated into major online businesses, taking an ever-growing piece of the market from print guides.

title: It Never Hurts to Quote the Classics
description: PARIS  Is traditional the new modern? Several innovative designers at the French fall mens shows made that case over the weekend, none more plausibly than Raf Simons, whose tailored suits and graphically patterned coats used textures and materials from handicrafts and at the same time looked 21st century.

title: Serbia: East-or-West Presidential Runoff Set
description: The runoff election between Serbias pro-Western president, Boris Tadic, and the ultranationalist challenger Tomislav Nikolic, who wants closer ties with Russia, will take place on Feb. 3, the state electoral commission said. First-round results of voting on Sunday gave Mr. Nikolic 39 percent and Mr. Tadic 35 percent. Other hard-line and liberal candidates shared the remainder, and the runoff next month, said Marko Blagojevic of the Center for Free Elections and Democracy, a vote monitoring group, will be the tightest election ever in Serbia.

title: China Wonders if Its Stock Boom Is Over
description: SHANGHAI  A dramatic sell-off that has sent share prices here plummeting more than 10 percent over the past two days is raising fears that Chinas spectacular stock market boom may be coming to an end.

title: Profit Off 95% at Bank of America
description: Bank of America said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit tumbled 95 percent because of huge write-downs of mortgage-related securities and higher provisions for future losses in credit card and home equity loans.

title: A Basic Hospital To-Do List Saves Lives
description: This is a call to arms for everyone who may someday be hospitalized, or who has a relative who may someday be hospitalized  which is to say everyone.

title: Charity Begins in Washington
description: The munificence of American corporate titans warms the heart, sort of. The Chronicle of Philanthropy reports that the top 50 donors gave $7.3 billion to charity last year  about $150 million per head. Excluding Warren Buffetts $43.5 billion burst of generosity in 2006, last years giving easily beat the record set the year before.

title: Europe, Cutting Biofuel Subsidies, Redirects Aid to Stress Greenest Options
description: Governments in Europe and elsewhere have begun rolling back generous, across-the-board subsidies for biofuels, acknowledging that the environmental benefits of these fuels have often been overstated.

title: The Prostate and Surgery (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Outcomes: Heeding Familiar Advice May Add Years to Your Life
description: The advice is as sound as it is familiar: avoid smoking, exercise, eat lots of fruits and vegetables, drink alcohol if you want (but not too much). Now researchers have figured out exactly how many years these habits will add to your life.

title: City Intends to Renovate Landmark Pier as a Hub
description: City officials have decided to try again to have a 122-year-old pier near Battery Park restored so that it can serve as a hub that links parks and attractions around the harbor to the rest of the city.

title: In Asia, Global Market Decline Accelerates
description: Amid fears that the United States may be in a recession, the decline in stock markets accelerated Tuesday across Asia.

title: Japans Bank, as Expected, Leaves Key Rate Unchanged
description: TOKYO (Bloomberg News)  As expected, the Bank of Japan on Tuesday left its interest rates unchanged at 0.5 percent in a unanimous vote, the bank said in a statement. The key rate was doubled last February.

title: World Markets Plunge on Fears of U.S. Slowdown
description: FRANKFURT  Fears that the United States may be in a recession reverberated around the world on Monday, sending stock markets from Mumbai to Frankfurt into a tailspin and puncturing the hopes of many investors that Europe and Asia would be able to sidestep an American downturn.

title: Obesity Surgery Found Effective in Treating Diabetes
description: Weight-loss surgery works much better than standard medical therapy as a treatment for type 2 diabetes in obese people, the first study to compare the two approaches has found.

title: In the Fatosphere, Big Is In, or at Least Accepted
description: For years, health experts have been warning that Americans are too fat, that we exercise too little and eat too much, that our health is in jeopardy.

title: For Ex-Trader, Sinking Feeling Is Reassuring
description: After four years of trading subprime mortgages, Jason Rew jettisoned his job at the investment bank Goldman Sachs and founded an off-shore business.

title: Thailand: Democracy Returns, and Politics Comes Full Circle
description: Parliament convened for the first time since last months election and since Thaksin Shinawatra was ousted as prime minister in a military coup in 2006. Lawmakers were to select a speaker of the House of Representatives on Tuesday and a prime minister on Friday, with the pro-Thaksin People Power Party, which will lead a coalition government, expected to nominate its deputy leader, Yongyuth Tiyapairat, a longtime Thaksin confidant, as speaker, and its leader, Samak Sundaravej, left, who calls himself a stand-in for Mr. Thaksin, as prime minister.

title: Lois Nettleton, 80, Dies; Acted on Stage and TV
description: Lois Nettleton, an actress whose dramatic and comic dexterity in theater, film and television earned her wide public recognition and deep professional respect for more than a half century, died on Friday in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 80.

title: The Voters Revolt
description: The Reagan administration had its pragmatists and its so-called ideologues. It had James Baker as well as Ed Meese. Reagan carried moderate states like Connecticut, Wisconsin and Washington, as well as conservative ones like Wyoming and South Carolina.

title: In S. Carolina, Its Obama vs. Clinton. Thats Bill Clinton.
description: Facing formidable support for Senator Barack Obama in South Carolina, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is deploying former President Bill Clinton there while she shifts her attention to campaigning in states with nominating contests next month and to raising money.

title: The Claim: Too Much Cola Can Cause Kidney Problems
description: THE FACTS

title: Memo Pad
description: FARE INCREASES ON AGAIN Major airlines have raised fares again, a week after a round of $50 round-trip fare increases collapsed when Continental Airlines rescinded its increases, causing all the others to back off as well. But on Thursday, American Airlines instituted a new increase of $40 round trip, citing fuel costs. Delta matched, and the others fell in line over the weekend, according to Tom Parsons, chief executive officer of Bestfares.com. Mr. Parsons said that business travelers booking flights at the last minute have been hard hit by incremental fare increases in recent years. "Since January 2005, business travelers who purchase tickets with little or no advance purchase have taken the brunt of increases in airfares, he said.

title: Earmarks Likely to Continue, but With Details
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush is unlikely to defy Congress on spending billions of dollars earmarked for pet projects, but he will probably insist that lawmakers provide more justification for such earmarks in the future, administration officials said Monday.

title: Red Bulls Coach Heads South to Find Players
description: His bags are packed, he is ready to go. Red Bulls Coach Juan Carlos Osorio is headed to South America this week on a scouting trip with scheduled stops in Colombia, Argentina and Brazil.

title: Oliver Stone's Presidential Ambition
description: Oliver Stone isnt a fan of the decision to invade Iraq, but in his next film he wants to render a fair, true portrait of President Bush, Variety reported. How did Bush go from an alcoholic bum to the most powerful figure in the world? Mr. Stone asked. Its like Frank Capra territory on one hand, but Ill also cover the demons in his private life, his bouts with his dad and his conversion to Christianity, which explains a lot of where he is coming from. It includes his belief that God personally chose him to be president of the United States, and his coming into his own, with the stunning, pre-emptive attack on Iraq. It will contain surprises for Bush supporters and his detractors. If financing materializes, Bush, starring Josh Brolin, above, as the president in a screenplay written by Stanley Weiser, who wrote Wall Street with Mr. Stone, will go before the cameras in April and could be in theaters by Election Day or by the inauguration of the next president. Im a dramatist who is interested in people, Mr. Stone said, and I have empathy for Bush as a human being, much as I did for Castro, Nixon, Jim Morrison, Jim Garrison and Alexander the Great.

title: The Blight That Is Still With Us
description: Columbia, S.C.

title: Stove for the Developing Worlds Health
description: When Kurt Hoffman visited Tanzania in the 1970s as a young product-development researcher, he could hardly bear to enter village huts to ask questions.

title: Remarks on Reagan Live On
description: In one of their starkest differences in Mondays debate, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that Senator Barack Obama had talked about admiring Ronald Reagan and that Mr. Obama said in the last week that he really liked the ideas of the Republicans over the last 10 to 15 years, and we can give you the exact quote.

title: Electric Cars Are Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Fears, Risks and Allergies (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Joe Burk, 93, Won Honors on Thames and in Pacific, Is Dead
description: Joe Burk, a single sculls champion of the 1930s who became a leading figure in American rowing and a highly decorated PT boat skipper in World War II, died Jan. 13 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 93.

title: California: Trade Mission to Cuba
description: California, the nations largest agricultural producer, is trying to increase its share of the hundreds of millions of dollars in food products that Cuba buys every year from the United States under a loophole in Washingtons trade embargo against the island. A. G. Kawamura, Californias secretary of food and agriculture, is leading a delegation of 18 business officials to Havana this week to promote products like nuts, citrus fruits and wine. California sold about $700,000 in products to Cuba in 2007, but the state predicted that the figure could be increased to $180 million. Pedro Alvarez Borrego, chairman of the Cuban government company that imports food products, said the biggest thing Cuba wanted from California was help in lifting what Havana calls an economic blockade.

title: Newlyweds Seething After a Photo Studio Fails to Deliver
description: Michael Ruiz de Somocurcio, a health insurance executive from Clifton, N.J., paid $5,500 to Celebration Studios, a regional photography service, before his wedding in September. The price included albums, personalized thank-you notes and a DVD starring his wife, Erika, and himself.

title: Teenagers, Scalpels and Real Cadavers
description: Around Oak Ridge, Tenn., Harry Hitchcock, a 61-year-old science teacher with owlish wire-rimmed glasses, a few wisps of white-blond hair and a gentle drawl, is known by his old military nickname, Whitey.

title: The Boomerang Effect
description: For more than a decade, Pakistans powerful and secretive intelligence service has fueled a treacherous dynamic in South Asia by supporting Islamic militants in Afghanistan and Kashmir. Now comes the distressing, but not surprising, news that the ISI, or Inter-Services Intelligence, has lost control of some of these Taliban and Al Qaeda-linked networks. The militants have turned on their former patrons and helped carry out a record number of suicide attacks inside Pakistan in 2007, including possibly the one that killed Benazir Bhutto.

title: Lew Spence, a Songwriter for Sinatra, Dies at 87
description: Lew Spence, a composer and lyricist whose songs were recorded by Frank Sinatra and many others, died on Jan. 9 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: A New Palm Species Is Discovered Through Its Swan Song
description: Even by the standards of species-rich Madagascar, the palm discovered along the northwestern coast of the island is unusual. Its a massive tree, close to 60 feet tall with fronds up to 15 feet in diameter.

title: Japan: Fujitsu Spins Off Unit
description: Fujitsu said that it would spin off its semiconductor division in a move that could make it easier for the new company to establish alliances with other chip makers and to share the significant development costs expected as the industry gears up for bigger silicon wafers. The company wants to spin off the semiconductor division by March, a company spokesman, Toshiyuki Fukuoka, said. The spinoff will begin as a 100 percent Fujitsu-owned subsidiary.

title: A Nazi Past Casts a Pall on Name of a Disease
description: Whats in a diseases name? Long-hidden shame, perhaps.

title: Investors Abroad No Longer Immune From U.S.
description: FRANKFURT  Since late summer, the United States economy has demonstrated an enduring power to surprise. And not for the better.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about last-minute Republican campaigning before the South Carolina primary referred imprecisely to the schedule for Feb. 5. There will be more than 20 nominating contests for Republicans, including primaries and caucuses  not more than 20 primaries.

title: Obama and Clinton Tangle at Debate
description: In the most intense and personal exchange of the presidential campaign, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama assailed each others integrity and voting records during a televised debate on Monday in South Carolina, the site of a critical primary in five days.

title: Stricter System to Trim Carbon Emissions Is Considered in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  European Union officials this week will propose an overhaul of the blocs sometimes dysfunctional carbon emissions trading system, aiming to reduce corporate influence and make polluting more expensive.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about last-minute Republican campaigning before the South Carolina primary referred imprecisely to the schedule for Feb. 5. There will be more than 20 nominating contests for Republicans, including primaries and caucuses  not more than 20 primaries. (Go to Article)

title: Sudans President Defends Accused Militia Leader
description: ISTANBUL  President Omar al-Bashir of Sudan on Monday defended a government appointment for an Arab sheik accused of leading a militia that helped the government suppress a rebel movement in the Darfur region, leading to 200,000 deaths.

title: Coughlin Tones It Down, but Still Puts on a Show
description: Through last season, networks could rely on Giants Coach Tom Coughlins unhappy, transparent body language and assortment of dyspeptic facial expressions to tell a running story of exasperation, anger, frustration and, often, extreme sorrow.

title: A Dream Is Achieved, a Legacy Is Established
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Editing of Frost Notebooks in Dispute
description: Robert Frost wrote some of this countrys most quoted  and in the minds of some, most misunderstood  poetic lines.

title: Hundreds of Layoffs Expected at Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo is planning to lay off hundreds of employees in an effort to increase its profitability, prop up its deflated stock price and narrow the focus of its sprawling Internet portal to a smaller number of crucial areas, people close to the company said Monday.

title: Regulators Look Closer at I.B.M. Deal
description: Antitrust regulators in the European Union have stepped up a review of International Business Machines proposed $4.9 billion bid for Cognos, a maker of business-analysis software. The European Commission said in a statement that the transactions combined market share was above certain thresholds for a simplified review. The commission did not change its Jan. 29 deadline to rule on the deal. The transaction no longer fulfills the criteria for simplified procedure, said Jonathan Todd, a commission spokesman.

title: Prime Roller, Prepare to Meet a Wiseacre
description: Sam Harriss 2004 book, The End of Faith: Religion, Terror and the Future of Reason, set off a noisy boomlet of antireligion books, including Richard Dawkinss provocative if preachy tome, The God Delusion (2006), and Christopher Hitchenss furious (and often very funny) jeremiad, God Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything (2007). These books provided a vehement response to the growing influence of evangelicals in American politics and the raging fires of fundamentalism around the world, and they even led to talk about the stirrings of a new atheist movement.

title: Brazil: Airline Buys 22 Airbus Jets
description: The Brazilian airline TAM said it had signed a contract to buy 46 Airbus jets, including 22 extra-wide-body A350s. The European-made A350 is a rival to the Boeing 787 Dreamliner. TAM said that the order is worth $6.9 billion at list prices, although most airlines obtain deep discounts. The addition of the A350s to TAMs fleet represents the first time that the plane will be used in South America, TAM said.

title: Congo Agrees to Peace Deal With Rebels
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Congos government reached an agreement on Monday with a renegade general to end an insurgency that has forced more than 400,000 people from their homes in the countrys volatile east in the past year and threatened to undermine the new democratically elected government, according to Congolese officials and Western diplomats involved in the negotiations.

title: Germany: More Cracks at Holocaust Memorial
description: More than half of the 2,711 pillars that make up the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in Berlin have cracked, the magazine Cicero reported. It said damage was found in 1,361 of the pillars, or stelae; last year the number was put at about 400. The study said the cracks might be a result of the expansion and contraction that come with temperature change. The Holocaust memorial, designed by the American architect Peter Eisenman, was officially opened in May 2005. Its gray concrete stelae are of varying heights and are arranged in a tight, waving grid that extends over more than five acres. Thousands of people visit the site daily, walking through the rows of pillars. City officials said repairs would begin in the spring.

title: Symptoms: Irritable Bowel Syndrome and Action by the Brain
description: Women who suffer from irritable bowel syndrome may respond to pain signals differently from other women, leaving them more vulnerable to the intestinal discomfort that characterizes the disease.

title: Tracking the Spread of Contaminants by Testing Blood Cells
description: Its a familiar scene following a major oil spill: struggling seabirds, doomed from the thick coat of oil on their plumage. They are a very visible indicator of how catastrophic a spill can be.

title: High in the Air, Artist Attracts a Crowd
description: I ALWAYS take a sketch pad with me when I fly. And I fly quite a bit, sometimes to meet with clients. Other times just for pleasure. There is something wonderful about being 35,000 feet in the air, looking down on the earth, that gives an artist a new perspective.

title: Unbeaten UConn Handles Injuries and No. 3 Tar Heels
description: STORRS, Conn.  With a little more than four minutes remaining Monday night against third-ranked North Carolina, Connecticut guard Renee Montgomery dribbled downcourt, as she had hundreds of times this season.

title: To Some, the Widening Crisis Seems Driven by Fear, Not Facts
description: The fear is spreading.

title: Celtics End Knicks Modest Winning Trend
description: Four giants of the New York sports landscape visited Madison Square Garden on Monday afternoon and bathed in roaring adulation from a packed house. Qualifying for the Super Bowl has that kind of effect on people.

title: In the Lab: Simple Math Errors Can Imperil Patients
description: Doctors make the same arithmetic mistakes the rest of us make, but the consequences can be considerably more serious.

title: Nostrums: Seawater Seems to Beat Medicine in Fighting Colds
description: There is no cure for the common cold, but researchers might have found a safe and simple way to reduce a childs symptoms and the chance of recurrence: wash out the nose with seawater.

title: Manning Enjoys Highlights
description: Eli Manning said he had trouble sleeping Sunday night, so he sat up in bed and watched various cable-sports television shows.

title: Lacking Flaws at 33-6, Celtics Nitpick and Roll
description: One of the perks of being the best team in the N.B.A. is that you get to invent your own adversity. And so it was on a cold Monday afternoon at Madison Square Garden that the Celtics never trailed, shrugged off the Knicks by 16 points and nevertheless left the building shaking their heads at all manner of seemingly phantom concerns.

title: Editor Fires Parting Shot at His Chain
description: The ousted editor of The Los Angeles Times on Monday offered a scathing critique of the newspaper industry and specifically his longtime employer, the Tribune Company, arguing that cost cuts, a lack of investment and an aversion to serious news was damaging the business.

title: The Rough-and-Tumble Online Universe Traversed by Young Cybernauts
description: A baby-faced eighth grader, viciously bullied online, hangs himself. With a click of her mouse, a young woman with anorexia uses cyberspace to find tips on starving. A high school student, with a world of plot outlines available on the Internet, admits that he cannot recall ever actually reading a book.

title: Icy Day Finds Old Union Outside Modern City Shops
description: The dramatic battles of the American labor movement were often fought in hazardous settings like the coal fields of Kentucky or the textile mills of Massachusetts.

title: Why the European Bank Is Sitting Back
description: LONDON  Monetary policy usually takes some time to bite. That is one explanation why the American stock market continued to gyrate on Tuesday after the Federal Reserves emergency rate cut. It may also explain why the European Central Bank has given no indication that it will follow suit.

title: What That Cholesterol Trial Didnt Show
description: The cholesterol drug Vytorin became known for its commercials showing people who look oddly similar to foods like tacos and banana cream pie. But now Vytorin is getting attention that is anything but funny.

title: Padilla Sentenced to 17 Years in Prison
description: MIAMI  Jose Padilla, the Brooklyn-born convert to Islam who was once accused by the government of plotting to detonate a dirty bomb in the United States, was sentenced on Tuesday to 17 years and four months in prison for his role in a conspiracy to help Islamic jihadist fighters abroad.

title: Strength Renewed, a Grand Old Building Is Back
description: SALT LAKE CITY  When engineers began poking and prodding at the Utah Capitol a few years ago, sounding the structure for how it might fare in the earthquake that seismologists say will surely strike here one day, they grew increasingly scared as they moved higher toward the dome.

title: Renewed Optimism for a Global Deal
description: Negotiators for the European Union and the United States said that they hoped a meeting of trade ministers in Davos, Switzerland, this week could help restart global trade talks and pave the way for a deal. Begun in 2001 to help increase trade and develop the economies of poorer countries, the talks have already missed a succession of deadlines. The European trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, sought to increase pressure for a breakthrough after a meeting on Monday with Susan C. Schwab, above, the United States trade representative. We are rapidly moving toward a moment of truth, Mr. Mandelson said.

title: Feisty Gods, Bored With Ambrosia, Still Get a Kick Out of the Cancan
description: Mocking the gods has provided irresistible comic material for artists from Jacques Offenbach to Monty Python, although blaspheming is also a surefire way to attract criticism. After the 1858 premiere of Offenbachs satirical Orpheus in the Underworld, one curmudgeonly critic wrote that the operetta, a sort of 19th-century Saturday Night Live satire of the myth of Orpheus (and Glucks Orfeo ed Euridice), was a profanation of holy and glorious antiquity.

title: Siemenss Prosperity Doesnt Obscure Bribery Scandal
description: FRANKFURT  Business is booming at Siemens under the new chief executive, Peter Lscher, who took over last summer in the wake of a corporate bribery scandal.

title: In the End, a Goodbye With Love and Dignity
description: Its not a joke, said the tall man in the F.D.N.Y. hat as he left the funeral home. I mean, its somebodys life, that just happened to pass away. Same things going to happen to all of us.

title: Fed Cuts Rate 0.75% and Stocks Swing
description: The Federal Reserve, responding to an international stock sell-off and fears about a possible United States recession, cut its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point on Tuesday, an aggressive move that came ahead of a regularly scheduled meeting of the central bank.

title: Mayor Bloomberg Tackles Poverty
description: Politicians have mostly skirted poverty as a political issue since President Lyndon Johnson declared war on it more than four decades ago. Even the federal governments method of measuring poverty is a relic from the 1960s  all but useless to cities and states seeking an accurate picture of the problem. Enter Michael Bloomberg, New Yorks solutions-minded mayor, who recently took on the challenge  and the measurement  of poverty.

title: An Illusory Existence (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Profit Doubled at Royal Philips
description: Royal Philips Electronics, the lighting and health care giant, said that fourth-quarter profit doubled to 1.39 billion euros ($2.03 billion) from 680 million for the same quarter a year ago, while sales rose 3.8 percent to 8.37 billion euros ($12.2 billion). Philips said its profit included gains from the 1.09 billion-euro ($1.60 billion) sale of stakes in several other companies, offset by 404 million euros ($591 million) in one-time charges. The medical equipment unit remained the most profitable, with earnings up 9.9 percent to 322 million euros ($471 million), despite a 2 percent fall in sales. The units operating profit rose 34 percent to 170 million euros ($249 million) on a sales rise of 14 percent.

title: Nascar Hopes Getting Back to Basics Brings Back Fans
description: CONCORD, N.C.  With the introduction of a new racecar, an expansion of the playoff format and the addition of ESPN as television partner in 2007, Nascar not only looked different, but it was viewed differently as well.

title: Proving Laughter Is Best Medicine for Air Sickness
description: MESA, Ariz.  When I last saw Rene Foss, a couple of years ago, she was in her underwear. She and about a dozen other flight attendants were wearing red lingerie, in fact, as they posed for a photograph around a shiny World War II trainer parked on an airport ramp.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $6,881,972

title: Illegal Boarding Houses Pit Citys Laws Against Lack of Alternatives
description: The four-story red-brick building blends in with the apartment houses on a hardscrabble stretch of hair salons and liquor stores in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. But it is here, miles from what was not long ago the most notorious skid row in America, where a new kind of Bowery makes its home.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: John M. Anderson, a longtime counsel to advertising and marketing communications agencies, joined Coblentz, Patch, Duffy & Bass, San Francisco from Heller Ehrman, San Francisco.

title: Weapons Trove Suspect Is Linked to Hate Crimes
description: It all happened in less than three hours on a cool September night  a prolific spurt of anti-Jewish vandalism at more than a dozen locations in the heart of Brooklyn Heights.

title: In Different Minor Keys, Three Formidable Pieces
description: You greet a cold, hard, wintry Sunday afternoon with either avoidance or embrace. Stay home and dream about the beach at Waikiki, or go hear the Emerson String Quartet play Brahms chamber music in three different minor keys.

title: Japan: Sanyo Sells Cellphone Unit
description: Sanyo, the electronics maker, will sell its troubled cellphone operations to a rival, Kyocera. The companies said the value of the business is about 40 billion yen ($374 million). Including debt, the deal  set for completion April 1  is worth about 50 billion yen ($467 million), although the companies have yet to agree on a final price. The long-anticipated sale of the unit comes months after Goldman Sachs and other investors saved Sanyo in a 300 billion yen ($2.8 billion) bailout.

title: Woods Calls Remarks Unfortunate
description: After a month out of the public eye, Tiger Woods addressed the controversy that has swirled in the news media about the inappropriate racial remarks made three weeks ago by a Golf Channel anchor.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 14 about The Associated Presss reporting on the entertainer Britney Spears misspelled the surname of a managing editor at the news agency who defended a decision to bolster coverage. He is Lou Ferrara, not Ferrera.

title: For the Record
description: In a Jan. 14 Editorial Notebook on gadgets: The VHS format was developed by Matsushita, not by Toshiba.

title: Burress Battles Back at Just the Right Time
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In his first five seasons in the N.F.L., Plaxico Burress made many friends on the Pittsburgh Steelers but never reached the Super Bowl. After he left as a free agent in 2005, the Steelers won the title.

title: Airwaves, Web Power at Auction
description: WASHINGTON  The auction for rights to a highly valuable swath of the nations airwaves will begin Thursday and is expected to include multibillion-dollar bids from the nations two biggest wireless phone companies, Verizon and AT&T, as well as Google.

title: Markets Wild Ride Ends With Dow at 15-Month Low
description: Tuesday began on Wall Street with ominous warnings that the stock market was set for its biggest plunge since the dark days after the terrorist attacks of 2001. It ended with the markets down scarcely 1 percent, as stocks somersaulted through a volatile day of trading.

title: Birds in Great Salt Lake Felled by Cholera by the Thousands
description: Some of the birds flew upside down or threw their heads back between their wings. Some fell out of the sky. Others tried to land a foot or more above the water, or swam in circles when they got there. And then they died.

title: Apocalypse, Described in Visions of Long Ago
description: Benjamin Bagby has put his bardic re-creation of the Beowulf epic behind him, but he is clearly still drawn to the dark and terrifying in projects for Sequentia, his early-music group.

title: Hopes for Vehicle Questioned After Iraq Blast
description: ARAB JABOUR, Iraq  From the blast and the high, thin plume of white smoke above the tree line, it looked and sounded like any other attack. The bare details were, sadly, routine enough: a gunner was killed and three crew members were wounded Saturday when their vehicle rolled over a homemade bomb buried beneath a road southeast of Baghdad.

title: Wal-Mart Says Most Workers Have Health Plan
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the nations largest private employer, said on Tuesday that for the first time in its 45-year history more than half of its workers had enrolled in the companys health insurance plan, a potent milestone for a retailer long associated with unaffordable benefits.

title: Whales in the Navys Way
description: According to a federal district judge in California, the Navys own research predicted that its sonar training exercises off the California coast will cause widespread harm  and possibly permanent injury or death  to nearly 30 species of marine mammals, including five species of endangered whales. That still didnt stop the Bush administration from rejecting the judges carefully crafted plan to protect these animals from avoidable harm.

title: New DVDs
description: 4 BY AGNS VARDA

title: If Everyones Finger-Pointing, Whos to Blame?
description: Everyone wants to know who is to blame for the losses paining Wall Street and homeowners.

title: Sutherland Out of Jail
description: Times up for Kiefer Sutherland. After 48 days Mr. Sutherland, the star of Fox televisions 24, walked out of jail in Glendale, Calif., at 12:05 a.m. Monday, The Associated Press reported. He was sentenced to 30 days after he pleaded no contest in October to driving with a blood alcohol level above the legal limit, and 18 days were added for violating probation in connection with a drunken driving arrest in 2004. He spent his jail time on laundry duty, cleaning sheets, pillowcases and blankets. John Balian, a police officer, said: He was very humble, never complained. He didnt give us any problems at all.

title: Blitzers Leniency Goes a Long Way
description: As a seemingly endless series of presidential candidate debates have proven this election cycle, the posture of the debate moderator can make the difference between a forgettable evening and a feisty one.

title: Endowing an Elite Prep School
description: The endowment of Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire last year surpassed $1 billion, making it richer than many universities.

title: Lighter Than Air Travel
description: Rene Foss, a flight attendant, has a one-woman show called Around the World in a Bad Mood, in which she ridicules the airline industry. Here is her explanation to the audience about why her fictional airline does not serve food:

title: Political Animals
description: From todays Science report:

title: Tom Cruise Parody
description: A sendup of the actors now-famous Scientology video (if you dont like constipation or flatulence jokes, dont watch):

title: Tom Brady Is Limping; Should the Spread Be Shrinking?
description: Should the Patriots be favored by 14 points if Tom Brady is hobbling around on a walking boot?

title: The Climate Challenge. Same as it Ever Was?
description: I have a story in Science Times looking at the latest round of climate-treaty talks, one month ago in Bali, from the vantage point of Kevin Conrad, the young man who represented Papua New Guinea and shook things up with a strong rebuke of the United States in the final tumultuous session. (An Associated Press video report is on YouTube.) It turns out things were not quite as they appeared.

title: Woodpecker Boom and Bust
description: Both the ivory-billed woodpecker and a thriving local economy are hard to find in the bayou of Arkansas.

title: ACA Capital Receives Extension to Unwind Subprime Exposure
description: ACA Capital Holdings, the troubled bond insurer, has received an additional month to unwind an estimated $69 billion of credit exposure stemming from the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: Maker of SuperPoke Takes $50 Million
description: A social network software maker, Slide, said on Friday it had closed a $50 million institutional financing round, marking the rising valuations of start-ups riding fast-growing Facebooks wave of popularity.

title: Indias Emaar Kicks Off $1.8 Billion I.P.O.
description: Emaar MGF Land, a real estate developer, started an initial public offering in India on Monday.

title: Israels Teva Takes CoGenesys for $400 Million
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries of Israel said on Tuesday that it plans to acquire CoGenesys, a privately held biopharmaceutical company, for $400 million in cash.

title: Europe Stabilizes
description: Davos, Switzerland

title: With Airline Mergers, Managers Foresee Higher Fares
description: Three-quarters of corporate travel managers said in a recent survey that they expect airline mergers to result in higher fares and more than half expect the quality of service to suffer.

title: Brazils Vale Confirms Talks to Merge With Xstrata
description: Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the worlds largest producer of iron ore, said on Monday that it was in talks with a rival, Xstrata, about a merger.

title: L.A. Times Editor Fires Parting Shot at Tribune
description: Its been only a month since Samuel Zell took control of Tribune and already hes facing the fallout from rebellion in the ranks.

title: Major Printer in Canada Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: Quebecor World, the second-largest commercial printer in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada and the United States on Monday.

title: If Everyones Finger-Pointing, Whos to Blame?
description: Everyone wants to know who is to blame for the losses paining Wall Street and homeowners.

title: Roche Wins Ventana With Sweetened $3.4 Billion Bid
description: Roche Holding has overcome Ventana Medical Systems resistance to its takeover bid by raising the price, acquiring the diagnostics maker for $3.4 billion to expand its cancer testing business.

title: Sears Reorganization: Prelude to a Break-up?
description: The billionaire hedge fund investor Edward Lampert is playing an old tune for Sears Holdings: break up to make up. Make up for the beating that Mr. Lamperts portfolio has taken on the retail giant he forged out of the merger of Sears and Kmart, that is.

title: Where They Didnt Pool Any Paunches
description: More of your late night humor (send via the comment link below):

title: Japans Kyocera Dials Up Deal for Sanyo Cellphone Unit
description: The Japanese electronics maker Kyocera said it would buy Sanyo Electrics money-losing cellphone business for as much as $468 million, creating the worlds sixth-largest cellphone maker.

title: G.E. Says Its Mulling Deal for Spains Colonial
description: General Electric confirmed Monday that it is studying a possible deal with Colonial, in a move that could spark a bidding war for the Spanish real estate firm.

title: Ambac Faces Shareholder Lawsuits
description: The Ambac Financial Group, the second-largest bond insurer, has been accused in two lawsuits of misleading investors and artificially raising its share price.

title: Dog Mascot Dance-Off
description: Will the Super Bowl halftime show be this good? Just asking.

title: Fund Run by Ex-SAC Trader Said to Suffer 12% Loss
description: Sailfish Capital Partners, a credit hedge fund run by a former SAC Capital Management bond trader, Mark Fishman, recorded a loss of more than 12 percent for the first 51 weeks of last year and is understood to be suffering significant client redemptions, Financial News reported.

title: Consolidation for German Banks Necessary, Minister Says
description: The German economy minister, Michael Glos, said on Tuesday the problems at the state lender WestLB showed that further consolidation in the German banking system was necessary.

title: British Advisers Reap $10.5 Billion from Buyout Deals
description: Whatever the subsequent fallout from the easy credit extended during the recent private equity boom, bankers nonetheless reaped handsome profits.

title: Is RiskMetrics I.P.O. a Bellwether for 2008?
description: A share sale this week for RiskMetrics Group, the owner of Institutional Shareholder Services, the proxy advisory service, could go a long way toward determining whether the new-issues market will have a smooth or bumpy ride in the early part of the year, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Britain to Use Bond Sale to Aid Northern Rock Sale
description: The British Treasury said on Monday that it would facilitate a sale of the troubled mortgage lender Northern Rock by converting a pool of the companys assets into bonds for sale to investors.

title: Getty Images Up for Sale, Could Fetch $1.5 Billion
description: Getty Images, the worlds biggest supplier of pictures and video to media and advertising companies, has put itself on the auction block and could fetch more than $1.5 billion, according to The New York Times.

title: Flowers May Bid for British Insurer
description: J.C. Flowers, the private equity shop run by J. Christopher Flowers, said Monday that it was floating an informal 4 billion pound ($7.8 billion) offer for Friends Provident, a British insurance company.

title: 2 Moguls Sons, 1 Bid
description: Lachlan Murdoch, a son of the media tycoon Rupert Murdoch, and the gambling magnate James D. Packer have made an offer of 3.3 billion Australian dollars ($2.9 billion) to buy the Packer-backed publishing company Consolidated Media Holdings.

title: For Ex-Goldman Trader, a Good Sinking Feeling
description: After four years of trading subprime mortgages, Jason Rew jettisoned his job at the investment bank Goldman Sachs and founded an off-shore business.

title: How Low Will the Market Go Tuesday?
description: Stocks looked ready to plunge in the United States early Tuesday, as the waves of anxious selling in Asian markets threatened to spread to Wall Street. Before the open of regular trading, Dow Jones Industrial Average futures were down more than 500 points, amid fears that the economic troubles in the United States were deeper and more far-reaching than previously thought. That was before the Federal Reserve announced early Tuesday it would cut its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point.

title: Whats Really Driving the Sovereign Fund Rush
description: If all these government-controlled funds in Asia and the Middle East that have been falling over one another to buy up stakes in Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley are so smart, where are all the big-name value investors like Warren Buffett? DealBook looked into this question in its latest column in The New York Times  and the answer seems to have a lot to do with politics.

title: Minnows Clash in African Cup of Nations
description: The first two days of the African Cup of Nations have unfolded according to form: hosts Ghana won the opening match 2-1, perhaps with more difficulty than was expected. Morocco handily dispatched Namibia, 5-1, thanks to a hattrick from Soufiane Alloudi. Mali earned a 1-0 victory over Benin. And in the marquee matchup of the first round, Nigeria fell 1-0 to Ivory Coast in a tight affair, Chelseas Salomon Kalou scoring the only goal.

title: The Early Word: Feisty Democrat Fight
description: As the presidential candidates march toward Super Tuesday (two weeks from today!), they are drawing sharp differences against their opponents. And last night in Myrtle Beach, S.C., the Democrats traded barbs in ways we hadnt seen before.

title: The Oscar Gun Goes Off
description: Here are the nominations for the Golden Guy:

title: Ambac Posts $3.3 Billion Loss
description: The Ambac Financial Groupm the bond insurance company, reported a quarterly loss of $3.3 billion on Tuesday after recording massive credit derivative write-downs and setting aside more money for credit losses.

title: Panic in Washington
description: DAVOS

title: Atonement: A Drama in Three Acts
description: Most Oscar ninnies, including the Bagger, had counted out Atonement, but there it was, the first picture mentioned in the tick-tock of best picture announcements by the Academy in the week hours of the California morning. The guessing for the No. 5 slot in the category had been spread around between Into the Wild or Diving Bell, but its Atonement that will be there for The Dance.
