title: Tracking the Markets After a Global Plunge
description: Following a full day of trading in the U.S. after 2 days of market dives around the world.

title: Preemptive easing
description: Wow. First the markets, now the Feds reaction.

title: Designs for a Downsized Future
description: DETROIT  One of the more refreshing displays here at the auto show, which runs through Sunday, is one for the Michelin Challenge Design, an annual competition held by the French tire maker.

title: Giuliani as Mayor: Tough, Ruthless and Vengeful
description: In a front-page article, Michael Powell and Russ Buettner explore Rudolph W. Giulianis tendency, during his eight years as mayor, to go after anyone who crossed him. In case after case, the Giuliani administration tried to silence or punish critics, including public interest lawyers, the nonprofit advocacy group Housing Works, top city officials and ordinary citizens.

title: Long Division
description: O.K., long weekend and the Opinionator is still catching up, but I think this still deserves mention: on Saturday Al Giordano, a former reporter for the alt-weekly Boston Phoenix now covering politics for the advocacy group RuralVotes blog, The Field, attended the caucuses held on the strip in Las Vegas. It was not pretty:

title: Playing Well With Others
description: Paramount Vantage and Miramax are in the midst of a very profitable corporate friendship. They share credits on the biggest winners today: No Country for Old Men and There Will Be Blood led the field with eight nominations each, including best picture. Paramount Vantage has domestic rights to TWBB while Miramax has foreign, and Miramax owns NCFOM in the United States while Paramount has the international rights. There will be some smiles across the room, along with quiet competition, between John Lesher of Paramount and Daniel Battsek of Miramax.

title: Davos in the Papers: Before the Show Starts
description: The World Economic Forum likes to see its annual meetings in Davos as a forum for politicians, business people and regulators to discuss the problems facing the world. For many captains of industry, however, the gathering is largely an opportunity to talk to each other  in private.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: Getting Around Davos: Our Annotated Map
description: View Larger Map

title: After Eight Rounds, Carlsen Leads at Corus
The Apparatus of Award
description: With No Country for Old Men and There Will Be Blood racking up nominations, the Bagger wonders what would happen in a throwdown between Anton Chigurh and Daniel Plainview. Both Javier Bardem (supporting) and Daniel Day-Lewis (lead) received nominations, but in a face-off between their characters, would the bowling pin-wielding Plainview or Chigurh, he of the lethal cattle stunner, come out on top?

title: The Senate Returns
description: Congress returns in full force today as the Senate ends the abbreviated pro forma sessions it has been conducting to deny President Bush recess appointments and opens its 2008 session in earnest.

title: Butterfly Flap
description: The Bagger and others had chosen The Diving Bell and the Butterfly for the fifth best picture slot, but the Miramax-backed French language film never emerged from its cocoon. Still, Diving Bell did get some love. Director Julian Schnabel was nominated for his efforts, which were remarkable, given that he had to come up with a way of visualizing and dramatizing the inner life of a man whose only communication with the outside world involved blinking one eye.

title: Weather Report: Mirroring the Markets, Gloom Over Davos
description: Todays stormy market looks as if it will be finding an echo in the weather for participants arriving in Switzerland on Tuesday for the World Economic Forum in Davos.

title: As Markets Fall, a Time for Panic  or Opportunity?
description: Crisis begets drama. Perhaps one of the more compelling stories of the 1987 market crash was the offering of British Petroleum shares.

title: From Davos, an Early Take on Rate Cuts
description: As world leaders such as Gordon Brown and business bigshots such as Lloyd Blankfein stream into Davos this week for the World Economic Forum, the stock markets are giving them plenty to talk about. Floyd Norris, the chief financial correspondent for The New York Times, is already in Davos for the event. The latest post on Mr. Norriss blog offers his initial thoughts on Tuesday mornings potentially market-moving development: the United States Federal Reserves interest-rate cut:

title: A Night Out in Accra
description: We set out to experience the Accra buzz this past weekend. Dinner at Celsbridge, a local favorite specializing in chicken and chips, fueled us for a long night. If you are in the area, I highly recommend it  especially if you enjoy your chicken crispy and spicy. A Star beer  a hoppy local lager that resembles Heineken, but better  easily washes the food down. A table of travelers decked out in green Nigeria kits was the only other exception in a restaurant glowing with Ghanaian colors.

title: The Insider | M. Blash
description: (Bryce Kass)

title: Moment of Truth in Toronto
description: The Toronto Maple Leafs have not won the Stanley Cup since 1967. They wont win it this season, either.

title: The Closer at a Cadillac Dealership
description: Aired Monday night on CBS: Pundits say that Mitt Romney may actually be too good-looking to be president. Well, thats what keeps me from running.

title: One Foot, Two Foot, Red Foot, Green Foot
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Countrywides Strangely Normal Deal Agreement
description: Last week Countrywide Financial filed its merger agreement with Bank of America. Given market conditions there was the expectation that there would be something particularly juicy in it.

title: Race Tightens in New York for G.O.P. Candidates
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City are running neck and neck among New York State Republicans likely to vote in their partys presidential primary on Feb. 5, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released this morning.

title: Clintons Big Spousal Shadow
description: On the heels of last nights Democratic debate, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton held a news conference this morning in Washington, D.C.. But all the reporters wanted to talk about was her husband.

title: The Panic Eases
description: DAVOS

title: Deep? Maybe. Long? Probably.
description: I still keep reading articles asserting that the last two recessions were brief and shallow. Formally, thats true. But both were followed by prolonged jobless recoveries that felt like continuing recessions. Below is the employment-population ratio since 1989, with shading showing the official recessions. In both cases the employment slump went on for a long time after the recession was supposedly over.

title: Writes Like a Girl
description: One of the more interesting and heartening bits of glittering data to emerge this morning has to in the screenplay categories. In both adapted and original, four great screenwriters who happen to be women were nominated. Theres a lesson down in there somewhere, something which suggest that while the loud clanky male voice has its uses  the Bagger is a proud bellower himself  if you are interested in making the kind of movie that engages audiences and wins lots of awards, maybe you should find someone who has interests beside NFL playoff point spreads.

title: Suicide Watch
description: Way back in August, Harvey Weinstein of the Weinstein Company looked toward this day and made a vow.

title: Miramax Plays Blackjack, and Draws 21
description: With 21 nominations across four movies  No Country For Old Men, The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, Gone Baby Gone, and There Will Be Blood (for which Miramax has international distribution rights)  Daniel Battsek, the head of Miramax, best have some champagne with his eggs.

title: Juno What? A Best Director Nom for Reitman
description: The biggest surprise in the directing category had to the nomination of Jason Reitman, the 30-year-old director of Juno, which had three other nominations including original screenplay (Diablo Cody), best actress (Ellen Page) and best picture. No one is more surprised that Mr. Reitman. Both he and the Bagger are in Sundance, and Mr. Reitman was half-asleep when he turned on the TV.

title: Davos Keeps Tabs on the Dow
description: As I write this, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down only 130 points. (Now theres a line I have not often used.) Financial stocks, after opening lower, are now up for the day. And Europe rose nicely. The Feds move, contrary to what I feared, has brought in buyers.

title: Fun Fact to Know and Forget
description: Per the Academy: For the second year in a row, an American director has been nominated for directing a foreign-language film. Last year, Clint Eastwood was nominated for the Japanese-language Letters from Iwo Jima; this year, Julian Schnabel is nominated for the French-language The Diving Bell and the Butterfly. (The Baggers colleague, Randy Kennedy, checked in with Mr. Schnabel back in November.)

title: Report Says Whitman to Leave After Conservative Decade at eBay
description: The Wall Street Journal is reporting that Meg Whitman is retiring as chief executive of eBay. In March, Ms. Whitman, 51, will have served in the position for 10 years.

title: Low Batting Average
description: Those of you ninnies who use the Screen Actors Guild awards as some king of indicator might want to wipe them from your database.

title: Romney and Keynes
description: Romney:

title: Hold Contest. Read 1,000 Entries. Name Winners!
description: Last week I challenged readers to dispense wisdom in just seven words. More than 1,000 of you offered ideas, adding up to more than 7,000 words of sage advice.

title: Huckabees Money Woes Curtail Campaign
description: A chronic lack of campaign money may finally be catching up to Mike Huckabee.

title: Chanel: Icon Power
description: On my way to the Armani couture show, I dropped by Chanel to see Karl Lagerfeld in his studio. The first person I saw was Amanda Harlech, sitting by the windows overlooking the Rue Cambon, and then I seemed to see everybody at onceOdile Gilbert, who always does the hair, Michel, who does the music, Elsa, who deals with VIPs who want to wear Chanel, Madame Jacqueline, who presides over the ateliers, and Sebastian, who drives Lagerfeld. Right away, Lagerfeld got down to business and said the collection had been inspired by shell patterns. He had never really thought about shells before, he said, and, as he opened a picture book of shellsCoquillages by Paul Starosta and Jacques Sendershe described it as an unknown world of color and texture.

title: Juno Over the Moon
description: A jet-lagged Ellen Page checked in with the Baguette from London, where Juno is set to open on Feb. 8. She said she was still a little in shock over the Oscar nomination: I mean, everything is obviously wonderful, and Im extremely grateful but of course this is very exciting. Im extremely humbled to be nominated with the women Im nominated with. Its crazy! Its absolutely crazy!

title: Academy Award Nominees
description: Images of the nominees for the 80th annual Academy Awards.

title: He Couldnt Afford the Grey Poupon
description: Aired Monday night on NBC: Folks, one year from today, we will swear in a new president of the United States. How about that? And as Hillary Clinton likes to say, Whoever she may be.

title: The Little Sparrows Voice
description: There were lots of noisy people speaking in French in the background when Marion Cotillard called the Baguette from her L.A. hotel. Its unbelievable! she said. Its unbelievable! Its huge. A French actress with a French movie to the Oscar is something that you cant imagine that its impossible.

title: The Rat Man Speaks
description: Brad Bird had a big morning: his film Ratatouille was been nominated for best animated film and he also got a nod for best screenplay. The Oscars are kind of the grand daddy of them all, he told the Baguette. I remember watching it as a little kid.

title: Should Student Test Scores Measure a Teachers Value?
description: What makes a good teacher? The citys Education Department has come up with one answer: Use standardized reading and math test scores to measure how much a teachers students improve from one year to the next. In a new pilot program at 140 city schools, the city has used a complicated statistical analysis to predict how much students should improve, then measure that against how well they actually do. Teachers are measured against other teachers with similar experiences and students. The outcome: Teachers will be rated to measure how well they taught their students in any given year.

title: BMW Welt
description: BMW Welt, or BMW World, joins an impressive list of high-profile architecture projects by German car companies in recent years.

title: Cameras PermittedMaybe
description: Over the weekend, I took my family to see a freestyle motocross show (motorcycle and bicycle stunt-riding) at a local arena. I know that, as a white bread suburban Ivy-League writer, Im not most peoples idea of a motocross-show goer, but you should see these guys: 19-year-old riders powering up a ramp and flying what must be 150 feet through the air, 50 feet off the ground, doing backflips, letting go of the bike altogether and otherwise channeling the spirit of Evel Kneivel.

title: Obama Continues Duel With Bill Clinton
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  As his campaign opened a telephone hotline for voters to report instances of dirty politics in the South Carolina primary fight, Senator Barack Obama did not back down from a defiant tone he struck at the Democratic debate last night.

title: Stocks Down, Interest In Business News Up
description: Whether markets are falling or rising, viewership of the business news network CNBC swells on volatile trading days. The same will likely be true for the four-month-old Fox Business Network.

title: 15 and Out
description: It was just 15 months ago that Buffets Inc., a restaurant company controlled by Caxton-Iseman Capital, a private equity firm, expanded by purchasing Ryans Restaurant Group, the owners of Ryans Family Steakhouses. The $16.25 per share purchase price was a 45 percent premium over the market price before the deal was announce.

title: Moviegoing
description: The third round of the Book Reviews Reading Room series is up and percolating.

title: Stocks Down, New Romney Ad Up
description: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.  In the midst of troubles in the stock market today, Mitt Romney has a new ad out in Florida touting his economic plan.

title: Race Tightens in New York for G.O.P. Candidates
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City are running neck and neck among New York State Republicans likely to vote in their partys presidential primary on Feb. 5, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released this morning.

title: Secret Plans, Private Meetings
description: While Senators Clinton and Obama brawl in South Carolina and John McCain, Mitt Romney and Rudy Giuliani gear up in Florida, the ground seems to be shifting under some of the other remaining headliners.

title: Now Screening | Suzy Menkes
description: Now that the Paris and Milan mens shows are over, The Moment would like to call your attention to the fine reporting of our fashion sister, Suzy  Suzy Menkes, that is  at the International Herald Tribune. Wed meant to say this earlier: Check out her interviews with Dior Hommes creative director Kris Van Assche and Gildo Zegna of Ermenegildo Zegna.

title: Passion Erupts in a Burst of African Colors
description: The highway from Accra to Sekondi is a two-lane road that follows the Atlantic. Its lined with palm trees and dotted with towns whose only reason for existing seems to be to sell pineapples and Ghanaian flags to travelers. The route is mostly dominated by overloaded trucks that list like boats and jam-packed tro-tros, the minibuses that are the transportation lifeblood of Ghana. In other words, its not the best road to be on if youre running late.

title: A Caribbean Restaurant Recommendation in Santo Domingo
description: As a present for a friend I want to give a meal at a very nice restaurant in the old city in Santo Domingo that serves (at least some) Caribbean food. Preferably not too big a place, and not in a hotel. Do you have any suggestions? Including how to contact them? Thanks!

title: The Man From Sicko
description: Michael Moore, nominated for the documentary Sicko, told the Baguette he clearly remembered his nomination and win for Bowling for Columbine.

title: The Valley Goes to the Mountains, in Full Blogging Mode
description: Tech is back at Davos this year, one of the participants exclaimed to me before I left Silicon Valley for the annual conference at this ski resort town.

title: Its Just Gravy
description: Javier Bardem is traveling in Europe with pals and swears that he is not carrying that pneumatic thingamajigie that Anton Chigurh used to dispatch people in No Country for Old Men. He watched the awards on television.

title: Bill Clinton Campaigns in S.C.
description: AIKEN, S.C.  As Senator Hillary Clinton flew off to Washington and then California, her husband stayed on the ground  and on message  to continue her campaign here in advance of Saturdays Democratic primary.

title: A Tale of Two Worlds
description: DAVOS, Switzerland

title: Science Explains Wilson the Volleyball
description: I have never understood why Wilson didnt get an Oscar for his performance in Castaway. The volleyball stole the movie! But now at least we have a scientific explanation for his existence.

title: Edwards Ad: Rivals Take Lobbyists Money
description: CONWAY, S.C.  Echoing a line of attack from Monday nights Democratic debate, John Edwards takes on both of his Democratic rivals for accepting money from drug companies and Washington lobbyists in a new television ad that goes up in South Carolina today.

title: Anti-Davos Gatherings Go Smaller, but Global
description: The World Social Forum has billed itself as the anti-Davos since 2001, when a collection of leftist activists of all stripes met in Porto Allegre, Brazil to proclaim Another World Is Possible. So, it turns out, is another kind of World Social Forum.

title: Finally, Deal Flow
description: After five days of wandering across the snowscape, the Bagger has finally found news of some deals from his colleague David M. Halbfinger.

title: Despite Strike, Oscar Organizers Are Optimistic
description: The Oscar nominations are out, one of the biggest questions about this years Oscar race  how a continuing writers strike will affect the ceremony  went unanswered, Brooks Barnes notes.

title: Atonement: Obits Were Dead on Arrival
description: James Schamus, poohbah of Focus Features, ribbed the Bagger and others for not picking Atonement to get into the final five, but he was in too good of a mood about the films seven nominations to dwell on the past.

title: Soft Serve  | A News Feed of Light Reading
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.The Journal reports that playing Wii and surgical training can be one in the same Going under the knife? Might as well make sure an indie knife from Joel Bukiewicz A non-invasive solution for men with small swords: the Wonderjock swimsuit from Aussiebum, an Australian-made pushup bra for a mans thunder down under Before hitting the beach, surf over to Shoppingblog, which has compiled an exhaustive list of all the new, hair-brained diet books If your latest regime has you skipping coffee, you might want to cheat with a halitosis-busting mouth spray thats super-charged with caffeine... Smell you later.

title: Just Browsing | Ripped From the Fashion Rags
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: Open Caucus: Voters View the S.C. Fracas
description: One of our Open Caucus participants, Patricia Barry, characterized last nights Democratic debate as a rousing, gloves-off session. With attacks flying every which way, members of our voters roundtable from around the country watched the fracas in Myrtle Beach, S.C. unfold on their television screens. Please feel free to join in the discussion in the comments section.

title: Can this be true?
description: According to Sam Stein:

title: Here, There and Everywhere, Week 4
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commuting trip for NYTimes.com/realestate, with additional details and reader comments here on City Room [Week 1 | Week 2 | Week 3]. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Thompsons Out
description: Everybodys been asking: Wheres Fred?

title: When Elbows Rub, Can Deals Be Far Behind?
description: A merger is like two people falling in love, Klaus Schwab, the founder of the World Economic Forum, was once quoted as saying in Wired magazine. Sometimes we are the place where the people first meet. Sometimes we are the place where they do the proposing. And sometimes we just provide the beautiful sunset.

title: A Brighter Year Ahead? Some C.E.O.s Think So
description: How this year looks depends on where you sit. If you sit in a developed economy, it doesnt look so good. But if you are in a developing economy, all is rosy.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Jan. 22:

title: Prince Charles Appears at an Energy Summit
description: Prince Charles gave a keynote lecture at a summit meeting on advanced energy technologies in Abu Dhabi on Monday  not in the flesh, but as a three-dimensional hologram. By not flying there and back, he avoided adding about 20 tons of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere (the carbon cost of flying him and his entourage), according to conference organizers.

title: Market Troubles Deter Few from Attending
description: Shares plummet, American central bankers meet for an emergency rate cut and George Soros asserts that this could be the worst financial crisis since World War II? Apparently thats no reason for the worlds top bankers and financial policy makers to cancel the annual schmoozefest that is the World Economic Forum in Davos.

title: Jeopardy! Returns to Air Without Writers
description: From Dateline Hollywood:

title: The Goddess Speaks
description: Its Julie, Ms. Christie said on the phone. She said it so softly that the name didnt immediately register with the Baguette  that Julie Christie, the legendary actress who won an Oscar for Darling (1965). Im sitting down to breakfast, she said with a laugh.

title: McCain Jokes About DAmatos Endorsement
description: FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla.  After two rallies in Floridas Panhandle this morning, Senator John McCain was airborne for New York to collect cash for his burgeoning campaign.

title: Sundance Winner: There Will Be Bagels
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Bagels may have gone coast-to-coast, but New Yorkers still sniff at the frozen supermarket creations and rolls-with-holes that masquerade as the real thing in other parts of the country. Which is why your City Room reporter was surprised to encounter real Brooklyn bagels in the Rocky Mountains last week during the Sundance Film Festival, which continues through Sunday.

title: Sarah Gets the News
description: Sarah Polley was having her hair done on a film set when she got the news that she had received an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay for Away From Her. I had my hair in curlers and was listening to the nominations on the radio, she told the Baguette.

title: Girls in Japan
description: On the subject of the mute, wide-eyed seductress who stares and goggles and cryptically gestures, my friend Shizu explains it all from Japan.

title: Writers Informally Meet With Studios
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: Europe: Your I.P. Address Is Personal
description: At a hearing Monday, a top privacy regulator in Europe said something that needs to be said: I.P. addresses need to be treated as personal information.

title: Federal Reserve Cuts Interest Rates
description: The Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut interest rates Tuesday morning.

title: Beyond Mad Men': AMCs Second Series Shows Promise
description: Fresh off its Golden Globe win for Mad Men, AMC is enjoying another round of positive press for its second original series, Breaking Bad.

title: High on Rebellion
description: After admitting that he passed up a live set by Patti Smith because of work, the Bagger took a little bit of a beat-down in comments and vowed not to make the same mistake twice when he heard there was a second show last night.

title: The Democrats Head South
description: As they campaigned across South Carolina in preparation for Saturday's primary, the Democratic candidates adopted a sharper tone.

title: Television for the Captive Commuter
description: Will New Jersey commuters turn into PATH potatoes?

title: Answers About The Jewish Americans, Part 2
description: Following is the second and final set of answers from David Grubin, a director, writer and cinematographer working in New York City, who took questions from readers over the past week on his new three-part documentary, The Jewish Americans on PBS. The previous set of questions and answers was posted on Jan. 18.

title: The Bidding Starts at $160,000
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: For The Moment | Jeff Kleins Anti-Formula
description: This weeks guest blogger is Jeff Klein, the hotelier behind The City Club in New York and the Sunset Tower in Los Angeles. To read all of Jeff Kleins prior blog posts, click here.

title: The Death of Heath Ledger
description: Updated, 10:17 p.m. | The actor Heath Ledger was found dead Tuesday afternoon in an apartment in Manhattan, according to the New York City police. Some signs pointed to an accidental overdose or a suicide, although no note was found, police sources said. Mr. Ledger was 28. [Now online: Comprehensive coverage prepared for Wednesday editions of The Times.]

title: NBC Sweeps Monday Night
description: NBC led every hour of prime time in Monday nights ratings, buoyed by the successful combination of American Gladiators (a new reality show/sports competition) followed by Deal or No Deal (a game show).

title: Ron Pauls MLK Fund-Raiser
description: There are a lot of ways to honor the memory of Martin Luther King Jr. Ron Pauls supporters turned MLK day into a fund-raising opportunity. With majestic and swelling music on a You Tube clip, supporers of Ron Paul kicked off the Free at Last 2008 Web site and his supporters responded by donating $1.85 million on the King anniversary  an amount that more cash-strapped candidates would envy.

title: The Unhappy Warrior
description: Well, that didnt take long: Fred D. Thompson, the former senator of Tennessee, dropped out of the Republican race for president today, reports The Times.

title: The Butterfly Effect
description: Julian Schnabel, speaking to the Baguette from Rome, about his Oscar nomination for directing The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, said he had friends waiting for him at a restaurant. Theyre going to buy me a bottle of champagne and were going to act like were excited.

title: Responses to Spitzers Budget Proposal
description: Updated, 7:07 p.m. | Reaction has been pouring in to Gov. Eliot Spitzers second executive budget, in which he proposed an array of new taxes and fees, $1 billion in health care cuts and scaled back plans for new education aid and property tax relief.

title: Debate Is a Ratings Hit for CNN
description: Political aficionados will remember Mondays Democratic presidential debate for the heated and personal exchanges between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama. Television executives will remember it as the most-watched presidential primary debate in cable news history.

title: Regulators Fault Con Ed on Steam Pipe Blast
description: Consolidated Edison faced a tough crowd this morning at a City Council hearing over the causes of the deadly steam pipe explosion in Midtown last July. On Dec. 28, the utility released an investigation that attributed the rupture to a combination of heavy rainfall, leaks in underground water and sewer pipes and debris that clogged two critical devices intended to let water out of the steam main.

title: Bobby G Opening Credits
description: Bobby G is a series on the Mojo HD Network that follows a publicity-loving entrepreneur and venture capitalist.

title: Gone Missing: Heath Ledger
description: Heath Ledger, a nice guy to deal with and a talented actor  he was nominated in 2005 for best actor for his role as a conflicted cowboy in Brokeback Mountain  was found dead in a Manhattan apartment. He was 28.

title: Bobby G Closing Credits
description: Bobby G is a series on the Mojo HD Network that follows a publicity-loving entrepreneur and venture capitalist.

title: Too Nasty?
description: Since Monday nights debate among Democrats, much of the talk in political circles has been around just how pointed the exchanges were between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

title: The Top-Rated Primary Debate In Cable History
description: Political aficionados will remember Mondays Democratic presidential debate for the heated and personal exchanges between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama. Television executives will remember it as the most-watched presidential primary debate in cable news history.

title: Silver lining to the financial crisis
description: The econoblogs have been great reading  and some of the commenters offer some much needed comic relief.

title: The Monster Is Back, and Its Hopeful
description: I often entertain a fantasy in which Im the editor of a newspaper that could be read by any organism on the planet, be it a bacterium or a hippopotamus. The newspaper is called The Hopeful Monster Daily News, and it has the slogan, All the news thats fit to select.

title: Dance Off!
description: GREENVILLE  Former President Bill Clinton said today that he would take Senator Barack Obama up on his challenge last night to prove himself as the first black president by entering a dance competition  against Mr. Obama.

title: Shredded Cabbage
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a crunchy midwinter salad with a frequently overlooked vegetable.

title: Blogtalk: Political Life Down South
description: Florida bloggers take their turn in the spotlight as their state is flooded with G.O.P. candidate meet and greets, pancake breakfasts, chicken dinners and the like.

title: Can the Touch Revive Apples iPod Sales?
description: Investors are all in a tizzy that Apple is only promising them a 30 percent growth, year over year, in its first-quarter revenue. But looking at the companys fourth-quarter 2007 results, its clear that the company is doing very, very well.

title: Writers to Spare Grammys From Picketing
description: Writers Guild of America members may not write for the Grammy Awards  but they will not picket the event either. Reuters reports:

title: Not Exactly in the Footsteps of the WUSA
description: Gayle Bryan is the publishing director of Fair Game Magazine, a publication dedicated to covering and supporting womens soccer. She writes a blog on Fair Games Web site and occasionally contributes to The Timess soccer blog, as she did from China during the Womens World Cup.

title: Meet the New Boss
description: Cliff Fletcher is not much like the old boss of the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: More Random Travel Notes: Heathrow, Zurich and Swiss
description: Back at Heathrow:  I must have angered the travel gods. Right after I criticizedHeathrow, I found myself back there, waiting for another delayed flight.It was an incremental delay, meaning the departure time kept inching back. Ground staff blamed communications between Heathrow and Zurich and added, disparagingly, that Everythings delayed today anyway.I am spoiled by Hong Kong International Airport, which has free wifi for those with laptops, and free computer terminals for those who dont.At least the electricity at Heathrows i-Pod and laptop charging stations is free. But an hour on a T-Mobile connection, which was about as quick as the security queue, cost me 5 pounds, or nearly U.S. $10.

title: Strike: Writers Pull Reality, Animation Off the Table
description: The Writers Guild of America has decided to withdraw its proposals relating to reality show and animation writers, removing a major impediment to a potential settlement between the guild and the alliance of major Hollywood studios.

title: No Habla Espaol
description: SALINAS, Calif.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton does not usually speak in Spanish as she makes overtures to Hispanic voters, and now we have evidence of why.

title: Can Washington Really Help?
description: John Harwood, of The Times and CNBC, interviews the president of the Urban Institute and former director of the Congressional Budget Office.

title: Solar City
description: Columnist Jim Dwyer's building is one of  the first private co-ops in the city to use arrays of solar panels.

title: A Little Eastern Promise among the Bardem Lovers
description: Im far away. Im in Javier Bardems country, Viggo Mortensen told the Baguettewhen he called to chat about his best acting Oscar nomination for Eastern Promises.Mr. Mortensen was in Madrid to finish editing books for his small press,percevalpress.com, and he told the Baguette that all the talk today was about Mr.Bardems nomination. People are very happy about him here, and theyre sort ofhappy about me being nominated, he said, as a wayward adoptive son I supposebecause Ive done a few movies here and Ive done a few movies in Spanish.

title: The Carpetbagger at Sundance
description: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) says goodbye to the surrogate center of the movie world, but not before taking in a hockey game.

title: Basketball: Perceptions of St. Johns
description: What do U.C.L.A., Indiana, Louisville and Arizona have in common? Each has fewer victories all-time than St. Johns.

title: Teen Gets Big Allowance
description: According to those always mysterious sources-close-to-the-negotiations, American Teen, a kind of cinematic diary of four teens making their way though their senior year of high school in a small town in Indiana, has been sold to Paramount Vantage for a rumored $2.5 million, a very hefty price. Both Fox Searchlight and Sony Pictures Classics apparently expressed interest, but decided to pull out when the asking grew under bidding pressure. Virtually everyone who has seen the documentary has come away thinking it may be the rare documentary that can do significant business in theatrical release.

title: Theres Pain in College Hockey, Too
description: College players have to wear full facemasks, but that doesnt make them immune to injury. Last weekend, a pair of season-ending injuries marred a great slate of college hockey games.

title: Will Falcons Wait for Spagnuolo?
description: The Atlanta Falcons are still interested in interviewing Steve Spagnuolo, the Giants defensive coordinator, for their vacant head-coaching position, but it is unclear whether they are willing to wait two weeks to talk to him.

title: Bloomberg Aides Schedule Is Revealed, Up to a Point
description: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg continues to dance around a presidential run, news media interest in the maneuverings of his chief political deputy, Kevin Sheekey, has intensified. Yet city officials have been slow to peel back the curtain on just how he spends his time.

title: Worries That the Good Times Were Mostly a Mirage
description: So, how bad could this get?

title: Strong Rail Prices Help CSX Beat Expectations
description: CHICAGO (Reuters)  The CSX Corporation reported a better-than-expected quarterly net profit Tuesday as strong pricing for rail freight offset higher fuel costs and weaker volumes, sending its shares up more than 5 percent.

title: Italys Premier Seeks to Bolster Support
description: ROME  Prime Minister Romano Prodi defiantly called Tuesday for a vote of confidence in both houses of Parliament, a move he hopes will keep his wounded coalition government alive. His longtime nemesis, the former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, kept up pressure for new elections he hopes will make him Italys leader again.

title: Recipe: Long Island Heirloom Squash
description: 1 Long Island, Cinderella, butternut or other flavorful winter squash, about 3 pounds

title: Letters
description: Thinking About Meat

title: No Country and Blood Lead Oscar Nominations
description: LOS ANGELES  Roll out the black carpet. A lineup of films bleak in tone and worldview will take center stage at the 80th annual Academy Awards next month, with critical darlings like There Will Be Blood, No Country for Old Men and Michael Clayton dominating the nominations, including the best picture category.

title: Bank of America Joins Parade of Mortgage-Related Losses
description: The upheaval in the mortgage market, a slowing economy and an increasingly stretched consumer have made the last few quarters among the toughest since Kenneth D. Lewis, the chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, took over in 2001.

title: Candidates Turn Attention to Gyrating Markets and Weakened Economy
description: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.  The weakened economy and the turmoil in financial markets have helped to cement a gradual shift in emphasis in the presidential campaign to domestic issues from national security, giving the candidates an opportunity on Tuesday to spotlight economic proposals and try to convince voters that they could handle a crisis.

title: Vietnam Agrees to the Return of Deportees From the U.S.
description: American immigration authorities reached an agreement on Tuesday with Vietnam that clears the way for Vietnamese immigrants under deportation orders to be sent back to their country.

title: Versus Extends Contract With N.H.L.
description: Buoyed by higher ratings this season, Versus has agreed to carry N.H.L. games through the 2010-11 season. The cable network, which is paying $72.5 million for the leagues rights this season, will pay inflationary increases over the next three years.

title: Mets Sign Chvez
description: The Mets avoided arbitration with their best defensive outfielder Tuesday by signing Endy Chvez to a two-year, $3.85 million contract. Chavez, 29, will make $1.8 million this season and $2.05 million in 2009. Chvez, who was limited to 71 games last season because of a left hamstring strain that knocked him out for nearly three months, batted .287 and scored 20 runs while playing his customary strong defense.

title: Retreat of the Foreign Investor Is Singularly Painful for Japan
description: TOKYO  From buoyant optimism just two years ago, the mood among foreign investors in Japan has swung to grim pessimism.

title: Ruses and Daring Escapes by a Jew in Nazi Germany
description: In June 1942 a 20-year-old Jew named Cioma Schnhaus stood in front of a Nazi bureaucrat in Berlin for final processing before being deported to a concentration camp in Poland. Asked if he had any money, he replied, Yes, my lucky penny. The penny went into the coffers of the Third Reich, duly noted in an account book.

title: Dragila and Stuczynski at Millrose
description: Stacy Dragila, who dominated American womens pole-vaulting for more than a decade, and Jenn Stuczynski, her successor, were matched Tuesday for the 101st Millrose Games on Feb. 1 in Madison Square Garden.Dragila, 36, is competing again after chronic Achilles tendon problems. In a two-week period last summer, Stuczynski broke Dragilas American record of 15 feet 10 inches, then became the second woman in track and field history to clear 16 feet.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the sentencing of a Border Patrol agent who helped smuggle more than 100 people into the United States misstated the reason that more than a dozen fellow agents were on hand. Some were there to condemn his actions; not all were there to support him.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 3 about an announcement by the Suffolk County, N.Y., district attorney that he would not retry Martin Tankleff in the murders of his parents after his conviction was overturned misstated the date of their deaths. It was Sept. 7, 1988, not Sept. 17. (The error was repeated in articles on Jan. 4 about Mr. Tankleffs plans for the future and on Saturday about the possibility that he would be investigated again by a special state prosecutor handling the case.)

title: Ambac Looks at Alternatives After $3.26 Billion Loss
description: The Ambac Financial Group, one of the largest companies that insures against bond losses, said Tuesday that it was exploring strategic alternatives as it announced a $3.26 billion loss for its fourth quarter.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening this Week

title: PATH Train From Hoboken to 33rd Street and Journal Square to 33rd Street
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Make the Tax Cuts Work
description: Washington

title: Times Company in Group Investing in Blog Publisher
description: Automattic, the commercial arm of the popular WordPress publishing platform for blogs, has received $29.5 million in financing from four companies, including a small portion from The New York Times Company.

title: Mattingly Cuts Coaching Role to Spend More Time at Home
description: Don Mattingly, who followed Joe Torre west to work for the Los Angeles Dodgers this season, has told the Dodgers that he cannot be their batting coach after all. Mattingly has decided to spend more time with his wife and his youngest son at home in Evansville, Ind. He will remain with the team as a special assignment coach.

title: When Fire Takes All but the Memories
description: Alener Baskins was on a lunch break from jury duty last fall when she got the bad news.

title: Pakistan: U.S. Commander and Army Chief Hold Talks
description: Adm. William J. Fallon, the senior American military commander in the Middle East, arrived for a one-day visit and called on President Pervez Musharrafs successor as army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, left. Mr. Musharraf is on a tour of European capitals. Little detail of the meeting with Admiral Fallon, held at military headquarters in Rawalpindi, was made available. The commanders discussed the overall security situation in the region, a spokesman for the Pakistan Army said. Admiral Fallon was recently quoted as saying that the United States military would play a greater role in training Pakistani forces and would provide technical advice to its troops.

title: Agreement on Proposal for New Iran Sanctions
description: BERLIN  The foreign ministers of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council agreed Tuesday to a new set of sanctions against Iran to present to the Council as a draft resolution, but they did not announce details of the sanctions, which are intended to induce Tehran to give up its nuclear program.

title: Booth in One Ear, Benches in Other
description: Pierre McGuire stood on a wobbly, foot-high black box and stretched his neck to watch the Rangers play the Bruins on Sunday at Madison Square Garden. His perch, nearer to Bostons bench, enabled him to watch the game as an NBC analyst and eavesdrop on what the coaches were telling the players. At stoppages, he strode to a nearby monitor to comment on replays. Between periods, he dashed to a makeshift studio, where he was the host for intermission reports with Mike Milbury.

title: On Marthas Vineyard, Using Scallops as Currency
description: Chilmark, Mass.

title: Footnotes
description: The Theater Hall of Fame has announced its new inductees: the actor and playwright Harvey Fierstein, the actors John Cullum, Lois Smith and Dana Ivey, the director Jack OBrien, the playwright Peter Shaffer, the librettist Joseph Stein and, posthumously, Mel Gussow, a critic for The New York Times. Tommy Tune will be the M.C. and the directors Hal Prince and Mike Nichols will be among the presenters at the induction on Monday at the Gershwin Theater in Manhattan.

title: How to Stop the Downturn
description: AMERICAS economy is headed for a major slowdown. Whether there is a recession (two quarters of negative growth) is less important than the fact that the economy will operate well below its potential, and unemployment will grow. The country needs a stimulus, but anything we do will add to our soaring deficit, so it is important to get as much bang for the buck as possible. The optimal package would contain one fast-acting measure along with others that could lead to increased spending if and only if the economy goes into a steep downturn.

title: Bush Pushes Justice Dept. Nominee
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Wednesday renominated Steven G. Bradbury to be an assistant attorney general in a move certain to be controversial because of Mr. Bradburys link to Justice Department memorandums authorizing the harsh interrogation of terrorism suspects.

title: Without Proof, an Ivory-Billed Boom Goes Bust
description: BRINKLEY, Ark.  David Baxter, 62, has hunted the Big Woods in eastern Arkansas for most of his life. But these days, his weapon of choice is an old 35-millimeter camera with a zoom lens, which he keeps in his blue pickup truck at all times just in case he comes across an ivory-billed woodpecker.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Friday about fallout from the 2006 arrest of a man who approached Vice President Dick Cheney and denounced the war in Iraq misidentified a former employer of the Secret Service agent who made the arrest, Virgil D. Reichle Jr. He worked for the Colorado State Patrol; there is no Colorado State Police.

title: Rating the Politicians, Past and Present
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief of eBay Is Expected to Retire
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An era at eBay is about to end.

title: (Solar) Power to the People Is Not So Easily Achieved
description: One day nearly four years ago, it suddenly seemed like a good idea to give solar electricity a try at home  home, for me, being an apartment house in Washington Heights, alias upstate Manhattan. The price of electricity was climbing. A war was being fought, if not over oil, then certainly over the ground the oil was in. Solar technology had proven that it could generate real power.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the marketing strategies of automakers misidentified the model of a Toyota sedan/station wagon aimed at baby boomers. It is the Venza  not the Versa, which is a small hatchback made by Nissan.

title: Rise of Chvez Sends Venezuelans to Florida
description: WESTON, Fla.  In December 2002, Ariel Dunaevschi, then the owner of a furniture business in Caracas, Venezuela, was on vacation in New York with his family when opponents of President Hugo Chvez called a crippling labor strike hoping to bring the government to its knees.

title: Going Far While Staying Close to Home
description: Life is good for Jessica McEntee. She has an apartment in the West Village, a 3.0 grade-point average at New York University and all-American recognition on the nations No. 3-ranked Division III womens basketball team.

title: Polishing the Brand in a Cathedral for Cars
description: MUNICH  I admit I had not been thrilled about flying here to see the BMW Welt, this car companys fancy new delivery center. The enthusiasm many of us once felt for the notion of an increasingly interconnected world has dimmed, a casualty of the canceled flights and lost luggage that is the reality of travel today. And I feared that the building itself  a luxury showroom that could double as a theme park for car fetishists  would be a monument to excess.

title: Asian Markets Ease Higher After Rate Cut
description: NEW DELHI  The United States Federal Reserves surprise rate cut stemmed bloodletting on the Asian stock markets on Wednesday, but heightened fears that a painful recession is imminent for the worlds largest economy.

title: What You Get for... $2 Million
description: Washington D.C.

title: Enticing Tough Cabbage to Show a Little Tenderness
description: THE days when late-fall vegetables had to last through the winter are long gone, but eating summer vegetables in midwinter doesnt make much sense, as most people recognize now. Traditional winter vegetables have a certain freshness that just cant be found in January asparagus or tomatoes. Enter cabbage salad, a crisp and flavorful alternative to tasteless winter lettuce.

title: Defense in Beating Death Points to Childs Gift
description: To bolster his case that a man accused of killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter is not guilty, the defense lawyer showed the jury on Tuesday a photo of a mug with the words Worlds Greatest Dad  the girls gift to the defendant, he said.

title: A Reminder From Mr. Doolittle
description: Representative John Doolittle, under criminal investigation for his past ties to Jack Abramoff, the imprisoned ber-lobbyist, has decided not to seek re-election. The nation may not have noticed his adieu, but surely other members of Congress can draw a timely lesson as they approach an important vote on whether to create an independent Office of Congressional Ethics.

title: EBay Names Successor to Whitman
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Meg Whitman, the chief executive of eBay for almost 10 years, is stepping down and will be replaced by John Donahoe, president of eBays marketplaces division, the company said Wednesday.

title: At Last, a $20,000 Cup of Coffee
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Justices Broaden Immunity for Officers
description: WASHINGTON  Federal law enforcement officers are immune from lawsuits for mishandling, losing or even stealing personal property that comes under their control in the course of their official duties, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday in a 5-to-4 decision.

title: Apple Earnings Up, but Stock Falls on Outlook
description: Apple beat Wall Street expectations with its earnings report Tuesday, but its shares fell more than 11 percent in after-hours trading as investors fretted over its prospects.

title: Gov. Spitzer Threads the Needle
description: Across the country, governors are wrestling with many of the same problems as investors watching the Big Board on Wall Street. Californias governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, announced that the wolf is back as his state faces a $14 billion shortfall and 10 percent budget cuts. Jon Corzine, the governor of New Jersey, is hoping that toll increases will fill the potholes in his states bottom line.

title: Turkmens End Holiday for Birthday of Ex-Leader
description: MOSCOW  Turkmenistans president has abolished a holiday honoring the birthday of his predecessor a year after his death, further undermining a personality cult that nevertheless clings to Turkmenistan, a hermetic Central Asian country.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about fierce competition in the South for black Democratic primary voters misstated the position of the Alabama Education Association, a teachers union. Although two of its leaders have endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the union has not endorsed a presidential candidate.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about a study linking caffeine and miscarriage misstated the name of the medical journal in which the study was published. It is The American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, not The Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

title: Bike Lanes in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fed Weighs In
description: Tuesdays stock market gyrations were stomach churning. There is no doubt that without the Federal Reserves large emergency interest rate cuts, the market slide would have been worse. The main stock gauges in the United States all fell, but not as far or as fast as some of their global counterparts and not as much as feared.

title: Clintons No. 1 Surrogate Clashes With No. 1 Rival
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  With Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigning more than 2,500 miles away, her fight against Senator Barack Obama in South Carolinas Democratic presidential primary emerged here Tuesday as a head-to-head match between him and her husband.

title: Victorious Giants Return Home and Its Time to Party On
description: Word had it the Giants were coming to the party. The promoter said to set your watch by it. The assistant promoter promised to make introductions. And the D.J. said thats a fact.

title: Recipe: Classic Fondue
description: 1 small garlic clove, halved

title: Product Placement on Reality TV Seems Somehow More Realistic
description: AS the writers strike keeps the television networks scrambling to fill their schedules, the producers of reality shows are gladly stepping in to fill the vacuum.

title: Villages At-Large Voting Is Found to Be Biased
description: Citing a history of official discrimination against Hispanic voters, a federal judge ruled on Tuesday that the way municipal elections are conducted in the village of Port Chester, N.Y., violates federal election law.

title: Asian Markets Ease Higher After Losses
description: SHANGHAI  The calm seemed to return to markets across Asian on Wednesday morning.

title: More Aid for City Schools, but Less Than Promised
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer came into office pledging to solve one of the most vexing issues in Albany  the way the state doled out money to pay for public schools  and to give New York City a greater share of the aid.

title: Junior League Appoints Black Woman as President
description: The New York Junior League announced on Tuesday the appointment of its first black president, characterizing the move as a groundbreaking one for an organization that has tried for years to cultivate a more socially and racially diverse image.

title: What New Yorkers Think
description: To the Editor:

title: Huckabee, Short on Cash, Curtails Effort in Florida
description: WASHINGTON  Before he won the Iowa Republican caucuses, Mike Huckabee told voters that sending him to victory would forever debunk the conventional wisdom that money could decide a presidential race.

title: Recipe: Cabbage Salad
description: Time: 10 minutes, plus 1 to 2 hours for salting

title: Borrowers With Good Credit May Benefit
description: The Federal Reserves decision on Tuesday to cut interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point should offer some comfort to consumers, with limits.

title: City Tries Again to Require Restaurants to Post Calories
description: New Yorkers wondering just how many calories they are consuming in each grande-size white hot chocolate at Starbucks (490) or Double Whopper with cheese at Burger King (990) could soon see those numbers printed alongside the price, according to revised regulations approved on Tuesday by the citys Board of Health.

title: One Pot
description: IRON pot chicken is a childhood favorite of Michael Huynh, the executive chef and a partner at Bun and Mai House. He learned to cook it by watching his mother in Saigon (now Ho Chi Minh City), Vietnam, as she sauted chicken with caramelized sugar and fish sauce. The dish, which takes only 12 minutes, is a bright, palate-awakening blend of salty, sweet and spicy. Best of all, it all comes together in a single pot.

title: Chang Elected to International Tennis Hall of Fame
description: Michael Chang, who at age 17 became the youngest man to win a Grand Slam title, was elected to the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

title: Fast Start for Egypt
description: Egypt opened the defense of its African Cup of Nations title by defeating Cameroon, 4-2, Tuesday as Mohamed Zidan and Hosni Abd Rabou scored two goals each. In Tuesdays other game, Zambia beat Sudan, 3-0.

title: Qualifying Plan in Indy League
description: The Indy Racing League will use a four-lap qualifying procedure similar to the Indianapolis 500 at all its oval-track races this season. The pole winner and lineup at those events will be determined by the overall times for all four laps, rather than the fastest of two qualifying laps as in the past. The format for road and street courses will remain unchanged, with single-lap qualifying for all cars followed by a 10-minute group session with the six fastest qualifiers to determine the pole position.

title: Clemens Saga Is Upstaging Santana Trade Talks
description: Correction: In this space two weeks ago, I wrote that the most popular baseball game of the winter was the Minnesota Twins attempt to trade Johan Santana, and the game, I said, seemed to be endless. The endless part was right, but Im not so sure I was right about it being the most popular game of the winter.

title: Urgently, Washington Responds to Fast-Spreading Market Turbulence
description: WASHINGTON  Even though Monday was a holiday, Ben S. Bernanke showed up early at his office at the Federal Reserve. The next day, he was planning a trip to New York.

title: Sharapova Upsets Henin; Venus Williams Loses
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  A good nights sleep failed to improve the Williams sisters fortunes at the Australian Open on Wednesday when Venus Williams followed her sister Serena out of this Grand Slam tournament at the quarterfinal stage.

title: Winehouse Is Shown in Apparent Drug Use
description: In a grainy video that circulated online Tuesday Amy Winehouse, 24, left, appears to smoke crack and claims to have taken about six Valium. It was posted on the Web site for The Sun, a British tabloid (thesun.co.uk), and an accompanying article, inset, said the video was taken early Friday morning at Ms. Winehouses London home, and that the two-minute clip follows a 19-minute binge in which she snorted powdered ecstasy and cocaine. Her record label, Universal, said in a statement: We are deeply disappointed and upset by these latest revelations and are doing everything we can to offer Amy our full support in dealing with her problems. Contradictory reports circulated online on Tuesday about whether Ms. Winehouse had been taken to a rehab clinic. (She had a hit with Rehab, in which she sings about refusing treatment.) A spokeswoman for her label declined to comment on that issue.

title: Padilla Gets 17 Years in Conspiracy Case
description: MIAMI  Jose Padilla, the Brooklyn-born convert to Islam whom the government once accused of plotting to detonate a dirty bomb in the United States, was sentenced on Tuesday to 17 years and 4 months in prison for his role in a conspiracy to help Islamic jihadist fighters abroad.

title: Drugs-for-Information Scandal Shakes Up New York Police Narcotics Force
description: In the world of urban policing, few relationships are as fraught with peril as those between narcotics officers and confidential informants. These informants  C.I.s in police parlance  are often small-time criminals who are paid or get criminal charges dropped in return for information about other, theoretically more dangerous criminals.

title: A Writer and Speaker Specializing in Everything
description: Doc, a nonfiction feature about the life of the novelist, inventor and cult figure Harold Louis Humes, known as Doc, starts with an audio snippet in which Mr. Humes insists that the best classroom lectures are those in which the speaker seems to be engaged in a perpetual search for his subject.

title: Southwestern Sun, Late in the Day
description: FOR one illustration of the chef Bobby Flays formidable celebrity, just check out the Food Network. He stars in, or appears on, three shows now in production, meaning you cant watch for long without spotting his sunny face.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,918 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

title: Citigroups Financial Hit
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Blocked From Reindicting a Justice
description: HOUSTON  A Texas judge on Tuesday dismissed the grand jury whose indictment of a State Supreme Court justice and his wife here last week was thwarted by prosecutors.

title: Dayton Coach Retires
description: Mike Kelly retired Tuesday after 27 years as coach at Dayton. Kelly compiled a 246-54-1 record for an .819 winning percentage, fourth-best among coaches with at least 25 years of experience. Rick Chamberlin, the defensive coordinator, will take over as head coach, Athletic Director Ted Kissell said. Kelly will remain at the university, expanding his duties as an associate athletic director.

title: Missouri Governor Will Not Seek 2nd Term
description: CHICAGO  Matt Blunt, the governor of Missouri and a Republican, announced late Tuesday that he would not seek re-election this fall, a decision that stunned many in the states political circles and threw the anticipated alignment of Missouris election into disarray.

title: Foreign Aid and Chicago Past Disputed in Latest Debate Back-and-Forth
description: WASHINGTON  In the Democratic debate on Monday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that Senator Barack Obama had not explained how he would pay for his proposal to increase foreign aid by $25 billion a year.

title: Writers Drop Demand and a Picket Plan
description: LOS ANGELES  In a major step toward ending a 12-week walkout, Hollywoods striking writers on Tuesday dropped their demand for extended jurisdiction over reality and animation work and agreed to extend informal talks with Hollywood production companies, even as they decided not to picket next months Grammy Awards telecast.

title: G.M. and Toyota in a Close Race in 07 Sales
description: DETROIT  General Motors and Toyota ended 2007 effectively tied in their fight to be the worlds largest automaker.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $6,914,159

title: Mystical to Muscular: Many Styles in Play at a Keyboard Marathon
description: Merkin Concert Hall, closed for refurbishing during the first part of the season, had its official opening two weeks ago and quickly got back to the business of presenting chamber and new-music concerts. But on Monday it changed pace with a Grand Piano Marathon: a free concert of piano music, including contemporary works, classical scores and jazz, that began at 2 p.m. and finished at nearly 9. For most of the day the hall was packed, with a line outside that was only partly alleviated by a late-afternoon decision to put seats on the stage. Not until the final hour did the audience begin to thin out.

title: Man Imprisoned for 9 Years for Murder Is Released in Wake of DNA Evidence
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  A judge on Tuesday threw out the murder conviction and life sentence of a Fort Collins man who said for years that he was innocent of one of this citys most sensational killings, the stabbing and mutilation of a woman whose body was found in February 1987 in a vacant field near the mans home.

title: Time-Travel Odyssey Through War and the Cosmos
description: Given the maiming and killing in Iraq and Afghanistan, the time seems nigh to revisit Kurt Vonneguts antiwar 1969 masterpiece, Slaughterhouse-Five. Few in the theater are better qualified to do so than the director Joe Tantalo and his Off Broadway troupe, Godlight Theater Company, which has made a specialty of exuberant, muscular adaptations of literate science fiction, including a provocative take on Fahrenheit 451 in 2006.

title: Surgery Makes Marbury More Irrelevant
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Stephon Marbury had surgery on his left ankle Tuesday, a routine procedure that was described as successful, but with the ultimate outcome yet unknown. Even New Yorks finest doctors cannot project where Marburys serpentine career is headed.

title: Google and Ad Conglomerate Teaming Up
description: PARIS  The chief executives of Publicis Groupe, the advertising conglomerate, and Google, the Internet giant, said Tuesday that they would jointly develop an approach to digital advertising that was both creative and technologically savvy, a combination they said is lacking.

title: Mexico: Army Seizes Guns From Police
description: The federal authorities stepped up their campaign against armed drug gangs and police corruption, sending soldiers to shut down temporarily the local police departments in Nuevo Laredo, Ro Bravo, Miguel Alemn, Valle Hermoso and Matamoros, all in Tamaulipas State, and seized the officers weapons to investigate whether any guns were linked to crimes.

title: On Wall Street, a Day of Frayed Nerves
description: Dan MacMillan was fearing the worst on Tuesday morning. Like many Wall Street traders he expected share prices to plummet after two days of severe declines in overseas markets.

title: Stocks Slide Steeply Again in Europe
description: PARIS  European stock markets fell steeply again on Wednesday after the head of the European Central Bank dampened investors hopes that the bank would follow the Federal Reserve in cutting interest rates.

title: Studies Link Other Ills to Mercury, Too
description: In the past few years, several studies have concluded that elevated mercury levels may be associated not only with neurological problems but with cardiovascular disease among adults as well.

title: Albert Bowker, 88, Dies; Ex-CUNY Head
description: Albert H. Bowker, the outspoken head of the City University of New York who stunned the campus and ruffled the citys self-esteem in 1971 by departing to become chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, where he spent nine sometimes turbulent years, died on Sunday in Portola Valley, Calif. He was 88.

title: Recipe: Beet Curry Soup
description: 2 tablespoons vegetable oil

title: Mickelson Recovers
description: The Buick Invitational will have the top two players in the world after all. After three days of bed rest and antibiotics for respiratory problems, Phil Mickelson said Tuesday he was feeling better and will play in the pro-am Wednesday at the Buick Invitational, paving the way for him to make his 2008 debut at Torrey Pines. He also has a practice session planned with his swing coach, Butch Harmon.

title: House Committee Subpoenas Knoblauch
description: The House oversight committee subpoenaed the former Yankee Chuck Knoblauch on Tuesday after he failed to respond to an invitation to give a deposition and testify before Congress about his suspected use of human growth hormone and his insights into Roger Clemens.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a new television advertisement in Spanish for the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney misstated the value of his company, Bain Capital, at the beginning of his tenure there. It was $36 million, not $6 billion. (Go to Article)

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the Sports Briefing column on Saturday about a new contract for Matt Holliday of the Colorado Rockies misstated the significance of his performance in 2007. He became the third player since 1967  not the first  to lead the National League outright in both batting average and runs batted in. (The others were Joe Torre in 1971 and Todd Helton in 2000.)

title: The Late Deciders
description: They are elusive. They can upend campaigns. They are the great swath of voters who decide just days before or even moments before they actually vote.

title: Asian Markets Endure 2 Brutal Days of Plunges
description: SHANGHAI  The stark sell-off that sent share prices plummeting around the world early this week brought renewed concern that the equity markets in China and India might be overvalued. But while Chinese investors and analysts worried this might be the case and fretted over the potential social consequences, in India the market chaos was often greeted as a buying opportunity.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports chart last Wednesday about the Pro Football Hall of Famers who were involved in the 1962 championship game between the Packers and the Giants misstated the titles of Vince Lombardi and Wellington Mara in some editions. Lombardi was Green Bays coach, not owner; Mara was the Giants owner, not coach.

title: Gladiators and Deal Deliver One-Two Punch
description: NBC led every hour of prime time in Monday nights ratings, buoyed by the successful combination of its new hit American Gladiators followed by the game show Deal or No Deal. Those shows earned the nights top ratings among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsens estimates, with Deal or No Deal also drawing the largest audience of the night, 14.1 million viewers at 9 p.m. American Gladiators, meanwhile, delivered a more modest 10.1 million viewers at 8. NBCs Medium, which also drew 10.1 million viewers, led the 10 p.m. hour in the 18-to-49 group. Fox finished second for the night in that demographic, thanks to its new show Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles, which attracted 8.6 million viewers while tying CBSs comedy repeats in the 9 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49. CBS, which broadcast reruns all night long, ranked third in that age group, but second in total viewers behind NBC. ABC was a distant fourth. Its Dance War averaged 9.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, but its October Road continued to struggle during the 10 p.m. time slot with just 5 million viewers.

title: Recipe: Pasta With Duck Confit
description: Time: 40 minutes

title: In Orphans Twilight, Memories of a Doomed Utopia
description: TEL AVIV  They are in their 80s now, the last living links to Janusz Korczak, the visionary champion of childrens rights who refused to part with his young charges even as they were herded to the gas chambers.

title: Recipe: Queso Fundido
description: 3 ounces chorizo, sliced 1/4 inch thick

title: Terrence Elkes, 73, President of Viacom in 80s, Dies
description: Terrence A. Elkes, a lawyer who rose to become president of Viacom in the 1980s and oversaw some major acquisitions, but left after Sumner M. Redstone bought control of the company, died on Friday in Washington. He was 73.

title: European Bank Chief Is Cool to a Rate Cut
description: PARIS  A day after the Federal Reserve announced an emergency rate cut in the United States in the face of a stock market meltdown, the president of the European Central Bank on Wednesday dashed hopes of any short-term rate relief on the Continent.

title: Gatlin Files Appeal
description: The Olympic sprint champion Justin Gatlin has appealed his four-year doping suspension in an attempt to return to the track for the Beijing Games in August. The notice was filed Monday to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, the international body that has the final say in such matters. A United States arbitration panel earlier this month reduced Gatlins potential eight-year ban to four, but Gatlin wants a further reduction.

title: Why the European Bank Is Sitting Back
description: LONDON  Monetary policy usually takes some time to bite. That is one explanation for the American stock markets continued gyrations on Tuesday after the Federal Reserves emergency rate cut. It may also explain why the European Central Bank has given no indication that it will follow suit.

title: Entrepreneur Unveils New Tourist Spacecraft
description: Burt Rutan took the cloak off of his new spacecraft on Wednesday.

title: Maybe Too Little, Always Too Late
description: The history of anti-recession efforts is that they are almost always initiated too late to do any good. This chart, based on recession timelines from the National Bureau of Economic Research, shows the enactment of stimulus plans is a fairly accurate indicator that we have hit the bottom of the business cycle, meaning the economy will improve even if the government does nothing.  Bruce Bartlett, author of Impostor: How George W. Bush Bankrupted America and Betrayed the Reagan Legacy.

title: House Leaders and Bush Move Closer to Deal on Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional leaders and the Bush administration appeared close to reaching a deal on a $145 billion economic stimulus package, with negotiations expected to continue through Wednesday night as the Treasury Department crunched the numbers on components of the plan, senior House officials said.

title: Whole Foods Chain to Stop Use of Plastic Bags
description: The Whole Foods Market chain said Tuesday that it would stop offering plastic grocery bags, giving customers instead a choice between recycled paper or reusable bags.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday about Georgia Frontiere, the longtime owner of the St. Louis Rams football team, misstated the timing of her comment to USA Today about encouragement she said she had received from her husband, Carroll Rosenbloom, who died in 1979. It was made before the 2000 Super Bowl, not before the 1980 Super Bowl. (USA Today was founded in 1982.)

title: Two Against One
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.

title: Lottery Numbers
Rice Rebukes Bush Envoy Who Criticized Policy on North Korea
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, in a rare public rebuke, has upbraided a White House envoy who criticized United States diplomacy toward North Korea that is aimed at coaxing the North Koreans to give up their nuclear weapons.

title: Living in a Dutch Town House
description: UTRECHT, the Netherlands

title: Pairings
description: The Napa cabernets were earthy and sometimes bold, with brambly fruit in the ones I liked. Call them rustic yet refined. That also describes the pasta, whole wheat or made with farro, I set out to sauce.

title: Recipe: Scallops With Preserved Lemons on the Half Shell
description: 4 scallop shells or oven-safe plates

title: Brown, in an Article, Needles the Knicks
description: Eighteen months after the Knicks fired him  and days before his current team will play them  Larry Brown has broken an apparently self-imposed silence to accuse the Knicks of espionage. The spying, Brown said, was directed at him.

title: City Parks Officials Seek Safety Review of Synthetic Surfaces
description: For more than a decade, the citys Parks Department has extolled the environmental and safety benefits of replacing the grass or asphalt at dozens of its play spaces with synthetic material made from recycled tires, despite safety concerns expressed by some scientists and childrens advocates.

title: Veto of Childrens Health Plan Stands
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats cited the nations economic problems as a reason to expand a popular health insurance program for children on Wednesday, but their effort failed as the House sustained President Bushs veto of a bill to provide coverage to nearly four million more uninsured children.

title: Toehold in Napa: Some Starter Bottles
description: NO California wine region has the branded power of Napa Valley. Whatever you think of the wines, the name is the vinous equivalent of Mercedes or Louis Vuitton. What that means, practically speaking, is that when you buy a Napa Valley wine you are paying for a lot more than whats in the bottle.

title: Hedge Fund Founder Sentenced for Fraud
description: A founder of several Bayou Management hedge funds was sentenced to more than four years in prison Tuesday for a scheme to defraud investors.

title: Diabetes Study Favors Surgery to Treat Obese
description: Weight-loss surgery works much better than standard medical therapy as a treatment for Type 2 diabetes in obese people, the first study to compare the two approaches has found.

title: Sierra Leone: Leader in Child Mortality
description: A newborn in Sierra Leone has the lowest chance in the world of surviving until age 5, and the prospects are almost as bad for children in Angola and Afghanistan, Unicef said in its annual report. In 2006, nearly 9.7 million children worldwide died before their fifth birthdays, mostly from preventable causes like diarrhea, malaria or malnutrition, it said, and on average more than 26,000 children under 5 died each day. Sierra Leone had the highest child mortality rate, with 270 deaths per 1,000 births. Angola was second with 260 deaths, followed by Afghanistan with 257. The rate worldwide in 2006, in contrast, was 72 deaths per 1,000 births. The average rate in industrialized countries was six deaths per 1,000 births. Sub-Saharan Africa, where the rate has dropped only 14 percent since 1990, is the region of greatest concern, the report said. It is home to 28 of the 30 countries with the highest child mortality rates. But the report said considerable progress had been made in East Asia and the Pacific, Central and Eastern Europe, and Latin America and the Caribbean. Child mortality in those regions has been cut roughly in half since 1990, to below 30 deaths per 1,000 births.

title: U.S. Given Poor Marks on the Environment
description: WASHINGTON  A new international ranking of environmental performance puts the United States at the bottom of the Group of 8 industrialized nations and 39th among the 149 countries on the list.

title: Closing the Barn Door After the Cows Have Gotten Out
description: Last week, the Food and Drug Administration cleared the way for the eventual sale of meat and dairy products from cloned animals, saying, in effect, that consumers face no health risks from them. The next day, the Department of Agriculture asked farmers to keep their cloned animals off the market until consumers have time to get over their anticloning prejudice. That is one prejudice I plan to hold on to. I will not be eating cloned meat.

title: Iraq Parliament Purges Hussein Vestiges on Flag
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi lawmakers adopted a modified version of the national flag on Tuesday, removing three stars that symbolized the Baathist ideals of unity, freedom and socialism, and Saddam Husseins handwritten calligraphy of the Koranic incantation Allahu akbar.

title: Russian Inquiries Threaten an Opposition Candidacy
description: MOSCOW  Russian prosecutors opened a criminal investigation on Tuesday into an opposition leaders effort to register as a candidate in the March 2 presidential election, raising doubts about whether he would be able to run against the Kremlins favorite choice.

title: Patriots Are Reluctant to Solve Limp Mystery
description: Officially, the New England Patriots say they know nothing about an injury to Tom Bradys right foot. Unofficially, something seems wrong.

title: Done Deals Finally Start to Appear at Sundance
description: PARK CITY, Utah  And on the fifth night, the wallets opened.

title: Test of Brain Device Is Setback for Maker
description: Any impact that Tuesdays plunging stock markets might have had on Northstar Neuroscience was lost in the bad news released before trading began  results from a crucial clinical trial showed that its brain-stimulating device failed to help stroke victims recover the use of their arms and hands.
