title: Heath Ledger, Actor, Is Found Dead at 28
description: Heath Ledger, the Australian-born actor whose breakthrough role as a gay cowboy in the 2005 movie Brokeback Mountain earned him a nomination for an Academy Award and comparisons to the likes of Marlon Brando, was found dead Tuesday in an apartment in Manhattan with sleeping pills near his body, the police said.

title: California: Driver in Ferrari Crash to Be Deported
description: A Swedish businessman who crashed a $1.5 million Ferrari in Malibu in 2006 will be soon released from a detention center near Los Angeles and deported to Sweden, a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said. The businessman, Bo Stefan Eriksson, left, pleaded no contest to a drunken-driving charge in connection with the crash on the Pacific Coast Highway, and also pleaded no contest to embezzlement and gun possession charges. He was sentenced to three years. The authorities say Mr. Eriksson and Trevor Michael Karney were traveling 162 miles per hour in a rare Ferrari Enzo, one of only 400 made, when it crashed into a pole.

title: Heirs Seek Proceeds From Russian Art Show
description: Descendants of two prominent czarist-era art collectors demanded compensation as a major exhibition of Russian art was previewed on Tuesday at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, Bloomberg News reported. The descendants, Andr-Marc Delocque-Fourcaud, grandson of Sergei Shchukin, and Pierre Konowaloff, great-grandson of Ivan Morosov, did not seek the return of paintings. Instead, they asserted a moral right to a portion of the proceeds from the show, to open on Saturday. A spokeswoman for the Russian Federal Agency of Culture and Cinematography declined to comment. Fears of legal claims to some of the 120 works in the show, From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925 From Moscow and St. Petersburg cast doubt over the exhibition for several weeks until Britain satisfied Russia that the paintings, including art by Gauguin, Kandinsky and van Gogh, would be returned after it ends on April 18.

title: California Race Increases Drug Testing
description: The Tour of California, a 650-mile, eight-day race that is expected to attract some of cyclings top international teams next month, announced Tuesday that it would increase testing of riders before and after each days event, and contribute its results to an antidoping database sponsored by the sports governing body.

title: Viewership of Debate Sets Record
description: Political aficionados will remember the Democratic presidential debate on Monday night for the heated and personal exchanges among Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Senator Barack Obama and John Edwards. Television executives will remember it as the most-watched presidential primary debate in cable news history.

title: Panel Questions Canadian Role in Afghanistan
description: OTTAWA  A government panel said Tuesday that the Canadian military should withdraw from a combat role in Afghanistan next year unless it is reinforced with 1,000 additional troops from other NATO countries.

title: Thai Soap Opera Receives a Cleanup
description: Longer skirts and shorter catfights were promised on Tuesday by the producers of a steamy Thai soap opera about airline crews that drew a protest from the Thai Airways International union, The Associated Press reported. At a news conference, executives from the Exact Company, which produces the show, said they were sorry if they had offended anyone and would tone down some of the raciness.

title: A Little Nostalgia, a Long Fork and Lots of Cheese
description: ONE chilly afternoon, my mother dropped by with a small shopping bag filled with fondue forks.

title: New York Is All McCains, for a Night
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Senator John McCain of Arizona scooped up $1 million for his presidential campaign on Tuesday night in the center of Rudolph W. Giulianis political turf, the St. Regis Hotel in Midtown Manhattan, and announced the support of former Senator Alfonse M. DAmato and a swath of the New York Republican establishment.

title: Child Soldiers Book Faces a Challenge
description: A best-selling author who is the worlds leading spokesman for child soldiers strongly defended himself against an Australian newspapers accusation that he had distorted the account of his service in Sierra Leones civil war during the 1990s. In a statement released on Tuesday, the author, Ishmael Beah, above, said: I am right about my story. This is not something one gets wrong. His publisher, Sarah Crichton Books, a Farrar, Straus & Giroux imprint, also defended the accuracy of his book, A Long Way Gone: Memoirs of a Boy Soldier. The Weekend Australian reported that his ordeal had lasted one year, not the three that he had stated. Mr. Beah, now 27, said the newspaper may not have understood that rebels first attacked his village in 1993, two years before they closed a village mine.

title: Israel Resumes Fuel Shipments to Gaza
description: GAZA  After widespread criticism of its decision to cut off supplies of industrial diesel oil required to run a power station that serves Gaza City and its hospitals, Israel resumed fuel shipments on Tuesday on what it said would be a temporary basis.

title: Wal-Mart Says More Than Half Its Workers Have Its Health Insurance
description: Wal-Mart, the nations largest private employer, said on Tuesday that for the first time in its 46-year history more than half its United States workers had enrolled in the companys health insurance plan, a milestone for a retailer long criticized as offering unaffordable benefits.

title: Missouri: Group Membership Prompts a Resignation
description: A member of the Kansas City Parks Board resigned after her membership in an anti-illegal-immigration group led two organizations, the National Council of La Raza and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, to hold their annual conventions elsewhere. The board appointee, Frances Semler, 74, a member of the Minuteman Civil Defense Corps, said she resigned because her involvement with the group had become too contentious and because she did not feel that Mayor Mark Funkhouser supported her. Ms. Semler defended her involvement with the group, which advocates vigilante patrolling of the Mexican border and reports illegal immigrants. Im a decent, nice person that happens to belong to the Minutemen and thinks our borders should be protected and our laws upheld, she said.

title: Bridging Civilizations to Make Sense of Slaughter
description: The women stand in sparkling evening dresses, barefoot, behind a chain-link fence. Their faces are brutalized.

title: New Cost for Some Smokers and Drinkers
description: On a sunny day in its parks and on its street corners, Hells Kitchen in Manhattan can be a parade of connoisseurs of low-end cigars and cheap malt liquor.

title: The Slow Hands of a Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Pigs Feet Fly?
description: IN this age of rapidly rising restaurant prices, its heartening to find a new place that serves a nine-course tasting menu for $40. The portions arent Lilliputian, the folks who work there are friendly and attentive and nothing on the  la carte menu costs more than $12.

title: A Neighbor Joins the Revival of Jamaica Avenue
description: The Dermot Company, a real estate developer in Manhattan, often invests in historic buildings and emerging neighborhoods. Three years ago, it took on both challenges when its development proposal to remake the old Queens Family Court building in downtown Jamaica was accepted by the New York City Economic Development Corporation.

title: A Restaurateur Bets on the Ribs and a Lucky 13
description: THE mantra of real estate investing has always been that success is dependent on three variables: location, location, location. Steven Levy, a 62-year-old former stockbroker, hopes its less vital to the restaurant business.

title: More Than Rock n Roll: U2 on Tour in 3-D Images
description: The musical documentary U2 3D, which stitches together three performances by this Irish rock band during a recent tour of South America, is not merely a technical landmark  shot entirely in digital 3D  but also an aesthetic one, in that its the first Imax movie that deserves to be called a work of art.

title: Pete Candoli, Trumpeter and Studio Musician, Dies at 84
description: Pete Candoli, a jazz trumpeter who made his mark as a high-note specialist in the big-band era and went on to become one of the busiest studio musicians in Hollywood, died on Jan. 11 at his home in Studio City, Calif. He was 84.

title: France: Not Yet Married to Sarkozy
description: The Italian fashion-model-turned-singer Carla Bruni said in an interview that she and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France are not married, quashing rumors that there had been a secret wedding ceremony in the lyse Palace. The newspaper Libration quoted Ms. Bruni as saying that she was not yet married. But she strongly suggested it would happen, adding, even if this is in our plans. She also said she would not accompany Mr. Sarkozy on his official visit later this week to India. I cannot take part in an official visit with the president, she said, without mentioning the protocol issues the relationship could have posed. She said that she was planning to begin recording her next album next month.

title: High Mercury Levels Are Found in Tuna Sushi
description: Recent laboratory tests found so much mercury in tuna sushi from 20 Manhattan stores and restaurants that at most of them, a regular diet of six pieces a week would exceed the levels considered acceptable by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Recipe: Iron Pot Chicken
description: 3 tablespoons fish sauce

title: Night Shift Has Long Ties to Corruption
description: Since the days of Teddy Roosevelt, the New York City Police Department has faced problems with lax supervision in the early morning hours, when officers prone to corruption or laziness face few challenges, and even fewer commanders.

title: Cuba: Will Castro Return?
description: Ricardo Alarcn, the National Assembly president, said in an interview that he expected Fidel Castro to be nominated for president on Feb. 24 when the new Parliament meets, but expressed uncertainty over whether he would accept the post again. Its obvious that he has been very successful in the recovery process, but he has the right to say yes or no, Mr. Alarcn said.

title: Seeking Room to Rock Where Cost of Space Just Keeps Rising
description: It is something many musicians hate to do but have to do, and now they hate it even more. Rehearsing can be tedious and time-consuming, and in New York City, musicians say it is more expensive than ever.

title: Anxiety Crashes the Party at Davos
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  There was George Soros hunched over a dinner table, deep in conversation with a nodding companion. Howard Stringer of Sony ran into Mickey Schulhof, who once ran Sonys American arm. And Klaus Schwab, the impresario of the World Economic Forum, welcomed an A-list crowd to a twinkling ballroom at the Hotel Belvedere.

title: ABC Drama Takes on Science and Parents
description: LOS ANGELES  A new legal drama making its debut this month on ABC is stepping into a subject that is the source of heated debate among some parents  the relationship between autism and childhood vaccines  and seemingly coming down on the side that has been all but dismissed by prominent scientific organizations.

title: Congos Death Rate Unchanged Since War Ended
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Five years after Congos catastrophic war officially ended, the rate at which people are dying in the country remains virtually unchanged, according to a new survey, despite the efforts of the worlds largest peacekeeping force, billions of dollars in international aid and a historic election that revived democracy after decades of violence and despotism.

title: Judge Delays Curlin Auction
description: A judge refused to force an auction of an ownership stake in Curlin, the Horse of the Year, saying the request has been made too soon. Special Judge Roger Crittenden left the door open for 418 people to pursue a 20 percent ownership stake. The judge made his decision during a hearing on Tuesday after concluding that the plaintiffs did not have enough information about the assets of the lawyers William Gallion and Shirley Cunningham Jr. The two men are accused of bilking former clients out of at least $42 million in a $200 million settlement involving the diet drug Fen-phen.

title: Stocks Surge, Erasing Big Losses, at End of Volatile Day
description: This week, investors were bracing for Black Tuesday. Instead, they got Whiplash Wednesday.

title: An Adult Soul Amid Cookies, Hugs, Puppets and Song
description: Fittingly, North opens with snow, but the static kind: television sets full of blurry patterns dot the small stage of the Club at La MaMa E.T.C. When the storm clears, a lone figure is revealed onscreen, exploring a wintry shoreline.

title: Legislation on Economy Will Start in House
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional leaders agreed Tuesday that the House would take the lead on legislation intended to stabilize the economy, giving the speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and Representative John A. Boehner, the Republican leader, primary responsibility for reaching an agreement with the White House.

title: Pittsburgh Perseveres Without Injured Starters
description: The anecdotes are almost too many to tell. Pittsburgh, a program already known for hard-nosed basketball, has overcome so much physical pain and so many obstacles that its season already sounds like folklore.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article in Science Times on Tuesday about politics in some species of animals was published out of order. The top of the second column of type, above the illustration, is continued at the top of the third column, followed by the bottom of the third column, the bottom of the second column and the top of the fourth column.

title: Calendar
description: Singing, Eating

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a new television advertisement in Spanish for the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney misstated the value of his company, Bain Capital, at the beginning of his tenure there. It was $36 million, not $6 billion.

title: Web Site Assembles U.S. Prewar Claims
description: WASHINGTON  Students of how the Bush administration led the nation into the Iraq war can now go online to browse a comprehensive database of top officials statements before the invasion, connecting the dots between hundreds of claims, mostly discredited since then, linking Saddam Hussein to Al Qaeda or warning that he possessed forbidden weapons.

title: Russias Gazprom Takes Control of Serbian Oil Monopoly
description: BERLIN  Serbia announced Tuesday that Russia has bought Serbias oil monopoly, the latest in Russias recent string of energy acquisitions. The deal will also allow Moscow to send more natural gas to Europe through its South Stream pipeline.

title: Rangers Mix Up Lines, Then Put It All Together
description: For the first 17 minutes of Tuesday nights game at Madison Square Garden, the Atlanta Thrashers hardly seemed to know what hit them. The Rangers were fiercely charging up ice on every possession. They battled for nearly every puck. This did not seem to be the team that had been drawing raised eyebrows around the N.H.L. for its lackluster record and turnover-filled games.

title: Wachovias Big-City Splash Has a Sobering Aftermath
description: In yet another concrete sign of trouble in the commercial real estate market, Wachovia, the nations fourth-largest bank, announced on Tuesday that it would be taking write-downs of more than $1 billion for commercial loans for the second half of last year. That sum includes $488 million in previously disclosed write-downs for the third quarter.

title: Giants Guarantee No Guarantees
description: Up close, Amani Toomer could see and hear the winning coach hyperventilating with joy. That is his most vivid memory of his only Super Bowl, or, as of now, his first Super Bowl.

title: City Parents Boycotting Added Tests at 2 Schools
description: New York City public school students have taken English tests for years. Math tests, too. This year, 10 diagnostic tests have been added to the menu in the hope that they will improve results on the real thing.

title: China Offers Plan to Clean Up Its Polluted Lakes
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government unveiled a detailed plan on Tuesday to limit pollution in Chinas lakes by 2010 and return them to their original state by 2030.

title: Lincoln Center Offers a Season of Russians, Romeos, Kafka and Woolf
description: Valery Gergiev is returning to Avery Fisher Hall next season with another Russian survey course.

title: No Country and There Will Be Blood Lead Oscars
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Hollywood is in a bleak mood this year, and the Oscar nominees announced Tuesday morning reflected that state of mind.

title: Star Light, Star Bright, Remake My Home Tonight
description: If you have never seen a certain kind of reality show or read a tabloid or heard about an actress demanding that her trailer be spritzed with Arpege 10 times a day, then Hollywood Residential will have something to say to you. It will feel like CNN.

title: Recipe: Sweet Gorgonzola Fondue
description: 1 garlic clove, halved

title: A World Right Around the Corner From Hell
description: Its no disgrace that Almost an Evening, the new bill of bite-size plays by Ethan Coen, lives up to the modesty of its title.

title: In a Reversal, AK Steel Reports Profit
description: CINCINNATI (AP)  AK Steel Holding said Tuesday that it swung to a fourth-quarter profit in contrast to a loss a year ago, when it took a one-time charge for employee health care benefits during a long lockout at its biggest mill.

title: Thompson Ends Campaign for G.O.P. Nomination
description: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.  Fred D. Thompson, the former senator from Tennessee, dropped out of the Republican race for president on Tuesday after a third-place primary showing on Saturday in South Carolina, a state he had hoped to win when he entered the race riding a wave of optimism among conservatives looking for a strong general election candidate.

title: Recipe: Italian Fonduta
description: 2 tablespoons unsalted butter

title: To Cut Costs, NBC Universal Ends Pilots
description: Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, said Tuesday the broadcaster was moving to save as much as $50 million a year by reducing its reliance on expensive pilots of new series on the NBC television channel.

title: Commercial Fishing
description: To the Editor:

title: Spitzer Plans Cuts and Fees to Close Deficit of $4.4 Billion
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer on Tuesday proposed an array of taxes and fees and almost $1 billion in health care cuts, and scaled back plans for new education aid and property tax relief, in an effort to close a budget deficit estimated at $4.4 billion.

title: A Last Goodbye for a Man Whose Body Was Rolled Down a Sidewalk
description: It seemed fitting that the last goodbye for Virgilio Cintron took place at Sacred Heart of Jesus Roman Catholic Church. It was the place where a far different future for Mr. Cintron was undoubtedly envisioned.

title: Senior Bowl Opens N.F.L. Scouting Season
description: MOBILE, Ala.  Romeo Crennel spoke softly into a digital recorder as he watched some of the top prospects for the coming N.F.L. draft go through drills and workouts Tuesday morning.

title: Dartmouth Joins Push to Reduce Costs for Middle Class
description: HANOVER, N.H. (AP)  Dartmouth College announced on Tuesday that beginning in the fall undergraduates from families with incomes less than $75,000 would receive free tuition.

title: Origins of The Great Moderation
description: James Stock, a Harvard economist, coined the phrase the great moderation while writing a research paper with Mark Watson of Princeton earlier in this decade. You can read the paper  Has the Business Cycle Changed and Why  here.

title: Democrats Try to Delay Eavesdropping Vote
description: WASHINGTONSenate Democrats concede that they probably lack the votes needed to stop a White House-backed plan to give immunity to phone utilities that helped the National Security Agencys eavesdropping, and they are seeking to put off the vote for another month.

title: Feds Action Stems Sell-Off in World Markets
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, confronted by deepening panic in global financial markets about a possible recession in the United States, struck back on Tuesday morning with the biggest one-day reduction of interest rates on record and at least temporarily stopped a vertigo-inducing plunge in stock prices.

title: Throngs Gather in City as News Spreads at the Speed of Technology
description: Hundreds of fans, curiosity seekers and news crews gathered in front of Heath Ledgers home in SoHo on Tuesday night, spilling into the street as the police struggled to keep one lane open for traffic and roped off a sidewalk path to the door.

title: Tuesday on the Trail
description: The remaining Republican candidates campaigned in Florida, and the Democrats were back on the trail after a debate.

title: Video: Winding Down at Sundance
Gretzky and Brady and Arizona
description: Six degrees of Tom Brady and Wayne Gretzky. Gretzky won four Stanley Cups. Brady is expected to win his fourth Super Bowl ring. Brady broke a record this season by throwing 50 touchdown passes. In 1981, Gretzky broke a record by scoring 50 goals in 39 games.

title: Dr. Z and Dr. David Banner
description: Tom Brady ditched his walking boot, and his injury doesnt appear to be serious. (If you click the link, youll probably find Gisele Bundchens boots more compelling.)

title: Zaha Hadid
description: Images of selected works from the architect's career.

title: Inside the Giants: Tiki Talks
description: A lot of fans have wondered just how Tiki Barber feels, watching his old team get to the Super Bowl the season after he retired. Thanks to the Sirius N.F.L. radio show that he co-hosts with his brother, Buccaneers cornerback Ronde Barber, now we know. Some excerpts, courtesy of Sirius, from Tuesday nights, The Barber Shop.

title: Fine Points | A Hand-Held Reporting for Duty
description: The pilot's bag goes civilian.

title: The $20,000 Coffee Maker, Step by Step
description: A look at how the Japanese siphon bar at the Blue Bottle Caf in San Francisco is used to brew coffee.

title: Field Bunches Up at Corus
The (Unlisted) Hot Tickets at Davos
description: Davos may seem like it is all about the big theatrically produced panels and presentations, like Bill Gates planned speech this year schedule titled A New Approach to Capitalism in the 21st Century. But the hottest tickets  and the hardest to come by  arent on the schedule at all.

title: Lessons in Democracy and Modesty
description: The world must be changing when on a World Economic Forum panel on geopolitics you have three Asians, two Europeans and just one American (even though that American was called Power  the Harvard professor Samantha Power).

title: Davos in the Papers: Crisis Management, Googles New Friend
description: The day before the official kick-off of the World Economic Forum in Davos Switzerland, it seemed like just another meeting of the worlds most exclusive talk shop, held each January in this Alpine ski resort.

title: Wachovias Big-City Splash Has a Sobering Aftermath
description: In yet another concrete sign of trouble in the commercial real estate market, Wachovia, the nations fourth-largest bank, announced on Tuesday that it would be taking write-downs of more than $1 billion for commercial loans for the second half of last year. That sum includes $488 million in previously disclosed write-downs for the third quarter.

title: Hedge Fund Founder Sentenced for Fraud
description: A founder of several Bayou Management hedge funds was sentenced to more than four years in prison Tuesday for a scheme to defraud investors.

title: Bird Flu  Still a Simmering Biological Bomb
description: For many years, Donald G. McNeil has been covering the grim toll wrought by infectious diseases in developing countries, and the global threat some pathogens pose in our increasingly interconnected world. In Science Times this week, he provides a valuable update on the H5N1 virus behind recent outbreaks of avian flu. While out of the headlines, it remains a simmering threat that, experts say, needs far more attention than it is getting. He took some time to explore the issue with me for Dot Earth readers. Please feel free to post any additional questions you may have, or comments, and Ill forward them to him.Q. That was a fine summary today of the bird flu situation, which seems to be on simmer, not boil, but hardly a non-threat at this point. This is a risk I want to explore on Dot Earth because its one of the potential hard knocks we face in a world of growing populations and mobility.

title: Ambac Looks at Alternatives After $3.26 Billion Loss
description: The Ambac Financial Group, one of the largest companies that insures against bond losses, said Tuesday that it was exploring strategic alternatives as it announced a $3.26 billion loss for its fourth quarter.

title: Chief of eBay Is Expected to Retire
description: An era at eBay is about to end.

title: Buffetts Berkshire Takes 3% Stake in Swiss Re
description: Swiss Reinsurance, the biggest reinsurer in the world, said the billionaire investor Warren Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway took a 3 percent stake and will assume a share of its non-life business, giving Swiss Res shares their biggest spike in four years.

title: Will eBay Ring Up Sales of Its Own?
description: With eBays chief executive, Meg Whitman, reportedly on the verge of retiring, attention will no doubt now turn to how her heir apparent, John Donahoe, will move to recharge the online auctioneers business  and its lackluster stock price.

title: Russias Gazprom Takes Control of Serbian Oil Monopoly
description: Serbia announced Tuesday that Russia had bought Serbias oil monopoly, the latest in Russias recent string of energy acquisitions. The deal will also allow Moscow to send more natural gas to Europe through its South Stream pipeline.

title: American Capital Flips Exstream to H.P.
description: American Capital Strategies is selling Exstream Software, an enterprise technology maker, to Hewlett-Packard only seven months after acquiring the company.

title: Index Closes First Late-Stage Venture Fund
description: In a move highlighting the growth of the European venture capital market, Index Ventures has closed its first fund targeting later-stage investments, a 400 million euro ($585 million) vehicle from which the firm may invest as much as 50 million euros in target companies.

title: 3i Leads $117 Million Investment in Gain Capital
description: The 3i Group has led a $117 million equity investment in an online foreign exchange service, the Gain Capital Group, which will provide growth capital for the company and liquidity for earlier investors.

title: China Mobile Plans I.P.O.
description: China Mobile Communications hopes to launch a domestic A-share listing as soon as possible, its chief executive, Wang Jianzhou, said Wednesday on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Tripwire Considers an I.P.O
description: With 2007 revenue approaching $50 million and a third year of profits in the books, Tripwire is better positioned to go public, according to the companys chief executive, Jim Johnson.

title: LBO France Said to Mull Sale of Cegelec
description: A private equity shop, LBO France, is considering selling its electrical contracting and IT group, Cegelec after receiving an approach for the business, according to The Deal.com.

title: Cenkos Pulls Close Brothers Bid
description: Cenkos, the British small and mid-cap securities broker, has decided to withdraw its offer for the British independent merchant bank Close Brothers.

title: Fortress Calls in MFS Loan
description: A hedge fund, the Fortress Investment Group has demanded repayment for its loan to the troubled Australian property and funds group MFS, The Australian Financial Review reported.

title: Fifth Third Reassures on First Charter Deal
description: Fifth Third offered some assurance on its earnings conference call Tuesday that its $1.1 billion merger with First Charter will go forward.

title: Times Company Joins $29.5 Million Round for WordPress Owner
description: Automattic, the commercial arm of the popular WordPress publishing platform for blogs, has received $29.5 million in financing from four companies, including a small portion from The New York Times Company.

title: How Does RiskMetrics Measure Up?
description: The RiskMetrics initial public offering is scheduled for this week. According to The Wall Street Journal, it could be a bellwether for this years I.P.O. market.

title: After Losses, BofAs Lewis Welcomes Rate Cut
description: The upheaval in the mortgage market, a slowing economy and an increasingly stretched consumer have made the last few quarters among the toughest since Kenneth D. Lewis, the chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, took over in 2001.

title: Quantcast Collects $20 Million in Second Round
description: A Web analytics start-up, Quantcast announced a $20 million second round of funding on Tuesday led by the Founders Fund and Polaris Venture Partners.

title: Insurance for Hedge Fund Investors
description: Amid a spate of allegations of fraud at hedge funds, a London-based firm has created fraud insurance for investors.

title: London May Lose $9 Billion Rusal I.P.O. to Hong Kong
description: United Company Rusal, the worlds largest aluminum producer, is considering shifting its initial public offering of more than $9 billion from the London Stock Exchange to Hong Kong amid souring relations between Britain and Russia and proposals for tougher British listing rules.

description: Britains biggest hedge fund managers have outlined plans to bolster standards on disclosure, valuation and risk management in an attempt to clean up the image of the industry.

title: Work/Life Balance  How Do You Do It?
description: I took that two-week, nonworking vacation and now Im paying for it. Aside from one prewritten blog post, I didnt plan ahead for the work that was awaiting me. So I came home, in the middle of a week, in need of two doctor visits to deal with trip-related maladies. My desk, clean when I left, quickly became a jumble of work stuff and personal bills, all vying for my attention. In the next three weeks, I have business travel, family responsibilities and a few more deadlines than usual. I worked through my first weekend back, and Im likely to do the same next weekend (on top of taking a business trip).

title: U.S. and China Still Sparring, But Smiling
description: After the geopolitics session saw a Chinese panelist offering lessons in democracy and an American speaker underscoring modesty, Chinese and American experts clashed  if good-naturedly, for the most part  during an economics-laden discussion Wednesday on whether the rest of the world still catches a cold if the United States sneezes.

title: Correction: Winter Day Out in Washington, D.C.
description: An article last Friday about what to do for a perfect winter weekend day in Washington referred imprecisely to the history of the Old Ebbitt Grill. It was founded in 1856 and moved to its current location in 1983; it was not built in 1856.

title: Museum Clubbing in Berlin
description: Berlin has never had a problem mixing traditional cultural attractions with more offbeat ones. This has birthed events like the Yellow Lounge, where string quartets play for the retro-sneakered and shawled set in clubs around the city; or performances by ballet troupes at the former transformer station that now houses the legendary Panorama bar.

title: A $200-a-Gram Tax on Cocaine
description: Among the hundreds of proposals contained in Gov. Eliot Spitzers second executive budget, which he unveiled on Tuesday in Albany, is a provision that would impose a $3.50-a-gram tax on marijuana and a $200-a-gram tax on other illegal drugs, like cocaine.We took a look at the fine print to better understand the details of this legislative proposal  which, incidentally, is very similar to a proposal that Mayor Edward I. Koch put forward in 1988. (That proposal, to tax illegal drugs in New York City, also at a rate of $200 a gram, did not come to fruition.)

title: Republicans, Lost in Space
description: Even by election-year standards, the current field of Republican candidates has been doing some truly ambitious pandering. First, Mitt Romney told the autoworkers in Michigan that he could get all their jobs backno problem, consider it done. Then, Mike Huckabee told South Carolinians that it was nobodys business but theirs if they wanted to wallpaper their public buildings with the Confederate flag. And now here comes Rudolph W. Giuliani to show these amateurs how its done. Campaigning in his make-or-break state of Florida last week, Mr. Giuliani released a statement promising to make space a priority. Apparently, America is facing a crisis far greater than health care or education reform: when the current fleet of space shuttles is retired in 2010, its going to take as much as five yearsfive years, people!before we can send another guy into orbit. This is not acceptable, Mr. Giuliani said. America should be number one in space. We have been. We shouldnt lose that position. In other words, it would be as if a guy had the number one position in all the national polls and then suddenly  well, you get the idea.

title: Davos and the iPhone Effect
description: In Silicon Valley, it may be all-iPhone-all-the-time, but here among the worlds business elites in Davos, its still very much a RIM Blackberry world. Indeed, if you pull an iPhone out of your pocket, it still creates a mild sensation here, because unlike in the United States, most Europeans have yet to touch Apples six-month-old handheld phenomenon.

But already Ford is well into another overhaul of the Taurus, which it plans to unveil next year.

description: La Compania Tango X2, a Buenos Aires based dance company performing at City Center, holds a late night tango party in SoHo. Melena Ryzik reports (in heels).

title: Kovalainen faster than Hamilton
description: Todays Formula One testing times in Valencia are enough to get the mouth watering and the heart beating hard in anticipation for the start to the season on 16 March. At the top of the time sheets we find Heikki Kovalainen, followed by the two Ferraris, Felipe Massa and then Kimi Raikkonenand then Lewis Hamilton in fourth. And the pattern of the teammates who were supposed to be faster but werent does not stop there: In fifth in a Williams we find Kazuki Nakajima, with Nico Rosberg in the other Williams finishing behind Fernando Alonso in the Renault.

title: Kucinich Starts New Impeachment Drive
description: Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio may get excluded from Democratic presidential debates, as he has been recently, but no one can deny him the floor in the House.

title: Fundamantals Are Strong, She Says
description: DAVOS, Switzerland

title: Barack Obama on the Economy
description: CNBC interviews democratic presidential candidate Sen. Barack Obama about his plan for the economy.

title: Sundance Film Festival: Last Dance at Sundance
description: Josh Groban, Felicity Huffman (Photo: George Frey/EPA)

title:
Living with Music:
A Playlist by David Rothenberg
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: Mitt Romney on the Economy
description: CNBC interviews Mitt Romney, Republican presidential candidate, on his economic agenda.

title: The War Is Your Secret
description: One of our readers, David Bishop, has verged into J.D. Salinger , citing Binxs Holden Caulfieldish superiority, his unphoniness. That gives me a convenient hook for mentioning that Salingers Franny and Zooey was one of the books that The Moviegoer beat out for the National Book Award in 1962 (Catch-22 was another). And Binx indeed has much in common with Holden, who is after all a moviegoer, too.

title: Another Dubious Achievement From Esquire
description: From the New York Observer:

title: Trial in Sean Bell Shooting Will Stay in Queens
description: A state appellate court has rejected an effort by defense lawyers to move the trial of three New York City police detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell, who was fatally shot in Queens on Nov. 25, 2006, hours before he was to be married.

title: Silverman Doesnt Worry About Reveille Relationship
description: In todays New York Times, Stuart Elliott cites new examples of product placements on reality television shows.

title: Southwest and the Airline Industry
description: CNBC interviews Gary Kelly, chief executive of Southwest Airlines, on the state of the airline industry.

title: Private Equity and the Economy
description: CNBC interviews John Snow, chairman of Cerberus Capital Management and former treasury secretary, on private equity and the state of the economy.

title: Seeing Signs of Systemic Failure
description: This is not a normal crisis, George Soros, the hedge fund pioneer turned philosopher, said today to a group of reporters he had invited to lunch at the World Economic Forum. It is the end of an era.

title: If I Wrote This on a Typewriter
description: If I wrote this on a type writerNever would I knowThat typewriter is just one word.Computer told me so.If I wrote this on a typewriterIt would not be trueThat words could be many colors.Thats from computer, too.If I wrote this on a typewriterYoud be missing outOn text effects like this and that.Computers work, no doubt.If I wrote this on a typewriterItd be sad for sure.This would still be spelled like tihs;Spellcheck-less spellings poor.Good thing I write on a computerThe payoff is immense.For if I wrote with typewritersThis poem would not make sense.

title: The Late Deciders
description: In her Web column today, Janet Elder writes about an elusive group of voters who can upend campaigns:

title: In the Polls: A Tight Race in New Jersey
description: A new Quinnipiac University poll in New Jersey finds a close Republican race, with many Republican voters not strongly committed to their choices.

title: The Great Deal Spread of 2008
description: Is it the greatest arbitrage opportunity of the century? There currently appear to be more than 20 pending transactions with deal spreads greater than 10 percent.

title: Finding bin Laden: Musharraf Sniffs, a Filmmaker Whiffs
description: The White Houses desire to find Osama bin Laden continues to be strong, with reported plans for a new covert push within Pakistan emerging in The New York Times earlier this month. But the leader of that country, President Pervez Musharraf, sounds sick and tired of hearing about the Al Qaeda chief.

title: The Latest Strike Casualty: Pilot Episodes
description: Every day, it seems, the television industry feels the effects of the ongoing writers strike in new ways.

title: Tickets by Any Means Necessary
description: Last week, before I left the United States, my friends in Ghana had been trying to explain to me the frenzy over tickets. My friend John Rue, who has been living in Ghana and had been searching for tickets nearly full-time, said last Thursday in an e-mail that the Ghanaian Embassy in Washington was selling tickets and that I needed to get there ASAP. Getting tickets in Ghana, especially for games involving the host team and countries in West Africa such as Ivory Coast, Cameroon and Nigeria, has been extremely difficult, my friend told me.

title: A History of Good Taste
description: In my column in todays newspaper I wrote about the wine panels recent tasting of some inexpensive Napa cabernets, if you can call wines $50 and under inexpensive. They are by Napa standards, where mediocre cabernets run $50 to $150 as a matter of course. Although we found wines we liked the tasting was disappointing on the whole. Not because so many wines were bad but because so many were boring and innocuous, with a sort of generic plush, smooth fruitiness.

title: Which Cities Pass Go and Collect Global Acclaim?
description: In recent years, New York and London have been dueling for the title of capital of the 21st century. Now Monopoly  thats right, the Hasbro board game  is allowing the world to cast a vote in an online contest that will determine which 22 cities will be immortalized in a new global edition of the 75-year-old board game.The contest began at midnight Greenwich Mean Time, or about 7 p.m., on Monday night. As of today, London and New York are in the top two positions, with Paris just a smidgen behind New York. The top winner will be awarded the Boardwalk position, while No. 2 will get Park Place. The new game is scheduled to be unveiled in August.

title: Kathleen Turner: Hold Susan Collins Accountable for the Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court has lurched far to the right in recent years, as President Bush has nominated Justices favored by the most conservative elements of the Republican Party. This shift has occurred in large part because moderate Republicans have voted in virtual lockstep with the administration on judicial nominations.

title: John Edwards, Funny Guy
description: Former Senator John Edwards did not receive an endorsement from David Letterman on CBSs The Late Show Tuesday night, but he did receive eight valuable minutes to woo voters.

title: Amid the Gloom, Calls for Optimism
description: When a government official starts talking about good economic fundamentals, you know something has gone wrong.

title: What Does It Cost to Get Into Davos?
description: Getting an invitation to the annual meeting at the World Economic Forum is considered an honor for most  but it sure doesnt come cheap.

title: Land Grabs
description: Of all the odd and ugly moments at the Democratic debate Monday night, the one that might have most mystified viewers was Hillary Clintons reference to Barack Obamas work for a Chicago slum landlord named Tony Rezko.

title: January 3, 2001
description: Aha. I thought I remembered something parallel to recent action.

title: What Do You Live By?
description: Readers points are striking home. Heres one, from the novelist Thomas McGuane, about Aunt Emilys big speech near the end of the book, which Jonathan described as in essence, an apologia for the values of the Old South and its class-based notions of chivalry and mutual interdependence:

title: Idols Ratings Luster Fades, But It Still Carries the Night
description: Tuesdays San Diego auditions of American Idol, with the usual mixture of the talented and the cringe-worthy, attracted 29.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, lifting Fox with ease into first place in the nights ratings.

title: Colonial Update
description: Theres a new twist in the tale of Inmobiliaria Colonial, Spains second largest property company. GE Real Estate, the property arm of General Electric, is confirming its interest in a possible takeover of the troubled company. This comes just a month after Colonial acknowledged merger talks with French company Gencia, and two weeks after the companys value plunged 40 percent and its founders were ousted.

title: Pa. Governor Backs Clinton
description: PHILADELPHIA  Pennsylvania Gov. Ed Rendell threw his political weight behind Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential candidacy on Wednesday afternoon, after months of courting by both Clintons, who hope that Mr. Rendells endorsement can give her a boost in the New Jersey and Delaware primaries on Feb. 5.

title: Skeletal Remains Discovered in Washington Sq. Park
description: Updated, 6:31 p.m. | Mostly intact skeletal remains from at least four people were discovered this morning by city archaeologists doing soil testing as part of a restoration of Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village, city officials said. The discovery could have significance for scholars studying the history of the early United States; the area of the park was used as a common burial ground, or potters field, from 1797 to 1826.

title: Picks and Pans From the Detroit Auto Show
description: With our coverage of the North American International Auto Show winding down, but while the show is still open to the public, here is a roundup of highlights and lowlights, as selected by some of The Timess writers and editors.

title: Sony Chief Says Dont Panic Yet
description: An increasing number of economists are predicting a recession in the United States, but some top executives here in Davos appear to be less dour. One of these executives is Sir Howard Stringer, chief executive of Sony, whom I interviewed as the World Economic Forum got underway on Wednesday.

title: Soft Serve  | A News Feed of Light Reading
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.As the global economy enters a tailspin, what better time to announce production of the Maybach 62 Landaulet  a convertible sports-car limo  that resembles a marshmallow and costs $1.19 million?  Heres one amenity Maybach engineers graciously omitted: a  La-Z-Boy jacuzzi in the trunk  If you cant drown your economic sorrows in the hot tub, drink a cup of joe from a  $20,000 coffee-maker Maybe the economy is okay after all  in Brooklyn a chic independent bookstore, Melville House, has just opened. Take that, Fox Books!  When times are hard, sometimes the only recourse is, well, shopping! White Lighting is crushing on lace-up wedge boots from Chlo Sevignys Opening Ceremony collection Speaking of footwear fetishism, two dudes from New Jersey were (are?) camped out in the freezing cold in front of a Foot Locker in Herald Square awaiting the new Air Jordan XX3 (23 get it?)  If youd like to remember more prosperous times, Allures Jessica Matlin has a notion: go for glitter! Like Mariah Carey, its back And so are we, tomorrow.

title: Party of what?
description: Um, Greg  I thought everyone knew that the party of ideas line came from Moynihan. The weirdness of Obamas use of the phrase came in the fact that he applied it to the Republican Party of the last 10 or 15 years, and suggested that the party of Tom DeLay and George W. Bush  a party that had nothing much to say except tax cuts good, terrorists bad  was challenging conventional wisdom.

title: Whos the Greenest of Them All?
description: We all love lists of winners and losers, and an obliging research team at Yale and Columbia has been trying to refine one that regularly ranks countries on their environmental performance. Switzerland is on top; Niger is dead last at 149th. The United States ranks 39th, below all of the other Group of 8 industrialized nations. By comparison, Albania is 25th, Russia 28th. Felicity Barringers story on the list, called an Environmental Performance Index, is online here.

title: Welcome to Our Bed and Breakfast
description: Once the house is finally finished we would love you to stop by and visit.

title: John Edwards Visits David Letterman
description: Former Senator John Edwards did not receive an endorsement from David Letterman on CBSs The Late Show Tuesday night, but he did receive eight valuable minutes to woo voters.

title: Menu Litterbugs Get the High-Five Sign
description: The vaguely threatening sign against menus that attracted attention this month is now available in an improved (and more grammatical) pentalingual version at Dangernomenus.com.

title: As the Price of Coffee Turns
description: As if Tuesdays market plunges werent enough to demoralize us all, The New York Timess Dining section followed up today with an article on a new insane price-point for your daily pick-me-up: At Last, a $20,000 Cup of Coffee.

title: New Green Brand for BMW?
description: According to Autocars Hilton Holloway, BMW  specifically, Stefan Krause, BMWs head of sales and marketing  is seriously considering starting up a new brand to build and sell a line of green vehicles:

title: Glenn Hutchins on Tech Buyouts
description: CNBC interviews Glenn Hutchins, co-founder of Silver Lake Partners, about the outlook for technology companies.

title: Clinton Goes Negative in South Carolina Radio Ad
description: ROCK HILL, S.C.  In the first negative candidate-to-candidate advertisement of the Democratic primary here, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday accused Senator Barack Obama of aligning himself with ideas of the Republican Party.

title: Barack Obama on the Economy
description: CNBC interviews democratic presidential candidate Sen. Barack Obama about his plan for the economy.

title: DAmato Explains His Support for McCain
description: Alfonse M. DAmato, a longtime kingmaker in Republican politics in New York State, said this week that he had decided to endorse Senator John McCain because he had the best chance of winning the White House in November, uniting the Republican Party and attracting independent and Democratic voters that none of the other candidates will be able to attract.

title: Police Give New Details on Ledger Death
description: Updated, 9:17 p.m. | The masseuse who discovered the body of Heath Ledger in a Manhattan apartment on Tuesday twice called a friend of his, the actress Mary-Kate Olsen, before calling 911, New York City police officials said on Wednesday. The officials, who provided new details about Mr. Ledgers death, emphasized that no illegal drugs were found in the apartment and that there were no obvious signs of suicide. Tests on a rolled-up $20 bill that was found in the apartment found no evidence that the bill had been used to handle drugs, they said.

title: Mitt Romney on the Economy
description: CNBC interviews Mitt Romney, Republican presidential candidate, on his economic agenda.

title: Gores Gay Marriage Gambit
description: Its widely agreed that Al Gore, private citizen, has done more to move the global political debate than Al Gore, elected official, ever did. Now Gore, who as vice president supported the Defense of Marriage Act, has put up a video on his Current TV Web site in which he stands up for gay marriage: Gay men and women ought to have the same rights as heterosexual men and women  to make contracts, to have hospital visiting rights, to join together in marriage, and I dont understand why it is considered by some people to be a threat to heterosexual marriage

title: Slipping Into a Recession?
description: Its not yet clear whether the nation as a whole has slipped into recession. But some parts of the country are clearly deep in the hole.

title: Sushi Eaters Weigh the Health Risks
description: Marian Burros reported in The Times on Wednesday that recent laboratory tests of tuna sushi from a sampling of stores and restaurants in Manhattan found high amounts of mercury. There was so much that a regular diet of six pieces a week would exceed the levels considered acceptable by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Davos avoidance
description: Im not at Davos. Partly this is because my wife and I really needed some quiet time together, before the semester starts. Partly its because textbook revision deadlines loom. But I also have to say that the scene at Davos, with all the great, good, wise, and, especially, rich gathered together to celebrate their greatness, goodness, wisdom, and, especially, wealth, has always made me uncomfortable. I usually end up skipping a couple of big dinner affairs and sneaking off to feast on the modern Swiss national dish  which is, of course, spaghetti carbonara.

title: Gore Defends Same-Sex Marriage
description: Taking a quick break from his environmental activism, Al Gore has spoken out on his Current TV site about same-sex marriage. Hes all for it.

title: An Interview With Howard Stringer
description: Andrew Ross Sorkin speaks to the chairman & CEO of Sony.

title: Sensing a U.S. Recession at Davos
description: Floyd Norris discusses the possible consequences of an American  recession.

title: The Moment of Truth
description: Beth, a participant on Fox's new show, discusses her role.

title: Edwards Appeals for the Rural Vote
description: Former Senator John Edwards devoted the day to traveling two-lane blacktops across the economically depressed northern arc of South Carolina, where he appealed to rural voters by telling them that as president he would not forget or neglect the state where he was born.

title: Your Comments on my China-Darfur Column
description: Id welcome your thoughts on my Thursday column, arguing that perhaps the best way to make progress on Darfur is to shame China. If you have other suggestions for how to make progress in Darfur (and also to reduce the risk of a new North-South war in Sudan), please post them as well.

title: So This Is It: Valentino
description: The ovation was still going as I moved toward the backstage, slowly and then at a brisk walk. I passed Marisa Berenson and Marie-Chantal of Greece, who was with her husband Pavlos and her in-laws, Queen Ann-Marie and King Constantine. I saw Uma ahead of me. I caught up with Uma in the backstage and asked her what she thought of the show, half embarrassed that I bothered. I have no comment to make at this time, she said, as if she had said it a million times before. Okay. Wouldnt beautiful have worked just as well? I turned away, toward the mob of photographers and models, all of them in identical red dresses, gathering with intensity around Valentino. Natalia V. had tears welling in her eyes. I saw Carlos Souza, who has done the press for Valentino for years, and I asked him if the girls were going to keep their red dresses. Theyd all came out in red for the finale. For sure! he said, watching Valentino and the mob. Later, I asked one of the models about it and the look she gave me said, Are you kidding?

title: Prominent Lawyer Is Fined by Ethics Board
description: The New York City Conflicts of Interest Board has fined Stanley K. Schlein, a prominent political lawyer, lobbyist and former chairman of the New York City Civil Service Commission, $15,000 for misusing city resources and personnel to perform work for his private law practice.

title: Close Quarters
description: The last batch of games before the N.H.L.s All-Star Break is to be played Thursday, and only 7 points separate the Devils, the first-place team in the Atlantic Division, from the Rangers, the last-place team. All five teams have more points than games played, and the Central Division is the only other division in the league with five teams in similar positions.

title: Lionsgate Poised to Make Deal With Writers
description: Lionsgate, the movie and television company, is soon expected to join the growing ranks of production houses that have signed independent deals with the Writers Guild of America.

title: A Crackdown on Cabbies Who Refuse Credit Cards
description: Watch out, cabbies. Your next fare could be an undercover agent for the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, posing as a passenger to check for rule violations. That includes a rule that passengers must be able to pay by credit card in certain cabs and a rule barring cabbies from chatting on cellphones while driving.

title: Scenes From a Hypothetical Puppet Show
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: The Unusual Suspects
description: While Cliff Fletcher puts together his best chicken salad recipe for the Maple Leafs, Richard Peddie, head of Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment, is leading the search for Torontos GM of the future.

title: Bloggingheads: Health Care Blowback
description:
Ruy Teixeira of the Center for American Progress, left, and Ross Douthat of the Atlantic debate the partisan politics of health care reform.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Goodbye Rudy, Tuesday
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Albert Einstein defined insanity as doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results. Flailing around Florida, Rudolph Giuliani is getting different results, just not the ones he wants. Call him a lot a things  weird, imperious, self-aggrandizing  but crazy he is not, at least by Einsteins notion.

title: CNBC Video: Silver Lakes Hutchins at Davos
description: With the future of private equity looking cloudy right now, pundits have speculated on what awaits the industry. CNBCs Maria Bartiromo interviewed Glenn Hutchins, the head of Silver Lake, at the World Economic Forum in Davos and got his thoughts.

title: Pessimistic Bulls, or Optimistic Bears?
description: It was an aptly named dinner debate on this first day of gloom and doom at the World Economic Forum: Recession, the title read in the forums program folder in bold red letters as if to drive home the point. After a day of debates dedicated to (or inevitably turning to) the United States economys sorry outlook, two high-profile chief executives joked that it felt like an act of masochism to end the day like this (rather than at the simultaneous wine-tasting or story-telling dinners).

title: A Writer Comes to Davos
description: Contrary to the stereotype, the folks at Davos are impressed by people other than hedge fund managers or captains of industry. They just might not always show it.

title: A New Age of Sail?
description: A parasail developed for the shipping industry could help cut fuel costs and carbon emissions.  (VIDEO CREDIT: DHL-Deutsche Post World Net)

title: ABC Debate Will Not Happen
description: ABC News on Wednesday scrapped plans for a three-person Republican presidential candidate debate, citing scheduling conflicts between John McCain, Mitt Romney and Mike Huckabee.

title: The Voice Behind Fired Up: Ready to Go
description: Weve been waiting a long time to bring you a video from our limited partnership with students involved in Campus Voices at Harvards Institute of Politics who were in New Hampshire throughout the runup to the primary.

title: A View on Private Equity From the Top
description: Theres no doubt that times are tough for private equity firms. But few men are in a better position to speak about whats next than Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman and chief executive of the Blackstone Group. In speaking with CNBCs Maria Bartiromo at the World Economic Forum, he said it was still too difficult to call an end to the credit markets tightening.

title: Continued Violence in Kenya
description: East Africa bureau chief Jeffrey Gettleman reports on continuing violence in Kenya.

title: CNBC Video: Kissinger on Globalization and Protectionism
description: If anything, the speed at which market turmoil swept across the globe demonstrates how much globalization has taken root. But at the same time, that erosion of national boundaries has also been reflected in the rise of sovereign wealth funds and their major investments in western financial institutions.

title: Purple States: Solutions for Health
description: Citizen reporters Tamara and Tanya talk to Democratic candidates campaigning in South Carolina about their health care proposals.

title: Scene From Curb Your Enthusiasm
description: Leon Black (JB Smoove) and Larry David accidentally switch cellphones.

title: Eddie Johnson Moves On
description: Its official  the American striker Eddie Johnson has joined his five compatriots at Fulham of the English Premier League; or Fulhamerica as it is coming to be known.

title: Giuliani's Florida Supporters
description: There's a difference, it seems, between Rudolph W. Giuliani's supporters in Florida who came from New York City and those who didn't.

title: Guild Board Member Predicts Detonation Day
description: Some decidedly mixed signals have been coming from union leaders to striking Writers Guild of America, West members for the last day.

title: American-Backed Sunni Militias
description: Attacks on American-backed predominantly Sunni militias threaten a fragile linchpin of the American strategy to pacify Iraq.

title: Look. Its a Freighter, a Sailboat. Its Both
description: In 1982, in my first journalism job, for Offshore Magazine, I got to interview Stinson Davis, a 100-year-old man in Five Islands, Maine, who was the last living captain of a ship powered entirely by sail. (He was hauling mahogany across the Atlantic from the Congo during World War I).

title: Weekend in New York
description: Seth Kugel explores Korean New York, whose cultural offerings extend far beyond food.

title: Continued Violence in Kenya
description: East Africa bureau chief Jeffrey Gettleman reports on continuing violence in Kenya.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,919 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday :

title: Providing Income While Promoting Education, Both College and Elementary
description: At an after-school program in Chinatown, fourth graders are reading My Side of the Mountain. Vocabulary words  downpour, snarl, cloudburst, reap  are written on the board.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Small, Shady and Eager

title: Playing Dress-Up With Barbie, With the Computer or Without
description: Aspiring fashion designers can now mix and match Barbies dresses, shoes and handbags using Barbie iDesign, the information-age equivalent of the paper doll.

title: Pinched by Price Controls, Power Plants in China Scale Back
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government issued an urgent notice on Wednesday to the countrys power generators, coal companies and railways to address an electricity shortage that has led to rationing in more than a third of Chinas provinces in recent weeks.

title: America Needs Frances Atomic Anne
description: Its not often that I find myself recommending a French state-owned industry as the answer to major U.S. problems, but I guess theres an exception to every rule.

title: Fourth Title Snatched From Fourth No-Trump
description: It is unusual in any sport for a player to win an event three years in a row. To win four consecutive years is almost unknown. But last week Jay Borker of Greenwich, Conn., won the Friday Open Pairs at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., for the fourth straight year with his fourth partner. This time he played with Doug Doub of West Hartford, Conn. They finished nearly two boards ahead of Arch McKellar of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Warren Rosner of White Plains. Third were Richard Laufer of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Faye Marino of Greenwich.

title: At Amateur Bullfights in Colombia, Alcohol and Blood Flow Freely
description: SINCELEJO, Colombia  The radio reporters huddled in a corner of the Red Cross tent on Sunday, waiting for the wounded to arrive on stretchers. They wanted details of the injuries. They were not disappointed.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: A Map in Decay and Renewal

title: Built to Fly Into Space With the Greatest of Ease (They Hope)
description: Virgin Galactic, the company that hopes to fly well-heeled tourists to the edge of space by the end of 2009, provided a peek Wednesday at the craft that will take them there.

title: Ex-Senator Cant Use Campaign Fund in Legal Case
description: TRENTON  A former state senator in New Jersey who is facing federal fraud and corruption charges cannot use money in his campaign account to pay for his criminal defense, a state commission said on Wednesday in a ruling that could establish a precedent for public officials and candidates facing criminal charges.

title: Edward D. Hoch, Writer of Over 900 Mystery Stories, Is Dead at 77
description: Edward D. Hoch, a crime writer who during his lifetime was widely believed to have been the worlds most prolific author of short mysteries, died last Thursday at his home in Rochester. He was 77.

title: Ambition Knows No Season
description: IN winter in Juneau, Alaska, snow blankets everything, bears hibernate and Grady Saunders, the owner of the Heritage Coffee Company, fills his schedule with trips to balmy coffee-growing parts of the world. He recently got back from a trip to Kona, Hawaii.

title: Filling the Void of a Vanished Window With Plants and Assorted Scenery
description: WITH so much condo construction in big cities in the last few years, some people are losing the light they had grown accustomed to.

title: Tuna Troubles
description: Here is a simple rule for life: the food you eat is only as safe as the environment it comes from. This is narrowly true, in that food from a dirty kitchen is likely to be unsafe. But its also true in the broadest sense. A good example is the tuna in sushi. Many New Yorkers have come to love the convenience, taste and aesthetic appeal of sushi. But as The Times reported Wednesday after testing tuna from 20 Manhattan stores and restaurants, sushi made from bluefin tuna may contain unacceptable levels of mercury, which acts as a neurotoxin. Every piece of that tuna, glistening on its bed of rice, is a report on the worrisome state of the oceans.

title: Practical Blood Pressure Advice, Too Often Shelved for Convenience
description: It tastes bland and can be a tough daily regimen to follow, so its not the ideal medicine for high blood pressure. But a low-salt, heart-healthy diet is staging a comeback as some 60-plus drugs fail to rein in staggering rates of hypertension in the United States.

title: Architects Next Prize: Michigan Museum
description: A Baghdad-born, London-based architect might not be the most obvious candidate for a commission in the heart of Middle America. But Zaha Hadid, who won the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004, has been chosen to design the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum at Michigan State University in East Lansing.

title: All Sides Now of a Seasoned Performer
description: The moon, like to a silver bow new-bent in heaven, reads Shakespeares poetic description of an enchanted evening in A Midsummer Nights Dream. Those words also evoke the sound and aura of the singer Judy Collins on a midwinter night. At Tuesdays opening performance of a six-week engagement at the Caf Carlyle her voice, clear and vibrato free but inflected with delicate little shivers, stole through the room like a shaft of light falling through a stained-glass window. When surrendering to the ethereal spell she casts, your impulse is to turn your head up, close your eyes and tune in to messages from far, far away.

title: In the South, Echoes of Jacksons Run
description: Nearly 25 years of social change, political realignment and demographic shifts separate the presidential candidacies of the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and Senator Barack Obama. Even so, there are echoes of 1984 as the battle for the Democratic nomination once again roars across the South, focused squarely on African Americans.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Monday about a change of commanders under consideration by the Pentagon misspelled the designation of an Army unit previously commanded by Lt. Gen. Peter W. Chiarelli, who might be selected to replace Gen. David H. Petraeus later this year as the top commander in Iraq. It is the First Cavalry Division, not Calvary. (Go to Article)

title: U.S. Envoy Wants Political Pact in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The American ambassador to Kenya said Wednesday that his deepest worries about the postelection crisis here were not about Kenyans rampaging in the streets or killing one another because of ethnic hatreds, both of which have claimed hundreds of lives.

title: Congo: Rebels Sign Deal to End Eastern Conflict
description: Rebel groups in eastern Congo signed a peace agreement with the government to end fighting in the last remaining war zone in the country. After a delay caused by last-minute objections from the rebel group, led by Laurent Nkunda, left, a Congolese Tutsi general, the sides agreed to a cease-fire, with the rebels to disarm eventually and join the national army under the supervision of a technical commission. More than 400,000 people have been forced from their homes in the past year by continuing violence in eastern Congo.

title: Correction: Generation Me vs. You Revisited
description: An article last Thursday about narcissistic behavior among young adults incorrectly attributed the following quotation to Plato: The children now love luxury. They have bad manners, contempt for authority; they show disrespect for elders and love chatter in place of exercise. Its origin is unclear, although many researchers agree that Plato is not the source.

title: Giuliani Finds Snowbird Friends in Florida, but Is He Winning Over Voters?
description: ESTERO, Fla.  Americas Mayor, Mr. Leadership himself, has just bathed in the applause of 400 mostly white-haired, mostly transplanted Northeasterners and he is about to spend four or five hours dialing for the dollars needed to keep his presidential campaign going.

title: No. 11 Oklahoma Routs Texas Tech
description: NORMAN, Okla. (AP)  Amanda Thompson scored 16 points and No. 11 Oklahoma rebounded from a rare home loss by routing Texas Tech, 78-39, on Wednesday night.

title: Home Prices Fell in 07 for First Time in Decades
description: It was a notable year for the housing industry, and not in a good way.

title: Starting Over, and Over, and Over
description: MANY domestic partnerships are unraveled by a renovation or, at the very least, sorely frayed by one. Yet, over 12 years and 3 huge projects, according to Michael Haverland, an architect, and Philip Galanes, a lawyer and novelist, their architectural and design collaborations have been the engine and the fuel of their life together.

title: Lil Wayne Arrested
description: The rapper Lil Wayne, below, was held at the Yuma County Sheriffs jail in Arizona on Wednesday after being booked on three felony drug charges, The Associated Press reported. His real name is Dwayne Michael Carter Jr. Lil Wayne, 25, was accused of possession of dangerous drugs, narcotics and drug paraphernalia, the authorities said.

title: Pitt Routs St. Johns; Rutgers Tops Villanova
description: With two injured starters sidelined and with few able bodies on its bench, Pittsburgh seemed ripe for the taking Wednesday night, but St. Johns was, instead, soundly beaten. Just now getting into the heart of the Big East portion of its schedule, the Red Storm is having a bad season that only figures to get worse.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Thursday about efforts in public high schools to improve preparation of students for college or for some form of post-secondary school training described incorrectly the economic makeup of the school district of Prince Georges County in Maryland, where such efforts are being made. Nearly half of its students receive free and reduced-price lunches, a measure of income; the district is not overwhelmingly low-income.

title: Clemenss House Interview Delayed
description: Roger Clemenss interview with staff for the House Oversight committee has been pushed back 10 days, rescheduled to Feb. 5 from Saturday, the committee announced Thursday.

title: Newark Editor Sues Police, Charging Rights Violation
description: NEWARK  The editor of a Brazilian community newspaper who said he was detained by the police in September sued the Police Department on Wednesday, saying that his rights were violated when officers demanded that he hand over photographs of a crime scene and handcuffed him to a bench when he refused.

title: Surgical Treatment for Diabetes
description: Evidence is accumulating that the best treatment for Type 2 diabetes related to obesity may well be the most drastic: stomach-shrinking surgery, perhaps accompanied by intestinal rearrangements. That such extreme remedies would even be considered is a measure of how intractable the intertwined epidemics of obesity and diabetes have become in the United States.

title: Reflections on Time and the Relationships It May Never Heal
description: At her best, Karole Armitage marries the fluidity and dynamism of certain contemporary European ballet choreographers with an austerity and classicism that bring to mind George Balanchine, or Merce Cunningham, in whose company she danced. At her worst, the marriage fails, succumbing to a fussy preciosity.

title: By the Numbers: Tigers Superiority
description: For all of the accolades and superlatives heaped upon Tiger Woods, none speak louder than his stats. Last year, Woods won the Vardon Trophy for the best scoring average on the PGA Tour -- the seventh time he has won it -- shooting one-and-a-half strokes better per round than Ernie Els, the runner up. Yes, that separation is impressive; more than 30 golfers averaged within one stroke of Els. But the PGA Tour's scoring average can actually understate Woods's superiority over his top rivals, many of whom will try to stop Woods from winning his fourth straight Buick Invitational this weekend.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Observatory column in Science Times on Jan. 8 about a study of parasitic butterfly larvae that infect two species of ants misidentified the journal in which the findings appeared. It was Science, not Nature.

title: Justice Nomination Seen as Snub to Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department lawyer who wrote a series of classified legal opinions in 2005 authorizing harsh C.I.A. interrogation techniques was renominated by the White House on Wednesday to a senior department post, a move that was seen as a snub to Senate Democrats who have long opposed his appointment.

title: All-Mail Vote in Colorado Isnt Needed, Governor Says
description: DENVER  Coloradans will not be required to vote by mail in November, Gov. Bill Ritter Jr. said Wednesday in announcing a one-year emergency repair plan for the states voting system.

title: Entry Process Is Simplified at City Schools
description: Trying to simplify the often bewildering process of enrolling children in prekindergarten and kindergarten classes in New York City and to make it more fair, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced Wednesday that he would standardize applications and deadlines citywide.

title: Autopsy on Actor Is Inconclusive as Calls for Help Are Revealed
description: The cause of the actor Heath Ledgers death could take two weeks to determine, the New York City medical examiners office said on Wednesday. An autopsy was conducted Wednesday morning, but the results were inconclusive and blood and tissue tests need to be completed, said Ellen Borakove, the spokeswoman for the office.

title: Wall Street Extends Rally
description: The Dow Jones industrials spent most of Thursday in positive territory and the major American markets closed near their highs for the day as investors extended a global financial rally that began Wednesday afternoon.

title: Chasing the Darkness With Sleight of Hand
description: SOMETIMES, subtle lighting tricks can compensate for a lack of natural sunlight.

title: Big Theft Ends in Shackles for a Young Goth Couple
description: CLEVELAND  It was a theft so large and brazen that even law enforcement officials admit some admiration for it.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Monday about a change of commanders under consideration by the Pentagon misspelled the designation of an Army unit previously commanded by Lt. Gen. Peter W. Chiarelli, who might be selected to replace Gen. David H. Petraeus later this year as the top commander in Iraq. It is the First Cavalry Division, not Calvary.

title: A Hand-Held Reporting for Duty
description: YES, gentlemen, its time to change your bag. Your messenger bag has had a good decadelong run, longer than it should have unless you are indeed a messenger, and then, by all means, keep on carrying it.

title: Bending, Posing and Teaching Beyond the Mat
description: BOSTON

title: Wider Troubles Trickle Down to Oil Sector
description: As fears of an American recession ripple across the globe this week, analysts and energy experts are wondering whether the great oil boom of the last five years is finally coming to an end  or whether it is simply taking a break.

title: Figure Skating's  Next Ones Are Closing in on Their Moment
description: ST. PAUL  As Caroline Zhang pulled her free foot toward her head in a Biellmann spin, one of figure skatings more difficult positions, her leg stretched with such apparent ease that she seemed to be made of elastic. Mirai Nagasu, like Zhang a promising 14-year-old, showed equally astonishing flexibility on a layback spin Wednesday, leaning so far that the back of her head nearly touched her backside.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about a fiscal stimulus plan for the economy described incorrectly the position on the Senate Budget Committee of Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, who warned of potential long-term costs from a hasty response to economic turmoil. He is the committees ranking Republican member, not its chairman.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page obituary on Saturday about the American chess champion Bobby Fischer misstated the length of time Soviet-born players had held the title of world champion before Mr. Fischer wrested it from Boris Spassky in 1972. It was 35 years, not more than four decades. The obituary also misstated the nationality of another champion, Tigran Petrosian, whom Mr. Fischer defeated to advance to the championship match against Mr. Spassky. Mr. Petrosian was born in Georgia of Armenian descent; he was not Russian.

title: Romney Leads in Ill Will Among G.O.P. Candidates
description: TAMPA, Fla.  At the end of the Republican presidential debate in New Hampshire this month, when the Democrats joined the candidates on stage, Mitt Romney found himself momentarily alone as his counterparts mingled, looking around a bit stiffly for a companion.

title: Mississippi to Use Some Hurricane Aid for Housing Program
description: As Mississippi awaits a decision on whether it can spend $600 million of federal hurricane relief on a controversial plan to rebuild and expand a shipping port, the state has added $100 million of federal aid to a program to develop housing for low- and moderate-income workers.

title: Seven Years Later, Giants Super Bowl Loss Still Stings
description: Jim Fassel, the former Giants coach, made an appearance at a gathering of Giants fans last weekend on the eve of the National Football Conference championship game at Green Bay.

title: Correction: Death and Decorating
description: A picture caption with an article last Thursday about Amy Redford, a film director and a daughter of Robert Redford, misidentified a family member. The girl in the photograph is Shauna Redford, an older daughter; Amy Redford was not pictured.

title: Floating Floors on Bright Ribbons
description: LIGHT isnt just a tool to beat back the darkness. Its also a design tool.

title: Whos Cuddly Now? Law Firms
description: IN the last two decades, as working schedules became flexible, and even accounting firms, of all places, embraced the mantra of work-life balance (at least on paper), there was one unbending, tradition-bound profession: the law.

title: Superman Down
