description: In just two years, Shaquille ONeal has transformed from a dominant champion into an oversized mortal. Now ONeal is out for two weeks because of an injured hip, the latest in a string of injuries. Is his time as a dominant big man finished, and if so what young centers are likely to replace him?

title: Nice Rsum. Have You Considered Botox?
description: IN a new self-help book called How Not to Look Old, chapter headings in screaming capital letters warn readers of the dreaded signs of aging that are to be avoided at all costs.

title: What to Ask About Hypertension
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and, because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Footnotes
description: The writers strike may have shrouded next months Academy Awards broadcast in uncertainty, but film fans seeking a major awards show can watch The British Academy Film Awards on BBC America at 8 p.m. on Feb. 10. The leading contenders at the ceremonies at the Royal Opera House in London include Atonement, No Country for Old Men and There Will Be Blood. ... Sara and Gerald Murphy, the expatriates who inspired the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel Tender Is the Night, will be the focus of an exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery from Feb. 26 through May 4. Making It New: The Art and Style of Sara and Gerald Murphy explores their relationships with pivotal figures in the avant-garde in France in the 1920s, including Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, Fernand Lger, Pablo Picasso, Cole Porter and Ernest Hemingway. The exhibition will include Gerald Murphys seven surviving paintings.

title: Tip of the Week: Adjusting the Pace of Your Audiobook
description: Some audiobook narrators talk too fast  and some too slow. If you are listening to Audible books and spoken-word content on your iPod, you can often change the pace. Just go to the Settings area on the iPods main menu and choose Audiobooks. On the next screen, you can adjust the playback speed of the file to Slower, Normal or Faster. You do not have to worry about your book sounding like someone reading underwater or narrating like a chipmunk the setting you select will not alter the pitch of the narrators voice.

title: New Tools to Bolster Macs World
description: Apple has been on a hot streak.

title: Retrace Your Steps or Just Say, Im All Right, by Satellite
description: Satellite phones are still largely associated with dashing reporters and superspies, but the Spot Satellite Messenger from Spot Inc. brings a little celestial high-tech to the common hiker.

title: Idol Outshines the Competition
description: The San Diego auditions of American Idol, with the usual mixture of the talented and the cringe-worthy, attracted 29.1 million viewers on Tuesday, lifting Fox with ease into first place in the nights ratings, Nielsen estimated. Although the shows third installment is down 4.6 million from the same night a year ago, it still had more than double the audience of any other network broadcast. Foxs rerun of House came closest, leading the 9 oclock hour after American Idol with 14 million viewers. NBCs Biggest Loser, meanwhile, trailed both programs as runner-up during 8 to 10 p.m. among adults 18 to 49, averaging a modest 8.9 million viewers. NBC ranked second for the night, leading at 10 with Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (13 million). CBS was third, and ABC finished fourth.

title: Attacks Imperil U.S.-Backed Militias in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  American-backed Sunni militias who have fought Sunni extremists to a standstill in some of Iraqs bloodiest battlegrounds are being hit with a wave of assassinations and bomb attacks, threatening a fragile linchpin of the militarys strategy to pacify the nation.

title: Manhattan Doctor Is Accused of Fleecing Mother Out of $800,000
description: Prosecutors are calling it an Astor copycat case.

title: Learning How to Use Picasa
description: Q. I downloaded all my vacation photos to Googles Picasa, but I am having trouble finding information on how to use it. Google sends you to a chat room with other confused users. Any ideas where to look? There doesnt seem to be a Dummies book.

title: In Washington, Bloomberg Says Politics Is the Problem
description: WASHINGTON  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City intensified his attacks on the political leadership here on Wednesday, pointing to what he called the governments failure to fix immigration policy and other problems of immediate concern to the nation.

title: Fears Anew in an Area Rife With Sex Offenders
description: MASTIC, N.Y.  Last Thursday, a sixth grader waited for the school bus across the street from her house in this working-class community on Long Island.

title: Former Princeton Star Turns Brown Into Contender
description: Craig Robinson understood that few thought he could win when he took over as the coach at Brown before the 2006-7 season. It was not that he did not have the credentials or the desire to turn the Bears around, but how could Brown  or anyone else  break the stranglehold Penn and Princeton had on the Ivy League? The two teams have won or shared Ivy titles in 46 of the leagues 52 years, which includes three Princeton championship teams in the early 80s that were anchored by Robinson, the fourth-leading scorer in Tigers history.

title: In Kabul, Shattered Illusions
description: Kabul, Afghanistan

title: CBS to Make Internet Music Unit More Like Radio
description: CBS said Wednesday that it would expand its Internet music service, Last.fm, to allow users to listen to any song on their computers whenever they wanted, up to three times.

title: Judge Replaces State Overseer of Health Care for Prisoners
description: LOS ANGELES  A federal judge who ruled in 2005 that Californias broken prison medical care system amounted to cruel and unusual punishment in many cases dismissed on Wednesday the receiver who had been appointed to repair the system.

title: Lottery Numbers
Voters Show Darker Mood Than in 2000
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Whatever their ideological differences this election year, Americans seem able to agree on one thing: the political landscape being crisscrossed by the 2008 candidates is barely recognizable as the one traveled by George W. Bush and Al Gore a mere eight years ago.

title: Woods and Mickelson: Real Season Begins
description: LA JOLLA, Calif.  Too early for hang gliders, Blacks Beach surfers and nude sunbathers  but not soon enough for golf lovers  the worlds two best golfers answered the 6:42 a.m. bell Wednesday in the final tuneup for the Buick Invitational at Torrey Pines Golf Course. As the full moon hung in the sky above the Pacific and the sun peeked over the eastern hills beyond Sorrento Valley, Tiger Woods teed up his ball at No. 1 on Torrey Pines South and Phil Mickelson did the same on No. 1 at Torrey Pines North.

title: Bill Clinton Accuses Obama Camp of Stirring Race Issue
description: KINGSTREE, S.C.  Former President Bill Clinton defended himself Wednesday against accusations that he and his wife had injected the issue of race into the Democratic presidential primary in South Carolina, and he accused Senator Barack Obama of Illinois of putting out a hit job on him.

title: Santanas Hometown Awaits His Next Move
description: TOVAR, Venezuela  Welcome to the territory of Johan Santana, reads a sign on the wall of the local baseball field in this Andean town more than 6,400 feet above sea level in southwestern Venezuela.

title: An MP3 Player That Works in Sync With Your Heartbeat
description: No one knows you as well as your Yamaha Bodibeat. This MP3 player scans your music collection and plays tunes in sync with your heartbeat.

title: PGA Commissioner Outlines Drug-Testing Program
description: LA JOLLA, Calif.  PGA Tour Commissioner Tim Finchem was at Torrey Pines on Wednesday and outlined the tours drug-testing program, which will commence in July.

title: A Museum Director Leaves the Smithsonian
description: Paul G. Risser, acting director at the Smithsonians National Museum of Natural History, is to step down on Friday after nine months in the job. Mr. Risser, a biologist, will return to his position as chairman of the University of Oklahoma Research Cabinet. I came here originally for a six-month period, and that has stretched longer, Mr. Risser, 68, said. He replaced Cristin Samper in April, when Mr. Samper was named acting secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. Mr. Samper succeeded Lawrence M. Small, who resigned in March after an investigation into his personal spending. While Mr. Risser was acting director, the Smithsonian Regents, its governing body, debated the appropriateness of accepting a $5 million donation for its Ocean Initiative from the American Petroleum Institute, prompting the institute to withdraw the offer.

title: Blueshirt No. 2, Cool as Ice
description: Brian Leetch, Ranger shirt No. 2, was brilliance in icy blue but not with a red-hot flame like Mark Messiers. Oh, no. Leetch -- a Connecticut Irishman with a pedigree of prep school, college and Olympics -- was a Yankee hybrid among the Canadian muckergrinders and Fancy Dan Euroflashes, like a cold-eyed, pool-room guy, smart and calculating, with major skills. Leetch, whose jersey will be retired tonight at Madison Square Garden, intuited angles, caroms and possibilities.

title: Making Dark Rooms Glow
description: AT home, where we cook and eat, sleep and dream, read and entertain, lighting has to be flexible, unlike the purposefully soft, romantic lighting in a restaurant or the dark, dramatic lighting in a nightclub.

title: Connecticut Toughens Law Against Home Invasions
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Six months after a deadly home invasion in the town of Cheshire shattered confidence in the states criminal justice system, legislators have overwhelmingly approved a bill to shore up the way Connecticut deals with offenders.

title: Sharapova Reaches the Final Again and Hopes for a Better Outcome
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Already vulnerable during the rallies against Maria Sharapova, Jelena Jankovic soon found herself lying face down on a towel, too, as she received treatment on her lower back.

title: Foreclosures Prompt Cities to Make Plea for Aid
description: WASHINGTON  Facing a collapse in the subprime mortgage market that has pockmarked their cities with vacant houses and crippled their budgets, the nations mayors pleaded Wednesday for a huge infusion of federal aid.

title: Mentors and Sisterhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Trapped in Gaza
description: The neglect and mistreatment of the 1.5 million Palestinians trapped in the Gaza Strip is a disgrace, and a very dangerous one. They are pawns in the struggle among Hamas, which controls Gaza and uses the territory to bombard Israel daily; its rivals in the Fatah movement that run the Palestinian Authority and the West Bank; and Israel. If something isnt done quickly to address the Gazans plight, President Bushs Annapolis peace process could implode.

title: Hiring of Soviet Scientists Has Strayed From Aim, Audit Says
description: WASHINGTON  An American effort set up after the fall of the Soviet Union to hire its former weapons scientists to keep them from selling their skills to nations seeking nuclear, biological or chemical weapons is now paying people who were never weapons scientists and are too young to have worked in the old Soviet program, according to Congressional auditors.

title: Palestinians Topple Gaza Wall and Cross to Egypt
description: RAFAH, Egypt  Tens of thousands of Palestinians streamed into northern Egypt on Wednesday after Hamas militants blew up parts of the fence dividing Egypt from the Gaza Strip, forcing an end to the closing of Gaza that had followed Hamass takeover of the territory last summer.

title: The Answers to Gridlock
description: New York has long treated traffic gridlock like it does the weather  as something outside of its control. It isnt, though. London proved as much when it adopted congestion pricing, charging drivers to use certain streets. Traffic moved faster, tailpipe emissions went down and the fees collected went to improve public transportation. New York is right to want the same results, and this month, congestion pricing took another welcome step forward.

title: EBays New Leader Moves Swiftly on a Revamping
description: SAN FRANCISCO  John Donahoe wasted little time as the new chief executive of Internet giant eBay before announcing big changes.

title: Tentative Deal Reached on Stimulus Plan
description: WASHINGTON  House leaders and the White House on Thursday announced a tentative agreement on an economic stimulus package of roughly $150 billion that would pay stipends of $300 to $1,200 per household, and more for families with children, plus provide tax incentives for businesses to encourage spending.

title: Dashing Through a Sex Comedy by Machiavelli (Yes, That Machiavelli)
description: Just because Broadway has cornered the market on moonlighting movie stars doesnt mean that downtown theaters dont traffic in celebrity.

title: Tattooed for a Day, Wild for a Night
description: LAURA EASTWOOD dropped by Linda Masons makeup boutique in SoHo last week, looking to add a bit of sizzle to her look. For a night on the town, she was wearing a strapless Gucci cocktail dress, a relic of the Tom Ford era. She planned to turn up its glamour by having her shoulders stamped with a constellation of press-on tattoos.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the widespread off-label use in the United States of stents approved only for use in bile ducts misidentified a market research company that monitors sales of the devices. It is the Millennium Research Group  not Millennium Research, which is a computer and software engineering consulting firm. The article also misstated Millenniums estimate of sales of the stents in 2006 for on-label use. Sales were under $38 million, not under $35 million.

title: Domestic Pampering for the 21st Century
description: Those with lots of stress and even more cash might be interested in the Spa Capsule, which starts at about $27,000 and is being touted as a sumptuous, destressing, rejuvenating spa by Simulated Environment Concepts of Miami, the company that manufactures it. Its a sci-fi chamber with aromatherapy, music and video, although the big selling point is the dry water massage. Your body is covered with a thin, silky sheet, explained Ella Frenkel, a chiropractor who runs the company and had traveled to the home of a Manhattan customer to demonstrate the Spa Capsule. There is an arm full of water jets inside the lid, she said, so that the water is not exposed, but you can actually feel the jets.Sara Herbert-Galloway, a socialite and former model who is the owner of this particular Spa Capsule, a jelly-red number with yellow leather upholstery purchased for $29,000, whispered, My friends call it the Orgasmatron. It had been set up in her lushly appointed living room, where it blended in as smoothly as a Ferrari. One lies in the Spa Capsule face down, head supported on a doughnut-shaped headrest, top right, but your head is completely outside the capsule, so it is nonclaustrophobic, Ms. Frenkel said. A video can be viewed, aromas can be sniffed and a touch screen allows the user to operate the lid. Ms. Herbert-Galloway said she uses a relaxation video supplied by the company, with abstract 70s-style images and a soothing soundtrack, delivered through Bose headphones. Her aroma of choice is lavender. For this reporters trial run, eucalyptus was suggested  good for the sinuses, it was said  although inside the Spa Capsule, no scent was detectable. The massage was very nice, but the sound system could not eradicate the steady sloshing of the water jets. It was like being in the tender embrace of a washing machine set on the gentle cycle. Had the reporter paid $29,000 she might have been a little stressed. Ms. Herbert-Galloway said the sound did not trouble her.

title: Miles Lerman, a Leading Force Behind Holocaust Museum, Dies at 88
description: Miles Lerman, a Jewish resistance fighter in Nazi-occupied Poland who was a major figure in creating the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington and persuading Soviet bloc countries to give it thousands of artifacts of the Holocaust, died on Tuesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 88.

title: Scientists Take New Step Toward Man-Made Life
description: Taking a significant step toward the creation of man-made forms of life, researchers reported Thursday that they had manufactured the entire genome of a bacterium by painstakingly stitching together its chemical components.

title: Digital Music Sales Grow, but at Slower Rate
description: LONDON  Digital music claimed an increasing share of overall music sales last year, though its growth rate slowed, the music industrys international trade group said Thursday.

title: Microsoft Delivers Strong Earnings and Outlook
description: Microsoft reported quarterly sales and profit gains that surpassed Wall Streets expectations, and delivered an optimistic outlook, suggesting that a weakening economy will not slow down the worlds largest software maker.

title: The Unavoidable Update
description: WHILE people like to complain that there is nothing to watch on television, about 21 million American households may find that literally true in February 2009. On the 17th of that month, most TV stations will quit broadcasting analog TV signals over the air, and older sets will go blank.

title: If Theyve Changed the Locks, Is It Really Home?
description: When a character who is talked about but never seen is the most interesting figure in a drama, is that a problem? It is for The Main(e) Play, Chad Beckims punning title for his quasi-autobiographical riff on family that opened on Wednesday night at the Lion Theater.

title: Bush and Congress Nearing a Deal on Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional leaders and the Bush administration were close to reaching a deal on a $145 billion economic stimulus package on Wednesday night as the Treasury Department crunched the numbers on components of the plan, senior House officials said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Thursday about the first day of testimony in the murder trial of Cesar Rodriguez, a Brooklyn man accused of killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, misspelled the given name of the prosecutions first witness, a neighbor of the family. She is Ulbis Rivera, not Ulvis.

title: Clinton Spells Out Her Economic Stimulus Plan
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  After a two-day absence, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton returned to South Carolina on Thursday and outlined her economic stimulus plan in a speech here  tackling both a huge concern of many Americans and playing the optimistic good cop to her husbands bad-cop routine against Senator Barack Obama.

title: Next on the Worry List: Shaky Insurers of Bonds
description: Even as stocks ended five days of losses with a surprising recovery on Wednesday, officials began moving to defuse another potential time bomb in the markets: the weakened condition of two large insurance companies that have guaranteed buyers against losses on more than $1 trillion of bonds.

title: U.S. Policies Evoke Scorn at Davos
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Over the years, the United States has fulfilled many roles at the World Economic Forum: dot-com dynamo, benevolent superpower, feared aggressor. Now add wounded giant.

title: Sallie Mae Records Huge Loss on Bad Bets
description: Sallie Mae, the embattled student lending giant, said Wednesday that it lost $1.6 billion in its fourth quarter as it prepared for a jump in student loan defaults and took a hit from bad bets on its stock price. It was a stark reversal from the $18 million it earned in the period last year.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about steps that President Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov of Turkmenistan is taking to change some of the more bizarre legacies of his predecessor misidentified the sea bordering the country where the new president plans to build a tourist resort. It is the Caspian Sea, not the Black Sea.

title: Profit Falls 42% at Capital One
description: The Capital One Financial Corporation, the credit card issuer, said Wednesday that fourth-quarter profit fell 42 percent as more borrowers failed to repay their debts.

title: Wal-Mart Chief Offers a Social Manifesto
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Wal-Mart pledged Wednesday to cut the energy used by many of its products 25 percent, to force the chains suppliers to meet stricter ethical standards and to apply its legendary cost-cutting skills to help other companies deliver health care for their employees.

title: Detainees Plotted Bombing in Spain, Judge Says
description: MADRID  Ten men arrested in Barcelona on Saturday on suspicion of planning a suicide attack on the citys public transportation system had intended to carry out the bombing last weekend, a Spanish judge said Wednesday in court documents ordering the men to remain in jail.

title: The Perfect Result Is ... Either One
description: On its face, Super Bowl XLII might seem non-competitive, with the Patriots a heavy favorite. But the game has generated one of the most fascinating choices ever regarding rooting interest:

title: E.P.A. Ignored Own Advice, Senator Says
description: The Environmental Protection Agency ignored the advice of its employees in rejecting Californias request to set rules on automotive carbon dioxide emissions, a senator says. Its clear that E.P.A.s own experts told Administrator Stephen Johnson that Californias case for the waiver is solid, Senator Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat who is chairwoman of the Committee on Environment and Public Works, said Monday. Her committee has scheduled a hearing on Thursday on the agencys decision last month denying Californias request to set emissions rules tougher than federal standards. Mr. Johnson said an energy bill signed by President Bush would achieve reductions in greenhouse gases through fuel-efficiency standards.

title: Mellon Millions Foster New Plays
description: Using a $2.7 million grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the Public Theater is starting a play series with its resident LAByrinth Theater Company. As part of the series, a new play, in a development stage somewhere between a staged reading and a full-blown production, will be put on every month, and heres the kicker: All tickets will be $10. This is not just for up-and-coming playwrights; most writers in the first series have already up and come. The series begins on Feb. 4 with Mom, How Did You Meet the Beatles? by Adam P. Kennedy and Adrienne Kennedy. Other writers in the series include Naomi Wallace, John Belluso, Tracey Scott Wilson and the musical-writing team of Steve Cosson and Michael Friedman. The LAByrinths previously announced Penalties and Interest by Rebecca Cohen and Sweet Storm by Scott Hudson will round out the series in June.

title: One-Day Strike in Belgium Warns on Pollution and Jobs
description: BRUSSELS  Thousands of steel workers at ArcelorMittal factories in Belgium walked off the job this week to protest European Union policies to combat climate change.

title: Texas: Justice Says He Used Campaign Money for Trips
description: A Texas Supreme Court justice, Nathan L. Hecht, said he used campaign money to pay for dozens of flights to his hometown last year because he was campaigning, even though he is not up for re-election until 2012. Justice Hecht, who is elected statewide, reported 42 payments to airlines for in-state trips last year and acknowledged that a good bit of the travel was to his hometown, Carrollton, where he still owns a home. Using political contributions for personal use is against state law, and the Texas Ethics Commission has interpreted the law to ban appellate judges from using donations to pay for commuting between the judges home city and the city where the court is situated.

title: First the Dimming, Now for the Movie
description: EVEN though home theaters are often dark, there is that moment when the movie stops, or is paused, and some light is needed. But what kind of light?

title: In Global Race, G.M. Wins by a Day of Pickup Sales
description: DETROIT  It was effectively a tie, but General Motors emerged from last years hard-fought global sales race with Toyota feeling like the winner.

title: Metro-North New Haven Line From Grand Central Terminal to Bridgeport, Conn.
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Rogaine Seeks Place in the Morning Routine
description: SINCE its introduction in 1988, Rogaine has always been a bit of a punch line, not only for what it does (help grow hair) but also for its sales results, which never quite (insert bad hair-growth pun here).

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about a California homeowner who is suing a real estate agent, claiming she was sold an overpriced house, misidentified the court in which the case is being heard. It is the north county division of San Diego Superior Court, not North County Superior Court.

title: Leetchs No. 2 to Assume a Lofty Perch at the Garden
description: Brian Leetchs teammates from his days with the Rangers love to tell the story of a game at Tampa Bay in 1999, watching Leetch block a shot by the hardest shooter in the league, Fredrik Modin. The shot broke Leetchs right wrist, but he stayed on the ice to block another and to play several more shifts before leaving the game.

title: That Mushroom Cloud? Theyre Just Svejking Around
description: PRAGUE  One Sunday, several months ago, early risers gazing at Czech Televisions CT2 channel saw picturesque panoramas of the Czech countryside, broadcast to the wordless accompaniment of elevator music. It was the usual narcoleptic morning weather show.

title: An Interior Landscape With a Glow Built In
description: IN 2006, when Omer Arbel, left, was hired to design a 7,800-square-foot duplex penthouse for a bachelor in Vancouver, he placed the living room, dining room and bedrooms in locations with spectacular views. But that left the kitchen, master bathroom, powder room and office not dark, exactly, but lacking lots of direct sunlight or intriguing sights.

title: Smoggy Beijing Plans to Cut Traffic by Half for Olympics, Paper Says
description: BEIJING  Faced with persistent air pollution despite promises to stage a green Olympics, Beijing is planning to reduce its motor traffic by half during the Games to improve air quality and ease traffic flow, according to a newspaper report on Wednesday.

title: Trouble in Our Economic House
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worldwide Challenge of Blood Pressure Control
description: Dr. Aram Chobanian is a professor of medicine and pharmacology at the Boston University School of Medicine. He chairs the Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation and Treatment of High Blood Pressure, a government-sponsored board that makes recommendations for controlling hypertension.

title: Keys Is No. 1 as CD Sales Plunge
description: So far 2008 has not been a good year for music sales. This week Alicia Keys, below, stays atop the Billboard chart with As I Am (J), but the number of copies that CD sold is barely above the historic low for a No. 1 album. Nielsen SoundScan reported that 61,000 copies of the album sold last week; the least number of weekly sales for No. 1 is 60,000, set by the Dreamgirls soundtrack a year ago. (The numbers are rounded.) This week the Juno soundtrack (Rhino) is at No. 2 with 58,000, Mary J. Bliges Growing Pains (Geffen) is No. 3 with 52,000, and Radioheads In Rainbows (ATO) is next with 46,000. The R&B singer Raheem DeVaughn opens at No. 5 with 45,000 sales of Love Behind the Melody (J) and John Legends new Live From Philadelphia, available only through Target, reached No. 7 with 33,000.

title: 2 Crips Members Are Arrested After Queens Teenager Is Shot
description: A teenager was wounded in the neck outside his high school in Queens on Wednesday, and the police said the shooting was gang related.

title: Clinton Is Endorsed by Pennsylvania Governor
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tended to her political backyard on Wednesday in anticipation of New Jerseys critical presidential primary on Feb. 5, picking up a major endorsement and headlining a fund-raiser and two lively rallies.

title: Tune In, Drop In, Vote Now: A Simpler Path to the Polls
description: MAHWAH, N.J.

title: California: Kidnapper Dies in Prison
description: Kenneth E. Parnell, left, whose abduction of a California boy became the basis of a TV movie, died of natural causes while serving a life sentence, state prison authorities said. Mr. Parnell, 76, died Monday at the California Medical Facility in Vacaville. Mr. Parnell was convicted of kidnapping the boy, Steven Stayner, 7, in Merced in 1972. He gave the boy a new name and kept him until Steven escaped in 1980. When Mr. Parnell abducted a second boy in Ukiah that year, Steven fled, taking the other boy. Mr. Parnell was paroled after serving about five years for the kidnappings. In 2004, he was sentenced to 25 years to life after he tried to obtain another child.

title: Boarding With the Stars
description: As the Winter X Games storm Aspen from today through Sunday, plenty of armchair athletes will fantasize about what it's like to flip like snowboarder Shaun White or fly like big-air skier Simon Dumont. But 11 regular riders can get out of the armchair -- and the chairlift -- to float through the powder with X Games champ Gretchen Bleiler and big-mountain rider Jeremy Jones during a "Shred Session" with Canadian Mountain Holidays (C.M.H.), an Alberta-based adventure travel company.

title: A Toll Increase in New Jersey? Residents Weigh In
description: To the Editor:

title: Busta Rhymes Is Sentenced
description: The rapper Busta Rhymes was sentenced on Wednesday to three years probation and 10 days of community service for assaulting his former driver and a fan, The Associated Press reported. Busta Rhymes, 35, whose real name is Trevor Smith, was also fined $1,250 and ordered to pay court costs for driving while intoxicated and with a suspended license. He pleaded guilty to the charges, stemming from four separate incidents, in Manhattan Criminal Court.

title: Out of Deep Freeze: Freeskiers Make Sport Cool Again
description: ASPEN, Colo.  The freeskier Tanner Hall comes from Kalispell, Mont., population 20,000. He is towheaded and resembles a young Ron Howard. So it is a testament to his flair for reinvention that he answers the telephone, without irony: Yo, what up? This is T.

title: Growing Online, BBC Is to Join With MySpace
description: The commercial arm of the British Broadcasting Corporation is expected to announce a partnership with MySpace on Thursday to make some of its content available on MySpace, the popular social networking Web site.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the efforts by Mexicos military and police to battle armed drug gangs near the United States border misstated the location of Tamaulipas state, where Mexican police have been going after drug-gang members known as the Zetas. It is south of southern Texas, not eastern Texas.

title: Drug Inquiry Widening in Brooklyn
description: Three more New York City police officers have been suspended without pay and stripped of their guns and badges in a widening police corruption investigation that involves paying confidential informants with drugs, officials said on Wednesday.

title: Olympic Teams Vying to Defeat Beijings Smog
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  As the lead exercise physiologist for the United States Olympic Committee, Randy Wilber has been fielding one bizarre question after another from American athletes training for the Beijing Games.

title: Most Reformists Appear Purged From Iran Ballot
description: TEHRAN  When voters go to the polls on March 14 to select members of Parliament, they may be able to choose only between conservative candidates and other conservative candidates, leaders of Irans main reform party said Wednesday.

title: Before the Image Fades
description: BY 7 p.m. on Tuesday, the line of fashionable people trying to get into the Danziger Projects gallery on West 26th Street to see a show by Scott Schuman, a photographer who takes pictures of fashionable people, had reached 10th Avenue and passed beneath a billboard that presumably was intended to tweak them on their behinds.

title: A Chanel as Big as the Ritz
description: Paris

title: Fugitive Accused of Shooting Chicago Officer Is to Surrender
description: CHICAGO  A man who the authorities say was a Black Panther who shot a Chicago police officer almost 40 years ago will return here from Canada, where he fled, to face trial.

title: Thomas Has No Comment on Browns Spying Charge
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Larry Brown crept ever so slightly back into the Knicks consciousness this week with a mildly provocative two-sentence quotation that hinted at the franchises paranoid culture.

title: Britain: Thousands of Police Protest in London Over Pay Deal
description: More than 22,500 police officers from across Britain marched through central London in their first major protest over pay in six years. They were contesting a government decision against backdating an annual pay increase, which had the effect of limiting the gain to just 1.9 percent.

title: Nokia Increases Profit and Market Share
description: BERLIN  Nokia said Thursday that it had extended its dominant share of the global mobile phone market to a record 40 percent in the fourth quarter as profit surged 44 percent on rising sales to China, Africa and the Middle East.

title: Bondss Lawyers Use Two Tactics to Battle Charges
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Barry Bondss lawyers filed a motion to dismiss perjury charges against him Wednesday. In case that is rejected, the lawyers moved to strike parts of his indictment, describing the charges against Bonds as ambiguous, inartful, scattershot, vague and confusing.

title: Prince of Intensity With a Lightness of Touch
description: The defining performance of Heath Ledgers tragically foreshortened career  more or less equivalent to what Jim Stark in Rebel Without a Cause was for James Dean  will surely be the role of Ennis Del Mar in Brokeback Mountain.

title: 14 Are Killed in Explosion at Building in Mosul
description: BAGHDAD  Victims were still being pulled from the rubble late Wednesday night in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul, where a building used by insurgents to store ammunition and other explosives blew up in a crowded neighborhood, killing at least 14 people and wounding 134, according to the police.

title: Mead-Drinking, Gruel-Eating, Sandal-Wearing, Reality-Fleeing Family Guy
description: Tod Wodicka has said that he began his debut novel in a spirit of satire and then let it deepen into something else. The wisdom of that approach is borne out by this tender, oddball book, one that performs a deft balancing act as it hides love, yearning and regret behind the mouthful of medieval incantation in its title.

title: Warnings Dont Deter Lovers of Sushi
description: Sara Barokas, a substitute teacher, noticed the yellow-and-red signs above the sushi case at the Gourmet Garage market on Broadway: Protect yourself and your family!!! Mercury in sushi.

title: Day Wins Book Prize
description: A. L. Kennedy, right, a Scottish stand-up comedian and author, won the Costa Book of the Year Award on Tuesday for her fifth novel, Day, about a former Royal Air Force tail-gunner and prisoner of war who returns to Germany to confront his demons. The Costa Book Awards, formerly the Whitbread Book Awards, honor books by writers based in Britain and Ireland. The judges said that Ms. Kennedy, who lives in Glasgow, was chosen from a shortlist of five books because, through an extraordinary act of ventriloquism, she describes the waste and eventual resurrection of a young life shattered by war. In a ceremony in London, Ms. Kennedy, whose book is published in the United States by Alfred A. Knopf, received a check for 25,000 ($48,766).

title: A Camera for Sharp Shots Even When Lights Are Low
description: Pentax on Wednesday introduced the K20D, a digital single-lens reflex camera for serious photographers that it will show off next week at the Photo Marketing Association trade show in Las Vegas. The sensor in the K20D uses complementary metal-oxide semiconductor technology, better known as C.M.O.S., instead of the more common charge-coupled device, or C.C.D. This new wave in digital cameras allows a vastly greater sensitivity to light, yielding better pictures.

title: 2 Big Dig Companies to Pay $407 Million
description: BOSTON  The two companies that managed the design and construction of the costly Big Dig project here will pay more than $400 million in an agreement with the government over leaky tunnels and a fatal ceiling collapse.

title: Italy Backs Its Coalition but Only Just for Now
description: ROME  As expected, Prime Minister Romano Prodi easily won the first of two confidence votes in Parliament on Wednesday, but pressure mounted for him to resign as Italys leader and hopes dimmed that he could keep his wounded government alive.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $6,921,774

title: Special Paper Required for Harry Potter Book
description: J. K. Rowling blocked the Finnish publication of her latest Harry Potter novel on paper from Finland because it lacked the ecologically friendly certification she favors, Agence France-Presse reported. Her Finnish publisher, Tammi, said that Ms. Rowling insisted that it import paper certified by the Forest Stewardship Council as being derived from wood grown and harvested in a way that promotes sustainable forest development. Sinikka Partanen, a spokeswoman for Tammi, said the first Potter books in Finnish were printed on recycled paper. This time its a more specific demand, she said. The Finnish-language version of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is due on March 7.

title: Veto Stands on Measure to Expand Health Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats cited the nations economic problems as a reason to expand a popular health insurance program for children on Wednesday, but their effort failed as the House sustained President Bushs veto of a bill to provide coverage to nearly four million uninsured children.

title: Art That Shines Without Reflected Glare
description: WHEN Dr. Louis Aledort, and his wife, Ruth, above, bought their six-room apartment on the Upper West Side in 2001, they interviewed several architects, and mentioned to each of them that they had an art collection. Only one architect, Richard Lavenstein, a partner at Bond Street Architecture & Design in Manhattan, asked to see the collection.

title: A Day of Sharp Swings, and a Final Gain
description: This week, investors were bracing for Black Tuesday. Instead, they got Whiplash Wednesday.

title: Big Dig Suit Settled for More Than $400 Million
description: BOSTON  The companies that designed and managed the costly Big Dig project will pay Massachusetts more than $400 million to settle litigation over leaky tunnels and a fatal ceiling collapse.

title: Without a Hit Razr Sequel, Profit Drops for Motorola
description: In Hollywood, it does not take long for the pundits to start grumbling when a studio has a string of flops. Nowadays, things are no different for the cellphone business, which, like the film industry, is a hit-driven pursuit. Fail to follow up on a blockbuster product and the critics can be punishing.

title: European Central Banker Says Inflation Is Still Focus
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The president of the European Central Bank gave a full-throated defense Wednesday of the banks determination to fight inflation, quashing hopes  at least for now  that it might follow the United States Federal Reserve in cutting interest rates to contain an economic slowdown.

title: Death Sentence for Afghan Student
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An Afghan court in northern Afghanistan sentenced a journalism student to death for blasphemy for distributing an article from the Internet that was considered an insult to the Prophet Muhammad, the judge in charge of the court said Wednesday.

title: In Real Time, Amy Winehouses Deeper Descent
description: It was witty, with a fillip of transgression, when Amy Winehouse sang, They tried to make me go to rehab/I said no, no, no on her album Back to Black, which was originally released in 2006 and has brought her six Grammy Award nominations, including Album of the Year. But there was nothing amusing, and barely any surprise, in Ms. Winehouses recent, notorious and possibly inadvertent public appearance: on a video released by an English tabloid, The Sun.

title: Paying for College
description: To the Editor:

title: Resizing Drives, for Extra Room
Indictment in Killing of Marine
description: A Camp Lejeune marine suspected of killing a colleague who was eight months pregnant last month, was formally charged with first degree murder Thursday by a North Carolina grand jury in Onslow County, where the military base is.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. A luxury hotel I recently stayed in had a TV in the bathroom. How do I install one at home?

title: Chinas Genocide Olympics
description: The Beijing Olympics this summer were supposed to be Chinas coming-out party, celebrating the end of nearly two centuries of weakness, poverty and humiliation.

title: Twins Caravan Rolls on; No News for Fans
description: MONTEVIDEO, Minn.  On a bitterly cold night in southwestern Minnesota, about 150 people packed into V.F.W. Post 380 for an appearance by the Minnesota Twins Winter Caravan. For $6, attendees got roast beef sandwiches with macaroni and potato salads, a look at a Twins promotional video, autographs, and a question-and-answer session led by the wisecracking Twins manager, Ron Gardenhire.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Nevada: Woman May See Bars Instead of View
description: A woman has been indicted on charges saying she had three large trees up to a century old cut down on environmentally sensitive federal land near Lake Tahoe to improve her view, prosecutors said. Officials said they were not aware of any similar federal prosecutions. The woman, Patricia M. Vincent, 58, was indicted last week on charges of theft of government property and willingly damaging government property. If convicted, she faces up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine for each count. The three ponderosa pines stood on a plot the Forest Service had designated as environmentally sensitive as part of a water quality plan. The trees were estimated to be 80 to 100 years old.

title: Canseco Is Said to Seek Favor to Omit Name
description: Jos Canseco, the former major league slugger and admitted steroid user who exposed other players in his 2005 best-selling book Juiced, offered to keep a Detroit Tigers outfielder clear in his next book if the player invested money in a film project Canseco was promoting, according to a person in baseball with knowledge of the situation.

title: Virginia Commonwealth Coach Is in Demand
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Virginia Commonwealth Coach Anthony Grant calmly stood in front of his bench with his hands on his hips as the clock wound down Wednesday night at Hofstras Mack Sports Complex. For the entire game, he never sat and his stoic expression rarely, if ever, changed.

title: F.D.A. Requiring Suicide Studies in Drug Trials
description: After decades of inattention to the possible psychiatric side effects of experimental medicines, the Food and Drug Administration is now requiring drug makers to study closely whether patients become suicidal during clinical trials.

title: Selected Studies: Hypertension
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Spitzer Is Said to Agree to a Raise for Legislators
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer has agreed to a pay raise for legislators, even as he has called for cuts elsewhere to help close a $4.4 billion deficit, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has told Assembly Democrats.

title: Met Opera Abandons Plan for On-Demand Telecasts
description: The Metropolitan Opera has canceled plans to offer performances through on-demand television, a rare miscalculation in its march to show operas on screens of all sizes.

title: 2nd Survey Finds Astronauts Havent Drunk Before Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  A new survey of astronauts and flight surgeons shows no evidence of crew members going on space missions drunk or impaired by alcohol, NASA officials said Wednesday.

title: Canadian Military Has Quit Turning Detainees Over to Afghans
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian military secretly stopped transferring prisoners to Afghanistans government in November after Canadian monitors found evidence that they were being abused and tortured.

title: Loud and Dumb Never Looked Better
description: IN the summer of 1989, I finally had a fake ID and went out at least five nights a week. (My name was Robert Bruce Macartey, and my birthday was June 4, 1965.) For my new club life, I shelved my floppy teenage knock-arounds and bought mock turtlenecks, striped vests and black rayon tapered-leg trousers from stores like the Le Chteau, Merry-Go-Round and Oak Tree. I wore these clothes while fake-smoking menthols, throwing attitude and dancing to Ofra Haza and Soul II Soul.

title: No Map Needed for Reality-Altering Trip
description: Looking for the travel agent of your dreams, someone to fly you out of the muddy rut of midwinter monotony? Allow me to suggest Richard Foreman, a man whose slogan, spelled out in a ravishing new show called Deep Trance Behavior in Potatoland, gets right to the point: Go to other places. And, boy, does he make sure that you do.

title: In a Town Known for Light, a House With Very Little
description: THE little 18th-century house in Siracusa, Italy, was striking for its location near the sea in a town known for its light. But when Enzo Cucchi, an Italian painter, bought it in 2005 to use as a summer house, he knew that it would be light challenged. It had windows on the front, right, but none on the rear or on the sides.

title: Court Rejects Venue Change in Police Killing
description: A New York state appeals court ruled on Wednesday against moving the trial of three detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell to a location out of New York City, clearing the way for jury selection to begin in Queens on Feb. 4.

title: What the Nurseries Like for Spring
description: ITS too bad that nursery trade shows arent open to the public, because they are far more exciting than flower shows. Instead of fantasy landscapes forced into bloom, a trade show has the energy of an international marketplace, where growers discuss the fine points of their new favorites  plants like Citronelle, a lime-green heuchera that can stand up to heat and humidity; or new hibiscuses like Plum Crazy and Copper King, which tolerate dry soil and are hardy to 30 below zero; or the rarest of plants, like a bonsai metasequoia, also known as dawn redwood, which grows only three inches a year, making it perfect for a pot on your patio.

title: New Jersey Child Welfare Chief Quits
description: The commissioner of New Jerseys Department of Children and Families announced his resignation Thursday, after two years of leading a court-ordered overhaul of the states embattled child welfare system.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Two articles on Wednesday, one on the front page and one in Business Day, about the reaction in Washington to market turmoil, misstated circumstances of a conversation on Monday between Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. and President Bush. According to additional information provided by the White House, Mr. Paulson spoke several times on Monday with the White House chief of staff, Joshua B. Bolten. When Mr. Bolten returned a call at 3:15 p.m., Mr. Bush joined the conversation, at which time Mr. Paulson briefed him on events in overseas stock markets. Mr. Paulson did not telephone the president directly at that point.

title: First Symphonies: One Agitated, One Light
description: Ninety is a nice round number, and also a good excuse to celebrate the memory of Leonard Bernstein, born in 1918. The Philadelphia Orchestra, led by Christoph Eschenbach, brought Bernsteins Jeremiah Symphony to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, surrounding it with music by Tchaikovsky.

title: Editing Hillarys Story
description: Last summer, I asked Hillary Clinton if she had any reservations about using her husband in her campaign. She said no, that having Bill on the team was a great gift. I have always believed you should get the very best people to advise you.

title: Correction: Personal Best | Too Cold to Exercise? Try Another Excuse
description: An article last Thursday about cold-weather exercise misstated the accomplishment of Lewis Gordon Pugh last July while swimming near the North Pole. He completed a kilometer in just under 19 minutes, not a mile.

title: Heart Group Backs Drug Made by Ally
description: After a study last week showed Vytorin, an expensive combination of two drugs for cholesterol, worked no better than cheap Zocor alone in reducing artery plaque that can lead to heart attacks, the American Heart Association came to the drugs defense.

title: In a 49-Year First, Greek Leader Visits Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  In an effort to overcome decades of mutual distrust, Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis of Greece arrived in Turkey on Wednesday for the first official visit by a Greek leader in almost half a century.

title: In Taxing Illegal Drugs, the Trouble Comes in Collecting
description: The Tennessee tax authorities slapped a young concertgoer with $11,506 in taxes and penalties when he was caught with marijuana-laced Rice Krispie Treats. North Carolina collected $11 million in taxes last year on illegal drugs and moonshine. And in Alabama, the rare drug user who chooses to pay state taxes on a stash is issued a sticker to place on the package that declares, Say no to marijuana.

title: A Fear That the Cure Could Be Poison
description: WASHINGTON  Even as the Federal Reserve grapples with the collapse of a speculative bubble in housing  the second speculative bust in less than a decade  is it at risk of repeating recent mistakes?

title: Brian Leetch, a Career Revisited
description: As Brian Leetch prepared for the retirement of his number by the Rangers Thursday night, he spent much of Wednesday recalling moments of the career that earned him the honor. Many of his old Rangers teammates provided anecdotes of their own as well, some you can read in our story.

title: N.H.L. Grounds Thrashers Kovalchuk
description: The Thrashers had a tough time with the Rangers on Tuesday, particularly after their best player, forward Ilya Kovalchuk, was thrown out of the game for boarding Rangers defenseman Michal Rozsival. Now Atlanta will have to do without Kovalchuk again. The N.H.L. suspended him a game for the hit.

title: Pleo, the (Yawn) Dino-Robot. Next!
description: One things for sure: this is the first time Ive ever reviewed a dinosaur.

title: Richard Foreman Machine
description: Photos from Mr. Foreman's new show "Deep Trance Behavior in Potatoland."

title: Respond to Todays Column: Editing Hillarys Story
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Jan. 24 column.

title: Border Crossing
description: Thousands crossed into Egypt from the Gaza Strip to buy supplies that have been cut off during days of blockade by Israel.

title: $7.1 Billion Fraud Uncovered at Socit Gnrale
description: PARIS  The French bank Socit Gnrale said Thursday that it had uncovered "an exceptional fraud" by a trader that would cost it 4.9 billion, or about $7.1 billion, and that it would seek new capital of about $8 billion.

title: Wildly romantic French chocolates for St. Valentines
description: The windows at Josephine Vannier chocolate shop are a startling sight for the uninitiated expecting standard boxes of bon bons wrapped in pristine ribbons. I did a doubletake when I first glanced at the shops whimsical sculptures of spikey heeled shoes, haute couture bags, and icons of the Virgin Mary  all fashioned in various shades of very real chocolate.

title: Writers and the Stories Behind Their Stories
description: How do story-tellers let outsiders into the secrets of their craft or art? By telling stories, of course.

title: South Africas Zuma Answers His Critics
description: Jacob Zuma, newly-elected head of South Africas ruling African National Congress, took time Thursday to address one of the many lingering controversies related to his attitude towards HIV/AIDS.

title: Davos in the Papers: The Fed, Soros, Egalitarianism
description: The Federal Reserves move to slash interest rates took those gathering in Davos for the World Economic Forum by surprise Tuesday. By Wednesday, they seemed to have digested the news  and many didnt find it to their liking.

title: Bank of America to Sell $6 Billion in New Shares
description: Bank of America announced on Wednesday that it planned to raise $6 billion by selling preferred shares, one day after reporting a 95 percent decline in quarterly profit.

title: Sovereign Posts $1.6 Billion Quarterly Loss
description: Sovereign Bancorp, the savings and loan, posted a $1.6 billion quarterly loss on Wednesday and canceled its dividend after a larger-than-expected write-down for consumer credit losses and a 2006 bank acquisition.

title: Sallie Mae Records Huge Loss on Bad Bets
description: Sallie Mae, the embattled student lending giant, said Wednesday that it lost $1.6 billion in its fourth quarter as it prepared for a jump in student loan defaults and took a hit from bad bets on its stock price. It was a stark reversal from the $18 million it earned in the period last year.

title: Apax Pulls Tommy Hilfiger I.P.O.
description: Stock market turbulence claimed its most fashion-conscious victim on Thursday as Tommy Hilfigers private equity owners decided to postpone a planned $2 billion initial public offering of the designer clothing brand indefinitely.

title: Constellation Uncorks Sales of 2 Brands
description: Constellation Brands, the worlds biggest wine company, is selling its Almaden and Inglenook wine brands and the Paul Masson winery in Madera, Calif., to the Wine Group for $134 million.

title: Lone Star Chief Leaves South Korea After Grilling
description: The chairman of Lone Star Funds, the buyout group, left South Korea on Thursday following extensive grilling by prosecutors over its activities in the country.

title: Popular Unloads Equity One to A.I.G. for $1.5 Billion
description: Popular agreed to sell much of its Equity One U.S. consumer finance business to a subsidiary of the American International Group for $1.5 billion, Popular said Wednesday.

title: Ad Infuse Gets $12 Million Injection
description: Ad Infuse on Wednesday became the latest mobile advertising upstart to tap into growing investor interest in the slowly emerging mobile ad market. Ad Infuse, a startup based in San Francisco, said it got $12 million from SoftBank Capital, ComVentures, and Storm Ventures.

title: Entrepreneur Unveils Tourist Spacecraft
description: Burt Rutan took the cloak off of his new spacecraft on Wednesday.

title: Tynes on Letterman
description: Funny stuff. Had he missed the kick, it would have been negative funny multiplied by 47.

title: Too Much Coal in Blackstones Stocking?
description: Throughout the West  in Colorado, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Utah and Wyoming  battles are raging over proposed coal plants.

title: Will Icahn Make Another Run at Motorola?
description: Is Carl C. Icahn going to once again take up the tomahawk at Motorola?

title: Finance C.E.O.s Urge Sovereign Wealth Transparency
description: Leaders of world finance told the holders of $2.5 trillion in sovereign wealth funds that they need to disclose more about their activities or risk further antagonizing American politicians.

title: All Shall Be Well; and All Shall Be Well; and All Manner of Things Shall Be Well
description: Dawn, or its German equivalent, cannot be far off. But here, at the top of the hill, night still clogs the forest. Being sixty-three years old and sleepy, I find it nearly impossible to differentiate now between the stray grapevines, the trees, and the waist-high shrubs that I know surround me. They could all be wild animals.

title: Market Speculates that Brewers Will Pull Bid for British Rival
description: Carlsberg and Heineken rose on speculation the brewers may pull out of a joint offer for a competitor, Scottish & Newcastle.

title: Pernod Buys Lillet
description: The French wines and spirits group Pernod Ricard said on Thursday it would acquire a small French aperitif maker, Lillet, and reaffirmed its interest in Absolut vodka despite the continuing turbulence in credit markets.

title: Opportunists Said to Be Circling Yahoo
description: While Yahoos co-foundersm Jerry Yang and David Filo, may not want to sell the struggling Internet company, its stock price is so low that the duo may not be able to fend off a takeover offer without compromising their fiduciary duty to shareholders, according to The New York Post.

title: Lessons in Brevity
description: I give a lot of presentations, and Im starting to think that I could use a good editor to make sure I dont stay past my welcome. So I was delighted and amused to see this artfully condensed version of Steve Jobss presentation at last weeks Macworld conference.

title: No Childish Talk Left Behind
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Cohen Pledges $50 Million to Childrens Hospital
description: Despite fears of recession looming, the hedge fund manager Steven A. Cohen doesnt seem to be hurting too much.

title: Jefferies Cuts Hedge Fund Investment Amid Loss
description: Jefferies Group, the middle-market investment bank, reported a fourth quarter loss of $24 million, including a loss of $6 million on a consumer equities hedge fund since Jan. 1.

title: Who Is Bill Belichick?
description: Were asking readers to help explain Bill Belichick.

title: Next on the Worry List: Shaky Insurers of Bonds

title: Do State Lawmakers Deserve a Raise?
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has agreed to a pay raise for legislators, even as his budget called for strict cuts elsewhere, the Assembly speaker Sheldon Silver has told New York lawmakers. The pay for the states 212 legislators is now the third-highest in the nation. Their base salary is $79,500, but they can earn more than $100,000 with various bonuses for committee or leadership posts. Their pay has not been increased since 1999. Mr. Spitzers move underscores the degree to which the once reform-focused governor is taking a more accommodating approach this year after spending much of last year mired in controversy.

title: YouTube On the Go
description: YouTube first dipped its toe in the mobile world in November of 2006 with a deal to deliver some video clips through the VCast service of Verizon Wireless. Last year it created a mobile Web site accessible on many Sprint and AT&T phones. But the site only carried a small slice of YouTube content. And it has another subset on the iPhone.

title: Stimulus disappointment
description: If this description is correct, the stimulus bill will be a real disappointment. As I pointed out in an earlier post, economic theory  Milton Friedmans theory!  suggests that if we want stimulus funds spent, they should go to people in temporary economic difficulty who are likely to be liquidity-constrained. But it appears that most of the measures that would do that  benefits to the unemployed, food stamps, aid to state and local governments  are being bargained away. Even the tax credit is apparently not fully refundable, so those who need it most, and are most likely to spend it, wont get the full amount.

title: A Little Heresy
description: Tom McGuanes comment is very trenchant. Its clear of course that Binx doesnt buy Aunt Emily fully; he cant, having put himself outside the charmed circle in which she lives. Yet one cant help but feel that he more than halfway wishes he could join her; he and Kate have a homesickness, a nostalgia to still be inside that circle, that it is for him a place of integrity and peace and comfort, even if an unreachable, outmoded one. However much of a voice from the past Aunt Emilys is, she is nevertheless is the only authentic authority figure in the book.

title: F-16s at Scene of U.F.O. Sighting in Texas

title: More Snow in Antarctica
description: Theres new evidence from an Antarctic ice core that the popular image of the melting poles doesnt quite fit reality at the southern one. Elizabeth R. Thomas of the British Antarctic Survey and colleagues report in Geophysical Research Letters that snow accumulation has doubled since 1850 in the western Antarctic peninsula, and that the trend has accelerated in recent decades.

title: The Impact of Sovereign Wealth Funds

description: The commercial arm of the British Broadcasting Corporation is expected to announce a partnership with MySpace on Thursday to make some of its content available on MySpace, the popular social networking Web site, Thursdays New York Times reports.

title: Philanthropic Transparency | The Glass House
description: There is a catalog for pretty much everything these days, so why not a catalog of philanthropy? The Glass House  the organization that oversees Philip Johnsons iconic weekend house in New Canaan, Conn., which is owned by the National Trust for Historic Preservation  recently sent several thousand potential donors a beautifully-photographed, catalog-like booklet called Projects, to present restoration, educational and outreach projects for which it needs donations. The rewards, apart from the satisfaction of doing your bit for the Modernist cause, arent bad either. Contribute $25,000 to the conservation of a Donald Judd concrete sculpture on the property, and you get a tour of both the Glass House and of Judd Foundation properties in Marfa, Texas. Instead of a gift, we give you an experience, says Christy MacLear, the Glass Houses executive director. Michael Bierut, a partner in the firm Pentagram (and the designer of the logo and signage for The Timess new building), designed the booklet. The catalog format makes for a more intimate experience, he explains  and so does the unusual choice of cover photograph, an image of the houses kitchen with the glorious landscape beyond. We had to de-familiarize people with the house. It was a chance to take them a bit by surprise.

title: Debating the Rise of Sovereign Funds

title: The Whole Creature Heaved and Pulsated
description: One of my favorite tropes in Cloverfield, the new J.J. Abrams-produced monster-destroys-Manhattan movie that made one zillion dollars (give or take) at the box-office last weekend, is that the camera rarely lingers on the giant beastie long enough for audiences to get a clear look at it. What makes the monster so frightening is whatever we viewers project onto it  its whatever we think it might be. (At Aint It Cool News, Harry Knowles wrote that it has a tail, it has teeth, and freaky eyes like that horse that died in Animal House.)

title: Scent Notes | Paestum Rose by lEau dItalie
description: One of the problems with classical beauty is, quite simply, that we know it too well. The eye can pass over a Caravaggio painting and not really see it, finding the image too familiar. It is much easier to attract with novelty and flash, but that burns off quickly and leaves a void. The real trick is to combine the two. If an artist can create new beauty with a classic form, he has done something marvelous because his creation is doubly fueled, by the exhilarating thrill of the new and by the visceral power of the old.

description: As if Restaurant Week wasnt enough of a bargain with $24.07 three-course lunches at top restaurants, the twice-a-year New York City culinary promotion is now simply giving away restaurant food. Today and Friday, from noon to 2 p.m., top chefs will be doling out their creations at the Delta Lounge at 57th Street and Sixth Avenue.This afternoon, the food will be presented by Chef Anne Burrell of Centro Vinoteca and Chef Sean Scotese of Mai House. Ms. Burrell is offering a flan-like dish called ricotta sformato, chicken liver pate, and truffled deviled eggs. Mr. Scotese is serving basa rolls and clay pot chicken. On Friday, the food will be offered from Amalia and Ruby Foos.

title: Percys New Orleans  and Mine
description: Walker Percy wrote about the South better than anyone Ive ever read.What I did not know until I moved to New Orleans, though, and bought ahouse in the Garden District, is how spot on a portrayal of the cityand its residents The Moviegoer really is. Ive always considered ita funny novel, but now I find myself laughing at everything. TheresWalter, Kates fianc feeling all proprietary about the house hethinks may one day be his, squatting on his heels, checking out thebaseboard, calculating the angle of the settle. As the world nowknows, the land beneath most houses in New Orleans closely resemblespudding  I spend a great deal of my own time squatting on my ownheels, looking at the dipping baseboards with a wary eye. Then thereis Binxs cousin Eddie Lovell and his wife Nell. Nell has taste,Binx says, and with those three words I can see her before me, thisinveterate house fixer-upper and flipper, improving the archetypalshotgun houses of New Orleans with old brick and sugar cane kettles,shutters in the bathroom and swinging saloon doors in the kitchen. Ihave been in countless of those very same spaces.

title: Boys Off the Bus

Ill have more to say about that in advance of Saturdays primary, but as I head South, I find myself thinking about an aspect of the campaign thats changed a lot this year, and thats the way the media covers it. I dont mean the horse race or the exclusion of certain candidates or some of the other stuff commenters here have talked about. I mean how we actually get from one event to the other and the way that those logistics inform what you read.

Bloomberg proposed a $58.5 billion budget today that would preserve a popular property tax cut and rebate but cut into virtually every agency, including core city services like education, police, fire, sanitation, cultural affairs and parks. Even after the budget cuts, however, total city spending would increase slightly.

title: Ex-Prosecutors Challenge Giulianis Assessment
description: A group of 25 former prosecutors from the New York area  most of them veterans of the United States attorneys office in Manhattan  have issued a public letter assailing Rudolph W. Giulianis record as the head of the office, from 1983 to 1989. The former mayors campaign dismissed the letter as criticism from lawyers who now have a vested interest in criminal defense.The letter asserts that Mr. Giuliani, who is now seeking the Republican Partys nomination for president, improperly used the office to promote himself, leaked information to reporters and exaggerated his accomplishments, and that such behavior casts doubt, generally, on Giulianis credibility and judgment.

title: Detectives in Sean Bell Shooting Will Waive Jury Trial
description: The detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell plan to waive a jury trial and present their case in a bench trial before the judge, prosecutors said Thursday. A hearing on the matter before Justice Arthur J. Cooperman is scheduled for Friday at 2 p.m. at State Supreme Court in Queens. Waiving a jury trial must be done in writing before the judge.

title: At Davos, LAffaire Kerviel Is the Topic du Jour
description: The figure that arrived on BlackBerries in Davos and made by far the most headlines on Thursday was this: 4.9 billion euros, or $7.2 billion. This massive trading fraud, announced by Socit Gnrale earlier in the day and allegedly executed by a single rogue trader, put Barings Nick Leeson to shame and sent shudders down the spines of all those working in the financial world and pressing the flesh this week at the World Economic Forum.

title: Purple States: Religion in Politics
description: In South Carolina, citizen reporters Tamara and Alex talk to the presidential candidates about faith and values.

title: A Minute With Wolves
description: Gray wolves in the northern Rockies. (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Video)

title: Spectrum Auction Day 1: $2.779  Billion in Bids
description: As promised, the highly touted auction of the 700-megahertz band of wireless spectrum, which began today, is excruciating to watch.

title: Joyful Headline Noise: Amy Winehouse
description: About a month before her album penetrated U.S. borders, Amy Winehouse was unveiled on The Lede as a kind of antidote to Britney Spears. Both produced embarrassing press coverage, yet only Ms. Winehouse was talking about it in her lyrics.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Lost in Beijing'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Lost in Beijing," directed by Yu Li.

title: Why worry about a poor stimulus plan?
description: So the stimulus plan agreed to by House Democrats is a real piece of, um, bad legislation. It could have been even worse  it could have been the plan Bush wanted, which would have delivered virtually no stimulus at all. But its very, very weak.

title: Romney Prepares for Battle
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.Mitt Romney said he would float like a butterfly and sting like a bee tonight.

title: The Late Show with Barack Obama
description: If elected, Barack Obama will name Oprah Winfrey his vice president and appoint Mitt Romney the secretary of lookin good.

title: Talk of Giants, Vice Presidents and Daddys Little Girl
description: BARNWELL, S.C.  At his fourth campaign stop of the day, former President Bill Clinton went on for two hours and remained on message. But he did pick a team for the Super Bowl. (Hows that for forcing you to read a little further?)

title: Hitting the National Airwaves
description: Media reporter Jacques Steinberg analyzes national campaign ads by Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

title: The Times Editorial Board Endorsements
description: The editorial board of The New York Times has just endorsed: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Democratic race and Senator John McCain in the Republican field.

title: U.S. Decline Makes History
description: Boosters in the U.S. may decry the medias characterization of the housing industrys woes, but theres no mistaking the terrible numbers released yesterday by the National Association of Realtors.

title: Live-Blogging the G.O.P. Debate in Fla.
description: 11:11 p.m. | Wrapup This debate crystallized some substantive differences among the Republican candidates, on the issue of the economy, the new stimulus package that Congress will take up, and of course, on their anticipated opponent, Senator Clinton.

title: John Harwood With David Plouffe
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times interviews Barack  Obama's campaign manager, David Plouffe.

title: Memory Refill
description: At home, hidden in the bread box, I have a few samples of a delicious herb-chicory mix given to me by my acupuncturist to help me break my addiction to coffee.

title: Cape Town, South Africa
description: A weekend in Cape Town, taking in its history and natural beauty, from the historic Long Street all the way down to Cape Point.

title: Raising McCain
description: Nearly lost in the blizzard of recent poll reports were the findings of a Gallup survey that the current Republican frontrunner, John McCain, might well give each of the two Democratic frontrunners a run for their money.

title: The Late Show with Barack Obama
description: If elected, Barack Obama will name Oprah Winfrey his vice president and appoint Mitt Romney the secretary of lookin good. The Democratic presidential candidate will announce those campaign promises and eight others in the familiar Top 10 segment of The Late Show with David Letterman on Thursday night.

title: So Far, Marketers Stick With Networks
description: From Fridays New York Times:

title: Wolfowitz Returns to U.S. Government as Adviser
description: Paul D. Wolfowitz, who resigned as World Bank chief after serving as second-in-command at the Pentagon, has returned to the Bush administration, albeit in an advisory role. From a short news release put out this afternoon:

title: Up Next on the Red Carpet: Adam Graves
description: When Adam Graves first heard Brian Leetch say he had something to announce during his number-retirement speech at Madison Square Garden Thursday night, he was as curious as anyone else. The acoustics were a bit challenging at ice level, Graves said, so he was not even sure he heard it right when Leetch said Graves number would be the next the Rangers would retire.

title: Rangers Relieved Heading Into All-Star Break
description: It was hard to tell what was a bigger motivation in the Rangers game Thursday night against Atlanta, not stinking it up on Brian Leetchs night or sending themselves into the All-Star break on a winning note.

title: Two Sides of Giuliani
description: Rudolph W. Giulianis presidential bid has been built on an image of him as the hero of Sept. 11. The International Association of Fire Fighters, however, is spending several hundred thousand dollars to debunk that image and has begun confronting Mr. Giuliani in Florida wherever he campaigns.

title: Comedy on Wheels
description: Trailer Park Boys: The Movie is like a feature-length version of the television sitcom My Name Is Earl, only Canadian  and not funny.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about moves to strengthen the finances of some bond insurance companies misspelled the surname of the chief executive of Tempus Advisors, who commented on the risk the companies are facing. He is Edward J. Grebeck, not Gerbeck.

title: Russia Talks of a Stability Beyond Ties to the U.S.
description: MOSCOW  In almost a decade since the Russian debt crisis of 1998, finance officials here have amassed an enviable war chest with the largest per capita currency reserves in the world while paying down nearly all sovereign debt.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Vermonts Forgotten Trails and Frozen Lifts of Winters Past
description: STANDING in a small, abandoned clearing alongside lonely Route 8 in southern Vermont, its hard to fathom that it was once a bustling ski area called Dutch Hill. On this site there were three lifts, two lodges, cafeterias and a ski shop  an attraction with a loyal following that stormed up this isolated country lane to fill Dutch Hills parking lots for 40 winters.

title: Palestinians Hurry to Finish Their Shopping in Egypt
description: RAFAH, Egypt  There was less joy than frenzy on Thursday at this border crossing, as Gazans and Gaza businessmen hurried to stock up while they still could.

title: Taos Ski Valley
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Blazing a Trail, and Following Her Own Sense of Whats Right
description: HER chambers in the Surrogates Court portion of the Supreme Court complex in Brooklyn are neither hushed nor imposing: Homey and aromatic (there is coffee brewing on the snack table) is more like it, with a foldaway bicycle in the corner attesting to this judges unstuffy approach to her magisterial duties.

title: French Bank Says Rogue Trader Lost $7 Billion
description: PARIS  A French bank announced Thursday that it had lost $7.2 billion, not because of complex subprime loans, but the old-fashioned way  because a 31-year-old rogue trader made bad bets on stocks and then, in trying to cover up those losses, dug himself deeper into a hole.

title: British Brewer Is Sold for $15.4 Billion
description: LONDON  Scottish & Newcastle, Britains largest brewer, agreed on Friday to a 7.8 billion ($15.4 billion) takeover by the European rivals Carlsberg and Heineken.

title: Unseeded Frenchman Derails Nadal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  As the acrobatic drop volleys, huge forehands and first serves kept turning into winners, Rafael Nadal puffed out his cheeks and raised his eyebrows.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Visionaries in a Bubble, Safe From Convention
description: Some people think the label outsider artist should be retired. Why does it matter whether an artist is self-taught, mentally impaired or deranged? The best outsider art is good for the same reasons that art by professional insiders is good: because it is formally eye-catching, inventively made, unpredictably imaginative and passionately driven.

title: Safety Nets in Citys Skies Protect Workers and Passers-by. But Not Always.
description: In the city of skyscrapers, the skyline is more colorful than ever.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Democrats Target Their Appeals in South Carolina
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  As Democrats headed on Friday toward the finish line of their first primary in the South, the candidates spent the day trying to widen their appeal to groups outside their core group of allies.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Dec. 3 about the growth in federal prosecutions of slavery cases, including one against a Long Island couple, Varsha and Mahender Sabhnani, accused of keeping two Indonesian domestic workers as slaves in their home, included an incorrect age from law enforcement officials for Mrs. Sabhnani. She is 45, not 35. (The error also appeared in brief reports on the case by The Associated Press in some editions on May 25, July 10 and Aug. 22.) A reader raised a question about the age in an e-mail message on Dec. 18, and this correction was delayed for research.

title: Judge Throws Out Rape Indictment of New York City Councilman
description: A State Supreme Court justice threw out the rape indictment against City Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher on Thursday, finding that prosecutors had prejudiced grand jury members while presenting the case against him.

title: At Ford, Chief Intends to Get Its Units in Sync
description: DETROIT  At a town hall meeting with employees on Thursday at the Ford Motor Company headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive, pulled out a laminated card emblazoned with the words One Ford and the companys blue oval logo.

title: Keeping the Heat On
description: AS with most things in life (appliances, your body, relationships), maintenance is the key to the health and proper functioning of your furnace. So the first thing to do at a seasonal home is to have the furnace checked annually.
