Especially if youre going to be away from the house for long periods of time, said Roger Fouche, owner and president of Schaal Heating and Cooling of Des Moines. The No. 1 most important thing is to do basic preventative maintenance.

title: Brutal, Painful Death, Just a Mouse Click Away
description: Morally duplicitous torture porn: how else to describe Untraceable, a bleak, rain-washed horror thriller whose predatory villain delivers a scolding lecture about Internet voyeurism and the dark side of human nature? That lecture arrives as a contemptuous I told you so at the end of the movie, after the designated fiend has streamed live video of several of his hideous crimes on his own Web site, killwithme.com.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Week in Review article on Sept. 16 and an entry in The Times Magazines 7th Annual Year in Ideas report on Dec. 9 about the use of computer maps to help find Steve Fossett, the aviation adventurer whose plane disappeared Sept. 3, 2007, misstated the area being studied by analysts on screen. It was plots of 77,284 square feet, or 278 feet by 278 feet, not 278 or 250 square feet. A readers e-mail messages calling attention to the errors were misdirected at The Times.

title: Czech Wins Title
description: Tomas Verner, a Czech, won his first major international championship Thursday, taking the European mens title over a pair of skaters with three world titles between them. Stephane Lambiel of Switzerland, the 2005-6 world champion, and Brian Joubert of France, the current world champion, were second and third. Verner, 21, skated early in the last group and did enough to hold onto his lead after the short program. He tried a quad but put his hand down. Then he completed seven triple jumps.The ice dancers Isabelle Delobel and Olivier Schoenfelder, the defending champions, extended their lead earlier Thursday.

title: Colorado Lawmaker Censured for Kicking
description: DENVER  In the week leading up to his first day on the job, State Representative Douglas Bruce, a Republican, got into a lengthy dispute with the Democratic speaker of the House over the time of his swearing in.

title: $650,000 Fine Urged for Indian Point Owner
description: WASHINGTON  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has proposed a fine of $650,000  10 times the normal size  against the owner of the Indian Point reactors because it missed a deadline to install new emergency warning sirens with backup power supplies.

title: Familiarity Breeds Gloom Among Financial Experts
description: DAVOS, Switzerland

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about moves to strengthen the finances of some bond insurance companies misspelled the surname of the chief executive of Tempus Advisors, who commented on the risk the companies are facing. He is Edward J. Grebeck, not Gerbeck. (Go to Article)

title: A Rejuvenated Weir Hopes for a Fresh Start
description: ST. PAUL  The tug of the rest of his life, and a future beyond figure skating, nagged at Johnny Weir late in 2006. Criticized for his outspokenness, his lifestyle, his affinity for all things Russian, and for frittering away a chance at a medal in the 2006 Winter Olympics, Weir dreaded the prospect of another skating season. Every morning, he said he questioned whether he wanted to continue.

title: The Bill Clinton Factor: Is It a Plus?
description: To the Editor:

title: Strains on the I.R.S. Could Delay Rebate Checks for Months
description: The checks will be in the mail  eventually.

title: In Senate, a White House Victory on Eavesdropping
description: WASHINGTON  A White House plan to broaden the National Security Agencys wiretapping powers won a key procedural victory in the Senate on Thursday, as backers defeated a more restrictive plan by Senate Democrats that would have imposed more court oversight on government spying.

title: Swedes Ponder Whether Killer Can Be a Doctor
description: STOCKHOLM  The Karolinska Institute here is famed for choosing the winners of the Nobel Prize in Medicine each year, and as one of the worlds most prestigious medical schools it rejects many students with the highest grades.

title: Obama Delivers an Anticorporate Message
description: Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, is running three new advertisements in six states ahead of the multistate primary on Feb. 5. This 30-second commercial, Need, is running in Connecticut, Delaware and Utah.

title: 10 Die in Mistaken Afghan Firefight
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least nine Afghan police officers and a civilian were killed early Thursday in a firefight between American forces and the officers in Ghazni Province, just south of the capital, local officials said.

title: Throughout Asia, Exporters Brace for Tremors From a U.S. Pullback
description: HONG KONG  Asian exporters are already feeling the effects of an American economic downturn  effects that may be magnified by a weak dollar, volatile world markets and fears that more bad loans may be ticking in the coffers of American companies.

title: Group Seeks New Warning About Botox
description: WASHINGTON  Botox and a similar injected drug have been associated with 16 deaths, four of them in children, and scores of serious injuries that occurred after the drug spread to vital organs, a health advocacy group says.

title: Turkey to Alter Speech Law
description: IZMIR, Turkey  When Atilla Yayla, a maverick political science professor, offered a mild criticism of Turkeys first years as a country, his remarks unleashed a torrent of abuse.

title: An Expressionist in Albuquerque
description: Like Georgia OKeeffe, Stuart Davis and others, Richard Diebenkorn went to New Mexico and had a breakthrough. He arrived in Albuquerque in January 1950, with his wife, Phyllis, and their young son and daughter. He had been teaching at the California School of Fine Arts but had decided to go to graduate school at the University of New Mexico, courtesy of the G.I. Bill, so that he could paint full time. He was 27 years old.

title: Traffic Panel Members Expect to Endorse Fees on Cars
description: The state commission studying ways to reduce traffic in Manhattan is likely to recommend that lawmakers approve a slimmed-down version of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing plan when it holds its final meeting next week, according to several members of the panel.

title: Magazine Started by Warhol Names Editorial Directors
description: Glenn OBrien, a longtime New York writer and editor, and Fabien Baron, most recently the creative director for French Vogue, were named joint editorial directors of Interview magazine after the resignation of its editor in chief, Ingrid Sischy.

title: Japan: Rules for Police Interrogations
description: The national police, shown to have used coercive practices to secure confessions, some entirely fabricated, issued interrogation guidelines for the first time. One-way mirrors will be placed in interrogation rooms, and officers may not touch, threaten or verbally abuse suspects, keep them in a fixed posture or offer favors in return for expressions of guilt. The police will also be limited to eight-hour sessions, and overnight interrogations, aimed at breaking suspects with exhaustion, are banned.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: The Simple Life, North of the Volvo Line
description: IT was love at first schuss for the Gulliver-Joyle family upon their first visit to Sugarloaf in western Maine in 1995. They bought a condo near the mountain three years later for $100,000, but soon realized it was not for them.

title: Flooding Stops Races
description: Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif., called off live racing Thursday for the fourth time this month because of heavy rainfall and overnight hail on a synthetic track that has had drainage problems since its installation. The track was open for simulcast racing. Ron Charles, the track president, said he was confident that a binding element applied to the racing surface, when the weather improved, would solve the drainage problem.

title: Ad Trade Group to Name Its First Female President
description: Ad Trade Group to Name

title: Paint on a Coat Brings an Arrest in Brooklyn Swastika Case
description: During a spate of swastika-painting incidents in Brooklyn last month, the police said they were alerted several times by an anonymous tipster who seemed curiously well informed.

title: Nation of Kazakhstan Enjoys Last Laugh
description: Cinematically speaking, things have taken a turn for the better in Kazakhstan. Derided in 2006 by Sacha Baron Cohens Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan, the former Soviet republic is basking in the glow of an Oscar nomination for best foreign film. The nominee, Mongol, directed by Sergei Bodrov, a Russian, is a tale of survival and war that tracks the early life of Genghis Khan. This nomination is a message to Kazakhstans business and government: Guys, you can export not just oil, gas and grain but highly creative products, Bolat Galimgereyev, below left, one of the films producers and sponsors, told Reuters. Mongol is the first Kazakh film to receive an Oscar nomination.

title: Bush Nudges Senate to Move on Stimulus Package
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush prodded the Senate on Friday to move quickly on the stimulus package laid out on Thursday, saying that Americans need extra cash in their wallets as soon as possible to rejuvenate the economy.

title: City Releases Police Data to Crime Research Group
description: The New York Police Department has turned over an electronic database on more than 500,000 street stops made by officers in 2006 to analysts at a national crime data archive in Michigan, officials from the City Law Department said on Thursday. The intent, officials said, is that the data will be released in some fashion to researchers and the public.

title: Senators Criticize U.N. Program in North Korea, but Question Set of Accusations
description: WASHINGTON  A Senate subcommittee criticized the United Nations Development Program in North Korea on Thursday, accusing it of lax management and poor accountability.

title: Golf Without Borders
description: MANUEL MEHOS was surfing one of Mexicos best-known breaks when he looked up from his paddling in the Pacific. I said to myself, he recalled, Wouldnt it be great if there were a development here someday?

title: U.S. Asking Iraq for Wide Rights on War
description: WASHINGTON  With its international mandate in Iraq set to expire in 11 months, the Bush administration will insist that the government in Baghdad give the United States broad authority to conduct combat operations and guarantee civilian contractors specific legal protections from Iraqi law, according to administration and military officials.

title: Primary Choices: John McCain
description: We have strong disagreements with all the Republicans running for president. The leading candidates have no plan for getting American troops out of Iraq. They are too wedded to discredited economic theories and unwilling even now to break with the legacy of President Bush. We disagree with them strongly on what makes a good Supreme Court justice.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Study Says Private Equity Isnt Big Job Killer
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Among the worlds private equity kings and policy makers, the issue of whether buyouts create jobs or result in more layoffs has always been the $100 billion question.

title: At 36, Toomey Is Outrunning Her Demons
description: BOSTON  Jen Toomeys on-and-off running career is on again, and forget the prerace jitters or the injuries that almost led the 36-year-old athlete to stop running.

title: Friend Indeed Who Doesnt Judge or Flinch
description: In 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days, a ferocious, unsentimental, often brilliantly directed film about a young woman who helps a friend secure an abortion, the camera doesnt follow the action, it expresses consciousness itself. This consciousness  alert to the world and insistently alive  is embodied by a young university student who, one wintry day in the late 1980s, helps her roommate with an abortion in Ceausescus Romania when such procedures were illegal, not uncommon and too often fatal. Its a pitiless, violent story that in its telling becomes a haunting and haunted intellectual and aesthetic achievement.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Clintons Multibillion-Dollar Energy Program
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign began broadcasting this spot, Serious, on Wednesday in California. The state, whose primary is on Feb. 5, is the ultimate prize for Democrats, assigning 441 convention delegates.

title: Amgen Posts Weak Results, but Hails Osteoporosis Drug
description: Amgen, the biotechnology company, said Thursday that its experimental osteoporosis drug, the brightest hope in its product pipeline, proved superior to Fosamax from Merck in a clinical trial.

title: Ghana Advances
description: The four-time winner Ghana moved near the quarterfinals at the African Cup of Nations on Thursday, beating Namibia by 1-0 on a goal by Junior Agogo. Ghana, which last won the title in 1982, leads Group A with 6 points and needs only a tie in its final game to ensure a place in the final eight. Guinea and Morocco have 3 points each, after Guinea beat Morocco, 3-2. Namibia has none.

title: Frailty of U.S. Finances Has Japanese Agonizing
description: TOKYO  As talk of an American recession has helped batter global financial markets in recent weeks, economic policy makers in Japan, the worlds second-largest economy, have largely sat on the sidelines.

title: Gangsterism as Allegory for Lifes Basic Themes
description: The Air I Breathe is an ingenious contraption that holds your attention for as long as it whirs and clicks like a mechanized Rubiks Cube. After its over, however, you may find yourself scratching your head and wondering if there was any purpose to this sleek little gizmo.

title: Rating Teachers: Are Tests the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharapova to Face Foe She Doesnt Quite Tower Over
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  At first glance, it will be tall, 20-year-old blonde versus tall, 20-year-old brunette in the womens final at the Australian Open on Saturday.

title: A Spiritual Fight
description: In the intriguingly layered documentary Orthodox Stance, a determined young boxer strives to prove that the laws of God and the laws of the ring need not be at odds.

title: Fraud Costs Bank $7.1 Billion
description: PARIS  Socit Gnrale, one of the largest banks in Europe, was thrown into turmoil Thursday after it disclosed that a rogue employee executed a series of elaborate, fictitious transactions that cost the bank more than $7 billion, the biggest loss ever recorded by a single trader.

title: A Spiral of Losses by a Plain Vanilla Trader
description: PARIS  On the elite trading floors here, where Frances brightest minds devise some of the most complex instruments in global finance, few people noticed Jrme Kerviel.

title: With a Day of Steady Gains, U.S. Stocks Join in a Global Rebound
description: The Dow Jones industrial average spent most of Thursday in positive territory, and the major American markets closed near their highs for the day as investors extended a global financial rally that began Wednesday afternoon.

title: California Justices Put Limits on Medical Marijuana Law
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the latest setback for advocates of medical marijuana in California, the State Supreme Court ruled Thursday that employers were within their rights to fire employees who fail drug tests.

title: In a Show of Accessibility, Schumann Joins Bruckner
description: Radu Lupu and the Schumann Piano Concerto have been making separate appearances in New York City this season, but the two are getting together this week at the New York Philharmonic. On Wednesday the Schumann joined Bruckners Sixth Symphony at Avery Fisher Hall for this weeks subscription program. Riccardo Muti was the conductor, continuing his extended visit with the orchestra.

title: Trading Partners Fear U.S. Consumers Wont Continue Free-Spending Ways
description: Not long ago, many experts were convinced that a vibrant world economy would prevent an American recession. Even if the beleaguered American consumer suddenly turned thrifty, they reasoned, healthy spending on other shores was supposed to keep the expansion rolling.

title: Those Sweet Mysteries of Life, Deciphered
description: The world is a crazy place. It makes perfect sense only to conspiracy theorists and economists of a certain stripe. Tim Harford, a columnist for The Financial Times and the author of The Undercover Economist, is one of these, a devotee of rational-choice theory, which he applies ingeniously and entertainingly to all kinds of problems in The Logic of Life.

title: Actors Death May Mean Films End
description: LOS ANGELES  Heath Ledgers death has created an enormous marketing challenge for Warner Brothers in promoting its Batman sequel, The Dark Knight, in which he plays the Joker. But that is nothing next to the predicament confronting Terry Gilliam, who was less than halfway through directing his next film when Mr. Ledger, one of its stars, was found dead in a New York apartment on Tuesday.

title: New York Republican Will Retire From House
description: WASHINGTON  Representative James T. Walsh, a Republican from central New York facing a tough re-election challenge, announced on Thursday that he would retire this year, delivering yet another blow to national Republicans.

title: Crimes in White Plains Decline to Record Lows
description: WHITE PLAINS  Serious crimes in this rapidly gentrifying city dropped to the lowest levels in more than four decades in 2007, according to statistics released on Thursday by officials here, and no murder has been recorded in White Plains since May 2006.

title: E.P.A. Chief Defends His Decision on California
description: WASHINGTON  Defending his refusal to let California set limits on the greenhouse gas emissions of automobiles, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency insisted before a Senate committee Thursday that climate change posed no compelling and extraordinary risk to the state.

title: Taking Sides in the Senate
description: The name of Senator Ben Nelson, a centrist Democrat from Nebraska, is regularly bandied about as a potential Democratic vice presidential pick given his status as a former governor able to reel in those elusive independents. But it is probably safe to strike him from Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons short list for No. 2.

title: Labor Dept. Working on Changes for Families Coping With Illness and Military Duty
description: Labor Department officials said on Thursday that they had proposed new regulations that address some corporate complaints that workers are abusing the Family and Medical Leave Act.

title: Turning the Triple Play
description: WHY is the Republicans three-legged stool wobbling?

title: Theater Listings
description: GLIMPSES OF THE MOON Some say the Algonquin Hotel is haunted by the spirits of Jazz Age literati like Alexander Woollcott, Dorothy Parker and other members of the celebrated Round Table who met daily in the 1920s to trade bons mots. Perhaps. Certainly many distinguished guests have dined at, or performed in, the hotels Oak Room, a busy cabaret supper club today. But Monday nights show, an adaptation of Edith Whartons comic novel The Glimpses of the Moon, is a departure. The Oak Room does not generally offer musical comedy.

title: Correction: Close to History, Art and Lots of Adobe
description: The High & Low column last Friday about condominiums in Santa Fe, N.M., misstated the age of the Plaza, the capitals historic hub. It dates to the early 1600s, not the early 1700s.

title: Four California Museums Are Raided
description: LOS ANGELES  Federal agents raided a Los Angeles gallery and four museums in Southern California on Thursday, including the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, as part of a five-year investigation into the smuggling of looted antiquities from Thailand, Myanmar, China and Native American sites.

title: Wall St. Journal to Continue Its Charges for Web Content
description: The Wall Street Journal will continue to charge readers for access to much of its Web site, Rupert Murdoch said Thursday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the legal limits of corporal punishment, an issue raised in the murder trial of Cesar Rodriguez of Brooklyn, accused of beating his 7-year-old stepdaughter to death, referred imprecisely to a bill introduced in the California Assembly last year. The bill, which was abandoned, would have criminalized parental discipline involving a closed fist, belt, electrical cord, shoe or other objects, but it would not have outlawed all corporal punishment.

title: Ad Industry Group Set to Name First Female Chief
description: The largest trade organization for the advertising industry is poised to name the first female leader in its 91-year history.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $6,921,774

title: Two Cheers for Wall St.
description: There is roughly a 100 percent chance that were going to spend much of this year talking about the subprime mortgage crisis, the financial markets and the worsening economy. The only question is which narrative is going to prevail, the Greed Narrative or the Ecology Narrative.

title: Leader of Child Agency in New Jersey Resigns
description: After two years of leading court-ordered reforms to New Jerseys embattled child welfare system, the commissioner of the State Department of Children and Families announced his resignation on Thursday.

title: Live Nation Finds a Buyer for Its Theater Business
description: After almost a year of fielding bids, Live Nation has sold most of its North American theater business, including the Broadway Across America touring network, to Key Brand Entertainment, a company owned by a British producer and run by an American entertainment executive.

title: Diva as Broadway Baby
description: What is an imperial Wagnerian soprano to make of Mary Poppins? When she administers that spoonful of sugar to make the medicine go down, how bitter should it taste behind its sickly sweet camouflage?

title: Researchers Take Step Toward Synthetic Life
description: Taking a significant step toward the creation of synthetic forms of life, researchers reported Thursday that they had manufactured the entire genome of a bacterium by stitching together its chemical components.

title: All of America, and Parking Too
description: WHEN people set out on a jaunt to a town they have never visited, they inevitably spend a short time touring some second-tier natural wonder  be it crag or cataract  or a building where Louisa May Alcott once slept, or a gimcrack museum containing the quill Washington Irving supposedly used to pen Rip Van Winkle. But mostly they spend their time shopping, because shopping is what Americans like to do. And when they are not shopping, they are eating.

title: Bound for New Life, Set to Music of the Old World
description: After the world premiere of Oltremare at the New York State Theater on Wednesday night, the New York City Ballet dancers were joined onstage first by the choreographer, Mauro Bigonzetti, and next by the composer of its commissioned score, Bruno Moretti. Seeing the two men together, with their similar clothes and spectacles, several people in the audience asked, Are they brothers?

title: Microsoft Delivers Strong Growth and Includes a Sunny Forecast
description: Microsoft reported quarterly sales and profit gains that surpassed Wall Streets expectations and delivered an optimistic outlook Thursday, suggesting that a weakening economy would not slow it down.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with a sports article on Wednesday about excitement over the Giants Super Bowl berth reversed the identities of two team members who attended the opening of the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday. Geoffrey Pope was on the left, and Gibril Wilson on the right.

title: Accident Closes Major Shipping Channel for Hours
description: A 669-foot tank ship carrying orange juice collided with a smaller dredging ship in Newark Bay on Thursday, forcing the Coast Guard to close a waterway that leads to some of the largest shipping terminals on the East Coast for about five hours.

title: Senate Looking at Endowments as Tuition Rises
description: The Senate Finance Committee, increasingly concerned about the rising cost of higher education, demanded detailed information on Thursday from the nations 136 wealthiest colleges and universities on how they raised tuition over the last decade, gave out financial aid and managed and spent their endowments.

title: Matteson Gets His Bearings and Grabs the Lead
description: SAN DIEGO  Each year during the first two rounds of the Buick Invitational at Torrey Pines Golf Course, there is enough bickering about North and South to cause one to wonder if they made a wrong turn into a Civil War symposium. This is because the field plays one round on each of the two layouts for the first two rounds of the Buick, which as often as not produces an unknown leader who shot a crazy number on the easier Torrey Pines North Course rather than the sprawling 7,300 yards of seaside golf that is the South.

title: Fishing for True Confessions by Dangling a Pot of Gold
description: In the annals of reality television, The Moment of Truth may be a milestone. Fox has come up with a cash-prize competition that is neither a game of chance nor a test of knowledge. Its a pseudo-psychological trial by ordeal in which the contestants trade candor for dollars.

title: Chronicles Editor to Take Broader Role at Hearst
description: After almost eight years as the top editor, Phil Bronstein will leave The San Francisco Chronicle and take a post with its parent, the Hearst Corporation, the company announced Wednesday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,920 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

title: New Details Emerge on Rogue Traders Deals
description: PARIS  As financial markets plunged on Monday, prompting anxious calls from the United States Treasury to the White House, no one quite seemed to know why things had become so unglued.

title: Finger-Pointing Over the Plight of the Gazans
description: To the Editor:

title: Gates Foundation to Give $306 Million to Assist Poor Farmers
description: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which has spent billions of dollars to improve the health of poor people in developing countries, will reach into its deep pockets on Friday for a newer philanthropic mission: to increase the productivity of impoverished farmers.

title: X1 Express Bus From Midtown to Staten Island
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Health Care Up to Public, Edwards Says
description: PATRICK, S.C.  Former Senator John Edwards does not discount the possibility that his health care proposal, which would allow Americans to buy new government insurance packages modeled on Medicare, could evolve into a federalized system like those in Canada and many European countries. And if it does, Mr. Edwards said he would be just fine with that.

title: Bill Hart, Theater Director, Is Dead at 70
description: Bill Hart, a theater director and dramaturge who worked closely with Sam Shepard and other downtown theater artists, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Footnotes
description: The next James Bond film has a title: Quantum of Solace, The Associated Press reported. At Pinewood Studios outside London on Thursday the producer, Michael G. Wilson, said the title was taken from an Ian Fleming story in the collection For Your Eyes Only. The film is to open in the United States and Britain on Nov. 7. ... Scarlett Johansson, known for her film performances, will release her debut album, Anywhere I Lay My Head, on May 20. Among other tracks, the album, on Atco Records, an imprint of Warner Music Groups Rhino Entertainment, features 10 Tom Waits songs. ... Last years Grease reality casting show on NBC drew critical snickers and laughable ratings. But it sold a heck of a lot of Broadway tickets. Now auditions for Legally Blonde: The Search for the New Elle Woods are set for this month in New York; Los Angeles; Chicago; Orlando, Fla.; and Nashville. Broadcasts will begin on MTV in the spring.

title: Committee Reviewing McNamee Tapes
description: The House oversight committee is reviewing transcripts of three conversations by Brian McNamee, the personal trainer who said he injected Roger Clemens with performance-enhancing drugs, a congressional staff person with direct knowledge of the matter said Thursday.

title: Undercover Work Seen as Mix of Art, Temptation and, Sometimes, Corruption
description: Working as an undercover narcotics officer is among the most dangerous jobs on the police force. You have to pretend to be an addict and win the trust of dealers. But if you must do the job, it would seem, a good place to land would be the area designated by the Police Department as Brooklyn South.

title: Diagnosing Mood Disorders in a New Generation
description: Dr. Ellen Leibenluft, a psychiatrist, directs the research program on bipolar disorder in children and adolescents at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md. Among other research into bipolar disorder, the N.I.M.H. currently is funding efforts to help clarify the diagnostic criteria for early-onset disease. The work is being undertaken against a backdrop of evidence that clinicians may be applying the diagnosis of bipolar disorder too broadly in children.

title: Funeral Plans for Ledger Remain Cloudy
description: Two days after the actor Heath Ledger was found dead in his apartment in SoHo, reporters and paparazzi converged on Thursday at the funeral home where his body had been taken.

title: Ford Narrows Loss for 2007
description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company said Thursday that it lost $2.75 billion in the fourth quarter, a loss that erased a small profit through the first nine months of the year.

title: Just When You Thought It Was Safe to Go Back in the Jungle
description: Has it really been 20 years? Last time we saw John Rambo, in 1988, he was involved in some cold war endgame stuff in Afghanistan, and his action-movie franchise, begun in 1982 with First Blood, seemed to be sputtering toward self-parody. Since then Rambo has faded into semi-obscurity, though his name is sometimes still used, perhaps a bit unfairly, as a synonym for revanchist, go-it-alone militarism.

title: Skiing is as Natural as Sneezing, but So Much More Fun
description: MY first ski-area season pass, encased in hard plastic with an old-lady brooch glued on the back, dates from 1973  one piece in a sizable collection of ski-related junk. But even though Ive been skiing for more than three decades, I still get that little belly flip of anticipation on a ski morning when the car rounds a bend and the windshield suddenly fills with a trail-laced mountain.

title: At Debate on the Economy, Republicans Become Kindest of Candidates
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  With the fiercely contested Florida primary election just days away, the Republican presidential candidates engaged in some decidedly gentle sparring here Thursday night as they all tried to cast themselves as able fiscal stewards who could steer the nations increasingly precarious economy back to health.

title: Manning Keeping Things Normal During Abnormal Times
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Eli Manning changed his cellphone number about a month ago, he had no idea how helpful it would be. He appreciated the benefits only after the Giants beat the Green Bay Packers on Sunday to earn a trip to Super Bowl XLII. The new number prevented an avalanche of ticket requests and congratulatory calls from those outside his inner circle.

title: Home Prices Sank in 2007, and Buyers Hid
description: The median price of an American single-family home fell in 2007 for the first time in at least four decades, according to the National Association of Realtors, a trade group.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the political difficulties faced by Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy misstated the number of times he met on Wednesday with President Giorgio Napolitano. It was once, not twice.

title: Britain: Plan to Hold Terror Suspects 42 Days
description: The government of Prime Minister Gordon Brown unveiled a plan to hold terrorism suspects up to 42 days without charges. The current limit is 28 days. The Home Office security minister, Tony McNulty, said the measure was needed because Britain could face two or three 9/11s in a single day, requiring complex investigations. The plan has stirred protests from opposition parties and from a group of the governing Labor Partys own parliamentary members. That could defeat the proposal, repeating the experience of 2005, when a 90-day detention proposed by Tony Blair was defeated in the House of Commons.

title: Bonus Plan for Pelini
description: Nebraska Coach Bo Pelinis contract, made public this week, calls for him to earn up to an additional $250,000 a year if his program reaches all academic milestones listed. That is the second-highest academic incentive pay in the nation behind the $300,000 Ohio States Jim Tressel could receive. But it is less than a third of the $800,000 Pelini would get for winning a national title. Pelini would be paid $125,000 if the programs graduation rate is equal to or greater than that of the student body. He also can earn bonuses based on the programs Academic Performance Rating, which the N.C.A.A. uses to measure athletes progress toward graduation.

title: Tens of Thousands More From Gaza Enter Egypt Seeking Consumer Goods
description: RAFAH, Egypt  Tens of thousands more Palestinians flooded across the breached border crossing from Gaza into Egypt on Thursday, and Egyptian merchants greeted them with a cornucopia of consumer goods and higher prices than on Wednesday, when Hamas militants toppled large sections of the fence.

title: Storm Prompts Flood Warnings in California
description: A powerful winter storm continued to lash southern California for the fifth consecutive day on Friday, prompting warnings of flash floods at lower elevations and snow in the mountains to the north and east of Los Angeles.

title: AT&T Downplays Damage From Economic Slowdown
description: Heads turned on Wall Street on Thursday as AT&T executives tempered earlier statements about the expected impact of lower consumer and business spending on their business.

title: Critiques of Spending Plan Retrace Old Debate
description: Useful, but flawed and probably not enough: that, in general terms, was the verdict pronounced on the $150 billion emergency spending plan agreed to by the White House and Congressional leaders on Thursday in a bid to stimulate the suddenly sputtering economy.

title: Alstott Retires
description: The six-time Pro Bowl fullback Mike Alstott announced his retirement after 12 seasons Thursday at a tearful news conference during which the Buccaneers played a film of his most memorable plays. Alstott, Tampa Bays career touchdown leader, spent the past season on injured reserve with a neck problem.

title: Bush and House in Accord for $150 Billion Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON  Hoping to give a quick adrenaline shot to the ailing economy, President Bush and House leaders struck a deal on Thursday for a $150 billion fiscal stimulus package, including rebates for most tax filers of up to $600 for individuals, $1,200 for couples and, for families, an additional $300 a child.

title: Italy: Fiats Profit Increases 26%
description: Fiat, one of Italys largest manufacturers, said its fourth-quarter profit rose 26 percent as it increased its share of the European car market and sold more trucks and tractors. Net income rose to 570 million euros ($833 million) from 452 million euros a year earlier, Fiat said. Fiat, based in Turin, Italy, raised its 2008 sales forecast to 60 billion euros from 58.5 billion euros in 2007.

title: Color Purple to Close
description: The Color Purple, the musical adaptation of the Alice Walker novel and the Broadway producing debut of Oprah Winfrey, is closing after its evening performance at the Broadway Theater on Feb. 24. At that time it will have played 910 regular performances and 30 previews. The musical, which has been bringing black theatergoers to Broadway in unprecedented numbers, recouped its original $11 million investment.

title: F.D.A. Plans to Post Inspectors Overseas
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration intends to post inspectors to embassies and consulates throughout the developing world in hopes of improving the quality of the food and medicines increasingly flowing to the United States, a top official said Thursday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Tuesday about New York Citys practice of referring the homeless to illegal rooming houses misidentified the city department that issued regulations in December to prohibit shelters from sending people to buildings that have excessive housing code violations or are in litigation with the Buildings Department. It was the Department of Homeless Services, not the Buildings Department.

title: Correction:  A Mining Town With a Bleak Past Starts to Blossom
description: The Havens column last Friday about Kellogg, Idaho, misstated the percentage of home sites sold by Silver Mountain Corporation at its new golf course-centered Galena Ridge development west of town. It is 72 percent of the first 49 sites for sale, not just over a third.

title: He May Be Loathsome, but This Evangelist Has Pipes
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  A 1960 movie review in The New York Times of Elmer Gantry, based on Sinclair Lewiss scathing 1927 satire about a womanizing preacher, noted that the sleaziness of some forms of evangelism is not too pressing an issue these days. That, of course, was before the improprieties of Jimmy Swaggart, Jim Bakker and Ted Haggard made embarrassing headlines.

title: So Quiet You Can Hear a Heart Stop
description: Sometimes, when she stops the restless chatter with which she fills her days and lets the silence take over, Lola Delaney seems to be staring at nothing in the deeply felt revival of Come Back, Little Sheba, which opened Thursday night at the Biltmore Theater. Yet as S. Epatha Merkerson portrays this housebound wife of an alcoholic, in a performance that stops the heart, her gaze is anything but empty.

title: Amy Winehouse Goes to Rehab
description: This time she said yes. Though Amy Winehouse, the troubled British singer, sang, They tried to make me go to rehab/I said no, no, no, on her breakthrough hit last year, she has assented to the idea and entered a rehabilitation clinic in the wake of a recently surfaced video that appears to depict her smoking crack. In a statement Thursday her British publicist said Ms. Winehouse, right, has come to understand that she requires specialist treatment to continue her ongoing recovery from drug addiction and prepare for her planned appearance at the Grammy Awards on Feb. 10 in Los Angeles, where she is up for six awards, and is the only nominee to be considered in all four marquee categories. But the statement also said she had canceled a planned appearance at the NRJ Music Awards in Cannes, France, on Saturday, the latest in a string of events she has scratched from her schedule amid her own legal troubles and those of her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, who is in jail for perverting the cause of justice after a pub brawl. Ms. Winehouses appearance on the Grammy show is still seen as a long shot, not only because of uncertainty about her ability to perform but also because of doubts about her effort to secure a visa to travel to the United States given an arrest for marijuana possession in Norway in October. But the publicist, Chris Goodman, said, If shes well enough to do it, she certainly wants to do it. He added that in terms of her recovery, What better incentive than six nominations? The latest blow to what had seemed a rising career came in the form of a grainy video posted on the Web site of the British tabloid The Sun. In the clip Ms. Winehouse is seen lighting a glass pipe and smoking what The Sun reported is crack cocaine. A copy of the video on YouTube has been viewed more than 800,000 times, according to the Web site. In an interview after the video had surfaced, Neil Portnow, the president of the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, which organizes the Grammy Awards, left open the possibility that Ms. Winehouse might yet manage to appear. Mr. Portnow said her representatives had notified the academy that they still are working on all of the possibilities of making this happen, and we want to give them an opportunity to work on that. He added, Things happen and things change, right up to and into showtime.

title: An Overabundance of Hormones
description: Chico Teixeiras languid, libidinous Alices House is the best argument against marriage and motherhood to appear in many a year.

title: Hard Days Behind Her, She Helps Families With Theirs
description: The subway in New York is a high-speed tour of the best and worst the city has to offer, a fast-moving showcase of surprising civility, but also, occasionally, unnerving cruelty. At those times, the commute home feels like a test: A woman across the car is shaking her child, shaking him hard enough that it hurts just to watch, but whos to say what to say, or when to say it?

title: Long Island Boy, 17, Dies of Meningitis
description: A Long Island teenager died of meningococcal meningitis on Thursday, health officials said, prompting a warning for people who had close contact with him to seek preventive medication.

title: The Songbook Stretches Its Range
description: Lincoln Centers American Songbook 2008 will run through March 1 in the Allen Room of the Frederick P. Rose Hall, Broadway and 60th Street. Performances are at 8:30 p.m. (with an additional 10:30 show on some days). Tickets, $35 to $150. (212) 721-6500; lincolncenter.org.

title: Artist Compensated for Vandalized Nude
description: Damage to the genitalia of Frank the Baggage Handler, a whimsical nude statue, will cost the City of Penticton in British Columbia $14,000, CBC News reported. The judgment was won on Tuesday by the artist Michael Hermesh, who created the statue depicting a naked man surrounded by suitcases. Many people liked the nude, which was put up in a traffic circle three years ago; others were offended by it, and some repeatedly vandalized the figures not-so-private parts. Eventually, Mr. Hermesh said, he removed Frank to prevent further damage but offered to put it up again elsewhere. They canceled my contract, refused to pay me for having made the piece and then refused to pay for repairs, he said. So he sued and won. Im very happy with it, he said of the outcome. Its not the actual dollar value, although this really hurt me financially. It was the exoneration, I guess. Frank has been bought by a winery in nearby Naramata and given safe surroundings.

title: Many Lessons Still to Be Taught by an Old Master
description: Marty Glickman is still teaching.

title: Memorial and Mold, Flecked With Nearly Everything
description: The word denkmal translates from German as monument or memorial. In Dutch it is a mold for thought. Both definitions fit the work of Jan De Cock, a 31-year-old Belgian artist who appropriates and arranges photographs in what might be viewed as an open-ended yet ultimately conservative encyclopedia.

title: Bronx Courthouse to Open, Costlier and Later Than Planned
description: After many delays and cost overruns of nearly $100 million, the states newest courthouse, the Bronx County Hall of Justice, is scheduled to open next week, officials said on Thursday.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Kenyas Political Rivals Meet
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  For the first time since Kenya plunged into postelection chaos four weeks ago, the nations warring political leaders met face to face on Thursday, but afterward opposition leaders accused the president of being a fraud.

title: So Far, Marketers Have Stuck With Networks
description: NEXT week will bring the beginning of a February sweeps season like no other.

title: Trappers Creek at Schweitzer Mountain Resort and Alea
description: Trappers Creek at Schweitzer Mountain Resort

title: Evan Galbraith, Ambassador, Dies at 79
description: Evan G. Galbraith Jr., a former ambassador to France and a Republican contender for governor of New York in 1994, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: Bill to Tighten Sale of Guns Is Turned Back in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Despite fervent support from families of those killed in the Virginia Tech massacre, a bill that would have required background checks of buyers at gun shows in Virginia has been defeated in a State Senate committee.

title: Separated by a Quarter-Century of Change, but Linked by Race
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly 25 years of social change, political realignment and demographic shifts separate the presidential candidacies of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator Barack Obama. Even so, there are echoes of 1984 as the battle for the Democratic nomination once again roars across the South, focused squarely on African-Americans.

title: At Davos, Foreign Funds Add Tension to the Talks
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Huge pools of state-controlled cash have rescued American and European banks from their own mistakes in recent months. And the people who run those funds want some respect.

title: Surprising Few, Italys Government Collapses
description: ROME  Italys government finally fell Thursday, after Prime Minister Romano Prodi lost a confidence vote that made it clear that Italys leaders know they face a deep political and economic crisis but are venomously divided over how to solve it.

title: In Turnabout, Mayor Seeks Spending Cuts
description: With an already dim fiscal picture turning darker, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday proposed a budget that would increase spending by 3.7 percent but cut money from every city department, from sanitation to schools.

title: Kucinich to Drop Bid and Focus on Re-election
description: Representative Dennis J. Kucinich has decided to end his long-shot presidential bid, thinning the Democratic field, and allowing him to focus on a contested race for re-election in his Ohio Congressional district.

title: Judge Demands a Report on Destroyed C.I.A. Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  A judge on Thursday gave the Justice Department three weeks to report in writing whether the destruction of C.I.A. videotapes in November 2005 violated an order he issued four months earlier to preserve evidence.

title: Space for Playtime
description: WHO Mimi and Richard Somerby, both 47, owners of an interior design business, and their sons, Rufus, 9, and Henry, 7 WHAT 3-bedroom house WHERE Bellport, N.Y.

title: Yanks and Can Work on New Deal
description: When major league teams and players submitted figures for salary arbitration last week, the Yankees and second baseman Robinson Can had a substantial gap. The team offered $3.2 million, and Can requested $4.55 million.

title: Tuna Fish Stories: The Candidates Spin the Sushi
description: Its been a rough week.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: All the Elis Encircle the Bandwagon
description: Not every bandwagon rolled after the turn of the year. Not every weekly observer of the Giants questioned whether their quarterback would live up to his famous surname.

title: Marie Antoinette: Home Furnishing Queen Goes Pastoral
description: One consequence of a successful political revolution is often a huge yard sale of the belongings of the ousted regime. In 1793, during the French Revolution, officers of the new, cash-starved French Republic organized a public auction of the contents of the Petit Trianon, the small chateau that had become Marie Antoinettes private domain at Versailles, filled with furnishings she had commissioned. The sale took place two months before her execution.

title: West Virginia: Reconsidering an Energy Ruling
description: The State Supreme Court unanimously voted to reconsider a 3-to-2 decision that had thrown out a $50 million verdict against Massey Energy, a coal company. Chief Justice Elliott E. Maynard withdrew from the case last week after the publication of photographs of him and Masseys chief executive, Don L. Blankenship, vacationing in Monte Carlo. A lower-court judge, Donald H. Cookman, replaced Chief Justice Maynard on the case, which will be re-argued March 12.

title: Clintons Campaign Sees Value in Keeping Former President in Attack Mode
description: ANDERSON, S.C.  Advisers to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton say they have concluded that Bill Clintons aggressive politicking against Senator Barack Obama is resonating with voters, and they intend to keep him on the campaign trail in a major role after the South Carolina primary.

title: Virginia Nears an About-Face on Costly Driver Penalties
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Responding to complaints from thousands of state residents, a Virginia Senate committee approved a measure Wednesday repealing costly fees that were being levied against residents caught driving 20 miles above the speed limit or engaging in other reckless driving.

title: Judge Removes Lawyer for Kerik From His Case
description: The lawyer for Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, has been removed from Mr. Keriks criminal case in federal court because of a conflict of interest so severe that no remedial measure will cure it, according to a judges order issued Thursday.

title: Correction: Winter Day Out in Washington, D.C.
description: An article last Friday about what to do for a perfect winter weekend day in Washington referred imprecisely to the history of the Old Ebbitt Grill. It was founded in 1856 and moved to its current location in 1983; it was not built in 1856.

title: Selected Studies: Bipolar Disorder
description: Government agencies, universities, physicians and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: New American Realism Emerges Amid Grousing and Hummers
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Shortly before I said my goodbyes at the Sundance Film Festival, I saw a man sitting in a parked S.U.V. with the vanity plate CARPDM. The window on the drivers side was down  a cigar idled in his left hand  and his voice and that of a man on a speakerphone were pouring into the frigid air, words like negotiation and agency mixing in with various numbers. Its the sort of image that encapsulates one Sundance, the festival of flamboyant self-importance, and if the films had not been as good this year, it might have become a defining moment rather than a comic memento of an unexpectedly rewarding week.

title: Brady Adds to Mystique Just by Not Being There
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  A clutch of reporters stood at his locker, beginning the long, lonely vigil for the quarterback who never appeared.

title: Art in Review
description: DAVID SMITH

title: Dance, Fight, Laugh, Cry and Read Great Literature
description: How She Move, a feature by the director Ian Iqbal Rashid (Touch of Pink) about a disaffected young woman competing in dance contests, is the latest incarnation of the up-by-your-bootstraps musical drama. Theres nary a twist you dont see coming. But the films strong acting, spectacular dance routines and culturally specific details turn clichs into catharsis. Its the sort of film that sends you home with a spring in your step.

title: Suicide Bombing Kills Iraq Police Chief in Mosul
description: BAGHDAD  A provincial police chief was killed in a suicide bombing in west Mosul on Thursday as he toured the site of an insurgent bomb factory that exploded the day before as Iraqi Army soldiers tried to enter. Thirty-four people were killed and at least 224 were wounded in the initial blast.

title: Leetch Returns Home to Stay
description: Brian Leetch stood on a red carpet on the ice at Madison Square Garden, his 2-year-old son Sean perched on his hip, their eyes following the No. 2 banner being hoisted to the rafters. Leetchs two older children, son Jack and daughter Riley, stood next to him, their necks craned and mouths open, taking in the emotional ceremony honoring their dad.

title: Bruce Nauman Chosen for Venice Biennale
description: BRUCE NAUMAN CHOSEN

title: Stimulus Gone Bad
description: House Democrats and the White House have reached an agreement on an economic stimulus plan. Unfortunately, the plan  which essentially consists of nothing but tax cuts and gives most of those tax cuts to people in fairly good financial shape  looks like a lemon.

title: Panel Says New Jersey Wont Save All Hospitals
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  New Jersey wants to get out of the business of saving every hospital from financial ruin.

title: At X Games, One-Upmanship Is a Trend in High Places
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Four years ago, the snowboarder Travis Rice was riding in Utahs Wasatch Mountains when he accidentally invented the double cork, one of the more progressive and talked-about tricks in snowboarding recently.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about what to do for a perfect winter weekend day in Washington referred imprecisely to the history of the Old Ebbitt Grill. It was founded in 1856 and moved to its current location in 1983; it was not built in 1856.

title: Nokia Increases Profit and Market Share
description: BERLIN  Nokia said Thursday that it had extended its share of the global cellphone market to a record 40 percent in the fourth quarter as profit surged 44 percent on rising sales to Africa, China and the Middle East.

title: Primary Choices: Hillary Clinton
description: This generally is the stage of a campaign when Democrats have to work hard to get excited about whichever candidate seems most likely to outlast an uninspiring pack. That is not remotely the case this year.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Philip Conisbee, 62, National Gallery Curator, Is Dead
description: Philip Conisbee, a curator at the National Gallery of Art in Washington who organized some of that museums most popular exhibitions, died on Jan. 16 at his home in Washington. He was 62.

title: Detectives in Shooting of Unarmed Man Seek to Waive Trial by Jury
description: The three detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell have opted to be tried by a judge rather than a jury, prosecutors said Thursday.

title: Trying to Support a Family After a Kidney Transplant
description: Ranny Smith, 51, became an American citizen in 1999, but he still carries Jamaica with him. It is in his first name  meant to be Danny, he said, but misspelled there on his birth certificate  and in his speech, accented with the molasses lilt of his homeland.

title: Resignation Embarrasses British Government
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Browns government suffered its first high-profile casualty on Thursday when Peter Hain, the work and pensions secretary, resigned in the face of a police investigation into his political fund-raising practices.

title: Tilghman Returns After Suspension
description: The Golf Channels Kelly Tilghman returned from a two-week, unpaid suspension Thursday and apologized for using the word lynch on a Jan. 4 broadcast when she and Nick Faldo were discussing how younger golfers could challenge Tiger Woods.

title: Democrats Test Messages in Early Nationwide Ads
description: A coast-to-coast onslaught of presidential campaign advertisements began rolling out this week, with Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton already spending millions on commercials in Feb. 5 nominating states on a scale more reminiscent of a general election.

title: In the City, Relationships Reduced to Transactions
description: Seen from the perspective of a window washer who is one of the main characters in Lost in Beijing, the Chinese capital is an endless vista of glassy high-rises. Closer to the ground, in the lyrical documentary montages that frame Li Yus modern urban melodrama, the city is a hive of human work and pleasure seeking. There are tango clubs and dive bars, car dealerships and open-air markets, nouveau riches in their Mercedes-Benzes and homeless people stretched out on benches.

title: Digital Music Sales Grow, but at Slower Rate
description: LONDON  As consumers lose interest in compact discs and balk at paying for the digital alternatives, the music industry is looking for new allies, including Internet service providers, lawmakers  even Chinese air guitarists.

title: Sounds and Flavors of a Land Left Behind in Cuban Miami
description: CUBAN culture is as integral to Miamis colorful fabric as the palm tree. One could be easily forgiven, in fact, for forgetting that the citys most ubiquitous import  the cafecito window, where locals of all persuasions converge to down tiny shots of strong, sugary coffee  has not been a fixture here for as long as the sand or the sun. Other elements play the same tricks on the mind, from minty mojitos to those boxy guayabera shirts, making it a challenge to spend even a few hours in Miami without experiencing at least a hint of its Cuban accent.

title: John Doe Files Lawsuit
description: A cyclist is suing the United States Anti-Doping Agency for overreaching its own rules and protocols, claiming the agency had planned to test the cyclists backup urine sample even though the original A sample test came back negative. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday on behalf of John Doe in Los Angeles County Superior Court, seeks an injunction to prevent the agency from ever testing the B sample. The agency originally planned to test the B sample Jan. 15, the lawsuit says, but after the plaintiffs lawyers demanded the agency scrap that test, the agency canceled it.The lawsuit calls for a jury trial and seeks to recoup damages the plaintiff claims were incurred when the antidoping agency revealed the case to race organizers and the U.C.L.A. testing lab.The plaintiffs name is redacted in the 25-page lawsuit, but the cyclists lawyers are Maurice Suh and Howard Jacobs, the same team that represents Floyd Landis in his doping case.Landis told The Associated Press he was not the plaintiff. The dates in the lawsuit did not conform to Landiss 2006 Tour de France dates.

title: What to Ask About Bipolar Disorder
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: At 101, Mugging Victim Has Her (Early) Day in Court
description: Demonstrating the same spunk she showed when she survived a vicious mugging almost a year ago at the age of 101, Rose Morat walked into a Queens courtroom on Thursday with the help of her walker and vividly described the events of that day.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about Rudolph W. Giulianis tenure as mayor of New York referred incorrectly in a quotation to the former director of a gay advocacy organization, the Hetrick-Martin Institute, who was mentioned in an anecdote about Mr. Giulianis power to silence critics. The former director, who was not named in the article, is a woman, not a man. Also, a caption referred imprecisely to Andy Humm, a gay activist and former worker at Hetrick-Martin who supplied the anecdote. He said it was the agency that was muzzled out of fear of losing financing for AIDS programs; he did not say that he muzzled himself.

title: Viewers Flock to Fox Game
description: The Moment of Truth, Foxs new game show in which contestants are questioned after having been hooked up to polygraph machines, passed its own first test with flying colors, drawing particularly impressive ratings in its debut on Wednesday at 9 p.m. Nielsen estimated that the show delivered 23.2 million viewers, more than any series premiere on any network in almost a year. The last new show to earn higher ratings was Foxs Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?, which drew 26.5 million viewers last February. That show and The Moment of Truth benefited from coveted time slots following American Idol, which led Wednesdays ratings with 26.8 million viewers at 8 p.m. Fox more than doubled its closest competitor on the night, NBC, whose game show Deal or No Deal was the top-rated runner up at 8, blazing past its counterpart in the hour, CBSs Power of 10, with 13.8 million viewers compared with 3.9 million. CBS ranked third overall, faring better later in the night with Criminal Minds at 9 (12.9 million) and CSI: NY at 10 (11.7 million). ABC was a distant fourth for the night.

title: Lottery Numbers
The View From Eli Lilly
description: To the Editor:

title: Julian Rosefeldt
description: Julian Rosefeldts solo show in Chelsea, his first in the United States, is an extravaganza of glossy production values, technical expertise, easy-to-read symbols and battling soundtracks," writes Roberta Smith.

title: Transparency in Derivatives?
description: DAVOS, Switzerland

title: All of America, and Parking Too
description: In the Escapes section, Joe Queenan reviews a mall in West Nyack, N.Y., as a travel destination in and of itself:

title: Finish Lines Big Gamble
description: The biggest grudge fight going in mergers and acquisitions heated up again this week when Finish Line and UBS filed an interlocutory appeal in the Tennessee Court of Appeals.

title: Live From Davos: Day 3
description: Three letters are echoing through this mountain town: S.W.F.

title: Shake Your Traffic Booty!
description: WKRC-TV in Cincinnati (no, not WKRP) gets down and funky on Friday if theres not much to report traffic-wise:

title: Bridezillas on a Diet
description: Forget the flowers, reception hall and wedding dress. For many brides-to-be, losing weight is the most important part of the wedding plan.

title: Davos in the Papers: Private Funds, Bill Gates, Nasdaq
description: One of the hottest topics to pop at the World Economic Forum Thursday produced a certain sense of deja vu.

title: Broadcom Founders Cited as Potential Co-Conspirators in Suit
description: Federal prosecutors on Thursday identified the co-founders of Broadcom, Henry T. Nicholas III and Henry Samueli, as unindicted potential co-conspirators in an investigation into the illegal backdating of stock options.

title: Security Capital Gets Downgrade From Fitch
description: Shares of bond insurers opened strongly Thursday on hopes of a bailout for the beleaguered sector, but ended up falling sharply after Fitch Ratings downgraded Security Capital Assurance.

title: E*Trade Discloses Turnaround Plan
description: E*Trade Financial, the discount brokerage that received a $2.55 billion cash infusion from the Citadel Investment Group in November, on Thursday announced details of a widely anticipated turnaround plan that includes disposing of non-core assets, cost-cutting and possibly raising money in capital markets later in the year.

title: Live Nation Finds a Buyer for Its Theater Business
description: After almost a year of fielding bids, Live Nation has sold most of its North American theater business, including the Broadway Across America touring network, to Key Brand Entertainment, a company owned by a British producer and run by an American entertainment executive.

title: Billionaires and Ice Stars
description: Russians, like blondes, have more fun. At least that was the impression at a party hosted Thursday night by the Russian investment firm Troika Dialog. Olympic ice skating stars were imported for the night, and guests were invited to try their luck with these supremos of the rink. Then they twirled and spun their way through well-known Russian folk tunes, with at least 200 spectators clapping along, fortified by vodka and gluehwein! In an after-party in a rink-side tent, there were possibly more billionaires per square foot than anywhere else, even in the town of Davos.

title: Study Says Private Equity Isnt Big Job Killer
description: Among the worlds private equity kings and policy makers, the issue of whether buyouts create jobs or result in more layoffs has always been the $100 billion question.

title: Imperial Bids $1.3 Billion for Logista
description: Imperial Tobacco Group plans to bid 910 million euros ($1.3 billion) for full control of Compania de Distribucion Integral Logista, Spains largest cigarette distributor, following its 12.6 billion euro ($18.26 billion) takeover of the Spanish competitor Altadis, the maker of Gauloises cigarettes.

title: Carlsberg and Heineken to Swallow British Brewer
description: Heineken is set to assume the mantle of Britains biggest brewer after Scottish & Newcastle on Friday accepted a $15.2 billion (7.8 billion pound) joint takeover offer made by the Dutch brewer and its Nordic counterpart, Carlsberg.

title: F.C.C. Approves $20 Billion Clear Channel Buyout
description: Federal communications regulators on Thursday said they had approved the $20 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications by Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners.

title: Deutsche Post May Sell DHL to FedEx, Report Says
description: Deutsche Post, the worlds biggest logistics group, is considering selling its ailing DHL express delivery unit in the United States to FedEx as part of a wider turnround plan that could be announced within months, The Financial Times Deutschland reported.

title: Allis-Chalmers Drills Down Deal for Bronco
description: An oilfield services company, Allis-Chalmers Energy, said Thursday it would acquire Bronco Drilling for $437.8 million in cash and stock, the third combination in the increasingly competitive industry in as many months.

title: Crunch Time for a Tech Start-Up
description: LiquidPlanner is one of about 70 tech companies preparing to make their pitch next week at the DEMO Conference in Palm Desert, Calif. John Cook of the Seattle Post-Intelligencer spent some time at the firms headquarters to see what life is like inside a pre-launch start-up.

title: RiskMetrics Raises $245 Million in I.P.O.
description: RiskMetrics Group began its highly touted initial public offering on Thursday, at a time when many others are shying away from a foray into the public markets.

title: SocGens Story Raises More Questions Than Answers
description: Socit Gnrale, one of Frances largest and most respected banks, announced Thursday that it had lost $7.2 billion, not because of complex subprime loans, but the old-fashioned way  because a 31-year-old rogue trader made bad bets on stocks and then, in trying to cover up those losses, dug himself deeper into a hole.

title: Chinese Retailer Pulls I.P.O.
description: A Chinese department store operator Maoye International Holdings postponed its $905 million Hong Kong initial public offering because of poor market conditions, becoming the latest listing hopeful to pull its deal amid poor risk appetite.

title: Some Big Names in Hedge Funds Are Hurting
description: Recent stock market drops hurt some of the worlds most famous hedge fund managers, who have long attracted money with promises that they could sidestep even the worst conditions.

title: Sprint Ousts Three Executives
description: In its latest move to restructure and shore up its stock, Sprint Nextel announced on Thursday the immediate departures of three top executives, including the chief financial officer, Paul Saleh.

title: Caxton Pulls Back from Private Equity investments
description: While hedge funds and private equity firms have increasingly begun to resemble each other, a move by one prominent hedge fund to pull back from private-equity-style investments indicates that the melding is not always smooth sailing.

title: A Risk Index for Sovereign Wealth Funds
description: Sovereign wealth funds were hardly talked about 12 months ago. Now they are one of the hottest topics in global financial markets. Over the last year, these state-owned entities have spent more than $75 billion snapping up stakes in some of the worlds biggest banks, taken big positions in stock exchanges on both sides of the Atlantic and even attempting a takeover of one of Britains leading supermarkets.

title: Two Shows to Cure Winter Blues in London
description: London in January can be rather dark and dreary. In fact, on Monday 21 January the BBC reported that it was the most depressing day of the year  according to a scientific study carried out by a Chris Arnall, a psychologist at Cardiff University. Apparently, a combination of failed New Year resolutions, cloudy, dull weather, post Christmas credit card bills  you get the drift  leads people to feel very low on this particular day.

title: LifeLock Takes $25.5 Millon from Big Name Investors
description: LifeLock said Wednesday that it received $25.5 million in venture capital funding from Goldman Sachs and other investors.

title: Box.net Takes $6 Million in Fresh Funding
description: Box.net, whose goal is to become the file system for the Web, has scooped up $6 million in B round funding led by U.S. Venture Partners, the company said Thursday.

title: W.H.O. Responds on F.G.M.
description: Early in our debate over female genital cutting, Richard Shweder of the University of Chicago critiqued a 2006 Lancet study by a group of researchers working with the World Health Organization. I invited those researchers from the W.H.O. study to respond.

title: Private Placements Rise as Markets Gyrate
description: Global investment banks and small-cap companies rarely have much in common when it comes to raising capital, but they have both been using private placements to meet their financial needs, according to Financial News.

title: No Remorse From John Snow
description: DAVOS, Switzerland

title: Belichick Part II: The Loyalty Test
description: A lot of insightful responses, some of which well highlight here and in the days ahead, as we continue to try to keep an open mind on Bill Belichick the man.

title: The Best Use of Euphemism So Far This Season!
description: He gives incredibly, enthusiastic blurb, but Pete Hammond will be doing it for somewhere other than Maxim. Hollywood Wiretap reports that Maxim editor James Kaminsky has decided to drop movie coverage.

title: Judy Garlands Ghost Settles Writers Strike
description: A hopeful sign appeared over the writers talks yesterday, and no, it was not Ben Silverman apologizing for calling writers ugly, prom-spoiling nerds. Its even better.

title: Why 2008 Is Not 2001
description: Some corporate chiefs see a silver lining amid the economic thunderclouds. A case in point is Henning Kagermann, the chief executive of SAP, Europes leading software firm. He argues that SAP will continue to prosper during a downturn because the business software it makes will help companies increase productivity and cut costs.

title: Ambac Shares Rise Amid Takeover Speculation
description: Shares of the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurer, rose in European trading Friday following a newspaper report, citing unnamed sources, that said Wilbur Ross is in talks to buy the company.

title: God Was a Metal Fan. So Was Wagner
description: Amongst the movies the Bagger missed at Sundance  there are so many to choose from  he kept hearing about Anvil: The Story of Anvil, directed by Sascha Gervasi and produced by Rebecca Yeldham. Cinematical has a pretty nifty podcast that helps explain why two big-deal movie types spent their time telling the story of a washed up metal band.

title: Sundance: Plenty of Heat Left, Some Light
description: The Bagger pulled out of Sundance because theres nothing in his drawers left that he was willing to place next to his skin he had been on the road two weeks and had to get back to headquarters, but the festival is far from over, as Living in Cinema points out.

title: Deadly Tick-Tock
description: If you havent seen No Country yet, you will want to skip the Film Experiences loving reconstruction of the mayhem, a series of scenes in which the bodies are stacked like just so much cordwood.

title: Another Surprise as Federer Falls to Djokovic
description: MELBOURNE -- A surprising Australian Open took its latest unexpected turn Friday when Roger Federer, of all people, failed to reach the final after failing to win a set against Novak Djokovic in the semifinal.

title: The Early Word: G.O.P. Keep It Civil
description: Viewers tuned in to Thursday nights debate between the leading Republican candidates may have been expecting a brutal, no-holds-barred attack show like the Democrats put on Monday night. Instead, though, the G.O.P. hopefuls kept their remarks to one another mostly friendly.

title: Workout Adviser Said to Leave CIT
description: As the restructuring industry awaits an uptick in corporate defaults, a well-known figure in New York bankruptcy circles has taken a new job.

title: Who Needs a Diving Bell When You Are Encased in This Much Ego?
description: Julian Schnabel, the director of The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, is setting out on the his anti-Oscar campaign, reminding people that in addition to having made an exquisite film, he is has an ego of Ruthian dimensions. Thanks to Defamer for the point.

title: Bill Clinton: Screw It, Im Running
description: From The Onion:

title: The Art of Nanotech
description: By day, Christian Orfescu relies on his training in materials science to run the analytical laboratory at Caleb Technology, a small company in Torrance, Calif., that is using nanotechnology to design improved lithium batteries. When the work day ends, though, Mr. Orfescus enthusiasm for the technology bubbles over into his other persona  Cris Orfescu, abstract artist.

title: Fridays Links: Career Advice from Marc Andreessen
description: A kind reader tipped me off to a series of postings on career planning posted by Marc Andreessen, a founder of Netscape, on his blog. Id suggest putting aside a little time to read these as they are jammed with valuable tips. The series is told in the form of advice Mr. Andreessen would give to someone starting out in a career. But much of it is applicable to those of us already in the midst of one. The advice also has a bit of a techie entrepreneurial orientation. The series begins with this post and continues here, and here.

title: At Sundance, a Second Life Sweatshop Is Art
description: One of the more exotic premieres at this years Sundance Film Festival is Invisible Threads. Its not a movie, but a virtual sweat shop that exists only on Second Life, the online virtual world, yet produces real-life, custom-ordered, personalized blue jeans.

title: How Effective Are Safety Nets at Construction Sites?
description: Required under a 1987 city law, safety nets have festooned construction sites across New York City for more than a decade, and now, amid a record-setting pace of high-rise construction, they are popping up all over, Thomas J. Lueck finds. The netting proved a lifesaver last week, when a construction worker fell from the 42nd floor of the Trump SoHo, a condominium hotel being built at Varick and Spring Streets, and was snared by a net that protruded 10 feet from the side of the building about two floors below where he was working. He was then lowered to the ground safely. But for another worker, who also fell from the 42nd floor, a similar net proved useless. For reasons that remain under investigation, he fell to the ground and died. For developers, contractors and construction workers, the accident in SoHo on Jan. 15 has raised questions about whether the citys requirement for safety netting, which has generally been applauded, goes far enough.

title: They Left the Gloves On
description: I doubt anyone tuned into last nights Republican debate on the economy hoping for the sorts of fireworks we saw among the Democrats on Monday, but still, the decidedly gentle sparring (as The Times described it) left nearly everybody unsated.

title: Perfect or Not, Economic Storm Stirs Debate
description: The BBC is putting on what it calls a debate on whether there is a perfect storm coming in the world economy.

title: Keeping Humor in Czech
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Growth of Sovereign Wealth
description: CNBC interviews Hamad Al-Thani, chief executive of Qatar Investment Authority, on the challenges of investing his nation's wealth.

title: The More Things Change
description: The National Law Journal ran a story this week asserting that lawyers specializing in mergers and acquisitions, particularly involving private equity firms, are scrutinizing more critically the bailout terms of contracts.

title: CNN Hires Managing Editor From NPR
description: A radio veteran is moving to television and taking a print job title: Jay Kernis, the senior vice president of programming for National Public Radio, is becoming the managing editor of CNN.

title: Interview With Condoleezza Rice
description: CNBC interviews Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice on the economy and geopolitics at Davos
