description: The chairman of Intel discusses the economy and information technology with Katrin Bennhold of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Head Scratchers: Levain Bakery
description: With this post, Diners Journal inaugurates an occasional feature called Head Scratchers. Its a device and a way to offer quick dispatches on oddities that have caught our attention during our wanderings through restaurants, markets, specialty shops and the like.

title: Sol Wachtler, Book Reviewer
description: If a district attorney can be a crime novelist, why cant a former judge be a book critic?

title: Business Executive Is Charged in Fatal Hit-Run
description: Updated, 2:24 p.m. | The chief executive of a Lower Manhattan technology consulting company was charged today with vehicular manslaughter following a hit-and-run crash that killed a 59-year-old woman on Thursday evening.

title: Double Standard?
description: Tony Romos trip to Mexico with Jessica Simpson before the Cowboys game against the Giants caused quite a furor in the media, but Tom Brady gets nearly a free pass for his off-week excursions to New York, where he hangs out with his supermodel girlfriend, Gisele Bundchen. Why is that?

title: Negroponte at Davos
description: John Markoff asks Nicholas Negroponte, the co-founder of the MIT  Media Lab for a progress report on his One Laptop per Child program.

description: There were a couple of models and a show producer on my flight yesterday from Paris, all of us in jeans and looking a little whacked. Three or four nights of staying up until 2 a.m. will do that to you, and I can only imagine the client demands nowadays on a show producer. Its ALL about money, one way or the other.

title: Davos 2008 Roundup

Rice on the Markets

description: One day after Bill Gates urged the worlds business leaders to embrace their altruistic side, a high-powered panel sat down Friday to talk about why companies should follow his advice.

title: Finding Their Voice, Then Losing It
description: Olive oil. No whispering. Extra water. These are some of the remedies the presidential candidates are using to prevent hoarseness on the campaign trail.

title: Stray Questions for: Karen Olsson
description: Karen Olsson is a senior editor at Texas Monthly and the author of the novel Waterloo.

title: Basketball: The Political Views of Majerus
description: Rick Majerus has taken some heat recently about his pro-choice and pro-stem cell research views. The criticism has mainly come from the Archbishop of St. Louis, Raymond Burke, who has said that Majerus, the first-year coach at St. Louis, should be disciplined for making those views public when he spoke to a television reporter at a Hillary Clinton rally last week.

title: Ode to Otey Ann
description: Throughout his career, Walker Percy took criticism for his portrayals of women. His usual refuge was to cheerfully claim that, in fact, he knew nothing about them whatsoever. There are few wholly flattering portraits of anyone, male or female, in The Moviegoer. Say what you will, the women are varied, strong each in her own way and vividly delineated: Aunt Emily, who is Prince Lorenzo, the New Orleans Marcus Aurelius, Hal to Binxs Falstaff; Kate (a most improbable Natasha Rostov; in my experience, fiances dont come much scarier than this); Binxs mother, Anna Smith, old Eve, the evident head of a clan that Percy somehow casts as a counterweight to the dynamic Bollings; and Sharon Kincaid, Binxs Alabama Aphrodite, she of the amber Coca-Cola droplet.

title: Very | Katie Holmes
description: (James Devaney/WireImage/Getty Images)

title: Giuliani Courts Little Havana Voters
description: MIAMI  Courting Cuban-American voters here, Rudolph W. Giuliani returned to his foreign-policy entanglements as mayor of New York  which essentially involved his role as official bouncer and street re-namer.

title: Bloomberg Embraces F.D.R.s New Deal
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has made a career of adopting new political identities at opportune times, this morning embraced that most central of liberal legacies  the New Deal as the answer to the countrys gloomy economic forecasts.

title: Has Bill Gone Bull Moose?
description: In light of recent headlines, some of you on the blog have asked me to revisit my Dec. 23 cover piece on Bill Clinton and the meaning of Clintonism. In particular, Chad N. pointed to this sentence: Clinton doesnt like to play an overtly political role anymore; he enjoys the statesmanlike aura that surrounds any ex-president, and he is not about to undermine it, even for his wifes campaign. I appreciate Chad and others reading that story so closely, and hes right: this does warrant some re-examination.

title: John Harwood With David Plouffe
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times interviews Barack  Obama's campaign manager, David Plouffe.

title: Hitting the National Airwaves
description: Media reporter Jacques Steinberg analyzes national campaign ads by Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

title: More Brazil Info
description: This weeks feature on Leblon in the Properties section of the IHT, Rarity fuels boom in Rio de Janeiros hottest neighborhood, details one of the cool neighborhoods in Brazils coolest city. But it only touches on the growing interest in Brazil from investors and second home buyers around the world, who see the country as one of the best deals in Latin America. The beach strip around Natal, in particular, has been exploding in recent years.

title: John Harwood With David Plouffe
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times interviews Barack  Obama's campaign manager, David Plouffe.

title: Edwards on Health Care
description: Following is the transcript of Kevin Sacks interview with John Edwards:

title: Little Plays Big
description: Variety points out that the star-laden vehicles  What Just Happened and The Great Buck Howard, which featured Robert Deniro and Tom Hanks, respectively  came to Sundance heralded by trumpets but are leaving to stony silence. On the other hand, there continues to be interest in and, in some cases, buyers of, little wonders like Ballast, Mermaid, and Baghead.

title: Little Big Man
description: This Indie vs. Studio parody of the Mac/ P.C. guys has some resonance for the upcoming doings, if they do take place, at the Kodak Theater. With only one straight-up major in the mix this year, is it really parody if its true?

title: Cause and Effect
description: After reading what some of the flesh-eating bacteria posing as journalists have written about the death of Heath Ledger, the Bagger realized something that he should have mentioned in his rant against publicists and talent for failing to contextualize Mr. Ledgers death with a little bit of his life: They did not get that way all by themselves.

title: For The Moment | The Definition of Luxury
description: This weeks guest blogger is Jeff Klein, the hotelier behind The City Club in New York and the Sunset Tower in Los Angeles. To read all of Jeff Kleins prior blog posts, click here.

title: Open Caucus: Florida Debate Reflections
description: Judging by these reactions, our Open Caucus participants found Thursday nights Republican debate in Boca Raton, Fla., a little on the dull side. While they were interested in hearing the candidates proposals for healing the economy, they had heard enough about Alaskas infamous bridge to nowhere.

title: Podcast: Along the Narrowing Campaign Button Trail
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: Guest Bloggers
description: Im delighted to introduce a new line-up of guest bloggers for On the Ground. Originally, I brought in guest bloggers only for the period when I was on book leave in the fall, but it worked so well that I thought Id continue it even when Im contributing to the blog as well. So heres the line-up for the next six months or so:

title: Goldman Plans to Lay Off 1,500 Employees
description: Not even Goldman Sachs can fight the tide.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, Jan. 25:

title: Moodys: They Lied to Us
description: DAVOS

title: A Railroad Rarity: Train Arrives Five Days Early
description: In these days of overburdened, frustrating transportation systems and drop-of-a-hat delays, its a headline to stun and gladden the heart: On the maiden voyage of a new cross-continental direct rail service between China and Germany, the first trainful of freight containers made it to their destination in Hamburg five days ahead of schedule. A journey that still would have been something of a logistical triumph if it had taken the expected 20 days was completed in 15, Bloomberg News and others reported. With some practice, railway officials say they may eventually be able to knock that down to 10.

title: Foxs Big Moment': The Truth Hurts
description: In the annals of reality television, The Moment of Truth may be a milestone, Alessandra Stanley writes in Fridays New York Times. Fox has come up with a cash-prize competition that is neither a game of chance nor a test of knowledge. Its a pseudo-psychological trial by ordeal in which the contestants trade candor for dollars.

title: Undecided in New York
description: Friends in Brooklyn discuss the Democratic field.

title: Now Booking | Riviera Maya, Mexico
description: Way back in 1997, Rosewood Hotels & Resorts made a big splash in Mexico with Las Ventanas al Paraso in Los Cabos, a stunning beachfront resort that in the decade since has become an icon in the world of luxury hotels. In December, following a long gestation and much anticipation, the company finally soft opened its second property in the country, Rosewood Mayakob on the Riviera Maya; the resorts official, full-scale launch is next week. Rosewood is the second company to open in the big mixed-use residential-hotel-golf community north of Playa del Carmen called Mayakob. (Fairmont was the first, and a Viceroy and Banyan Tree are slated to open later this year.) Though we havent yet booked ourselves in, early reports suggest the new Rosewood is a winner. Of the 128 suites  all done in a stylish, pared-down style using local limestone and woods from renewable sources  the 16 on the beach are obviously prime real estate, though the remainder, arranged along a network of lagoons that wend their way through mangrove forest, provide a novel take on the typical Mexican resort experience: each has its own dock, and guests are transported around the property via silent boats (silent, to avoid disturbing the wildlife). All rooms have a private plunge pool, and theres a staff of 40 butlers to take care of your needs. The nice thing about the Riviera Maya in general, of course, is that theres more to do than just loll on the beach  youve got Mayan ruins at Tulum; some decent shopping, restaurants and bars in Playa del Carmen and coral reef for diving and snorkeling offshore  but looking at the images from Rosewood, we think it might be hard to tear yourself away.

title: Quotes of the Day at Davos
description: Im glad that this time we did not cause it.

title: 'The Invention of Hugo Cabret'
description: An excerpt from "The Invention of Hugo Cabret" by Brian Selznick, published by Scholastic Audio.

title: Hit the Brakes! Wait, on This Bike, There Are None
description: Fifty or so people  local bicycle racers and their fans  crowded into a semicircle around the large clocklike machine at the center of Bar East on the Upper East Side on Thursday night. The machine: Four sets of bike rollers  black, blue, green and red  connected to a hexagonal clock face with four similarly colored hands shaped like thick arrows.

title: A Rezko-Clinton Connection?
description: A photograph of Antoin Rezko, an indicted Chicago businessman, standing between Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, which surfaced on NBCs Today show on Friday, might have been taken at a 1997 fund-raiser in Chicago for former United States Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, political insiders say.

title: Where Will Qatar Invest Next?
description: The latest rise of sovereign wealth funds can probably be traced back to their major stakes in troubled financial firms. Will Qatars state-run fund follow that same path?

title: Taking Sides in the Senate
description: In his Web column today, Carl Hulse writes that Democratic senators are feeling the pressure to choose among their colleagues in the presidential race, forcing them to risk awkward moments now or in the future. Go to column

title: Barack the Clintonian
description: It was a remarkable moment: A young, free-thinking presidential hopeful named Bill Clinton sat down with reporters and editors at The Post in October 1991 and started saying things most Democrats wouldnt allow to pass their lips, recalls E.J. Dionne in his Washington Post column today. Ronald Reagan, Clinton said, deserved credit for winning the Cold War. He praised Reagans rhetoric in defense of freedom and his role in advancing the idea that communism could be rolled back.

title: To Break the Crime Scene Tension, Jokes
description: On Wednesday, I spent a day with the friendly people at the Bio-Recovery Corporation, a Long Island City-based company specializing in what its business card succinctly describes as crime and death scene cleanup.It was an uneventful day, which came as something of a relief, considering what happen on a busy day.

title: Tough Times for Star Gazing
description: Davos may be loaded with moguls and political bigwigs this week, but its glitz quotient is not what it used to be. It could use a little glamour, dont you think? a top executive lamented over drinks. Its not nearly as cool to go home and say you hung out with a bunch of C.E.O.s.

title: There Will Be Baggage for the Saggage
description: Got cable and a miners helmet to find coverage of the SAG awards? Is a tiny part of you hoping to fill in the hole left by glamourless Golden Globs? An immodest proposal: If you take the time to look at the nominees, and make some guesses, the Bagger promises to steal all your best ones and synthesize them with his own before the broadcast on Sunday. And the Bagger further promises will send one U.S. dollar to the best guesser. Movies only, and remember, you cant win if you dont play.

title: Like an American President in a Canadian Movie
description: Aired Thursday night on CBS: Earlier tonight right here on CBS, the hit show Without a Trace. Every week they go looking for something that has disappeared. And earlier tonight investigators tried to locate the Giuliani campaign.

title: I Thought They Were Married
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Did you all see American Gladiators the other night? Not the NBC show, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

title: Bill Clinton Takes on the Polarizing Issue
description: SPARTANBURG, S.C. Bill Clinton just staged a passionate defense of his wife here, after a voter asked how Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton could unite this country when it is so split, politically and racially, and when she is such a polarizing figure.

title: Going, Going, Gone: Meg Whitman Leaves eBay
description: Meg Whitman, the long-serving C.E.O. of eBay, stepped down this week. It is the end of an era for eBay, and something of a nostalgic moment for me. I wrote a history of eBay a few years ago, The Perfect Store: Inside eBay, and Ms. Whitman was one of its heroes: the brash Harvard M.B.A. who took eBay from a fledgling website of uncertain prospects to the $40 billion company it is today.

title: Egypt Attempts to Secure Border
description: Egypt moved to restore its border with Gaza on Friday, but Palestinians used a bulldozer to knock down another portion of the wall, originally built by Israel just inside Gaza, to continue their shopping spree.

title: Highlights From Davos
description: A review of the buzz, the agenda, and the participants at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland.

title: Taking the Microphone
description: One of the contenders in the Hip-Hop Karaoke NYC championship explains how it's done.

title: Frugal Hawaii
description: As exorbitant as Hawaii can be, the Frugal Traveler finds bargains on the southern Kona coast of the Big Island.

title: The Death of Reading, Continued
description: Cant get enough of reading about the decline of reading? The recent report by the National Endowment of the Arts lamenting the shrinking number of Americans who read books for pleasure continues to provoke some heated criticism.

title: G.O.P. Web Ads Recall Kerry to the Same Tune
description: From soundtrack to subtext, two new Web ads from the campaigns of Mitt Romney and Senator John McCain hurl strikingly similar attacks related to a shared issue of possible vulnerability.

title: Spectrum Auction: Bidders Spurn Frequencies Linked to Public Safety
description: The news from Fridays two rounds of bidding in the 700-megahertz spectrum auction is that no one seems to be bidding for the D block of frequencies. These offer the right to operate a nationwide voice and data service that would also serve local public safety agencies.

title: Crowning a New York Idol (in Hip-Hop Karaoke)
description: Video

title: Open Caucus: View from Florida
description: Weve asked our Open Caucus voters to send us their observations about candidate events and advertisements as the primary season unfolds across the country. With Floridas primary on Tuesday, it sounds as though voters are being contacted in many different ways. One of our Florida voters sent us a dispatch from an event held by Senator John McCain yesterday.

title: The Week in Comments: The Truth Is, Being a Star Is Not All Its Cracked Up to Be
description: Tuesday, Jan. 22

title: Flying the Flag
description: Take a quick look at the national flag of Angola, one of the 16 nations participating in the African Cup of Nations in Ghana, and you might think it is the only banner left in the world that displays the hammer and sickle  the recognizable emblem of the Soviet Union and communism.

title: Obamas Christian Campaign
description: Early Wednesday evening, Senator Barack Obama entered the sanctuary of the St. James United Methodist Church in Darlington to the strains of a gospel singer chanting, He is able. I know he is able, as the congregation clapped and sang along. Addressing the overflowing crowd, Mr. Obama compared his fund-raising coffers to a collection plate and talked about a bit of Scripture that a woman had passed him earlier in the day. That kind of spirit truly lifts us up, he said, asking for prayers as well as votes.

title: On the Road: Re-cal-cu-la-ting
description: MIAMI  Ever since Timothy Crouse wrote The Boys on the Bus about the coverage of the 1972 campaign, and perhaps before that, serious people have worried about the inside-the-bubble-mentality that can afflict campaign reporters, which at its extremes can beget either Stockholm syndrome or contempt-breeding familiarity.

title: Soft Serve News | Pillows, American Collectibles, Kanyes Bike
description: Soft Serve is a news feed of light reading. We scan newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: The Making of a Davos Man
description: Its not easy to generate buzz here if your name isnt Bono or Clinton or Gates. For a billionaire pipe-maker from Ukraine named Victor Pinchuk, it would seem harder still. Yet over the last four years, Mr. Pinchuk has transformed himself and his country into a bona-fide Davos brand.

title: Answers About Tenant-Landlord Issues, Part 1
description: Following is a first set of answers to readers questions from Lucas A. Ferrara, a partner at Finkelstein Newman Ferrara who has practiced in the landlord-tenant arena for more than two decades.

title: SAG Awards Provide Glamour Amid Strike
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: Ending Presidential Run, Kucinich Looks Ahead
description: At a news conference on Friday, Representative Dennis J. Kucinich officially ended one campaign  his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination  and quickly turned his attention to two others.

title: Who gets stimulated ?
description: Fast work by the people at the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center, who figure out who gets what from tax plans. They now have distribution tables for the stimulus proposal announced yesterday, and they more or less match my expectations.

title: Ratings: Cant Donald Trump Fire Chuck?
description: Facing minimal competition on Thursday, two episodes of Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader? gave Fox a slight victory in the nights ratings among adults 18 to 49. Drawing 10.5 million viewers at 8 p.m. and 10.2 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates, the quiz show also delivered some of the nights largest audiences overall, trailing only CBSs repeats at 9 and 10 p.m. of CSI (13.3 million) and Without a Trace (11.7 million), respectively.

title: Finally, a Kitchen
description: I havent been thinking about the kitchen much lately, but M&L Cabinets just sent me the final plans. So, let me give you a tour:

title: A List Worth Thinking About
description: Every once in a while I like to highlight a great wine list. What do I mean by a great list? Well, certain kinds of lists you can take for granted. Restaurants like Veritas or Cru in New York are built around wine  they better have great lists! Similarly, a restaurant in wine country, like Cyrus in Healdsburg, Calif., ought to have a great list, too. What I love about the Cyrus list is that it not only has an excellent selection of locally made wines, but of great wines from around the world. Im looking forward to eating there someday soon so I can write about that list.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: Childrens Crusade
description: The much-anticipated XO laptop is an upbeat little instrument, the size of a Bible with a handle. Its green, the universal color of contemporary virtue. Its dandy.

title: Bill Gates, Michael Dell and Bono
description: CNBC interviews Bill Gates, Michael Dell and U2's Bono on how the RED campaign has lifted AIDS awareness.

title: Candidates Foreign Policy Aides
description: Foreign policy advisers to three presidential hopefuls gathered at the National Press Club in Washington on Friday to discuss their bosses strategies for Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: Ruminating Over Identity at Sundance
description: Discussion panels at the Sundance Film Festival, even those that are technology-oriented, usually have at least some practical application. This year, for instance, there was a panel on the digital distribution of independent films, and another on new film making technology.

title: A Modest Proposal for the All-Star Game
description: Almost everyone seems to have a suggestion for doing something about the N.H.L. All-Star Game, including, in this blog and elsewhere, moving it outdoors. Well, heres another one:

title: Video: Undecided in New York
description: Video

title: You Go, Rudy!
description: Some fresh reader comedy (send via the comment link below):

title: From One New Yorker to Another
description: ROCK HILL, S.C.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is 2 for 3 in Democratic nominating contest victories, while her fellow New Yorker and old nemesis Rudolph W. Giuliani is 0 for 6 and seems on the ropes as the Florida primary approaches on Tuesday.

title: A Vocabulary Lesson Gleaned From a Trading Crisis
description: What is epiphany risk? Davos is full of bankers but this term is of recent enough vintage  and its humor black enough  that Howard Davies could get some good laughs when he gave the definition.

title: The New Stadium Rises
description: I hadnt been to Yankee Stadium in a couple of months, but I ventured down today for a beat-writers session with the media relations department. Joe Torre will be happy to know they havent painted over the 6 on his parking space yet. And Roger Clemens still has his 22.

title: Just Browsing
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: Hints That Europe Will Let Google Buy DoubleClick
description: Whether or not Googles bid to buy DoubleClick is completed, the worlds governments have certainly given Google a hazing, delaying the deal since it was announced last April.

title: What If Subways and Buses Were Free?
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Disputing the $5 Million Terror-Tip Reward
description: If it werent connected to the worst terror attack in American history, it might almost put The Lede in mind of a Saturday afternoon Western: A big reward for turning in a villain, a big dispute over who is entitled to it.

title: For People Who Thought PBS Hated Capitalism
description: Standing on the worn brown carpet of a narrow balcony overlooking the New York Stock Exchange, Susie Gharib covers stock market news, earning reports, and economic indicators every day.

title: Undecided in Brooklyn
description: Video

title: Blogtalk: S.C. and Florida
description: South Carolinians find themselves once again enmeshed in debates about race and politics; at least thats the case if you read some of the blogs rippling across the state.

title: Forget Sundance: Indie Films Come to Istanbul
description: The stars of American Fork include Hubbel Palmer, left, and William Baldwin.

title: Some Personal Notes
description: I grew up in the Mississippi Delta town where Percy lived with his Uncle Will, said to be the model for Aunt Emily. His brother and his nephew were both my neighbors when I was growing up. When my husband and I decided to buy our house, we discovered that it had belonged to Percys other brother, Phinizy, known as Phin, who is still alive and now lives a few blocks away on St. Charles Avenue. Phin, a World War II veteran who was in the PT boat just behind Jack Kennedys when it got rammed by the Japanese, taught at Tulane Law School and lived with his wife and their four children, in the house I now live in between 1955 and 1977.

title: The Path to Super Tuesday
description: For most Americans, the current race for the White House has been the most unpredictable and exciting in many years. On Feb. 5, voters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will help to choose the Democratic and Republican presidential nominees. Super Tuesday could result in a clear favorite in both parties  or the race could remain wide-open until the summer conventions. From now through the primaries, City Room will focus on the presidential contest as it is waged in our region. Already, the schedule of campaign events is busier, and a sampling from the New York region this weekend is below.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 25
description: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Manhattans winter chill, the greening of an apartment building in Washington Heights and the death of the actor Heath Ledger.

title: Any Means Necessary
description: Ezra Klein at Tapped just got an interesting e-mail from the Hillary Clinton campaign. It read:

title: Airlines and Punctuation
description: As long-time Pogues Postians are aware, Im obsessed with the signs in airplanes.

title: Vows: Kat and Matt
description: Kat and Matt were just beginning to think about getting married when they  discovered their first child was due in April.

title: Bloggingheads: Obama and the Right
description:
Authors Reza Aslan, left, and Rod Dreher debate whether conservatives really like Barack Obama and whether they could push him over the top in November.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Predictor in Chief
description: The Colbert Reports recap of the week:

title: Raw Politics
description: With the mercury rising in New York tuna and the presidential race, columnist Clyde Haberman whimsically unpacks the candidates positions in Fridays fish wrapper:

title: John McCain's Economic Plan
description: Senator John McCain discusses what his approach to economic issues would be if he were elected president.

title: On the Federal Reserve
description: The Arizona Senator talks about Alan Greenspan and Ben Bernanke with David Leonhardt of The New York Times.

title: On His Vice Presidential Choice
description: The Arizona Senator talks about whether he would feel compelled to pick a vice president with deep experience in economics.

title: Reader Responses to Chinas Genocide Olympics.
description: Heres a sampling of reader comments from Nicks Thursday column about China and Darfur. Horsham wrote that Nick chose the wrong mechanism to use as leverage.

title: On the Ground: Nicki Bennett in Bangladesh
John McCain's Economic Plan
description: Senator John McCain discusses what his approach to economic issues would be if he were elected president.

title: Once Plentiful, Activists Are a Rare Breed at Davos
description: There was a time in the 1990s that Davos had little time for what was then called  it seems so quaint a label now  the anti-globalization movement. Protests prompted a security lockdown, and at times managed to shut down parts of the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum.

title: Wonder Returning to New Orleans
description: Stevie Wonder, right, will perform at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival after an absence of 35 years, The Associated Press reported. On May 2 Mr. Wonder is scheduled to headline the second weekend of this years event, along with Billy Joel, Sheryl Crow and Tim McGraw. The festival will be held from April 25 to April 27, and from May 1 to May 4. Headlining the festivals opening day are Ms. Crow, Robert Plant and Alison Krauss. Also scheduled to perform are Dr. John, Al Green, Elvis Costello and Allen Toussaint. Performers on the second weekend include Randy Newman, Widespread Panic, Aaron Neville and  Santana. The event, with more than 1,000 musicians, is held at a racetrack where 11 stages and tents are set up. This year features a particularly strong lineup of female jazz singers, including Patti Austin, Cassandra Wilson, Dianne Reeves, Diana Krall and Ruby Wilson.

title: Hedge Fund Seeks Board Seats at Times Co.
description: An Alabama-based hedge fund gave notice Friday that it would try to elect directors to The New York Times Company board, a day after the same hedge fund gave similar notice to another newspaper company, Media General.

title: A Song-and-Dance Salute to the King of French Operetta
description: Offenbach Cabaret: Jacques in the Big Apple, presented by Opra Franais de New York and the French Institute Alliance Franaise, promised a satirical and saucy musical review. But glancing at the glum, perplexed faces of audience members in the French Institutes elegant Skyroom on Thursday, you might have thought they were investors watching their stocks plummet, not Champagne-sipping cabaret patrons.

title: Giants Move On, With Two Stars in Their Wake
description: The playoff vogue among Giants fans has been to frame the teams climb in the context of addition by subtraction: the Giants are Super Bowl-bound largely because Tiki Barber retired and Jeremy Shockey broke his leg.

title: A Bitter Rivalry Finds a Little Common Ground
description: WAYNE, N.J.  For 365 days each year, the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox are ferocious rivals. With offices that are only 206 miles apart, Brian Cashman, the general manager of the Yankees, and Theo Epstein, Cashmans counterpart with the Red Sox, try to do anything and everything to have the superior team.

title: Draft of New Iran Sanctions Restricts Cargo and Travel
description: UNITED NATIONS  A new Security Council resolution on Irans nuclear program will propose restrictions on cargo to and from Iran, travel bans and asset freezes for people involved in the program and monitoring of Iranian financial institutions, according to a draft text circulated Friday.

title: Wonders and Woes of a Working-Class Life
description: A cornerstone of country music is an age-old celebration of family values: not the politically loaded kind often put in quotation marks as a buzz term for a right-wing social agenda, but the meat-and-potatoes satisfactions and sorrows of everyday life. On Thursday evening Lori McKenna, a twangy-voiced mother of five children from Stoughton, Mass., brought it all back home at the Allen Room, where she was appearing as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series.

title: The Stuff Pack Rats Are Made Of
description: EVER since we moved to our new home last month, I have been obsessed with the cost of clutter.

title: Housing Market Gives Hints of a Thaw
description: ROMEOVILLE, Ill.  The temperature was in the single digits and the forecast for the real estate market was even chillier, but Fran and Mark Gable went out the other day to see about buying a four-bedroom house.

title: The FISA Follies, Redux
description: The Senate (reportedly still under Democratic control) seems determined to help President Bush violate Americans civil liberties and undermine the constitutional separation of powers. Majority Leader Harry Reid is supporting White House-backed legislation that would expand the administrations ability to spy on Americans without court supervision and ensure that the country never learns the full extent of Mr. Bushs illegal wiretapping program.

title: Same Office, Different Planets
description: DO human resource executives know their employees?

title: Car Bomb Kills a Top Lebanese Terrorism Investigator
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A powerful car bomb killed one of Lebanons top terrorism investigators and three other people in eastern Beirut on Friday. It was the latest in a long series of attacks aimed at Lebanese politicians, journalists and security officials.

title: New Editor Named in San Francisco
description: Ward Bushee, editor of The Arizona Republic, was named executive vice president and editor of The San Francisco Chronicle, succeeding Phil Bronstein.

title: Webster Rebounds as Giants Roll On
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Corey Webster of the Giants has an appropriate locker at Giants Stadium  in the corner of the room, on the edge, a logical place for a cornerback.

title: Hate to Spoil a Weekend, but ....
description: Back in his mid-1980s heyday, when he was Americas most famous investor, managing Americas most famous mutual fund, Peter Lynch used to hate Mondays. Monday, you see, was the day the market was most likely to go down; according to research Mr. Lynch had compiled, from 1955 to 1985, it dropped by a cumulative 1,500 points just on that one day.

title: Blaze Sends Thousands Fleeing a Las Vegas Resort
description: A fire on Friday swept parts of the top several floors of a hotel-casino on the Las Vegas Strip, but no one was seriously injured, a remarkably fortunate outcome given that thousands of guests and employees were inside when the blaze broke out around midday.

title: Schools Call on Alumni Networks to Help Fill Coffers
description: Rich prep schools, with wealthy and talented alumni to draw on, are becoming a lot richer. And its not just because they have a lot of generous donors.

title: Swedish Star Finds Motivation in Variety
description: BOSTON  Carolina Kluft of Sweden will not turn 25 until next Saturday, but in the heptathlon, the seven-event test in womens track and field, she has won the last Olympic gold medal, the last two European championships and the last three world championships. She has won her last 19 heptathlons. Only the legendary Jackie Joyner-Kersee has scored higher.

title: Coach Filed 2nd Resignation
description: More than two weeks after he was sued over a $4 million buyout clause in his contract at West Virginia, Rich Rodriguez turned in a second resignation letter, which claimed that Mike Garrison, the university president, reneged on a deal to reduce and possibly eliminate the clause. The letter obtained by The Associated Press and bearing Rodriguezs name indicated the tack his legal defense will take when he files a response to that lawsuit in United States District Court.Rodriguez resigned with a one-sentence letter Dec. 18 to take the coaching job at Michigan. The latest letter is dated Jan. 10. In the letter, sent to Athletic Director Ed Pastilong, Rodriguez restated his displeasure with how slowly West Virginia was responding to additional demands he made in December 2006, when he passed up a $12 million deal at Alabama.

title: A Light at the End of the Half-Pipe, Through Closed Eyes
description: THE last thing I saw before plunging down the bobsled track at the Olympic Sports Complex outside Lake Placid, N.Y., was an eerie orange light. I shivered in a wind chill of minus 17 degrees that penetrated all the way from my crash helmet to my long johns. I realized that the orange light was the sunset reflecting off the summit of Whiteface Mountain a dozen or so miles to the north. But I had no idea whether it foreboded the thrill of a lifetime or imminent death.

title: Officer in Scuffle Killed by Police in White Plains
description: An off-duty Mount Vernon, N.Y., police officer was shot and killed in downtown White Plains on Friday evening after he pulled his gun on another man and was fired at by Westchester County police officers, the authorities said.

title: In Matchup of Futility, Knicks Stand Taller Than Struggling Sixers
description: Just when the Knicks had begun to look sufferable, Larry Brown haunted them this week through a magazine article with a reminder of one of the franchises worst seasons.

title: Congress Moving for Swift Passage of Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON  House Democrats on Friday said they would try to speed passage of a $150 billion economic stimulus package by scheduling it for a vote on Tuesday, eight days earlier than originally planned.

title: Listen Up and Fly Right
description: Grand Forks, N.D.

title: Out of Favor for Benefiting From Favors, Rowland Stirs Varied Sentiments
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  The job description may be less impressive than governor or congressman, but John G. Rowland is raring to go.

title: Author Faults a Game, and Gamers Flame Back
description: The Internet hath no fury like a gamer scorned.

title: Reads Like a Book, Looks Like a Film
description: Brian Selznick, the author and illustrator of The Invention of Hugo Cabret, uses the word obsessed a lot. As in: I was deeply obsessed with Star Wars (elaborate pencil drawings of Princess Leia and Darth Vader that he did as a 10-year-old hang on a wall of the art studio in his Brooklyn apartment) or I remember being really obsessed with the Virgin of the Rocks, by Leonardo da Vinci (a sketch of the angel from that painting hangs in the hallway).

title: Mr. Bloombergs Budget Plan
description: New York has never had a more fiscally fluent mayor than Michael Bloomberg, a self-made billionaire. As he unveiled his preliminary $58.5 billion budget this week, the mayor warned of challenges ahead, but he also predicted that he could successfully steer the city through another downturn. There are a lot of uncertainties, but we take comfort in knowing that Mr. Bloomberg has prepared New York to weather bad times.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the entry of tens of thousands of Palestinians into Egypt after Hamas militants destroyed part of a fence at the border with Gaza described incompletely the events regarding Gaza and Egypt three decades ago. In that era, Egypt accepted the return of Sinai from Israel but declined to take back Gaza, not just the Gazan half of the border city of Rafah. The article also misstated, in some editions, the location of the border. It separates Gaza from northern Egypt, not southern Egypt.

title: Sentencing in Murder
description: A man who pleaded guilty in Phoenix to murder in the 2003 slaying of a Cincinnati Reds prospect was sentenced to life in prison Friday, but a judge decided that the man, Reginald Riddle, would be eligible for parole after 25 years. Riddle, 23, pleaded guilty in 2006 to the first-degree murder of outfielder Dernell Stenson of LaGrange, Ga., as part of a plea agreement.

title: And Triplets Make Seven in Rookie Policemans Home
description: As Boatema Amoah was having her eighth-week sonogram, the technician asked her three times, Was this a natural pregnancy?

title: Wyeth Says It May Cut 10% of Jobs
description: Wyeth said Friday that it might cut as many as 5,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its worldwide work force, after federal regulators delayed four medicines in the last year.

title: Colombia: Rice Lobbies for Trade Deal
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice wrapped up a two-day visit with a strong show of support for President lvaro Uribe, a close ally of the Bush administration who is seeking a trade agreement with the United States. Ms. Rice, accompanied by nine Democratic lawmakers, lobbied for the United States Congress to approve the deal, which faces resistance from labor and human rights groups amid concerns over killings of union officials in Colombia and ties to paramilitary death squads among political supporters of Mr. Uribe. Democratic leaders in Congress and the leading Democratic candidates for president have shown little enthusiasm for the trade agreement.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the effect of the television and film writers strike on soap operas referred incorrectly to the financial core designation held by some writers who have returned to work. It is a provision of federal law under which individuals pay some union dues and fees and are covered by collective bargaining agreements, but are not union members and not compelled to go on strike. The designation is not based on financial need.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Sports Briefing column on Wednesday about the African Cup of Nations soccer tournament misstated the outcome of a match involving Zambia. Zambia defeated Sudan, 3-0.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the entry of tens of thousands of Palestinians into Egypt after Hamas militants destroyed part of a fence at the border with Gaza described incompletely the events regarding Gaza and Egypt three decades ago. In that era, Egypt accepted the return of Sinai from Israel but declined to take back Gaza, not just the Gazan half of the border city of Rafah. The article also misstated, in some editions, the location of the border. It separates Gaza from northern Egypt, not southern Egypt. (Go to Article)

title: Going Live From Pyongyang
description: The New York Philharmonics concert in North Korea, to take place on Feb. 26 at the East Pyongyang Grand Theater, will be broadcast live internationally. The broadcast will be produced by the New York Philharmonic and EuroArts Music International, in co-production with the Munhwa Broadcasting Company of South Korea and ARTE France, and in cooperation with the European Broadcasting Union. Details of the broadcast in the United States are to be announced later. The concert, to be conducted by Lorin Maazel, above, the orchestras music director, will include the national anthems of North Korea and the United States; the Prelude to Act III of Wagners Lohengrin; Dvoraks Symphony No. 9, From the New World; and Gershwins American in Paris. The concert, and the Philharmonics visit, have aroused controversy, with some contending that they offer legitimacy to North Koreas government.

title: Museum Workers Are Called Complicit
description: LOS ANGELES  Appraisal forms, import applications, reference materials. To that usual array of tools a museum might harness in assessing donated artifacts, some museums in Southern California appear to have added one more, according to investigators affidavits: a wink and a nudge.

title: Scottish & Newcastle Agrees to Be Bought and Split
description: LONDON  Scottish & Newcastle, Britains largest brewer, agreed on Friday to a 7.8 billion ($15.4 billion) takeover by the European rivals Carlsberg and Heineken.

title: Young Singers Chance to Fill a Stage All Alone
description: This week the Marilyn Horne Foundation and the Weill Music Institute at Carnegie Hall joined forces to present The Song Continues, this years installment of Ms. Hornes annual series of master classes and concerts meant to encourage young singers toward recital singing as an art worth cultivating, even as they prepare for bigger-ticket operatic careers.

title: Beating Federer, Djokovic Has Look of a Champion
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Novak Djokovic, a master of imitating the quirks and strokes of other tennis stars, did a fine impression of a champion Friday night by refusing to surrender even one set to Roger Federer, of all people, in the semifinals of the Australian Open.

title: As State Primary Nears, Pataki Is Barely Visible
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki left office last January, he was the dominant Republican politician in New York. Over three terms, he had shattered fund-raising records and had racked up double-digit victory margins in an overwhelmingly Democratic state, becoming a national political figure in the process. Mr. Pataki ruled Albany for so long that even now some swatches of state bureaucracy are still run by his political appointees.

title: Two Twins Agree to Deals
description: Justin Morneau, the 2006 American League Most Valuable Player, received the most lucrative contract in Minnesota Twins history, a six-year, $80 million deal announced Friday. The Twins also announced a three-year, $24 million agreement for right fielder Michael Cuddyer. General Manager Bill Smith said the deals did not affect other players.

title: 3 Leading Executives Resign at Insurer Under Inquiry
description: The top managers of WellCare Health Plans, an insurer being investigated by the F.B.I. for possible fraud, resigned Friday.

title: Bulking Up for Rambo
description: Sylvester Stallone says he used human growth hormone, though not steroids, to get in shape for Rambo, which opened on Friday, and defends its use in an article on Time magazines Web site (time.com). Mr. Stallone, 61, says he gained 41 pounds to play Rambo by using prescription testosterone. Everyone over 40 years old would be wise to investigate it because it increases the quality of your life, he says. Mark my words. In 10 years it will be over the counter. HGH and other performance-enhancing substances have become a matter of concern to sports officials, who are fighting their use among athletes.

title: Ivory Coast Advances
description: Didier Drogba scored one goal and set up another for Aruna Dindane to help Ivory Coast to a 4-1 victory against Benin on Friday in Sekondi, Ghana, making the Elephants the first team to qualify for the quarterfinals of the African Cup of Nations. Nigeria struggled again to create chances in a 0-0 draw against Mali in Group Bs other match.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the visit to Turkey by Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis of Greece misidentified, in some copies, the city where he met with his Turkish counterpart, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. It was in Ankara, not Istanbul.

title: Venezuelan Pleads Guilty in Cover-Up of Suitcase of Cash
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A Venezuelan lawyer pleaded guilty in Miami on Friday to his role in a plot to cover up the destination of a suitcase stuffed with $800,000 in cash that United States prosecutors say was intended as a campaign contribution from the Venezuelan government to Argentinas president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner.

title: Two Presidents Are Worse Than One
description: Evanston, Ill.

title: Democratic Hopefuls Seek to Widen Appeal Beyond Core Groups
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  As Democrats headed on Friday toward the finish line of their first presidential primary in the South, the three candidates sought to widen their appeal to voters outside their core support groups.

title: Dropping Pants, Dispelling Rumors
description: The popular South Korean singer Na Hoon-a, below, went live on national television Thursday and unexpectedly dropped his trousers, saying he was ready to prove he had not been castrated or dismembered in a love quarrel over an unnamed actress, Reuters reported. The singer addressed a packed news conference to deny rumors that he had undergone amputation or injury at the hands of a Japanese gangster.

title: Union Membership Sees Biggest Rise Since 83
description: The roll of American workers belonging to labor unions climbed last year by the largest number since 1983, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday.

title: Doing Battle on the Field of Parody
description: So much has been written about the homoeroticism in the film 300 that any spoof is bound to feel like overkill. Fortunately, overkill is what Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer do best: as the uncontested titans of the parody genre (with fingers in everything from the Scary Movie franchise to the more recent Epic Movie) they continue to prove that ridiculing other movies is much easier than making your own.

title: Questions Surround Idea of Privatizing the Lottery
description: ALBANY  Can New York hit the jackpot by selling its lottery?

title: Lo Duca Will See Doctor
description: Nationals catcher Paul Lo Duca injured his left knee during a workout and will travel to Washington next week to be examined by a team doctor. Lo Duca, who signed a $5 million deal for one season as a free agent this off-season, was hurt this week and had a magnetic resonance imaging exam Friday.

title: House Republicans Urge Earmark Moratorium
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans called on Friday for an immediate moratorium on earmarking money for pet projects. They urged Democrats to join them in establishing a bipartisan panel to set strict new standards for such spending.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Jan. 5 with a dance review of New York City Ballet misspelled, in some copies, the given name of a dancer. He is Damian Woetzel, not Damien.

title: Reprising Anonymous Role in Another Super Bowl
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants tight end Jerome Collins will be attending his second consecutive Super Bowl next week in Arizona. A member of the Indianapolis Colts last season, Collins has a Super Bowl ring and has pocketed hundreds of thousands of dollars in winning team playoff shares over the last two postseasons.

title: At the Tournament Table, Learning by Doing
description: Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., gives an annual gift of sorts to its students. During the winter they are allowed almost a month away from regular classes to pursue a nonacademic subject. Some use the time to enhance their skiing and partygoing skills. But this year seven students  Todd Bustard, Chris Chudzicki, Jon Dahlberg, Jason Griffith, Bill Jannen, Edward Newkirk and Bryant Renaud  chose to pursue tournament bridge under the tutelage of Frank Morgan, the Atwell professor of mathematics.

title: Italian Leads
description: Carolina Kostner held off a strong challenge from two Finnish teenagers to lead the womens competition after the short program Friday at the European Figure Skating Championships in Zagreb, Croatia.Kostner, an Italian, opened defense of her title with a triple flip-triple toe loop combination. She made mistakes on her next two jumps, but her spins and triple-triple gave her an overall total of 59.31 points. Kiira Korpi, last years bronze medalist, finished with 58.60 points. The Finnish champion Laura Lepisto was third with 56.96.The ice dancing title went to the Russians Oksana Domnina and Maxim Shabalin, who overtook Isabelle Delobel and Olivier Schoenfelder of France.

title: Seeking a More Flattering Light on, and From, Bulbs
description: SOME 26 years ago, when Robert Pai joined Sylvanias fluorescent technology laboratories, he and his fellow researchers did not think much about compact fluorescents. They were more interested in solving problems with mercury and ballast, and otherwise making big industrial fluorescent lamps more efficient and safer for the environment. Much has happened since. Sylvania is now part of Osram Sylvania, a unit of the German company Siemens. Dr. Pai  he has a doctorate in physics  is heading compact fluorescent research. And compact fluorescents, usually called C.F.L.s, are definitely on researchers minds.

title: In South Carolina, Everything Turns on Jobs
description: ORANGEBURG, S.C.  Officially, the state of South Carolina calls the fancy new building the Orangeburg Workforce Center. Around here, people know it as the unemployment office. And everyone in Orangeburg County, it seems, can tell you how to get there.

title: Jockey Barred
description: The champion jockey Kieren Fallon was barred for 18 months after a second positive test for an unidentified banned substance. Fallon, from Ireland, appealed the ruling by the governing body of thoroughbred and steeplechase racing in France. He can race in France until his appeal is heard. Fallon, 42, tested positive for cocaine Aug. 19 in Deauville after riding Myboycharlie. He served a ban from December 2006 to June 2007 after testing positive for cocaine while riding in France.

title: Ex-HarperCollins Publisher Settles Defamation Suit
description: Judith Regan, the publisher who was fired from HarperCollins in late 2006 after the company decided to scrap the release of If I Did It, O. J. Simpsons hypothetical murder confession, has settled her $100 million defamation lawsuit against News Corporation, Harpers parent.

title: Easing Taut Prog-Metal Into a Majestic Crunch
description: Neurosis started out in the late 80s as a hard-core punk band, making rickety songs in speedy two-beat rhythms. Its music was a slanted plywood hutch. Now it makes monument music: slow and graceful, determined, balanced, imperious.

title: Taking the Bears to Task
description: ON Monday, Barry Ritholtz, the chief executive of the research firm Fusion IQ and the author of the popular blog the Big Picture, criticized what he called the Long and Wrong crowd  people who insist on remaining positive about the markets and the economy.

title: Memo Details Objections to Command Center Site
description: The New York Police Department produced a detailed analysis in 1998 opposing plans by the city to locate its emergency command center at the World Trade Center, but the Giuliani administration overrode those objections. The command center later collapsed from damage in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

title: Getting Ships in Shape
description: The Heritage Lottery Fund awarded grants toward the preservation of two historic British ships, the Mary Rose and the Cutty Sark, Agence France-Presse reported. The fund awarded 10 million ($19.7 million) for extensive restoration to the Cutty Sark, a tea clipper shown above in a computer image, after it was gutted by fire last May. And 21 million ($41.4 million) went to the Mary Rose, King Henry VIIIs flagship, which sank in 1545 and was raised in 1982. The money is to pay for a museum in the dockyards at Portsmouth, England, that will house the Mary Rose and the artifacts found with it.

title: Woman Who Survived 9/11 Is Killed by a Car in the City
description: It was a beautiful morning on Sept. 11, 2001, so Florence Cioffi made a decision that helped save her life: She left her office in the World Trade Center for a coffee break and was able to flee the devastation of the terrorist attack.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Jan. 15 about an experiment in which a robot was controlled by a monkeys thoughts misattributed the robots design. It was by the Sarcos Research Corporation in Salt Lake City, not Gordon Cheng and colleagues at the ATR Computational Neuroscience Laboratories in Kyoto, Japan. (The Kyoto group helped design the experiment.)

title: A Stress-Filled Week Shows Obama With a Blend of Humor and Fire
description: CLEMSON, S.C.  On the fifth day, Senator Barack Obama chose humor.

title: Building Costs Deal Blow to Local Budgets
description: SEATTLE  State and local governments in many parts of the country are struggling to pay for roads, bridges and other building projects because of rising construction costs, adding another burden to budgets already stressed by the troubled housing market.

title: Only Private Security Will Do, Until It Doesnt
description: On a Friday evening exactly 29 years ago, a man in a town house on West 54th Street in Manhattan had a heart attack. His name was Nelson A. Rockefeller; he had built a life of power atop the oil fortune that came down to him from his father, serving as governor of New York and vice president of the United States.

title: Richard G. Darman, 64, Aide for 5 Presidents, Dies
description: Richard G. Darman, who marshaled a deep, prickly intelligence to guide policy and deal making in four Republican administrations, including negotiating the reversal of the first President George Bushs campaign pledge not to raise taxes, died Friday. He was 64 and lived in McLean, Va.

title: Conviction in Poisoning of Indonesian Rights Activist
description: SOLO, Indonesia  In a high-profile case that had become a test of the independence of Indonesias judiciary, the Supreme Court convicted on Friday a former airline pilot for the 2004 poisoning of a human rights advocate and sentenced him to 20 years in prison.

title: Russian Police Arrest a Suspected Racketeer
description: MOSCOW  Semyon Y. Mogilevich, a reputed kingpin of the Russian mob, was arrested in Moscow this week on tax evasion charges.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A caption in Science Times on Tuesday about blogs that celebrate fat people omitted the source of an illustration for the blog fatgrrl.com, which said, Love Your Fat Self. It was from an article in Utne Reader about obesity that the blog was highlighting on its home page.

title: Loud Crashes, Dignified Stereotypes and a Touch of Wagner
description: Julian Rosefeldt, a German artist born in 1965 who lives in Berlin, makes visually opulent, earnestly political films and videos. Most of his work is high-minded, excessively middlebrow and seemingly bent on tweaking consciousness seductively and without strain.

title: With Third Title, Sharapova Shows Shes Back
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Nothing could stop Maria Sharapova at the Australian Open this year. Not her usual nemesis, Serena Williams, who was beaten by someone else in the quarterfinals. Not her fragile right shoulder, which remained loose and pain free.

title: Giants Have Fan in Cashman
description: WAYNE, N.J.  When Brian Cashman was an assistant general manager for the Yankees, one of his roommates was Timmy Coughlin, son of Tom Coughlin, the Giants coach.

title: Yanks and Can Agree on Deal
description: The Yankees and second baseman Robinson Can reached a preliminary agreement Friday on a contract that could pay him about $55 million over six years.

title: Judge to Decide 3 Detectives Fate
description: The three detectives charged in the 2006 shooting death of Sean Bell will be tried by a judge, not a jury, the judge in the case ruled Friday.

title: McCains Fiscal Mantra Becomes Less Is More
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Senator John McCain said that, if elected, he would do what other presidents had tried but failed to do: cut government spending sharply enough to reduce the budget deficit while lowering taxes at the same time.

title: Death of Troubled Connecticut Surgeon Leads to Charges Against an Employee
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  Ian M. Rubins appeared to have it all. He was a skilled plastic surgeon who treated breast cancer patients in need of reconstructive surgery, and his surgical talents helped him achieve a pampered life, with a $2 million house here, a ski house on 10 acres in Vermont, a 39-foot boat and a plane.

title: Report by British Military Finds No Systematic Abuse of Iraqi Prisoners by Its Soldiers
description: LONDON  A British Army report on the mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners by British soldiers in southern Iraq in the first year after the allied invasion in 2003 has concluded that there was no systematic abuse but that there were individual instances where people behaved disgracefully.

title: Egypt Tries to Plug Border; Gazans Poke New Hole
description: GAZA  Egypt tried to restore its border with Gaza on Friday, stationing riot police officers in an effort to block Palestinians from entering. But Palestinians used a bulldozer to knock down another portion of the wall separating Egypt and Gaza.

title: Britain Seeks Its Essence, and Finds Punch Lines
description: LONDON  It was a lofty idea: formulate a British statement of values defining what it means to be British, much the way a document like the Declaration of Independence sets out the ideals that help explain what it means to be American.

title: Who Has the Optimism? The Have-Nots
description: DAVOS, Switzerland

title: Masters of Zen, Not of Winning
description: A book called The Complete Pocket Positives sat at the center of Cathy Andruzzis desk after a recent practice. One of her players had bought it for her earlier this season, and Andruzzi, the womens basketball coach at Fordham, has taken to flipping it open to a random page and having a member of her team read one of the quotes out loud before each practice.

title: A Lovefest, if Misery Loves Company
description: Pain, alienation and the thousand varieties of loneliness that flesh is heir to: these are the topics that Abi Morgans Tender, a British play being given its New York premiere by Thirteenth Night Theater, means to address. The action has been moved to New York from London, but misery trumps geography  these characters would be unhappy anywhere.

title: Arkansas: Not-Guilty Plea Entered for Bus Driver
description: A not-guilty plea was entered on behalf of a bus driver charged with four felonies after he tested positive for amphetamines in a deadly crash in eastern Arkansas. The driver, Felix Badillo Tapia, 28, did not attend the hearing. Mr. Tapia, who faces four counts of negligent homicide, was previously released on $50,000 bond. If convicted, he could be sentenced to up to 10 years in prison. Mr. Tapia was driving a Tornado Bus Company bus Nov. 25 when it crossed the median near Forrest City and collided with a pickup and a tractor-trailer.

title: The Endorsements: The Readers Turn
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Said to Be Weighing Public Pricing of Derivatives
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  United States regulators are considering forcing investment banks to make public markets in some of the more exotic financial instruments that have plunged in value in the last six months, the head of the New York Stock Exchange said Friday.

title: Tackling a Character Whos a Real Character
description: Richard Thomas, the composer of Jerry Springer: The Opera, says that the libretto contains only 174 objectionable words, including nipple. That tally may not account for certain expressions  all of them unprintable in this newspaper  that are repeated over and over, but is nevertheless considerably shy of the 8,000 swear words and obscenities claimed, Mr. Thomas says, by overexcited critics of the show during its run in London. Jerry Springer: The Opera was a huge hit in the West End, but when it was shown on BBC television in January 2005, it generated so many complaints that some BBC executives asked for police protection.

title: All of Nature Is on the Stage, in Sound and Light and Moves
description: Jordan Fuchss new Thicket is a small, neatly constructed piece that didnt just fill the stage on Thursday at Danspace Project. Mr. Fuchs created an entire universe of throbbing, sprinting natural life in just 45 minutes, with four dancers and a mysterious score by Andy Russ. Carol Mullinss stark lighting shifts, from pitch-black night to blazing orange-honey noon, added immeasurably to the dances quiet power.

title: Mosul Bombings Prompt Promise of New Offensive
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki announced Friday that he was sending more forces to Mosul for what he vowed would be a decisive struggle to rid the city of insurgents.

title: Being Sports New Face, After Homework Is Done
description: ST. PAUL  The little girl in the pink skating dress could not have been more adorable, or more charming.

title: Museum Seeks Ruling on Claim to Painting
description: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, has turned to the courts to validate its claim to a 1913 Oskar Kokoschka painting sought by Claudia Seger-Thomschitz, an Austrian woman who says it was sold under duress during the Nazi occupation of Austria, The Boston Globe reported. Lawyers for Ms. Seger-Thomschitz contend that there is no doubt that the Kokoschka painting, Two Nudes (Lovers), was sold under duress by Oskar Reichel, a physician who ran an art gallery in Vienna. The Museum of Fine Arts, citing months of research, maintained that the sale in 1939 was voluntary and to another Jew, the Viennese art dealer Otto Kallir. The painting was never confiscated by the Nazis, was never sold by force as a result of Nazi persecution and was not otherwise taken from Dr. Reichel, the museums complaint states. Ms. Seger-Thomschitzs lawyers said they would respond to the suit.

title: Moodys Official Concedes Failures in Some Ratings
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The chief executive of Moodys, the credit rating agency, conceded on Friday that his agency had made significant mistakes in the rating of structured finance products, but added that the agency had been deceived by people who put together the products.

title: U.S. Race Captures Worlds Eye, and Holds It
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  To look at the reams of coverage in newspapers outside the United States or to follow the hours of television news broadcasts, you might conclude that foreigners had a vote in selecting an American presidential candidate  or, at least, deserved one, so great is Americas influence on their lives.

title: Stakeholder Sues IAC Over Breakup Plan
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, the entertainment and Internet retailing company controlled by the billionaire John C. Malone, has sued IAC/InterActiveCorp in a dispute over IACs plans to split into five companies.

title: Woods Isnt Driving Perfectly, but Hes Cruising
description: SAN DIEGO  In the relative calm before the coming Pacific storm, Tiger Woods churned inexorably across the North Course at Torrey Pines on Friday, making birdies from the rough, a par from the sand, a chip-in par from the green and putts from everywhere else. His bogey-free round of 65 on a striking California day provided yet another Tiger Woods Clinic, this one titled: How to Thrive When You Cant Drive.

title: After Break for Debate, Two Rivals Resume Spat
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  A day after a relatively reserved debate in which they appeared to take pains to avoid attacking each other, Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney on Friday engaged in their most vigorous sniping since their back-and-forth before the New Hampshire primary over two weeks ago.

title: Where Would the 12 Million Go?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Does It His Way in New Yorks Balmier Precincts
description: Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Mayors Amorous Texts Lead to Perjury Inquiry
description: DETROIT  The citys charismatic but scandal-plagued mayor and his chief of staff will be the subject of an investigation into whether they lied under oath when they denied having an extramarital affair, the Wayne County prosecutor announced here Friday.

title: Alton G. Marshall, 86, Nelson Rockefellers Top Aide, Is Dead
description: Alton G. Marshall, who as executive secretary to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York in the late 1960s was considered a behind-the-scenes manager of the governors programs, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Fighting for Justice, Even at His Own Peril
description: BRISBANE, Australia

title: U.S. Ignores Finding on Student Lender
description: The Education Department has brushed aside a finding by its own inspector general that a student lender improperly received $34 million in federal subsidies, and is instructing the lender to decide for itself how much money it should pay back.

title: Taking Aim at the Perks of Districts in Nassau
description: GREAT NECK, N.Y.  The man who oversees the Water Authority of Great Neck North drives a Crown Victoria financed by taxpayers, who also pick up the tab for the gas and insurance.

title: Peyton Sees Success in His Brothers Future
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The empty space between the conference championship games and the Super Bowl has always been filled with predictions. This year, the New England Patriots are heavily favored to beat the Giants and become the first N.F.L. team to finish with a 19-0 record.

title: Questions for the Clintons
description: Charleston, S.C.

title: No Apparent Link Between Two Fatal Cases of Meningitis, Health Officials Say
description: Two people from local high schools  a Queens woman and a Long Island teenager  have died of bacterial meningitis in the past two days.

title: French Trader Is Remembered as Mr. Average
description: PARIS  Jrme Kerviel was too middling to be considered a loser. Until he was charged by Socit Gnrale with perpetrating the biggest fraud of its kind in banking history, there was nothing superlative about him.

title: So Is Waterboarding Torture? Mukasey May Never Say
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey suggested Friday that he might never provide an answer to the question that threatened his Senate confirmation last year: Does the harsh interrogation technique known as waterboarding amount to torture?

title: Heeeres Rudy!
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

title: At Elite Prep Schools, College-Size Endowments
description: EXETER, N.H.  When Curtis Thomas, a 14-year-old from a poor family living in St. Rose, La., arrived here two years ago to attend Phillips Exeter Academy, he brought little more than a pair of jeans and two shirts. That would hardly do at a 227-year-old prep school where ties are still required for boys in class.

title: Fight Brews in Italy Over New Elections
description: ROME  The day after Prime Minister Romano Prodi resigned, Italys leaders began gearing up Friday for a new fight: whether to hold immediate elections, an option considered favorable to former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, or first fix an electoral law blamed for the current instability.

title: Behind the Abortion Decline
description: Coinciding with this months 35th anniversary of the Supreme Courts ruling that legalized abortion, a new study shows that the United States continues to make progress on reducing the abortion rate. The progress would be greater if more was done to avoid unintended pregnancies.

title: Knoblauch Wait Continues
description: HOUSTON  The mother of the former Yankees player Chuck Knoblauch said Friday that she believed he would cooperate with a Congressional committee investigating the use of steroids in baseball.

title: French Film Nominations
description: La Vie en Rose, Persepolis, The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, La Graine et le Mulet and Un Secret are the nominees for the Csars, Frances version of the Academy Awards, as best picture. La Vie, about the singer Edith Piaf, led with 11 nominations, including one for Marion Cotillard, above, who plays Piaf,  for best actress. The Csars will be awarded in Paris on Feb. 22.

title: Why Replace Our Drawbridge? It Can Be Repaired
description: To the Editor:

title: Tensions Grow at Egypt-Gaza Border
description: JERUSALEM  Egyptian riot police used armored vehicles to try to restrict Gazans from taking their cars into Egypt on Saturday, and the Egyptian foreign minister warned of provocations at the border. He said that at least 36 Egyptian security officers had been hospitalized, some in critical condition, after confrontations with Palestinians.

title: Florida: New Head of Hurricane Center
description: A veteran weather forecaster was named the new director of the National Hurricane Center. The forecaster, Bill Read, 58, had been the interim deputy director of the center since August, when X. William Proenza was ousted as director. Mr. Proenzas staff had urged federal officials to dismiss him because they said he was exaggerating problems with a satellite. Mr. Read ran the Houston-Galveston office of the National Weather Service before joining the center. The interim director of the center, Edward N. Rappaport, chose not to apply for the permanent position and will return to his previous post as deputy director.

title: Belt-Tightening, but No Collapse, Is Forecast in Technology Spending
description: In the consumer economy, the Main Street shopper leads the way. In the corporate economy, big technology buyers like Monte Ford will determine the arc of business spending in the coming months.

title: Socit Gnrales Sales May Have Incited Market Plunge
description: PARIS  As panic swept European markets on Monday, word spread that a big hedge fund was in trouble and dumping stocks.

title: Judge Rules for the City in Gun Sting of Dealers
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn ruled on Friday that the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg did not break the law in conducting sting operations meant to catch out-of-state gun dealers making illegal sales.

title: Lottery Numbers
In South Carolina, Race Seen Through Economic Lens
description: ORANGEBURG, S.C.  Officially, the state of South Carolina calls the fancy new building the Orangeburg Workforce Center. Around here, people know it as the unemployment office. And everyone in Orangeburg County, it seems, can tell you how to get there.

title: Inspired by Remark, Weir Has Slim Lead
description: ST. PAUL  Similar senses of relief enveloped Johnny Weir and Evan Lysacek after their short programs at the United States Figure Skating Championships. Weir put his hand over his heart and made a sign of the cross, although he admits to not being particularly religious. Lysacek, the defending champion, brought his hands to the sides of his head and later said to reporters, Jesus was with me today.

title: Pakistani Official Dismisses Concerns Over Nuclear Security
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  A top Pakistani official dismissed on Saturday concerns over the safety and security of the countrys nuclear program but said there was increased security alertness around its nuclear weapons and facilities given the recent political turmoil and militant violence in the country.

title: Too Much Jersey Rock
description: The first Vineland Festival, to have been held southeast of Philadelphia in Vineland, N.J., has been postponed because of competition from the newly announced All Points West at Liberty State Park in Jersey City. Due to the overall festival traffic in the Northeast and big bands touring through this area at the same time, co-producers Festival Republic and C3 Presents have decided to step back and launch Vineland in 2009, organizers said in a statement. Vineland had been scheduled for Aug. 8-10, the same dates as All Points West, which is being organized by the promoters behind the Coachella Music Festival in Southern California.

title: For Police Fix-It Man, a Scandal to Work On
description: Police officers sum up different bosses in different ways.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart with the continuation of a front-page article on Wednesday about high mercury levels found in tuna sushi in New York stores and restaurants referred imprecisely to what the Environmental Protection Agency deems to be an acceptable level of mercury consumption over a period of several months by an adult of average weight. The agency uses the phrase reference dose to refer to the daily level of mercury consumption it considers acceptable for a long-term diet; it does not use the phrase weekly reference dose. (To find the acceptable weekly level of consumption over the long term, the reference dose is multiplied by seven.)

title:
Where the Ice Bowl
Meets the Ice
description: OSHKOSH, Wis.  The home of the Otter Street Fishing Club is Jerrys Bar, family owned since 1911, nestled in a neighborhood a few blocks from frozen Lake Winnebago.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $6,938,431

title: Networks Ponder Poststrike Landscape
description: Scripts have been junked, pilots have been canceled, deals with writers have been wiped off the books, and almost no one in the television industry has been able to make any plans during the past three months.

title: Actors Body Is Leaving New York for Burial in Australia
description: The body of the Australian-born actor Heath Ledger was taken from a Manhattan funeral home on Friday, and police officers who had been assigned to the funeral home said the body would be flown to Australia for burial.

title: A Battle of Mind Over Mishaps
description: ASPEN, Colo.  In the moments before a snowboardcross race, Peter Foley, the United States snowboard coach, has found that sometimes the best way to help Lindsey Jacobellis is to distract her.

title: Violence Continues in Kenya a Day After Talks
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The political bickering continued in Kenya on Friday, and so did the violence, with young men in gangs from opposing ethnic groups killing one another in the streets with machetes and bows and arrows.

title: Texas: Ex-Chief of Norris Charity Pleads Guilty
description: The former chief executive of Chuck Norriss martial arts program for inner-city children has pleaded guilty to stealing from the Houston charity, the United States attorneys office said. The executive, James D. Brasher, 47, pleaded guilty on Thursday to one count of uttering a forged security, the office said in a statement. Mr. Brasher confessed to opening bank accounts in names similar to that of Mr. Norriss Kick Drugs Out of America Foundation, then fraudulently endorsing checks sent to the foundation and depositing them into his own accounts, the office said. Mr. Brasher is scheduled to be sentenced in April.

title: A Novice Filmmaker Profiles a Lonely Man of Faith
description: When the mail arrived one day in the late summer of 2004, Rabbi Jacob J. Schacter found a large envelope bearing the return address of one Ethan Isenberg. Rabbi Schacter vaguely remembered a young man by that name from his former synagogue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a young man who was working as a computer programmer.

title: Obama Wins South Carolina Primary
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Senator Barack Obama won a commanding victory over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the South Carolina Democratic primary on Saturday, forging a coalition of support among black and white voters in a contest that sets the stage for a state-by-state fight for the partys presidential nomination.

title: Respond to Todays Column: Heeeres Rudy
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Jan. 26 column.

title: CNBC Video: Rice on the State of Private Equity
description: Should private equity be worried about the slowing of the markets? Joseph Rice, of the buyout firm Clayton Dubilier and Rice, doesnt seem to think so.

title: Super Bowl Kin
description: Justin Tuck and Adalius Thomas, cousins, will face each other in the Super Bowl.

title: A Progress Report on One Laptop Per Child
