Rosewood Hotels & Resorts newest property is the Rosewood Mayakob, which has 128 suites  16 of them beachfront  and which includes lagoons, mangrove forests and, of course, sandy beaches. Amenities include plunge pools in all rooms, 40 butlers, an 18-hole Greg Norman golf course and a tequila library. The spa, scheduled to open in March, is built around a cenote. Through April 30, guests who stay for a minimum of three nights will get $100 off the normal nightly rate on any room (rates begin at $695), plus breakfast for two, which is not usually included; www.rosewoodmayakoba.com.

title: Loan Reviewer Aiding Inquiry Into Big Banks
description: A company that analyzed the quality of thousands of home loans for investment banks has agreed to provide evidence to New York state prosecutors that the banks had detailed information about the risks posed by ill-fated subprime mortgages.

title: Letters
description: Conservation on the Farm

title: Correction: When a Mountaintop Might as Well Have Been the Moon
description: An article on Jan. 13 about the conquest of Mount Everest by Sir Edmund Hillary, who died Jan. 11, and the explorations of space that followed it rendered incorrectly the initial report of trouble aboard the lunar mission Apollo 13. In a recording made available by NASAs Johnson Space Center, the astronaut John Swigert Jr. alerts mission headquarters to the explosion in the rear of the spacecraft with the words, O.K., Houston, weve had a problem here, not Houston, weve got a problem. (About 15 seconds later, after Houston asked for the message to be repeated, another astronaut, the mission commander, James Lovell, confirms: Uh, Houston, weve had a problem.)

title: Phone Call Into History
description: IT took a president to get it done.

title: In Sickness and in Health, and in Overtime
description: My wife and I had accepted an invitation to a wedding in Philadelphia last Sunday. Who would plan to marry on the day of the N.F.L.s conference championship games? In fairness, who could have expected the Giants to be playing for the National Football Conference title?

title: Towns Use Zoning to Limit Sex Businesses
description: CARLSTADT

title: Revisiting the Past in Vincents Book
description: Before Frank Robinson became baseballs first black manager with the Cleveland Indians in 1975, he might have become the first black manager with the Yankees in 1974.

title: Correction: Arguing the Just War in Islam
description: A review on Jan. 6 about Arguing the Just War in Islam, by John Kelsay, misstated the circumstances of the burial of the Islamic worlds only Nobel laureate in science, Abdus Salam, who belonged to a banned sect. He was buried in his home country, Pakistan, with full religious rites, but the authorities later erased the word Muslim from his headstone. It is not the case that to this day he cannot be buried with proper religious rites in Pakistan.

title: Stories That Speak for Themselves
description: TODAY and for the past two Sundays, The Times has devoted front-page play and pages of inside space to a continuing investigative series called War Torn, about veterans of Iraq or Afghanistan who have killed or been charged with killings after returning home.

title: Students Wage War on a Disease
description: HUNTINGTON

title: Ex-Mayor Resurfaces as a Corzine Antagonist
description: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE

title: Carnaval on a Smaller Stage
description: CARNAVAL starts Friday in Brazil, so you can bet that tourists have already started to flood into Rio de Janeiro, Salvador and Recife, Brazils three most famous headquarters for pre-Lenten hedonism.

title: Farewell to a Pub, and Maybe to an Era
description: GARRISON, N.Y.

title: The Unthinkable, Right Around the Corner
description: THE first time I saw it happen, in 2004, I was walking down 14th Street along Union Square on my way home, wondering what we were going to have for dinner that night. A dozen police cars came squealing around the corner, pulled up to the sidewalk, and parked with their back wheels on the curb.

title: Toll Discounts for Going Green
description: CAR companies advertise how hybrid cars get great mileage. They could also add tolls to the list of savings.

title: Sex in the City
description: As an art dealer, Ive always liked to be involved in big productions, says the curator and gallerist Emi Fontana. Im not particularly good at selling small things that end up in the living room. Fontanas current big production, Women in the City, which goes up Feb. 9, is the debut of West of Rome, her newly founded nonprofit arts organization based in Los Angeles.

title: Long Island Sound Proposal Awaits Crucial Ruling
description: FEDERAL approval for the liquefied natural gas plant that Broadwater Energy has proposed for Long Island Sound got closer this month when the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission staff concluded that the project, with 86 recommended changes, would have limited environmental impact.

title: Correction: Condoleezza Rice
description: A subheading last Sunday with a review about Condoleezza Rice: An American Life misspelled the authors given name. As noted in the review, she is Elisabeth Bumiller, not Elizabeth.

title: Garage Sale, Fourth Floor
description: Garage Sale, Fourth Floor

title: Nature Has Protectors Here
description: The Living In article last Sunday about Mahopac, Putnam County, misidentified the Metro-North Railroad line that serves nearby Croton Falls. It is the Harlem Line, not the Hudson Line.

title: Sandra Zucker and Joshua Bennett
description: Sandra Hope Zucker, the daughter of Lee R. Zucker and Gary A. Zucker of East Meadow, N.Y., is to be married on Sunday afternoon to Joshua Michael Bennett, a son of Sandra R. Bennett and Leslie R. Bennett of Merrick, N.Y. Rabbi Bruce Goldwasser is to officiate at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Surge in Early Balloting Shifts Florida Races
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  A surge of early voting by Florida Democrats and Republicans has startled officials here and injected additional complexity into the states presidential primaries on Tuesday.

title: Plan for Childrens Museum at Historic Site Faces Delay
description: UNTIL the Westchester Childrens Museum raises $7 million, plans for it to occupy a historic bathhouse complex at Playland Amusement Park in Rye are delayed, county officials said.

title: Kennedy Plans to Back Obama Over Clinton
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Senator Edward M. Kennedy intends to endorse the presidential candidacy of Senator Barack Obama during a rally on Monday in Washington, associates to both men confirmed, a decision that squarely pits one American political dynasty against another.

title: Cleveland Is Rocking
description: Cleveland Is Rocking

title: The Lemur
description: The Lemur: Chapter 3: The Bite

title: Was Huntington Right?
description: Was Huntington Right?

title: Norris Post, Charles Daniels
description: Lula Norris Post was married Saturday to Charles Page Daniels at St. James Church in New York. The Rev. Martha Metzler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 26 of Arts & Leisure today about the conductor Vladimir Jurowski misstated one date that he will lead the Russian National Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. In addition to a performance on Feb. 24, the orchestra will appear with Mr. Jurowski on Feb. 23, not Feb. 25.

title: Laura Brown and Brian Vogt
description: IN Laura Anne Browns experience, few men are brave enough to call a date a date. Guys would invite her to a movie, for coffee or to dinner, but rarely would they identify it by that word, loaded as it is with potential for joy or pain.

title: The Age of Ambition
description: DAVOS, Switzerland

title: A Little Suspense Travels a Long Way
description: ANIMAL, vegetable or mineral? Bigger than a breadbox? Useful or decorative?

title: Another Elmer Gantry
description: To the Editor:

title: Identified Flying Objects Over Phoenix
description: PHOENIX  IT may be too late now, but if you moved quickly the other day you could have booked a three-night stay over Super Bowl weekend at the Ramada Limited Airport North in Phoenix for a cool $2,382.78.

title: Dont Dismiss the Psychology of the Tax Refund
description: Withholding taxes from paychecks is far from an exact science. If it were exact, refund statistics from the I.R.S. would look a lot different. About three-quarters of the tax returns that the I.R.S. processed last year resulted in refunds. The average refund was more than $2,300.

title: Green Buildings Dont Have to Be New
description: JUST about every month, a glitzy tower rises somewhere in the country, boasting the latest in green design and technology. To many people, that is an encouraging trend, especially when considering that commercial buildings account for more than 60 percent of the nations electricity consumption, according to government estimates, and generate 30 percent of all greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Bushs 2002 State of the Union Volunteerism Initiative Is Seen as Sputtering
description: WASHINGTON  In the annals of State of the Union addresses, 2002 will be remembered as the year President Bush warned of an axis of evil, arming to threaten the peace of the world. But 2002 was also the year Mr. Bush offered a grand domestic vision: to create a new culture of responsibility in America.

title: A Little Cybermagic Builds the Unbuilt
description: ILL admit it. Looking at floor plans and trying to visualize walking through a space, figuring out how big the bathroom is and if my dining table will actually fit into the living room alcove, is not my strong suit.

title: G.O.P. Move to Change State Ballots Stirs Debate
description: A legal fight could be looming over an effort by the states Republican Party to drop three candidates from the ballot for the Feb. 5 presidential primary. Critics, including some party insiders, contend that the move is intended to give the state partys favored candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani, better name display at the polls, a charge the Republicans deny.

title: Fondue Redux (circa 1960s)
description: Those who doubt that history repeats itself may notice that at least one hallmark of the 1960s has been revived in White Plains. The Melting Pot  one in a national franchise of more than 150 fondue restaurants  hasnt forgotten the ritual involving long forks, mounds of raw ingredients and a communal cooking pot of bubbling liquid. Order the four-course Big Night Out, as most do, and make a sociable evening of it.

title: A Baptist Coalition Aims for Moderate Image
description: For more than 150 years, Baptists in the United States have splintered along political, theological and racial lines. But this week, some of the countrys largest Baptist groups  representing about 20 million believers  will meet to try to mend the old fractures and, some leaders say, present a more diverse and moderate image of their faith than the one offered by the conservative Southern Baptist Convention.

title: How Its Couched
description: Whether we cast a suspicious eye on the whole enterprise or have taken the plunge ourselves (perhaps even as we continue to feel suspicious), weve all wondered: What goes on behind the closed doors of psychotherapy? Is it a crucial and unique relationship that contains within it the kernel of personal transformation? Or is it a form of self-indulgence, a way of forcing someone to listen  if only because youve paid him or her  as you repetitively pour out the emotional subtext of your life?

title: On the Couch on a Hollywood Soundstage
description: ASIDE from its being a half-hour long, you wouldnt think HBOs new therapy-session series, In Treatment, had anything in common with the channels hit comedy about wild boys in Hollywood, Entourage. They do, however, share an executive producer, Stephen Levinson, who said he thinks that there is an intersection between them: Each presents a glimpse into a world that feels eerily accurate.

title: A Fallen Marines Father Waging a Righteous Battle
description: Winslow

title: Loch, 18, Claims Gold
description: Felix Loch of Germany became the youngest mens luge world champion on Saturday. Loch, 18, a two-time junior world champion, finished the first run in 44.996 seconds and won gold in 1:30.643 in Oberhoff, Germany. In a German sweep, David Mller was second (1:30.717), followed by Andi Langenhan (1:30.814).

title: Can Darwins Lab Survive Success?
description: FOR anyone touring the Galpagos Islands, it is hard to imagine the globes first World Heritage Site is at risk. The marine reserve is populated with sea turtles and humpback whales, and the national parks trails are inhabited by herons and albatrosses.

title: How Are the Bees of Winter? Doing Fine, Sticking Together
description: WESTON

title: French Bank Offers Details of Big Loss
description: PARIS  The French bank Socit Gnrale, facing persistent questions over how one junior trader could have caused more than $7 billion in losses, acknowledged Sunday that his activities prompted questions from risk managers several times last year, but that the bank never began a wider investigation because his explanations defused any suspicions.

title: Minorities for Money?
description: I teach at a state university that offers financial incentives to hire minority candidates. A department receives $1,000 for completing a tenure-track hire but $5,000 if it hires a minority candidate. Im concerned that colleagues will make recommendations based on the financial reward rather than pursue the best candidate. Should the institution offer these bounties?  DR. MARK E. CHASE, SLIPPERY ROCK, PA.

title: Plan to Close Prisons Stirs Anxiety in Rural Towns
description: GABRIELS, N.Y.  After 17 years of marriage, Joy and Richard Gonyea managed to save enough to trade their trailer in November for a cozy prefabricated home with a room for each of their two children and a pool in the backyard. The home overlooks the pine trees on the edge of their two-acre property in rural Vermontville, eight miles from the secluded state prison where Mrs. Gonyea works.

title: Letters: Bad (and Good) Airports
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Journeys column "Europe's Worst Airports: Congestion and Other Terminal Illnesses (Jan. 13): Thirty years ago everyone lamented the annoying change of planes at Hartsfield airport in Atlanta. It was said that in order to get to heaven, even God had to change planes in Atlanta. Heathrow, near London, is the new Atlanta.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded $6,938,431

title: Lagat Wins in Scotland
description: Bernard Lagat successfully defended his 1,500 meters title Saturday at the Norwich Union International indoor meet in Glasgow.Lagat, of the United States, finished in 3:45.89 after taking the lead in the final 200. Shadrack Korir of Kenya was second, finishing in 3:46.96.The American pole-vaulter Brad Walker, 26, landed awkwardly after attempting 18 feet 4  inches, the winning height for Alexander Straub of Germany. Walker said he had no broken bones but he could miss Fridays Millrose Games in New York.The British athletes edged the United States by a point to win the meet.

title: Moviegoers in Seoul Will Love This Film
description: LOS ANGELES  AN avid moviegoer, Lindsay Bern takes in a flick at her local multiplex about twice a week. But Ms. Bern, the co-owner of a Los Angeles recording studio, has recently become irritated by what she sees as a disturbing trend on the big screen: the obliteration of New York City.

title: Can Their Wish Be the Markets Command?
description: LONG ago and far away, I was a student of law and of economics at Yale. The economics I found fairly easy, probably because the material was the same as what I heard my two economist-parents discussing around the dinner table all my life. (My parents would literally discuss monetary policy with the meatloaf.)

title: Elmer Gantry: Is It an Opera?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebirth of a Bohemian Barrio
description: THE Boedo section of Buenos Aires was an artistic hotbed in the early 20th century, home to Argentine cultural giants like the writer Roberto Arlt and the tango lyricist Homero Manzi. But it drifted into anonymity after World War II, a low-slung, middle-class neighborhood whose famous soccer stadium was razed and turned into a Carrefour supermarket.

title: For Pamperers of the Pampered, Its Beauty, Interrupted
description: THE situation seemed dire.

title: Life Past the Classroom and After the Orchestra
description: AS a young man, the composer John Corigliano swore that there were two things he would never do: write a symphony and teach composition. He has since learned the folly of speaking in absolutes. By now Mr. Corigliano has written three symphonies, the first two having won prestigious awards. And thanks to a recent Lehman College subway ad campaign, he is perhaps the citys most visible composition teacher. He also teaches at the Juilliard School, and some of his students have gone on to establish major careers.

title: Barclays Host and PGA Tour Reach a Deal
description: SAN DIEGO  Westchester Country Club and the PGA Tour have settled their dispute over the clubs hosting of the Barclays tournament. The Barclays, the first of four events in the PGA Tours playoffs for the FedEx Cup, will move from Westchester, in Harrison, N.Y., to Ridgewood Country Club in Paramus, N.J., for this years event, scheduled for Aug. 18-24.

title: Filipino Nurses, Healers in Trouble
description: THEY are recruited in their homeland with perks like free airfare. Some have been offered thousands of dollars in bonuses to relocate. And in the process, they have become a mainstay of the New York areas hospitals and nursing homes.

title: Cameras Show if Surf Is Good, but Surfers Are Getting in Way
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  Ever since Jimmy Minardi mounted his $8,500 video camera last summer and aimed it at the Atlantic Ocean, the surfers here have been complaining.

title: Mary Kerwin and Nicholas Holmes
description: Mary Alice Kerwin was married on Saturday to Nicholas Stone Holmes. The Rev. Olivia Holmes, a Unitarian Universalist minister and an aunt of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York.

title: The Art of War
description: When German gunners flattened the city of Ypres in World War I, they destroyed, along with thousands of innocent lives, the famous Cloth Hall, a landmark of medieval Flemish architecture. That ruined masterpiece, as Paul Fussell wrote in The Great War and Modern Memory, served as an eloquent emblem of what happens when war collides with art. That same collision is central to Pat Barkers new novel, Life Class, which follows a group of British artists  loosely based on gifted figures like Paul Nash, Christopher Nevinson and Dora Carrington  from the comfortable confines of the Slade School of Fine Art in London to the carnage of the Western Front.

title: Mamaroneck and School Settle Dispute
description: MAMARONECK

title: A Second Wave of Success Is Sweeter for Sharapova
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Beers in hand on the terrace of the players lounge, Michael Joyce and his fellow coach Yuri Sharapov were reveling in their pupil Maria Sharapovas first Australian Open singles title. They were laughing and relaxing, the pressure gone at least for a few days until she lands in Israel to play her first Fed Cup match for Russia.

title: Put the Emergency! Back in the E.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: Datebook
description: VENICE

title: Freed From the Page, but a Book Nonetheless
description: PRINTED books provide pleasures no device created by an electrical engineer can match. The sweet smell of a brand-new book. The tactile pleasures of turning a page. The reassuring sight on ones bookshelves of personal journeys.

title: This Macbeth Goes for the Gore
description: Out, damnd spot! Out, I say! has never had quite this much resonance. Pity the poor crew at the Two River Theater doing the cleanup that surely follows each performance of a new, unrelentingly bloody Macbeth, on stage in Red Bank through Feb. 10. Conceived and directed by Teller, the quieter half of the comedy-magic team Penn and Teller, and Aaron Posner, Two Rivers artistic director, the show oozes, drips and squirts forth a river of crimson horror.

title: With Donated Painting, Aquarium Enters Art World Controversy
description: Mystic

title: Library Walks Fine Line on Web Pornography
description: MAHOPAC

title: King of the Road
description: Id love to take William T. Vollmann out for a beer. Id ask him about his adventures in Afghanistan, Bosnia, Iraq and Congo and at the North Pole. Id buy him a good cigar, tell him that for years Ive been a fan of his journalism, novels and essays. Then, when the moment felt right, Id lean in, look Vollmann square in the eye and say: Pal, what the hells wrong with you?

title: A Final Curtain Call for Valentino
description: Paris

title: Thrashers Kovalchuk Lets His Mature Side Show
description: ATLANTA  In an Atlanta Thrashers game here against Edmonton in 2002, the enraged Oilers were ready to come off their bench after Ilya Kovalchuk, the Thrashers brash rookie wing.

title: Ross of Consequence
description: A new East End producer specializing in ros wines is sending his first vintage to local stores and restaurants at the right moment.

title: So Efficient, L.E.D.s Are Now Fashion Plates, Too
description: IN recent seasons, a new fashion accessory has become a must-have for the debutants of the auto-show circuit. No automaker introduces a new concept car, it seems, before dressing it up with L.E.D. jewelry.

title: Devalued Sonics Seek New Arena or a New City to Call Home
description: SEATTLE  The SuperSonics losing streak reached 11 games last Monday with a loss to the Rockets in Houston, then mechanical problems forced the team plane to land temporarily in Oklahoma City.

title: Deaths Army
description: During the Civil War, my great-great-grandfather, a Presbyterian clergyman, served as chaplain to the 104th New York Infantry Regiment. He was a man of stern moral conviction and in weekly letters to his parishioners back home allowed little to escape his censorious eye. President Lincolns erratic church attendance irritated him. So did mud and heat and the intemperance and profanity that he believed were the great sins of our army, and he was infuriated by the proximity of his quarters to the tents of several of the most blasphemous, immoral persons I ever heard. But in the aftermath of Gettysburg, words failed him. Sad scenes! was all he could write after two days spent officiating at the trench burials of Union and Confederate boys. I have no time, strength nor heart to recall and narrate what I have seen!

title: No Break-Ins, Just Incessant Wailing
description: A FEW months ago, the burglary alarm rang in the middle of the night at Kimtex Fabric Services, a Paterson company that dyes fabric samples.

title: The Isolationist
description: For the first time since Bill Clintons initial term in office, Patrick J. Buchanan seems as if he could plausibly compete for the Republican presidential nomination. In Iowa and elsewhere, an economic populist and Christian conservative has threatened to topple the party establishments preferred nominees. Online, in what is sometimes called the money primary, a foreign policy noninterventionist is breaking fund-raising records. And in the national popularity contest, if those two men (Mike Huckabee and Ron Paul) could have been combined  in a dubious but nonetheless irresistible exercise  to form a single Buchananite candidate, that person would have acquired a front-running 25 percent of the vote in a recent New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: New Listings With Your Decaf?
description: An In the Region article in some copies on Jan. 13 about real estate sales offices that camouflage themselves as other businesses to lure customers referred imprecisely to a service offered at the Real Estate Cafe in Cambridge, Mass., in 1995, before listings were publicly accessible on the Internet. Buyers could peruse listings in the cafe on a computer terminal, not in books.

title: A Dying Breed
description: GERSHOM MUGIRA COMES from a long line of cattle-keepers. His people, the Bahima, are thought to have migrated into the hilly grasslands of western Uganda more than a thousand years ago, alongside a hardy breed of longhorns known as the Ankole. For centuries, man and beast subsisted there in a tight symbiotic embrace. Mugiras nomadic ancestors wandered in search of fresh pasture for their cattle, which in turn provided them with milk. It is only within the last few generations that most Bahima have accepted the concept of private property. Mugiras family lives on a 500-acre ranch, and one sunny day in November, the wiry 26-year-old showed me around, explaining, with some sadness but more pragmatism, why the Ankole breed that sustained his forebears for so many generations is now being driven to extinction.

title: With Cheese You Get Crackers
description: Say Cheese! is not a camera shop, but its display of 80 wedges, rounds and blocks of cheeses, in gleaming glass cases behind the counter, is picture perfect.

title: Shows Survive by Sharing a Stage
description: IF you are thinking of taking in a show at New World Stages, the Off Broadway theater complex on West 50th Street, you had better take a close look at your ticket before you go inside. Going to see Altar Boyz? O.K. That has a typical evening curtain time of 8 p.m. But if youre attending My First Time, the hour is 7 p.m. The family-oriented musical Pinkalicious runs sometimes at noon, sometimes at 2 p.m. As for Naked Boys Singing  well, that could be either 6 p.m. or 10:30 p.m.

title: A Champion Vaulter Has Come a Long Way
description: BOSTON  When Jenn Stuczynski started pole-vaulting, she trained in two primitive Quonset huts in Churchville, N.Y., near Rochester. In her first meet, she cleared 8 feet 6 inches.

title: Katharine Applegarth and Matthew Simons
description: Katharine Davis Applegarth, a daughter of Dr. Linda D. Applegarth and Paul V. Applegarth of Greenwich, Conn., was married on Saturday evening to Dr. Matthew Franklin Simons, the son of Victoria R. Simons and Dr. Robert L. Simons of Key Biscayne, Fla. Robert J. Paolucci, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at St. Mary Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Church Creek, Md., with Cantor Nancy R. Ginsberg taking part.

title: For Rahlves, No Longer Man Against Mountain
description: ASPEN, Colo.  When Daron Rahlves began competing in skiercross last year, he figured to be one of the fastest men in the field as a former World Cup and Olympic racer. But in the newer racing discipline  it resembles motocross on skis  Rahlves was plagued by poor starts and wipeouts in the first five events, and he looked like a rookie with a lot to learn.

title: Sounds That May Remind You of Something, or of Nothing
description: LENNY KRAVITZ is set to release his eighth studio album, It Is Time for a Love Revolution (Virgin), on Feb. 5. With guitar licks of funk, rock and soul, Mr. Kravitz, 43, sings about love, spiritual awakening, abandonment and, in one song that draws a parallel between the wars in Iraq and Vietnam, politics. His albums, he said, are about whats going on in the world and whats going on in my life at the time. Although Mr. Kravitz writes, arranges, sings and produces his albums, he recently managed in his spare time to appear in the coming indie film Push and to work with his design firm to create a piano lounge in the Delano Hotel in Miami. In Los Angeles to rehearse for a tour that will span South America and Canada this spring, Europe over the summer and the United States in the fall, Mr. Kravitz spoke on the phone with Winter Miller about what hes listening to and watching.

title: Armchair Traveler
description: "Taschen Guides to London, Berlin and Paris Hotels" ($29.99 each, paperback); "Restaurants" ($14.99 each, paperback); and "Shopping" ($12.95 each, paperback)

title: Ethnic Violence in Rift Valley Is Tearing Kenya Apart
description: NAKURU, Kenya  Nairobi, the capital of Kenya, may seem calm, but anarchy reigns just two hours away.

title: Instant Nostalgia? Lets Go to the Videotape
description: BE KIND REWIND, Michel Gondrys latest adventure in high-concept whimsy, appears to take place in a parallel universe without Netflix, TiVo or iTunes. When the entire VHS inventory of an old-school video store is demagnetized, the clerks respond to the disaster not by upgrading to DVD, but by enlisting the customers to remake the films with a VHS camcorder. Not far beneath the slapstick humor and communitarian spirit of Mr. Gondrys movie (which had its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival last week and is set to open Feb. 22) lies a strong nostalgia for a technology that revolutionized home viewing but now seems destined for the dustbin of history.

title: Red Sox-Yankees Rivalry Wears Suits
description: Wayne, N.J.

title: Rangers Are Set to Open in Prague
description: ATLANTA  The N.H.L. said Saturday that it had chosen the Rangers and three other teams to serve as ambassadors in Europe, but the players union is not so sure.

title: As Seen on TV
description: WHEN I was 10, in the late 1960s, I started to notice mail-order ads in magazines and became intrigued by the Popeil Pocket Fisherman ad I saw on TV. I loved gadgets and begged my mother to get me one, even though I didnt fish.

title: When Icons Die Young
description: A YOUNG man lying in bed seems at peace. You might recognize him, or not, as he is not in a familiar role. He is supposed to wake up but he never does, causing a surge of public sadness.

title: Patrice Battey and Andrew Simon
description: Patrice Isabelle Battey was married on Saturday afternoon to Andrew James Simon at Riverside Church in Manhattan.

title: Perestroika for Connecticut
description: Contract scandals, F.B.I. investigations and flooded highways dont generally have a brighter side, but in Connecticut, they just may.

title: A Campus Serves as a Needed Oasis in a Crowded City
description: ALTHOUGH the last thing students or parents on vacation want to think about is school, indulging in higher-education tourism in Mexico City can be a refreshingly unacademic experience. Especially when the university you are talking about is a city unto itself.

title: Suharto, 1921-2008
description: Suharto of Indonesia, whose 32-year dictatorship ended in 1998 when he was driven from office by widespread rioting, economic paralysis and political chaos, has died.

title: Introducing Ski Cross
description: In Ski cross, a new Olympic event for 2010, six skiers compete head to head against bumps, turns, the clock and each other.

title: Democratic Primary Night in South Carolina
description: Senator Barack Obama celebrated his victory while his two main rivals looked forward to the Feb. 5 contests.

title: Water, River and Sundance
description: Sundance handed out some frozen bon-bons to end the festival, including the Grand Jury Prize in documentary to Trouble the Water with the dramatic nod going to Frozen River. It was a big week for the Trouble the Water, the remarkable documentary directed by Tia Lessen and Carl Deal that traced the human and natural consequences of Hurricane Katrina. An audience favorite, the premier included a remarkable appearance by a very pregnant Kimberly Roberts, the subject of the documentary who used a vid cam to chronicle her trip through the hurricane and its aftermath. The day after last Sundays premier, Monday, she gave birth to Skyy Kaylen Rivers Roberts, born a survivor and now a winner by proxy. Frozen River charted the relationship of a trailer mom and a Mohawk Indian girl as they teamed up to smuggle illegals from the Canada to the United States. For a full list of all the laurels, check right here.

title: Water, River and Sundance
description: Kim Rivers and Scott Roberts in a scene from "Trouble The Water," the documentary that won the Grand Jury Prize at the 2008 Sundance Film Festival. Sundance handed out some frozen bon-bons to end the festival, including the Grand Jury Prize in documentary to "Trouble the Water" with the dramatic nod going to "Frozen River." It was a big week for the "Trouble the Water," the remarkable documentary directed by Tia Lessen and Carl Deal that traced the human and natural consequences of Hurricane Katrina. An audience favorite, the premier included a remarkable appearance by a very pregnant Kimberly Roberts, the subject of the documentary who used a vid cam to chronicle her trip through the hurricane and it's aftermath. The day after last Sunday's premier, Monday, she gave birth to Skyy Kaylen Rivers Roberts, born a survivor and now a winner by proxy. "Frozen River" charted the relationship of a trailer mom and a Mohawk Indian girl as they teamed up to smuggle illegals from the Canada to the United States. For a full list of all the laurels, check right here.

title: DGA: No Country? No Kidding.
description: The directors guild announced late last night that Joel and Ethan Coen won its award for best feature film.  Will the Coens and No Country for Old Men add another bit of hardware tonight for best ensemble and walk away with that steely bunned Actor statue given away by the Screen Actors Guild?

title: List of Screen Actors Guild Award Nominees and Winners
description: Motion picture and television nominees and winners for the 14th Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards.

title: Keeping Up Appearances
description: Britains government has begun a national debate about what it actually means to be British, so The Times of London asked its readers to come up with a national motto. Among the entries:

title: The Week Ahead: Jan. 27-Feb. 2
description: Film

title: Tightening the Alligator Belt
description: Boy, its really getting rough out there for some Manhattanites:

title: Welcome to the Jungle
description: You skip rock memoirs at your own peril. Youll miss out on pearls of wisdom like this: Thats a wonderful side effect of leather pants, writes the guitarist Slash. When you urinate in them, theyre more forgiving than jeans. Read our review.

title: A Golden Age
description: March 1971

title: This Republic of Suffering
description: The work of death

title: Life Class
description: They'd been drawing for over half an hour. There was no sound except for the slurring of pencils on Michelet paper or the barely perceptible squeak of charcoal. At the center of the circle of students, close to the dais, a stove cast a barred red light onto the floor. The smell of burning coke mingled with other smells: sweat, hot cloth, cigar and tobacco smoke. Now and again you could hear the soft pop of lips inhaling and another plume of blue smoke would rise to join the pall that hung over the whole room.

title: A Gym Becomes a Hit
description: Upper East Side residents are slowly discovering what is going on at a gym beneath Madison Avenue.

title: Fans Journal: In Ghana, Everyone Is an Expert
description: It seems as if everyone here in Ghana is a soccer expert  and no one is shy to share his opinions about the Black Stars chances in the African Cup of Nations with a visitor.

title: Djokovic Wins His First Grand Slam
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was early, very early, in the first set of this year's Australian Open final when an Australian voice yelled out from high in Rod Laver Arena: "Let's go Roger!"

title: Clinton to Stop in Fla. on Primary Night
description: On CBSs Face the Nation this morning, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton confirmed that she would be in Florida on Tuesday night for the results in that states primary.

title: SAG Awards: Stars in the Flesh. Pot.
description: Seeing as he will be covering the SAG awards from his New Jersey basement, the Bagger could act like the annual ego-fest is a sideshow, but this year, it is the show, at least so far. In Hollywood, you need pomp for a little circumstance and the SAG awards have plenty: Real actual stars in full plumage in their natural habitat, which on a red carpet hunted at every turn by cameras. The fluff, the froth, the whole actors choosing actors conceit? Mad, jolly fun in a town that could use a little. In each of the last two years, the Bagger has ended up at the People party afterwards and it is a doozey. Last year, he spent part of the evening with the Little Miss Sunshine contingent. The directors, Valerie Faris and Jonathan Dayton, were having the time of their lives, partly because they won ensemble and partly because they were as surprised and happy as anyone else. Who will be doing the hugging and thanking and crying tonight? Will it be Juno that will hop in the LMS van and ride to glory or will the Coens continue their roll, which picked up a bit more heat last night from the DGA? Picks later. (Sasha Stone points out that a bit of a cloud hanging over the SAG Awards, but there still be plenty of wattage under the canopy.)

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, Jan. 27:

title: McCain Touts His New Backers
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  It felt like a replay this morning on NBCs Meet the Press with Senator John McCain. Many of the questions posed to him were similar to those hed faced during the Thursday night G.O.P. debate in Boca Raton. He defended his positions on the Bush tax cuts and basically declared dead his legislative effort that called for comprehensive immigration reform and failed in the Senate last year.

title: Kennedy to Endorse Obama
description: MACON, Ga.  Senator Edward M. Kennedy intends to endorse the presidential candidacy of Senator Barack Obama during a rally on Monday in Washington.

title: SAG Wisdom?
description: The Bagger consulted with his gorgeous but incredibly stupid blond lab Charlie a series of historical analytics and is ready to take the plunge for this evening.

title: John McCain on Mitt Romney and Iraq
description: A day after being criticized for saying that Governor Mitt Romney had favored timetables for withdrawl from Iraq, Senator John McCain stood by his remarks at a press conference in Polk City, Florida.

title: Why has the Bush economy been so lousy? (part I)
description: OK, Im trying to figure something out. One question we wont get answered in tomorrows State of the Union is why economic performance since 2001 has been a pale shadow of Clinton-era prosperity. In fact, its a question nobody in political life wants to answer. The administration and its supporters wont admit that performance has been lousy; critics are happy simply to point out how bad things have been, and blame Bush.

title: Romney Goes Casual
description: SWEETWATER, Fla.A buzz went through the press corps when Mitt Romney showed up at a Cuban-American community center here on the outskirts of Miami this morning.

title: Local Obama Backers, Eyes Turned South
description: To an even greater extent than Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons, Senator Barack Obamas campaign effort in New York appears to be relying in large part on a profusion of small gatherings, like dinner parties and meet-ups at local bars. The Obama campaigns Web site called on Saturday for supporters to gather at Mintons Playhouse, a well-known restaurant and nightclub at 208 West 118th Street, near Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard in Harlem, to watch as the results from the South Carolina Democratic primary were captured on television. Rob Bennett, a photographer for The Times, captured these images in the moments during and after Mr. Obamas victory speech.

title: For Some Harlem Voters, Clintons Experience Is Key
description: A day after Barack Obamas decisive victory in South Carolina, propelled by overwhelming support among black voters, it remained an open question whether Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton would be able to hold on to her African-American base in New York.

title: At City Hall, a Rousing Rally for Obama
description: Senator Barack Obama was nowhere in sight, but the more than 300 people who gathered on the steps of City Hall in Lower Manhattan on a chilly Sunday afternoon were clearly as energized as if the Illinois senator had been there in person.

title: Spreading economic misinformation
description: Mark Thoma and Brad DeLong are right: this is a crime by the Washington Post against its readers.

title: Of Glamour and Gravitas
description: Tonight, you will likely hear some brave political speeches from the Screen Actors Guild membership, wagging a finger about the writers right to participate in the fruits of their labors, but a little historical perspective might have you reaching for the shaker of salt. This is the bunch, after all, that chose Ronald Reagan as its president. And Patty Duke. And Ed Asner. Notice a trend here? The Bagger doesnt either. The only flag the Screen Actors Guild flies with any consistency is one with a finger to the wind on it. Harsh? Well, in 1953, the Screen Actors Guild decided to take a rigorous stand on blacklisting: Some 96 percent of their members voted in favor of making members sign a loyalty oath. They said they were sorry, oh, 50 years later. This glittering assembly of human jewelry, a delight to behold on screen and on the carpet, has all of the subtlety and not much of the homework of Michael Moore, who is fond of dishing out the brussel sprouts when it comes to making acceptance speeches.

title: Red Carpet Real Estate
description: The Gold Rush blog at the Hollywood Reporter has noted that demand for inane, stand-up Q&As is up. Because of the glitter outage at the Golden Globes, press officials at the Screen Actors Guild have lengthened the red carpet at the Shrine Auditorium by 20 feet to accommodate all of the banal questions that were left over from events that had to without, thanks to threats of picketing by the striking Writers Guild of America.

title: Senators Lieberman, Martinez Stump With McCain
description: THE VILLAGES, Fla.  The town hall meeting here, at the Savannah Center, was jammed to the rafters. People were standing around every single wall and streaming outside the door.

title: Free at Last
description: Turns out everybody has used the strike to, yes, spend more time with their family. Talking with E! on the red carpet, Tina Fey of 30 Rock said she had spent a lot of quality time with her daughter. But not that she minded going to the SAG awards.

title: Giuliani Hangs Loose
description: COCOA BEACH  After a low-energy day or two, he seemed amped. Perhaps even stoked. And, despite some gnarly polls, not remotely concerned about a wipe-out.

title: Bourne Lucky
description: The Bourne Ultimatum picked up the chit for best film stunt team in an announcement that preceded the show. 24 won for television stunt dudes and dudettes. This is the first time the SAG Awards has given out award for the people who nearly kill themselves, or at least look like they do, to get movies and television made. The Bagger is one for one on his picks, a nice trend that.

title: Clintons Kennedy Backers
description: News of Kennedy support for Senator Barack Obama has prompted the campaign of Senator Hillary Clinton to issue a reminder that it has support from Kennedys too.

title: Belly Up
description: Ellen Page, the 20-year-old star of Juno, did not know whose shoes she was wearing, bringing shame and umbrage from the red carpet crew at E!

title: GUM: A Piece of Soviet History, Turned Mall
description: My first visit to GUM, the shopping arcade on Red Square just opposite Lenins Mausoleum, was hardly auspicious. It was 1988 and I was in the Soviet Union with my mother and sister. It was sweltering and we desperately wanted a drink. Sounds easy enough, especially since we spoke fluent Russian.

title: Striking. A. Pose.
description: What is the appropriate mien for a potential winner at the SAG awards? A Nikki Blonsky freak-out would not seem to be appropriate given the fact that so many people are out of work, but then to go completely bummer and serious would seem not in keeping with the frothy spirit of the occasion. This being Hollywood, trust that someone will get both the mood and the zeitgeist completely wrong and clank one off the rim. Probably a TV person  the movie folks are much more carefully managed.

title: What It All Means  and Doesnt
description: In a year when all five Oscar nominees for best picture would seem to have a shot  and the muted Golden Globes did little to clarify the picture  the Screen Actors Guild awards would seem to have a huge role to play. But theres just one small unhelpful fact: Only one of this years nominees for the best picture Oscars is in the running for the SAG ensemble award, which is how the actors settle on a best picture. 3:10 to Yuma, Hairspray, American Gangster, and Into the Wild did not make it to the dance for the Big 5. Only No Country for Old Men garnered nominations from both the Screen Actors and the Academy.

title: Whacked, but Still Winning
description: Early on in what Steve Carrell called the most glamorous and exciting evening in the history of the world, it was New Jersey proud early on at the SAG Awards. James Gandolfini and Edie Falco won male and female outstanding perfomance for their work in the final season of The Sopranos, and the entire cast won for outstanding performance by an ensemble.

title: Stone Cold Killer
description: Javier Bardem, who won outstanding performance for a male actor in a supporting role, is so stone-cold handsome, he could just stand there mute at the microphone and people would adore him. But he came through with a classy speech on top of it all, making a sincere acknowledgement of his co-nominees  Casey Affleck, Hal Holbrook, Tommy Lee Jones and Tom Wilkinson  whose performances will stay with us forever. He also thanked his directors, the Coen brothers, for a very specific favor: ignoring the takes where I really sucked.

title: Panama Controversy
description: One of the pioneer foreign developers in Panama is embroiled in a six-year legal controversy, which is heading to the countrys Supreme Court.

title: Watching the Party End for Gazans in Egypt
description: Life in the Egyptian towns of Rafah and El Arish has been unusual since Wednesday, when thousands of Gazans streamed through breaks in the border wall. To get a feel for the situation on the ground, The Lede asked Nadim Audi, who has been contributing to The New York Timess coverage, to write about what he saw over the weekend.

title: Tasteful Tastemakers
description: The SAG Awards has been known to host its share of rhetorical excess in the past, but the discourse from the podium was remarkably chaste, with both James Gandolfini and Edie Falco, best actor and actress in a dramatic series respectively, giving very short speeches long on thank yous. Tina Fey, who won for her role as Liz Lemon in 30 Rock, compared her acting skills to a hat rack and was the first speaker of the night to address a strike that was very much on the mind of the audience of the event. She kept it short.

title: Confessions of a Ninny
description: Would it be untoward for the Bagger to admit that he is happy to see famous people back at the microphone saying that its about the work. No surprise there, but there is something in the ritual of it, the kabuki of a rotating cast saying the same things over and over. One clanky note though: The SAGs self-congratulatory infomercials, about the unions fight for racial tolerance, safety and worker dignity. All nice stuff, but as long as they are doing a historical tick-tock, they might want to mention that when the pall of a black-list hug over America, the union capitulated, throwing may of their colleagues under a bus.

title: Back Office
description: T. L. Stanley is locked back in the press room where the Bagger would be if he were not on the wrong coast. But reading the Gold Rush blog is almost like being there. Better in fact.

title: Relying On The Gut Of The Programmer
description: What will television look like when the strike ends, and how is the next season going to be changed? Beyond the conviction that some scripted television series will be replaced by reality shows, network and production studio executives are expressing hope that one outcome of the strike will be a different, and much cheaper, process for getting scripted shows on the air, Bill Carter reported in Saturdays New York Times.

title: Tone Poem
description: The SAG Awards, historically a B-List event populated by A-List actors, did a good job of filling in the glamour gap without being unseemly. The speeches have been short and tasteful, the strike and the effect it has had on working people in the industry was present, but did not overwhelm. Broadcast on TBS and TNT, the SAG awards will not provide the kind of marketing firepower that the Globes might have, had they not been downsized by the threat of pickets. The industry is in a middle place, with uncertainty abounding and no clear path to settlement at the negotiating table. So far, the SAG Awards have reflected the mood without seeming downright moody.

title: Rock of Ages
description: Many people, prior to the show, reminded us that the SAG Awards tend to recognize a large body of work over many years, and so they have, giving Ruby Dee her first SAG award for her supporting role in American Gangster. The Bagger chose Amy Ryan for this category, and something tells him his Ellen Page pick in best actress aint looking so great right now. Right now, hes 2-3.

title: Beyond the Fringe
description: The South Carolina primary results were so amazing that it took me a while to notice that while a record-breaking number of voters were racing to the polls to take part in the historic Clinton-Obama-Edwards showdown, 240 Democratic voters had cast their ballots for Mike Gravel.

title: Aiming Point
description: In the least surprising win of the night, Daniel Day-Lewis was named the best leading actor in a dramatic role. He was halting, smashing and affecting in receiving the award. Instead of merely saying he was humbled, he clearly demonstrated it. It has always been the work of my fellow actors, including my fellow nominees, who have given me a sense of regeneration.

title: March of the Barbies!
description: The red carpet at the SAG Awards tonight looked surprisingly scripted, even by red carpet standards. Did the stylists and publicists get together and decide that (nearly) every actress should go strapless? Maybe my tube was small, maybe there were too many people and pets crowding in my kitchen on this Sunday night, but the view was predominantly of bare shoulders and bobbing bouffant heads. Oh, and a little slash of fabric representing the bodice & cleavage of a dress. The camera angles could be lascivious. In the strapless contingent were Cate Blanchett, Kate Beckinsale, Vanessa Williams, Angelina Jolie, Michelle Pfeiffer, Sandra Oh, and Teri Hatcher. Though I couldnt see all of her dress, Ellen Paige looked smart, I thought, in a black Zac Posen dress with a v-neck and short kimono sleeves, especially with her smooth hair. Debra Messings gold Oscar de la Renta dress at least had some kind of interesting neckline on an evening of what amounted to table-top dressing.

title: A Knockout
description: Julie Christie took the stage to accept her award for outstanding actress in a leading role, as an Alzheimers patient in Away From Her, and reminded anybody who was in the room or tuning in that beauty sometimes matches and endures along with talent. She said that her win and the movie were a reminder of how important unions are. She went into a long tick-tock of thank yous, most effusively the films director, Sarah Polley, but then added, If I have forgotten anybody, its just because I am in character.

title: Sticking It to The Man, Whoever That Is
description: Josh Brolin has had a big year, what with his turns in both No Country for Old Men and American Gangster. On screen, he frequently seems as if he might explode, sending human shrapnel in all direction. On stage? About the same. He was langorously making his way through thank yous when Woody Harrelson came over his shoulder to remind him to thank the Coen brothers; Brolin told him to back off.

title: Beyond the Fringe
description: The South Carolina primary results were so amazing that it took me a while to notice that while a record-breaking number of voters were racing to the polls to take part in the historic Clinton-Obama-Edwards showdown, 240 Democratic voters had cast their ballots for Mike Gravel.

title: Tall Money
description: Rugrats by the handles of Warrior Ant and Christopher nailed four out of five in the SAG Awards  missing only Ruby Dee, earning them much respect and one dollar a piece. Congrats boys and girls, or animal and vegetable, or whatever you are behind the commenting avatars. Nicely done. The Bagger got four out of six, because he picked stunt too, but take that away and he was three out of five, sort of miserable, actually. He went with the youth brigade  Any Ryan and Ellen Page  while it was experience and guile  Ruby Dee and Julie Christie  that took home The Actor statue. Nice tidy night, good balance of glam and gravitas. And how bout that Josh Brolin? Well have what hes having, some kind of substance that makes you see the world as your own little plaything. This is my fricking moment. Hope it was fricking swell and thanks for, um, sharing, Josh.

title: Does Constitutional Theory Matter?
description: While we are still in the primary season, the quarrels candidates have are largely intramural. Republicans argue about who is tougher on immigration and who will cut more taxes. Democrats argue about who will get us out of Iraq quicker and whose health plans covers the most people. But once the nominations are settled, the focus will shift to the differences between the two parties, and issues that have been on the back burner for a while will come front and center.

title: Stars Come Out at the Annual Writers Dinner
description: I just got back from the 85th annual dinner of the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America. There were three-plus hours of baseball talk and not a single mention of steroids or salaries. Hallelujah!

title: Hedge Funds Letter Explains Intentions Regarding The Times
description: One of two hedge funds seeking to name directors at The New York Times Company sought on Sunday to clarify its intentions for the newspaper publisher, saying it wanted the company to sell some assets and focus on digital publishing.

title: A Little Bit County, a Little Bit Coloratura
description: How is a Broadway golden girl to proceed when the whole world appears to be at her beck and call? That is the treacherous question facing Kelli OHara, the luminous star of two successive hit shows (The Light in the Piazza and the revival of The Pajama Game) and an imminent production of South Pacific.

title: The College Admissions Frenzy
description: To the Editor:

title: Children of Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Pathologist Accused of Profiting From Office
description: PITTSBURGH  By his own count, Dr. Cyril H. Wecht, one of the nations foremost forensic pathologists, has testified in more than 1,000 civil and criminal trials in his 46-year career, and opined on thousands more on television, on radio and in print.

title: McCain and Romney Trade Sharp Attacks
description: Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney traded blistering attacks in Florida on Monday morning, a day before the states Republican primary.

title: Directors Acclaim Coen Brothers
description: Joel and Ethan Coen woke up on Sunday as the favorites for the Academy Award for directing after being chosen best directors by the Directors Guild of America on Saturday night in Los Angeles for their latter-day western, No Country for Old Men, Reuters reported. Since the guild began honoring directors in 1949, only six of its choices have failed to win the Oscar . Its nice to get the acknowledgment of critics and even audiences, but there is something about being acknowledged by people who do the same thing you do, said Joel Coen, above right, who has joined his brother, in cowboy hat, in making films like Fargo and Blood Simple in the last 25 years. The last time the guild honored two men as best feature-film directors was 1961, when the winners were Robert Wise and Jerome Robbins for West Side Story. No Country for Old Men has been nominated for eight Academy Awards.

title: Despite Housing Slide, Real Estate Sites Sell
description: TALK about an uh-oh moment.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition of works by Richard Diebenkorn at the Grey Art Gallery at New York University misidentified the site of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery, which organized a Diebenkorn retrospective in 1976 in which a work at the Grey Gallery, Untitled (Albuquerque), was shown. It is in Buffalo, not Rochester.

title: Washington Post Starts an Online Magazine for Blacks
description: In attempt to broaden its online audience, The Washington Post Company on Monday is to introduce an online magazine primarily for a black audience, with news and commentary on politics and culture, and tools for readers to research their family histories.

title: Lottery Numbers
Chief of Sears to Step Down
description: Wanted: a retail chief who can do more with less  and save Sears.

title: Charges Are Sought Against French Trader
description: PARIS  Jerome Kerviel, the former Socit Gnrale employee at the center of the biggest trading fraud in history, has confessed to police that he hid his activities from superiors, and he gambled in the markets because he wanted to be a star trader, the Paris prosecutor said Monday.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Rob Cristo joined Sawchuk Brown Associates, Albany, as an account executive. He had been a reporter at The Record, Troy, N.Y., part of the Journal Register Company.

title: Footnote
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art at Altria will close on Tuesday after 25 years of presenting new work by contemporary artists at 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street. The closing of the branch, which was expected, comes as Altria, formerly the Philip Morris Companies, prepares to relocate its corporate headquarters from the site.

title: New CDs
description: VAMPIRE WEEKEND

title: Clintons Camp Seeks Gentler Role for Ex-President
description: Democrats inside and outside the Clinton campaign on Sunday debated and in some cases bemoaned the degree to which former President Bill Clintons criticism of Senator Barack Obama last week had inflicted lasting damage on his wifes presidential candidacy.

title: Homeowners and the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: Schumer Says F.A.A. Plans to Move Jobs
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer said on Sunday that the Federal Aviation Administration was considering transferring nearly 100 engineering jobs for the regions three major airports to Atlanta within months. The senator criticized any transfer, saying such jobs are crucial to installing new technology to improve safety and reduce delays. The possible transfer of jobs at the F.A.A.s eastern regional office in Jamaica, Queens, is part of the agencys nationwide consolidation plan, Mr. Schumer said. Jim Peters, a spokesman for the F.A.A., said on Sunday, Theres been no official announcement, or plans, that additional staff will be transferred.

title: Another Rolex Win for Ganassi Team
description: Juan Pablo Montoya teamed with Dario Franchitti, Scott Pruett and Memo Rojas to give Chip Ganassis team an unprecedented third consecutive victory in the Rolex 24-Hour race in Daytona Beach, Fla.Other than a minor handling problem for Pruett at the start of the race Saturday afternoon, the teams No. 01 Lexus Riley Daytona Prototype was almost perfect, racing at or near the lead in the race, which until its waning hours was the most competitive in the events 46-year history.At dawn on Sunday, with about six hours to go, there were five other prototypes on the lead lap. But as often happens in endurance events, attrition took its toll.The Ganassi car had been swapping leads with the Ford Riley shared by Nascars A. J. Allmendinger, Ian James, Burt Frisselle and John Pew. The Ford Riley car, driven by Frisselle, was only seconds behind the leader when a tire blew, damaging the suspension midway through the 21st hour and knocking it out of contention.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about the Canadian militarys secret action to stop transferring prisoners to Afghanistans government after Canadian monitors found evidence that they were being abused and tortured misspelled the surname of the leader of the British Columbia Civil Liberties Association, one of the groups seeking an injunction to block more transfers. He is Jason Gratl, not Gretl.

title: A Shelter Is Built Green, to Heal Inside and Out
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Although he will not be moving from the dilapidated homeless shelter here for another week, Paul McClendon, 55, has his oversized baby-blue garbage bags packed. Sitting on his bed in a winter jacket, he talked Thursday about the new, so-called green shelter with the central heating that he will be moving into.

title: LeapFrog Hopes for Next Hit With Interactive Reading Toy
description: EMERYVILLE, Calif.-- LeapFrog Enterprises needs a knockout hit.

title: Martz Trailways Bus from Mount Pocono, Pa., to the Port Authority in Manhattan
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Novel to Screen to Stage: Evolving, Step by Step
description: In London the award-winning theatrical comedy is billed as John Buchans The 39 Steps. But on Broadway, where the British import opened this month, it is called Alfred Hitchcocks The 39 Steps. Is it possible that Buchan, who published his novel The 39 Steps in 1915, is better known in Britain than Hitchcock, the cinematic master of suspense who in 1935 made his film adaptation of that novel into one of the triumphs of his early London period?

title: Briton Opposed by Afghans Wont Take U.N. Post
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The British politician Paddy Ashdown withdrew his name from consideration for the post of United Nations special envoy to Afghanistan on Sunday, after being rejected by President Hamid Karzai in what was widely seen as a move to assert his authority against Western control.

title: Russia Bars Opposition Candidate From March 2 Ballot
description: MOSCOW  The Russian government on Sunday denied an opposition leaders application to appear on the March 2 presidential ballot, clearing a path for the Kremlins favorite candidate to run all but unchallenged.

title: Ta-ta! Give Em the Old Existential Soft-Shoe
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  As he approaches his 80th birthday, Edward Albee, that most distinguished of American dramatists, is being seriously silly. Or is it sillily serious? Sillily  that cant be right. Isnt that one of a group of islands off the coast of England? Or do I mean the ingnue from The Importance of Being Earnest? Am I making any sense at all?

title: Michael Abbott, Producer,  Is Dead at 81
description: Michael Abbott, a television, film and theater producer who was bringing a revival of Stalag 17 to Broadway 57 years after producing its premiere Off Broadway, died Thursday in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: A Sweet Sundae? No, Its Primaries
description: Super Duper Tuesday sounds like a special mealtime offering at Friendlys or Applebees. But it is an expression coined last February by Bill Schneider, CNNs senior political analyst, during a discussion on The Situation Room about the crowded calendar for presidential primaries.

title: McCain, Long a G.O.P. Maverick, Is Gaining Mainstream Support
description: LADY LAKE, Fla.  Is John McCain, the maverick flyboy of the Republican Party, becoming the candidate of the Republican establishment?

title: 19 Burned to Death in Violence in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Ethnically driven violence intensified in Kenya on Sunday, and police officials said at least 19 people, including 11 children, were burned to death in a house by a mob.

title: No Campaigning but Much Debate Over Florida
description: MIAMI  One of the big disputes taking place between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama these days is over an election that is  or is not  taking place here on Tuesday: the Florida Democratic primary.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded 6,938,431

title: With a Whisper, Cubas Housing Market Booms
description: HAVANA  Virtually every square foot of this capital city is owned by the socialist state, which would seem sure to put a damper on the buying and selling of property.

title: 13 Arrested in Push to Stifle Turkish Ultranationalists Suspected in Political Killings
description: ISTANBUL  In one of the biggest operations against Turkish ultranationalists in decades, the authorities announced on Saturday night that they had arrested 13 people who were part of a criminal group that was suspected of carrying out political killings and having shadowy ties to the Turkish state.

title: U.S. Stocks Recover After Sell-Off Abroad
description: An early tumble gave way to a modest rally on Wall Street on Monday, as American investors shrugged off heavy losses in the Asian markets and sent stocks steadily up in the afternoon.

title: Should Bankers Pay for Their Mismanagement?
description: What is to be done with the bankers? From the savings and loan meltdown in the 1980s to the current housing-led seizure, financial institutions have proved unable to curb their appetite for risky assets  blowing up the bank and spreading economic mayhem.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A television review in Weekend on Friday about the Fox game show The Moment of Truth misstated the amount of money a contestant won on the show Deal or No Deal on Wednesday night in comparing The Moment of Truth with other game shows. The contestant, Britney Lewzader, won $471,000, not $1 million.

title: For the Record
description: An editorial on Jan. 13 about Eli Broad incorrectly described the arrangements he announced for his private art collection. Mr. Broad will put it into his existing foundation, which will control the art. He did not create a new foundation for that purpose.

title: Majesty of Bach, With a Wild West Trip
description: There was no dancing at one of the best performances of Jerome Robbinss Goldberg Variations that I have attended. I was late for the matinee. And as the score welled out into the First Ring lobby of the New York State Theater, I sat in the early afternoon sunshine and simply listened to the music in the company of the lobbys giant Nadelman ladies. It was unexpected magic and perhaps forgivable considering George Balanchines famous observation that if you didnt like the ballet you could just close your eyes and hear the music.

title: When Neither A Nor B Looks Good
description: A study in The Journal of Consumer Research finds that people have more trouble choosing between bad alternatives than good ones. In one experiment, college students were asked to choose between a car with a poor warranty and one without air-conditioning. They took 26 percent longer to choose than students who were asked to pick between a car with good financing and one with a powerful engine.

title: A Pan-American Welcome to Warm the Corazn
description: Alejandro Sanz strolled onstage at the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, smiling appreciatively, maybe a little sheepishly. One of Spains biggest pop stars, he is a first-rate balladeer who has gradually expanded his reach, experimenting with the rich rhythms that have long underpinned even his gentlest love songs.

title: In Death, Ex-Dictator Elicits Grief and Tributes
description: SOLO, Indonesia  _ Former President Suharto was buried in a family tomb on a sacred hillside here on Monday, one day after his death in Jakarta, embraced by many as a great leader despite his reign as a brutal and corrupt dictator.

title: Bernsteins New York: West Side and Beyond
description: In case youve forgotten: New York, New York, its a helluva town! Those words by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, borne aloft on the music of Leonard Bernstein, were wafted high into the stratosphere by the singers Gavin Creel and Kate Baldwin at the Allen Room on Friday evening.

title: Disney Youth Dont Bop; Theyre Singing in Hindi
description: LOS ANGELES  How do you sing bop to the top in Hindi? If you are the Walt Disney Company, very carefully.

title: Moon and Earth and Sky: A Festivals Long Reach
description: Young Soon Kim, the founder and director of the White Wave modern dance company, has a thing for festivals. But there are usually several choreographers and performers who stand out in what are essentially showcase series. The Cool New York festivals program on Friday, at the companys John Ryan Theater in Brooklyn, opened on a high note with 359 Degrees, a solo choreographed and performed by Ashley Lecille Suttlar. Set to music by Donny Hathaway, the dance communicated a deeply felt emotional state clearly and evocatively, through a strongly centered body that seemed drawn to the earth and sky from moment to moment.

title: Bank Outlines How Trader Hid His Activities
description: PARIS  The French bank Socit Gnrale, facing persistent questions over how a lone, junior trader could have instigated more than $7 billion in losses, acknowledged on Sunday that his activities prompted questions from risk managers several times last year, but that the bank never began an investigation because his explanations defused any suspicions.

title: This Weeks Economic Reports
description: ECONOMIC INDICATORS A big week for economic news will be led off by the Federal Reserves announcement on interest rates on Wednesday and capped by the unemployment report for January. Other reports will include new home sales for December (Monday); durable goods for December and the Conference Board consumer confidence index for January (Tuesday); the first estimate of fourth-quarter gross domestic product and the ADP employment forecast (Wednesday); personal income and spending for December and the Chicago purchasing managers index for January (Thursday); and reports on unemployment for January, the Institute for Supply Managements manufacturing index for January, construction spending for December and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday).

title: Old Memories Look Better Through New Glasses
description: Sasha Meza lifted her tiny finger, delicately pointing herself out among her junior high school classmates in the yearbook. Her mother and grandmother shuffled through photographs that were spread across a heavy, dark wood table in the rectory of St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn  pictures of Sasha at the Special Olympics and at her eighth-grade prom, and some from past Easters of Sasha, her brother, Gabriel Samolyuk, now 5, and her sister, Sabrina Samolyuk, now 12.

title: The Bush Who Got Away
description: AS George W. Bush prepares to deliver his final State of the Union address, its worth revisiting the first speech he gave to a joint session of Congress. His valedictory words tonight will provide an opportunity to reflect on the kind of president Mr. Bush was. The speech delivered seven years ago points to the very different sort of president he might have been.

title: Real Estate Troubles Are Weighing on Florida Voters Minds as Primary Nears
description: ST. CLOUD, Fla.  Florida is a cultural patchwork. The Panhandle seems to have more in common with neighboring Alabama and Georgia than with Fort Lauderdale and Miami in the eclectic southern reaches of the state. The condo canyons on the coasts are worlds away from the sugar cane and orange plantations in the interior.

title: Vetoing Historys Responsibility
description: President Bushs threat to veto a bill intended to improve health care for the nations American Indians is both cruel and grossly unfair. Five years ago, the United States Commission on Civil Rights examined the governments centuries-old treaty obligations for the welfare of Native Americans and found Washington spending 50 percent less per capita on their health care than is devoted to felons in prison and the poor on Medicaid.

title: Waiter, Is That Mercury in My Sushi?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lieberthal Retires
description: Catcher Mike Lieberthal, 36, has decided to retire after a 14-year major league career with the Phillies and the Dodgers.The Dodgers declined the option they had on Lieberthal for the coming season. Lieberthal played in 38 games last season, hitting .234 in 77 at-bats.

title: Tie Breaker Allows Lysacek to Defend Title
description: ST. PAUL  Nobody could have anticipated an ending like this. A tie breaker? In figure skating?

title: Gordon B. Hinckley, Mormon Leader, Is Dead at 97
description: Gordon B. Hinckley, the president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints who led Mormonism through a period of global expansion, died Sunday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 97.

title: A Violation of Both the Law and the Spirit
description: RIPTON, Vt.

title: Direct-to-DVD Releases Shed Their Loser Label
description: LOS ANGELES  If you missed the red-carpet premiere for the latest American Pie movie, you are not alone. There wasnt one. American Pie Presents: Beta House, the sixth film in the popular comedy series, was sent straight to DVD.

title: Echo of First Bush: Good Economy Turns Sour
description: WASHINGTON  Will George W. Bush be remembered as the president who lost the economy while trying to win a war?

title: White Cruises to Win After a Near-Perfect Run
description: ASPEN, Colo.  With the snow and wind flying through the Elk Mountain Range, many of the riders in the halfpipe final at the Winter X Games on Sunday night were somewhat grounded. But not Shaun White.

title: Kennedy Chooses Obama, Spurning Plea by Clintons
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, rejecting entreaties from the Clintons and their supporters, is set to endorse Senator Barack Obamas presidential bid on Monday as part of an effort to lend Kennedy charisma and connections before the 22-state Feb. 5 showdown for the Democratic nomination.

title: Former Assemblyman Spreads the Largess as a Lobbyist
description: ALBANY  Paul A. Tokasz, a former Assembly majority leader, has put his campaign war chest to work since leaving the Legislature to become a lobbyist.

title: Brady Says Ankle Was Hurt on Sack
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Tom Brady and his right ankle arrived here for the Super Bowl on Sunday night, and with flashes from more than a dozen cameras going off just feet from him, he handled his first significant challenge of the week. Wearing brown wingtips, Brady, the Patriots quarterback, scaled the two steps to the podium with only the slightest limp and climbed down with apparent ease.

title: Music in Review
description: THE SONG CONTINUES

title: Four Days, a Therapist; Fifth Day, a Patient
description: Some things sound simply awful: a family reunion holiday cruise, an all-you-can-eat haggis buffet, a television series set entirely in a psychotherapists office.

title: Bush Pledges Vetoes to Slow Earmarks
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush will veto spending bills this year unless they cut in half the total amount of money earmarked for lawmakers pet projects, and he will order agencies to ignore future earmarks unless they are explicitly listed in the text of legislation, the White House said Monday.

title: Eddie Sutton Chases 800th Victory, and a Brighter Legacy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The story of how Eddie Sutton went from his home in Oklahoma to a hotel at Fishermans Wharf involves a bottle and a big round number.

title: Stars Seize Their Chance to Shine at SAG Awards
description: LOS ANGELES  There is no show business without a show. And so, in a year when a writers strike has all but shut down much of Hollywood, the Screen Actors Guild Awards  as anonymous in most years as Cop No. 3 in a summer blockbuster  took top billing Sunday and drew an inordinate amount of star wattage.

title: Seeking Raw Beauty in Fluid Movement
description: Eduardo Vilaro was born in Cuba and grew up in the Bronx before he landed on his feet as a principal dancer with Ballet Hispanico in Manhattan. Now hes conquered another city, but this time its not as a dancer. After receiving his masters degree from Columbia College Chicago, Mr. Vilaro stayed put and formed a company, Luna Negra Dance Theater, which is dedicated to fostering the work of Latino choreographers.

title: DNA Collection and Marijuana Arrests
description: To the Editor:

title: Yemens Deals With Jihadists Unsettle the U.S.
description: SANA, Yemen  When the Yemeni authorities released a convicted terrorist of Al Qaeda named Jamal al-Badawi from prison last October, American officials were furious. Mr. Badawi helped plan the attack on the American destroyer Cole in 2000, in which 17 American sailors were killed.

title: In Florida, Rivals Focus on Economy and Security
description: SWEETWATER, Fla.  Mitt Romney and Senator John McCain continued their tug-of-war Sunday over what should be the top concern of voters in the Florida Republican primary on Tuesday  the economy or national security.

title: Students Click, and a Quiz Becomes a Game
description: GREAT NECK, N.Y.  The games had begun. In a darkened classroom at Great Neck South High School on a recent afternoon, the Advanced Placement physics students sped through a pop quiz, furiously pressing keys on hand-held clickers. A projection screen tracked their responses in real time, showing who knew what through an animated display of spaceships  individually numbered for each student  that blasted off or fell by the wayside with each right or wrong answer.

title: After Djokovics Quick Ascent, Its a Little More Crowded at the Top
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was early, very early, in the first set of Sundays Australian Open final when an Australian voice yelled out from high in Rod Laver Arena, Lets go Roger!

title: Target Tells a Blogger to Go Away
description: Target to the blogosphere: youre irrelevant.

title: Sundance Honors Immigration Drama
description: Frozen River, a first feature about a struggling single mother in upstate New York who joins a Mohawk widow in smuggling Chinese migrants from Canada into the United States, won the grand jury prize for best American drama on Saturday at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, The Associated Press reported. Quentin Tarantino, one of the jurors, described the film, starring Melissa Leo, above right, and Misty Upham, above left, as a wonderful depiction of poverty in America. Trade papers reported that Sony Pictures Classics had bought the film, adapted by Courtney Hunt from her 2004 short of the same title, for under $1 million.
