Trouble in the Water, a film by Tia Lessin and Carl Deal about a New Orleans couples survival through Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath, won the grand jury award in the American documentary category. The audience award for favorite American drama was won by The Wackness, starring Ben Kingsley as a psychiatrist who trades therapy for marijuana.

title: Carrying Ball and Message: N.F.L. Rewards a 10-Year-Old
description: Jared Doutt, a football player from Erie, Pa., will be making his first Super Bowl appearance Sunday.

title: California Governors Plan for Health Care in Trouble
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It has been a January to forget for Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California.

title: Excerpts From Bushs Speech
description: Following are excerpts from President Bushs State of the Union address on Jan. 28, 2009, as prepared for delivery and provided by the White House:

title: Kanye Wests Unexpected Rap
description: The audience at Flavorpills One Step Beyond party at the American Museum of Natural History in New York got a huge surprise on Friday night. During a set by the Chicago indie rapper Kid Sister in the Rose Center for Earth and Space, Kanye West, above, rushed onstage to rap along to her single Pro Nails. Afterward, to deafening cheers from the crowd, Mr. West and his D.J., A-Trak, performed a string of songs from his recent album, Graduation, including the radio smashes Stronger and Good Life. Mr. West wore a bulky fur coat, leading Kid Sister to quip, Yall look like my grandma.

title: Texas Ensemble Plants Flag in New York
description: To judge by the accented conversation and hearty glad-handing among audience members, there were a lot of Texans in attendance on Saturday night for the Carnegie Hall debut of the Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra. Still, that the hall was nearly full was a testimony to the growing reputation of this active regional orchestra, which maintains a year-round season, has built a $27 million endowment and draws loyal audiences to Bass Hall in Fort Worth.

title: Fox Mashes Up the Supers
description: Fox is going to get an early jump on Super Sunday. At 9 a.m. E.S.T. next Sunday morning  more than nine hours before the coin is tossed  players and tactics will be scrutinized, coaches will get the once-over, and sideline savants will predict the outcome.

title: Queens: Prison-Release Party Leads to Killing
description: The police said they found a man dead of a gunshot wound to the forehead shortly before 5 a.m. on Sunday in Hunters Point. The man was identified as Joseph Prince, 30, of 35th Avenue in Ravenswood, the police said. At a news conference on Sunday, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said people had been throwing bottles at each other before the shooting. The party was a celebration of someone getting out of prison, he said. Mr. Prince was found in front of 44-3 23rd Street, the police said. There were no arrests on Sunday, the police said.

title: Bush Urges Quick Action on Economy
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush sought to reassure Americans about the economy on Monday night, declaring in his last State of the Union address that the United States would banish the specter of an imminent recession, provided that Congress acts quickly on the economic stimulus package laid out last week.

title: Senate Panel Unveils Its Own Stimulus Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Finance Committee, moving to put its own stamp on a rescue plan for the ailing economy, unveiled a $156 billion fiscal stimulus package on Monday that would pay $500 to most individual tax filers and $1,000 to couples, with an additional $300 a child for families, with no income cap to disqualify high earners.

title: No Survivors After Night Attack at Home of Baghdad Ex-Official
description: BAGHDAD  A band of attackers on Saturday night broke into the home of a man who was a senior Baghdad city official under the government of Saddam Hussein and shot and stabbed him and his family, killing everyone in the home, an Iraqi official said Sunday. The American military also disclosed the deaths of two United States soldiers in Baghdad, one on Saturday and the other on Sunday.

title: Less Preening, More Fun and a Touch of Dignity at Awards Show
description: Some awards shows are born great, some achieve greatness and some are thrust upon us. Like England watching with trepidation in 1936 as an untried Duke of York replaced the abdicating Edward VIII, viewers enjoyed a happy surprise Sunday night.

title: Mellencamp Channels Defiance and Dreams
description: Everyone could hear him when John Mellencamp leaned away from the microphone and declaimed a verse of Minutes to Memories virtually unamplified on Friday night. That doesnt happen when he plays his usual theaters and arenas, but on this night he was leading his band at the Housing Works Used Book Cafe, which holds fewer than 200 people. It was the fifth anniversary concert for Live From Home, a series of benefits for the nonprofit AIDS service organization Housing Works that has steadily booked first-rate songwriters to play for audiences much smaller than their usual crowds.

title: Brooklyn: Hate Crime Charges in Graffiti Cases
description: A Brooklyn Heights man arrested on Jan. 20 after a cache of weapons that included guns and pipe bombs was found in his Remsen Street apartment has also been charged with a hate crime in connection with swastika graffiti in the neighborhood, the police and prosecutors said on Sunday. The suspect, Ivaylo Ivanov, 37, left, was charged with criminal weapons possession, as well as with aggravated harassment as a hate crime. A second man, Pavel Andreenko, has also been arrested in connection with an unrelated spate of spray-painted swastikas last month around Flatbush and Sheepshead Bay, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, an auction of two-year notes on Monday and auctions of five-year notes and four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Amity May Give Bush a Lift
description: This week showcases an unusual role reversal: someplace else will look angrier and more dysfunctional than political Washington, at least for a moment.

title: For Gay Democrats, a Primary Where Rights Are Not an Issue, This Time
description: The impromptu debate, over light beers and dirty martinis, was at once mundane and remarkable. Provoked by a reporter, four middle-aged men at a Greenwich Village gay bar made fiery pitches for the Democratic presidential front-runners. Two backed Senator Barack Obama, one argued for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, and the fourth made an emotional plea for the cause of John Edwards, the former senator from North Carolina.

title: Smitten by Lyon, a Visitor Tries to Recreate the Magic
description: LYON, France  Strolling the streets of Lyon with his wife last October, Buti Saeed al-Ghandi was suddenly overcome by a double wave of love, for the city and for his spouse.

title: Suharto Dies at 86; Indonesian Dictator Brought Order and Bloodshed
description: Suharto of Indonesia, whose 32-year dictatorship was one of the most brutal and corrupt of the 20th century, died Sunday in Jakarta. He was 86.

title: Cisco to Sell Faster Switch for Flood of Remote Data
description: Cisco Systems plans on Monday to introduce a network switch for corporations grappling with rapidly growing Internet data transfers and the increased use of applications that draw on remote data storage, known as cloud computing.

title: Belichick Left the Giants, but They Havent Left Him
description: PHOENIX  They nicknamed him Captain Sominex back then, because even when he was first tasting the success that is now the norm for him, Bill Belichick had a monotone that sent Giants linebackers to their slumber in a darkened meeting room.

title: Angola and Tunisia Win
description: Angola and Tunisia each won, 3-1, in Tamale, Ghana, to improve their chances of qualifying for the quarterfinals of the African Cup of Nations.Angola rallied to top Senegal, and Tunisia easily defeated South Africa.Angola and Tunisia play Thursday in their final first-round games; each will advance with a tie.

title: In the Woods and Streams of New York State, an Artemis for Modern Times
description: WATERFORD, N.Y.  Patricia Riexinger, the new director of New York States Division of Fish, Wildlife and Marine Resources, stood in the falling snow here and peered through her binoculars, looking for bald eagles. Suddenly, a bird leapt from a tree and soared out of sight, and Ms. Riexinger, visibly excited, set off in pursuit, traversing streams and sloshing across muddy slopes.

title: Too Easy to Refuse
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made Iran another offer it could refuse last week. Speaking in Davos, Ms. Rice said that the United States didnt want Iran as a permanent enemy and that better relations were possible if Tehran would give up its nuclear fuel program.

title: Lessons of 1992
description: Its starting to feel a bit like 1992 again. A Bush is in the White House, the economy is a mess, and theres a candidate who, in the view of a number of observers, is running on a message of hope, of moving past partisan differences, that resembles Bill Clintons campaign 16 years ago.

title: SAG Awards: Reading Tea Leaves on Whos the Latest Cup of Tea
description: What It All Means  and Doesnt

title: Once Synagogues, Now Churches, and Ailing Quietly
description: Jewell Cunninghams year of exodus was 1953.

title: A French Style of Capitalism Is Now Stained
description: PARIS  In a country where the hurly-burly of market capitalism has long been viewed with suspicion, Socit Gnrale was a rare Gallic success story  the Chanel or Chteau Margaux of French banking.

title: Spartans Victorious Over Rambo
description: Meet the Spartans, a parody starring Sean Maguire and Carmen Electra in yet another retelling of the historic battle against the Persians, barely outslugged Sylvester Stallone in Rambo to seize control of the No. 1 ranking at the weekend box office. In their debuts Meet the Spartans, distributed by Fox, pulled in an estimated $18.7 million, while Rambo (Lionsgate) came away with $18.1 million, the tracking company Media by Numbers reported. The romantic comedy 27 Dresses (Fox), with $13.6 million, fell to third place from second last week. The monster movie Cloverfield (Paramount), on a gross of $12.7 million, plunged to fourth place from No. 1 a week ago. Fifth place went to the newcomer Untraceable (Sony), the horror thriller starring Diane Lane as an F.B.I. cyberwizard. It grossed $11.2 million.

title: Is It a Recession? Marketers Seem to Think So
description: Let the economists and politicians debate whether the American economy is in a recession. Madison Avenue is already battening down the hatches.

title: Bronx: D.W.I. Charge in Fatal Crash
description: A driver lost control of his Honda Accord early Sunday morning on the Major Deegan Expressway, crossing the center line and killing a passenger when the car slammed into a tree, the police said. The driver, Marcelo Uribe, 21, of Sleepy Hollow, was charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter, the police said. The accident occurred near Van Cortlandt Park about 4:20 a.m. A second passenger was in stable condition at St. Barnabas Hospital on Sunday. The passenger who was killed was not identified Sunday.

title: F.E.C. Enforcement
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Vows Not to Block Supplies to Gaza
description: JERUSALEM Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel promised the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Sunday that Israel would no longer disrupt the supply of food, medicine and necessary energy into the Gaza Strip and intended to prevent a humanitarian disaster there.

title: Names of Officers in Shooting Released
description: The names of four Westchester County police officers who were involved in the shooting death of an off-duty officer in White Plains on Friday were made public on Monday as the investigation into the shooting continued.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Composer Whos 99 With Plenty to Celebrate
description: Perhaps its true that composers of formidably complex music, like Elliott Carter, are tough sells for mainstream audiences. That is why the scene at the Juilliard School on Friday night was so encouraging. Outside the schools Peter Jay Sharp Theater a long line of people stood in the wintry chill, hoping to get tickets for the first concert of Focus! 2008: All About Elliott, the schools free, weeklong festival devoted to music by Mr. Carter, interspersed with works by composers who influenced him and by sympathetic colleagues.

title: A Lengthy Duel in France, Championship Berth at Stake
description: They work their players hard in France. The trial final to decide that countrys team for the 49th European Open Team Championship being played in June was over 200 boards, from Dec. 20 to 23.

title: Kremlin Denies Ballot Spot to Putin Opponent
description: MOSCOW  The Russian government on Sunday denied an opposition leaders application to appear on the March 2 presidential ballot, clearing a path for the Kremlins favorite candidate to run all but unchallenged.

title: Shooting Highlights a Growing Gap in White Plains
description: A van pulls up outside the Westchester County Department of Social Services in downtown White Plains every weekday morning, discharging homeless men who live in a shelter five miles to the north. The men are brought there for appointments  with substance-abuse and mental-health counselors, or with social workers who hope to find them jobs  joining dozens of other poor people there in need of public assistance.

title: Eastern All-Stars Win, and Fun Also Prevails
description: ATLANTA  For a game that does not mean anything in the standings, the N.H.L. All-Star Game generated a weekend-long referendum on the sport that seemed far too serious for an event that is supposed to be about fun.

title: Diary Revisits American Tragedy
description: On March 30, 1908, Chester Gillette, 25, was executed at Auburn State Prison in New York for the murder of his pregnant lover, Grace Brown, on an Adirondack lake in 1906. His sensational trial inspired the Theodore Dreiser novel An American Tragedy, the 1951 film A Place in the Sun and an opera staged by the Metropolitan Opera. Now, as the 100th anniversary of Gillettes electrocution approaches, Hamilton College has published The Prison Diary and Letters of Chester Gillette, taken from papers donated to the college last year by Gillettes grandniece, Marlynn McWade-Murray, The Associated Press reported. The editors, Jack Sherman and Craig Brandon, said Gillettes writings offer neither an explicit admission of guilt nor any clear assertion of innocence, but they do provide a window into his character and his metamorphosis in prison from a blithe youth into an introspective, compassionate, religious adult. In the penultimate entry in the diary, Gillette wrote: In all that I have done, I hope I have done as men would have me do. I know that I am right with God, and that is the all important thing.

title: Paulsons Deal-Making Revives Treasurys Relevance
description: WASHINGTON  In his first two years as Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr. spent much of his time learning what his can-do pragmatism could not do.

title: Kennedy Calls Obama New Generation of Leadership
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy implored Americans on Monday to reject the counsels of doubt and calculation, as he extended his endorsement and placed the aura of his familys name around the presidential candidacy of Senator Barack Obama.

title: Tuna Sales Halt Urged
description: OSLO (Reuters)  A global conservation group urged retailers on Monday to stop selling Mediterranean bluefin tuna as part of a move by several European supermarket chains meant to help the fishs stocks recover.

title: Manchester United Rallies
description: Manchester United rallied past visiting Tottenham, 3-1, in the fourth round of the F.A. Cup behind two goals by Cristiano Ronaldo.Carlos Tvez scored the other goal for United, which reached the Round of 16. United joined Chelsea, Arsenal and Liverpool in Mondays fifth-round draw. Visiting Manchester City lost to the League Championship team Sheffield United, 2-1.

title: Races Entering Complex Phase Over Delegates
description: MIAMI  The presidential campaign is entering a new phase as Democratic and Republican candidates move beyond state-by-state competition and into a potentially protracted scramble for delegates Congressional district by Congressional district.

title: A PG-13 Rating, Despite the Haze
description: Has Hollywoods get-tough stance on cigarettes gone up in smoke?

title: Sales of New Homes Fell by 26% in 2007
description: The housing industry, caught in a maelstrom of sinking demand, rising foreclosures, and bulging inventories, is in its worst slump in decades, a growing body of economic evidence shows.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Friday about Evan G. Galbraith Jr., a former United States ambassador to France, gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for the surname of the former secretary of state who disagreed with Mr. Galbraiths argument that political appointees made the best ambassadors. He is George P. Shultz, not Schultz.

title: Lo Duca to Have Surgery
description: Nationals catcher Paul Lo Duca was scheduled to have surgery on his left knee Monday to repair what his agent called a minor meniscus tear. Lo Duca will need an estimated 3-6 weeks for full recovery, his agent, Andrew Mongelluzzi, wrote in an e-mail message Sunday.Lo Duca, a former Met who signed a one-year, $5 million deal as a free agent this off-season, hurt himself during a workout last week, the Nationals said Friday.

title: Sallie Mae Settles Suit Over Buyout That Fizzled
description: Sallie Mae, the embattled student lending giant, reached a settlement on Sunday over its scuttled $25 billion buyout, ending months of legal fighting that had cast a cloud over the company, according to people briefed on the agreement.

title: The Still-in-Danger Gray Wolf
description: One of the great wildlife management stories of our time is the reintroduction of the gray wolf to the Rocky Mountains. From a few dozen animals released in Yellowstone in 1995, the wolf population has grown to about 1,500 in Idaho, Montana and Wyoming. This remarkable comeback means that later this year the gray wolf will be removed from the list of endangered species, at which point its fate will be entrusted to federally approved state management plans that conservationists warn are unacceptably weak.

title: Rahlves Earns Victory, but Says He Has Much to Learn
description: ASPEN, Colo.  After a year as an apprentice, Daron Rahlves has begun to figure out skiercross, his new discipline.

title: Sales of HD DVD Players Plunge After Warner Move
description: LOS ANGELES  One week after Warner Brothers Entertainment announced that it was abandoning its support for the next-generation HD DVD format in favor of the Blu-ray high-definition format, consumers abandoned HD DVD.

title: China Now Pays Troops Involved in Nuclear Tests
description: BEIJING  China has begun paying military personnel involved in nuclear tests, as part of its effort to improve benefits for veterans, the state news media reported over the weekend.

title: Palm to Close Most of Its Retail Stores
description: Palm, the smartphone maker that is losing sales to BlackBerrys and iPhones, will close seven of eight of its retail stores next month.

title: Houstons G.M. Is a Revolutionary Spirit in a Risk-Averse Mind
description: Daryl Morey has charts and spreadsheets and clever formulas for evaluating basketball players, and a degree from M.I.T. to make sense of it all. He would explain this mathematical wizardry, except that every few minutes his train of logical thought is interrupted by impulsive exclamations.

title: Back on West Coast, Knicks Are Still Doing Anything but Coasting
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Eddy Curry left Oracle Arena with many regrets Sunday night, though none of them related specifically to the 26 rebounds that were gathered by his waiflike counterpart on the Golden State Warriors.

title: If You Cant Win the Case, Buy an Election and Get Your Own Judge
description: The Appeal is John Grishams handy primer on a timely subject: how to rig an election. Blow by blow, this not-very-fictitious-sounding novel depicts the tactics by which political candidates either can be propelled or ambushed and their campaigns can be subverted. Since so much of what happens here involves legal maneuvering in Mississippi, as have many of his other books, Mr. Grisham knows just how these games are played. He has sadly little trouble making such dirty tricks sound real.

title: Knoblauch to Talk With House Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Chuck Knoblauch will come to Washington on Friday to talk to congressional staff members about Roger Clemenss challenge to the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, the House Oversight committee announced Monday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about the Canadian militarys secret action to stop transferring prisoners to Afghanistans government after Canadian monitors found evidence that they were being abused and tortured misspelled the surname of the leader of the British Columbia Civil Liberties Association, one of the groups seeking an injunction to block more transfers. He is Jason Gratl, not Gretl. (Go to Article)

title: Rapid Changes Since 2001 Cloud Outlook for Viewers
description: A few months ago, media companies were facing declining readership, flat advertising and the prospect of a damaging writers strike.

title: From Prison, Encouraging Words for Giants Tynes
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Of the congratulatory telephone calls that Lawrence Tynes received after his field goal sent the Giants to the Super Bowl, the least unusual was the one from a 30-year-old inmate at the Forrest City Federal Correctional Institution in Arkansas.

title: North Korean Orchestra to Visit England
description: On the heels of plans by the New York Philharmonic to perform in North Korea comes word that the 120-member North Korea State Symphony Orchestra is to play two concerts in England. The Guardian of London reported that after three years of planning and organizing, that orchestra will perform in September at the Royal Festival Hall in London and in Middlesbrough in northeast England. The visit was described as the brainchild of the opera singer Suzannah Clarke, who, in 2003, became the first British singer to perform in Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea. The newspaper said that she had suggested that her hosts invite other foreign musicians to North Korea and send its orchestra abroad. Ms. Clarke comes from Middlesbrough.

title: New Campaign Tries to Butter Up Shoppers
description: A food brand with a funny name, which is known for funny advertising, is starting a campaign that offers a humorous look back at eating habits when Dwight and Mamie were in the White House, Dick and Dorothy were on the radio and Ozzie and Harriet were on TV.

title: Stranger in a Strange Land Earns Himself an Encore
description: Derrick Braxton has six fingers on his left hand, but thats only one of the reasons he had a circle of fascinated students gathered around him one day early in his first semester at college. A freshman at Finger Lakes Community College in Canandaigua, N.Y., Mr. Braxton was eating a salami and cheese sandwich in the school lounge last fall when a curious student stopped to chat and ask where he was from.

title: Deadly Protests in Beirut Leave 7 Dead
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Deadly clashes erupted in Beirut on Sunday, leaving at least seven people dead and escalating Lebanons deepest political crisis since the end of its civil war in 1990.

title: Desperate Husband
description: In the run-up to Saturdays South Carolina primary, Bill Clinton repeatedly denounced racial divisions in American politics. Indeed, he said Friday in Spartanburg, Americans are literally aching to live in a post-racial future.

title: Scientology Writes; Gawker Rises
description: If Tom Cruise jumping on Oprahs couch was an 8 on the scale of scary, this is a 10, Nick Denton wrote on his media and gossip Web site Gawker.com on Jan. 15, when he posted an internal Church of Scientology video in which Mr. Cruise rhapsodizes about his religion. The page has been viewed over 2.3 million times, a record for Gawker.

title: Woods Renews Attack on the Record Book
description: SAN DIEGO  Tiger Woods began his 2008 season by once again opening the golf history books and stepping inside. On a blustery Sunday at Torrey Pines Golf Course, Woods won the Buick Invitational by a tournament-record eight strokes for his 62nd PGA Tour victory, tying Arnold Palmer for fourth on the career list and moving within two wins of Ben Hogan.

title: Merkel Partys Edge Is Tiny in Crucial State
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels conservative party limped to an anemic victory in the hotly contested election in the state of Hesse on Sunday. Her Christian Democrats could yet lose control of the state, depending on the outcome of coalition negotiations, for the first time in nine years.

title: Beirut Violence Kills 7 and Wounds Dozens
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Violent clashes erupted Sunday in Beirut, leaving at least seven people dead and escalating Lebanons most serious political crisis since its civil war ended in 1990.

title: Violence Spreads in Kenya, Killing 19 in Fire
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Ethnically driven violence intensified in Kenya on Sunday, and police officials said at least 19 people, including 11 children, were burned to death in a house by a mob.

title: Comptroller Audit Critical of Toll Increase
description: Thomas DiNapoli, the New York State comptroller, released a report on Sunday urging the states Thruway Authority to call off a toll increase that the agency had planned for July. The audit of the Thruway Authority says the agency should put off increases until it analyzes its expenses, operations and projects. The audit examined the calculations used in justifying proposed toll increases in July 2008, January 2009, July 2009 and January 2010. Mr. DiNapolis report recommended cutting costs, using a collection agency to collect unpaid E-Z Pass tolls, and prioritizing capital projects. We disagree with the financial impact of the recommendations, said Michael Fleischer, executive director of the authority. We believe it would be just a fraction of the revenue necessary to continue making the proper investments in the highway. Compiled by Denise Fuhs

title: The Secret to (Synthetic) Life
description: You were expecting poetry perhaps? The secret messages hidden in scientist J. Craig Venters synthetic bacterial genome have now been revealed. They are  his name, and that of his research institute and co-workers.

title: Sony Ericsson Sets Deals With 3 Labels
description: LONDON (Dow Jones)  Sony Ericsson announced content deals on Sunday with three of the worlds four top music labels, ahead of the introduction of its online music store in May.

title: In Open Nomination, Superdelegates May Hold Key to Victory
description: WASHINGTON  Not all Democratic presidential convention delegates are awarded like door prizes in the primaries and caucuses being so fiercely contested around the country.

title: Inquiry Raises New Questions on French Bank
description: PARIS  New questions emerged Monday about Socit Gnrales management after the banks former trader, Jrme Kerviel, told French prosecutors that his fictitious trading started as far back as 2005  a year earlier than the bank has acknowledged  and that other employees also routinely exceeded their authorized trading risk limits.

title: Former Patriots Coach Dies
description: Mike Holovak, a longtime N.F.L. executive who coached the Patriots to their first championship game, died Sunday, a few hours before the team left for the Super Bowl. He was 88.Holovak died in Ruskin, Fla., of complications from pneumonia, the Boston College spokesman Reid Oslin said after speaking with Holovaks wife, Pauline Scudder Holovak. Holovak was a former football star and coach at Boston College.Holovak led the Boston Patriots to the American Football League title game after the 1963 season. They lost to San Diego, 51-10. Holovak had a 53-47-9 record as Patriots coach. Only Bill Belichick has more wins, with 105.Holovak later was vice president for player personnel and general manager of the Houston Oilers, a position he kept when the team moved to Tennessee to become the Titans.

title: Bushs Final Speech Recalls Presidents Past
description: WASHINGTON  President Bushs final State of the Union address on Monday night was in some ways reminiscent in some ways of the speech given by his father 16 years ago.

title: Spoof Goes the Super Bowl
description: Do you think Tom Coughlin would see the humor in this?Headline in the Onion:Giants: We Almost Beat The Patriots Once, We Can Almost Beat Them AgainExcerpt:

title: Yemen's Counterterrorism Unit
description: Yemen's counterterrorism unit added 15 female combat troops in order to foil Al Qaeda's tactic of using women's dress to evade capture.

title: Screen Actors Guild Award Winners
description: Images from the 14th annual Screen Actors Guild Awards.

title: Hello, Mr. President?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Superstars T-Shirt, Match-Fixing, and Addressing the Trumpet Shortage
description: The African Cup of Nations in Ghana wouldnt be much of an international soccer tournament if there werent some geopolitical kerfuffle to add spice to the proceedings. Fortunately there is one, thanks to Egypt midfielder Mohamed Aboutreika, who lifted his jersey on Saturday after scoring against Sudan to reveal a T-shirt that read Sympathize with Gaza.

title: Vulnerable Places
description: Ecologists fear that climate change will make protected landscapes inhospitable to prized species.

title: Hes No Jack Kennedy
description: More of your late-night jokes ( send via the comment link below):

title: Monday, Fuddy-Duddy Monday
description: Tell us whats going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Why doesnt Bush get economic credit?
description: Todays Times asserts as fact:

title: Kellwood Lowers Defenses to Sun Capital Bid
description: Kellwood, the apparel company that makes the Baby Phat line of clothing, will remove all barriers to a cash tender offer of $21 a share made by the private equity firm Sun Capital so that the deal can be concluded if a majority of the shares are tendered, the company said on Sunday.

title: Brinksmanship in the Kellwood Showdown
description: Last night the Kellwood board of directors did the most unusual thing. Throwing out their 80s playbook, the board simply folded in the wake of Sun Capitals bid. The board announced that it intends to remove all impediments to the $21 per share hostile tender offer being made by the Sun Capital Securities Group. Kellwood said it would permit Sun to freely close its Feb. 12 tender offer if a majority of Kellwoods shares are tendered into the offer.

title: Resistant Bacteria, Football Players and Gay Men
description: Recent media reports about a new strain of resistant bacteria among men in San Francisco angered national gay rights groups concerned that the reports would create hysteria and a backlash against gay men. The university researchers who first announced the problem even issued an apology, saying their press release about the original study contained some information that could be interpreted as misleading.

title: In January, Record Number of I.P.O.s Are Pulled
description: Tumbling equity markets prompted 24 companies this month to halt plans for initial public offerings, the most in at least a decade.

title: Smaller Banks See Opportunity, but History Is Skeptical
description: Despite the terrible time in leveraged finance some lenders see opportunity in the crisis. In fact, a few foreign banks are pushing to increase market share by capitalizing on the hobbled condition of the largest lenders stuck with billions in loan and bond commitments.

title: Ranking the Top V.C.s in the World
description: Putting money into a start-up company can be exciting, but at the end of the day, its the money you take out that matters most to a venture funds investors.

title: Analyzing the M&A Boom
description: The M&A boom that defined the most recent business cycle may well prove the largest ever, especially for that rich M&A subset of leveraged buyouts. With about $4.5 trillion of companies bought and sold in 2007 alone, its sheer size is astonishing and unparalleled.

title: In Palm, Elevation Still Hasnt Found What Its Looking For
description: In June, Elevation Partners announced that it was paying $325 million to buy a 25 percent stake in Palm in what the private equity shop termed the largest investment that Elevation has ever made.

title: Nokia Dials Up Deal for Norways Trolltech
description: Nokia has offered 843 million Norwegian crowns ($153.3 million) for a software company, Trolltech, to support its new push to services and software operations.

title: Fortis Shares Surge After Assuaging Investor Concerns
description: Fortis, Belgiums biggest financial-services company, rose the most in almost 5 years in Brussels trading after the bank eased concerns about possible writedowns on subprime mortgage assets and raising new capital.

title: Investcorp Technology Raises $500 Million for Third Fund
description: Investcorp Technology Partners, the technology buyout arm of the Bahrain-based investment firm, announced Monday that it had raised $500 million for its third fund, outstripping the $400 million it originally sought to raise.

title: Swiss V.C. HBM Aims to Raise $137 Million in I.P.O.
description: A Swiss biotech investor HBM Bioventures plans to raise up to 150 million Swiss francs ($137.7 million) from its initial public offering next month, when it will also list all existing shares.

title: Sallie Mae Settles Suit Over Failed Buyout
description: Sallie Mae, the embattled student lending giant, reached a settlement on Sunday over its scuttled $25 billion buyout, ending months of legal fighting that had cast a cloud over the company, The New York Times reported.

title: Hedge Fund Urges Times Co. to Sell More Assets
description: One of two hedge funds seeking to name directors at The New York Times Company sought on Sunday to clarify its intentions for the newspaper publisher, saying it wanted the company to sell some assets and focus on digital publishing.

title: Credit Squeeze Spurs Record Trading at Exchanges
description: While the rising number of delayed or canceled initial public offerings is certainly not good news for the worlds stock exchanges, the current gloomy market conditions seem to have a silver lining for them.

title: Ex-Dow Jones Director Said to Settle With S.E.C.
description: David K. P. Li, a former board member of Dow Jones & Company, has reached a tentative agreement with federal securities regulators to pay more than $8 million to settle allegations of insider trading during last years takeover battle for the media group, The Financial Times reported.

title: Loan Reviewer Aiding Inquiry Into Big Banks
description: A company that analyzed the quality of thousands of home loans for investment banks has agreed to provide evidence to New York state prosecutors that the banks had detailed information about the risks posed by ill-fated subprime mortgages.

title: Saving Sears Doesnt Look Easy Anymore
description: By all accounts, Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire hedge fund manager whose investment savvy earned him renown as the next Warren Buffett, is a man not accustomed to rebukes.

title: Whats $34 Billion on Wall Street?
description: Under the stewardship of Dow Kim and Thomas G. Maheras, Merrill Lynch and Citigroup built positions in subprime-related securities that led to $34 billion in write-downs last year. The debacle cost chief executives their jobs and brought two of the worlds premier financial institutions to their knees.

title: Despite Credit Crunch, Vegas Deals Look Lucky
description: Despite the credit environment and the uncertain economic outlook, Las Vegas deals seem to be getting done.

title: Xstrata Close to Vale Bid, Report Says
description: Xstrata, the worlds fourth-largest copper producer, rose to a three-week high in London trading after newspaper reports that Companhia Vale do Rio Doce may agree to buy the company within the next few days.

title: Bank Outlines How Trader Hid His Activities
description: The French bank Socit Gnrale, facing persistent questions over how a lone, junior trader could have instigated more than $7 billion in losses, acknowledged on Sunday that his activities prompted questions from risk managers several times last year, but that the bank never began an investigation because his explanations defused any suspicions.

title: Seeking Day-in-the-Life Bloggers
description: When I was deciding whether to go to law school, I read Scott Turows One L. Everyone did. You bought it along with your LSAT prep materials. Today, we still have memoirs that give a window into the life in a profession (like the recent Diary of a Real Estate Rookie, by Alison Rogers or Atul Gawandes articles and books about a life in medicine). But if I were considering being a lawyer today, Id be looking for blogs that offer a regular glimpse of a life in the law, like this one by Evan Schaeffer, offering tips and techniques for trial lawyers.

title: Sears to Replace C.E.O.
description: As billionaire Edward S. Lampert struggles to turn around the Sears Holdings Corporation, the company announced Monday that said its chief executive, Aylwin Lewis, will leave the company on Saturday.

title: What Now for Societe Generale?
description: In a country where the hurly-burly of market capitalism has long been viewed with suspicion, Socit Gnrale was a rare Gallic success story  the Chanel or Chteau Margaux of French banking.

title: Will Scandal Force French Bank to Find a Dance Partner?
description: As details of how a rogue trader blew a $7.2 billion hole in Socit Gnrale weigh on investor confidence in the leading French bank, analysts and industry observers wonder if a white knight might be necessary to restore the banks image.

title: G.E. Dives for Tenaris Hydril Unit
description: General Electric said Monday it would purchase the Hydril pressure control business, a unit of a steel tube supplier, Tenaris for $1.12 billion to expand its oil and gas business.

title: Finish Lines Road Map
description: Late Friday, Finish Line filed its answer in the lawsuit brought against it by its very own investment banker, UBS. UBS is seeking to terminate its obligations to finance Finish Lines pending acquisition of Genesco.

title: Mozilo to Give Up $37.5 Million Severance Pay
description: The cash pile that Countrywide Financials chief executive, Angelo R. Mozilo, stands to reap from the lenders $2 billion sale to the Bank of Americajust got a little smaller.

title: Senate Eyes Economic Package
description: It promises to be a short but intense week for the House of Representatives, which meets only two days. But it should be an interesting two days.

title: Fans Journal: This Is African Soccer
description: The last stop on my three-city tour of Ghana was easily the most star-studded: a journey to Sekondi for Group B games featuring Ivory Coast, Mali, Nigeria and Benin. My friends and I were tired from traveling and didnt have tickets, but we were determined to see a few of these matches in the newly built Sekondi Sports Stadium.

title: Alliance Data Says Blackstone Deal Is in Trouble
description: For months, Alliance Data Systems has maintained that its $6.43 billion sale to the Blackstone Group was on track. In recent weeks, amid sudden, sharp declines in Alliance Datas stock price, people briefed on the deal negotiations told DealBook and other media outlets that the acquisition was proceeding.

title: Watching the Detectives
description: Did you ever notice that the same people who try to regulate the morals of others sometimes have their own moral, uh, issues?

title: Once More With Feeling
description: Falling Slowly, the duet from Once that has been nominated for best song, may have some eligibility problems. An announcement will probably come later today, but if it gets doinked, Enchanted will have a 75 percent chance of getting best song. There may be egg on some faces, or crowds carrying lanterns and pitchforks.

title: Meta on Meta
description: The Bagger was up late live-blogging the SAG Awards. He typed so much that he banged up his space-bar thumb, so light posts today.

title: Romney Pays Tribute to Mormon Church President
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Mitt Romney elected to begin a news conference this morning, held at a gas station to spotlight his economic message, with some comments to mark the death of Gordon B. Hinckley, president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

title: Obama's Youth-Driven Movement
description: GREELEYVILLE, South Carolina  Something is stirring in the U.S.A.. Even in this depressed corner of the country, a place where trains no longer stop and poor families get water from shallow wells, you feel it. A political campaign has become a movement with Barack Obama at its head.

title: The Early Word: Obama Rides New Wave of Support
description: Two days after soundly winning the South Carolina primary, Team Barack Obama is holding a rally at American University this afternoon, where Mr. Obama is set to receive the in-person endorsement of Edward M. Kennedy, the senior senator from Massachusetts, and Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of President John F. Kennedy.

title: Speaking of not getting credit
description: From Polling Report:

title: Both Neglect and Prosperity Threaten Houses of Worship
description: Churches, synagogues and other houses of worship that have played host to generations of immigrants are under threat throughout the city, either because of neglect in more impoverished areas or development in choice real estate markets, David Gonzalez reports. Preservationists and urban planners say that the concern over separation of church and state has made city officials generally reluctant to designate religious buildings as landmarks or to help them with funds for structural repairs.

title: Cultural Imperialism at the W.H.O.?
description: The post from World Health Organization researchers on the practice they call female genital mutilation (FGM) has prompted a couple of critical responses from other researchers. One is a comment from Richard Shweder of the University of Chicago, who calls it bureaucratic boilerplate and says its further evidence that identity politics has triumphed over science and critical reason at the W.H.O.

title: Compassionate conservatism
description: Oy. Why are political writers still unaware that Bushs phrase compassionate conservatism wasnt an acceptance of the Great Society, but rather a dog-whistle to the religious right? It comes from Marvin Olaskys The Tragedy of American Compassion. From the Publishers Weekly review:

title: Romney Links McCain to Democrats  Even Kerry
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.Mitt Romney pounded his rival, Senator John McCain, this morning with a series of epithets among conservative Republicans: McCain-Feingold, McCain-Kennedy, McCain-Lieberman and, well, Kerry-McCain.

title: Binx and Mercer
description: Many relationships in The Moviegoer speak to the class divide in New Orleans and the South of the 1960s. Binxs interchangeable secretaries, his Marcias and Lindas, all strapping country and suburban girls, are nothing like the delicately tuned Kate. His customers are assorted gangsters, bookies and working people, unlike the customers of the bond firms Uptown headquarters, who seem to be professional investors. His mother and her family are worlds apart from the Cutrers. (As a Bolling in Feliciana Parish, I became accustomed to sitting on the porch in the dark and talking of the size of universe and the treachery of men; as a Smith on the Gulf Coast I have become accustomed to eating crabs and drinking beer under a hundred and fifty watt bulb  and one is as pleasant a way as the other of passing a summer night.)

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: Big Brothers Technical Difficulties
description: Updated, 11:47 p.m.

title: The Red Carpet at the SAG Awards
description: A look at the fashions from the 14th annual Screen Actors Guild Awards.

title: Aronian Wins Corus on Tiebreak Over Carlsen
CME, Nymex in Discussions Over an $11 Billion Deal
description: The CME Group, the owner of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, and Nymex Holdings said Monday that they are in preliminary talks about an $11 billion merger, in what could create one of the biggest marketplaces for energy trading in the world.

title: Jackson: Not Upset by Clinton Remarks
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said late Sunday that he was not offended by comments on Saturday by former President Bill Clinton, who brought up Mr. Jacksons name in response to a question about Senator Barack Obama.

title: SAG Awards: One Last Tribute To The Sopranos
description: Reuters reports:

title: McCain Fires Back at Romney
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  John McCain used his first appearance of the day to go after Mitt Romney for alleged flip-flopping.

title: The Answer Man: A Mistake on Wine
description: A reader recently wrote me to share a story  a complaint, really  that Ive heard versions of before. It concerned a mistakenly ordered wine. And it concerned spending an amount of money that was never intended.

title: SAG Awards: Acknowledging The Strike
description: Recapping Sunday nights Screen Actors Guild Awards:

title: The Kennedy Factor
description: Does Ted Kennedys endorsement of Barack Obama matter? Brian Beutler, a Washington-based blogger who works for a network of liberal journalism organizations, says Kennedys endorsement indicates that Obama might have an easier time managing relations with Congress than Hillary Clinton would. Beutler writes on his personal blog:

title: SAG Awards: The Winners
description: The television winners at the Screen Actors Guild Awards:

title: Ghosts of 1984
description: Imagine this. For the first time in years, New Yorks Democratic presidential primary actually counts. The leading candidates have opened campaign offices, held fund-raisers, bought TV ads and scheduled visits. Angering some of his fellow black politicians, Representative Charles B. Rangel, the dean of Harlem politics, has endorsed the establishment candidate over an insurgent African-American challenger. It sounds a lot like 2008  but this was New York 24 years ago.More than 1,350,000 New York State Democrats went to the polls on April 3, 1984, to choose among three leading candidates for the party nomination  former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Black New Yorkers turned out in record numbers. The contest exposed social and racial divisions that would affect future state and city elections for years to come. And many of the operatives from that race are still active in local politics.

title: Shopping Berlins Fashion Week
description: The Premium trade fair has grown exponentially in recent years

title: The Debate: Explaining the Giants Success
description: In the regular-season finale, the Giants ignored calls to rest their starters heading into the playoffs, and instead gave the Patriots a fierce battle in one of the best games of the season. What elements of the Giants success in the playoffs  team unity, confidence, Eli Mannings poise and efficiency, and just plain mojo  can be attributed to that decision? And is that giving short shrift to another component of their success: pure talent?

title: City Room: Ghosts of 1984 in New York
description: Imagine this. For the first time in years, New Yorks Democratic presidential primary actually counts. The leading candidates have opened campaign offices, held fund-raisers, bought TV ads and scheduled visits. Angering some of his fellow black politicians, Representative Charles B. Rangel, the dean of Harlem politics, has endorsed the establishment candidate over an insurgent African-American challenger. It sounds a lot like 2008  but this was New York 24 years ago.

title: Amity May Give Bush a Lift
description: This week showcases an unusual role reversal: someplace else will look angrier and more dysfunctional than political Washington, at least for a moment.

title: Toni Morrison Endorses Obama
description: A decade ago, she affectionately referred to Bill Clinton as the nations first black president. But today, the author Toni Morrison is supporting the man who  if elected  would assume that place in history.

title: And Thats Just Among His Children
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: In political news, our old friend Dennis Kucinich has dropped out of the presidential race. Hes going back to his old job as a Keebler elf.

title: An AARP Discount on Ammo
description: Aired Friday night on CBS: You know Sylvester Stallone is Rambo again. Its the fourth Rambo movie and it opened this weekend. And it happens to everybody. Rambo is a little older now so he gets an AARP discount on ammo.

title: Extremely Loud Minimal Metal
description: If Robert Christgau had never written a word of rock criticism, Tom Carson once said, he would still be known as a legendary editor. After The Village Voice fired its legend in 2006, he was asked to serve as guest editor of Best Music Writing 2007. His choices for the book are, as you might expect, eclectic: e.g., Jonathan Lethem on James Brown, Ann Powers on Neil Diamond (!) and Jody Rosen on the Hasidic reggae artist Matisyahu. My favorite piece is a journal entry/concert review by that sublime oddball David Byrne:

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Automobiles Editor James G. Cobb
description: James G. Cobb, automobiles editor, answered reader questions Jan. 28-Feb. 1. To move ahead to the most recent answer, click here.

title: For Blackstone, a Question of Best Efforts
description: Alliance Data Systems announced Monday that the Blackstone Group had dropped the bombshell the market had been fearing. Blackstone informed Alliance Data that it does not anticipate the condition to closing the merger relating to obtaining approvals from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency will be satisfied.

title: Answers About Tenant-Landlord Issues, Part 2
description: Following is a second set of answers to readers questions selected by Lucas A. Ferrara, a partner at Finkelstein Newman Ferrara who has practiced in the landlord-tenant arena for more than two decades.

title: The High Low | Lee Angel Earrings, $135
description: You dont need a degree from Central St. Martins to know that good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant affordable gets. In this column, Ts fashion team roll up their Balenciaga sleeves to rummage for the cheap and the chic.

title: The Economys Effects On TV
description: In previous recessions, TV has always been that last resort, Robert J. Thompson, a professor of media and popular culture at Syracuse University, says in todays New York Times.

title: Credit Debacle Gives Old Theory New Life
description: Hyman Minsky, the economist and professor, died in 1996. But his model of the boom-to-bust credit cycle  sometimes described, or even dismissed, as a radical idea  is getting mentioned a lot these days. And it should be, according to John Cassidy, who writes about Mr. Minsky and his theories in the latest issue of The New Yorker.

title: Do Resets No Longer Matter?
description: Has the Fed solved the mortgage reset problem?

title: Damon on Gaining Weight and Cashman on Williams
description: Johnny Damon does not ruffle easily. I encountered Damon at the 85th Annual dinner for the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America and asked him if he knew that General Manager Brian Cashman had said Damon was out of shape last spring. Damon said he had heard about Cashmans remarks, but he did not seem worried about them.

title: On HBO, Nine Weeks of Head Therapy
description: In Treatment, a new HBO series set entirely in a psychotherapists office, has garnered some positive reviews ahead of tonights premiere.

title: How a CME-Nymex Deal Would Stack Up
description: Even a global credit crunch cant seem to slow the pace of multibillion-dollar deals among the worlds securities exchanges. Few industries have been such a rich source of mergers in recent years: There were nearly $25 billion in exchange-related mergers in 2006 and almost $28 billion in 2007, according to Dealogic.

title: Monday Tipoff: Sutton in San Francisco
description: Eddie Suttons presence has drawn plenty of attention to the San Francisco basketball team, but not many victories. The Times Jesse McKinley chronicled some of the struggles Sutton has faced since taking over the Dons. (Somebody get the poor man an In-N-Out Burger!) Meanwhile, SI.coms Cory McCartney writes that Suttons return reeks of a man simply chasing a number and its not doing him justice.

title: Giulianis New Ad: Not Endorsed
description: Rudolph W. Giulianis new Web ad takes the Groucho Marx approach to newspaper endorsements: I would not join any club that would have someone like me for a member.

title: Purple States: Security and the War
description: Citizen reporters Tanya and Alex discuss the war in Iraq and national security with candidates, a soldier turned anti-war activist, and others.

title: Aboard Air Giuliani
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is struggling here in polls of the state he staked his candidacy on, said aboard his plane Monday that regardless of what happens in the Florida primary on Tuesday that we fully intend to participate in the debate that the Republican candidates plan to hold Wednesday in California.

title: Richard Ford on the Book That Changed His Life
description: Its hard to say how many literary disciples Walker Percy has today, but one is surely Richard Ford. Fords novel The Sportswriter strikingly recalls The Moviegoer, starting with that compound noun in the title. In 2005, Ford was a guest on the National Public Radio program The Connection, for a series called The Book That Changed My Life. The book Ford chose to talk about was indeed The Moviegoer. It was a fine discussion. Ford views the books dynamic as a renewing experience and Binx as a hero headed toward the light and trying to find a vocabulary for affirmation, trying to find the institutions in life that will let him like life better and be better at it. It intrigues me that Ford never mentions religion as a force in the novel. This despite the fact that the exchange features a cameo call-in by Linda, evidently Linda Whitney Hobson, who wrote an accessible little book, Understanding Walker Percy, in which Percys Christianity is the single most important critical thread. You can still listen to the program in the online archives of the Boston public radio station WBUR.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Jan. 28:

title: A Final Push Before Florida
description: While the major Republican candidates  battled for Florida, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama campaigned in Tennessee and Alabama.

title: For The Moment | John Jay
description: This weeks guest blogger is John Jay, the Executive Creative Director and Partner of the Wieden + Kennedy advertising agency which includes Nike among its clients. Now based in Portland, Ore., Jay works in Asia once a month. In addition to helping to open W+Ks Tokyo, Shanghai, Beijing and New Delhi offices, he also founded W+K Tokyo Lab (an independent DVD music label) and Studio J, a private creative consultancy in Portlands Chinatown. Jay writes a blog for Honeyee.com in Tokyo and is a contributor to magazines in Tokyo and the U.S. on creativity and pop culture, including Tokion Japan, Giant Robot, Theme and Spread magazine. This week, Jay will be posting from Tokyo on the commodification of Japanese youth culture.

title: On South Carolina and Self-Image
description: Almost two years ago now, I interviewed Joe Trippi, the Democratic strategist, at a Starbucks in Northwest Washington. At that time, Mr. Trippi hadnt signed on with any of the campaigns, and he laid out a case for why Hillary Clinton couldnt be beaten in the primaries. The reason was simple: black voters.

title: Candor About 30 Rock
description: Backstage in Los Angeles last night, after Tina Fey accepted a Screen Actors Guild award for 30 Rock, she remarked:

title: The Clipboard: Super Bowl Wackiness
No Campaigning but Much Debate Over Florida
description: One of the big disputes taking place between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama these days is over an election that is  or is not  taking place here on Tuesday: the Florida Democratic primary.

title: 'Meet the Buttertons' - 30 Seconds
description: A campaign for I Can't Believe It's Not Butter is centered on a fictitious family of the 1950s named the Buttertons.

title: Villeneuve and Pollock Part
description: Jacques Villeneuve, the former F1 driver and world champion, today announced that he and his longtime manager, Craig Pollock have ended their business relationship. Villeneuve is now racing in Nascar and Pollock has other projects  notably, like Jacques, a new young family.

title: 'Meet the Buttertons' - 30 Seconds
description: A campaign for I Can't Believe It's Not Butter is centered on a fictitious family of the 1950s named the Buttertons.

title: 'Meet the Buttertons' - 15 Seconds
description: A campaign for I Can't Believe It's Not Butter is centered on a fictitious family of the 1950s named the Buttertons.

title: Ex-JPMorgan Chief to Advise Buyout Firm
description: William B. Harrison, the former chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has joined the investment advisory committee of the Aurora Capital Group, a private equity firm that acquired midsize companies, Aurora said Monday. Mr. Harrison, who oversaw JP Morgans $58 billion merger with Bank One in 2004, will help Los Angeles-based Aurora identify potential investments and evaluate potential executives to run its portfolio companies, the firm said

title: Clinton Stumps in the Northeast
description: HARTFORD  The roaring reception that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton received here on Monday morning reaffirmed just how far she has traveled since the days she and her husband tooled around Connecticut as Yale Law School students in a beat-up car held together with duct tape, as she joked.

title: Kennedy Endorses Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy implored Americans on Monday to reject the counsels of doubt and calculation, as he extended his endorsement and placed the aura of his familys name around the presidential candidacy of Senator Barack Obama.

title: Mysteries of New York Democratic Delegates, Explained
description: Updated, Jan. 31 | When New York Democrats cast their ballots a week from Tuesday, it will be only one part of the complicated  and often baffling  delegate-selection system that their party uses to decide their presidential nominee. Here is a guide to how the system works.

title: Tracking Consumer Savings on eBay
description: Is eBay turning away from auctions at precisely the wrong moment?

title: Connecticuts Disgraced Ex-Governor Gets a Job
description: Former Connecticut Gov. John G. Rowland, who resigned in disgrace for corruption and served ten months in prison, will soon return to the city he called only half in jest the center of the universe.

title: More Torture Debate, Courtesy of Saddam Hussein
description: In the days after Saddam Husseins capture, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was tossing wisecracks on subjects serious and trivial. The cab that the former Iraqi leader hid inside? He didnt have the meter running. Whos going to be responsible for interrogation? It was a three-minute decision, and the first two were for coffee.

title: Into the Home Stretch, Again and Again, Week 4
description: Every weekday through Feb. 1, Billie Cohen documented a different commuting trip for NYTimes.com/realestate, with additional details and reader comments here on City Room [Week 1 | Week 2 | Week 3| Week 4]. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: A New You: Jane E. Brody on Nutrition
description: Are carbohydrates really bad for you? Is there a connection between diet and cancer? Just how strong is the link between saturated fat and heart disease? Reporter Jane E. Brody writes the award-winning Personal Health column in The Times and has authored several books on medicine and science. This week, Ms. Brody is answering readers questions about diet and nutrition. You may post your questions below. Please remember that she cannot answer all questions submitted, and she cannot respond to solicitations for personal medical advice. [Eds. note: We are no longer accepting questions and comments.]

title: Davos Style | Spittin Images
description: As the World Economic Forum wraps up in Davos, Switzerland, steely-faced business leaders have been doing more than worrying about the economy and networking at fabulous events. They have been spitting. In public.

title: Reader Responses to The Age of Ambition
description: Im going to do something different with the reader responses to Nicks Sunday column about social entrepreneurs. Cyndy asked to have all the organizations that were mentioned in the comments. Ive pulled together the list with the caveat that these are the organizations mentioned by the readers and they arent groups that we necessarily endorse or recommend.

title: Bye, Bye, McMansions
description: Is the housing recession nearing an end?

title: In Shanghai, a museum dedicated to urban planning
description: By Harriet Hirshorn

title: Spitzer Is Shortchanging City, Mayor Says
description: Testifying in Albany, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today that Gov. Eliot Spitzers state budget unfairly shortchanges New York City out of millions in promised financial support for health care and education, among other things. If not reversed, he said, the broken promises could force the city to further squeeze taxpayers and deepen cuts in programs.

title: Running to Be Obamas New York Delegates
description: He ran unsuccessfully for mayor in 1997 and left the City Council at the end of that year. Since then, Sal F. Albanese has done very little in politics, outside of responding to some local candidates requests for campaign advice  and money. This year, however, Mr. Albanese is running to be a delegate for Barack Obama.Mr. Albanese is a liberal Democrat who for 15 years represented some of New York Citys most conservative neighborhoods, like Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst in Brooklyn. Since leaving the Council, he has been steeped in the world of business, and works for Mesirow Financial, a company with headquarters in Chicago.

title: Guidance
Aligning Super Bowl and Super Tuesday
description: As noted on Jan. 17, Fox News will produce two hours of politics-and-football coverage ahead of the Super Bowl next Sunday.

title: Liked Crash, the Movie? Perhaps Youll Like the Series
description: Several producers of Crash have signed on to produce a 13-episode television series based on the film, which won the Academy Award for best picture in 2004.

title: Obama, Kennedys Resonate with Youth
description: Patrick Kennedy, a representative of Rhode Island, today reminded a packed crowd at American University in Washington that the 26th Amendment that lowered the voting age from 21 to 18 came about largely through the work of his father, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.

title: The Innovators Dilemma of a Toy Maker
description: We tend to think of the innovators dilemma, a term coined by the Harvard Business school professor Clayton M. Christensen, as something that affects large companies. It refers to disruptive innovations  for example, digital photography  which existing businesses  for example, Kodak  are often reluctant to embrace because they could harm their core businesses. Its a failure that often leads to the downfall of great companies, Mr. Christensen argued in his best-selling book The Innovators Dilemma.

title: The Stallone Factor
description: Sylvester Stallone has endorsed John McCain for president. Is the fourth Rambo movie a film-length argument for a hawkish, McCain-like foreign policy? At The House Next Door, Matt Zoller Seitz says Rambo has a sharp pro-interventionist flavor: Its a Stay the Course movie, an inspirational blood-and-guts action flick whose message seems aimed equally at the portion of the American left that wants to see democracy spread, but not in this way, and that supposedly has no stomach for war; and that growing sector of the American right that views Iraq as noble crusade led by incompetents. He also writes:

title: Clinton Seeks Edge in Bayonnes War of the Volunteers
description: BAYONNE, N.J.  There is a Winston Churchill poster on the wall of the Hillary Rodham Clinton storefront campaign hub here on Broadway that portrays the prime minister proclaiming, Success is the ability to go from one failure to another with no loss of enthusiasm.

title: Wendy's New Ad Campaign
description: A new ad campaign aims to return Wendy to a place of honor.

description: Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, said that while Rudolph W. Giulianis poll numbers in the Republican presidential race are not looking so well he is sticking by his man. With the Republican primary in Florida on Tuesday, Mr. Bruno said he believes a good showing could catapult Mr. Giuliani back into the race.

description: I am thinking that we should do a different sea theme for each of the rooms, Alison mentioned apropos of absolutely nothing Saturday afternoon, as she stared at the snow clouds gathering over Duxbury, Mass.

description: A new ad campaign aims to return Wendy to a place of honor.

description: Soft Serve is a news feed of light reading. We scan newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Earth is Us
description: March 27 | Updated Some earth scientists are pushing to enshrine officially a decades-old idea  that Earth is now in a biogeochemical era of our own making that should be distinguished from the Holocene, the epoch that began with the end of the last ice age.

title: Good News in the One Million Missing iPhones
description: Wall Street analysts have begun to search the globe for 1.7 million lost iPhones.

description: In advance of tomorrows primary in Florida, two new polls there show John McCain and Mitt Romney locked in a tight race, with Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mike Huckabee vying further back for third place.

description: The International Herald Tribune's managing editor, Alison Smale, discusses events in world news.

title: Romney Campaign Criticizes Calls
description: PANAMA CITY, Fla.The Romney campaign said Monday that some of their supporters in the Miami area have begun reporting receiving automated phone calls Monday afternoon accusing Mr. Romney of wanting to re-open relations with Fidel Castros Cuba.

title: Spectrum Auctions: Billion Dollar Leapfrog
description: CORRECTED

title: Rudys Identity Crisis
description: In a political universe over-populated by second-guessers, backseat drivers and Monday morning quarterbacks, Rudy Giulianis strategic risk to sit out the first several Republican presidential primaries and focus his energy and attention on Florida has provoked an onslaught of debate. By removing himself from the national media coverage surrounding the outcomes in Iowa, New Hampshire and other early states, Mr. Giuliani also removed himself from the consciousness of Florida voters. As his poll numbers have tumbled during the last several weeks, the chorus of criticism has grown louder. By the time the polls open on Tuesday, theyll be roasting the former mayor of New York on an open fire.

title: Jazz in New York
description: Long before Lincoln Center, this neighborhood was a performing arts complex in its own right. John Strausbaugh explores.

title: All Their Ducks in a Row
description: Teemu Selanne has returned to the Ducks. He practiced with the team and will travel with the Ducks when they hit the road this week, the team reported here.

title: City Room: Primary Journal for Jan. 28
description: Monday in the New York Region: On the stump in Connecticut with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, and a visit with her volunteers in Bayonne, N.J. A closer look at the New Yorkers running to be Senator Barack Obamas delegates. A conversation with Rudolph W. Giulianis biggest fan in Albany. And an explanation of the complicated Democratic delegate system in New York.

title: A Star Under the Golden Arches?
description: Aziah Bolling is a 20 year-old cashier hoping to trade her McJob for fame and fortune, through a company singing contest.

title: A Seal Visits the Upper West Side
description: Cute is not a word normally associated with the Hudson River waterfront but when a juvenile harbor seal decided to take some sun at the 79th Street boat basin, the word sprang to mind. He was moving around pretty fine, yawning and sunning himself, said Sgt. Rakeem Taylor, an urban park ranger for the city Parks Department. Sergeant Taylor said the workers spotted the seal just before 10 a.m. The animal, which he estimated to be 3 to 4 feet long and about 90 pounds, was lying on the dock.

title: Just When You Thought It Was Safe to Answer the Phone
description: NAPLES, Fla.  In the last remaining hours until the Florida primary, residents in the state are being bombarded with phone calls and pre-recorded messages supporting one candidate or another. Over the course of six hours this weekend, one home in the predominantly Republican city of Naples received no less than eight phone calls from various presidential campaigns.

title: Recipe: Broiled Cornish Hens With Spicy Salt
description: This recipe looks like an ordinary weeknight sort of dish  after all, its just Cornish hens, salt and pepper. But it is elevated far beyond that by two simple tricks.

title: Cold Rink, Warm Hearts
description: Our colleague Michael Winerip offers up a poignant story that demonstrates in yet another way why hockey is a great game.

title: Bloggingheads: Romney and McCain
description:
Journalist Robert Wright (l) and scholar Francis Fukuyama (r) discuss the foreign policy views of the two Republican front-runners.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Indonesia Buries Suharto
description: Twenty-three hours after his death in Jakarta following a three-week hospitalization, Indonesia's former strongman, Suharto, was buried on Monday in a family mausoleum.

title: Wanted: Single or Married Adult with Online Matchmaking Story
description: Im ready to hear your online matchmaking success stories  and, of course, the horror stories, too.

title: Yogi Berra Wants a Bigger Bathroom
description: Instead of asking questions on Monday, I was one of several journalists answering questions at the Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center on the campus of Montclair State University. Malcolm Moran, a former writer at The New York Times, is now the Knight Chair in Sports Journalism and Society at Penn State. Moran asked me to partake in a panel discussion with some college students.

title: The House the (Giants) Fan Built
description: Few people may be more excited about this years Super Bowl than Peter Eisenman, the architect and football fan who designed the University of Phoenix stadium that will play host to Sundays game. Eisenman, you see, has had Giants season tickets since 1957 and was in the stands for the famed 1958 championship game against the Colts.

title: The U.K.: The Morning After
description: The party is over may be the most often used phrase to describe the state of the U.K. property market. That may sound horrible, but in the realm of operable clichs, its a long way from the sky is falling and head for the hills.

title: 60 Minutes Keeps Its Lock on Sunday Night
description: CBS and ABC shared the lead in the ratings on Sunday, with CBS attracting the most total viewers and ABC earning the highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. ABC got a lift in that demographic from a two-hour edition of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition, which drew an average of 13.6 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates.

title: Will Cholesterol Pills Save Your Life?
description: Cholesterol-lowering statin drugs are among the most popular prescription drugs in the world. In addition to lowering cholesterol, they also lower the risk for heart attacks.

title: Obama Accepts Kennedy Endorsement
description: Senator Barack Obama accepts the endorsement of Senator Edward M. Kennedy at American University. (Video: NBC)

title: Grammys Reach Deal With Writers
description: Reuters reports:

title: Kennedys Endorse Obama
description: Caroline Kennedy and Senator Edward M. Kennedy endorse Senator Barack Obama at American University. (Video: NBC)

title: The Economy in Florida
description: One of the biggest concerns in central Florida ahead of Tuesday's primary is the economy, especially the slumping housing market.

title: California: Collapse Kills Worker
description: An abandoned power plant in San Francisco collapsed during a demolition project, killing a worker and seriously injuring two others. One worker escaped with the help of co-workers and was taken to a hospital with a life-threatening leg injury, a Fire Department spokeswoman said.

title: Seattle Symphony Wins in Court
description: A state court judge in Seattle has dismissed the third and final claim of a lawsuit brought by a violinist who accused the Seattle Symphony and its music director, Gerard Schwarz, of abuse and discrimination. The violinist, Peter Kaman, charged that the orchestra had discriminated against him because of his disability  a severe anxiety disorder  and systematically harassed him. The judge, Catherine Shaffer of King County Superior Court, previously dismissed the discrimination claims and last week threw out a claim that Mr. Kaman had suffered outrageous conduct and emotional distress. Mr. Kamans lawyer, Brenda Little, said on Monday that she would file a motion for the judge to reconsider last weeks ruling; an appeal of the earlier dismissals is already pending, she said. The lawsuit was the latest chapter of turmoil in the orchestra: Mr. Schwarz has enjoyed the support of some players, several of whom have said they were targets of vandalism.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the failure of the French bank Socit Gnrale to investigate the actions of a junior trader that eventually cost the bank more than $7 billion misstated, in some copies, the volume of trades placed by the employee. It was $70 billion, not $750 billion. (Go to Article)

title: France: U2s Manager Assails Piracy
description: Saying that Internet and technology companies have for too long had a free ride on music, the veteran manager of the band U2 urged them to start sharing their enormous revenue with singers and songwriters. At the annual music industry trade show in the south of France, the manager, Paul McGuinness, blamed broadband Internet service providers in particular for allowing mass piracy of digital music over their networks while sales of recorded music and royalty payments to musicians have plunged. Global music sales have fallen to $17.6 billion last year from $38 billion in 1998, according to industry estimates. Mr. McGuinness endorsed a proposal first raised in France late last year for Internet service providers to voluntarily band together and crack down on subscribers who dominate illegal file-sharing networks.

title: Wisdom of the Web
description: It may be a little late to the game, but business travel is now the subject of a variety of blogs.

title: Power Through Delegates May Be Edwards Strategy
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  With the Democratic nominating contest building to Feb. 5, the candidates have been focusing on the crucial game of accumulating delegates, a task that has become a possible raison dtre for John Edwards.

title: Senate Panel Unveils Plan of Its Own on Economy
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Finance Committee, moving to put its own stamp on a rescue plan for the ailing economy, unveiled a $156 billion fiscal stimulus package on Monday. The plan would pay $500 to most individual tax filers and $1,000 to couples, with an additional $300 a child for families, with no income cap to disqualify high earners.

title: Finland: Nokia Buys a Software Maker
description: Nokia, a cellphone maker, said it had agreed to buy Trolltech, a Norwegian software company that makes products that create applications that work on different operating systems, for 844 million Norwegian kroner ($154 million). Nokia, based in Finland, said Trolltechs set of software development tools would allow it to create new applications compatible with the operating systems on its mobile phones. Nokias purchase of Trolltech, founded in 1994, followed its $8.1 billion acquisition in August of Navteq, an American maker of digital map data. Trolltech, based in Oslo, reported a loss of 48.7 million kroner in 2006, the last year for which full-year figures were available, on sales of 174 million kroner.

title: Doomsday for Vermin
description: Q. If I could snap my fingers and make every rat, cockroach and bedbug disappear from New York City, would that be a good thing, ecologically speaking?

title: Vengeance Reignites Kenyan City
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kisumu, Kenyas third largest city, erupted again on Monday as thousands of rioters tore through the streets, burned down stores, looted schools and vented their outrage over a spate of ethnically driven killings over the weekend.

title: Private Giving, Public Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Remembering When U.S. Finally (and Really) Joined the Space Race
description: If Sputnik 1 was the beep-beep-beep heard round the world, Explorer 1 announced itself 50 years ago this week by the collective sigh of relief from an anxious American public.

title: The Faith to Outlast Politics
description: IN his State of the Union address Monday evening, President Bush asked Congress to permanently extend the federal laws permitting religious nonprofit organizations to compete for federal grants.

title: ABC Show Will Go on, Over Protest by Doctors
