description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: City Room: Many New Yorkers Are Called to Run; Few Are Chosen
description: If former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani or Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton manages to reach the White House, either would be the first New Yorker nominated, much less elected, by a major party for president since Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in 1948  and the first to actually capture the presidency since Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.

title: An Iraq recession?
description: One thing I get asked fairly often is whether the Iraq war is responsible for our economic difficulties. The answer (with slight qualifications) is no.

title: Answers About Tenant-Landlord Issues, Part 3
description: Following is a third set of answers to readers questions selected by Lucas A. Ferrara, a partner at Finkelstein Newman Ferrara who has practiced in the landlord-tenant arena for more than two decades.

title: Check, Mate
description: Hugh Atkin, a 23-year-old Australian online humor whiz, has hit two American nails on their two heads by digitally mashing them up into one nail. Nice.

title: Memory lane
description: Remember when those of us who argued that the United States was in the midst of a serious housing bubble were ridiculed, and told that we were simply motivated by irrational Bush-hatred? Ah, memories.

title: For New York Republicans, the Winner Takes All
description: Unlike the intricate and somewhat confusing system used by New York Democrats to allocate delegates, New York Republicans use a simple winner-take-all system.

title: When Is Losing a Good Thing?
description: Is a loss ever better than a victory in basketball?

title: County Leaders Criticize Spitzers Budget
description: County leaders in both parties assailed Gov. Eliot Spitzers budget shortly after the governor addressed them at their annual conference in Albany this morning. The governor, in his remarks, said he was making the best of a bad economic situation, and said this year, there is in the budget I just proposed a net benefit of $519 million for counties.

title: Clips: Current IPO, Eli Stone, FiOS Figures
description: Current TV, the cable network co-founded by Al Gore, said Monday that it plans to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq, Dealbook reports. Nearly $37 million of the offerings proceeds will pay off debt, including $30.4 million to NBC Universal, the company said in its prospectus. Last year, Current lost $9.9 million on revenue of $63.8 million.

title: Deal or No Deal
description: The Risk Biz Blog finds eerie parallels between What Just Happened and The Deal, two star vehicles at Sundance.

title: TV Decoder, Live at the NATPE Conference
description: LAS VEGAS  The annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives, being held here this week, is where stations come to buy and producers come to sell.

title: An Embarrassment of Riches
description: Anne Thompson, poking through the tea leaves of Sundance, talked to Jonathan Dana, a knowledgeable insider, about why there was a glut of unsold films this year, and not just at Sundance.

title: $5 Million for Moussaoui: Far Too Much?
description: The State Departments awarding of a $5 million reward to one individual for information leading to the arrest of Zacarias Moussaoui, the 20th hijacker convicted of conspiring in the Sept. 11 terror plot, has attracted enough criticism to warrant an informal Lede reader poll.

title: Raymond and Family Guy Are Rare Bright Spots in Syndication Firmament
description: LAS VEGAS  The last few years have been particularly rough for syndicated television shows. Local stations that are affiliated with the major networks purchase the rights to these shows and sell advertisements against them, but those ads can be a tough sell in the absence of hit shows.

title: Waving Goodbye From a Distance
description: Director Chris Nolan spent some time in Newsweek talking about Heath Ledger, who knew his way around both a set and skateboard. Mr. Nolan writes about having Ledger very much on his mind as he cuts The Dark Knight, the Batman sequel in which the actor played the Joker.

title: In Giulianis Old Brooklyn Neighborhood, Skepticism
description: Along the quiet low-slung Brooklyn street where Rudolph W. Giuliani spent his earliest childhood years, residents express respect for his tenure as mayor, but are not optimistic about his presidential chances in the fiercely competitive primary race.

title: Morgan Stanley and the $7 Billion Unknowable
description: If you thought the fog surrounding the value of debt securities was starting to lift, think again.

title: The Envelope, Please
description: The Baguette just checked with this update on the undersung guys who, as much as anyone, make the movies magical. Robert Elswit was awarded this years top prize in the film category by the American Society of Cinematographers for his work on There Will Be Blood. Mr. Elswit also shot Michael Clayton.

title: Now Playing
description: This is a character whose one contact with a kind of para-reality is through film. Actually hes not a movie buff in the conventional sense. He doesnt really care about movies as entertainment, let alone about films as an artform. He just goes to the movie theater to touch a kind of reality he can depend on. Stanley Kauffmann, who edited The Moviegoer for Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Soft Serve | Gucci Lost In Brooklyn, Posh Undressed, Obama In Limited Edition
description: Soft Serve is a news feed of light reading. We scan newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Slashdot Founder Questions Crowds Wisdom
description: One of the oldest rivals to the community news site Digg is pointing to recent unrest at the site as evidence that the social news model is flawed.

title: Bill Clinton, in South Jersey, Doesnt Mention Obama
description: BLACKWOOD, N.J.  Nice Bill is back.

title: World Club Top 10: Ominous for Rangers Fans
description: With all the January breaks for international play and the NHL All-Star Game out of the way, we look again at the World Club Top 10 and find the topmost clubs pretty much unchanged. But there are some new faces, especially Metallurg Magnitogorsk, who won the European championship a couple of weeks ago. Theyve been on a tear in the Russian Superliga under a new coach, Fedor Kanareikin, and have moved up to second, displacing faltering SKA St. Petersburg.

title: Alfred Kazins Winesburg, Ohio
description: As a literary reporter, I spend most of my waking hours tracking people down and trying to connect the dots. Which is to say, Im a Google addict. In recent years, tons of ink has been spilled about Google  as a business model, as an intellectual phenomenon and as a way of reflecting on reading habits.

title: When 50 Percent Growth Isnt Enough
description: On Wall Street, hype cuts both ways.

title: For The Moment | Kicking It With Hiroki Nakamura
description: This weeks guest blogger is John Jay, the Executive Creative Director and Partner of the Wieden + Kennedy advertising agency which includes Nike among its clients. Now based in Portland, Ore., Jay works in Asia once a month. In addition to helping to open W+Ks Tokyo, Shanghai, Beijing and New Delhi offices, he also founded W+K Tokyo Lab (an independent DVD music label) and Studio J, a private creative consultancy in Portlands Chinatown. Jay writes a blog for Honeyee.com in Tokyo and is a contributor to magazines in Tokyo and the U.S. on creativity and pop culture, including Tokion Japan, Giant Robot, Theme and Spread magazine. In todays post, Jay meets with Hiroki Nakamura, the designer behind the Visvim brand. (For all of John Jays posts, click here)

title: Caroline Kennedy in Campaign Ads for Obama
description: Updated, 5:06 p.m. | David Plouffe, the campaign manager for Senator Barack Obama, told reporters in a conference call this afternoon that the campaign would begin showing television advertisements on Wednesday in New York  an indication that the Illinois senator intends to wage a fight to win delegates in the home state of his chief rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Jan. 29:

title: Sellers Give Negative Feedback on eBay Changes
description: EBays highly touted cut in sellers fees announced this morning is not so clearly a boon for sellers as it may appear at first look. AuctionBytes, a newsletter and blog for eBay sellers, calculated that for some scenarios, sellers actually will end up paying more than they did before. In one comparison, the fees increased by 33 percent. What is more, eBays changes to its feedback system have many sellers up in arms.

title: Forest Fire: Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
description: LAS VEGAS  Perhaps the ongoing writers strike is the forest fire the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

title: Thai Leader Vows to Revive Cooking Show
description: Emeril Lagasse, take note: heres how to get a cooking show back on the air, courtesy of Thailands new prime minister, Samak Sundaravej.

title: Obama Says It Was a Turn, Not a Snub
description: EL DORADO, Kan.  Was it the great snub beneath the Capitol Dome or a simple turn of the head?

title: Sudden Impact in Boston
description: Milan Lucic hit the Boston Bruins training camp in the fall fresh off unimaginable success in his final moments of junior hockey.

title: O Canada, Where the Writers Arent on Strike
description: As the networks search for work-arounds to find fresh material during the writers strike, CBS has hit on a novel strategy: go to countries where the writers are not striking.

title: Can a Sandwich Be Slandered?
description: Video

title: Another Skyscraper Is Planned Near Ground Zero
description: Less than a century after it soared heavenward as the worlds tallest building, the Woolworth Building  the icy Gothic pinnacle that generations of New Yorkers knew as the Cathedral of Commerce  will soon fall under the shadow of an 80-story next-door neighbor.The new 912-foot tower at 99 Church Street, designed by Robert A. M. Stern Architects for Silverstein Properties, will have a 175-room Four Seasons hotel on the first 22 floors and 143 condominium apartments in the floors above, managed by Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts. Larry A. Silverstein, the president and chief executive of Silverstein Properties, unveiled the design this morning.

title: Fire at Will: Talking to the Automobiles Editor
description: Readers of this blog may want to look at another online feature this week. James G. Cobb, automobiles editor of The Times (including the Sunday Automobiles section, the Web section and the Wheels blog), is responding to reader questions as part of the Talk to the Newsroom feature. So far, hes answered questions about advertisers and editorial independence, midsize hybrids and the proper focus of automotive journalism.

title: Rome Underground (the Catacombs!)
description: Recently, over dinner, a neighbor told me that my apartment building in Rome  indeed my entire neighborhood  is built over a series of ancient catacombs that contain the remains of tens of thousands of bodies. My first reaction was a shiver.

title: Just Browsing
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: Chow Down
description: At an all-you-can-eat banquet, 350 men consume 500 pounds of tenderloin in less than an hour.

title: Floridas Democratic Delegate Mess
description: MIAMI  What a strange situation were facing here in Florida today.

title: Clipboard: What Happens if the Patriots Lose?
description: William C. Rhoden says that the New England Patriots are the greatest professional football team in regular-season history. But we wont know until Sunday night exactly where they fit in the pantheon of N.F.L. history.

title: A Nixon Grandson Leads McCains New York Effort
description: Christopher Nixon Cox said that he and his grandfather rarely spoke about politics. Instead, he said, his conversations with the 37th president centered more on baseball.

title: Where Are Those Million iPhones? Everywhere.
description: Our readers think they have found the million unaccounted-for iPhones discussed in an earlier post  phones that were bought but then never activated on the networks of the wireless carriers that are Apples partners. They are all around the world, in many countries where Apple has not yet worked out deals with local carriers, indicating that these phones have been unlocked. A sample of some of the comments (with a little editing for punctuation):

title: What You Didnt Know About Sovereign Wealth Funds
description: Sovereign wealth funds are all the rage. But with all the talk it is hard to separate out the truth from the fiction. Here is a guide to the burning questions surrounding these phenomena.

title: Ratings: State of the Union Down, ABC News Up
description: Because of last nights State of the Union address, final ratings data will not be issued by Nielsen until late on Tuesday, but overnight estimates suggest that ratings for the presidents speech may be down considerably from a year ago. Then again, one difference last year was that Fox broadcast American Idol in the hour preceding the speech, which could have given President Bush a ratings bump.

title: Youth Activists Defend Generation
description: Todays youth are not apathetic, they arent dazzled by celebrity politicians and they do care about substantive issues.

title: Unrest Escalates in Kenya
Slide Show: Florida Primary
description: Republican candidates made last minute appearances to rally supporters in the hotly-contested Florida primary, where the turnout is expected to be high.

title: The Sex of Your Surgeon May Matter
description: Whether a woman receives radiation treatment after breast cancer surgery may be influenced by the gender of her surgeon, according to a new report from The Journal of the National Cancer Institute.

title: Excited Volunteers Greet Obama Team in Queens
description: The hook that Mike Griffin uses with would-be volunteers is pretty much fail-safe. I ask them, he said Tuesday, can you give me one hour to help change the world?

title: Walnut Tart
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes pecan pie -- with walnuts.

title: Bush Logic: The State of The Union & Telecom Immunity
description: President Bushs State of the Union address last night was not only uninspiring, full of bad ideas, and short on prescriptions for the serious problems facing the country. It was also packed with faulty logic  the sort that has made reasoned debate with this administration so difficult.

title: Pouring Over the Border
description: The old rule about matching foods with wines of the same region is a truism  always useful when youre dealing with cuisines from winemaking regions but often limiting. For a case in point, I offer up my dinner Sunday night, where I relearned this lesson in a most pleasant way.

title: The Satisfaction of Saying That They Tried
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: John Edwardss New York Strategy (Yes, There Is One)
description: In New York, it is easy to feel a little outnumbered if youre trying to be a delegate for John Edwards. As Marc A. Landis, a lawyer from Manhattan who is on the ballot to be an Edwards delegate in the 8th Congressional District, put it, Look, this is the kind of thing you do in politics as a labor of love.

title: False Alert: About.Com Is Not for Sale
description: Speculation emerged Tuesday afternoon that The New York Times Company had put About.com up for sale. A report from Silicon Alley Insider said The Times had hired an unnamed bank and was shopping the digital unit, which it estimated was worth as much as $600 million. However, people close to the company  and were well placed  flatly denied the report.

title: Clinton Booked On Letterman
description: Democrat Hillary Rodham Clinton will yuk it up on CBSs Late Show with David Letterman on Monday, a day before the Feb. 5 Super Tuesday contests, the Associated Press notes.

title: Films for Short Attention Spans
description: The Oscar-nominated short films dont get noticed much, maybe because few moviegoers get the chance to see them. But as the Baguette notes, a good short can launch a career. Take the Irish playwright Martin McDonagh. He won an Oscar in 2006 for a short called Six Shooter, and this year In Bruges, his first feature, which Mr. McDonagh wrote and directed, had its premiere at Sundance and will open in New York and L.A. on Feb. 8.

title: Psst.  Wanna Buy a House?
description: Wall Street keeps bidding up the prices of homebuilding stocks, secure in the belief that the bottom is nigh. The S&P 1500 homebuilder index is up 48 percent from its low earlier this month.

title: A Giants-Patriots Bet: Go Easy on the Cheese
description: With all the spontaneity of a summit conference, the mayors of New York and Boston have announced their friendly wager on the Super Bowl. If the Giants emerge victorious on Sunday night, City Hall is due to receive a veritable grocery aisle from One City Hall Plaza in Boston. Should the New England Patriots win to complete their undefeated season, a similar collection of goodies will head north from Manhattan. Here are the details of the wager:

title: Romney Entourage Sightings
description: TAMPA  A few items of note from Mitt Romneys morning event, in which he fought through a hoarse voice to address up about 150 supporters:

title: Keeping Predators Away From Spacebook
description: In a bipartisan effort to keep sexual predators from trolling social networking sites like MySpace and Facebook, lawmakers have drafted a bill that would track the e-mail addresses of serious sex offenders and restrict their use of the Internet.The bill was announced this afternoon and promised a bridging of the technological gap between young and old. We have to admit that life is different than when we were growing up, said Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol. We have to have educational programs so that parents know about MySpace and Spacebook and

title: In Fla., McCain Outspends Romney on TV Lately
description: TAMPA  Senator John McCain appears to have slightly outspent Mitt Romney, with Rudolph W. Giuliani lagging significantly behind, in television advertising in Florida in the week leading up to the Republican primary here, according to newly released data from the Campaign Media Advisory Group, which estimates ad spending.

title: Ex-Bayou C.F.O. Gets 20-Year Prison Sentence
description: The former chief financial officer of the hedge fund Bayou Group was sentenced to 20 years in prison Tuesday for his role in a scheme that defrauded investors of $450 million and led to the funds collapse.

title: Yahoo Will Cut 1,000 Jobs
description: The punch line in Yahoos droning conference call came 40 minutes in. After Jerry Yang, the chief executive, and Sue Decker, the No. 2 exec, spoke about the companys goals in terms worthy of career bureaucrats, Blake Jorgensen, the chief financial officer, got to the meat.

title: Clinton Aspires to be an Amiga
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton puckers up to kiss a Latina toddler against a soundtrack of salsa music in her latest Spanish-language TV ad, now showing in Super Tuesday states Arizona, California, Connecticut and New York.

title: In Las Vegas, a Beauty Contest for Game Shows
description: Howie Mandel will host the syndicated version of Deal or No Deal. (NBC/2005)

title: Navy Aims to Break Record With Next Test of Railgun
description: What is the electromagnetic railgun?, the Navy asks in a news release today. In a word, innovation.

title: Obamas New Ads in the Big States
description: In a sign of the overarching importance of paid media in Feb. 5 strategies, Senator Barack Obamas campaign is out with a flurry of new ads.

title: New Hampshire is Not Amused
description: The editorial page of New Hampshires Union Leader is, shall we say, irked by Hillary Clintons decision to attend a rally tonight in Florida, which is holding a beauty contest primary for the Democrats (no delegates will be awarded) in addition to a Republican primary.

title: Near Clintons Home, the Latest Major Event
description: WHITE PLAINS  Clinton Campaign Launches Major Central New York Effort. Clinton Campaign Launches Major Broome County Effort. Clinton Campaign Launches Major Effort in Westchester County.

title: Bill Clinton Draws Hundreds in Ohio
description: CLEVELAND  Bill Clinton stuck to the script on Tuesday during a rally at a community college near Cleveland, keeping the focus on his wife and steering clear of any fresh remarks about Senator Barack Obama.

title: Live-Blogging the Sunshine Primary
description: 10:39 p.m. | The Last Word From our reporters in the field, heres what we know  just at this moment and were sure therell be more to come: Mr. Giulianis campaign and the McCain camp have been in talks about a possible endorsement. It will likely happen later this week. Could we suggest tomorrow?

title: The Repeater
description: Heres an evolutionists dream: 10,000 planet Earths, starting from the same point at the same time, and left to their own devices for four and a half billion years. What would happen? Could you go on safari from one planet to the next seeing an endless procession of wildly different organisms? Or would many of the planets be home to life forms that are broadly similar?

title: Many Are Already at Work on Fulfilling Gatess Vision
description: Bill Gatess bold Davos challenge to the worlds capitalists last week should have come with equally bold footnotes.

title: A One-Woman Man With a Zen-like Approach to Life
description: The New England Patriots were very business-like and reserved in their approach to media day.

title: Undecided in New York
description: Kelle Jacob, a first-time voter, and her friends share their perceptions of the Democratic candidates. And sashimi.

title: Kenyan Politician Assassinated
description: A popular parliament member was gunned down outside his home in Nairobi, sparking clashes between mourners and police.

title: Waiting Out the Rain
De Savary Sells Abaco Interest
description: British entrepreneur Peter de Savary has sold his percentage in the Abaco Club on Winding Bay, the seminal resort and residential project he developed in the Bahamas with Ritz Carlton.

title: Yanks Step Back From the Brink and Watch Santana Go to the Mets
description: Resisting the temptation to trade for Johan Santana may be the surest sign weve seen that the Yankees are operating differently now. Even as late as Tuesday afternoon, when the Mets were finishing off their deal with the Twins - which is contingent on Santana agreeing to a contract extension - some insiders believed the Yankees could pounce in the final moments.

title: A Giants-Patriots Bet: Go Easy on the Cheese
description: John Sullivan writes on the City Room blog:

title: Media Day: Your Virtual News Conference
description: With Super Bowl XLII five days away, the N.Y. Giants and New England Patriots made players and coaches available to the news media Tuesday at University of Phoenix Stadium to answer questions. Questions about the game, their lives and the experience of preparing for the big game. Some of the answers were cliche. Others funny. A few were insightful.

title: Once Again, a Legit Nominee
description: At the 11th hour, members of the executive committee of the music branch of the Academy met and decided that in spite of some questions about the validity of Falling Slowly, a nominee for best song from the movie Once, the song was eligible and would be on ballots that shipped tomorrow morning. Charles Bernstein, chairman of the music branch executive committee, speaking to the Bagger by phone, read part of the committees statement on the matter:

title: Voter Profile: John Weiss
description: Meet John Weiss, a police officer and Iraq veteran, and an independent voter from Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.

title: Schieffer To Retire Next January
description: Bob Schieffer, a reporter for CBS News for nearly four decades and the host of Face the Nation for 17 years, said on Tuesday that he would retire next January, as a new president moves into the White House and he nears his 72nd birthday.

title: McCains Florida Win: What It Means
description: Three instant reactions to John McCains victory in Florida:

title: Forever Young
description: The Associated Press has a report of actress Sean Young checking into rehab , while the Hollywood Reporter has a video of director Julian Schnabel at the Directors Guild Awards, attempting to make his speech over Ms. Youngs heckling.

title: The Florida Primary
description: Senator John McCain won the biggest delegate prize so far in a closely contested primary.

title: Eating Meat: Is It Killing Us, and the Planet?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Year Into Job, WNET President Seeks a Heightened Urgency
description: When Neal Shapiro, president of the New York public television station WNET, Channel 13, heard about the Virginia Tech massacre in April, he reacted like the former NBC News president that he is: he wanted the station to produce a documentary about teenage rage and mental illness. Right away.

title: Feds Issue on Rates: How Low?
description: WASHINGTON  Having stunned investors one week ago by unexpectedly slashing short-term interest rates, the Federal Reserve appears poised to announce another rate cut on Wednesday as insurance against a recession.

title: Dip Once or Dip Twice?
description: OUR annual national snacking binge is almost here. It would take a very large bowl indeed to hold all the guacamole mashed from the more than 100 million avocados that are consumed on Super Bowl Sunday. (My rough calculation gives a hemisphere bowl 20 yards in diameter and 3 times the height of the goal post crossbars.) And guacamole is just one of many dips that will be shared around the TV.

title: Restoring Civil Rights
description: In recent decades, and to much public acclaim, Congress passed a series of landmark laws designed to ensure equal rights for all Americans. Lately, and without much notice, the Supreme Court has been gutting them.

title: Two More G.O.P. Congressmen Wont Run
description: Two Republican representatives, Kenny Hulshof of Missouri and Ron Lewis of Kentucky, have announced plans to leave Congress, adding their names to a list of more than 24 House Republicans who will not be running for re-election. Mr. Hulshof, 49, who is in his sixth term in the House, is leaving Congress to run for governor of Missouri. Mr. Lewis, 61, who is completing his eighth term, said he was resigning to concentrate on his family.

title: Amazons Profit More Than Doubles
description: For Amazon.com, the fourth quarter was even sweeter than usual. But Wall Street reacted negatively because profit margins slid slightly.

title: Seeing Red Over Hillary
description: WASHINGTON

title: Where Everyone, and Anything, Goes
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  A rope barred the walkway leading to the field at University of Phoenix Stadium on Tuesday morning. Reporters and camera operators strained behind it, fingers sticky from free pastries offered as they waited for the clock above the field to read 9:45 a.m.

title: Foreign Retailers Follow Their Shoppers to New York
description: New Yorks chic shopping districts seem to be teeming these days with foreign tourists, particularly Europeans, who have flown over to take advantage of the weak dollar. Less noticeable, perhaps, is the spate of new foreign shops. But brokers say that foreign retailers are also spending lavishly in New York.

title: Special Flavor: The Big Rhubarb
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Forgery Sentence
description: An 84-year-old man whose family forged statues and paintings that were sold to museums including the Art Institute of Chicago received a two-year suspended sentence in London on Monday, The Associated Press reported. The man, George Greenhalgh, right; his wife, Olive, 83; and their son, Shaun, 46, pleaded guilty in 2002 to laundering money from the sale of forged artworks. In November a sentence of more than four years was imposed on Shaun, described by the authorities as the creator of fakes that supposedly ranged across the millennia, from gold and silver Roman and Anglo-Saxon works to sculptures attributed to Paul Gauguin and Henry Moore. Mrs. Greenhalgh received a one-year sentence. The police said the parents handled most of the sales. Detective Sgt. Vernon Rapley, chief of Scotland Yards art and antiques unit, said there was little doubt that some of the familys forgeries were still circulating in the art world.

title: Research Groups Boom in Washington
On Senator Kennedys Endorsement of Obama
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Truman Daniel, Presidents Daughter and Popular Author, Dies at 83
Penguins Try to Stay in the Race Without Crosby
description: NEWARK  Like the waiting room at a train station, a visitors dressing room is a place to get in and get out. But the Pittsburgh Penguins made themselves at home on Tuesday at Prudential Center, covering the walls with logos and laying a rug on the floor.

title: On a Day of Talk, Burresss Words Anger Giants Coach
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  In training camp six months ago, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin unveiled the seasons theme and had it printed on T-shirts: Talk is cheap. Play the game.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about a disabled American spy satellite that is likely to plunge to earth by late February or early March referred imprecisely to Jonathan McDowell, an astronomer at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics who said it was fairly common for satellites to drop out of orbit. He is an analyst of various government space programs; he does not work for the government as an analyst of space programs.

title: Financial Ties Are Cited as Issue in Spine Study
description: Some of the nations most prominent spine surgeons hailed it as a medical breakthrough.

title: Village Wants to Keep Its Fields as They Are
description: Mellora Ansbro plays soccer for the Gotham girls team on the huge green fields within Pier 40, where city noises and river winds seem as remote as the Holland America Line ships that once pulled up alongside.

title: Would-Be Peacemaker Killed in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Melitus Mugabe Were, a freshman member of Parliament, could have been one of the keys to unlocking Kenyas crisis, but he never got the chance.

title: Rule Change to Help Smaller Companies Raise Funds
description: Federal regulators are about to ease rules that have made it difficult for small and medium-size publicly traded companies to raise money. The changes, experts say, are well timed, given the tightening credit market.

title: Memorial Planned for Barbaro
description: Barbaro, who won the 2006 Kentucky Derby and broke down two weeks later at the Preakness, will have his ashes interred at Churchill Downs. He was euthanized Jan. 29, 2007. The site will include a bronze statue commissioned by Barbaros owners, Roy and Gretchen Jackson. The statue will be loaned to the track.

title: New Hijuelos Books
description: Oscar Hijuelos plans a companion novel to his 1990 Pulitzer Prize winner, The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love, as well as a memoir that will recall his encounters with musicians including Rubn Blades and Lou Reed, The Associated Press reported. The new novel, Beautiful Maria of My Soul, and the memoir, Thoughts Without Cigarettes, were announced jointly on Tuesday by Hyperion Books, which will publish the novel in 2009, and Gotham Books, a Penguin Group (USA) imprint, which will release the memoir in 2010.

title: Diva Back in Damascus
description: Singing in Damascus for the first time in more than 20 years, the Lebanese diva Fairuz, 73, electrified an audience that included Vice President Farouq al-Shara on Monday night as that Syrian capital celebrated its designation as Arab Capital of Culture 2008, Agence France-Presse reported. Fairuz, above, widely considered the greatest Arab singer after the death of Umm Kalthoum in 1975, is to give eight concerts, all sold out.

title: More Testing of Seafood to Address Mercury Concerns
description: A NUMBER of restaurants and retailers in different parts of the country have started testing the fish they sell in response to concerns about the amount of mercury in seafood, and the Environmental Protection Agency is beginning to examine the mercury content in fish sold in the New York City region.

title: At White House, a Second Look at Iraq Troop Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Four months after announcing troop reductions in Iraq, President Bush is now sending signals that the cuts may not continue past this summer, a development likely to infuriate Democrats and renew concerns among military planners about strains on the force.

title: 3 More Airlines Cite Fuel Costs for Losses
description: Three airlines  Northwest, JetBlue and AirTran Holdings  posted fourth-quarter losses on Tuesday as rising fuel costs erased gains from fare increases.

title: Seeking a Change, but Finding Few Choices
description: COLUMBIA, Tenn.  The domed courthouse clock tower tolls the hour, but not much else breaks the stillness in this centuries-old county seat where politics seems to have reached equilibrium, balanced between ancient Democratic traditions and newer Republican ones.

title: Editors Note
description: A letter yesterday about Caroline Kennedys Op-Ed article endorsing Barack Obama was published under a false name. The writer was Joan Sommers, not Maggie Atwood.

title: Bernankes Midterm Tests
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve has come to seem a bit like a Supreme Court justice  an unelected, unaccountable figure who wields power for years, regardless of whos in the White House.

title: For Giuliani, Opening Note Stayed True
description: On his way to school one morning, a 13-year-old boy was knocked down by a cab outside his home on East 86th Street in Manhattan. The first ambulance arrived in six minutes. The boy was conscious. He had a small cut on his head. His leg hurt. With a supervisor steadying the boys head, the medics moved him onto a backboard, and then into the rear of the ambulance.

title: Georgia: Troubled Hospitals Leader Quits
description: The chief executive of Grady Memorial Hospital, Otis L. Story Sr., has resigned, ending a brief stint as the troubled hospitals fourth C.E.O. since 2000. The public hospital, which handles a million patient visits a year and is one of the nations largest safety-net health providers, is millions of dollars in debt, needs more than $350 million in capital improvements and has faced steep drops in state and federal assistance. Mr. Storys resignation came one day after the hospital board approved an agreement to lease the hospital to a new nonprofit corporation, a move board members hope will streamline costs and attract new government and philanthropic money.

title: Kidd Shows Nets How Much They Could Soon Be Missing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets nine-game losing streak ended Tuesday night, thanks in part to the play of Jason Kidd over the final two minutes. But how much longer the Nets can count on him to bail them out of tough spots remained uncertain after their 87-80 victory over Milwaukee.

title: Germany: Lufthansa in Deal With Pilots
description: Deutsche Lufthansa, the German airline, reached an 18-month contract agreement with pilots to avoid further strikes. The airlines 4,400 pilots will receive a 2.5 percent raise retroactive to Oct. 1 and an additional 3 percent increase retroactive to Jan. 1, Lufthansa said. The agreement runs through March 2009 and includes a one-time payment equal to 25 percent of a months wages.

title: Drag Queen Who Reminisces About Her Drunken Family
description: Early in Sisters, Such Devoted Sisters, a crudely effective solo portrait of the seedy gay underworld in Glasgow, Russell Barr, the author and performer who portrays an angry, bruised drag queen, says that when he was young he accidentally cut off half his thumb.

title: Super Bowl Game Balls: The Pride of Ada, Ohio
description: ADA, Ohio  The calls come in every year, right before the N.F.L.s conference championship games, and when they do, Peg Price tries not to laugh.

title: Bushs Last State of the Union Address
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Criticizes Envoy Over Iran
description: WASHINGTON  White House officials expressed anger on Tuesday about an appearance in which the United States ambassador to the United Nations, Zalmay Khalilzad, sat beside the Iranian foreign minister at a panel of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Saturday.

title: A Lovefest, if Misery Loves Company
description: Pain, alienation and the thousand varieties of loneliness that flesh is heir to: these are the topics that Abi Morgans Tender, a British play being given its New York premiere by Thirteenth Night Theater, means to address. The action has been moved to New York from London, but misery trumps geography  these characters would be unhappy anywhere.

title: Calendar
description: Simply Chocolate

title: Imus Closer to a Return to TV in Big Cities
description: Viewers in Washington, D.C., Boston, Chicago and San Francisco, among other big cities, moved a step closer on Wednesday to being able to see a simulcast of Don Imuss morning radio show on television.

title: Beirut, On and Off the Radar
description: IN addition to its considerable charms, intermittent disappointments and svelte-letter palindrome of a name, the new restaurant Ilili presents a case study: how do you try to turn a medium-profile cuisine into a big-time event?

title: Fed Reduces Rate by Half-Point; 2nd Cut in 8 Days
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve reduced short-term interest rates on Wednesday for the second time in eight days, meeting widespread expectations by investors on Wall Street for a big rate cut.

title: Pressure Mounts for Resignation at French Bank
description: PARIS  Senior politicians here increased calls for the resignation of top executives at Socit Gnrale, ahead of the boards regular meeting, scheduled for early Wednesday.

title: In the South Bronx, Robotics and Rebirth
description: At the end of a distinctly pugilistic day of sixth grade, Abdoulie Lemon was escorted by a dean to the industrial-arts classroom that doubled as the detention pen. No sooner had he restlessly settled into his chair than he caught sight of a dozen students gathered in rapt attention around a table at the other end of the room.

title: Dining Briefs
description: NEW PLACES

title: For a Change, New Jerseys Primary Is at the Storms Center
description: BLACKWOOD, N.J.  From the spectacle of a visit by a former president to the buzz of informal gatherings in living rooms and coffee shops across New Jersey, Democrats find themselves in a competitive Democratic presidential primary for the first time in a generation.

title: Knicks Cant Keep Up With Kobe and the Lakers
description: LOS ANGELES  Isiah Thomas did not need to see Kobe Bryant orchestrate a fourth-quarter comeback and a near triple-double to endorse his candidacy for most valuable player. He got that out of the way on Monday, about 36 hours before the Knicks had to actually cope with Bryant.

title: Good Times for Some
description: To the Editor:

title: Big-Selling Drugs Aid Lilly Profit
description: INDIANAPOLIS (AP)  Strong sales from several drugs helped Eli Lilly & Company post a higher-than-expected fourth-quarter profit.

title: Professor From Harvard to Be Barnard President
description: Barnard College has named as its next president Debora L. Spar, a Harvard Business School professor who has written about the economics of the human fertility industry and the evolution of the Internet but has not previously been affiliated with a womens college.

title: Canada: Cold Weather Shuts Down Oil Project
description: Extreme temperatures have frozen equipment and forced a shutdown at Syncrude Canada, the oil sands project. Most of the 350,000 barrels of oil produced daily at the project are sent to the United States. But temperatures in northern Alberta, where Syncrude is located, have dipped below minus 40 degrees at night this week. That has led to several instrument freeze-ups, the Canadian Oil Sands Trust, which owns about 37 percent of the project, said on Tuesday. Full production will probably not resume for several days.

title: Nigeria Tops Benin to Advance
description: John Obi Mikel and Yakubu Aiyegbeni scored to lead Nigeria over Benin, 2-0, on Tuesday in Sekondi, Ghana, and into the quarterfinals of the African Cup of Nations. Ivory Coast (3-0), which already was assured of advancing, defeated Mali, 3-0. Ivory Coast won Group B and will play the Group A runner-up, Guinea, on Sunday. Nigeria (1-1-1) will meet host Ghana.

title: It All Comes Down to (or Looks Up to) Bach
description: The jingling piano, the humming traffic and the prancing horse tap out separate if connecting songs in the beguiling nonnarrative film The Silence Before Bach, from the septuagenarian Spanish auteur Pere Portabella. You could say that these three make beautiful music together, though this observation doesnt capture the contrapuntal complexity of the film, which unfolds note against note, scene against scene.

title: North Carolina: Arrest Warrant for Marine
description: An arrest warrant has been issued in Mexico for a marine wanted in North Carolina for killing a fellow marine who had accused him of rape, said an official at the United States Embassy in Mexico City. The marine, Cpl. Cesar Laurean, 21, a naturalized United States citizen, was spotted visiting relatives in Guadalajara earlier this month. The warrant has been issued for the purposes of extradition, officials said. Corporal Laurean is accused of killing Lance Cpl. Maria Lauterbach and burying her remains in a fire pit in his backyard sometime in mid-December. She was eight months pregnant when she died. It remains unclear if Corporal Laurean was the father. Both marines were stationed at Camp Lejeune.

title: Tropical Teaser: Lost Clues Decoded
description: Here is the problem for ABC: In Lost it has the show with perhaps the most compelling continuing story line in television history, one whose resumption this week has been hotly anticipated by its devoted fans.

title: Recipe: Roasted Delicata Squash Pure
description: Adapted from North Pond, ChicagoTime: About 1 hour 15 minutes (depending on size of squash)

title: Italian Style Is Refracted Through a Chinese Lens
description: In one of the stranger acts of globalism, the Chinese are writing Italian operas. Xiao Bais Farewell My Concubine from the China National Opera House is touring the United States and came semistaged to Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night.

title: Profit Drops at Dow Chemical
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. (AP)  The nations largest chemical company, Dow Chemical, said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 52 percent because of an overhaul effort and a $1.7 billion jump in spending on materials and energy.

title: Clinton Wins in Florida, but Without Any Delegates to Sweeten the Victory
description: MIAMI  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won the Florida Democratic primary on Tuesday, a contest that generated extraordinary voter interest even though the result will have no practical impact because no delegates were at stake.

title: Lilly in Settlement Talks With U.S.
description: Eli Lilly and federal prosecutors are discussing a settlement of a civil and criminal investigation into the companys marketing of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa that could result in Lillys paying more than $1 billion to federal and state governments.

title: Britain: Guilty Plea in Plot to Behead Soldier
description: A 37-year-old man from Birmingham, in the English midlands, has pleaded guilty to plotting to behead a British soldier. Parviz Khan, who described himself to investigators as a Muslim charity worker, was heard in covert recordings made by Britains security services outlining a plan to kidnap a soldier from Birminghams nightclub district and have him beheaded, the court in Leicester was told. Nigel Rumfitt, the prosecutor, said Mr. Khans plan was to videotape the killing and release the tape to cause panic and fear within the British armed forces and wider public. Three other men, all Muslims, have admitted offenses in the case, one of them a Gambian citizen tasked by Mr. Khan to identify a Muslim West African soldier serving in the British Army as the victim for the beheading plot, according to the prosecution. Mr. Khan was said to have shown the other men videos of terrorist beheadings in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $6,987,843

title: Beyond Banks $7 Billion Loss, Fear of More
description: LONDON  Jrme Kerviels 4.8 billion euro trading loss ($7.1 billion) had a positive effect for Socit Gnrale, at least temporarily.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about residents of Marthas Vineyard, Mass., who get most of their food in winter from the islands farms, omitted a description about a protest that residents mounted regarding a 43-acre farm that had been leased to the islands Community Sponsored Agriculture program. The protest was an attempt to keep the property from being sold to become a horse farm.

title: Roddick and Blake in Cup Lineup
description: Andy Roddick and James Blake will lead the defending champion United States against Austria in the first round of the Davis Cup in Vienna on Feb. 8-10.

title: Costa Rica: Delay in Trade Agreement Sought
description: President scar Arias of Costa Rica, below, said he would ask the United States to delay the start of a free-trade agreement to give the country time to pass several local laws. Costa Rica approved the Central American Free Trade Agreement in October, but its Congress has passed only 4 of 13 laws necessary to begin it, Mr. Arias said. The deadline for doing so is Feb. 29 and Mr. Arias acknowledged that his administration would not be ready by that date. The pact has already taken effect in the Dominican Republic, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador.

title: Stimulus Plan Advances
description: The Senate Finance Committee is set to produce an economic stimulus bill that, on balance, improves on the bill passed by the House on Tuesday. Among other things, the Senate version would extend unemployment benefits as needed for laid-off workers.

title: Coach Follows Dream to Footballs Summit
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  He knew early on what his happiest days would look like, rising before the sun when he was 4 years old to be with his father at football practice at a high school in Canton, Ohio. Thom McDaniels is an Ohio coaching legend; Josh McDaniels wanted to be a coach  a high school coach  just like him.

title: Some Quirky Drills for Gritty Players
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  No two practices ever seem the same for the Giants tight ends, not with their coach thumbing through his file of 430 practice drills, all of them specific to tight ends and some of them downright peculiar.

title: Sensor Deprivation
description: AT the suggestion of the federal Department of Homeland Security, New York City Council members have drafted legislation requiring anyone who has or uses a detector that measures chemical, biological or radioactive agents to get a license from the Police Department.

title: Brief Extension for Eavesdropping Law
description: Congress approved a 15-day extension of the governments authority to eavesdrop on suspected terrorists to give lawmakers more time to consider permanent legislation. President Bush has threatened to veto a 30-day extension of the surveillance law that Democrats favor. The current law expires Friday, and Democrats and Republicans agreed on the 15-day measure. The Senate rejected Mr. Bushs demand for quick passage of a permanent extension of the law.

title: Festivals to Lead Carnegies Season
description: Phrases from spirituals floated softly from the podium. Plenty good room, good room, in my Fathers kingdom, Jessye Norman sang on Tuesday in a reception space at Carnegie Hall.

title: Pouring of Concrete at High-Rise Sites Is Choreographed Like Ballet in Sky
description: The trucks navigate a cumbersome stop-and-go route on the chaotic streets of New York. The workers  dozens of them simultaneously  move with precision, nailing wood, twisting metal reinforcements, smoothing cement and climbing narrow wooden frames on cue, hundreds of feet in the air, sometimes in the face of swirling winds. Neighboring high rises often sit a cranes whip away.

title: Oh, Yugoslavia! How They Long for Your Firm Embrace
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia  This spring, Bostjan Troha and 50 of his friends from across the former Yugoslavia plan to celebrate the official 116th birthday of the former dictator Josip Broz Tito with a pilgrimage in boxy Yugoslav-era Fico cars to Titos Croatian birthplace and his marble tomb in Belgrade.

title: Jury to Start Deliberations in Wesley Snipes Tax Case
description: OCALA, Fla.  The most prominent tax prosecution in nearly two decades went to the jury Tuesday after defense lawyers argued that while a defendant, the actor Wesley Snipes, did in fact owe tens of millions of dollars in back taxes, interest and penalties, he had not committed a crime.

title: Subpoenas Over Fraudulent Drug Data
description: A Congressional subcommittee voted to subpoena former and current Food and Drug Administration investigators to testify about fraudulent clinical data that supported approval of the antibiotic drug Ketek. Ketek was approved in 2004. It is manufactured by Sanofi Aventis. Last February, after getting reports of liver failure in some patients treated with the drug, the F.D.A. issued its sternest warning and restricted use to patients with pneumonia. The four people subpoenaed had conducted their own inquiry in connection with Keteks approval.

title: Learning to Mix Business With Art
description: Hospital administrators usually do not find themselves offering advice or encouragement to art museum curators. But in an elegant Upper East Side town house the other day, Harold E. Varmus, the Nobel laureate and president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, told a group of prestigious curators something that made several gasp audibly.

title: A Pilgrimage in India Timed by a Taxi Meter
description: The title characters in Three Travelers, a comedy by Richard Abrons, arent lost, but the actors playing them seem to be. And that costs the production, staged by the New Federal Theater under the direction of Jay Broad, a lot of its punch.

title: Overhaul, Make It a Venti
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.When a Starbucks moved in next door, the coffee fanatics who run the Broadway Cafe trembled. Sure, they roasted their own beans and served up handmade espresso drinks to a loyal clientele. But would it be enough to fight off a corporate behemoth?

title: Italy: Sales Rise at Eyeglass Maker
description: The Luxottica Group, the Italian maker of eyeglasses, said fourth-quarter sales rose 7.1 percent after last years acquisition of Oakley. Revenue at the company, which operates Sunglass Hut and LensCrafter stores and makes Ray-Ban sunglasses, climbed to 1.19 billion euros ($1.8 billion) from 1.11 billion euros a year earlier. Fourth-quarter wholesale sales rose 16 percent to 479 million euros ($705 million). Sales fell 1.7 percent at retail stores open at least a year, reflecting Luxotticas exposure in the United States. Luxottica bought Oakley for $2 billion in June.

title: Starbucks Scales Back U.S. Expansion
description: As it begins a major turnaround effort, Starbucks on Wednesday announced a slight gain in quarterly profits and a significant slowdown in the rate of growth in the United States as it seeks to recapture its former glory.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening this Week

title: McCain Defeats Romney in Florida Vote
description: MIAMI  Senator John McCain defeated Mitt Romney on Tuesday to win the delegate-rich Florida primary, solidifying his transformation to the Republican front-runner and dealing a devastating blow to the presidential hopes of Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: DeCamp Bus Line No. 66 From the Port Authority to Upper Montclair, N.J.
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: Recipe: Braised Kale
description: Adapted from North Pond, Chicago

title: Dissidents Arrest Hints at Olympic Crackdown
description: BEIJING  When state security agents burst into his apartment last month, Hu Jia was chatting on Skype, the Internet-based telephone system. Mr. Hus computer was his most potent tool. He disseminated information about human rights cases, peasant protests and other politically touchy topics even though he often lived under de facto house arrest.

title: Kicking Democracys Corpse in Russia
description: Look into the eyes of Vladimir Putin, the president of Russia, and what you see is a K.G.B.-trained mind that apparently cannot tolerate leaving any detail of an election to chance.

title: One Pot
description: A COCIDO, a soulful, slow-cooked stew of tender chickpeas, bacon, spareribs and chorizo, is an ancient Spanish dish.

title: What You Get for... $12.5 Million
description: Water Mill, N.Y.

title: Wal-Mart Will Shake Up Apparel Unit; Layoffs Set
description: In a major revamping of its sluggish clothing business, Wal-Mart Stores will shut two divisions at its headquarters in Arkansas, eliminate dozens of positions and move dozens more to New York City.

title: Doctor Accused of Leak to Drug Maker
description: A key member of the Senate said Wednesday that a prominent diabetes expert leaked an unpublished and confidential medical journal article to GlaxoSmithKline last year, tipping the company to the imminent publication of safety questions involving the companys diabetes drug Avandia.

title: Down on the Farm and Up in Washington, Hoyas Wallace Excels
description: WASHINGTON  When Georgetown point guard Jonathan Wallace was in elementary school, he worked on his familys 80-acre cattle farm in Harvest, Ala.

title: S.& P. Home Price Index Continued to Fall in November
description: Home prices in 20 metropolitan areas fell in November for the 11th consecutive month, as foreclosures and a slump in sales added to the glut of unsold properties.

title: Thomas Barr, Top Lawyer in I.B.M. Case, Dies at 77
description: Thomas D. Barr, a formidable lawyer whose tenacity and discipline helped transform the way major corporate litigation is conducted, died Thursday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 77.

title: A Long Surrender: The Guerrilla War After the Civil War
description: In April 1865 Robert E. Lee surrendered to Ulysses S. Grant, putting an end to four years of savage internecine conflict and settling the issue of slavery forever. The war is over, Grant said. The rebels are our countrymen again.

title: Pettitte Deposition Postponed
description: WASHINGTON  The House oversight committee has postponed a deposition of Andy Pettitte as part of its investigation into Roger Clemenss denials that he used performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Pettitte Will Discuss Clemens, Lawyers Say
description: WASHINGTON Andy Pettitte will soon give a sworn deposition to staff members of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and lawyers for his former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, say they believe they know part of what he will say.

title: Iran Executes Bribery Convict
description: TEHRAN  Irans judiciary has executed an airport customs contractor accused of bribe-taking and other corruption and has sentenced three other airport employees to death, the Iranian news agency ISNA reported Tuesday.

title: Bill Would Bar Sex Offenders From Facebook and MySpace
description: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo and state lawmakers, with the backing of the social networking sites MySpace and Facebook, are pushing a bill that would crack down on sex offenders use of the sites.

title: Bomb Explodes Near U.S. Patrol in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide car bomb exploded near an American patrol in the northern city of Mosul on Tuesday, a day after Sunni Arab guerrillas killed five American soldiers during an ambush on a convoy in Mosul.

title: Police Shooting of Mother and Infant Exposes a Citys Racial Tension
description: LIMA, Ohio  The air of Southside is foul-smelling and thick, filled with fumes from an oil refinery and diesel smoke from a train yard, with talk of riot and recrimination, and with angry questions: Why is Tarika Wilson dead? Why did the police shoot her baby?

title: Lawmakers Say Mattel Broke Word on Lead
description: Dozens of members of Congress sent a letter Tuesday to the chief executive of Mattel, accusing the company of not living up to its promise to keep lead-tainted toys out of childrens hands.

title: Comfort Food in Hong Kong
description: The Eskimos, so they say, have 12 different words for snow. Well, in Hong Kong, we have a dozen or more ways to say: Eat Here!

title: U.S. Failed to Oversee Corps on Iraq Work, Agency Says
description: A federal report released Tuesday says the Army Corps of Engineers charged the government hundreds of millions of dollars for supervising projects in Iraq that have been identified as having failed or fallen behind schedule specifically because oversight was lax or nonexistent.

title: Illinois: Energy Dept. Pulling Support for Clean Power Plant
description: Frustrated by ballooning costs for an ambitious plan to build a virtually emissions-free power plant, the Energy Department told federal lawmakers that it planned to pull its support for the $1.8 billion project in Illinois, lawmakers said. The department would not divulge its intentions about the plant, called FutureGen, or discuss what was said in the private meeting with lawmakers, saying only that it planned an announcement. But some lawmakers who attended the briefing later insisted that any departure from building the coal-fired, 275-megawatt prototype power plant anywhere other than the central Illinois town of Mattoon would be unacceptable  and grounds for a possibly nasty Congressional fight. Senator Richard J. Durbin, above, Democrat of Illinois, accused Energy Secretary Samuel W. Bodman of cruel deception of Illinoisans by creating false hope in a FutureGen project which he has no intention of funding or supporting.

title: Young Runner Lets a Champion Dictate His Pace
description: At age 21, baby face and all, Galen Rupp is one of the United States brightest young distance runners. He is also a realist. He says he will not win the Wanamaker Mile in the Millrose Games on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, but he expects to be in the fight.

title: Pitching Prize in Mets Grasp: Twins Santana
description: Until Tuesday, the Mets had conducted a quiet off-season, switching catchers and acquiring a few relievers and an outfielder. None of the moves did much to counteract the disenchantment that took hold after the teams memorable collapse in the final weeks of last season.

title: When the Campaign Comes to New York, Its a Tough Room but a Rich Prize
description: With Florida behind them and more than 20 primaries looming next Tuesday, the presidential candidates are about to grapple with a state where the Democratic governors popularity is in the gutter, the most powerful Republican is under federal investigation and the mayor of the largest city bolted not one but both political parties and has been mulling a presidential race himself.

title: City Centralizes Hiring Process for Principals
description: The Bloomberg administration is overhauling the way that principals at New York Citys 1,500 public schools are evaluated and selected, taking centralized control of the initial screening of candidates and trying to shake up a system where, officials say, a vast majority of principals routinely get satisfactory evaluations.

title: Hotel Where Dodgers Celebrated a Title Is Up for Sale
description: The historic Hotel Bossert, where the Brooklyn Dodgers celebrated their first and last World Series championship more than a half-century and many bittersweet memories ago, is being put up for sale.

title: Gluttonous Rite Survives Without Silverware
description: IT was Friday evening at V.F.W. Post 4591 in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and the scene was a vegetarians nightmare.

title: Estonia Bans Travel for Kremlin Youth Group
description: MOSCOW  Like many Russians, Mariana B. Skvortsova planned to spend her winter vacation traveling abroad. Yet, as she tried to cross from Russia into Finland this month, border guards refused her entry.

title: Brady Stands Up to Blitz: Pass Rushers or Paparazzi
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  It was with much sympathy that Joe Montana watched the footage of New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady facing an all-out blitz in New York last week. And a little surprise. In that situation, Montana wondered, why wouldnt Brady try a play fake?

title: Patriots Backup Quarterback Happy Playing Himself
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The backup spends his days in the shadow of the famous quarterback. There is Tom Brady, always, with his magazine covers and his model companion and his record-breaking season as the Patriots starting quarterback.

title: Recipe: Crispy Potato Wedges With Mustard
description: Adapted from Waldy Malouf, Beacon Restaurant

title: Man Killed in Hoboken Blaze
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  A four-alarm fire swept through an apartment building here early Tuesday, killing one man and leaving more than 60 people homeless.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A dance review on Monday about the Cool New York 2008 Dance Festival, at the John Ryan Theater in Brooklyn, misidentified the dancer who performed a solo by Darcy Naganuma. He is Kambi Gathesha, not Charly Wenzel (who is a woman).

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Verizons earnings misstated its revenue for 2007 in some copies. It was $93.4 billion, not million.

title: Mets Acquiring Santana From Twins
description: Until Tuesday, the Mets had, by their standards, conducted a quiet offseason, having switched catchers and added a few bullpen pieces and an outfielder but done nothing to prevent last seasons historic collapse from being the most-discussed topic when spring training gets under way in two weeks.

title: Lottery Numbers
Shockeys Loss Is Not the Giants Gain
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Mike Pope, the Giants tight ends coach, is aware of the conjecture that their offense has been better off without Jeremy Shockey, who broke his leg in mid-December. In Shockeys absence, the Giants offense, and most especially quarterback Eli Manning, have been startlingly effective.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 23 about Senate debate on a plan to provide immunity for telephone companies that helped the National Security Agency with a wiretapping program misspelled the surname of the director of the Washington legislative office of the American Civil Liberties Union who criticized Senator Harry Reids strategy for handling the measure. She is Caroline Fredrickson, not Frederickson.

title: Outside Groups Aid Obama, Their Vocal Critic
description: After months of denouncing the influence of special-interest money in politics, Senator Barack Obama is nonetheless entering a critical phase of the presidential campaign benefiting from millions of dollars being spent outside campaign finance rules.

title: Colorado Woman Faces Murder Charge in Fire That Killed One Child and Injured 4
description: DENVER  A woman is suspected of setting her house in Colorado Springs on fire Monday night, killing her 16-month-old daughter and badly injuring her four other children.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Verizons earnings misstated its revenue for 2007 in some copies. It was $93.4 billion, not million. (Go to Article)

title: Jerry Springer, the Great American Musical
description: Oh hear America singing, citizens of New York, as you never have heard it before. Hearken to your everyday sisters and brothers  the lost, the lonely, the fetishists, the freaks  as their voices swell and meld into one common chord of longing: to be seen, to be heard, to be (oh yes) famous.

title: The Suit Maker Who Sounded the Alarm About Nazis
description: If youve always found puppets only slightly more appealing than, say, clowns, Fabrik: The Legend of M. Rabinowitz may well change your mind. This modest yet powerfully affecting production capitalizes on the range of the art form and takes it to impressive heights.

title: Mukasey Offers View on Waterboarding
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey said Tuesday that the harsh C.I.A. interrogation technique known as waterboarding was not clearly illegal, and suggested that it could be used against terrorism suspects once again if requested by the White House.

title: After 40 Years, Schieffer Plans to Quit CBS in Early 2009
description: Bob Schieffer, a reporter for CBS News for nearly four decades and the host of Face the Nation for 17 years, said Tuesday night that he would retire next January, as a new president is sworn in and as he nears his 72nd birthday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the News Corporation blending its news and sports divisions to cover the Super Bowl and the coming Tuesday primaries, misidentified the location of the Super Bowl this Sunday. The game will be played at the University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Ariz., not in Phoenix itself.

title: F.B.I. Opens Subprime Inquiry
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has opened criminal inquiries into 14 companies as part of a wide-ranging investigation of the troubled mortgage industry, F.B.I. officials said Tuesday.

title: Roasted Beefsteak Sirloin With Blood and Butter Sauce
description: Adapted from Waldy Malouf, Beacon Restaurant

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary in some editions on Monday about Gordon B. Hinckley, the president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, attributed an erroneous distinction to him concerning the number of years he spent in the churchs top leadership. Although he spent 46 years in leadership posts, he was not the longest-serving president; Brigham Young was. The obituary also described the churchs office of the First Presidency incorrectly. It encompasses the church president and his two advisers; it is not a two-man team that counsels the president. The obituary also rendered incorrectly the name of a fund Mr. Hinckley established to pay for needy church members to attend college and misstated its source of financing. It is the Perpetual Education Fund, not the Perpetual Loan Fund, and it is financed by contributions, not tithes.

title: Spellman Arrested After Chase
description: The former N.F.L. player Alonzo Spellman was arrested Tuesday in Tulsa, Okla., after a nearly 20-minute chase in which police fired pepper-spray pellets into his car. His bond was set at $10,700, and Spellman remained jailed early Tuesday evening. Spellman played nine seasons in the N.F.L. for the Chicago Bears, the Detroit Lions and the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the management turnover at Interview magazine referred incompletely to the positions held by Sandra Brant at Brant Publications, which owns Interview. Ms. Brant is the chief executive, president and publisher of Brant Publications, and will continue in those roles until Feb. 22; she is not just the publisher.

title: A Comeback Story Decades in the Making
description: WASHINGTON  Many neglected urban neighborhoods have been renewed across the country in recent years, but few cities have experienced changes as extensive as those in Washington.

title: NBC Sues Dick Wolf
description: In a spat between partners who have shared a lot of success, NBC Universal has filed suit against Dick Wolf, the prolific producer of the networks three Law & Order series. The suit, filed last week in Los Angeles County Superior Court, centers on complex terms in Mr. Wolfs contract. NBC argues that Mr. Wolf, right, is misinterpreting them to demand millions of dollars in executive-producer fees for two years after his shows leave the air. NBCs interpretation is that if the network produces a sufficient number of episodes it can fulfill the contract and not owe Mr. Wolf for work he is no longer doing. Mr. Wolfs side contends that the contract guarantees the money as a kind of termination payment, or kill fee. No matter when NBC decides to end his series, Mr. Wolf argues, he is to be paid for 48 more episodes. NBC asks that if the court finds the contract language ambiguous, it direct that the errors be fixed rather than force NBC to pay the money. A representative of Mr. Wolf, who like other Hollywood writers is on strike, said he was traveling on Tuesday and could not be reached. But Mr. Wolf issued a statement last week saying: NBC Universal is trying to rewrite an existing contract. Apparently, our partner is willing to commission rewrites during the strike.

title: The Fine Print
description: With President Bush, you always have to read the footnotes.

title: War Concussions Linked to Stress
description: About one in six combat troops returning from Iraq have suffered at least one concussion in the war, injuries that, while fleeting, could heighten their risk of developing post-traumatic stress disorder, researchers are reporting.

title: Vuitton Is Embracing Medium of the Masses
description: IN an unusual marketing move for a fashion and luxury goods brand, Louis Vuitton said Tuesday that it planned to advertise on television for the first time, with a travel-themed 90-second spot that was shot in France, Spain, India and Japan.

title: The French Answer to Pecan Pie
description: AMONG the many assets of pecan pie is, oddly enough, an intensity so piercing that you cant eat much of it. In fact, pecan pie usually feeds twice as many people as you expect it to.

title: Coughlin Writes His Own Material
description: Glendale, Ariz.

title: Methodists Against Bush Library Lobby for Vote
description: DALLAS  Methodists opposed to a George W. Bush Presidential Library, museum and policy institute at Southern Methodist University here are mounting a last-ditch effort to block a nearly completed deal by throwing the decision to a regional church conference in July.

title: Curry and Brown Still Struggling to Fulfill Potential
description: LOS ANGELES  In seven N.B.A seasons, Eddy Curry has been praised, cheered, berated, traded, cheered, booed and benched. No wonder his expression sometimes seems fixed in a state of bemusement. The person who may best understand that look stood across from Curry on Tuesday night, providing a momentary mirror image of teenage dreams gone awry.

title: Recipe: Roasted Arctic Char With Ancho-Shallot Butter
description: Adapted from North Pond, Chicago

title: When Truck Is Disabled, the Meals Stop, Too
description: The orders were coming in fast. Rice and pigeon peas, fried plantains, okra, tripe soup, and steak with onions. Inside a truck, nestled under a rocky drop from Highbridge Park in Upper Manhattan, four Dominican women, wearing multiple layers to protect them from the freezing January air, gracefully hustled to fill each order. They filled tins with hefty scoops of rice and ladles of soupy red beans.

title: In Santana Duel, Mets Are Left Standing
description: All winter, the experts said the Mets didnt have a chance, and all winter, the Mets general manager quietly and confidently said he would be the last one standing when the Minnesota Twins traded Johan Santana. The Twins traded Santana on Tuesday, and look who got him.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the On Baseball column on Sunday about a book to be released this spring that includes interviews with 11 stars of the game from the 1950s and 60s attributed an incorrect distinction to four of the men. The former players Ralph Branca, Carl Erskine, Bill Rigney and Lew Burdette are not in the Hall of Fame.

title: Obama Campaigns in His Grandfathers Hometown
description: EL DORADO, Kan.  When Senator Barack Obama arrived here Tuesday afternoon on the gusty plains of Kansas, the political stage was set for a homecoming, a moment to highlight a branch of his family tree that receives far less attention in a presidential campaign that has been rooted in biography.

title: For Giuliani, a Dizzying Free-Fall
description: Perhaps he was living an illusion all along.

title: Stocks Rally Then Fall Back
description: Wall Street watched a Fed rally abruptly fizzle on Wednesday, as excitement over an interest rate cut gave way to concern about a new round of problems related to the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: Pellicano Delivers a Surprise
description: In a surprise move in his first appearance since taking over as his own lawyer, Anthony Pellicano, the embattled Hollywood private investigator, withdrew his request for a hearing into allegations that the F.B.I. and federal prosecutors violated his constitutional rights by using his former girlfriend to elicit confidential information, The Los Angeles Times reported. In withdrawing the request, Mr. Pellicano, who is facing trial on wiretapping and conspiracy charges, told Judge Dale S. Fischer of United States District Court, I dont believe I had any chance of prevailing. The accusation of prosecutorial misconduct was a crucial element in the defense of the lawyers who previously represented Mr. Pellicano. Thom Mrozek, a spokesman for the United States Attorneys Office in Los Angeles, expressed satisfaction with the withdrawal and said, We have always believed that the motion was unfounded. The judge plans to begin the trial on Feb. 27.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,924 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: McCains Victory in a Party-Only Primary Raises the Hurdles for Romney
description: MIAMI  Senator John McCains victory in the Florida primary came in the face of considerable odds and suggests that his chief rival here, Mitt Romney, faces tough going in what has effectively become a two-person Republican field.

title: Edwards Drops Out of Democratic Race
description: NEW ORLEANS  John Edwards, the progressive Democratic candidate who made a populist, antipoverty message the centerpiece of his campaign, announced his exit from the presidential primary race on Wednesday, saying he was stepping aside so that history can blaze its path.

title: Campo Returns to Cowboys
description: The former Cowboys coach Dave Campo rejoined the staff Tuesday as the secondary coach. Campo was the only coach never to get Dallas into the playoffs  the Cowboys were 5-11 in each of his three seasons. He replaces Todd Bowles, one of several assistants who left to join the staff of the new Dolphins coach Tony Sparano, a former Cowboys assistant.

title: Papers Show Wider Focus in Inquiry of Artifacts
description: LOS ANGELES  A federal investigation into the smuggling and sale of looted Asian and American Indian antiquities has expanded to include stolen artifacts from Central America; a collector who is on the board of the Art Institute of Chicago; a gallery in Encino, Calif.; and a second alleged smuggler, according to federal court documents made public this week.

title: Inhabiting the Spirits of Songs, While Letting Them Speak for Themselves
description: Not long ago a countertenor could be expected to specialize in early music: that was the point of becoming one. David Daniels has accepted that limitation in his opera career, and until a vogue erupts for countertenor Alfredos or Tristans, he doesnt have much choice. But in recitals Mr. Daniels does as he likes, and if that means opening a concert with a Brahms group, as he did on Monday evening at Zankel Hall, who will complain?

title: Robbins Celebration
description: Jerome Robbins, below, will be celebrated by New York City Ballet in performances of 33 of his dances during its spring season, running from April 29 through June 29. The tribute at the New York State Theater, featuring 10 all-Robbins programs, each showcasing a different aspect of his work, will commemorate the 90th anniversary of his birth. Guest artists participating in the event will include dancers from American Ballet Theater, the Paris Opera Ballet and the Royal Ballet.

title: Austria: Death Camp Case Reopened
description: Prosecutors reopened the case of Erna Wallisch, 85, who ranks seventh on the Simon Wiesenthal Centers list of most-wanted Nazi war criminals, after new evidence suggested that the woman might have taken part in the mass murder of inmates in the Majdanek concentration camp near Lublin, Poland. We are trying to establish whether statements from Polish witnesses are sufficient to identify Mrs. Wallisch, said Gerhard Jarosch, spokesman for the state prosecutors in Vienna, in a telephone interview. Obviously this is very difficult more than six decades later. The woman, who served as a guard in the death camp, is living in a small apartment in Vienna.

title: Justice in Darfur
description: To the Editor:

title: N.Y.U. Offers an Accord on Growth
description: Eager to cool its often rancorous relations with its neighbors in Greenwich Village  and to pave the way for its next 25 years of expansion  New York University has agreed to try to push some of its expansion farther from its central core, to consult the community when it designs new space and to develop policies to relocate tenants when they must be moved because of university construction.

title: 7-Year-Olds Blood Found on Stepfather, Expert Says
description: Blood found throughout the apartment of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown and under the fingernails of the man accused of killing her belonged to the girl, a representative of the chief medical examiners office testified Tuesday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Kidney Thefts Shock India
description: GURGAON, India  As the anesthetic wore off, Naseem Mohammed said, he felt an acute pain in the lower left side of his abdomen. Fighting drowsiness, he fumbled beneath the unfamiliar folds of a green medical gown and traced his fingers over a bandage attached with surgical tape. An armed guard by the door told him that his kidney had been removed.
