title: David Bradley, 92, Author, Antinuclear Advocate, Champion Skier and State Legislator, Is Dead
description: David Bradley, a writer, surgeon and antinuclear advocate whose best-selling first book, No Place to Hide, was an eyewitness account of the postwar atomic tests on Bikini Atoll in the South Pacific, died on Jan. 7 in Norway, Me. He was 92. A former resident of Hanover, N.H., Dr. Bradley had lived in Maine in recent years.

title: For Many Turks, Head Scarfs Return Aids Religion and Democracy
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish governments decision this week to lift a ban on women wearing head scarves in universities raised a troubling question: Is Islam starting to erode Turkeys secular democracy?

title: France: Mitterrand Items Auctioned
description: A famous black felt hat and other personal objects worn by the former French president, Franois Mitterrand, were sold at a Paris auction. The sale fetched about $192,000, money that will be donated to a charity run by Mr. Mitterrands widow, Danielle. More than 300 items went under the gavel, including official gifts, like a miniature ceramic house from Barbara Bush and a crocodile-skin briefcase from Fidel Castro. The auction was the third organized by Mrs. Mitterrand since her husbands death 12 years ago.

title: Obama Donates Challenged Funds
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  After another review of campaign contributions, an aide to Senator Barack Obama said Tuesday evening that the campaign was giving to charity $72,650 in donations tied to an indicted Chicago businessman, Antoin Rezko, who helped raise money for Mr. Obamas Senate campaign four years ago.

title: Rutgers Will Expand Stadium
description: Rutgers University approved spending $102 million to expand its football stadium by 14,000 seats. The plan approved by the universitys governing board will boost the stadiums capacity to 56,000.The plan calls for borrowing $72 million that will be repaid through increased ticket revenues. Another $30 million is to come from private donations. The project is expected to be completed by 2009.

title: Yahoo to Cut 1,000 Jobs, and Warns on Growth
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After announcing a sharp drop in fourth-quarter profits Tuesday, Yahoo issued a disappointing outlook for this year, suggesting that investors would have to wait until 2009 for a turnaround.

title: Where Moss Goes, So Go Brady and the Patriots
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The woman in the wedding dress was gone, and so was the genie who predicted Patriots quarterback Tom Brady would receive two rings in 2008  a Super Bowl championship ring and a wedding band.

title: Worker in Brooklyn Killed in Fall
description: Two workers apparently fell from a scaffold on Wednesday while working on the roof of a 13-story high-rise under construction in Brooklyn, officials said.

title: Moss Is More Than Sound Bites
description: Glendale, Ariz.

title: Snow Buries Many Areas as West Braces for New Storms
description: BOISE, Idaho (AP)  A powerful storm system raced across the nation Tuesday, bringing heavy snow and numbing cold as well as thunderstorms and possible tornadoes, and forecasters warned that more bad weather was on the way.

title: Recipe: Cocido
description: Adapted from Alexandra Raij, Ta Pol

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 18 about A A Bronsons School for Young Shamans at John Connelly Presents, in Chelsea, rendered part of Mr. Bronsons name incorrectly. He uses A A, not A.A. The entry also misstated the former relationship between Mr. Bronson and the artist Terence Koh, who collaborated on a work in the show. Mr. Koh was Mr. Bronsons studio assistant, not his student.

title: New Literary Program to Make Its Home Online
description: Daniel Menaker, who left his post as executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group in June, is moving online in March to be the host of a new Web-based book show.

title: Costs of Overfishing
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC News in Front
description: In the extremely tight ratings race between the two leading evening news broadcasts, ABCs World News With Charles Gibson last week edged past its rival, NBCs Nightly News With Brian Williams, for the first time in eight weeks. Nielsen estimated that the ABC newscast drew 9.8 million viewers, its highest average in nearly a year and slightly more than the 9.6 million who tuned in to NBC. ABCs slim margin of victory was only modestly higher in the age bracket of adults 25 to 54, a demographic the two networks split evenly during the previous week. The last time ABC finished No. 1 was during the November sweeps period. Last week CBSs Evening News With Katie Couric remained a distant third (7.13 million).

title: Recipe: Walnut Tart
description: Time: 40 minutes (with premade crust), plus chilling

title: Instant Nutrition
description: Butte, Mont.

title: Afghan Women Protest Aid Workers Kidnapping
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  About 500 Afghan women gathered Tuesday in this southern city to protest the kidnapping of an American aid worker and her Afghan driver and to call for her release.

title: Hall of Fame Game to Be Dropped
description: This years Hall of Fame Game between the Chicago Cubs and San Diego Padres on June 16 will be the last in the exhibition series. Officials at the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum said Tuesday that Major League Baseball decided that keeping the game was too difficult because of the complexities of the major league schedule. The first Hall of Fame Game was played in 1940.

title: A Befuddlement of Liquor Laws
description: I have a confession to make. I am a lawbreaker.

title: House Approves Economic Stimulus Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted on Tuesday to approve a $146 billion fiscal stimulus package, hoping to seal a fast-paced deal with President Bush on tax rebates and business incentives intended to jolt the economy with new spending.

title: Mukasey Demurs on Waterboarding
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey got a harsh reception on Wednesday from senators of both parties, who used his appearance on Capitol Hill to accuse the Bush administration yet again of contempt for the rule of law and American values. But they told Mr. Mukasey he was a big improvement over his predecessor, Alberto R. Gonzalez.

title: An Appeal That Looks to (and Uses) the Spirit of the 1960s
description: This 30-second advertisement for Senator Barack Obama begins on Wednesday in Boston, Los Angeles, New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco and nationally on cable television. The spot, Caroline, is the first with Caroline Kennedy.

title: A Police Confrontation Comes Slowly Into Focus
description: WHITE PLAINS  The off-duty police officer was sitting in his parked car when he saw two men fighting on a downtown street. He stepped out of the car and tried to break up the confrontation, then rushed inside the county government building nearby to ask for help.

title: No Go for Foxy Brown
description: The truculent rapper Foxy Brown will stay put  in jail  after Acting Justice Melissa C. Jackson of the New York State Supreme Court rejected her petition for early release to enable her to travel to California for an ear examination and repair of an electronic ear implant, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Brown, 29, right, whose real name is Inga Marchand, complained that her hearing problems were worsening in jail and that she faced serious harm unless her cochlear implant was repaired and reprogrammed. Prosecutors said she could get the treatment she needs in New York. She was sentenced in September to a year in jail for violating probation. She was put on probation after pleading guilty to misdemeanor assault of two manicurists at a Manhattan nail salon in August 2004.

title: French Bank Chief Stays for Now
description: PARIS  With pressure for his resignation flowing from nearly every major French politician amid a trading scandal that has darkened Frances reputation as well as his banks, the chief of Socit Gnrale put his job on the table Wednesday for the second time in a week.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Saturday about optimistic comments by Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning regarding his brother Elis prospects for future Super Bowls with the Giants misidentified the location of the 2006 season opener between their teams. It was at Giants Stadium, not in Indianapolis.

title: TV Showman, Once Exiled, Returns With Video Site
description: LOS ANGELES  One of Big Medias most controversial executives is back after a period of quasi-forced retirement.

title: Taking Worry Off the Plate
description: WATCHING the amount of mercury in your diet does not have to mean avoiding seafood.

title: Wariner Splits With Coach
description: With the Beijing Games only seven months away, the defending Olympic 400 meters champion Jeremy Wariner and his longtime coach have split over a contract dispute. Clyde Hart, who has coached Wariner for five years beginning with their days at Baylor University, said Wariner wanted to pay him less than in his previous contracts. Michael Johnson, the world-record holder in the 200 and Wariners agent, did not immediately respond to a telephone message seeking comment left with Wariners manager, Deon Minor.

title: On Iraq, Bush Shows a More Restrained Optimism
description: President Bush left his comments on Iraq until nearly halfway through his final State of the Union address on Monday night, after his discussion of domestic issues like the economy, health care and education, even though the war is one of the two most important factors shaping the American agenda, along with the economy.

title: 3Ms Profit Falls After a 2006 Gain
description: MINNEAPOLIS (AP)  The 3M Company, which makes Scotch tape, Post-it notes and industrial adhesives, posted lower fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, compared with the quarter a year ago, which included a one-time gain.

title: Field Narrows as Giuliani and Edwards End Campaigns
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Rudolph W. Giuliani, the combative former Republican mayor of New York City, and John Edwards, the Democrat who ran for the White House as an anti-poverty populist, both dropped out of the presidential race on Wednesday, leaving a narrowed field hurtling toward what amounts to a national primary next week.

title: Pakistan Movie Ban
description: A Pakistani Senate committee has proposed an end to the four-decade ban on showing movies from India, Agence France-Press reported. In a statement on Tuesday, the committee referred to the films when it said, The ban has practically become ineffective as these are being viewed uncensored in almost every household on cable TV as well as CDs and DVDs, necessitating a reappraisal to deal with the issue rationally.

title: Henry Froehlich, Pioneer in Japanese Camera Imports, Is Dead at 85
description: Henry Froehlich, one of the first distributors of high-tech Japanese cameras in the United States and one of the developers of an easy process for transferring home movies from film to videotape, died in Manhattan last Thursday. He was 85 and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Letters
description: Coffee Royale

title: A Celebration Unto Itself
description: WHEN it happened for the second time in two weeks, I paid attention.

title: Youth to Be Tried as Adult in Newark Triple Murder
description: NEWARK  A 17-year-old will be tried as an adult for what prosecutors said was his active role in the killings of three young people in a Newark schoolyard last summer, a judge ruled on Tuesday.

title: Controversy Dogs Inquiry on Bridge Collapse
description: WASHINGTON  The National Transportation Safety Boards working theory about last summers bridge collapse in Minneapolis  that it was caused by a design error four decades ago  has run into a peculiar problem: it contradicts much public belief.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Big City column on Monday, about Derrick Braxton, a black student from a Brooklyn housing project now attending a small, mostly white college in upstate New York, referred incorrectly to his Brooklyn high school, Bedford Academy. It is a public school, not a charter school.

title: Kenyan Politician Assassinated
description: A popular parliament member was gunned down outside his home in Nairobi, sparking clashes between mourners and police.

title: What Florida Taught Me
description: Here are a few things I learned Tuesday night.

title: New Journal Blog a Sign of Murdochs Green Bent?
description: No, your computer isnt misfiring.

title: Climate Change
description: GLENDALE, Ariz. In their first 10 games this season, the undefeated Patriots only played one game in which they didnt win by at least 17 points. In their eight victories since, five have been by 10 points or fewer, which includes their 38-35 victory against the Giants in both teams regular-season finale.

title: John Edwards in New Orleans
description: Following is the transcript of John Edwards's announcement to suspend his campaign, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

title: Forever Tom
description: GLENDALE, Ariz. With a victory in Sundays Super Bowl XLII against the Giants, New England quarterback Tom Brady would tie Terry Bradshaw and Joe Montana at four for most Super Bowl wins by a quarterback.

title: Championship Friends
description: GLENDALE, Ariz. During media day Tuesday, New England Coach Bill Belichick discussed his relationship with other successful coaches, including his friend Bob Knight, the Texas Tech basketball coach. The two men met through Bill Parcells, Belichicks former boss when the two won Super Bowl championships with the Giants in 1986 and 1990.

title: Airbus and the Environment
description: It wasnt long ago that the aviation sector turned up its nose at the environment. After all airplanes are only responsible for about two or three percent of global emissions, making them far less of a factor than cars or power stations in pumping out the gases linked to global warming.

title: Correction: Sounds and Flavors of a Land Left Behind in Cuban Miami
description: The American Journeys column last Friday, about Cuban culture in Miami, gave incomplete lyrics for a song performed in Spanish by the Cuban singer Albita at a club in Little Havana. The correct lyrics include the preposition "de" three times: "Que culpa tengo yo de estas caderas? Que culpa tengo yo de este sabor? Que culpa tengo yo de haber nacido en Cuba?"

title: Food Stuff
description: How Hard Is It to Boil an Egg? (It's Becoming Easier)

title: UBS Takes a $14 Billion Write-Off
description: PARIS  UBS, the largest Swiss bank, said Wednesday that it would write off $14 billion in losses on the troubled U.S. housing market and post a net loss for 2007.

title: Even in Death, Fischer Spawns Controversy
description: Nearly two weeks after Bobby Fischer died, strange reports continue to trickle out about his life and death. Among the stories have been the circumstances surrounding

title: Eating in Hong Kong: the Cha Chaan Teng
description: Twin Ducks in a Teacup: Hong Kongs yun yeung coffee-tea

title: A Closer Look at Mercury
description: Images of Mercury taken by the Messenger spacecraft.

title: No Dip for You!
description: At last, proof that George was being pretty gross when he double-dipped that chip at a funeral reception on Seinfeld. Prof. Paul L. Dawson, a food microbiologist, did a study and found that the brother of Georges late girlfriend was justifiably outraged (Super Bowl partyers, be advised):

title: Letter from Pakistans Former Chief Justice
description: AN OPEN LETTER TO:

title: The Bloody Shirt
description: PROLOGUE

title: TV Showman, Once Exiled, Returns With Video Site
description: One of Big Medias most controversial executives is back after a period of quasi-forced retirement.

title: Iberdrola Hires Merrill to Sell Stake in Portugese Energy Firm
description: Spanish utility Iberdrola  said Wednesday it has hired investment bank Merrill Lynch to sell its 4 percent stake in in Portuguese energy firm Galp Energia. In a Spanish regulatory filing, Iberdrola said the Galp shares will be sold to qualified institutional investors.

title: V.C.s Pump $20 Million into Virtual Iron
description: Virtual Iron, a start-up aiming to commercialize the open-source Xen virtualization software, has raised $20 million.

title: XAware Takes $7.4 Million in Latest Round
description: XAware, an open-source data integration developer, announced Tuesday that it raised a $7.4 million third round of funding.

title: F.B.I. Opens Subprime Inquiry
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation officials said the agency has opened criminal inquiries into 14 companies as part of a wide-ranging investigation of the troubled mortgage industry.

title: Margaret Truman Daniel
description: Margaret Truman Daniel, a presidents daughter whose achievements as a singer, author and radio and television host won her renown, died at 83.

title: Is the United States Chess Federation in Trouble?
description: A statement from a meeting about the finances of the United States Chess Federation was posted over the weekend on the federations Web forum by Bill Goichberg, the president of the federation. In the statement, Goichberg talked about the federations finances, saying they are not in good shape and the federation is projected to run a significant deficit (significant from the federations standpoint as it does not have much in the way of financial reserves and its revenues are about $3 million a year). He also suggested some plans of action. Here is an excerpt from the statement, with the first few paragraphs about technology used to conduct the meeting and plans for the next meeting of the federations executive board, omitted.

title: Goldcorp May Sell Silver Wheaton in Offering
description: Hoping to raise capital to fund the rising costs of its development projects, Canadas Goldcorp is reportedly looking to unload its 49 percent stake in Silver Wheaton, but The Globe and Mail noted that its unclear whether there will be enough investor appetite for what would be a massive $1.8 billion stock sale.

title: Rule Change to Help Smaller Companies Raise Funds
description: Federal regulators are about to ease rules that have made it difficult for small and medium-size publicly traded companies to raise money. The changes, experts say, are well timed, given the tightening credit market.

title: UnitedHealth Faces Fine Related to PacifiCare Merger
description: California regulators announced Tuesday that they are seeking as much as $1.33 billion in penalties from PacifiCare as a result of widespread problems stemming from its takeover two years ago by healthcare giant UnitedHealth Group.

title: Sprint, Clearwire Said to Seek Funding for WiMax Venture
description: Wireless Internet provider Clearwire and cellular operator Sprint Nextel have reportedly restarted talks to combine their high-speed wireless WiMax networks.

title: Kirkland & Ellis Said to Open Silicon Valley Office
description: Kirkland & Ellis, the litigation-focused law firm, plans to open an office in Palo Alto, Calif., later this year as firms rush to the Silicon Valley area to grab talent and clients in the U.S. technology company center, The National Law Journal reported.

title: Hedge Funds Take Dillards Stake
description: Dillards shares rose 3.4 percent after two New York-based hedge funds reported a stake in the department store company, saying Dillards shares are significantly undervalued.

title: Hedge Turns Up Heat on Compton Petroleum
description: Canadas Compton Petroleum is under renewed assault from its largest shareholder, hedge fund Centennial Energy Partners, which is now dismissing the Calgary gas producers latest business plan as ill-conceived and reiterating an earlier demand that it put itself up for sale in order to maximize value for investors.

title: UBS Takes a $14 Billion Hit
description: UBS, the largest Swiss bank, said Wednesday that it would write off $14 billion in exposure to the troubled U.S. housing market and post a net loss for 2007.

title: Countrywide Posts $422 Million Loss, but Deal Is Still a Go
description: Countrywide Financial, the mortgage lender and loan servicer, reported a fourth-quarter loss of $422 million Tuesday, but the results were not expected to hinder its proposed $4.1 billion takeover by the Bank of America.

title: AirTran Hopes for a Delta-Northwest Merger
description: As industry observers continue to speculate on the airline merger game, one carrier has made its own wish list.

title: Excel Pays $2.4 Billion to Board Quintana
description: Excel Maritime Carriers said Tuesday it would acquire competitor Quintana Maritime  in a deal it valued at nearly $2.45 billion that will create one of the worlds largest dry bulk companies by fleet and capacity.

title: GSO Nears Deadline to Close Reddy Buyout
description: At a time when all buyouts have been subject to doubts, the $680 million buyout of Reddy Ice Holdings by GSO Capital Partners is running up against the end of its extended marketing period.

title: A Statesman Without Borders
description: Can Bernard Kouchner make France a global player again?

title: Crosslink Closes $400 Million Fund
description: Crosslink Capital said Wednesday it closed its Crossover Fund V with $400 million in capital commitments, bringing its total capital under management to more than $1.4 billion. The new fund will continue Crosslinks strategy of investing in early-stage ventures, public companies and those at stages in between, the firm said in a press release.

description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

description: Is there still a way for Alliance Data Systems to be acquired by Blackstone Group?

description: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said Tuesday that it had record fourth-quarter profits of $122.6 million, powered by increased revenues from its deal advisory business  despite the beginning of a slowdown in mergers and acquisitions at the same time.

description: If searching online can produce a life partner, it should be an effective way to find a mentor. At least thats the thinking behind iMantri, a new Silicon Valley social networking site that opened its online doors this week.

description: Senior politicians here increased calls for the resignation of top executives at Socit Gnrale, ahead of the boards regular meeting, scheduled for early Wednesday.

title: Carlyle Chairman: Theres No Crisis
description: Cheap credit may have disappeared, the equity markets may be in the dumps, and the deal graveyard may be littered with failed buyouts, but dont call it crisis. At least not if youre speaking with Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman of the Carlyle Group, one of the worlds largest private equity firms.

description: Mike Huckabee speaks to supporters after the Florida primary. (NBC video)

title: LAffaire Kerviel Distracts from SocGens Subprime Woes
description: Jrme Kerviels 4.8 billion euro trading loss ($7.1 billion) had a positive effect for Socit Gnrale, at least temporarily.

title: At French Bank, Directors Trades Raise Eyebrows
description: Amid all the hoopla surrounding Jrme Kerviel, whose fraudulent trades saddled Socit Gnrale with a $7.1 billion loss, new questions have emerged about a different set of trades: Those carried out by Robert A. Day, a member of the French banks board of directors.

title: John McCain's Victory Speech
description: John McCain speaks to supporters after winning the Florida primary. (NBC video)

title: Now Carpetbagger Finally Offers Merchandise
Juno Laid Low by Success
description: The Bagger was never much of a critic, but he used to cover music occasionally and he was always struck by what happened when some indie plaything hit it big  the Replacements or Liz Phair back in the day, and the Strokes or Clap Your Hands Say Yeah more recently. He learned that you could almost set your watch by the backlash. Critics work to lift worthy work into public consciousness, but once it is embraced by the tawdry masses, they drop their treasure like a box of rocks.

title: The Early Word: Floridas Waves
description: MIAMI  The calendar is spinning forward quickly, and today should be another newsy day as Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to throw his support behind Senator John McCain, the winner here. The G.O.P. field  grower smaller is headed out to the Ronald Reagan Library in California for another debate tonight.

title: Patriots, Giants and a Big Bowl of Chips
description: Friday Night Update: The reader submissions were, overwhelmingly, fattening, cheap, tasty concoctions. They prove we are a dip nation, in tune with avocados (right on, Roger, Billy D and Jen) and artichokes (Yea, Helen and Ashley). We like our chips fresh from a boiling vat of oil, not from the bag. We are willing to eat anything (including roadkill) as long as its spicy or creamy.

title: A Former Mayors Failed Endgame in Florida
description: For the New York papers, the focus today is on Rudolph W. Giulianis precipitous political free fall, after his third-place finish in the Republican presidential primary in Florida on Tuesday night. Rudys Ruin, says the front of The Post. The Fat Ladys Singin, declares The Daily News. In The Times, Michael Powell and Michael Cooper dissect what is called a dizzying free-fall for the ex-mayor, noting that just a few months ago a senior Giuliani aide had surveyed the Republican field and said: I dont believe this can be taken from us. Now that I have that locked up, I can go do battle elsewhere.Instead, hubris and strategic miscalculations plagued his campaign, political observers say. For one, he allowed a tight coterie of New York aides, none with national political experience, to run much of his campaign. And while he accumulated a fat war chest  he had $16.6 million on hand at the end of September, more than Mitt Romney ($9.5 million) or Senator John McCain ($3.2 million)  he spent vast sums on direct mail instead of building strong organizations on the ground in South Carolina and New Hampshire.

title: SOTU Attracts 37.5 Million Viewers
description: An estimated 37.5 million watched President Bushs address to Congress Monday night, which was broadcast live on ABC, CBS, NBC, Fox, CNN, Fox News Channel, MSNBC, Univision and Telemundo, the Associated Press reports.

title: Sweet Winter Treat:  Sahlep
description: Hot sahlep at Pia Cafe in Beyoglu, with dried chick peas on the side. Photo by Susanne Fowler

title: Where Obama Lived in 1980s New York
description: The six-story walk-up at 339 East 94th Street has seen much over the decades: generations of mostly white and Hispanic immigrants, nests of mice, drug deals, a police bust, at least one stabbing, a recent influx of young professionals, and a future presidential candidate: Barack Obama.

title: Open Caucus: An Independent Fla. Voter
description: MIAMI  On the eve of Floridas primary, we sat down in Palm Beach Gardens with one of our Open Caucus voters, John Weiss, and talked with him about the candidates in the G.O.P. and Democratic fields. Mr. Weiss, 42, is a police officer, veteran of Desert Storm and most recently was in Iraq as an instructor training security forces.

title: Microsoft Ruling: Split Decision, Two More Years of Oversight
description: The Federal District Court in Washington ruled late Tuesday to extend the consent decree against Microsoft for another two years.

description: Nothing like waking up on a Wednesday morning to a threat from space on the minds of the top military brass, trumpeted in bright red type on the Drudge Report:

title: Message from UBS: Its Not Just Subprime
description: You might think that investors and analysts would be used to hearing about 11-digit write-downs by now. Maybe even jaded. So why was Wednesdays UBS announcement  or, as the bank called it, a pre-announcement  about $14 billion in write-downs such a shock? I had assumed additional losses, but not of this magnitude, an analyst told The New York Times. Shares of UBS were down 2.8 percent in early trading Wednesday in New York.

title: At a Staten Island Pub, Young Republicans Weigh the Choices
description: Joyces Tavern, a homey Irish pub in the southeastern corner of Staten Island, draws a Giants crowd during football season, and a Mets crowd during the baseball season. But lately its been drawing a crowd that has a lot more trouble agreeing on a favorite: Young Republicans.

title: Casualties of the (Possibly) Upcoming Recession
description: For most politicians a recession is more an abstraction than a wrenching reality. For many Americans, however, a recession would mean very real pain.

title: Edwards Is Dropping Out
description: Updated: NEW ORLEANS  Democratic candidate John Edwards has decided to drop out of the presidential primary race, giving a speech this afternoon at the same place where he began this campaign  in New Orleans.

title: Caffeine May Hamper Diabetes Control
description: Caffeine may make it tougher for people with diabetes to control their blood sugar, a new study shows.

description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton speaks to supporters after the Florida  primary. (NBC video)

description: John McCain speaks to supporters after winning the Florida primary. (NBC video)

title: The Debate: Confidence or Boasting?
description: At least since Joe Namath, predictions and victory guarantees by players have often accompanied the run-up to big games. Yesterday, the Giants Plaxico Burress took his turn.

title: French Banks Chief to Stay, For Now
description: Societe Generale s top executive has offered to resign for a second time since the French bank disclosed a $7 billion trading scandal. But the banks directors on Wednesday asked him to stay in his post  at least for the moment.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by David Lehman
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: And Then There Were Two?
description: With the expected exits today of John Edwards from the Democratic race and Rudolph W. Giuliani from the Republican race, both primaries are shaping up as two-person contests. Narrowing the fields will clarify the choices for voters without spoilers who can siphon off support.

title: After Florida: The Road Ahead
description: John McCain's success has rocked the Republican field, says John Harwood of CNBC and The Times, while the Democrats look to Super Tuesday.

title: Nice Calculation, Mr. Byrne
description: Overstock.com is out with its financial results this morning  conference call is now going on  and the news is good, according to both Patrick Byrne, the chief executive, and the stock market. Shares are up 9% as I write this.

title: WNET President Seeks a Heightened Urgency
description: On Monday Neal Shapiros one-year apprenticeship as the president of WNET, Channel 13 in New York, will end when he takes on the top job, as president and chief executive of the stations parent, the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, Elizabeth Jensen reports in todays New York Times.

title: New York Republicans Rally Around McCain
description: Updated, 1:48 p.m. | Eight years after New York Republicans, led by Gov. George E. Pataki, fought unsuccessfully to keep Senator John McCain off the Republican presidential primary ballot, they are moving swiftly to embrace him as the partys front-runner Wednesday morning, as Rudolph W. Giuliani prepares to exit the race. The Republican leaders in the State Legislature both announced their support for Mr. McCain this morning.

title: A Fool for Smart
description: When I tell people Im buying a Smart Car, I generally get one of three reactions. Most people still dont know what it is  they havent seen the half-pint two seater from Daimler. Many of those who do know about them laugh. The Smart is a tiny thing, comical in its styling and proportions: just 8.8 feet long. (Its about 40 inches shorter than a Mini Cooper, that road hog.) And then there are the very few who get a sort of funny smile on their faces. Not quite envy, but the look you got in high school from people who had realized that you really were going to jump from that 40-foot tower into the lake, and were waiting with pleasure to see if youd make it.

title: The Rigors of the Big East
description: Is basketball in the Big East akin to football in the SEC? ESPN.coms Pat Forde thinks so: There are no soft spots on the 18-game schedule. Anything can happen on a given night, and it already has.

title: The ownership society
description: Not.

title: The Battle for New York, 1992
description: The relationship between the Clintons and the Democrats of New York goes back far before Hillary Rodham Clinton moved to New York to run for the Senate in 2000. In 1992, New York played a crucial role in securing the Democratic nomination for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, but the outcome of the primary also revealed a divided and uncertain electorate.

description: Listening to the droning, jargon-filled Yahoo conference call on Tuesday night, you could only think that Jerry Yang and Sue Decker were aiming their conversation only at analysts who needed to fill out their 2008 spreadsheets.

description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.During Wednesdays press conference, Patriots Coach Bill Belichick was wearing a red Rutgers lacrosse jacket.

title: The Midlife Crisis Goes Global
description: The midlife crisis, a time of self-doubt and turmoil familiar to many in their 40s and 50s, is often viewed as a phenomenon of Western culture. But new research suggests that people all over the world are miserable in middle age.

title: Imus Closer to a Return to TV
description: Patrick Gottsch, the founder and president of RFD-TV, a cable channel that carries Don Imuss show but primarily chronicles life in rural America, said on Wednesday morning that he had signed an affiliation agreement with Comcast, the nations largest cable operator, Jacques Steinberg reports.

description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: If you watched the Presidents state of the union address last night, you know that President Bush promised to cut 151 programs that are performing poorly. Or as we call that at NBC, our fall schedule.

title: Clash of the (Media) Titans
description: The dispute between Barry Diller and John Malone has spawned three lawsuits and devolved into a name-calling contest. Earlier this week, Mr. Diller, the chief executive of IAC, referred to the people at Liberty Media, John Malones holding company and the controlling shareholder of IAC, as being insane. Meanwhile, Liberty was kind enough to point out in its lawsuit that a study in 2005 had found Mr. Diller to be one of the twenty-five most overpaid executives in the United States.

title: On Michelle Obamas Guest List: Alma Rangel

Rangel, according to a person familiar with the guest list for the event.More in City RoomMore Primary Journals

title: On Michelle Obamas Guest List: Alma Rangel
description: Updated, 5:10 p.m. | Michelle Obama spoke this afternoon at a fund-raising lunch on the Upper East Side for her husbands presidential campaign, and one of the more prominent people present was Alma Rangel, the wife of Representative Charles B. Rangel, according to a person familiar with the guest list for the event. Mr. Rangel has been a leading supporter of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, so his wifes attendance at a fund-raiser for Senator Barack Obama, Mrs. Clintons chief rival, seems noteworthy.

title: Catching Up With | Mika
The Edwards Announcement
description: 1:40 Mr. Edwards says hes suspending his campaign, a technical distinction that will allow him to do some bookkeeping. He also says that he almost changed his mind about dropping out after seeing supporters recently in Oklahoma, Missouri and Minnesota, who told him, dont forget us.

title: Idol and House Dominate Tuesdays Ratings
description: Fox overwhelmingly dominated the ratings Tuesday night thanks to the one-two punch of the popular shows American Idol and House. At 8 p.m., Idol delivered an average of 28.1 million viewers, and House reeled in 22.5 million at 9 p.m.

title: A Laughable Idea: More Bush Tax Cuts for the Rich
description: One of President Bushs laugh lines in his State of the Union address Monday night was in defense of his plan to make his tax cuts permanent, now, even though theyre not scheduled to expire until the end of 2010.

title: The Fashionable Pejorative
description: Not long ago, a well-known culture critic with strong neoconservative inclinations told me he was reluctant to be forthright about his political views because once the label neoconservative becomes attached to you, people stop listening to what you have to say. Theres no question that neoconservative has become, in many quarters of both the left and right, a fashionable pejorative, to be casually tossed about, and just as casually misapplied.

title: Q and A:  Fabio Trabocchi
description: Fabio Trabocchi took over the kitchen at Fiamma Osteria in SoHo last year. When he did, the restaurants name changed slightly  its now simply called Fiamma  and its cooking changed more than that. While it still bills itself as an Italian restaurant, its dishes are less traditionally Italian, more fanciful and more reflective of French influences than the dishes under the previous chef, Michael White, were.

title: Consumers Turn Tail
description: Buried in the G.D.P. report this morning is an interesting fact: Consumers are buying less of the everyday stuff. And it looks to me like the Fed expects a poor employment report on Friday.

title: The Post-Surge Campaign
description: As recently as last summer, almost no one would have thought the events of the last week very likely  that Barack Obama would have a won a convincing victory in South Carolina, edging ahead of Hillary Rodham Clinton in the delegate count, or that John McCain would beat all comers in Florida last night, emerging at his partys leading candidate. I was traveling a lot during those months, and I was surprised to find that the vast majority of voters I met then had effectively written off the struggling Senator Obama, while Senator McCain seemed to have disappeared from view.

description: Elizabeth B. Moynihan, the widow of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who shepherded Hillary Rodham Clinton as his successor in the United States Senate, has endorsed Barack Obama, Mrs. Clintons chief rival for the Democratic presidential nomination.

description: CNBC interviews Susan Bies, former Federal Reserve governor and Al Broaddus, former Richmond Federal Reserve president, on the Fed's rate cut.

title: For The Moment | Oki Sato, design superstar
description: This weeks guest blogger is John Jay, the Executive Creative Director and Partner of the Wieden + Kennedy advertising agency which includes Nike among its clients. Jay writes a blog for Honeyee.com in Tokyo and is a contributor to magazines in Tokyo and the U.S. on creativity and pop culture, including Tokion Japan, Giant Robot, Theme and Spread magazine. In todays post, Jay introduces the designer Oki Sato. (For all of John Jays posts, click here)

title: Clinton Will Answer Questions in National Town Hall
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will play host to a national town hall in New York City at 9 p.m. on Monday  the eve of the Democratic presidential primaries in 22 states, including New York  that will allow voters in 22 cities to ask questions through a live Webcast, Mrs. Clintons campaign just announced.

title: Growing Demand for Video on Demand
description: LAS VEGAS  Video on demand, as popularized by HBO and the major cable operators, doesnt have the cachet of online video but is increasingly gaining viewers, said Matthew Strauss, the senior vice president for new media at Comcast Cable, at a panel discussion at the National Association of Television Program Executives conference on Tuesday.

title: Obama in Denver
description: DENVER  In seven months, the Democratic Party will crown its presidential nominee here at the foot of the Rocky Mountains, the gateway to the West  and, they hope, the White House.

title: Artfully Planned Decay
description: For a renowned garden designer, all's well only if it ends well.

title: In Queens, They Speak From Experience
description: Forget your Zogby and your Quinnipiac. Cast aside your Roper and your Gallup. It was neck and neck between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama at the Woodside Senior Center on Wednesday, according to the latest sampling of an extremely informal and totally unrepresentative universe of elderly voters.

title: John Edwards Drops Out
description: The former Senator from North Carolina announced that he was ending his campaign for the Democratic nomination for president.

title: Soft Serve | Fashion Food, Fly Shampoo, Barneys Gossip
description: Soft Serve is a news feed of light reading. We scan newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

description: Does Mitt Romney have a victory to cling to in Florida? Joshua Trevino, one of the founders of the conservative blog RedState, breaks down the numbers on his personal blog.

title: New York Post Endorses Obama Over Clinton
description: The New York Post has endorsed Barack Obama in Tuesdays New York Democratic primary, saying that his chief rival for the partys presidential nomination, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, represented the politics of the past. Obama represents a fresh start, The Post stated in an editorial on its Web site. His opponent, and her husband, stand for dj vu all over again  a return to the opportunistic, scandal-scarred, morally muddled years of the almost infinitely self-indulgent Clinton co-presidency.

title: New York Post Endorses Obama
description: The New York Post has endorsed Barack Obama for president, saying his rival for the Democratic nomination, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, represented the old politics of the past. Obama represents a fresh start, The Post stated in an editorial on its Web site. His opponent, and her husband, stand for dj vu all over again  a return to the opportunistic, scandal-scarred, morally muddled years of the almost infinitely self-indulgent Clinton co-presidency.More in City Room

title: A Queens Conservative Wants to Be a Huckabee Delegate
description: In a relatively liberal bastion of western Queens, Alice Lemos said that she has found it hard to find like-minded, socially conservative New Yorkers. And to find kindred Republican spirits, she explained, she must sometimes travel outside of her neighborhood of Woodside, Queens, to other parts of the city.

title: Standoff in Minnesota Over Elephant Rides
description: A childhood rite of passage may be banned in Minneapolis on Friday, when according to The Star Tribune, the city council is expected to vote on an unusual issue: elephant rides.

title: Clipboard: The Coughlin/Manning Combination
description: A year ago, there was speculation Tom Coughlin would be fired. He had a year left on his contract and the ownership took several days to decide whether or not they wanted to bring him back for a final year. They ultimately decided to bring him back, but it was a very tepid, welcome back, yes youre still our coach sort of embrace, and they gave him a one year extension.

title: Extolling a New Buildings Virtues, Then and Now
description: The 80-story hotel and apartment tower that Larry A. Silverstein plans at 99 Church Street was described on Tuesday by the Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, which will handle condominium sales, as a project that would unquestionably advance the revitalization efforts of downtown. The architect of the project near ground zero, Robert A. M. Stern, said the tower would help Lower Manhattan realize its potential.

title: Close-up on Bathrooms, Part 1: Guest Bath
description: Friends, family members and perfect strangers have all been asking about the bathrooms: Have you decided on faucets yet? What about tile? What color schemes have you come up with?

title: Saved by Cities, if We Make Them Livable
description: I feel compelled to highlight part of a comment posted today by Gary Peters, a professor emeritus of geography and planning at California State University in Chico  about the need to smooth our journey toward being a mainly urban species, and the mixed consequences of inhabiting increasingly manufactured landscapes. A prime example is the astonishing sprawl of Tokyo, as seen from space above.

title: Endorsement Scorecard
description: While Senator Hillary Clinton of New York and Senator Barack Obama of Illinois are now eagerly vying for the endorsement of former Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, who dropped out of the race today, they have also been lining up other top Democratic officials in advance of Super Tuesday.

description: CHANDLER, Ariz.Although there has been speculation that defensive end Michael Strahan could retire if the Giants win Sundays Super Bowl, he insists he has not talked to team officials about such a scenario.

title: One for the Road
description: Its the unwritten rule of campaigns: You know theres trouble when election night features a cash bar.

title: Dont Assume Another Run, Obamas Wife Says
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Michelle Obama told a group of supporters today not to assume that her husband, Barack Obama, would return for another try at the White House, or be any more appealing as a candidate later, if this bid falls short. Its not a threat, she said. Its the reality.

title: An Idol Creator Predicts More Growth in Reality
description: LAS VEGAS  How much reality is too much reality?

title: Plotting the Post-Edwards Strategy
description: John Edwardss departure from the race Wednesday  after poor showings in Nevada and South Carolina  was no surprise. In the often cold-hearted world of politics, the time for tribute and farewell is brief, and the question quickly arises: How can the two remaining candidates benefit from Mr. Edwardss exit? And what should they do to maximize that benefit?

title: Virtual News Conference
description: For the second day this week, the N.Y. Giants and New England Patriots made players and coaches available to the news media. Questions were asked about player-coach relationships, coming back from injuries and staying even-keeled before the biggest game of their careers.

title: Netroots Unplugged
description: Was John Edwards poor showing in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination a sign that the netroots dont understand how to run a winning campaign?

title: Spectrum Auction Teeters on the Brink of Success
description: Kevin Martin, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has promised a $10 billion contribution to the federal budget from the auction of the 700-megahertz spectrum to be abandoned next year by UHF television stations.

title: Scientists Weigh In on Mercury
description: After The Times reported in a front page article on Jan. 23 that much of the tuna sushi sold in New York contained high levels of mercury, representatives of the seafood industry questioned whether that mercury posed a health risk.

title: Whats a Young American Goalkeeper to Do?
description: Mick Jones of the Clash struggled with it. Many of us have too. And now, 27 years after punks erstwhile guitarist first deliberated over the intense dilemma, a growing number of American soccer players are asking themselves: should I stay or should I go?

title: Blogtalk: Florida Shuffles the Deck
description: Floridas primaries on Tuesday definitely rearranged the field of presidential hopefuls. Two of them are gone  John Edwards and Rudolph W. Giuliani  and another has emerged as the front-runner in the Republican race, and just a few months after being all but counted out.

title: Giulianis Pre-Debate Show
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Today I am officially announcing my withdrawal as a candidate for President of the United States.

title: Clinton on Edwards
description: Within minutes of John Edwards officially dropping out of the presidential race, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton offered praise for him at a press conference.

title: The Pools of Riverside County
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  Look around at the still-life of half-built neighborhoods and red-tiled roofs, all so new, planted during the Miracle-Gro years when homes became A.T.M.s.

title: Bloggingheads: Hillary's Worse Half
description: Jon Fine of BusinessWeek, left, and Choire Sicha of The New York Observer debate whether Bill Clinton's political skills are obsolete.

title: Live Blogging the Republican Debate
description: Wrapup:  This was the Republicans last encounter before Super Tuesday, and they are still trying to make the same point theyve been trying to make for nearly a year, that each of them is the true conservative, the true son of Reagan. The context has changed drastically, though, since Mr. McCain has gone through a near-death experience, politically, and is now back after a string of successes.

title: GDP  its both better and worse than youve heard
description: Todays GDP report needs to be read a bit carefully, for three reasons.

title: Your Comments on my Dynasty Column
description: My Thursday column asks whether we should be concerned about political dynasties, and specifically by the fact that if Hillary Rodham Clinton is elected president for two terms, then 40 percent of Americans will have spent their entire lives under the presidency of a Bush or a Clinton.

title: My evil ways
description: Hmm. A little while back I learned from various sources that the reason I criticize Barack Obama is that my son works for Hillary. This was news to me, since I wasnt aware that I have any children.

title: A Day of Departure and Debate
description: John Edwards and Rudy Giuliani withdraw from the race, and the Republicans debate in California.

title: Rudolph Giuliani Withdraws from Race
description: Former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threw his support behind Senator John McCain. (NBC Video)

title: Dot Earth:The Cost of Cars
description: Andrew C. Revkin explores plans to ease traffic congestion and promote sustainability by charging drivers to use New York City streets.

title: The California Voter
description: Whatever is happening in America, it is a safe bet it is happening in California.

title: Ground Level: California
description: Campaigns in both parties have come to the conclusion that working-class voters may be a key to victory on Tuesday.

title: Report: Half of Spains Estate Agents Shut Down
description: This has the ring of urban myth, but the number is so huge it seems worth repeating: API, the trade association for Spanish property agents, is reporting that 40,000 estate agents-half the estate agents in the country-closed down last year, in the wake of the slowdown in the market. As a result, it is believed that as many as 100,000 property agents lost their jobs last year.

title: The Oscars Contingency Plan
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: Big Seller in Syndication: A Talk Show With Bonnie Hunt
description: LAS VEGAS  The Warner Bros. sales staff doesnt have to work too hard at the National Association of Television Program Executives conference this year. The syndicated show it is distributing next fall, The Bonnie Hunt Show, has already been sold to stations representing 95 percent of the country.

title: One Eye on the Fish, the Other on North Korea
description: BAENGNYEONG ISLAND, South Korea  On a clear day, one can stand on this island and see the coast of North Korea, pale and milky on the horizon, 10 miles away. The channel could be crossed in just half an hour by boat.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Slap Shot column on Sunday about the growing worth of Canadian N.H.L. franchises referred imprecisely to the interest of Alex Shnaider, a steel magnate, in buying the Toronto Maple Leafs and their properties. Although he is said to have expressed interest, and a price of $1.75 billion has been reported, Mr. Shnaider has not made such an offer.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the Giants arrival in Arizona for the Super Bowl misstated Coach Tom Coughlins history in the title game. This is his second Super Bowl appearance as a coach, not his first. (He was an assistant coach with the Giants when they won Super Bowl XXV in January 1991.)

title: Regulators Warn France on Shielding Bank
description: PARIS  As numerous European banks assess whether to make a bid for Socit Gnrale, still reeling from a devastating $7.1 billion trading loss, regulators in Brussels issued a stark warning to the French government Thursday against any effort to thwart open competition to protect one of its corporate jewels.

title: The Bill Clinton Factor, From Two More Angles
description: To the Editor:

title: Snap-Together Gadgets for the 21st-Century Tinkerer
description: Is it time to move on from Erector sets and Lego kits? BUG kits from Bug Labs give tech-loving hobbyists something new to tinker with.

title: The Mets Are Still on Probation
description: Exciting trade, but the Mets are still on probation.

title: Italian Leader Calls for Temporary Government
description: ROME  Seeking to head off early elections, President Giorgio Napolitano asked the Senate president, Franco Marini, on Wednesday to try to form a temporary government aimed at fixing Italys flawed election law.

title: Starbucks to Close Stores and End Sandwich Sales
description: At the very least, Starbucks will smell like coffee again.

title: They Kind of Knew It Wouldnt Work
description: It was the morning after the Florida presidential primary, and in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the Barrioses were disagreeing.

title: Charities Vie for Prizes in Online Giving Experiment
description: Fledgling charities, like a year-old group that rescues abandoned dogs in Georgia, are among the leading contenders for prizes in an experimental online fund-raising contest sponsored by the Case Foundation. Meanwhile, more established nonprofit groups have struggled to attract support.

title: Mutant Flu Virus Is Found That Resists Popular Drug
description: A small but significant percentage of the main influenza virus causing illness this winter in Europe, Canada and the United States has a mutation that makes it resistant to the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.

title: G.O.P. Exodus in House Bodes Ill for Fall Success
description: WASHINGTON  A swelling exodus of senior Republican incumbents from the House, worsened by a persistent disadvantage in campaign money, threatens to cripple Republican efforts to topple the Democratic majority in November.

title: Canada: Suncor Expands in Oil Sands
description: In a move that will make it the countrys largest oil sands producer, Suncor Energy said it would spend 20.6 billion Canadian dollars (about the same in American dollars) to expand operations near Fort McMurray, Alberta. The operation will be able to produce 550,000 barrels of oil a day when completed in 2012. The chief executive of Suncor, Richard L. George, said that with the new project, the company expects to generate a 15 percent return on investment at an oil price of $60 a barrel. The expansion will also allow Suncor to use an underground steam heating process rather than open-pit mining for about half of its tar sands oil production, which will reduce the effect on the environment.

title: Scout Listens to His Instincts, Not to His Boss, and Uncovers a Star
description: Andrs Reiner, a scout for the Houston Astros, watched the 15-year-old play in a tournament in Venezuela. Reiner liked the way he scooted smoothly around center field and he really liked his powerful arm. Reiner studied him for three games, enough to realize he had found an exceptional player.

title: Lasers Make Other Metals Look Like Gold
description: All that glitters golden is not gold. It could be aluminum. Or tungsten. Or another metal of Chunlei Guos choosing.

title: Museum Seeks Prophet Caricatures
description: The Museum of Danish Cartoon Art in Copenhagen, part of the Royal Library of Denmark, is in discussions to buy the 12 caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad that ignited riots leading to 50 deaths around the world after they were published in a Danish newspaper in 2005, The Art Newspaper reported. The caricatures have become a part of Danish history, Jytte Kjaergaard, a spokeswoman for the Royal Library, said. Claus Seidel, one of the cartoonists and the chairman of a Danish cartoonists association, said, We have generally agreed that we want a museum to have the works, but everyone still has to take a final decision for himself.

title: Higher Costs Cited as U.S. Shuts Down Coal Project
description: WASHINGTON  The Energy Department on Wednesday canceled its main program for demonstrating how to use coal without adding to global warming, saying the project needed an overhaul to rein in soaring costs.

title: Germany: E.ON. Fined for a Broken Security Seal
description: E.On-Energie, the electrical unit of the energy giant E.On, was fined $56 million by the European Union for a broken seal that had been placed across an office door during an antitrust investigation. The European Commission said the broken seal meant E.On had the chance to remove documents after a raid in May 2006  although it could not prove that the company had deliberately tampered with the seal or removed anything. E.On said it would appeal the fine. Regulators sealed the door to make sure no documents could be removed. When they returned the next day, signs of tampering showed that someone had removed the tape and tried to put it back, regulators said.

title: Blue-Collar Giants Revel in Unity and Obscurity
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  The Giants Tom Coughlin, a football coach for nearly 40 years, emerged from a recent meeting of his offensive linemen and wondered what aspect of football he had just witnessed.

title: Boeing Beats Wall Streets Forecast
description: CHICAGO (AP)  Boeing reported a 4 percent increase in fourth-quarter profit on Wednesday, topping Wall Streets expectations despite concerns over delays in the 787 Dreamliner.

title: Strong Holiday Season Lifts Amazons Revenue
description: Amazon.com, the leading online retailer, had a lot of good news in its financial report Wednesday, but it was overshadowed by just a small bit of bad news.

title: Pirouettes and Extensions From North of the Border
description: The act of artistic creation is often trumpeted as developing in brave opposition to oppressive regimes, and dance has had its share of highlights, from the defection of great Russian ballet stars to Chronicle, Martha Grahams antifascist work from 1936.

title: Footnotes
description: The Conor McPherson drama The Seafarer will end its run at the Booth Theater on March 30 after 19 previews and 133 regular performances. ... Take Me Along, the musical based on the Eugene ONeill comedy Ah, Wilderness!, will be presented by the Irish Repertory Theater beginning with previews on Feb. 20. Directed by Charlotte Moore, the show, with a book by Joseph Stein (Fiddler on the Roof) and Robert Russell and music and lyrics by Bob Merrill, opens on Feb. 28. ... Oprah Winfrey has made A New Earth (Penguin Group), the 2005 self-help guide by Eckhart Tolle, her latest book-club selection, The Associated Press reported. ... The appointment of Martin E. Sullivan as director of the National Portrait Gallery of the Smithsonian Institution, effective April 28, was announced on Wednesday. Mr. Sullivan, since 1999 the chief executive of the Historic St. Marys City Commission in Maryland, succeeds Marc Pachter, who retired on Jan. 25.

title: Lilly Considers $1 Billion Fine to Settle Case
description: Eli Lilly and federal prosecutors are discussing a settlement of a civil and criminal investigation into the companys marketing of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa that could result in Lillys paying more than $1 billion to federal and state governments.

title: Ailing Fortunoff Attracts a Suitor
description: One of the most storied names in New York retailing plans to bail out another.

title: China Orders Relief Efforts, but Public Is Still Angry
description: SHANGHAI  As unusually heavy snow and cold weather continued over much of China, the government on Wednesday stepped up emergency efforts to handle a crisis that threatens to become as much a public relations disaster as it has been a logistical one.

title: The Patriots Are Baffled by Burresss Crystal Ball
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. New England quarterback Tom Brady seemed perplexed Wednesday by Plaxico Burresss prediction that the Giants would beat the Patriots, 23-17, in Sundays Super Bowl.

title: Star Soprano Coaxes a Puccini Role From the Vault
description: There was basically one reason the Metropolitan Opera dusted off its drearily realistic, unbecoming old production of Puccinis Manon Lescaut and brought it back to the house for the first time in 18 years on Tuesday night: the soprano Karita Mattila.

title: Well-Dressed Travels Well
description: IN fashion the swaggering march of progress sometimes offers more questions than answers. Like, why does a minor yet sublime improvement (upgrading to cashmere socks or handmade shoes, say) always take a back seat to some Dutch-designed, laser-cut, steel-paillette tank top that struts up and down a runway, to be worn maybe once more  by a model on the cover of Angst?

title: Romney and McCain Tangle at Debate, but Also Try to Mold a Two-Man Race
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Mitt Romney tried to slow Senator John McCains momentum Wednesday night as their final debate before the Tuesday contests turned into a raucous and occasionally angry clash over their conservative credentials, the war in Iraq, their government records and charges and countercharges of dirty campaigning.

title: Bush Seeks Surplus via Medicare Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  In his new budget, to be unveiled Monday, President Bush will call for large cuts in the growth of Medicare, far exceeding what he proposed last year, and he will again seek major savings in Medicaid, according to administration officials and budget documents.

title: Pennsylvania: More Police in Philadelphia
description: Philadelphias new police commissioner promised to decrease gun violence in the city sharply by putting 200 more officers on the street, using stop and frisk searches in tough neighborhoods and installing 200 more surveillance cameras. The commissioner, Charles Ramsey, who spent eight years as police chief in Washington, set a goal of reducing killings by 25 percent this year, in large part by allocating more officers to the most violent neighborhoods. There were 392 killings in 2007 in Philadelphia, and 406 in 2006.

title: A Warning on Insurers Frays Nerves
description: While the Federal Reserve tried to soothe Wall Streets nerves on Wednesday, a hedge fund manager frayed them by warning that two pillars of the financial markets might crumble.

title: Keeping an Eye on Chinas Security
description: HONG KONG  Since Imperial times, Chinese governments have relied on neighbors to inform on each other as a way to preserve social control.

title: A Face-Off, Not Necessarily Televised
description: The Democrats may be planning a traditional use of television advertising, but their Republican counterparts are approaching the contest differently.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a dance review in Weekend on Friday about New York City Ballet and the world premiere of Oltremare referred incorrectly to a dancer at one point. The dancer, Tiler Peck, is a woman.

title: A Handmade Home
description: CORNVILLE, Ariz.

title: Australia to Apologize to Aborigines for Past Mistreatment
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The new government of Prime Minister Kevin Rudd says it will apologize for past mistreatment of Australias Aboriginal minority when Parliament convenes next month, addressing an issue that has blighted race relations in the country for years.

title: Jimmy James, P.O.W. Plotter of Escapes, Is Dead at 92
description: Jimmy James, a British flier in World War II obsessed with escape plots during his five years in German captivity, most prominently the breakout portrayed in the movie The Great Escape, died Jan. 18 in Shrewsbury, England. Mr. James, who lived in Ludlow, England, was 92.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: New York: Images and Preservation

title: The Dynastic Question
description: In a presidential campaign that has involved battles over everything from Iraq to drivers licenses, one sweeping topic has gone curiously unexamined: Does it diminish American democracy if we keep the presidency in the same two families that have held it since 1989?

title: Abruptly, Edwards Ends His White House Bid
description: NEW ORLEANS  As of Tuesday afternoon, John Edwardss campaign staff members were still heading to North Dakota and Georgia. A television advertising campaign was about to hit the airwaves. And that evening Mr. Edwards was flying here to deliver what was billed as a major speech on poverty.

title: Google Earnings Fall Short of Expectations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said Thursday that its profits jumped 17 percent in the fourth quarter as sales grew at a healthy 51 percent, propelled by continued strength in the companys core search advertising business. The results fell short of analysts expectations, raising concerns that the Internet search giant will not be immune from the economic slowdown.

title: Documentary to Compete in Berlin
description: A film about the prisoner abuse scandal at the Abu Ghraib jail in Iraq will become the first documentary to enter the competition at the Berlin International Film Festival when it is shown next month, Agence France-Presse reported. Made by the Oscar-winning director Errol Morris (The Fog of War), above, the documentary, Standard Operating Procedure, uses film, re-enactments and photographs that were published around the world to shed light on the treatment of inmates. Twenty-one films will vie for awards during the 58th Berlin film festival, running Feb. 7-17.

title: Burress Stirs Up Controversy Without Showing Up
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  It seems Plaxico Burress can draw a crowd even when he is not present.

title: Stocks Rally as Concern Over Bond Insurer Eases
description: Inflation on the rise. Consumers cutting back. Investment banks on edge. Thursday had all the ingredients for a bearish day on Wall Street.

title: U.S. Growth Slowed Drastically in 4th Quarter
description: The United States economy expanded by a disappointingly weak annual rate of 0.6 percent during the last three months of 2007, the government reported Wednesday, offering the latest indication that the United States is already suffering a substantial slowdown, and perhaps a recession.

title: On Demand, on Time and for a Fee, an Army of Tutors Appears
description: JEN cut her pie into 12 pieces and ate 9, and then Louisa cut her pie into 8 pieces and ate 6, which for some reason prompted me to open a bottle of white wine and drink two glasses.

title: Rally Sputters in a Late-Day Sell-Off
description: A Fed rally on Wall Street abruptly fizzled Wednesday as excitement over an interest rate cut gave way to concern about a new round of problems related to subprime mortgages.

title: In This War, How to Ally With Both
description: The electronics industry has spent billions of dollars on a stupid and unnecessary battle between the next-generation DVD formats: Blu-ray and HD DVD. And so far, its all been pretty much for nothing; consumers arent touching the things. Nobody wants to risk buying a DVD player that can play only half of the worlds movies.

title: Michigan: Detroits Mayor Says He Wont Quit
description: Detroits mayor emerged after nearly a week in seclusion and apologized to the citys residents for having had an affair with his chief of staff and lying about it under oath. But the mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, said he would not step down. Mr. Kilpatrick was joined by his wife, Carlita. I truly apologize to each and every one of you individually and to the whole city, Mr. Kilpatrick said. Mr. Kilpatrick, 37, did not mention his former chief of staff, Christine Beatty, who quit her job Monday, nor did he address his potential exposure to perjury charges. The Wayne County prosecutor is investigating whether Mr. Kilpatrick or Ms. Beatty should be charged criminally.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $6,987,843

title: Economic Stimulus, Gridiron Style
description: The bulls are rooting for Wall Street's home team, the New York Giants. Or at least they should be if they believe that football results influence the stock market. On average, the market goes up after the Giants win the Super Bowl and down when they lose. The opposite is true for the New England Patriots.

title: Official Sees Kenyan Ethnic Cleansing
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The top American diplomat for Africa said Wednesday that some of the violence that has swept across Kenya in the past month has been ethnic cleansing intended to drive people from their homes, but that it should not be considered genocide.

title: Female Student Sues Hofstra
description: A former athletic manager for Hofstra Universitys football team said in a federal discrimination lawsuit that players sexually harassed her repeatedly, including when an assistant played a sexually explicit film on a team bus. Lauren Summa, a 23-year-old graduate student, said that her complaints to coaches and university officials went unheeded, and that she was dropped from the teams athletic staff after speaking out. Hofstras vice president for university relations, Melissa Connolly, said in a statement the college was confident that all matters relating to these allegations were handled appropriately.

title: Cleric Urges a Science and Religion Dialogue
description: Prompted by what he called the increasingly vocal hostility of some religions to science, and some scientists to religion, the president of the United Church of Christ has appealed for both groups to communicate more openly and to recognize, as he put it, that each has something to contribute to the other.

title: Doctor Accused of Leak to Drug Maker
description: A leading member of the Senate said Wednesday that a prominent diabetes expert had leaked an unpublished and confidential medical journal article to GlaxoSmithKline last year, tipping the company to the imminent publication of safety questions involving the companys diabetes drug Avandia.

title: After Mining Deal, Financier Donated to Clinton
description: Late on Sept. 6, 2005, a private plane carrying the Canadian mining financier Frank Giustra touched down in Almaty, a ruggedly picturesque city in southeast Kazakhstan. Several hundred miles to the west a fortune awaited: highly coveted deposits of uranium that could fuel nuclear reactors around the world. And Mr. Giustra was in hot pursuit of an exclusive deal to tap them.

title: An Investigation Focuses on Antiquities Dealer
description: CERRITOS, Calif.  Robert Olson hardly looks like the head of a smuggling ring specializing in Asian antiquities.

title: Mukasey Will Not Rule Out Waterboarding
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey said Wednesday that while he would consider it torture if he underwent the harsh Central Intelligence Agency interrogation technique known as waterboarding, the practice was not necessarily illegal, and he would not rule out its use in the future.

title: Pakistani Justice Breaks Silence
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, the former chief justice of Pakistan who was removed last year when President Pervez Musharraf imposed a state of emergency, has finally broken his silence.

title: Simpler Labels for Food Content Proposed
description: The European Commission proposed simpler food labels highlighting fat, sugar and salt content in an effort to contain the spread of obesity and junk food. Under the proposals, six content elements will have to appear on packages: energy, total fat, saturated fat, carbohydrates, sugar and salts. The labels will indicate what percentage of advisable daily intake they represent. Consumers have to be able to make the right choice. They need the right information to plan their diet, the health commissioner Markos Kyprianou, above, said. The proposals exclude beer, wine and spirits. They will now be taken up by the European Parliament and must be approved by member nations.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: A Melancholic Baptisia

title: Congestion Pricing Plan Is Panned in Albany
description: A plan to ease traffic in Manhattan received harsh reviews this week in Albany.

title: Big-Donor Politics Elude North Dakota
description: BISMARCK, N.D.  Consider the tactic one local Democratic Party leader in this state resorted to last summer to raise money. He chained hot-pink plywood elephants, 2 1/2 feet tall and 2 1/2 feet wide, to trees in the yards of known Democrats, then offered to remove the Republican beasts in exchange for $25 donations.

title: No. 1 in a Slow Race
description: Last week was another miserable one for music sales, but with one modest highlight: The indie-heavy Juno movie soundtrack rose one spot to the top of the Billboard chart, becoming the first album in Rhino Records three-decade history to reach No. 1. After the announcement of four Oscar nominations for Juno, including best picture, the soundtrack sold 65,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping Alicia Keyss As I Am (J), which moved 60,000, to No. 2. In the fourth straight week of very low sales, Natasha Bedingfield opened at No. 3 with 50,000 copies of Pocketful of Sunshine (Epic), Mary J. Bliges Growing Pains (Geffen) sold 45,000 to reach No. 4, and Radiohead dropped one spot to No. 5 with In Rainbows (ATO), moving 35,000. Cat Powers new Jukebox (Matador) reached No. 12 with 29,000 copies sold.

title: The Rookie Eli Manning
description: Back in December 2004, Eli Manning had just taken over as the starting quarterback of the Giants, replacing Kurt Warner, a former most valuable player. Michael Lewis, a regular contributor to PLAY, profiled the elusive, private, and talented young quarterback for The New York Times Magazine, explaining how the team's fortunes were tied to the youngest Manning:

title: Weak Dollar Has Small Businesses Thinking Globally
description: THE declining dollar spurred Peggy Karr Glass to exhibit its handmade fused glass products at a spring trade show in London.

title: Thailand: Nose-Holding for the New Leader
description: Sign language interpreters in Thailand have run afoul of supporters among the governing party by holding their noses to refer to the new prime minister, Samak Sundaravej. Thai sign language interpreters often indicate prominent facial features as shorthand for dignitaries, and during a live broadcast of the parliamentary session on Monday that selected Mr. Samak, left, they held their noses between two fingers to refer to him. It is not meant as a nose joke, said one interpreter, Kanittha Rattanasin. We have touched our noses for years to refer to Samak, but people noticed this time because we had to repeat the movement over 300 times. Another interpreter, Juthamas Suthonwattanacharoen, said supporters of Mr. Samak, who is nicknamed Mr. Rose Apple Nose because many claim his nose resembles the long, Asian fruit, have called the National Association of the Deaf in Thailand to say the sign does not befit the countrys leader. For now, there are no plans to change it, she said.

title: Delay in Decision on Protecting Polar Bears
description: A decision on whether to protect Alaskas polar bears under the Endangered Species Act might not be made before the government opens a major bear habitat to oil leases next week, although staff recommendations are complete, the Fish and Wildlife Service chief, Dale Hall, said. Mr. Hall faced criticism at a Senate hearing from lawmakers who accused the Interior Department of stalling to make it easier for oil companies to obtain drilling leases in the Chukchi Sea, where a fifth of the Arctics polar bears depend on sea ice in their hunt for food. Another Interior Department agency, the Minerals Management Service, plans to open a large area of the Chukchi Sea to oil and gas leases on Wednesday. Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California and chairwoman of the Environment and Natural Resources Committee, demanded a commitment to take immediate action to protect the bears.

title: H.P. Case to Go Forward in India
description: NEW DELHI  A decision by Indias highest court may force international companies who outsource business here to do more to guard the safety of local workers.

title: Arthur B. Kramer, Lawyer and Brother of Playwright Larry Kramer, Dies at 81
description: Arthur B. Kramer, who built a small New York law firm into one with international reach and whose fraught relationship with his brother, Larry Kramer, the playwright and gay rights advocate, helped inspire a benchmark play of the 1980s, died on Saturday. He was 81 and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: While the Election Watchdog Wanders
description: The presidential campaigns heated fund-raising sweepstakes finds lobbyists hurriedly bundling  amassing additional hundreds of thousands from donors to re-stake surviving contenders for the next primary rounds. (Lobbyists reportedly bundled $300,000 for Senator John McCain in one night in Washington after his stock revived on the campaign trail.)

title: South Korea Wins Handball Replay
description: South Korea defeated Japan, 28-25, Wednesday in a replay of a qualifying match for the mens handball tournament at the Beijing Olympics. The Asian qualifiers were initially held in September, when referees from Jordan and Iran were assigned at the last minute by the Asian Handball Federation to replace German referees.Their disputed calls helped Kuwait win the mens tournament and Kazakhstan the womens, qualifying them for the Olympics. In December, the International Handball Federation ordered replays of the qualifiers.The Asian federation has denied match fixing and has said it will punish countries taking part in the replays (Japan and South Korea). South Koreas womens team defeated Japan on Tuesday to advance to the Beijing Olympics.

title: In Europe, Questions Over Continuing Write-Downs
description: FRANKFURT  When UBS disclosed in October that it had written down $3.6 billion in mortgage-backed securities, it was praised for biting the bullet.

title: A Coffee Shop Closes, and Therell Be Sad Songs Down at Morys
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Sony Profit Increases 25 Percent
description: TOKYO  Sony said Thursday that its profit rose more than 25 percent in the final three months of 2007, helped by robust sales of televisions and computer games. But it said the strong yen and subprime problems would weigh on demand this year.

title: And Blessed Are the Singing, Pole-Dancing Fetishists
description: Oh hear America singing, citizens of New York, as you never have heard it before.
