Hearken to your everyday sisters and brothers  the lost, the lonely, the fetishists, the freaks  as their voices swell and meld into one common chord of longing: to be seen, to be heard, to be (oh yes) famous.

title: The Slow Life Picks Up Speed
description: I HAVE a little spiel I like to give about thread, Natalie Chanin said the other day. The ladies laugh at me and call it my Oprah moment, but heres how it goes: Its called loving your thread, and its all about talking to the thread, coaxing it to take the path of least resistance. At the crux of it, thats what Slow Design is all about.

title: Stopping iPhoto From Starting
description: Q. Every time I plug in my Sony digital camera to my Mac Powerbook, iPhoto automatically launches, even though I never use iPhoto for anything. I just want to download my images and edit them with Photoshop or view them with Preview. But every time I have to quit iPhoto. How can I fix this?

title: A Long Ramble Along the Road to the Blues
description: The North Mississippi Allstars dont believe in squandering words. Within the first five songs at the Highline Ballroom on Tuesday night, the bands lead singer and guitarist, Luther Dickinson, managed to wring several different connotations out of the verb shake. It first appeared as a frisky command. (Shake what your mama gave you.) Then it propelled a carnal boast. (We gonna shake em on down.) Its next usage was more descriptive: Shes shakin like a leaf/Tremblin on a tree.

title: Ronaldo Leads Manchester United
description: Cristiano Ronaldo scored two goals to lead Manchester United over visiting Portsmouth, 2-0, Wednesday and back into first place in the English Premier League. Manchester United (18-3-3) and Arsenal (17-1-6) each have 57 points; United leads on goal difference.

title: Officers Slaying Leaves New Orleans Asking Why
description: NEW ORLEANS  On Monday morning, in a bleak shopping strip almost under the Pontchartrain Expressway, Bernel P. Johnson wrestled the gun away from a young police officer and shot her dead. When backup officers arrived, he handed them the weapon.

title: Moynihan Backed Clinton; His Widow Backs Obama
description: Elizabeth B. Moynihan, the widow of Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York senator who, from a hayfield on his upstate farm, helped shepherd Hillary Rodham Clinton into his Senate seat, has endorsed Barack Obama for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Americas Riveting Democracy
description: BERLIN

title: Two Hits Buoy Fox
description: Fox dominated the ratings on Tuesday, thanks to two popular shows, American Idol at 8 p.m. and House at 9. Those shows delivered 28.1 million and 22.5 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. A repeat of CBSs NCIS at 8 attracted the nights third-largest audience (11.7 million). CBSs all-rerun lineup tied NBC for runner-up on the night, but NBC fared better among adults 18 to 49 with The Biggest Loser at 8 (8.3 million) followed by Law & Order: Special Victims Unit at 10 (9.4 million). ABC finished fourth overall. On Monday President Bushs final State of the Union address attracted the smallest audience of his two terms, 37.5 million viewers. That tally was 8 million fewer than a year ago, but 6 million more than President Clintons last State of the Union address in 2000. The speech was broadcast live at 9 p.m. on a total of nine network and cable channels.

title: Afghanistan: Road Workers Beheaded
description: Four Afghan road construction workers were discovered beheaded in Kamdesh, in northeastern Nuristan Province, the provincial governor said. The Interior Ministry confirmed the beheadings and said the men were kidnapped last week and a ransom had been demanded. It blamed the Taliban. The army recently mounted an operation in the Kamdesh area and killed a number of Taliban fighters, including a commander, the governor said, and he suggested that the beheadings were an act of revenge.

title: Assassins, Hot Cars and Post-Apocalyptic Struggle, With a Dash of HDTV
description: When I bought a big television 15 years ago, my wife at that time said it was like a billboard announcing that our lives revolved entirely around TV. With the advent of the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, which support high-definition TV, my television had become a billboard announcing that I could not afford a proper display for my video games.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. There are so many kinds of mosaic tile. How do I choose something interesting and tasteful?

title: Nuclear Scientists
description: To the Editor:

title: Fleeting or for Real?
description: Even late into the regular season, Eli Mannings erratic play prompted questions about whether he could take himself  and the Giants  to the next level. His game improved dramatically in the playoffs, which makes us wonder: Is Mannings recent performance what we should we expect from him on Sunday and in the future, or just sudden and short-lived?

title: Needing a Hail Mary, Fans Find a Monastery
description: PHOENIX  There is no sauna, no heated pool, no chauffeur or sommelier. In fact, no alcohol is allowed on the premises, and guests share a bathroom with their next-door neighbor.

title: Digital S.L.R.s for the Beginner, With Ways to Reduce Shakes While Shaking Off the Dust
description: The Photo Marketing Association convention, which opens Thursday in Las Vegas, is the arena where camera-gear companies battle for market share and mind share. Some combatants have faded in the move from film to digital, but Nikon and Canon continue to duke it out with hardware that sets the tone for the show and the industry.

title: Ohio: Rebuff for Man Called a Nazi Guard
description: A former autoworker from Cleveland who is accused of being a Nazi death camp guard lost another battle in his 30-year fight to maintain his American citizenship and residence. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit rejected a challenge from the man, John Demjanjuk, 87, above, to a final deportation order by the nations chief immigration judge. The order would send Mr. Demjanjuk to Germany, Poland or his native Ukraine. The government initially claimed Mr. Demjanjuk was the notoriously sadistic guard at the Treblinka camp known as Ivan the Terrible. Officials later concluded that he was not, but a judge ruled in 2002 that documents from World War II prove Mr. Demjanjuk was a Nazi guard.

title: Credit Card Processor Sues Blackstone to Finish Buyout
description: Another broken Wall Street deal headed to court on Wednesday as Alliance Data Systems sued the Blackstone Group, seeking to force the private equity firm to complete its $6.4 billion buyout of the company.

title: Big Vote Day Looms for Narrowed Field
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Rudolph W. Giuliani, the combative former Republican mayor of New York City, and John Edwards, the Democrat who ran for the White House as an anti-poverty populist, both dropped out of the presidential race on Wednesday, leaving a narrowed field hurtling toward what amounts to a national primary next week.

title: A Form of Internet Piracy That Involves Actual (Virtual) Pirates
description: What do Henry Morgan and Blackbeard have in common with Luke Skywalker and Merlin? They have all captured the imagination of millions through tales of their daring deeds, and now they have all inspired online role-playing games.

title: Electronic Arts Posts Loss but Record Revenue
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Electronic Arts swung to a loss Thursday because of restructuring charges and deferred revenue, but posted record revenue during the most brisk holiday season the video game industry has seen.

title: Jury Shown Store Video in Death of 7-Year-Old
description: The jury in the trial of a Brooklyn man charged with killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter watched a surveillance video on Wednesday that prosecutors are hinting is crucial to their case.

title: Absent With Leave: Missing the Big Game
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  Jeremy Shockey left a voice-mail message for Mike Pope, the Giants tight ends coach, with about five minutes left in the National Football Conference championship game.

title: After the Fed
description: Whether or not the Federal Reserves recent dramatic interest rate cuts are the right medicine for todays stalling economy  and the jury is very much out on that  it is clear that the Fed has used up a big chunk of its recession-fighting ammunition in a very short span of time. In just over a week, it has slashed its benchmark interest rate by a total of 1.25 percentage points, to 3 percent. That doesnt leave a lot of room to cut further without opening the door to a potentially nasty upsurge in prices, which are already rising at a worrisome rate, and a possible disorderly decline in the dollar.

title: The Official Line vs. the Betting Line
description: They were not only close friends and founding fathers of the N.F.L., but Art Rooney and Tim Mara were also gamblers, proud ones. In 1936, Rooney, whose family still owns the Pittsburgh Steelers, famously turned two prescient days at the racetrack into $300,000. In 1925, Mara, a bookmaker in the days when that profession was not only legal but honorable, paid $500 for the New York Giants.

title: Mcgahee Replaces Tomlinson
description: San Diego Chargers running back LaDainian Tomlinson withdrew from the Pro Bowl, paving the way for Baltimore Ravens running back Willis McGahee to make his first appearance in the game. McGahee earned a spot on the American Conference team because Tomlinson has a sprained knee.

title: Tainted Drugs Tied to Maker of Abortion Pill
description: BEIJING  A huge state-owned Chinese pharmaceutical company that exports to dozens of countries, including the United States, is at the center of a nationwide drug scandal after nearly 200 Chinese cancer patients were paralyzed or otherwise harmed last summer by contaminated leukemia drugs.

title: U.S. Accused of Overlooking Rights Violations
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration is giving lip service to promoting democracy by endorsing suspect elections in Kenya, Nigeria and Pakistan while allowing human rights violations in those countries to go unchecked, the advocacy group Human Rights Watch said Thursday.

title: Lenovo Sells Phone Unit
description: The Lenovo Group, the personal computer maker, said Thursday that it planned to sell its slumping cellphone unit so that it could focus on its personal computer business.

title: Rebate Psychology
description: Chicago

title: A Warning on Insurers Frays Nerves
description: While the Federal Reserve tried to soothe Wall Streets nerves on Wednesday, a hedge fund manager frayed them by warning that two pillars of the financial markets might crumble.

title: Recent Moves by Guild Leaders Rattle Writers Talks
description: LOS ANGELES  Promising closed-door talks aimed at settling Hollywoods three-month-old strike by movie and television writers have been jolted in the last few days by the actions of some prominent guild leaders.

title: Miles to Go Before Martin Finishes Journey
description: Sages have said we must walk a mile in another persons shoes before we can pass judgment. Unless the shoes belong to George Martin. Then you have to walk 1,600 miles.

title: Beauty Blogs Come of Age: Swag, Please!
description: TWO years ago, when beauty bloggers called makeup companies to request free samples, many calls went unreturned.

title: Bringing the Internet and Television a Step Closer Together
description: As the fusion of the Internet and television continues to evolve, new hardware has been popping up in the living room. With its circular design, Sonys Vaio TP Home Theater PC stands out on a home entertainment shelf full of typical black and silver boxes  and brings a Blu-ray disc player, HDTV recorder and a full Windows Vista Home Premium system into the mix.

title: Consumer Spending Falls Off
description: Consumer spending slowed in December and inflation continued to rise, the government said Thursday, leaving the Federal Reserve little leeway as it ponders policy decisions in the months ahead.

title: City Catholic School League Makes National Impact
description: After several years of steady if unspectacular play, New York Citys Catholic High School Athletic Association Class AA boys basketball league has returned to prominence  as much for its talent as for its depth.

title: Profit Up, Lazard Defies Investment Banking Trend
description: While other financial services companies are bleeding, Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, stood out Wednesday by reporting a 43 percent jump in its fourth-quarter profits from the period a year ago.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, the On Religion column on Saturday, about Lonely Man of Faith, a film on Joseph Soloveitchik, the important 20th-century Orthodox rabbi, referred incorrectly to its success rate at film festivals. Although it was turned down by the New York Jewish Film Festival, it did indeed appear at Jewish film festivals elsewhere; it was not turned down by all major Jewish festivals.

title: Fleecing the Sheep, Who Keep Coming Back for More
description: In 1917 the charlatan John R. Brinkley experienced what was truly a seminal moment. This so-called doctor, whose diploma had come from a medical school that was vague, obliging and long defunct and whose expertise was dubious at best (if the white coat reassured people, the healing had begun), was consulting with a 46-year-old Kansas farmer named Bill Stittsworth. Im all in, Stittsworth said. No pep. Im a flat tire.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Wednesday with an article about efforts to block Southern Methodist University from housing the George W. Bush Presidential Library misstated an action of the librarys opponents. As the article noted, Methodists opposed to the library are lobbying members of a regional church conference to vote against the library; the opponents did not force the conference to hold that vote.

title: Power Failures Outrage South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  At first, the power blackouts seemed a mere nuisance, the electricity suddenly dead for two or three hours at a time, two or three times a day. Radio announcers jocularly advised listeners to make their morning toast by vigorously rubbing two pieces of bread together and wisecracked about amorous uses for the extra darkness.

title: Office Tower to Rise in Harlem for Baseball TV Network
description: Major League Baseball plans to build a home on 125th Street, Harlems premier boulevard, for its cable network, which is scheduled to make its debut early next year with some 50 million subscribers, real estate and baseball executives said on Wednesday.

title: One Town, 2 Campaigns for President
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

title: Correction
description: Editors' Note

title: Peter Staudhammer, Who Designed NASA Instruments, Dies at 73
description: Peter Staudhammer, a wide-ranging aerospace engineer and executive who helped design instruments and engines used by NASA in landings on Mars and the Moon, died on Jan. 14 at his home in La Quinta, Calif. He was 73.

title: Desert Attractions
description: PHOENIX -- While you wouldn't exactly label metropolitan Phoenix as culture-drenched, there is at least a healthy handful of intriguing local attractions to fit into your itinerary if you're out for the Super Bowl. Start with the Heard Museum on North Central Avenue, 10 minutes north of downtown Phoenix. Arguably the nation's finest showcase of Native American culture, the Heard dishes out historical information and artistic works by Southwestern tribes such as the Apache, Hopi, Navajo and Zuni. Not to be missed are the lodging exhibits, which include a Navajo Hogan and an Apache wickiup. www.heard.org, 602-252-8848; admission, $10; open daily, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.

title: High-Energy Cartoons, Drawn in Jazz
description: David King, the drummer of the trio Happy Apple, is a heavy-gauge clown, honest, graceful and intuitive. He looks as if hes constantly subverting his own nature around the drums. His body language says hes going to cream them, really boss them around, but at the last instant he hesitates, hitting lightly or leaving a blank.

title: Lelouch to Open Festival
description: The United States premiere of Roman de Gare, directed by Claude Lelouch (A Man and a Woman) and starring Dominique Pinon and Fanny Ardant, right, will open the 13th Rendezvous With French Cinema on Feb. 29 at the Walter Reade Theater. The movie, about a best-selling novelist whose plots bear similarities to the acts of a serial killer, will be one of 15 films shown at the Walter Reade and the IFC Center in Manhattan through March 9.

title: Lawmaker Demands That Ashcroft Testify
description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee demanded that former Attorney General John Ashcroft testify about his appointment to oversee a Justice Department corporate settlement. The chairman, Representative John Conyers Jr., a Michigan Democrat, said Mr. Ashcroft had not returned calls inviting him to appear on Feb. 26 before a subcommittee that is reviewing the hiring of former government officials as corporate monitors. Mr. Ashcroft, who runs a consulting firm in Washington, is supervising a settlement between the government and Zimmer Holdings Inc., the worlds biggest maker of artificial hips and knees. For 18 months work, the company says it will pay him $28 million to $52 million.

title: Iraqi Troops Mass for Operation in Mosul
description: BAGHDAD  The unsettled situation in northern Iraq continued Wednesday as Iraqi troops massed in Mosul to fight Sunni Arab extremists, and a Turkmen political group in Kirkuk threatened to resort to arms in response to the kidnapping and killing of Turkmens by extremists.

title: In North Dakota Forget Money. Politics Is Different.
description: BISMARCK, N.D.  Consider the tactic one local Democratic Party leader in this state resorted to last summer to raise money. He chained hot pink plywood elephants, 2-and-a-half feet tall and 2-and-a-half feet wide, to trees in the yards of known Democrats, then offered to remove the Republican beasts in exchange for $25 donations.

title: Rams Hire Saunders
description: The St. Louis Rams signed Al Saunders to a three-year contract as offensive coordinator, another step in an overhaul of the coaching staff after a three-win season. Saunders was fired by the Washington Redskins last Saturday after two seasons in the same job.

title: Battle Concussions Tied to Stress Disorder
description: About one in six combat troops returning from Iraq have suffered at least one concussion in the war, injuries that, while temporary, could heighten their risk of developing post-traumatic stress disorder, researchers are reporting.

title: Judge in Courthouse Shooting Case Steps Down
description: ATLANTA  The judge presiding over the quadruple-murder trial in the case of the 2005 shooting at the Fulton County Courthouse removed himself from the case on Wednesday after an article in The New Yorker quoted him as saying of the defendant, Brian Nichols, that everyone in the world knows he did it.

title: Imus Marches On
description: Viewers in Washington, Boston, Chicago and San Francisco, among other big cities, moved a step closer on Wednesday to watching the simulcast of the Don Imus morning radio show on RFD-TV, a cable channel. Patrick Gottsch, the founder and president of RFD, which primarily chronicles life in rural America, said that he had signed an affiliation agreement with Comcast. With the agreement RFD-TV is authorized to begin negotiations with individual Comcast cable systems. Comcast is available in more than 24 million households. While RFD-TV is available in 30 million homes, many are in towns and small cities outside the Northeast; the exception are those that receive the channel via satellite. Jenni Moyer, a Comcast spokeswoman, confirmed the deal. In signing Mr. Imus last year after his firing by CBS Radio and MSNBC over a racial remark, Mr. Gottsch was hoping that Mr. Imus would become a lure for big-city cable operators. RFD is seeking a similar agreement with Time Warner Cable, which has systems in New York City and Los Angeles.

title: Bank Defies French Elite and Keeps Chief, for Now
description: PARIS The board of Socit Gnrale gathered Wednesday in a conference room on the 35th floor of the banks headquarters outside Paris. The chairman of the nominating committee reminded them that the resignation of the chairman and chief executive, Daniel Bouton, was still on the table.

title: Suddenly, Seton Hall Looks Like a Surging Team
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Seton Hall was playing a dangerous team, a resurgent Rutgers group that was coming off back-to-back victories against ranked opponents. But the Scarlet Knights ran into a hotter team Wednesday night at the Louis Brown Athletic Center.

title: A Landscape in Winter, Dying Heroically
description: HUMMELO, The Netherlands

title: Tip of the Week: Shortcuts for Microsoft Word
description: Microsoft Word includes keyboard shortcuts for quickly inserting the current date and time into your documents and memos. On most Windows versions of Word, press Alt+Shift+D to automatically add the date into the text of your document, or Alt+Shift+T to add the time. (On the Mac edition of Word, press Shift+Control+D or Shift+Control+T to get the same results.)

title: Undersized Patriots Are Shedding Their Anonymity
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Another game is approaching, so the familiar fear is due to arrive in Dante Scarnecchias head any day. For years, he has had it just before every game, especially the 2004 Super Bowl against the Carolina Panthers, when three of his opening-day starters were on injured reserve.

title: Magic Johnson Sees the Knicks in the Playoffs
description: SALT LAKE CITY  The Knicks went 0 for California, but Coach Isiah Thomas left the state with some nice parting gifts  a warm hug and a big endorsement, both from his longtime friend Magic Johnson.

title: Scaffold Falls, Killing Worker in Brooklyn
description: A construction worker fell 12 stories to his death in Brooklyn on Wednesday when the scaffold he was standing on collapsed, apparently because of high winds, according to city officials and witnesses.

title: Managers Proceed With Shuttle Mission Plans
description: WASHINGTON  Pending resolution of a potential radiator hose problem, the space shuttle Atlantis is scheduled for launching on Feb. 7 on a twice-delayed mission to the International Space Station, NASA managers said Wednesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the difficulties facing the Federal Reserve misstated the federal funds rate after the Feds policy-making committee made a quarter-point cut in December. It was 4.25 percent, not 3.5 percent. (The Feds three-quarter-point cut last week reduced the rate to 3.5 percent.)

title: European Election Monitors May Boycott Russia Vote
description: MOSCOW  European election observers warned Wednesday that they might once again refuse to take part in a Russian election, saying the government was still imposing unacceptable restrictions on their work.

title: Editors Note
description: An article in the Itineraries section of Business Day on Tuesday reported on the increasing popularity of blogs written by or aimed at business travelers. The article reported that a directory of travel blogs that is known as BoardingArea.com, started by Randy Petersen, founder of the online forum FlyerTalk, would feature nine such blogs, including one by Joe Sharkey, who also writes the weekly business travel column On the Road for The New York Times. The article referred imprecisely to the terms of Mr. Sharkeys participation. Mr. Petersen has offered a small payment to reprint Mr. Sharkeys blog. While some of the blogs will seek advertising, referred to in the article as sponsorships, the one Mr. Sharkey writes is not among them, and he should have been asked what its relationship with BoardingArea.com was before the article was published.

title: For Knicks, New City, Same Desultory Result
description: SALT LAKE CITY  As the final second ticked off the clock late Wednesday night, Mardy Collins fired the ball 60 feet toward the far basket. The buzzer sounded, the ball clanged and the Knicks  drained, ill and foul-tempered  dragged themselves off the court and to the next city.

title: This Years Super Bowl Ads to Be Gentle and Sweet
description: NO matter how rough the action gets on the field on Sunday, when the New England Patriots meet the New York Giants in Super Bowl XLII, the advertisers will be playing nice.

title: Sprawling, Diverse State Poses Special Challenge for Candidates
description: REDLANDS, Calif.  The most trenchant symbol of the California presidential primary can be found on an isolated stretch of Interstate 15, smack in the middle of the Mojave Desert. There, affixed to an old trailer, is possibly the largest candidate billboard in the entire state, and it is for the Republican fringe candidate, Ron Paul.

title: Better Pay for Federal Judges
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to vote today on a proposed pay raise for federal judges  an issue of considerable importance to the quality and independence of the judiciary.

title: Formatting Lost in the Mail
description: Q. When I format my e-mail with italic, underscore or boldface, my recipient cant see it. I have Microsoft Outlook set to compose in HTML, so why cant my recipient see the message as I sent it?

title: 2 Accused of Keeping Girl, 13, as Prostitute
description: A police detective and his female companion kidnapped a 13-year-old runaway girl and forced her into prostitution with 20 men at private parties, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Myanmar: Prepare for the Worst, Suu Kyi Advises
description: The pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was allowed a rare respite from house arrest to meet with members of her party, the National League for Democracy. A party spokesman reported that she had criticized the series of meetings she has held since October with Aung Kyi, a senior junta official  they met for the fifth time after her meeting with party colleagues  for failing to set a deadline to achieve any real political change. She also cautioned the nation to hope for the best but prepare for the worst, the spokesman said.

title: No Tomorrow? 95 Years of Yesterdays
description: The singer Tony Martin may be his generations Last Man Standing. A belting crooner of the old school whose 1949 hit, Theres No Tomorrow, adapted from O Sole Mio, predated Its Now or Never, Elvis Presleys version of the same Italian melody (with different lyrics) by 11 years, he turned 95 last December.

title: Like Giuliani, New York G.O.P. Rushes to McCain
description: New Yorks Republican establishment rushed to embrace Senator John McCain on Wednesday, with party leaders expressing confidence that his appeal to independents could help fend off a Democratic sweep that might cost them the State Senate in November.

title: Israeli Court Rejects Appeal to Ease Restrictions on Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected an appeal to block Israel from further reducing supplies of fuel and electricity to the Gaza Strip.

title: Macao: Ex-Minister Gets 27 Years for Bribery
description: Ao Man-long, the former transport and public works minister, became Macaos highest-level official ever convicted of corruption and was sentenced to 27 years in prison. He was found guilty of takings tens of millions of dollars in kickbacks from developers in the casino resort construction boom that has allowed the former Portuguese colony, now a special administrative region of China, to overtake Las Vegas in gambling revenues.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,925 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

title: Fours a Crowd
description: DENVER

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about a fellowship program intended to help art museum curators deal better with the business aspects of their jobs misstated part of the name of the institution where Eleanor Jones Harvey, who took part in the program, is chief curator. It is the Smithsonian American Art Museum, not Gallery.

title: Stretching the Truth Just Became Easier (and Cheaper)
description: WHEN Carlo Baldassi came home from vacation and looked at a picture he took of his girlfriend on the Charles Bridge in Prague, he was torn. She looked beautiful, but the proportions of the picture were all wrong. It seemed tight and constrained, and it would not fill his widescreen monitor.

title: Israeli Inquiry Finds Grave Failings in 06 War
description: JERUSALEM  In a widely anticipated judgment, a formal inquiry released Wednesday found grave failings among Israels political and military leaders in the 2006 Lebanon war, especially in their failure to decide what kind of war to fight.

title: Bloombergs Poverty Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Experiments in Language and Texture
description: Elliott Carter has touched on just about every musical format in his long and prolific career, but chamber music is where he has always seemed the most comfortable, or at least the most inclined to experiment with language and texture. The Juilliard School has taken that point to heart in this years weeklong Focus! festival, which celebrates Mr. Carters music. The first and last concerts offer orchestral works; the rest cut a wide swath through his chamber music, old and new.

title: The Chelsea Womens Team Signs Its First American Player
description: Chelsea has signed its first American soccer player. Not Landon Donovan, not Michael Bradley and not Jozy Altidore, but Lorrie Fair.

title: Will Democrats Learn From History?
description: To the Editor:

title: Economists Dissect the Yuck Factor
description: WASHINGTON  You can kill a horse to make pet food in California, but not to feed a person. You can hoist a woman over your shoulder while running a 253-meter obstacle course in the Wife-Carrying World Championship in Finland, but you cant hold a dwarf-tossing contest in France. You can donate a kidney to prevent a death and be hailed as a hero, but if you take any money for your life-saving offer in the United States, youll be jailed.

title: Quarters Weak Growth Adds to Signs of Slowdown
description: The United States economy expanded by a weak 0.6 percent annual rate during the last three months of 2007, the government reported Wednesday, offering the latest indication that the economy is already suffering from a substantial slowdown, and perhaps a recession.

title: The Online Peanut Gallery Weighs in, and South Plays Up
description: Apart from the fun of watching the play during matches broadcast live over the Internet at www.bridgebase.com, it is also interesting to read the remarks by commentators. The diagramed deal occurred on Dec. 22 in the final of the French trial. What would you say about Souths one-spade overcall?

title: New Look Planned for Hermitage
description: The Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas, a winner of the Pritzker Prize for architecture, has been chosen to redesign the art displays in the State Hermitage Museum, right, in St. Petersburg, Russia, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Koolhaas and the museum will begin the six-year project by establishing a master plan for a new way of displaying about three million treasures in the museums roughly 2,000 rooms. He will also alter the displays in the Islamic and Chinese rooms and transform a section of the imperial general staff building into a space for contemporary art.

title: The Newly Uptight
description: STEPHANIE LaCAVA has glimpsed fashions future, and she likes what she sees. Ive really been into this kind of sculptured feminine silhouette, said Ms. LaCava, 24, a features associate at Vogue. To judge by the outfit she wore at the Winter Antiques Show in Manhattan last week  a sedate cream-colored sheath that Letitia Baldrige would have admired  Ms. LaCava has embraced the fashions of the Kennedy years without irony.

title: A Lawyer Who Hears New Ways to Argue
description: There is really no good reason for Eli Stone to be quite as much fun as it is, given that the premise seems spraywashed with earnestness and spun to alienate the atheistic and the greedy. A new comic drama beginning Thursday on ABC, it revolves around a Stanford-trained lawyer who undergoes a moral conversion in the midst of a career spent ensuring that litigious average Joes, bitten by evil corporate carnivores, never walk off with more than the cost of a Happy Meal. The anti-John Edwards, Eli has contentedly sequestered himself in one of the two Americas  specifically, a vast, honey-colored apartment in downturn-resistant San Francisco  until the Armani suits start to feel itchy.

title: No Extradition for Dog
description: A three-judge panel in Mexico has ruled unanimously that Duane Chapman, known as Dog, right, who starred on the A&E television show Dog the Bounty Hunter, cannot be extradited to that country to face criminal charges for seizing Andrew Luster, heir to the Max Factor cosmetics fortune, on a street in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Chapman seized Mr. Luster in order to return him to the United States to serve a 124-year jail sentence for drugging and raping three women.

title: Ahmadinejad Sees Nuclear Energy in Iran by 2009
description: TEHRAN  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran said Wednesday that his country would produce nuclear energy by next year and condemned Israel as a filthy entity that would soon collapse.

title: Senate Democrats Short of Votes for Stimulus Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Backed solidly by the Bush administration, Senate Republicans on Thursday blocked a $157 billion economic stimulus package championed by Senate Democrats, who said they would have no choice but to quickly adopt a cheaper, more streamlined plan approved earlier this week by the House.

title: Gestures on Darfur: The World Must Do Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain: Victim Can Sue Lotto Rapist
description: A 78-year-old woman who was sexually assaulted in 1988 by Iorworth Hoare, a rapist who went on to win $14 million in the national lottery in 2004, is entitled to seek a share of his fortune, Britains highest court ruled. Courts had previously held that a claim for compensation in an assault case must be made within six years of the attack. Mr. Hoare, 53, spent 16 years in prison before buying the winning lottery ticket while on a day pass from prison. He was released in 2005 is said to live in a $1.4 million house near Newcastle.

title: 2 Communication Cables in the Mediterranean Are Cut
description: NEW DELHI  Two undersea telecommunication cables were cut on Tuesday evening, knocking out Internet access to much of Egypt, disrupting the worlds back office in India and slowing down service for some Verizon customers.

title: Republicans Battle for Votes and Money in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Competition between Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney for Californias vast array of Republican delegates heated up on Thursday, with Mr. McCain receiving a major endorsement and Mr. Romney preparing to broadcast television advertisements in California and several other February 5 states.

title: New York Leads the Field in a High School Science Competition
description: Stuyvesant High School led the nations schools in finalists in the latest round of the Intel Science Talent Search, the countrys most celebrated high school science competition. The 40 finalists were announced on Wednesday by competition officials.

title: A Disappointing Debut
description: About the best we can say about Attorney General Michael Mukaseys testimony Wednesday in the Senate is that he was no Alberto Gonzales, with the frequent memory lapses and possibly intentional misstatements. But that is a very low bar. On torture, domestic spying and other important matters, Mr. Mukasey parroted the Bush administrations deplorable line. He was particularly disappointing in his see-no-evil approach to the misconduct at the Justice Department before he arrived.

title: What Romney Said About Troop Pullout
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Senator John McCain of Arizona, who makes straight talk something of a political brand, likes to say he always tells voters the truth.

title: Santanas Rocky Finish Raises a Few Concerns
description: The Mets began contract negotiations Wednesday with the agent for the star left-hander Johan Santana, and very soon they expect to shift their focus from one astronomical figure (his salary) to another (his strikeout totals, victories, innings pitched  take your pick).

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about conservation planning in a warming world misstated the position of Healy Hamilton, who voiced concern about the future of protected areas. She is the director of the Center for Biodiversity Research and Information at the California Academy of Sciences; she is not the overall director of the academy.

title: Home Depot Plans Layoffs at Headquarters
description: Home Depot, battered by a downturn in the housing market, is laying off 500 workers at its headquarters in Atlanta, or about 10 percent of its work force there, the company said.

title: Long Island Rail Road From Penn Station to Ronkonkoma, N.Y.
description: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

title: This Is a Test: Do We Know Anything About Football?
description: Fellow football fans, let us acknowledge a truth: Much of the game is invisible and unknown to us in a way that our other sports passions are not. How did our left offensive guard do? You know, the fat guy from Nebraska? No idea, unless he happened to pancake the middle linebacker a couple of times or draw serial flags for holding. That blown coverage coverage across the middle? Just for fun, let's put that one on the nickel back lined up across from the slot. But really, we don't know and we're not meant to. Even the coach will say he has to check the film.

title: For a Woman Who Has Trouble Getting Around, Help Getting By
description: Chaya Tolwinski said she knew that Yehuda Tolwinski was the man for her on their second date.

title: Lottery Numbers
Text of Federal Reserve Statement
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve on Wednesday after the Feds monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to lower interest rates by half a percentage point:

title: Staying a Step Ahead of Aging
description: YOU know what is supposed to happen when you grow old. You will slow down, you will grow weak, your steps will become short and mincing, and you will lose your sense of balance. Thats what aging researchers consistently find, and its no surprise to most of us.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The About New York column in some editions on Jan. 5, about a legal and public relations fight over allegations of short-selling between Institutional Credit Partners, a private investment bank with offices in Manhattan, and Fairfax Financial Holdings, a Canadian insurance company, referred imprecisely to the banks charges against Fairfax. It claims that Fairfax operatives have a history of stealing garbage  which prompted bank executives to take emergency measures for protection  but it does not accuse Fairfax operatives of stealing garbage in this particular dispute.

title: A Site to Bring Parents Up to Speed on Video Games
description: It often seems that being clueless about video games goes hand in hand with being a parent. But a new site called WhatTheyPlay.com aims to give parents an inside scoop by going beyond the ratings and offering evaluations written by knowledgeable gamers  many of them parents.

title: The Final Two in a Multifront Battle
description: Even before Wednesday morning, the candidates had been befuddled by the sheer strategic challenge presented by Feb. 5. As if things were not complicated enough, John Edwards dropped out of the race, forcing the other campaigns to return to the drawing boards.

title: Audit Raises Concerns About Fraud at Boat Basin
description: An audit released on Wednesday by the city comptroller found widespread financial irregularities with record-keeping at the 79th Street Boat Basin in Manhattan, raising concerns about the possibility of fraud.

title: The New Race: Four Candidates, 24 States and One Hectic Week
description: MIAMI  For most of the year, the race for president has been a muddle for both parties: An amorphous cast of candidates seeking to distinguish themselves and win attention from voters, donors and the news media.

title: Vespers Still Startling After All These Years
description: It says something for Monteverdis powerful presence that 400 years of shifting musical standards have not softened his voice. How startling, for example, his galloping brass writing must have sounded to contemporary ears: an early 17th-century audience innocent of Mozarts diminished seventh chords, Wagners wandering key changes or Schoenbergs serialist combinations.

title: End Tax Deal for Garden, Council Urges
description: Madison Square Garden and its chairman, James L. Dolan, may have run out of friends at City Hall. The City Council voted 40 to 3 on Wednesday in favor of ending the arenas unusual tax deal with the city, which for 25 years has exempted the Garden from property taxes.

title: Zhang Hanzhi, Maos Tutor, Is Dead at 72
description: SHANGHAI  Zhang Hanzhi, a former Chinese diplomat who once served as Maos English tutor and who also interpreted for President Nixon during his historic trip to China in 1972, died on Saturday. She was 72.

title: N.C.A.A. to Ease Limits on Athletes Expenses
description: INDIANAPOLIS (AP)  The N.C.A.A. said it planned to ease restrictions on educational expenses for current student-athletes and set aside $10 million to reimburse former athletes as part of a tentative class-action lawsuit settlement.

title: Pictures Reveal Mercurys Tumultuous Past
description: WASHINGTON  The Messenger spacecraft that zipped past Mercury two weeks ago found more evidence of the innermost planets turbulent past, including ridges that run hundreds of miles and a unique feature made up of more than 100 troughs radiating in all directions, scientists said Wednesday.

title: Ryder Cup Format Changed
description: The United States captain Paul Azinger is switching the Ryder Cup format with hopes of giving his team an edge, going back to alternate shot in the opening matches for the first time since 1999. The Ryder Cup will be played Sept. 19-21 at Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Ky.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Bengals Sign Another Palmer
description: Jordan Palmer signed a two-year deal with the Cincinnati Bengals on Wednesday that will give him a chance to play behind his brother, quarterback Carson Palmer, who was the No. 1 pick in the 2003 draft. Jordan Palmer, who is five years younger, set school records at Texas-El Paso by throwing for 11,084 yards and 88 touchdowns. Washington drafted him in the sixth round last year, but he was waived Sept. 1.

title: Hoosiers Are Grateful for a Star Who Stayed
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. (AP)  Eric Gordon makes every move look naturally smooth  the slick drives to the basket, the whip passes to teammates, the poke-away steals, even his long 3-pointers.

title: Fed Cuts Key Rate as Stimulus Plan Advances
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates on Wednesday for the second time in eight days, meeting Wall Street hopes for cheaper money. At the same time, the Senate pushed ahead on a $161 billion plan to prop up Main Street with tax rebates and temporary tax cuts.

title: Cape Town, South Africa
description: A weekend in Cape Town narrated by Erik Olsen, taking in its history and natural beauty, from the historic Long Street all the way down to Cape Point.

title: Countdown to the Super Bowl
description: Wednesday was heavy with media coverage of the Giants and Patriots as Super Bowl XLII approached.

title: Kovalchuk Hurt on Ruutu Hit
description: Atlantas Ilya Kovalchuk left Wednesday nights game after a check by Penguins irritator Jarko Ruutu on a play for which Ruutu received a kneeing major. The play took place in the second period of a 4-1 Thrashers victory in Atlanta. Here are details from the Atlanta Constitutions account of the game, which describes the play as a knee-on-knee hit. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette described the game this way and said that Ruutu checked Kovalchuk into the boards in front of the Atlanta bench. Well post video as soon as it becomes available.  And here it is:

title: Respond to Todays Column: Fours a Crowd
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Jan. 31 column.

title: The Aftermath of Violence in Limuru, Kenya
description: After a second Kenyan opposition lawmaker was shot dead on Thursday, riots exploded in opposition strongholds, putting the country increasingly on edge. In Limuru, 30 miles north of Nairobi, both ethnic Luos and Kikuyus coped with the aftermath of the continuing violence.

title: Sales in Rome: Grab Yourself a Gaultier!
description: Im not an avid clothes shopper. But its hard not to turn shopaholic with prices as low as they are at Italian boutiques this week!

title: Michelangelo, Vasari and Their Contemporaries
description: Images from the show at the Morgan Library & Museum.

title: Dress Codes | Well-Dressed Travels Well
description: How to shop, pack and dress as a creative fashion executive.

title: The Neediest Cases | Coping After a Fire
description: When Eggie and Luis Perezs home was destroyed by fire last fall, their after-school program stepped in to help.

title: Sense and Civility
description: Finding comfort in the little beige dresses and circle skirts of simpler times.

title: Bond Trustee Sues Tropicana
description: Tropicana Casino & Resort, which has been on the block since the New Jersey gaming commission stripped then-parent Columbia-Sussex of its operating license, is being sued by a major local bond trustee who blames its chief executive officer for losing the casinos gaming license.

title: King & Spalding Poaches Silicon Valley Lawyers
description: In the latest example of the rush on Silicon Valley to grab talent and clients in the U.S. technology company center, Atlanta-based law firm King & Spalding is venturing into California, poaching at least eight attorneys from Perkins Coies Silicon Valley office.

title: Britains Friends Provident Announces Asset Disposals
description: British insurer Friends Provident on Thursday said it would dispose of its controlling stake in F&C Asset Management, the U.K.-listed fund manager, and pull out of its other wealth management businesses as part of a restructuring that would see the life assurer cut costs and rebase its dividend.

title: Britains Kesa Agrees to Sell French Chain to Consortium
description: Kesa Electricals, which owns Comet in Britain, is selling its its French furniture and electricals business BUT for 550 million euros ($814.4 million) to Decomeubles Partners, a company backed by a consortium made up of Colony Capital, Goldman Sachs and Merchant Equity Partners.

title: Marsh Chooses a Semi-Outsider to Be Its Chief
description: The insurance broker Marsh & McLennan named the former head of the ACE insurance company, Brian Duperreault, as its chief executive on Wednesday.

title: Buyout Shops Said to Consider Deal for Dulles Rail Line
description: Private equity investors, including the Carlyle Group, are drawing up proposals to partner with Virginia for a rail line to Dulles International Airport as hope fades that the federal government will help fund the 23-mile Metrorail extension, according to The Washington Post.

title: Deutsche Bank Reaps More of Chinas Harvest
description: Deutsche Bank, Germanys largest bank, raised its stake in Chinese partner Harvest Fund Management Co. to tap growing demand for mutual funds and investment products in the worlds most populous nation.

title: Tribune Clears Set at Original Warner Bros. Studio
description: The original Warner Bros. studio in Hollywood, now home to KTLA-TV Channel 5 and other Tribune entertainment companies, was sold for $125 million Wednesday to a Los Angeles real estate investment firm.

title: In Europe, Questions Over Continuing Write-Downs
description: When UBS disclosed in October that it had written down $3.6 billion in mortgage-backed securities, it was praised for biting the bullet.

title: Japans Biggest Banks Said to Face $4.7 Billion in Subprime Losses
description: Japans four biggest banks face 500 billion yen ($4.7 billion) in losses associated with U.S. subprime mortgages in the current fiscal year through March 31, according to a published report.

title: Crosslink Capital Closes on $400 Million Hybrid Fund
description: Crosslink Capital has closed on a new $400 million venture capital-hedge fund hybrid fund believed to be the largest of its kind, the company announced Wednesday.

title: Banks In-House Funds Fail to Shine
description: While many big-name hedge funds prospered in 2007, Dow Jones notes that one notable group struggled: funds run by large Wall Street firms and traditional money managers.

title: Ackmans Warning on Insurers Frays Nerves
description: While the Federal Reserve tried to soothe Wall Streets nerves on Wednesday, a hedge fund manager frayed them by warning that two pillars of the financial markets might crumble.

title: V.C.s Said to Switch On to Luxim
description: Luxim, a Sunnyvale, Calif. company that boasts it produces one of the most efficient light sources on the globe  144 lumens per watt  or almost twice as efficient as other sources, has raised $21 million more in financing, according to VentureBeat.

title: Etsy Brings Out Accels Crafty Side
description: Etsy, a site for buying and selling hand-made crafts, has raised $27 million in a round led by Accel Partners, with Accels Jim Breyer joining the companys board of directors.

title: Indias Wockhardt Hospital Trims I.P.O.
description: Wockhardt Hospitals cut the size of its initial public offering, the first Indian company to reduce a sale amid a plunge in equity markets.

title: No Bonuses for Top Merrill Executives
description: Merrill Lynch said on Wednesday that top executives, including Merrill President Gregory Fleming, will not receive bonuses for 2007 after the worlds largest brokerage posted $12.1 billion in net losses during the second half of the year.

title: Chinese Developers to Brave I.P.O. Market, Report Says
description: Four more Chinese property firms plan Hong Kong initial public offerings this year to raise a combined $2.6 billion, Reuters said, as Beijings clampdown on bank lending forces developers to brave stock market volatility.

title: Is Wassersteins Bonus Over the Top?
description: Bruce Wasserstein is an important rainmaker at Lazard, the investment bank he runs.

title: New Rules Could Shine Spotlight on Deal Fees
description: New accounting rules for mergers and acquisitions are likely to have some far-reaching consequences for what such deals cost and how they get done, Compliance Week reports.

title: Behind SocGens Decision to Stand By Its Man
description: The board of Socit Gnrale, gathering Wednesday in a conference room on the 35th floor of the banks headquarters outside Paris, tacitly agreed to grant the banks chairman and chief executive, Daniel Bouton, a reprieve.

description: From The Sun of London:

title: Alliance Datas Complaint
description: Alliance Data Systems filed suit against Blackstone Group on Wednesday in Delaware Chancery Court.

title: Ailing Fortunoff Attracts a Suitor
description: One of the most storied names in New York retailing plans to bail out another.

title: The Weak Dollar Isnt All Bad News
description: It is nearly impossible to go a day without hearing about the dismal state of our economy. And small businesses have been particularly hard hit in recent years. According to one economist I spoke to this week, the housing meltdown has trickled into so many crevices of small business that it will take quite a long time for the overall performance of small business to improve even if there are positive signs in areas that have nothing to do with housing.

title: Polar Bears and Seer Suckers
description: A new contrarian report on polar bears and global warming in the Arctic has been released by the minority members of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works. As youd expect, its a selective hodgepodge of science and politics. There are useful summaries and links of research challenging some of the media hype about the Arctic, but some of the rhetoric gets in the way of the facts.

title: Remembering the Little Ones
description: The L.A. Times has a keen feature about all the teeny roles in the last year that landed with impact, some of them in movies that will be around for the Big Dance. Who was that guy flipping a coin with Anton Chigurh for the highest stakes of all in No Country for Old Men? Read on, Friendo.

title: What Should a Candidate Read?
description: CBS asked the presidential candidates to choose the one book they think would be essential to take to the White House, other than the Bible. Only one chose a book related to economics, and that was Senator John McCain, a Republican candidate who has been criticized for lacking economic expertise.

title: Democratic Debate in Los Angeles
description: The following is a transcript of the Democratic debate in Los Angeles, as provided by Federal News Service.

title: Restaurants for the Global Food Crisis
description: With eggroll you get sick  or maybe its just someones rare sense of humor.

title: Altria Plans to Spin Off Overseas Division in March
description: The Altria Group said Wednesday that it would spin off its international tobacco business on March 28, freeing it to pursue cigarette sales more aggressively outside the United States.

title: Mr. Bo Jangles
description: At a time when the culture seems long on snark and short on guys wearing headbands who are one-man dynamos of justice, A.O. Scott is happy to see an old friend, bloody mayhem in tow, return after a 20-year break. Rambo, welcome back.

title: The Dance of the Low Sloping Foreheads
description: Drunken heckler vs. indie auteur? Have another cocktail honey, they love you.

title: Prized Peaches
description: SpoutBlog, as usual, jumps ahead, this time getting in front of the Juno backlash. Not the movie, silly, the soundtrack. Use that Guitar Hero digit to click here and get some nice, fresh, Moldy Peaches, introduced by the well-known indie queen, Whoopi Goldberg.

description: Living in Cinema points to a Variety story that does mix-and-match with the BAFTAs and the Oscars. The story throws a flag for overuse of the word blighty.

title: Nice Going, Friendo
description: Jennybee takes the cake and the hardcover copy of No Country for Old Men for her acronymical excellence: Not Crazy, Friendo, Only Mad. You want milk with that or what?

title: The Early Word: The Race Narrows
description: What a difference a day can make. On both sides yesterday, the fields for the presidential nominations shrunk considerably.

title: Niche Homework
description: Every year come Oscar pool time, its the same old routine. Pick your favorites in the big categories and then, when it comes to the more granular categories, you punt, or go with whoever Gurus of Gold is hot on.

title: Doris Lessing Tweaks Her Tune on the Nobel
description: What a difference a few months make? Not so much when it comes to Doris Lessing, whose first shot at accepting her Nobel Prize for Literature was notable for her lack of acceptance. She had a second shot last night.

title: About those UI claims
description: A number of people  Greg Mankiw, in particular  have been pointing to relatively low new claims for unemployment insurance as a sign that the economy is actually doing just fine.

description: Once again, here are some notable eaters who answered the question: If you jump on a plane right now, all expenses paid, where would you go eat? And once again, wed love to hear your dining fantasies.

description: Will Leitch, a regular contributor to Play Magazine and our weekly newsletter, is in Phoenix for Super Bowl XLII and filing daily columns with his impressions and opinions on the issues surrounding the scene, the teams, and the game.

title: Armchair Strategists Assess Giulianis Defeat
description: The momentum for the Republican presidential nomination shifted toward John McCain in the New York region as former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani endorsed the Arizona senator in front of the Ronald Reagan Library in California after his campaign-ending third-place finish in Florida.

title: Managing Traffic in the Urban Age
description: The human species is, at this moment, in the process of becoming a mainly urban animal after a thousand generations spent mainly in rural conditions. Many economists and sociologists see this trend as our potential salvation in a world heading toward 9 billion people, although there are some big ifs.

description: Bob Wright is jumping from G.E. to P.E.

description: William H. Gross, the founder of the bond mutual fund PIMCO (and Morningstars 2007 fixed-income manager of the year), doesnt like the stimulus package that President Bush and the Congress have agreed upon.

title: N.O.W. President Rallies Clintons Connecticut Volunteers
description: NEW HAVEN  Debra Hauser, a clinical psychologist from this Democratic-leaning city, had never worked on a presidential campaign before this year. But between now and Tuesday, as she volunteers for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, thats just about all she will think about.

title: Its So Incredibly Tulsa': Bill Haders Book Picks
description: Last fall, when I wrote a profile of Bill Hader, the actor and comedian of Saturday Night Live and Superbad fame, I was pleasantly surprised to learn that the 29-year-old Tulsa native is not only capable of a totally killer Vincent Price impression  hes also one of the most well-read science-fiction and horror fans Ive ever met.

description: We had a little fun again this morning with our debate analysis feature, the interactive graphic we offer so that you can search either the video of last nights G.O.P. forum or the transcript of it.

description: Promising closed-door talks aimed at settling Hollywoods three-month-old strike by movie and television writers have been jolted in the last few days by the actions of some prominent guild leaders, Michael Cieply reports in todays Times. Read more

title: Citi Planning to Sell PE Assets?
description: CNBC interviews Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times and Dan Primack of PEhub.com on reports that Citigroup is in talks to sell $1.4 billion in private equity assets.

title: Spectrum Auction: C Block Hits Reserve Price
description: A bid of $4.7 billion this morning for the most valuable group of wireless licenses in the Federal Communications Commission auction for 700Mhz spectrum pushed the price over the minimum price the government set. That means that the government is likely to receive over $12 billion for the block of spectrum that is being abandoned next year as television broadcasters move permanently to new digital frequencies. The government has said it hoped to earn at least $10 billion from the auction.

title: Campaigns Rebuff a Real, Working Woman
description: While the Clinton and Obama presidential campaigns claim to care about working women, one working woman is not exactly feeling the love.

title: On the Trail
description: Democrats debated and Republicans continued campaigning in the countdown to the Feb. 5 contests.

description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.Giants quarterback Eli Manning has a fan in New England.

title: Burress at the Center of Everything but Practice
description: TEMPE, Ariz.Giants wide receiver Plaxico Burress was held out of his teams two-hour practice Wednesday, according to the designated pool reporter at the session.

title: Money Sent Home by Mexicans Almost Stagnant in 2007
description: The money sent home by Mexicans working abroad  known as remittances  is the countrys second-greatest source of foreign income, after oil exports. But the flow has been leveling off after years of growth.

title: A Civics Lesson Amid the Hoopla
description: Will Leitch is the editor of Deadspin.com and a frequent contributor to Play: The New York Times Sports Magazine. His latest book, God Save the Fan, was released last week.

description: Ive learned to appreciate the power of a coaching tree. Playing against some of the best coaches and greatest programs will do that to a man.

description: Whats the early read on Amazon.coms deal to buy Audible? Like many things related to Amazon these days, its all relative.

description: LOS ANGELES  A $32 million month.

title: So They Can Spend More Time With Each Other
description: Aired Wednesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: John Edwards and Rudy Giuliani both today announced theyre pulling out of the race for president so they can spend more time with each other.

title: Clearing Up Some of the Confusion Over HDTV
description: According to the Consumer Electronics Association, this Sundays Super Bowl will inspire the sales of 2.4 million high-definition TV sets. Thats a lot of plasma. (And L.C.D., and projection sets.)

title: Covers, Credit and My New Haircut
description: Joe Sabia is a whippersnapper at HBO who speaks to the Web the way Dolittle does to animals.

title: Die-Hard Sports Fans Face Heart Risk
description: Rabid sports fans have more to worry about than the final score. New research shows that a heart-pounding sports match may be bad for the heart.

title: Readers Weigh In
description: Weve had some fabulous contributions from readers. I want to feature a few very sharp comments of theirs that either tend against the grain of the rest of the conversation here or else run counter, in one way or another, to much Moviegoer criticism Ive read.

title: Each Gun Aimed at a Different Lawyer
description: Aired Wednesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: It is Dick Cheneys birthday and there was a big celebration in Washington, with a 21-gun salute. Each gun aimed at a different lawyer.

title: Citis Private Equity Stakes on the Block?
description: Even after its outside investments and its controversial dividend cut, Citigroup may still be looking for additional capital. PE Hubs Dan Primack reports that the wounded financial giant may try a new tack: selling some of its private equity portfolios.

title: For The Moment | Being Numero One
description: This weeks guest blogger is John Jay, the Executive Creative Director and Partner of the Wieden + Kennedy advertising agency which includes Nike among its clients. Jay writes a blog for Honeyee.com in Tokyo and is a contributor to magazines in Tokyo and the U.S. on creativity and pop culture, including Tokion Japan, Giant Robot, Theme and Spread magazine. In todays post, Jay writes about the state of the Japanese fashion magazine industry. (For all of John Jays posts, click here)

title: The Angina Monologues
description: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: How about this presidential race? Its getting crazier and crazier. Yesterday in Florida they had the primary. Rudy Giuliani came in third, so he dropped out of the presidential race. But dont worry about him. Hes already busy looking for wife number four. So hes got his hands full.

title: Jimmy Carter and the New York Democrats
description: The modern presidential primary system began in 1976, when for the first time delegate candidates in New York were entitled to list on the ballots the presidential candidate they supported under their names. Previously, voters had to discern on their own which delegates favored which candidates, leaving party bosses with considerable control. This simple reform has altered the New York primary on Tuesday from an Easter egg hunt into a relatively rational political process, a Times editorial declared on April 4, 1976.

title: A Small Turnout at Yoga for Hillary
description: Journalists easily outnumbered the participants in a Yoga for Hillary fund-raiser on Wednesday night in Times Square. A German television cameraman, a Canadian radio reporter, a New York Times photographer and this City Room reporter crowded into the Champions Dance Studio, at 257 West 39th Street, to document three students doing downward-facing dog and warrior poses. The yoga instructor, Brian Williams, who collected $10 from each participant, said he had heard that Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign has yoga classes for her staff. He cautioned that yoga  sometimes a favorite activity in Times Square  is not particularly partisan. I know a lot of people that do yoga who are conservative Republicans, he said. Namaste.

title: Spectrum Auction: The C-Block Bidding Stalls at $4.7 Billion
description: UPDATE: This post was wrong in saying that rules prohibit anyone from bidding higher than $4.7 billion for the C block. There are some rather complex ways that another company could in fact raise the bid in coming days. Ill write a post explaining this later.

title: Farewell Montel
description: After 17 years, The Montel Williams Show will cease production in May.

title: A Republican With an Exit Strategy
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Congratulations to Senator John McCain, the big winner in Florida. You know, this was what they call a GOP-only primary. So McCain had to win over a whole new voter group for him  Republicans.

title: The Debate: Fleeting or for Real?
description: Even late into the regular season, Eli Mannings erratic play prompted questions about whether he could take himself  and the Giants  to the next level. His game improved dramatically in the playoffs, which makes us wonder: Is Mannings recent performance what we should we expect from him on Sunday and in the future, or just sudden and short-lived?

description: The modern presidential primary system began in 1976, when for the first time delegate candidates in New York were entitled to list on the ballots the presidential candidate they supported under their names. Previously, voters had to discern on their own which delegates favored which candidates, leaving party bosses with considerable control. This simple reform has altered the New York primary on Tuesday from an Easter egg hunt into a relatively rational political process, a Times editorial declared on April 4, 1976.More in City Room

title: Open Caucus: Assessing McCain vs. Romney
description: Our Open Caucus participants got their first taste of a John McCain-Mitt Romney G.O.P. race on Wednesday, but they thought the debate recipe could have used a bit more Mike Huckabee-Ron Paul flavor. Read on to hear their opinions of the candidates conservative credentials, their bickering and, um, zombies.

title: 4 Edwards Delegates Throw Support to Obama
description: John Edwardss withdrawal from the presidential contest has touched off a scramble for his supporters by the two leading Democratic candidates, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton. This morning, Mr. Obamas New York office announced that four Edwards delegate candidates in New York City had switched their support to the Illinois senator.

title: This Is a Test: Do We Know Anything About Football?
description: Here is what we do know: On any given N.F.L. Sunday, there are 70-some guys on each team involved in the competition once you count the players and all those coaches, coordinators, assistant coaches, assistants to the assistants and so forth. But two men count above all: the head coach and quarterback. In all of team sports, no two positions loom as large, Michael Sokolove writes in this weeks Play newsletter.

title: Counting Down To Digital TV

title: Clipboard: Surprises Are Fun

description: On rare occasions, David N. Dinkins says, he is approached by New Yorkers who ask him how he could possibly support Hillary Rodham Clinton in her quest to become president rather than Barack Obama.

description: From which cities can I fly to Cuba? What are the restrictions for United States citizens? Thank you.

title: Economy in Freefall, Says Clinton Ad

title: Hill or Bama? Take the Quiz!
description: With Super Tuesday fast approaching, many Democratic voters are still undecided about whether they are a Hillary Clinton supporter (a Hill) or a Barack Obama supporter (a Bama). What these confused individuals dont realize is that their subconscious minds have already made the decision  Its kind of like when you read the menu board at a fast-food restaurant even though you always order a cheeseburger. To help identify which candidate your subconscious mind has selected, take this simple test. If you are dissatisfied with the results, theres still time for therapy, flipping a coin or writing in Al Gore:

title: Movie Minutes: 'Caramel'
description: A. O. Scott reviews 'Caramel,' co-written, directed by and starring Nadine Labaki.

title: Foxs Reality Squirmfests Continue to Deliver
description: The return of Lost  albeit a two-hour repeat of the last season finale  buoyed ABCs ratings on a night otherwise dominated by Foxs American Idol and Moment of Truth. According to Nielsens estimates, the two Fox programs delivered the nights largest audiences by far, 25.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. for American Idol followed by 17.9 million for The Moment of Truth at 9 p.m.

title: Kate the Great
description: Steve correctly points out that all through The Moviegoer, Percy makes brief allusions to crazy or eccentric or just plain bad-acting women. But the truth is that especially in Percys part of the world, those sorts of women do waft in and out of casual conversation in just such a way. Its another spot-on detail he gets exactly right. In my youth, women were forever collecting the equivalent of iron deer, or auditioning and being discovered and going off to Biloxi or maybe even New York or Busch Gardens. They certainly did  and do  a fair share of going off to Natchez, of checking in and out of nuthouses, and all such activities were usually reported or repeated at the dinner table. Percy and his brothers believed that their own mothers accident was likely no such thing, that, despite the fact that youngest brother Phin was in the car with her, she drove off the road intentionally. Im sure that whispered assumption was a brief aside at many a Delta dinner table.

title: How Not to Beat a Ticket
description: In March 2004, Andrew Bamberg faced an all-too-familiar problem: He received a citation for running a stop sign in Redwood City, Calif., an infraction that ordinarily draws a fine of $215.

title: Nakamura Wins Gibtelecom Masters
The Day After
description: Were at that stage of a campaign now where once serious contenders for the nominations of their parties are forced to cancel events and huddle with their families, to make those difficult calls to friends and supporters who already knew it was coming, to direct their own final scenes on the national stage. It is, in a sense, like planning your own funeral, and Im sure it feels that way, or at least for a while. I can remember sitting with Bill Bradley in his bare campaign office just after his withdrawal speech in 2000. Everyone was already gone except for a few loyal staff members and the last two Secret Service agents guarding the door. All the noise from all the rallies had subsided, and all that remained were a few empty cubicles and the occasional unanswered phone. I will never forget how one of the agents, checking his watch, offered the candidate a ride home before the final shift came to an end. Its not just the candidate, though, who suffers the trauma. For all the people who work on a campaign, who share cramped apartments with other true believers and keep most of their belongings in a car, the end really does feel like The End. I stood in the Ohio headquarters of America Coming Together, the massive Democratic voter turnout operation, as John Kerry and John Edwards gave their concession speech the day after the 2004 election. A smart young organizer was weeping on her bosss shoulder. I knew that if she lived to be 90, no matter what else she did or how successfully, the memory of that moment would probably still feel like a kick in the gut.

title: Is Connecticut Becoming a Battleground?
description: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have both announced that they will campaign in Connecticut on Monday, signaling that the state might be suddenly shaping up as a critical battleground among the 22 states holding their Democratic presidential primaries on Super Tuesday. Connecticut is a relatively small state, offering only 60 delegates out of 4,050  but its Democrats have proved to be a volatile group.

title: Guzan Snubbed by Home Office
description: The eleventh hour came and went, and so did Brad Guzans chances of relocating to England or Scotland.

title: Schwarzenegger Endorses McCain
description: LOS ANGELESSenator John McCain picked up the potent endorsement of Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger of California today as Mr. McCain and his Republican rival Mitt Romney battled across the daunting political landscape of the nations largest state.

title: So Exotic, These New York Republicans
description: Republicans in New York City, outnumbered 5 to 1 by Democrats, are used to being a local curiosity. But with the worlds attention focused on the presidential primary, they have now become a global curiosity, fielding media requests from Japan, Germany, Sweden, and even letting humble local City Room observe them.When about a dozen members of the governing board of New York Citys Young Republican Club gathered on Wednesday night to eat dinner and watch the presidential debate on CNN, one member ducked out for an interview with the BBC.

title: Who Let the Dogs Out?
description: MBIA has what may be the longest conference call Ive heard. (It is at 3 hours, 25 minutes and counting.) You wont be stunned to hear that they do not agree with Bill Ackmans critique of them.

title: Allegra, Barack and Mrs. Hefty
description: In this weeks New Republic, Allegra Goodman has a lovely short essay about what it means that Barack Obama grew up, in part, in Hawaii.

title: Giants Starving for Pressure on Brady
description: CHANDLER, Ariz. To win the Super Bowl, the Giants know they must get pressure on Patriots quarterback Tom Brady.

title:
New Rule at the Canadian Border:
Two IDs, Please
description: While the Democrats and Republicans continue to draw attention to the finer points of border safety by duking it out at presidential primary debates, the Department of Homeland Security has been going ahead with some tougher policies on the ground.

title: Only Connect
description: How John beat Rudy: Daniel Henninger, a columnist for The Wall Street Journal, says John McCains superior skills in retail politics have made him the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Bears Back Pats
description: In case you have been wondering who to root for in the Super Bowl on Sunday, I have looked into history and concluded that the stock market will do better if the Giants win.

title: Bloomberg@Google, Where Lunch Is Free
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, who remains a minor folk hero in financial and technology circles, was greeted with cheers at the Chelsea offices of Google this morning, where he met privately with company executives, then fielded questions from a roomful of nerdy yet chic employees who waited up to an hour to see the billionaire mayor.

title: An Activist Tries a Soft Touch with Times Co.
description: A spoonful of sugar helps the medicine go down.

title: E.W. Scripps Earnings Decline; Cable Revenues Rise
description: E.W. Scripps, the owner of the HGTV and the Food Network, said Thursday that fourth-quarter profits fell 8 percent on declining advertising sales at its newspapers and television stations, the Associated Press reports:

title: $90,000 Per Second for Super Bowl Ads
description: Among the commercials that Fox Broadcasting will run during the Super Bowl on Sunday, there will be cute animals, at least one talking baby, an appeal to help fight AIDS, a talent contest, light-hearted parodies and enough celebrities to fill several seasons of Dancing With the Stars,' Stuart Elliott reports in todays New York Times.

title: The Darfur Contagion Spreads
description: I just had an email from Chad that the U.N. is today evacuating Guereda, a major town in eastern Chad that has been a base for helping Darfuri refugees. Frankly, this will mean that more Darfuri refugees will die, but the U.N. has to protect its own people as well. Its an agonizing position for aid organizations to face when their own staff are attacked.

title: On the Road With Hillary Clinton
description: Traveling with one candidate, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, as the campaign goes national.

title: More on the Befuddlement of Liquor Laws
description: I wanted to do a quick follow-up to my column on Wednesday about the confusion of laws governing interstate sales from retail wine shops to consumers. Ive gotten enough response on this to warrant some amplifications and clarifications.

title: Answers About Tenant-Landlord Issues, Part 5
description: Following is a fifth set of answers to readers questions selected by Lucas A. Ferrara, a partner at Finkelstein Newman Ferrara who has practiced in the landlord-tenant arena for more than two decades.

title: The Apologetic Jerry Yang
description: By most accounts, Jerry Yang, the co-founder and chief executive of Yahoo, is well liked inside the company. But some insiders are fretting that Mr. Yang is lacking a skill thats often seen as critical for chief executives: the ability to deliver upbeat, rally-the-troops speeches to audiences of investors, customers and even employees.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Thursday, Jan. 31:

title: The Insider | Carol Lim
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Carol Lim, a co-owner of New Yorks mega boutique, Opening Ceremony, shares with The Moment a few of her stylish essentials. Look for Lim on the dance floor ; shell be celebrating the launch of Opening Ceremonys new clothing line with Chlo Sevigny at Webster Hall on Febuary 4th.
