description: AP: McCain changes story on tax cut stance

title: A U.K. Restaurant Happy to Take Bankers Bonuses
description: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague in London:

title: Amid McCain Surge, Romney Camp Perseveres in New Jersey
description: The decision by nearly two dozen New Jersey Republicans to endorse Senator John McCain today left supporters of Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor who is challenging Mr. McCain for the Republican nomination, feeling somewhat lonely.

title: Among TV Judges, Judy Is Renewed but Hatchett Is Axed
description: Judge Judy, the longest-running and highest-rated courtroom show in syndication, earned a two-year renewal this week, which will extend its run through 2012.

title: Soft Serve | Snarky Tote Bags, Fancy Strawberries, Chocolatemania
description: Soft Serve is a news feed of light reading. We scan newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Hamilton dominates Renault launch
description: It was an interesting, but slightly curious atmosphere at the Renault F1 team 2008 car launch today outside Paris. Fernando Alonso may have left McLaren Mercedes to rejoin his old team, Renault, but for the moment he seems to have unwittingly brought his teammate with him.

title: Could Amazon and Audible Rewrite the Rules of Publishing?
description: Steve Jobs said earlier this month that Amazons Kindle e-book reader was dead on arrival, since Americans have largely abandoned reading.

title: Move Over for Forsberg
description: The three biggest personnel stories leading up to the Feb. 26 trade deadline are 1) Will Marian Hossa re-sign with Atlanta 2) Will the Leafs deal Mats Sundin 3) Will Peter Forsberg return to the NHL.

title: City Room: The Race in the New York Region
description: Todays Journal Entries: Hillary Rodham Clintons national town hall will be televised on The Hallmark Channel. The battle for Connecticut is on, as Mrs. Clinton and Barack Obama plan visits there the day before Super Tuesday. Four John Edwards delegates in Manhattan have switched their support to Mr. Obama. David Dinkins, the former New York mayor, explains his support for Mrs. Clinton: She came into the Senate with the perspective that she was one of 100 senators and she did everything but fetch coffee for the Republican senators. She did the hard work and learned how to do the job well. Bill Bradley speaks to the Obama generation at Rutgers Outnumbered urban Republicans are much in demand from the global news media. The McCain and Romney campaigns duel for support from New Jersey Republican leaders  A Wall Street titan is now backing McCain.  New York City election officials, bracing for heavy turnout, roll out the old mechanical lever machines. New Yorks diverse ethnic press  hundreds of publications, dozens of nationalities  is covering the race with gusto. The two Democrats have taken their campaigns upstate to Kemp country. Back in Manhattan Yoga for Hillary hasnt quite caught on.

title: City Election Officials Gear Up for Heavy Turnout
description: If all goes as planned, more than 30,000 poll workers will help citizens use 6,293 voting machines at 1,363 polling places across New York City on Tuesday, as voters go to the polls for the Democratic and Republican presidential primaries. The machinery of democracy is in full gear, even though New York State is expected to replace the machines by next year, to comply belatedly with the Help America Vote Act of 2002, which was intended to prevent a recurrence of the Florida recount debacle of 2000.

title: Panel Passes Congestion Pricing Plan
description: A plan to thin Manhattans perpetual throngs of traffic by charging fees to drivers and increasing prices for on-street parking was approved by a 13-2 vote on Thursday afternoon by a state commission appointed to review different proposals. The plan to decrease traffic [pdf] in much of Manhattan, first proposed in a slightly different form by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg last April, would charge drivers $8 to go below 60th Street from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. The commission, the Traffic Congestion Mitigation Commission, also recommended imposing a $1 surcharge for taxi trips starting or ending in the area and increased parking rates below 60th Street.

title: Doctor, It Hurts When I And Other Questions
description: CBS Television Distribution is hoping The Doctors can do for medical information shows what Dr. Phil did for the mental health genre.

title: Ensberg Joins the Yankees to Compete for First Base
description: Add another name to the Yankees mix at first base: Morgan Ensberg. The Yankees have signed Ensberg to a minor-league contract and invited him to spring training, according to Ensberg himself, who confirmed the news to ESPN.coms Jerry Crasnick.

title: Thursdays Virtual News Conference
description: As Super Bowl XLII draws near, reporters and players struggle to find new ground to cover. But at the third media day for players and coaches, there were some new insights, moments of humor and hyperbole that befit the run-up to Sundays sports spectacular. Listen for yourself below.

title: Now Screening | Band of Outsiders
description: Welcome to fashion week almost. As we speak, theres a presentation underway for Band of Outsiders, the small label known for its preppy basics like skinny ties, button downs and a womens collection called Boy. Our friends at Refinery 29 posted a video today with behind-the-scenes footage of the preparations for tonights event. In the episode, we follow Scott Sternberg, the designer, through the casting process. He calls the plaid-infused collection, a little romantic, a little older. (He also mentions that hes really vibing on ecotones right now.) See for yourself.

title: A Hallmark Moment?
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons national town hall on Monday evening will be broadcast live on the Hallmark Channel, the cable television network that is best known for sentimental tearjerkers, didactic after-school specials and adaptations of well-loved serial juvenile fiction. The Clinton campaign disclosed this unusual fact in a conference call with reporters this afternoon.

title: In Cairo, Seizing the Day, but Not the Internet
description: Just a few days after Nadim Audis account of the Palestinian shopping invasion of Egypt, The Lede asked him to file on another matter. Hours later, he responded: Its ironic that the very topic you want me to blog about is preventing me from answering your e-mail.

title: Rangers Dive Back Into Division Race
description: Clearly not having heard the wake-up call signaling the end of the All-Star break, the Rangers hope back-to-back games against bitter division rivals does the trick, starting Thursday night in Philadelphia.

title: Hot Coffee but Cold Food
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: A Pitched Battle Upstate for Democratic Votes
description: BUFFALO  Strong support from upstate New York voters helped Hillary Rodham Clinton to comfortable victory margins in each of her two successful races for the Senate, but both her campaign and Barack Obamas are operating as if Tuesdays primary is very much in play.

title: Langone, Wall Street Titan, Now Backs McCain
description: Long before it was foregone that Rudolph W. Giuliani would bow out of the race for president, other Republican campaigns were making plays for some of his staunchest, and richest, backers.

title: Googles Loss Is Murdochs Gain
description: The stock market may be fretting over Googles disappointing earnings, but somewhere Rupert Murdoch is smiling.

title: Arte No Es Vida
description: Images from the show at El Museo del Barrio.

title: A Look at the Numbers
description: So far, the 2008 primaries and caucuses have been anything but predictable  comebacks, fallbacks, not to mention surprised pollsters. But a closer look reveals some common themes that have emerged, despite a still-forming consensus about nominees.

title: Jobs and Monster
description: Identifying turning points  the points at which the economy goes from expansion to recession or vice versa  is hard, because the official data tend to lag well behind. So we look for scraps of evidence from the private sector. One of those scraps, the employment estimate from ADP (which handles payrolls for many companies, so that it can produce its own employment estimates), is actually looking pretty good for January. But via knzn, the Monster employment index, produced by the online job-listing company, looks terrible.

title: Q & A: Knight Franks Research Guru Looks Into the Crystal Ball
description: So where are the next opportunities for a big property run-up? Liam Bailey, head of residential research for Knight Frank, the property firm, believes Asia, Brazil, Romania, inland Bulgaria and parts of western Germany may be poised for growth, in sharp contrast to most markets.

title: Bill Bradley and the Obama Generation
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Though most of the more than 100 students at a Barack Obama rally at Rutgers University on Thursday afternoon were not yet teenagers when the events keynote speaker, Bill Bradley, was a presidential candidate, they still gave the former senator two standing ovations.
